column2: TOKYO, March 1 -- Gen. Douglas MacArthur said today that if Russia attacked Japan "we should certainly defend her."

The goal of a world community cannot be attained unless greater concern is shown for Russians as individuals, particularly by Christians, the Rev. Dr. Henry Smith Leiper declared yesterday in an address to Protestant clergymen here.

What is the issue in the parliamentary struggle that has now got under way in the Senate over the revision of Rule XXII? Stripped of all mumbo-jumbo and flag-waving, it is whether this country's highest legislative body will permit important measures to be kept from a vote through the activities of a few leather-throated, iron-legged members who don't want a democratic decision.

The recent report to the Economic Cooperation Administration by the Council of the Organization for European Economic Cooperation presents a "gloomy picture" of European prospects in 1952-53, even though it considers the various programs likely to fall short of their goals by only small percentages.
ST. LOUIS, March 1 -- A spirited discussion on the use of released time for religious instruction in the public schools divided educators here today into two opposing groups.

LONDON, March 1 -- As a compliment and expression of thanks to British and American air and ground crews that have maintained the airlift to Berlin for more than eight months Prime Minister Attlee will pay a visit to Berlin and the British one of Germany over the next week-end, leaving here Friday.

The organization CARE -- Cooperative for American Remittances to Europe -- has made an honored name for itself in its own country and throughout the world. Government-sponsored, supported by all major welfare groups, it has long been proved that CARE is always motivated by a deep sense of responsibility.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- A high Administration official predicted today that the White House- sponsored labor relations bill probably would be reported out, by Friday, without amendments, by the Senate Labor and Public Welfare Committee.

BOSTON, March 1 (AP) -- Outhustling and outplaying their more illustrious opponents through virtually the entire 40 minutes, Brown's steadily improving basketball team tonight upset Holy Cross, 63 -- 55.

LONDON, March 1 -- More than half of all the shipping launched in 1948 was built in British yards, according to the annual summary of mercantile ship building of Lloyd's Register, published here today.
Ground was broken yesterday for three New York City Housing Authority projects in Manhattan and the Bronx. They are expected to accommodate 2,700 families in twelve to eighteen months.

PARIS, March 1 -- With the authority vested in him as the artisan of victory, with all his art as a writer and with his persuasive good faith, Winston Churchill has just published his account of the tragic events of May and June, 1940.

BERLIN, March 1 -- Polish representatives in Berlin are approaching British military government circles with requests for an end of the present critical situation and suggestions that negotiations on the currency question be reopened.
Fred Wilt, the FBI man whose distance-running feats have been the brightest spot of the post-Olympic track campaign from the purely American point of view, is a fellow who likes fast company.

RAS EN NAQURA, Palestine, March 1 -- Lebanese and Israeli delegations met today on Lebanon's side of this border town to discuss the proposed armistice agreement submitted by the United Nations as a result of preliminary talks. Indications are that an agreement may be signed Thursday when the delegations meet again.
Reynolds Co., members of the New York Stock Exchange, have opened an office in Chicago under the management of John G. White.

WARSAW, March 1 -- The Polish Government is pressing with unremitting force its fight against the influence of the Catholic Church. While the Government's methods are less spectacular than those used in Hungary and Bulgaria many church leaders feel that they are facing the same basic problems without obtaining the same support and understanding of the Western countries.

Several Negro organizations went on record yesterday as opposed to transferring administrative control of the State University to the Board of Regents. Such a move would serve "to choke off the university by placing control in the hands of an indifferent agency," they said.

In its move to enforce legal requirements and restrict apartments in thirteen housing projects to low-income families, the New York City Housing Authority said yesterday that it was contemplating eviction actions against 2,000 families with annual yearly incomes from $3,600 to $5,000.

District Attorney Miles F. McDonald set up yesterday a special unit to investigate street warfare in Brooklyn between groups of teen-age boys. The unit will hold its first meeting this morning in the District Attorney's office.

WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP) -- Stanley Wohl of this city, a holder of common stock of the Long Island Lighting Company, urged today that the proposed acquisition of the company by the Consolidated Edison Company of New York be delayed "five or ten years." He made his appeal at a hearing by the Securities and Exchange Commission on the proposed acquisition.

The United Corporation, twenty-year-old investment organization that holds securities which had a book value of $99,025,668 at the close of 1948, had a net income of $5,646,020 in that year, compared with $3,770,629 for 1947, it was announced in the annual report being distributed today.

Discontinuance of two daily trains between New York and Philadelphia, one daily train from St. Louis to New York and five Saturday trains and seven Sunday trains between this city and New Jersey points was announced yesterday by the Pennsylvania Railroad.

VIENNA, March 1 -- The Hungarian Government last week dissolved all Zionist organizations, closed their headquarters and expelled ten Zionist leaders, authoritative Jewish sources disclosed here today. The principal groups affected were the Jewish Agency Keren Kayemet [the Jewish National Fund] and the local Zionist organizations.
Lloyd B. Reid, consultant to the city's new Traffic Commission, designated the Greater New York Safety Council yesterday to organize public support for the safety work envisioned by the commission.

WHERE holiness begins and madness leaves off is a problem which has always troubled mankind. Primitive peoples, preferring to take no chances, have generally chosen to regard madness as a divine affliction. More sophisticated ones are not so sure. A St. Simeon Stylites, spending most of his life on top of a pillar, cannot command the respect and affection of a St. Francis, who demonstrated his holiness by his conduct in the world of men.
WASHINGTON, March 1 -- The long fight between butter and oleomargarine blocs in Congress reopened today with hearings before the House Agriculture Committee.

Charles G. Coster, chairman of the New York City Rent Commission, said yesterday that his office was withholding any statement until he and the other two members of the commission received copies of the report of the temporary State Rent Commission released in Albany and had studied it.

There is one provision in the Taft-Hartley Law which is conspicuously missing from the Administration's proposed successor legislation, the Thomas bill, and whose retention is in some respects perhaps more important than that of many of the sections that have been much more widely debated. This is to be found in Sections 401-403, which create and set forth the functions of the Joint Committee on Labor-Management Relations (the so-called "Watchdog Committee").

TOKYO, March 1 -- A husky, blond Soviet Air Force pilot stood before a group of British and American newspaper men in Tokyo today and told how and why he escaped from the Soviet Union in a dangerous single-handed flight in a twin-engined transport plane that he had stolen while the others of its crew left him on guard.

A new type of report card, which will rate personality development and "home background" as well as scholastic achievement, will be used next fall by the city's kindergarten and first-year classes, the Board of Education announced yesterday.

Plans for a Harlem edition of The Sunday Worker, week-end counterpart of The Daily Worker, Communist party newspaper, to start this week, were revealed last night by City Councilman Benjamin J. Davis Jr., who is president of The Daily Worker Corporation.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- The "Wac Corporal" rocket that flashed a record 250 miles up into space at the White Sands, N. M., proving grounds last week probably is buried so deep it will never be found, Army Ordnance officials said today.
The Board of Estimate will consider on March 10 the purchase of the buildings and campus of Manhattanville College of the Sacred Heart, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- Secretary of Defense James Forrestal named Dr. Philip M. Morse, outstanding physicist, as research director and deputy director of the Weapons Evaluation Group of the National Military Establishment today.
YONKERS, N. Y., March 1 -- Five hundred striking city employes were discharged today in the state's first test of the two-year-old Condon-Wadlin Law outlawing strikes by state or municipal workers.

GENEVA, March 1 -- In a triumph of historic Swiss political principles, the Federal Council at Berne decided today not to be represented by a member of the Government on the ministerial consultative group recently formed in Paris [by the five Brussels treaty powers] to spark the European Recovery Program.
New financing transactions for railroad and public utility enterprises were executed yesterday, involving the issuance of $28,029,000 of new securities.

Fines totaling $43,000 were imposed by Federal Judge Simon H. Rifkind yesterday on E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., National Lead Company and its subsidiary, Titan Company, Inc., and three individuals on their plea of nolo contendere to an indictment charging conspiracy to control the production and marketing of titanium compounds.

The excitement of the couturier collections of New York was increased yesterday, when, at 5 o'clock in the afternoon Bergdorf Goodman held its spring and summer showing. This Fifth Avenue specialty store's trio of designers had their show on the fourth floor.

The University of Kentucky's mighty basketball team has accepted bids to both major post-season tournaments, it was announced yesterday by Asa S. Bushnell. The variance of dates makes it possible for the Wildcats to compete in the National Invitation tournament as well as defend their National Collegiate A. A. title.

DUESSELDORF, Germany, March 1 -- Twin placards were posted today in all mines in the Ruhr area notifying 517,000 underground and surface workers of the successful conclusion their efforts to obtain extension of their annual paid holidays.

Guy C. Kiddoo, a banker with long experience in construction loans, warned members of the Associated General Contractors of America yesterday against assuming that costs were going down substantially. The vice president of the First National Bank of Chicago spoke at the group's thirtieth annual convention in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

The Abbe Practical Workshop announced yesterday that three productions would be presented within the next two months. The group, which attracted attention this season with the production of "The Heeple Steeple," will revive Philip Barry's "Here Come the Clowns" for four evenings, March 15 through March 18, at the Workshop's Theatre, 310 Riverside Drive.

Fresh fish for Lent will be more abundant and cheaper in price than it has been for the last twelve years. This prediction from Charles Strang, a veteran of thirty-five years in the Fulton Fish Market, is only part of the encouraging outlook for the six weeks ahead.

By a vote of 1,852 to 32, members of the Bloomingdale Department Store Union, Local 3, independent, last night authorized a "strategy committee" to call a strike at "any time." The group met at Manhattan Center.

Columbia will meet Princeton at the Morningside Heights gymnasium tonight in a game that will have important bearing on the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League race. Play will start at 8:30 P. M.

RICHMOND, Va., March 1 -- A Virginia state lair designed to deter strikes of state and local government workers was invoked for the first time here today, as 180 city garbage collectors continued a two-day walkout.

A bronze plaque, symbolical of "enlightened service" to show business, was presented to Twentieth Century-Fox and the Rivoli Theatre at the theatre at 12:30 P. M. yesterday in commemoration of the long-run engagement of "The Snake Pit."

Two-thirds of the medical staff of Maimonides Hospital, Brooklyn have applied for reappointment under the hospital's directive that they limit their practice to one field of medicine by July 1 or be dropped from the staff, Dr. Jacob Prager, director, announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 1 -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee turned thumbs down today on any relaxation of loyalty tests in the operations of the European Recovery Program.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., March 1 -- A Navy civil service employe of unquestioned loyalty and ability has been discharged because his personality made him "a poor risk," the Navy Electronics Laboratory announced last night. The employe, Louis Brosseau, 38 years old, said he would appeal.
Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed a decline of 6 per cent in February, compared with the same month last year, according to the survey made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 1 (AP) -- Allen Stack, Olympic backstroke champion, churned 880 yards through the 20-yard Payne Whitney Gymnasium pool at Yale University today and established seven new American swimming records.

A "terrific job of public relations" must he done by the social agencies authorized to work with unmarried mothers before the public is as well informed about proper child-placing procedure as it seems to be about the imporper channels, spokesmen for child welfare agencies agreed yesterday.

LONDON, March 1 (AP) -- A Tass dispatch from Moscow said that the new price cuts ordered yesterday by Prime Minister Stalin caused lively trading today in big department stores in the Russian capital.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 1 (AP) -- Pennsylvania sent Harvard down to its fifteenth straight loss tonight, 78 -- 63, in an Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League contest.

The proposal of the Long Island Rail Road to impose a charge for store-door pick-up and delivery service on less-than-carload business was opposed yesterday by a group of shippers from Queens at a hearing by the freight traffic committee of the Eastern Territory Railroads at 144 Liberty Street. The hearing, called at the request of the Chamber of Commerce of the Borough of Queens, was attended by fifty merchants and shippers.

Relief for American Indians will be handled for the time being under the supervision of the American Red Cross, Julius A. Krug, Secretary of the Interior, told the Cooperative for American Remittances to Europe (CARE) yesterday. Plans for a committee to push Indian relief by that organization were suspended pending more information.
SHANGHAI, March 1 (AP) -- China's crisis turned melodramatic today.

WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP) -- Amid freshets of tears, Mildred E. (Axis Sally) Gillars testified at her treason trial today that when the war ended American GI's taunted her by predicting she would be hanged as a traitor.

A ten-page letter by Thomas Paine written in 1789 brought $575 at auction yesterday at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street. The letter was written to the author's young friend, "Kitty" Nicholson, on the occasion of her marriage to Col. William Few, a member of the Constitutional Convention.

A resolution calling for a joint fund of $25,000 to undertake the preliminary organization of a national promotional program for men's clothing, in cooperation with the woolen mills and retailers, was unanimously adopted yesterday by the Clothing Manufacturers Association of the U. S. A. at a meeting at its offices at 220 Fifth Avenue.
The creation of a health education division to coordinate the activities of health agencies in that field was voted yesterday at a membership meeting of the Health Council of Greater New York.

VIENNA, Feb. 16 -- The Rumanian middle class already has been victimized by a fraud that Premier Stalin and other leading Communists recently have tried out on the world at large. This is the conception that "capitalism and communism can live very well together."

State-chartered banks in the United States and Hawaii reached a new high record for resources in 1948, these totaling $87,505,473,000 on Dec. 31, according to the semi-annual report of all such banks to be issued today by A. A. Rogers, president of the National Association of Supervisors of State Banks.

The $158,000,000 Connecticut Light and Power Company, which serves about 42 per cent of the gas and electric needs in 71 per cent of Connecticut, reported yesterday that it had met a demand for these services in 1948 that was unprecedented in its forty-four-year history.

WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP) -- The House Appropriations Committee voted today to give 1,500 more employes to the Internal Revenue Bureau to check tax returns. The Bureau had asked for 7,000, on the score that the extra help would collect many times their salaries in tax payments.

Charges that American war crimes investigators used physical brutality and other third-degree methods on seventy-four Nazi defendants in the Malmedy war crimes trial mounted yesterday as Gen. Lucius D. Clay prepared his final recommendations on twelve men condemned to death in that trial.

Commercial stationery products as a "barometer" of business volume and white-collar employment and the course of business generally indicate steadiness, it was declared yesterday at the annual meeting of the Wholesale Stationers' Association of the U.S.A. and Canada in the Commodore Hotel.

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 1 -- Under a bright desert sun, the Giants today officially launched their 1949 spring training season and before the first workout was an hour under way it disclosed a pair of young ball players who already have received an unusual high rating in Manager Leo Durocher's future book.

The National Physicians Committee denied yesterday the charges of encouraging racial discrimination that were brought against it Monday night by a standing vote of doctors at the monthly meeting of the New York County Medical Society.
A special train for playgoers who live in southern Connecticut made its first run yesterday evening -- and startled even its sponsors.
Atomic energy laid a cornerstone yesterday.

ALBANY, March 1 -- Few of the $102,330,000 cuts in the state budget proposed by Erie Republican legislators in their revolt against Governor Dewey's $168,200,000 tax increase program are likely to win the Democratic support necessary for adoption, it developed today.

ALBANY, March 1 -- With only four Republican votes in opposition, the Senate adopted today the Mitchell-Van Duzer constitutional amendment that would provide a limited preference for veterans in civil service appointments and promotions after Dec. 31, 1950.

A field-tested "pay-as-you-go" plan of financing gasoline retailers' inventory credits is being launched nationally by Bowser, Inc., gasoline pump maker, through its subsidiary, Johnson Fare Box Company, E. A. Nahm, vice president, revealed here yesterday.
LONDON, March 1 (AP) -- A British business organization proposed today that Britain end its dollar shortage by trading with the United States on a strictly credit basis.

Continuation of the European Recovery Program through fiscal 1950 is supported by the National Association of Manufacturers. This was revealed yesterday in letters to Senator Tom Connally, chairman of the Senate Committee on Foreign Relations, and Representative Sol Bloom, chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, by Curtis E. Calder, chairman of the NAM's international relations committee.
The annual Ash Wednesday services in Christian churches marking the opening of Lent were held throughout the country yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 2 (UP) -- United States troop strength in Japan is to be increased by about 20,000 men in the fiscal year starting July 1, reliable sources said today.

WASHINGTON, March 2 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board is proposing a revision in the mail pay rates for trans-pacific operations of Pan American Airways and Northwest Airlines, in view of expanded operations:

LAKE SUCCESS, March 2 -John J. McCloy, president of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, today denied a charge made here in the Economic Committee of the United Nations Economic and Social Council by Poland that the banking institution had helped finance wars against Viet Nam and Indonesia.
WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., March 2 -- Indictments that could entail prison sentences totaling 365 years were voted today against Gerard Graham Dennis by a Westchester County Grand Jury.

BALTIMORE, Md., March 2 -In 1948, "business as a whole made the largest profits in the history of the United States after taxes were paid," Vice President Alben W. Barkley declared here tonight. He spoke at the annual dinner of the Pennsylvania and Atlantic Seaboard Hardware Association, Inc., which is to conclude a four-day convention tomorrow.

The Long Island Rail Road, which has survived raids by farmers who tore up its tracks, the blizzards of 1888 and 1947, and seagulls in its power transformers, has been through bankruptcy proceedings twice before yesterday's action.

Ground will be broken within two months for a $1,300,000 expansion of the Beth Israel Hospital, Stuyvesant Park and East Seventeenth Street, hospital trustees announced last night at graduation exercises for twenty-five nurses in the hospital auditorium.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- Representative John E. Rankin of Mississippi told the House Rules Committee today that the over-all cost of the veterans' pension program he was sponsoring was estimated at $109,000,000,000.

FRANKFORT, Germany, March 2 -- The three Western Military Governors granted permission today for representatives of the city of Berlin to "attend" but not "participate" in the meetings of the parliament of the projected Western German government.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- President Truman asked Congress today for supplemental appropriations totaling $561,513,801.67 in cash and $301,406,000 in contract authorizations to cover additional needs of nine executive departments, nine independent offices, the District of Columbia and Congress.

Some carpet mills are cutting back production of twenty-seven-inch and nine-foot merchandise between 10 and 15 per cent, manufacturers spokesmen revealed yesterday. Cutbacks for the most part are limited to smaller mills but it is understood that two industry leaders are following suit to lesser extent.

Arriving at an Henri Bendel collection, one settles down with a sense of ease and anticipation, for this long-established specialty house, at 10 West Fifty-seventh Street, under the guidance of Mr. Leon, carries on the traditions for which it has been well known since Henri Bendel founded it.

An attractive palette of sand tones ranging from beige to brown provided the theme for a well-thought-out showing of spring fashions yesterday at Macy's. Coupled with a wide assortment of amusingly chic accessories, there were swaggeringly full coats dashingly belted into a small waist.

Led by Cardinal Spellman, who said last night he would "do anything the foreman tells me to do," one hundred seminarians will take over burying of the dead today at the strike-bound Calvary Cemetery in Queens, largest Roman Catholic burial ground in the New York area.
The text of the statement issued by William Z. Foster and Eugene Dennis on the Communist position in the event of another war follows:
C.H. Smith has been named divisional controller of the Cadillac Motor Car division. He succeeds W.B. Wardle, who becomes special assistant to the general manager.
WASHINGTON, March 2 -- The White House announced today the appointment of David H. Stowe, 38 years old, a native of New Canaan, Conn., as an administrative assistant to President Truman.

The Ingalls Shipbuilding Corporation's yard at Pascagoula, Miss., which was established some ten years ago specifically for the construction of all-welded ships, has expanded its plant to take on welded steel projectss, such as the building of large tanks, pressure vessels, dredging pipe and structural steel.

With 50,000 volunteer workers out soliciting funds to meet the city's quota of $4,635,000, the New York Chapter of the American Red Cross announced yesterday that it had received pledges of wholehearted support from city unions and state councils of organized labor representing a million workers in the five boroughs.

Bishop James P. De Wolfe of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Long Island officially removed the Rev. Dr. John Howard Melish yesterday from the rectorship of Holy Trinity Church, Brooklyn, a post the 74-year-old clergyman has held for forty-five years. The removal order is effective April 4.

The Federal Trade Commission's relatively swift move to correct action considered a virtual wrecking of proposed trade practice rules for the cosmetics and toiletries industry was commended yesterday by trade spokesmen as reopening the way for eventual majority agreement.

PARIS, March 2 -- The Soviet Union has decided to curtail drastically its exports to the United States of strategically important manganese and chrome ores which are essential to the manufacture of hard steel.

Pope Pius XII in a special Ash Wednesday message yesterday urged the Catholic school children of America to keep in mind in their Lenten prayers their more unfortunate brothers and sistersthroughout the world.

Alastair B. Martin of Glen Head, L.I., former titleholder and runner-up to Ogden Phipps last year, set the pace for a succession of quickly won victories as the national amateur court tennis championship started yesterday at the Racquet and Tennis Club.

By an interesting combination of circumstances which, in their coincidence, may or may not suggest design, Yonkers becomes the scene of the first substantial test of the state's Condon-Wadlin law, which forbids strikes by public employes.
Substantial improvements in sales and earnings for 1948 were reported by Rayonier, Inc., in its annual report released yesterday.

STORRS, Conn., March 2 (AP) -Yale's great hook-shot artist, Tony Lavelli, brought his all-time scoring total for the Blue to 1,870 points tonight as he led the Eli team to an easy 71-55 victory over the University of Connecticut.
An amended budget proposal for the New York Public Library for 1949-50, asking for an additional $210,471, has been made to Budget Director Thomas J. Patterson, it was announced yesterday.
I wish to add my own small voice in protest against the award given to Ezra Pound.

The Cleveland Electric Illuminating Company, a $249,000,000 utility system serving 391,182 residential, commercial and industrial customers in the Cleveland-Northeast Ohio area, had a net income of $8,074,535, equal to $2.98 a common share, last year, compared with $7,646,496 or $2.80 a share in 1947, according to the annual report issued yesterday by Elmer L. Lindseth.

GENEVA, March 2 -- The United Nations World Health Organization is taking steps to procure penicillin manufacturing equipment for Eastern European countries whose own efforts to purchase such equipment in the United States, these countries assert, have been frustrated by the refusal of export licenses.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- The Northern Democratic-- Republican Senate coalition put off today, in fear that action now might harm: its cause, its first scheduled sortie in force against the Southerners in the filibuster fight.

From the West Coast Robert Montgomery confirms a report that he and Elliott Nugent are contemplating a musical entitled "Nosegay," designed for the especial talents of Jimmy Durante. Mr. Montgomery says nothing is very definite at the moment, but if Mr. Durante is available and "if the market justifies the investment," it will be done on Broadway next season.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- The Commission on Organization of the Executive Branch of the Government recommended today that the Veterans Administration's insurance operations, which it criticized severely, be put under a separate Government corporation.

Joseph Vitale and Hamilton Lowd have purchased the two-story one-family house at 3112 Avenue K, Brooklyn, from Albert P. Huels. Timothy J. Keyes was the broker. The Fulton Savings Bank made a purchase money mortgage of $5,000 in connection with the transaction.

JERSEY CITY, March 2 -- A jurisdictional dispute between Jersey City and different members of the International Longshoremen's Association resulted in a work stoppage by 300 stevedores on three_American Export Lines piers here today.

MADRID, March 2 (UP) -- "Press Mission in Spain," written by a Mexican newspaper editor, became the most popular book in the country today when it was disclosed that it nearly had caused a duel between two of Spain's most prominent men.

MOSCOW, March 2 (AP) -- The official journal of the Council of Ministers disclosed today the three-months-old appointment of artillery Marshal N. D. Yakovlev as a Vice Minister for the Soviet Armed Forces.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- The late Mr. Justice Oliver Wendell Holmes was brought into the North Atlantic defense pact discussion today by Secretary of State Dean Acheson at the latter's weekly press conference.

Financing operations in the new capital market yesterday included the public sale of $12,300,000 of new equipment obligations of the New York Central Railroad, private placement of $9,000,000 of bonds for Woodward Lothrop, Washington, D. C., department store enterprise, and a $3,000,000 loan from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to F. L. Jacobs Company, automotive parts manufacturer.

ON BOARD U.S.S. POCONO, off Vieques Island, March 2 -- Amphibious tractors and ramp-bowed landing craft grated ashore on the white sand beaches of Vieques Island today as more than 13,000 marines and soldiers and three platoons of the Canadian Army started the largest United States amphibious exercise since the war.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, March 2 -- Judge Konstantin Oundjiev tonight recessed the trial of fifteen Protestant ministers until Friday morning, when the chief prosecutor, Dimiter Georgiev, will sum up the State case against the prisoners.

Their Army uniforms fit perfectly, their faces are smoothly tanned and their conversation well modulated. They never deign to salute or pick up a cigarette butt. For them "chow" is a breed of dog, "retreat" a quiet nook, and "promotion" a press agent's business.

A new series of sonata recitals will be introduced on Monday over WQXR with a performance of Brahms' Sonata No. 1 in E minor by Joseph Schuster, 'cellist, and Nadia Reisenberg, concert pianist. The program will be heard from 10:30 to 11 P. M.

Although knitted outerwear and sportswear purchasing reflect the cautious purchasing policy of retailers, these lines are showing considerable activity for spring, it was learned yesterday. Retailers are using sweaters, knitted shirts, skirts, blouses and other sportswear items for an increasing number of promotional events, buyers said, to offset poor business in other ready-to-wear departments.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, March 2 -- The Danish Government, it is understood, received overwhelming Parliamentary support today for a policy of linking Denmark's defense with the West, a policy that the Government is known to favor.

The stock market encountered a set-back yesterday after three successive advances, although the losses were minor and pressure limited. Only a slight margin separated the number of gains from the losses and the composite rate dipped 0.20 point.

MADISON TOWNSHIP, N. J., March 2 -- A neat but slightly weather-beaten signboard was removed today from the door of a house a short distance from Highway S-28 in Old Bridge as the only outward indication that this community has a new township clerk for the first time in twenty-seven years.

Another courtroom footnote was appended yesterday to the litigation-haunted $15,000,000 bond financing of the New Orleans union passenger railroad terminal. For a change, what happened yesterday was the signal for a formal halting of litigation, rather than the opening up of new issues.

DETROIT, March 2 -- The Ford Motor Company warned the United Automobile Workers, CIO, today that a wage increase in 1949 might mean a loss of jobs and added that no pension plan could be set up without a pay cut.

Nashville, Tenn., sold yesterday an issue of $5,000,000 of electric power revenue bonds due from March 1, 1952 to June 1, 1959, to a banking group headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., at a bid of 100.53 for 4s and 1 1/2s, an interest of 2.545 per cent.

ROME, March 2 -- The right wing Socialists decided early this morning to continue participating in Premier Alcide de Gasperi's coalition Government. They instructed their leader, Giuseppe Saragat, to withdraw his resignation from the Cabinet.

MIAMI, Fla., March 2 (AP) -- Promoter Joe Louis, who learned about contracts from Mike Jacobs, revealed today he had tied up the National Boxing Association version of the heavyweight championship for his International Boxing Club by exclusive two-year agreements with Ezzard Charles and Jersey Joe Walcott.

Another book about Russia, "My Life in the Red Army," by Fred Virski, will be issued by Macmillan March 29. The author, a young Pole who was drafted into the Soviet Army in 1940, presents an account of the common soldier's life in that army and of the differences between the Government regime and the Russian people.

Michigan authorities delayed formal legal proceedings against Raymond M. Fernandez, 34 years old, and his 29-year-old confederate, Mrs. Martha Beck, yesterday in an apparent effort to obtain the death penalty, through a New York trial, for the two confessed killers of two widows and a child in a lonely hearts extortion racket.

Edward Connors, a deputy chief of staff and operations of the Fire Department, two fire lieutenants and a firemen were injured early today while fighting a four-alarm blaze that swept through the four upper floors of a seven-story loft building at 6 Birmingham Street, between Madison and Henry Streets, on the lower East Side.

MIAMI, Fla., March 2 -- Winner of only four of her previous four dozen starts in four seasons of racetracking, the Gardenia Stable's 5-year-old mare, Roman Candle, surprised most of the 15,489 customers at Hialeah Park today by getting to the wire first in the $24,300 Black Helen Handicap, Florida's No. 1 race for fillies and mares.

Twenty-one alleged rent gougers, a record number, were named yesterday in New York County grand jury criminal informations. The defendants -- landlords, rental agents and building superintendents, including two women -- were accused of extorting $36,870 in illegal rental fees.

Hugh Feltis, president of the Broadcast Measurement Bureau since its founding in January, 1945, has resigned, effective on April 15, it was announced yesterday following a board meeting in the Bureau's headquarters, 270 Park Avenue.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- Even with the price cuts proclaimed by the Soviet Union this week, the Russian worker's standard of living remains well below most Western European standards and is hardly comparable with the United States level, according to the best available comparisons made here today.
C.C.N.Y. will face Manhattan and L.I.U. will engage Muhlenberg in the college basketball double-header at Madison Square Garden tonight. City College and Long Island are favored to win.

Sharp criticism was directed yesterday against members of the House of Representatives who did not include liquor among the items upon which they approved reduction of excise taxes to pre-war levels, by Thomas F. McCarthy, chairman of the newly created Alcoholic Beverage Tax Council.
The text of the decision of Bishop De Wolfe of the Diocese of Long Island in the Melish case and a supplementary statement issued by the Bishop follow:

Decreases in commercial and residential construction this year were forecast yesterday by contractors at the convention of the Associated General Contractors of America at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. The informal personal comments were made from the floor at a session of the group's building contractors division.

David Van Alstyne Jr., president of the New Jersey Senate, was directed by Federal Judge John W. Clancy yesterday to appear at the Federal Courthouse, Foley Square, on March 23 to give a deposition in connection with a $328,000 damage suit against the stock brokerage concern of Van Alstyne, Noel Co., Inc., by fifty-one stockholders in a Cuban airline.
LAKE SUCCESS, March 2 -- Complaints of border incidents in the Balkans have been arriving in a steady stream at United Nations headquarters here ever since the end of the Paris General Assembly.
Abraham Lincoln and Curtis yesterday gained the quarter-finals of the Public Schools Athletic League basketball tournament at Madison Square Garden.

CAIRO, March 2 -- The urgency with which the Egyptian Government is trying to deal with the ancient problem of destitution was evidenced today when it was learned that the Ministry of Social Welfare had completed its draft of legislation to reintroduce the tithe as a legal tax after a lapse of centuries.
Government and defense counsel each filed fifty-five-page briefs yesterday on the defense challenge to the jury in the trial of the eleven Communist leaders.

The top leaders of the American Communist party served notice yesterday that they would pursue a policy intended to defeat United States aims if this nation were involved in a war they considered "unjust, aggressive, imperialist."

The Netherlands Government may or may not have been surprised by the coolness with which its Indonesian peace proposal of last Saturday was received in Java and other places. There was certainly no occasion for surprise. Since December Dutch troops had been carrying on warfare within the territory of the Indonesian Republic.

The Boeing B-50 recovered its place in the "first line" as an intercontinental bomber with the flight of the Lucky Lady II yesterday. Of the same practical dimensions as the B-29 Superfortress, it had been classed as a medium bomber.

CHICAGO, March 2 -- The financially weakened Tucker Corporation announced today plans to file a petition for its reorganization under Chapter 10 of the Federal Bankruptcy Laws. The petition, involving possession of the corporation's big plant here, is scheduled to be submitted tomorrow to Federal District Judge Michael L. Igoe.

ALBANY, March 2 -- Abolition of the New York City Rent Commission and the vesting of control over evictions and hotel rents in New York in the hands of the courts or a state agency appeared today to be a likely sequel of official reports of waste and political influences within the commission.

HELSINKI, Finland, March 2 -- Unruffled by the storms raging around their tiny country on the Soviet Union's doorstep, Finnish political leaders see Finland's problems of the moment as principally domestic ones.
WASHINGTON, March 2 (AP) -The hot controversy over legality of pricing systems which absorb freight costs appeared likely today to get a chance to "cool off" for at least a year.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today authorized the Central Railroad of New Jersey to submit a plan for the voluntary modification of outstanding securities which, if it is accepted by three-quarters of the holders, will take that railroad out of bankruptcy proceedings.

A legislative conference representing 2,000 faculty members of the city's four public colleges charged yesterday that 100 teachers had quit their jobs in the institutions because of inadequate salary and pension protection under the Teachers Salary Law of 1947.

Because of a delay by the Curtiss-Wright Corporation in announcing a plan to call for tenders of its common stock, the New York Stock Exchange has written the aircraft-manufacturing company reminding it "pointedly" of its obligation to disclose promptly such actions, an official of the Exchange said yesterday.

About a year ago Kraft Foods Company issued a leaflet that, judging by the response that followed its announcement in this column, was generally considered a fine contribution to the kitchen library. It was "And Then -- The Cheese Tray."

ST. LOUIS, March 2 -- A vast system of publicly supported two-year community colleges, to be situated in every part of the country and available to all high school graduates, was proposed here by leading American educators.

RHODES, March 2 -- Armistice talks between Israel and Transjordan were delayed again today while the Transjordanian delegates awaited instructions from Amman. No joint meeting has yet been held, though the acting Mediator, Dr. Ralph J. Bunche, had hoped last night to have one today and settle a formal cease-fire agreement between the two countries.

On their last evening in this country, 489 Jewish refugees from Shanghai heard farewell talks by high officials of Jewish relief and political organizations and were entertained by singers of the Metropolitan Opera Company. The men, women and children, as old as 70 years and as young as 22 days, will leave Ellis Island by ferry to board the Army transport General Stewart at the Staten Island Port of Embarkation about noon today.
Theodore W. Kheel, former director of the city's Division of Labor Relations, proposed yesterday that New York breweries pay their workers a guaranteed annual wage for guaranteed annual production.
Marietta Bitter, harpist, and nine skillful associates presented an evening of chamber music with the harp last night at Times Hall. The event had charm, interest and musical distinction.

LEXINGTON, Ky., March 2 (UP) -- A pre-dawn fire swept through a training barn at Clifford Mooers' Walnut Springs training farm today, killing sixteen thoroughbreds and causing an estimated $200,000 in damage. The cause of the fire was not determined immediately.

The American Medical Association sprung a surprise last Monday when it declared that if we had President Truman's national health insurance we should have to spend eighteen billion dollars a year on doctors, hospitals, dentistry, nurses, medicines and all the fixings.

The former home of Dr. George Bollins Lee at 20 East Sixty-sixth Street will be converted into ten professional apartments as the result of its sale by the 20 East Sixty - sixth Street Corporation, Mrs. Emma Adler, president, to Dr. Louis Berg, the well-known psychiatrist.

PARIS, March 2 -- Sir Stafford Cripps, British Chancellor of the Exchequer, arrived in Paris tonight for a conference with Maurice Petsche, French Finance Minister tomorrow and a meeting Friday of the new steering committee of eight named by the European Marshall Plan Council.

A Federal law to compel members of Congress to live up to their election promises and to prohibit re-election of office holders was advocated last night by Robert R. Young, chairman of the Federation of Railway Progress.

WASHINGTON, March 2 (AP) -Two bids, one to buy and the other to lease with an option to purchase a surplus Government-owned aluminum plant at Burlington, N.J., were received today by the War Assets Administration.

VIENNA, March 2 -- "The rising sun will be hailed by the free people of Communist Hungary, which will recognize neither the capitalists of the West nor Asiatic Muscovite imperialism," according to a multigraphed "newspaper" sent through the mails to the correspondents of United States newspapers and news agencies here.

FRANKFORT, Germany, March 2 -- The United States Army military police threw a cordon of armed guards around the Soviet repatriation mission building today and began a siege of eight Russians who had refused to leave when ordered to do so by Gen. Lucius D. Clay.

The transfer of control of nine C-4 type "emergency class" passenger vessels from the Maritime Commission to the Army, which was ordered by President Truman last Friday, remained a puzzle in local shipping circles yesterday. Five of the ships were used for the movement of displaced persons under the International Refugee Organization, the others moved repatriates and commercial passengers at low rates.

PASADENA, Calif., March 2 -- As the climax of a short tour of California cities, the Masquers Club presented on Monday night "What Price Glory," by Maxwell Anderson and Laurence Stallings, before an audience of 2,000 at Pasadena Civic Auditorium.

Just prior to the opening of the National Sportsmen's Show we devoted one column to the difficulties which have been facing those interested in falconry, and pointing out that the Linnaean Society, an ornithological group, had prevented the inclusion of a live hawk at the falconry exhibit at the show.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange fluctuated within a narrow range yesterday and closed steady, unchanged to 15 points higher.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee of the National Board of Review, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 a group of motion pictures to be shown, tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified. The programs follow:

Yesterday afternoon, it was Stein Blaine's turn to show a custom-made collection. Harriette Harra was the designer. Throughout she stressed the narrower silhouette, save in the case of formal evening gowns and a few afternoon silks. The suits were slim of silhouette.

Enrollment in Columbia University's School of Engineering must be reduced to 600 or 800 students if it is to make its best contribution to engineering education and to American life, James Kip Finch, Dean of the school, declared in his annual report for the academic year 1947-48, made public yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended Feb. 23:

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- Spurred by the Air Force's spectacular feat in circling the globe non-stop, Congressional air power advocates called anew today for a bigger and better air force to bolster the nation's defenses.

LONDON, March 2 -- Some dissatisfaction with Winston Churchill's leadership of the Conservative party, which already has found expression in Conservative newspapers, is being voiced today among the rank and file of the Conservative members of Parliament.

CHICAGO, March 2 (AP) -- The Chicago Black Hawks moved three points away from the National Hockey League cellar tonight with a 5-to-2 victory over the last-place New York Rangers before 15,556 fans at the Stadium.
PARIS, March 2 -- After an outbreak of discord in the Cabinet today, Premier Henri Queuille was obliged to threaten to resign to restore respect for the political truce.
ALBANY, March 2 (AP) -- Governor Dewey scheduled today clemency hearings on March 16 for three men sentenced to die for the 1947 murder of Anthony Hintz, boss stevedore.
DETROIT, March 2 -- A suspension of work for 4,500 employes, because of a cut of more than 17 per cent in production, was announced today by the Hudson Motor Car Company. It is effective Monday.
The Long Island Rail Road, which carries the world's largest commuter load daily, filed a bankruptcy petition yesterday in Federal Court, Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- Pressures of domestic surpluses in certain commodities which figure largely in the European Recovery Program and of "historic" pre-war exports were felt today by the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.
WASHINGTON, March 2 (AP) -The Government finished the eighth month of its fiscal year 1949 with a budget deficit of $735,383,000, the Treasury reported today.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- Earle J. Machold, president of the Niagara Hudson Power Corporation, Syracuse, N. Y., said today it would be "reasonable to assume" that the new operating company to be created by the proposed consolidation of three of Niagara Hudson's subsidiaries, would be able to pay an annual dividend of $1.40 a share on its common stock.
Among the sites proposed for the new State College the Revolutionary camping ground at Temple Hill, near Newburgh, seems to be in some favor.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- Attorneys for the country's shippers pressed railroad officials in cross-examination today on the subject of rail efficiency, and the possibility of loss of traffic to other forms of transportation, if the railroads received the 13 per cent increase in freight rates and charges that is the subject of the hearing.

LONDON, March 2 -- Efforts by the British Government to restrict the importation of American motion pictures was blamed by the country's movie theatre operators today for the crisis in British film production that has put 40 per cent of the industry's technicians out of work.

LONDON, March 2 -- The Soviet Union announced today its full support of Yugoslavia's claims to "rectification" of the existing Austro-Yugoslav frontier in favor of Yugoslavia and to the creation of an autonomous Slovene province within Austria.

Having failed to raise sufficient private funds, officials of Sydenham Hospital in Harlem met yesterday afternoon in a four-hour closed session with Dr. Marcus D. Kogel, Hospitals Commissioner, to study measures the city might have to carry out to save the institution from discontinuing its services.
By a strictly party vote of 7 to 4 the Congressional Joint Committee on the Economic Report has sent to Congress with its stamp of approval the President's so-called "anti-inflation" program.

The nation's gasoline stocks increased 1,849,000 barrels last week to a new peak of 124,382,000 barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute. A week earlier, they were 122,533,000 barrels and a year earlier 111,040,000.

For the first time since March, 1947, the New York Knickerbockers scored a Basketball Association of America victory over the Chicago Stags last night, but it required a basket by Ray Lumpp with two seconds remaining to give the New Yorkers their 81-79 triumph.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, March 2 -- The Swedish Foreign Ministry today flatly rejected in all parts accusations by the Soviet Embassy here that Swedish authorities had improperly tried to hinder persons of Baltic origin from returning to their home countries.

WASHINGTON, March 2 (AP) -- Mildred E. (Axis Sally) Gillars turned from tears to bristling defiance at her treason trial today, angrily resisting prosecution attempts to probe deeper into her love life in wartime Germany.

WASHINGTON, March 2 (AP) -- The International Longshoremen's Association, AFL, asked prompt Senate approval today of a House bill banning "overtime on overtime" payments in the stevedoring and building construction industries.

Howard S. Cullman, chairman of the Port of New York Authority, whose investments in the theatre have made him Broadway's leading "angel," urged here yesterday that the city's building code be revised to encourage construction of new playhouses.

Hats are off to the United States Air Force for the brilliant feat of its B-50 bomber Lucky Lady II in completing the first non-stop flight around the world. The implications of this globe circuit in 94 hours 1 minute, which was described as a "training flight," are important and need not be spelled out.

The United Gas Corporation, a $389,000,000 natural-gas producing and distributing company serving a five-state area in the South, had a net income in 1948 of $18,239,406, equal to $1.71 on each of the 10,653,320 common shares, according to the nineteenth annual report being distributed today.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- Members of the House Ways and Means Committee made it plain today that they would write no "blank check" for general relief of the needy despite the lack of any over-all ceiling for such Federal aid in President Truman's Public Welfare Bill.

Pledging himself to work for a broadened concept of sportsmanship, Gene Tunney, former heavyweight boxing champion, accepted yesterday the chairmanship of the 1949 Urban League Fund Campaign, which has set a goal of $450,000.

ALBANY, March 2 -- The Assembly completed legislative action today on the Mitchell-Van Duzer resolution on preference for veterans in civil service employment. Opponents said that the measure had been prepared "in bad faith" and would virtually destroy rights now held by veterans.

Having some personal knowledge of the latest bureaucratic techniques, Samuel Spewack is satirizing them in a knockabout comedy, "Two Blind Mice," which was put on at the Cort last evening. He is taking up the problem of a minor bureau which is still in existence although Congress abolished it more than four years ago.

Improvement in the rules in air travel to prevent collisions of airplanes was demanded yesterday by witnesses at an inquiry by the Civil Aeronautics Board's safety division into the crash of a light Cessna plane into a Pan.American Airways Constellation over Port Washington on Jan. 30.

"Three Godfathers," a Western drama in Technicolor, featuring John Wayne, Pedro Armendariz and Harry Carey Jr., will have its local premiere this morning at the Capitol. John Ford directed the Argosy Pictures presentation, which is being released by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer.

VERO BEACH, Fla., March 2 -- Two of the Brooklyn Club's missing persons were accounted for today when Branch Rickey, Dodger president, and Oakland Joe Hatten, southpaw pitcher, arrived in Dodgertown at about the same time.

Senator Wayne Morse, Oregon Republican, said last night that labor leaders were deluding themselves if they believed the Eighty-first Congress would repeal the Taft-Hartley Act and restore the Wagner Act exactly as it was.

After nineteen months of labor, the Hoover Commission has now completed what is by all odds the most penetrating study of our Federal Government ever made, and has laid down a broad program for a sweeping reorganization of that Government to make it more efficient, more economical and, above all, more effective in meeting its vastly expanded responsibilities at home and abroad.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- The Displaced Persons Commission advised Congress today that, in seeking to fulfill Congressional intent that 205,000 refugees be admitted to this country within two years, it is being forced to evade the law.

LONDON, March 2 -- Any idea that the public would rush in to buy shares for the new account, now that they have to pay only one commission on buying and selling, was dispelled when the stock market opened today.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- Despite the "soundings" of the Secretary of Labor, Maurice J. Tobin, on Capitol Hill for the last forty-eight hours there appeared to be only a slim chance that his desire for a quick report on the Administration's labor bill would be met by the Senate Labor and Public Welfare Committee.
The Alliance Realty Company yesterday observed informally its fiftieth birthday in its offices at 25 Broad Street, with Clarke G. Dailey, president, acting as host.

Extensive newspaper schedules were announced yesterday by Park Tilford for its spring sales and promotion campaigns on All-fabric Tintex Dyes, P cosmetics and perfumes, and Winx eye preparations. Details were presented at the first of a series of sales meetings, held here at the Biltmore Hotel.

NORTH BERGEN, N.J., March 2 -- In the first open revolt against his dominance of municipal government since he took office in 1934, Mayor Paul E. Cullum was defeated by a 3 to 1 vote of the Town Commission today, in connection with a home-owners' tax protest.

MIAMI, March 2 -- The best way to get a true appreciation of the difference between the chilblain belt and the palm tree sector is to fly from New York to Florida. When you're hanging from a cloud -- figuratively and not literally, thank heavens -- you get what amounts to a panoramic view of that difference.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 2 -- Joe DiMaggio was whisked by air today to Baltimore in what Yankee executives thought for a time was a threatening emergency. However Manager Casey Stengel announced the slugging outfielder was expected back in uniform tomorrow and the club was relieved at having experienced nothing more than a bad scare.

Little more than a mathematical chance for the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League championship remained for Columbia following a surprising 48-45 victory by Princeton over the local Lions last night on the Morningside Heights floor.

Country-wide damage caused to highways by overloaded trucks was emphasized yesterday by the American Automobile Association. Rigid restrictive methods were urged in a warning that cited thousands of miles of roads reported badly deteriorated by winter ravages in New York, New Jersey and other areas.
CARSWELL AIR FORCE BASE, Fort Worth, Tex., March 2 -- A B-50 bomber, Lucky Lady II, returned here this morning from the first non-stop, round-the-world trip ever flown.

AT this time H.M. Government attached great importance to aiding General de Gaulle and the Free French to rally the African possessions and colonies of France, especially those upon the Atlantic Coast. Our information was that a large portion of the French officers, officials and traders in all these territories had not despaired.

SHANGHAI, March 2 -- Mao Tzetung, leader of the Chinese Communist party, has assured Acting President Li Tsung-jen that the Communists would name their delegation and the site for the peace talks shortly after March 15, a usually reliable source reported today.

WASHINGTON, March 2 (AP) -- Members of Congress assailed American Communist leaders tonight for saying that in case of another war they would not support the "predatory war aims of American imperialism."
BUDAPEST, Hungary, March 2 (AP) -- Spectators wept as fourteen persons accused of aiding Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty in an alleged political conspiracy began final statements to the court today.

ALBANY, March 2 -- State university trustees asserted formally today that budget cuts proposedby insurgent Erie Republicans were linked with the Condon-Barrett Bill, sponsored by the Regents, as part of a program to delay or prevent establishment of a state university system.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- In a Government of divided powers one of the most difficult decisions the people must make is where official responsibility lies for what is done or not done byGovernment. The blame or the credit is usually a matter of dispute between the executive and legislative branches, and sometimes the judiciary is a party to the argument.

Thomas K. Scherman and his Little Orchestra Society put on one of their most felicitous concerts at the Town Hall last night. With the aid of three singers -- Kathleen Ferrier, Ann Ayars and Louisa Kinlock -- and a group of about forty from the Westminster Choir, Mr. Scherman directed a concert performance of Gluck's "Orfeo e Euridice."
Josep'h ]cConnell, financial vice president of the Radio Corporation of America, has leased an apart[ment in 3 East Seventy-first Street through Douglas L. Elliman Co.

Charges made by American lawyers that brutality was used by American war crimes investigators to extort confessions from German prisoners also are being made by German churchmen on the scene, it was learned yesterday. Numerous protests have been made in this country over the proposed execution of twelve Germans condemned to death for their supposed part in executing American prisoners captured in the Battle of the Bulge in December, 1944.

Several hundred friends and associates in the arts, society and the theatre attended a funeral service yesterday for Charles Hanson Towne, editor, poet and author, in the Little Church Around the Corner. Mr. Towne died on Monday night at Flower-Fifth Avenue Hospital after a long illness, at the age of 72.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- The committee on education of the American Federation of Labor said today it would seek an appropriation of $1,000,000,000 for Federal aid to education and called the Taft-Thomas $300,000,000 bill "inadequate and inequitable."

ALBANY, March 2 -- In a special message to the Legislature today urging adoption of the Fino-McCullough bill creating a State Building Code Commission, Governor Dewey estimated that the promulgation of a state-wide code would save house buyers $800,000,000 in the next five years.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- The Illinois Power Company, Decatur, filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering 200,000 shares of cumulative preferred stock, $50 par value, which are to be offered at competitive bidding.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- President Truman will welcome tomorrow forty high school students selected by competition from among 2,482 entrants to participate in the eighth annual Science Talent Institute, promoted by the Westinghouse Electric Corporation.

In his brilliant and moving memoirs now printed in THE NEW YORK TIMES Winston Churchill gives an accurate account of all the great events he has personally witnessed. However, when he writes about facts he did not himself see, he fairly informs his readers that he then speaks according to some one else's opinion.
Continuous jams and spirited riding marked the six-day bike race at the Twenty-second Engineers Armory last night as the long grind passed the half-way mark.
Renewed interest by home-buyers is reported by developers of several projects in Long Island areas.

TOKYO, March 2 -- Gen. Douglas MacArthur's headquarters this morning produced its second refugee from the Soviet Union within the last three days and assembled the press to interview him. He was 24-year-old Innokenti A. Zyryanov, who floated to Japan on a home-made raft from Kunashiri Island in the Kuriles -- a distance of about twenty miles -- and was rescued half frozen by Japanese fishermen last September.
Two hours of mediation failed yesterday to bring any settlement of a dispute that has closed down the plants of New York's six largest producers of wrapped white bread and cake since Sunday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 2 -- The Motion Picture Industry Council, which was established late in 1947 as a solid-front group for film labor, talent and management and which split wide open recently when Cecil B. de Mille was chosen chairman, met last night and arrived at a compromise which re-established much of its lost solidarity.

Word was received here yesterday that the executive committee of the National Association of Retail Clothiers and Furnishers is proceeding immediately with its plan for the national promotion of the men's apparel industry. The association, convening at White Sulphur Springs, W. Va., will raise $25,000 to retain an advertising agency, public relations organization and firm of management consultants to survey the clothing industry.

CHICAGO, March 2 -- Grain markets were irregular on the Board of Trade today, all items breaking early under general selling which found that support was slow in developing. What was off 1 1/2 cents a bushel, and corn 2 5/8 cents at one time, but a late rally came in wheat and closing trades were at gains of 1/8 to 1 cent, May advancing the least.
Coffee futures were mixed on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday. Contract "S" was easier in active trading, while contract "D" was steady in light trading.

ATHENS, March 2 -- Cominform efforts to use the NOF organization, the National Liberation Front of Macedonia, as an instrument of Communist international policy against both Greece and Yugoslavia have been indicated in a series of Greek rebel broadcasts monitored here in the last few days.
PHOENIX, Ariz., March 2 -- The Giants' perennial problem concerning the identity of the club's center fielder is likely to be with the Polo Grounders another spring.

Scott Paper Company had record sales and earnings last year, it is disclosed in the annual report released for publication today by Raymond C. Mateer, executive vice president. Net sales were $73,597,062 in 1948 and net income rose to $3,839,179.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- Representative Harold D. Cooley, Democrat, of North Carolina, chairman of the House Agriculture Committee, issued an open invitation today to anyone opposing repeal of oleomargarine taxes to take the witness stand. There was no response.
The city of Yonkers, which discharged 500 striking municipal employes Tuesday under the Condon-Wadlin Law, failed yesterday in its first attempt to collect garbage with newly recruited workers.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- While Presidential advisers renewed today their assurances of a "bright and promising" business outlook, a sharp decline in installment buying caused the Federal Reserve Board to loosen credit controls on such things as automobiles, furniture and appliances, beginning Monday.

The Commerce and Industry Association of New York, Inc., called yesterday on the Legislature, "in the interest of sound public finance," to execute final passage of two constitutional amendments on the powers of municipalities to contract debt and real estate tax limitations so that the questions can be submitted to the voters at the November elections.

Jim Gilhooley, New York University's middle-distance stalwart and Henry Laskau, Olympic Walker from the Maccabi A. C., shared the spotlight with record-smashing performances at the annual indoor games of the New York Pioneer Club at the 369th Regiment Armory last night.

Stronger measures to combat juvenile delinquency and organized boy gangsterism were urged by social welfare leaders and law-enforcement officers yesterday afternoon at a conference in the Astor Hotel.
LONDON, March 2 (AP) -- Dr. Dave Freeman of San Diego, Calif., favorite to win the men's singles in the English badminton championships, advanced today to the third round.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 2 (UP) -- A group of Harvard students, rebelling against the Hollywood movie fare, presented the world premiere today of their own film.
Helping the new democracy of Israel to flourish was emphasized yesterday by Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. as the basis for Americans to contribute to the United Jewish Appeal of Greater New York.

The famous Hudson River Day Line, which went out of business in November after eighty-five years of service, was saved from oblivion yesterday when its stockholders approved sale of its four vessels and facilities at Newburgh and Poughkeepsie for $500,000.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- Republican Congressional campaign leaders of the House and Senate today called a joint meeting for tomorrow to discuss greatly expanded electioneering efforts looking toward the 1950 contests for control of Congress.

Reorganization of the American Section of the Jewish Agency Executive into seven departments was announced yesterday. The agency has named Dr. Nahum Goldman as acting chairman of the section. It has not yet acted on the resignation of Dr. Abba Hillel Silver as chairman, and officials would not comment on when action might be taken.

When the House Committee on the Judiciary was holding hearings on the bill to lift the barriers to immigration for 250,000,000 Asiatics -- the bill which passed the House by a large margin on Tuesday -- one of the witnesses was Mike Masaoka, a native-born American of Japanese ancestry whose mother was ineligible for citizenship under the old restrictions.

VIENNA, Feb. 17 -- In moments of frankness Rumanian Communists may tell you that war is necessary. In a country located hard against Russia they have more opportunities than other Rumanians to observe the preparations, to know what is going on.

Following announcement by the El Paso Natural Gas Company after the close of trading on Tuesday of a three-for-one split-up of the 1,100,000 authorized common shares and a 30-cent increase in the quarterly dividend to 90 cents on the present number of shares, the stock closed yesterday at 75 1/4 on the New York Stock Exchange, up 1 1/4 on a turnover of 900 shares.
Five hundred florists from the metropolitan area went to school yesterday in the Statler Hotel. The object of the sessions was to provide some hints on how to sell flowers in a buyers' market.
Jose Basora, veteran Puerto Rican middleweight, fought a draw with Henry Brimm of Buffalo in the star bout of ten rounds at the Manhattan Center last night.

ALBANY, March 2 -- Part of New York State's historic blue laws was well on its way to repealtoday as the Senate completed legislative action on a bill that would legalize football, basketball and soccer on Sundays after 2 P.M.

The Board of Higher Education will hold a public meeting today to permit the representatives of at least eighteen organizations to have their say on the hotly debated subject of who shall be the next president of Queens College.
Fashions for the family in spring coats and suits and frocks for the young fry as well as for older sister and mother made up the extensive showing presented at Martin's of Brooklyn yesterday.

Persons with a curious interest in the changing face of our city will note that it is an unusual design for a midtown building which is proposed for the block fronting on Sixth Avenue -- or the Avenue of the Americas -- between Forty-third and Forty-fourth Streets.

Proposals that the Export-Import Bank or other Government agencies guarantee to American exporters the conversion or transfer into dollars of foreign exchange covering export transactions met no support yesterday at the meeting of the Foreign Credit Interchange Bureau at the Statler Hotel.

The principal event on last night's program by the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo at the City Center was the season's first presentation of George Balanchine's "Ballet Imperial," set to Tchaikovsky's Second Piano Concerto. It is one of the most successful of all the Balanchine works, and when Mary Ellen Moylan dances the central role, as she did last night, it becomes an occasion.

PARIS, March 2 -- "We deny that our Government has the right to sign the Atlantic pact," shouted Maurice Thorez, Communist leader, in a speech tonight to a crowd that filled the Velodrome d'Hiver, largest hall in Paris.

"ELIOT, T[HOMAS] S[TEARNS] (1888- )," the admirable "Oxford Companion to American Literature" tells us, was "born in St. Louis, graduated from Harvard (1910) and studied at the Sorbonne and at Merton College, Oxford. For a year he was an instructor in philosophy at Harvard, and his first articles were on this subject.
WASHINGTON, March 2 -- James Forrestal, Secretary of Defense, will resign about April 1, it was reliably reported tonight in a recurrence of speculation on changes in President Truman's Cabinet.

NANKING, March 3 -- Apparently encouraged by the Communist reception of the unofficial Shanghai peace mission and a "polite" letter from Communist Chairman Mao Tze-tung, Acting President Li Tsung-jen has named a ten-man committee to prepare for formal peace talks in North China some time after March 15.

The Niagara Hudson Power Corporation had the highest revenues in its twenty-five-year history last year, but net income was below that of 1947 due to increased costs, according to the annual report for 1948 which is being distributed today by Earle J. Machold, president of the up-state utility.

CLEVELAND, March 3 (AP) -- Federal Judge Emerich B. Freed late today held the Timken Roller Bearing Company of Canton, Ohio, guilty of entering into a world cartel to fix prices and eliminate competition in violation of the Sherman Anti-Trust Law.

PHILADELPHIA, March 3 (AP) -- The New York Knickerbockers spurted into a commanding edge at the start and led all the way to trounce the Providence Steam Rollers, 86 -- 65, in a Basketball Association of America game tonight.

ALBANY, March 3 -- A trial of issues to determine whether Father Divine, religious cult leader, inherited $600,000 by suppressing forcefully a new will of an 80-year old woman follower was ordered today by the Court of Appeals.

Employe representatives in 8,105 concerns will solicit funds from 1,164,107 fellow-workers as the American Red Cross seeks to meet the city's quota of $4,635,000 in the 1949 drive, the New York Chapter announced yesterday.

LONDON, March 3 -- Viscount Bruce of Melbourne, former Australian Prime Minister and empire statesman, said today that fear of rising discontent within the Soviet Union against bad living standards had driven Soviet leaders to adopt an intransigent policy in world affairs.
Community Service Society nutritionists suggested corn muffins yesterday as a substitute for bread during the tie-up of the major bakeries here.

Mayor O'Dwyer, members of the Board of Estimate, other city officials and 1,000 friends paid final tribute yesterday in City Hall to Capt. Jacob Joseph of the Marine Corps Reserve, son of Controller Lazarus Joseph. The 22-year-old marine captain was killed on Oct. 22, 1942, at Guadalcanal.
WASHINGTON, March 3 -- "Electric eyes" for blind war veterans will undergo tests soon, the Army revealed today.

The Customs Service, at an auction yesterday, realized $16,227 from the sale of 600 lots of abandoned, unclaimed and seized merchandise, ranging from a 1941 Dodge sedan to miscellaneous items of no commercial value.

GENEVA, Switzerland, March 3 -- Trustees of the Waltham Watch Company have cabled their thanks to the Swiss Watchmakers' Federation for their offer of modern watchmaking machinery to help the Massachusetts company out of its difficulties.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Republican House and Senate campaign leaders met to day and agreed to press their requests upon the party's national organization for large increases in funds authorized for preliminary electioneering looking toward the 1950 elections.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 3 (AP) -- Bob Hamilton, taking off strokes as he takes off pounds, hammered his way into the lead in the $10,000 St. Petersburg open golf tournament today with a 34, 33 -- 67.

Informed by Yonkers officials that they were fighting a losing battle to maintain essential city services through use of the Condon-Wadlin Anti-Strike Law, Governor Dewey last night instructed the State Health and Public Works Departments to send representatives to Yonkers to help cope with the strike of 500 municipal employes.
The typewriter may replace the pen and pencil in elementary school if an experiment now under way at the Hunter College "Model School" proves successful.
L. William Dilts has been appointed vice president in charge of sales of both the Vanity Fair and Extacee divisions of Vanity Fair Mills, Inc., with offices at 10 East Fortieth Street.

TEL AVIV, Israel, March 3 -- Premier David Ben-Gurion assembled today his new Government -- a four-party coalition with his own moderate Socialist Mapai party holding seven of twelve seats, including all the key portfolios. The Orthodox bloc obtained three seats and the Progressives and Sephardim (Levantine Jews) one each.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- The House Banking and Currency Committee virtually completed action today on a measure extending rent control in somewhat strengthened form for another fifteen months. A late effort to add an anti-discrimination feature blocked final approval.

LONDON, March 3 -- The British Government successfully withstood in the House of Commons today a strong Opposition attack on its defense policy. After a long debate the Government's White Paper on defense was, in effect, approved by a vote of 291 to 155.
As one of the "nine philosophers" mentioned in THE TIMES of Feb. 2. and again in Prof. Paul Weiss' letter on Feb. 10, I should like to ask the privilege of comment on that letter.

One of the main arguments used with dull consistency by the opponents and doubters of civil rights is that "You can't change human nature simply by passing a law." As a full federal program is offered to secure the people's rights, that fallacious assumption again is echoed.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Charles W. Holman, secretary of the National Cooperative Milk Producers Association, today predicted that free sale of yellow margarine as provided in the Page Bill would reduce the butter market by 25 to 40 per cent, and "turn the present dairy recession into a true depression."
There is now pending before the state Legislature a bill to introduce permanent personal registration on a state-wide basis.

VERO BEACH, Fla., March 3 -- On this, the third day of conditioning for the Brooklyn Dodgers, there were nearly 300 players in uniform and doing every sort of exercise from calisthenics to knocking baseballs off a stationary tee.

Whenever intracity rivals cross paths, anything is likely to happen and the anything in last night's case at Madison Square Garden was a totally unexpected 44-43 basketball victory for Manhattan College over C. C. N. Y. This was the second upset of the night, for in the opener, Muhlenberg routed Long Island University, 62 -- 54, before 16,215 fans.

The board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that the Exchange will be closed on Saturdays from May 28 through Sept. 24. The Exchange was closed for Saturday trading during the same four months last year.

The criticisms leveled in Winston Churchill's war memoirs against the French military and political leadership during the last war are now drawing replies from the French leaders involved. Such replies have been issued by Generals Gamelin, Weygand and Prioux, with promises of further elucidation, and by former Premiers Chautemps and Reynaud.

PHILADELPHIA, March 3 -- In contrast to the findings of other scholars, Dr. Solomon Zeitlin, Professor of Rabbinical Literature at Dropsie College, believes the Biblical manuscripts recently discovered by wandering Bedouin are "not an important discovery, but possibly a hoax."

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 3 -- Joe DiMaggio came back to the Yankees today from a flying visit to Dr. George Bennett in Baltimore, but his return did not completely remove the club's apprehension over his condition.

PARIS, March 3 -- The newly created steering committee of men of cabinet rank will meet here tomorrow under the leadership of Sir Stafford Cripps, British Chancellor of the Exchequer; French Foreign Minister Robert Schuman and Belgian Prime Minister Paul-Henri Spaak, to "advise" the European Marshall Plan council regarding possible harmonization of long-range recovery plans in Europe.

A 50 per cent decline in the artificial flower industry during 1948 was reported yesterday by Jacob Goldman, executive secretary of the Artificial Flower Manufacturers Board of Trade, after a series of executive sessions with leading manufacturers.

GENEVA, March 3 -- The revelation of a gross overestimation of the effective demand for timber in Europe during 1948 threatens to force serious revisions in the calculations of economic planners about one of Europe's three most important internationally traded raw materials.
