Pete, a tired old hippopotamus who has been sleeping standing up since last Friday, waited patiently yesterday for the signal to return to his pool in the Elephant House at the Bronx Zoo.

Some of the best skiing this unusual winter lies ahead, and this week-end will find midseason sport available at most of the northern points, as well as the metropolitan area. The wise skier will take time before storing his hickory boards, as prospects for a long spring period of fun are most encouraging.

One does not have to rhapsodize over every stroke of Bruno Walter's baton, or even agree to a hair with all that he does, to say that the Beethoven series he is now offering on Thursday nights and Friday afternoons with the Philharmonic - Symphony in Carnegie Hall has a special attraction and charm for the public.
NEWARK, March 3 -- Archbishop Thomas J. Walsh announced today that Msgr. James Francis Kelley had resigned as president of Seton Hall College in South Orange, N. J.

JERSEY CITY, N. J., March 3 -- A two-day strike of 300 stevedores on Piers C, D and F of the American Export Lines, here, ended tonight as a result of mediation efforts of Mayor Frank H. Eggers. An agreement, reached after a two and one-half hour conference in the mayor's office, provides for a new hiring system which will undergo a thirty-day trial.
WASHINGTON, March 3 -- President Truman came out today for a far stiffer anti-filibuster rule than the one on which the Senate all week has been bitterly engaged.
Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower made a strong appeal last night for revision of the Armed Services Unification Act so as to permit the Secretary of Defense to accomplish what he wishes to be done.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- The Senate Armed Services Committee unanimously today to devote voted five more days to the consideration of the nomination of Mon C. Wallgren, former Governor of Washington, as chairman of the National Security Resources Board.

The first of five lectures on "Two Hundred Years of American Homes," describing the fine points of antique furniture and room settings of Colonial and early Republic days, was given yesterday afternoon in the lecture hall at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
WASHINGTON, March 3 -- President Truman today branded the two top leaders of the American Communist party as "traitors." His statement, made at a news conference, had immediate repercussions.
WASHINGTON, March 3 -- The United States gave its full support today to General Clay in a note to the Soviet Union rejecting its protest against the exit order.

Aluminum alloy casting ingot prices were quoted here yesterday by leading smelters and refiners 2 to 3 cents or more below prices at the last official listing on Feb. 4. Last previous official price of 22 3/4 cents for lowest grade alloys yesterday was changed to 20 cents.

"Bad Men of Tombstone," a Western produced by the King Brothers for Allied Artists, will open this morning at the Rialto. Barry Sullivan, Marjorie Reynolds and Broderick Crawford head the cast of the offering, which was directed by Kurt Newmann from a screen play by Philip Yordan and Arthur Strawn and the novel by Jay Monaghan.

Installment credit controls will be relaxed beginning next Monday under a ruling just announced by the Federal Reserve Board. Customers will be given more time in which to make their installment payments on all items now subject to control under the Board's "Regulation W."

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Both the President and James Forrestal, the first Secretary of Defense in our history, are content with the arrangement whereby Mr. Forrestal is to leave office March 31. They are content for virtually the same reasons, which is unusual in the circumstances.

WASHINGTON, March 3 (AP) -- The Baltimore Ohio Railroad Company objected today to a proposal by the Pennsylvania and Wabash Railroads to acquire control of about 500 miles of additional trackage in the Great Lakes industrial area.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- President Truman announced to day the resignation of James Forrestal, the first person to hold the office of Secretary of Defense, and the appointment of Louis A. Johnson of Clarksburg, W. Va., as his successor.

A jurisdictional dispute in the field of television involving three unions came out into the open yesterday, with indications that the controversy might assume serious proportions after May 1. The labor groups involved are the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employes and the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, both A. F. of L. affiliates, and the National Association of Broadcast Engineers and Technicians, an independent union.

PARIS, March 3 -- Paul Ramadier, French Minister of Defense, today expressed regret at the delay in the conclusion of the North Atlantic defense pact and other Allied military agreements. In a debate on military credits, the Defense Minister said these delays were partly the cause of the difficulties of the French Government in estimating a definite military budget.
EL PASO, Tex., March 3 (AP) -- Dr. Alton Ochsner said tonight golfer Ben Hogan would "completely recover" from a blood clot operation.

Meat is going to be the big problem for shoppers seeking thrifty possibilities for the coming weekend. Though the seasonal increase in veal supplies is under way, only three cuts are lower in retail shops today. Counter-balancing these are increases of 2 to 6 cents on several selections of beef, pork and lamb.

CLEVELAND, March 3 (AP) -- A stockholders suit demanding an accounting and compensation for "losses to stockholders by the unlawful acts of the organizers" of the $30,000,000 Jack Heintz Precision Industries, Inc., was filed today in Common Pleas Court.

MUNICH, Germany, March 3 (AP) -- A refugee Czechoslovak Army officer testified before a United States military commission today that his Communist - dominated country had laid out a broad spy network in Europe.
PARIS, March 3 -- Gen. Maxime Weygand took strong exception today to statements in Winston Churchill's memoirs concerning his activities as head of the French forces in 1940.

LAKE SUCCESS, March 3 -- Leroy D. Stinebower of the United States told the United Nations Economic and Social Council today, in response to many critical questions raised by delegations seeking precise details of President Truman's proposed program of technical aid to underdeveloped countries, that it was up to the world organization to work out its own effective plan.

Major Julian S. Ellenberg, Protestant chaplain at Fort Jay, Governors Island, has left this post for new duties in the Far East Command, Yokohama, Japan, it was announced yesterday at First Army Headquarters. He is to be assigned as senior chaplain at the Forty-ninth General Hospital in Japan.

LAKE SUCCESS, March 3 -- France and China announced today that they would support Israel's application for membership in the United Nations, thus making certain its approval by the Security Council. However, a parliamentary wrangle prevented the Council from taking a vote this afternoon, and it will resume its discussions tomorrow.

The stock market drifted yesterday into the doldrums. Price changes were meaningless and there was a further drop in trading volume. A few of the industrials made modest gains but the list generally held level with Wednesday's close.

PARIS, Feb. 26 -- The fundamental economic ambition of France is the achievement of a balance of payments equilibrium in 1952-1953, accompanied by establishment of a sufficiently high standard of living to undermine much of the political threat of communism.

Selection of a new standard of wool top for Army serge cloth to permit use of coarser grades was announced yesterday by the Quartermaster Corps, Department of the Army. The new standard, however, will not apply to 4,000,000 linear yards of blue serge for the Air Force, for which invitations to bid have been sent to the trade, or other goods currently under contract.
Summit County, N. J., announced yesterday that it will receive bids on March 15 for an issue of $1,000,000 of school bonds dated April 1, 1949 and due on each April 1 from 1950 to 1969.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 3 -- Henry Ginsberg, Paramount production chief, today announced to the company's East-West executive conference being held at the studio here that the Paramount production program for the rest of 1949, including pictures now before the cameras, will amount to twenty-two features.

The management of the impending "Miss Liberty" was determined to secure Allyn McLerie for a principal role in the Irving Berlin-Robert E. Sherwood musical. They have. Tied up to a run-of-the-play contract in the musical hit, "Where's Charley?" starring Ray Bolger Miss McLerie couldn't obtain a release until her agreement expired on May 31.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- The State Department announced tonight the establishment of an Office of German and Austrian Affairs under the direction of Robert D. Murphy, political adviser with the rank of Ambassador to Gen. Lucius D. Clay, United States military commander in Germany.

Landers, Frary Clark yesterday reduced the list price of one of its upright vacuum cleaners from $64.95 to $49.95. The reduction was announced by R. C. Nielson, metropolitan district sales manager, at a meeting of New York State distributors of the company's Universal line of major appliances in the Commodore Hotel.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Friday, March 4 -- Russian authorities ordered their repatriation mission here last night to accede to Gen. Lucius D. Clay's demand that they leave the United States zone. At the same time they annulled the right of United States Graves Registration personnel in the Soviet zone to carry on their work there.

Dr. Irwin Edman, Professor of Philosophy at Columbia University, announced yesterday he had withdrawn as a sponsor of the Cultural and Scientific Conference for World Peace scheduled for March 25-27 at the Waldorf-Astoria.

Economic research and industrial relations are two major activities of business and educational institutions in which great strides are being made throughout the country. These facts were disclosed here yesterday by W. Walter Williams of Seattle, Wash., chairman of the Committee for Economic Development, at the first national Business-Education Conference, held at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel and attended by more than sixty leading industrialists and educators.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- The Central Hudson Gas and Electric Corporation, Poughkeepisie, N. Y., filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering 20,000 shares of cumulative preferred stock that is to be offered at competitive bidding.

Financially, the nation's economy is strong and liquid, the National City Bank of New York declares in its Monthly Letter, published today. Not only is current income backed by an unprecedented volume of liquid assets, the bank says, "but there is no such structure of private debt and no such evidence of financial strain as has preceded past periods of general and severe liquidation."
The art of the ancient Near East, "the Fertile Crescent" and "cradle of civilization" in our school-day books, makes a fascinating exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum. It opens to the public today.

Wallace F. Bennett, president of the National Association of Manufacturers, said yesterday that the question of industrial sabotage had been raised by Wednesday's statement of American Communist leaders that they would oppose this country in a war with Soviet Russia.

Complete defiance of Bishop James P. De Wolfe's decision ordering his removal April 4 from the rectorship of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Holy Trinity, Brooklyn, was expressed yesterday by the Rev. Dr. John Howard Melish in his first public statement on the Bishop's action.

MIAMI, Fla., March 3 -- Getaway day at Hialeah always serves as the occasion for the staging of the flamboyant show of the Florida racing season. It is quite an affair, one that could not be produced with any degree of plausibility anywhere else. To begin with, Hialeah is breathtakingly beautiful. It is far more beautiful than, let's say, Jamaica. Or even Aqueduct.

BERLIN, March 3 -- Unemployment in the bizonal area of Germany has gone above the million mark, prompting a re-examination of economic conditions that may lead to a Western Allied decision to increase the issue of West Deutsche marks.

Delaware Power Light Company arranged yesterday for the stand-by underwriting of 232,520 additional shares of its common stock by accepting the bid of a syndicate headed by Blyth Co., Inc., to manage an eighteen-day offering of the new issue to stockholders at $18.50 a share.

CHICAGO, March 3 -- The Tucker Corporation, beset with financial difficulties, was authorized today by Federal District Judge Michael L. Igoe to enter into reorganization under Chapter 10 of the Federal Bankruptcy Law. Attorneys Aaron Colnon and John H. Chatz were appointed by Judge Igoe as trustees of the court to handle the reorganization.

Just about a year ago a veritable flood of mail suddenly poured in to our desk and because these letters were so different in content from the normal correspondence received, they made quite an impression.
OSLO, Norway, March 3 -- Norway's adherence to the Atlantic pact was discussed at length at today's secret session of the Storting (Parliament).

Denouncing the practice of saving the best china for company meals as "disgraceful" and the use of only two or three different sets of dinnerware in a lifetime as "psychologically demoralizing," Carole Stupell urged yesterday that the table be made a "dynamic part of the day, not a convenience with nuisance value."

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended Feb. 26, 1949, totaled 688,128 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 9,207 cars, or 1.3 per cent fewer than for the preceding week, 102,782 cars, or 13 per cent fewer than for the corresponding week last year, and 161,863 cars, or 19 per cent fewer than during the corresponding week of 1947.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Senator Pat McCarran, Democrat, of Nevada, chairman of the Joint Committee serving as Congressional "watchdog" over the Marshall Plan, today called on Paul G. Hoffman, Economic Cooperation Administrator, to revise the ECA's recently adopted policy on the insuring of shipments of aid to recovery countries.
ALBANY, March 3 -- Governor Dewey approved bills today to increase the salaries of city court justices in New York City and to extend for one year the life of the State Temporary Commission on Rents.

The consent decree through which the Paramount Pictures Corporation agreed last week to divorce its domestic exhibition business from its production and distribution enterprises was approved yesterday by a Federal statutory court.

Henry A. Wallace announced last night that he was in complete disagreement with the "wisdom" of recent statements of American, French and Italian Communist leaders on what they would do in the event of a war with the Soviet Union, though he understood their reasons.
The opening of the new fashion thrift floor at Abraham Straus was the occasion for a fashion show held last evening on the second floor of the Brooklyn store.

Ogden Phipps, the defending titleholder; Alastair B. Martin and Robert Grant 3d, former wearers of the crown, and Robert L. Gerry Jr. advanced to the semi-finals of the national amateur court tennis championship yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- President Truman's effort to bring the country's 8,500,000 farmers into the Federal old-age and survivors' insurance system received a possibly fatal blow today from a key Congressional quarter.

PARIS, March 3 -- The arrest of a member of the staff of the French Atomic Energy Commission was the outstanding development today in the Government's inquiry into Communist leaks of secret information on defense.
MUSKEGON, Mich., March 3 -- A mother, nine of her thirteen children and a roomer were burned fatally today in a fire that leveled their flimsy home at Lakewood in a matter of minutes.

ALBANY, March 3 -- R. H. Hughes, vice president of the New York Telephone Company, told the Public Service Commission today that earnings on the company's intrastate operations under present rates would drop to 3.28 per cent in 1949, compared with earnings of 4.45 per cent last year.
MIAMI, Fla., Mar. 3 -- It was Olympia all the way in the $67,100 Flamingo Stakes before Hialeah's record 1949 crowd of 28,359 today.

Offsetting exactly their gain of the previous week, business loans by banks in this area during the week ended on Wednesday declined $11,000,000, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. Repayments by department stores, oil and sales finance companies, and on commodity loans, were the major factors in the reduction of such borrowings by the reporting New York City member banks.
WASHINGTON, March 3 (AP) -- Two top-ranking Air Force officers will swap commands next month, Gen. Hoyt S. Vandenberg, Air Force Chief of Staff, said today.
The International Business Machines Corporation achieved record earnings and sales in 1948, Thomas J. Watson, president, announces in the annual report to stockholders, issued for publication today.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Department store sales in the week ended Feb. 26 were 7 per cent below sales in the corresponding week of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The following lists percentage changes from like periods of 1948:

The Shipbuilders Council of America took issue yesterday with the United States Maritime Commission on the agency's plan to drydock and preserve the hulls of 2,300 laid-up merchant vessels without use of the private ship repair industry.

Refusal of a witness to answer questions before the special Federal grand jury investigating subversive activities led to his being haled before Federal Judge Simon H. Rifkind yesterday for instructions as to the right to withhold the information sought.
The State Public Service Commission authorized the bankrupt Long Island Rail Road yesterday to put its new, higher commutation fare into effect immediately after midnight tomorrow.

BUENOS AIRES, March 3 -- Argentina is determined to do everything in her power to liberalize conditions for importers here but will cling to export controls as a basic defense of her national economy, according to Roberto Ares, President Juan D. Peron's new 37-year-old Secretary of Economy.

A century ago the United States had (with the exception of Alaska) practically the same continental interior it has today, but not until a hundred years ago this week did it have an agency of Cabinet rank to administer the same. Interior has often seemed a grab-bag of agencies.

DETROIT, March 3 -- The United Automobile Workers, CIO, invited the Ford Motor Company today to examine "top-heavy prices" instead of "meager paychecks" of the workers to find a way "to preserve the company's high rate of profit."

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- The possibility of a new United States aid program for China was seen today in a meeting of the National Security Council at the White House, where Far Eastern matters were taken under consideration.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, March 3 -- There was an unconfirmed report tonight that Bulgarian authorities had placed a ban on forty Protestant ministers forbidding them to exercise church functions until further orders.
WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Appointment of Louis A. Johnson as Secretary of Defense brings to the nation's top security post a man with a reputation as an advocate of air power and the record to prove it.

A $1,000,000 rider to Senator Elbert Thomas' pending $325,000,000 bill on aid to education, to be earmarked for the performing arts, was proposed yesterday by Morton Baum, chairman of the executive committee of the New York City Center of Music and Drama.

TRENTON, N. J., March 3 -- Legislation was being prepared today under bipartisan sponsorship, and with the approval of Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll, to bar Communists from public jobs in New Jersey. The bill is not inspired by knowledge of known Communists on any public payroll, but to guard against them, it was said.

TEL AVIV, Israel, March 3 -- Inasmuch as Palestine's Arab refugees have already flocked into neighboring countries in barely manageable numbers, many observers here are puzzled that apparently nobody did anything to dissuade the civilian Arabs from evacuating Faluja.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., March 3 -- The Atlantic City branch of the Young Women's Christian Association severed all connections today with its parent body, the Young Women's Christian Association of the United States of America.

The Board of Higher Education defied Mayor O'Dwyer last night by adopting in executive session a resolution declaring that it realized that it should exercise its "free judgment" in the choice of a new president for Queens College.

The soldier of this war just past has his memories. They are starting to fade now. The big experience is remembered, but more and more of the little things are slipping away into the lost corners of the mind.

Harlem's Sydenham Hospital, virtually the only voluntary hospital in the city to admit private patients of Negro physicians, was taken over by the city yesterday when its 156 patients were faced with a shortage of medical supplies, food and heat.
WASHINGTON, March 3 -- During the week ended March 2, member bank reserve balances increased $243,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

Part of the cost-of-living bonuses of 100,000 city employes will become part of their regular salaries on July 1 with a resulting average pension increase of $200 a year Mayor O'Dwyer announced yesterday.

A conference yesterday at the Statler Hotel on an economy housing program, sponsored by Federal and state agencies and private associations, societies and real estate boards, failed to receive the cooperation of American Federation of Labor representatives.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- The Electric Power and Light Corporation, New York, filed today an amendment to its plan of dissolution and the Securities and Exchange Commission gave the program its full approval.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- The National Labor Relations Board issued its first ruling today under the Taft-Hartley Law's provisions on jurisdictional disputes, but a minority of the board disputed the procedure, arguing that the issue was not a true jurisdictional dispute.

ON BOARD U. S. S. POCONO, SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, March 3 -- The atomic bomb in time may radically modify the tactics of amphibious assaults and probably will force greater use of airborne troops, Admiral W. H. P. Blandy, commanding the Atlantic Fleet, said today in an interview aboard his flagship.

Fields for two major Madison Square Garden basketball tournaments -- the National Invitation and the Eastern National Collegiate Athletic Association playoffs -- were half filled yesterday with the selection of Yale for the N. C. A. A. meet.

CHICAGO, March 3 -- William Wrigley Jr. Company had net income in 1948 of $11,455,114, equal to $5.82 a share on the common stock, compared with $8,490,561, or $4.31 a share, in the preceding year, J. C. Cox, president, told stockholders today in the annual report. Sales rose to $61,440,166 last year from $50,186,953 in 1947.

FRANKFORT, Germany, March 3 -- German political leaders and some sources in the press already have responded with gratification to the series of recommendations made by three Western Allied military governors for revising the draft constitution for the proposed Western German government.

Two provisions of the bill to raise postal rates, H. R. 2945, were criticized by the American Association of Advertising Agencies yesterday as harmful to advertising generally, and to specialized publications, such as women's and business magazines, in particular.

PRINCETON, N. J., March 3 -- The traditional highlight of the winter social season at Princeton University, the annual junior promenade in Dillon Gymnasium, is expected to attract more than 1,000 young women guests tomorrow evening.

WASHINGTON, March 3 (AP) -- Following are the texts of a Russian note protesting the action of General Lucius D. Clay, United States commander in Germany, in ordering the Soviet repatriation mission to leave the United States zone, and the United States reply supporting General Clay's action:

CHICAGO, March 3 -- Dave Beck, executive vice president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, AFL, told 700 local officials of the union today that, if necessary to achieve a "proper settlement" of the bakery strike in New York, he was ready to go there at once and "call a mass meeting of every member of the teamsters."

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Winston Churchill, former Prime Minister of Great Britain, will look back into history and President Truman will peer into the future when they speak on March 31 and April 1 at a convocation of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

ALBANY, March 3 -- Assemblyman Elisha T. Barrett Jr., Suffolk Republican, branded as false today a charge by trustees of the state University that a bill he is cosponsoring is linked with the fight of insurgent Republican legislators to prune Governor Dewey's budget.

RENO, Nev., March 2 -- Mrs. Alice Stewart Moore obtained today a divorce from Adrian Pulitzer Moore of Bar Harbor, Me., on grounds of cruelty. The couple were married Dec. 5, 1943, in Darien, Conn. There was an agreement as to the custody of their child.

The North Atlantic Pact is an outgrowth of the sorrowful recognition that under present conditions world security means very little, Hume Wrong, Canadian Ambassador to the United States, declared last night.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., March 3 -- A new philosophy of education that many authorities believe will prevail in the future is guiding the 2,200 students at Adelphi College. Under the leadership of Dr. Paul Dawson Eddy, president of the college, the traditional type of education is heightened with an emphasis on fitting the students for living.
Members of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York gathered at noon yesterday to participate in the election of Herbert Hoover to honorary membership in the organization.

The Department of National Defense is today at a critical stage of development. Set up under the National Security Act of 1947 as the unified agency of national defense, it has in a year and a half of operation shown many minor and some major defects. Suggested remedies, based on Congressional observation, a thorough study by the Hoover Commission and recommendations from within the Department itself, are soon to be presented to the Eighty-first Congress.
WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Norway today requested and received an invitation to join the diplomatic conversations on the North Atlantic security pact.

Passage of the Judd bill for equality in naturalization and immigration (H. R. 199) with an overwhelming majority vote in the House of Representatives, as reported in THE NEW YORK TIMES of March 2, is heartening to those of us who have hoped that discrimination would be removed from this phase of our national life.
WASHINGTON, March 3 -- The Commission on Organization of the Executive Branch of the Government will recommend considerable enlargement of the Department of Labor, it was reported today.
DEL RIO, Tex., March 3 (AP) -- The charred wreckage of a C-47 Air Force plane was found today in Mexico, far off its California-to-Texas course. All nine persons on board were reported killed.
Five hundred and forty-nine European refugees arrived here yesterday on the United States Lines' Marine Shark -- the twelfth vessel to enter the country under the Displaced Persons Act of 1948.

Brown, Simon Firstsch, Inc., sold the new six-story apartment house for seventy families at 186 East 164th Street, the Bronx, which they finished about four months ago, to a syndicate consisting of Dr. Rocholin, and Betsey and Judy Weinstein.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Polite but firm disagreement on United States Military Government policy in Germany marked an exchange of correspondence between Gen. Lucius D. Clay, United States Commander in Chief in Germany, and Matthew Woll, chairman of the International Labor Relations Department of the American Federation of Labor.

TOKYO, March 3 -- The results of a major series of by-elections held this week throughout Japan have confirmed the nation's strong swing to the right as indicated by the triumph of the Conservatives in last month's voting for the national government.

Harry Markson gave calm consideration to the explosion in the heavyweight boxing ranks on his return from Miami yesterday. The acting director of the Twentieth Century Sporting Club, fresh from a visit to the organization's president Mike Jacobs, expressed himself as willing to handle situations as they might arise in commenting on that created by the decision recently made by Joe Louis to become a boxing promoter.

Your recent thought-provoking editorial, "Harbor Funds," touches on a matter that is disturbing to all informed persons and organizations who have to do with shipping; deepening the channels, anchorages and slips in New York Harbor.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Nine airlines, including eight of the major carriers, today dropped without explanation a proposal to impose a service charge for the sale of tickets on top of regular fares. The eight big carriers had planned to add $1 to regular ticket charges, while Southwest Airlines, a regional service, had served notice of an extra charge of 40 cents.

The Standard Oil Company (Indiana) reported yesterday for 1948 a consolidated net income $140,079,286 after charges, taxes and reserves, equal to $9.11 each on the 15,284,793 capital snares outstanding at the year-end. This compares with $94,880,715, or $6.21 a share, in 1947.

Aided by new production facilities completed since the war, improved supplies of paper and slightly greater receipts of steel, sales of the American Can Company rose to $409,511,398 last year, according to the annual report issued for publication today by D. W. Figgis, president. In 1947 net sales aggregated $338,163,242.
Two thousand and sixty cases of chickenpox were reported to the Department of Health in February and 1,389 cases in January, Dr. Harry S. Mustard, Health Commissioner, announced yesterday.

LONDON, March 3 -- The United States moved today to ease the deadlock between the Soviet Union and the three Western powers that has all but brought the Austrian treaty talks here to a standstill. With the backing of Britain and France, United States Deputy Samuel Reber proposed a four-point program guaranteeing full rights for Austria's ethnic minorities and specifically for the Slovenes in Carinthia.

ATHENS, March 3 -- The Communist Information Bureau (Cominform) has ordered the Communist party of Greece to declare itself unequivocally in favor of an autonomous Macedonia and henceforth to work toward the creation and organization of such a state, sources close to the Communists in Athens revealed today.
OTTAWA, March 3 (Canadian Press) -- Transport Minister Lionel Chevrier said today that Canada's war-built merchant ships should be replaced if they were to compete with ships of other countries.

After early steadiness coffee futures turned easy on scattered selling on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday. Final prices for contract "D" were 5 to 32 points lower with the spot month steadiest. The major part of the activity consisted in switching from 1949 to the 1950 delivery positions.

Samuel Sanders, 11-year-old pianist, gave a recital last night at Times Hall. Born a "blue baby," the boy was cured of his affliction two years ago and shortly afterward began his musical studies. Although his appearance as a concert artist was premature, he disclosed decided talent, having made unusual progress during the brief period he has devoted to his art.

Yesterday's fashion showing presented an aspect different from the majority of those reviewed in the course of the week. The show was De Pinna's, the clothes all ready-to-wear. The exhibit took place in the Terrace Room of the Plaza Hotel.
WASHINGTON, March 3 -- President Truman declared today that his Administration still needed power to put a roof on price spirals upward and a floor under downward spirals.

George Sanders, owner of the Sutton Line, confirmed yesterday his purchase of the Hudson River Day Line for $500,000 and said that he expected to begin operations with at least two of the four river boats involved by the third week in May.

The Communist party of the United States has now joined the Communist parties of France, Italy, Great Britain and Germany in what amounts to a declaration of superior loyalty to Russia in the event of a conflict between the Soviets and the various nations of which these Communist parties profess to be good citizens.

BERLIN, March 3 -- The British Military Government flatly refused tonight to discuss unofficial Soviet proposals for the withdrawal of occupation forces from Germany until the Russians began "to honor Stalin's signature" to the Potsdam Agreement by carrying out that document.

LONDON, March 3 -- Following yesterday's declines, share prices again were unsettled in the stock market here today. A further general drop occurred at the opening when equities came under fire from bear speculators. Covering operations toward close, however, brought about partial rally in most sections but there was no sign of genuine support.

Ending one of the bitterest airline fights in the history of the industry, Capt. Eddie Rickenbacker, president of Eastern Air Lines, and George T. Baker, president of National Airlines, announced yesterday that they had reached an agreement for interchange of traffic between Florida and Texas.

ALBANY, March 3 -- In a unanimous decision, the Court of Appeals ruled today that the trustees of the New York City Fire Department Pension Fund could not compel disabled firemen to retire against their wishes if they were capable of performing light duty.

Seven new leading singers have been added to the roster of the New York City Opera Company for its spring season beginning March 24, it was announced yesterday. Of the five tenors and two sopranos, two are being drafted from Broadway musicals and three will come here from abroad.
WASHINGTON, March 3 (AP) -- President Truman's letter accepting the resignation of James Forrestal, Secretary of Defense, follows:

LONDON, March 3 -- Calmly puffing his cigar, Winston Churchill sat in a meeting of Conservative Members of Parliament for an hour and a half tonight listening to an inquest on the party's latest election defeat, which some critics have laid in part to his leadership.

Cardinal Spellman, Roman Catholic Archbishop of New York, oversaw 100 seminarians digging graves in Calvary Cemetery, Queens, yesterday, temporarily replacing 240 gravediggers who have been on strike for seven weeks.

With a shortage of new cars in the lower-priced brackets already existing in this city, according to a survey completed yesterday by the Automobile Merchants Association of New York, the easing of Regulation W credit restrictions is expected to bring an additional influx of potential buyers into the market.

LAKE SUCCESS, March 3 -- Seventeen members of the United Nations will hold an important private conference in New York tomorrow to draw up plans for diplomatic action against the Netherlands for its policy in Indonesia.

Retailers, manufacturers and distributors greeted the easing of consumer installment terms through the revision of Regulation W, announced Wednesday by the Federal Reserve Board, with divided opinions, according to a survey here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 3 (UP) -- Some 19,700,000 veterans of World War II probably will get their long-awaited dividends on National Service Life Insurance by June 30, 1950, Carl R. Gray Jr., Veterans Administrator, said today.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange experienced a very quiet day yesterday and final prices were 2 points higher to 7 points lower.

The State Mediation Board had the busiest year in its twelve-year history in 1948, the board reported yesterday. The state agency handled 3,021 casese, almost evenly divided between mediation and arbitration, and adjusted disputes involving more than 200,000 workers.
ALBANY, March 3 -- Governor Dewey asked tile Legislature in a special message today to act quickly on legislation to abate pollution of the state's waters.

Billy Graham, East Side welter-weight, will trade punches with Paddy de Marco of the Brooklyn Navy Yard district in the main bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden tonight. The battle will mark Graham's first home appearance since his trip to London, where he lost a ten-round decision to Eddie Thomas.

Following the matinee withdrawal of two riders, only ten of the original fourteen teams were left in competition last night as the six-day bicycle race at the Twenty-second Engineers Armory headed into its fast and furious final forty-eight hours before some 5,000 spectators.
ALBANY, March 3 -- The 1949 Legislature has established a record for the number of bills introduced at any one session, a tabulation by Legislative clerks showed today.

The season's first performance of Leonide Massine's "Rouge et Noir" with Alicia Markova in the central role was the feature of last night's program by the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo at the City Center.

SINCLAIR LEWIS, who has been writing novels for thirty-five years, has now written his twenty-first, "The God-Seeker."* It isn't a very good novel, not nearly so good as the half a dozen fine ones which made their author the most celebrated American novelist of his generation. But in one important respect it is much better than its two immediate predecessors, "Cass Timberlane" and "Kingsblood Royal."

The six winners of the Overseas Press Club of America's awards for outstanding correspondence in 1948 will receive their prizes at the tenth anniversary dinner of the club tonight at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

PITTSBURGH, March 3 -- Business in the Pittsburgh district last week declined about 2 per cent to the lowest level since mid-July, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh. The bureau's seasonally adjusted index was 184.5 per cent of the 1935-39 average last week.

LAKE SUCCESS, March 4 -- The ouster of Soviet Foreign Minister Molotov came as a surprise here, but some sources expressed the view tonight that Premier Stalin was probably dissatisfied with Mr. Molotov's tactics in the "cold war" with the Western powers.
Pyramid clubs are, in essence, lotteries and are therefore illegal, State Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein declared yesterday in response to a query from THE NEW YORK TIMES.

WHEN we discovered that the T. S. Eliot review we wrote for last Thursday's paper had been feloniously pinned on our co-editor, Orville Prescott, we immediately sent OP a telegram of condolences and then looked into an important new book, Sigmund Freud's "An Outline of Psychoanalysis,"* for an explanation of such nefarious shenanigans.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 4 (UP) -- Pete Cooper, a home-grown Floridian, and Johnny Palmer from North Carolina, shot into the lead at the halfway point of the St. Petersburg open golf tourney today.

The advertising industry honored one of its top veteran leaders last night, and heard one of its youngest urge a plan of action to give advertising $100,000,000 worth of "better know-how" in the new era of full competition.
WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP) -- The American Legion Rehabilitation Commission unanimously recommended today "immediate and complete" restoration of the veterans hospital construction program.
LONDON, March 4 -- Although the stock market here today had a steadier appearance after the opening, the almost complete absence of buyers made itself felt and prices started to advance a little.
New York's radios, girls and subways have captivated the crew of the Argentine cruiser Almirante Brown, here on a thirteen-day good-will cruise.
ALBANY, N. Y., March 4 (AP) -- The State Commerce Department reported today the following conditions at New York ski centers:

CHAPEL HILL, N. C., March 4 -- Plans for the formal organization and development of a Southeastern theatre conference were made today at the University of North Carolina by delegates from college drama departments and little theatre groups of ten Southeastern States.

Ogden Phipps of Roslyn, L. I., will defend his national amateur court tennis championship against the player he defeated in the final a year ago, Alastair B. Martin of Glen Head. They will meet for the title at 1:30 today at the Racquet and Tennis Club.

Isaac Don Levine, writer and editor of the magazine Plain Talk, said last night that the ousting of V. M. Molotov as Soviet Foreign Minister "portends a tactical approach towards a new effort to bamboozle the West."

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- Lieut. Gen. Robert L. Eichelberger, retired, has been named a part-time civilian consultant to the Army on Japanese occupation policies, Kenneth C. Royall, Secretary of the Army, announced today.

The nine vestrymen of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Holy Trinity, Brooklyn, who had sought removal of the Rev. Dr. John Howard Melish as rector and his son, William, as associate rector, protested last night as "illegal" a counter meeting of parish members called for next Monday night.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- Ugo Carusi, chairman of the Displaced Persons Commission, today told a House Judiciary subcommtitee considering changes in the DP Act that there were "many, many simpler ways" of settling displaced persons here "than the one we are struggling with."

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- Members of the uneasy Northern Democratic-Republican coalition for a stronger Senate anti-filibuster rule fell to bitter quarreling among themselves today in an atmosphere of declining hope for their cause.

LONDON, March 4 -- The Bulgarian Legation here dismissed tonight as an "absurd fallacy" a recent allegation by the British Council of Churches that the Bulgarian Government and Communist party had issued secret orders for the persecution of Protestants in Bulgaria.

A formidable array of celebrated stage performers will be on hand for the second annual "ANTA Album," the entertainment comprising great moments in the theatre, which will be given for a single performance tomorrow evening at the Ziegfeld Theatre.

The annual "Battle of the Bronx" between New York University and Fordham at the Sixty-Ninth Regiment Armory and Columbia's effort to keep in the running for the Eastern Intercollegiate League title with a victory over Pennsylvania at the Palestra in Philadelphia will command the chief attention of metropolitan college basketball fans today. Both are afternoon games.

CHICAGO, March 4 -- Grains staged a strong rally on the Board of Trade today after breaking early, and final trades were at the top, with wheat unchanged to 3/4 cent a bushel higher. Corn rose 1/8 to 7/8 cent; oats were unchanged to cent up; rye, unchanged, and soybeans, 1/2 cent lower to 1/4 cent higher.

PARIS, March 4 -- The French National Assembly today refused to remove parliamentary immunity from Marcel Cachin, Communist leader. The request that it do so was not connected with the Communist press campaign to the effect that the French should not fight if a Soviet Army entered their country.

With vast new funds in prospect, the city must plan expansion of its low-rent public housing facilities on a scale never before contemplated, Gen. Thomas F. Farrell, chairman of the New York City Housing Authority, declared last night.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, March 4 -- A new list of prohibited imports was published in the Government Gazette today. Checking the list in several stores, this correspondent found it applicable to most American goods at every counter.

TEL AVIV, Israel, March 4 -- A protest has been sent to Dr. Bunche at Rhodes against alleged continued violations of the truce by Arab bands originating in the Arab triangle -- the Nablus-Jenin-Tulkarm area on the central front -- it was disclosed tonight by Foreign Minister Moshe Shertok.

American business is gaining broader public representation and is developing a practical remedy for false economic prejudices by two-way cooperation of educational groups, business leaders and educators revealed yesterday. They addressed the national Business-Education Conference of the Committee for Economic Development at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Paddy De Marco's aggressiveness and body-punching ability enabled him to score an upset victory over Billy Graham, clever welter-weight from the East Side, in the star bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden last night.

Two private contractors held conferences yesterday with John A. Peterson, Acting City Manager of Yonkers, and proposed that they be hired to collect the city's five-day accumulation of garbage and refuse.
The United States Air Force has done an about-face on some phases of its strategic and tactical thinking as a result of flying tests made recently at Eglin Air Force Base, Fla.
CHARLESTON, S. C., March 4 (UP) -- The Navy revealed today that a high official of the Charleston shipyard had taken two capsules of radium from the base here and had suffered burns as a consequence.

NANKING, March 4 -- The Nationalist Legislative Yuan, meeting in Nanking despite the shift of the Government to Canton, lined up solidly behind Acting President Li Tsung-jen today and took Premier Sun Fo's Cabinet to task for not having carried out General Li's "liberalization program."

ALBANY, March 4 -- Willard W. Hampton, assistant vice president of the New York Telephone Company, declared today that savings of more than $11,000,000 a year have been realized from services performed for the New York Telephone Company by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

The Temporary State Rent Commission's criticism of the City Rent Commission was denounced yesterday by Benjamin Bogart, executive secretary of the Associated Hotel and Residence Clubs, Inc., an association of medium and small hotels here.

Antiques ranging from rare colonial furnishings to an early automobile and the first television set are being installed this morning at Madison Square Garden in preparation for the opening on Monday at 1 P. M. of the fifth annual National Antiques Show.

Manufacturers and retailers will have their first opportunity in the history of the home furnishings industry to discuss mutual efforts to increase volume at two meetings to be held in Chicago on July 7 and 8. This was announced at a press conference yesterday by Alexander Lewi, chairman of the National Retail Dry Goods Association's home furnishing and appliance group, which is sponsoring the meeting.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed 2 points higher to 10 points lower yesterday under a small volume of business.

LAKE SUCCESS, March 4 -- A request by the Latin American labor leader, Vicente Lombardo Toledano, that the World Federation of Trades Unions be permitted to participate in United Nations debates on proposed labor investigation resolutions was voted down today by a committee of the Economic and Social Council.

The first volume of a series about famous police forces at work has been scheduled for July publication by Putnam. It will be "Secrets of the Surete," the memoirs of Commissioner Jean Belin of France. The book will contain stories of famous French crimes of the last thirty years and of the author's work with the French underground in World War II.

LACONIA, N. H., March 4 -- America's counterpart of Norways famous Holmenkollen classic is slated to be held in the $1,000,000 Belknap Mountain Recreation Center in near-by Gilford tomorrow and Sunday.

LAKE SUCCESS, March 4 -- Israel's application for membership in the United Nations was approved by the Security Council today by a vote of 9 to 1, with Egypt opposed and Britain abstaining. The application must now be accepted by the General Assembly, which convenes at Flushing Meadow on April 5, but it is generally agreed that Israel will become the fifty-ninth member of the United Nations during the Assembly session.

WASHINGTON, March 4 (UP) -- The House Rules Committee today cleared four key defense bills for speedy House action, including a super-secret measure legalizing the work of the Central Intelligence Agency, the nation's top espionage organization.

Sweden will soon be able to provide adequate housing and recreational facilities for her merchant seamen here by the reconversion of six four-story buildings in Brooklyn, Lennart Nylander, Swedish Consul General in New York, said yesterday.
Federal Judge Harold R. Medina rejected the defense challenge to the jury in the trial of the eleven Communists yesterday and denied motions to void the indictment and quash the trial-jury panel.

ATHENS, March 4 -- The plight of nearly 700,000 persons, or almost a tenth of Greece's population, forced to flee their homes on account of the Communist-led guerrilla terror is the concern of a strongly worded memorandum to the Secretary General of the United Nations released here today.

The Maytag Company, producer of washing machines and other home appliances, last year had the most successful period in its fifty-six-year history, according to the annual report released for publication today by Fred Maytag 2d, president.

WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP) -- The first route in All American Airways' recently authorized short-hop regional service over 2,000 miles in seven states and the District of Columbia will start operation Monday morning.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- The Institute of Inter-American Studies today reported that "the United States has expanded its purchase of Latin-American goods to provide the greatest volume of dollar-purchasing power ever enjoyed by Latin America."

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- Describing I. G. Chemie, a Swiss company, as a former "cloak or dummy" for the giant German corporation, I. G. Farben, Attorney General Tom C. Clark reiterated today the Government's demand for a $100,000,000 interest in the General Aniline and Film Corporation, to which the Swiss concern asserts ownership.

WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP) -- Testimony in the six-week-old "Axis Sally" treason trial ended today. The final witness was Johannes Schmidt-Hansen, a former German radio official, who was on the stand only brief.
WASHINGTON, March 4 -- The Senate Labor and Public Welfare Committee voted today to report to the Senate the Administration's labor bill without any changes.

The United States Court of Appeals reversed yesterday a Federal Court decision levying a $20,000 contempt-of-court fine against the Department Store Employes Union, independent, for allegedly disobeying an injunction forbidding strike action against Oppenheim Collins Co.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, March 4 -- Dimiter Georgiev, chief prosecutor of Bulgaria, demanded today the death penalty for the four principal defendants in the trial of fifteen Protestant ministers. Mr. Georgiev was followed by his deputy prosecutor, Todor Tsakov, who demanded the heaviest prison sentences for the eleven other defendants.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- A plea for fair play for the Arabs was made by Sheikh Asad AlFaqih in presenting his letters of credence today to President Truman as Ambassador of Saudi Arabia. He has been Minister here for the past three years but has now had his mission raised to the status of an embassy.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 4 -- The review hearing on the ouster of Dr. Miriam Van Waters as superintendent of the Massachusetts Women's Reformatory at Framingham ended today on a note of bitterness following summation by both sides.
BERLIN, March 4 -- The dismissal of Vyacheslav M. Molotov as Foreign Minister of the Soviet Union and his replacement by Andrei Y. Vishinsky is basically the admission of the failure of a policy.

FORT MEADE, Md., March 4 (AP) -- Col. Harold H. McClune was acquitted by a general court-martial today on charges of neglecting and mistreating prisoners in an Army disciplinary barracks at Wurzburg, Germany.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, March 4 -- Bauxite and oil, rather than the great locks of the Panama Canal, are today the dominant factors in Caribbean strategic concepts, a brief survey of Caribbean defense problems indicates.

The Public Service Commission indicated yesterday in a three-to-one opinion that it would approve acquisition of the Long Island Lighting Company by the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc. Its sanction, however, depends upon completion of certain steps that cannot be taken until the Securities and Exchange Commission announces its decision on the PSC-approved plan for consolidation of the three companies that comprise the Long Island Lighting system.

Assurances were given yesterday by Dr. Marcus D. Kogel, Commissioner of Hospitals, that Sydenham Hospital would continue to provide facilities for semi-private and private beds. The statement was made, he said, to put at rest rumors that the city would back down on its promises to maintain the best features of the inter-racial private hospital.
WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP) -- Infantile paralysis totals for January and February of this year hit new highs for those two months, the Public Health Service said today.

In the passing of Dr. James Rowland Angell American education has lost a good friend. For many years, as President of Yale University and later as educational consultant of the National Broadcasting Company, he held a position of leadership in the intellectual life of this country.

In its first action, the special committee set up to recommend a program for the joint carrier-shipper-underwriter campaign to improve export packaging standards has approved sending of questionnaires to foreign buyers and individual shippers and consignees, it was announced yesterday.

American exports this year are likely to run close to those of 1948, "without any significant decline," it was stated yesterday by Francis McIntyre, assistant director of the Office of International Trade.

TENAFLY, N. J., March 4 -- Nine years of experimenting with flower growing as a hobby have taught Mrs. Herbert E. Carnes, who is also a bird bander of note, how to have flowers blooming in her outdoor garden at her home at 25 Kenwood road here all through the winds.

LAKE SUCCESS, March 4 -- With the Slav bloc nations abstaining, the United Nations Economic and Social Council gave full approval today to a United States resolution calling upon Secretary General Trygve Lie to draft an international program of long-range economic aid for the backward regions of the world.
The Public Service Commission announced yesterday that the Staten Island Edison Corporation would be permitted to increase its rates for electric service in the Borough of Richmond.

Borrowing by railroads to finance purchases of rolling stock continues to figure largely in the calendar of new issues of securities. The Southern Railway will offer $11,850,000 of equipment-trust certificates on next Wednesday. Other railroad equipment borrowing consists of an offering of $2,550,000 by the Missouri-Kansas-Texas on Tuesday and one of $3,165,000 by the Wabash on Thursday.

Once 4,000 Jews from Yemen were wandering around the streets of Aden. They were weary, hungry and homeless. One day a plump woman with gray hair began putting them on a magic carpet. Now they all have landed in Israel and are living there happily.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- The armed services have asked for an area off the east coast of Florida in the vicinity of Banana River for secret air research. No details were released, but an Air Force official said the three services "plan a research program requiring aerial activity."
GENEVA, March 4 -- Why some of the world is still somewhat confused about President Truman's "point four" economic development program was illustrated here today in two international gatherings.

LONDON, March 4 (UP) -- Rumanian officials, in carrying out their latest land expropriation, aroused some farm families at 3 A. M. and ordered them off their property with nothing more than they could carry, official British reports from Bucharest said today.

Activity and weakness featured trading in cottonseed oil futures on the New York Produce Exchange yesterday. Prices declined 25 to 41 points on weakness in cash oils in the South, and early weakness in allied Western markets.
EL PASO, Tex., March 4 (AP) -Steady improvement was reported late today in the condition of Ben Hogan.

Little, oddly shaped rooms in old country houses usually call for wallpapers with a trompe-l'oeil effect -- tiny, closely spaced patterns that seem to smooth over surface irregularities and create an illusion of unity and space. Half a dozen such designs have just been added to the collection of machine - printed papers at Katzenbach Warren, where they are available through decorators.
LONDON, March 4 (AP) -- Players of England's eighty-eight major soccer league clubs threatened today to go on strike.

The Federal Court Press Association, an informal group composed of reporters from many of the New York City newspapers who are assigned to the United States Court House on Foley Square, has lost a large part of its membership in the last several days, it was learned yesterday.

Commuters whose tickets were about to expire lined up yesterday at Long Island Rail Road stations to buy the last monthly tickets available before rates go up at midnight tonight. Clerks at Pennsylvania Station were selling the old-style sixty-trip monthly tickets at the old rates.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 4 -- Paramount's recently concluded arrangement with Mack Sennett to produce a screen version of his life includes the acquisition of Gene Fowler's biography of the producer of silent-film comedies, "Father Goose," it was learned today.
LAKE PLACID, March 4 -- Lyndon Institute of Lyndonville, Vt., took a slim lead at the halfway mark in the four-event United States eastern interscholastic ski tournament today.

The Metropolitan Opera Guild's campaign to raise $250,000, not yet three weeks old, has already reached the $100,000 mark, it was announced yesterday. Some 7,050 opera-lovers have responded to the plea for public assistance, and the guild itself has contributed $25,000.

VIENNA, March 4 -- full-page letter from the Central Committee of Czechoslovakia's Communist party to members, published in the party organ, Rude Pravo, today, announced that the admission of new members to the party had been halted "in order to devote all efforts to raising the ideological level of present members."

ONEIDA, N. Y., March 4 -- Oneida, Ltd., silverware manufacturer, declared a profit bonus of $535,000, payable this week, and Miles E. Robertson, general manager, said the business continued good as the fiscal year began. The company's business year closed on Jan. 31.
CHAMPAIGN, Ill., March 4 (AP) -Wisconsin's Don Gehrmann, billed for stardom in the Big Nine indoor track meet, tonight breezed through the 880-yard run in 1:59.7.
A FRESH,. though not entirely unexpected outrage by Mussolini, with baffling problems and far-reaching consequences to all our harassed affairs, now broke upon the Mediterranean scene.

A follower of this department's cogitations has sent in a note written, he says, in the interest of improving the quality of casual, everyday conversation. The writer would like to see every man paste upon his shaving mirror Voltaire's observation that "the secret of being tiresome is in telling everything."

As Foreign Minister for the U.S.S.R. in the last several years, Vyacheslav M. Molotov has been one of the leaders in the Russian battle against the success of the Marshall Plan. He appears to have lost both his fight and his job.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- Louis A. Johnson, named yesterday to succeed James Forrestal as Secretary of Defense, declared today that his objective would be to build a strong National Military Establishment because "there will be no peace without strength in America."
NORWALK, Conn., March 4 -- The Board of Education today faced the possibility of having two superintendents of schools to fill one vacancy when the school term opens in the fall.

BUENOS AIRES, March 4 -- Argentina's two independent newspapers, the Nacion and the Prensa, reappeared today after a twenty-four-day printers' strike, but now face a new Government cut from sixteen to twelve pages. Prior to the Government's decree of Oct. 8, both papers averaged better than thirty pages.

Frank Glaser, pianist, who played last night in Carnegie Hall, proved his thoughtfulness and taste, not only by his performances but also by his unconventional program. It contained, regardless of expediency or exterior effect, pieces that he liked to play.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- Seizures of cocaine and heroin last year were on a scale "unknown since before" World War II, Commissioner of Narcotics Harry J. Anslinger and Acting Commissioner of Customs Frank Dow reported to Secretary Snyder of the Treasury Department today. Captures of marijuana showed a high increase.

Congressional disputes over new labor legislation may engender an excessively gloomy view of the current state of labor-management relations in this country. Two luncheons held in the same midtown hotel this week offer a pleasant antidote to such pessimism.
KIRKENES, Norway, March. 4 (AP) -- Communist agitators are spreading fear among the scattered Norwegians who live in Arctic isolation near the Soviet border.
RHODES, March 4 (AP) -- Israel and Transjordan began armistice talks today in a chilly atmosphere that precluded even the formal introduction of the members of the two delegations to each other.

ALBANY, March 4 -- An amendment to the State University Law to permit the Fashion Institute of Technology and Design in New York City to become a community college under the new State University was offered in the Legislature today.

VERO BEACH, Fla., March 4 -- If there is an owner or manager in the National League who wants a catcher he can make a deal with Branch Rickey at any moment, provided, of course, the Mahatma of the Dodgers gets what he regards as value received.

TOKYO, March 4 -- The Allied Occupation authorities have demanded a big slash in Japan's record national budget of 578,000,000,000 yen, it was indicated today. As a result the Cabinet of Premier Shigeru Yoshida decided late in the day to postpone for ten days the scheduled opening of the new Parliament session while it drastically revised the financial bills for the fiscal year 1949-50.

An interesting addition to the Western Hemisphere's magazine field has made its bow. Volume 1, Number 1 of "Americas," an official publication of the Pan American Union (which since the Bogota Conference has become the General Secretariat of the Organization of American States), makes a good start in the effort to explain the work of the Inter-American organization and to introduce us to each other.

Michigan authorities temporarily stayed efforts by this state for the speedy surrender for trial here on charges of murder of two confessed lonely hearts killers yesterday, as they set a hearing for next Tuesday on New York's request for extradition.
HOBOKEN, N. J., March 4 (AP) -- Square-jawed C. K. Randolph Clausen, 80-year-old hero of the Spanish-American War, doesn't want to retire.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- The apointment of Andrei Y. Vishinsky as Soviet Foreign Minister and the removal of Vyacheslav M. Molotov from that post are considered here to mean a change of tactics but not of objectives in Russian foreign policy.

LONDON, March 4 -- The House of Commons today approved on second reading a measure to tighten up the century-old law against cock fighting. Sir William Darling declared the sport still flourishes in some parts of England and quoted an old tavern ditty which he said still is sung in some lustier pubs:

Minors who deliver beer or ale for a grocery store are not violating the Alcoholic Beverage Control Law, Magistrate Morris Ploscowe held yesterday in an eight-page decision in Bronx Magistrates Court.

Five American members of the Roman Catholic hierarchy and twelve prelates and priests of the staff of the Catholic University of America, Washington, have contributed to a symposium on Pope Pius XII in the March issue of the American Ecclesiastical Review, a monthly periodical published by the university.

LONDON, March 4 -- The Moscow radio announced tonight that Vyacheslav M. Molotov had been relieved of his duties as Foreign Minister of the Soviet Union and replaced by Andrei Y. Vishinsky, a Deputy Foreign Minister.

BANGKOK, Siam, March 4 -- Four former government leaders were slain today while in police custody. The four, who had been arrested in the investigation of last week end's abortive uprising, were shot while attempting to escape, police said.

JERSEY CITY, N. J., March 4 -- The strike of longshoremen at the American Export Lines terminal here, which was settled on a trial basis last night after conferences with Mayor Frank H. Eggers, flared up again this morning as some 300 men walked off the piers after one hour's work.

A hold-up man raided a haberdashery store within shouting distance of the West Fifty-fourth Street Police Station at 7:30 o'clock last night and was caught a few minutes afterward by a rookie patrolman who was en route to the station house to report for duty.

PARIS, March 4 -- A memorandum that was described as a defense of permanent economic controls and as designed to induce continental nations to align their economies with Britain's was submitted by Chancellor of the Exchequer Sir Stafford Cripps today to the new steering committee of men of Cabinet rank named to "advise" the European Marshall Plan Council.
Representative Jacob K. Javits, New York Republican, told delegates from the theatre, opera and ballet world yesterday that their major hope of gaining governmental aid depended upon themselves.
Seven passenger liners, carrying 3,081 persons, moved in or out of New York yesterday on one of the busiest days of the winter "off" season.

BUFFALO, N. Y., March 4 (AP) -- The board of directors of the Bell Aircraft Corporation said today it will ask the Securities and Exchange Commission to approve a stock deal which would give Bell ontrol of two other manufacturing concerns.

A few days ago we printed a letter from the New York correspondent of the Paris Franc-Tireur in answer to an article by Edmund Demaitre in our issue of Feb. 13. The Franc-Tireur correspondent defended herself against an alleged "inaccurate quotation" from her articles in that newspaper.
Rain or shine, the umbrella or parasol has an important place as a fashion accessory in a woman's wardrobe this year, according to designers and shops.

In Paris last Dec. 11 fifty-five nations approved and twenty nations signed the newly completed convention on genocide. For the first time in history nations demanded that it be written into international law that the crime of genocide -- the killing of national, ethnic, religious groups; or the inflicting on them of conditions calculated to lead to their annihilation or their children's destruction, in peace or war -- was a crime against civilization, and punishable.

CHICAGO, March 4 -- Court-appointed trustees for the now officially bankrupt Tucker Corporation visited the vast plant today, examined available records, and decided that the company's cash on hand will last about two weeks if the current payroll is maintained.

Considerable progress in the negotiation of the North Atlantic pact was indicated last night by Wilhelm Munthe Morgenstierne, Ambassador of Norway, when he opened an address with the remark, "we are almost allies once again."

Track and field's headline performers will hold their last Madison Square Garden rendezvous of the winter tonight in the thirtieth annual indoor games of the New York Chapter, Knights of Columbus. Grouping of the season's big winners in the featured events promises the swiftest racing and most stirring competition of the indoor season.
Inspectors of the Health Department's drug division have been ordered to report any instances of false or misleading advertising over television, it was learned yesterday.

A few of the new fabrics from several low-priced collections designed for spring decorating have begun to appear in New York stores. As forerunners, they indicate some of the colors and types of patterns to be in abundance in a month or so.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- The Economic Cooperation Administration was asked by the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today to acquaint it with the types of recovery projects on which the agency proposes to spend $5,580,000,000 to carry the Marshall Plan through its second year.

LOS ANGELES, March 4 -- The Pacific Western Oil Corporation has obtained an oil concession covering the Saudi-Arabian half-interest in a 2,200-square-mile neutral zone on the Persian Gulf, J. Paul Getty, president, announced today.
WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP) -- A bill to permit Federal Savings and Loan Associations to convert into state-chartered mutual savings banks was introduced today by Senator Frear, Democrat, of Delaware.
WASHINGTON, March -- The Office of Education today issued a guide on the teaching of atomic energy in the public schools as a supplement to its magazine School Life.
WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP) -- Trans-Caribbean Airlines asked the Civil Aeronautics Board today to set rates for coach-type service between New York City and San Juan, Puerto Rico.
While there is much to commend in your Feb. 19 editorial "Unemployment insurance," two aspects of the present budget crisis in the employment security program need more attention.

CLEVELAND, March 4 -- Frank Morrow, who has been in the securities business here since 1919, is advertising his wares in the labor press. He says he believes more investment dealers should do the same to stir up the sale of sound, good-yield stocks.

The United States is losing the propaganda war between democracy and totalitarianism, and the world is turning anti-American, Leon M. Birkhead, national director of Friends of Democracy, told 200 teachers attending the twenty-third annual conference of the Secondary Education Board yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- House opponents of the pension bill for veterans of both World Wars told the Rules Committee today that the $109,000,000,000 estimate of its over-all cost, announced by its sponsor, Representative John E. Rankin, Democrat, of Mississippi, was far short of what it should be.

W. R. Grace Co. of New York, old international trading and shipping concern, has completed negotiations to acquire about 174,000 shares of the capital stock of National Airlines, it was announced yesterday.

FRANKFORT, Germany, March 4 -- Lawrence A. Wilkinson, economic adviser to Gen. Lucius D. Clay, said today that an investigation of the International Trade Products Corporation of Switzerland in Germany had indicated that the company's contract with the Robert Bosch concern of Stuttgart - did not constitute a cartel arrangement.

One of the most interesting wildlife surveys conducted in recent years is now under way in Havana, Ill., which already has revealed some astounding facts on the losses in waterfowl due to lead poisoning.
"Moonrise," a Republic production of the Theodore Strauss novel, directed by Frank Borzage and starring Dane Clark, Gail Russell and Ethel Barrymore, begins an engagement this morning at the Globe.
ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., March 4 (AP) -- The E. and B. Beer five of Detroit tonight fell 12 pins short of taking the lead in the team standings of the American Bowling Congress tournament.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- Reports of persecution of Jews in Czechoslovakia were firmly denied here today by two high-ranking members of Czech officialdom who stated that they themselves and many leading members of their Government were Jews.

Denials that physical violence or third-degree methods had been used on the twelve German prisoners condemned to death in the controversial Malmedy trials came yesterday from two prosecution investigators.
OSLO, Norway, March 4 (UP) -- Following is the text of the Norwegian note rejecting a Soviet offer of a nonaggression treaty:

SAN FRANCISCO, March 4 -- Consent decrees, providing a total of $390,000 for the heirs of eighteen merchant seamen killed in the Port Chicago explosion in 1944, were approved by the Federal District Court here today.
Rochester, N. Y., announced yesterday that it would receive bids on March 10 on an issue of $500,000 of tax-anticipation notes dated March 16, 1949, and due March 16, 1950.

Taking cognizance of the decline in rayon textile sales, the American Viscose Corporation has cut back production of viscose filament yarn by an aggregate of 12 per cent, it was learned yesterday. Viscose output has been curtailed in four plants according to company officials, and acetate production in one plant.

Advertising in the eight major metropolitan newspapers during February totaled 10,982,878 lines, a decline of 3.01 per cent under the like period of last year, an analysis of Media Records showed yesterday. Automotive gained 27.61 per cent, financial was down 10.69 per cent; classified, 7.92 per cent; retail, 3.54 per cent, and general, 1.31 per cent.

The proposed Economic Stability Act of 1949 now pending in Congress was endorsed as an aid to foreign policy and to national defense, but criticized for inadequate aids to small business, in a resolution adopted unanimously yesterday by delegates to the annual meeting of the Association of Steel Distributors, Inc., at the St. Moritz Hotel.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- Norway joined the North Atlantic defense pact negotiations for the first time today, as word was received from Copenhagen that the Danish Foreign Minister would fly here next Tuesday to decide his country's final attitude toward signing the security alliance.

The Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service moved yesterday to forestall a threatened strike by 1,800 bakery drivers in New Jersey by calling representatives of management and the union to a meeting here.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- The State Department announced today that the United States would not appoint a representative to the American Committee on Dependent Territories, which will meet at Havana on March 15 to consider measures for inducing European countries to relinquish their colonies or other dependent territories in the Western hemisphere.

Lumber production for the week ended Feb. 26 was 7 per cent over the preceding week but was 18.2 per cent below the like week last year according to reports wired yesterday to THE NEW YORK TIMES by trade associations. Shipments were down 19.7 per cent and orders 18.5 per cent.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- President Truman's proposal to put the Federal Government back into the general relief picture appeared today to be headed for a pigeonhole in the House Ways and Means Committee.

Retail sales declined during the week, according to estimates made here yesterday. Department store sales were believed to be about 9 per cent below the corresponding week last year. Sales last week were 1 per cent below last year. Snow during the early part of the week and comparison with earlier Easter sales last year are blamed for the decline.

LONDON, March 4 -- The Big Four Foreign Ministers' deputies agreed today to recall Yugoslav representatives again for a further discussion of the Yugoslav claims on Austria. These claims have blocked all efforts to write an Austrian peace treaty during the past month.

HALLANDALE, Fla., March 4 -- Gulfstream Park, the handsome horse-racing establishment about fifteen miles north of Miami and little more than a Widener chute run from the ocean, opened its 40day meeting today with weather clear, track fast and Jockey Al Schmidl red-hot.

BOSTON, March 4 (AP) -- Ski conditions for the New England area were reported today. The forecasts were: Maine, partly cloudy Saturday with a little light snow in north portion and thawing in south portion; fair and somewhat colder Sunday.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- The Department of Commerce today suspended for two months all export license privileges of the Traders Syndicate, Inc., of 97 Warren Street, New York, and its officers. These officers were named as Emile V. Netter, president; Henry H. Mitchell, vice president, and Ruth Netter, secretary.

A time-saving system of expressways and one-way streets would eliminate forty-eight of fifty-eight traffic-light controls on the route from the Air Terminal at Forty- second Street and Park Avenue to the New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, according to a survey released yesterday by the American Road Builders Association.

The report of the Coca-Cola Company and its consolidated subsidiaries for 1948, made public yesterday, shows a net profit of $33,794,170, after provision for taxes, class A dividends and all charges. This is equivalent to $8.22 a share on 4,113,665 shares of common stock.
BERLIN, March 4 (AP) -- The Soviet Repatriation Mission quit the United States zone of Germany tonight after a motor trip reminiscent of the pioneer days of the automobile.
ROME, March 4 -- The directorate of the right-wing Socialist party, which forms a part of the Government coalition, declared itself opposed today to Italy's entry into the Atlantic pact.
Cardinal Spellman, Roman Catholic Archbishop of New York, continued yesterday to supervise the digging of graves in Calvary Cemetery, Queens, while striking gravediggers took two conciliatory steps.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- President Truman refused today to set up a permanent office of civil defense, rejecting a recommendation by the Office of Civil Defense Planning set up by James Forrestal, Secretary of Defense.

WASHINGTON, March 4 (UP) -- The American Legion's National Rehabilitation Conference today voted to assess each member 25 cents a year to help finance a campaign against health insurance plans, including one proposed by the American Medical Association.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- Average primary market prices advanced 0.2 per cent in the week ended on last Tuesday, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The index reached 158.8 per cent of the 1926 average, the same level as four weeks ago and 1.6 per cent less than that of the comparable week in 1948.

BERLIN, March 4 -- Irregularities in the treatment of the accused, including physical force and threats that if they did not talk their relatives would lose their ration cards, are charged in the report of the Administration of Justice Review Board in the Malmedy case.

By a two-to-one verdict in the paternity part of Special Sessions, Ferruccio Tagliavini, Metropolitan Opera singer, was adjudged yesterday the father of a sixteen-month-old girl born to Mary Phillips, a concert singer.

An hour-long television program featuring the Fred Waring orchestra, glee club and soloists, under the sponsorship of the General Electric Company, will go into the 9-to-10 period on Sunday night and will be seen and heard over the full network of the Columbia Broadcasting System.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- President Truman in a message to Congress today asked for legislation authorizing the appointment of additional Assistant Secretaries of State in order to carry out the reorganization of the State Department as recommended by the Hoover Commission.
