LONDON, March 4 -- The news of Mr. Molotov's departure came as a complete surprise to the British Foreign Office. An official said the British Government had received no preliminary indication of the change and, in the absence of any information, could not offer any comment.

Despite a creeping recovery in the last hour, the stock market failed yesterday to make a decisive move. Gains and losses were fairly evenly divided, and price changes in excess of a point were reserved for a few issues. The composite rate declined 0.16 point on the day.
WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP) -- The text of President Truman's message to Congress on changes in the Department of State:

BERLIN, March 4 -- There are three ways of looking at Berlin: from the West, from the East and from under "the bridge" as Berliners call the airlift. They live in the shadow and sound of wings rising and falling with the regular rhythm of a mechanical pulse beat.

Puerto Rico and Cuba are sending that most fragrant of fresh fruit, pineapples. Chile ships north to New York honeydew melons, red grapes, two kinds each of peaches, plums and nectarines. South Africa supplies us with black grapes and also with red plums.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- The number of jobless Americans aggregated 3,200,000 in February, an increase of 550,000 over the January total, the Census Bureau said today. However, the rate of increase was less than in January, when about 700,000 persons were added to the unemployment rolls.
GENEVA, March 4 -- Europe's estimated total coal deficit dropped by one quarter for the second quarter of 1949. The United Nations Economic Commission for Europe announced today.

ROME, March 4 -- The Transport Committee of the Italian Chamber of Deputies, in a report on the recently approved Government bill to subsidize the shipbuilding industry, stated that the Italian merchant marine had been "pulverized" by the war. The term was demonstrably appropriate.
OLIVET, Mich., March 4 -- Seven members of the faculty of Olivet College submitted their resignations today in a fresh rebellion against Dr. Aubrey L. Ashby, president.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- The House Banking Committee completed action today on a bill that strengthened rent controls and extended them to June 30, 1950. The Administration had requested a twenty-four-month extension.
PHOENIX, Ariz., March 4 -- The Giants' pennant hopes almost can be determined by the figures on a convalescent chart.

In the lead all the way, St. John's basketball team ended its season on a triumphant note last night by defeating its borough rival, St. Francis, by 57 -- 43 before 3,000 fans at the Fourteenth Regiment Armory. The victory was the Redmen's twenty-fifth in the thirty-three meetings between these two teams.

Volunteer workers in the Salvation Army's campaign for $1,100,000 to maintain sixty separate services in welfare and relief were urged yesterday at a luncheon in the Park Lane Hotel, 299 Park Avenue, to continue their efforts to complete this goal.

A crowd of 10,000 -- matching the big turnout on opening night -was treated to some spectacular riding last night as the sixty-ninth international bike race went into its final thirty hours at the Twenty-second Engineers Armory.

BERLIN, March 4 -- Prime Minister Attlee returned to Berlin tonight to survey the airlift of the blockaded city forced upon the Western Allies by the Soviet blockade. When last here in 1945, the British leader signed the Potsdam Agreement designed to prevent such discord.

The House Judiciary Committee has approved a bill calling for a sixteen-month moratorium on new anti-trust prosecutions involving the use of basing point pricing systems where such action is "innocent and individual." The purpose of the proposed measure is to reassure business men, pending badly needed clarification of existing court decisions on the subject, that the use of basing point systems is not illegal per se.

As a college professor myself, and one who has always stood for intellectual freedom in teaching and in the arts, I believe that I have both the right and the duty to speak about the so-called "freedom" of Communists to teach in American schools and colleges.

PATERSON, N. J., March 4 -- The little man with the better mousetrap has had a chance to prove it here this week at the inventors' show of the Paterson Chamber of Commerce, which will close tomorrow after a successful engagement.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Mar. 4 -- The modified training routine for Joe DiMaggio got under way today.
An original needlepoint tapestry, hand woven by three Brooklyn schoolgirls, will hang soon in the City Hall of Breukelen, Holland.

Yesterday was commencement day at the city penitentiary on Rikers Island. Five gray-clad inmates, serving terms of ten to twenty months for various crimes, received University of the State of New York high school equivalency diplomas from Warden Milton Klein at brief graduation exercises in the institutional school.
ARCADIA, Calif., March 4 (AP) -- The first three finishers in the $139,100 Santa Anita Handicap last Saturday will meet again tomorrow in the $50,000 added San Juan Capistrano Handicap.

Outlining its promotional and educational program to increase wool consumption, the Wool Bureau, Inc., announced yesterday that it will allocate $500,000 for these activities during the current year. In addition, the bureau will alocate another $50,000 toward an advertising campaign on behalf of men's tropical worsteds if the industry will supply the balance needed for an effective campaign.
WASHINGTON, March 4 (UP) -- Top CIO leaders told President Truman today that they favored his idea of a grass-roots tour on behalf of his legislative program.

GREAT NECK, L.I., March 5 -- -- Residents of this community are being treated to an unusual display -- a large, two-tone blue globe, 7 feet in diameter, that was erected today by the local chapter of the United World Federalists at the railroad station in Great Neck Plaza. Across it in red letters are the words: "World Peace through World Government."

"Behind the Closed Door of the Grand Jury," by Robert G. Whalen, was read with profit, but I must take issue with Mr. Whalen for failing to mention the Women Grand Jury Associations. * * * More women serving is one of our aims.

BARRING political and economic upheavals which, at this moment, are neither foreseen nor foreseeable, this should be the first normal international travel year of the post-war era. It has been twelve years since the world last saw, in 1937, what it had by then come to accept as the normal spring and summer push of American tourists into distant lands.

MR. DELDERFIELD'S awareness that former generation were made up of people much like ourselves is the secret of his historical novel's readability. As he pictures them here, the men in the Napoleonic infantry argued and groused about everything from food to the high command in much the same way as the GI's and the Tommies did in World War II.

VERO BEACH, Fla., March 5 -- What may be the 1949 Dodgers' No. 1 team, or a reasonable facsimile thereof, was piloted to its first victory today by Pee Wee Reese, topping Bruce Edwards' boys, 2 -- 0, in six innings.

MISSOURI VALLEY, Iowa, March 5 (AP) -- Caught in the flood waters of two ice-jammed streams, this Western Iowa town of 4,000 persons tonight was without gas and on a strictly limited drinking water ration.

FOR its third week at the City Center the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo offers as something of a novelty its revival of Michel Fokine's '"Carnaval." The original plan was to have Markova and Dolin dance it, but that is out. Nathalie Krassovaka win be the Columbine, Leon Danielian the Harlequin and Michel Katcharoff the Pantalon. Markova and Dolin will devote themselves to other items in the repertoire.

LONDON, March 5 (AP) -- with a performance that thrilled a crowd of 6,000, Dave Freeman of San Diego and Pasadena, Calif., captured the men's singles today in the English badminton championships. The 28-year-old physician defeated the Malayan champion. Ooi Teik Hock, 15 -- 1, 15 -- 6.

The members of one orchestra helped those of another yesterday afternoon when sixty men from the New York Philharmonic-Symphony donated their services for a concert at Carnegie Hall for the benefit of the Manila Symphony Orchestra, which lost much of its music and many of its instruments during the war.
CHICAGO, March 5 -- Citizens throughout the Central West this week were discussing interracial relations and a movement aimed at imposing income taxes on urban dwellers.

PANAMA -- The two major obstacles to tourist traffic to Central America have been overcome and this corner of the Tropics is ready and eager for the hoped-for resurgence of holiday travel from North America this spring. It is no longer difficult, if not impossible, to obtain hotel accommodations in Central America.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- Senator Scott W. Lucas of Illinois, the majority leader, voiced an overture for a negotiated peace today as the Senate ended the first week of the harsh battle over curbing filibusters.

Ladislas Philip Czettel, artist and designer, was found dead at 8:10 o'clock last night in the bathtub in his apartment at 1022 Park Avenue, with two empty medicine bottles beside him. The police listed the death as an apparent suicide.

A NOVEL of suspense -- no detectives. The revelation of crime is neatly worked out through the mind of Marjorie Carter, a motherly type. Tucked away in a high New York duplex with her adored husband, Charles, and their new baby, she feels a shade too fortunate to be completely happy.

By Tuesday the Long Island Rail Road will have laid off 500 craft workers in one of six shops in Queens and Long Island, a union official declared last night. He said that the carrier, to which higher commutation rates were granted last Tuesday and which then filed a bankruptcy petition, had been dismissing shop employes since Feb. 23.

LONDON, March 5 -- After twenty-four hours of hard thinking and prolonged discussion British official circles now regard the "relief" of Vyacheslav M. Molotov as Soviet Foreign Minister as a distinct promotion for the Soviet statesman and not as has been widely suggested in the British press as a "sacking."
GENEVA, March 5 -- The triumph of world revolution over isolationism is seen by United Nations sources here as the chief significance of the replacement of Mr. Molotov by Mr. Vishinsky

The hardy Swiss team of Walter Diggelman and Hugo Koblet took premiere honors in the six-day bicycle race that came to an end at the Twenty-second Engineers Armory last night. While a crowd of more than 11,000 fans looked on, the Helvetian pedalers made a one-lap lead stand up all through the torrid riding that marked the final phase of the program.

WASHINGTON, March 5 (UP) -- Pan American Airways will establish tourist-class air service to Europe this fall at fares one-third less than present luxury rates if foreign Governments permit, Juan Trippe, president of Pan American, announced here today.

WARSAW, March 5 -- The Polish Government is preparing its population for the early recognition of a government of Eastern Germany and the establishment of closer economic ties with such a state. Before the year is out Eastern Germany may be a member of the Council for Economic Mutual Assistance of the satellite states, Western observers believe.

The first step in the legislative process that should make Hawaii the forty-ninth state this year has been taken with unanimous approval by a subcommittee of the House Public Lands Committee of H.R. 49, the appropriately numbered bill of Delegate Joseph Farrington.

'What about Sophocles and Euripides and Shakespeare and Browning?' [a red-headed girl demands in Frances Noyes Hart's "The Bellamy Trial"]. 'Do you know what "The Ring and the Book" is? It's a murder trial! What's "Othello" but a murder story? What's "Hamlet" but five murder stories? What's "Macbeth"? Or "The Cenci"? Or "Lamia"? Or "Crime and Punishment"? Or "Carmen"? Or . . .'
BOSTON, March 5 -- Nine records were broken and one equaled tonight as Army scored in every event to upset favored Yale in the fifteenth Heptagonal Games at Boston Garden.

PARIS, March 5 -- Political shifts whose import and scope cannot yet be judged are now taking place in the tightly disciplined organization of international communism. Whether they will lead to a critical new phase in global relationships or whether the tension will temporarily be eased is a question upon which the attention of all European capitals is focused this week-end.

MIAMI, Fla., March 5 -- Just before the Kentucky Derby a year ago the hardboots were in a dither of uncertainty. They were pretty sure that Ben Jones would saddle the winner but they didn't know which of his Calumet colts would be wearing the saddle, Citation or Coaltown. The magnificent Citation had turned in a series of superb performances but Coaltown seemed to be much too fast to be true.

Herbert L. Matthews' "Report on Britain's 'Cradle-to- Grave' plan" contains some inaccuracies. Says Mr. Mat thews: "18,000 (general practitioners) agreed voluntarily to join the scheme." It was sheer economic coercion which persuaded the majority of doctors to join.

MINEOLA, L.I, March 5 -- The water level in the so-called "shallow" wells of Nassau County is higher than at any time since the record height of 1939 and has caused a few cesspools in South Shore communities to overflow, county officials reported today.

AMILD surprise and a nasty shock for best-seller-chart scanners this week. After a series of books which won warm ca/t/ca/ applause and sold only a few thousand copies each, Anne Goodwin W/nalow has found a , public at last.

CAIRO, March 5 -- Studies which have been prepared by investigators of the United States Departments of State and Commerce who visited the Middle East recently or are resident here emphasize that the success of the European Recovery Program plus the failure to develop new American outlets for Middle Eastern goods is strangling the market for United States goods in Egypt and other Middle Eastern countries.

WHEN March rolls around in Moscow, Sasha Kovalenko and Sergei Silkin will be 23 years old -- and though launched on separate careers, still close friends and living with their parents in the same apartment house they knew in infancy.

LONDON, March 5 -- With the conclusion of the Atlantic Pact a virtual certainty, some Mediterranean countries are showing anxiety lest Washington and London overlook the importance of their sea in global strategic considerations.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- The Soviet Ambassador, Alexander S. Panyushkin, demanded this afternoon that the United States release Valentin A. Gubitchev, held in New York on espionage charges. The Russian called on the Under-Secretary of State, James E. Webb, and discussed the case with him for nearly an hour.

ONE of the most striking developments in recent American art has been the increasing preoccupation with space organization. There has been a considerable decrease in the number of shows of nonobjective work of the kind concerned primarily with flat surface patterning and a growing tendency to develop both old and new concepts of space perception. Five of the newly opened one-man shows are cases in point.

AN earnest young man, who has done a little research in the history of Minnesota and thinks he might make the bestseller list if he writes a novel full of picturesque frontier characters and a fine, middle-of-the-road, affirmative faith, has produced a reasonably good routine story with some lively incidents, a lot of impossible dialogue, a number of intrusive remarks directed against modern radicals, and a conclusion which is pure corn.

Many New York botanists and horticulturists were wistfully anticipating the first rose of summer yesterday. But Louis P. Politi of the New York Botanical Garden in Bronx Park was busy unpacking some of the 2,000 plant specimens he gathered during a four-month expedition to Cerro Sipapo, a 7,000 foot-high sandstone mountain in the jungles of Venezuela.

It is a common burden, this heavy and mysterious fearfulness, of all human souls. The terrifying ritual ceremonies and loathsome blood sacrifices of primitive religions, whether those of prehistory or of "stagnant" civilizations, of Eskimos, nomads or Polynesians, have their origins in this great fear.

With prices generally at or below last year's levels, the forty-sixth American Toy Fair, the largest ever held, will open tomorrow at the McAlpin and New Yorker Hotels. Showings will also be made at 200 Fifth Ave., 1107 Broadway and the Breslin Hotel.

DUBLIN -- For Americans who intend to visit Ireland this year, the first bit of advice must be that accommodations should be booked well in advance, especially if the trips are planned for the peak months of July, August and September.

On next Thursday, 27,000 taprooms, restaurants, hotels and clubs in the metropolitan area will be ready to serve something their patrons haven't had for seven years -- bock beer. For March 10 is the official opening of the bock beer season.
PHOENIX, March 5 -- The Navajo Indians, whose reservation occupies 25,000 square miles of Arizona, Colorado, New Mexico and Utah, have caught public attention.

The Doehler-Jarvis Corporation, manufacturer of metal castings and hardware specialties in Toledo, Ohio, and other cities, had record sales and income last year, according to the annual report issued yesterday to stockholders by H.H. Doehler, chairman of the board.

FRUSTRATED INVASION Klamath weed, a plant stowaway from Europe and called St.-John's-wort there, makes American cattle which eat it very sick. It was spreading rapidly on Western ranges, overrunning proper forage grass, until the Department of Agriculture took a masterful step to destroy it by importing a kind of Australian beetle whose sole diet it is. Half a million beetles last season in twenty California counties were devouring the Klamath weed patches.

THIS is the season of the year when producers with options on serious plays begin postponing their hopes. Having spent the fall and winter in the futile casting chase, not to mention the business of being sweet to angels, they now are deciding to wait till fall.

TO judge by "The Big Knife," Hollywood has had no visible influence on the literary talents of Clifford Odets. Although his blast at Hollywood misses the target by a considerable margin, it is not the broadside of a hack, and it has a great deal more integrity than "Joy to the World," which was lampooning Hollywood last season.

Stationed on the sixth floor of the New York Stock Exchange Building New York bankers and brokers yesterday competed by RCA radio against the Amsterdam Stock Exchange chess team. In a previous encounter the Dutch experts came out on top.
MOSCOW, March 5 -- The newspaper Soviet Art said today that reactionary "bourgeois tendencies" have been noted in Soviet circuses and that persons responsible for it ought to be exposed.

GLASGOW -- Within the last few years Scotland has come to realize that tourism can be developed into a profitable industry. The war was in part responsible for this awakening. Many American and Dominion troops stationed in the British Isles discovered Scotland's charms while on furlough, and when they returned home after the war they spread the gospel.
WASHINGTON, March 5 (AP) -- Two top-ranking tax experts in the Senate said today that President Truman's demands for a $4,000,000,000 increase in taxes suffered a major setback this week.

THE sharp comeback registered by Florida's east coast resorts in February after a poor early winter season is promising to continue through March, according to reports from Miami Beach. The so-called recovery in the past four weeks has been so strong that business leaders believe now that this winter will set something of a record for tourist occupancy for southeast Florida.

THERE are those among us who have been bewitched by the atomic bomb. Because they see that we now have a weapon of fantastic power, because they know that we are in the forefront of the whole world in the further development of this revolutionary weapon, they have come to believe that the real power of America is to be found in the possession of this incredibly destructive instrument of war.

Joseph A. Barry's article on Sartre ("Sartre Enters 'A New Phase'") has that gentleman surprisingly doubtful as to why an American literary figure cannot function in American politics as a French writer can in French politics.

WASHINGTON, March 5 (AP) -- The House will be in the mood to pass a labor law much "as President Truman wants it," Representative A.B. Kelley, Democrat, of Pennsylvania, a member of the House Labor Committee, predicted today.

Fine English eighteenth century furniture, early American silver and a wide variety of art objects and decorations will be auctioned at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street, on Thursday, Friday and Saturday.

NANKING, March 5 -- The drive to eliminate the remaining influence of Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek, now in "retirement" in Chekiang Province, gathered steam here today as the Nanking newspaper Salvation Daily openly demanded that the Generalissimo "go abroad."

THE Reports of the Council of Economic Advisers deal with two principal matters: (1) the present (or recent) state of the economy, including the outlook for 1949, and (2) the long-run prospects for production. Although purporting to be a review and an analysis, the Reports constitute in large measure a brief in support of policy decisions which the Administration has reached.
VIENNA, March 5 -- Czechoslovaks have been allowed to see some interesting facts as to their economic prospects in planned economy in the current issue of the Prague weekly Hospodas.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 5 -- Casey Stengel cast an appraising eye over forty-three Yankee regulars, rookies and farm hands this afternoon at Huggins Field and expressed satisfaction with the progress of the first week's conditioning for the 1949 American League pennant drive.

PASADENA, Calif., March 5 (UP) -- Development of a new type of camera that enlarges, or blows up, a second of time 1,250 times its former size was disclosed today. The camera is part of the equipment of a water tunnel in which fluids can be sent at the rate of 100 feet per second.

More Satellite Trials Two trials arising out of the struggle between communism and churches in Eastern Europe drew to a close last week. The pattern for each -- one in Sofia, capital of Bulgaria, and the other 390 miles away in Budapest, capital of Hungary -- was practically identical.

MR. ORWELL, in his Feb. 13 review of Evelyn Waugh's "Scott King's Modern Europe," suggests that Mr. Waugh "turn aside to read a sixpenny pamphlet on Marxism." Now, this sounds right; I don't think it is. Mr. Waugh has done well enough.

TOKYO, Feb. 22 -- Plans are now being announced here for the celebration next summer in Nagasaki -- the second city to feel the blast of the atomic bomb -- of the quad ricentennial of St. Francis Xavier's arrival in Japan as the first Christian missionary.

CHAMPAIGN, Ill., March 5 (AP) -- Three records were smashed today in an unprecedented Western Conference indoor track and field meet which produced co-champions -- Wisconsin and Ohio State -- for the first time in history.

Establishment of 198 new settlements in Israel is planned for 1949, Magistrate Morris Rothenberg, president of the Jewish National Fund of America, told delegates to a special conference of the organization at its opening session last night in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Following directly on the heels of the Hoover Commission report on our national security organization, urging the necessary legislation to strengthen civilian control and provide real unification for the three armed forces, a memorandum was directed last week from the Joint Chiefs of Staff to James Forrestal, Secretary of Defense.
Federal mediators continued yesterday efforts to avert a threatened walkout by 1,800 New Jersey bakery drivers that may come today or tomorrow.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., March 5 -- The Johnson Automatics Manufacturing Company of this city, wartime maker of the noted Johnson semi-automatic rifle and light machine gun, will place its manufacturing and office equipment on the auction block next Wednesday.
WASHINGTON, March 5 (AP) -- The capital heard reports today that Secretary of the Army Kenneth C. Royal might step out of his job by mid-April.

Columbia's swimming and fencing teams lost their matches in the last Saturday afternoon of winter sports activity at the University Hall Gym, yesterday, when Cornell crushed the Lion natators, 62 -- 13, and Harvard defeated Columbia's swordsmen, 14 -- 13.

EXETER, N.H., March 5 -Andover defeated Exeter in the thirty-first annual basketball game today largely by the basket shooting of Jim Windsor who totaled 13 points to lead his team to a 61-54 victory.

The Senate Labor and Public Welfare Committee has reported out of committee a bill (S. 247) to establish a national science foundation. The bill is nearly identical with a measure which was passed by the Senate but which died in the House of Representatives in the Eightieth Congress.

The stock market ended the week on a rallying note after erasing part of the earlier gains during yesterday's abbreviated session. Gains of a fraction to a point were scored as traders took a more optimistic view of the foreign situation.

AN outstanding fact in connection with the Metropolitan's revival of Verdi's "Falstaff" under Fritz Reiner's baton is the public response which it has elicited. Never in this city has the Italian master's chief-d'oeuvre aroused such enthusiasm.

ALTHOUGH tried-and-true old favorites probably form the nucleus of most gardens, novelties and other rare and difficult plants can usually be found there, too. These latter add that extra fillip of interest to a garden year that would otherwise be fairly routine and dull.
BERLIN, March 5 -- The United States is discussing with Britain and France changes of restrictions on German industry that would remove all but the most basic security limitations on production.
There were major changes -- and major proposals for change -- last week in the nation's organization for defense.

CHICAGO, March 5 -- Users of International Harvester Company's farm equipment and motor trucks will be able to obtain more new machines this spring than at any time in the last seven years, John McCaffrey, president, said today.

AN enlarging camera to take 16mm movie film frames has been introduced by Federal Manufacturing and Engineering Corporation. The Federal Enlarging Camera for 16mm film features the Select-A-Frame masking device, uses standard No. 127 rollfilm and costs $19.95.

After seeing the pictures of Lassie that accompanied Helen Colton's story ("Top Dog in Hollywood") I now know what movie reviewers have in mind when they complain that screen acting has gone to the dogs in the past quarter-century.

THE riddle of which husband ran off with Addle, the narrator in "A Letter to Three Wives" -- an enigma which has kept movie fans in constant argument since the film's release -- was solved last week by none other than Joseph Mankiewicz, the director and scenarist. Said Mr. Mankiewicz:

PORT ELIZABETH, South Africa, March 5 (Reuters) -- A battle between England's bowlers and Bruce Mitchell South, Africa's opening batsman, marked the first day's play in the fifth and final test cricket match today. At the close South Africa had scored 219 runs for three wickets.

MONT TREMBLANT, Que., March 5 -- In a spectacular performance among a record entry list from the United States, France, and Canada, Colin Stewart, 22-year-old Dartmouth Olympic star, twice today smashed the Kandahar downhill record held by Emile Allais in the fifteenth running of the famed Kandahar classic.

FORT MYERS, Fla. -- The scenery in and around Fort Myers is spectacular now because of the abundance of new construction, for the community has been busy enlarging its facilities for visitors and refurbishing existing establishments.

Fifteen thousand radio-electronics scientists from thirty countries are expected to attend the 1949 convention of the Institute of Radio Engineers, which will open tomorrow morning at the Commodore Hotel and Grand Central Palace and continue four days.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- Developing its strategy issue by issue, the Republican minority of Congress already has put itself in a position where it holds the balance of power on such key issues of President Truman's "fair deal" program as labor, civil rights, housing and taxes.

Since the Federal Government relieved the states of all control in the hunting of migratory birds, principally waterfowl, the battle has been joined between wildfowlers and Federal authorities, with charges and counter charges marking the course of the conflict.

Representatives of this country and great Britain gave assurance yesterday of the success of the economic recovery program for "the free nations of Western Europe" and declared that these nations were winning the "cold war" on the economic front.

THIS collection of essays and biographical sketches calls attention to how substantial has been the achievement of Jews in America. That achievement, as someone once said, has been a "two-way passage," in which Jews have both received and given.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 5 -- The downward trend of retail business activity in the Twelfth District continued unabated during the past week. While reports from larger stores disclosed that San Francisco and Spokane showed gains, all other areas suffered losses compared with the same week a year ago.
FORMOSA, Argentina, March 5 (UP) -- Reports from Asuncion late tonight said a new revolution had started in Paraguay and that the rebels had taken several towns near the capital.

COPENHAGEN -- Touring Denmark means, to the American visitor to live in the friendly atmosphere of a small European country, one of the few kingdoms still existing, but at the same time one of the oldest democracies.
NOT long ago most peculiar news reached me. A violinist-soloist to His Majesty Emperor Haile Selassie of Ethiopia played my violin pieces in Addis Ababa.
VIENNA -- Austria expects the best summer tourist traffic this year since the war ended and is certainly in much better shape to handle it than during any of the last five years.

ARCADIA, Calif., March 5 -- Miss Grillo, distance-running mare from the Argentine, closed her racing career today when she won the $50,000 added San Juan Capistrano Handicap before the largest crowd of the season at Santa Anita Park.

THE Administration was caught in a Janus pose last week on its anti-inflation program. While Mr. Truman continued to press in one direction for stiffer controls, his other face gave the nod to easing of installment credit terms.
THE Long Lines Department of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company last week made known its 1949 construction program for extension of television networks.

The item about Arne Sucksdorff in THE TIMES of Sunday, Feb. 20 has given some people the impression that Sucksdorff received no credit whatever on the Academy Award nominee "Symphony of City" and on "Struggle for Survival." Such is not the case.

The Caravan of East and West Inc., with headquarters at 132 East Sixty-fifth Street, is appealing for dozens, even hundreds of Americans to answer letters being received in its offices daily from persons in Germany.
For the third successive day theological students, led by Cardinal Spellman, Roman Catholic Archbishop of New York, dug graves yesterday in strike-bound Calvary Cemetery in Queens.

MORE than anything, a wee child to cradle in her arms and sing to before the fire was what the Widow wanted. All she had, though, was her goat, a conceited old spalpeen, proud because, as he himself said, "'Tis a great family I belong to -- the O'Donnells.

TUBEROUS begonias, members of the useful greenhouse family, make valuable garden plants which may be grown in part shade -- even under trees if the branches are high. The time is at hand to start them for summer bloom.

WASHINGTON, March 5 (UP) -- The Atomic Energy Commission is considering the construction of a multimillion dollar giant atomic experimental station "somewhere in the Midwest," officials revealed tonight.

SALEM, Ore., March 5 -- A "battle of the century" in the power-short Pacific Northwest, with lobbyists for fishing and conservation interests slugging it out with those for hydro-electric producers, is nearing an end in the Oregon Legislature.

NEW DELHI, India, March 5 -- Answering criticism by labor sympathizers that the Government was trying to disrupt legitimate trade unionism, Prime Minister Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru withdraw in Parliament today a bill to outlaw strikes in essential industries.

Taking cognizance of the fact that business conditions are "spotty" throughout the country, the Federal Reserve Board last week cut credit terms on installment buying. This may help some industries, notably appliance manufacturers, but it brought no spark to the stock market.

FRITZ REINER'S successes with "Salome" and "Falstaff" have created unusual interest in his forthcoming "Parsifal" and the Metropolitan Opera box office has been flooded with requests for tickets. The music-drama will be presented three times. It will be done March 18, during the last week of the regular season, and twice again during Holy Week on Wednesday, April 13 and on Good Friday afternoon, April 15.

Many producers of domestic hand-made household glassware have cut back production between 15 and 20 per cent in the last sixty days because of continuing sharp drops in retail orders, Herman L. Dillingham, secretary of the American Glassware Association, disclosed in an interview last week.
WASHINGTON, March 5 (AP) -- Property owners hit by the recent storms and blizzards in the West can take an income tax deduction for their losses, but not generally on the returns due March 15.
WASHINGTON, March 5 -- The Army is using a new-type telescopic camera mounted on a 90-mm. gun to measure the speed and height of the V-2 rockets fired at White Sands, N.M.

The plight of the homeless street urchins in at least one part of Europe over which the war moved is being lessened. In Italy seven Boys' Towns have been built with the help of American funds. The small village of Pozzuoli, on the Bay of Naples, is the site of the eighth such town now being constructed.
Dr. Ralph Sikes, Health Commissioner of Yonkers, said yesterday that unless garbage collections were resumed by tomorrow, the health of the city's 150,000 residents would be menaced.

Discounting local eccentricities of weather, such as March snowstorms, once spring starts moving north it travels at a fairly regular and predictable pace. The rate is approximately seventeen miles a day. Just for example, if red maples should start opening bud in Washington, D.C., on March 15, which is most unlikely, the same variety of trees could be expected to open bud in Baltimore two days later.

Provision for adequate fuel is vital to both the agricultural and industrial segments of Brazil's economy, John Abbink, chairman of the United States section of the Joint Brazil-United States Technical Commission, said here yesterday.

Two weeks ago the "Wac Corporal," a two-stage rocket consisting of a V-2 a smaller unit, roared into the atmosphere above White Sands, N.M., and broke two records: first, a speed of 5,000 miles an hour was attained; second, a height of 250 miles was reached.

Retail trade here last week again showed losses under the comparative week last year. Department store sales were estimated at about 9 per cent below 1947. Food purchasing showed an increase, with dollar volume of large independent, chain and supermarkets running ahead of last year despite the lower prices.
NASSAU -- One-third of the Bahama Islands visitors now come in the seven so-called "off-season" months and the islands plan to make another bid for a summer season this year.

WHILE the television networks fretfully debate whether art can be "entertaining'' on the screen without a living painter to perform or a jokester to pep things up, three films on old masters supply an affirmative answer.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 5 -- Waterfront employers and their longshoremen employes today predicted that the established peace between the two groups would mean increasing activity and more business and jobs for both sides. The prediction was issued in a statement today, which followed the close yesterday of a two-day promotional conference.

Democracy must understand the menace of mass-mindedness if it is to remain free in a period of rising totalitarianism, 1,000 teachers representing 294 independent elementary and secondary schools throughout the United States were told here yesterday.
BILOXI, Miss. -- The big event of this season along the Mississippi Gulf Coast will be the celebration of the 250th anniversary of the founding of Biloxi on April 3-8.

A few men in the Kremlin knew yesterday precisely what was intended and signified by the changes in the Foreign Ministry and the Foreign Trade Ministry they had just announced. They knew why Vyacheslav M. Molotov was being replaced as Foreign Minister by Andrei Y. Vishinsky.

STAY home and hear the world. That probably has been used as a slogan for records. If not, it has point. Have you ever encountered a Cuban operetta by Gonzalo Roig, composer and founder of the National Opera in Cuba? I confess I had not until I heard the Cetra-Soria album devoted to Cecilia Valdes (four twelve-inch disks).

MADRID -- With their new "open door" policy Spanish authorities are preparing to receive a record number of tourists this year. They are confident that the 50 per cent increase in the exchange rate for the peseta which came into force early this year will stimulate the flow of visitors.

With Harvard slated to face Navy at Annapolis in the opener, the Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League will open its 1949 schedule on Saturday, April 9, it was announced yesterday. A schedule of forty-five games has been arranged with the program ending on June 20 when Harvard tangles with Yale at New Haven.

CHARLESTON, S.C. -- Nineteen of this country's finest early American houses, unchanged by a century or two of time, will be opened this spring to the public. For years shuttered against the outside world and seen only by friends and relatives of the owners, these Charleston dwellings are to be included in a series of tours from March 21 through April 16.

NANKING, March 5 -- An early meeting between Kuomintang and Communist delegates for the resumption of peace negotiations is being taken for granted here following word from Communist Chairman Mao Tze-tung that March 15 might be an "opportune" time for opening formal talks in North China.

LISBON -- If a complete change is the essence of a successful holiday, Portugal should draw tens of thousands of visitors every year from the United States. The climate here is mild, the scenery Arcadian, the life calm and unhurried even by European standards, for though the country has definite Atlantic commitments it lies out of the main stream of European life.

LUXEMBOURG -- It is a curious fact that during the past 1,000 years literally millions of men have been at first surprised by Luxembourg, then charmed or intrigued, according to the nature of their business here; and, finally, have departed greatly impressed with what they found.
ATLANTIC City, N.J., March 5 (AP) -- Detroit bowlers played hob today with the standings as the American Bowling Congress tournament moved into its fourth week.

One of the most effective means of proving public education is to have a citizens of a community actually participate in solving a common educational problem, according to the Metropolitan School Study Council, a search affiliate of Teachers College, Columbia University.

"SUSPENSE," one of the better radio thrillers, last week appeared in television form. As presented on CBS-TV at 9:30 P.M. Tuesday, the whodunit was a badly contrived piece of trivia that even the police could have figured out. At the same time, however, it served to make clear that, once the rough edges are worn off, the mystery show should be a serviceable staple on video.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- "It's time for us old 'fuds' to begin to go," said the President to an American Legion group here yesterday, "and let the next generation come into its own. That is true of government also."

A small fire in the basement service room of the Shubert Theatre, 225 West Forty-fourth Street, caused by a short-circuit in the main power cable leading from the street resulted yesterday in the cancellation of the matinee performance of "Anne of the Thousand Days."

STOWE, Vt., March 5 -- Robert Bourdon, member of the Mount Mansfield Ski Club, flashed to a stunning lead in the Victor Constant Memorial Ski race today over three of the Mansfield downhill runs. Bourdon covered the Ski Meister, Lord and Stowe Standard trails in 3 minutes 11.2 seconds to lead a field of fifty-four of the outstanding Eastern United States skiers in the second annual event.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- Pilots and ground crews of the Eighty-first Fighter Wing are coming home soon from the Wheeler Air Force base at Oahu, Hawaii, leaving their planes behind. Wheeler base, however, will be kept in operation.

DUESSELDORF, Germany, March 5 -- The final phase in formulating a plan for decentralizing and regrouping the Ruhr coal properties has been reached. At a press conference in Essen today, Harry Collins, Chief of the United States-British Coal Control Board, indicated that a session on Monday with the German administrators might result in initialing a mutually acceptable document.

Five women received yesterday the annual awards of the New York Newspaper Womens Club. The awards, consisting of citations and $50 savings bonds, were presented in the Wellesley Club in the Hotel Barclay. Louis P. Lochner was chairman of the judges.

DURING the last fifteen years only one star of the Yiddish stage has been untouched by the audience attrition that has closed most of the once-flourishing theatres along Second Avenue. The contrary thespian is Menasha Skulnik, the comedian who crept into the downtown Rialto during the depression and has never had an unprofitable season.

To augment its course in salesmanship, instituted more than forty years ago, the Department of Marketing at New York University will give a course in sales management beginning in September, it was learned last week. The new course will be announced coincidentally with publication of the N.Y.U. 1949 fall catalogue some time in late spring.

OSLO -- As far back as anyone can remember, there has never been a winter like this one in the far north of Europe. The wild goose has already been seen over Oslo, and along the coast flowers which usually do not bloom until April or May are coloring the countryside.

TORONTO -- Vacationists from the United States this spring and summer will find Canada preparing for a national election, and thus will be able to observe how their northern neighbors conduct a political campaign. They will also find a number of new roads, built since last year, and less-crowded conditions at hotels and resorts.

SALEM, Mass., March 5 (UP) -- The bulk of the $1,400,000 estate of the late Mrs. Mary Magrane Glynn of Rockport, Me., widow of former New York Gov. Martin H. Glynn, was left to five relatives in her will filed for probate today.

BRUSSELS -- The only trouble with Belgium as a tourist attraction since the war is that it has on the whole represented far too much of a good thing. There was too much of sugar and spice and all things nice, except the prices, which have been consistently too high.

Some time ago there appeared in THE TIMES a report from France by C.L. Sulzberger on "profit-sharing in industry" which could be and should be of the greatest interest to every American. The report describes a system operating in hundreds of French plants which if adopted here would go far toward insuring full justice for workers while safeguarding industrial interests.
WASHINGTON, March 5 -- The proposals for reorganizing the National Military Establishment that President Truman sent to Capitol Hill today largely follow the recommendations of the Hoover Commission.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- President Truman and Secretary of State Dean Acheson have been experimenting recently with the application of common sense to the conduct of foreign policy and on the whole the thing seems to work pretty well.

THE Victorians, we are beginning to realize, were not such fools as we once thought them. In these twelve essays Miss Jordan, former Supervisor of Work with Children, Boston Public Library, moves toward a needed reappraisal of nineteenth-century children's literature in America.

JOHN P. MARQUAND is a novelist of great gifts in the technical area of his craft, and for this reason alone he always deserves consideration. There are other reasons, although "B.F.'s Daughter," his last novel, was also one of his weakest and this new one is not altogether a success.

LIKE W.S. Gilbert's Fairy Queen, Agnes Repplier, writing in the early decades of this century, turned the hose of common sense upon fires that burned with heat intense for the idolaters of contemporary causes, cults and cants.

A trend toward statism or collectivist economy threatens American democracy and can lead to the end not only of economic rights but our other freedoms as well, Spruille Braden, former Assistant Secretary of State, declared yesterday.

Due to anticipation of keener competition in the liquor industry resulting from the first post-war produced whiskies becoming four years old this summer, Seagram-Distillers Corporation last week launched a six-months merchandising and training program for its sales representatives.
The cotton futures market closed 13 points higher to 2 points lower yesterday, with the volume on the New York Cotton Exchange fairly heavy. All deliveries but that for July 1950 rose.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, March 5 -- A Workers' Court convicted thirteen persons today of black market money deals in an alleged political conspiracy with Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty and sentenced them to prison.

THE SOCIETY OF AUTOMOTIVE ENGINEERS will meet this week to consider ways of cutting costs of passenger cars and simultaneously of improving them. The S.A.E. production clinic will open in Detroit on Tuesday and continue through Thursday.
A revival of true religion in the world today, especially as it influences international politics, is essential to avert the increasing menace of war, rabbis declared in sermons here yesterday.

May I add a small footnote to Winston Churchill's account, in your issue of March 1, of an incident in the summer of 1940 which holds special interest for Americans -- the famous "destroyer-base deal."

IF Postmaster General Jesse M. Donaldson and certain Senators have their way with regard to proposals for United States postage stamps during 1949, it will be a case of "Congress proposes but the Postoffice Department disposes."

BRONC BURNETT and his Sonora, N.M., team-mates are rolling on toward a national American Legion Junior Baseball championship. In this volume, the third in the series for teen-aged boys, they win the Regional playoffs at Denver and head for the Sectionals.
SAN FRANCISCO, March 5 -- The West Coast considered this week the remarkable change of attitude that has developed within a few years toward the region's residents of Japanese ancestry.

FOR THIS WEEK: Make cuttings of fuchsia, heliotrope and lantana in order to have bedding or pot plants for summer.... Sow seeds of petunia, aster, phlox drummondi and scabiosa indoors, and transplant seedlings when the second pair of leaves open.... Look over pots of parsley for aphids (especially if leaves are turning yellow) and spray with a mild nicotine sulfate solution....

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- The Navy released a "communique" from Admiral W.H.P. Blandy, commander-in-chief of the Atlantic Fleet, describing theoretically heavy damage from a simulated underwater blast today of an atomic bomb among the ships of the expeditionary force off Vieques Island in the Caribbean.
I take issue with David L. Cohn's comments on the austerity of modern life in "Lace Curtains and Quail."

THE younger set is not "getting a bang" out of things any more. A youth who used such a dated expression would be strictly a "drag." Today, an exciting thing is "the real Bikini." What has happened is that slang has gone through another of its revolutions so that even the generation which mystified the adult population with its jargon just before the war now wonders what in the world the juniors are talking about.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 5 -- While never leading by more than 6 points, Princeton's basketball team gained a 44-38 Eastern Intercollegiate league victory tonight at the expense of Cornell. The Tigers thus gained undisputed possession of second place, one game behind Yale, with their fifth consecutive victory.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., March 5 (AP) A wide-open, well-balanced Kentucky Derby took form today as Col. Matt Winn called off the names of 113 nominees for the diamond jubilee running May 7 at Churchill Downs.
Andrei Andreyevitch Gromyko, new No. 2 man in Russia's Foreign Office, knows the United States better than any top-ranking diplomat in the Soviet hierarchy.

ROME, March 5 -- The replacement of Vyacheslav M. Molotov by Andrei Y. Vishinsky as Soviet Foreign Minister, caused something of a sensation in Italy but most persons doubted whether it indicated that the Kremlin intended to follow a "softer" line toward the Western democracies.

THE letter, the situation, the Miss Sandifer are problems I've had to face all my professional life. They have been problems I have never dealt with completely successfully. Perhaps that has been because my generalizations about the theatre, when I've met my Miss Sandifers personally, never seemed to the stage-struck young hopefuls to apply to themselves.

WASHINGTON, March 5 (UP) -The National Labor Relations Board said today that 357 unfair labor charges were filed against employers in January to establish a new monthly peak under the Taft-Hartley Law.

AFTER ten years of investigations and court hearings the score for the Government in its anti-trust actions to compel the five major motion picture companies to split up into separately owned theatre operating and producing-distributing corporations now stands at two down and three to go.

It is apparent from his article "Into the Word of Nothingness" that author Sam Boal and Hall Hibbard of Lockheed are still thinking in terms of the physics of Aristotle. The statment " * * * there is no limit whatever to the speeds man can attain" is nonsense.

The appearance of a new novel by Elizabeth Bowen is always a literary event. Here is an abridgment of a biographical account she wrote for her publisher, Alfred A. Knopf, together with some of her answers to a questionnaire sent her by the Literary Guild just before the publication of "The Heat of the Day" (Feb. 23).

ANYONE who goes shopping for a carpet this spring will run into a queer anomaly. Prices are up -- that is, a standard, solid color twist carpet will be tagged with a price about 11 per cent higher than the same quality bore a year ago.

It seemed to this department, even before jet propulsion and V-2 rockets had been introduced, that the intellectual delights of exploring interplanetary space and landing suitably clad on Mars and Venus had been exhausted by the more imaginative writers of fiction.

A 16-year-old member of golf's noted Turnesa family gained a blue ribbon of distinction at the Brooklyn Cavalry horse show at Squadron C. Armory yesterday. Miss Phyllis Turnesa, daughter of Phil. senior member of the golfing clan, captured the A.S.P.C.A. horsemanship event and thereby became eligible to compete in the 1949 championship when the class is held in the national fixture at Madison Square Garden.
PHILADELPHIA, March 5 -- The United States Navy has developed the world's fastest helicopter, the Piassecki Helicopter Corporation announced today.

Dr. Alvin C. Eurich, president of the State University of New York, warned yesterday that passage of the Condon-Barrett Bill to strip the board of trustees of its administrative powers would "kill" the plans to develop a publicly supported university in this state.

I WONDER if Howard Spring, whose pleasant, copious novels of middle-class English life are as familiar now to Americans as to his countrymen, did not originally conceive this book as his autobiography -- as a portrait of the artist through all but the final age of man.

PARIS, March 5 -- Premier Stalin, by shifting his key Ministers of Foreign Affairs and Foreign Trade, not only has completely confused the governments of the Western world that await some clue as to the real import of this dramatic move but also has left his hands completely free to ameliorate or aggravate the international crisis without giving an advance hint as to which road he win select.

BELGRADE. MARSHAL TITO is waiting now for the Cominform to make the next feint. He doesn't know how or where the Cominform will renew the attack, but he knows that when it comes it will require all his strength and resourcefulness to parry it.
WASHINGTON, March 5 (AP) -- President Truman indicated tonight that he expected another White House occupant after 1952.

A PASTIME as old as sport itself has taken its place alongside modern scientific aids in making aviation safer. Peregrine falcons, those earliest hunters of game for the table, are keeping British airfields clear of unwelcome hosts of small birds.
EXETER, N.H., March 5 -- Exeter defeated Andover's track team, 44 1-3 to 36 2-3, in a dual meet today.

The New York Knickerbockers tallied 8 straight points in the final minute and forty-five seconds and defeated the Boston Celtics, 66 -- 61, in a Basketball Association of America contest at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory before 3,942 fans last night.

ST. LOUIS, March 5 -- A vigorous recruitment campaign to get more high school students to enter elementary grade teaching will be conducted during the coming year by the nation's ailing school groups, in cooperation in non-educational organizations.

LONDON -- Advance bookings for England's 1949 season show that tourists are planning to arrive earlier and stay later, and that they are growing younger. Travel habits are changing: the season beginning as early as March, running on to September, and there are more students, teachers and youthful visitors who have to budget their vacations carefully.

NEXT to affection, laughter is the prime requisite of childhood. This fat collection of stories and poems will help to answer the demands of youngsters who are always asking for "something funny." They may take their pick from the fantastic, the realistic, tall tales, adventure stories and a special section on the drama.
GENEVA -- After a bad summer in 1948 and what looks now like a disastrous winter, the Swiss tourist industry is looking hopefully to the summer of 1949 to stave off a serious crisis.

On paper it looked like a breather for the Violets, but on the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory court yesterday it was quite a struggle as the New York University basketball team defeated Fordham, 57 -- 51. Howard Cann's favored athletes, striving to salvage something from the season's wreckage, needed a stirring closing spurt to annex their eleventh triumph of the campaign.

Governor Dewey's quest for the Presidency, Frank Costello's fund-raising dinner at the Copacabana night club, and Fire Commissioner Quayle's suspension of Chief Peter Loftus were re-enacted humorously in song and story last night by the members of the Inner Circle at their annual stunt dinner in the Astor Hotel.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- James Forrestal, Secretary of Defense, announced today that the National Military establishment has decided to support a bill authorizing an Air Force Academy like the United States Military and Naval Academies.

* * * Milton Bracker's excellent analysis ("Beneath the Ferment in South America") left out one event which I think worthy of mention. In the revolution in Brazil in 1945, when the 13-year-old dictatorship of Vargas was finally overthrown largely through the efforts of certain army officers and students, there was no attempt made by this group to install one of their own members in the Presidency.

THIS is a top-notch Margery Allingham murder mystery -- that is to say, full of keen characterization, humor, old English atmosphere, a charmingly decadent family and a few sudden deaths. And Albert Campion, shrewd, scholarly crime detector, is there to check the widely scattered clues and put the pieces of the puzzle together.

VIENNA, March 5 -- The biggest shock the Communist rulers of Czechoslovakia have had since they took power a year ago was the Russian proposal to move 300,000 Germans from the Soviet Zone of Germany into the underpopulated fringe of Czechoslovakia from which 3,000,000 Sudeten Germans have been expelled since the war.

Whether or not Representative Wilbur D. Mills of Arkansas anticipated that the United States Tax Court will be made a court of record, his introduction, on Feb. 24, of his bill (H. R. 2983) in the House of Representatives, the purpose of which is to establish a "Tax Settlement Board," is important and timely.
PHILADELPHIA, March 5 -- Using a fast-breaking offense, Pennsylvania defeated Columbia in an Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League game at the Palestra today, 57 -- 47, before 2,500 spectators.

The Polish Ambassador to the United States, Dr. Josef Winiewicz, declared on his arrival at La Guardia Field yesterday from London that he foresaw no "substantial change in policy" on the part of the Soviet Union as a result of the replacement of Vyacheslav M. Molotov as Foreign Minister by Andrei Y. Vishinsky.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- A political squall that may become a damaging hurricane has blown up on the House side of Capitol Hill with Mississippi's Congressman John Rankin pushing the bellows. The storm center is the veterans' pension bill which the Veterans Affairs Committee, of which Mr. Rankin is chairman, reported favorably to the House.

The American Bureau of Shipping last week added Italy to the list, now comprising Canada and Japan, of foreign nations whose shipbuilders are constructing new vessels to classification standards prescribed by the bureau.

In the immense, fortresslike Pentagon Building, across the Potomac from Washington, the nation's top military planners are busier than they have been since the peak days of World War II. As headquarters of the National Military Establishment, the Pentagon houses both civilian and uniformed chiefs of the armed forces and their staffs, with a total personnel estimated at 20,000.
THIS year's vacation to foreign lands will cost approximately what last year's did, but the 1949 traveler will get more for his money.

BUENOS AIRES, March 5 -- Government distribution of all newsprint, following the expropriation of all stocks presently in the country, will begin Thursday, Finance Minister Ramon Cereijo declared last night.

NEW HEAVEN, March 5 -- Capt. Tony Lavelli of Yale tallied 21 points tonight to establish a modern scoring record for a major college player as the Elis rallied in the late stages of an Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League contest to overpower Harvard, 77-58.

Republicans vs. Dewey The Republican organization in New York State split wide open last week. For the first time since 1942 a group of Republican legislators challenged openly Gov. Thomas E. Dewey's control of the party. The split came over the fiscal program outlined by the Governor in his budget message to the Legislature on last Feb. 1.

SPECIAL excursion airline fares and off-season hotel rates will attract many vacationists to the West Indies this spring and summer. Pan American World Airways, K.L.M., Linea Aeropostal Venezolana, and Trans-Canada Airlines plan to reduce their regular airline fares to the West Indies by 20 per cent from May 15 to late September.

TEL AVIV, Israel, March 5 -- Britain's abstention on the vote for Israel's membership in the United Nations has caused considerable resentment here, and it is felt that the unfavorable reaction may be reflected in future relations.

Joe Yackanich and Joe (Sammy) Ososki have been named to coach the Fordham freshman football squad, Jack Coffey, graduate manager of athletics, announced yesterday. The appointments, following the signing of Lou DeFilippo and George (Eck) Allen as aides to Coach Ed Danowski, completed the Rams' gridiron coaching roster.

LONDON, March 5 -- A proud and optimistic statement on Britain's economic recovery made by Christopher Mayhew, a British Under-Secretary for Foreign Affairs, raised an important question on both sides of the Atlantic this week: Exactly how far has Britain recovered?

IN the revised edition of "Peaks and Lamas" Marco Pallis stresses his interest in the "mountains of Tradition" as opposed to the mountains of government charts, for to him the great fascination of Tibet is the people, anachronisms of modern civilization, primitive and serene.

THIS vigorous little volume joins in the current outcry against those false prophets who predicted the election of Mr. Dewey. The thesis is that the pollsters and other forecasters unwittingly organized a gigantic conspiracy to persuade the Trumanites either to stay at home or scramble onto the Dewey bandwagon.

AS the reviewer in THE NEW YORK TIMES Book Review of Ezra Pound's "Cantos" cited in THE TIMES' account [Feb. 20 issue] of Mr. Pound's winning the Bollingen Prize, I should like to correct what was obviously a typographical error.

"SAY, it sounds funny for you to be called daddy and mother, doesn't it?" remarks Pierre the Pelican, addressing parents of a first-born baby; "I guess you have been practicing on it some before the baby came. Most folks do, just like they usually name the baby before it is born."

THE five Burrington brothers and sisters were far from happy about spending their spring holidays with an unknown grandfather, but in true English fashion they were prepared to see it through. Once arrived at Chipping Langton, life proved highly exciting, with a deserted cottage on the sand dunes to explore, the sinister actions of a four-fingered butler to investigate, as well as periodic flights of an unidentified plane.

Television as a medium of education and entertainment received about equal praise and criticism yesterday from a panel of six junior high school pupils on a Youth Forum sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES and broadcast over THE TIMES station, WQXR.

Since the pound sterling ceased nearly two years ago to be freely convertible into the world's other moneys, the value of the pound in international trade keeps taking on greater resemblance to the intricately devised multiples of German international money spawned during the Thirties under the economic inspiration of Dr. Hjalmar Schacht in Germany's frantic pre-war "export-or-die" campaign.

BOSTON, March 5 -- New England's town-meeting season opened this week with several common problems confronting communities in the region. Involved in the perennial struggle against rising tax rates were the choices of reducing long-accepted government services; postponing needed civic projects another year, or raising the money required to finance a muncipal program in a still inflationary period.

MINEOLA, L.I., March 5 -- Two men accused of looting Long Island homes of nearly $100,000 worth of jewelry, fur coats, television sets and other valuables within the last five months were in the county jail here today.

Judith Coplon, arrested yesterday for conspiracy, dresses simply and apparently has few interests outside her work and cultural activities. The few complaints her Washington landlord received about her were that she sometimes typed until 2 o'clock in the morning.

A PAIR of plain barn doors with old-fashioned black iron handles provided the material for a series of photographic impressions in a one-man show which opened last week at the Photo League, 23 East Tenth Street.

THE mist on Mr. Green's waters is the slowly spreading shadow of crime, of a specific crime, moving through the lives and minds of a little group in Belfast, Ireland. Two frightened amateurs have carried out a bit of blackmail in an old office building on Saturday afternoon.

WHEN Hollywood finally gets up its courage to discuss any social reform on the screen, it tackles the problem with a vengeance. The question of the American Negro and the cruelty of society toward him is being faced by the film industry this year with a which, to an extraplanetary observer, might suggest that the injustice involved is less than seventy-five years old.

WE are taking our car to Europe this summer because we concluded from pre-war traveling abroad that we never really got to know France until we had motored leisurely through the country. WE are taking our car to Europe this summer because we concluded from pre-war traveling abroad that we never really got to know France until we had motored leisurely through the country.

I HAVE read with interest Harold J. Kennedy's article entitled "Cure for the Fabulous Invalid." I had the pleasure of hearing Mr. Kennedy lecture here in Roswell recently and I agree completely with his views as to the plausibility of bringing first-class plays to small towns all over the country.

CHIEF news for the international air traveler in 1949 is that the newest and most luxurious air transport ever put into regular airline service is operating, and that a few new routes have been added to the world air map.
LARCHMONT, N. Y, March 5 -- In a Moth series today at the Larchmont Yacht Club, the Larchmont skippers defeated those from Yale University, 4 -- 2.
STOCKHOLM -- It should be possible to "do" Sweden for as low as $15 a day this summer, transportation included. Hotel rates and the cost of restaurant meals remain essentially the same as last year.

TORONTO, March 5 -- The play-off-hope lights almost went out tonight for the lowly New York Rangers as they were swamped, 7 -- 1, by the Toronto Maple Leafs. The points strengthened the Leafs' hold on the National Hockey League's fourth place, last slot in the Stanley Cup play-off circle.

THE dearth of snow on Eastern slopes this winter also finds a low in the production of ski books. Instead of the usual heavy flow of literature, covering every phase of the fast-growing ski sport, new books are few. Here are three.

A contemporary recently remarked that the stock market has acted strangely for ten years. To which has been added the comment that it might very well continue to act strangely and continue to hold together despite the repeated and justified mention of such nasty words as "deflation" and "unemployment."
TAMPA, Fla., March 5 (AP) -- A Federal jury here has ordered National Airlines to pay $5,000 to a man it removed from a plane in favor of a regular customer.

BERLIN, March 5 -- Western diplomats in Berlin are watching Russian actions closely for any sign of a change in foreign policy as a result of the replacement of Vyacheslav M. Molotov as Foreign Minister and Anastas I. Mikoyan as Foreign Trade Minister.

An article appeared in your Feb. 16 edition stating the fact that a Broadway repertory is being planned for next season by such notables as Messrs. Ferrer and Aldrich. It was also stated by another member of the prospective organization, Sam Wanamaker, that a repertory cannot operate without stars.

NINETEEN weeks (and nine more to go) after the Margaret Webster Shakespeare Company boarded a bus and lit out on the Boston Post Road, life-out-of-two-suitcases-apiece has become a thespian saga. Between performances our motorized "Hamlet" and "Macbeth" have already rolled over 15,000 miles.

IT is questionable whether T.S. Eliot has in this book helped to define culture or even succeeded in specifying, as he seems to think he has done, the conditions of its survival. But about one phase of Mr. Eliot's work there is no question whatever.

BUENOS AIRES -- Having played host last month to the Inter-American Travel Congress for the first time, South America is newly conscious of its possibilities as a place for vacationing nortecamericanos to spend their dollars.

IN his review of "Edward, My Son" in the Feb. 13 issue of the Book Review, Robert Morley contends that the time to read a play is before it is produced. I believe it is a much more satisfying experience to read a play after you've seen it.

WASHINGTON, March 5 (UP) -- The chairman of the House Republican Conference said today that Congress has "practically ceased to function" because of quarrels between President Truman and Democratic legislators.

Growing dissatisfaction among Federal Reserve member banks over the advantages of affiliation with the system has caused the Federal Reserve Bank of New York to make an over-all study of the situation, it was learned yesterday.

BIG MOUNTAIN, Mont., March 5 (AP) -- Yves Latreille, a 25-year-old Canadian, skiing for the Sun Valley. Idaho, Ski Club, skimmed down Big Mountain at more than 60 miles an hour to win the National downhill championship today.

OMAHA, Neb., March 5 -- Water rights, perennial promoter of regional strife, are causing new squabbles here. On one side of a developing controversy is the State of Nebraska. On the other is the United States Bureau of Reclamation. Wyoming is cast, somewhat unwillingly, in a secondary role.

LEST any one take this sprightly volume as a technical tome, it should be said that the kind of doctor the compiler has in mind is the one who heard that a patient of his was at death's door. 'That's all right," he remarked briskly, "I'll pull him through."

MEXICO CITY -- After a winter season that converted a slump into a thumping boom in tourist trade, Mexico is preparing to welcome her early spring and Easter visitors with festival merriment, more new luxury hotels and better internal travel facilities.

The 1949 Census of Business will begin in New York on Thursday when approximately forty enumerators will start the enumeration which will eventually cover all retail, wholesale and service establishments in the New York City area, it was announced yesterday by Melville J. Weiss, district supervisor.

LAKE SUCCESS, March 5 (AP) -- Records of the United Nations show that twenty-four Russian and three Ukrainian citizens are working among its 3,038 employes at Lake Success and its headquarters in New York City.

"Music of the Twentieth Century," the last in a series of music history lectures by Dr. Curt Sachs, consultant to the New York Public Library's Music Division, will be held tomorrow at 8:30 P.M. in the Central Building, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second-Street.

AFTER traveling 7,000 miles by car all over the European continent from Stockholm to Sorrento in the comparatively short time of thirty-five days, it may be reported that motoring in Europe is not any more hazardous or adventurous than journeying by automobile in the United States.

THERE is a healthy reaction nowadays against an excess of outlines, surveys, textbooks, digests and the like. We are quite rightly urged to go back to the great books themselves. But in the millennia since the Greeks and the Jews gave us the first of these books a lot of great writing has accumulated.

GILFORD, N.H., March 5 -Olavi Alakuppti, 33-year-old Finn from Camp Dodge, gave a dynamic exhibition of cross-country skiing in dominating the Class A field in the opening half of the United States Eastern Amateur Ski Association's championships today.

SO many Monday morning quarterbacks have second guessed the polls since last Nov. 2 that we are apt to overlook this essential point: Election predictions are only the show case of the public-opinion-polling business. They are the loss-leader on which, in the past, the pollsters have built the argument that they can and do measure public opinion.
PHOENIX, Ariz., March 5 -- With the completion of the fifth day of training today, Manager Leo Durocher pronounced his squad ready for the Giants' first intra-camp game tomorrow.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., March 5 -- The Rhode Island jewelry industry is in the midst of a seasonal upswing while some other local industries are ordering production cutbacks in the face of weakening sales volume.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- For all its seeming irrelevance to the pressing affairs of the day, the current controversy in the Senate over the question of closure -- the device limiting debate -- has far-reaching implications. This holds true not only for the immediate program of the Fair Deal but for future legislation generally.
ABOARD U.S.S. EDISTO, Off East Coast of Greenland, March 5 -- A rare ice tempest bombarded this ship this week with heavy icebergs tossing on thirty-foot waves.

Approval of proposed legislation that would permit rental of garage space in multiple dwellings to non-tenants was given yesterday by civic and real estate groups, planning agencies and real estate men as an aid in producing more shelter for automobiles and reducing parking at curbs.

The American Communist leaders, William Z. Foster and Eugene Dennis, have given us an opportunity to clear our minds as to just what the Communist movement in this country means. Not that there is much that is new in the statement issued by Messrs. Foster and Dennis on March 1.
WASHINGTON, March 5 -- Senator Margaret Chase Smith, Republican, of Maine, moved gently into a North-South argument today, and won it.

PHILADELPHIA, March 5 --Pennsylvania Railroad carloading last week totaled 109,924 as against 128,950 a year ago, a decrease of 14.8 per cent. For 1949 to date Pennsylvania Railroad loadings totaled 890,327, to compare with 976,609 last year, a decrease of 8.8 per cent.

Principles of sound distribution evolved during the lean years prior to World War II are receiving full vindication in the buyers' market currently existing in the textile and apparel trades, it was pointed out last week.

LENT Italian style? And why not so far as cooking is concerned? Giacinta Sardi said her family had only about a "kilo of meat a week when I was growing up in Asti." Dishes had to be meatless not only during a special season but throughout the year.

PARIS, March 5 -- The new Marshall Plan steering committee at Cabinet level met twice today and will meet again tomorrow in an effort to agree on the recovery policies it will recommend to the European governments receiving dollar aid.

The Philadelphia Seventeenth Annual Turf Conference will be held at Llanerch Country Club, Manoa, Pa., March 9, 7:30 P.M. Better turf for home lawns, athletic field parka and golf courses will be discussed.

GENEVA, March 5 (UP) -- The executive board of the World Health Organization recommended tonight that the organization spend $9,000,000 next year to aid underdeveloped areas of the world in line with President Truman's program.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, March 5 -- A Sofia District Court heard today the final pleas of fifteen Protestant ministers and the twelve remaining defense counsel who had not been heard yesterday and then adjourned until Tuesday when it will render its verdict.

ATLANTA, Ga., March 5 -- The Southern filibuster in the United States Senate, freezing temperatures that gave growers some anxious moments, and a few heartening business signs were among the items commanding top interest this week throughout the Southeast.

ESQUIMALT, B.C., March 5 -- (UP) -- Naval officials reported tonight that crew members aboard the Canadian destroyer Athabaskan had created "a disturbance" because of dissatisfaction with currency exchange restrictions aboard ship.
WASHINGTON, March 5 -- President Truman called upon Congress today to create an over-all Department of Defense with full and unquestioned authority over the separate armed forces.
LONDON -- Having returned from my first visit to Wonderland, meaning the United States of America, I can better appreciate now the feelings of American tourists when they first visit my country.
WASHINGTON, March 5 (AP) -- Following is the text of president Truman's message to Congress today on revision of the armed services unification act:

The action last week of the Pennsylvania Railroad in throwing The Long Island Rail Road, a wholly owned subsidiary, into bankruptcy proceedings again drew attention to the difficulties encountered by the nation's carriers in adjusting operations to the changed conditions in the post-war period.

NANKING, March 5 -- The Communist radio announced tonight that 5,000 troops of the Nationalist 106th army stationed on the south bank of the Yangtze near Wuhu, about fifty miles southwest of Nanking, had crossed the river and deserted to the "People's Liberation Army."

The idea of compressing the history of the world in a single volume was taken up some years after the idea of sailing round the world in a ship but well before the idea of flying round the world non-stop in a bomber.

The Security Council vote of 9 to 1 for the admission of the new state of Israel as the fifty-ninth United Nation forecasts similar action by the General Assembly in its April meeting and the raising of the flag of the Star of David alongside the present fifty-eight national colors on the Flushing Meadows.

The appoinment of Louis R. Deutekom, as general manager of the Royal Netherlands Steamship Company in the United States and Canada, was announced here last week. Mr. Deutekom succeeds Hendrik A. Statius Muller, who retired after nearly forty-one years' service.

PARIS -- France, having regained her place last year as the No. 1 tourist attraction of the world, intends to see that she retains this rank in 1949. The Cabinet's recent agreement in principle on the proposal to drop the visa requirement for United States citizens is one indication of how seriously French officials are taking foreign travel in France this year as a means of bolstering the nation's shaky economy.
Ogden Phipps won the national amateur court tennis championship for the seventh time yesterday.

CHICAGO, March 5 (AP) -- Grains opened higher and kept their gains through to the close on the Board of Trade today. Soy beans and lard participated in the advance, the latter commodity being helped by belief that the Army would be in the market for prime steam lard for export.

THIS year's European traveler may take encouragement from the fact that the formidable barriers of red tape raised at national borders are finally beginning to shrink. Great Britain, Belgium and Italy all dropped their visa requirements during the last year for American tourists, joining Luxembourg, the Netherlands, Switzerland, Denmark, Norway and Sweden in admitting visitors on valid United States passports alone.
BERLIN, March 5 (AP) -- Marshal Sokolovsky's letter to General Clay asserted that the situation regarding the restitution of Soviet property in the United States zone was "completely inadmissible."

TOKYO, March 5 -- Although Japan's new radio law is not yet on the books, sixteen organizations already have been established to take advantage of its provisions for private broadcasting.
