Of these, twelve reportedly have arranged financing and are ready to apply for licensing as soon as the bars are lowered.

LONDON -- Thousands of Americans will include a visit to Wales this summer on their tour of Britain and they will find so much that is "different" in the little Principality that they will quickly discover why Welshmen do not approve of being lumped with English and Scots to become just "Britons."

THERE are very few now alive who knew Georges Clemenceau intimately and had his confidence. Among the general public, even in his own country, the memory of what he was and what he did has faded in the turmoil of events. Wythe Williams has therefore done good service to the memory of the man who, perhaps more than all others, won the victory over Germany in 1918.

Continuous casting of steel, a rellatively simple and economic process for converting steel from the liquid state to semi-finished shapes, may be advanced by the end of the year to the point where its first commercial application by the steel industry is possible.
PARIS -- Paris is not France, any more than New York is the United States. If you want to see France, you must go outside Paris.

THE rather alarming assumption that the movies are on the skids -- a notion which some frightened people in the business have helped, in fact, to spread -- is like that premature obit of the far from defunct Mark Twain. It is slightly exaggerated.

Sales of meat in large independent, chain and supermarket groceries are now greater in both unit sales and dollar volume compared with the corresponding period last year, according to a survey just completed by the American Institute of Food Distribution, Inc.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., March 5 -- Army's last-ditch rally fell two points short and Navy wound up with its third straight basketball victory over the cadets in Dahlgren Hall here tonight, 42 to 40.

PARIS, March 5 -- French Foreign Ministry officials withheld today all comment on the shake-up in the Soviet Union's Cabinet, but generally in Government circles there was a sober view of its purport.

A shy, 15-year-old Japanese boy, hugging a tennis racket and a fishing pole, stepped from a train at Pennsylvania Station yesterday and was reunited with his mother and father after a ten-year separation.

BERLIN, March 5 -- Following on the change in the Soviet Foreign Office Marshal Vassily D. Sokolovsky, Soviet Commander in Germany, reiterated today Russia's objections to the formation of a Western German state in a letter to Gen. Lucius D. Clay, United States Military Governor.

TEL AVIV, Israel -- Even before the Egyptian armistice was signed the Government of the world's newest state, Israel, was busy making plans for tourism for this year. Fifteen thousand visitors are expected, and though this is a tiny figure compared to the 100,000 travelers in Palestine in 1935, still it will make for the biggest tourist season since that year.

Ralph Wright, Assistant Secretary of Labor, was honored last night by his former colleagues in Typographical Union No. 6 at a testimonial dinner given by the union at the St. George Hotel in Brooklyn.

HALLANDALE, Fla., March 5 -- Conn McCreary lost two decisions in one race today -- the first on the track and the second in the stewards' stand. George M. Jacobson's Big Dial gave a four-length beating to the McCreary-ridden First Nighter in the $7,500 Fort Lauderdale Handicap at Gulfstream Park and then the officials turned thumbs down on Conn's howl of foul.

To the Music Editor: May I stake my claim to several inches of space for the announcement of the establishment of a new musical organization? The organization, which has just completed the preliminary founding details except for a letterhead that is still in the process of design, is entitled "American Association for the Abolition of Encores, Especially Cute Ones," -- to be known briefly as the AAAEECO.

THE average anthology of this sort is a rather unhappy compromise between a collection of the writing which at any period was good and the writing which was historically significant. And it is likely to suffer too from the limitations of space.

THAT report by the Allied States Association of Motion Picture Exhibitors, which THE TIMES published last Sunday, isn't likely to afford film producers much guidance. Allied complains that Hollywood is trying too hard to please Broadway sophisticates and the professional critics.
LONDON, March 5 -- The Soviet Union promoted Andrei A. Gromyko, former Ambassador to Washington and former chief Soviet United Nations delegate, to First Deputy Foreign Minister tonight.

Passage of the bill now before the New York State Legislature that provides for the licensing of watchmen and guards on this city's piers has been urged by the Commerce and Industry Association of New York in letters to members of the Senate and Assembly Judiciary Committees by Joseph A. Sinclair, association secretary.

FLORENCE -- Most important news for the spring and summer visitor to Italy is this: there is now plenty of gasoline. Although fuel costs more here than in most other European countries, foreign motorists will not have to bother too much about the mileage of their vacation itineraries or about the gasoline black market.

A beardless plaster bust of Abraham Lincoln done in 1860 and said to be the first for which the future President had ever sat will be presented to the Lincoln Museum in Washington, its owner Henry C. Roberts, announced last week.

ROME -- The pre-war visitor to Rome used to see first the Termini Station, a name recalling not only that it was here that the thermae (baths) of Emperor Diocletian offered the ancient Romans the most extensive and luxurious bathing facilities, but also suggesting that the Eternal City's central railroad station is a terminal.

Inexpensive rayon and print dresses, priced from $5.98 to $10.98, were featured in retail promotions here last week, according to a report made especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by the Retail News Bureau. Retailers continued vigorous promotions of the "short shortie" coat, with prices ranging from $12.98 to $45, it was said.

Business, education and labor have teamed up throughout the country to meet economic problems before, instead of after, they have produced serious economic losses. This trend, now so accelerated that many leading universities are vieing with each other to add new courses in such subjects as "industrial relations" and "communications," is considered the most advanced technique of management participation in planning activities that has emerged since the war.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., March 5 -- Southern history of a sort was being made this week, and it jolted those who have pictured the Deep South as the only section of the country in which cotton is a major crop.
The Metropolitan Fair Rent Committee and affiliated realty organizations here will put on a demonstration in Washington tomorrow to dramatize their opposition to rent controls.
LONDON, March 5, (Reuters) -- Leaders in all four major leagues retained their positions in England's soccer football after today's play, which was under the worst conditions of the season.

IN one of the many little soda and stationery stores that dot New York's upper West Side, 11-year-old Judy Marshall proudly dispensed good things to eat from behind her fathers fountain. She loved helping in the store, talking to customers, and eating sundaes, and there wasn't much that went on in the neighborhood that Judy missed.

A familiar name was missing from the roster of winners last night as the curtain fell on the indoor track season at Madison Square Garden in the thirtieth annual New York Chapter, Knights of Columbus, games, staged before 13,000 spectators.

ALTHOUGH man has progressed from mead to manhattans, his approach to chronic inebriates has been, until recent times, largely moralistic. The discovery that the compulsive imbiber is seriously ill and not sinful is this century's glimmer of hope for the afflicted.

OTTAWA, March 5 -- More noisy interruption has marked the present session of the Canadian House of Commons than has been the case for many years. On several occasions it has degenerated into plain rowdiness and given indications of the heat with which the next general election will be fought.
WASHINGTON, March 5 (UP) -- The Navy revealed tonight that it has sent a seaplane tender to equatorial waters for a major experiment in shooting big, long-range rockets from ships' decks.

More than 3,500 student journalists representing primary and secondary school newspapers are expected to attend the twenty-fifth annual three-day convention of the Columbia Scholastic Press Association, which opens at Columbia University Thursday at 1:30 P.M. in the McMillin Academic Theatre, Broadway at 116th Street, Joseph M. Murphy, director of the association, announced yesterday.

ROME, March 5 (UP) -- The Ministry of Justice has filed seventy-one complaints against Italian Deputies, forty-eight of them Communists, for defamation, political violence or offenses against the dignity of Pope Pius XII, it was announced today.
We write this letter in view of the widespread misunderstanding of the position of the Anti-Defamation League in connection with the exhibition of the J. Arthur Rank production of "Oliver Twist."

From many years' knowledge of Carinthia I should like to say something as to Tito's claims on this southern province of Austria which is separated from Slovenia, the northern province of Yugoslavia, by the abrupt and rugged wall of the Karawanken mountains, a chain of the Julian Alps.

TEN years ago Mrs. Gaither turned from the short story, biography and books for children to the novel, and within the decade has produced three distinguished pieces of fiction. All are set in the Deep South during slavery and are concerned with the whole rich and dramatic complex of social and racial relations inherent in the times.

Chairman Ugi Carusi of the Displaced Persons Commission used mild language on Friday when he told a House Judiciary subcommittee of the operations of the 1948 DP law. There were, he said, "many, many simpler ways" of settling displaced persons than "the one we have been struggling with."
IF a stitch in time saves nine, then a spray in time will save countless fruit. A schedule for fruit trees, then, is vitally important.

The Urban League of Greater New York announced yesterday its annual vocational opportunity campaign to be conducted throughout the Boroughs of Manhattan, the Bronx, Brooklyn and Queens during the week from next Sunday to March 20.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg, Republican, of Michigan, declared today that Russia had exchanged a "relentless" for a "ruthless" Foreign Minister by replacing Vyacheslav M. Molotov with Andrei Y. Vishinsky.

A new formula for calculating the basis for industry's depreciation allowances for manufacturing plants may provide an answer to present "unrealistic methods" under which it may cost as much as 120 per cent more than original cost to replace plants out of profits.
WASHINGTON, March 5 -- The Post Office Department tonight suspended United States parcel post service into Berlin

FROM the standpoint of the ship traveler, this will be the brightest post-war year to date. It is also likely to establish a new post-war record for sea-and-air transport between the United States and European points.

A Negro tenant farmer in Michigan recently obtained a loan to build a home, with the aid of the Federal Farmers Home Administration and a Negro insurance company, officials of the United States Department of Agriculture, which sponsors that agency, said yesterday.

THIS department is in sharp disagreement with the review of "From the City, From the Plough" which appeared in these columns last Sunday. Mr. Liebling wrote a completely unfavorable review of a British war story so good, in my estimation, that it bothers me to think that for honesty, brevity, impact, and balance in its point of view, we on this side of the water have not produced a book to match it.

HAVANA -- The carnival in Havana, which begins this week-end, is the gayest part of the season. Every effort is being made by city officials to revive the traditional lavish celebrations of this period.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 5 -- Florida's champion, Pete Cooper of Ponte Vedra Beach, showed his heels to the touring professionals today as he took the third round lead in the St. Petersburg open golf tourney.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, March 5 (UP) -- Members of the United States military mission in Turkey said today they had protested to Washington that the success of their efforts was jeopardized by a State Department order slashing their living allowance.

Activity in the wholesale apparel market here last week was generally slow and buyers were extremely cautious in placing orders, according to a report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company, resident buying office.
"A SMALL-TOWN guy in a big city talking about things which folks have been thinking but just never get around to saying" is the way Herb Shriner identifies his own particular brand of humor.
WASHINGTON, March 5 (UP) -- Government sources said today there was a good chance that the rise in unemployment might be reversed in the next thirty days.

IN 1823 President Monroe proposed "that we should form a just estimate of our resources, revenue and progress in every kind of improvement connected with the national prosperity and public defense." In 1946, 123 years later, the Congress reluctantly approved an Employment Act which provided for analysis and recommendations of policy by a Council of Economic Advisers to the President and periodic economic reports to Congress by the President.
DANVILLE, Va., March 5 -- Southern tobacco planters have been told for the first time, in all seriousness, that they are facing competition in other countries.

Republican members of the Legislature from this city, at a conference with party leaders at the National Republican Club, indicated yesterday willingness to support a bill for consolidation of the city's courts proposed by Presiding Justice David W. Peck of the Appellate Division, First Department.
WASHINGTON, March 5 -- The Bureau of Labor Statistics wants to freshen up its consumers' price index, one of the Government's most popular products. The job would take three or four years.

SAN JUAN, P.R., March 5 -- Responsibility for planning and wartime operations -- and some, but not many, administrative and logistical responsibilities -- in the Caribbean have been concentrated under the authority of Lieut. Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, who is "CincCarib," or Commander in Chief, Caribbean.

HAMILTON, Bermuda -- Bermuda's tourist trade for the current season is just about back to pre-war levels and "Sold Out" signs have been hung at hotels and guest houses since the Furness liner Queen of Bermuda resumed her New York-Bermuda service last month.

The formal opening of the United Jewish Appeal $250,000,000 campaign which will be carried on in 4,960 communities in the United States, will take place on March 19 at an emergency conference of the UJA in Washington, Henry Morgenthau Jr., general chairman of the organization, announced yesterday.

Politicians, according to Adam Smith, who wrote the great treatise, "The Wealth of Nations," were able to make the rich poor and the poor poorer, but they could not make the rich poorer and the poor rich.

Strength in the 200-yard dash, which was the final test on the ten-event senior program, meant the difference between defeat and victory for Bishop Loughlin High in the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association's twenty-second track and field championships at Madison Square Garden yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 5 (UP) -- House spy hunters said today they may investigate charges that Soviet delegates to the United Nations have engaged in espionage activities in the United States.

Declaring that he had encountered no difficulty in obtaining permission to leave Czechoslovakia, but declining any further comment on political affairs in that country, Vojtech Benes, 72-year-old elder brother of the late President Eduard Benes, and former member of Parliament, arrived here yesterday aboard the United States liner America.

WEST POINT, N.Y. March 5 -Army's swimming team, one of the strongest in the history of the sport at the Military Academy, closed a successful campaign in stirring fashion today by beating Navy, 48 to 27, in their traditional inter-service rivalry.

A "substantial" number of dress and sportswear manufacturers has avoided bankruptcy proceedings since the first of the year by frank discussion of their difficulties with creditors, it was revealed last week by Mortimer J. Davis, executive manager of the New York Credit Men's Association.

In the homestretch of the Basketball Association of America's regular season of sixty games, the Knickerbockers are slated to see plenty of action this week. Listed to face the Washington Capitols at Madison Square Garden Wednesday night, the New Yorkers will tangle with the Baltimore Bullets on Thursday and the Chicago Stags on Saturday.

The new Russian Foreign Minister may get quickly an opportunity to use his language on the United States. Mr. Vishinsky has shown in the past that he is an expert in vituperative defense of his position, good or bad.

A woman analyst employed in the internal security section of the Department of Justice in Washington and a Russian engineer on the United Nations staff, who formerly was an official of the Soviet Foreign Office, were held in high bail here yesterday on suspicion of espionage.

JOE WILMOT, a small-town movie-house operator, is tired of his wife, Elizabeth, and interested in another woman. But Elizabeth will clear out only if Joe and his lady friend aid her in bilking the insurance company of $25,000.
SALT LAKE CITY -- March 5 -- Confronted by an extremely spotty economic picture in their own back yard this week, residents of this region were casting worried glances toward Washington.

THE HAGUE -- Along the flat sandy belt in the lee of the dunes between here and Haarlem there is growing activity each day as tulip time draws near. Next month the drab waste landscape of the North Sea coast will be alive once more with vivid strips of color, and a new season will have blossomed in the Netherlands.

DETROIT, March 5 -- Relying upon its best hydraulic brakes, fog lights, warning signals and non-skid tires, the automobile industry is proceeding cautiously over a transitory mesa between a seller's and a buyer's market.

PARIS -- The Normandy beachheads of World War II are proving to be among the most popular tourist attractions of all Europe. Unfortunately, Normandy has not yet had time to recover from its devastating war experience.

In the fall of 1939 -- just after the Molotov-Ribbentrop Pact and the outbreak of World War II -- Winston Churchill described Russia in these terms: "It is a riddle, wrapped in a mystery inside an enigma."

For the first time in the seventy- two-year history of the Harvard University summer school, students this year will be offered a course taught by the president of the university. President James B. Conant this summer will teach "Science and General Education at the College Level."

ADEN, March 5 -- Royal Air Force planes have blown up Arab forts along the northern borders of the Aden Protectorate on the southwestern tip of Arabia, after a revolt of tribesmen in Yemen, according to reports reaching here tonight.

Fifty pedestrians and two persons in an automobile narrowly escaped death or serious injury yesterday when an explosion from an excavation site between Fifty-fifth and Fifty-sixth Streets on Broadway sent three tons of rocks high into the air and on to the sidewalks.

The fourteenth annual subscription bridge party for the benefit of the Little Sisters of the Assumption will be held Friday night in the grand ballroom of the Hotel Commodore. Many valuable gifts, donated by leading stores and specialty shops, will be distributed to the guests at the party.

To the Music Editor: RECENTLY I read with great interest Gaspar Cassado's press release in which he uses the name of his onetime teacher and my good friend Pablo Casals -- who left Spain in protest against Fascist Franco in 1936.

LONDON, March 5 -- Winston Churchill has agreed to be the chairman of a subscription formed to launch a Jan Masaryk memorial fund, it was announced here today by the United Nations Association of Great Britain and Northern Ireland.

ROME, March 5 -- Right-wing Socialist Senators and Deputies will meet on Monday or Tuesday of next week to decide whether they will support their leader, Giuseppe Saragat, whose motion in favor of Italy's entry into the North Atlantic defense pact was rejected by the party's directorate yesterday.

THE presentation of a program of three ballets by Todd Bolender at the Y.M.H.A. last week was an experiment by the "Y" which turned out most successfully. As a result, a whole series is planned for next season in which young ballet choreographers may present their works under the sponsorship of the organization's Dance Theatre, in much the same manner that young modern dance choreographers have been able to do for the past twelve years.

ALONG what lines is our democracy evolving and to what use shall government be put in achieving the greatest possible freedom and happiness for human beings? These are the questions to which Francis Biddle, our wartime Attorney General, addresses himself in his thoughtful book.

Sales of five homes in the Daylight Homes development in the Lido Canals section of Long Beach, L. I., were reported by Stewart A. Burkland and his son, Howard A. Bprkland, the sponsors, as follows: Martin Monganelle, 67 Dalton Street; Bernard Silversmith, 54 Kerrigan Street; Gilbert Ziering, 57 Dalton Street; Harold Zerfuss, 65 Kerrigan Street and Seymour Green, 55 Boyd Street.

BERLIN, March 6 -- Nowhere has the reshuffle in the Soviet Foreign Office caused a greater sensation than in Berlin. Since Berliners regard their city as the focal point of East-West conflict, they immediately connect changes in the Moscow high command with effects of the blockade.

The shift in the top command of the Soviet Government, in particular the replacement of Mr. Molotov with Mr. Vishinsky as Foreign Minister, has unleashed such a flood of speculations land varying interpretations as to its meaning that it has thrown the world into new confusion and uncertainty.

It's just about a case of "wait till next year" for the New York Rangers now. Lynn Patrick's Blue Shirts were practically put out of National Hockey League play-off consideration at Madison Square Garden last night when the Toronto Maple Leafs handed them a 4-to-3 setback.
In the expectation that retail toy volume this year will equal the high levels of 1947 and 1948, the American Toy Fair will open here today with more than ten acres of new playthings.
Fifty thousand veterans of World War II have attended special classes for high school diplomas certificates, refesher courses and vocational training, the Board of Education announced yesterday.

On Feb. 8 the management of "Edward, My Son" made known that George Sanders had been engaged to succeed Robert Morley on April 25. At present things are far from being that definite. Over the week-end the Broadway grapevine reported that Mr. Sanders had undergone a change of heart and was seeking a release from his commitment.

WASHINGTON, March 6 --Representative Hugh D. Scott Jr., Republican national chairman, declared today that the Democratic record of performance on campaign promises to date "presents conclusive evidence that the American people bought another gold brick last November."

Last week the Congressional Joint Committee on the Economic Report, on a strictly party vote, approved a toned-down version of the Administration's so-called "anti-inflation" program. In the course of so doing it summed up the philosophy of that program very much as the authors of the latter would probably have done themselves.

PARIS, March 6 -- It was stated here tonight that the French Government expected to reach an agreement early this week with Bao Dai, former Emperor of Anham, for the constitution of a new state of Viet Nam in Indo-China. The agreement was expected to take the form of an exchange of letters between Bao Dai and President Vincent Auriol in his capacity as President of the French Union, or Commonwealth.

CHICAGO, March 6 -- Government loans on corn as of Feb. 1 aggregated 148,000,000 bushels, the largest in some years, but this figure is expected to be increased materially before June 30, the deadline for making application for loans, unless there is a drastic advance in prices.

WASHINGTON, March 6 (UP) -- The House Republican leader, Joseph W. Martin Jr. of Massachussets, today questioned the need for extreme secrecy on the so-called "hush-hush" spy bill to legalize the country's new espionage organization.

WASHINGTON, March 6 (UP) -- Nearly $9,000,000 of contracts to clear the way for completion of Grand Coulee Dam as the world's biggest power producer were announced today by J. A. Krug, Secretary of the Interior.

NANKING, March 6 -- The newspaper National Salvation Daily was suspended indefinitely and its publisher arrested by Nanking garrison headquarters today following the publication of two editorials demanding that President Chiang Kai-shek cease his alleged behind - the - scenes "manipulation" of political affairs and "go abroad."

Outstanding performances by swift invaders from Europe marked the post-Olympic indoor track campaign, but America was not without its own heroes in board-track competition, which ended in the East last Saturday night with the Knights of Columbus meet here and the Heptagonal championships in Boston.

Breaking all records for continuous play in international chess competition, the New York Stock Exchange, encountering the stiffest sort of opposition in its return match by radio teletype with the Amsterdam Stock Exchange, succeeded in scoring a 5-5 tie.

CINCINNATI, March 6 (AP) -- Mac F. Cahal of Kansas City, executive secretary of the American Academy of General Practice, today pledged, the organization's solid support to the American Medical Association's fight against "socialized medicine."

MOSCOW, March 6 (UP) -- Komsomolskaya Pravda, the Communist youth organ, continued the campaign against "cosmopolitanism," and failure to concentrate on Russian and Communistic interests in the field of Soviet sports writing.

A new marine terminal on city-owned property but requiring no financial outlay by the city is rising on the East River at Thirty-third Street, it was announced yesterday by G. Joseph Minetti, Commissioner of Marine and Aviation.

ROME, March 6 (UP) -- Italy's Left - Wing Socialists formally joined forces with the Communists today to fight this country's participation in the proposed Atlantic pact, and the Leftist bloc announced it would seek a no-confidence vote in the Government's pro-Western policy.
Ten new films, including importations from England, France and Italy, are slated to open in midtown theatres this week. The programs follow:

Andrew Frierson of Louisville, Ky., who made his New York debut yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Recital Hall, is a young baritone who gives promise of being a fine concert artist. He already has the essential attributes -- a beautiful voice, good technique, musicianship, sympathy and a fine presence.
WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP) -- Two Republican members of the House Veterans Committee today proposed limiting veterans' pensions to former servicemen actually in need.

An estimated $16,700,000 was spent by hardware dealers throughout the country for advertising in 1948, it was announced over the week-end by Fred R. Olmstead, advertising and promotion manager of the National Retail Hardware Association, Indianapolis.

Preaching the first in a series of Lenten sermons at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral, Msgr. Fulton J. Sheen of the faculty of Catholic University declared yesterday that the passion of Christ "in His physical body" continues today in attacks upon the church, withdrawals from it, and "betrayals from within."

Acting both as raconteur and pianist, Henry Cowell, the composer, presented a program of his own music last night at Times Hall that illustrated the way he sought to develop more kinds of tone qualities from the piano between 1915 and 1928 when he was specializing in that instrument.
Two top leaders of the Communist party likened themselves yesterday to Lincoln and Jefferson as patriots fighting for peace and criticized President Truman for having called them "traitors."

Fifteen minutes in the oven and two new pre-cooked frozen foods -- French fried shrimps and French fried scallops -- are ready to serve. This abbreviated preparation time isn't the only point that recommends Louis L. Libby's seafood products for Lenten menus.

Spurred by the warnings of the National Security Resources Board as well as by population shifts and other changes in the national economy, American industry has been carrying out for some time a program of plant dispersal that extends from coast to coast.

MIAMI, Fla., March 6 -- In one of the early races on Getaway Day at Hialeah, Ted Atkinson came charging up the homestretch on board some goat who didn't have a chance in the world of winning. It was only a claiming race of little consequence. But Ted produced a ride such as he might have fashioned with a leg up on Citation in the Kentucky Derby.

Heida Hermanns, German-born pianist who made her New York debut about seven years ago, gave a recital, part of which was broadcast, late yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall. Featured on the program was Dussek's Sonata in F sharp minor, Op. 61, which was outstanding not only for its intrinsic interest but for the authoritative interpretation it received.
Borough President Hugo E. Rogers of Manhattan will turn over to the Traffic Commission this week a list of his projects for Manhattan traffic improvement.

MONT TREMBLANT, Que., March 6 (Canadian Press) -France's daring ski runners, repeating their performance in last week's Dominion championships, today captured the first five places in the famed Kandahar combined race.

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 6 --Leo Durocher sent his entire Giant squad into action today before a gathering of 6,500 spectators and the result was a bizarre display that went nine innings and three hours by the clock.

Presiding Justice David W. Peck of the Appellate Division appealed to the public last night for support of his plan for court reorganization in this city, embodied in an amended Williamson - Brook bill about to be presented to the Legislature.
Clothing for the growing boy is in the spring "Merry Mite" collection on the children's floor of B. Altman Co.

The observance of "Port of New York Day" affords a real opportunity to draw public attention to the "rundown condition" of this port and the need for immediate corrective steps, Paul G. Boise, president of the Foreign Commerce Club of New York, declared yesterday.
Mildred Victor, pianist, gave her first New York recital yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. Possessing strong, sure fingers, she was able to give a clean, accurate account of the works presented.

Children should not be sent to nursery school immediately after the birth of a new brother or sister. A toddler who is slow to talk will not turn into a little chatterbox merely from associating with children who speak well. The child who is insecure and unresponsive because of a basic weakness in his attachment to his mother will not gain confidence from being sent to a nursery group.

BOSTON, March 6 -- In a series of rulings during the filing of interrogatories in the Government's anti-trust suit against the United Shoe Machinery Corporation Judge Charles E. Wyzanski Jr. of the Boston Federal District Court has been credited with putting into effect important modifications to streamline the usually ponderous legal procedure in such cases.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 6 -- "Look at that: How's that for neatness on a job done only seven weeks ago?"

ABOVE the roar and clash of arms there now loomed upon us a world-fateful event of a different order. The Presidential election took place on November 5 [1940]. In spite of the tenacity and vigour with which these four-yearly contests are conducted, and the bitter differences on domestic issues which at this time divided the two main parties, the Supreme Cause was respected by the responsible leaders, Republicans and Democrats alike.
LONDON, March 6 (AP) -- Russian designers have finally reached a compromise with the West. They say they have adopted the "new look" while avoiding the "standardized doll" appearance for women.

The Government will explain today to a grand jury here why a Russian engineer attached to the United Nations staff and an American woman employed by the Department of Justice were arrested Friday evening on suspicion of espionage.

The failure of Sydenham Hospital to rally sufficient funds to continue operation as an interracial voluntary hospital in Harlem should not dampen the enthusiasm of supporters in this city who sought to prove by example that the day of overt discrimination against Negro physicians in the matter of training and a place to practice was drawing to an end.

SHANGHAI, March 6 -- Travellers reaching this city from Communist-held towns on the north bank of the Yangtze River tell of the intensive indoctrination of troops for the crossing and a drive southward past Shanghai toward Hangchow.

CHICAGO, March 6 -- Liberal tenders of cash lard on March contracts on the Board of Trade led last week to liquidation in that delivery and the price dropped to a new low since early February before the break was checked by short covering induced by reports the Government was in the market for 12,000,000 pounds of prime steam lard.

The Kennecott Copper Corporation had last year a consolidated net income of $93,806,919 after all charges, including the expense of a strike and shutdown, but before charges for depletion of mines, according to its thirty-fourth annual report, released for publication today.

The proposed Atlantic Pact was described yesterday by the Rev. Donald Harrington staff minister of the Community Church, 40 East Thirty-fifth Street, as "unnecessary, dangerous, and a piddling around with the peace."

ROSLYN, L. I., March 6 -- If William J. Levitt, Long Island mass building contractor, had any illusions about the end of the housing shortage, they were rudely dispelled this morning when he found nearly 300 home-hungry veterans camping on the doorstep of his model home here.

John L. Flynn, New York attorney, said last night that suits totaling millions of dollars would be filed against organized baseball soon in behalf of major league players who jumped to the Mexican League, The Associated Press reported.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- The Administration's bill to increase the the minimum wage requirement of the Fair Labor Standards Act from 40 cents an hour to 75 cents appeared to be in danger in the House Labor and Public Welfare Committee, a check of some members of the committee disclosed tonight.

Federal Judge Harold R. Medina will mount the bench in the United States Court House in Foley Square at 10:30 A. M. today and the much-delayed trial proceedings of eleven top Communist leaders will get under way.

The State Federation of Labor vigorously opposes any reduction in Governor Dewey's budget that would eliminate road and public building construction because more than 25,000 men would be thrown out of work by such action, Thomas A. Murray, president of the federation, announced in New York yesterday.

LONDON, March 6 -- Although he said that some persons would not believe him, John Strachey, Minister of Food, said today that the amount of food available to Britons was only ten calories a day less than before the war, when the average was 3,000 calories.

The threat of a New Jersey bread strike was put off for at least a week yesterday when union officials decided to submit an employer wage offer to a vote by 1,800 bakery drivers at meetings to be held throughout the state.

PHILADELPHIA, March 6 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Stock Exchange -- America's oldest -- will get a new name tomorrow and expand its territory to serve a population of more than 7,000,000. The merged Philadelphia and Baltimore exchanges will begin formal operations as the Philadelphia-Baltimore Stock Exchange.

American Airlines has retired from service all its DC-3 transport airplanes with the exception of three milk-runners which are slated to go April 1. While the "Doug" has years of scheduled flying ahead of it, the shift to Convair airliners by one of the nation's largest carriers cannot fail to mark an era for the aircraft which has been the workhorse of the airlines since 1933.

NEW DELHI, India, March 6 -- Another Asian conference may meet "in the next month or two," Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru told a press conference today. Pandit Nehru was chairman of the first meeting of nineteen Asian nations here on Jan. 20.

The League of Composers concert at the Museum of Modern Art last night was distinguished by the performance of Leon Kirchner's Duo for Violin and Piano. The one-movement composition was a mature conception fully realized, and received a performance of rare beauty by Broadus Erle, violinist, and the composer at the piano.

Twin boys, 5 years old, died yesterday and eight other persons were burned or injured in a flash-fire in an old-law tenement at 328 East Fifty-ninth Street, directly across the street from the south side ramp leading to the Queensboro Bridge.

Many things are exceptionally good in anticipation. Christmas is good, and vacation, and the evening that is arranged for the theatre. A visit to the dentist is not, generally speaking, quite up to par. Saturday afternoon is good, and all of Sunday, and the party being held Friday night. Blue Monday is bad.

In the opinion of many who reviewed last Friday the spring and summer collection at the Hattie Carnegie Salon, 42 East Forty-ninth Street, Miss Carnegie has crowned all her previous efforts for many a season. In the wealth of rich and original ideas there was no doubting her abilities as a perfectionist and fashion figure.

The majority of stores restrict charge account privileges when an account is between sixty and ninety days delinquent and refer it to a special collection department when it is more than six months overdue. This was one of the findings of a nation-wide survey conducted by A. L. Trotta, manager of the credit management division of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, announced over the week-end.

SAVANNAH Ga., March 6 -- The first step in Georgia's program to recapture its former position as a principal port terminal for Southeastern trade and water commerce has already produced results in this famous old port city.

Belief in the Lord as both human and divine affords "untold comfort" in the present "noisy" world, Canon Frederic Hood, principal of Pusey House, Oxford, England, said yesterday in a sermon at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 6 -- The national convention of the Young Women's Christian Association, which opens here tomorrow, is not scheduled to take direct action on a resolution last week by the Y. W. C. A. of Atlantic City, N. J., to disaffiliate from the parent body.

LEIPZIG, Germany, March 6 (AP) -- The 700-year-old Leipzig Fair opened today in a swirling snowstorm that reduced the attendance to 20,000. Eighty thousand had been counted on. Only a sprinkling came from the West to this ancient city, deep in the Soviet zone.

THE TIMES of Feb. 24 reports the dismissal of a professor from Oregon State University for supporting the teachings of Lysenko. The president of the institution is reported as saying: "Any scientist who has such poor power of discrimination so as to choose to support Lysenko's genetics against all the weight of evidence is not much of a scientist or has lost the freedom that an instructor should possess."

LAKE SUCCESS, March 6 -- The Gubitchev case could hardly have come at a worse time, as far as relations between the United Nations and the United States Congress are concerned. United Nations officials acknowledged today that the spy charges were certain to make it harder to obtain Congressional approval of two measures that are of vital importance in establishing the permanent headquarters of the organization in New York.

PARIS, March 6 -- The Marshall Plan Steering Committee for Europe, led by Sir Stafford Cripps of Britain, Robert Schuman of France and Paul-Henri Spaak of Belgium, will complete tomorrow a report that will urge steps toward closer cooperation, but will amount to a tacit abandonment of the project for a common recovery plan for Europe.

A redoubled assault on the problem of developing an effective vaccine against infantile paralysis will open today. To mobilize scientists in universities and hospitals in every part of the United States for a concerted drive to isolate and identify the "family of viruses" that causes poliomyelitis, the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis will expend $2,565,159 in March of Dimes funds during the current year, it was announced yesterday.

A volume of air freight equivalent in weight and revenue to the volume of passenger business is predicted for the airlines of the United States in 1955 in a survey by the Civil Aeronautics Administration that is being distributed among airport planners and others.
SAN JUAN, P. R., March 6 (UP) -- Sugar industry workers were scheduled to strike at midnight tonight after the failure of attempts to settle their wage dispute.

VIENNA, Feb. 18 -- Last New Year's Day Gheorghe Gheorghiu-Dej, secretary general of the Rumanian Communist party, declared that the present Rumanian Republic was only a transitional state that must make way for a Socialist republic of the Soviet type.

Mrs. Clare Boothe Luce, playwright, former member of Congress and convert to Catholicism, proposed yesterday that the Catholic Church pattern a program for conversion on the mushrooming tactics of the Pyramid Friendship Clubs.
STOCKHOLM, March 6 (AP) -U. S. and Swedish hockey players threw punches at each other again today and once more police had to be called to calm both the participants and spectators.

Up in the North Country, beyond Kingsbridge Road, the Equity Library Theatre has been doing big things over the week-end. With an unsalaried but enthusiastic cast and staff it has undertaken the production of the musical, "Pal Joey." A delighted audience at the Walton Community Center proved last night that the presentation was welcome.
WASHINGTON, March 6 -- The votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls during the period, Feb. 26 to March 4, are given in the appended tabulation:

Good buying of the Canadian free dollar lifted that currency to 93.44 cents, last week, a new peak since October 8, last. Buying originated with out of town banks and was later shared by local institutions. The combination quickly accounted for the advance. Supply was noticeably light.

ALBANY, March 6 -- Robert Moses, New York City construction coordinator, upbraided critics of Governor Dewey's fiscal program today for suggesting that funds for highway and parkway construction be reduced or eliminated.

The John and Mary R. Markle Foundation, 14 Wall Street, has named thirteen medical scientists as the second group of "Scholars in Medical Science" as part of a five-year program to keep young doctors on teaching and research staffs of medical schools, it was announced yesterday.

Proxy statements, detailing the terms of the consent decree recently signed with the Department of Justice and outlining a plan of reorganization in line with that action, were mailed over the weekend to stockholders of Paramount Pictures, Inc.
PARIS, March 6 -- The Metal Workers Council of the Communist-dominated General Confederation of Labor today denounced alleged shipments of French raw materials to German armaments plants.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 6 -- Price controls were used at least 3,800 years ago in the ancient Babylonian kingdom of Eshnunna, according to a translation of what is believed to be the oldest code of laws in the world, made public here today.

LONDON, March 6 -- In the last few days a break in the stock markets here has occurred which has been likened to the violence in which Wall Street sometimes indulges and which happily the London market has been spared for many months.

Recommendations designed to govern Japanese trade-marks, patents and copyrights in the postwar era and to prevent evasions, fraud or piracy in their use, were submitted to the Departments of State, Army and Commerce last week by the Far East-America Council of Commerce and Industry.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 6 ((AP)) -- Pete Cooper made an eagle three on the last hole to win the $10,000 St. Petersburg open golf tourney today.

Asserting that questions raised by the "cold war" were disturbing because "it has yet to be proved that all the right answers are in our favor," the Rev. Franklin P. Cole, pastor of the Congregational Church - in - the - Gardens, Forest Hills, Queens, said in his sermon yesterday morning that he nevertheless believed that they would be so proved in time.

The letter from Rabbi D. de Sola Pool printed in your issue of Feb. 23 gives encouraging evidence that there are spiritual leaders among the Jews of America who recognize the terrible plight of the Palestinian Arab refugees and want to do something about it.

LONDON, March 6 -- The dispute between the South African Government and the International Monetary Fund which has developed out of the former's sale of industrial gold at a premium is being followed with keen interest in London. Much more, it is coming to be felt, is involved in this tussle than just South Africa's attempt to get out of economic difficulties into which she has been plunged.

Wagner's "Parsifal" will be the featured work of the Metropolitan Opera's sixteenth and final week of its subscription season, it was announced yesterday. The work will be given on March 18, with Fritz Reiner conducting and Charles Kullman singing the title role for the first time.

The twenty-fourth annual Eastern States contract bridge championships tournament got under way yesterday afternoon at the Park Sheraton Hotel. Eighty-four pairs entered the mixed pair contest, the first event on the tournament program.

LONDON, March 6 (UP) -- An authoritative article in the Yugoslav Communist party newspaper organ Borba said today that the United States and Britain blocked in 1944 a secret Yugoslav-Bulgarian agreement that would have developed into a Balkan federation.

MEXICO CITY, March 6 (UP) -Antonio Bermudez, director general of Petroleos Mexicanos, announced last night the signing of a drilling contract with a group formed by Edwin W. Pauley, California oil man, the American Independent Oil Company and the Signal Oil Company.
Arthur H. Rogow has resigned as president of Eversharp, Inc., effective on April 1.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 6 -- Alfred Hitchcock will leave for England next month to prepare for production there of "Stage Fright," a melodrama based on Selwyn Jepson's novel, "Man Running," in which Jane Wyman will star. Hitchcock will produce and direct the picture for Warner Brothers.

TEL AVIV, March 6 -- In accordance with the current practice here of reverting to Hebrew family names or selecting Hebrew equivalents, Moshe Shertok formally changed his name to Sharet. The name Shertok, of Russian origin, means "little devil."

The Manhattan Chamber Orchestra, another young and competent group of musicians, made its first downtown appearance at Carnegie Recital Hall Saturday night. Charles Schiff was the conductor in a program that included two first New York concert performances.

WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP) -United States oil men said today that their contract with the Mexican Government to drill for oil in Mexico opened "the way to far-reaching progress in hemisphere security and self-sufficiency."

LARCHMONT, N. Y., March 6 -- Snapping back into the spring series at the Larchmont Yacht Club after visiting team competition, forty-two craft raced today. They engaged in ten contests under a snappy north-northwest breeze of from fourteen to seventeen miles an hour strength.

The real enemies of the Church are not the Communists, who seek openly to obstruct its work, but "so-called Christians" who are indifferent to their church responsibilities, the Rev. Albert L. Neibacher, pastor of St. Luke's Evangelical Lutheran Church, 308 West Forty-sixth Street, declared in his morning sermon yesterday.

Armed with a Supreme Court order forbidding continuance of the Yonkers municipal employes' strike, officials of that city will make a new effort today to find ways of removing the eight-day accumulation of garbage, ashes and industrial waste before it becomes a threat to the health of Yonkers' 150,000 residents.

James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians, AFL, announced yesterday that the union had appropriated $1,400,212 to finance its program of free public music during the remainder of 1949 and next year.

Declaring that "normal decency is not enough," the Rev. Martin A. Klingberg, pastor of the Rutgers Presbyterian Church, Broadway and Seventy-third Street, said in his morning sermon yesterday that "that very decency may be the thing that frustrates your life."

The Long Island Lighting Company's annual report, which is being distributed today to stockholders, shows a net income of $2,509,697 for 1948, a gain of $628,807 over the $1,879,890 reported for 1947.

Eighteen hundred employes in the big Sunshine Biscuit bakery in Long Island City have transferred their union affiliation from the Congress of Industrial Organizations to the American Federation of Labor, Joseph Kane, president of the Sunshine local, announced yesterday.

ALBANY, March 6 -- A new low death rate of 10.8 per 1,000 of population in New York was established in 1948, the State Health Department announced today. The 1947 death rate was 11.1. The department recorded the deaths of 157,948 persons last year.

LAKE SUCCESS, March 6 -- A second attempt will be made this year to interest Americans in the world-wide fund campaign of the United Nations for the relief of needy children in war-devasted countries, it was disclosed today.

KEY WEST, Fla., March 6 -- President Truman "interviewed" Robert G. Nixon, president of the White House Correspondents Association, here this afternoon about the removal of Vyacheslav M. Molotov as Russian Foreign Minister.

CAIRO, Egypt, March 6 -- Egypt's new Foreign Minister, Ahmed Khashaba Pasha, declared here tonight that his country wanted to establish its relations with Britain on a foundation of mutual cooperation. British-Egyptian relations are considered here to be the cornerstone of peace and order in the Middle East.

OPELOUSAS, La., March 6 -A 25-year-old Negro, kidnapped from the St. Landry Parish Prison and on the verge of being lynched, jumped into the Atchafalaya River today and escaped while the leaders of a mob matched coins to see who would be his executioner.

HONOLULU, March 6 -- Bill Odom, around-the-world flier, took off from the Honolulu Airport at 7:04 P. M. tonight (12:04 A. M., Monday, New York time) on his second attempt to fly 5,010 miles non-stop to Teterboro, N. J., in a one-engined Beechcraft Bonanza plane.

The Rev. William Howard Melish, chairman of the National Council of American-Soviet Friendship, defended his concept of an active Christian ministry in a sermon yesterday morning in the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Holy Trinity, Clinton and Montague Streets, Brooklyn, of which he is the assistant rector.

LONDON, March 6 -- With a demonstration at Albert Hall tonight, Labor party supporters in London opened their campaign for the municipal elections to be held in April and May. The elections, a nation-wide test of strength between the Labor and Conservative parties, will be watched for indications of the trend in the next general election for Parliament, which will be held about a year later.

WEST ORANGE, N. J., March 6 -- A snappy imported wire-haired foxterrier that took the event a year ago, Champion Chief Barmaid, repeated as best-in-show winner of the third and biggest all-breed competition of the Twin Brooks Kennel Club today.
BIG MOUNTAIN, Mont., March 6 (AP) -- George Macomber, 21-year-old amateur from West Newton, Mass., won the National combined downhill-slalom ski championship today.
The Long Island Rail Road confirmed last night statements made previously only by spokesmen for a labor union that the company had instituted heavy lay-offs among its non-operating personnel.

WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP) -- The $5,580,000,000 European Recovery Program must be spelled out in more detail before it can be taken to the Senate floor for approval, Senator Walter F. George, Democrat, of Georgia, said today.

Representative Schuyler Otis Bland, chairman of the House Committee on Merchant Marine and Fisheries, gave assurance to the shipping industry yesterday that the committee would make every effort to complete an early legislative program for the merchant marine.

VERO BEACH, Fla., March 6 -- Although his feat wasn't quite on a par with Cookie Lavagetto's wrecking of Bill Bevens' no-hitter in the 1947 world series, another athlete gained some fame of the same brand here today.

The New York Americans defeated the Brooklyn Hispanos, 3 -- 1, in an American Soccer League game at Hawthorne Field yesterday. The victory enabled the Americans to tie the Philadelphia Nationals for first place.

WASHINGTON, March 6 (UP) -- Senator Connally asserted today that the Molotov-Vishinsky diplomatic shift would not cause this nation to "budge one inch" from its all-out support of the North Atlantic security alliance.

Between 850,000 and 900,000 refugees from Palestine present "a great point of danger in the modern social fabric which it is impossible to exaggerate," the Rev. Dr. Bayard Dodge, president emeritus of the American University in Beirut, Lebanon, declared yesterday at the morning service of the Collegiate Reformed Church of St. Nicholas, Fifth Avenue and Forty-eighth Street.

Mozart's "The Marriage of Figaro" was presented Saturday night at the Metropolitan Opera House. All of the principals had been heard previously in their respective roles, except Anne Bollinger, who assumed the part of Cherubino for the first time with the company.

AMSTERDAM, March 6 -- The Amsterdam Stock Exchange for the past weeks has come under fairly heavy selling pressure, with substantial losses along the whole line, so that the general share average at the end of February was 151, against 157 at the end of January and 178 at the end of July last.

ZURICH, March 6 -- At an extraordinary general meeting of shareholders of the Internationale Industrie und Handelsbeteiligunden A. G. -- popularly known as Interhandel -- held in Basle on March 5, all resolutions submitted by the board of directors were carried.

In a listless market prices of active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange last week moved within a narrow and irregular range. At the close of trading on Saturday the list showed no change to a decline of 29 points, compared with an advance of 23 points to a decline of 17 points in the preceding week.

BUENOS AIRES, March 6 -- The downfall of Miguel Miranda as Argentina's economic "czar" was precipitated by Senator Dennis Chavez of New Mexico as the result of a small dinner party in the suburb of Vicente Lopez on Dec. 22, this correspondent is now in a position to reveal.

Many supporters of fair employment in New York State will applaud the opening and question the seeming final conclusion of THE TIMES' editorial, "Against Discrimination," appearing in the issue of Feb. 28.

MANY novelists have a feeling for words, a gift for story-telling and personal knowledge (usually acquired in youth) of some particular aspect of contemporary life. Not so many combine expert literary craftsmanship with uncommon insight into both private and public character. Private character is the customary theme of fiction, its emotional, personal, intellec tual problems.

A study of why people kill and how murder can be prevented, written by Dr. Fredric Wertham, author of "Dark Legend," will be issued by Doubleday on May 5. "The Show of Violence" also discusses the role of the psychiatrist in the courtroom and the law's inadequacy in dealing with the psychiatric facts of murder.

WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP) -- The State Department will have to put a cost tag on the proposed North Atlantic security agreement before the Senate will approve it, Senator Walter F. George, Democrat, of Georgia, said today.

The Vienna Choir Boys, who had not appeared in this city since 1938, presented a program last night at Carnegie Hall. The group of twenty-one singers ranging from 7 to 14 years of age were heard in a program which featured Offen-bach's one-act comic opera, "Mons. et Madame Denis," but also contained sacred and secular choral compositions.
Memories of prohibition days were revived yesterday when detectives walked into a Brooklyn home and arrested the last survivor of the Clutching Hand gang that flourished in the dry twenties.
Dr. Chaim Weizmann, first President of Israel, and David Ben-Gurion, Prime Minister in his Cabinet, called yesterday on all Jews in the United States for help in Israel's development.

An impressive concert of his own compositions was given by Alan Hovhaness, the Armenian-American composer, yesterday afternoon in Town Hall. The principal performers were the Columbia University and Barnard Choruses, Maro Ajemian, pianist; Anahid Ajemian, violinist, and John Powell, baritone, and an orchestra of thirty-five musicians.

For the second year in a row, the American National Theatre and Academy hit the bull's eye with its annual benefit the "ANTA Album," last night at the Ziegfeld Theatre. Entertainers galore appeared in a program consisting in the main of memorable scenes of famous shows of yesteryear.

PARIS, Feb. 26 -- Two of France's fundamental requirements in the battle for economic recovery are the discovery of new sources of certain basic raw materials, such as oil, and an increase of the available national labor force, presumably by immigration.

CAIRO, March 6 -- A sharp warning has been given here that the prosperity of Egypt is seriously threatened by a situation that has developed in cotton, which accounts for 70 per cent of the country's foreign trade. The diplomatic community emphasizes that an economic setback to Egypt now could have most serious political consequences for the entire Middle East.

Development of Sprain Valley in Westchester County as a state park and parkway to relieve congestion in other county parks and to provide traffic relief on the Bronx River Parkway was recommended yesterday by the New York State Council of Parks in a report issued by Robert Moses, its chairman.

TOKYO, March 6 -- The expected "labor offensive" against the Conservative government of Premier Shigeru Yoshida now has begun with strikes or threats of strikes in several of Japan's key industries. These include electric power, railroad transportation and shipping trades.

CHICAGO, March 6 -- Grain prices moved upward in the early trading on the Board of Trade last week under the stimulus of the Government's aggressive buying of cash wheat and corn. May wheat at the top showed a recovery of 24 cents a bushel and corn 25 3/4 cents from the low in February, but the markets eased again when the demand let up.

Although response to promotions continued good, activity in the wholesale apparel market here last week was slow and reorders were on the conservative side, according to reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

BERLIN, March 6 -- The United States will reject Marshal Vassily D. Sokolovsky's demand that Russian restitution teams be admitted into the United States zone, American military government officials said today. Marshal Sokolovsky's letter to Gen. Lucius D. Clay, United States Military Governor, released early this morning by ADN, the Soviet-licensed news service, purports to be a Russian attempt to speed recovery of materiel taken from Russia during the war.

In a leading investment deal reported over the week-end, the nine-story apartment house for fifty-four families at 250 Riverside Drive, northeast corner of Ninety-seventh Street, was sold by 250 R. S. D. Corporation to the Ninety-seventh and Riverside Corporation for cash over a mortgage of $220,000.

Phil Watson's New York Rovers wound up their Quebec Senior Hockey League season in rousing fashion at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon. Connecting for two goals in the third period, the Red Shirts did themselves proud in handing the Valleyfield Braves a 4-2 thumping before 8,412 satisfied customers.

A program under which relief applicants in this city were referred to jobs through the State Employment Service may be adopted throughout the state, Industrial Commissioner Edward Corsi reported yesterday. He said that he had suggested the move to State Welfare Commissioner Robert T. Lansdale after a six-month study.
WASHINGTON, March 6 -- The National Labor Relations Board announced today its unanimous decision that a strike for a closed-shop clause in a union contract violates the Taft-Hartley labor law.

GUATEMALA, March 6 -- Foreign Minister Enrique Munoz Meany in a press statement last night said the Government of Guatemala strongly regretted that the United States was not participating in the forthcoming Havana Conference on American territories and dependencies.
CHICAGO, March 6 -- The frozen foods industry this year is expected to increase substantially its production over its pack of 1;125,000,000 pounds in 1948.
OMAHA, Neb., March 6 -- Despite extensive local overflowing of rivers, the general flood situation in the Missouri River Valley appeared good to official observers today.

The President has moved quickly to strengthen the hand of his new Secretary of Defense by transmitting to Congress in a special message his recommendations for changes in the National Security Act of 1947, under which the Department of National Defense was organized.

LOS ANGELES, March 6 -- The case of Charles G. Glenn, graduate student who checked a book out of the University of California library here on Saturday when nobody was around, and wound up in jail, was under study today.

Offers of higher prices for Indian manganese ores by the Supreme Command of the Allied Powers (SCAP) in Japan are competing with the stockpiling program of the American Government and industry here, and constitute a major reason why supplies of manganese from India to the United States are decreasing, according to Ralph R. Feuerring, vice president of the Ferro Metal and Chemical Corporation, 50 Broad Street.

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 6 -- Confronted by a water shortage which threatens a drastic curtailment in agriculture, one of the state's main-sources of income, Arizona leaders are marshaling renewed support for one of the most ambitious projects in the forty-seven-year history of federal reclamation work.
PITTSBURGH, March 6 -- Finished steel output last week was running at new high levels. This condition resulted from the unusually high and sustained output of steel ingots in the last eight weeks.

Two suspects in a $20,000 midtown jewelry hold-up were arrested yesterday by detectives of the West Forty-seventh Street station because one's appearance betrayed him to the robbery victim, the police said.

Chuck Taylor, welterweight battler from Coalport, Pa., defeated Patsy Brandino of Hamilton, Ont., in the feature bout of ten rounds at the St. Nicholas Arena last night. The fight was a dull one, with the crowd of 1,038 frequently clamoring for action.

WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP) -- Senator Herbert R. O'Conor of Maryland proposed today that the Senate declare itself opposed to "unrestricted diplomatic immunity" for foreigners who come to this country on United Nations business.

Now that Soviet Art, an official Moscow publication, has excoriated the "bourgeois tendencies" of the Russian circus, the Young Man on the Flying Trapeze will have to leap through the air and hang by his feet in the true Marxian way if he is not to lose his job.

Five top-ranking detective commanders were shifted yesterday by Police Commissioner William P. O'Brien in a move that was interpreted as trying in part to curb the continuing racketeering and crime along the city's waterfronts.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- The Federal Trade Commission said today that legislation, proposed in both Houses of Congress, to provide a moratorium on new prosecutions of business for absorbing freight on an individual basis was "neither necessary nor desirable."

MAPLEWOOD, N. J., March 7 -- Essex County authorities held a 15-year-old boy here today on suspicion of murder in the fatal shooting last Friday of his 16year-old companion, Fred Januszkiewicz, of Newark.
TUCSON, Ariz., March 7 (AP) -President Bill Veeck of the Cleveland Indians virtually eliminated his holdout problem today, five players agreeing to terms.

HUNTINGTON, L. I., March 7 -- One of the North Shore's most beautiful harbors, although one of the trickiest to navigate, is being widened, deepened and generally turned upside down by a long-term dredging operation. The benefits will accrue chiefly to yachtsmen, but their gain, it turns out, will be shared with the United Nations.
NANKING, Tuesday, March 8 -- China's Premier, Dr. Sun Fo, announced today the resignation of his Nationalist Cabinet.

Two new films will arrive in first-run theatres this morning. At the Mayfair the attraction is "The Red Pony," John Steinbeck's adaptation of his short story, with Robert Mitchum, Myrna Loy, Peter Miles and Louis Calhern heading the cast.
An appeal to schools to abolish homework to allow children to be free at home "for the important business of a child's life -- play," was made yesterday by Pearl S. Buck, the novelist.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 7 -- Dissolution of the Waterfront Employers Association of the Pacific Coast and the Pacific American Shipowners Association was recommended today by their respective directorates. It was suggested that a new organization -- the Pacific Maritime Association -- replace the two groups, effective on April 1.
HALLANDALE, Fla., March 7 (AP) -- Speedy Lee, a $46.20-for-$2 shot from Milton Shagrin's barn, survived a four-way nose finish to win today's Coconut Grove purse before 15,387 at Gulfstream Park.

Kentucky, the Blue Grass basketball boys who ran off with the Southeastern Conference tournament last week and who are aiming at two national tourneys, completely dominated the final Associated Press basketball ranking poll for the 1948-49 season.

Six weeks of negotiations between the Port of New York Authority and eight airlines seeking to use New York International Airport at Idlewild have been fruitless, it was learned last night. It was suggested by some persons familiar with the discussions that a solution would be to return the controversy to Justice Thomas J. Cuff of the Supreme Court in Jamaica.

Buyers' market problems likely to affect brand names and advertising will be examined by twenty-six leaders in national sales promotion, retailing, research, employe education and community promotion during Brand Names Day meetings April 12 at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, it was announced yesterday.

Appointment of 175 men as cadet-midshipmen in the United States Merchant Marine Cadet Corps was announced yesterday at the United States Merchant Marine Academy, Kings Points, L. I. The men were selected after a nationwide written competitive examination.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores declined 11 per cent last week compared with the corresponding week last year, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The decline for the four weeks ended last Saturday was 6 per cent.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 7 -- Unless it protects "fundamental rights," no society is "truly satisfactory for mankind," President Truman said in a message to the National Catholic Conference on Family Life, which opened here today.

LONDON, March 7 -- From the end of the war to April, 1950, Polish servicemen who came to Britain after having fought on Western war fronts will have cost this country the equivalent of $442,000,000. Of the 114,037 who came here, fewer than 9,000 have returned to Poland.

For the fifth successive year the St. Regis Paper Company and its subsidiaries increased its sales, with the volume for 1948 reaching a new peak of $162,672,926, compared with $143,864,583 in 1947, the annual report revealed yesterday.

CAIRO, Egypt, March 7 -- Egyptian Minister of Commerce Mahmoud Riad said tonight that the new agreement that the Egyptian Government initialed today with the Suez Canal Company provided that nine out of every ten administrative posts in the Suez Canal organization and four out of every five technical posts be held by Egyptians.

Use of city-wide television networks to carry spot news, special current events and other happenings from central depots to motion-picture theatres over special high-frequency radio channels set up for the purpose, was foreseen here yesterday at the opening sessions of the convention of the Institute of Radio Engineers as a "certainty within five years."

CHICAGO, March 7 -- The Chicago Convention Bureau reported today delegates to conventions held in this city last year left with business concerns $123,778,973. It was estimated they spent nearly $50,000,000 additional on such items as booths, flowers, insurance, printing and numerous other items.
OMAHA, Neb., March 7 -- Two New Jersey youths, students at Creighton University here, reached Omaha late today after having been trapped for two days by flood waters.

A 24-year-old British factory girl from Pagebank, a mining village in Durham, arrived last night on the Cunard liner Queen Elizabeth as an exchange employe of the Duro Test Corporation of North Bergen, N. J.
Three men were under arrest yesterday on charges of overcharging twenty-four tenants of the garden-apartment development at 36-23 168th Street, Flushing, Queens. Bail for each was set at $1,500.
WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP) -- A hint of a new coal strike "soon" over safety in mines was given at a Senate committee hearing today by John Owens, secretary-treasurer of the United Mine Workers.

VIENNA, March 7 -- In direct contradiction of the denial issued in Prague by Czechoslovak Deputy Premier Zdenek Fierlinger, informed Czechoslovak sources here today reported that the first group of several score Germans from the Soviet zone of Germany had just been resettled in the vicinity of Cheb, southwest of Karlovy Vary [Karlsbad].

Now is March, and this is the month for indulging in a bitter practice. Unpleasant under whatever name, the practice is described by believers in rolling periods as "repairing the ravages of the winter," while the more earthy say merely, "cleaning up the yard."
WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP) -- The Government today denounced Mildred E. (Axis Sally) Gillars as a traitor who broadcast "rotten propaganda" for wartime Germany and got a "sadistic joy" out of it.
The trial of the eleven Communists finally began yesterday after a seven-week delay caused by their futile attack on the Federal jury system.

Those who have been dreaming of a trip to Alaska for caribou, giant moose or big brown bear may receive something of a shock when they read the Forest Service report on the game kill made on national forests in that territory during the past season.

Six German police officials, twenty-four clergymen and nine anti-Communist trade union leaders from the western sector of Berlin arrived in this city yesterday to observe democracy at work in the United States.

Wool futures were easier yesterday on profit-taking and local selling. Offerings were absorbed on scale - down buying by dealers. Wool top futures closed 2.2 to 3.2 cents a pound net lower in sales of 355,000 pounds. Grease wool futures were down 1.5 cents a pound on transactions of only 18,000 pounds.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- Representative Sol Bloom, Democrat, of New York, died tonight of a heart attack, the United States Naval Hospital announced. A member of Congress since 1923, he was 78 years old.

Proved reserves of crude oil and natural gas liquids in the United States were increased last year 2,079,567,000 barrels, the biggest one-year gain in more than a decade, according to the American Petroleum Institute. At the year-end the reserves amounted to 26,821,227,000 barrels, compared with 24,741,660,000 on Dec. 31, 1947.

Room decorating ideas in capsule form are offered in tiny settings displayed this week in Stern's rug department, where Betty Carlisle, Masland color consultant, is also on hand to offer individual decorating advice to homemakers.
WORCESTER, Mass., March 7 -- The Rev. G. Antonio Laberge, only American Roman Catholic priest stationed in Moscow, has been barred from returning to the Soviet Union.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 7 -- Manager Casey Stengel today launched an intensive drive to eliminate the rough edges from his 1949 baseball machine.

Unseeded Daniel Rivkind of Brooklyn reached the quarter-finals of the men's singles in the Eastern indoor tennis championships yesterday by upsetting second-seeded Frank Bowden of Madison, N. J., on Nick's courts at the Fifteenth Regiment Armory. The 19-year-old Brooklyn College player won by 6 -- 3, 6 -- 4.

Dr. Peter Zenkl, chairman of the Council of Free Czechoslovakia, pledged the new organization last night to an anti-Communist program in the spirit of Thomas G. Masaryk, as the first Czechoslovak President's ninety-ninth birthday anniversary was commemorated.

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 7 -- Although it may have taken something of an over developed optimist to see anything encouraging in the weird assortment of baseball which the Giants squad put on exhibition in its first intra-camp game yesterday, Manager Leo Durocher was far from lacking in enthusiasm as he reviewed that struggle at the close of another sizzling workout today.
WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP) -- The Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that Oklahoma may tax oil produced by companies operating on Indian lands.

PARIS, March 7 -- It is unlikely that anyone who is not a member of that exclusive body, the Soviet Politburo, really yet knows the full import of the replacement of Vyacheslav M. Molotov and Anastas I. Mikoyan. Proof of this, despite the various "expert" opinions that are being offered, is in the contradictory reports emanating from Moscow itself.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- Eating up food surpluses at home to the benefit of national nutrition, rather than dumping them overseas or curtailing crops, was advocated in a pamphlet issued today by the National Planning Association as one means of helping avert a major farm depression.

LONDON, March 7 -- Very urgent consultations, it is reliably reported today, are taking place among British Commonwealth countries with a view to arranging another high level Commonwealth conference in the near future.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., March 7 -- After two weeks of intermittent questioning of Gerard Graham Dennis, alleged society jewel thief, Capt. Emmett Jones of the Los Angeles police said today that he had obtained full confessions to thirteen California burglaries amounting to $395,850.

YONKERS, N. Y., March 7 -- The appointment of Don C. Wagner, former city manager of Portsmouth, Ohio, and Long Beach, L. I., to that post here appeared likely tonight after six of the seven Common Council members conferred on a selection from thirty-one candidates.

LEWES, Del., March 7 -- The cruiser Milwaukee, first of the American ships sent to the Russians under lend-lease during the war to be returned will arrive off the breakwater here at 11 A. M. tomorrow, according to word received today from the ship.

LAKE SUCCESS, March 7 -- The United Nations Security Council decided today to turn over to the Trusteeship Council its functions regarding political, economic, social and educational matters in the Marshall, Mariannas and Caroline Islands.

ALBANY, March 7 -- Republican Administration leaders decided tonight to seek a showdown tomorrow with the coalition of insurgent Republicans and Democrats who have stalemated action on Governor Dewey's budget and tax program for the past two weeks.

Chicago, Ill., Sanitary District announced yesterday that it would receive on March 24 bids for $15,000,000 of construction bonds dated April 1, 1949, due on Jan. 1, 1969, and callable in 1952 and thereafter.
MONTREAL, March 7 (AP) -Willy Slykhuis, the flying Dutchman, tonight won the Canadian invitation Legion mile at the Canadian indoor track and field championships -- but he didn't run a mile.
SOFIA, Bulgaria, March 7 -- A Sofia District Court will sentence the fifteen Protestant ministers tomorrow afternoon at 3 P. M. (8 A. M. EST).

CAMDEN, N. J., March 7 -- David Williams, vice president and works manager of the New York Shipbuilding Corporation, announced here today that keels would be laid early in April for one of three liners for the American President Line and for one of three tankers scheduled to be built at the yard for the Philadelphia Tanking Company.

THE letter [of Dec. 8, 1940 to President Roosevelt setting forth Britain's needs and prospects for 1941; cf. Installment 27], which was one of the most important I ever wrote, reached our great friend when he was cruising, on board an American warship, the Tuscaloosa, in the sunlight of the Caribbean Sea.

Ever since Congress failed last year, in the rush of other business and election-year politics, to complete action on a repealer of taxes on margarine, the butter lobby has been busy dreaming up new strategy. Last fall it thought of the device of an outright prohibition against the making of yellow margarine.

City College, ready to conclude its regular season tonight in the traditional meeting with new York University at Madison Square Garden, yesterday received a coveted berth in the forthcoming national invitation college basketball tournament.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- The Pacific Lighting Corporation, San Francisco, has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering 100,000 shares of $4.50 dividend preferred stock (cumulative), no par value, that is to be offered to the public at a price to be filed by amendment.

WASHINGTON, March 7 (UP) -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, chairman of the Senate Republican Policy Committee, said tonight that a guaranteed annual wage might be practical in some industries and "deserves experimentation.
LAKE SUCCESS, March 7 -- The United Nations International Labor Organization warned today that a worldwide housing boom in the 1950's would plunge many nations into depression soon after.

THE ship sent to pick up British gold in South Africa at the end of 1940 was the heavy cruiser Louisville. She completed the mission despite the appeal of Prime Minister Churchill against it.
