The story of the voyage is told in "Man of War" (Dunlap Printing Co., Philadelphia; copyright 1946 by J. Pennington Straus).

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- The House Education and Labor Committee began its public hearings on the Administration's labor relations bill today with a spirited clash between Democratic and Republican members over the Tool Owners Union, which is headed by former Representative Fred A. Hartley Jr. of New Jersey.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 7 -- Howard Hughes has concluded a deal with Republic and Howard Welsch for RKO, the Hughes company to take over distribution of "Montana Belle," which Welsch, Robert Peters and Walter Colmes produced independently for Republic release late last year.

Dull buying and marked price resistance in many cases were noted yesterday at the first variety store show to be held here in more than a decade. Conducted in the New Yorker Hotel by the National Association of Variety Stores, Inc., a group with about 500 independent retail members, mostly in the Midwest, the show exhibited lines from 100 manufacturers ranging in price from 5 cents to $5.
SOFIA, Bulgaria, March 7 (UP) -- A Government spokesman announced today that the security police had seized more Protestant clergymen and said it was "possible" as many as fifty were in jail.
The Marquess and Marchioness of Northampton, who arrived recently from England, are at the Plazs lfr.

DETROIT, March 7 -- The immediate creation of a new political party that would rather "be right than be elected" was urged today by Dr. Walter E. Spahr of New York, executive vice president of the Economists National Committee on Monetary Policy.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, March 7 -- Tension between Zulus and Indians continues in Durban, according to reports received here. Armed police dispersed today a mob of nearly 1,000 that had gathered outside a store in the main Indian market following a complaint by a Zulu woman that she had been "poisoned" by candy purchased there.
The Pure Oil Company in 1948 had the greatest volume of business and net income in its thirty-five-year history, the annual report revealed today.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was quiet yesterday and final prices were 2 to 9 points net lower than the close on Saturday.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., March 7 -- Robert Moses, chairman of the State Council of Parks, was accused at a meeting of the Westchester Board of Supervisors here today of advocating undesirable parkway plans for the county and of firing a "jet-propelled blast" to gain state funds for the plans.

OPELOUSAS, La., March 7 (UP) -- Sheriff Clayton Guilbeau today charged three men, including a well-to-do former deputy sheriff, with kidnapping a Negro from the St. Landry Parish Prison for a lynching mob.

Heavy buyer attendance marked the opening yesterday of the American Toy Fair here. Estimates put registration for the first day at some 2,500 against 2,000 on the opening day last year. The fair is being held at the McAlpin and New Yorker Hotels and at permanent showrooms of manufacturers at 200 Fifth Avenue, the Breslin Hotel, 1107 Broadway, and other business quarters.

In a move to curb automobile thefts, which have reached alarming proportions with the scarcity of new cars, Clifford J. Fletcher, Commissioner of Motor Vehicles, yesterday announced drastic new regulations affecting renewal and transfer of car ownership.
FRANKFORT, Germany, March 7 (AP) -- The Abendpost said today that the Russians are organizing their own airlift -- to beat a Yugoslav blockade of Albania.

A group of major league players suspended for jumping to the Mexican League will file multi-million dollar suits today against organized baseball, John L. Flynn, attorney, said yesterday, The Associated Press reported.

BUENOS AIRES, March 7 (AP) -- The Government issued today a promised decree giving itself monopoly over newsprint in Argentina. The decree authorized seizure of present stocks and creation of a "pool" of paper to be administered by the chief of the Presidential Press Office.

Although slowed by technicalities in shifting civil service personnel, the city's new Department of Traffic Engineering has completed selection of its key executives, it was learned yesterday. All but one now are functioning in the department's new quarters at 100 Gold Street.
WASHINGTON, March 7 -- The Senate's filibuster fight was suspended today because of the death of one who had been poised to enter it on the Southern side.
George F. Warner has been named vice president of the Cott Beverage Corporation, with headquarters in New Haven, Conn.
The Carrie Munn custom collection, shown yesterday at 640 Madison Avenue, emphasized flaring courtier jackets, boned bodices, small waists and elegant evening attire.

Pratt Institute registered an upset last night in the metropolitan basketball tournament for small colleges when it beat Wagner, 68 to 54, in the opening round at the Brooklyn Technical High gymnasium. In another first-round encounter, Brooklyn Polytech advanced by easily downing Cooper Union, 60 to 42.

Henry Morgenthau Jr., general chairman of the United Jewish Appeal, in a telephone conference yesterday afternoon in which 150 communities took part, asked for $50,000,000 in contributions in the next twelve days. He stressed that the money was needed to meet urgent needs in the United Jewish Appeal $250,000,000 campaign.

An electrical appliance that looks like a toasters but actually is a deep-fat fryer is a star attraction at Hearn's semi-annual Housewares Fair. For the two-week spring show that opened yesterday the store has converted its basement department into a busy midway with "barkers" demonstrating the latest in kitchen equipment.

OMAHA, Neb., March 7 -- New flood trouble spots developed today in the Missouri River Valley, driving several hundred more persons from their homes, sending high waters swirling into small communities and blocking highways and railroads.

A field of ten books was announced yesterday by the Book Manufacturers Institute as candidates for the $1,000 Gutenberg Award offered by the institute. From the ten, judges will pick the one that is considered to have "most progressively influenced American thought in 1948."

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- A March sailing schedule of nine ships carrying displaced persons from North German ports to the United States was announced today by the International Refugee Organization. Seven ships sailed in February.

New York City's population has grown so rapidly that its higher educational facilities have not been able to follow the pace. The lack of space is shown in the College of the City of New York. In 1847 City began as a public institution with 143 students. One hundred and two years later the enrollment is 33,000.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- Two actions taken by the Supreme Court today are expected to have a strong effect upon labor pay policies of this government in connection with its far-flung program of military construction in other lands.

A private distribution system for national magazines was reported under consideration yesterday as publisher and advertiser groups here prepared to fight "drastic and discriminatory" increases in second-class mail rates. The increases, included with others in a bill now before Congress, would make such a private system no more expensive, a spokesman commented.

An unusual variety of antiques characterizes the fifth annual National Antiques Show, which opened yesterday afternoon at the Madison Square Garden. It offers a choice of prices ranging from less than a dollar for old-time table utensils to $5,000 for a dozen American Hepplewhite chairs.

ALBANY, March 7 -- Final approval was given by the Senate tonight to an Assembly resolution amending the Constitution to permit New York City to issue $150,000,000 in bonds for hospital construction outside of the city's debt limit.

CHICAGO, March 7 -- Professional operations dominated the action of the grain markets on the Board of Trade today. The undertone, however, was firm except on May wheat, which closed 1/4 cent lower on the day because of back-spreading with the July.

The American Radiator and Standard Sanitary Corporation and its United States subsidiaries established new highs for sales and earnings last year, according to the annual report issued yesterday by Theodore E. Mueller, president.
BOSTON, March 7 (AP) -- The Holy Cross basketball team bid adieu for the season to Boston Garden crowds in a blaze of baskets tonight, swamping Dartmouth, 76 -- 41.

Relocation of tenants living on the site of the proposed New York University Law Center is showing "real progress," according to a report made public yesterday by Russell D. Niles, dean of the university's School of Law.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- National Airlines, major passenger-mail carrier, today punctuated hearings on its possible dismemberment initiated by the Civil Aeronautics Board with announcement of a plan to sell almost one-half of its stock to Pan American Airways and Panagra, a Latin-American line owned jointly by Pan American and W. R. Grace Co.

The United States Maritime Commission, with five full-time members and a little army of 6,816 employes, has two wholly different jobs. On the one hand it exercises regulating functions affecting the whole Merchant Marine., On the other hand it buys, sells and subsidizes shipping and makes loans on ships on a huge scale.

The interference of Mayor O'Dwyer in the selection of a president for Queens College has made that position a political football. The reaction of pressure groups in Queens has reduced the choice to a popularity contest, and as a result Queens College, the faculty and the student body become the real victims.

ST. LOUIS, March 7 (AP) -- Consolidated Retail Stores, Inc., reported today record sales of $35,645,596 in 1948 and net profits of $1,501,677, exceeded only once before. In 1947 sales totaled $31,594,906 and net was $1,317,385. The company earned $3.73 a share on its common stock in 1948 against $3.23 in 1947.
SANTIAGO, Chile, March 7 (AP) -- Almost complete returns tonight gave the Government parties victory in both the Senate and Chamber races of Chile's Congressional elections.

LOS ANGELES, Calif., March 7 -- The National Cotton Council went on record here today as being opposed to enactment of a seventy-five-cent minimum wage in agriculture and in full support of the Taft-Hartley Act.

Whoever thought that legislation fathered by Senator Robert Taft and tagged with his name would be labeled "socialistic" and the forerunner of an American socialist state? Yet if we are to take statements by leading union spokesmen seriously, this seems the latest stratagem in the fight for repeal of the Taft-Hartley Act.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- A California youth who wants to be a zoologist, and an Oklahoma girl who plans a career as a physicist, were announced tonight as top winners in the eighth annual science talent search conducted by the Westinghouse Electric Corporation.

NEW DELHI, India, March 7 -Parliament today voted the rupee equivalent of $562,000,000 for India's defense services for the fiscal year 1949-50. This represents a little more than 50 per cent of the total estimated revenue. Defense expenditures for the sister Dominion of Pakistan, now before that country's Parliament, are set slightly higher at 55 per cent of the new budget.

WASHINGTON, March 7 (UP) -- Some 500 aroused demonstrators seeking an end to rent controls were told today that the fight on limiting Senate debate might prevent Congress from extending the law beyond March 31.

Bonwit Teller presented a double showing yesterday morning in the salon on the ninth floor. It was composed of custom-made fashions by Lepole, a young designer who works exclusively for Bonwit Teller, and imports from Paris.
SAN JUAN, P. R., March 4 (Delayed) -- There are many military problems in the Caribbean besides those of command and organization.

The Merritt-Chapman and Scott Corporation, 89-year-old marine engineering and construction organization, had gross revenues of $32,716,247 at the close of 1948, the largest for any peacetime year in its history, according to the annual report issued yesterday by F. E. Lyford, president, and T. A. Scott, chairman.
TEL AVIV, March 7 (AP) -- Israel plans to import 38,000,000 Israeli pounds (about $116,000,000) worth of raw and finished goods this year.

More than 800 industrial executives are now working with the National Security Resources Board to solve problems of industrial mobilization preparedness, and probably as many as 600 or 700 more will be called in before present planning studies have been finished, Edward V. Hickey, director of production, NSRB, declared yesterday.
LIMA, Peru, March 7 (UP) -- About ninety Americans are stranded in Lima as a result of the business failure of Peruvian International Airways, the local manager said today.

SAN JUAN, P. R., March 7 (AP) -- A strike closed thirty-two of Puerto Rico's thirty-five sugar mills today. The workers seek higher pay and better working conditions. Negotiations for a general settlement collapsed yesterday.

Declaring that the last half of this year could prove slightly stronger than the first half, Edwin B. George, economist of Dun Bradstreet, Inc., said yesterday that gross national product during the second quarter of this year may range around $255,000,000,000 against a rate of $265,000,000,000 in the last quarter of 1948.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 7 -- Development of persons "capable of helping to build a world in which good-will, justice and freedom are the controlling forces" was presented as the goal of the Young Women's Christian Association for the next triennium as the organization's national convention opened here today.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- In an atmosphere of dense secrecy, the House today approved, by a vote of 348 to 4, a bill designed to strengthen the country's far-flung intelligence network. The vote, which sent the measure to the Senate, was taken with the members generally knowing little about how new authority proposed for the Central Intelligence Agency would be used.

There is little reason to wonder that our young people have been turning away from a teaching career in droves. Nobody seems to have given a thought to trying to "sell" teaching as a career for the college graduate. All the emphasis has, instead, been on the negative.

CHICAGO, March 7 -- John F. O'Keefe, secretary of the Chicago Newspaper Publishers Association, said today that an end was near of the strike of 1,500 members of Chicago Typographical Union, Local 16, of the American Federation of Labor, against the city's five daily newspapers. It has lasted nearly sixteen months.
A plea for mediation of the two-month-old strike of 240 gravediggers at Calvary Cemetery in Queens was rebuffed yesterday by Cardinal Spellman.

Effects of the week-old bread strike were felt yesterday in Staten Island when pickets from Local 550 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, AFL, succeeded in turning back New Jersey bakery wagon drivers at the Staten Island ends of the Goethals and Bayonne bridges.

Much guessing is going on in Wall Street as to whether a relaxation in the 75 per cent margin requirements for market loans on listed securities may be coming in the wake of the Federal Reserve Board's order relaxing installment buying credit restrictions. However, the talk has little of the life that the margin issue used to raise before the market went into its long shrinking sickness.

Thomas J. Donegan, special assistant to the Attorney General, asked Federal Judge Simon H. Rifkind yesterday to cite for contempt of court a witness who refused to testify before the special Federal grand jury investigating subversive activities concerning his alleged acquisition of an automobile owned by Alger Hiss.

CINCINNATI, March 7 -- Fatigue complaints constituted "one of the biggest problems in medicine," Dr. Walter C. Alvarez of the Mayo Clinic at Rochester, Minn., told the first annual scientific assembly of the American Academy of General Practice today.

A special Federal grand jury heard yesterday the first chapter in the Government's story of its latest arrests for suspicion of espionage. After a brief session the grand jury adjourned until tomorrow morning.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- The Supreme Court ruled today that the states might impose tougher curbs on "union security" contracts than were provided in Federal laws. The court split 7-2 in holding that neither the Taft-Hartley Act nor the Wagner Act that preceded it prohibited skates from regulating union security agreements.

Prepared for their task by a four day "football school," sixty-seven candidates for the Fordham eleven yesterday reported to Coach Ed Danowski for the inaugural outdoor drill of a five week spring practice schedule.

TRENTON, N. J., March 7 -- Higher minimum pay for school teachers, comprehensive unemployment compensation coverage and veterans' bonus legislation, all on the administrative agenda of Governor Alfred E. Driscoll, received attention today by the New Jersey Legislature.
VERO BEACH, Fla., March 7 -There were two uncontrollable elements in the Brooklyn training camp today -- a very high wind and the team of assorted Dodgers managed by Peewee Reese.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- Representative Sol Bloom of New York will be "greatly missed and widely mourned," President Truman said in a telegram to Mr. Bloom's daughter, Miss Vera Bloom. The President is at Key West.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- In a report likely to provoke controversy the Commission on Organization of the Executive Branch of the Government urged today unification of the Government's major non-regulatory transportation activities in the Department of Commerce.

With orders beginning to show greater repeat frequency, popular price dress manufacturers still have an opportunity to salvage the spring season, it was pointed out yesterday. For some manufacturers, total production for the first three months of the year, it was said, is close to that of the corresponding period in 1948, even though the major portion of the business was written on one and two week deliveries.
In a tense struggle featured by a rousing finish, Columbia's quintet defeated Cornell University, 51 -- 49, in an Eastern Intercollegiate League game on the Lions' court last night.

Stock prices moved within a narrow range yesterday until the final hour, when a moderate rally expanded the volume and the list closed fractions to a point higher on the day. Sales approximating 280,000 shares near the close brought the day's total to 840,000 shares compared with 730,000 shares on Friday.

LAKE SUCCESS, March 7 -- The United Nations Economic and Social Council agreed today to recommend a special investigation into charges that there are 8,000,000 to 14,000,000 persons in slave labor camps of Russia and other Eastern European countries.

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, president of Columbia University, announced yesterday the creation of four new university vice presidencies in major divisions of activity provided as a result of a survey begun nearly two years ago.

WASHINGTON, March 7 (UP) -- Benjamin F. Fairless, president of United States Steel Corporation, said today that steel supply and demand would be in balance within a few months if present trends continued.
LONDON, March 7 -- Losses on production of opera by the Covent Garden Opera Trust are shown by the Arts Council of Great Britain in its civil appropriation accounts published today.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- The Democrats in the Eighty-first Congress show no anxiety as a group over President Truman's Jackson Day criticism of their legislative pace or his implication that he may take the stump for his program, as he did when the record of the Eightieth Congress was his successful target.

Uta Graf, soprano, who has sung in opera and concert in Europe, gave her first New York recital last night at Town Hall. She confined herself to three groups of lieder, a Mozart concert aria and four songs by Poulenc.

The United States Maritime Commission's policy of permitting subsidized steamship operators to establish services in competition with non-subsidized lines was criticized yesterday by Ben Geaslin, vice president and general counsel of the Waterman Steamship Corporation, in a strongly worded letter to the commission.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., March 7 -A drive to obtain pledges for 5,000 trees to be planted this spring in an Israeli forest named for President Truman was opened today at a luncheon meeting of the Midwest regional conference of the Mizrachi Women's Organization of America.

A suit to require officers of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association to file an accounting of funds was dismissed by Justice Thomas J. Cuff in Queens Supreme Court yesterday because of insufficiency of the complaint. The suit was filed by L. C. Hamilton and sixty other patrolmen.

People's Songs, an organization which holds "Hootenannys" at intervals, last night put on its party clothes for a gala performance in Carnegie Hall. Called "New York: A Musical Tapestry," narrated by William S. Gailmor, the event rang most of the possible musical changes on the city's racial patterns, and a few which were pretty far-fetched.

" Peace or Pestilence," by Theodor Rosebury, an analysis of the released facts on biological warfare, will be published in May by Whittlesey House. The author was chief of the Air-Borne Infection project at United States Biological Headquarters in the war and is now Associate Professor of Bacteriology, College of Physicians and Surgeons, Columbia University.

LONDON, March 7 -- Any hopes brokers had of a rally in prices after last week's setback were dashed as soon as the stock market opened today. The news of the Molotov-Vishinsky shuffle, together with various home uncertainties that have resulted in unsettled markets, caused a steady trickle of selling which brokers fear may grow more persistent.

If the Musicians Guild, Inc., which ended its third lively season at Times Hall last night, has a flossy list of patrons, it has kept the names to itself. All it has sold the public is the music. Since virtually every concert has been a fine blend of valuable new and old music, the public has responded.

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., March 7 -- Jimmy Dykes returned to the big league scene in approximately the same fashion in which he left it a few years ago. He was still talking. Fast and furiously, too. He also was smoking a big cigar. However, it probably was a different cigar. At least an ear-weary listener has to make that concession to him.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., March 7 -- Hofstra and Adelphi advanced into the Queens-Nassau semi-final of the Greater New York college tournament by vanquishing Queens and Kings Point, respectively, in Calkins gymnasium tonight.

BERLIN, March 7 -- German Communists led by Wilhelm Pieck, titular head of the party, announced the start of intensive campaign, a political civil war, against Western Germany and the Western powers today.
GENEVA, March 7 -- The governing body of the International Labor Office voted unanimously today to consider the "position of the trade union movement in various countries" at its next session.
KEY WEST, Fla., March 7 -- It took seventeen booms of a Navy three-inch gun to wake up President Truman at 8 o'clock this morning. He turned over, fell asleep again and did not rise until 9:30 A. M.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- The Ambassadors Committee on the projected North Atlantic Pact has sent a complete draft of the proposed treaty to Canada and Western Europe for the official approval of the Governments concerned, it was learned today.

PARIS, March 7 -- After hearing speech by W. Averell Harriman, roving representative of the Economic Cooperation Administration, today the new Marshall Plan Steering Committee of Cabinet members postponed its adjournment twenty-four hours and spent the day revising its recommendations to the European Governments.

CHICAGO, March 7 -- Sixty-nine employes of the Tucker Corporation, including James K. Coolidge, assistant secretary, will be dropped from the company's payroll immediately, John H. Chatz, co-trustee of the corporation, said today. Mr. Chatz and Mr. Aaron Colnon were appointed trustees by the Federal District Court last Thursday when the company went into reorganization.
ALBANY, March 7 -- The Senate tonight approved a bill to permit school districts to exchange teachers with foreign countries.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- For the second time the conviction of Carl Aldo Marzani for concealing Communist party activities during a Federal Government loyalty test was upheld by a 4-to-4 verdict in the Supreme Court today. The action was announced through a brief statement which, as usual did not disclose the attitudes of the eight justices.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- The National Military Establishment, with Secretary of Defense James Forrestal as its direct spokesman, today laid before Congress a proposed law to establish the first uniform court-martial proceedings for all services in this country's history.

The week's only Broadway opening takes place tonight at the Booth Theatre, where "At War With the Army," "a farce-comedy," by James B. Allardice, makes its bow under the combined auspices of Henry May, Jerome E. Rosenfeld and Charles Ray McCallum.

Spokesmen for R. H. Macy Co. and the unaffiliated Local 1-S, Department Store Employes Union, exchanged statements yesterday expressing mutual hope that a new collective bargaining agreement could be reached with few difficulties.

LONDON, March 7 (AP) -- Yugoslavia filed seven new war claims against Austria today. In a note to the Big Four deputies, Deputy Foreign Minister Ales Bebler supplemented the Belgrade Government's previous treaty claims with these demands:

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- There is a distinct "good riddance" atmosphere about most of the comments here on the "release" of Vyacheslav M. Molotov, but there is another point of view in Washington that may be summarized as follows:

Nine banking syndicates submitted bids yesterday for an issue of $4,000,000 of new first-mortgage thirty-year bonds of the Minnesota Power and Light Company. The bids designated interest costs ranging from about 3.02 per cent to about 3.05 per cent.

GUATEMALA, March 7 -- Representatives of the Carnegie Instiution have reported an extraordinary archaeological find at the site of the ancient city Kaminal Juyu, just outside this city. The huge tomb discovered last January by Ewin M. Shook, chief of the excavators, on further investigation is believed to date from the beginning of the Christian Era.

There is a resurgence of spirit in Greece. It is reminiscent of the spirit that fired the Greeks when they said "No" to Mussolini's Fascist invaders in 1940. As an American it is amazing to me that Greece retains this spirit after her tragedy of the recent war followed by the even greater tragedy starting in December, 1944, when Greeks massacred Greeks to save themselves from communism. But there are reasons.

An unexpected tie-up of nine bus lines of the Kingsbridge division of the Surface Transportation Corporation inconvenienced an estimated 175,000 residents of the Bronx yesterday both on their way to work in the morning and on their way home at night.

YONKERS, N. Y., March 7 -- The eight-day strike of municipal employes that has halted garbage collection and impeded other public services ended at 6 P. M. today on the basis of a three-point "memorandum of understanding" between city officials and union leaders.

A Committee to Save the State University, held "gravely threatened" by the Condon-Barrett Bill, was formed here yesterday. It was set up for representatives of civic, educational and labor groups, who had been invited by the university's board of trustees to meet in the offices of Dr. Oliver C. Carmichael, chairman of the board, at 522 Fifth Avenue.

Dr. Justin F. Wait, internationally known chemist, declared yesterday that Russia had enough manufacturing equipment adequately to supply penicillin and streptomycin to her satellite nations without further help from the United States.

Summer season service between Montreal and Liverpool by the two 20,000-ton Canadian Pacific liners, the Empress of Canada and the Empress of France, will start on April 19 with the arrival of the France at Montreal, the company announced here yesterday.

NANKING, Tuesday, March 8 (UP) -- Dr. Sun Fo announced his resignation in an administrative policy report to the Legislative Yuan, the members of which are the leaders of the campaign to oust the son of the founder of modern China.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- The Munitions Board, procurement agency of the National Military Establishment, will be controlled to a far greater degree by civilians, rather than military leaders, under reorganization plans announced today by Donald F. Carpenter, chairman.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- In a move designed to attract equity capital for corporate financing, Representative John W. Byrnes, Republican, of Wisconsin, offered a bill today granting a tax credit of 20 per cent of annual dividends up to $2,000 a year.

A meeting of parishioners of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Holy Trinity in Brooklyn voted 261 to 27 last night for the removal of nine vestrymen from office because of their activity in seeking the ouster of the Rev. Dr. John Howard Melish, the rector.

JERSEY CITY, N. J., March 7 -- A City Hall peace conference, called by Mayor Frank H. Eggers in an effort to head off the longshoremen's work stoppage that spread to two more piers today, ended in a stalemate at noon.

LONDON, March 7 -- Soviet Ambassador George Zarubin today criticized the three Western powers for their refusal to agree to a Soviet-backed Yugoslav proposal to create within Austria a politically independent Slovene province.
WASHINGTON, March 7 -- Twenty-six Post Office employes filed suit in Federal Court today challenging constitutionality of the Government's loyalty program.

VIENNA, March 7 -- Education Minister Gyula Ortutay has addressed a complaint "to all mass organizations" that "the supremacy of the workers' children has not yet become a fully realized political and social endeavor in Hungary."

Beginning Sept. 11, "The Theatre Guild on the Air" will be heard Sunday nights over the NBC network, instead of over ABC, as at present. The time will be from 8:30 to 9:30 P. M., an hour earlier than now.

Two sliver medals for "acts of bravery," inexplicably delayed for fifteen years, were awarded yesterday to Police Capt. Otto Arthur Kafka Jr. of the Sheriff Street station and Acting Sgt. Joseph W. Forsythe, retired.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee voted unanimous approval today of a $5,580,000,000 authorization for the European Recovery Program in the fifteen months ending June 30, 1950.
Consolidated Edison and the Utility Workers of America, CIO, were reported yesterday to have reached an agreement in principle on a modified "loyalty oath" for new employes.

CHICAGO, March 7 -- Of 2,407 urban area housewives interviewed recently in a survey for the frozen food industry, 76 per cent said they bought frozen foods, and 64 per cent said they served them once or more a week.

PORT ELIZABETH, South Africa, March 7 (Reuters) -- England brought South Africa's first innings to a close for 379 runs today in the fifth and final test cricket match and at close of play had replied with 80 for one wicket.
ALBANY, March 8 -- The Legislature sent to Governor Dewey today a bill that would end the current experiment in the use of a small metal tag attached to the previous year's motor vehicle plates.

NEW DELHI, India, March 8 -- "Binding covenants" will be avoided by the Asian nations in future conferences of these powers, Prime Minister Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru told the Indian Parliament in an important speech on foreign policy today.
LONDON, March 8 -- King George VI will soon undergo a minor nerve operation to improve the supply of blood to his right foot, which is still suffering from an obstruction of the circulation.

DETROIT, March 8 -- Radioactive isotopes used as tracers can now be put to work for the improvement of automotive fuels, lubricants and engines, the Society of Automotive Engineers was told today by three California scientists.

The first major price reduction in a primary non-ferrous metal, since the lifting of price controls of the Office of Price Administration in 1946, was made yesterday when American Smelting and Refining Company and St. Joseph Lead Company, large producers and refiners, reduced pig lead 2 cents a pound, setting a new official level of 19.5 cents, New York, and 19.3 cents, St. Louis.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, March 8 -- A Sofia court sentenced today four leading members of the Supreme Council of United Protestant Churches of Bulgaria to life imprisonment, loss of civil rights, confiscation of property and fines of 1,000,000 leva.

Directors of the Bucyrus-Erie Company have voted a dividend of 40 cents a share on the common stock, payable on April 1. Last year the company paid 35 cents a share in April, July and October and 45 cents in December.
An old land mark for thoroughbred racing in the metropolitan are, the Empire City race track in Yonkers, has been sold to a syndicate that proposes to conduct harness racing there this year.

O. D. Niedermeyer has been appointed manager of the Texas Mining and Smelting division of the National Lead Company. George Diehlman has been appointed sales promotion manager for protective coating paints by National Lead.

The New York Knickerbockers, currently on a four-game winning streak, encounter the Washington Capitols in a Basketball Association of America contest at Madison Square Garden tonight. National City and Abraham Straus meet in the 7:30 preliminary.

A judicial inquiry into alleged professional misconduct by three Brooklyn lawyers was ordered yesterday by the Appellate Division, Second Department. The court, acting on a petition by the Brooklyn Bar Association, appointed Official Referee Peter B. Smith to conduct hearings and report on his findings.

An ailing 38-year-old father of ten children was sentenced yesterday to sixty days in the workhouse because he had tried augment his wages as a part-time steamfitter with relief funds from the Department of Welfare.

ROME, March 8 -- The entire Cabinet, including its three Right-Wing Socialist members, this morning approved the policies followed by Foreign Minister Count Carlo Sforza, especially with reference to the Atlantic pact. It "noted with satisfaction" that the policies aimed at the "consolidation of peace and of Italian security."
The prospects of peace in the Far East and the Near East are dubious now but may improve, 500 teachers were told yesterday by two members of THE NEW YORK TIMES staff.

After an ownership of a week, the five-and-a-half-story apartment house with 151 rooms at 610-16 Academy Street has been resold by Michael Newman to the 270 Seaman Avenue Corporation, Elizabeth Schmidt, president. Nehring Bros. were the brokers in the purchase and resale of the property, which is 100 by 100 feet and is assessed for $145,000.

A special Federal grand jury will see today the papers that led to the arrest of two espionage suspects on Friday. These documents are believed to be the major evidence in the Government's case for indictments against a Russian engineer attached to the United Nations staff and a woman employe of the Department of Justice.
WASHINGTON, March 8 (AP) -- Public hearings by the Senate Finance Committee on extending the reciprocal trade program ended today in a flurry of criticism of South Africa for "premium sales" of gold.

The thirty-nine German police, religious and trade union leaders who arrived here Monday to observe democracy at work in the United State spent most of their first full day in New York sight-seeing and visiting friends and relatives.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee indicated today informal approval of the proposed North Atlantic defense pact in a three-hour session with Secretary of State Dean Acheson.

The television version of General Eisenhower's book, "Crusade in Europe," has been postponed "until April," it was made known yesterday by the American Broadcasting Company. The most recent word on the film series had been that it would start on video "early in March."

Congratulations are in order to Captain Bill Odom for his astounding flight of some 5,300 miles from Honolulu to Teterboro, N. J., in a single-engined Beechcraft Bonanza. Headwinds and storms made him detour over the Pacific and put him on instruments at times over the continent. At other times he had good tail-winds.

Prices held about unchanged at the opening of fall leathers yesterday under the auspices of the Tanners Council of America at the Waldorf - Astoria Hotel. Buying was for immediate needs, with some evidence of confidence, however, that shoe manufacturers will begin to feel an expanded demand from retailers for deliveries through May.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- The House Ways and Means Committee was reported as being in informal agreement today on a compromise formula of Federal grants to states for aid to the needy aged, to the blind, to unemployables and for dependent children.

Striking cemetery workers met the objection of Cardinal Spellman that their parent union was "Communist affiliated" when they voted unanimously last night to quit the International Food, Tobacco and Agricultural Workers Union, CIO.

Production and earnings of the Eastman Kodak Company last year were substantially higher than in 1947, the annual report of Perley S. Wilcox, chairman, and Thomas J. Hargrave, president, will inform stockholders today.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 8 -- Alan Winslow, president of Harvard's Hasty Pudding Club, disclosed today that he had written to Margaret Truman, daughter of the President, notifying her she had been elected the organization's "woman of the year," and inviting her to sing in their annual show, "Tomorrow Is Manana," which opens Friday.

Arbitration cases cleared through the arbitration bureau of the National Federation of Textiles in 1948 reached an all-time record, according to Irene Blunt, secretary-treasurer. In her report at the annual meeting of the association yesterday, Miss Blunt revealed that 424 cases were filed last year, 31 per cent more than the previous high record in 1934, and 40 per cent more than in 1947.

Lessing J. Rosenwald, president of the American Council for Judaism, urged yesterday that all religious faiths come to the support of 750,000 Arabs forced into the role of refugees by the recent Palestine hostilities.

First reactions of banking observers yesterday to the preliminary proposals of the task force of the Hoover Commission for increasing the powers of the Federal Reserve Board were somewhat critical. There was general agreement that some kind of national monetary council would be desirable.

LAKE SUCCESS, March 8 -- The United Nations Economic and Social Council today rejected a Soviet resolution proposing that it cite thirteen countries by name for alleged persecution of labor leaders and stifling of trade union movements.
WASHINGTON, March 8 (AP) -- Millions of dollars more in Federal funds to fight cancer, heart diseases and mental illness were voted today by the House Appropriations Committee.

LONDON, March 8 (UP) -- The Soviet Union led the world's Communists in celebrating International Women's Day today, a project Marxists had taken up with vigor. The Soviet line was to compare the so-called emancipated Russian woman with her capitalist sister.

PARIS, March 8 -- Letters approving the accord establishing "an independent Viet Nam within the French Commonwealth" were signed at Elysee Palace today by French President Vincent Auriol and the Emperor of Annam, Boa Dai.

A formal request that Bishop James P. De Wolfe revoke his order removing the Rev. Dr. John Howard Melish as rector of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Holy Trinity, Brooklyn, was made yesterday by the rector's supporters.
Spring is the season when thrifty Europeans bring out their favorite recipes for preparing young chicken. The birds are tenderest and most succulent and, what's perhaps more important, inexpensive.

The New York and Cuba Mail Line is considering a construction program designed to regain the prestige it enjoyed in the Cuba and Mexico trades in pre-war days which was lost by failure to regain vessels requisitioned in World War II, Lewis D Parmelee, president of the line, declared yesterday.

Visiting buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday totaled 1,677, compared with 1,824 last week and 1,276 in the similar week of 1948, according to lists published in THE NEW YORK TIMES. There were 898 arrivals yesterday against 687 last Tuesday.

A fifteen-member team of British steel foundry workers, technicians and managers is scheduled to arrive here next Monday on the Queen Mary, it was announced yesterday. The team is the first to visit the United States under the auspices of the Anglo-American Council on Productivity to study American industrial "know-how" at first hand.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- Louis A. Johnson, named by President Truman to succeed James Forrestal as Secretary of Defense, has picked an active Republican as one of his two chief assistants, it was learned today.

Arnost Heidrich. writing in the letters column of THE NEW YORK TIMES of Feb. 17, asks whether if, in classifying his statements to Mr. Reston as a tale, I meant to challenge his information about the death of Jan Masaryk.

For the stated purpose of acting "in conformity with the principles of democracy," the City Council decided yesterday to arrange its sessions so that Councilman Benjamin J. Davis Jr., Manhattan Communist on trial in Federal Court, could attend meetings of the legislative body to which he was elected.

Cognizant of the nuances of theatrical management, Jed Harris is often able to command generous booking terms for his offerings. Theatre operators hesitate to reject a bid from him because of the realization that a producer-director of his reputation is apt to pop up at any time with a substantial hit.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- Senator Harry P. Cain, Republican, of Washington, took literally tens of thousands of words to tell the Senate today why he was opposing confirmation of Mon C. Wallgren as chairman of the National Security Resources Board.

Hospital administrators are largely responsible for the drive against enforcing the licensing provisions of the Nurse Practice Act in this state, Mrs. Mabel Detmold, president of the New York State Nurses Association, charged here yesterday.

The account in THE TIMES of March 6 of the walkout and adjournment of the Guam Congress until our Congress in Washington acts on legislation to give Guam an organic act and civil government, as well as American citizenship for Guamanians, dramatizes our extraordinary neglect of these people who suffered greater ravages of war than any other segment of the American civil population.

CHICAGO, March 8 -- There was a lack of aggressive buying in the grain markets on the Board of Trade today and the undertone was heavy from the start. Final trades were about the bottom except on oats. Wheat lost 1 1/2 to 2 cents, December leading.
WASHINGTON, March 8 -- The House Rules Committee postponed action on the Rankin veterans' pension bill again today after strong opposition to it had been entered from the Executive Branch.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- Sylvania Electric Products, Inc., New York, filed a statement for registration with the Securities and Exchange Commission today of 250,000 shares of no-par value common stock that is to be offered to the public at a price to be filed by amendment.

YONKERS, N. Y., March 8 -- While 500 reinstated strikers made major inroads into an eight-day accumulation of garbage, Yonkers officials asserted flatly today that they intended to live up to the letter of the Condon-Wadlin law in carrying out the strike settlement they reached with union leaders last night.

The American Jewish League Against Communism, Inc., 220 West Forty-second Street, protested yesterday a concert and meeting to be held Saturday evening at Hunter College Auditorium. The league asserted that the program was being sponsored by the International Workers Order to "attack" the Board of Education.

Judge Harold R. Medina excused eighty-six prospective jurors for reasons of business or family hardship yesterday in the trial of the eleven Communists. Ttoday he will begin the examination of seventy-eight remaining talesmen to eliminate those biased for or against the defendants.

Supreme Court Justice Meier Steinbrink, speaking for the board of justices of the Second Judicial District, last night called the Williamson-Brook bill for reorganizing the court structure in this city "a constitutional crazy-quilt."

Hudson Bay Company beaver sold up to $39 for Eskimo Bay double extra large types at the sale held yesterday by Lampson, Fraser Huth. Prices showed a 10 per cent decline, with 60 per cent of the offering of 2,877 skins sold.

Form and figures dictated a C. C. N. Y. victory over New York University as the regular season college basketball schedule was concluded before 18,137 fans at Madison Square Garden last night. Also, there was reason to expect a spectacular, close contest, regardless of how it ended.

The Miranda Brothers Trading Corporation, tenant of the three upper floors in the new fifteen-story office building at 4 West Fifty-eighth Street, has subleased a portion of the space to four firms. Brown, Harris, Stevens, Inc., agents of the building, who were brokers in the transactions said the rentals were in excess of $6 a square foot a year and substantially above the original rentals.

MOST critical reports on new books are designed to provide essential information, a description of what the book is like and an opinion of its merits, so that potential readers can decide whether they wish to make closer acquaintance with the book in question. Critical discussions of old books, classics, near-classics and even forgotten mediocrities have a different function.

WASHINGTON, March 8 (AP) -Congress learned today that while President Truman favors a pay rise for members of the armed services, he believes their allowances should be subject to income tax. He also believes they should contribute to their own retirement.

A vacant plot, 205 by 100 feet, at the southwest corner of White Plains Road and Arnow Avenue, the Bronx, has been purchased by Fred H. Hill and associates from Clarence and Herbert Poll. The new owners plan to erect a two-story taxpayer building on the site, which is adjacent to the proposed Parkside Houses development.

A large subscription has been reported for the performance of "The Madwoman of Chaillot" next Tuesday night at the Belasco Theatre, which has been taken over to raise funds for the Pestalozzi Foundation of America, Inc. The beneficiary, founded in 1942, provides relief to distressed and poverty-stricken children of all countries, including domestic charity centers, irrespective of race, creed or nationality.

New financing transactions involving the issuance of issues of public utility and railroad securities totaling $21,550,000 in par value were executed yesterday at public competitive bidding. The awards were as follows:

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- A strong indication that the Republican minority in the House will oppose continuing rent control beyond June 30 came today as a bill providing for a fifteen-month extension was cleared by the Rules Committee for floor action.

LEWES, Del., March 8 -- The old Milwaukee, the United States light cruiser that ended its war days as the ship Murmansk of the Soviet Navy, arrived in Delaware Bay today for return to the United States Navy.

Reporting on operations last year of Merck Co., Inc., drug and chemical concern, George W. Merck, president, informed shareholders in the report issued for release today that sales were the highest in the company's history even though price averages for the most important product groups were lower than in 1947.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 8 -- The motion picture industry has arranged with the Roman Catholic Church for the effective release of $3,000,000 worth of impounded Italian lire from accrued revenue of American films in Italy, it was learned today.

Mayor O'Dwyer and other city officials called attention yesterday to a small but steady increase in the number of tuberculosis victims in New York in the last three years and outlined steps the city would take to avert a greater threat.

With the legal staff of Governor Dewey concurring in the arrangements, Nassau County began preparations yesterday afternoon to bring Raymond M. Fernandez and his 200-pound sweetheart, Mrs. Martha Beck, from Michigan to face a possible death penalty.

The Liggett Myers Tobacco Company, one of the three leading domestic producers of tobacco products, announced yesterday that its directors were considering an offering of 784,235 shares of common stock to present stockholders in April.
WASHINGTON, March 8 (AP) -- The House Public Lands Committee today recommended statehood for Hawaii and Alaska.

VERO BEACH, Fla., March 8 -- Cal Abrams, the Brooklyn boy whose name, like Abou Ben Adhem's, leads all the rest of the outfielders on the Brooklyn roster, seems on the verge of winning a regular job with the 1949 Dodgers.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 8 -- The long-awaited experiment with Joe DiMaggio's troublesome heel was tried today, and produced complications.
TOKYO, March 8 -- The Japanese Democratic party, once the second largest political group in the nation, disappeared tonight after two years' existence.

HALLANDALE, Fla., March 8 (AP) -- Armed drew the loudest applause of the Florida turf season today when, in the third attempt of his winter comeback campaign, he scored his first triumph since his victory here at Gulfstream Park on Jan. 2, 1948.

YONKERS, N. Y., March 9 -- Don C. Wagner, city manager of Portsmouth, Ohio, and former city manager of Long Beach, L. I., was appointed tonight to the city managership here by a vote of 4 to 3 in the Common Council. The change in city managers is the eighth to be made by Yonkers in the last six and a half years.

A committee to study the application of the rule making dogs whose appearance had been altered artificially ineligible for shows was named by the board of directors of the American Kennel Club yesterday as part of the business of the organization's annual meeting at the Hotel Commodore.
PALM BEACH, Fla., March 8 (AP) -- Two favorites turned in sub-par scores today to advance in first round matches of the forty-second annual South Florida golf tournament at the Palm Beach Golf Club.

The Patrolmen's Benevolent Association ousted four of its members last night after a six-hour hearing at which the men were charged with having promoted "dual unionism" and other activity against the organization.

LONDON, March 8 -- With business still well below normal little change was seen in prices on the stock market here today. Brokers reported fewer selling orders, but there still was no sign of a genuine buying movement.

Harlem Hospital was described by officials yesterday as an institution devoted to high standards despite constant overcrowding, which has overtaxed the nurses, the professional staff and the administrative personnel.

PARIS, March 8 -- After five days of discussion, the new European Marshall Plan Steering Committee, composed of Cabinet Ministers, agreed today on a series of proposals to coordinate the recovery policies of recipients of dollar aid under the European Recovery Program.
CHICAGO, March 8 -- Five leaders of the frozen food industry today called for unified action among its several subdivisions to meet common problems and focused attention on the matter of pricing.

ALBANY, March 8 -- Legislation to allow mutual savings banks a wider range in the choice of investments was introduced in the Legislature today by the Rules Committee at the request of the State Banking Department.

With women voting for the first time, Chile's electors went to the polls in quiet fashion Monday to return to office the moderate government of President Gabriel Gonzalez Videla. The Army stayed in barracks and the Left lost ground. This successful functioning of democratic government stands in contrast to the last two Latin-American "elections" in neighboring Peru and Venezuela.
Six baby elephants took longer getting out of a plane at New York International Airport last night than they took to fly there from Gander, Nfld., on the last leg of a peaceful flight from Singapore.

Further selling featured trading in the wool futures market yesterday. Wool top contracts declined 0.5 to 1.5 cents a pound on sales of 230,000 pounds. Grease wool futures were off 1 cent a pound in all deliveries except the maturing March contract which was unchanged

TETERBORO, N. J., March 8 -- A new world record for non-stop distance flight in a light private airplane was set today when Capt. William P. Odom landed his single-engine Beechcraft Bonanza here at 12:05 P. M. to end a 5,300-mile hop that started exactly thirty-six hours earlier in Honolulu.

ALBANY, March 8 -- The Assembly Judiciary Committee approved unanimously today a bill sponsored by Assemblywoman Maude E. Ten Eyck, Republican, of Manhattan, that provides for the licensing and fingerprinting of private watchmen and guards on New York City's piers.
WARSAW, March 8 -- Students at the University of Poznan [Posen] have been warned that the school's rectors and city officials will no longer tolerate demonstrations.
MILWAUKEE, March 8 (AP) -- A member of one of the nation's wealthiest brewery families said today he planned to devote his full time "to encouraging the organization of white-collar workers."

LAKE SUCCESS, March 8 -- The International Court of Justice was asked today to decide if the United Nations had a right to present international claims against governments in such cases as the assassination of Count Folke Bernadotte, United Nations mediator for Palestine.
It seemed an afterthought on the part of Judge James Garrett Wallace in General Sessions yesterday, but it cost a convicted jewel thief an additional five to ten years in state prison.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- A bipartisan group of Senators will introduce tomorrow a resolution to provide shipping to send 7,500 students and teachers abroad next summer at round-trip fares of less than $250.

NANKING, March 8 -- Acting President Li Tsung-jen dispatched to Shanghai today a telegram urging Gen. Ho Ying-chin, former Minister of National Defense, to return to Nanking to take over the Premiership.

Two young Negroes and two young white men have chosen thirty days hard labor on a North Carolina road gang beginning March 21 rather than prejudice by their own appeal a better test case of the Southern states' "Jim Crow" laws, it was announced yesterday.

OTTAWA, March 8 -- Medical experts who flew to Chesterfield Inlet on the west shore of Hudson Bay last week to investigate an epidemic of poliomyelitis among Canadian Eskimos have returned here with an amazing story of the reasons why an area of 40,000 square miles of Arctic territory has been quarantined.

Swinging panels and flowing overdrapes were frequently noted details in the collection of French originals yesterday at Henri Bendel, 10 West Fifty-seventh Street. Such designers as Dior, Mad Carpentier, Lanvin, Balenciaga Molyneux, Marcelle Dormoy, Marcelle Chaumont, Jacques Fath, Robert Biquet, Jean Desses and Griffe were included.

LEIPZIG, Germany, March 8 -- This city in the Soviet zone, festive and decorated for the Leipzig Fair, is the best proof of how the Russians are enlisting German nationalism in the struggle against the West.

LONDON, March 8 -- Brendan Bracken, a former First Lord of the Admiralty and close political associate of Winston Churchill, declared on the floor of the House of Commons tonight that the Soviet Union had 220 submarines built for "the express purpose of conquering the world."

CHICAGO, March 8 -- The Tucker Corporation's trustees, John H. Chatz and Aaron Colnon, today studied a plan to keep Aircooled Motors, Inc., subsidiary of the Tucker Corporation in Buffalo, N. Y., out of financial difficulties.
Spring ensembles, belted coats and silk shantung dresses were featured by Saks-34th Street in a press preview held yesterday afternoon in the store.
ALBANY, March 8 -- Democratic legislators joined with some Republicans today to defeat in the Senate the Desmond-Mailler newspaper confidence bill by a vote of 36 to 18.

PRINCETON, N. J., March 8 -- Dr. Cyril E. Black, former State Department official who was called an American spy at the trial of fifteen Protestant ministers in Sofia, denied today that he had asked anyone for unauthorized information while he was in Bulgaria.

Joe Louis, retired undefeated heavyweight champion of the world, told all -- or nearly all -- yesterday in a mass interview at Toots Shor's. At least, the man who, as monarch of his division for more than eleven years successfully defended his crown against all comers twenty - five times, presented his side of the story.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 8 -- "Right Cross," a photoplay by Charles Schnee about prizefighting, has been scheduled for fall production at M-G-M with Ricardo Montalban in the leading role, the studio announced today. Armand Deutsch will produce the film after he completes "Ambush."

ALBANY, March 8 -- Governor Dewey conferred for more than eight hours this afternoon and tonight with key advisers and administration spokesmen in the Legislature on strategy to win approval of his budget and tax programs.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- Two programs designed to strengthen the Merchant Marine as an important adjunct to national defense were before Congress today in the form of bills introduced by Representative S. Otis Bland of Virginia, chairman of the House Merchant Marine and Fisheries Committee.

Father Buddy came down from his Poughkeepsie parish yesterday to donate a pint of his blood to the Red Cross at 4 East Thirty-seventh Street. It was the ninety-second pint donation he has made since his first transfusion saved an altar boy's life in December, 1938.

CHICAGO, March 8 (AP) -- The general counsel of the National City Lines, Inc., testified today that alleged secret "deals" between the company and its suppliers were a matter of public record. He is C. Frank Reavis of New York City, who was a witness for the defense in the Government's anti-trust suit against the transit company, six other companies and seven individuals on charges of conspiring to monopolize transit service in forty-two cities.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 8 -There is "great need" in this country for protection of the "moral health and safety" of the family by the state, the Rev. Edgar Schmiedeler of Washington, director of the Family Life Bureau, said here today at the convention of the National Catholic Conference on Family Life.

William Rosen, 65 years old, of Santa Monica, Calif., was sentenced to six months in prison yesterday for disobeying a Federal Court order to tell the special Federal grand jury investigating subversive activities about his connection, if any, with an automobile formerly owned by Alger Hiss.

LONDON, March 8 -- The British Navy will conduct atomic bomb tests this summer -- without an atomic bomb -- John Dugdale, parliamentary undersecretary of the Admiralty, disclosed today in the House of Commons.

More than 500 members of one of the nation's most influential organizations, although little known, the National Federation of Financial Analysts, gathered at the Hotel Statler for their second conclave last night. They, and the 1,500 other members of the group, decide the investment value of several billion dollars worth of securities held by more than 5,000,000 persons.

CLEVELAND, March 8 -- John Foster Dulles bluntly warned the negotiators of the proposed Atlantic pact today to avoid all commitments that might be construed by the Soviet Government as "bringing United States military might" directly to Russia's Scandinavian border. At the same time he cautioned against permitting "military judgments" to dominate national policy.
PHOENIX, Ariz., March 8 -- Leo Durocher today turned his eye to relief pitching, which could hold the key to whatever success the Giants attain in their National League pennant bid this year.

New York's rising birth rate, which will bring an additional 215,000 boys and girls into the city's public schools by 1954-55, will force the Board of Education to raise its budgets by a total of $68,239,191 in the next six years to take care of these children alone, it was estimated yesterday.

Gustav and Marienne Hunger sold the one-story garage building at 1105 - 1107 DeKalb Avenue, northeast corner of Reid Avenue, Brooklyn, to the 1105 DeKalb Avenue Realty Corporation, represented by Alexander Freiser, attorney.

Gertrude Ribla, New York soprano, who was heard as Aida earlier this season, assumed her second role at the Metropolitan Opera last night when she sang Leonora in the special performance of Verdi's "Il Trovatore" for the benefit of the New York Chapter of Hadassah.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- Although yesterday's Supreme Court decision upheld state power to legislate drastic restraints on closed shop activities, legal spokesmen for labor and industry agreed today that the ruling completely sustained Congressional authority to write laws nullifying the effect of such local statutes.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- Representatives of the Associated Industries of the State of New York today told the Interstate Commerce Commission, which is holding hearings on a request of the railroad for a 13 per cent increase in freight rates, that further increases will add to an already substantial diversion of traffic to trucks.

When James B. Allardice's "At War With the Army" was performed at the Yale Drama School last season, it must have seemed sensationally funny. For Mr. Allardice, who is still one of Uncle Marc Connelly's students, writes about the customs and manners of the army with the humorous relish of a man who is no longer in it.

Three books on Johann Wolfgang von Goethe have been announced for publication by two concerns. On April 1, New Directions will issue "Goethe's World as Seen in Letters and Memoirs," edited by Berthold Biermann. To commemorate the 200th anniversary of the poets birth, Harvard University Press will bring out on Aug. 28 "Goethe the Poet," by Karl Vietor.

All passengers using the Long Island Railroad -- I happen to be one of them -- must be keenly interested in finding a modern solution for the island's transportation problems. It is evident that if the Public Service Commission had acted in the past with more wisdom in regard to fare increases, and if the management of the railroad had employed the proper kind of public relations, this messy situation might have been postponed.

Genocide, the deliberate, systematic extermination of racial and national groups, exists today in the Soviet Baltic states and parts of the Ukraine, Adolf A. Berle charged last night at a meeting of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York.
The contractual structure of America's national pastime moved toward ultimate examination and decision by the United States Supreme Court yesterday.

Allegheny County, Pa., sold yesterday issues of bonds totaling $7,260,000 and maturing on each March 1 from 1950 to 1979 to a banking group headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., at a bid of 100.558 for 2 1/8s, an interest cost of 2.089 per cent.

Production and punctuality paid off for Ada Fishburn of Pagebank, Durham, England, who never dreamed she would come to America -- never! And at 9 A. M. yesterday the 24-year-old daughter of a coal miner awoke in Union City, N. J.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -There was a division of opinion in Government circles tonight as to why the Russians were delivering the cruiser Milwaukee to the United States at Lewes, Del. The Navy Department said that Lewes was agreed upon as an exchange site by the Soviet and United States naval representatives at a Four-Power conference in Paris in 1947.

Especially designed French costumes made of American fabrics and some French ones constituted an interesting showing yesterday afternoon in the little theatre atop the Chanin Building. The fabrics all showing new textures were of estron, a product of A. M. Tenney Associates, which company presented the fashion review.

WINTER PARK, Fla., March 8 -- President Truman declared this afternoon that education was the world's best weapon against communism. Then in a tribute to the peoples of Western Europe, he said that their intelligence was "the world's best hope for peace today."
ALBANY, March 8 -- The McMullen bill, which would bar Communist party members from holding civil service jobs or teaching posts, was approved by the Assembly today by a vote of 148 to 2.

Plans for the tallest office building to be erected in the downtown insurance district in the post-war period were announced yesterday in connection with the sale of the northwest corner of William and Ann Streets to Samuel Friedenberg, builder and owner of the twenty-eight-story offices at 90 John Street and the adjoining parcels at 104-10 John Street.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- A $100,000,000 export subsidy for the fresh fruits industry, designed to prevent wholesale destruction of commercial groves and orchards and give to Marshall Plan countries a commodity they could not otherwise afford, is receiving favorable consideration by the Economic Cooperation Administration.

Despite allowances for the gradual seasonal decline in liquor sales during spring, industry members reported here yesterday that wholesale and retail buying is slower than normal. While high taxes were still named as the "determining factor" in sales, it was also believed that the trade is becoming extremely "sensitive" because of the first post-war whiskies which become four years old this summer.
The light-tackle catches are improving every day, and word comes from Cat Cay that Allen Merrill of Grosse Point, Mich., has taken a 96 1/2-pound white marlin on a 9-thread line.

Paced by Ray Felix, star 6-foot-10-inch center, the Metropolitan Vocational team won a first round game from Andrew Jackson High, 54 to 48, in the P.S.A.L. basketball elimination trials at Madison Square Garden yesterday.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 8 (AP) -- Government regulation of industry might have a disastrous effect on industrial activity, a General Motors vice president said today.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 8 -- A new constitution that is regarded as broadening the democratic base of the Young Women's Christian Association was adopted here today by unanimous vote at the organization's triennial convention.

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., March 8 -- There probably isn't a chap in the big leagues who is more appreciative of the fact that he is toiling in the big leagues than Leland Victor Brissie of Ware Shoal, S. C. This big, striking youngster has achieved his boyhood ambition of pitching for the Philadelphia Athletics, but it was a mighty close call.

The National Academy of Design will hold a preview reception this evening to launch the first part of its 123d annual exhibition. Beginning tomorrow it will be open to the public through March 23 and will be followed by the second half of the annual.

Communism's latest attack on organized religion -- the "treason" trials in Bulgaria -- has ended with the sentencing to life imprisonment of the four principal defendants -- ministers, respectively, of the Methodist, Congregational, Baptist and Pentecostal churches. Other defendants have received prison terms ranging from one to fifteen years.

The newspapers told the other day the latest chapter in the bizarre history of Peter the Great. Pete, for short -- which is far from what he is -- holds the distinction of being the Zoo's largest hippopotamus.
A new board has been established in the city's Department of Welfare to review proposed dismissals of probationary employes, it was announced yesterday.

William P. Buckner and two other men, involved in the promotion of a Park Avenue gambling party last summer, pleaded guilty to amended charges of conspiracy to violate gambling statutes as they were about to go on trial yesterday in Special Sessions.

Although there were five Sundays in 1948's leap-year February, advertising in the eight major New York newspapers during the first two months of 1949 totaled 22,808,287 lines for a gain of 4.28 per cent over the comparable calendar period of last year, an analysis of Media Records showed yesterday.

In a letter to the three big milk distributing companies in the city, asking them to submit "truly competitive bids" on the price of milk to hospitals and prisons. John M. Murtagh, Commissioner of Investigation, condemned yesterday "the type of collusive bidding which has been the practice since 1942."

PATERSON, N. J., March 8 -- A national drive to have Congress place an embargo on Japanese woven silks, rayons and labels was launched here today by a committee of local textile manufacturers in an effort to eliminate what they describe as the "ruinous competition forced upon American industry" by the military occupation government in Japan.

The strike of civil service workers in Yonkers has ended with reinstatement of 500 city employes, but the real test of the Condon-Wadlin law lies ahead. In this test Yonkers city officials and New York State officials are themselves on trial before the public in a determination whether they will faithfully see to it that the legal penalties established by law for a strike against the people are carried out.

ADMIRAL RAEDER, whose ideas on the conduct of the German war at sea were technically sound, had some difficulty in carrying his views in the Fuehrer's councils. During the summer however he had fitted out a number of merchant ships as disguised raiders. They were more powerfully armed, were generally faster than our armed merchant-cruisers and were provided with reconnaissance aircraft.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- New efforts to move by law against the American Communists, to expose and isolate them and especially to cut their communication with the Soviet Union, were begun today in Congress.
The April Ball, arranged for bachelors and debutantes of recent seasons, will take place on April 1 in the ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton.
The number of workers drawing state unemployment insurance benefits went up nearly 18,000 last week, according to figures made public yesterday by Edward Corsi, State Industrial Commissioner.
MIAMI BEACH, Fla., March 8 (AP) -- Two mishaps today thwarted efforts by power boat drivers to set new speed records.

JERSEY CITY, N. J., March 8 -- The on-again-off-again strike of some 300 dockworkers here, which has plagued the operation of the American Export Lines terminal for the last week, was settled tonight for the third time after two long conferences in the offices of Mayor Frank H. Eggers.

TEL AVIV, Israel, March 8 -- Premier David Ben-Gurion presented a draft of a four-year plan today at the first meeting of the Knesset (Assembly) in Tel Aviv after he had introduced the new Cabinet for approval. His plan, if accepted and carried out, would create the kind of state optimistically visualized by President Chaim Weizmann and Theodor Herzl, the father of Zionism.

In November, 1940, Soviet Foreign Minister Molotov visited Berlin, where, in extended conferences, German Foreign Minister von Ribbentrop repeatedly tried to get the Russian to state whether his country was prepared to cooperate in "the great liquidation of the British Empire." Mr. Churchill, in Volume II of "The Second World War," takes up the story:

Promotional effort by the men's clothing industry should aim at exceeding previous high volume figures, according to Sidney Rosenblum, president of the National Association of Shirt Pajama Manufacturers. He warned, however, that no further time can be lost in launching a campaign for the industry to avoid damaging consequences resulting from the slowdown in business.

Banks and business men throughout the country have been duped into accepting social security cards as a means of "identification" in a new fraudulent check racket, it was revealed yesterday. The disclosure was contained in a warning to its members by the Association of Casualty and Surety Companies following receipt of a report from the Social Security Administration.

The first branch library in Queens to lend music records to card holders will begin its new service Monday, it was announced yesterday. The project was carried through by the Flushing Council of Women's Organizations, which has fifty-nine member clubs and a membership of 8,500.

The Atchison, Topeka Santa Fe Railway reported yesterday for 1948 a net income of $62,842,771 after charges and taxes, equal after preferred dividend requirements to $23.33 each on the 2,427,060 common shares outstanding.

In November, 1940, Soviet Foreign Minister Molotov visited Berlin, where, in extended conferences, German Foreign Minister von Ribbentrop repeatedly tried to get the Russian to state whether his country was prepared to cooperate in "the great liquidation of the British Empire." Mr. Churchill, in Volume II of "The Second World War," takes up the story:

Promotional effort by the men's clothing industry should aim at exceeding previous high volume figures, according to Sidney Rosenblum, president of the National Association of Shirt Pajama Manufacturers. He warned, however, that no further time can be lost in launching a campaign for the industry to avoid damaging consequences resulting from the slowdown in business.

Banks and business men throughout the country have been duped into accepting social security cards as a means of "identification" in a new fraudulent check racket, it was revealed yesterday. The disclosure was contained in a warning to its members by the Association of Casualty and Surety Companies following receipt of a report from the Social Security Administration.

The first branch library in Queens to lend music records to card holders will begin its new service Monday, it was announced yesterday. The project was carried through by the Flushing Council of Women's Organizations, which has fifty-nine member clubs and a membership of 8,500.

WASHINGTON, March 8 (UP) -- The treason trial of Mildred E. (Axis Sally) Gillars ended today with a surprise defense plea. Her lawyer, James J. Laughlin, maintained that her alleged oath of allegiance to Germany automatically had freed the Maine-born defendant from guilt as a betrayer of the United States.
Ed McGrath of Brooklyn, the defending champion, gained the semi-finals in the Eastern indoor tennis championships last night by defeating William Lurie of New York, 6 -- 2, 7 -- 5.

CINCINNATI, March 8 -- Despite the many advances in medical science, chronic illness with its resultant physical disability "has become one of the nation's primary medical problems," Dr. Howard A. Rusk told delegates here today at the first annual scientific assembly of the American Academy of General Practice.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, March 8 -- The blame for what is termed the impending collapse of the Indonesian economy is placed on the United States in a report prepared by the Netherlands Government on the operation of the European Recovery Program in the Netherlands.
GENEVA, March 8 -- Trygve Lie, Secretary General of the United Nations, has asked the Swiss Government for definite action to improve facilities for United Nations headquarters in Geneva.
WASHINGTON, March 8 -- Industry spokesmen urged today that Congress not only retain the Taft-Hartley Act but put more "teeth" in the law which the Democrats have promised to repeal.

BEATRICE, Neb., March 8 -- Icy flood waters swirled through this southeastern Nebraska community today to bisect the city as streams in the Missouri River basin continued to overflow their banks and send ice racing toward the Missouri.

The number of Chorus Equity members on the council of Actors Equity will be increased from five to nine as the result of action by the council at a meeting here yesterday. The nine Chorus Equity representatives will serve for three years.
An aircraft "block system" similar in principle to a railroad's was described yesterday as a not too distant system of controlling the increasingly crowded air lanes.

Two new films will open in Broadway theatres this morning. At Loew's State, the offering is "Take Me Out to the Ball Game," a period romantic comedy with music featuring Gene Kelly, Frank Sinatra and Esther Williams. The Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer production, which was filmed in Technicolor, was directed by Busby Berkeley and produced by Arthur Freed from a screen play by Harry Tugend and George Wells and a story by Gene Kelly and Stanley Donen.

Selectivity continued the feature of trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, as the price average moved up for the third consecutive session. Although there was an easier tone in the steel and rail groups, the list closed irregularly higher on increased volume.

After an absence of a number of years, Michel Fokine's "Carnaval," or an approximation thereof, returned to the repertoire of the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo in its performance at the City Center last night. It was done without decor, without furniture, and without style, and there were many variations of comparatively minor moment in the action.
WINTER PARK, Fla., March 8 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Truman's remarks on receiving a degree at Rollins College today:
Edward C. Oelsner and Richard Cooley of the University Club were established as the new metropolitan squash racquets doubles champions last night.

After an absence of a number of years, Michel Fokine's "Carnaval," or an approximation thereof, returned to the repertoire of the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo in its performance at the City Center last night. It was done without decor, without furniture, and without style, and there were many variations of comparatively minor moment in the action.
WINTER PARK, Fla., March 8 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Truman's remarks on receiving a degree at Rollins College today:
Edward C. Oelsner and Richard Cooley of the University Club were established as the new metropolitan squash racquets doubles champions last night.

TOKYO, March 9 -- Emperor Hirohito believes Japan's war on the United States and her defeat and occupation have been "not without beneficial results" in so far as they have led to deeper understanding between the two nations, it was stated today.

ALBANY, March 9 -- A committee of the American Academy of Medicine appealed to Governor Dewey today to support the principle of state aid for the care of the mentally ill in general hospitals and to provide for the expansion on the local level of clinic facilities.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- Senator Watkins of Utah voiced the feelings of many when he took the Senate floor to complain of the secrecy in which the State Department has shrouded the process of composing the text of the proposed North Atlantic Defense Pact. His fears, said Senator Watkins, were these:
