Richard (Pancho) Gonzales, 20-year-old United States champion from Los Angeles, will seek a second national title next week when the forty-sixth United States Lawn Tennis Association indoor tournament is conducted on the courts of the Seventh Regiment Armory. The competition will start one week from today.

A doll with nylon "hair" that can be waved with a home permanent, a "tractor" tricycle with fire truck trailer, a bicycle with removable "outrigger" wheels in back, toy automobiles in the shape of armored bank cars and sanitation trucks, indicate the continuing trend toward realism and practicality evident in playthings being shown this week at the forty-sixth annual Toy Fair.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange fluctuated within a narrow range yesterday and closed 9 points net lower to 1 point net higher.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 9 -- A "National Family Allowance Act" for "some millions" of American families until the economic system "assures them genuine security" was advocated today by the National Catholic Conference on Family Life.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., March 9 (AP) -- Miss Pat O'Sullivan of Orange, Conn., continued the upset pattern in the Florida East Coast women's golf tournament today by eliminating Miss Mary Agnes Wall of Menominee, Mich.

TRENTON, N. J., March 9 -- State Senator Elmer H. Wene, Vineland chick raiser and former Democratic member of Congress, filed nominating petitions for Governor today with the office of Secretary of State. He will have the support of the Frank Hague Democratic state organization.

A long-distance telephone call from Hollywood, Calif., relayed to the New York Police Department, led last night to the discovery of a double murder and suicide in a London Terrace apartment in what the police put down as an astonishing version of the hackneyed theme of "the eternal triangle."

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 9 -- Engaging in their second and concluding intra-camp game before the opening of the regular exhibition campaign against the Indians next Saturday, the Giants today put on quite a show for the edification of Manager Leo Durocher as well as some 2,500 onlookers.

HAVANA, March 9 -- Cuba today protested to Russia against an "attempt to perturb international peace" through statements of Communist leaders in various countries that they would support Russia against their own countries in case of war.

Rug shampoo equipment that housewives will be able to rent in time for spring cleaning was introduced at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday by the Clarke Sanding Machine Company. The equipment, said to be the first offered on a rental basis for the housewife to operate by herself, includes two machines that resemble an electric floor polisher and a separate tank-type vacuum cleaner.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, March 9 -- Heated debate on the implications of the proposed North Atlantic pact marked the second day of a national study conference on world order being held here under the auspices of the Federal Council of the Churches of Christ in America.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- The House Education and Labor Committee approved today a bill for a minimum wage of 75 cents. House action within two weeks will be sought. The final committee vote was 15 to 6, with four members voting "present," but the key vote came just before that. It was 13 to 12.

The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People asked yesterday that the public realize that the organization "is not taking orders from any subversive group or power, Moscow or otherwise, because we are mapping our civil rights fight according to the guarantees of our American Constitution."

ROME, March 9 -- Premier Alcide de Gasperi began to make arrangements today to get quick parliamentary approval of Italy's participation in the Atlantic pact if and when an official invitation was received. Stiff Communist opposition is certain and the fight is expected to be particularly severe in the Senate where the Government's position is not so strong as it is in the Chamber of Deputies.

PARIS, March 9 -- On the heels of the convictions announced in the Sofia trial of the Protestant pastors comes information from Czechoslovakia that that nation's Catholic clergy must "clarify their stand" toward the "people's democratic state."

VERO BEACH, Fla., March 9 -- The baseball factory known as Dodgertown has to be seen to be believed. And even then you can't believe it. It's assembly line baseball at its fantastic best. Just the other day Jocko Conlan, the umpire, got a glimpse of it for the first time and gasped. "A circus, ain't it?" he chortled.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- The whole program for reorganization of the executive branch of the Government in the interest of efficiency and economy is being held up, dangerously in the view of some, by the protracted battle in the Senate over the proposed change in rules governing debate.

At least twenty-seven American airmen who fought in the Lafayette Flying Corps for the French in World War I will lift a cup and carve a fowl in the Lafayette Hotel at University Place and Ninth Street for the last time tomorrow night. The hotel will close its doors March 31.

While preparations for grand jury action went forward at Mineola, Governor Dewey, at Albany, signed an agreement with Michigan yesterday, making possible the extradition of Raymond M. Fernandez and Mrs. Martha Beck, confessed "lonely heart" slayers.
Unranked Daniel Rivkind of Brooklyn eliminated his second seeded rival yesterday to gain the semi-finals of the Eastern indoor tennis championships.

Nearly 100 tenants of the housing development at 2700 and 2800 Bronx Park East, the Bronx, picketed in front of the Empire State Building yesterday afternoon in protest against a rent increase granted to their landlord by the Office of the Housing Expediter.

The Northern Insurance Company of New York, with home offices at 83 Maiden Lane and 7 Gold Street, yesterday bought the adjoining eight-story store and office building at 87 Maiden Lane and 1 to 5 Gold Street, occupying a plot of about 3,500 square feet at the northwest corner of Maiden Lane and Gold Street.

The wool futures market was again under pressure yesterday. Grease wool contracts finished at net losses of 1.5 to 2.5 cents a pound on sales of 108,000 pounds. Wool-top contracts showed net losses of 0.5 to 1.2 cents a pound at the close.

LONDON, March 9 (AP) -- Two American horses were among the fifty-three final acceptors announced today for the 103d running of the Grand National Steeplechase March 26 at Aintree. Both are longshots in the betting on the four and a half mile classic.

MARTINSBURG, W. Va., March 9 -- Four young men, waving pistols in the fashion of the old Wild West, held up the Ambassador Limited of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad here this evening. Then they held up a night club near the scene of the train robbery, engaged in a gun duel with a passer-by, and escaped in two stolen automobiles, the second of which they took after wrecking the first on a curve.
Bloomingdale's Green Room spring collection, presented yesterday morning, told its story in trends, those that are firmly ensconsed for the coming season.

WASHINGTON, March 9 (AP) -- The Economic Cooperation Administrator, Paul G. Hoffman, rejected today a proposal that the agency require part of the insurance on Marshall Plan cargoes to be written with American companies. Senator Pat McCarran of Nevada, chairman of the Congressional "watchdog" committee on foreign aid, had proposed it.
A tentative jury was chosen by lot yesterday in the trial of the eleven Communists, but its composition is subject to change under examination by the court and challenge by opposing counsel.

The $65,000,000 Atlas Corporation, an investment concern headed by Floyd B. Odium, reported in its annual statement being issued today to its shareholders, that the indicated asset value of its common stock was about $27.18 on each of the 1,970,092 shares at the close of 1948, compared with $30.01 on Dec. 31, 1947.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee of the National Board of Review, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 a group of motion pictures to be shown, tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- Bare explanations, purposely incomplete for security reasons, took the place of partisan debate in the House today to win unanimous approval, by voice vote, of Air Force projects designed to buttress the United States from a "Pearl Harbor" and to develop facilities for testing guided missiles that could strike an enemy target at least 3,000 miles away.

WASHINGTON, March 9 (UP) -- Senate Republicans protested today when Mort C. Wallgren, former Washington State Governor, was listed in the new Congressional Directory as "chairman of the National Security Resources Board."
The American Labor party's initial experiment in selling milk below the retail market price was met yesterday with mixed expressions of enthusiasm and bitterness.
LONDON, March 9 -- The Brussels treaty consultative council, which consists of the Foreign Ministers of the five Western Union countries, will meet here Monday, the Foreign Office announced today.

A new "rapid advance" program to enable pupils with superior ability to complete three years of junior high school work in two will go into effect next September, the Board of Education announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- This country can avoid a major depression only by refusing to join those who are planning one for us, Secretary of Agriculture Charles F. Brannan, Coordinator of President Truman's Economic Program, declared today.
BOSTON, March 9 -- Charles Pomerantz of New York, pest-control expert, warned today of the need for controlling mite-bearing rodents in fighting disease in thickly populated areas.

Claudette Colbert may be lured back next fall to the Broadway stage which she deserted in 1929 for a career in motion pictures. If she decides to return it will be in "Lily Henry," a dramatization by Mae Cooper and her sister, Grace Klein, of Miss Cooper's novel.

The editorial in THE TIMES of March 9 on the Yonkers garbage strike settlement seems to me to overlook the principal lesson to be drawn from the whole episode -- namely, that you cannot put municipal officials or municipal employes in a legal straitjacket affording no avenue for the orderly adjustment of normal human disagreements without expecting sporadic eruptions.

A court battle between two California parents for the custody of their four children was decided yesterday by Referee Edwin L. Garvin in Supreme Court in favor of Zoel N. Lynch of Coalinga, Calif., the father, despite the children's own testimony against him.

As an interne who received part of his medical training under the Navy V-12 program during the war, I should like to give the reasons why I and many other young doctors hesitate to volunteer for military service.

The balance of the year will be a definite item promotion year in the variety store field, G. W. McCormick, assistant sales manager of the G. C. Murphy Company, operator of 210 variety stores throughout the nation, declared yesterday.
Everything from beach togs and cottons to chic town suits and romantic lace-shadowed nets made up the complete spring showing offered by Milgrim yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 9 -- The Overseas Reconstruction Fund of the Young Women's Christian Association, authorized at its Atlantic City convention three years ago, with a goal of $2,000,000, has reached $2,245,369 and checks are still coming in, the triennial convention was informed today by Mrs. Maurice P. Moore of New York, chairman of the Foreign Division of the National Board.

YONKERS, N. Y., March 9 -- Acting City Manager John A. Peterson said today that he would continue to observe the Condon-Wadlin law in whatever acts he performed before the end of his term. He will be replaced next Monday by Donald C. Wagner of Portsmouth, Ohio.

A 10 to 15 per cent reduction in the price of corkboard, effective on all orders received after Feb. 25, was announced yesterday by the Armstrong Cork Company. All classes of trade and all types of the company's corkboard insulation, standard, super-service, mastic-finish corkboard and corkboard roof insulation are affected by the reduction.

CHICAGO, March 9 (AP) -- Bill Durnan's shut-out record as a National Hockey League goalie came to an end at 309 minutes, 21 seconds tonight but his Montreal mates pulled out a 2-2 tie with the Black Hawks before 15,311 fans.

In a Washington dispatch published by THE NEW YORK TIMES on Feb. 24 anent a hearing the preceding day by the House Foreign Affairs Committee on the European Recovery Program, there occurred the following paragraph:

VIENNA, March 9 -- Paul Katscher, Austrian railroad expert kidnapped by the Russians on Dec. 19, 1947 -- the day before he was scheduled to depart for Geneva to represent Austria at a meeting of the railroad committee of the United Nations European Economic Commission -- has died of starvation in a Soviet prison camp in Lvov, according to a prisoner who escaped to Vienna.

Masterpieces of Chinese painting from the Fifteenth to the early Eighteenth Century make up an exhibition for the benefit of the Asia Institute to be held at the Wildenstein Galleries. A preview reception will be held this evening and the exhibition will open to the public tomorrow.

The Louvre Museum in Paris has lent for exhibition in the United States five silver vessels from the great Boscoreale treasure. They have just been put on view at the Metropolitan Museum and will remain here through April 14.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- The new chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, Representative John Kee of West Virginia, is a quiet, modest, 74-year-old man from the Pocahontas coal region around Bluefield.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended March 2:
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, March 9 -- A mood of profound depression has settled over the Netherlands on the question of Indonesia.

The future role of the nine C-4 type, emergency class passenger vessels, control of which passed from the Maritime Commission to the Army on March 1 upon orders of President Truman, was clarified yesterday by Maj. Gen. Ewart G. Plank, commandant of the New York Port of Embarkation, whose task will be operation of the ships.

" Functional and feminine" describe the fashion show of young clothes offered yesterday afternoon at B. Altman's. The latter was seen in the Sunday-go-to-meeting black faille redingote and the ingenue dance dress, while versatility marked the cotton shirtwaist and skirt costumes as well as the classic suits that were smartly accessorized.

The Reading Company last year invested $18,700,000 in new equipment and road improvements, according to the road's fifty-first annual report, released for publication today. This brought the total to $55,300,000 invested in improvements in the five-year period 1944-48.

Columbia University has received $300,000 more from the estate of William Nelson Cromwell, New York attorney who died July 19, 1948, as a result of reallocation by the estate's executors of a bequest made by Mr. Cromwell to the Alumni Association of the Columbia Law School, it was announced yesterday.

Sounding a note of pessimism on the future status of private power in the Northwest, Frank McLaughlin, president of the $144,000,000 Puget Sound Power and Light Company, told the 21,500 stockholders of the utility in the 1948 report, being distributed today, that "no other electric utility in the country is in a comparable situation to that of Puget."

When the Belgian Line's cargo vessel Stavelot leaves Pier 37, North River, this afternoon she will be carrying seven veterans of New York City's streets, the victims of the almost complete conquest of the city by the bus.

As the new State of Israel takes on full responsibility as an independent nation it faces no greater problem than that of its relations with the Arabs in general and with the Arab States. Premier Ben-Gurion's four-year plan, presented this week at the first Tel-Aviv meeting of the Assembly, had some reassuring words.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- The American Federation of Labor placed before Secretary of State Dean Acheson today a comprehensive program covering both international policy and labor's role in international affairs.
Sales and earnings last year of the Continental Can Company, Inc., and its wholly owned subsidiaries were the largest in its forty-four-year history, according to the annual report released today.

BOSTON, March 9 (AP) -- The Boston Bruins, scoreless in their last two games, went on a goal-making spree tonight to rout the New York Rangers, 8 -- 1. The victory, fashioned before 12,211 fans at the Boston Garden, assured the Bruins of a berth in the Stanley Cup play-offs and knocked the Rangers out of any chance at the National Hockey League's post-season series.
ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., March 9 (AP) -- The executive directors of the American Bowling Congress voted today to keep it a white man's organization.

Loans from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation this year may be the only way out of a difficult credit situation for his own and other airlines, J. H. (Slim) Carmichael, president of Capital Airlines, told the monthly luncheon of the Wings Club yesterday in the Biltmore Hotel.

Disclosing that the company had not shown a profit since December, Henry M. McAdoo, president of the United States Leather Company, told stockholders at the annual meeting here yesterday that there was no prospect for dividends on the Class A and the common stocks this year.
A delegation of seventeen Negro men and women protested yesterday to Police Commissioner William P. O'Brien, charging police brutality in Brooklyn upon members of their race.

Two new films will have local premieres today. At the Radio City Music Hall, the attraction is "Little Women," Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer's adaptation of the Louisa May Alcott novel featuring June Allyson, Peter Lawford, Elizabeth Taylor, Margaret O'Brien, Janet Leigh and Rossano Brazzi.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that the Northern Natural Gas Company, Omaha, Neb., had filed a registration statement covering 406,000 additional shares of the company's $10 par value common stock.

Those extra-long sofas, curved couches and especially deep "California-style" modern seating pieces -- which are growing in popularity as well as in size -- have clashed head-on with the dimensions of apartment house elevators and foyers.

Everyone wanted to get into the act, so the selection committee of the twelfth annual national invitation college basketball tournament yesterday shattered precedent and let them all join in the fun. Asa Bushnell's group, confronted with the headache of naming one of five candidates for the eighth berth in the post-season competition, bobbed up with the bright idea of making it a twelve-team tourney, four over par.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 9 -- One of the front-line Yankee hurlers went under fire today in an intra-squad game with highly satisfying results.
A complete reorganization of the way in which New York handles its detention facilities for delinquent children was recommended yesterday by the Community Service Society.

Boston, Mass., borrowed $5,000,000 yesterday on an issue of temporary loan notes dated March 14 and due on Nov. 2. The issue was bought by J. P. Morgan Co., Inc., and C. J. Devine Co., Inc., at 0.96 per cent discount plus $83.

BEFORE a great enterprise is launched the days pass slowly. The remedy is other urgent business, of which there was at this time certainly no lack. I was myself so pleased that our generals would take the offensive that I did not worry unduly about the result. Meanwhile, outside the small group who knew what was going to be attempted, there was plenty to talk about and do.

When Governor Dewey cited recently, as a horrible example of bond issue financing for public improvements, a "plank road" built in the Eighties that won't be paid for until 2147, a friend of ours got interested and did a bit of his own research.

LONDON, March 9 -- Members of the British military training mission in Burma are being evacuated from the hill town of Maymyo, near Mandalay, as a consequence of attacks there by rebel Karen tribesmen, it was officially reported here today.

AN editorial in this paper last Saturday answered all who go around saying that "very few GI's have been in real combat" and that "Americans have no idea of the realities of war." We'd like to see that editorial pasted in a number of hats -- when their owners stop talking through them long enough. The editorial pointed out that the Army and Navy's casualties were 1,134,000 and that of these 314,000 were killed.

The North American College in Rome was identified yesterday as the element of the Roman Catholic Church that has negotiated an arrangement with the Motion Picture Association of America for the transfer of frozen American film earnings in Italy to this country.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- Spokesmen of organizations devoted to the interests of blind persons asked the House Ways and Means Committee today to protect the special needs of the blind under President Truman's Public Welfare Bill.

GENEVA, March 9 -- The United Nations World Health Organization has determined to assist Eastern European countries to get penicillin machinery despite a decision of the United States not to export it to those lands, it was learned here today.
Despite the spring-like weather in metropolitan New York, competitive skiers will find the heaviest period of activity scheduled for this week-end.

LAKE SUCCESS, March 9 -- Britain asked today that the United Nations terminate its child-feeding programs by summer in four Central and Eastern European countries on the ground that recovery had reached pre-war levels.

SHANGHAI, March 9 -- A United States pilot and two other crew members of a Chinese airliner that mysteriously left its assigned flight path, and landed in Communist-held Tsinan on Jan. 30, returned here today and told of having been kidnapped in mid-air.

Whether the Dutch are attempting to undo Indonesian independence and reassert their imperialism there was sharply debated last night by four experts on "What's on Your Mind," the weekly radio forum of Station WQXR.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- The proposed North Atlantic defense pact will be published soon and probably will be signed early in April after a period of public debate, Secretary of State Dean Acheson said today.

There are 200,000,000 children in Europe, the Middle East and the Far East who need everything in life to fatten, warm and heal their bodies and to renourish their minds -- and the adult world sits by, continues its deliberations and argues whether money shall or shall not be raised to take them out of their terrible plight.
INDIANAPOLIS, March 9 (AP) -- Farmers have been hit hard by price declines but they shouldn't feel sorry for themselves, a Cornell University agricultural economist observed tonight.

The Phelps Dodge Corporation reported yesterday for 1948 a consolidated net income of $52,247,294 after charges and taxes, but before mine depletion. This is equal to $10.30 each on the 5,071,250 capital shares outstanding. For 1947, the company reported a net income of $43,817,664, or $8.64 a share.
BALTIMORE, March 9 -- The largest ship ever built in Maryland touched water for its first time today after it sailed gracefully down the way at the Bethlehem Steel, Sparrows Point shipyards.

The new 3,800-ton motor vessel Horta, latest addition to the fleet of passenger-cargo ships operated by the Portuguese Line (Companhia de Navegacao Carregadores Acoreanos) is due here Monday on her maiden voyage from Lisbon, it was announced yesterday by Flomarcy Company, Inc., 90 Broad Street, agents for the line in this country.

Never behind, the New York Knickerbockers routed the Washington Capitols, 90 -- 74, before 7,193 fans at Madison Square Garden last night. It was the fifth straight victory in the Basketball Association of America for the New Yorkers, who strengthened their hold on second place in the Eastern Division.

The controversy over the court reorganization plan sponsored by Presiding Justice David W. Peck of the Appellate Division has turned into a full dress battle, it became evident yesterday. Bar association and civic group leaders are lined up behind Justice Peck, but a majority of the city's judiciary, influential with the State Legislature, are on the opposing side.

FRANKFORT, Germany, March 9 (AP) -- American officials announced today that Gen. Lucius D. Clay had barred all German business men with pro-Nazi records from going to the German industry show opening in New York April 9.

SAN JUAN, P. R., March 9 -- Some 400 Protestant leaders from the United States and Latin America arrived here to take part in a three-day celebration, Friday through Sunday, commemorating the fiftieth anniversary of Protestant mission work in Puerto Rico.

Flower shows are not reserved for our colleagues in the garden news department; newspaper and magazine food editors went to one the other day specially staged just for them. The chief and only exhibitor was Mrs. Eleanor Street, who decorates cakes with blossoms and leaves that not only axe realistic, but turn out to be good to eat, too.

RHODES, March 9 -- The report that Israeli troops were on the move in the Negeb near Aqaba caused concern tonight in United Nations circles lest such action disrupt armistice talks here that began today to make real progress.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- The House Agriculture Committee, by a vote of 24 to 3, today approved a bill to take all Federal taxes off margarine but to ban the sale of yellow margarine in interstate commerce.

PARIS, March 9 -- The text of the proposed North Atlantic defense pact, available here until now to only three of four top officials of the Foreign Ministry, was read to the Cabinet today by Foreign Minister Robert Schuman. Meanwhile fairly full summaries appeared for the first time in the press and the Government began what is considered the difficult task of explaining the pact to the public.

PRINCETON, N. J., March 9 -- In its last home appearance of the season, Princeton defeated Harvard tonight, 63 -- 46, and tied Yale or first place in the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League as the result of the Ells' loss to Columbia.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- Dean Acheson, Secretary of State, told Alexander S. Panyushkin, Soviet Ambassador, today that the United States did not recognize the diplomatic immunity claimed for Valentin A. Gubitchev, the Russian employe of the United Nations who was arrested last week in New York with Judith Coplon, a Department of Justice employe.
WILMINGTON, Del., March 9 (AP) -- E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. reported today $968,700,000 of sales for 1948. The figure -- a peacetime record -- was some $185,000,000 greater than in 1947.

BUENOS AIRES, March 9 -- After the Radicals, the Opposition party, had walked out of the Constitutional Convention late last night in protest against "steamrollering" tactics, the Peronista majority approved unanimously the principles of the new proposed Constitution.

After many months of discussions and negotiations the final draft of the North Atlantic Security Pact has been completed and has been submitted to the sponsoring governments for their consideration. It has already been informally approved by the members of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, and since the text was drafted in constant consultation with all the interested governments it may be assumed that their approval is assured.

ALBANY, March 9 -- Negotiations for a settlement of the Republican revolt over Governor Dewey's budget and tax increase program got under way today. Administration spokesmen offered to prune $20,000,000 from the proposed appropriation, but dissidents from Westchester and Erie Counties held out for more.

KEY WEST, Fla., March 9 -- President Truman was ready to begin his vacation in earnest today after wrestling with figures and the gobledygook language of Form 1040. In other words, he settled his income tax.
WASHINGTON, March 9 -- Jurors in the treason trial of Mildred E. (Axis Sally) Gillars were at least temporarily deadlocked tonight after ten and a half hours of deliberation.

ALBANY, March 9 -- Governor Dewey declared today that he would not recommend a general investigation of Mayor O'Dwyer's administration of New York City without specific evidence before him that would warrant such action.

A tiny corner of what used to be the attic of the American Museum of Natural History is the planning center for a far-flung program of esoteric studies conducted by Dr. Theodore C. Schneirla, who is one of the world's leading ant psychologists.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., March 9 -- Brooklyn Polytech and Hofstra College advanced to the final round of the metropolitan small college basketball tournament tonight in Hofstra's gymnasium. Favored Brooklyn Poly scored a hard-earned success over Pratt Institute, also of Brooklyn, 41 to 35, while Hofstra subdued Adelphi College, 72 to 61.

Attendance dipped slightly yesterday on the second day of the display of fall leathers at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, but the moderate optimism of the opening day appeared to have gained ground. Registration yesterday at the event, sponsored by the Tanners' Council of America, was estimated at about 3,500, bringing the two-day total to above 8,500.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 9 -- Borba, official newspaper of the Yugoslav Communist party, wrote an unexpected epilogue today to the trial of the fifteen Protestant ministers that ended yesterday in Sofia, by casting grave doubts on the testimony of two of the star witnesses against the defendants.
PARIS, March 9 -- Denying charges brought against their clients by a military court, attorneys for several defendants held for espionage today asked their release on bail.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., March 9 -- The advocates of "white supremacy'' at Southern polls are employing "blind-alley" tactics in their efforts to bar Negroes from voting, the Southern Regional Council reported today. The flexibility of the United States Constitution and the humanistic legal interpretations of the Federal courts, the council said, are blocking every "white supremacy" move "to find the magic combination of ambiguous wording, legalisms and technicalities which allow them to make possible the impossible."

In one of the dullest trading sessions of the year, prices on the New York Stock Exchange moved listlessly in a narrow range yesterday. Changes ranged from fractions to more than a point. During the afternoon the ticker was practically at a standstill with transactions in leading issues extremely scarce.
Ronson Art Metal Works, Inc., Newark, N. J., to Grey Advertising Agency, Inc., effective June 1.

NANKING, March 9 -- Busy Communist troop movements on the upper bank of the Yangtze River between Nanking and Shanghai kept local political nerves on edge here today as Acting President Li Tsung-jen tried to muster a new Cabinet to plug another hole in the weakened Nationalist political, economic and military dykes.
Latest reports from Maine favor an extremely early ice-out this spring. According to a number of wardens, the state should have the earliest ice-out since records have been kept.

Magistrate Joseph Levine reduced yesterday the high bail he had imposed last week on six youths accused of felonious assault and violations of the Sullivan Law. The six, who were arrested after the clash of two gangs near Public School 55, waived examination yesterday in Youth Term of the Bronx Magistrates' Court and were held for the grand jury.

The first break in official published prices for domestic bituminous coal was posted yesterday by the Pittsburgh Consolidation Coal Company, one of the worlds largest producers. The company reduced industrial coal prices 15 to 40 cents a ton in the northern West Virginia field, fulfilling expectations of buyers here who had awaited official quotations for the past week.
LONDON, March 9 -- With selling pressure absent and with some professional bear covering there was a slightly better tone in the stock market here today.

Neither settlement nor truce was reached yesterday in the eight-week strike of cemetery workers who had changed their union affiliation Tuesday night in an effort to meet one of Cardinal Spellman's objections to the walkout.
Two persons were burned to death and three others were injured in a fire caused by the explosion of an oil stove in a two-story frame house at 616 Herkimer Street, Brooklyn, yesterday at 8:09 A. M.

Capt. William P. Odom, who set a new light-plane distance-record of 5,300 miles last Tuesday when he flew non-stop from Honolulu to Teterboro, N. J., announced last night that next Monday he would start a flying tour of the United States to raise funds for the American Red Cross.
OMAHA, March 9 -- Flooding in the Missouri River valley eased considerably today as cold weather returned overnight and slowed the rise of streams. Temperatures fell as much as 20 degrees.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- Representative Wright Patman, Democrat, of Texas, demanded today that the Federal Reserve Board reduce immediately the margin requirement for purchasing stocks to 50 per cent. The present requirement is 75 per cent.

A record number of textile manufacturers responded to the Quartermaster's invitation to bid on the Army Air Force uniform fabrics, it was learned yesterday at the New York Quartermaster Purchasing Office when bids were opened. A total of 122 bids was received on the wool, rayon, and cotton fabrics needed to make the new blue garb, with the range of prices giving a definite indication of the current downward trend in textiles.

WASHINGTON, March 9 (UP) -- The House today passed by voice vote and sent to the Senate a $2,211,794,085 spending bill to operate the Department of Labor and Federal Security Agency during the fiscal year 1950 beginning July 1.

Following closely upon reduction of prices of pig lead, the National Lead Company yesterday reduced prices of a wide variety of lead products in the first major price decline since the end of Office of Price Administration controls.

Consolidated net income of the Allied Chemical and Dye Corporation for 1948 reached a new high of $31,771,204, equal to $14.35 a share on the 2,401,288 shares of no-par common stock outstanding, according to the annual report issued for publication today.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- The Senate coalition of Republicans and Northern Democrats opened today its first frontal assault upon the Southern filibuster group. Since Feb. 28, the Southerners with many interruptions for other Senate business, have been standing up on the floor in resistance to a hardening of the closure or "gag" rule.

Attacking the present leadership of Tammany Hall, the Fair Deal Democrats, an organization of youthful members of that party, has sent out letters from headquarters at 8 West Fortieth Street, asking for contributions to a proposed $100,000 campaign fund, it was learned yesterday.
BERLIN, March 9 -- All Allied nationals crossing the frontier of the United States zone will be subjected to customs inspection and can cross the frontier only at selected points after April 15.
AMMAN, Transjordan, March 9 -- The Defense Ministry reported tonight a clash between Transjordan's Arab Legion and Israeli armed forces moving toward the Gulf of Aqaba.

DETROIT, March 9 (AP) -- The Detroit Red Wings won the National Hockey League championship -- their first in six years -- by blanking the Toronto Maple Leafs, defending champions, 5 to 0, before 13,664 delighted fans tonight.

The gas-range industry has cut back production 50 per cent because of a sharp drop in retail demand, Arthur Stockton, president of the American Stove Company, revealed yesterday. He declared that the industry is having difficulty maintaining even this reduced operation because of a continuing lack of retail reorders of any consequence.

To commemorate the presentation to President Truman of America's Democratic Legacy Award for 1948 by the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith, "The Goal Is Freedom," a special half-hour drama on human relations, will be heard over CBS from 9:30 to 10 P. M. on April 6.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- In the midst of apparently succeeding Administration tactics designed to block the veterans' pension (Rankin) bill, the House was told today that this program had a "privileged" status and thus could be forced to a voting showdown at any time.

LEWES, Del., March 9 -- American newspaper men completed a seventeen-hour vigil at 5 P. M. today waiting for Rear Admiral E. G. Glinkov, Soviet naval attache, and Capt. K. P. Ryzhkov, assistant Soviet naval attache, here from Washington, to come ashore from the cruiser Milwaukee lying in anchor five miles up the Delaware Bay, near Brown Shoals, only once more to receive a polite but firm Russian "Niet" to requests to go aboard.

The 'cello recital given last night in Carnegie Hall by Edmund Kurtz with Anthony di Bonaventura pianist, as his collaborator, avoided the stock succession of pieces of Bach, Brahms and Boellmannn, and offered much music that was entertaining, idiomatic for the stringed instrument, and of varied character.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 9 -- Form took a beating tonight as aggressive Columbia hustled to a sparkling 58-54 victory over Yale in a loosely played basketball contest. The defeat, coupled with Princeton's triumph over Harvard, dropped the Elis into a first-place tie with the Tigers in the Eastern Intercollegiate League.

Clendenin J. Ryan, an aide to the late Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia, challenged Mayor O'Dwyer yesterday to say whether Frank Costello, gambler, ex-convict and intimate of top politicians, was "the real boss of New York City."
SARASOTA, Fla., March 9 (AP) -- The Cardinals and Browns failed to settle their sizzling park-rental feud today in a one-hour hearing before Baseball Commissioner Albert B. Chandler.

PORT ELIZABETH, South Africa, March 9 (Reuters) -- With only a minute to spare, England today raced to a thrilling victory over South Africa in the fifth and final cricket test match. The English won by three wickets, scoring 174 runs in 95 minutes after a sporting South African declaration.

GENEVA, March 9 (AP) -- A secret United Nations conference reached final agreement here last week on setting up an all-European highway network, it was learned today. With car-ferry jumps, it would link Scotland to the Russian frontier and Norway to the southern tip of Italy.

Although it appears uncertain just when the Federal Communications Commission will "kick" television signals into the proposed new upper frequencies, at least part of the television industry could be made ready for the shift "in a matter of weeks" and have new sets in production in "six months," it was learned yesterday at the convention of the Institute of Radio Engineers.

THE NEW YORK TIMES of Feb. 28 publishes some excerpts from a survey by the Jewish Labor Committee, released at its convention in Atlantic City, concerning the fate of the Jews in four countries behind the Iron Curtain.

Speculation has arisen anew as to whether or not the steel industry and others which had been using the basing-point system of pricing would reinstate their former pricing methods if Congressional approval is given to a pending bill establishing a moratorium on Federal Trade Commission action against sellers using delivered price quotations.

In the arbitration proceedings soon to begin between several private bus lines and their employes to settle a considerable body of disputed issues the New York City government is not directly an interested party. For all practical purposes, however, the city is the controlling influence, because it is within the framework of city limitations on bus line revenues that the arbitrator must make his decision.

LOS ANGELES, March 9 (UP) -- Igor Stravinsky, noted composer, today was denied $250,000 damages from the Leeds Music Company on his contention that the company falsely associated his name with a popular ballad.

Widespread efforts to tighten up legislation regarding the licensing of drivers are reported by the American Association of Motor Vehicle Administrators. In Nevada and Arizona bills have been introduced which would bring state laws into conformity with the uniform code promulgated some years ago.

VERO BEACH, Fla., March 9 -- It was a day of frustration for a lot of Dodgers and would-be Dodgers on the various fields of carnage here today. Six teams piled up a total of 53 runs, but only two triumphs resulted.

It was "bottoms up" last night at the 165th Regiment Armory, Twenty-third Street and Lexington Avenue. The bock beer season had started and in recognition of that foaming fact New York and New Jersey brewers staged a Spring Bock Festival, for the benefit of the American Red Cross.

Another book by a newspaper woman has been scheduled for publication this spring. Last month Knopf issued "Washington By-Line," by Bess Furman of THE NEW YORK TIMES. In June Harper will issue "Newspaperwoman," by Agness Underwood.

ALBANY, March 9 -- The future of the Long Island Rail Road, now in bankruptcy, and the need for adequate transportation facilities in the communities it serves were discussed today by Governor Dewey at a conference with J. Russel Sprague, Nassau Republican leader, and Frank Kenna, Queens Republican leader.
A young Latvian farmer and his wife stepped timidly off the Marine Flasher yesterday morning soon after the refugee ship had docked here.
Two players from Kentucky's National champions and one each from St. Louis, Yale and Denver were named yesterday to the 1949 Associated Press All-America collegiate basketball team.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 9 (AP) -- An advertising expert advised business today that the return of a buyer's market called for bold decisions and more enterprise.

The Department of Welfare, asserting its legal right to withhold specific information on relief clients, declined yesterday to discuss the case of a father of ten who on Tuesday was sentenced to the workhouse for sixty days.

CHICAGO, March 9 (AP) -- M. S. Szymczak, a governor of the Federal Reserve System, said today the danger in the present financial situation is in the temptation to adopt a policy of chronic deficit financing.
WASHINGTON, March 9 (UP) -- The festivities which normally featured the birthday of Representative Sol Bloom gave way today to a solemn commemoration for the New York Congressman.

The nation's gasoline supplies rose 1,983,000 barrels last week to a new peak of 126,365,000, according to the weekly figures of the American Petroleum Institute. A week earlier, they were 124,382,000 barrels and a year earlier, 111,474,000.

The Railway Express Agency, confronted by a work stoppage and slow-downs in all its terminals in the metropolitan area, placed an embargo yesterday on all air and rail shipments of less than a carload into, out of and through New York.

The Columbia Scholastic Press Association will open its twenty-fifth annual three-day convention today at 1:30 P. M. in Columbia University's McMillin Academic Theatre, Broadway at 116th Street, the association's director, Joseph M. Murphy, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- The Munitions Board of the National Military Establishment denied today that shipments of manganese from India to the Supreme Command of the Allied Powers in Japan are competing with American needs and the national stockpiling program for strategic materials.

The Southern Railway borrowed yesterday $11,850,000 on equipment-trust certificates maturing semi-annually from Oct. 1, 1949, to April 1, 1964, at an interest cost of about 2.515 per cent. The issue of serial certificates was sold at competitive bidding to Salomon Brothers Hutzler and associates at a bid of 99.0413 for interest of 2 3/8 per cent.
The United Jewish Appeal received a check for $250,000 yesterday from David Dubinsky, president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 9 -- Niven Busch, screen writer and independent producer, announced today that he had signed Lew Ayres for the leading male role in "Daybreak," a photoplay which Busch has written for production by Showtime Pictures, Inc., an independent company in which he and his wife, Teresa Wright, are partners.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Thursday, March 10 (AP) -- The United party of the veteran political leader Field Marshal Jan Christiaan Smuts was making a comeback today in the initial returns from South Africa's provincial elections.

HALLANDALE, Fla., March 9 (AP) -- Fred W. Hooper, whose Olympia won the Flamingo Stakes at Hialeah last Thursday, sent out his fleet filly, Silly Gyp, to capture today's featured Claire Purse before 13,302 fans at Gulfstream Park.
CHICAGO, March 9 (AP) -- Marshall Field Co. today reported a net income of $11,234,077, equal to $5.45 a common share, for 1948, compared with $10,556,783, or $5.10 a share, in 1947.

MIDDLETOWN, N. J., March 9 -- Fred B. Philipp, New Jersey's No. 1 oologist, plans soon to augment his collection of 50,000 North American birds' eggs with a set or two of those of the bristle-thighed curlew, a Siberian species of the snipe family recently reported to have been found nesting in the Alaskan wastelands.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- Century-old laws providing for low-cost circulation of periodicals as a means of promoting distribution of knowledge came today under official Congressional study as the Post Office Department requested multiplication of rates for handling second-class printed matter.

LONDON, March 9 -- Sir Alec Seath Kirkbride, British Minister in Amman, has informed the Foreign Office that Transjordanian official sources have reported an Israeli military force moving in the eastern Negeb in the direction of the port of Aqaba.

The quick thinking of 11-year-old James Magennis of 507 East Fortieth Street, Brooklyn, a 6B pupil in Little Flower Parochial School, was rewarded yesterday when he received $29.58 from the Brooklyn Police Property Clerk's office.
HOLLYWOOD, March 9 (UP) -- Mrs. Elsie Thomas sobbed tonight that she was talking to her daughter and son-in-law on the telephone when she heard three shots.

The by-election won by Britain's Labor Government in London's South Hammersmith area two weeks ago proves that the party "will certainly be returned in the next general election," probably in May or June of 1950, Francis Williams, former public relations adviser to Prime Minister Clement Attlee, declared here yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, March 9 -- Countries admitting displaced persons from Europe for resettlement were urged by the United Nations Economic and Social Council today to take in a greater proportion of intellectual refugees.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 9 -- A "large" earthquake shook a 200-mile-long stretch of Northern and Central California before daybreak today, routing householders from their beds, rattling or breaking windows and toppling a few chimneys.

For many years the highest authority in New York State's educational system has been our Board of Regents, with whom the Commissioner of Education and the Department of Education constitute the University of the State of New York.

ALBANY, March 10 -- A suggestion that women's clubs and similar groups undertake a scholarship program to train leaders in home economics was made today at a conference on family living held under the auspices of the State Education Department's bureau of home economics education.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- The National Advisory Council, at the request of the Department of State, is formulating recommendations of measures that this Government might take to encourage the international flow of capital, it was announced today.

Butter is being offered today for 73 cents a pound in many stores throughout the city and for 71 cents in several of the chains. These tariffs, although they represent a two-cent decline since last Friday, are described by wholesale dealers as "just temporary."

Directors of General Public Utilities Corporation yesterday fixed $41 a share as the price at which 800,000 shares of common stock of New York State Electric and Gas Corporation would be offered to General Public Utility stockholders, "subject to prompt issuance of appropriate orders by the Securities and Exchange Commission."
WASHINGTON, March 10 -- A Federal jury found Mildred E. (Axis Sally) Gillars guilty of treason today for broadcasting Nazi propaganda during World War II.

Valentin A. Gubitchev, Russian engineer employed by the United Nations, and Judith Coplon, Brooklyn-born analyst in the internal security section of the Department of Justice, were in dicted on espionage charges yesterday by the special Federal grand jury investigating subversive activities.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 10 -- Borba, official newspaper of the Yugoslav Communist party, asserted today that its daily circulation had increased by more than 100,000 copies since the Communist Information Bureau expelled the Yugoslav party and that today it had the largest circulation of any Communist newspaper outside the Soviet Union.

Hopes for an early resumption of negotiations in the eight-week strike at Calvary and Gate of Heaven Cemeteries were expressed yesterday when an American Federation of Labor charter was presented to the strikers who had quit the Congress of Industrial Organizations under pressure from Cardinal Spellman.

The Continental Oil Company reported yesterday for 1948 a consolidated net income of $54,216,729 after charges, taxes and reserves, equal to $11.24 each on the 4,879,500 capital shares outstanding. Net income in 1947 was $31,356,663, or $6.61 a share.

TEL AVIV, Israel, March 10 -- Israel's first elected Government received a vote of confidence from the Knesset (Assembly) today and Premier David Ben-Gurion's four-party coalition Cabinet was accepted by 73 votes to 45.

Robert P. Patterson, former Secretary of War, and Senator Harley M. Kilgore of West Virginia agreed last night that the House Un-American Activities Committee had abused its privileges and had violated the rights of private citizens, but they disagreed on the remedy.

The Viking Press, Inc., publishers of Gene Fowler's forthcoming biography of the late James J. Walker, asked the Supreme Court yesterday to stop Cosmopolitan magazine from advertising that the complete book is appearing in its March number, whereas only a 26,000-word condensation is printed there.

A silver-haired gentleman with keen blue eyes and leathery skin came into the office and thrust out both hands. "See them?" he asked. The hands were remarkable for the bumps and lumps and knots and burls all over the fingers; these were hands that had had a career of violence.

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 10 -- Although it had been his intention to end the intra-squad games, Leo Durocher, who can change his mind on a moment's notice if expediency demands it, decided today his athletes needed a little more regular baseball in order to be ready to face the world champion Indians in Saturday's exhibition opener at Tucson.
FRANKFORT, Germany, March 10 -- The United States and British Military Governors have agreed to throw the German economy open to non-Germans for the first time since the end of the war.

VERO BEACH, Fla., March 10 -- "These managerial worries are getting me down," plaintively remarked Peewee Reese today after his team had dropped its third straight, this time being shellacked by Bruce Edwards' boys, 12 -- 4.

Snow continues to be scarce this unseasonable winter with the result that skiing is extremely limited in the eastern United States, while our Canadian neighbors in the Laurentians report the usual "good." The Weather Bureau offered some encouragement in its report last night that snows were expected in the higher elevations and northern portions of this state and New England.

A situation almost without parallel in the long history of the American Institute of Architects has developed in the form of a lively contest over election of officers as part of the institute's eighty-first convention to be held next week in Houston, Tex.

Mayor O'Dwyer extensively modified yesterday the position he had taken when he berated the Board of Higher Education for trying to "stuff" its selection for president of Queens College "down the throats" of the people of Queens.

LAKELAND, Fla., March 10 -- Many small, independent colleges in this country are in serious financial plights and may have to close their doors unless they receive immediate support, prominent Southern educators warned here today.

A wooden tray that has numerous uses as well as a broad aim in life is the latest product of United Specialties, Inc., a woodworking shop in Mount Vernon, N. Y., for disabled veterans, most of whom are amputees.

Earning assets of the reporting New York City member banks were increased $56,000,000 last week, according to the data issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. Business loans, however, underwent a further decline of $14,000,000 during the weekly reporting period ended on Wednesday, and repayments by sales finance, tobacco, soap and meat companies were prominent factors in the decrease.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 10 -- Having signed John Wayne and Randolph Scott to multiple picture deals yesterday, Warner Brothers is now negotiating similar contracts with John Garfield and Kirk Douglas, it was learned today. The prospective Garfield agreement involves two pictures a year for five years, while the negotiations with Douglas look toward one picture a year for five years.
Sales of R. H. Macy Co., Inc., in the six and twelve months ended on last Jan. 29 were at new high levels, according to the semi-annual unaudited report issued for publication today.
TRENTON, N. J., March 10 -- Rent control legislation and amendments to a bill to curb racial discrimination occupied attention today of the New Jersey Legislature.

TRENTON, N. J., March 10 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll, Republican, State Senator Elmer H. Wene, Democrat, and four other candidates completed the filing today of nominating petitions for the office of Governor. This was the final day for filing.

Borough President James A. Burke of Queens appeared last night at a rally in Forest Hills, held to oppose a proposed zoning change that would permit the Bulova Watch Company to erect a factory in that community.
W. Frank Watkins, district director of the Immigration and Naturalization Service in New York since 1942, will retire from the post on March 31, it was announced here yesterday.

In opening the meeting of the Inter-County Republican Committee for Return of Good Government to New York City at the National Republican Club last night, Secretary of State Thomas J. Curran, New York County chairman, criticized John E. Carton, president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association for having said that Mayor O'Dwyer should be drafted if he did not run voluntarily for re-election.

The United Seamen's Service, on the verge of liquidation a year ago, will continue indefinitely its program of providing housing, food, medical care and recreational facilities for merchant seamen in overseas ports, its executive committee announced yesterday.

Giuseppe Arcuri the Cobbler pegged a dainty slipper heel yesterday in his tiny shop at 241 East Fifty-fourth Street. Late afternoon sun struggled through the living jungle in the shop window and traced lovely leaf patterns on the cobbler's white thatch, on his white shirt and on his blue work apron.

The largest wage dividend in its history will be distributed by the Eastman Kodak Company on Monday when it will send about $13,000,000 to about 50,000 employes in the Western Hemisphere, it was announced yesterday in Rochester.

BURLESON, Tex., March 10 (UP) -- Dr. John W. Lord, dean of the Texas Christian University Graduate School, was found slain today in the lonely farm retreat he took for his home little more than a month ago.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 10 -- On Saturday Bobby Brown will launch a campaign here which will determine whether he will continue as a major league ball player or turn his attention exclusively to the career in medicine for which he has been studying at Tulane University.

Federal Judge Harold R. Medina threatened contempt of court proceedings by implication yesterday against one of the lawyers for the eleven Communists on trial before him for "willful and deliberate disobedience" of court orders.

LAKE SUCCESS, March 10 -- The United States hit out today at the Netherlands policy in the East Indies and insisted that The Hague allow the Republic of Indonesia to set itself up again as a working government.

Charles G. Mortimer Jr., vice president of General Foods Corporation, was re-elected chairman of the Advertising Council yesterday at the annual meeting of the organization's board of directors. Three new vice chairmen chosen are: Lee H. Bristol, president of the Bristol-Myers Company; Leo Burnett, president of Leo Burnett Company, Inc., and Albert E. Winger, president of the Crowell-Collier Publishing Company.
LONDON, March 10 -- The Labor party maintained its unbroken run of successes in parliamentary by-elections since the general election in 1945 by another victory at the polls today.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 10 -- Ship operators and stevedoring companies representing all West Coast ports voted at a membership meeting here today to set up a single maritime employers' group, to be known as the Pacific Maritime Association, to take over the functions of the Pacific American Shipowners Association and the Waterfront Employers Association.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- David T. Roadley, representing the American Cotton Manufacturers Association, told a House Labor subcommittee today that the burden of proof was on those who want to repeal the Taft-Hartley Law and return to the situation which prevailed before its enactment.

CHICAGO, March 10 -- There is not yet an adequate "reserve shelf of public works," blueprinted and ready for the contractor, to "stabilize the construction cycle and bolster the business cycle" in the event of a business recession, Maj. Gen. Philip B. Fleming, Administrator of the Federal Works Agency, declared here today.

Wheelchair basketball returned to New York yesterday morning when twelve members of the Flying Wheels, national champion paraplegic team from Birmingham Veterans' Hospital, Van Nuys, Calif., arrived here from Boston to play teams from the Bronx and Halloran Veterans' Administration Hospitals and the St. Albans Naval Hospital.

ALBANY, March 10 -- A bill that would automatically bar from school employment any person affiliated with an organization listed as subversive by the Board of Regents was introduced today with the backing of Republican leaders of the Legislature.

TRIPOLIS, Greece, March 10 -- Things are looking up in the Peloponnesus. Here in this agricultural center, the capital of Arcadia and the largest inland town on the peninsula, the very faces of the people reflect a change that has taken place since the Greek Army started its major offensive against the Communist-led rebel bands last Christmas week.
WASHINGTON, March 10 -- James Forrestal, Secretary of Defense, today named three senior military representatives to the Joint Weapons Evaluation Group of the National Military Establishment.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- The Joint Brazil-United States Technical Commission reported unanimously today that the economic development of Brazil "should be accelerated by carefully considered programs of governmental expenditures, by policies favoring a balanced development of Brazil's resources by private enterprise, and by policies directed specifically toward controlling inflation and meeting the balance-of-payments problem."

It is not pleasant to be informed by the New York Society for Prevention of Cruelty to Children, through its annual report, that neglect, abuse and criminal maltreatment of children in the city were on the rise in 1948. Nor can we take any satisfaction in knowing that the 430 cases of adult criminal offenses against children brought to courts in Manhattan represented an increase of 16 per cent in such arrests in the year.

Steve Belloise, Bronx middleweight who is one of the leading contenders for the championship of his division, will risk his standing tonight when he tackles J. T. Ross of San Jose, Calif., in the main bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden.
Welfare Commissioner Raymond M. Hilliard moved yesterday to get early action on his plan for a temporary shelter for the supervision and treatment of delinquent children.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- In a compromise forced by an opposition seeking to end all regulation, Administration leaders in the House, battling to obtain a fifteen-months' extension of rent control from March 31, agreed today to accept an amendment guaranteeing a "reasonable return" for landlords.

If it takes you more than three minutes to read this story, you are wasting valuable time. This is the contention of Dr. J. Wayne Wrightstone, assistant director in charge of tests and measurements for the Board of Education, who asserts that there is no valid reason why any adult of average intelligence cannot read at the rate of 250 or 300 words a minute.

Operations of the Distillers Corporation-Seagrams, Ltd., and its subsidiaries for the six months ended with last January produced a net profit of $19,853,354 after all charges, including $14,395,000 income taxes, according to the report announced yesterday.
BERLIN, March 10 -- The United States Air Force today announced plans for personnel replacements that would facilitate carrying on the airlift to Soviet - blockaded Berlin for years, if necessary.
HALLANDALE, Fla., March 10 (AP) -- Carrara Marble today became the shortest-priced winner of the Gulfstream Park meeting when he paid 9 to 20 in the Kendall Purse.

CHICAGO, March 10 -- Contract negotiations between the Chicago Newspaper Publishers Association and Chicago Typographical Union 16 ended today with all sections of the contract settled with the exception of wages and the term the new contract will run.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Special school programs for the children of migrant agricultural workers, estimated at nearly 1,000,000, were urged in a study issued today by the National Education Association.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Strong sentiment for curbing distribution of Communist propaganda through the mails by "front" groups was shown in Congressional circles today, but initial consideration of the means to do this immediately ran into difficulties.

WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP) -- Fifty Senators asked the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today for action on a bill by Senator Pat McCarran, Democrat of Nevada, to set up an aid plan for Nationalist China.

In a protest against a faculty plan to cut down truancy, 500 screaming, singing students at the all-girl Walton High School, Jerome Avenue and 195th Street, the Bronx, refused for three hours yesterday to attend their classes. Twenty patrolmen helped quell the commotion.

John L. Collyer, president of the B. F. Goodrich Company, urged last night that Congress authorize a nonpartisan fact-finding body to preserve democracy by fixing the role of Government in our economy.

Officials of the State Medical Society voted approval yesterday of the American Medical Association's twelve-point health program and requested New York State members of Congress "to use every effort at their command" to defeat pending Federal legislation that would establish national compulsory health insurance.
Every child's vital need for adult love, acceptance and understanding was made clear yesterday in a discussion of the methods used by the Girls Service League in its work with disturbed adolescents.

" This Is Red China," by Jack Belden, has been scheduled for June publication by Harper. Mr. Belden, author of "Retreat With Stillwell" and "Still Time to Die," lived in China for ten years, leaving in 1943. Returning in 1946, he visited both the Communist and Nationalist-held sections, His new book presents a personal interpretation of China's immediate past, an analysis of her present and a prognostication of her future.
Clendenin J. Ryan, secretary to the late Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia, announced yesterday that he was establishing the National Foundation for Good Government and underwriting it for $500,000.

ROME, March 10 -- A bill to abolish all present import taxes and quota restrictions on foreignmade films will be discussed by the Italian Cabinet on Monday, it was learned today. The bill is expected to be submitted to the Constituent Assembly shortly thereafter and its approval by that body is said to be certain.

Vasa Prihoda, Czechoslovak violinist who had not appeared in this city since the early Thirties, gave a recital last night at Town Hall. His program comprised Dvorak's Sonatina in G major, Op. 100; Richard Strauss' Sonata in E flat major, and an Adagio, a Sonatine and the "Introduction and Variations on 'Nel cor piu non mi sento'" by Paganini.
Opposition amounting to 100 per cent of those affected is expected to be brought against the program for governmental reorganization, former President Herbert Hoover declared yesterday.

New York's state - chartered banks and trust companies increased their loans $568,000,000 in 1948 to a total of $6,057,000,000, the highest level in nineteen years, the State Banking Department reported yesterday. The total was only $200,000,000 below the high record made in 1929.

The complete schedule for the first two weeks of the New York City Opera Company's spring season, beginning March 24, was announced yesterday by Laszlo Halasz, artistic and music director. It follows:

NANKING, March 10 -- Acting President Li Tsung-jen was reported tonight to have achieved some success in persuading Gen. Ho Ying-chin, former Minister of National Defense, to "consider" accepting the post of Premier in succession to Dr. Sun Fo.

Mayor O'Dwyer incurred the displeasure of the Eastern District, Slovak League of America, the American Friends of Slovak Freedom and the Federation of Slovak Societies by using the term "Americans of Czechoslovak descent" in his proclamation designating March 7 as Masaryk Day in memory of Thomas G. Masaryk, former president of Czechoslovakia.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- George F. Kennan, chief of the policy planning staff in the State Department, left by plane this afternoon for Frankfort, Germany, to confer with United States officials on future plans involved in the recent establishment of an office of German and Austrian affairs in the State Department.

Wall Street has been warming up during the past fortnight to the job of marketing large aggregates of common stock, particularly in the public-utility field, but it was little prepared for the sudden announcement that the Standard Gas and Electric Company would take bids today for 364,684 shares of common stock of the Northern States Power Company of Minnesota.

TOKYO, March 10 -- Strife over communism is splitting Japan's labor movement into smaller factions. The two great national federations, the Communist-dominated National Congress of Industrial Organizations and the conservative General Federation of Labor, which once asserted that they had 3,500,000 members between them, now count perhaps 1,000,000 each.

LONDON, March 10 -- Austrian treaty negotiations reached a climax here today when both the Yugoslav and Austrian delegates appeared before the Council of Foreign Ministers' deputies and refused flatly to budge from their respective positions.

A bright outlook for limited price variety stores, provided they follow procedures which have proven effective in the past, was painted last night by speakers at the annual midwinter dinner and conference of the Limited Price Variety Store Association in the Statler Hotel.

A trio of new films, two from Hollywood and one from Italy, will have local premieres in midtown houses this morning. At the Roxy, the attraction is "Mother Is a Freshman," a Twentieth Century-Fox romantic comedy starring Loretta Young and Van Johnson.
Important changes designed to prevent juvenile delinquency are called for in a bill to revise the New York State Children's Court Act, it was learned yesterday.

Hospitals in this city would have to violate the law if a state measure requiring the licensing of all practical nurses takes effect as scheduled on April 1, it was asserted yesterday. Commissioner of Hospitals Marcus D. Kogel and leaders of voluntary hospital associations said that they would have no other choice.

New indications that the sculptured look is supplanting the square, boxy look in contemporary furniture design may be seen in a group of seven tables added to the collection designed by Jens Risom. One is an extension dining table of convenient size that would fit nicely into a small dinette or foyer as well as into a moderate-size dining room.

Argentina's Constitutional Convention has responded to its master's voice and changed the long-held Hispanic formula of government and of election so as to permit President Peron to perpetuate himself in power. In addition to removing the restriction against a President succeeding himself, the Convention has made other basic changes that leave little of the character of the document of 1853.

Secretary of State Acheson on Wednesday took up a phase of the labor relations problem to which too little thought may have been given. How is the public, which hires people to run its government, going to get the best work out of them? Tactfully, Mr. Acheson did not mention hours or pay.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on March 5 were 705,552 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 17,424 cars, or 2.5 per cent more than for the preceding week, 86,432 cars, or 10.9 per cent fewer than for the corresponding week of last year, and 100,223 cars, or 12.4 per cent fewer than during the corresponding week two years ago.

MOSCOW, March 10 -- Finance Minister Arseny G. Zverev told Parliament (the Supreme Soviet) tonight that the Soviet Union planned to spend almost 20 per cent more on its armed forces this year than last.
CAIRO, Egypt, March 10 (UP) -- Transjordan followed up its report of heavy fighting in the Negeb desert tonight by charging Israel with having massed troops on the Iraqi front in Central Palestine.
WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Samuel L. Wahrhaftig of Brooklyn has been dismissed from the Department of the Army on grounds of disloyalty, it was disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Department store sales in the week ended March 5 were 9 per cent below sales in the corresponding week last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The following lists percentage changes from like periods of last year:

The thirty-seventh anniversary of the Girl Scouts will be celebrated nationally tomorrow and will mark the successful completion of a fifteen-month clothing collection project called Clothes for Friendship, for destitute children of Europe and Asia.
ALBANY, March 10 -- Peace negotiations in the Republican budget fight struck a snag today.

A record 3,500 young journalists swept over Columbia University's campus yesterday afternoon to attend the opening of the twenty-fifth annual three-day convention of the Columbia Scholastic Press Association. Representing the publications of elementary and secondary schools, preparatory schools and junior and teachers' colleges, they came from twenty-five states and the District of Columbia.

Retailer reports that Philco Corporation will reduce list prices of sixteen radio models from $2.45 to $60, effective March 16, were confirmed yesterday by a Philco spokesman. The units involved include table and console models and the more expensive ones have FM reception and automatic record changers.

Four self-confessed "fixers," who had attempted to rig a college basketball game by offering a $1,000 bribe to a player, were sentenced to prison yesterday by General Sessions Judge Jonah J. Goldstein.
CLEVELAND, March 10 -- John Foster Dulles expressed the hope today that the proposed North Atlantic defense pact would develop a "reality" similar to that implicit in the Monroe Doctrine.

New York's business and commerce, and to a certain extent the nation's business, is steadily bedeviled by work stoppages here affecting the hauling of goods. The loss in recent years must have run into many millions of dollars. Nobody profits from this. In the long run labor itself probably pockets most of the loss, because when transport of goods stops the effect backs up into all forms of production.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Those citizens with varying experience in governmental affairs were named by the Atomic Energy Commission today as a permanent Personnel Security Review Board for the commission.
WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP) -- The United States Air Force has several long-range bomber groups specialy trained and equipped for dropping atom bombs, it was learned tonight.

WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP) -- The text of a ruling by Vice President Barkley upholding a debate-limiting closure petition filed in the Senate by Senator Scott W. Lucas of Illinois, the Democratic leader, and thirty-two other Senators, was as follows: ...
BALTIMORE, March 10 (AP) -- The New York Knickerbockers staved off a fourth-period rally by t heBaltimore Bullets tonight to win a Basketball Association of America game, 99 -- 94.
As a non-resident visitor I am frequently struck by articles in the American press complaining of European ignorance of America.
KEY WEST, Fla., March 10 -- There was something in the nature of a book review from President Truman today, but not what a reporter would call news.
HARTFORD, March 10 -- State Highway Commissioner G. Albert Hill today proposed a one-cent increase in gasoline taxes to finance forty-one major highway projects.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- The Commission on Organization of the Executive Branch of the Government recommended to Congress today that three Federal lending and guarantee agencies be transferred to the Treasury Department. This shift was described as one phase of a program to reorganize the department and integrate the financial processes of the Government.

CHICAGO, March 10 -- Grain markets reversed their action of Wednesday and closed about the bottom on the Board of Trade today after fluctuating in a very nervous manner. Professional traders who bought wheat and corn early turned sellers late in the day and found support less aggressive.

LAKE SUCCESS, March 10 -- A British proposal to cut United Nations child-feeding programs in Poland, Czechoslovakia, Rumania and Bulgaria by one-half was rejected today by the United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund.

In line with an industry trend to recognize operating problems of the retailer. Popper Morson Corporation, distillers, importers and exporters of liquor, will offer a 1 per cent discount effective April 1 on all invoices, including taxes, paid within ten days of the shipment date, it was disclosed yesterday.

Those who put away their fly fishing equipment last fall without first checking the rod for loose ferrules or worn guides, who failed to check the fly box for expended patterns, or the fly reel for worn-out line now have only a few weeks to remedy these omissions.

General Electric Company will introduce three new table television receivers early next month at list prices $30 to $86 below present comparable models, dealers reported yesterday. The company confirmed the report and set April 7 as the probable date for introduction.

Play in the men's doubles of the Eastern Lawn Tennis Association's indoor championships reached the final stage yesterday at the Fifteenth Regiment Armory with the two top-seeded combinations gaining the right to meet for the title tomorrow.
The vivid Mexican personality of Cesar Rubio of 40 East Fiftieth Street was expressed in the striking colors and flamboyant hats shown during luncheon yesterday at the Plaza Hotel.

OMAHA, Neb., March 10 -- The efforts of farmers to reduce costs and produce more efficiently in the face of falling prices were related today by farmers themselves at the first national pasture-forage-livestock conference at the Union Stock Yards here. About 400 were expected but about 1,000 are here.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Wilfred Fleisher, veteran newspaper man, was appointed today to direct the United States Information Service in Sweden. He will reactivate the office in Stockholm which for some months has been operated by a skeleton staff.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, March 11 (Reuters) -- Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan's Nationalist party, fighting the South African Provincial elections on its policy of racial segregation, was early today assured of an over-all majority in the Union of South Africa.
WASHINGTON, March 10 -- During the week ended March 9, member bank reserve balances decreased $260,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

LONDON, March 10 -- Britain's Cabinet was reliably reported today to have approved promptly the final draft of the Atlantic pact. The Cabinet met for two hours in private and heard a report on alliance negotiations from Foreign Secretary Bevin, who will probably go to the United States to sign the pact.

The wool futures market showed weakness again yesterday, as did other commodities, except sugar. Grease wool contracts here closed with net losses of 0.2 to 1 cent a pound on sales of 228,000 pounds, while wool-top futures had final losses of 1 to 2.2 cents on sales of 325,000 pounds.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- The Eastern Gas and Fuel Associates, Boston, received permission from the Securities and Exchange Commission today to issue and sell $12,000,000 of twenty-five-year, first-mortgage and collateral-trust bonds at competitive bidding.

VERO BEACH, Fla., March 10 -- Wise Barney Shotton is in a unique position as the Brooklyn manager, not that uniqueness is uncommon in Flatbush. He came in on a rain-check just after the 1947 season had begun and he came back on a return check in the middle of the 1948 campaign. The odd part about it, though, is that he never before has directed a Dodger squad in spring training.

The General Electric Company operated at a record pace in 1948 and had a net profit of $123,835,000, the highest in the fifty-seven-year history of the company, according to the annual report being distributed today. Earnings on each of the 28,845,036 shares of common stock outstanding last year were $4.29, compared with $3.30 a share in 1947 when the net profit was $95,299,000.
It will be Miami vs. Yale in the final for the National intercollegiate indoor polo championship at the Squadron A Armory tomorrow night.

Cranston Williams, general manager of the American Newspaper Publishers Association, singled out the International Typographical Union yesterday as the only union with which the nation's daily newspapers had failed generally to maintain "the most cordial relations" during the life of the Taft-Hartley Act.
