BERKELEY, Calif., March 10 (UP) -- The University of California announced today the successful operation of what was described as the world's first supersonic wind tunnel designed to study rocket models under conditions found fifty, to eighty miles above the earth.

Charging that the Long Island Rail Road's increase of up to 33 1-3 per cent in commutation rates is "arbitrary and discriminatory," the Suffolk County Commuters Association served both the railroad and the Public Service Commission with a show cause order yesterday calling for revocation of the increase.

Emory Holt, marine engineer, was racked by emotional storms and by rankling bitterness before he shot and killed his wife Norma, David Whittaker, her companion, and then himself, in Mr. Whittaker's London Terrace apartment on Wednesday night.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., March 10 -- Putting on the pressure in the second half, Hofstra ran and used the pivot effectively to down Brooklyn Poly for the Greater New York collegiate basketball tournament crown tonight. The score was 62 to 46.
A memorial exhibition of masks, paintings and drawings by the late Polish-American artist, W. T. Benda (1873-1948), is being held at the Kosciuszko Foundation, 15 East Sixty-fifth Street.

MIAMI, Fla., March 10 (AP) -- Defending champions Jim Ferrier and Cary Middlecoff led the way into the second round of the $10,000 Miami international four-ball golf tournament today but Sammy Snead and Lloyd Mangrum stole the show.

While some rent controls probably will be needed for fifteen or twenty years, it is now time to begin relaxing controls in certain rental classifications, Robert W. Dowling declared yesterday. He is president of City Investing. Company, which owns many luxury residential properties, and vice president of Starrett Brothers Eken, builder of thousands of moderate rental apartments, including Parkchester and Stuyvesant Town.

The trend in the stock market yesterday followed generally the pattern of the last two weeks. Price changes were mostly in small fractions and the number of gains and losses were about equal. The trading volume dropped to 630,000 shares, the smallest in a week, and compared with the 640,000 shares traded on Wednesday.
COPENHAGEN, Denmark, March 10 -- All flags will fly in Copenhagen tomorrow when King Frederik IX celebrates his fiftieth birthday.

MANILA, Friday, March 11 -The Philippine "Rump" Senate Investigating Committee announced today it found deposed Senate President Jose Avelino guilty of all accusations against him involving alleged illegal transactions with Chinese dealers in United States surplus property, of enunciating a political doctrine tolerating governmental corruption and of election frauds, tax evasion and intervention in judicial cases.

Domestic steel mills in February established a new high record for average weekly production of raw steel and probably would have set a new monthly peak if the month had had a normal number of working days. With weekly production averaging 1,865,982 tons, February's output was 7,463,928 net tons of ingots and steel for castings, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

Daniel Sullivan, general chairman of the Brotherhood of Railway and Steamship Clerks, AFL, threatened yesterday to have his union put picket lines around Grand Central Terminal and Pennsylvania Station.
LONDON, March 10 -- Apart from some heavy dealings in new issues, the "buyers' strike" continued in the stock market here today and as a result prices generally drifted aimlessly.
Construction of a fifth big hangar at New York International Airport at Idlewild, Queens, was authorized yesterday at a meeting of the Commissioners of the Port of New York Authority.

Immediate trade prospects with "dollar-broke" Argentina are not bright, but that nation's relaxation of its rigid export controls undoubtedly will have a stimulating effect upon traffic to this country, Robert C. Lee, executive vice president of Moore-McCormack Lines, asserted yesterday.

PARIS, March 10 -- In a speech that was considered the beginning of a campaign by the Government to counteract Communist propaganda by educating the French public regarding the Atlantic pact, President Vincent Auriol said today that in the present state of the world France could not run the risk of being Isolated or disarmed.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- James Forrestal, Secretary of Defense, addressed urgently worded letters to 8,000 young doctors and dentists today, appealing to them to take commissions for active duty in the armed forces.

PARIS, March 10 -- In the midst of a debate on the Indo-China problem late tonight, the National Assembly voted to postpone the ending of debate until it acted on a Cochin China bill tomorrow. The move was aimed, it is thought, to put off parliamentary interruptions until the Assembly returned from the election recess that begins tomorrow.
A Brooklyn longshoreman was shot and killed last night by an unidentified assailant at the time when he had arranged to meet his wife to attend a novena service in a Roman Catholic church.

The vacant two-family dwelling at 81-83 Johnson Avenue, Brooklyn, on a plot 50 by 100 feet, has been purchased by the Lasky Motor Car Corporation from Salvatore and Antonetta Colucci. The new owner will raze the building and use the site in connection with its Ford showroom a block away at 90 Montrose Avenue.

Dean Martin and Jerry Lewis, the comedy team that NBC hopes will regain popularity for its Sunday night schedule, will start their half-hour show over that network at 6:30 P. M. on April 3, it was announced yesterday. The show replaces "The Adventures of Ozzie and Harriet," which on the same day will be heard over CBS.

Designed to aid representation of American companies in foreign markets, proposals for individual income tax changes affecting United States citizens working abroad and foreigners in this country have been made by the National Foreign Trade Council to the Treasury and State Departments and the Joint Congressional Committee on Taxation.

Kentucky's powerful Wildcats dominated the 1949 United Press all-America basketball team yesterday, placing Alex Groza, Ralph Beard and Wallace (Wah Wah) Jones on the first five along with Ed Macauley of St. Louis and Tony Lavelli of Yale.

Helen M. Cohen sold the two-story four-family building at 167 Beach Forty-fourth Street, Edgemere, Queens, to the Johan Realty Corporation. Sale was subject to a mortgage of $4,000. A purchase money mortgage of $6,900 was executed at the closing.

Police Commissioner William P. O'Brien denied yesterday that he carried any obligations with him into his new post. He pledged his full efforts to emulate his predecessor, Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander, in the efficient administration of the police force.

A check of offices of the Collector of Internal Revenue disclosed yesterday that thus far only worried looks are being worn by the visitors. The frantic and desperate atmosphere, veteran officials said, is not due until Monday and Tuesday.

Spring made her appearance three weeks early this year in the city's parks. Old-timers in the horticulture division of the Park Department said yesterday that such a phenomenon had not occurred here for at least thirty years.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Foreign Minister Gustav Rasmussen of Denmark arrived in the capital this evening to discuss the proposed North Atlantic defense pact with Secretary of State Dean Acheson and other United States officials.

Revenge after the shooting is over doesn't come easy to Americans. No doubt this is why the jury took so long to bring in its verdict of guilty in the case of Mildred E. ("Axis Sally") Gillars in Judge Curran's court in Washington yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 10 -- Working women delegates to the national convention of the Young Women's Christian Association agreed today that the post-war world was marked by job discrimination against women, frustrations for women in matters of health, food and housing and, in many cases, lower wages.

Today's events: PhilharmonicSymphony, Bruno Walter, conductor, Erica Morini, violin, Carnegie Hall, 2:30 P. M.; "The Barber of Seville," Metropolitan Opera, 8:15; Frederic White, bass-baritone, and Stuart Fastofsky, violin (Debut and Encore Concert), Town Hall, 8:30; Roberta Berlin, piano, Times Hall, 8:30; Erno Meringer, tenor, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- The House today took the first step to correct the statutory weakness of the Office of Secretary of Defense by passing the bill which will furnish that official with an Under-Secretary. This direct assistance to the Secretary was urged by many when the National Military Establishment was created by Congress in 1947 to integrate the armed services.

The Metropolitan Jockey Club, which will open the New York racing season three weeks from today at the Jamaica track, yesterday announced the list of thirty-five nominations for the $15,000 added Prioress Stakes, a six-furlong sprint scheduled for April 6.

New York City has only 113 nursery beds where prematurely born infants can get proper medical attention, the City Department of Health reported last night to the section on pediatrics of the New York Academy of Medicine.

Various maneuvers are now under way in Washington to create a parliamentary situation which will not let the House of Representatives vote on Mr. Rankin's new bill providing general pensions for all veterans of both World Wars. The reasoning behind these maneuvers is that if this measure is permitted to come to the floor the House will not have enough courage to vote it down.

BUENOS AIRES, March 10 -- President Juan Peron and the Army exchanged praise and expressions of loyalty today at a carefully staged luncheon. The Minister of Defense, Maj. Gen. Humberto Sosa Molina, went out of his way to lavishly praise Senora Peron, who was a special guest of honor.

Jewish Family Service, a distinguished affiliate of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies, is now rounding out a career of seventy-five years of administering its professional method of helping normal people face the strains of everyday living. In its three-quarters of a century of experience this organization has learned much about what makes family life full and productive for its members and what factors threaten and weaken it.

LAKE SUCCESS, March 10 -- Leroy D. Stinebower of the United States stalked angrily out of the meeting of the United Nations Economic and Social Council here today in protest against Polish charges that the Korean Republic was a puppet Government set up by the United States and maintained by United States bayonets.
New high records in sales and earnings were established last year by the National Lead Company, J. A. Martino, president, informed shareholders in the 1948 annual report, issued yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Vice President Alben W. Barkley held tonight that the Senate's Southerners were not entitled to an area of immunity from the closure or "gag" rule that they have used to prevent action on President Truman's civil rights program and hope to use again.

The Eastern Golden Gloves finals in the Tournament of Champions amateur boxing program came to a close at Madison Square Garden last night, with a crowd of 11,546 in attendance. The competition was the culmination of four days of battling in which warriors from many points on the Eastern seaboard battled away with each other for the top honors.

Monteith Gilpin of the Society for the Prevention of World War Three, in his letter published on Feb. 22, questioned the attitude of THE NEW YORK TIMES on dismantlement and the accuracy of your report that two-thirds of the German factories declared to be "surplus" have already been shipped to other countries.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- President Truman's bill to expand Federal participation in state relief and welfare programs was assailed by a spokesman of the Catholic Church today on the ground that its enactment would practically put religious and other private agencies out of the childcare field.

Formation of a clear and sound national security is the nation's most urgent need, Ferdinand Eberstadt, chairman of the Committee on the National Security Organization of the Hoover Commission, declared last night.

WASHINGTON, March 10 (UP) -- Representative John E. Rankin, Democrat, of Mississippi, said today he would take advantage of a long-forgotten, 69-year-old parliamentary rule and bring his veterans' pension bill to the House floor on March 22.

Five and a half years have elapsed since Peggy Wood last acted on the Broadway stage in "Blithe Spirit," Noel Coward's improbable farce. She now is slated to return here the week of April 18 in "The Happiest Years," after a Boston tryout starting April 12.

New radio-electronic equipment, in many cases saving as much as 75 per cent in the size and weight of present-day Army and Navy apparatus, ranging from communications receivers to radars and servicing kits, was explained here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Two young gunmen who staged a "Wild West" robbery on a Baltimore Ohio express train in West Virginia last night were captured today by Washington po lice. One was wounded critically.
Subway-wise New Yorkers bog down in the sticks. In their occasional safaris into the back country their hauteur frequently suffers rude shock when they find themselves stuck at a wayside station.
WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Representatives of the construction industry approved today seven recommendations to serve as a guide for future industry policy.
Plans for an ambitious privately financed housing project in Israel were announced yesterday by Levitt Sons, suburban Long Island builders.

GENEVA, March 10 -- The United Nations will welcome suggestions from individuals and private companies as to the best means of carrying out its new work in the field of economic development, Trygve Lie, Secretary General, said today.

Organized baseball, already the target of lawsuits by suspended players who jumped to the "outlaw" Mexican League, is about to be confronted with another legal headache. This was learned last night when Frederic A. Johnson, attorney for Danny Gardella, said he would seek a court order for the immediate reinstatement of the one-time Giant outfielder who was suspended for five years in 1946.

NORFOLK, Neb., March 10 -- The flood picture in the Missouri Valley was vastly improved today except for a few isolated spots. Snow added to the woes of the region, however, as amounts up to five inches fell over a wide area.

ONE of the curious paradoxes about the art of literature is the way authors, without meaning to, dwarf their own creations. Most literary characters, no matter how convincingly real and subtly portrayed, do not linger in the memory. They are crowded out by the stronger personality of their creators. Few indeed are the literary characters who know an immortality of their own.

GENEVA, March 10 -- While the United States is financing importation of more than 25,000 tractors into Western Europe this year, 1,000 perfectly good new tractors are rusting outside Italian factories.

ROME, March 10 -- While the Communists were busy today propounding the theory that Parliament lacks the authority to "drag Italy into a catastrophic military alliance," it was announced that Premier Alcide de Gasperi would ask the Chamber of Deputies tomorrow to sanction Italy's entry into the Atlantic pact.

City Controller Lazarus Joseph announced yesterday that the city had borrowed $60,000,000 from twenty-six local banks and banking companies on 1 1/4 per cent tax-anticipation notes dated March 11 and due on May 5.

ATLANTA, March 10 -- The Georgia Real Estate Commission was trying to decide today how a residential area changes from white to Negro. The commission heard testimony from residents in one area, as it deliberated on whether a Negro real estate broker, J. H. Calhoun, should lose his license.

It is evident that Bruno Walter's heart is in the Beethoven cycle which he is presenting these weeks with the New York PhilharmonicSymphony Orchestra. It is just as evident that the public still buys Beethoven avidly. Carnegie Hall has been filled regularly for this series, as it was again last night when the third week of the cycle began.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- The Senate Finance Committee, by a straight party vote of 7 to 6, approved without change today a House bill to restore to the President the full tariff-making powers exercised by the chief executive under the original Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act.

A plan for the exchange of labor groups between the United States and the nations of Europe to promote international understanding has been adopted by the international executive board of the United Automobile Workers, CIO, it was revealed here yesterday.
For the last two weeks nine youngsters in the Bronx have put aside their games, dolls and roller skates to help the hearts of less fortunate youngsters keep beating.

Your soundly reasoned, forthright editorial, "No Time for Compromise," in your edition of Feb. 28 is welcome encouragement to those of us who for years have urged effective action to curb the filibuster. The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People has long realized that the filibuster is a national disgrace, undermining faith in democracy and exposing the nation to ridicule and censure of peoples the world over.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was quiet yesterday and final prices were 3 points lower to 6 points higher than the day before.

DUESSELDORF, Germany, March 10 -- About 6,500 Germans north of Aachen are apprehensive of border changes in favor of the Netherlands. The populace of eight or nine villages that have been German for more than 100 years is acutely conscious that at any hour or minute the borders may be changed. Yet demonstrations have been so minor as to be negligible.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., March 10 (AP) -- Michigan's "lonely hearts" killers got a court-appointed lawyer today amid reports that they might engage in all possible legal maneuvers to delay their return to New York.

Members of the New York Junior League and their children will participate in a mother-and-children fashion show planned to feature a luncheon arranged for next Tuesday in the Cotillion Room of the Pierre.

BERLIN, March 10 -- Although considerable progress has been made toward writing a constitution for a Western German state and an occupation statute very little has been made toward an agreement fusing the three Military Governments into a single control authority in the proposed new state.

WASHINGTON, March 11 (AP) -- Senate investigators were told today that "disgruntled employes" about to be discharged by the Maritime Commission threw away or destroyed hundreds of records needed to collect $26,000,000 owed the Government.

A venetian blind with an attached cornice long enough to extend over side drapery panels is among new devices now available to improve the appearance of windows. The new blind not only has the additional drapery cornice but it has been made to be hung in much the same way as a window shade, without complicated mechanism.

LONDON, March 11 -- With Israeli troops operating only a short distance away from the Transjordanian port of Aqaba, British authorities were reliably reported today to have decided to strengthen the British task force there. British units were sent to Aqaba under terms of the Anglo-Transjordanian treaty to guard the area against Israeli incursions.

A sensational wiretapping plot against New York City officials by a hired former city detective was uncovered last night by Mayor O'Dwyer and high police officials at City Hall, according to an announcement by Mayor O'Dwyer, The Associated Press said early today.
BUENOS AIRES, March 11 (UP) -- A grim appraisal of trade and economic conditions in this country was published today by the Argentine Chamber of Commerce.

New Financing The need for financing the purchase of new rolling stock keeps bringing the railroads to market. Sales of equipment-trust serials scheduled for next week include $4,500,000 by the Spokane, Portland Seattle Railway on Monday, $2,808,000 by the Chicago, Rock Island Pacific on Tuesday, $3,780,000 by the Delaware, Lackawanna Western on Wednesday, and $4,250,000 by the St. Louis-San Francisco on Thursday.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- An elderly visitor shot himself to death in a corridor just off the Senate gallery today during the debate on curbing filibusters. A three-page typewritten and pencilled letter "to the American people," found in his pocket expressed disgust with "the stupidity, ignorance, greed and corruption of many politicians."

Help with emotional problems is hard enough for the average person to obtain, but for those of the 800,000 congenitally deaf persons of the country who might seek psychiatric treatment, it is far more difficult. This was emphasized yesterday by Mrs. Tanya Nash, director of the Society for the Welfare of the Jewish Deaf, an affiliate of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York.

CAIRO, March 11 (AP) -- Victories assuring an All-American final in the Egyptian international tennis championships were almost overshadowed today by the disclosure that Jaroslav Drobny, Czech Davis Cup ace and Europe's foremost net star, is suffering from lumbago.

PARIS, March 11 -- The French Cabinet is expected to discuss and probably approve the Atlantic pact Wednesday after it hears a report of Foreign Minister Robert Schuman, on his return from the London meeting of the Foreign Ministers of the Brussels Treaty powers for consideration of the pact.

ROME, March 11 -- Premier Alcide de Gasperi informed the Chamber and Senate this afternoon that the Cabinet unanimously favored, in principle, Italy's "accession" to the proposed North Atlantic defense pact and her participation in the final phases of the negotiations for its conclusion.
Easter promotional efforts this year will be larger and expenditures will be greater than ever before in the history of retailing, it was learned here yesterday

The dramatic rights to "Ceremony of Innocence," a South African prize novel by the late Elizabeth Charlotte Webster, have been purchased by Eddie Dowling, it was learned yesterday. No production details have been arranged at this stage, but indications are that the play version of the novel will take form on Broadway next season.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- Kenneth C. Royall, Secretary of the Army, charged today, in an indictment of unusual sharpness for any but the most blunt diplomatic exchange, that the Soviet Union's blockade of Berlin was "a day-to-day threat to the peace of the world."

Efforts by the Transport Workers Union, CIO, to organize in the railroad field received a set-back yesterday with announcement of the outcome of a representation election among employes of the Hudson Manhattan Railroad.

Four persons were dropped from the tentative jury at the trial of the eleven Communists yesterday on peremptory challenges, three of which were exercised by the defense and one by the Government. Four new jurors were drawn by lot to take their places.

GENEVA, Feb. 26 -- On March 14 a project will be laid before a meeting of statistical experts of most of the European governments for producing rapidly and economically a complete analysis of the trade pattern of Europe -- who buys what, who sells where and how much.

The U . S. Atlantic Gulf-Netherlands West Indies and Venezuela Conference has amended its basic steamship freight rates and emergency surcharges in recognition of improved cargo conditions at Venezuelan ports, A. J. Pasch, chairman of the group, announced yesterday.

The first post-war major price reductions in steel conduit, an essential item in all home building and industrial construction, are being placed in effect with industrial buyers and contractors at this time. Notices of price changes will be received by purchasing agents from all except one supplier before the end of next week, manufacturers revealed here yesterday.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 11 -- A threat of disciplinary action hung heavy over the heads of the Yankee squad in training here tonight.

With the four top-seeded squads sitting in the stands and taking notes as the result of the eleventh-hour expansion of the field to twelve teams, play in the twelfth annual national invitation basketball tournament will get under way at Madison Square Garden today.

RHODES, March 11 -- Israel and Transjordan signed a "complete and enduring" cease-fire agreement here today that is believed to remove the danger of any clash in the Negeb while armistice negotiations continue. The agreement is actually independent of the armistice and remains binding even if the two nations fail to reach agreement on other points.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- Administration forces in the House, their majority threatened by Southern Democratic defections, staved off today by a narrow margin a determined drive, spearheaded by the Republicans, to limit the extension of rent controls to ninety days.

TEL AVIV, March 11 (UP) -- Israel has occupied the disputed five-mile Elath coastal area at the southern tip of Palestine after a minor clash with Transjordanian troops based at Aqaba, it was reported here today.

This afternoon basketball play starts in the National Invitation Tournament. For another two weeks there will be competition in this and other championship tournaments. Then the basketball season will close. For many the end is welcome. No other sport makes such unreasonable demands on the spectator.

This morning I watched the delivery of bread and rolls to a large bakery store. The bakery truck was unloaded in the street in the drizzling rain. Two large baskets, without tops, full of rolls, were removed from the truck and placed side by side directly on the wet and dirty pavement, both exposed to rain.
LONDON, March 11 -- A White Paper published today said that Britain, at the end of last year, "must have approached very close to the position of an over-all balance -- though not a dollar balance."
BOSTON, March 11 (AP) -- Ski report for New England:

WASHINGTON, March 11 (AP) -- Roscoe Martin of the faculty of the University of Alabama, was elected president of the American Society for Public Administration tonight. He succeeds John J. Corson of The Washington Post.
COPENHAGEN, Denmark, March 11 -- Denmark, the world's oldest monarchy, gave King Frederik a busy fiftieth birthday today.
ITHACA, N. Y., March 11 (AP) -- Lehigh University qualified seven of its eight-man team for the semi-finals of the Eastern Intercollegiate Wrestling Association tournament tonight.

WASHINGTON, March 11 (AP) -Immediate removal of export controls over all forest products except Port Orford cedar, to all destinations other than Europe, was announced by the Department of Commerce today.

Net profit reported yesterday by the Abitibi Power Paper Co., Ltd. for the year 1948 amounted to $9,415,086 after taxes and all charges, including $1,500,000 reserve for possible decline in inventory values.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- A program designed to eliminate confusion and duplication in the operation of the many business enterprises in which the Government has an interest will be recommended to Congress by the Commission on the Organization of the Executive Branch of the Government, it was learned today.

Suggested list prices of Frigidaire household refrigerators will be reduced approximately 5 per cent and electric ranges 7 per cent on Monday when the Frigidaire division of General Motors Corporation announces an improved line to dealers.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- AMVETS, national organization of World War II veterans, gave its support today to the proposed widening of Federal participation in public relief programs but called for a "strict needs test."

Another way to use that thrifty, nutritious product, dry skim milk, has been discovered. Combining it with molasses, also nourishing and inexpensive, and graham cracker crumbs gives confections for children that not only satisfy an appetite for such things but fill a function many sweets do not.

Switching their allegiance from NBC, George Burns and Gracie Allen have signed a contract committing their services in both radio and television exclusively to CBS. It was said there is no capital gains feature in the agreement under which the comedy team will return to the air in the fall for their new employer.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- Charles M. Brooks, a former associate general counsel of the National Labor Relations Board, today urged Congress to repeal the "mandatory" injunction section of the Taft-Hartley Law, but without diminishing the general counsel's authority to seek discretionary writs.

The student "strike" at the all-girl Walton High School in the Bronx over a faculty plan to cut down truancy was on an "on again, off again" basis after the 500 girls who left their classes Thursday and then returned, were joined yesterday by 250 others from a near-by annex in a revival of the walkout.

A "full report of the facts" involved in the recent controversy that resulted in terminating the pastorate of the Rev. Dr. John Howard Melish at the Holy Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church in Brooklyn, has been mailed to communicants of the parish, it became known yesterday.

YONKERS, N. Y., March 11 -- Yonkers city officials met for nearly three hours today with representatives of 500 public works employes who were off the job for eight days in apparent defiance of the Condon-Wadlin Act, but failed to reach an agreement on the status of the men.

Horace Mann and Barnard, both from the Bronx, captured honors at the Columbia University gymnasium last night in the finals of the second annual basketball tournament of the Athletic Association of Private Schools.

For the last five weeks this newspaper has been publishing Winston Churchill's record of the stirring, desperate days of 1940 and 1941 when every morning's newspapers seemed to bring only reports of fresh disasters. France held out for just forty days. The Balkans were overrun.

The growing number of wholesale drug houses that are installing punch-card equipment will soon make it possible for the industry to report more detailed statistics and sales trends, a trade association official reported yesterday. Important shifts in demand and turnover will be more quickly disclosed by such data, he said, so that a valuable aid will be given inventory control.

NANKING, March 11 -- Three top generals and a highly placed civilian took off by plane today for Hangchow, Chekiang Province resort city, to help a man make up 20 per cent of his mind. They went to see Gen. Ho Ying-chin, former Minister of National Defense, who is said to have informed Acting President Li Tsung-jen by telephone yesterday that he had decided "80 per cent" to accept the Premiership.
Your recent editorial, "Danger Ahead," is most unfair to the veterans.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- Average primary market prices advanced .1 per cent in the week ended March 8, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The index is now 159 per cent of the 1926 average, 1.3 per cent higher than four weeks ago and 1.2 per cent less than the comparable week in 1948.

Because the amount revolved is so small, it should not be difficult for the state to correct a serious injustice now practiced against the city's 2,000 teachers in the four municipal colleges. The Legislature should provide the same pension rights and protection to the college staff as is now given to the other public school teachers.

All Hallows became champion of the Catholic High School Athletic Association of New York City last night by turning back a stubborn St. Ann's quintet, 34 -- 25, before a crowd of 3,000 at the Fordham University gymnasium.
The Federal Housing Administration was asked yesterday to forbid exclusion of Negroes from any housing insured by that agency.
WASHINGTON, March 11 (UP) -- A bill authorizing a seventy-group Air Force and an 837,000-man Army was cleared for swift House action today by the Rules Committee.

DUESSELDORF, Germany, March 11 -- Still operating in a fog of uncertainty and amid a spate of rumors, German officials of North Rhine-Westphalia have scheduled a protest mass meeting Sunday in Dueren over the "border corrections" believed to be impending. Minister - President Karl Arnold will be the main speaker.

When he was overseas the veteran dreamed of many things. One of the things he did not seek was charity in the form of a pension grab. He did not visualize his country paying $90 a month to all veterans 65 years of age who served ninety days in either World War.

CHICAGO, March 11 -- The downward trend in business, which started last November, continued in February, W. B. Cressy, chairman of the business survey committee of the Purchasing Agents Association of Chicago, said today in releasing the monthly report of the organization's survey.

MEXICO CITY, March 11 -- The insistence of Carlos Chavez that he now wishes to devote all his time to "music study and composition'' resulted today not only in the regretful acceptance of his resignation as director, but also in the dissolution of the National Symphony Orchestra of Mexico which he founded twenty-one years ago.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- James Forrestal, Secretary of Defense, today presented the award of the National Military Establishment to Harold B. Hinton, director of the Defense Department's Office of Public Information.

Under the leadership of railroad shares, prices on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday rallied fractions to 3 points in the heaviest trading in more than a month. Sales aggregated 1,070,000 shares, crossing the million-share mark for the first time since Feb. 7.

WASHINGTON, March 11 (AP) -- Universal Military Training had definitely been shelved so far as this session of Congress is concerned, Representative Carl Vinson, Democrat, of Georgia, announced today. He is chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, which has jurisdiction over such matters.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was barely steady yesterday and closed 10 points lower to 4 points higher.

WASHINGTON, March 11 (UP) -- Senate investigators asked President Truman today to stay the executions of twelve condemned Germans until it can be determined whether they were tortured into confessing war crimes.

TORONTO, March 11 (Canadian Press) -- Governors of the National Hockey League today rejected a seventy-game schedule for each of its six teams next winter. At the end of a closed session a spokesman said that a proposed schedule calling for a total of 210 games over the twenty-three-week season instead of the present 180 was not feasible.

As observers from the State Department, the Russian Embassy and the United Nations watched intently, Valentin A. Gubitchev, Soviet engineer in the employ of the United Nations, claimed diplomatic immunity in Federal Court yesterday and declared that he regarded the espionage charges against him as "a provocation to pursue certain aims."

MONTCLAIR, N. J., March 11 -- While conceding that "disturbing trends are at work in the world," Irving S. Olds, chairman of the United States Steel Corporation, expressed optimism over the future in a talk tonight before 200 Yale University alumni at the annual smoker of the Yale Club of Montclair and Vicinity.
LAKELAND, Fla., March 11 (AP) -- Art Houtteman, his skull fractured in an auto-truck collision, smiled from behind his bandages today and bravely promised his Detroit Tiger team-mates:

Philharmonic-Symphony Young People's Concert, Leopold Stokowski, conductor, Carnegie Hall, 11 A. M.; "Gianni Schicchi" and "Salome", at 2 P. M. and "Otello" at 8, Metropolitan Opera; Solomon, piano, Carnegie Hall, 2:30; Fania Shapiro, piano, Town Hall, 3; Julio De Pol, baritone; Frederic Kramer, piano; Marta Nita, dancer.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -Mexico needs unlimited capital for the development of her oil industry but will make no changes in her present laws. This was emphasized today by Antonio Bermudez, director general of Petroleos Mexicanos, (PEMEX) the Mexican Government oil monopoly, during a news conference at the Mexican Embassy.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 11 -- Irving Allen and Franchot Tone, who recently produced "The Man on the Eiffel Tower" in France, have acquired the screen rights to "A Sound of Hunting," the play by Harry Brown which was presented on Broadway in 1945, Allen announced today.

VERO BEACH, Fla., March 11 -Casualties are popping up among both present and future Dodgers. Bobby Morgan, who moved to the Brooklyn roster from St. Paul this spring, is the latest to go under the X-ray.
LEWES, Del., March 11 -- For nearly four days, 364 sailors of the Soviet cruiser Murmansk -- the old U. S. S. Milwaukee -- have been cooped up aboard ship without shore liberty.

LAKE SUCCESS, March 11 -- In the first conservation conference ever to be held on a global scale 700 scientists and technologists will pool their talents here this summer to try to show the way toward a better world with high standards of living for all people. Invitations have gone out to seventy-seven nations to send experts. At least fifty are expected to accept.

VIENNA, March 11 -- The Allied Council for Austria tried today to hand over to the Russians thirteen war criminals whom the Russians want. However, the Russians refused to accept the thirteen from the Council because they wished to set a precedent by having the Austrian Government hand them over instead.

Plans for this year's Loyalty Day Parade, instituted a year ago to rival the Communist-dominated May Day Parade, were formulated yesterday at a luncheon attended by thirty of the 100 parade committee members at the Astor Hotel.
WASHINGTON, March 11 -- The United Mine Workers of America called today a two-week "memorial" stoppage of all members working in anthracite and bituminous coal mines east of the Mississippi River.

LONDON, March 11 -- Soviet Deputy Georgi Zarubin sidestepped today a challenge from the three Western deputies to state where the Soviet Union stood on the vital question of Austria's future frontiers.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- Paul G. Hoffman, Economic Cooperation Administrator, has notified the Bureau of the Budget of his intention to get rid of the so-called Informational Media Program for which Congress provided $10,000,000 to guarantee convertibility of earnings of American newspapers, periodicals and motion pictures seat to Marshall Plan countries.

Retail sales declined during the week, according to estimates made here yesterday. Department store sales here were believed to be about 14 per cent below the corresponding week last year. Sales last week were 14 per cent below last year.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., March 11 -- The American Bowling Congress at its annual convention here today rejected an amendment to its constitution to permit bowlers outside the white race to participate in its yearly tournament.
Settlement of the strike of grave-diggers at Calvary Cemetery in Queens and the Gate of Heaven Cemetery in Hawthorne, N. Y., was announced yesterday and the men immediately began to return to work.
An extravaganza of spring fashion was presented yesterday afternoon by Abraham Straus for the benefit of the School Settlement at the St. George Hotel in Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, March 11 (AP) -A price-supporting loan program for gum naval stores of the 1949 crop was announced today by the Department of Agriculture. The support rate will be $99.89 for the gum naval stores production unit of 50 gallons of turpentine and 1,100 pounds of N-grade rosin.

Production schedules have been stepped up by toy factories, some to capacity, as the result of orders by some 6,000 buyers who visited the American Toy Fair here last week. The fair, sponsored by the Toy Manufacturers of the U. S. A., will continue through March 18, and features 1,200 exhibits at the McAlpin and New Yorker Hotels and at permanent showrooms at 200 Fifth Avenue, 1107 Broadway, the Breslin Hotel and other buildings.

Preparations for the permanent lay-up of two Army transports, the Thomas H. Barry and the Mercy, have been halted and the vessels are being restored to operating condition, a spokesman for the New York Port of Embarkation announced yesterday.

Amid a great trampling of photographers, Clendenin J. Ryan, wealthy coordinator of city Fusion politics, nailed to a City Hall front door yesterday a document containing five-year-old charges against Mayor O'Dwyer.

It seems ironic now that leaders of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee express an unwillingness to assume the kind of commitment in backing up the North Atlantic pact which they were able to assume with respect to the Americas in the Rio treaty. But then, Pan-Americanism and the Monroe Doctrine always have been, for many, cloaks for isolationism.

The owner of a small grocery store was interviewed recently for the 1949 Census of Business but forgot to mention his sales figures for one month. He was asked to send the information to the New York office of the Census Bureau at 641 Washington Street.

Lumber production for the week ended March 5 was 6.9 per cent above the preceding week but was 16.1 per cent below the like week last year, according to reports wired yesterday to THE NEW YORK TIMES by trade associations. Shipments were down 18.2 per cent compared with last year and orders 27.8 per cent.

Hospital officials were accused yesterday of distorting facts to justify their opposition to the compulsory licensing of practical nurses in this state. Leaders of the two major nurse associations also charged the hospital administrators with putting "pecuniary interest" before the public interest.

I read in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Feb. 24 that the House Armed Services Committee has unanimously approved a bill offering residence in this country to aliens who engage in espionage on behalf of the United States or who aid American secret agents overseas. Apparently the intent of this bill is that the United States shall reward citizens of other nations for committing treason to their country.

Combined backing of the State Department, Department of the Army and Allied Military Government in Western Germany for the Military Government German Exhibition was announced yesterday at a press conference in the Barbizon-Plaza Hotel.

Sales of leading mail order and chain store companies decreased 2 per cent in February, compared with the corresponding month in 1948, according to a compilation covering forty - two companies made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

WINDOW ROCK, Ariz., March 11 -- The resubmission today to Congress of Secretary of the Interior J. A. Krug's $90,000,000 ten-year program for rehabilitation of the Navajo Indians, as requested by President Truman, is being watched with intense interest and hope at the Navajo Agency here.

CHICAGO, March 11 -- The Commonwealth Edison Company plans to sell $50,000,000 of fifty-year sinking fund debentures as the second step in financing its $500,000,000 post-war construction program. Charles Y. Freeman, chairman, announced today.

A group representing owners, operators and employes of New York City theatres protested yesterday to Fire Commissioner Frank J. Quayle on pending legislation providing for the use of uniformed guards in place of city firemen in theatres during performances.
WASHINGTON, March 11 -- A moderate seasonal pick-up in employment was now being expected within the next sixty days, Robert C. Goodwin, director of the Bureau of Employment Security, said today.
AUGSBURG, Germany, March 11 -- The mission of the famed United States Constabulary has been changed.
FAIR HAVEN, N. J., March 11 -- Capt. Henry E. Raabe, veteran of seventy-seven years of action-packed adventure of the Seven Seas, is trying out the role of landlubber at the age of 89.
Your editorial entitled "Two NLRB Rulings" cites the NLRB ruling in the Smith Cabinet case to support your conclusion that the Taft-Hartley Law ought to be retained.

"The Violent Men: A Study of Human Relations in the First American Congress, by Cornelia Meigs, has been scheduled for April publication by Macmillan. The volume covers the two years and three meetings of the Continental Congress and the men who argued whether to break away from England or to compromise and conciliate. Miss Meigs is Professor of English Composition and American Literature at Bryn Mawr College.

The cotton pickin' season has arrived in the fashion world, and pickin's of hot weather garb are more varied in style and texture than ever, according to deliveries being made to stores this month. Sheers like voiles and organdies, broadcloth with a pigskin finish, no-need-to-iron seersucker types and shirtwaists made of cotton jersey are among the points of interest shoppers will have in their wardrobes this summer.

PARIS, March 11 -- An amazing new kind of strike in which customs inspectors are working harder than ever in order to slow down border traffic is causing impatience and red faces at the frontiers these days.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- Following is the vote by which the Senate tonight overruled Vice President Barkley's ruling that two-thirds of the Senators voting can shut off a filibuster under present Senate rules if they so desire:

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., March 11 -- Senator Edwin C. Johnson of Colorado, chairman of the Senate Committee on Interstate and Foreign Commerce, spoke up today in defense of Federal efforts to keep the public fully informed about possible obsolescence of present television sets.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., March 11 -- A charge that a national "slot machine racket," of which Frank Costello of New York was described as "the reputed head," was spending at least $400,000,000 a year for "bribery and corruption of public officials" was made today by the California Commission on Organized Crime.

MIAMI, Fla., March 11 (AP) -- Jimmy Demaret of Ojai, Calif., and Lew Worsham of Oakmont, Pa., continued their blistering pace in the twenty-fourth annual $10,000 Miami international four-ball golf tournament today.

The two big men of the mile will be missing from today's track and field competition, which takes place on widely scattered fronts. Wisconsin withdrew Don Gehrmann from the Illinois Tech Relays in Chicago and Willy Slykhuis of the Netherlands was scratched from the Hamilton, Ont., meet in which he had been entered.

The withdrawal from service of the 17,707-ton passenger vessel Gen. M. C. Meigs, on transpacific interim duty for the American President Lines since 1946, was announced yesterday. The former troop transport will be turned back after March 22 to the United States Maritime Commission at San Francisco, where she was due yesterday with 900 passengers from the Far East.

PORTLAND, Ore., March 11 (UP) -- AFL Web Pressmen's Union Local 17, which has been on strike against The Portland Oregonian and Oregon Journal since Feb. 18, signed a two-year contract with the publishers today.

ARDMORE, Pa., March 11 (AP) -- Richard T. Button, world and Olympic champion, today took a commanding lead in defense of his North American figure skating championship at the rink of the Philadelphia Skating Club and Humane Society.

YOU can disaffiliate yourself from the notion that there has been a disinflation of books disassembled from The New Yorker. They are here to stay. Indeed, they form such a vast trend on the mighty avalanche of literary trends that they contain trends within trends -- lately, for example, the prefaces and forewords and introductions have not all been profiles of The New Yorker's editor, Harold Ross.

An internationally known Dutch chemist warned scientists last night against relying too much on present technical methods and declared that a continuing supply of new basic knowledge must be maintained.

ALBANY, March 11 -- Orange juice and peanut butter, important items in the diet of the growing child, are assured to school children in New York State through the school lunch program, Margaret Prentice, chairman of school lunch supervisors of the State Education Department, said today.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 11 -- A proposed public affairs program for adoption by the triennial convention of the Young Women's Christian Association was presented to the 2,000 delegates today by Mrs. Alfred E. Mudge of Brooklyn, chairman of the association's National Public Affairs Committee.

Again the public has an opportunity to help carry on an excellent work with emotionally disturbed children and their parents. The annual drive for funds of the Brooklyn Juvenile Guidance Center, Inc., 201 Montague Street, Brooklyn 2, is now under way and, if successful, will make possible the help and adjustment that will mark for many the road away from the reformatory and the jail.
Top local leaders of the Brotherhood of Railway and Steamship Clerks, AFL, decided yesterday to prolong their work stoppage against the Railway Express Agency until they get their full demands.
WASHINGTON, March 11 (AP) -- Bell Telephone Company, Philadelphia, today registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission a public offering of $25,000,000 in twenty-five-year debentures.

Several days ago I heard a double alarm and fire engines going through my street, only to learn later that a tragedy had occurred, taking the lives of two 5-year-old twin boys and perhaps the lives of their father and mother, who are in a serious condition in the hospital at Welfare Island.

PARIS, Saturday, March 12 -- After passage of the Cochin China bill and the postponement, over protests, of general discussion on Indo-China, the National Assembly adjourned early today in tumult caused by a demand by a de Gaullist Deputy for a vote of censure.
BUENOS AIRES, March 11 -Argentina has banned the issuance of immigration visas to all persons whose country of origin is behind the Iron Curtain, it was confirmed this evening.

There is a tendency among many radio listeners to regard Charlie McCarthy and Mortimer Snerd as real persons. These figures are so much before the public eye that they sometimes overshadow their creator, Edgar Bergen. People forget that "Charlie" and "Mortimer" are merely contrivances of wood, and that it is the unassuming Mr. Bergen who makes their gestures and moves their jaws for them.

NEW DELHI, India, March 3 -- The cease-fire in Kashmir has now been in force for two uncomfortable months. The discomfort has been both climatic and military. A correspondent recently spent three weeks with the troops on both sides, being the first civilian allowed to cross the front, and found them on hills from between 6,000 and 12,000 feet high, under ten to twenty feet of snow, with icy winds blowing around their bunkers.

PINKHAM NOTCH N. H., March 11 -- Heavy snow was visiting this popular White Mountain National Forest ski retreat while a field of eighty of the outstanding racers in this part of the country today got in their last-minute workouts on the precipitous Wildcat Trail for tomorrow's United States Eastern downhill championship.

A woman struck by a sedan at Nineteenth Street and the Avenue of the Americas was critically injured yesterday when she was dragged along the sidewalk on the car's bumper and hurled through a plate glass window. Three men also were hurt.

Plastic zippers are finding increasing uses in the garment trades and housefurnishings field, according to George Waldes, of Waldes Kohinoor, Inc. His company is shipping 1,000,000 nylon zippers a month, Mr. Waldes revealed yesterday, and could triple its production if supplied with sufficient nylon plastic molding material.
Operations last year of the McGraw Electric Company resulted in record sales and earnings, Max McGraw, president, reported in the annual statement mailed to stockholders yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 11 -- The State Department announced tonight that it expected the proposed North Atlantic defense pact to be signed in Washington during the first week in April.

CLEVELAND, March 11-- The National Study Conference on the Churches and World Order refused today to act on a proposal that "high-level" representatives of the Vatican and the World Council of Churches participate in joint consultations on the threat of communism to religious freedom.

The third Debut and Encore concert of the season was given last night at Town Hall. Two young artists were presented. Frederic White, bass-baritone, who had not appeared in recital before in this city, and Stuart Fastofsky, violinist, heard previously here on the concert stage.

BRUNSWICK, Germany, March 11 (A) -- An explosion ripped through a British scrap iron dump near Brunswick today, killing thirteen workers and injuring sixty-eight others. The victims were Germans and displaced persons, mainly Poles.

PARIS, March 11 -- Obviously the Soviet Government is not going to provide any information voluntarily to the United Nations Economic and Social Council aiding that body's efforts to find out about conditions in slave labor camps within the U.S.S.R.

LAKELAND, Fla., March 11 -- A vigorous campaign to indoctrinate the school and college students of this country with the principles of democracy and to enable them to recognize the "poison of communism" was urged here today by prominent American educators.
DETROIT, March 11 -- A wildcat strike provoked by the disciplining of two workers in the Highland Park plant of the Ford Motor Company made 4,000 employes idle today.

Every year, usually in February, Detective George Lamb, chief of the Queens District Attorney's Abandonment Squad, takes a trip to sunny Florida. There, he ends the "vacations" of men who have abandoned their wives and children in the borough of Queens.

Studies on the blood of personnel working in the radiology departments of two Baltimore hospitals have yielded evidence that X-rays, even in amounts undetectable by sensitive films, produce changes in the blood serum, it was reported yesterday at the annual winter meeting of the Optical Society of America at the Statler Hotel.
BUFFALO, March 11 (AP) -- The $154.16 express charges for this city's gift from the Freedom Gratitude Train were paid today.
HALLANDALE, Fla., March 11 (AP) -- Long shots ran rampant at Gulfstream Park today, and one of them, Mrs. Alfred Roberts' Realtor, accounted for the featured sixth event at $43.30 for $2.

A group of twelve top Swedish labor leaders and another of three Italians arrived in New York yesterday to study American labor relations, working conditions and union organization for three weeks as the guests of the United States Government.

A reduction in the rental rates of New York City piers probably would encourage greater use of this port's facilities, Representative James J. Murphy of the Sixteenth Congressional District asserted in a statement yesterday.

Louis Fahnestock, last survivor of the Fahnestock brothers of Harrisburg, Pa., who were leading bankers and railroad men here and in Washington many years ago, died yesterday at his home in Washington at the age of 100, according to word received here by a niece, Mrs. Elizabeth Foster Mann of 333 East Fifty-seventh Street.

Mayor O'Dwyer expressed the hope last night that the State Department would make diplomatic representations to end the "intolerable" division of Northern and Southern Ireland. Then, be said, a "thirty-two-county United Ireland can rightfully take her place as a nation among the democracies of the world."
WASHINGTON, March 11 -- The Senate overruled tonight by 46 to 41 a decision by Vice President Albert W. Barkley that would have made the closure or "gag" rule applicable to the Southern filibuster.

TOKYO, Feb. 26 -- Japan again is in difficulties over her food supply. The country faces a shortage of staple foodstuffs during the fiscal year beginning next month, even in the face of heavy imports, largely from the United States.

PARIS, March 11 -- In calling on Marshall Plan countries to report by May 1 on the steps they intend to take to stabilize their currencies this year, the new steering committee of Cabinet Ministers began bringing pressure for action similar to that formerly brought by the United States, in the opinion of American officials here.

WASHINGTON, March 11 (AP) -Speculative and other types of trading in wheat, corn and cotton in the futures markets increased sharply in February, a Commodity Exchange Administration report showed today.

Warren R. Austin, this country's chief delegate to the United Nations, will be principal speaker at the eighth annual meeting of the Laymen's Movement for a Christian World at a dinner at 6:30 P. M. Friday at the Statler Hotel. The meeting win last until 5 P. M. Saturdays.

The sale of more than $3,400,000 of common stock of Northern States Power Company of Minnesota at deadline bidding to a banking syndicate headed by Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Beane was the occasion of confusion and informal complaint yesterday despite the fact that the transaction was cleared for secondary distribution by both the Securities and Exchange Commission and the New York Stock Exchange.
WASHINGTON, March 11 (AP) -The Federal Government had concern lest domestic oil reserves be depleted before substitute fuels are developed. Secretary of Interior Krug disclosed today.

TRENTON, N. J., March 11 -- Many New Jersey municipal officials, expressing themselves today at a legislative hearing on proposed revision of local governments, found present forms good enough. They said they have proved efficient and satisfactory ever the years.

DETROIT, March 11 -- Walter P. Reuther, president of the United Automobile Workers, CIO, told the Ford Motor Company today that the union was not impressed by the Ford "plea of poverty" to escape labor's demands for 1949.

CLEBURNE, Tex., March 11 (UP) -- A 19-year-old youth, charged with beating to death the aged man who took him from an orphanage and adopted him as his son, was sought by officers from El Paso to Los Angeles tonight.
BOSTON, March 11 (AP) -- The Hollingsworth Whitney Company, paper manufacturer, today reported consolidated net profit of $3,570,355 for 1948, compared with $1,905,788 in 1947.

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., March 11 -- Representatives of twenty-three Pennsylvania colleges, forty-eight Luzerne County high schools and several little theatre groups will open tomorrow the first eastern Pennsylvania intercollegiate theatre conference under auspices of Wilkes College Cue N Curtain Club.

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 11 -- Leo Durocher, who could be toying with the idea of bursting out with a brand new keystone combination when the Giants set out on their pennant venture next month, announced today that Bill Jennings would be at short and Bob Hofman at second when the Polo Grounders open their annual spring exhibition series with the Indians in Tucson tomorrow.

NEW DELHI, India, March 3 -- Indian nationals in Burma, who before the war were an influential community numbering 700,000, have become a minority in independent Burma that suffers from anti-Indian prejudice and stands to lose most of its wealth under reformed land and property laws.

GENEVA, March 11 -- A significant example of European self-help to reduce dependence on dollar aid is furnished by the complete 1948 record of the timber trade, on which figures were released here today.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 11 -- Bound for the most part for new homes in Israel, 228 displaced persons, chiefly German Jews from Shanghai, arrived here today aboard the American President Lines's steamship General Meigs. Of the number, 192 are headed for Israel and thirty-six for European countries.

Judge Harold M. Kennedy reserved decision in Brooklyn Federal Court yesterday on the appointment of one or more trustees to conduct operations of the Long Island Rail Road in connection with its bankruptcy plea.

LAKE SUCCESS, March 11 -- Canada asked the United Nations Security Council today to sponsor one more attempt at bringing the Netherlands and the Republic of Indonesia to political agreement on the future of the islands of the East Indies.

Commercial bankers, aroused over the State Banking Department's sponsorship of the proposed legislation to broaden the investment power of mutual savings banks, are considering the desirability of opposing its enactment, it was learned yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 11 -- The National Labor Relations Board ordered today a collective bargaining election in a long-standing Hollywood jurisdictional dispute.

Wool futures continued yesterday their downward trend. Grease wool contracts closed at net losses of 0.8 to 1.5 cents a pound, excepting the spot March delivery, which was unchanged. Sales amounted to 174,000 pounds. Wool top futures were down 0.8 to 1 cent a pound, excepting the March position which also was unchanged.

Dates for fall hunt meetings -four in Pennsylvania, two in New Jersey and two in Virginia -- have been approved by the hunts committee of the National Steeplechase and Hunt Association, it was announced yesterday.

The mild winter is expected to result in an earlier opening of the "black" salmon season in New Brunswick, for the best fishing is right after ice-out, when these winter-locked fish head for salt water.
GAINESVILLE, Fla., March 11 (AP) -- Doug Ford, amateur golfer from Larchmont, N. Y., took the lead today in the first round of the Gainesville open golf tourney with a 35, 32 -- 67.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, March 11 -- Dr. Daniel F. Malan, South Africa's Prime Minister, whose Nationalist party emerged victorious in the provincial elections, today hailed the results as "gratifying" and an indication that South Africa approved of his policy of "apartheid" (racial segregation) in a message replying to the opposition leader, Field Marshal Jan Christiaan Smuts.

The recital given by Zino Francescatti, violinist, with the collaboration of Arthur Balsam, pianist, and Robert Casadesus, appearing as composer-pianist in the performance of his sonata, last night in Carnegie Hall must be accounted an outstanding musical event of this and of many seasons.

ALBANY, March 11 -- Governor Dewey's pay-as-you-go policy of financing state capital improvements out of current revenues and past surpluses may be challenged seriously in the current Republican budget and tax battle, it developed today.

Steve Belloise retained his standing as a leading challenger for the world middleweight title by stopping J. T. Ross of San Jose, Calif., in the scheduled star bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden last night.

CHICAGO, March 11 -- Grain markets broke sharply on the Board of Trade today on general liquidation by commission-house longs which disclosed a lack of aggressive buying. Wheat was down 4 1/4 cents a bushel; corn 3 1/4 cents, and soy beans, 7 1/2 cents at one time with numerous stop-loss orders uncovered on the way down.

OTTAWA, March 11 -- Canada's holdings of gold and United States dollars at the end of 1948 amounted to $997,800,000, according to the annual report of the Foreign Exchange Control Board released today.

PHILADELPHIA, March 11 (AP) -- An artist from Pittsburgh and another from Philadelphia were named today to share the Harrison S. Morris prize for water-color at the annual exhibition of the fellowship of the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts.
LONDON, March 11 -- An editorial in The London Daily Express today said:

KEY WEST, Fla., March 11 -- It is very difficult for a visitor to get within calling-card reach of President Truman in his Naval Station retreat here. If any had succeeded today he would have received a "go-away" card.

Directors of the Associates Investment Company have elected Robert L. Oare, company legal consultant and director, to the new office of vice chairman of the board of directors, and W. F. Gaunitz, formerly executive vice president, to the presidency of the company, E. M. Morris, board chairman, announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 11 -- These are the major events in the Senate struggle over curbing the filibusters, the use of unending debate to prevent the reaching of a decisive vote on a measure:

Miss Patricia Sinclair of the Orhbach A. C. successfully defended her 100-yard metropolitan senior breast-stroke championship by defeating Miss Joan Bereswell of the Women's Swimming Association in the Women's A. A. U. swimming meet at the City Athletic Club pool last night.
HUMBOLDT, Iowa, March 11 -- The small-town business men in the rich Midwest farm belt are out "courting" the farmers again.

The resignation of the Rev. William S. Chalmers, headmaster for the last eight years of Kent School, the religious preparatory school at Kent, Conn., was announced last night at the annual alumni dinner at the Columbia University Club, 4 West Forty-third Street.

STATE COLLEGE, Pa., March 11 (AP) -- Marty Crandell, a well-built 19-year-old Syracuse sophomore, and Chuck Drazenovich, Penn State's defending heavyweight champion, turned in two of the top performances tonight to lead the way into the finals of the twenty-sixth annual Intercollegiate Boxing Association championships.

LONDON, March 11 -- Although brokers found little to keep them busy in the stock market here today, they did have to deal with a sudden spurt of speculative activity in rubber shares. Buyers had been chary about entering the rubber market because of unsettled conditions in Malaya, but resumption of dividends stimulated some demand for shares, which in many cases had sunk below the levels touched during the Japanese occupation.
BERLIN, March 11 -- United States, British and French financial experts are working out details for introduction of the West mark, possibly in a month, as the only valid currency in western Berlin.

The overcrowding of parks in the metropolitan area is analyzed in the new report "Metropolitan Park Needs" just issued by the State Council of Parks. The report admits its survey was made both on account of increasing congestion of parks within a fifty-mile radius of New York City and because of the furor that resulted last fall when Westchester sought to restrict the use of certain of its parks to local residents.

It is good news that the Greater New York Safety Council plans to expand its activities in the traffic field and work closely with the new City department of traffic engineering. The Council has always recognized the importance of traffic in safety work in New York, but hitherto has not been able to spread its limited means sufficiently to give effective support in this field.

Two new foreign offerings constitute today's film arrivals. "Outcry," an Italian production about the resistance movement in Italy during the German occupation, will be presented at the Avenue Playhouse. A new personality, Lea Padovani, is introduced in a leading role with Massimo Serato, Elli Parvo and Vittorio Duse.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., March 11 -- Lenient sentences were given here this afternoon by Judge John P. Donohoe in County Court to four former union leaders who played minor roles in the theft four years ago of $250,000 from the treasury of Yonkers Local 60 of the International Hodcarriers, Building and Common Laborers Union, AFL.

BLOOMFIELD, N. J., March 11 -- Four hundred and seventy-five students of Bloomfield High School learned today that getting a job or going to college requires more effort and ability than just answering a "want-ad" or writing a letter of application.

CHICAGO, March 11 -- A $100,000,000 oil concession in Syria awarded at the request of President Shukri al-Kuwatly, for which independent oil companies in the United States are expected to furnish $50,000,000 capital, was announced today by James W. Menhall of Benton, Ill., oil producer, former manufacturer and banker. He returned from Syria ten days ago.

From time to time in recent months the American people have been mildly surprised by pronunciamentos bursting from the U.S.S.R. on the subject of inventions. It is possible many Russians now firmly believe -- or else -- that Soviet genius produced the first airplane and created the incandescent lamp, to name a couple of items which we, in our capitalistic stupidity, had thought of as having been Made in U. S. A.
BERLIN, March 11 -- The Soviet Military Administration approved today with ideological qualifications a plan for Germany neutrality in the present East-West conflict.
LONDON, March 11 -- Ernest Bevin was in an optimistic mood on the future of world affairs as he faced hecklers tonight among his prospective constituents.

BOSTON, March 12 -- In the city where he first gained recognition, Tony Lavelli finished his regular season collegiate career by scoring 24 points as Yale captured the Eastern League basketball championship by defeating Harvard, 87 -- 47, at the Boston Arena tonight.
PHILADELPHIA, March 12 -- Playing one of its best and most inspired games of the season, Pennsylvania defeated Princeton at the Palestra today, 66 to 47, before 4,500 spectators.

LIKE an Elizabethan beefeater's neck ruff or the paper trimming around an Englishman's Sunday pie are the pleated paper shades that the Danes like to use on table lamps, hanging lamps, any kind of lamp.

ITHACA, N. Y., March 12 (AP) -- Syracuse University captured three finals at Cornell University tonight to win the championship of the Eastern Intercollegiate Wrestling Association. It was the first victory for the Orange team since it joined the association in 1925.

MANY of us who studied Shakespeare in William J. Rolle's carefully expurgated edition will remember the name Cowden Clarke. It stands against many notes that irritated us by their heavy moralizing. Desdemona, "the innately pure woman," is contrasted with Emilia, "the ingrained coarse woman": "the white-souled Desdemona and the gross-thoughted, mercenary lax-principled Emilia."

THE recently opened exhibition of Chinese paintings of the Ming and Ch'ing dynasties, at the Wildenstein Galleries, for the benefit of Asia Institute, rounds out a unique opportunity to obtain a quick chronological perspective of the development of Chinese painting.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 12 -- The Agricultural Division of the Young Women's Christian Association disclosed today that one of its major projects now was taking sex education into farm homes "where the specialized educator in that field does not reach."
ARITHMETIC and not crossword puzzles will be the occupation of the citizenry over this week-end, though a few cross words probably will be spoken too. Because this is income-tax time.
CHICAGO, March 12 (AP) -- A new technique for making furniture has been developed by the Armour Research Foundation. It is aimed at the mass production of strong fiber furniture at lower costs.

Stock prices closed firm in yesterday's abbreviated session, as overnight news of a two-week stoppage in coal mining tempered the advance which had started on Friday. Sales on the Stock Exchange dropped to the smallest volume for a Saturday in two weeks, the turnover of 390,000 shares comparing with one of 450,000 shares a week ago.

A recession from the record business peaks of last year is undoubtedly in progress in the New York Federal Reserve District. How far it will go, or whether it will be succeeded by a leveling-off or rebound during the next six months, is still uncertain.

FRANKFORT, Germany, March 12 -- A United States Military Government official said today that many German business men are threatening to withdraw from participation in the German Industries Fair in New York in April because their friends or business associates have been declared ineligible as former Nazis.
WASHINGTON, March 12 -- The Truman Administration's Senate leaders in effect conceded defeat tonight in their present effort to harden the closure, or "gag," rule against filibusters.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- Salaries of the members of the Federal Government's nine regulatory commissions should be "raised substantially" to attract men of the caliber needed to administer the various offices capably. This was recommended to Congress today by the Commission on Organization of the Executive Branch of the Government.
YOUNG John Dillahay decided to become a doctor when his brother Billy was thrown by an outlaw bronco and John helped "Doc" Ledinger -- capable doctor but periodic drunkard -- set a compound fracture.

SEATTLE, March 12 (AP) -- A jury acquitted Dr. Herbert J. Phillips of contempt of the State Un-American Activities Committee yesterday. The state went ahead today, however, with plans to prosecute five other persons on the same charge.

The Army's globe-circling B-50 bomber, driven by four conventional engines, averaged 239 miles an hour. It was refueled in mid-air four times during its four-day, 23,452-mile flight. A supersonic plane, traveling only slightly above the 760-mile-an-hour sonic barrier, could make the same trip in about thirty hours.

TWO of the problems which faced Eric Johnston, president of the Motion Picture Association of America, during his visit to Hollywood -- the militant objection by film labor to American-financed foreign production, and the schism in the Motion Picture Industry Council -- were solved, at least on a temporary basis, before Mr. Johnston left town last week.

BUENOS AIRES, March 12 -- Dr. Jose L. Figuerola, President Juan D. Peron's technical secretary, who charted the five-year plan and much of the President's labor policy, resigned today following a last-minute change in the new constitution, that requires all officials of Cabinet rank be native Argentines.
CHICAGO, March 12 (AP) -- Snow flurries and cold winds whipped across wide areas from the Plains States to the North Atlantic Coast today.

If an educated adult reads fewer than 250 words of ordinary reading matter a minute, he is wasting time. This is the contention of Prof. Arthur W. Heilman of Michigan State College, who conducts, each term, a reading clinic to enable 150 students to "cover more territory via the written word."

IT is barely possible that most book shoppers regard published lectures much as they regard published sermons -- as something with a higher utility to the producer than to the consumer. It would be unfortunate if this book were neglected for that reason.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- Gustav Rasmussen, Danish Foreign Minister, discussed "several aspects of the Greenland problem" at the State Department today. He raised "various" questions and received "satisfactory" replies where answers could be provided immediately, he said.

Only four out of ten major indexes of the condition of heavy industry activities continued to show strong tendencies at the close of the week. The predominance of indications of recession was considered significant by industrial leaders here.

Customs collections at this port continued their steady decline last month, falling $3,494,262 below the total for February, 1948, Harry M. Durning, Collector of the Port, made known yesterday. The February total, however, was only $600,000 below that for January.

DOROTHY DOW, Texas soprano who made a hit in Virgil Thomson's "The Mother of Us All" two years ago, has found that it is once more possible for an American singer to go to Europe to get operatic experience. As a result of auditions here last spring with the conductor, Victor Reinshagen, she landed a job with the Zurich Opera.

When the Senate upset Vice President Barkley's closure ruling on Friday, it was, as it seems to us, making use of a technicality to prolong the obstructive powers of a small minority. Mr. Barkley had argued convincingly that Rule XXII, adopted in 1917, was intended to make it possible to limit debate by a two-thirds vote at any stage of actual legislation.

ELIZABETH TAYLOR'S fourth novel is the detailed account of two ordinary young Englishwomen paying a summer visit to an old teacher of theirs. None of the characters turns into a symbol of anything. Liz remains a young mother, married to a clergyman.

Retailers increased their advertising of apparel promotions here last week, according to a survey made especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by the Retail News Bureau. Among the leading promotions were dark basic dresses priced from $12.95 to $39.95 and toppers retailed at $8.41 to $12.95.

BELGRADE, March 12 -- Borba, official newspaper of the Yugoslav Communist party, asserted today that Yugoslavia had achieved a greater rate of increase in industrial production since the war than any other of the "people's democracies" in Eastern Europe.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- James Forrestal, Secretary of Defense, broke an official three-year military silence today on the use or discussion of the term "biological warfare," and in a formal statement characterized much that had been written about the potency of germ weapons as "exaggerated," "fantastic" or "unduly spectacular."

BERLIN, March 12 -- There has been a sudden sharp drop in the hopes for the early establishment of a Western German state -- hopes which were so high at the beginning of the month. This is due partly to the fact that the United States-British-French meeting on the Occupation Statute in London has made so little progress.

FROM "abduction" and "absolution" to "Zionism" and "Zwinglianism," the variety of topics covered in "A Catholic Dictionary" is impressive. Actually the volume is more a condensed encyclopedia than a dictionary, as the subjects are discussed (often in as many as 500 words or more) as well as defined.
Predominately Negro railroad unions were reported yesterday to be fighting on many fronts to control bargaining rights of non-operating employes of United States and Canadian railroads.

President Chaim Weizmann of Israel, in a message to Magistrate Morris Rothenberg, acting national chairman of the United Palestine Appeal and a chairman of the United Jewish Appeal campaign for $250,000,000, voiced confidence yesterday that American Jews wholeheartedly would support the Appeal's campaign.

The experimental atomic power plant in course of construction near West Milton, Saratoga County, N. Y., will use liquid metal to transfer heat created by atomic fission to the heat-exchanger (a sort of boiler), where steam will be produced to drive turbine generators.

BROOKLYN has become such a specialized borough for the writer that, like the arrondissements of Paris, it is now being covered by neighborhoods. Thomas Wolfe's "Only the Dead Know Brooklyn," dealing with the earthy section called Bensonhurst, has also been frequented by Irwin Shaw's characters, and a 1949 entry from Kings County, by first-novelist Robert Mende, concerns Williamsburg, where the tree grew.

ALTHOUGH tests to establish the practicability of piping music and advertisements into buses as they travel this city's streets already have been under way for some time, a check on the situation indicates that bus passengers in New York need not be too concerned with the imminence of that phenomenon.

New complications arose yesterday in the case of the Russian engineer and the American woman employe of the Department of Justice who were indicted for espionage conspiracy. The lawyer assigned yesterday to the Russian by a Federal judge was told by his client that he was not sure he wanted the attorney's services.

Wiretapping, with modern equipment, has become a very simple operation for those initiated in it. One method is to use an induction coil, which can be bought for as little as $6. Placed next to the phone line, the coil picks up conversations on the line, and is usually impossible to detect.
