Just below Ninth Street on Second Avenue -- hard by the Bowery and in a web of tenements and rooming houses -- stands the Ottendorfer branch of the New York Public Library. It's the oldest building in the library system. Little of Second Avenue's racket filters into the three-story structure.
WASHINGTON, March 11 -- The Supreme Court has sharpened the national controversy over the closed shop and related "union- security" issues.

CONCORD in the days of the Alcotts -- who appear as minor characters -- is the set ring for this charming story. Melody Merrill disagrees with the prevailing view that teaching school is a man's business. Her struggles to get and keep the Brier's Nest school appointment are heightened by the unwelcome attentions of a widower "school boarder." and by the perplexing behavior of handsome Phillip Walton.

BATAVIA, Java, March 12 (UP) -- General Soedirman announced over the clandestine Republican radio today that he had resumed command of the Indonesian Republican Army and he vowed to lead it to ultimate victory over the Dutch.

MAX RADIN'S latest book is likely to discourage obiter dicta from those laymen who know a little law and always seem ready to hand down a fast judgment. It makes, therefore, a valuable contribution to legal literature.

Under the direction of Drs. Herbert M. Evans and Herman Becks of the University of California, the pure growth hormone of the pituitary gland has been used to produce giant rats that remained young even though they reached an age equivalent to 100 for humans.

KANSAS CITY, March 12 -- The general feeling of financial, agricultural and industrial leaders here is that a gradual period of slowing up in business is likely for this year. They like to term it a readjustment from the high war and post-war levels.

JAN MAARTENS had not wanted to return to the Dutch island of Walcheren with his mother and sister and little brother. On this island his father had been killed, betrayed, Jan believed, by a traitor, the old carpenter.

The Home for the Destitute Blind will be the beneficiary of a loan exhibition of Seurat paintings and drawings, which will open with a preview on the afternoon of April 19 at the Knoedler Galleries and continue through May 7.

The national intercollegiate indoor polo championship returned to Florida last night when the slick-riding youngsters from Miami University handed Yale trio a 15-to-7 setback in the final round match at the Squadron A Armory.

IT is apparently to the Lexington Avenue Y. M. H. A. (if not to the Broadway theatre) that we must turn for most of our excitement in the field of the dance these days, the latest instance being the reappearance there the other Sunday afternoon of Katherine Litz, as part of an excellent program which she shared with Mary Anthony and Joseph Gifford.

BUENOS AIRES, March 12 -- The biggest brass in the Argentine Army toasted Senora Maria Eva Duarte de Peron at Campo de Mayo barracks on Thursday; but the gesture by no means settled the controversy that has raged for nearly three years over her unprecedented role in public life.
The Purim lesson teaching the ultimate doom of tyrants and of bigoted oppressors of minorities is needed more than ever in the world today, rabbis declared in sermons yesterday.

The consumer response to retail offerings of special value merchandise spurred activity in the wholesale apparel market here last week, according to a report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., Inc., resident buying office.

Publisher and advertising opponents of legislation that would raise mailing rates more than 300 per cent, particularly on second class printed matter, will begin an all-out attack on the measure tomorrow.

PARIS, March 12 -- As a result of international developments during the past month, it is abundantly clear that not only has the "cold war" between the Communist bloc and the rest of the world been intensified but that both coalitions are nervously preparing for a long period of anxious uneasiness replete with fears of eventual conflict.

NO matter how you look at him, Mr. Evelyn Waugh is a deceptive man: what meets the eye is at variance with what meets the ear. A remark he makes suggests cynicism, or perhaps a satiric humor, but Mr. Waugh's face -- bland, pink and cherubic -- suggests only innocence.

Albert Einstein, who demonstrated in his relativity theory that absolute time has no objective reality, will be 70 years old tomorrow in terms of ordinary years as measured by the non-relativistic calendar.

WASHINGTON, March 12 (AP) -- The Government paid to private dentists throughout the United States $9,559,000 for services to war veterans during the last three months of 1948, the Veterans Administration said today. Similar payments during July, August and September, 1948, totaled $11,838,452.
BOSTON, March 12 -- With characteristic caution, New England business leaders are maintaining a crossed-fingers attitude toward the present economic climate of their region.

THE ETHNIC FOLKWAYS LIBRARY, which has produced a series of valuable albums devoted to music and folkways of various remote sections of our contracting globe, has added two new volumes to its list. One is concerned with our own country, the other with Africa; each has four ten-inch unbreakable disks plus booklets with indispensable notes.
WASHINGTON, March 12 (AP) -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations today called for "substantial" new wage increases, a slash in corporation profits and an expanded security program for workers.
WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., March 12 -- Sharp controversy marks thirteen of the twenty village elections to be held in Westchester County on Tuesday.

THE key concept in this book of nine critical essays by Lord David Cecil, the young English biographer and critic, is the concept of the key. What, he asks in each of the rather limited areas in which he chooses to work, is the single ruling concept which will unlock the inner meaning of the poet's or the novelist's intention?

Prof. Norbert Wiener, one of the nation's foremost mathematicians, called on United States scientists yesterday to resist the inroads of "tyranny" in this country which seeks to make them "the milk cows of power."
BOSTON, March 12 -- The proposal of Gov. Paul A. Dever of Massachusetts to shift the deficit burden of Greater Boston's subway system to the state evoked considerable interest this week.

Further progress in studies aiming to unravel the mechanism of photosynthesis, the process whereby plants utilize the energy of sunlight to produce the food that maintains life on earth, was reported yesterday at a symposium on biocatalysis at the Polytechnic Institute of Brooklyn.

A slow, gradual and long-term strengthening of Russia's military positions along her Siberian and Pacific "frontiers," and of the economic, industrial and transportation facilities that support them, are indicated by Soviet activities since the war, a recent visit to Alaska disclosed.

MIAMI, Fla., March 12 -- Skip Alexander, Southern Pines, N. C., and Pete Cooper, Ponte Vedra, Fla., battled their way into the final of the $10,000 Miami international four-ball golf tournament today along with the defending champions, Cary Middlecoff, Memphis, Tenn., and Jim Ferrier, San Francisco.

LET there be no quibbling this morning. Worthington Miner's production of "Julius Caesar" in modern dress, presented last Sunday evening over CBS, as part of the "Studio One" series, was the most exciting television yet seen on the home screen -- a magnificently bold, imaginative and independent achievement that stands as an event of the season.

For a sport which requires such precise footwork in delivering the ball to the alley as bowling does the American Bowling Congress remains woefully out of step in its reassertion of its tournament ban on all colored races. The Congress is first of all out of step with liberal opinion all over the world in reasserting the arrogance of race.

PHILADELPHIA, March 12 (AP) -- Robert Stout, national intercollegiate and AAU calesthenics champion, retained his Eastern Intercollegiate Gymnastic League all-around championship today to lead Temple University to the team title in the twenty-second annual meet.

One year ago this Thursday -- on March 17, 1948 -- in the Palais des Academies in Brussels, the Foreign Ministers of Great Britain, France, Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg affixed their signatures to a fifty-year treaty, joining them in a military and political alliance for collective defense.

Amid a continuous din that marked the six hours of play at Madison Square Garden, representative teams from Manhattan, Bronx, Queens and Brooklyn gained the semi-final brackets of the P. S. A. L. basketball championship yesterday.

As if an early spring did not pose enough problems, the staff of the New York Botanical Garden is digging away at a more specialized annual task -- preparation of the garden's exhibit for the International Flower Show.

Federal Government expenditures to support prices of the major farm products are expected to reach an "alarmingly high level" following the harvest of this year's crops. With no restriction as to the acreage to be planted, farmers may be expected to take full advantage of the last year of non-recourse loans by the Government at 90 per cent of parity and produce to their limit.

All but one of the persons mentioned prominently in connection with the plot to tap the wires of city officials have strong links with the Fusion Administration of the late Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia.

CHICAGO, March 12 (AP) -- A jury of twelve housewives tonight convicted the National City Lines, Inc., and fourteen other companies and individuals of anti-trust charges. The jury was out more than thirty-six hours.

WINDOW ROCK, Ariz., March 12 -- A sweeping revision in the economy of the Navajos, the country's largest Indian tribe, is projected by the Government to end the chronic tribal distress which the recent blizzards severely aggravated.

NEW DELHI, India, March 12 -- Indian and Pakistani military commanders conferring here with the United Nations Commission on India and Pakistan agreed today on a provisional truce line to replace the present cease-fire positions in the State of Jammu and Kashmir.

CINCINNATI, March 12 -- Jack Kroll, national director of the Congress of Industrial Organizations' Political Action Committee, said today that he believed that labors attempt to obtain repeal of the Taft-Hartley Law would be impeded by John L. Lewis' call for a two-Week mine suspension east of the Mississippi.

FRIENDS, Romans and countrymen, lend me your ears. This poignant little book is the story of a girl who became deaf while she was in college, and slowly became deafer -- as all of us deaf ones do. Being deaf, she says, is like standing on your toes all the time while others sit in comfortable chairs.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 12 -- California politics became sufficiently lively this week to absorb West Coast attention. Even those who agree that anything can happen in California were astonished at the bitterness shown in a verbal slugging match between Gov. Earl Warren and Attorney General Fred N. Howser, both Republicans, on the subject of crime.

SEOUL, Korea, March 12 -- It was estimated here today that South Korea, in which there are two-thirds of the country's 29,000,000 people, had potential military manpower reserves of upward of a quarter of a million men of military age.

WASHINGTON, March 12 (AP) -- Representative John Taber, Republican, of New York, today told Senators investigating the Maritime Commission's delay in collecting some $26,000,000 that a shake-up of the commission was necessary.

FOR the first time in the history of the human race, representatives of all but one of the branches of Broadway show business sat down together to talk things over at the Astor Hotel recently. Since the business of the meetings had been carefully prepared by a steering committee, and since Morton Baum, in the chair, stuck firmly to the agenda, several good ideas for expanding show business were intelligently presented and discussed.
* * * Professor Hook's article tacitly implies that average students, if given the "Lenin line," will walk it. He has a lamentable lack of faith in their judgment.
Congratulations to Professor Hook on his most able presentation of the Communist problem in our universities.

THE problem of what is going to happen to a 65-year-old orchestra musician once he is let out to pasture is one that usually rates less attention than the prospects of a 6-year-old prodigy. But not in Abram Goutkin's notebook.

THE home gardener who grows his own vegetables has one great advantage over the commercial grower. He does not have to consider what kind will produce the largest crop, or whether the variety he grows will ship well.

The post-war shipbuilding program of the United Fruit Company, completed last year with delivery of the last of eighteen new freighters, has made up for the wartime loss of twenty-four vessels, and now affords a smaller but more efficient and speedier fleet, according to the company's annual report.

PHILADELPHIA, March 12 -- Pennsylvania Railroad carloadings last week totaled 109,293, as against 128,210 last year, a decrease of 14.8 per cent, and for 1949 to date totaled 999,620, in contrast with 104,819 up to March 6, 1948, a decrease of 9.5 per cent.

Colleges which arbitrarily reject students who rank in the lowest third of a high school graduating class are denying opportunity to "some who stand to profit most" from higher education. This is the contention of Prof. June B. Winlow, chairman of the scholarship committee at the University of Toledo, who has just surveyed the first semester grades of the top fifteen students among 915 freshmen.

LONDON, March 12 -- Sales in British retail stores fell sharply in January from the previous month, the Board of Trade Journal announced last night. Non-food sales were down 40 per cent, with particularly heavy declines for apparel. Food volume dropped 13 per cent.

THEY tell us, those carefree characters who go out and consort with lambs or commune with crocuses, that spring is on the way. Nevertheless, the British film industry is facing the bleakest winter of its history.

THE HAGUE, March 12 -- A series of complicated measures designed to achieve the full economic union of Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg -- familiarly known as Benelux -- by July 1, 1950, has been taken here at a top-level conference of Cabinet Ministers from the three countries.

NANKING, March 12 -- The Legislative Yuan approved today the appointment of Gen. Ho Ying-chin, former Minister of Defense and an important figure in the "Whampoa generals' clique," as Premier to succeed Dr. Sun Fo.
TOKYO, March 1 -- The Japanese have been surveying their manners and their post-war sense of responsibility recently -- and finding both lamentable.

On the island of Rhodes last Feb. 24 an Israeli-Egyptian armistice was signed -- the land of the Pharaohs thus becoming the first of the Arab countries to acknowledge that an independent Jewish nation exists. Last week another important step toward peace in the Middle East was taken on the island of Rhodes.

William Bell, the tuba player of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony, was the hit of the young people's concert that the orchestra gave under Leopold Stokowski's direction yesterday morning at Carnegie Hall. In the triple capacity of narrator, singer and instrumental soloist, Mr. Bell delighted the children who far outnumbered the adults in the audience of 2,500.
BERLIN, March 12 -- The British-licensed newspaper Sozialdemokrat said today that reports of reviving German nationalism were exaggerated.

FELIX SPER has performed, in this book, a trying task: the analyzing and codifying of American regional drama. Within these hundreds of plays, largely one-act, are the seeds of a rich authentic and varied American folk-drama.
A panel of six high school students was divided yesterday as to whether the Taft-Hartley Act should be repealed but agreed that there should be a "balance" between labor and management.

MORE young American students are signing up for summer vacation travel to Europe this year than in any other year since before the war. Student-tour leaders report that despite plans widely expanded over last year, practically all reservations are already taken, and hundreds of applications are continuing to pour in each week.

CAIRO, Egypt, March 3 -- Egypt's Government, essentially representative of the wealthy and the privileged, is steadily pressing through the parliamentary commissions a law that will anchor in the country's legislation the principle of the workers right to social security.

Native orators have facetiously described North Carolina as "a valley of humility between two mountains of pride, Virginia and South Carolina." The pride of the state of the long-leaf pine must be swelling these days, for it is achieving notable gains among progressive Southern states.
KEY WEST, Fla., March 12 -- President Truman wound up the first week of his vacation today in a gay, smiling, "no comment" demeanor.

THE touring tent drama is on the march again. While the Broadway stage continues on the defensive, still surrendering an occasional theatre to radio and television, out in the rural regions "live" entertainment has launched the most promising offensive since the word "comeback" began rolling off the tongues of unemployed troupers.

THIS year's stamp-issuing program is expected to include a postal item to direct public attention to the national campaign against cancer. It was learned last week that Eric A. Johnston, president of the American Cancer Society, wrote President Truman several months ago requesting that such a stamp be issued and that the President forwarded the letter, with his approval, to Postmaster General Jesse M. Donaldson.

TO be a good private secretary entails most of the virtues of a Boy Scout. This anyone who has ever been or has employed a secretary will readily admit, but it took Marcia Lee several trials and some beartbreaks to discover this when, at 18, she embarked on her chosen career.

WINDSOR, England, March 12 -- Lord Mildmay's brown gelding Cromwell, 100-to-7 favorite for the Grand National on March 26, won his final tune-up race today. Immediately afterward, odds against him at Aintree dropped to 10 to 1.

AS one who has always supported a good, whopping Western film and has taken considerable amusement and refreshment from this type of fare, this reviewer is torn, this morning, between a stoical urge to stay mute and a passionate, rebellious disposition to bolt the stockade and make for the hills.

NEW automobile safety devices to provide added protection for drivers and passengers are a feature of the 1949 line of Chrysler cars. One of the most important of the advances is a leather-covered cushion of thick sponge rubber at the top of the instrument panel which extends around the front of the compartment.

"The Function of Artists and Designers in Industry" will be the opening lecture on Tuesday at 6 P. M., when the spring session of the Art Education Project of the New York Public Library begins Jacques Martial, industrial designer, will deliver the lecture in Room 213 at Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street.

JULIAN AMERY was parachuted into Albania in 1944 as a member of the British military mission attached to Abas Kupi, the leader of the guerilla forces that were loyal to former King Zog. Amery's mission, headed by Col. William MacLean (not to be confused with Tito's admirer, Brig. Fitzroy MacLean), was ordered to incite Kupi and his Zogist followers into revolting against the crumbling German army of occupation.
THOSE who are interested in the esthetics of art to the exclusion of its economics miss one of the most fascinating aspects of the art world -- the auctions.

NOT the least of California's industries are the odd, flourishing religious cults of statewide and frequently national prominence. Mining some of the strangest and strongest of these cults, Hector Chevigny has used the ore to mold the heroine and plot of his new novel.

NORAH LOFTS turns from history to myth in selecting a basis for this bated-breath tale of romance. The subject of her latest novel, "A Calf for Venus," cropped up (according to the foreword) as the result of a chat between Jupiter and Venus in 1801; Venus complaining prettily that her altars were going bare (under the influence of Reason and other modern nonsense) and Jupiter promising to find a suitable calf to propitiate her.

MISS CORBETT'S romantic case-history deals with events in the Nineties. Mr. Marks' is an account of recent happenings. Each writes with the ease and authority of one who has done this sort of thing a good many times before.

Tables in the foreign department of the large bookstore are well covered with Russian books -- Russian grammars, Russian "first books," Russian readers, lessons in Russian conversation, Russian - in - a - few - easy - lessons books.

FOR late-season bloom in the cool greenhouse, nothing surpasses the glowing beauty of Clivia miniata. Its large flowers, borne in umbels of from three to twenty-four, closely resemble the amaryllis, to which it is related.

A QUICK move with his handkerchief and Davy Dale had tied together the jaws of his newfound pet, a baby alligator no longer than Davy's own foot. Out of the Everglades swamp and back to the family's general store and house, the little boy carried his treasure.
All freedom must be evaluated by its effects upon society, Prof. Sidney Hook, chairman of the Department of Philosophy at Washington Square College, New York University, declared last night.

IF one of your ears should freeze, would you rub it with snow? When you go to a football or hockey game, do you take along a few nips to keep warm? Does your blood thin in the tropics and thicken in the Arctic? Are natives of New England or Minnesota more adaptable to cold than natives of Florida or southern California?

THE highly unusual practice of seeking public support for film production as typified by "Monsieur Vincent," which was turned out by virtue of 75,000,000 francs contributed by 100,000 Frenchmen, seems to have caught on in France.

BERLIN, March 12 -- Communism has carried its war against the Christian church into the Soviet zone of Germany. Only minor skirmishes have been fought so far, but there are signs that the campaign is soon to be pressed with renewed vigor.

The Department of the Interior has restored to the public domain about fifty-four square miles of land in the Colorado carnotite ore fields and has withdrawn from mineral entry for use of the Atomic Energy Commission some forty square miles in place of the area restored.

Expectations in foreign trade circles here are that the International Trade Organization (ITO) will be up for Congressional action before the end of this month. It is believed that United States membership and ratification of the charter will be sought in a joint resolution by both houses of Congress.

LIGHT values in an outdoor scene have a fixed relationship to one another, no matter what the general lighting condition, Frank J. Reilly, artist and instructor at the Art Students League, explained at a meeting last week of the Hypo Club.

Even people who feel that "magic" is children's-party stuff, often have a fondness for card tricks. It is hard to see, therefore, why "The Card Wizard" should be only the second good popular handbook in two decades.

The program to improve American export packaging standards, started officially last month under joint sponsorship of steamship, shipper and underwriter groups, will be extended eventually on a world-wide scale, it was learned yesterday.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., March 12 (AP) -- Records fell by the wayside tonight as Rutgers swept the Eastern Collegiate Swimming Association championship with 63 points for its sixth ECSA triumph in a row.

HANOVER, N. H., March 12 -- Dartmouth's basketball team ended its season tonight by turning a 5-point half-time margin into a 57-45 victory over Cornell. Captain Ed Leede, playing his last game, became the first Indian player to top the 400-point mark.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 12 -- What has come to be known as a "recession" is taking place on the West Coast, according to a cross-section of opinion. Many business men and financiers prefer to call it an "adjustment" and a few use "disinflation."
STATE COLLEGE, Pa., March 12 -- Syracuse breezed to its eighth team championship in the Intercollegiate Boxing Association championships tonight, carrying off three individual championships enroute.
Reorganization of rehabilitation facilities in Greece will be needed to care for the thousands of casualties of the current civil war, according to a Greek doctor returning to that country.
WASHINGTON, March 12 -- Administration forces scurried around today rallying House Democrats for a showdown on rent controls next Tuesday.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 12 -- Five goals in the third period gave Harvard's hockey team a lopsided 8-3 victory over Yale at the Arena tonight before an estimated 1,500 people.

THE new Bolsey 35mm miniature camera, the Bolsey Model B2, is now available. It has a built-in synchronized shutter and a device to prevent double exposure. It costs $66.90. The Bolsey Flashgun No. 2, designed for the new camera, is $8.95.

JOHN ISCHELER, 52, of New York's fashionable East Sixties, died when he fell downstairs and bashed his head on the newel post -- a clear-cut accident. When the housekeeper died of poisoning a few days later, the D. A.'s office took another look at the case.

A meeting that had real medical significance was held last week in Cincinnati. It was the first meeting of the American Academy of General Practice, an organization of more than 10,000 general practitioners.

Postponement of play in the international chess masters tournament has been necessitated by the late arrival of Arturito Pomar, 17- year-old Spanish master, according to a report from Buenos Aires. Pomar, who has met many of the leading European experts in tournaments, is due from Madrid today.

CHICAGO, March 12 -- The next few months hold no prospect of any serious falling off of business activity in the Central Western states, but in the view of most business men the present situation is somewhat tight because of a seasonal and "cyclical" downturn.
ATLANTA, Ga., March 12 -- Southerners, in general, approved their Senators' filibuster stand this week as the first engagement in the battle against President Truman's civil-rights program.

RECENT reports about the future of the Douglas DC-3, one of the greatest passenger airplanes ever built, have left the air-traveling public wondering whether a tear should be shed or a mighty cheer sent up for the old airline veteran.

The fifty-eighth anniversary of the founding of the Silver Cross Day Nursery, 249 East 117th Street, will be marked by the third annual April Ball to be given April 21 in the main ballroom of the Plaza. Mrs. Wyndham L. Gary, general chairman for the benefit dance, will conduct a meeting of committee members tomorrow afternoon at Chez Jean, 11 East Sixtieth Street.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 12 -- Yale University recovered from a disqualification in the first race and went on to win all of the remaining events as the Blue defeated Harvard's swimming team, 53 -- 22, for its forty-sixth consecutive triumph at the Indoor Athletic Building tonight.

A GOOD investment for any home grounds Is the versatile euonymus or winter-creeper. This evergreens plant may be grown as a vine, shrub or ground cover. Aside from the features of all-year foliage and diverse form of growth, the extreme hardiness of euonymus makes it desirable for any location, for it is adaptable to sun or shade, poor soil or rich.
A coalition of Southern Democrats and Midwestern Republicans last week dealt the Truman Administration its first severe setback in the 69-day-old Eighty-first Congress.

With 680 student salesmen enrolled in its various sections, the City College Midtown Business Center at 430 West Fiftieth Street now has the world's largest school for salesmen, according to Jack S. Schiff, supervisor of the sales training unit.

FROM varying viewpoints the life record of John George Nicolay is a success story of an immigrant boy, a chapter in pioneer journalism, a literary narrative, a now-it-can-be-told revelation, and, best of all, an essential link in the life chain of Abraham Lincoln.
MALCOLM W. BINGAY, Detroit's best-known journalist, is like the newspaper business itself. A long, intimate, personal knowledge of the subject is necessary for thorough appreciation.

John L. Lewis' real motives in calling 400,000 miners out of the pits east of the Mississippi for a two weeks "memorial period" can only be surmised. His assigned reason was a lack of confidence in the qualifications for head of the Bureau of Mines of President Truman's nominee for that position, Dr. James Boyd, former dean of the Colorado School of Mines.

ANY New Yorker who shows signs of possessing both a bankroll and an interest in the theatre is likely these days to get a warm invitation to drop around for some drinks and to listen to some music. It sounds very pleasant -- but there's a motive in it. Broadway calls it "rusting for dough" or "singing for next season's suppers."

ISABEL BOLTON has attempted a task that, one may predict, novelists of a certain kind will find increasingly imperative: to extend the novel of sensibility in such a way that it will not only incorporate the rhythms of modern life but also reproduce, in the psychological tensions of its characters, the moral quality of world events.
HANOVER, N. H., March 12 -- Dartmouth concluded its swimming season by routing Princeton, 56 -- 19, before a capacity crowd at Spaulding Pool today.

Tone down that grudge you may still hold against Wall Street brokers for the Twenty-nine crash. Edward Allen Pierce, one of five names on ninety-seven brokerage office doors in thirty-three states, the District of Columbia, Havana and Mexico City, says his firm, "like many others in the Street, foresaw the crash and did its best for a year or more to induce customers to lighten their loads."

The Panther Dam project, which will rob the Adirondack Forest Preserve of a large slice of its finest wildlife habitat and destroy the wilderness aspect of thousands of acres on the fringe of the project, could, by the passage of a bill now in committee at the Legislature, be the swan song of the power interests responsible for such land grabs.
FORT WORTH, Tex., March 12 -- A crippled B-36 superbomber landed at Carswell Air Base today with a new distance record for these giant planes.

CHICAGO, March 12 (AP) -- After falling a few cents in early dealings, grains staged a mild rally on the Board of Trade today. Some contracts got back above the previous close. May wheat showed the best recovery powers.
LINCOLN, Neb., March 12 -- The best estimates on range cattle and sheep losses from the severe snowstorms and blizzards in Nebraska, Wyoming, Colorado and South Dakota range from 2 to 10 per cent.

Correspondents of THE NEW YORK TIMES in each of the nation's twelve Federal Reserve districts were requested last week to report on the economic situation in their areas and on the outlook for the next six months.

NEW ORLEANS, March 12 (AP) -- B. F. Whitaker's My Request carried top weight of 125 pounds to an easy victory today in the $25,000-added New Orleans Handicap at the Fair Grounds. J. J. Amiel's Isigny was second and Miss Request, stablemate of the winner, was third.

After having slowly sunk up to his neck in a mud flat, a fisherman was rescued yesterday from Jamaica Bay by a police helicopter and his son was saved with a human chain formed by two patrolmen and two Long Island Rail Road carpenters.

WHEN an artist starts to reveal what and how he creates, it is time for the reader to don his gas mask, adjust his flak helmet and in every other possible way prepare to protect his reasoning powers from the barrage of epigrams, excuses, boasts, facts, fantasies, threats and tearful confessions that is sure to follow.

YOKOSUKA, Japan, March 12 (AP) -- United States Navy seaman who said he had been shanghaied into the French Foreign Legion declared today the same thing had happened to Walter Levy, 20 years of age, of Boston.
HAVANA, March 12 -- An enraged Cuban crowd threatened to lynch three drunken United States sailors last night after watching them desecrate the statue of the Cuban national hero ...

JOEL BERGLUND has been appointed general manager of Sweden's Royal Opera House in Stockholm. It means that the Swedish baritone will be leaving the Metropolitan, where he has sung for the last four years. The association will not be ended, though, for one of his plans in his new post is to bring about closer cooperation between the Metropolitan and the Swedish Opera.

First results of the activities of the Hoover Commission in the monetary field, as published last week, evoked a critical response in financial circles here. Pending a study of the proposals, reaction among bankers was mostly restrained, but it ranged from lukewarm comment in the Wall Street sector to icy blasts from out-of-town.

ROME, March 12 (AP) -- Vatican City was decorated with the white and gold papal flags. The Pope's tenth coronation anniversary celebration was somewhat curtailed. Because of "sorrowful conditions" facing the church in some parts of the world, the Pontiff did not wish to hold the receptions that have marked the occasion in the past.

AT the end of last Sunday's column I made a statement which stands in need, I think, of being modified, clarified and amplified. I said that my preference for the British war novel. "From the City, From the Plough," over our own recent entries in that field, stems from the conviction that "American realism is the realism of a spoiled child."
CHICAGO, March 12 -- Rabbi Stephen S. Wise of New York City tonight formally received the 1948 award of merit of the Decalogue Society of Lawyers at the society's fourteenth annual banquet.

I feel that Professor Hook did not serve up to his readers the real issues in the question of whether Communists should be permitted to teach. In imagination I saw it as the first, perhaps, in a series, variously titled: "Should Atheists Be Permitted to Teach?" Or Isolationists.

SARASOTA, Fla., March 12 (AP) -- Cincinnati's National League Reds helped inaugurate baseball's pre-season exhibitions today by humbling the American League's highly regarded Red Sox, 5 -- 3, in ten innings.
Don Sheff of the Flatbush Boys Y. M. C. A. and Tom McDermott of the New York A. C. won metropolitan A. A. U. senior swimming championships at the New York A. C. last night.

DUESSELDORF, Germany, Mar. 12 -- The directors of the Social Democratic party, concluding a two days' session in Cologne this afternoon, announced their decision to continue their efforts to reach a compromise with the Western Allies on the final form of a Western German constitution.

THIS is the final week of the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo at the City Center. No novelties, of course, at this late date, but both Ruth Page's new "Love Song" and the revival of "Carnaval" are scheduled for repetitions, and "Madronos" is hopefully listed once more after several postponements thus far because of illnesses in the company.

FILM theatre operators, having taken several hard looks at television, have decided not to fight this newly arisen competition, but instead to embrace and use it to their own advantage. This choice has been influenced by television's future rather than its present status.

Clendenin J. Ryan, part-heir to a fortune of $141,000,000 left by his paternal grandfather, Thomas Fortune Ryan, who died in 1928, was one of a group of wealthy men's sons who flocked to the standard of Fiorello H. La Guardia.
LEWES, Del., March 12 -- Four Russian naval officers on the staff of what is still the Soviet cruiser Murmansk were unable to return to their ship this morning when high seas made a boarding risky.

ROME, March 12 -- Pope Pius XII today celebrated the tenth anniversary of his coronation as head of the Catholic Church by attending a solemn function in the Sistine Chapel with twelve of the Cardinals resident in Rome and many archbishops, bishops - and members of his court.

FOR nearly half a century Buffalo Bill's Wild West Show was an American institution, an annual attraction rivaled only by the circus. They are middle-aged now who can remember that exhibition, but none will ever forget the spotlighted appearance of a cream-colored stallion bearing a tall figure in snow-white buckskin and high patent-leather boots.

ATLANTA, Ga., March 12 -- Southeasterners are deeply apprehensive about the current economic downtrend. But the general feeling is that there will be no serious recession or depression if people don't talk themselves into it and if business men guard against precipitous action, such as extreme economies or a wave of competitive price cutting that would lead to widespread distress selling.

VERO BEACH, Fla., March 12 -- The literal translation of the Latin word Rex is king. At the moment Rex Barney of the Dodger pitching staff is neither the king of that staff nor the ruling hurler of the National League. But the big and rawboned fireball thrower could very well become both. His potentialities are so immense that baseball men wax lyrical about him.

FROM England comes this surprisingly varied handful of volumes, the first in a popular-priced series of picture-story books for 6 to 9 year olds which boasts some fine color printing. They are fragile in binding, but profusely illustrated.
THESE pictures relate the story of a beef roast. Does it need telling? It would seem yes.
DALLAS, Tex., March 12 -- Southwestern merchants this spring are doing business cautiously to prevent a mild retreat in their business from becoming a rout.

THE world observes this year the centenary of the death of Frederic Francois Chopin. Nowhere will the observances have such scope and impressiveness as in Poland. This is not only appropriate in the land of the master's birth; it is also symbolic of Chopin's unique position as an artist.

District Attorney Frank S. Hogan questioned two men at his office yesterday in an effort to identify the principal behind the fantastic wire-tapping plot aimed at Mayor O'Dwyer and other city officials, disclosed by the Mayor at 1:30 o'clock yesterday morning in City Hall.

ST. LOUIS, March 12 -- There is a general feeling throughout the Eighth Federal Reserve District (St. Louis) that business has reached a leveling-off period and will remain quite stable throughout the remainder of 1949, according to an official of the Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis.

The situation in the nation's coal industry today is this: The aboveground coal surplus is 70,000,000 tons -- enough to last from seven to eight weeks -- compared with the normal surplus of 45,000,000 tons. Coal sales have been declining recently, partly because of the mild winter in the Northeast, partly because the Economic Cooperation Administration has cut its demands for American coal.

Climaxing the annual Easter seal campaign for the New York State Association for Crippled Children, Inc., a spring ball will be given on April 22 in the main ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton. Mrs. Fred Lincoln Heyes is general chairman of the fete.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- A trial examiner of the National Labor Relations Board held today that a New York City local of the Teamsters Union, AFL, violated the secondary-boycott ban of the Taft-Hartley Act when it picketed the trucks of an employer while they were on the premises of customers.

The following comments on criticism are by the critic of The London (England) Observer, Ivor Brown, who ably upholds the high standards of literary and dramatic criticism set by his predecessors since The Observer was founded in 1791.

THIS book about the Politburo will not feed the passions underlying much of the current comment on Russian policy. It is largely an informative book, and, being a discussion of Soviet policy in terms of the men who make it and of their prior achievements in home affairs, it is both instructive and steadying.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange fluctuated within a narrow range yesterday, and final prices were 1 to 7 points net lower than on Friday.
IF a 4 - year - old recognizes letters, wants to make O's and A's, to write his own name, points to printed signs and asks "What does that say?," parents nervously inquire: "Is it all right to help?"

Eastern railroads, anticipating a sharp decline in their coal-hauling traffic as a result of the scheduled two-week stoppage by the United Mine Workers, yesterday announced layoff plans immediately affecting more than 55,000 workers.

EVANSTON, Ill., March 12 (AP) -- Albert Einstein, one of the great scholars of all time, has dipped a probing pen into education. Suggesting freedom for students to study things that interest them, he writes:

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- Official Washington's concern about the spy menace, largely dormant since the Hiss-Chambers case moved from the local stage into the Federal courts in New York early in the winter, has been awakened by the Coplon-Gubitchev affair which broke with such startling suddenness this week.

With purchases by the armed forces likely to be reduced until appropriations are made for the new fiscal year beginning July 1, textile manufacturers will have to look elsewhere in the next few months for orders to keep production from slipping further, it was pointed out last week.

Representatives of six foreign nations and three American welfare agencies met last week to discuss future plans for seamen's sports in New York including a possible resumption of the annual international lifeboat races and Atlantic Cup soccer matches interrupted by the war.

TUCSON, Ariz., March 12 -- Leo Durocher, to whom life past 40 seems to bring a deal of new adventures, today got his first sample of Giant-Indian springtime rivalry and what he saw must have startled him no end.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- The first installment of the annual sortie by Congress against the Federal Government's publishing activities was delivered this week by Senator Styles Bridges, Republican, of New Hampshire.

The great storm of '88 was weathered again yesterday without noticeable casualties as the Blizzard Men of 1888 celebrated their twentieth anniversary as a club. The luncheon meeting was held at the Statler Hotel with 320 de-iced members in attendance.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 12 -- During the past week, retail business activity in the Twelfth District continued to show marked decreases from the same period a year ago. Seattle and Spokane were the only areas reporting gains in sale volume of larger stores.
THE theatrical season of 1949 is on the wane and the unfortunate citizens of Washington, D. C., continue to live in a city devoid of a legitimate theatre.

In replying to the letter by G. M. of Boston, let me say at the outset that a full open discussion of the projected plans for a repertory theatre in New York would be both healthy and stimulating. The road toward the successful realization of such a plan has many hurdles and pitfalls and it is our intention to examine and avoid as many as we can find.

HALLANDALE, Fla., March 12 -- Three Rings, owned by Mrs. E. L. Hopkins of Cleveland, drove to a front-running half-length triumph in the mile and a furlong Horning Handicap at Gulfstream Park before a crowd of 16,229 that bet $1,073,361 on the nine races.

MINNEAPOLIS, March 12 -- Business and industry in the Ninth Federal Reserve District, buttressed by a farm structure incomparably stronger than the one which cracked after World War I, are cautious these days but are not losing too much sleep over the economic outlook.
ROME, March 12 -- The first organized Communist moves to block Italy's entry into the projected North Atlantic defense pact occurred in Italy today.

MIAMI March 12 -- With a record crowd of 7,518 cash customers filling all available seating and standing room, the Dodgers opened the citrus circuit season here today by trouncing the champion Boston Braves, 5 -- 2, at Miami Field.

WEST INDIES Governments are improving tourist guide facilities with the result that today's visitors find Caribbean stopovers more profitable and enjoyable than formerly. A tourist recently returned from a Caribbean cruise reports a great difference between now and a year ago.

James H. Mysbergh's letter which appeared in your paper of Feb. 27 deserves careful consideration at the hands of all those who are interested in putting a halt to the ever-increasing influence of the Communists in Southeast Asia.

Large equipment manufacturers in four major lines -- office equipment, farm equipment, construction equipment and refrigeration -- are starting to prepare "equity financing" plans for increasing the use of local bank credit to finance distributors' stocks throughout the United States.

Marta Nita, who has danced hereabouts in a number of Broadway productions, yesterday made her local debut in a new type of performance which she calls "drama-dance" before an invited audience in Times Hall. Here she combines speech and dramatic action with her dancing in a series of theatre vignettes written for her by R. Hart Phillips and choreographed by herself and Irma Hart Carrier.
STATE COLLEGE, Pa., March 12 -- Pennsylvania State College changed football coaches today without any of the fuss and furore that usually accompanies such swaps.

PARIS, March 12 -- Final passage of the Cochin China bill, considered the key to the French proposal to attempt to restore peace in Indo-China, was voted by the National Assembly on its second reading late tonight by 348 votes to 202.

LONDON. MILLIONS of Soviet citizens must now be silently pondering the question of Stalin's successor. They dare not discuss it openly, but Vyacheslav Molotov's departure from the Foreign Ministry must have set off an immense speculation.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., March 12 (AP) -- Billy Dwyer of Providence, co-holder of the world record for the 60-yard dash, captured two individual titles in the Providence College invitation outdoor board track meet before 3,500 fans today.

As a result of its drive last spring to persuade industry and business to employ older persons, the Federation Employment Service, 67 West Forty-seventh Street, New York 19, has issued a report with recommendations designed to attack the problem on a long-range and large-scale basis.
WILKES-BARRE, Pa., March 12 -- Major anthracite operators today called on their employes to report for work on Monday. This was in spite of the suspension of two weeks ordered by John L. Lewis.
ALBANY, March 12 (AP) -- Governor Dewey and President Truman were portrayed tonight by jesting Albany political writers as agreeing that "All we want for taxes is your two gold teeth."
WASHINGTON, March 12 -- Following is the text of a statement issued today by James Forrestal, Secretary of Defense, to correct misunderstandings of the potentialities of biological warfare:

Deliveries of rayon in the first two months of this year were 4 per cent below those in the correspondng period of 1948, it was announced yesterday by the Textile Economics Bureau. January and February shipments were 87,600,000 and 78,000,000 pounds, respectively.

FOR THIS WEEK: Spread wood ashes, accumulated during winter, over rose beds and under shrubs. . . . Prune shrubs that do not flower earlier than June, but do not touch azaleas or rhododendrons unless some stems have been broken. . . . Remember that shade trees need a dormant spray this month. It will also kill scale on lilacs. . . .

WHEN your partner bids two suits -- so goes the rule in all the bridge books -- you must show him which of his suits you prefer. Usually, the rule goes on, you prefer the suit in which you are longer.

I was much impressed with Sidney Hook's discussion of Communist professors on college faculties in your magazine. His analysis of the situation is sound and his constructive proposal good. I go perhaps a little farther than he in believing there are cases where men competent in fields unrelated to national security who are open Communists would actually strengthen a faculty and stir up in discussion a positive faith in democracy among most students.

WASHINGTON, 12 (UP) -- Joseph L. Moody, president of the Southern Coal Producers Association, said today he had "reason to believe" the forthcoming coal mine shutdown might be extended beyond the two-week limit set by John L. Lewis.

The little birds are beginning to sing again. They are the sparrows, the chickadees, the snow-birds and all those other winter birds who have been so independent during the fair weeks and so eager to crowd the window feeding box on foul days.

LAKELAND, Fla., March 12 -- Development of an extensive regional college program for the South was proposed by educators, business and civic leaders and college officials who came here this week for the 'Sixty-seventh Annual Founders' Week celebration of Florida Southern College.

YELLOW SPRINGS, Ohio, March 12 -- Mrs. Caroline Urie, a 75-year-old Quaker widow, who does not want to help finance military preparedness, reduced the first installment of her income tax accordingly today.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 12 -- The Yankees' celebration of Casey Stengel's competitive debut as manager was a seventeen-hit demonstration with which they sank the Cardinals, 10 to 3, before a record crowd of 6,854 at Al Lang Field today.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- Fifteen trial examiners for the National Labor Relations Board have been found not qualified for their jobs under new standards and examinations set up by the Civil Service Commission, it was learned today.

Retail trade here last week showed the largest percentage decline since the start of the year. Department store sales were estimated as running about 14 per cent below the same week last year. The comparison, however, was with early Easter sales in 1948 against a late Easter this year.

HOUSTON, Tex. -- The U. S. S. Texas, which was rescued from the scrap heap when she was given to her name state by the Navy, is proving to be the most popular shrine for tourists and Texans alike in the Lone Star State.

Two new science programs leading to the Doctor of Philosophy degree will be offered by the University of Tennessee. The doctoral degrees will henceforth be awarded by the Department of Bacteriology and the Department of Zoology and Entomology. The first program is designed to "relieve the shortage of trained bacteriologists in the South."
Nine thousand employes of the Railway Express Agency officially lost their jobs yesterday when seventy-two-hour lay-off notices issued by the company on Wednesday became effective.

DESPITE brilliant and notorious exceptions painters still respond to the visible world whether they have roots in the soil or merely feet in the studio. Contrasting responses are seen in two new exhibitions, one of young Irish painters at Associated American and another at the Peridot Gallery, in the first American appearance of Irmgard Burchard, a Swiss artist whose views of Paris bear traces of her sojourns in both France and Brazil.

The reinstatement of Dr. Miriam Van Waters as superintendent of the Massachusetts Reformatory for Women was greeted with expressions of approval yesterday by leaders in the correction and allied fields who had watched the progress of the hearings with concern.

GRAPE pruning seems to be a mystery to some people, but actually it is a comparatively simple chore. A few basic principles must be understood at the outset, but once these are established, the job is not difficult.

BOYS who long for a rifle of their own will welcome this story of Bob Winchester, who receives for his twelfth birthday, in 1801, a specially made small replica of his father's long rifle, complete with powder horn and pouch.

GEORGE CREEL has an old and honored name as a worker in liberal fields, a fighter for high causes. It is a pity, therefore, that he has allowed himself to be drawn into an area with which he cannot be sufficiently familiar, and it is painful to say that he has written a rather foolish book.

THE Seventy-eighth annual New England Spring Flower Show opens at 1 P. M. today in the Mechanics Building, Boston. Daily thereafter, through Saturday, the hours will be 10 A. M. to 10 P. M. The main feature of the show is a replica of the jungle wilds around the headwaters of the Amazon River.

The variety show presented yesterday by nine Bronx youngsters in the Williamsbridge section of the Bronx for the benefit of the New York Heart Campaign delighted the 200 children and fifty parents who attended and enriched the campaign to the extent of $79.70.

THE British Broadcasting Corporation has started an inquest on the venerable body of its radio humor. Whether this was inspired by the competition of television, the coming of spring, or mere conscience, nobody knows. Anyway, the critics have sharpened their knives and attacked the task with relish.

FOR more than thirty years the Texas Folklore Society has been publishing valuable studies in American folklore, overlooking no aspect of Southwest folk belief and custom. Volume Twenty-two in the series presents a large group of Kiowa-Apache folktales by J. Gilbert McAllister and ten short articles by other Texas folklorists, J. Frank Dobie among them.

RICHMOND, Va., March 12 -- A widespread feeling exists in this region that a downward trend in business activity is in progress, but no one is ready to call it a depression, and only a few would define it as a recession.

TRAVELERS devoted to ships, and they still constitute the majority of overseas tourists, were cheered last week by the announcement of new ships for Mediterranean service, and the opening of Japan to pleasure travel.

PITTSBURGH, March 12 -- A tax reduction, or "even the simple pledge of Government that tax rates will be maintained as they are," would stimulate business activity and provide greater national income, the American Society of Tool Engineers was told tonight.

Photographs of Miss Mildred E. Gillars leaving a Washington court room after her conviction for treason must have reminded many people of what a lonesome thing it is to be disloyal to one's country. No other offense brings up quite the same combination of emotions. With indignation there may be mixed some pity.

Preliminary steps were taken last week in the formation of a central committee representing several local and national business groups to coordinate "disjointed" efforts to obtain employment for qualified older workers. The new committee will seek to carry the fight to break down employer prejudice against workers over 40 "out of the talking into the action stage" by appealing directly to top management rather than to personnel managers who do not set company hiring policies.

ANOTHER post-mortem on the late lamented literary year -- this time by a rental-library expert. In the March issue of The Retail Bookseller, Nelson R. McNaughton reports that 1948 rental revenues were 12 per cent (or more) lower than those for 1947.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 12 -- Capturing nine of the thirteen events contested, Coach Bob Giegengack's Yale track team continued its dual meet supremacy by overpowering Dartmouth, 70-39, in the Coxe Cage today. It was the twelfth consecutive success for the Elis in dual meet competition.

Increased riding comfort, performance and visibility in the 1949 Chrysler cars were emphasized yesterday by the Chrysler Corporation. Although the cars are lower, shorter and narrower than previous models, they are roomier and the seating capacity has been increased.
Member of the Board of Russian Studies at Syracuse University and former Intelligence Specialist on Russia with the State Department and Office of Strategic Services.
RHODES, March 12 -- Armistice lines for Jerusalem occupied the Israeli and Transjordanian delegations through two long joint meetings today.

NANKING, March 12 -- Chiang Kai-shek at 61, despite his retirement as President of China, remains an important figure in Nationalist politics. His influence is still strongly felt here and various high-placed Chinese figures either have telephoned or visited him at Fenghua, his native district in Chekiang province.
HACKETTSTOWN, N. J., March 12 -- Clendenin J. Ryan, one of Mayor O'Dwyer's most vocal political opponents, denied today all knowledge of the alleged plans to tap the telephones of city officials.

The League of Composers, which honored Serge Koussevitzky two years ago on the fifth anniversary of the Koussevitzky Music Foundation, will honor him again on May 10 with a dinner and concert at the Waldorf-Astoria on his silver anniversary as conductor of the Boston Symphony Orchestra.

LONDON, March 12 (Reuters) -- Portsmouth advanced a step closer to the championship of the English Football League today by winning, 4 -- 1, at Sunderland, while second- place Newcastle United lost at Wolverhampton, 3 -- 0.

LAKE SUCCESS, March 12 -- War and politics in Indonesia have supplied the United Nations Security Council with a longer-lasting controversy than any other international headache. But militarily and politically the situation in the islands of the East Indies is as gloomy and tangled as any time since the name Indonesia first cropped up on a Council agenda more than three years ago.
Raymond Swing tries desperately hard to roll back and undo the mounding American repudiation of the Yalta agreement -- but he fails completely.

THE early riser has a choice of some of the best picture material New York City has to offer, Dr. D. J. Ruzicka, an amateur photographer for forty-eight years, reported at the preview view last week of his one-hundred-print show at the Camera Club, 121 West Sixty-eighth Street.

PITTSBURGH, March 12 -- Homes and steel mills were in a good position today to weather the two-week coal suspension ordered by John L. Lewis. District railroads, however, felt the pinch almost immediately.

THERE may be dark clouds over Hollywood but the bright day of the six-figure movie deal has not yet passed. Playwright-scenarist Norman Krasna, it was learned last week, has not only convinced the powers at Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer that what he had to sell was their meat but that his whopping price was right.

CLEVELAND, March 12 -- Industrial employment in Greater Cleveland is showing unexpected stability in the face of lay-offs and reduced hours that prevail elsewhere in the nation. The Chamber of Commerce's latest monthly survey of 100 large concerns showed a net decline of only 331 in total employment last month -- less than 1 per cent.
I want to call your attention to an error in 'Into the World of 'Nothingness'," crediting Hall Hibbard with designing the first all-metal, low-wing transport in 1933 at Lockheed.

MIDDLEBURY, Vt., March 12 -- Miss Ruth Marie Stewart, 1948 Olympic team member now competing under the colors of the Dartmouth Outing Club, won the Eastern women's downhill ski championship today at Middlebury College's Bread Loaf Mountain snow bowl.

LONDON, March 12 -- King George VI underwent a successful operation this morning to improve the supply of blood to his right foot. The operation began At 10 A. M. in a specially converted bedroom on the first floor of Buckingham Palace and at 11:15 A. M. palace officials issued the following bulletin:

TEL AVIV, March 12 -- Just a few minutes after he had been elected first president of the State of Israel, Dr. Chaim Weizmann walked down from the dais and threw his arms around an old friend with whom he had visualized the new state around the turn of the century.

CHICAGO, March 12 -- The ten-month-old wage and hour dispute between the country's Class 1 railroads and their 1,000,000 non-operating employes has not reached the "signed agreement stage," George Leighty, spokesman for the unions, said tonight.

SOME time this week or next, representatives of the League of New York Theatres and those of the Association of Theatrical Press Agents and Managers are supposed to sit down again to discuss that contemplated promotion campaign in the theatre's behalf.

NEWFOUNDLAND, which with Labrador will be joined to Canada as a tenth province on March 31, holds many attractions for the vacationist. With the growing popularity of travel northward from the United States, the island is expected to receive increasing numbers of visitors in coming seasons.

BUENOS AIRES. ASK an ardent peronista why Truman was elected and he will echo the afternoon paper, La Epoca: "Because his social ideas were just like Peron's." An Argentine intellectual who opposes the regime but who was in the United States last October and November said, "Frankly, the Truman campaign ended up as demagogically as Peron's in 1946."

Although hopes for a downward revision of margin requirements for the purchasing of securities were dimmed somewhat last week by reports that officials of the Federal Reserve Board did not favor such action now, agitation for a reduction continued, some of it coming from outside the Wall Street area.

WEST POINT, March 12 -- Two last-period goals by Warner (Bud) Bonfoey gave Army's hockey team a 5-4 victory over the Royal Military College of Kingston, Ont., tonight in a tense, exciting struggle between the United States Military Academy and its Canadian counterpart.

SENATORS, Representatives: if I were a Congressman there would be, I know, many books I would want to read. Luckily Congressmen are not required by the Constitution to be able to read -- it's enough that they are of the right age, citizenship and habitat -- but by fortunate chance they almost always can.

LONDON, March 12 -- The British Government, in a note to Bulgaria published tonight, impugned part of the testimony in one of the confessions at the recent trial of fifteen Bulgarian Protestant pastors. From this "clear example of misrepresentation," the British Government concluded that the whole of the testimony was "suspect."

ARDMORE, Pa., March 12 (AP) -- Miss Yvonne Sherman, 18-year-old New York girl, tonight won the North American figure - skating championship. She is the first United States woman to lift the event since 1939 when Boston's Maribel Y. Vinson triumphed.

Impatient for fitting out days and the arrival of the pleasure boating season, members of the New York Athletic Club's Yachting Department will do the next best thing on Thursday night, March 24. When they aren't yachting they're talking about it and this will largely be a night for talking.

The Metropolitan Golf Association has announced that the Metropolitan Open, which is being revived this year, will be played Sept. 20, 21 and 22 at the Metropolis Country Club, White Plains, N. Y. It was announced at the annual meeting of the organization that the tourney would be staged for the first time since 1940 but no dates were selected at the time.

PHILADELPHIA, March 12 -- The Foster and Kester Company, Inc., local chemical manufacturing and research concern, announced today the development of a long-sought plastic coating which, when applied, is fast-drying, completely flexible and offers resistance to surface-damaging elements.

Financial markets, which have been in the doldrums for some time, broke out of the trading rut late last week and closed higher on balance. Uncertainty regarding Congressional action on labor and taxes, however, kept prices for the greater part of the period within a narrow range despite record earnings by several of the country's largest corporations.

CAMDEN, S. C., March 12 (AP) -- A 9-year-old bay gelding, fresh from winter training in the Midwest, outshone Southern-trained horses today for a surprise victory in the King Haiglar Steeplechase feature event of the Springdale Hunt race meeting.
WASHINGTON, March 12 -- The proposed North Atlantic defense treaty, the text of which will be published in a few days, already has provoked a number of violent and contradictory opinions.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- John L. Lewis' call for a two-week shutdown of coal mining in the eastern United States was criticized and defended at the Capitol today, but there was nothing so far to indicate that his action would weigh heavily in the fate of the Taft-Hartley Law.

Sidney Hook's article slights or ignores two important phases of this problem. First, how does one prove a teacher is a Communist when most members of that organization deny such political affiliation?

MINEOLA, L. I., March 12 -- Spring elections in forty-seven incorporated villages in Nassau County on Tuesday will be quiet except in eleven of the home-rule municipalities where local issues have arisen to place more than one slate of candidates on the ballot.

Fifteen Girl Guides, representing seven foreign countries, who are members of the United Nations Girl Guide Company at Lake Success, took part yesterday in a special celebration conducted by the Greater New York Girl Scouts' organization, commemorating the thirty-seventh anniversary of the Girl Scouts of the United States of America.

PEOPLE IN EIRE are amazed when they pick up an American periodical and read about shenanigans on St. Patrick's Day. That day is celebrated there just the same as any other holy day of obligation and they don't even have a special March 17 feast.

Once upon a yesterday there were four local quintets in the twelfth annual national invitation tournament. San Francisco conquered Manhattan, 68 -- 43, and then there were three. Bradley defeated N. Y. U., 89 -- 67, and thee there were two.

Assistant Secretary of State Dean Rusk indicated here yesterday that the United States might give strong support to any move at the United Nations General Assembly next month to reverse the anti-Franco resolution of 1946, which called upon all member Governments to withdraw their envoys from Madrid.

This country's policy of trying to communicate directly with other peoples as evidenced in the Voice of America is based on the belief that understanding among peoples will mean "getting along together," George V. Allen, Assistant Secretary of State for Public Affairs, told 3,500 young journalists yesterday.

In his article Sidney Hook proves his point that anyone tied to the Cominform by a leash is not free to search for truth and is, therefore, not a good teacher. It is a point, but a small one which should not be inflated.

Ever since I first heard of psychoanalysis I have wished for just such a book as this. Its idea is simple: to present, clearly and compactly, the major theories beginning with Freud. In turn, the main points of Freud, Adler, Jung, Otto Rank, Karen Horney, Erich Fromm and Harry Stack Sullivan are condensed and explained.

SCHENECTADY, March 12 -- Fifteen thousand members of General Electric management are devoting themselves to a re-education in economics and in human motivations and relationships in an attempt to find out how jobs may be made better, Lemuel S. Boulware, GE vice president of employe relations, told a meeting of 600 engineers here last night.

PINKHAMNOTCH, N. H., March 12 -- Young Dick Ireland, Gould Academy senior of Bethel, Me., winner of the National junior Alpine combined a year ago, today showed his flying hickory wings to a formidable field of seventy-one and captured the United States Eastern Amateur Ski Association's downhill title.

WASHINGTON, March 12 (AP) -- Gerald D. Reilly, a former Government labor lawyer, declared today that the Administration's labor bill, if passed, would "be a disservice to free-trade unionism, to individual workers, to employers, and to the whole public."

GENEVA, March 12 -- Striking differences between basic agricultural conditions in the Soviet Union and other Eastern European Communist countries are revealed by figures compiled by United Nations economists here.

CHICAGO, March 12 -- Business in the Chicago area continued to hold a rapid pace, although industrial and retail activity indicated a somewhat spotty trend in comparison with last year. Retail sales this week were again below the corresponding period a year ago, estimates showed, as unfavorable weather conditions early in the week added to merchandising difficulties in meeting the marks set last year when Easter occurred at an earlier date.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., March 12 -- Cardinal Spellman officiated today at the dedication of Mother Augustine Gill Hall, a new dining room on the campus of the College of New Rochelle, largest Catholic college for women in the United States.
CHICAGO, March 12 (AP) -- Garion Campbell of Michigan Normal won the college 70-yard dash in 0:07.0 to tie the American indoor record tonight in the Illinois Tech relays.

AS one academically interested in all aspects of the pursuit of truth, I agree in principle with Dr. Sidney Hook's analysis of Communist teaching in our schools, but I disagree sharply with his conclusions.

In spite of my sincere admiration for Prof. Sidney Hook's understanding and analysis of Marxist communism, I feel that he missed the point in his article. I share his dislike for the deplorable means that the Communists use to instill their Weltansicht in all phases of academic inquiry.

Mr. and Mrs. J. Rich Steers of 33 East Seventieth Street and Huntington, L. I., gave a dance for their debutante daughter, Miss Carol Steers, last night at the St. Regis Roof. Miss Steers, who wore a bouffant gown of cream-colored satin, received with her parents.

WHEN the Metropolitan Opera drops the curtain next Saturday night on "La Traviata," the final production of its subscription season, Alessio De Paolis, the Italian tenor singing Gastone, should be given a special bow for having sung more performances during the season than any other member of the company.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- The Senate Finance Committee today formally reported a House-approved bill to restore the full tariff-making prerogatives of the President. Enactment of the measure, the committee declared, would "greatly strengthen" the reciprocal trade agreements program.

In an awe-inspiring display of strength which enabled them to turn in one of the most lop-sided victories in the annals of the meet, Boys High School's nimble-footed operatives captured the Public School Athletic League's forty-sixth annual track and field championship yesterday.

KEY WEST, Fla. -- The people of Key West and the White House newspaper correspondents are grateful to President Truman. Since he began coming down here for his midwinter vacations Key West has prospered as a holiday town; a brisk building boom in the last year has added many motels, guest houses and some small hotels to the southernmost city of the United States.

THE synthesis of pedagogue and artist is rarely found in the history of music. A composer often lacks the inclination to explain to others not only what he has fully absorbed, but are what he is using to develop new, intensely personal modes of expression.
The development of our Federal tax system may be said to have been of a "protective" character -- protective of the revenues from the respective sources.

IN this season when man face more questions than he can answer comfortably, Mr. Jackman has not been afraid to put a query and to frame a reply. He had fashioned his catechism in the form of a novel which, though slight in bulk, is of a fine and satisfying workmanship.

I always read "Topics of The Times" with delight and profit, but the writer's contention that the English people today are "the modern representatives of the Angles, Saxons and Jutes" is one which surely requires much greater qualification than he has given it.

MR. J. DONALD ADAMS, in objecting to my recent remarks on Alexander Baron's "From the City, From the Plough," has used them as an excuse for writing a series of capsule reviews of three other books, "The Naked and the Dead," "An Act of Love" and "The Young Lions," of whose merits, incidentally, I hold unequal opinions, but which I certainly hadn't mentioned in connection with "From."

MONTREAL, March 12 (AP) -- Goalie Bill Durnan recorded his tenth shut-out of the National Hockey League season tonight as the Canadiens won the first of two week-end meetings with the Rangers, 3 -- 0, at the Forum. The same teams will clash again tomorrow night at Madison Square Garden, New York.

NOW that the State of Israel has been firmly established in the Middle East and has started to make peace with its neighbors, the most important question in the country's future is its relationship with the Arab and Moslem States that surround it.

OMAHA, Neb., March 12 -- Although highway modernizing programs have high priority in most states, they are having hard sledding in the Middle West. A number of factors are working against the good intentions of legislators, Governors and highway study groups.

WHAT was dubious about this bridegroom was his bigamy -- a question which seemed almost a minor matter when the D. A. decided that he was also a murderer. Perry Mason comes up with dazzling answers to both problems in his thirty-third recorded case.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., March 12 -- Child welfare work in New Jersey would be advanced materially if the Legislature adopted a pending bill to extend services of the State Board of Child Welfare, Edward F. Hann Jr., assistant executive director of the board, said today.

Gold and enamel snuffboxes and watches collected by the late Enrico Caruso will be auctioned on Tuesday and Wednesday at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street. The collection was bequeathed to the tenor's daughter, Gloria Caruso Murray, who has ordered the sale.

TOKYO, March 12 -- The headquarters of Gen. Douglas MacArthur today issued a series of sweeping instructions to the Japanese Government for greater efficiency and higher production in the nation's vital coal mining industry.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- Organized labor presented a united front tonight in a special broadcast arranged by the Democratic National Committee to stir up public sentiment for repeal of the Taft-Hartley Act and enactment of the Administration's new labor law, which faces a hard fight on the Senate floor.

The struggle between Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty, who is awaiting appeal from his sentence to life imprisonment, and the Communist-controlled government in Budapest has been set forth in "Cardinal Mindszenty Speaks: An Authorized White Book." The book will contain the story of the struggle in the years 1945-48 based on 105 documents that were smuggled to Switzerland, and on material of recent weeks.

Thomas F. Farrell, chairman of the New York City Housing Authority, yesterday announced that applications will be received starting today at the Authority's central applications office, 2 Frankfort Street, for apartments in the Lillian Wald Houses on the Lower East Side. The first apartments in the 1,861-family development will be ready for tenants next month, he said.

Shorn of its local angle as a result of the opening day's skirmishes Saturday during which all four of New York's entrants were eliminated, the twelfth National Invitation basketball tournament will enter the quarter-final round today at Madison Square Garden.

LAKE SUCCESS, March 13 -- The outlines of a permanent settlement are at last beginning to emerge from the negotiations between Israel and her Arab foes. Although only an armistice now exists between Egypt and Israel, and the agreement last week between Israel and Transjordan is merely a cease-fire, there is general agreement here that serious fighting in Palestine is at last at an end.

GENEVA, March l3 -- The tunnel being built under the Alps between France and Italy is included in a recently disclosed plan for a network of modern highways to link the countries of Europe. Thirteen European Governments, the United States and the three Western zones of Germany have reached final agreement on the proposed network, it was announced today.

Lazare Saminsky, who celebrates his twenty-fifth anniversary as director of music at Temple Emanu-El this year, conducted a program of his own compositions and adaptations at Times Hall last night. Assisting him was the temple's choir plus a small group of vocal and instrumental performers.
The American Academy in Rome announced yesterday the awarding of ten scholarships, valued at about $3,000 each, to Americans for study in Rome.

PITTSBURGH, March 13 -- The nation's steel industry operated at 102 per cent of rated capacity last week as compared with the revised rate of 101 per cent in the preceding week. On a tonnage basis output of ingots last week reached a new weekly high.

CHICAGO, March 13 -- Government buying of cash corn last week was relatively small, and trade reports indicate that the European demand is not as large as had been estimated. Prices last week dropped to the lowest level in about a month, although holding well above the low level reached during the early February break, when May sold down to $1.10, or about 45 cents a bushel under the Government loan level.
PITTSBURGH, March 13 (UP) -- Dr. James Boyd declared tonight that neither John L. Lewis nor anyone else could scare him into quitting as Director of the United States Bureau of Mines.

CHICAGO, March 13 -- Wage and hour negotiations involving 1,000,000 employes of the country's railroads became focused today on what appears to be the final issue in the complicated case, now nearly eleven months old.

How irresistibly appealing reads your proposed advertisement to recruit new teachers. I am reasonably certain that if this were all, the teacher shortage in New York (presumably you are writing about this city) would disappear overnight.

MIAMI, Fla., March 13 -- Dr. Abba Hillel Silver of Cleveland, head of the Zionist Emergency Council, was urged today by high-ranking Zionist Organization of America officers here to run for the presidency of the organization at its convention this summer.

ALBANY, March 13 -- The total of deaths in motor vehicle accidents in the state in 1948 was 6 per cent below that of 1947, compared with a national decline of 2 per cent, according to a compilation released today by the State Motor Vehicle Bureau.

PRINCETON, N. J., March 13 -- Dr. Albert Einstein, who will celebrate his seventieth birthday tomorrow, accepted today as a "magnificent birthday gift" a pledge given to him by William Rosenwald that all the displaced persons camps in Europe would be emptied by the end of 1949.

In a quick turnover of a West Side property acquired recently, the twelve-story Hotel Prescot at 1851-55 Broadway, southwest corner of Sixty-first Street, has been resold by Land Properties, Inc., to Herbert Baum and Edward Sulzberger for investment. Assessed for $500,000, the hotel occupies a plot 87 by 81 feet and contains 200 rooms and stores.

While some provisional progress has been made, the Administration has not as yet been able to work out a filibuster compromise which the Southern Senators, inflated by their victory last Friday, would accept. The Republicans, whose votes helped the Southerners to overrule Vice President Barkley's decision that a motion to take up a measure was subject to closure, attended yesterday's two-hour session, which failed to produce any decisive result.

Harvey Siegel, pianist, of this city, gave a recital yesterday afternoon at Town Hall.
