His program comprised Bach's Partita in C minor, Mozart's Fantasy in C minor (K. 396), Schumann's Sonata in G minor, six of Beethoven's "Bagatelles," Op 33: Mendelssohn's "Rondo Capriccioso," Liszt's "Hungarian Rhapsody," No. 13, and, as novelties, two pieces by Mendelssohn and Arthur Berger's Fantasy, which received their first New York performance.

Leading law-enforcement officials conceded yesterday that no one to their knowledge ever had gone to jail in this state for unauthorized wiretapping. In addition, members of the bar with an interest in this subject asserted that New York State law was inadequate to cover illegal wiretapping by modern methods.

Despite minor skirmishes in the Negeb, peace continues to make progress in Palestine. Having signed a permanent armistice with Egypt, Israel has now also signed a "complete and enduring" cease-fire agreement with Transjordan as a preliminary to a similar armistice with that state.

Psychological counseling for personal, marital and family problems as practiced by family service agencies today has become one of the most effective means of preventing "family breakdown," it was maintained yesterday by Ralph K. Guinzburg, president of the board of trustees of Jewish Family Service.

SHANGHAI, Monday, March 14 -- The Chinese Communists have established a regional Government for a three-Province area north of the Yangtze River, the Communist radio announced today. The area contains 50,000,000 persons.

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 13 -- Bill Rigney, Giant second baseman playing his first game of the spring exhibition series with the Indians today, collapsed in the clubhouse a few minutes after retiring from the game in the fifth inning and tonight was in a local hospital being treated for a heart attack.
Well contrasted in Bergdorf Goodman's showing at the shop last Friday were the daring decollettes of Irene of Hollywood's fashions against the demure, almost quaint charm of Bernard Newman's.

Caging five goals in the second period and five more in the third, the New York Rovers came up with one of those "old time" performances yesterday afternoon at Madison Square Garden. They routed the Royal Canadian Air Force Flyers, 11 to 0, before 8,221 fans.

ALBANY, March 13 -- The lack of any negotiations for the settlement of basic conflicts within the Republican party appeared today to be largely responsible for the delay and difficulty in arriving at a compromise on the budget and tax-cut issues as the controversy went into its seventh week.
KEY WEST, Fla., March 13 -- President Truman's main activity today was to listen to a Lenten sermon in the Naval Chapel here with his aides and Chief Justice Fred Vinson.
DETROIT, March 12 (AP) -- The Kaiser-Frazer Corporation will go back into production on Monday after a three-week shut-down.

Airlines, particularly those serving Bermuda and Europe, are pre. paring for a record Easter vacation traffic. The domestic lines are soliciting all college towns, showing students from distant places that where an Easter vacation at home had not always been possible, they can make it this year.

The atomic bomb may prove to be humanity's greatest blessing rather than its greatest curse by developing a new scientific study of man's moral capacity, the Rev. Dr. John M. Ratcliffe, dean of Tufts College School of Religion, said yesterday. He spoke at the Unitarian Church of All Souls, Lexington Avenue and Eightieth Street.
Memories of an exhibition held three years ago at the Brooklyn Museum are evoked by a new collection of "Far East" furniture that has just been arranged in two room settings at W. J. Sloane.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- Measurable progress was made today, in an anxious Sunday morning conference of eight leaders on a harsh and multi-sided issue, toward a possible compromise in the Senate's filibuster crisis.
AMITYVILLE, March 13 -- Five fishermen who had been stranded overnight on a sand bar in Great South Bay were rescued this morning by a lifeboat crew from the Short Beach Coast Guard Station.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 13 -- The election of Mrs. Arthur Forrest Anderson of New York as national president of the Young Women's Christian Association under a new constitution was announced at the YMCA convention here tonight.

A resolution seeking to bar City Councilmen Eugene Connolly and Benjamin Davis from marching in the St. Patrick's Day parade was adopted yesterday at a communion breakfast of the Kings County division of the Ancient Order of Hibernians.

The Rev. Dr. John Howard Melish, whose retirement as rector of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Holy Trinity, Brooklyn, has been ordered by Bishop James P. De Wolfe of the Long Island diocese effective April 4, called yesterday a special parish election to be held in the church, Montague and Clinton Streets, at 8 P. M. today.

The editorial of March 8 entitled "Recruiting the New Teacher" is interesting and challenging but does not accurately apply to our state. It is true that we have erred in our methods of recruiting our ranks, but not quite to the degree stated.

The notion of "selling teaching" as a career to the college graduate fails to take into account that, unlike other fields of employment, youth is fresh from first-hand experience with the teacher's conditions of work on both high school and college levels. In many instances he has participated in student groups seeking redress for victimized instructors.

CHICAGO, March 13 -- The United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh (Chicago) Circuit ruled yesterday that price reductions made in good faith to meet a competitor's price were not always a complete defense against prosecution under provisions of the Robinson-Patman Act.

Victor Dyrgall, representing the Millrose A. A., captured honors in the modified marathon held under the auspices of the Ninety-second Street Y. M. H. A. in and around Central Park yesterday. The winner was clocked in 1:17:29.7 for the 14.2 mile grind.
PITTSBURGH, March 13 -- Western Pennsylvania's 55,000 miners have started their two-week shut-down of the pits, obeying an order from John L. Lewis.

As retail store operating costs show no sign of declining, expansion of the low-overhead "pipe-rack" and factory-outlet type of retail operation are appearing or are in planning stages for various parts of the country.
The Government wants to sell some more islands.

A detective's belief that a man leaving 61 East Ninety-third Street was too shabbily dressed to be a resident of the neighborhood resulted in the recovery of $10,000 in furs and jewelry taken earlier from a Park Avenue apartment. After his arrest, the man was identified as Nicholas Angelo, 33-year-old ex-convict of 312 East Twelfth Street.

Aurora Ragaini, American pianist, who made her bow here nineteen years ago, returned to Town Hall yesterday afternoon to give her first New York recital since her debut. Her program included Mozart's C minor Fantasia, Beethoven's Thirty-two Variations in C minor and groups by Brahms, Chopin and Rachmaninoff.

SPARTA, Greece, March 13 -- The Greek Army's Ninth Division, which began the offensive against the Communist-led rebels in the Peloponnesus at the end of 1948, is slated to leave this area in a week or so, its enemy beaten.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., March 13 -- Cardinal Spellman officiated today at dedication of the $350,000 Ryan Memorial Library on the campus of Iona College here. He blessed the library rooms, with facilities for 40,000 volumes, and the lower floor cafeteria, which will serve 290 students.

PRINCETON, N. J., March 13 -- In the face of a 10 per cent rent increase on the Princeton campus, university authorities have accepted an undergraduate proposal to suspend personal janitor service and retain the present rates in the twenty-two dormitories next fall.

PARIS, March 13 -- The advent of spring in the present world is becoming almost as synonymous with alarums as with warmer weather and traditional holidaymaking. This spring promises to be far from exceptional in that respect.

Though some non-Catholics fear the Catholic Church as a threat to the American way of life, the United States "has nothing to fear in the nature of a change of our religious-freedom clause, should Catholics ever become a powerful majority in this country," the Rev. Vincent F. Holden, director and founder of the Paulist Information Center, declared yesterday.

The Pennsylvania Railroad Company reported yesterday for 1948 a net income of $34,429,934 after charges and taxes. This was equal to $2.28 each on the 13,167,754 capital shares outstanding after sinking-fund charges and advances to leased and affiliated companies.

The General Electric Company over the week-end announced price reductions effective today in many of its major lines of home appliances. The changes will cover several refrigerator models, home freezers and electric ranges.

TEL AVIV, Israel, March 13 -- The mystery enveloping the Aqaba area on the Red Sea was dispelled today when it was learned that Arab Legion troops had been driven out from strategic positions they had held in Israeli territory of the Negeb and also had been forced to withdraw from outposts along the highly contested area to the north of Aqaba.
A work stoppage by an estimated 425,000 members of the United Mine Workers, scheduled for two weeks, began today in coal pits east of the Mississippi.

WASHINGTON, March 13 (UP) -Representative Walter K. Granger, Democrat, of Utah, predicted today that domestic wool prices will jump sharply next year as a result. of the recent costly storms over the Western range states.
A Coast Guard helicopter rescued two boys yesterday from a Jamaica Bay sandbar on which they had spent Saturday night after the shipwreck of their rowboat on its maiden voyage of exploration.

GODESBERG, Germany, March 13 (Reuters) -- Dr. Hermann Puender, chief German executive of the bizonal administration and other West German conservative economic and political leaders, met Rudolf Nadolny, former German Ambassador in Moscow and reported Soviet emissary, at a secret conference here today to discuss "questions of German national unity."

ALBANY, March 13 -- Private college presidents of the state, in a statement today, minimized the importance of the fight between the Board of Regents and the State University trustees over the administrative control of state-aided colleges.

There is pending before the Legislature a bill introduced by Senator Williamson, providing that voters one registered would be able to vote with out registering again, unless disqualified by removal, failure to vote for two years, or by conviction of a felony.

WASHINGTON, March 13 (AP) -- Foreign countries bought more than twenty-five billion American-made cigarettes in 1948, five times as many as in pre-war years, the Department of Commerce reported tonight.

Gross and net income of the Skelly Oil Company reached new high levels last year, exceeding those for 1947 by a wide margin. William G. Skelly, president, reports in the twenty-ninth annual statement to be released today. Gross operating income rose to $180,044,371 from $121,323,798, the year before.
Your laudable effort to "sell" the teaching profession as it emerged in your editorial, "Recruiting the New Teacher," calls for a little correction.

The German language daily, Staatszeitung und Herold of New York, published on Feb. 20 the text of a German broadcast made by the Voice of America, under the headline "Voice of America Unmasks Hypocrisy of 'Russian Peace Offensive'."

ROCHESTER, N. Y., March 13 (AP) -- A new pulp process which, in tests, has resulted in savings of about $5.50 a ton in the manufacture of newsprint was announced today by Consolidated Machine Tool Corporation.

We published an editorial on March 8 which endorsed the novel suggestion that to encourage the recruiting of greatly needed new teachers for the public schools a little salesmanship be used, emphasizing the attractive features of teaching as a career. Two columns of letters commenting on the editorial are printed on this page today.

With less than four minutes of play remaining, Bill Durnan, goalie for the Canadiens of Montreal, seemed on the way to a shut-out triumph over the New York Rangers at Madison Square Garden last night. The crowd of 10,117 fans was tense as the game drew to a close, some hoping that the northern goalie would make it, and others cheering the Rangers on to get at least a goal.

WASHINGTON, March 13 (UP) -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee forwarded today to Secretary of State Dean Acheson a request that he spell out his ideas on stopping communism in China before seeking American arms shipments to bolster Europe against the threat of Communist aggression.

Apart from some linguistic difficulties such as the English use in America of "fancy" and the American use in England of "homely" the two young women who have temporarily swapped jobs in North Bergen, N. J., and Spennymoor, England, are finding things "first rate," or, "okay."

FRANKFORT, Germany, March 13 -- Four Czech nationals, apparently refugees, landed at the nearby Rhein-Main airfield today following their flight from a field near Prague. They were taken into custody by United States Air Force agents who sent them to Air Force headquarters at Wiesbaden for further questioning.
NORWALK, Conn., March 13 -- Henry A. Wallace delivered an address as a surprise speaker this morning during a regular Sunday hour devoted to religious broadcasts on Station WNLK here.

The Eastern States mixed team-of-four contract bridge championship was won last night by the team of Mrs. Helen Sobel, Samuel Fry Jr., Mrs. Lester Rhodes and Richard F. Kahan, all of New York, after afternoon and evening play at the Park Sheraton Hotel.

Two "Parsifals" and two "Lucias" will be among the operas presented by the Metropolitan Opera during its annual post-season Holy Week performances, it was announced yesterday. The productions of "Parsifal" will be conducted by Fritz Reiner.
MIAMI, Fla., March 13 -- It may be that playing the Braves is an inspiration to the Dodgers. If so, Barney Shotton hopes it holds throughout the season.

ST, PETERSBURG, Fla., March 13 -- Johnny Lindell unloaded the first Yankee homer of the year at Al Lang Field this afternoon and, in moderate measure, erased some of the agony from an otherwise depressing ball game as the Yanks made it two in a row over the St. Louis Cardinals. The score was 3 to 1.

Claiming she was within her rights in rescinding her contract with William L. Taub because of "one or more material misrepresentations" by him, Margaret Sullavan has been upheld by an arbitration decision in her dispute with Mr. Taub, it became known yesterday.

A contractual requirement that dress manufacturers build up cash reserves in periods of prosperity to provide a cushion against future slack seasons may become part of the bargaining program of the Dress Joint Board of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, AFL, Julius Hochman, manager of the joint board, said yesterday.

Two dancers from India, Sujata and Asoka, made their New York concert debut on Saturday evening at the Ziegfeld Theare, in a program consisting of dances based on various Indian styles with a pair of numbers from Tibet thrown in for good measure.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 13 (AP) -- Marty Marion, St. Louis Cardinal player representative, said today the Cards favored establishment of a three-man arbitration committee of neutrals to settle disputes.

First steps in the distribution of 880,000 shares of common stock of New York State Electric and Gas Corporation, now owned by General Public Utilities Corporation, will be taken today with the offering by the parent company to its stockholders of shares of the New York State utility.

ALBANY, March 13 -- Assemblyman Lee B. Mailler of Orange, Republican Majority Leader of the Assembly, announced today that he and Senator William F. Condon of Westchester would introduce tomorrow night the Administration's Disability Compensation Bill.

John Warren Hill, presiding justice of the Domestic Relations Court, took issue yesterday with several recommendations and assertions concerning the city's detention facilities for juvenile delinquents made last week in a report issued by the Community Service Society.
WASHINGTON, March 13 -- The votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-call during the period March 5 to 12 are given in the appended tabulation:

With residential construction forming the bulk of the activity, permits for permanent building work in this state last year amounted to $561,000,000. State Industrial Commissioner Edward Corsi reported yesterday. Housing accounted for 40,698 new family units, or about 55 per cent of the volume.

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., March 13 -- Michael Kosik, president of District 1, United Mine Workers of America, said tonight that no distress would result from suspension of operations in mines east of the Mississippi, starting tomorrow.

The Catholic Church "not unlikely" is entering a period when it will be attacked violently all over the world and condemned, as was Christ, as "too worldly and too unworldly, too divine and too human," Msgr. Fulton J. Sheen of the faculty of Catholic University, Washington, declared yesterday.
WINDOW ROCK, Ariz., March 13 -- Encouraging efforts are under way to alleviate two of the worst phases of the chronic distress among the Navajo Indians -- lack of medical and educational facilities.

LONDON, March 13 -- A large-scale conference of the Cabinet Ministers of the Western Union of Europe will convene here tomorrow to consider how the existing organization of the five Brussels treaty powers can be integrated into the larger framework of the Atlantic pact, which will be signed in April.

A plan designed to reduce the competitive advantage of foreign-flag vessels over United States tonnage will be offered soon by the States Marine Corporation for consideration by the House Committee on the Merchant Marine and Fisheries, it became known yesterday.

LACONIA-GILFORD, N. H., March 13 -- Gusty winds made ski jumping for the postponed Eastern championships at Rowe Mountain today most hazardous and of the original field of more than 100 only eighteen participated for Class A and B honors.
ALBANY, N. Y., March 13 (AP) -The price index of New York State farm products in February dropped 10 points from the level of the preceding month, the State Department of Agriculture reported today.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- A recommendation will be made to Congress, it was learned today, to convert the Department of the Interior into a great public works agency, fully responsible for development of the country's water and subsoil resources.

BERLIN, March 13 -- Citing what it called official Russian zone figures, Neue Zeitung, official organ of the United States Military Government, today revealed that the death rate was rising and the birth rate falling in the Soviet zone of occupation.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., March 13 -- Passage of President Truman's Civil Rights program and the adoption of an extensive educational campaign interpreting the democratic rights and responsibilities of all Americans was urged today by Benjamin R. Epstein of New York City, National Director of the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai Brith.
Three new films, including a pair of importations from France, are scheduled to arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:

The large-scale shipment of fresh fruit from Argentina to this country, halted two years ago because of the prevalance of the Mediterranean fruit fly in consignments, has been resumed as the result of a plan worked out by the Moore-McCormack Lines in cooperation with the United States Department of Agriculture.

FRANKFORT, Germany, March 8 -- An estimated $1,000,000,000 worth of United States Army goods and equipment has been turned over to the German economy since the end of the war, according to a summary prepared by a United States Military Government official.

Buyers in the wholesale apparel market here last week were mainly interested in fill-in orders for Easter merchandise, according to reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices. Reorders were received for toppers and cotton dresses retail priced at $5.98.

Park Department horticulturists will be busy this spring in New York's parks, planting 1,100 new flowering trees, made possible partly through the gifts of 500 children. Three hundred flowering shrubs are due for later planting.

Clendenin J. Ryan, multi-millionaire civic reformer and former aide to the late Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia, received at 6:35 P. M. yesterday a subpoena requiring his testimony in a Grand Jury investigation of a wiretapping plot against Mayor O'Dwyer and seventy-five other city officials.
Sizes of garment bags and other closet equipment in relation to the dimensions of clothes closets are stressed by the sponsors of a "space-saving clinic" that will open today on Altman's fifth floor.

PARIS, March 13 -- Continuance of the slump in business and on the Bourse is regarded by French financial circles as one of the most important of problems at present. It can best be gauged by evolution of the shares on the Bourse. This has been showing an increasing depression from week to week, affecting foreign and French shares alike.

Net sales and net income of the General Motors Corporation in 1948 were at new peaks and the physical volume of production during the year represented a peacetime record, C. E. Wilson, president, and Alfred P. Sloan Jr., chairman, said in the annual report to almost 434,000 stockholders, issued today.

Samuel H. Telsey, president of the Hebrew Immigrant Aid Society, announced yesterday at its sixty-fourth annual meeting that HIAS had set a budget of $5,005,000, the largest in its history, as "the minimum sum to carry on the imperatively urgent work among the displaced and suffering Jews of the world."

RHODES, March 13 -- Israeli military activity near the Gulf of Aqaba is clearly a breach of the truce, Dr. Ralph J. Bunche, Acting United Nations mediator, stated tonight. He emphasized that until he had received a full report he could not say whether it was more serious than others that had been passed over.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 13 -- "The Edge of Doom," a first novel by Leo Brady, which will be published next fall, has been acquired for the screen by Samuel Goldwyn, the producer announced today. The story deals with the murder of a priest, and Farley Granger is expected to play the leading role, with filming scheduled for next September, according to Mr. Goldwyn.

Citing the success of a number of European products in winning customers in this country, notably in the food lines, an agency executive last week credited their genuine high quality with opening markets for them. American enterprises, he suggested, might soft-pedal some of their vaunted "know-how" in order to heed a kind of "moral" in these successes made under adverse conditions.

DUBLIN, March 13 -- Premier John A. Costello gave Eire taxpayers a pleasant surprise on the opening of St. Patrick's week when he announced in a speech at Mary-borough, Leix County, tonight a cut in fiscal demands for Eire's public services of more than 5,000,000 ($20,000,000) for 1949-50.
Two distinct characteristics mark the collection of hats by Keneth Hopkins, West Coast milliner, that Gunther-Jaeckel is offering for spring.

Efforts by the National Mediation Board to end the tie-up of Railway Express Agency operations in the metropolitan area were unsuccessful last night, but this setback was offset by indications that the parent union involved would disapprove picketing of New York rail terminals in connection with the dispute.
Joseph Campbell, former assistant treasurer of Columbia University, has been elected treasurer, Frederick Coykendall, chairman of the trustees, announced yesterday.

LEWES, Del., March 13 -- Five thousand dollars' worth of "slop chest" gear for the Russian crew of the Soviet cruiser Murmansk was loaded aboard the ship today on the eve of its transfer to the United States Navy.

While phenomenal achievements like the round-the-world refueling flight of the Air Force and Captain Odom's remarkable solo journey of 5,300 miles in a light plane are writing new chapters of aviation history, scheduled air transport continues to set less spectacular, but certainly equally important, records of safe and dependable flight.

MIAMI, Fla., March 13 (AP) -- Cary Middlecoff and Jim Ferrier beat Skip Alexander and Pete Cooper by 9 and 8 in the final of Miami's $10,000 international four-ball golf tournament today in the most spectacular exhibition of precision golf ever witnessed here.

PUBLIC life in the twentieth century, it sometimes seems, has been monopolized by mediocrities and villains. The lists of both are long. Such men as Harding and Coolidge, MacDonald, Baldwin and Chamberlain, Daladier and Reynaud had little more than good intentions to offer to their countries' service. Such men as Hitler and Himmler, Mussolini and Franco, Laval and Tojo and Stalin have drenched the world in blood and undermined the structure of civilization.

Margaret Fairchild has been concerned with meal-preparation in a ship's galley rather than in a home kitchen in the experiments on electronic cooking she has been conducting at Columbia University. But in her work on the Radarange as possible equipment for the United States Navy, the technician has discovered many advantages that housewives will enjoy in the future in this fastest device for preparing food for the table.
The one bright spot in the foreign exchange market last week was the action of the Canadian free dollar continuing its strength and reaching a new high of 93.82 cents, unmatched since June 21, 1948.

CANTON, N. Y., March 13 (AP) -- Dr. Frank F. Williams, dean of St. Lawrence county physicians, was injured fatally today in the collision of his automobile and a New York Central train here. He was 91 years old.

HAGUE, the Netherlands, March 13 -- The protocol setting forth the steps whereby provisional economic union can be attained by Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg [Benelux] within the next fifteen-and-a-half months was made public here today upon the conclusion of the important ministerial conference.

CAIRO, March 13 -- Egypt has informed the United States State Department that she does not wish to conclude an agreement providing for the use of war surplus material funds to bring scholars, research men and specialists to this country under the Fulbright Act unless she receives full equality in determining for what projects and where the money shall be used.

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 13 -- Encircled by an overflow gathering of 9,025, largest crowd ever to attend a ball game in Arizona, the Giants today served notice on all and sundry they have no intention of playing second fiddle to the Indians merely because Lou Boudreau's tribe has gained in stature since their meetings in the 1948 training season.

CHICAGO, March 13 -- Republican state chairmen named tonight leaders from California, Iowa and New York to serve on a national policy committee, acting after an eight-hour round-table discussion seeking a pattern for victory in the 1950 Congressional elections.

Ceremonies marking the establishment of Oak Ridge, Tenn., as a normal American community will be broadcast over the coast-to-coast Mutual network on Saturday from 3 to 3:30 P. M. Scheduled to speak on the broadcast are Vice President Alben W. Barkley, Senators Kenneth McKellar and Estes Kefauver of Tennessee, David E. Lilienthal, chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, and Perry Brown, national commander of the American Legion.

The first attempt in this country at an amalgam of all anti-Communist Russian emigres seeking the overthrow of the Soviet regime was made here yesterday at a mass meeting. The group established a "Union for the Liberation of the Peoples of Russia."

Modern emphasis on material accomplishments has made simple living and simple thinking lost arts, the Rev. Dr. Robert J. McCracken said yesterday in his sermon at the Riverside Church, 122d Street and Riverside Drive.

BERLIN, March 13 -- Allied Military Government officials disclosed today that there had been a steady flight of corporate headquarters out of Berlin since December's municipal elections returned a Socialist majority for the Western sectors of the blockaded city.

LONDON, March 13 -- Routine diplomatic exchanges are taking place between the United States, Britain and France on the future of Italy's former colonies in Africa, which will again come to the attention of the United Nations General Assembly meeting next month.
M. E. Springer has been appointed assistant vice president of American News Company, Inc., in charge of the stationery department. He joined the company thirty-eight years ago.
MINNEAPOLIS, March 13 (AP) -- Dropping 22 out of 40 shots, George Mikan racked up 51 points as his Minneapolis Lakers halted New York, 100 to 90 in a Basketball Association of America game tonight.

Scientists the world over will shower Einstein with their expressions of goodwill and admiration on this, his seventieth birthday. As for the general public, it is still puzz.led by such startling conceptions as space-time and a closed universe, but it knows greatness when it sees it.

DUESSELDORF, Germany, March 13 -- Annexation of German territory and population to Belgium and the Netherlands without the benefit of a plebiscite may prove to be the spark that will touch off active rebellion, Dr. Leo Schwering asserted today.

Prices for cotton in the domestic market moved over a narrow range last week, with the day-to-day changes mostly insignificant. At the close on Saturday, active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were down 3 to 27 points from the level of the week previous.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- Representative Frederic R. Coudert Jr., Republican, of New York, proposed today amending the Federal Constitution to provide for the selection of Presidential electors on the same basis as members of the House of Representative and the Senate.

MIDDLEBURY, Vt., March 13 -- Miss Rose Marie Stewart, 21-year-old Green Mountain Junior College student, won the United States Eastern Ski Association women's slalom title today at Middlebury College's Bread Loaf Mountain Snow Bowl.
There is something about the atmosphere at this time of year that appears to be especially favorable to the propagation of certain communicable diseases which commonly afflict the young.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., March 13 -- Exhibitors, judges and professional handlers showed a divergence of opinion today on how desirable the experiment of the Saw Mill River Kennel Club was in eliminating group judging and best-in-show as factors in an all-breed dog show.
WASHINGTON, March 13 (AP) -- President Truman's proposal for prepaid medical insurance was denounced and defended by Congressional figures today.

Lois Hunt, 23-year-old Philadelphia lyric soprano, and Denis Harbour, 29, a French-Canadian bass-baritone, received contracts yesterday to sing with the Metropolitan Opera Company and $1,000 scholarships as winners of the 1949 Metropolitan Opera Auditions of the Air.

There is little evidence that productivity for manufacturing as a whole increased in 1948, compared with the two previous years, according to an analysis of productivity by the National Industrial Conference Board, released over the week-end.
ASPEN, Col., March 13 (AP) -- Yves Latreille of Sun Valley flashed down Roch Run in 3:11.1 today to win the Roch Club Derby.

Marked expansion of industrial activity in the area served by the New Haven Railroad is in prospect for 1949, according to Laurence F. Whittemore, president of the company, who reported yesterday that more than thirty industries had purchased 400 acres of land for new or extended operations in Southern New England and Southeastern New York.

Proponents of the court reorganization plan sponsored by Presiding Justice David W. Peck of the Appellate Division produced yesterday a series of documented cases showing that court calendar delays -- which the Peck plan seeks to cure -- are reducing to virtual beggarhood some litigants with worthy claims for justice.

Maritime labor leaders said here yesterday that they were planning a vigorous campaign to prevent the Government's transfer of the American-flag displaced persons fleet to Army operation, but Maritime Commission officials said they were proceeding with the project and would turn the first ship over to the Army this week.

NANKING, March 13 (UP) -- New Premier Ho Ying-chin prepared to come here tomorrow from Hang-chow to form a new Cabinet as ominous Communist troop movements north of the Yangtze River indicated that the Reds were ready to apply more pressure to force an early Government surrender.

NORTH CONWAY, N. H., March 13 -- Colin Stewart, Dartmouth's 22-year-old Olympic star, today put together two stylish and consistent performances to win the United States Eastern Amateur Ski Association slalom championship.

Jennie Tourel gave a recital last night at Town Hall, which attracted an extremely enthusiastic capacity audience. As usual, the accomplished mezzo-soprano had arranged an interesting and unhackneyed program, and delivered it with the intelligence, warmth and insight unfailingly hers as a purveyor of song.

The Newport News Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company, in its annual report to be mailed to stockholders today, discloses a net income for 1948 of $7,804,490, equal to $9.76 a share, compared with $5,162,807 or $6.45 a share earned in 1947.

LONDON, March 13 -- Although the stock markets in the past few days have shown to rather better advantage than they did previously for a time, this has been largely due to the technical factor of bear covering and not to any real return of confidence among investors.

Anis Fuleihan, composer-pianist who was born on the Island of Cyprus, gave his first recital here since 1947 yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall's Twilight Series. His program included Mozart's Sonata in E flat (K. 282); Beethoven's Op. 10. No. 3; Schumann's "Carnaval," six of his own Short Pieces for Piano and his arrangement of Bach's Organ Prelude and Fugue in E minor.

Pending in the New York State Legislature is the Williamson-Brook bill, which provides for the consolidation and simplification of the courts in New York, Bronx and Kings Counties in a manner urged by Presiding Justice Peck of the Appellate Division, with the support of the Association of the Bar, the New York County Lawyers Association and other civic organizations of standing.

Those who attempt to build a new world on values that have no permanence are now writing history's greatest tragedy, the Rev. Dr. Joseph R. Sizoo, president of the New Brunswick Thelogical Seminary, declared yesterday in a sermon at the First Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Twelfth Street.

NORTH CONWAY, N. H., March 13 -- Colin Stewart, Dartmouth's 22-year-old Olympic star, today put together two stylish and consistent performances to win the United States Eastern Amateur Ski Association slalom championship.

Jennie Tourel gave a recital last night at Town Hall, which attracted an extremely enthusiastic capacity audience. As usual, the accomplished mezzo-soprano had arranged an interesting and unhackneyed program, and delivered it with the intelligence, warmth and insight unfailingly hers as a purveyor of song.

The Newport News Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company, in its annual report to be mailed to stockholders today, discloses a net income for 1948 of $7,804,490, equal to $9.76 a share, compared with $5,162,807 or $6.45 a share earned in 1947.

Eight platinum capsules containing fifty milligrams of radium are believed to be buried in tons of refuse aboard a Sanitation Department scow at Fresh Kills, Staten Island. Today at 10 A. M. radium-detection equipment will be used in an attempt to locate the substance, valued at $1,300.
WASHINGTON, March 14 -- Merchant fleets of the Marshall Plan countries are recovering rapidly from their war losses, the National Federation of American Shipping reported today.

ALBANY, March 14 -- By offering to jettison Governor Dewey's cherished pay-as-you-go policy for financing new state construction, Republican legislative leaders tonight were on the verge of compromising the seven-week-old row within the party over budget and tax increase programs.
SEOUL, Korea, March 14 -- Korean Army forces have opened a spring offensive against Communist-led guerrilla bands that are terrorizing South Korea.

OTTAWA, March 14 -- Canada is increasing this year's defense appropriation by nearly 50 per cent, it was revealed today when the 1949-50 estimates of expenditure were tabled in the House of Commons by Finance Minister Douglas C. Abbott.

ALBANY, March 14 -- Both employers and labor are divided over merits of the Condon-Mailler bill, introduced today, which sets up a state sickness disability plan. It would guarantee benefits up to a $26 for a maximum of thirteen weeks for disabilities incurred other than through employment to most workers in the state.
MOSCOW, March 14 (AP) -- The Supreme Soviet approved tonight the 1949 budget. The Supreme Soviet, which had convened last Thursday, then adjourned its sessions.
BERLIN, March 14 -- The United States and Britain have agreed on eight Germans as managerial trustees of the Ruhr iron and steel industries.

LONDON, March 14 -- The deadlock between the Soviet deputy for the Austrian treaty talks, Georgi N. Zarubin, and his colleagues representing the United States, Britain and France on the question of Austria's frontiers continued today.
LONDON, March 14 -- Dr. Geoffrey Fisher, Archbishop of Canterbury, issued a statement today dissociating himself from the political opinions and activities of Dr. Hewlett Johnson, Dean of Canterbury.

CINCINNATI, March 14 -- The office of Baseball Commissioner Albert B. Chandler tonight announced several playing rule changes, including one that bars uniformed players from mingling with fans and friends before the start of a game.

Valentin A. Gubitchev refused to plead either guilty or not guilty yesterday to an indictment accusing him of conspiring to commit espionage. Instead the Russian engineer used the pleading opportunity in Federal District Court to denounce the proceedings as a "comedy" and "inquisition" that deprived him of diplomatic immunity.

WASHINGTON, Tuesday, March 15 -- The Truman Administration's Senate forces surrendered last night to the Southern filibuster after the collapse of compromise negotiations, but agreed this morning to try fresh armistice talks.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- The drive of Administration Democrats in the House to push through a fifteen-month extension of rent control faced a new hurdle tonight in a persuasive opposition proposal, supported by a powerful coalition, to relax Federal regulation.

ZURICH, March 14 -- On March 8 the Swiss Federal Council approved a recent Anglo-Swiss compromise whereby, subject to the adjustments demanded by each side, the trade and payments agreement of March 12, 1946 is prolonged for another year.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., March 14 -- A dispute between twenty-one villages and eighteen towns of Westchester over the distribution of state aid was carried to the floor of the County Board of Supervisors today when Gordon Miller, Pelham supervisor, proposed an amendment to the Moore plan of fund allocation.
NEW ORLEANS, La., March 14 -- A small reproduction of the New York harbor's Statue of Liberty greeted the first shipload of displaced persons to enter the port of New Orleans.

DUBLIN, March 14 -- The audience at the Abbey Theatre here tonight for the opening of Bryan MacMahon's play, "The Bugle in the Blood," left no doubt about its verdict as it clamored for the author at the final curtain.

George La Falgio, Bronx light-weight, scored a knockout victory over Billy Murphy of Brooklyn in the feature bout of eight rounds at the St. Nicholas Arena last night, winning in 1:06 of the first as Referee Frank Fullam intervened.

D. B. Wyndham Lewis, the English biographer of Francois Villon, Louis XI of France and James Boswell, has a new book on the Longmans, Green list for April. It is "Four Favorites," containing studies of Melbourne, Godoy, Potemkin and Mme. Pompadour.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 14 -- Ten Los Angeles residents convicted of civil contempt last fall for refusing to answer questions about Communist party organization for a Federal grand jury were, in effect, ordered back to jail today by the Ninth Federal Circuit Court of Appeals.
HALLANDALE, Fla., March 14 (AP) -- Buzfuz, long a favorite with Florida fans, outran eight other sprinters in today's Uleta Purse, one of two features on the Gulfstream Park card.

Banks are rapidly losing ground in the thrift field to other types of savings institutions and must reappraise their methods of business solicitation and advertising, William A. Marcus, senior vice president of the American Trust Company, San Francisco, declared yesterday.
VERO BEACH, Fla., March 14 -- Normalcy, as major league clubs used to know it before such baseball settlements as "Dodgertown" were founded, returned to this camp today.

ROME, March 14 -- While spokesmen for extreme left-wing parties continued to attack the projected North Atlantic defense pact in the Chamber of Deputies today, the police and carabinieri were mobilized to deal with possible Communist-instigated disturbance tomorrow and in the following days.

The significance of the case of Dr. Miriam Van Waters, who was reinstated Friday as superintendent of the Massachusetts Reformatory for Women, extends far beyond the boundaries of that commonwealth. It reaches into every nation of the world where there is a prison.

MOSCOW, March 14 -- The Presidium of the Supreme Soviet has released Nikolai A. Voznesensky from his important duties as Chairman of the State Planning Commission and Vice Chairman of the Council of Ministers.

TOKYO, March 14 -- Japan's Conservative Premier, Shigeru Yoshida, made known today that he intended to establish an Anti-Japanese Activities Committee directly under Cabinet control to investigate Communist subversive maneuvers here.

A resolution to rescind the vote of the membership of the New York County Medical Society against the American Medical Association's national health program was approved last night by the executive board of the county society. It had been introduced by fifteen doctors whose names were not made known.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 14 -- After an unsuccessful protest to the producers of "Champion" a boxing film starring Kirk Douglas which United Artists will distribute, RKO has scheduled "The Set Up," also a boxing picture, for immediate release in an effort to beat the United Artists film to the market, it was learned today from RKO.

The Union Pacific Railroad Company reported yesterday that its earnings last year from oil and gas operations were $26,540,409, exclusive of Federal income taxes, a gain of $9,583,191 over the $16,957,217 profit for 1947. The road's net income from all sources in 1948 was $67,289,592 as previously published -- compared with $54,447,495 in 1947.

Topsy-turvy went the twelfth annual national invitation college basketball tournament yesterday when, following day and night activity at Madison Square Garden, the competition was completely shorn of all its four seeded quintets.
LONDON, March 14 (Reuters) -- The Madrid radio broadcast a reply to Winston Churchill's chapter on Spain in his war memoirs, in its main news bulletin tonight.

The letter written by Dr. Miller Burrows and published in your columns on March 7 has placed the question of the Arab refugees on a political level where it does not belong. Dr. Burrows also makes one or two allegations that need clarification, at least from the point of view of the State of Israel.

LEWIS, Del., March 14 -- The 12,000-ton transport Molotov, flagship of the Soviet Black Sea merchant fleet, arrived in the north breakwater in Delaware Bay tonight to embark the officers and the 364 men of the Soviet Navy aboard the United States cruiser Milwaukee.

A comparative newcomer has drawn the important assignment of staging the forthcoming Gertrude Macy production, "The Happiest Years," starring Peggy Wood. He is James Neilson, a former Marine, who saw action in the South Pacific during the recent war.

The backlog of Latin-American draft collection items sent out for payment but not yet paid increased $6,000,000 during February, according to the collection experience of twelve New York City banks, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- The President's public observation, during the early part of the Senate rules filibuster, that he believes twenty-five Senators of the total of ninety-six should be able to force Senate action on virtually anything, including changes in the rules and closure, undoubtedly lost votes for the less drastic committee proposal that the minimum for such purposes should be thirty-three.

One of the major premises behind much of the current discussion of the future of China is largely suppositious. It has repeatedly been presumed that China faced the alternative of a Kuomintang Government or a Communist Government, possibly under the guise of a "coalition." A third possibility has been overlooked That is, no central government for China.
The flag of Israel flew for the first time over a ship in the Western Hemisphere at 2:30 P. M. yesterday as the S. S. Haifa was dedicated at Potts Cove Pier, at Twelfth Street, Astoria, Queens.

Stock trading moved at a quiet pace yesterday, with prices changed slightly from the close on Saturday. The irregular trend in slower trading came despite activity in low-price utility shares which lifted transfers to 800,000 shares. This compared with 1,070,000 shares traded on Friday, when the market broke out of its previous trading range.

WIESBADEN, Germany, March 14 (UP) -- A United States military court today reduced to five years the twenty-year prison term to which Mrs. Wilma Ybarbo, 23, of Malden, Mass., was sentenced last December for the fatal shooting of her husband, Sgt. John Ybarbo.

TOLEDO, Ohio, March 14 -- Larry Gara, 27 years old, a history instructor at Bluffton College, Bluffton, Ohio, was found guilty in Federal court today of having knowingly counseled, aided and abetted a former Bluffton senior in refusing to register under the Selective Service Act of 1948.
MADISON, N. J., March 14 (AP) -- The bench show chairman of the Morris and Essex dog show, biggest one-day affair, hurried today to the defense of the best-in-show award.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 14 -- Joe McCarthy unveiled three of his starting pitchers at Al Lang Field this afternoon and stopped the Yankees dead in their tracks.

Thomas McCormack, 31-year-old machinist's helper, of 1479 York Avenue, was held in Felony Court without bail yesterday morning for a hearing March 28 on a charge of homicide. McCormack was arrested in a restaurant near his home at 1 A. M. yesterday by Patrolman Michael Gannon.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- The Department of Agriculture an- today its decision to revise completely the classification and pricing of milk in excess of that consumed as fluid milk or cream for the New York market.
A veteran police aide in City Hall, Charles H. Stoffers, was reduced last night from first grade detective to patrolman and assigned to duty in the 120th Precinct, in St. George, S. I.

The International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., and its subsidiaries, in the annual report released for publication today estimates its capital expenditures for 1949 will be about $18,000,000, and showed all-time high sales and the second largest earnings on record for last year's operations.

LAKE SUCCESS, March 14 -- Dr. Jan Herman van Royen, the Netherlands representative, told the Security Council today that the Netherlands would agree to hold preliminary talks with Indonesian leaders under the auspices of the United Nations Commission on Indonesia regarding the time and conditions for the proposed roundtable conference at The Hague.

The New York Rangers, faced only with the task of playing out their National Hockey League schedule, will oppose the Boston Bruins at Madison Square Garden tonight. Completely out of any consideration for post-season competition, the Rangers, nevertheless can serve as spoilers against the Bruins.
The $21,500,000-a-year cut in Consolidated Edison Company light bills that went into effect on on Jan. 10 was rescinded yesterday by court action, and will end as of tomorrow.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 14 -- The Young Women's Christian Association, closing its eighteenth national convention here today, was urged to establish a new department for young married women. It would be known as "Y. W. Wives."

ALBANY, March 14 -- Professor Herbert Wechsler, a member of the New York City Rent Commission, urged today that a new state agency be set up to administer eviction and hotel rent laws in New York City if the city commission were abolished.

Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr., third son of the late President, will be a candidate for Congress to succeed the late Sol Bloom, who died last week after representing the Twentieth District on the West Side of Manhattan for the last twenty-six years.

Hotpoint, Inc., a General Electric Company subsidiary, yesterday reduced list prices of its refrigerators $16 to $30 and electric ranges $10 to $20. The reduction, effective immediately, was made known in a letter to Hotpoint distributors.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 14 -- The Communists in control in North China "are eager to reestablish trade," according to a letter received by American President Lines from Bryner Co., Ltd., the company's agent at Tientsin.

HAVANA, March 12 -- While the Cuban Government frowns on Communist activities here and may soon break off diplomatic relations with Russia, Communist leaders are well satisfied with the progress being made in spreading Communistic doctrine and arousing anti-United States sentiment.

When New Yorkers read last week that President Truman had caught a grouper while vacationing in Florida, many of them probably wondered, "And what is a grouper?" But not Milo Miloradovitch, who, in discussing the news item with this column, described the size, shape and savor of this curious creature.

Federal Judge Harold M. Kennedy in Brooklyn appointed yesterday three trustees to handle reorganization of the bankrupt Long Island Rail Road. Two of them are lawyers who formerly were associated with him, and the third is the general manager of the railroad.

Jean Borotra, one of France's famous Four Musketeers of the courts, is included with Richard (Pancho) Gonzales, the national grass-court champion, and William Talbert, the indoor titleholder, in the field of sixty-four men who were drawn yesterday for play in the national indoor tournament.

New York's reputation as a "tough" Customs port is receiving wide recognition, even to the extent of shipmasters of incoming vessels posting warnings to crew members to file complete personal declarations, Joseph J. Flynn, assistant surveyor of Customs here, reported yesterday.

In an otherwise imperfect world we are apparently to understand that there is at least one perfect institution. This is the Senate of the United States. New conditions elsewhere may require change; new factors may arise in some sections of our national life to counsel modernization; something may conceivably occur some day to make it advisable to adopt a new amendment to the Constitution.

Mystery surrounded last night the identity and motives of the person who mailed a note to Theodore D. Helprin, insurance adjuster, of 116 John Street, enclosed in a small box with $48,000 worth of industrial diamonds.

LONDON, March 14 -- The present 45 per cent quota of British films that must be shown in motion-picture theatres here is too low to keep British studio space fully occupied, G. H. Elvin, general secretary of the Association of Cinematograph and Allied Technicians, declared tonight.

Joseph M. Ziegler, deputy chief of the New York Fire Department, and James M. McMahon, battalion chief, pleaded guilty yesterday to violating the rules of the department in attending the Great Jones Street firehouse party on Dec. 16. First Deputy Commissioner James J. Moran, who presided at the departmental trial at Fire Headquarters, reserved decision.

When John L. Lewis orders his miners to stop working he sometimes calls it a strike and sometimes he calls it something else. The two-week work stoppage which began yesterday is not called a strike. Actually, Mr. Lewis has a purpose or two to achieve by this maneuver. There seems to be too much coal above ground.

Drug sales throughout the nation are currently ahead of the corresponding period last year, according to members and officials of the Federal Wholesale Druggists' Association, which began a three-day buyers "get-together" yesterday at the Statler Hotel.
WASHINGTON, March 14 -- J. Edgar Hoover, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, reported today that a serious crime occurred every 18.7 seconds in 1948.
Bonwit Teller's spring collection of custom millinery, presented yesterday morning at the store, shows the talent of Bonwit's new designer, Mme. Andree.

ASBURY PARK, N. J., March 14 -- Three-year-old Roy Holloway, who was put on a watermelon diet by his doctors in Fitkin Memorial Hospital here in an effort to combat acute nephritis, ate his fill of the juicy fruit today. Melons began arriving last night from Florida and other points in answer to an appeal by Roy's father, Chief of Police Leroy Holloway.
WASHINGTON, March 14 -- Newspaper spokesmen told the House Post Office Committee today that proposed second-class postal rate rises would force publishers to use other distribution systems.
Not a pick was swung anywhere in the Eastern coal-producing areas of the country yesterday as 425,000 members of John L. Lewis' United Mine Workers took the "holiday" they had been ordered.
Bobby Locke, South Africa's sensational golf star, will leave New York today to join the circuit of traveling professionals with high hopes of winning major honors during his stay in this country.

Although 1948 was the first full year since 1940 when sugar was free from wartime controls, prices of both raw and refined sugar were lower than those in effect at the end of Government control, Joseph F. Abbott, president of the American Sugar Refining Company, informed shareholders in the 1948 annual report released today.
WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP) -- United States exports in January totaled $1,085,100,000, a drop of $198,600,000, or 15.5 per cent, from the 1948 peak reached in December.
PRINCETON, N. J., March 14 -- Not even his seventieth birthday anniversary was sufficient cause to alter custom at the Princeton household of Dr. Albert Einstein at 112 Mercer Street.

Even today, a two-bedroom apartment can be completely furnished and decorated for $645 -- provided one is equipped with imagination, home-workshop facilities and a talent for tracking down usable second-hand cast-offs.

In a quick move to prevent the election, scheduled for last night, of a second vestry at the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Holy Trinity, Brooklyn, the church's nine "deposed" vestrymen obtained yesterday a show cause order and a temporary stay in Supreme Court, Brooklyn.

The Texas Company reported yesterday for 1948 a record consolidated net income of $165,980,980 after charges, taxes and reserves, equal to $12.03 each on the 13,797,624 capital shares outstanding at the year-end. In 1947, the company had a net income of $106,312,617, or $7.90 a capital share.
Seven members of the tentative jury in the trial of the eleven Communist leaders were removed from the case yesterday on peremptory challenges.

Mass blood donations were made here yesterday to the American Red Cross by postal employes and members of the Sanitation and Police Departments. Among the beneficiaries of the donations will be four children suffering from anemia.

Governor Dewey was asked yes-I terday to take the lead in an attack on segregation in housing. The request was made in an open letter signed by Bishop Charles K. [Gilbert, Rabbi Stephen S. Wise, Joseph M. Proskauer and others. It was made public at a conference of the New York State Committee on Discrimination in Housing at the Martinique Hotel.
BRADENTON, Fla., March 14 (AP) -- Boston's National League champion Braves won their first citrus circuit exhibition in three starts today by blanking the St. Louis Cardinals, 5 -- 0.

Second Deputy Police Commissioner John J. Ryan and Fourth Deputy Commissioner James J. Sheehy applied yesterday for retirement, effective tomorrow. The move cleared the way for the expected reshuffling of chief officers of the Police Department.
CHICAGO, March 14 -- Grains on the Board of Trade were under pressure earlyl today, but rallied stronglyl and closed irregular.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- The Department of Commerce announced today that it had eliminated special quota restrictions on the amount of tinplate which can be used in the manufacture of beer and animal-food cans. This was done by amending Allocation Order M-81.

A quiet, unassuming mail clerk with forty-two years' service in the Post Office was arrested early yesterday morning and charged with stealing $4,500 from letters addressed to religious organizations. Police said he admitted taking the money to play the numbers and the horses for a retirement nest-egg.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- Attacks against Hawaii's power to control teaching of foreign languages in its schools were dismissed by the Supreme Court on technical grounds today. Although a Hawaiian law on the subject had been assailed as unconstitutional, the high court did not deal with that fundamental question.

The Western Union Telegraph Company had a deficit of $171,621 in 1948, contrasted with a net income of $9,141,346 in 1947, according to the ninety-third annual report, being distributed to stockholders today.

FRANKFORT, Germany, March 14 -- On express authority of the Foreign Office in Paris, the French Military Government made public today a proposal to the United States for revision of the zones of occupation originally outlined at the Yalta Conference and in the London agreement of July, 1945.

LAKE SUCCESS, March 14 -- The United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization reported today that while hunger and cold remained the prime concerns of the 700,000 Arab refugees in the Middle East, an urgent need also existed for instruction for youngsters and organized recreation.

TUCSON, Ariz., March 14 -- The Giants carried the world champion Indians into extra innings today. They even shot ahead two runs in the tenth. But then they found the load too heavy and dropped it with a dull thud.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- Senator Harry F. Byrd, Democrat, of Virginia, announced today that he would vote against confirmation of Mon C. Wallgren as chairman of the National Security Resources Board on the ground that he was not qualified.

Occasional snow and morning frost to the contrary, spring is not too far away. There are signs. Buds are appearing on the less sedate local trees, the crocuses are up, the baseball players are in Florida. Spring is good. Perhaps it is not so good in itself as in the promise that presently there will be better.

WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture announced today that it would support producer prices of 1949-crop grain sorghums at 70 per cent of parity. This compares with 77 per cent for the 1948 crop.

PARIS, March 14 (AP) -- Dieudonne Coste, pioneer transatlantic airman, testified today that he had "fooled" the Germans and helped the Allies while he was connected with both the German and American espionage services in World War II.

Maurice Chevalier starts his own program over WOR and the Mutual network on Thursdays from 10 to 10:30 P. M., beginning March 31. The half-hour transcribed shows will originate in the Mirror Room of the Cafe de la Paix, and the plan is for Mr. Chevalier to introduce the cream of the crop of new French singing talent to American audiences.

A British industrial team of sixteen men, proud of their own skills but eager to be shown what the United States has to offer in steel "know-how," arrived here yesterday on the Canard White Star liner Queen Mary.

New improvements in both the appearance and construction of sofa beds and studio couches have resulted in designs that have as much eye-appeal and as much sleeping comfort as standard beds. The choice now includes trim sectional loveseats that may be used in conversation groups with chairs of similar outward appearance, and neat-looking studio beds with fully upholstered backs.
WASHINGTON, March 14 -- President Truman bowed today to the wishes of the House of Representatives and postponed a projected increase in tolls charged vessels for using the Panama Canal.

LONDON, March 14 -- Israel's Government received a clear warning from Britain last week that if Israeli forces on the Gulf of Aqaba crossed into Transjordanian territory, British troops at Aqaba would be reluctantly obliged to resist the intrusion, it became known today.

Five-year-old Marguerite Missirlian has had a temperature ranging between 103 and 107 degrees for most of the last eighteen months and many of the city's leading medical specialists now admit that they are baffled by her mysterious affliction.

SHANGHAI, March 10 -- Some of China's Communist leaders have given assurances that religious freedom will be written into the future Constitution of their regime, but they have also stated that such liberty would be "reciprocal." Under this doctrine, while there would be freedom to carry on religious activities there would also be freedom to criticize and ridicule religion.
WASHINGTON, March 14 -- Four independent labor organizations today gave Congress their special reasons for wanting the Taft-Hartley Labor law wiped off the statute books.

The first step in a program for community betterment was taken yesterday with the opening of an outpatient clinic at the Mount Morris Park Hospital, 10 Mount Morris Park West, the only entirely Negro-financed medical institution in New York since the Department of Hospitals assumed control of Sydenham Hospital March 3.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores dropped 11 ,per cent last week below the corresponding period last year, ae(cording to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Fedell Reserve Bank of Hew York. The decline for the four weeks ended last Saturday was 8 per cent.
TRENTON, N. J., March 14 A i meaure to encourage state-wide opposition to racial discrimin-ationi and to increase penalties againstl offenders was approved today by the New Jersey Senate.

Mortgage loans and purchases of industrial securities by the Prudential Insurance Company last year reached the heaviest volume in its history, Carrol M. Shanks, the president, reported yesterday at the opening of a three-day conference in the Hotel Commodore.

A protest that commercial gift parcel shippers are being adversely affected by the regulations contained in Export Bulletin 511 has been sent to the Office of International Trade by the National Association of Gift Parcel Packers and Shippers, Inc., 565 Fifth Avenue.
BOSTON, March 14 (AP) -- Ragged and round-eyed, a 14-year-old "wild boy" saw today sunlit world from which police said his mother locked him away for ten years to hide her "secret sin."

The excellent Yale Glee Club, which has not sung here in nine years, gave at Carnegie Hall last night a program devoted to "Music of the Americas." The sixty-four young men who make up its present membership were led by Marshall Bartholomew, who has been in charge of the club since 1921.

New issues of public utility and railroad securities totaling $9,500,000 were sold here yesterday at competitive bidding. Central Maine Power Company sold $5,000,000 of thirty-year bonds to Salomon Brothers Hutzler and associates at an interest cost of about 2.99 per cent.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed irregular yesterday, 7 points lower to 9 points higher than on Saturday.
RHODES, March 14 -- Israeli forces in the southern Negeb have been increased to approximately 3,000, according to a report received here today.

BOSTON, March 14 -- Three goals, scored in the stunning space of 26 seconds, turned what had been a lifeless Dartmouth College hockey team into a ball of fire at the Boston Arena tonight as the Indians scored a decisive 7-2 triumph over Harvard to win the Pentagonal League championship and the Hobey Baker Memorial Trophy.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- With three of its twelve members dissenting, the Commission on Organization of the Executive Branch of the Government today recommended to Congress that the Selective Service System be placed in the Labor Department.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- France and Canada squared their World War II accounts with the United States today. The bilateral agreements were signed at the State Department by Secretary Dean Acheson and Ambassadors Henri Bonnet and Hume Wrong for their respective governments.

MANILA, March 14 -- The Supreme Court of the Philippines upheld today the removal of Jose Avelino as Senate President and the election in his place of Senator Mariano Cuenco by a quorum of twelve of the twenty-four members. One is absent in the United States.

Five women, considered to be typical American shoppers, will compete for the title of "Brand Quiz Queen" in a contest that will feature the luncheon session of Brand Names Day at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel April 12, it was announced yesterday.

Organized baseball was directed in an order signed by Federal Judge Edward A. Conger yesterday to show cause in court this morning why Danny Gardella, suspended New York Giants outfielder, should not be reinstated immediately.
The part that psychiatrists can play in curbing juvenile delinquency has been vastly exaggerated in the public mind, it was agreed yesterday by two experts in the field.

LONDON, March 14 -- The five foreign ministers of the Western European Union, flanked by their defense and finance colleagues and accompanied by top-ranking experts, began here today a two-day conference to "fit" the present Western European Union defense organization into the coming North Atlantic defense pact.

Still sputtering charges against Mayor O'Dwyer, Frank Costello and District Attorney Frank S. Hogan, Clendenin J. Ryan went before the New York County Grand Jury yesterday as Kenneth Ryan, former city detective, surrendered and was indicted.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- The United States is prepared to negotiate a German peace treaty with the Soviet Union any time the blockade of Berlin is lifted, it was made clear at the State Department today. This position has been publicly stated repeatedly.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- A complaint charging more than thirty manufacturers and distributors of twine products with combination and conspiracy to lessen and eliminate competition and to restrain trade in the manufacture, sale and distribution of these commodities, was issued today by the Federal Trade Commission.

An impressive array of symphony orchestras, soloists, dramas, operas and ballets has been assembled for this summer's International Festival of Music and Drama at Edinburgh, Scotland, it was announced yesterday. The third of the annual events, it will run from Aug. 21 to Sept. 11.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- After 425,000 hard and soft coal miners began a two-week "memorial" stoppage today, the Senate Interior and Insular Affairs Committee approved President Truman's nomination of Dr. James M. Boyd as Director of the Federal Bureau of Mines.
The resignation of Mrs. Jessica G. Cosgrave as president of Finch Junior College was announced yesterday by Edward Larocque Tinker, chairman of the board of trustees.
Your editorial of March 4 "The French Reply" seems to me unduly scornful and unfair to France.

A sit-in strike by 143 members of the crew of the Maritime Commission's converted transport, Marine Jumper, called at 5 P. M. in protest against the impending transfer of the vessel to the Army, ended shortly before 10 o'clock last night with the arrest of one man and the departure of the others.
WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP) -- The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether segregation violates the basic rights of a Negro.

The full story of the wire-tapping "plot" to listen in on the telephone conversations of high New York City officials remains to be told. But the average good citizen knows enough of it already to feel a revulsion against such methods of conducting politics, no matter who uses them. The late Justice Holmes once spoke of wire-tapping as "dirty business."

LONDON, March 14 -- After being in effect for seven years and 287 days, rationing of clothing in Britain was abolished today amid prolonged cheering from the Labor Government's supporters in the House of Commons.
GREAT CAPTAIN'S ISLAND, Conn., March 14 -- The Coast Guard crew that tends the 120-year-old light station here, two miles south of Greenwich in Long Island Sound, experiences a curious isolation.

The frost-bite brigade, that hardy fraternity of early flounder fishermen whose ability to with-stand cold is exceeded only by the non-shanty ice fishermen, have been having fair luck both on the north and south shores of Long Island.
Marshal Rodion Y. Malinovsky apparently is the most important Soviet military figure in the Far East.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, March 14 (AP) -- The Soviet Embassy tonight released a second note to Sweden protesting alleged persecution of Baltic refugees. The note accused Swedish authorities of "systematically preventing" the return to the Soviet Union of Soviet citizens in Sweden.

A transportation crisis that would have halted operation of the Surface Transportation Corporation was averted yesterday when the Public Service Commission approved an agreement between the Third Avenue Transit Corporation, parent of Surface Transportation, and this city, whereby Third Avenue will pledge $865,000 of its bonds which it had reacquired, as a guarantee for payment of franchise tax arrears.
ALBANY, March 14 -- The Senate adopted unanimously tonight a bill that may eventually abolish segregation in the state's National Guard and other military units.

Sales of the Borden Company and its consolidated subsidiaries in 1948 rose for the ninth consecutive year to a record $649,592,375, a gain of 7.7 per cent from the 1947 volume of $602,959,406, but earnings declined 3.1 per cent, Theodore G. Montague, president, announced in the annual report to stockholders and employes, to be released today.
BERLIN, March 14 -- There is now little doubt in the minds of qualified observers here that the top level of the government of the Soviet Union is being thoroughly reorganized.

DETROIT, March 14 -- More than 1,500 war surplus radio sets, each containing enough explosives "to blow a man's head off," have been sold unwittingly to innocent buyers by at least two Michigan concerns, authorities warned today.

LAKE SUCCESS, March 14 -- United Nations officials said today that the Security Council's committee of "neutral" experts had reported the failure of its efforts to draw up a plan for the settlement of the Berlin dispute. The report, which was received here from Geneva several weeks ago, is to be made public later this week.

BAYONNE, N. J., March 14 -- Six years ago, seventeen fathoms deep off Guadalcanal, Carpenter's Mate First Class George E. Sherman groped sluggishly through the water and picked a lead-bound book off the bottom. Through the window of his diver's helmet he saw the first copy of the Japanese Imperial code to fall into American hands.

BOSTON, March 14 -- Eight leaders in the field of physical education were awarded honorary degrees today by Dr. Daniel L. Marsh, president of Boston University, at the eighteenth annual Founders' Day Convocation.

Add to the list of films opening this week "The Last Bandit," a Republic Western featuring William Elliott, Adrian Booth, Forrest Tucker, Andy Devine and Jack Holt, which will arrive at the Mayfair on Saturday. Joseph Kane produced and directed from a screen play by Thames Williamson and a story by Luci Ward and Jack Natteford.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- The Danish Foreign Minister, Gustav Rasmussen, presented to the State Department today his Government's estimate of the military supplies Denmark would need to play an effective role in the projected North Atlantic security pact.

Operations last year of the Celanese Corporation of America resulted in new high records for sales, earnings, taxes, dividends and capital expenditures, according to the annual, report mailed to stockholders today in every state of the Union.
NANKING, March 14 (AP) -- A subcommittee of the Chinese Government's Control Yuan indicted retiring Premier Sun Fo today on a charge of officially approving improper disposal of enemy alien property.

The fabrics in the custom collection of D'Laurence Roth, presented yesterday morning at his salon at 36 Central Park South, showed the results of his recent trip to Europe. All the clothes, including suit and dress ensembles, afternoon and evening gowns, were made of worsteds, silks and linens imported from France and Italy.

Thirty-two championship regattas for the coming summer, a 6:30 P. M. time limit so that crews may escape midnight dinners and an adherence to the few changes in the rules of the North American Yacht Racing Union were adopted last night at a meeting of the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound, held in the New York Yacht Club.

The drive by Dave Beck, executive vice president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, AFL, to win control over warehouse workers in department stores has been set back by ser-stores has been set back by a series of adverse rulings by the Na-became known yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 14 -- Retreating from its previous decision to shun the Motion Picture Industry Council, an organization established to present a solid labor-management front for the film industry in matters of public relations, the American Federation of Labor Film Council today voted to participate in the MPIC.

Henry A. Wallace issued a statement yesterday expressing "surprise" that the message he delivered on Sunday at the First Methodist Church of South Norwalk and broadcast over Station WNLK in Norwalk, Conn., during an hour program devoted to religious broadcasts, was "regarded as political."

The thirty-day standby offering of 880,000 shares of New York State Electric Gas Corporation's common stock to stockholders of General Public Utilities Corporation is off to an impressive start. Trading in the over-the-counter market begain right after the announcement late last week that the stock would be priced at $41 a share.

The $16,000,000,000 electric power industry is about to shed its cloak of hesitancy on the growing issue of public power and open a regional program of aggressive public relations, it was learned yesterday.

FRANKFORT, Germany, March 14 -- Eight persons were convicted and sentenced today by a special military commission in Munich for spying on the United States Army and political refugees in the United States zone and transmitting information to the Czechoslovak Intelligence Service.

KEY WEST, Fla., March 14 -- The White House today imposed a firm censorship on news photographers after they had taken still and newsreel pictures of President Truman, Chief Justice Fred Vinson and others disporting on a beach here.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- Charges that French officials in Morocco were using Marshall Plan aid to further a systematic "freeze-out" of American business interests in the area were voiced today by the final witness before the House Foreign Affairs Committee considering renewal of the program.

Wool futures resumed their downward trend in the local market yesterday on continued liquidation. At the close, grease wool futures showed net declines of 1 to 2 cents a pound on sales of 174,000 pounds during the session. Wool top futures finished at net losses of 0.5 to 1.5 cents a pound on transactions of 190,000 pounds.

Last Friday, with Senator Vandenberg leading the attack, the decision of Vice President Barkley that closure was applicable to a "motion" was overruled by the Senate. The result of the vote is to make it virtually impossible, at this time, to block the filibuster of the Southern Democrats.

LOS ANGELES, Calif., March 14 -- Across the desk at the Downey plant of the North American Aviation Corporation near here a rather tall, 46-year-old man talked of the past. He talked of the distant future, too. But of the present and the next few years he could say nothing.

ON the jacket of Isabel Bolton's novel "The Christmas Tree"* is a drawing by Mary Petty of a chaste and ghostly angel blowing a trumpet while hovering over a Christmas tree lighted with old-fashioned candles. Here, it might lead the unwary to think, is a nice, wholesome story for children published a little out of season. Such an impression would be quite natural; but it couldn't be more mistaken.
New York City Housing Authority announced yesterday that it would receive bids on March 23 on $32,453,000 of temporary loan notes dated April 15 and due on Oct. 17 and Dec. 15.
A one-man strike by a building superintendent led to the arrest on disorderly conduct charges of forty-one pickets and a union attorney at 3052 Kingsbridge Avenue, the Bronx, yesterday afternoon.
RANGOON, Burma, March 14 (AP) -- The hard-pressed Burmese Government offered today to give the rebellious Karen tribesmen an autonomous state of their own within the Burma Union.

Union clerks picketed seven closed depots of the Railway Express Agency yesterday but continued to withhold picketing of Grand Central Terminal, Pennsylvania Station and other passenger and freight stations in the metropolitan area.

LONDON, March 14 -- Britain's Labor Government was vociferously accused by its opponents today of bungling the most ambitious single project ever undertaken for the development of the colonial empire, a project of the general type encouraged by President Truman for the backward areas of the world.
LONDON, March 14 -- Apart from new issues, oils and rubbers fared best in the stock market here today.

le dem;nd made on Sunday by Thomas J. Curran, Republican leader of New York County, that Senator Robert F. Wagner resign his seat met with no comment yesterday from spokesmen for the senior Senator, who has been ill and unable to attend Senate'sessions for several years.

Work clothes prices will reflect the decrease in denims to the extent of around $1 a dozen for overalls and dungarees, it was learned yesterday. The price decrease of 4 cents a yard, manufacturers said, should aid in restoring buyers' confidence in the work clothes picture for fall.

HAVANA, March 14 -- The Inter-American Commission on Dependent Territories, which gets under way here tomorrow, marks the beginning of a new juridical era in colonial problems, Dr. Enrique Corominas, president of the Organization of American States and head of the Argentine delegation, said here tonight.
