SAN FRANCISCO, March 15 -- Hugh Bryson, president of the National Union of Marine Cooks and Stewards, CIO, sent a telegram to President Truman today protesting the "manhandling" of crew members of the Maritime Commission's converted transport Marine Jumper at Brooklyn army base last night.

A private sale of $16,000,000 of bonds of the Kingdom of Belgium by the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development to a life insurance company and a group of New York City savings banks was announced here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 15 (UP) -- Army Secretary Kenneth C. Royall announced today that he had stayed the death sentences of twelve Germans convicted in the Malmedy war crimes trials until he could review their cases.

Valentin A. Gubitchev refused again yesterday in Federal court to plead to an indictment charging him with espionage or to accept the services of an attorney assigned him by Judge Simon H. Rifkind. But the jurist directed that a not-guilty plea be entered for the Russian and that his trial be set for April 1.

LONDON, March 15 -- Arthur Henderson, Air Secretary, outlined in the House of Commons today a plan for doubling the Royal Air Force's jet fighter strength by the middle of next year and the development of high performance jet bombers.
Almost one-third of the city's quota in this year's Red Cross fund drive has been raised in the two weeks since the appeal started, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- The Senate Armed Services Committee struck a personal blow at President Truman today in tabling the nomination of Mon C. Wallgren as chairman of the National Security Resources Board.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- Despite continuing gains in this country's agricultural and industrial production, export and other controls authorized under the Second Decontrol Act are still needed to protect the domestic economy and help fulfill America's international responsibilities, Charles Sawyer Secretary of Commerce, said today.

Correcting some recent statements of its more enthusiastic representatives, the British Government has issued a new survey of Britain's economic position. It lists both the solid achievements in economic recovery and the dangers that must still be overcome before recovery can be pronounced complete.
WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., March 15 (AP) -- Three teams led today in the Seminole Club's annual 36-hole pro-amateur golf tournament.

WASHINGTON, March 15 (UP) -- A small group of Republicans and Administration Senators said tonight that they would meet tomorrow morning to consider an all-out, last-ditch fight against the Knowland closure proposal. They called it a "sell-out."
The Pennsylvania Railroad's new Broadway Limited began last night its first run from here to Chicago, thereby driving a few more spikes into the coffin of the old-fashioned back-stiffening coach.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- Unification of the armed services was advanced another step today as James Forrestal, Secretary of Defense, announced the consolidation of all responsibility for military land transportation under the Department of the Army.
A "thorough, impartial, nonpolitical" inquiry into wiretapping here was demanded last night in the City Council by Councilman Edward Rager, Manhattan Republican.

Part of the collection of eighteenth and early nineteenth century snuff boxes and watches that Enrico Caruso bequeathed to his daughter, Gloria Caruso Murray, was sold at auction yesterday at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street.
PHOENIX, Ariz., March 15 -The Giants for the second successive afternoon carried the world champions into overtime today only to blow another game, 9 to 8.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 15 -- When Charles Dillon Stengel was named as manager of the Yankees one most irreverent newspaperman summed it up in most succinct fashion. "Ole Case," he said, "had better win the pennant or else be awfully funny." So far Casey hasn't had a chance to win any pennants and he hasn't been particularly funny.

" America's Town Meeting of the Air" is making plans for a round-the-world trip by air during July, August and September, George V. Denny Jr., president of Town Hall and originator of the program, announced last night on his program, broadcast from Boston.

Drug wholesalers operating in well-populated areas are in danger of losing business to a new type of rapid-delivery medical supply house, Edward J. Carroll, economic research director of Sharp Dohme, Inc., warned about 200 members of the Federal Wholesale Druggists' Association yesterday at a buyers' meeting in the Statler Hotel.

Plans for what is described as Brown-Forman Distillers Corporation's "largest and most vigorous advertising, sales and sales promotion program" were announced yesterday following five days of conferences by seventy-one regional field executives with officials of the company and its agency, Ruthrauff Ryan, Inc.
The National Association of Manufacturers made its debut in a new role yesterday -- interpreter of American slang, signboards, and saloons for sixteen visiting British steel officials and workers.

Wool futures reversed their previous trend yesterday and recovered sharply in rather heavy trading. Grease wool contracts rallied to close at net gains of 1.5 to 2.5 cents a pound in a sales volume of 300,000 pounds. Wool top contracts finished at net advances of 2.9 to 3.4 cents a pound on transactions of 175,000 pounds.

Despite the protests of the merchant marine industry and government agencies dealing with shipping, district headquarters of the United States Coast Guard will move out of 42 Broadway and into new offices at 80 Lafayette Street this month, it was announced yesterday.

In quiet trading prices of stocks on the New York Stock Exchange slipped fractions to more than a point along a broad front yesterday. Attempts to rally selected issues met with a lack of enthusiasm, and the list was sprinkled liberally with minus signs at the close.

ALBANY, March 15 -- Reversing its decision of a year ago, the Assembly Committee on the Affairs of New York City today approved a bill to make possible restoration of Castle Clinton at Battery Park as a national monument.
CHICAGO, March 15 (AP) -- A Marshall Plan industrial expert forecast today that global demand for such metals as aluminum and lead will continue heavy.

The Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, Inc., will reduce today the tank car price of heating oil 0.3 cent a gallon in the New York metropolitan area and 0.2 cent by tank wagon delivery. This is the sixth reduction in price of that product by Socony since Dec. 2, and it brings the price about 1.5 cents a gallon below the level prevailing at that time.

LAKE SUCCESS, March 15 -Preliminary results of a special United Nations survey show that more than 200 Secretariat families are eager to start building their own international community in Westchester County or some other suburban spot within commuting distance of the permanent world capital site on Manhattan's East River.

The fight between Ike Williams, lightweight champion of the world and Kid Gavilan of Cuba, scheduled for Madison Square Garden for Friday night, was postponed yesterday, it was announced by Harry Markson, acting director of the Twentieth Century Sporting Club.

The United States in 1948 rose from eighth to third place among the world's maritime nations in the construction of merchant vessels, according to a report yesterday by the Shipbuilders Council of America. The report, which included craft of 1,000 or more gross tons, showed that this nation was surpassed only by Great Britain and Sweden in number of ships as well as percentage of tonnage under construction or on order.
PHILADELPHIA, March 15 -Philip N. Arnold, president of the Mortgage and Appraisal Company of Philadelphia, forecast today a sharp decline in real estate prices, especially for new homes.

Frogs' legs, escargots (garden snails) and brook trout are too expensive to become every-day fare. But these delicacies make an occasional variation on Lenten menus of interest to epicures. One serves them at home with the knowledge one is following a precedent established by many fine restaurants in the city, where they are "played up" on menus throughout the year.

Bankers, along with others concerned, are "on trial" in the current effort to provide suitable housing for all American families, Raymond M. Foley, Administrator of the Housing and Home Finance Agency, warned a banking group here yesterday.

Dr. Karl von Frisch, Austrian scientist, reported at the American Museum of Natural History yesterday morning that after forty years of patient observation he had succeeded in understanding the rudimentary principles of the language of bees.

ROME, March 15 -- A threat of dissension in its own ranks obliged the Communist-dominated General Italian Labor Confederation this morning to abandon all thought, at least for the present, of proclaiming a general strike in protest against Italy's participation in the Atlantic Pact.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -A decrease in the domestic supply of meat products made it necessary to impose a more stringent control over export allocation, it was made known today by the Office of International Trade, Department of Commerce.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -The Far Eastern Commission adopted unanimously today a policy decision stating that no further trials should be initiated with respect to Japanese suspected of having planned, prepared, or conspired to wage a war of aggression.

LONDON, March 15 -- Derationing of clothing and the prospect of removal of other controls and shadows of price cuts weakened the stock market here today. With spending money the deciding factor in stores, the market does not foresee any big increase in buying by public and a subsequent increase in profits.

Predictions that a proposed shift of television broadcasting to higher frequencies will make present receiving sets obsolete were assailed yesterday by Dr. Allen B. Du Mont, television network and set manufacturer president.

PHILADELPHIA, March 15 (AP) -- Stockholders of the Sun Oil Company were told today that its current production of crude oil is about 20 per cent less than a year ago. John J. Pew, vice president in charge of production, made the statement at their annual meeting.

The extent to which Negro organizations can be kept free of Communist control will determine in the long run their effectiveness in the present struggle to expand our civil rights laws. No true liberal can deny that the Negro American has a just cause. The same can be said about the Indian American and the Oriental American.

Out-of-town buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday numbered 1,986, against 1,677 last week and 1,170 in the corresponding week a year ago, according to the listings appearing in THE NEW YORK TIMES. There were 814 arrivals yesterday, compared with 898 last Tuesday.
Commodore Cary W. Magruder, USN, and Mrs. Magruder of Shoreby Hill, Jamestown, R. I., are at the Waldorf-Astoria.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., March 15 (AP) -John A. Nemeth, a 48 year-old mechanic, today added some luster to the bowling achievement of his South Bend, Ind., five-man team. Nemeth came up with 1,861 in all-events, good for a seventh-place tie in that division of the American Bowling Congress tournament.
The cotton futures market closed quietly on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday with final prices 4 points higher to 3 points net lower on the day.

William D. Benson has been appointed vice president in charge of sales, Industrial Rayon Corporation, Cleveland. He formerly was general sales manager of the rayon division of the American Viscose Corporation.
NORTHAMPTON, Mass., March 15 (AP) -- Dr. Benjamin Fletcher Wright, a Texas-born Harvard professor, today was named president of Smith College.
Supporters of Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. for the Democratic nomination for Congress to succeed the late Sol Bloom were understood last night to have procured the aid of Mayor O'Dwyer.

After losing the first round in their fight to avoid postponement of the effective date of the Nurse Practice Act, the New York State Nurses Association wired Governor Dewey yesterday for help in preventing the delaying action from passing the State Senate.

Another collector's item in the world of investment securities came to market yesterday for distribution to the public. It took the form of a secondary distribution by Morgan, Stanley Co. of 1,000 shares of capital stock of the First National Bank of New York.

BERLIN, March 15 -- Britain announced tonight that she was lifting immediately all production restrictions on a wide range of restricted German engineering industries and disclosed that the United States already had done so.

" Dream No More," the feature film produced in its entirety in Israel, will be released in this country on April 26. The picture, a fictional story done in documentary style, was written and directed by Joseph Krumgold and produced by Krumgold and Norman Lourie for Palestine Films, Inc. Avram Sroka, a member of the Ohel Theatre in Israel, makes his screen debut in the starring role in "Dream No More."

Twenty-five thousand elevator operators and other service employes in 3,000 Manhattan office and loft buildings will receive a fourth-round wage increase of $3.50 a week as an outgrowth of an arbitration award made public yesterday by the State Mediation Board.

Inter-plant studies of packaging and cooperative research with external carriers in an effort to cut down huge losses now being experienced in shipping goods were urged last night by H. H. Pratt, general traffic manager of the Crucible Steel Company of America.
DES MOINES, March 15 (AP) -Al Kawal, head football coach at Drake University, tonight announced his resignation to take a similar post at Temple University, Philadelphia.

Three of the nine games in the first round of the international chess masters tournament, now under way in the Gran Casino's Auditorium at Mar del Plata, resulted in decisive victories, according to a report received from Argentina yesterday. Two matches were drawn and four adjourned.

The Boston Bruins made their final local appearance of the National Hockey League season a good one at Madison Square Garden last night. Dit Clapper's stick wielders, thanks mainly to three fast goals in the first period, humbled the New York Rangers by the score of 4 to 2, in the presence of a slim crowd of 7,619 fans.
Why all this controversy over Washington Square and the New York University Law School?

Iranian officials voiced fears here yesterday that the Soviet Union planned to invoke a twenty-eight-year-old treaty whereby its troops might enter Iran on the pretext that her security was threatened.
BERLIN, March 15 -- Russian conscripts of the class of 1928 are being sent to Germany to take part in spring maneuvers of the Soviet Army. The maneuvers are now in their opening phase.

Sales of the Pittsburgh Plate Glass Company last year increased 6.7 per cent to a new high record of $280,037,351 from the previous peak of $262,529,489 in 1947, partly as the result of post-war plant expansion and a slightly higher price level, the annual report to stockholders revealed today.

President Truman is apparently headed for his first major defeat in the new Congress. The passage of a compromise plan, opposed by the Administration, seems to have sufficient support to insure Senate approval. The new plan seems likely to block any Administration effort to advance its civil rights program at this time.

A partial lifting of the iron curtain which shut off the flow of American motion pictures to Yugoslavia became effective yesterday with the signing in Belgrade of an agreement permitting the distribution of twenty-five feature-length Hollywood films and an equal number of short subjects during the next twelve months.

The Baldwin Locomotive Works reported yesterday for 1948 a net income of $3,167,741 after charges and taxes, equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to $1.26 each on the 2,375,553 common shares outstanding. This compares with $2,651,331, or $1.33 each on the 1,875,553 common shares outstanding in 1947.

Younger members of society headed by Miss Cynthia Cogswell and including the Misses Melissa Weston and Nancy Harris are aiding members of the executive committee in furthering the success of the Spring supper dance on the night of April 6 in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria.

What disturbs prospective tenants most about living in a housing project, the dweller was saying, is the apparent uniformity. There is the frightening knowedge that thousands of people within an area the size of a few city blocks have exactly the same apartments.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- A group of coal-mining and coal-shipping interests combined in the Fuels Research Council, Inc., opened today a broad public campaign against plans by the Atomic Energy Commission to feed 60,000,000 cubic feet of gas daily into the steam plants at the Oak Ridge, Tenn., atomic energy plant.

KEY WEST, Fla., March 15 -President Truman, Chief Justice Fred M. Vinson and Gen. George C. Marshall, former Secretary of State, lunched together today, but the White House assigned nothing but "social" significance to the occasion.

Irving S. Olds, chairman of the United States Steel Corporation, declared in the annual report issued yesterday that "much of the present unbalance between steel demand and supply will have been adjusted" before new steel plants suggested by Government officials could be placed in operation.

A "balanced" market in America can be maintained and kept on an upward trend by industry's national force of salesmen because they flourish under buyer's market conditions, J. R. Davis, vice president in charge of sales and advertising, Ford Motor Company, declared yesterday.
ORONO, Me., March 15 -- Trygve Lie, Secretary General of the United Nations, warned today that the present East-West conflict was "too dangerous to last."

DETROIT, March 15 -- More than doubling its consolidated net income of the preceding year, the Hudson Motor Car Company in 1948 earned $13,225,923, or $7.28 on each of 1,815,783 outstanding shares of stock, it was disclosed today in the annual report of A. E. Barit, president and general manager.

CHICAGO, March 15 -- Grain markets on the Board of Trade were under pressure early today but rallied later. Wheat showed the most strength, closing 3/8 to 1 cent a bushel higher than yesterday, strength in the May future in Kansas City and Minneapolis being a factor.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 15 -- For four innings today at Al Lang Field, the Yankees sped steadily on what promised to be their third straight triumph over the Cardinals. In the fifth, however, their one-run edge dissolved and, despite the combined efforts of twenty New York regulars and rookies the National Leaguers won, 8 to 1.

MINEOLA, L. I., March 15 -- Raymond M. Fernandez and Mrs. Martha Beck, so-called "lonely hearts" slayers extradited from Michigan on a charge that they killed Mrs. Janet Fay, 50-year-old widow, in Valley Stream last January, waived examination here today and were remanded to the county jail to await grand jury action.

A cost study which the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad had presented for consideration in connection with the road's application for increases in commutation fares, was attacked again yesterday at the resumption of hearings by Public Service Commissioner George A. Arkwright, at the commission's office at 233 Broadway.

So many letters have reached me from readers of THE NEW YORK TIMES concerning your report of my talk to the New York Chapter of the American Council for Judaism that I wish to clarify two points in it. One has to do with my concern for the danger of suspicions of "dual nationality." Here is a transcript of a wire recording of what I said:

The annual observance yesterday of "Port of New York Day" was highlighted by "dressed ship" conditions aboard the almost 200 merchant ships in the harbor, giving the normally drab waterfront a holiday appearance with gaily colored signal flags strung from stem to stern of each vessel.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- The House of Representatives voted today to extend rent controls fifteen months beyond the March 31 deadline, but it put into the bill a clause permitting localities to do away with curbs if they chose to do so.

WASHINGTON, March 15 (UP) -The cost to the taxpayer of the Government price supports for last year's potato crop has hit the $180,000,000 mark and is still rising, Government officials reported today.

NANKING, March 15 -- The complicated status of strategically placed Formosa, which lies on the American communications lifeline between the Philippines and Japan, was introduced by the Communists tonight as a major issue in China's unsettled peace-or-war politics.

A total reduction of $30,000 in the values of four major races has been made for the summer meeting opening at Aqueduct June 13, according to the schedule announced by the Queens County Jockey Club yesterday. The list of twelve stakes carry $250,000 in added money, but this is under last year's mark.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -While John L. Lewis maintained silence today on the second day of the United Mine Workers' "memorial" stoppage, coal operators complained that the union was going farther to curtail production than was usual in stoppages.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -Leonard B. Boudin of New York, chairman of the Labor Law Committee of the National Lawyers Guild, told a House Labor subcommittee today that the non-Communist affidavit insulted American workers because Congress thereby told them they were not wise enough to tonnage their own affairs.
PHILADELPHIA, March 15 (AP) -- A special loading operation today sent twenty-three new railroad passenger cars on their way to South America.

Village elections in four counties near New York were marked yesterday by several unexpected Democratic upsets in usually Republican Westchester communities. Most of them were regarded as personal rather than party victories. Eighty-nine elections took place in Westchester, Rockland, Nassau and Suffolk villages, thirty-four of them involving contests.

The Public Service Commission does not believe it has been defeated as a result of the temporary court stay of ifs order decreasing the Consolidated Edison Company light bills by $21,500,000 a year, it became known yesterday.

Lola Corini, pianist, who appeared in one of the Philharmonic-Symphony's Young People's concerts two years ago kat the age of 16, gave a recital at Times Hall last night. She is gifted with strong, agile fingers beyond her age, uncommon balance of agility between the two hands, and an often attractive candor of approach to the notes.

" The Pride of the Malay Race," a biography of Jose Rizal. Philippine national hero, will be published by Prentice-Hall on June 19 to commemorate the anniversary of his birth. Rizal, who was executed as a revolutionary in 1896 at the age of 35, had been a doctor of medicine, a sculptor, poet and novelist.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- A nonpartisan movement by private citizens for a federal union of the North Atlantic democracies was announced here today by Owen J. Roberts, former associate justice of the United States Supreme Court.

Issues of new public utility and railroad securities totaling $27,808,000 will be placed on the market today by underwriting syndicates. The offerings, which follow upon award at public competitive bidding, are as follows:

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 15 -- Cecil B. de Mille, chairman of the Motion Picture Industry Council, the film labor-management public relations organization, today answered the American Federation of Labor Film Council, which yesterday agreed to rejoin the MPIC, after having withdrawn when de Mille became chairman.

WASHINGTON, March 15 (AP) -- The proposed North Atlantic defense alliance assumed broader dimensions tonight as the Portuguese Government disclosed that it has started talks with the United States about joining the mutual-aid pact.

CHICAGO, March 15 -- Wilson Co., meat packers, operated at a profit in the first quarter of its 1949 fiscal year, Edward Foss Wilson, president, told stockholders today at the annual meeting. He did not divulge the profit for the quarter which ended Jan. 31, but he said sales totaled $179,000,000, which represented a decline of 9.6 per cent from the $198,000,000 sales reported in the corresponding quarter a year ago.

LONDON, March 15 -- Raising the proportion of British exports to the United States and Canada in an effort to remedy the "crucial problem" of the country's dollar deficit will be the most important single aim of British economic policy this year, the Treasury stated today in its Economic Survey for 1949.

The annual luncheon for the benefit of the Lots for Little Thrift Shop, located at 902 Third Avenue, will be held on April 26 in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria. Mrs. Frederick Kane is general chairman of the event. Proceeds will be donated to the six philanthropic organizations that receive the funds realized from all sales at the shop.

Net dollar earnings last year were the largest in the history of the General Foods Corporation, with net sales for the fifteenth consecutive year exceeding any other on record, according to the annual report to stockholders signed jointly by Clarence Francis, chairman, and Austin S. Igleheart, president.

Nine hand-screened prints that might be described as fresh rather than modern were introduced yesterday morning at the opening of the new uptown decorators' showroom of Decorative Fabrics, Inc., at 13 East Fifty-third Street. They were designed by Harold M. Schwartz, who is now consultant-designer for the company.

A few doors away from Dazian's Theatrical Emporium, noted source for display and theatrical fabrics, the company opened yesterday a new branch for decorative fabrics. The Dazian retail store at 112 West Forty-fourth Street includes not only a wide variety of drapery, upholstery, slipcover and curtaining fabrics, but has also some of the theatrical materials that have been found worthwhile for homes as well as stage settings.
ST. LOUIS, March 15 (UP) -- A sudden strike shut down the Wabash Railroad today, but the walkout appeared to be shortlived after intervention by President Truman.

The Fire Department wrote "finis" yesterday to the Great Jones Street firehouse party when Commissioner Frank J. Quayle reprimanded two ranking officers and agreed to the dismissal of charges against two captains, two lieutenants and four firemen.

The selection of an important actor to assume such a pivotal role as Robert Morley enacts in "Edward, My Son," had Gilbert Miner and Henry Sherek, producers of the hit play, trotting around in circles. Mr. Miller did his pacing here, while Mr. Sherek did his in London.
Congratulations on your editorial "Recruiting the New Teacher," published March 8. Too much cannot be said in endorsement of its truth and logic.

Paintings in two exhibitions devoted to twentieth-century American artists and opening yesterday, those of the late Arnold Friedman, at Marquie, and Anatol Shulkin, at Midtown, manage to express themselves without wandering from the fortress of realism. Less surprising than Friedman's growing posthumous reputation is the neglect he suffered before his death in 1946, for here, if ever, was an approachable artist whose work was heavily charged with feeling.

The churches of the world were called upon yesterday by the Federal Council of the Churches of Christ in America to "stand together" in resisting attempts of Communist-controlled Governments to destroy or curtail religious freedom.

LEWES, Del., March 15 -- A sudden northwest gale that blew up at noon caused a last-minute postponement today of transfer of the Soviet cruiser Murmansk, the former Milwaukee, back to the United States Navy.

Pan American Airways reported yesterday for 1948 an estimated net income of $4,590,000, equal to 74 cents a capital share. Since mail rates for last year are still awaiting action by the Civil Aeronautics Board, the airline's statement noted, exact earnings cannot be determined.

Inventories of soft-surface floor coverings in warehouses of local distributors have increased from 30 to 40 per cent since Jan. 1, R. Morton Clarke, president, Floor Covering Distributors Council, disclosed yesterday. He attributed the rise to a sharp decline in retail orders.
HAVANA, March 15 -- A conference of thirteen Latin American states on dependent territories in the Americas opened here today.

In THE TIMES of Feb. 28 I read a letter addressed to you by Maria Craipeau, correspondent of the Paris Franc-Tireur, who alleges that excerpts from an article published under her signature distorted its meaning.

With the opening of the trout season only about three weeks off, reports are coming about a number of popular rivers within a hundred-mile radius of the city and most of them indicate that unless heavy rains change the picture the streams will be in unusually fine shape on the opening

MONTREAL, March 15 (Canadian Press) -- The University of Montreal Carabins came from behind with a three-goal rally in the third period to beat the Dartmouth College Indians, 4 -- 3, here tonight and capture the international intercollegiate senior hockey championship before 3,000 fans.

The second volume of the memoirs of Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, covering her years in the White House, will be published in McCall's magazine, starting in June, it was announced yesterday. It also will be published in book form by Harper's in the fall.

Orders and inquiries for rayon fabrics received by mail and from salesmen's efforts have resulted in substantial improvement of sales, it was learned yesterday. Prices have firmed up on most constructions, suppliers said, and there is reason to believe that a leveling-off period has been reached.

Dr. Ralph J. Bunche, acting mediator for the United Nations in the Palestine situation, will receive this year the thirty-fourth Spingarn Medal from the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, the awards committee announced yesterday.

The most frustrated musicians in town these days are the self-styled "Musical Moles." They are the four instrumentalists who have played Alex North's background music for every performance of "Death of a Salesman" but will have to wait until their vacations forty weeks hence before they see the show.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 15 -- Columbia has suspended Evelyn Keyes, contract actress, from salary because she refused the leading famine role in "Baby Is Here," in which Ronald Reagan is expected to star.

Richard (Pancho) Gonzales, national grass court champion, arrived by plane from Los Angeles yesterday to compete in the national indoor tennis championship which gets under way tomorrow at the Seventh Regiment Armory.

PHILADELPHIA, March 15 (AP) -- The United States Circuit Court of Appeals today threw out fifteen suits in which hundreds of thousands of Congress of Industrial Organization workers in the Pittsburgh steel and electrical industry sought portal-to-portal pay running into millions of dollars.
The Irish will have a fair and seasonably cold day, according to the Weather Bureau, when 80,000 persons march up Fifth Avenue tomorrow at 1 P. M. in the annual St. Patrick's Day Parade.
Members of the Brotherhood of Railway and Steamship Clerks, AFL, extended their picket lines yesterday to the office building of the Railway Express Agency, 219 East Forty-second Street.

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., March 15 -- If anybody feels impelled to inquire again whether the Dodgers are still in the league, Connie Mack and Billy Southworth might be willing to reply that the Brooks are in both leagues.

New furloughs that will raise the total of railroad workers made idle to more than 67,000 by the end of the week were announced yesterday as the coal-mine "holiday" further curtailed hard-fuel traffic available to the carriers.

ALBANY, March 15 -- The way was cleared for legislative action on the Condon-Barrett bill today when the Assembly Ways and Means Committee reported the bill to the floor without comment. The bill amends the state university law to strip the trustees of administrative control over the existing thirty-one state-aided colleges.
Selection of the jury was nearly completed yesterday at the trial of the eleven men charged with conspiracy to organize the Communist party to advocate the forcible overthrow of the Government.

A two-hour hearing before Federal Court Judge Edward A. Conger yesterday failed to produce any immediate results in the plea for reinstatement by Max Lanier and Fred Martin, former St. Louis Cardinal players who were suspended by organized baseball for "jumping" their contracts.

Ruling that the company has not shown the need for interim relief, the Public Service Commission disapproved yesterday a request by the Westchester Street Transportation Company, Inc., for an interim fare increase amounting to about $210,000 a year.
Mayor O'Dwyer joined battle openly with his fusion opponents yesterday by accusing them of "a double-cross and a frame-up" in a self-serving effort to capture the city administration.

A designer with a great flair for a true sense of ingenuity in fur design is Esther Dorothy, who, in her collection yesterday at 68 East Fifty-sixth Street, hailed the revival of fox, highlighted shorter, curved shawls in place of stoles, liked glistening black furs and used quantities of small shining buttons to trim closings.

MOSCOW, March 15 -- Jacob M. Lomakin, former Soviet Consul General in New York, who is the new acting chief of the Foreign Office Press Department, said today that the United States maintained the world's worst news censorship.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 15 -- Borba, official newspaper of the Yugoslav Communist party, announced today that the distribution of rationed textiles and footwear would be increased 30 per cent this year.

The Suffolk County Commuters Association got an order yesterday from Judge Harold M. Kennedy directing the Long Island Rail Road to show cause in Brooklyn Federal Court tomorrow why the commuters' suit to revoke a recent fare increase should not be tried.

PARIS, March 15 -- The French Cabinet is expected to discuss the proposed Atlantic pact tomorrow upon hearing a report from Foreign Minister Robert Schuman on the talks held in London on that subject yesterday and today by the Foreign Ministers of the five Brussels Treaty powers.
LONDON, March 15 -- A United States airliner whose nose wheel would not retract fully after leaving Shannon Airport for New York made an emergency landing at a London airport tonight.

A round-robin petition to the Legislature to enact the Williamson-Brook constitutional amendment for the reorganization of the New York City court system was signed yesterday by representatives of a group of civic associations after a luncheon at the Astor Hotel.

The Philadelphia Orchestra under Eugene Ormandy's direction gave magnificent performances last night in Carnegie Hall. Seymour Lipkin was the soloist, playing, in commemoration of the sixth anniversary of Rachmaninoff's death in May of 1943, that composer's last imposing work for piano and orchestra, the "Rhapsody on a Theme of Paganini."

NORTH CONWAY, N. H., March 15 -- The heavy backlog of major ski competitions in the East, the result of a snow-scarce winter, will be partly reduced soon. Unfortunately, the piling up of dates means a conflict in several of the top-notch events, three title meets being scheduled this week-end.
WASHINGTON, March 15 (UP) -- The State Department today clamped a news black-out on the negotiations for renewal of United States rights in the strategic B-29 bomber base at Dhahran, Saudi Arabia.

LONDON, March 15 -- The Foreign Ministers of the five Brussels Treaty powers -- Britain, France, Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg -- ended here tonight a two-day conference during which they approved the terms of their impending entry into the Atlantic pact.

MOSCOW, March 15 -- To an observer returning to the Soviet Union for the first time since the victory of the days of 1944 many changes are evident in the Russian scene -- striking changes both physically and psychologically.

Hearing on the court order requiring the Rev. Dr. John Howard Melish, rector of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Holy Trinity, Brooklyn, and his supporters to show cause why the church's nine "deposed" vestrymen should not continue in office was adjourned yesterday in Supreme Court, Brooklyn.

NORTH CONWAY, N. H., March 15 -- The heavy backlog of major ski competitions in the East, the result of a snow-scarce winter, will be partly reduced soon. Unfortunately, the piling up of dates means a conflict in several of the top-notch events, three title meets being scheduled this week-end.
WASHINGTON, March 15 (UP) -- The State Department today clamped a news black-out on the negotiations for renewal of United States rights in the strategic B-29 bomber base at Dhahran, Saudi Arabia.

LONDON, March 15 -- The Foreign Ministers of the five Brussels Treaty powers -- Britain, France, Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg -- ended here tonight a two-day conference during which they approved the terms of their impending entry into the Atlantic pact.

RHODES, March 15 -- Israeli troops have occupied positions on the Dead Sea four miles on the Transjordan side of the truce line, it was revealed here today. The Israeli delegation announced the new move at a joint in formal meeting with Transjordanians for discussions of an armistice line.

By way of proving how becoming her spring hats are, Peg Fischer wore one of her newest models at her own showing yesterday noon in the Oval Room of the Ritz Carlton Hotel. She also acted as commentator. Her chapeau of white marguerites stood for a silhouette that she endorsed throughout the presentation.

The New York Knickerbockers will make their final home appearance of the regular season tonight, meeting the Rochester Royals at Madison Square Garden. This contest will be the nightcap of the first Basketball Association of America double-header ever staged here.

Several hundred persons waited yesterday during the noon hour to be the first to use the new 90-foot passageway connecting the concourse of the Hudson Terminal building on Church Street with the platform of the Chambers Street IND subway.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- Heavy pressure for and against the entrance of Dmitri Shostakovich and other Russians into this country as delegates to a "Cultural and Scientific Conference for World Peace" in New York City, March 25-27, is being brought upon the Department of State.

The General Telephone Corporation, largest telephone system in the United States outside the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, had the highest consolidated operating revenues in its history last year, it reported yesterday.

NORWALK, Conn., March 15 -- The Norwalk Ministerial Association protested today the suspension of religious radio broadcasts from the First Methodist Church of South Norwalk where Henry A. Wallace delivered on Sunday an unannounced talk over a local station.

Large corporate and individual taxpayers, waiting until the last day to save interest on their payments, flooded the collection offices yesterday with checks for Federal income levies. The rush of small taxpayers had spent itself, however.

Los Angeles, Calif., sold yesterday $10,000,000 of sewer bonds due on each March 1, from 1950 to 1969 to a banking syndicate headed by Bank of America National Trust Savings Association at an interest cost of 1.9499 per cent. The winning bid was 100.00069 for 4 1/2s, 1 1/2s and 2s.

A major switch in the concept of Alaskan defense in the post-war period has shifted emphasis from the Aleutians, scene of most of our war-time activity in the North Pacific, to the so-called Alaskan "heartland" in the Anchorage-Fairbanks area.

FRANKFORT, Germany, March 15 -- United States Military Government authorities informally rejected today a proposal by the French that the American and French zones of occupation be revised. Some American officials expressed surprise that the French had publicly announced a proposal that they had pressed in committee meetings for a long time.

Turner Catledge, assistant managing editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, told 500 school teachers yesterday that a majority of the Senators was not seriously concerned with establishing rules to stop a filibuster.

In your March 10 column you published a letter by Dr. Mackenzie Walser, who received government aid in his professional training in addition to military deferment under the Navy V-12 program during the war. Among a number of statements of doubtful validity, Dr. Walser falls back on the overworked and unsupported theory that "the very nature of the military organization conflicts hopelessly with good medical practice."

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- The Truman Administration program suffered three staggering blows on Capitol Hill today, each made possible by an informal but highly effective combination of Republican and Southern Democratic votes.

MOSCOW, March 15 -- Eugen S. Varga, who is possibly the best-known Soviet economist, gave the lie today to those "organs of black reaction" of the West, as he called them, that have suggested that he might be numbered among the supporters of the Marshall Plan.

The motorman and conductor of an IND subway express train reported yesterday to the police that a shot had been fired at the train, making a hole in a window of the fourth car, as the train was passing through the Sixty-fifth Street local station in Jackson Heights, Queens, at 3:06 P. M.
TAMPA, Fla., March 15 (AP) -The Cincinnati Reds buried the Boston Braves under a barrage of seventeen hits today to walk off with an 11-1 exhibition game victory before 1,134 fans.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- The California-Pacific Utilities Company, San Francisco, has filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission covering 50,000 shares of 5 1/2 per cent cumulative preferred stock, $20 par value.

PARIS, March 15 -- Premier Henri Queuille today won a personal victory and obtained a strong majority on the verge of the cantonal elections, beating off a double-edged attack from the Government's chief electoral opponents, the Communists and followers of Charles de Gaulle.
Your editorial of March 3 on "Legislating Civil Rights" is sound, ethically and logically. Law has no function if it is not effective in influencing human behavior.

It must be hoped that the withdrawal of the name Fairchild from private airplane manufacture is not permanent. The statement by Chairman J. Carlton Ward Jr. of Fairchild Engine and Airplane Corporation that his company will stop making the F-24, does, however, mark the end of a bit of aviation romance.

A determination to settle the long dispute between the Port of New York Authority and the airlines over the use of New York International Airport at Idlewild, Queens, was evidenced yesterday by Justice Thomas J. Cuff in a day-long conference in his Supreme Court chambers at Jamaica, Queens.
SAN ANTONIO, Tex., March 15 (AP) -- The state railroad commission today ordered that crude oil production in Texas be reduced in April by 234,211 barrels a day.

One hundred and twenty-five years ago last Dec. 2 President Monroe issued the declaration of United States policy on European colonies in the Western Hemisphere which became known as the Monroe Doctrine. Its essence was that this country would not permit further European encroachment in North, Central or South America.

Every dollar spent on highway development results in three dollars business, Charles M. Upham, engineer-director of the American Road Builders Association, said yesterday at a meeting of the National Association of Security Bond Producers.

HALLANDALE, Fla., March 15 (AP) -- Calumet Farm's 3-to-5 favorite, De Luxe, finished first at Gulfstream Park in today's Sunny Isles Purse, but was disqualified and placed third after doing everything except stop for a bag of oats in the stretch Later the stewards absolved Apprentice Eldon Nelson, the rider, of blame for De Luxe's antics.

ALBANY, March 16 -- After a year's study of milk costs in New York City, the State Temporary Commission on Agriculture reported today that reductions in the price of milk to metropolitan consumers could be brought about only by more efficient operations among processors and distributors.
JOHNSTON, S. C., March 16 -- "We must continue our production of atomic bombs," James F. Byrnes, former Secretary of State, said today.

PHILADELPHIA March 16 -With assets, surplus and premium income soaring to record highs, last year was the "best in the history" of the Insurance Company of North America group, John A. Diemand, president, reported at today's annual stockholders' meeting.

BANGKOK, Siam, Thursday, March 17 (UP) -- The Government disclosed today a new plot against Premier Pibul Songgram and announced that another abortive attempt Feb. 26 to overthrow the Government had been led by former Premier Pridi Panymyong.

CHICAGO, March 16 -- The extent to which railroads will improve their efficiency and service in the future depends upon their earning power, William T. Faricy, president of the Association of American Railroads, said today. He spoke here at the anniversary dinner of the American Railway Engineering Association.

BUENOS AIRES, March 16 -With Ambassador James Bruce, former Ambassador to Brazil William Pawley and officials of the River Plate now in Washington concentrating on the Argentine financial situation, the Peron regime has taken a further nominal step to improve trade prospects with the United States.
Lee Oma, the Detroit heavyweight has been matched with Omelio Agramonte of Havana for tomorrow night's main bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden.

Thousands of patriotic Americans of Irish extraction will celebrate the Feast of St. Patrick today with religious services in the morning, luncheons at noon and then the annual parade up Fifth Avenue.

WASHINGTON, March 16 (UP) -- Lester Barlow, Baltimore inventor and aviation engineer, asserted today that Louis A. Johnson's appointment as Secretary of Defense would "menace" the country's future security.

Newspapers, by recording the sizable gain of 35 per cent, again topped all other media in national advertising volume for January, it was reported yesterday by Printers' Ink. In the year-to-year comparison for January the general index was 14 per cent higher than in 1948.

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 16 -After four days of world championship fare, which they found entirely too rich and heavy, the Giants today switched their diet to what Leo Durocher doubtless hoped would prove a lighter menu by taking on the Cubs, last year's tailenders in the National League.

CHICAGO, March 16 (UP) -- Better working methods and mechanization of hand operation are being used to offset higher costs of rail operation, S. R. Hursh of Philadelphia told the American Railway Engineering Association at its convention here today. Mr. Hursh is assistant chief engineer, maintenance, for the Pennsylvania Railroad.
J. H. Bleistein has withdrawn as executive vice president of Motty Eitingon, Inc., and has accepted an appointment as manager of the Fur Dressers Guild, Inc., 101 West
WARSAW, March 16 -- French-Polish relations, which have been deteriorating for some time, dipped to a new low today as the French Government became the principal target pf Polish press criticism.
LONDON, March 16 (AP) -- Lord Mildmay's Cromwell, favorite for the Grand National Steeplechase at Aintree March 26, shortened in price to 8 to 1 tonight.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- The State Department charged today that Bulgaria, Hungary and Rumania, with the aid of the Soviet Government, had "flagrantly violated" their peace treaties and not fulfilled many of their obligations.

Great riches in mineral and other wealth await American investors in the still undeveloped state of Matto Grosso, in Brazil, Dr. Harry B. Wright, anthropologist and explorer, declared last night at the annual meeting of the American Brazilian Association at the University Club.
DETROIT, March 16 (AP) -- The first-place Detroit Red Wings warmed up late but delivered a 6-2 victory over the last-place New York Rangers before 11,315 National Hockey League fans tonight.

CHICAGO, March 16 -- Net income of Commonwealth Edison Company in 1948 was $24,219,263, or $1.76 a share, compared with $27,015,107, or $1.97 a share, a year earlier, despite new records in sales and number of customers served, Charles Y. Freeman, chairman, told stockholders today in his annual report.

LEWES, Del., March 16 -- The cruiser Milwaukee, lent by the United States to the Soviet Navy during the war, was formally returned in this port at 2:45 P. M. today in a unique ceremony devised by the Russians to avoid requiring the Soviet crew to give a courtesy salute to the American flag.

It may be significant that St. Patrick, though he loved the Irish, was not, according to the available authorities, born in Ireland. In this he resembles most of the rest of us. But the Irish took St. Patrick to their hearts and he took them to his heart. There was warmth in him and warmth in them, and the combination has made St. Patrick's Day something more than was originally contemplated.

LONDON, March 16 -- A report from Bucharest today that the Israeli Legation had demanded the release of seven Israeli citizens who have been detained for "some time" by Rumanian authorities called attention to the vigorous anti-Zionist campaign that has been waged in Rumania for the past four months.

LAKE SUCCESS, March 16 -- Norway suggested to the United Nations Security Council here today that charges of alleged atrocities in Indonesia be investigated at once as a special problem separate from the political issues in the dispute between the Netherlands Government and the Republic of Indonesia.
ALBANY, March 16 (AP) -- The Senate Finance Committee reported favorably today a bill to strip The Jockey Club of power to make rules for horse race meetings in New York.

"Paisan," the prize-winning Italian- made topical drama, now in its fifty-first and final week of its premiere engagement here at the World Theatre, has been booked to be shown in all the houses of the Loew's circuit in the metropolitan area starting next month, it was reported yesterday by Mayer Burstyn, the distributors.

General Norwegian support for the North Atlantic Pact was reported yesterday by Halfdan E. Stokke, Mayor of Oslo, Norway, on his arrival at the New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, aboard a Scandinavian Airlines plane.

Semi-finals in the twelfth annual national invitation college basketball tournament will pit Loyola of Chicago against Bradley and San Francisco against Bowling Green of Ohio tonight at Madison Square Garden. Tickets are available at the box office for the twin bill, as well as for Saturday night's final, it was announced yesterday.

MOSCOW, March 16 -- No one who travels the 560-mile route by rail from the Finnish frontier to Moscow can long doubt the magnitude of the reconstruction task with which the Soviet Government has been wrestling since the war's end.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- The National Military Establishment reported today that the combined troop strength of the three armed services dropped about 5,000 men during February, bringing the total to 1,663,600 on March 1.

A reduction of 6 per cent in motor vehicle deaths in New York State last year, as compared with the year before, is encouraging news, but unfortunately there is a reverse side to the medal. Non-fatal injuries showed an increase last year, and it can only be attributed to good luck that deaths were down.

PANAMA, Panama, March 16 (UP) -- A labor delegation today protested against a Government order to deport Max Brodsky, regional director of the United Public Workers of America (CIO). The delegation petitioned President Domingo Diaz to revoke the order.
VERO BEACH, Fla., March 16 -- The Dodgers returned to their old Ebbets Field habits today by using eleven innings and two hours and fifty minutes to lose a ball game.

The Chaplaincy Institute of the New York Board of Rabbis, organized last year to aid chaplains of the many groups and institutions in the city, began its operations yesterday with a seminar on psychosomatic medicine at Mount Sinai Hospital.
Following is the text of a reply by the Soviet expert, dated Feb. 11:
CHICAGO, March 16 (AP) -- H. C. Bonfig, vice president of Zenith Radio Corporation, today urged radio manufacturers to "take the whiskers off the question of television obsolescence."

Several thousand BMT subway passengers were delayed yesterday morning when two short circuits in electric signal power lines caused a two-and-one-half-hour slowdown in service between Union Square, Manhattan, and Queens Plaza, Long Island City.
WASHINGTON, March 16 -- Leaders of the International Wheat Conference today announced agreement between exporting and importing countries on the price scale and duration of the new wheat agreement.

BOSTON, March 16 (AP) -- Chicago's Black Hawk's outfought the Boston Bruins, 4 -- 3, tonight in the next-to-last game of the regular National Hockey League season on Boston Garden ice, attended by 12,633 paying fans.

CHICAGO, March 16 -- A continued upward trend in personal savings and maintenance of a high level of mortgage lending in 1949 are predicted in the Quarterly Letter on Savings and Home Mortgage Lending, the first issue of which was made public today.

TEL AVIV, Israel, March 16 -- Israel has protested to the acting Mediator, Dr. Ralph J. Bunche, against the replacement of Iraqi troops on Palestine's central front by Transjordan's Arab Legion, it was officially confirmed tonight.

Miguel Czerniak of Palestine, Rodrigo Flores of Chile and Marcos Luckis of Lithuania topped the standing of the eighteen competitors after two rounds of the international chess masters tournament at Mar del Plata, according to a report received from Argentina, yesterday.

The number of income taxpayers in the New York area who filed Federal returns this year just about equals the number who filed last year, it was estimated yesterday at the offices of the Collectors of Internal Revenue.

The eighty-fifth annual report of the St. Joseph Lead Company and domestic subsidiaries disclosed yesterday a net income of $9,636,737 after deducting the non-recurring net pension cost of $1,456,050.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was somewhat irregular yesterday and final prices were 4 points higher to 14 points lower.
The New York State Institute of Applied Arts and Sciences at 300 Pearl Street, Brooklyn, is a lusty educational infant whose curriculum is a faithful barometer of business conditions and employment.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- The Department of Commerce said today that exports of American goods and services exceeded imports by $6,300,000,000 in 1948. This was a sharp decline from the $11,200,000,000 excess of exports over imports in 1947.

Puddings that may be prepared in thirty seconds, frostings ready for spreading, popcorn of every hue in the rainbow, chocolates so tiny it takes 135 to make a pound, and "pink" peaches provide the news today. When a delegate from this department went shopping recently, these were the novel products she purchased for testing in the kitchen of THE NEW YORK TIMES.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, agreed with a member of the House Labor Committee today that unions should have democratic procedures for electing officers and preventing capricious expulsions, but he would not concede that these procedures should be required by law.

Handprinted wallpapers, tidy in appearance because of their small motifs, orderly arrangements and such crisp colorings as blue on white, were shown yesterday by the Renverne Corporation, 515 Madison Avenue. While the blue and white combination predominates, such unusual colorings as deep purple on light blue, pink on mustard and greens on tan are much in evidence.

Information on the scope and intent of wiretapping activities here will be given on Saturday to Democratic members of the House of Representatives from this city at a City Hall meeting with a view toward a possible "full-dress Congressional investigation" of wiretapping, it was learned last night.

ROME, Thursday, March 17 -- The Chamber of Deputies, which met at 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon to end its debate on Italy's entry into the Atlantic Pact, was still in session at 8:20 o'clock this morning and the end was not yet in sight.

Police Commissioner William P. O'Brien appointed three Deputy Commissioners yesterday -- one of them from outside the department -- and promoted thirty-two other officers in the detective and uniformed forces.

PHILADELPHIA March 16 -- Net profits after taxes of the Rohm Haas Company were $4,289,922 in 1948, compared with $3,829,368 in 1947. Otto Haas, president, announced today. Sales last year reached a new high of $62,419,158, compared with $52,842,057 in 1947.

An investing client of Pearce Mayer, brokers has purchased the seven-story apartment house twenty-eight families at 604 West 115th Street, near Columbia University, from Adolph Franklin for cash over mortgages amounting to $86,000. The assessed valuation is $100,000.

A decline of 465,000 barrels last week in the nation's stocks of gasoline was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end, they amounted to 125,801,000 barrels, compared with 126,286,000 a week earlier and 111,918,000 on March 14, 1948.

VIENNA, March 16 (UP) -- An Austrian was shot and killed by Soviet sentries at a Russian military airfield near Vienna on March 5, the Austrian Ministry of Interior announced last night. Soviet authorities informed the lW_inistry that the Austrian was involved in a fatal accident, was intoxicated and did not comply with security regulations.

BERLIN, March 16 -- A constitution for all Germany will be presented to the "People's Council" here in the next three days as a high point in efforts of the German Communists and their Russian tutors to halt formation of a West German state.
A new telephone instrument designed to aid both the speaker and the listener has been developed at the Bell Telephone Laboratories, 463 West Street, the company announced yesterday.
The search of American steel companies for new foreign sources of iron ore has added Liberia, West Africa, to a growing list.

For the third year in a row Abraham Lincoln High School gained the final round of the Public School Athletic League basketball championship tourney by turning back Long Island City, 52 to 34, in the semi-finals at Madison Square Garden yesterday.

The Blaw-Knox Company booked new business last year at a rate which exceeded production, William P. Witherow, president, informed shareholders in the annual report, issued yesterday for publication today. As a result, the blacklog grew to $39,000,000 at the year end, "a reasonable indication of satisfactory volume in 1949," he said.
HOUSTON, March 16 -- Motion-picture stars and other celebrities paraded through the palatial lobby of Glenn McCarthy's new Shamrock Hotel here tonight. The hotel will open formally tomorrow.

Local 802, American Federation of Musicians, AFL, representing 30,000 musicians in the New York area, announced yesterday that it would take no part in the Cultural and Scientific Conference for World Peace, sponsored by the National Council of the Arts, Sciences and Professions.

With production increased approximately 78 per cent over the 1947 output, the Packard Motor Car Company in 1948 realized a consolidated net profit of $15,109,439, equal to slightly more than $1 a common share, compared with $1,100,691, or 7 cents a share, in the preceding year, George T. Christopher, president and general manager, reported in the annual statement mailed yesterday to stockholders.

HARTFORD, Conn., March 16 (AP) -- Gov. Chester Bowles signed a bill today prohibiting racial segregation in the Connecticut National Guard. He used the occasion to strike out against Congressional opponents of President Truman's civil rights program.

PATERSON, N. J., March 16 -Residents of this city who yearn for the "good old days" of the 5-cent beer and the horse and buggy are at last given an opportunity to reminisce in the proper surroundings.
Miss Mary E. Dillon cheerfully joined the ranks of retired executives yesterday.
When 6-year-old Erna Kulmanis, a shy, blonde war orphan, was given a plate of pot roast yesterday she started to cry. She said she didn't know what it was.

LAKE SUCCESS, March 15 -- Following is the text giving the principal points of the United States expert's counter-proposal for a settlement of the Berlin currency question, as submitted to a "neutral" committee of experts of the United Nations Security Council and transmitted to the Soviet expert in Geneva on Jan. 20:

TOKYO, March 16 -- Premier Shigeru Yoshida's proposal to establish an Anti-Japanese Activities Committee directly under the Cabinet for the investigation of subversive acts now is meeting with considerable opposition. Apparently some Japanese fear that such a body would approximate a return to the wartime "thought control" and would not be responsible either to the people or to their elected representatives in the Diet.
Four authorities in the field of taxation and finance discussed last night the question: "Who Should Pay Higher Taxes?" on THE NEW YORK TIMES radio forum, "What's on Your Mind?" over Station WQXR.
NEW DELHI, India, March 16 (AP) -- Deputy Foreign Minister B.] K. Keskar told Parliameht today] that negotiations were expected toI start shortly for a "more comprehensive'' Russian trade agreement.

Renewed selling pressure developed in the wool futures market yesterday and Tuesday's gains were erased. Grease wool contracts closed at net losses of 2.5 to 3.5 cents a pound in transactions of 198,000 pounds. Wool top futures yielded 3 to 3.9 cents a pound in sales of 195,000 pounds.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- Underlying some of the trouble encountered by the Administration's legislative program is plainly the enduring strength of an old American principle. The principle is that the people should be allowed to deal locally with certain social welfare problems instead of having them administered by a large and distant federal government.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- The House passed and sent to the White House today a bill to authorize a $16,000,000 contribution to the United Nations for the relief of Arabs and Jews displaced from their homes by the fighting in Palestine.

Plans are being advanced for the spring tea dance to be held on March 31 at Le Coq Rouge under the auspices of the Thrift Shop Committee for Union Settlement. Guests have been requested to bring as part of the admission fee, packages of useful articles suitable for resale later at Everybody's Thrift Shop for the benefit of the settlement.

Russeks Fifth Avenue concentrated its showing yesterday noon in the Cotillion Room of the Pierre Hotel, on the Easter parade, 1949. If the pageant on the Avenue on April 17 looks anything like the sample presented at the show it will be very modish indeed.

Dalton Trumbo's new play, "The Biggest Thief in Town," has decided to spend more time on the road for polishing purposes before challenging the opinions of the Broadway critics. Under the new arrangement, the attraction will arrive at the Mansfield Theatre on Wednesday evening, March 30, instead of March 22. Now testing its wings in Philadelphia, it will remain there for an additional week through March 26.
Dr. Stephen S. Wise, an outstanding leader in American Jewish life and a pioneer Zionist official, will observe his seventy-fifth birthday today.
ALBANY, March 16 -- The Desmond parking bill, which seeks to ease the parking problem by using the cities' condemnation powers for private projects, was passed unanimously by the Senate today.

BUENOS AIRES, March 16 -- President Juan Peron swore today in the Hall of Congress to uphold the new Constitution that was drawn to his specifications by the Constitutional Convention made up exclusively of Peronistas.

Directors of the American Bosch Corporation declared yesterday a regular quarterly dividend of 25 cents a share on the new common stock to be issued pursuant to the consolidation with the Amra Corporation. The dividend is payable on April 15.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- Proposed increases in postal rates would cost two of the leading magazine publishers -- the Curtis Company of Philadelphia and Crowell-Collier of New York -- a sum twice as great as their 1948 profits in the first year of operation and much more thereafter, their principal executives said here today.
Editorials in THE NEW YORK TIMES are so influential that I cannot permit your recent eulogy to the penny postcard to pass unchallenged.

A jury was completed and sworn in yesterday in the ninth week of the trial of the eleven Communists charged with conspiracy to organize the Communist party for advocacy of the violent overthrow of the United States Government.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- The United States has renewed its demand for Russia to repatriate German prisoners of war. A new note was delivered in Moscow charging that on at least six separate occasions Russia had promised to free them by the end of last year.

LONDON, March 16 -- If a woman gives birth to a child by artificial insemination, has her marriage been consummated? If the donor is not her husband, is she guilty of adultery? Is the child legitimate? Is her child entitled to inherit her husband's property, although he is not the child's actual father?

An official invitation to residents of all sections of this country and the world to visit New York was extended yesterday at a special ceremony held during the noon hour on the steps of City Hall to commemorate "Visit New York Day," which was proclaimed last week by Mayor O'Dwyer.
WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., March 16 (AP) -- Three teams tied for first place today in the Seminole annual pro-amateur golf tournament
Tavern owners here estimated yesterday that their sales so far this year are approximately 33 1-3 per cent lower than the corresponding period last year.

ORLANDO, Fla., March 16 -The Senators sent Ed Klieman out to stop the Yankees today, but the ex-Indian had a rough time of it. So did Dick Weik, a recruit from Chattanooga, and Paul Calvert, a rookie from the Mexican and Cuban winter scene.
PHILADELPHIA, March 16 (AP) -- Steve Van Buren, the National Football League's top ground-gainer, today signed a contract to play four more years with the champion Philadelphia Eagles.

BOMBAY, India, March 16 -- Freight rates between ports on the west coast of India or Karachi, Pakistan, and Antwerp, Rotterdam, Hamburg and Bremen had been slashed by 50 per cent today as a rate war between a Dutch line and British, United States, Continental and Indian competitors intensified to spread to hitherto unaffected routes.

ALBANY, March 16 -- Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein charged today that operators of "non-profit" cemeteries, who have amassed large fortunes through the sale of cemetery lots, have taken the lead in a campaign to defeat legislation to curb the abuses through state regulation.

STOCKHOLM, March 16 -- Gen. Helge Victor Jung, Swedish Commander in Chief, said tonight he believed that in the event of war Sweden could be defended for a long time even against atomic bombs, and chemical and bacteriological warfare because of the country's peculiar topography and geographical situation.

The recently reported "uproar" of Scandinavian business circles over alleged "dumping" of bleached sulphite cellulose by American and Canadian wood-pulp mills in South American and European markets was attributed yesterday to their own domestic price controls.

Ruth Chatterton, stage and screen actress, is a pretty gamey cook, according to Sydney J. Dicketts, supervisor of the Ritz Tower Hotel, and at least one guest, Walter C. Strauss, who are seeking a court order to enjoin her from cooking in her apartment.

Prospect of the extension of the College of the City of New York southward along the heights above St. Nicholas Park has incited our scout -- addicted to nostalgic retrospect, as we know -- to make a pilgrimage to a part of the town with which he was once familiar and where many changes have taken place.
Following are extracts from a joint memorandum, submitted to the committee on Feb. 4, from the American, British and French experts:

TOKYO, March 16 -- Rules for foreign investments here have just been promulgated implementing Gen. Douglas MacArthur's directive issued two months ago. Perhaps the outstanding feature of the new regulations is the definition of what constitutes a foreign company because it effectively prevents foreigners from establishing a "Japanese corporation" in order to dodge provisions requiring applications and reports.

The New York Stock Exchange is finding that compulsory competitive bidding and compulsory minimum spreads are strange bedfellows in the present market. The problem of relating bids and spreads to the Exchange's rules about the secondary distribution of stock bought at deadline bidding is still being discussed in the wake of the sale of 364,648 shares of Northern States Power Company stock last Friday.

BERLIN, March 16 -- The Russians plugged a few more holes in their blockade of Berlin today by building stone and steel barricades across three streets linking the Soviet sector with the Western sectors of the besieged city.

LONDON, March 16 (AP) -- Six Boeing Stratocruisers on order for the British Overseas Airways Corporation are expected to be delivered in time to begin a "limited" North Atlantic service next Jan. 1, the House of Commons was told today.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- The State Department announced today that official visas would be issued to twenty-three delegates from behind the Iron Curtain, including Dmitri Shostakovich, Russian composer, to attend the Cultural and Scientific Conference for World Peace, March 25-27, in New York.

RICHMOND, Va., March 16 (AP) -- The executive committee of the Professional Golfers Association of America has decided against inviting Bobby Locke, South African golfer, to participate in the thirty-first annual national P. G. A. championship here.

ST. LOUIS, March 16 -- A satisfactory solution of the chemical problems involved in nuclear fuel "represents the highest hurdle to be cleared before atomic energy can really become useful as a widespread source of power," Sumner T. Pike of the Atomic Energy Commission said tonight.

Indications are that manufacturers of men's clothing will open fall lines during the week of April 18, immediately after Easter. A few may open earlier, but the post-Easter date appears to be favored in most quarters, it was reported here yesterday.

LONDON, March 16 -- "Bearish" implications of the Economic Survey for 1949, calling for continued disinflation and putting the brake on hopes for relief from taxation caused the stock market here today to start new account in dismal fashion.

Delaware, Lackawanna Western Railroad borrowed yesterday $3,780,000 on equipment trust certificates due semi-annually from Sept 15, 1949 to March 15, 1964 at an interest cost of about 2.62 per cent. The issue was sold at competitive bidding to a banking group headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., at a bid of 99.176 for an interest rate of 20 per cent.

ALBANY, March 16 -- In accordance with decisions reached at Republican conferences, the Senate and Assembly approved today a modified version of Governor Dewey's budget and tax-increase programs after voting down a series of Democratic amendments.

Although the New York Knickerbockers played a good game against the Rochester Royals last night at Madison Square Garden, it was not quite good enough to stop the Western Division leaders in the Basketball Association of America.

Between two works which the Symphony Orchestra has played here often and well, Dr. Koussevitzky put Vaughan-Williams' Sixth and latest Symphony on the program of the concert that he directed last night in Carnegie Hall.
NANKING, March 16 (UP) -- Premier Ho ran into an embarrassing stumbling block today as he sought to speed up selection of a Cabinet that would make peace negotiations easier.

LAKE SUCCESS, March 16 -- A committee of "neutral" experts notified the United Nations Security Council today that it had failed to work out an independent solution of the currency dispute between the Soviet Union and the Western powers -- the dispute that precipitated the Soviet blockade of Berlin.

The important point about the battle of Albany, which has now been settled by compromise, is that the taxpayer has been able to put some handwriting on the wall. Legible as far away as Washington, other state capitals, and the New York City Hall, this handwriting says that at a time when business faces uncertain prospects the costs of government are being examined with a critical eye.

Within the space of twenty-four hours President Truman has experienced three sharp defeats at the hands of a Congress in which his own party has a majority of votes. The Senate Armed Services Committee has tabled his nomination of Mon C. Wallgren as chairman of the National Security Resources Board.

KIRKENES, Norway, March 16 The big shot of Arctic Norway is a $115-a-month clerk who loves communism more than his country's freedom. One might mistake Gotfred Hoelvold for the most popular man in Kirkenes until one heard the whispers:

TRENTON, N. J., March 16 (AP) -- Here is a comparative table of commutation fares charged by the Central Railroad of New Jersey under its present schedule and those approved by the Interstate Commerce Commission and the State Board of Public Utility Commissioners:

The appointment of five city- wide general chairmen to serve as "combined chief of staff of the 1949 fund-raising campaign of the United Jewish Appeal of Greater New York was announced yesterday by Monroe Goldwater, the president.

Dr. William F. Russell, dean of Columbia's Teachers College, will become the 62-year-old college's third president and the first since Walter L. Hervey held the title from 1891 to 1897, it was announced yesterday. Dr. Hollis L. Coswell, associate dean, will become dean.

A combination of circumstances, including three flat tires, prevented us from attending the final winter safari of the Feather Dusters Club, which ushered out the last day of the preserve season with a cloud of smokeless powder and a flurry of pheasant feathers.

TRENTON, N. J., March 16 -The Central Railroad of New Jersey was authorized today to increase its commuter fares by an average of 16 per cent, with a maximum increase of $3 a month a ticket, as a result of the federal-state hearings that began last September.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- The Senate angrily debated into tonight a change in the anti-filibuster rule that it was nevertheless certain at length to adopt over the deep objection of the Truman Administration leaders. A recess at 8 P. M. until 11 A. M. tomorrow postponed the decisive vote.

Mayor O'Dwyer said yesterday that he would like to see Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. elected to the House of Representatives to succeed the late Sol Bloom, but added that, as a member of the Kings County Democratic organization, he did not intend to interfere in any nomination in New York County.

TRENTON, N. J., March 16 -Civil rights legislation, designed to combat racial and religious discrimination, was cleared by the New Jersey Assembly today and awaits Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll's signature.

LONDON, March 16 (AP) -- Dr. Ales Bebler, Yugoslav Deputy Foreign Minister, predicted today that the Communist Information Bureau would intensify its pressure on Premier Marshal Tito's regime in the next six months.

After two years of organizing, fund - raising and campaigning, the Brooklyn Orchestral Society launched the Brooklyn Symphony last night at the Academy of Music in the latest attempt to establish a permanent symphony in the borough that has had no durable orchestra of its own since 1891.

Moshe Sharett, Israel's Foreign Minister, arriving here by plane yesterday, declared that his nation's major problem was "peace with its neighbors." He pointed out that an armistice had been effected only with Egypt, but that Israel was in negotiation with other Arab countries.

Although 87 per cent of all Jewish students who applied for admission to liberal arts colleges last year were admitted, some discriminatory entrance practices were found, the American Council on Education reported yesterday.
MOSCOW, March 15 -- The Literary Gazette asserted today "American literary gangsters" had turned Tolstoy's classic "Anna Karenina" into a vulgar "he and she" romance.

WHAT has happened to the girls in modern novels? We haven't had a memorable heroine since -- well, in a long time. In fact, it might be an interesting idea for someone to make a list of the ten heroines of the ten leading novels of the day and see how many people can identify the current Anna Kareninas and Scarlett O'Haras and Catherine Barkleys, bringing to book each portrait of a lady.
WASHINGTON, March 16 -- The United States Government has decided on the two main principles that will govern its 1949-50 arms program for Western Europe.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, March 16 -- To impress upon South Africa that after an orgy of spending she must henceforth live within her means, Finance Minister Nicolaas C. Havenga announced today in the House of Assembly a surcharge of 20 per cent on the income tax and the supertax.

Sweeping changes in existing mid-Manhattan traffic regulations were urged yesterday in a committee report adopted by the Twenty-Third Street Association at its luncheon meeting in the Cornish Arms Hotel.

SEOUL, Korea, March 16 -- Premier Lee Bum Suk, who holds the rank of Minister of Defense in the Korean Government, today told a press conference that the Soviet Union was actively aiding anti-Government guerrilla forces in South Korea.

Swaying panels that flared to one side or floated out behind the manikins as they walked provided the chief fashion interest in the Rosette Pennington show yesterday at the Plaza Hotel of this shop's French collection and their custom designs.
Spring millinery by Madame Aranka of 19 East Fifty-sixth Street was presented during luncheon yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
Your front page story today says that Lomakin reports me as admitting that the United States has the worst censorship. This is mostly false, and the rest misleading.

New Orleans, La., sold bond issues totaling $4,500,000 to banking syndicates here yesterday. A group headed by First National Bank of New York and Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., bought $4,000,000 of street improvement bonds due on each May 1, from 1951 to 1989, with a bid of 100.10 for 2 3/4s and 2 1/2s, a net interest cost of 2.539 per cent.

Through publication of the war report of the Radiation Laboratory of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, the McGraw-Hill Book Company will have saved the Government $330,000 by the end of 1949, it was estimated yesterday by Curtis Benjamin, president of the company.
