LONDON, March 16 -- Hector McNeil, Minister of State for the Foreign Office, accused Bulgaria, Rumania and Hungary today of flagrantly violating their peace treaties with the connivance of the Soviet Union.

Proxies to elect five new directors to the board of Nu-Enamel Corporation at the annual meeting to be held on March 28, are being solicited by an independent stockholders committee. According to the committee, under the present management, the company's working capital shrank from $1,527,000 to $390,000 in 1948.
Grandma Emma Taylor doesn't know why she lived to be 100 years old, "and I don't want to live no other hundred," she emphasized between morsels of cake and ice cream at her birthday party yestreday.

The reported trial, sentencing and execution of seven Jews by the Iraqi Government for alleged Zionist activities brought protests yesterday from three Jewish organizations. Heads of the groups sent telegrams to Secretary of State Dean Acheson urging intervention by the United States.

A new book about Franklin D. Roosevelt will be published by the American Artists Group on April 12, the fourth anniversary of his death. It is "Franklin Roosevelt at Hyde Park," by Olin Dows, artist-neighbor and friend of the Roosevelt family. The book will contain 174 drawings and a documented text about Hyde Park from the early days of Franklin Roosevelt to the time it was dedicated as a national shrine.

A one-man show in New York, the ambition of struggling artists, is an unsought-for reality for 84-year-old Meichel Pressman of the Bronx, who began to paint eight months ago. His show will open on Monday at the Carlebach Gallery, 937 Third Avenue, but the event, while gratifying, will make little difference in the artist's life.

The Suffolk County Commuters Association brought an action in Supreme Court yesterday to set aside commutation increases recently granted by the Public Service Commission to the Long Island Rail Road on the ground that the increase was "illegal, arbitrary and discriminatory."

Shoes with a shorter look, more rounded toes and toes turned up like those of Dutch wooden ones are only a few of the trends for showing next fall, according to Roger Vivier, French designer for Delman M. Vivier was present yesterday at a preview of fifty of his designs at the Delman Salon at 745 Fifth Avenue.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- Any proposal to increase further the Federal tax rates "raises a serious question as to the stability of our system of free enterprise to resist the pressures toward socialization," the Chamber of Commerce of the United States said today.

Silver Beaver awards, the highest honors conferred by local Boy Scout councils, were presented yesterday to General Sessions Judge Jonah J. Goldstein and Charles De Wolfe Gibson, vice president of the Air Reduction Company. The presentations were made at the annual meeting of the Greater New York Councils, Boy Scouts of America, at 120 West Forty-second Street.
PITTSBURGH, March 16 (AP) -- Hard coal operators today called the three-day old mine shut-down a violation of the anthracite mine contract.
DETROIT, March 16 (AP) -- An increase in carloadings in the Great Lakes area, as part of "a general upturn in business," was forecast today at a meeting of the Great Lakes Regional Advisory Board.

ST. LOUIS, March 16 -- National officers of four striking railway brotherhoods refused today to order 3,500 operating employes back to work on the Wabash Railroad despite the issuance of an emergency order by President Truman who called for a sixty-day postponement of the walkout.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- The Association of American Ship Owners suggested today that Congress act now on non-controversial proposals designed to strengthen the Merchant Marine, postponing until later those at issue between the subsidized and non-subsidized operators.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- President Truman's principal legislative advisers have recommended recall of the Congress, almost immediately after the regular session adjourns in June or July, to debate the Administration's civil - rights program to a definitive conclusion without the distraction of other pressing legislative issues.

The Bach Aria Group, William H. Scheide, director, gave its third and final concert of a series devoted to arias and duets by Johann Sebastian Bach, last night at Town Hall. Participants included Jean Carlton, soprano; Margaret Tobias alto; Robert Harmon, tenor; Norman Farrow, bass; Sergius Kagen, pianist; Maurice Wilk,' violinist; Bernard Greenhouse, 'cellist; Julius Baker, flutist, and Bernard Greenhouse, 'cellist.

FRANKFORT, March 16 -- The United States, British and French Military Governors sent to their respective governments today the terms of the dispute over the German proposals for modification of state boundaries of southwestern Germany.

PARIS, March 16 -- According to diplomatic sources, the French and British Foreign Offices are considering the advisability of eventually extending the defensive apparatus of the impending North Atlantic pact into the Eastern Mediterranean area.
The close relationship between eye problems and emotional makeup was stressed yesterday by speakers at the fortieth anniversary conference of the National Society for the Prevention of Blindness.
WASHINGTON, March 16 Influential members of the House called today for a Congressional investigation of the recent release and publication of various military and atomic energy information.

Thank you for the understanding and pertinent editorial in THE NEW YORK TIMES on March 3 concerning the Judd bill for equality in naturalization and immigration and for the fine news story of the preceding day.

RHODES, March 16 -- Israel and Transjordan have agreed on armistice lines in the critical Jerusalem area, it was announced late this evening though Transjordan has filed a formal complaint over an alleged Israeli violation of the truce lines at Engeddi (Ein Geddi) on the Dead Sea.

The fiftieth anniversary of the ordination of the Rev. John Focacci, of the Roman Catholic Order of Salesians of St. John Bosco, will be celebrated Sunday in three metropolitan area Salesian churches, it was announced yesterday. The actual anniversary is today.

WASHINGTON, March 16 (UP) -- Vice Admiral W. M. Fechteler, deputy chief of naval operations, revealed today that more than one-fourth of the men who served in submarines in World War II were killed in action.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- The Senate will be asked to vote a 15 per cent increase for every landlord, reached by a 5 per cent rise each six months, in the final subcommittee version of the rent control bill that was approved today.

LONDON, March 15 -- Foreign Secretary Bevin, Foreign Minister Robert Schuman of France and United States Ambassador Lewis W. Douglas are reported to have agreed here today that representatives of their three countries should "get down to work" on United States proposals for reducing the number of German industrial plants to be dismantled for reparations.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended March 9:
I have been very much encouraged by the public response to the efforts of our organization to foster good industrial relations in the financial community.

Evidence showing increased bus service in the last month by the Surface Transportation Company, which operates chiefly in the Bronx, was introduced yesterday at the last of three hearings on charges of inadequate service held before the State Public Service Commission, 233 Broadway.

PARIS, March 16 -- The French Cabinet approved the Atlantic pact tonight and decided to ask Washington for clarification of the strategy, the armaments and the military organization that would accompany it.

Speedy adoption of regulations to end the practice of irregular air carriers selling bargain trips to California, Florida and other points through joint ticket agencies in competition with the scheduled lines was predicted in Washington yesterday by an official of the Civil Aeronautics Board.

There is no doubt that relations with our Latin-American neighbors are at low ebb. Something concrete and effective must be done to strengthen and preserve any semblance of real goodwill which existed. This can be accomplished not by promises but by acts and deeds.

Norah Drewett, pianist, and Geza de Kresz, violinist, who had not appeared together on the local recital stage since the late Twenties, presented a program last night at Times Hall. Mr. de Kresz was last heard in this city in 1935 with the Harthouse Quartet, which he led for twelve years. He then left for Hungary, where he headed the violin department of the Conservatory of Music in Budapest until 1947.

Detailed plans for the new passenger service of the Home Lines of Italy between New York and Mediterranean ports were made public here yesterday by Giuseppe Cosulich, Italian shipping operator and a member of the family that formerly operated the Cosulich Line.

Continuing the trend, the stock market closed irregularly lower in slow trading yesterday. Losses were fractions to more than a point, although prices staged a creeping recovery in the final hour. Sales fell to 670,000 shares, from 730,000 shares on Tuesday.

CLEVELAND, March 16 -- Bankers of this city today protested that northern Ohio institutions are losing out on the financing of millions of dollars of Marshall Plan orders held by manufacturers in this area.

The great Air Force bases at Anchorage, Fairbanks and Eielson, in Alaska's "heartland," today are defended by fewer than 100 jet fighters without range enough to reach Nome and return, and by a single battalion of anti-aircraft artillery, armed with obsolete weapons, none larger than 40 mm.

BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., March 16 -- The Lutheran churches of the United States are currently prepared to receive and resettle a total of 16,500 displaced persons, it was disclosed today by the Rev. Dr. Clarence E. Krumbholz, executive secretary of the National Lutheran Council.

TOKYO, Thursday, March 17 (AP) -- Gen. Douglas MacArthur today flatly denied any prospective change in the Japanese occupation regime and said that he intended to stay on the job until the peace treaty was signed.

About half of the eighty Polish seamen who jumped two ships of the Gdynia-America Line in New York last January and February rather than go back to Communist-dominated Poland have surrendered to Immigration officials and appealed for refuge in the United States, it was learned yesterday.

The new motor vessel Horta, operated by the Portuguese Line (Companhia de Navegacao Carregadores Acoreanos), arrived here yesterday on her maiden voyage from Lisbon and the Azores. The trim 3,800 - deadweight - ton passenger-cargo ship, with fifteen passengers, docked at Pier 38, East River, shortly before noon.

Two hundred angry pickets besieged the huge West Side terminal of the Railway Express Agency yesterday and forced twenty-five supervisors to abandon efforts to move Easter hats and dresses tied up by last week's express embargo.
WASHINGTON, March 16 -- Judith Coplon, the young former employe of the Department of Justice charged with aiding Russian espionage, was indicted by a Federal grand jury here today.

TOKYO, March 16 -- The too free use of security classifications on matters of a purely business nature was severely criticized today in a statement issued by Dennis McEvoy, president of the American Chamber of Commerce in Japan.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 16 -- In one of his more pontifical moments, which is practically all the time, Branch Rickey intoned, "A manager's most important qualification is his selectivity." A free translation of the Mahatma's statement is that the test of a manager is his ability to judge and assay ball players. On his selection of the talent which passes before his gaze do his fortunes rise or fall.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 16 -- Republic Pictures, the leading producer of Western films, today announced plans for the launching of a new cowboy star, Rex Allen, whom the studio has recruited from radio.

Richard (Pancho) Gonzales will be seen in action in the East today for the first time since he won the national tennis championship at Forest Hills last September. The young Californian will turn loose his tremendously fast service on the board courts of the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street, in the national indoor tournament.
KEY WEST, Fla., March 16 -- President Truman went fishing in the green Atlantic this afternoon and returned after sunset with a sixteen-pound barracuda and a grouper of equal weight.

A new variety show featuring Paul Winchell and his dummy, Jerry Mahoney, will have its premiere tomorrow night from 9 to 9:30 o'clock over Du Mont's television stations in New York, Philadelphia and Washington. Master-of-ceremonies for the show, to be called "Front Row Center," will be Buddy Lester.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- The House dealt President Truman another blow today by approving the initial step of a plan to compel construction of a seventy-group Air Force despite the President's insistence on a "balanced" military establishment with forty-eight air groups.
HALLANDALE, Fla., March 16 (AP) -- Tarport Kid, claimed last Saturday for $8,000, carried Edward Dibe's silks to victory at the first asking at Gulfstream Park today.

A factor to reduce traffic and parking congestion is offered in the 1949 Plymouth line announced yesterday by the Plymouth division, Chrysler Corporation. Overall dimensions of all the cars have been reduced while a new wheelbase measuring only 111 inches has been adopted for one series.

The handprinted wallpapers introduced yesterday by Thibaut, 509 Madison Avenue, indicate that pinks and light blues have at last come out of the nursery. In the new designs, pinks are frequently combined with deep rose, lively light green and either deep gray or soft brown, while the blues are used together with yellow-greens or golden beiges and white.

LONDON, March 17 -- A report of the British inquiry into the shooting down of Royal Air Force planes by Israeli forces in January, which was published today, insisted that the aircraft were over Egypt when attacked.

The fourth week of Bruno Walter's Beethoven cycle with the New York Philharmonic-Symphony at Carnegie Hall last night brought together one of the towering masterworks, the Seventh Symphony; one of the scores just a cut or two below the greatest, the Fourth Symphony, and the Triple Concerto, which is a good many notches below the composer's best.

Publicker Industries, Inc., and its subsidiaries, including Paco Tankers, Inc., reported yesterday in a preliminary annual statement for 1948 that net income rose to $13,664,439 from $4,733,064 earned the year before. The income, which includes a Federal tax credit estimated at $847,000, is equivalent to $5.84 each on the 2,266,414 shares of common stock outstanding.

BOSTON, March 17 -- In speeches and interviews here and in New Haven, Conn., today Representative Hugh D. Scott Jr., Republican National Chairman, accused the Administration of never having intended to "put through its civil-rights program."

The five Communist-dominated nations to be represented at the Cultural and Scientific Conference for World Peace here next week will pay from their government treasuries all expenses of their twenty-three delegates, it was learned yesterday.

CHICAGO, March 17 -- Bearishness predominated in the grain markets on the Board of Trade today with an early dip and a closing rally. Free selling of May wheat and buying of July cash interests and commission houses featured trading in that grain, but professional traders who sold July tried to cover late in the session and found little for sale, causing a rally of 2 3/8 cents from the early low.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- Paul G. Hoffman, Economic Cooperation Administrator, predicted today that Soviet Russia would be forced into a policy of "live and let live" if the United States was victorious in the so-called cold war. Mr. Hoffman spoke his views to a delegation of Italian labor leaders beginning a two-week tour of industrial establishments.
WASHINGTON, March 17 -- The United States has reserved all rights on behalf of United States citizens whose property is seized in Rumania under the nationalization law.
The total earnings of all who work just about equal the spending power of all the people, those who work and those who don't.

WASHINGTON, March 17 (AP) -- The Bureau of the Census reported today that cotton consumed during February was 640,182 bales of lint and 119,007 bales of linters This compared with 674,463 bales of lint and 123,038 bales of linters consumed during January this year, and 785,677 bales of lint and 98,104 bales of linters consumed during February last year.

SEOUL, Korea, Friday, March 18 -- Mrs. Horace H. Underwood, wife of a prominent American missionary and educator, was shot to death here yesterday afternoon by a pair of hooded Korean assassins, who entered the Underwood home during a tea party and plunged the gathering into panic.
WASHINGTON, March 17 -- The authority of the National Labor Relations Board to dismiss a case initiated by the independent General Counsel's office was challenged today.

BRADENTON, Fla., March 17 (AP) -- With considerable help from the Braves' pitchers, the Reds trounced the National League champions, 9 -- 4, today. Cincinnati got thirteen hits, while Boston pitchers walked six and hit four batsmen.
LONDON, March 17 -- The Labor party added one more to its unbroken and unprecedented string of by-election victories today when it won the constituency of Sowerby, in Yorkshire.
PARIS, March 17 -- Dieudonne Coste, who, in 1930, made the first East-West flight across the North Atlantic with Maurice Bellonte, was acquitted today of a charge of having been a German agent.

VIENNA, March 17 -- A number of former Hungarian officers and their alleged civilian accomplices have been arrested and will shortly be made defendants in a large scale "American espionage" trial by Hungary's Communist - dominated Government.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., March 17 -- Col. Robert M. Stillman, former commander of Stewart Field, N. Y., has been named deputy for operations at headquarters of the First Air Force at Fort Slocum, it was announced today.

WASHINGTON,. March 17 -- Robert N. Denham, general counsel, National Labor Relations Board, refused today to dismiss the charge of unfair labor practice against the CIO Longshoremen's Union because the union and the employers had made a contract which settled their differences.

Saturday would seem to be a good day on which to lay plans for the Sunday afternoon nap. Perhaps Friday would be even better. The Sunday afternoon nap ought to be prepared for, and announced, well in advance.
VERO BEACH, Fla., March 17 -- Watching his Dodgers taking their second workout as a unit this morning, Manager Barney Shotton let go with a few comments, all pertinent and some pungent.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, March 17 -- Foreign Minister Gustav Rasmussen arrived here from Washington this afternoon. He was received at the airport by Premier Hans Hedtoft; J. R. Dahl, director of the Foreign Office, and the United States Charge d'Affaires, Edward J. Sparks.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., March 17 -- The cornerstone of the new Macy's White Plains store, a branch of Macy's of New York, was laid this morning by Silas S. Clark, Mayor of White Plains, and Jack I. Straus, president of Macy's. Mementos of the city and the store were sealed in a wall behind the stone.

MOSCOW, March 17 -- A sparkling electric display comparable to those on Broadway proclaims in Arbat Square the latest Soviet film success. "The Meeting on the Elbe." The Red Army, in the movie, thwarts nefarious United States schemes in occupied Germany.
John J. McQuade, who is still on the job he thought was temporary fifty years ago, is due for a surprise today.

Yesterday, as it seemed, the Senate was giving funeral honors to the President's civil rights program. If, as Republican leaders were suggesting, this was not the case, that will be this year's outstanding surprise. Last November Governors Thurmond and Wright, running on the States Rights ticket, received about 2 1/2 per cent of the votes cast for President.

The Phillips Petroleum Company reported yesterday for 1948 a consolidated net income of $72,630,997 after charges, taxes and reserves, equal to $12.01 each on the average of 6,046,000 shares outstanding. In 1947, net income was $40,893,647, or $8.11 on the average of 5,044,000 shares then outstanding. Gross income was $493,724,011, against $302,772,051.

Miss Shirley C. Titus, chairman of the American Nurses' Association Committee on Employment Conditions, predicted yesterday that "strong" resolutions urging nurses to use their right to bargain collectively would be adopted tomorrow at the final session of the National Socio-Economic Conference for Industrial Nurses in the Henry Hudson Hotel.

Syndicates were in formation yesterday for bidding on two forthcoming public utility financing transactions. Four banking groups are getting ready to bid for $37,000,000 of debt of the Potomac Electric Power Company. The company's plans have called for the private sale of this issue to institutional investors and a hearing thereon is scheduled for next Monday.

Chairman Vinson of the House Armed Services Committee is confusing issues when he attempts to put forward a seventy-group Air Force as a substitute for Universal Military Training. The two are considerably different parts of the defense problem. Yet he would finance part of the larger Air Force by diversion of the $800,000,000 (which hasn't yet been appropriated) which the President had earmarked in his budget for the start of U. M. T.

Winter has dealt kindly with motorists in this city thus far this year as compared with a corresponding period in 1948. A tabulation of emergency road service calls presented yesterday by the Automobile Club of New York emphasized a substantial decrease in cold weather automotive ailments.

The odors that proved so noxious to the guests of the Ritz Towers Hotel have ceased and Ruth Chatterton, former star of "Come Out of the Kitchen," who caused all the fuss, will come out the kitchen and stay out the kitchen.

ALBANY, March 17 -- Three bills to regulate and require the licensing of finance companies, limited in their application to companies engaged in the financing of automobiles on installment plans, were introduced in the Legislature today by Senator J. Raymond McGovern of New Rochelle, chairman of the Joint Legislative Committee on Installment Financing.

Aided by a retroactive award of $2,902,000 for mail pay and reimbursement of costs connected with the grounding of its DC-6 aircraft, United Air Lines held its net loss for 1948 to $1,070,358, equal to 72 cents a common share, compared with a deficit of $3,474,366, or $2.03 a share, in 1947, W. A. Patterson, president, reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- James Forrestal, Secretary of Defense, abruptly ordered today the consolidation of the public information sections of the armed forces following sharp Congressional inquiries into "news leaks" and unilateral actions by the individual services bidding for public attention and funds.

Wool goods buying for fall by the women's apparel trades has come to a virtual standstill owing to price uncertainties, it was learned yesterday. Cutters have placed only a small percentage of their fall season requirements, foreseeing the possibility of a price cut in the wool market even though major producers have reiterated that prices cannot come down in the face of high raw material costs.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- Department store sales in the week ended March 12 were 8 per cent below sales in the corresponding week of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported tonight. The following lists percentage changes from like periods of 1948:

SARASOTA, Fla., March 17 (AP) -- Dave (Boo) Ferriss, question mark right-hander of the Red Sox staff, yielded only one dinky hit in six innings today as the Boston American leaguers tripped the Philadelphia Phils, 4 -- 1.
Solventol Chemical Products, Inc., makers of Sterol, house cleaner, to Luckoff, Wayburn Frankel, Detroit. Newspaper advertising.

The Southern Pacific Company reported yesterday for 1948 a consolidated net income of $43,770,280 after charges and taxes, equal to $11.60 each on the 3,772,763 capital shares in the hands of the public. For 1947 the company reported a net income of $35,518,989, or $9.41 a share.

Plans were advanced at a tea given by Mrs. Robert B. Reed yesterday afternoon in her home at 444 East Fifty-seventh Street for a spring frolic and tea dance in behalf of the Humane Society of New York to be held on the afternoon of May 12 in the main ballroom of the Plaza.

St. Patrick reaped homage yesterday from Eire's sons and daughters, by Liffey's and Shannon's and Hudson's bright waters. With the Old Sod now free after long bitter years, the faithful rejoiced with masses and music, and laughter and tears.

VIENNA, March 17 -- The secretary-general of the Austrian Communist party, Friedl Fuernberg, informed the Russian high commissioner, Col. Gen. Vladimir Kurasov, at a recent meeting that the best service the Russians could render to the Austrian Communist party would be to announce the reduction or elimination of Russian charges for occupation costs, reliable Austrian political sources reported today.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- A virtual declaration of Congressional intent to end the Federal regulation of rents on June 30, 1950, is contained in the final version of the Senate rent-control bill reported today.

With first occupancy of Bell Park Gardens in Bayside, Queens, expected in July, prospective tenants are organizing to operate the 800-apartment development, Herman T. Stichman, State Housing Commissioner, reported yesterday.
Official notice of his intention to carry his municipal corruption fight to the City Council floor was filed yesterday by Councilman Edward Rager, Manhattan Republican.

BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., March 17 -- A four-month campaign to raise six million dollars for the support of its church-related colleges and seminaries will be undertaken next January by the United Lutheran Church in America, it was learned today.

One of the few marriage ceremonies ever performed during the long history of Ellis Island as an immigrant detention center marked the arrival here yesterday of 228 Jewish displaced persons from Shanghai en route to Europe and Israel.

With sales up sharply, the Curtiss-Wright Corporation realized a consolidated net profit of $5,313,298 in 1948, contrasted with a net loss of $1,365,258 in 1947, W. C. Jordan, president, reported yesterday. Net sales last year were $111,747,027, against $83,161,988 in 1947.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- The Senate adopted late tonight a new closure, or "gag," rule over the assertions of Administration Democrats that it would strengthen rather than weaken future Southern filibusters against the President's civil rights program.

Frustration and emotional maladjustment are increasing among students and graduates of liberal arts colleges because these institutions are failing to provide "education with a mission," according to Dr. Jacob S. Orleans, Professor of Education at City College.

Two unseeded quintets will clash in the final of the twelfth annual National Invitation college basketball tournament at Madison Square Garden tomorrow night. It will be between Loyola of Chicago and San Francisco, which qualified last night by defeating Bradley, 55 -- 50, and Bowling Green of Ohio, 49 -- 39, respectively.
Eugene Dennis, chief of the eleven Communists being tried for conspiracy against the Government, received permission yesterday to dismiss his attorney and represent himself in court.
WASHINGTON, March 17 (AP) -- Another edition of the Washington "bible" -- the Congressional Directory -- has rolled from Government presses.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on March 12 were 709,326 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 3,774 cars, or 0.5 per cent more than in the preceding week, 87,160 cars, or 10.9 per cent fewer than for the corresponding week last year, and 131,821 cars or 15.7 per cent fewer than during the corresponding week of 1947.
WASHINGTON, March 17 (AP) -- Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery said today the Allies went into the Italian campaign in World War II without a "pre-determined plan of action."

It is unfortunate that the Senate vote on March 11 on Vice President Barkley's ruling on the closure petition has not been more widely reported, for it is one of the most significant and revealing votes of recent years.

WELLESLEY, Mass., March 17 -- Robert F. Bacher, a member of the Atomic Energy Commission, said today that the United States Air Force's work on plans for an atomic-powered airplane was "probably the most exciting of new experiments with atoms."

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- The New York State Electric and Gas Corporation, Ithaca, N. Y., received authorization from the Securities and Exchange Commission today to acquire the outstanding 6 per cent income debentures and common stock of the Keuka Lake Power Corporation, Syracuse, N. Y. Both are subsidiaries of the General Public Utilities Corporation, New York.

Some of the best skiing this unusual winter, which has only a few days remaining, can be had this week-end as reports from the north country yesterday told of fresh powder surfaces on firm bases. Some areas even reported good "spring" skiing, the type that lures thousands to the higher elevations.

Pittsburgh, Pa., sold yesterday bond issues totaling $6,600,000 due from 1950 to 1969 to a banking group headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., at. a bid of 100.375 for 1.80s. The borrowing consisted of $4,600,000 of public improvement bonds and $2,000,000 of funding bonds.

NANUET, N. Y., March 17 -- Chief of Police Walter Liebert of Clarkstown is starting a campaign to educate rural policemen and sheriffs in the advantages of bloodhounds. He says there is a scarcity of trained trailers.

Seven delegates from Russia, five from Czechoslovakia, four from Poland, two from Rumania and five from Yugoslavia have obtained American visas to attend the Cultural and Scientific Conference for World Peace to be held in this city from March 25 to March 27.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- Securities registered for new-money purposes reached a new record level of $5,032,199,000 in 1948, an increase of $1,212,888,000 over 1947, the Securities and Exchange Commission disclosed today in its fourteenth annual report to Congress.

All but twenty of the eighty Polish seamen who failed to report for the sailings of the Gdynia America liners Sobieski and Batory in January and February have surrendered to Immigration authorities or to the Polish Immigration Committee, it was reported yesterday.

DUBLIN, March 17 -- This was one of the sunniest, mildest St. Patrick's Days Ireland has had in recent years. With College Green, Dublin, bathed in sunshine and blue skies overhead, Premier John A. Costello stood on the reviewing stand to take the salute this morning, while green-uniformed units of the Irish Army with shamrocks in their caps marched by to stirring music.

LAKE SUCCESS, March 17 -Bolivia proposed today that the United Nations General Assembly take up the case of Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty, who was sentenced to life imprisonment in February for allegedly conspiring against the Hungarian Government.

Shoppers who chose yesterday to buy sheets, yarn or art needlework supplies at Gimbels had the selection eased for them by the new design of the redecorated and relocated departments, part of a two and a half million dollar store modernization program along lines laid out by Raymond Loewy Associates, industrial designers.

Educational and civic leaders urged Albany leaders yesterday to pass legislation to open the top administrative positions of the Board of Education's Bureau of Attendance to general competitive examination.
PITTSBURGH, March 17 (AP) -- Householders fearful of being caught with empty coal bins during the mine stoppage created a "run" on retail stocks today.

Lee Oma will oppose Omelio Agramonte of Cuba in the main bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden tonight. The match was virtually a last-minute one, being made after Ike Williams, lightweight champion of the world, withdrew from his scheduled match with Kid Gavilan, another Cuban, because of a sore shoulder.

Price policies of America's industries have too frequently been determined on a "crisis basis" and should be replaced with a research approach to price policy formation, Dr. Joel P. Dean, Professor, Business Economics, School of Business, Columbia University, declared yesterday.

Tangible developments yesterday in the wiretapping investigation were limited to a thirteen-state alarm being sent out for a missing witness, and a promise by his employer, John G. Broady, counsel for Clendenin J. Ryan Jr., Fusion leader, that the missing witness would be brought back to the city as soon as possible.

HARTFORD, Conn., March 17 -- The annual spring flower show of The Hartford Times opened here today to capacity crowds. Five-year-old Dora Coleman, daughter of Mayor Cyril Coleman, used a shamrock as the key to the West Hartford Armory to open the show.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- A bitter fight, certain to reach the floor of Congress, brewed today over the recommendation that civil functions of the Army Corps of Engineers be transferred to the Department of the Interior.

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 17 -- The Giants finally got back on the victory beam today when they scored three in the last half of the ninth, the last one forced in with a pass from Ralph Hamner to vanquish the Cubs, 6 to 5.

An early season for channel bass on the North Carolina outer banks seems indicated by the unusually early catches of these fish by commercial fishermen in the Hatteras area, according to a report just received from Aycock Brown at Nags Head.

TOKYO, March 17 -- Gen. Douglas MacArthur's statement that he intends to "see this job through" in Japan until the signing of the peace treaty unless he is transferred to other duties by the United States Government is arousing great interest here.

Unionized Railway Express clerks in this city moved yesterday to extend the shutdown of express operations to all parts of the East. Their first direct action was to send pickets to Railway Express depots in Newark, Elizabeth and Plainfield, N. J., forcing all three offices to close.

A general price reduction of from 12 to 17 1/2 per cent in brass screwed pipe fittings is being announced to the industrial and contracting trade, distributors revealed here yesterday. The reductions do not apply to flanged brass or bronze fittings and has not been extended to valves or other brass items.
HALLANDALE, Fla., March 17 (AP) -- You and Me streamlined to victory in today's St. Patrick Purse under the guidance of Willie (Smoky) Saunders.
HOUSTON, March 17 -- New York members of the American Institute of Architects won a major share of the honors at today's sessions of the eighty-first convention of the organization.

CHICAGO, March 17 (AP) -- Sears, Roebuck Co., the nation's largest retail and mail order merchandising company, announced today it is cutting prices on all wearing apparel made of denim 9 per cent. The price cuts will go into effect immediately and will apply to both retail stores and the mail-order business.

TEL AVIV, Israel, March 17 -- The loan of $100,000,000 by the Export-Import Bank to the State of Israel was ratified tonight by the Knesset (Assembly) by 85 to 3 after a five-hour debate. The only dissenters were the Communists.
PASSAIC, N. J., March 17 -- Whenever any member of the Simon family here falls ill, they send for Dr. J. Ollen Yager, who lives in near-by Paterson.

Heavy selling, attributed to price weakness in South African wools, appeared in the wool futures market here yesterday and depressed prices 8 to 9 cents a pound. Sales of wool top futures totaled 1,000,000 pounds and grease wool transactions aggregated 600,000 pounds, both of which were the highest sales in many years.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 17 -- Mounting rumors of military preparations in states attached to the Communist Information Bureau against Yugoslavia have not produced the slightest reaction in this country. Lack of evidence of any military and police precautions casts a serious doubt on the authenticity of these rumors.

The National Retail Furniture Association may take a definite stand on continuance of Regulation W beyond the June 30 expiration date when its board of directors meets in Washington from April 4 through 6, Roscoe R. Rau, executive vice president, said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 17 (UP) -- The National Labor Relations Board ruled tonight that an employer may call a union "outlaw," "wildcat" and "off-breed."

Two and a half months after the city began its five-year, $95,000,000 sewage disposal program to clean up recreational waters around New York, 7 per cent of the job is complete, Public Works Commissioner Frederick H. Zurmuhlen reported yesterday.

Helen Hayes yesterday advised graduating students of the American Academy of Dramatic Arts to turn their backs on Broadway as the first step toward preparing themselves for professional acting careers. Miss Hayes spoke at the graduation exercises of the sixty-fourth year of the academy held on the stage of the Fulton Theatre.

Lingering radioactivity after an atomic bomb burst of any kind can be "cleaned up" by means now available, an official of the United States Atomic Energy Commission declared last night. He addressed the Fortieth Anniversary Conference of the National Society for the Prevention of Blindness at the New Yorker Hotel.
The cotton futures market closed 9 to 18 points net higher yesterday under a moderate volume of business on the New York Cotton Exchange.

The Rev. William Howard Melish, assistant rector of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Holy Trinity in Brooklyn, gave up the chairmanship of the National Council of Soviet-American Friendship last night but remained a member of its board of directors.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- Among the reasons why a bi-partisan coalition has continued to take occasional control of Congress since the New Deal waned is that reorganization of the two major political parties is long overdue. Governor Dewey's recent statement that "the Republican party is split wide open" might accurately have included its chief rival for office.

Two double-feature programs, one from France and the other from Hollywood, arrive in midtown theatres this morning. At the Ambassador, the French-made newcomers are "Rumeurs" and "The Woman Who Dared." Jany Holt and Jacques Dumesnil are starred in "Rumeurs," a drama directed by Jacques Daroy from a story by Simon Gantillon.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 17 -- Reassuring word on the condition of Joe DiMaggio came today in a statement issued by the Yankee management on the authorization of Dr. George E. Bennett of Baltimore, who operated on the Yankee slugger last November for removal of a bone spur in the right heel.

The anti-trust suit brought by the Federal Government against seventeen investment banking firms cost the First Boston Corporation, one of the defendants, more than $100,000 last year and took up much time of senior officers and many employes, James Coggeshall Jr. said yesterday at the annual meeting of the corporation's stockholders.
A plea that families seeking to adopt children accept those who may not be quite perfect was made yesterday by the Rev. George P. Jacoby, executive director of the Catholic Home Bureau.

Thirty-five concert musicians, all of whom were sided in their careers by New York Philharmonic-Symphony Society scholarships, have banded together to revive the scholarship program and offer free training and guidance to promising music students in the New York public schools.

Morris D. Reiss, 63 years old, former Assistant United States Attorney in New York and a former State Assemblyman, fell or jumped to his death yesterday morning from his eighth-floor room in the Pierrepont Hotel, 55 Pierrepont Street, Brooklyn, police of the Poplar Street station reported.

The Realty Advisory Board on Labor Relations and Local 32-B of the Building Service Employes International Union, AFL, have earned public commendation for the orderly manner in which they have settled the wage dispute affecting 25,000 workers in Manhattan office and loft buildings.

The Government may soon permit larger steel exports, by revising controls, Wilson Sweeney, chief, metals and minerals branch, Office of International Trade, Department of Commerce, declared yesterday. He addressed more than 200 executives attending a world trade meeting of the Commerce and Industry Association of New York, Inc., in the Woolworth Building.

The Port of New York Authority's second survey of port rehabilitation is taking much longer to complete than originally expected and will not be ready until the middle of next month, it was reported yesterday. The $114,000,000 plan proposed by the bi-state agency last year is being completely revised, and the report covering it will be a comprehensive work almost as large as the first prospectus, it was said.

In an action of unprecedented scope, Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools, canceled yesterday the unused substitute licenses of 8,000 former teachers who have been inactive in the public schools since September, 1945.
WASHINGTON, March 17 -- During the week ended March 16, member bank reserve balances increased $512,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
H. Freeman Matthews, United States Ambassador to Sweden, Mrs. Matthews and their son, Thomas Matthews, have come to the Drake from Washington for a stay of two weeks.

WASHINGTON, March 17 (AP) -- A demand that the United States and the other wartime Pacific Allies decide promptly "what to do with Japan" was served on the eleven-nation Far Eastern Commission today by the Philippines.
PATCHOGUE, L. I., March 17 -- Ground will be broken May 8 for the proposed new $1,200,000 building for Seton Hall Catholic Co-ed High School, on a twenty-acre tract on Roe Boulevard.

TOKYO, March 17 -- By the time Joseph M. Dodge, president of the Detroit Bank, who is now Gen. Douglas MacArthur's chief economic adviser, is finished with the Japanese budget it is highly unlikely that it will bear much resemblance to the figures already published.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- The Education Policies Commission of the National Education Association announced today that it would publish policy recommendations soon on how United States schools should help "win the cold war against the Soviet Union."

" COMING home was the big thing." That was the dream of the men in the desert, the Air Force men who patrolled in trucks and not in planes, who fought sand and flies and filth and an occasional Bedouin sniper instead of Germans. The dream was of familiar places and beloved faces, of a home in England where green things grew and the rain fell and milk and papers were delivered at the door.

NEWARK N. J., March 17 -- The American worker essentially is in business for himself, it was emphasized here tonight by Crawford H. Greenewalt, president of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc. He spoke at a dinner meeting of more than 650 foremen and other management representatives of four Northern New Jersey du Pont plants in the Robert Treat Hotel.

Secretary of Defense James Forrestal said last night that the strength of America's armed forces was the keystone of a vigorous foreign policy that in the last twelve months alone had vastly increased the outlook for world peace.

PARIS, March 17 -- In a broadcast to the French nation tomorrow night, Foreign Minister Robert A. Schuman will explain the Atlantic pact. His speech will be the beginning of what the Government considers a necessary campaign of education since the French public knows little about the pact as yet save that the Communists have violently attacked.

Because the artist is an important educator, his education must be "both that of a technician and of a citizen," Dr. Irwin Edman, Professor of Philosophy at Columbia University, declared last night at the university's first art forum in the McMillin Academic Theatre.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- Following is the vote by which the Senate approved tonight a compromise change in its rules permitting the "yes" votes of 64 of the 96 members to curb debate on all business except discussion of a proposal to bring up a future rules change.

In a recent editorial THE NEW YORK TIMES correctly criticized the failure of the Federal Administration to reimburse New York State in an amount sufficient to permit adequate administration of the functions of the Division of Placement and Unemployment Insurance.
Spring arrives officially on Sunday, and as if to herald that happy occasion, food markets today offer many of the products associated with the new season.

Niels Groen, Danish-American pianist, made his local debut last night at Town Hall. His program was composed of Mozart's Fantasy in D minor; Bach's English Suite in G minor; Chopin's Sonata in B flat minor; Roy Harris' "Little Suite"; Virgil Thomson's Sonata, No. 4; Paul Bowles' "El Bejuco"; Villa-Lobos' "A Condessa" and Ravel's "Gaspard de la Nuit."

CHICAGO, March 17 -- A nationwide strike, effective March 31, has been voted by Pullman car conductors throughout the country, A. G. Wise, executive vice president of the Order of Railway Conductors, announced today.

LAKE SUCCESS, March 17 -- Secretary General Trygve Lie said today that final Congressional approval of an $8,000,000 advance fund for aid to Palestine refugees had gone a "long way" to assure the success of the whole United Nations relief program.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., March 17 -- The Rev. Morgan J. O'Brien, 43 years old, assistant pastor of St. Bernard's Roman Catholic Church at South Lexington Avenue and Prospect Street, White Plains, died here late this afternoon when his automobile left the Bronx River Parkway, north of Harney Road.

HOUSTON, Tex., March 17 -- Ceremonies formally opening Glenn McCarthy's luxurious new Shamrock Hotel today in Hollywood style were turned into a St. Patrick's Day celebration in which virtually the whole of Houston participated.

MEXICO CITY, March 17 (AP) -- An ingot of uranium, originally believed to have been stolen from a United States atomic laboratory, was declared tonight to be merely refined metal without any explosive power.

PRINCETON, N. J., March 17 -- Forbes Norris Jr., Harvard's Olympic scorer, won the first title of the ninth annual invitation individual championships of the Eastern Intercollegiate Swimming League by capturing the 1,500-meter freestyle test in the good time of 19:40.6 tonight in Princeton's magnificent new Dillon gymnasium pool.

Sales of the J. C. Penney Company last year were up 14.09 per cent or $109,322,546 to a new high of $885,195,137, compared with the $775,872,591 volume for 1947, according to the annual report issued yesterday. At the year end the company was operating 1,601 stores, or two less than a year before.

A refugee Polish tailor, clutching a large oil painting, eagerly scanned the faces of the large crowd of people who waited on Pier 60, North River, yesterday to welcome the arrival of the transport Gen. W. G. Haan with 884 displaced persons -- the largest single shipload to enter the country under the Displaced Persons Act of 1948.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- A bill intended to wipe out any segregation based on "race, color, creed, national derivation or ancestry" existing in the District of Columbia was introduced in the House today by Representative Arthur G. Klein, Democrat, of New York.

PARIS, March 11 -- The speculation that arose after Vyacheslav M. Molotov and Anastas I. Mikoyan were relieved of their specific ministerial duties in the Soviet Council of Ministers has had as a corollary further conjecture concerning the health and position of Prime Minister Stalin.

NANKING, March 17 -- Communist Gen. Lin Piao, whose "Northeast Liberation Army" conquered Manchuria and helped to wrest North China from the National Government, was reported today to have dispatched 100,000 of his seasoned troops southward to join the two major Communist field armies operating in East and Central China.

Richard (Pancho) Gonzales played his first match in the East since he won the national grass court championship and seemed as much at home yesterday on the board courts of the Seventh Regiment Armory as on the turf of Forest Hills.

Senator Herbert R. O'Conor of Maryland expressed the hope last night that the United Nations would devote its attention to Irish affairs, particularly to the present differences arising out of the partition of Ireland.

ALBANY, March 17 -- With the budget out of the way and comparative harmony restored in the ranks of the Republican majorities, Senate and Assembly leaders began today a drive to bring the legislative session to a close within two weeks.

BUENOS AIRES, March 17 -- President Juan Peron this morning administered the oath of fidelity to the new Constitution to his expanded Cabinet. Seventeen men were sworn in at the ceremony. The eighteenth, Jose Maria Freire, Minister of Labor and Social Welware, was ill.

Two of the major transcontinental scheduled airlines announced yesterday coach fares, coast to coast, to compete with the irregulars who have been offering $99 and $88 fares and whose practice of selling them through joint ticket agencies is due to get a "death sentence" from the Civil Aeronautics Board.

Trading on the stock market was highly selective yesterday. Interest was centered in a relatively few issues which advanced as much as 3 points. Prices for the main body of stocks were changed only slightly, with closing levels irregularly higher. Sales rose to 760,000 shares, up 90,000 from Wednesday's level, and final prices were about the best for the day.

DUESSELDORF, March 17 -- With twenty Communist delegates abstaining, deputies of all the other parties in the North Rhine-Westphalia Landtag [state Parliament] today unanimously voted confidence in Minister President Karl Arnold for his handling to date of the western border problems.

WASHINGTON, March 17 (AP) -- Dr. Hans Kindler revealed today, in discussing his resignation as conductor of the National Symphony Orchestra which took effect last night, that he had perpetrated a musical hoax for a year and a half.

CHICAGO, March 17 -- The board of directors of the Radio Manufacturers Association voted today to appoint a committee to make an "objective, constructive and orderly presentation" of engineering and service facts relating to television.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- President Truman reported to Congress today that since the first of the year the tide of battle had been running against the Communist-led guerrillas in the Greek civil war. At the same time he cautioned against any expectation of "a quick and easy victory."

Denouncing the "so-called compromise" agreement to end the filibuster in the United States Senate as capitulation, seven organizations joined yesterday in telegrams to Senator J. Howard McGrath, Democratic National Chairman, Representative Hugh D. Scott Jr., Republican National Chairman, and Senate leaders of both major parties, urging them to use their influence to prevent minority rule in the Senate.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 17 -- Dick Wakefield now bears a suspicious resemblance to a football tackle whose program weight has been slyly faked by his coach. The Red Book has this amiable giant listed at 188 pounds. "You look like an alderman," he was told. "How much do you really weigh?" He patted himself tenderly on his midsection nad grinned engagingly.
MILWAUKEE, March 17 (AP) -- The Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company reported today a profit of $15,441,523 for 1948, compared with $5,422,308 in 1947, a gain of about 184 per cent.

Secretary of Defense James V. Forrestal digressed from his prepared text at last night's dinner of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick to praise Col. Louis Johnson who succeeds him March 31 as head of the National Military Establishment.

Twice a day Capt. Alexander Donnegan of the S. S. John W. Brown shouts "Cast off the lines" and "Half-speed astern." Yet even after more than a year of this the 10,000-ton Liberty ship has not budged from her berth -- and the chances are that she never will.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- The House Foreign Affairs Committee voted today to increase the discretionary authority of Paul G. Hoffman, Economic Cooperation Administrator, in the use of American or foreign flag vessels for Marshall Plan shipments originating in the United States.

LONDON, March 17 -- As a result of Argentina not keeping up with deliveries, Britain's meat ration was cut today to the lowest point since rationing was introduced nine years ago. Beginning March 27 the ration will be less than half of what it was in 1940.
Your editorial in THE TIMES of March 6 titled "Boy's Town of Italy," is commendable. I wonder if you are aware of another Boys' Town movement located at Verden, Germany, in the British zone?

There is every indication that H. Daroff Sons, Inc., will be obliged to continue allocation of its men's clothing lines through 1949, Michael Daroff, president, has informed his salesmen in a letter. Spring orders, he said, were higher than at any time in the company's history and for the fiscal year ending in June, 1949, business is 20 per cent ahead of 1948.

Something of the spirit of adventure of modern childhood disappeared a few days ago when the Travelers Aid Society reported that children who travel nowadays "alone on vacation" do not usually run away -- they just get lost. Perhaps it is true that many a serious would-be runaway has his fill of the wandering life after fifteen minutes "on the road" and hies himself back to the comforts of home.
WASHINGTON, March 17 (AP) -- The House Labor Committee formally recommended a 75-cent national minimum wage today, but said the national economy could stand a much higher one.

The six-story apartment house at 1845 Phelan Place, the Bronx, accommodating eighty-four families, has been sold by Hyman Cooperman and Eli Besen to the Hardel Realty Company. The property, on a plot 100 by 175 feet, was sold subject to a first mortgage of $218,000.

PARIS, March 17 -- The French never have shown enthusiasm for a Western German state. They accepted reluctantly the London agreement for the state's creation, after having argued for postponement until another effort had been made to treat with the Soviet Union.

Subject to confirmation, a deal has been virtually concluded whereby the Shakespeare Festival Company of Stratford-on-Avon will journey to these shores next season under the Theatre Guild's wing. Lawrence Langner, co-administrator of the Guild, said last night it was up to the Guild's board to approve the project.

LONDON, March 17 -- The stock market here today had a much steadier appearance following two days of falling prices. The reason was the cessation of selling, plus the fact that professional bears were not inclined to extend their short commitments for the time being.

Two exhibitions opening this week, the Delius Gallery's group of drawings by European masters, ranging from the high renaissance to the twentieth century, and at the American British Art Center water-colors and drawings from the sketch book of the contemporary Scottish born etcher, James McBey, are of general interest, both for quality and for demonstrating what an important role in European painting has been played by preliminary sketches.

The Tournament of Champions boxing promoting organization enlarged its position on the local pugilistic scene yesterday when its president, David B. Charnay, announced the signing of articles with the New York Giants for the use of the Polo Grounds for at least two years.

The third volume in a history of American contributions to economic thinking by Joseph Dorfman has been scheduled for April 22 publication by the Viking Press. Entitled "The Economic Mind in American Civilization," it deals with the growth of industry and industrial life in the United States from 1865 to 1918. Mr. Dorfman is also the author of "Thorstein Veblen and His America."

With $520,000 at its disposal from state and city funds, the New York City Youth Board plans to start immediately its comprehensive juvenile delinquency program, Nathaniel Kaplan, board chairman, said yesterday.
MONTREAL, March 17 (AP) -- Counting once in each period, the Montreal Canadiens defeated the Toronto Maple Leafs, 3 -- 1, tonight.

KEY WEST, Fla., March 17 -- Two newsreels of President Truman's vacation activities, made from a Navy blimp and confiscated on Monday, were released today after the White House censored twenty-one of a total of 400 feet of film.

FRANKFORT, Germany, March 17 -- A former member of the Nazi party, who was chief architect for many German fairs throughout Europe during the days of the Hitler conquest, was barred from a similar role in the. forthcoming German fair in New York City by direct order of Gen. Lucius D. Clay.

The 200th anniversary of the birth of Johann Wolfgang von Goethe will be marked from June 27 to July 16 with a convocation and music festival at Aspen, Col., in which international scholars and musical artists will participate, it was announced yesterday by the Goethe Bicentennial Foundation.

BERLIN, March 17 -- Anger and distaste for delaying tactics employed by the French in formation of a West German state have reached a climax in top levels of the United States Military Government, and a meeting of the United States, British and French Foreign Ministers is viewed as the only means whereby Western policy on Germany can be coordinated.
WASHINGTON, March 17 (AP) -- An appeal to people's instinct to clean up a debt is helping to speed the wind-up of a former lending agency of the Federal Government, the Home Owners Loan Corporation.

There is little cheer in the annual bulletin, Uniform Crime Reports, issued by the Federal Bureau of Investigation, based on the statistics for 1948. There was an increase, although only a fraction of 1 per cent, in crime in urban areas during the year, but in rural areas the increase was 4.3 per cent over 1947.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 17 -- Warner Brothers has concluded a deal with Burt Lancaster by which the actor will make three pictures for the studio within the next three years. In addition, Lancaster's own independent company, Norma Productions, in which he is associated with Harold Hecht, will make three pictures for Warner release in partnership with the studio.
WASHINGTON, March 17 -- Preston Delano, Controller of the Currency, announced today that the total assets of national banks on Dec. 31, 1948, amounted to more than $88,000,000,000.

More interesting to horsemen than the latest best seller is the condition book, fresh off the press, which covers the first fourteen days of the Metropolitan Jockey Club's race meeting at the Jamaica track. New York's 196-day season opens two weeks from today; the pages of the first condition book are now being thumbed by owners, trainers, jockey agents and others who will help to put on the shows.

AUGUSTA, Ga., March 17 (AP) -- Two women golf stars from the Far West, Mrs. Babe Zaharias and Miss Dot Kielty, came to the Deep South today to take the lead after the first round of the titleholders tournament with two-under-par 73s.

Most of the furniture designed in this country today appears to be a personal expression of the designer, reflecting his individual reaction to such influences as Russia and the atomic bomb, according to Neil Morris, furniture manufacturer of Glasgow, Scotland. Mr. Morris sailed for home yesterday on the Queen Mary after a honeymoon in Bermuda and a flying tour of American furniture markets.

Business loans by banks in this area have declined for the third successive week and the total of $5,534,000,000 now outstanding is the smallest thus far in 1949. According to the data issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, covering the week ended on Wednesday, repayments by oil companies, meat packers and chain stores were the principal factors in the latest decline of $36,000,000.

EVANSTON, Ill., March 17 -- More than half of the country's increasing juvenile delinquency is "drink-caused or initiated," Mrs. D. Leigh Colvin, president of the National Woman's Christian Temperance Union, said today in urging zoning to prevent alcoholic beverage sales in residential neighborhoods.

BERLIN, March 17 -- Gen. Lucius D. Clay, United States Military Governor, has reaffirmed one of the death sentences passed on twelve German soldiers involved in the Malmedy massacres of United States troops and has commuted another to life imprisonment.
COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo., March 17 (AP) -- Dartmouth's Indians opened the National Collegiate A. A. hockey tournament tonight by upsetting Michigan, defending champions, 4 -- 2.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- The text of the North Atlantic defense pact will be released for publication at 11 A. M. tomorrow, the State Department announced today. Secretary of State Acheson will meet with reporters at 9 A. M. to answer questions about it.

JERSEY CITY, N. J., March 17 -- John V. Kenny, former political lieutenant of ex-Mayor Frank Hague and since last fall an opponent of the Hague Democratic machine, announced today a full slate of candidates for the City Commission election here next May 10.

ROME, Friday, March 18 -- Strikes, rioting and other disturbances broke out in several places yesterday while the Chamber of Deputies, whose debate on the Atlantic Pact has been prolonged by a Communist filibuster, was well into its second day of continuous sitting.
BRUSSELS, March 17 -- Almost unnoticed either inside or outside the country, Belgium has just taken two daring steps toward making the Belgian franc fully convertible national currency.

RHODES, March 17 -- Syria, last of Israel's neighbors still standing aloof from armistice talks, has dropped her previous refusal and agreed to accept the invitation of Dr. Ralph J. Bunche, Acting United Nations Mediator for Palestine, to open negotiations, it was learned tonight from a competent source.

The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People moved yesterday to bar left-wing groups from a conference today at which the association will press its fight against Federal Housing Administration policies.

LONDON, March 17 -- The freight war which hitherto has been confined to services between Continental European ports and India, Pakistan and Ceylon, is now being carried to the United Kingdom by the United Netherlands Navigation Company.

A home - study center to aid children with their homework was described yesterday by Mary Webber, General Electric home lighting specialist. She spoke at a meeting of the Residence Lighting Forum in the GE auditorium, 570 Lexington Avenue.

LONDON, March 17 (AP) -- Israeli sources here denounced the action as "virtual annexation" of Arab Palestine by Transjordan. King Abdullah of Transjordan has been urged by groups of Palestine Arabs to extend his kingdom to take in those areas in the Holy Land outside the boundaries of Israel.

BOSTON, March 18 (AP) -- The New England Telephone and Telegraph Company today lost its plea for a $10,000,000 rate increase to the Massachusetts Public Utilities Commission. The board also denied the company's request that a temporary $5,000,000 increase granted in 1947 be made permanent, but it gave the company the right to make certain other changes in its rate structure to make up for the loss of the temporary rise.

A news story published in THE NEW YORK TIMES on March 4 refers to an article by Prof. Solomon Zeitlin of Dropsie College, Philadelphia, questioning the antiquity of the ancient Hebrew scrolls which were recently discovered by Bedouins in a cave in the Judaean desert.

The formation of an organization to check Government control of business at the state and Federal levels was suggested by James A. Fulton, president of the Home Life Insurance Company, at the annual conference of the New York State Society of Real Estate Appraisers yesterday at the Hotel Astor.
For the third year in succession, Fordham Prep captured the Athletic Association of Private Schools swimming championship by scoring 38 points in the competition at the New York A.C. pool last night.

In keeping with the democratic tradition which pays decent respect to the opinions of mankind and calls for open covenants openly arrived at, the Western Powers now submit the text of the momentous North Atlantic Security Pact to the judgment of their own peoples and of the world.

Miss Louise Arner Boyd, explorer, writer and lecturer, added another decoration to her long list yesterday when she received the Department of Army "Certificate of Appreciation." Maj. Gen. Roscoe B. Woodruff, commander of the First Army, made the presentation in his office at Governors Island.

OAK RIDGE, Tenn. March 18 -- This city that cradled the atomic age will be formally separated tomorrow from the security area surrounding the nuclear fission plants, and its gates will be thrown open to the public for the first time in colorful ceremonies.

BRUSSELS, March 18 -- Commenting on the North Atlantic defense pact. Prime Minister Paul-Henri Spaak said today that for the first time in diplomatic history a text has been published to be discussed by the press and public opinion before being signed by the governments concerned.
WASHINGTON, March 18 -- Dr. Earl G. McGrath assumed the duties of Commissioner of Education today with a warning that our schools "can only go forward with the aid of Federal support."

GUAM, Saturday, March 19 (AP) -- The Governor of Guam today ousted thirty-four members of the Guamanian lower house who walked out early this month in a revolt against the United States Navy administration.

Support mounted yesterday for Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. in his candidacy for the Democratic nomination for Representative in the Twentieth Congressional District to fill the vacancy caused by the death of Sol Bloom.

Fifty-three displaced persons from resettlement camps in Eu rope who will live permanently in the United States arrived at La Guardia Airport yesterday aboard a chartered American Overseas Airlines plane from Hamburg. Several hours after their arrival they were on their way to their new homes and places of employment in cities and rural areas throughout the country.

Fred Allen has signed a contract which commits his services in both radio and television for next season exclusively to the National Broadcasting Company. The information was released jointly yesterday by Mr. Allen and Niles Trammell, president of NBC.
PARIS, March 18 -- Explaining the North Atlantic pact, in a broadcast to the nation tonight Foreign Minister Robert Schuman said:

Pointing out that observance of fair trade practice rules simultaneously provided opportunity for all competitors to start on an even footing, Harold L. Briggs of the Federal Trade Commission yesterday called upon handkerchief manufacturers and distributors to cooperate in maintaining the fair trade code for the handkerchief industry.
OTTAWA, Ont., March 18 (Canadian Press) -- The Canadian National Railways had in 1948 a deficit of $33,527,741, it was shown in the company's annual report tabled today in the House of Commons.

BERWICK, Pa., March 18 (UP) -- A "caterpillar" train, built secretly for Spain and which may revolutionize passenger train construction, struck an automobile at a grade crossing near here today during a trial run.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- The Senate passed, and sent to the House today, a bill to establish a national science foundation. As proposed, the organization would stimulate and coordinate basic research under a progressive national policy of scientific development.

Prices in the New York Stock Exchange yesterday reverted to the irregularly lower trend that was interrupted on Thursday. A few selected issues were strong, but losses of small fractions predominated. Trading was at a slow pace, with sales totaling 670,000 shares, compared with 760,000 shares the day before.

ALBANY, March 18 -- The State Department of Taxation and Finance faces the problem of making tax refunds to more than 100,000 taxpayers whose returns were filed before the Legislature determined the personal income tax rate on 1948 income.

Edward J. Shaughnessy, special assistant to the Commissioner of Immigration and Naturalization, appointed this week as director of the New York immigration district, will begin his dual role on Monday.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- Average primary market prices declined 0.3 per cent in the week ended March 15, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The index stood at 158.5 per cent of the 1926 average, the same level as four weeks ago, and 2 per cent less than the corresponding week in 1948.
Only two days before the arrival of spring, March was still roaring like a lion yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, March 18 -- Warren R. Austin, United States representative to the United Nations, said today that "the North Atlantic pact is an historic move toward peace taken within the concept of the United Nations."

BERLIN, March 18 -- Eastern Germany's Communist-dominated People's Council today invited the principal political and economic leaders of Western Germany to meet April 8 in Brunswick in the British zone and plan German unity.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- The Senate unanimously passed and sent to the White House today a bill to authorize a radar network and air-control system as the basic element of defense against possible attack by air.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- Lieut. Gen. Sir Gerald Templer and Gen. J. Lawton Collins, vice chiefs respectively of the British Imperial General Staff and of the United States Army General Staff, will be this year's exchange lecturers under the terms of the Kermit Roosevelt Fund, the Army said here tonight.

The Highway Commission of New Jersey has purchased for $225,000 eight acres of land in a thirty-two-acre tract on Belleville Avenue, adjoining the Third River, Bloomfield, N. J., for the proposed Route 4 Parkway, it was learned yesterday.
BUDAPEST, Hungary, March 18 (AP) -- The Hungarian Government charged today that "official American attitude towards Hungary has been aggressive lately."
LONDON, March 18 -- The stock markets here today staged a bright finish to what had been a difficult week.

A joint protest against the transfer of control of nine C-4 type emergency class passenger vessels from the Maritime Commission to the Army will be made to President Truman on Monday by steamship management and maritime labor, it was made known yesterday.

Two new films will open here today. "Impact," story of a business leader who begins a new life under an assumed name in a small town, will be presented at the Globe. Brian Donlevy plays the lead role, assisted by Ella Raines, Charles Coburn, Helen Walker and Anna May Wong. . . . The newcomer at the Mayfair is "The Last Bandit," a Western melodrama featuring William Elliott, Adrian Booth and Forrest Tucker.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., March 18 (AP) -- Cary Middlecoff, hottest golfer on the tour, and E. J. (Dutch) Harrison, also of the top five money winners, blasted six under par 66's for the first round lead in the Jacksonville open today.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 18 -- Peter Stambolitch, Premier of Serbia and secretary of the Yugoslav Politburo, told the Serbian Youth Congress yesterday that leaders of the Communist Information Bureau were "losing their nerve" in the fight against Yugoslavia and were therefore "using all kinds of means to disturb the development of socialism in our country."
Federal Judge Harold R. Medina told the jury in the trial of the eleven Communist leaders yesterday to report directly to him any attempts at jury-tampering.

FRANKFORT, Germany, March 18 -- Western German reaction to the North Atlantic defense pact was marked by open recognition of the great step that the United States was taking in assuming the role as leader in a Western defense system.

NANKING, March 18 (UP) -- The Control Yuan, a division of the Government with powers of audit and impeachment, today demanded legal prosecution of former Premier Sun Fo for alleged misappropriation of public funds.

WASHINGTON, March 18 (AP) -Railroad operating revenues were estimated today to have declined 6.8 per cent in February, as compared with the same month in 1948. The Association of American j Railroads, which issued the figures, said they were based on advance reports from representative Class I carriers.
PARIS, March 18 -- Depending upon his politics, the average European's reaction to the terms of the North Atlantic defense pact can be described as relief, fear or fury.

The board of managers of the Missionary Education Movement of the United States and Canada, composed of representatives of thirty Protestant denominations, voted last night to join in a merger of Protestant forces in a proposed National Council of the Churches of Christ in the United States of America. Their meeting was at the Presbyterian Labor Temple, 242 East Fourteenth Street. It was one of several sessions started Thursday, which will end Monday.

San Francisco, without a senior on the squad, and Loyola of Chicago, neither of which figured to survive, will clash tonight at Madison Square Garden for top honors in the twelfth national invitation college basketball tournament. Loyola's Ramblers from Chicago are favored to win by a 2 1/2-point margin.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 18 -- Paramount today named William Holden to replace Montgomery Clift as leading man in the forthcoming "Sunset Boulevard," a film about Hollywood in which Gloria Swanson, Erich Von Stroheim and Nancy Olson will also appear.

Classes were canceled yesterday at Julia Richmond High School, 317 East Sixty-seventh Street, but the 4,000 students reported just the same. Even the falling snow failed to dampen the festive spirit, and students and teachers of the all-girl institution introduced the spring season with a colorful "International Fair."

The annual nation-wide campaign of the United Jewish Appeal has special significance this year because its success will bring closer the solving of the problem of the homelessness of large numbers of people. In 1948 the Appeal raised $150,000,000. This year it aims at a goal of $250,000,000 for mass migration and settlement in Israel, rehabilitation in Europe and North Africa and refugee adjustment in the United States.

Decorative figurines and serving pieces dating from the times when Europeans were fascinated by Chinese wares and factories had the patronage of noblemen are included in the exhibit, "Masterpieces of European Porcelain," which opened yesterday at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Most of the 500 pieces on view, which are lavish in detail and decoration, reflect the American collector's particular interest in figurines.

A three-point program for action by Protestant churches on resettlement of displaced persons arriving in this country was presented yesterday to the Protestant Council of New York by Dr. Roland Elliott. director of the Department of Displaced Persons of Church World Service.

The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was quiet yesterday, and final prices were 3 points higher to 5 points lower. The market opened 1 to 7 points lower on some Southern selling but steadied on trade demand and lack of offerings.

Defense Secretary Forrestal's announcement of consolidation of public information functions for all armed service branches under an assistant in his office who is to be responsible only to him should help to control some of the inter-service rivalries that have plagued attempts at unification.

CHICAGO, March 18 -- Edwin G. Nourse, chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, expressed today his "belief that we may, through the process of intelligent diagnosis of business conditions and economic needs, formulate and execute policies and programs to prolong our period of economic health."

HOUSTON, March 18 -- Summer T. Pike, a member of the Atomic Energy Commission, today dismissed as illogical and unnecessary the idea that Americans must abandon their accepted way of life and alter all their plans for the future because of the possibility of an atomic attack.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- The North Atlantic treaty text received a generally friendly reception in the Senate today, but storm signals were flying for the parallel program for United States aid to rearm Western European nations.

WELLESLEY, Mass., March 18 -- A plea for "moral competence" to control the tools and weapons of "this age of scientific progress" was made today by Dr. Edmund Sinnott, director of the Sheffield Scientific School of Yale University.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- The Baltimore and Ohio Railroad was actually responsible for the bizarre robbery on one of its express trains March 9 in West Virginia, the mother of one of the two youthful gunmen asserted today.

ALBANY, March 18 -- In an effort to defeat the administration's sickness-benefit program, which would involve a payroll tax on employers and employes, several upstate Republican legislators are urging that it be considered at Republican Senate and Assembly conferences before being brought to a vote.

LONDON, March 18 -- An attempt by the Conservative party to capture some of the mass trade union support of the Labor Government in the next general election was forecast today at the final session of the two-day annual meeting of the Conservative Central Council.

CLEVELAND, March 18 (AP) -- Richard (Boo) Morcom, former New Hampshire star competing for the Boston Athletic Association, cleared 14 feet 9 inches in the pole vault tonight at the ninth annual Knights of Columbus track meet -- the best mark of the indoor season.
ALBANY, March 18 -- Governor Dewey signed a bill today that changes the qualifications for certified psychologists as well as the method of certification.
LONG BEACH, Calif., March 18 -- A fracas among crew members disrupted the sailing of the freighter Marymar last night and brought an emergency call to the Coast Guard to help quell a "mutiny."

Glaucoma, a hardening of the eyeballs that may cause blindness, appears to affect about one person out of sixty over the age of 40 years, according to a survey reported yesterday morning before the National Society for the Prevention of Blindness, meeting at the New Yorker Hotel.

An official continuing body to carry on activities of the World Council of Churches, organized last August in Amsterdam, the Netherlands, will be formed next week at a meeting of more than seventy-five World Council delegates from Protestant and Eastern Orthodox Churches in the United States.

If the American reporter turned on his own country the same detached, quizzical and probing scrutiny he turns on other countries, perhaps he would have a clearer view of the United States and what's happening here. The observer abroad is conscious of the limitations of his knowledge and experience.
