CHICAGO, March 18 -- The officers and negotiating committee of Chicago Typographical Union No. 16 will "unanimously recommend rejection" of the entire final contract proposal made by the Chicago Newspaper Publishers Association for settlement of the sixteen-month, newspaper strike, John J. Pilch, Local 16 president, has disclosed.
MOSCOW, March 18 -- The Soviet press today editorially noted the thirtieth anniversary of the Bolshevik party's Eighth Congress, whose 1919 program was described as having now been fulfilled.

Plans for continuation of the Advertising Council's campaign on the economic system beyond the current initial series of advertisements will be prepared in a new campaign guide to be issued later this year, it was learned yesterday. The council's new retail advisory committee is working on a program for more extensive promotion of the system campaign.

The various divisions of the Coast Guard deal with the shipping industry and allied fields on a daily basis. Merchant marine inspection, safety, navigation, ship standards, the signing on and off of crews that man the ships -- these and other functions mean constant contact and require visits to headquarters by shipping men and vessel personnel.
FORT DIX, N. J., March 18 -- The "Three R's" have been combined with reveille, retreat and KP at this historic Army camp.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- Moshe Sharett, Foreign Minister of Israel, advocated at a news conference today placing the Old City of Jerusalem under international control through a United Nations trusteeship. The New City, he declared, would remain Israeli in sovereignty.

New flatware patterns and a few pieces of holloware selected from leading silversmiths and manufacturers in this country and abroad will be introduced Monday at Altman's. In addition to the display, the store will play host to three silver craftsmen who will demonstrate the arts of hand chasing, die cutting and engraving during the week.

SEOUL, Korea, March 18 -- All available facilities and detectives of the capital police force were ordered today by President Syngman Rhee to investigate the murder yesterday of Mrs. Horace H. Underwood, wife of a prominent United States educator and missionary.

PARIS, March 18 -- Charges that the French were using delaying tactics to prevent formation of a West German state met with a denial here today in official quarters, which deprecated that such charges should be made.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- The Government of Israel plans to "tax its population to the limit" and to introduce a regime of "strict austerity" in order to facilitate large-scale immigration and agricultural and industrial expansion, Prime Minister David Ben Gurion said today in a statement to the United Jewish Appeal.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson held a press conference on the North Atlantic pact this morning. Reporters' questions and Mr. Acheson's replies (which the State Department does not permit to be quoted directly) follow:

Stephen J. Halsey Junior High School, first school unit to be started in Queens under the Board of Education's post-war building program, was dedicated yesterday at a ceremony attended by 600 pupils, parents and civic leaders. The school, which cost $2,464,000, is at Sixty-fourth Avenue and 102d Street, Flushing.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- Two of its examiners today recommended to the Interstate Commerce Commission that it approve a lease of the Wheeling Lake Erie Railway Company to the New York, Chicago St. Louis (Nickel Plate) Railway Company, which controls the Wheeling through ownership of about 80 per cent of its outstanding capital stock.

RHODES, March 18 -- Israeli-Transjordanian armistice talks have been adjourned until Monday while both sides consult their Governments on "an agreed list of all outstanding questions," it was announced tonight.

"In 1948 the excess of income over expenses for the six months' period [from July 1 to the end of the year] was $7,016,144. In 1947 there was a $14,860,639 loss." This in brief, including net gain in fare revenue at an annual rate of $76,653,762, is what the first six months of the ten-and-seven-cent fare has meant to the city.

Carlos Guimard of Buenos Aires, Argentina's international chess ace and former national champion, took the lead among the eighteen experts competing in the annual tournament when he won his third-round game yesterday from Pedro Martin, another Argentinian, according to a report from Mar del Plata. Martin was outplayed positionally in a French defense, adopted by Guimard, and resigned after forty moves.

ALBANY, March 18 -- A proposed revision of the mortgage tax law that might have cost New York City a $3,500,000 annual loss of revenue has been recalled from Governor Dewey by the Senate. Previously it had been approved by Senate and Assembly.

Clendenin J. Ryan created a furor yesterday when after a brief appearance before the grand jury he told reporters that he had "recommended" to an Assistant District Attorney, in the presence of the jurors, that Mayor O'Dwyer be indicted as a way out of the wiretapping "mess" for the prosecutor.

A new English translation of the most important works of Johann Wolfgang von Goethe, to be issued in a ten-volume edition, has been arranged by the Goethe Bicentennial Foundation. The first volume, containing "Werther," "The Elective Affinities," "The Tales of German Refugees," "Parable" and "Novelle," is planned for issuance this summer at the time of the international Goethe Convocation and Music Festival at Aspen, Col.
The vote just taken by the House Education and Labor Committee approving a 75-cent minimum wage is, at long last, some indication that at least part of the Fair Deal program may soon be enacted.

The Collegiate Chorale, under Robert Shaw, gave its annual sponsors' concert last night at Carnegie Hall. For the event, the conductor had arranged a carefully chosen program which afforded sharp contrasts, covered a wide range of styles and featured the premiere of Peter Mennin's Symphony No. 4, "The Cycle."

Judge Harold M. Kennedy in Federal Court, Brooklyn, reserved decision yesterday on four petitions of intervention filed in behalf of three organizations and a Long Island community in connection with the reorganization of the Long Island Rail Road. A fifth petition, filed in behalf of Nassau County by Marcus G. Christ, county attorney, was denied by the court.

Today's events: "Rigoletto" at 2 o'clock, and "La Traviata" at 8:30, Metropolitan Opera; Boston Symphony, Serge Koussevitzky, conductor, Carnegie Hall, 2:30; Sheila Minzer, piano, Town Hall, 3; Gloria Strassner, 'cello, Brooklyn Museum, 2; Carlton Gauld, baritone, and Alice Krieger, piano, Music School Settlement, 5.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 18 (AP) -- The confidential poll Dixie Walker is taking among National League players on how they feel about baseball's reserve clause won't be tabulated for at least two weeks, and results probably won't be released even then.
The short interest in listed stocks traded on the New York Stock Exchange increased 123,473 shares in the month through March 15, to 1,343,759 shares, it was reported yesterday.
VERO BEACH, Fla., March 18 -- It became obvious today that Branch Rickey didn't fly out to Hollywood, Calif., just to look after the needs of that Pacific Coast League club, a new Brooklyn farm.

Retail sales of major appliances increased slightly this week for the first time in more than four months, local buyers reported yesterday. They said that volume is about 5 per cent ahead of last week but emphasized it is still well behind the comparable week last year.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- Benjamin Bogan, vice president of the Conde Nast Publishing Company today suggested to the House Post Office and Civil Service Committee that, if rates on second-class mail (periodicals and newspapers) must be raised, the increase be made possibly 5 per cent a year for each of five successive years.

Although sales of the Electric Storage Battery Company and its subsidiaries reached a new high record of $105,549,765 last year, an increase of 17 per cent over the 1947 volume of $78,792,775, earnings were slightly lower, according to the annual report issued yesterday.
A sustained interest in purchases of residential properties in Queens and other sections of Long Island is reported by Butterly Green, real estate brokers of Jamaica.
The National Labor Relations Board announced yesterday that Local 1250, Department Store Employes Union, independent, had won the right to represent the workers of the Namm store in Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- As a result of the two weeks "memorial" coal stoppage called by John L. Lewis, the possibility of forming a permanent nation-wide bituminous coal operators organization to deal with the demands of the United Mine Workers is being discussed in coal circles.

The four-story apartment building at 51-04 Skillman Avenue, Long Island City, Queens, has been purchased by Adolf Schauer from Mary Coles. The property, on a plot 100 by 113 feet, is assessed at $130,000. Louis Carreau, Inc., and Louis Beritella were the brokers. Title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.

All segments of the liquor industry -- distillers, wholesalers, retailers and law enforcement officials -- voiced strong approval here yesterday for a bill now before the state legislature calling for a single price book for the industry. The book is intended to clarify current "price confusion" resulting from frequent price changes under Fair Trade laws here.

Dr. Hans Kindler, former conductor of the National Symphony Orchestra in Washington, sailed on the Swedish American liner Gripsholm yesterday on a tour of the music centers of Europe that will take him behind the "iron curtain" to Budapest, Hungary.
WASHINGTON, March 18 (AP) -- Poland's first withdrawal of gold from the United States in more than a year was reported by the Census Bureau today.

In THE TIMES of March 7 Sidney Hook, discussing the case of a professor at Oregon State University, makes a controversial observation. Taking issue with the action of the president of that institution, Professor Hook says of the dismissed instructor: "* * * if he has pitted his own independent judgment against the weight of scientific evidence, then, even if he is a thousand times wrong, he must be protected against dismissal."
The city's new Department of Traffic Engineering has been unable to hire a single assistant or junior engineer since it was set up by local laws seven weeks ago, it was reported yesterday.
HALLANDALE, Fla., March 18 (AP) -- With the favored Ramadan last in the field of six, Cer Vantes breezed to a five-length score in today's Alhambra Purse at Gulfstream Park.

Retail sales declined sharply during the week in comparison with the week before Easter last year, according to estimates made here yesterday. Department store sales here were believed to be about 22 per cent below the corresponding week last year, which was the second week before Easter.

NANKING, March 18 -- The Chinese Communists, lining up again behind their party comrades in Europe, hailed Premier Stalin tonight as "the great leader of mankind fighting for peace" and accused the United States of trying to provoke a world war by the formation of the North Atlantic pact.

More than 300 foods prepared according to Hebraic tradition and dietary laws will be offered in the Passover department that opens on Monday at Macy's. Several new items will appear on the shelves this year, the forty-second that the store has set aside a section of one floor for the festive foods of the Jewish holiday.

Hotel reservations for delegates to the first convention to be held by Rotary International in this city were drawn by lot yesterday at the headquarters of the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau, Inc., at 500 Park Avenue, to assure those coming from distant points of accommodations during the week of June 12.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- Lieut. Gen. Walter Bedell Smith, who wishes to retire as our ambassador to Russia, may return to that post temporarily, a usually well informed source said tonight. The same person indicated that it was possible that Ambassador Smith would become Chief of Staff of the Army after finally being relieved of the Moscow post.
WASHINGTON, March 18 -- Five exporting and forty-one importing nations today agreed upon a wheat treaty that will cover 450,000,000 bushels annually for four years and will not include Soviet Russia.
WASHINGTON, March 18 (AP) -- Better law enforcement against drunken drivers was demanded today by the National Committee for Traffic Safety.

The secret of the atomic structure of protein molecules, the basic building blocks of living substance, will be solved "within the next decade or two," it was asserted last night by Prof. Linus Pauling, president of the American Chemical Society, one of the world's outstanding chemists.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- Theodore W. Kheel, former director of the New York City Division of Labor Relations, urged the House Labor Committee today to avoid writing into law rigid procedures for settling labor disputes, and termed the 80-day provision of the Taft-Hartley Act an "irritant."

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- The official text of the North Atlantic Treaty was published today. The pact proposed a defensive twenty-year alliance between North America and Western Europe, designed to prevent war from starting and to meet it with all due constitutional haste if it comes.

At its downtown playhouse, 159 Bleecker Street, New Stages, Inc., will offer tomorrow evening its third production of the season. It is Barrie Stavis' "The Sun and I," a comedy by the same author whose "Lamp at Midnight" gave the company its start two years ago.

Driven aground by a northeast wind in zero visibility conditions at 11 A. M. yesterday, the 7,176-ton freighter Christian Bergh was refloated last night in a blinding snowstorm. The vessel was refloated with the help of a salvage tug from Merritt, Chapman Scott.
LONDON, March 18 (AP) -- The official Yugoslav news agency repudiated tonight statements attributed to Dr. Ales Bebler, Deputy Foreign Minister of Yugoslavia, in a London interview.
The Provident Loan Society is a charitable institution and entitled to exemption from real estate taxes, Supreme Court Justice Benjamin F. Schreiber ruled yesterday.

Agitation for extension of the five-hour trading session on the New York Stock Exchange to 4 P. M. has prompted Emil Schram, its president, to appoint a committee to study the question, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- The Senate's machinery, clogged by the civil rights filibuster since Feb. 28, began to mesh again today, but appeared to be heading back toward new and almost immediate controversy.
Cardinal Spellman, who personally led seminary students across picket lines to dig graves at Calvary Cemetery in Queens, has sent individual $65 checks to 275 strikers, now back at work.

OTTAWA, March 18 -- Prime Minister Louis St. Laurent laid the text of the proposed North Atlantic defense pact on the table of the House of Commons this morning and said he hoped it would be possible to discuss it briefly and obtain the approval of the House before the final meeting and signature in Washington early in April.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- The Czechoslovak Embassy criticized the State Department today for its attitude toward the Cultural and Scientific Conference for World Peace that will be held in New York from March 25 to 27.

TOKYO, March 18 -- Eight of the most powerful unions of Japanese Government employes have decided to carry on a joint campaign to defeat the plans of the conservative government of Premier Shigeru Yoshida to streamline the overstaffed public services by mass discharges, it became known today.
WASHINGTON, March 18 -- The text of the North Atlantic security alliance, to be signed here the first week in April:

In line with the fourth point of President Truman's inaugural address, Paul G. Hoffman. European Cooperation Administrator, yesterday called for European Marshall Plan countries to intensify activities in the field of colonial development.
WASHINGTON, March 18 -- Following is the text of Secretary of State Acheson's nation-wide radio address last night as recorded and transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

LAKE SUCCESS, March 18 -- The eighth and probably most acrid session to date of the United Nations Economic and Social Council ended tonight with the Council's president, James Thorn of New Zealand, expressing an appeal and hope for "common sense and sweet reason" in the future around the international table.

The Railway Express Agency filed yesterday a $5,000,000 damage suit against the Brotherhood of Railway and Steamship Clerks, AFL, charging that the union's slowdown strike had cost at least that much in lost business.

New York University's squad led a strong field for three-weapon honors as the first half of the fifty-second Intercollegiate Fencing Association championships was completed in the City College gymnasium last night.

John J. McQuade, who had completed fifty years as an employe of Brooklyn Supreme Court, received a leather-bound scroll bearing more than 300 signatures in commemoration of the event at a ceremony in Justice Michael F. Walsh's part of the Supreme Court.

Wool futures recovered yesterday a large part of their losses of Thursday. Reflecting partly short covering, wool top contracts closed at net gains of 3.5 to 6.5 cents a pound in sales of 1,000,000 pounds. Grease wool futures finished at net advances of 2.5 to 3.6 cents a pound, with transactions amounting to 480,000 pounds.

The Federal Housing Administration lacks the powers to bring builders to terms with Negro buyers on FHA-backed projects, Thomas G. Grace, state director, told a protesting group yesterday in a discussion of the Levittown, L. I., race discrimination problem.
If you are not planning to do any crow shooting this spring, this is as good a time as any to send your shotgun to the gunsmith or back to the factory for check-up, overhaul and necessary repairs.

A police emergency squad worked for almost an hour yesterday afternoon to extricate a 46-year-old man pinned in the wreckage of his auto after the vehicle had smashed into a parked heavy oil truck in the factory section of south Brooklyn.

Booths hung with rare hand-woven coverlets and hooked rugs provide settings for old-time furnishings at the New York Antiques Exposition, which opened yesterday afternoon at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

THE Russians, Robert Magidoff says in his informing new book, "In Anger and Pity,"* have a magnificent sense of humor. A good many of their desperate jests seem to be based on the Five-Year Plan. Which Five-Year Plan? Oh, any of those glittering totalitarian promises to supply pie in the sky -- five years from a given moment.

LONDON, March 18 -- In "Adventure Story," Terence Rattigan has written his most ambitious play -- about the rise and decline of Alexander the Great. The first-night audience in St. James' Theatre gave it an enthusiastic reception last night but newspaper critics today were inclined to think Rattigan hadn't quite pulled it off.
KEY WEST, Fla., March 18 -- President Truman said today that he would have Winston Churchill, wartime Prime Minister of Great Britain, as a luncheon or dinner guest sometime this month.

SPRING VALLEY, N. Y., March 18 -- Two months and thirteen days ago a short, husky man pulled a screen from a window on the ground floor of the Bader Hotel here. He opened the window, crawled through, replaced the screen and closed the window.

PHILADELPHIA, March 18 -- Judge Curtis Bok in Quarter Sessions Court dismissed today the commonwealth's case against five central city book dealers accused of violating a Pennsylvania law banning the sale of obscene literature.

A $50 fine and a suspended six-month workhouse sentence were imposed yesterday by Chief Magistrate Edgar Bromberger in Probation Court on the parents of a 15-year-old student at Walton High School in the Bronx, where the pupils went on strike last week.

While playing baseball in Central Park on Thursday, five 15-year-old boys were attacked by a gang of fifteen hoodlums, who beat one of the boys unconscious and injured another, according to their mothers.
WASHINGTON, March 18 (AP) -- Bleriot H. Lamarre, who first gave false testimony and then helped to send Maj. Gen. Bennett E. Meyers to jail, will not have to serve prison time for his perjury.

LONDON, March 18 -- The Atlantic pact was hailed here today with more fervor and hope than any agreement in the memory of living men. From Foreign Secretary Bevin, who spoke in Parliament and in a broadcast to the nation, to the humblest British citizen it seemed to bring the first genuine promise of peace in our time.
WASHINGTON, March 18 -- Speakers at the first National Congress of Private Schools today opposed Federal aid to education and praised the private enterprise system.

HARTFORD, Conn., March 18 -- Governor Chester Bowles proposed today that New England industry help finance unionism in the south to assist New England in protecting itself "against competition from sweatshop operators."

One of the most important jobs set for this Legislative session by Governor Dewey is to bring some order and uniformity out of the local building codes in the state, as an encouragement to economy and efficiency in home construction. Everybody pays lip service to the need for code modernization, but as soon as anybody tries to do something about it one vested interest and another begin to be heard from.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 18 -- The essential elements in advertising managements' problems in a buyer's market are no different than those in any kind of market it was emphasized here today by Marion Harper Jr., president of McCann-Erickson, Inc.

TRENTON, N. J., March 18 -- While juvenile delinquency in New Jersey has decreased "quantitatively," the types of offenses being committed are more serious, it was revealed today by Douglas H. MacNeil, director of the state's delinquency prevention program.
WASHINGTON, March 18 -- Federal aid to education, one of the main points of President Truman's legislative program, was approved today by the Senate Labor and Public Welfare Committee.

Lee Oma, heavyweight veteran from Detroit, had just the merest bit of trouble with Omelio Agramonte of Cuba in the main bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden last night. Oma won the unanimous decision, and he deserved it.

PRINCETON, N. J., March 18 -- One meet record was broken and another was tied tonight, as the ninth annual invitation individual championships of the Eastern Intercollegiate Swimming League got into full swing before a crowded gallery at Princeton's magnificent new Dillon Gymnasium pool.

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 18 -- The Giants today engaged the tail end of the American League, but this in no way prevented Leo Durocher's Polo Grounders from putting on another amazing show of their peculiar talents.

KEY WEST, Fla., March 18 -- Despite the rebuffs he has received in Congress this week, President Truman declared today that he was determined as well as hopeful that his "Fair Deal" program would be enacted.

There is no doubt that the hardest of the Wagner operas to produce with the needed atmosphere and nuance is "Parsifal." The performance last night at the Metropolitan had as its principal virtues the highly intelligent and expressive Parsifal of Charles Kullman, the singing of Kundry's music by Rose Bampton and the dramatic Klingsor of Gerhard Pechner. Other important roles were done in very mediocre fashion.
CLEVELAND, March 18 -- Shock waves, once considered the chief obstacle to supersonic flight by man, now are being put to work to give jet aircraft much greater efficiency.
Transportation is "the Achilles heel" of Alaska. It is conspicuous by its absence.

BOSTON, March 18 (AP) -- The Boston Celtics made their last home start in the Basketball Association of America a winning one tonight by turning back the New York Knickerbockers, 70 -- 56, before 1,965, the smallest crowd of the season.
ROME, March 18 -- The Chamber of Deputies confirmed its confidence in Premier Alcide de Gasperi's government and authorized it to negotiate Italy's adherence to the Atlantic pact by

Opposition to the bill which has passed the State Senate and is now being considered by the Assembly, creating a state mental hygiene commission, seems to indicate a difference of opinion as to who should plan for a state-wide program and how funds should be spent.
SARASOTA, Fla., March 18 -- For the beating they absorbed at the hands of Joe McCarthy's Red Sox last Monday, the Yankees today got a full measure of revenge.
The Atlantic Gulf and West Indies Steamship Lines announced yesterday the sale of three of its ships and all company assets in Puerto Rico and the Dominican Republic for $4,430,000.
East Side and West Side, up and down town, florist shops this week have a varied array of flowers. They offer endless ideas for bouquets in the home or apartment.

GLENS FALLS, N. Y., March 18 (AP) -- West Catholic High School of Philadelphia came from behind tonight to trip All Hallows Catholic High of New York City, 39 -- 36, in the semi-finals of the twenty-seventh Eastern States scholastic basketball tournament.

Mayor O'Dwyer was mildly criticized for his previous inaction on wiretapping yesterday, and then warmly welcomed as the "number one complainant" against the practice by Herman Hoffman, president of the New York County Criminal Courts Bar Association.
HONOLULU, T. H., March 18 -- Forty-one Indonesians, who were shipwrecked last October on an uninhabited Pacific island, have been rescued by an auxiliary naval ship, the Navy announced today.

KEY WEST, Fla., March 18 -- Twenty "top-notch kids of the Navy," receiving diplomas of an anti-submarine warfare school here, were told by President Truman today that they would be of great value to their country and might contribute to the peace of the world.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, March 18 -- The North Atlantic pact was laid before the people of the Netherlands today by Foreign Minister D. U. Stikker with the comment that it represented a really remarkable effort on the part of the United States in peacetime and was on the whole generally favorable to the interests of this country.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- Col. John Callan O'Laughlin, publisher of the Army and Navy Journal, has bequeathed the influential service publication to the Gridiron Club in trust, his will revealed when filed for probate today. Colonel O'Laughlin, a member of the club for thirty-nine years, died at Walter Reed Hospital last Monday at the age of 76 and without immediate survivors.
Jean Borotra made his entrance yesterday at the Seventh Regiment Armory, where he has stormed the net for many years, and Sidney Wood made his exit.

VIENNA, March 18 -- Austrian reaction to the proclamation of the North Atlantic defense pact has been centered mainly on the assumption, supported by London news dispatches, that it would automatically include Austria, or at least that part occupied by the Western powers.

WARSAW, March 18 -- The Polish Government has demanded the immediate recall of a United States State Department official because Poland was described as a "Soviet satellite" in a news bulletin published by the United States Information Service.
AUGUSTA, Ga., March 18 (AP) -- The Misses Dot Kirby, Peggy Kirk and Dot Kielty -- along with Louise Suggs -- took charge of the women's titleholders' tournament today in the second round.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- The General Telephone Corporation, New York, registered today with the Securities and Exchange Commission $10,000,000 of debentures due in 1964, to be offered publicly at a price to be filed by amendment. Paine, Webber, Jackson Curtis, the Stone Webster Securities Corporation and Mitchum, Tully Co. were named the principal underwriters.

As anyone with half an eye in his head can see, the winter is a magpie. The magpie is that bird which collects bits of colored glass and string, and the winter is just like that. It can be none other than the winter which, seeping through even the storm windows, has filled the house with oddments not there in the autumn.

WHEN a gardener buys a new home he also acquires a new set of gardening problems. Some of these are surface problems and their solution is obvious. For example, the foundation planting might need pruning or rearranging, or the shrubbery border be in need of thinning out.

NEWARK, N. J., March 19 -- A four-goal rally in the final chukker gave the Squadron A Blues of New York a 13 -- 12 victory over Ramapo Valley in the Eastern semi-finals of the Sherman Memorial low-goal polo championship tonight at Essex Troop Armory.

A milestone has been reached by the National Office of Vocational Rehabilitation with the recent announcement that currently it is aiding 127,000 disabled men and women to learn how to make their own livelihoods. This represents the largest number ever enrolled in the program.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- Senator J. Howard McGrath, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, censured the press and radio today, charging that they had "played down" what he called the "shocking" testimony that the Republican National Committee had paid the salary of a lawyer who drafted the House version of the Taft-Hartley Act in 1947.

MR. TUNIS, author of some of the best sports stories of our time, has ever been concerned with the working-out of democratic ideals in American life. In this new novel for 'teen-aged aged readers he has turned from the gridiron and the baseball diamond to explore the significance of a great democratic experiment: that of the Tennessee Valley Authority.

THE 1949 spring list of garden books contains a number of fine titles authored by widely known old-timers of the gardening world. Subjects range from herbs to country living, and the volumes make an imposing array on the bookshelf.
Field interviewers for business research organizations are reporting a marked increase in the number of doors being slammed on them, it was learned yesterday.

THE robin is the first bird, but the peeper is the first creature to herald the coming of spring and does it much more accurately. The robin sometimes gets ahead of the season The peeper never does. This small, brown toad, being cold-blooded, partakes of the temperature of its environment.

Many reservations have been made for the fourth annual Bal des Berceaux, a dinner dance to be given Friday in the St. Regis Roof under the auspices of the Committee of French-American Wives. The sponsoring organization will direct the proceeds to well-established agencies in France working for the relief of children. A percentage of the funds also will be donated to the Red Cross.

American toy production this year at levels equal to the $300,000,000 high volume of 1947 and 1948 and immediate increases in toy factory employment throughout the country were predicted yesterday by Kenneth P. Fallon, president of the Toy Manufacturers of the U. S. A.

With two popular Verdi operas -- "Rigoletto" in the afternoon and "La Traviata" at night -- the Metropolitan Opera Association yesterday closed its sixty-fourth subscription season at the old opera house.
GORGAS, Ala., March 19 (UP) -- Using equipment once intended for Russia, engineers are producing gases from burning coal underground and hope the gases may be turned into economical power.

CHATTANOOGA, March 19 -- The attention of the Deep South turned this week to Birmingham, where States' Rights Democrats (Dixiecrats) and supporters of President Truman dueled politically in what promises to be the most colorful post-election incident in the region.

Frederick H. Zurmuhlen, Commissioner of Public Works, announced yesterday that work would start tomorrow on the construction of the Riverside health and sub-station for the Health Department at 129th Street and Old Broadway.

AT noon tomorrow, 18 hours and 11 minutes after spring has come officially to New York, the thirty-third International Flower Showy opens at the Grand Central Palace, Forty-sixth Street and Lexington Avenue. Here, until next Saturday night, with disregard for the weather outside, spring -- and summer -- will be in full bloom.

NORWALK, Conn., March 19 -- The board of deacons of the First Congregational Church of South Norwalk, in a letter today to the Rev. Charles W. Lee, pastor of the First Methodist Church of South Norwalk, apologized "to fellow-Christians of other faiths for your and for your speaker's effrontery."

WILLIAMSBURG, Va. -- Spring comes early to Tidewater Virginia, and in this restored colonial capital many of its flowers -- crocuses, primroses, peach and plum blossoms -- are already adding fragrance and beauty to history.

HANOVER, N. H., March 19 (AP) -- Thomas A. Doxsee, a 22-year-old Dartmouth College junior from Fayetteville, N. Y., was charged with manslaughter today in the death of a fellow student after a brawl last night.

The revolt of Congress against President Truman was criticized by some rabbis in sermons here yesterday. Other rabbis hailed the work of Dr. Ralph J. Bunche, acting United Nations mediator for Palestine, praised the loyalty of American Jews and deplored mistreatment of co-religionists abroad.

Despite prospects of a lower volume of traffic, which already is insufficient to support the present wage structure, the nation's railroads last week accepted the recommendations of the President's Emergency Board, created under the Railway Labor Act, and will establish on Sept. 1 a forty-hour week for their non-operating employes.

THE opera on which Igor Stravinsky is working, "The Rake's Progress," may receive its world premiere at one of the summer festivals held in Central City, Colo. The composer was in Denver for a concert earlier this month and discussed the matter width F. H. Ricketson Jr., president of the Central City Opera House Association. The Denver Post then carried a story that the Central City premiere had "reached the planning stag."

PRINCETON, N. J., March 19 -- Joe Verdeur, the superlative waterman from La Salle, completed his third consecutive double triumph in the Eastern Intercollegiate Swimming League championships by winning the 300-yard individual medley in record-smashing time tonight.

ONE of the week's pleasanter discoveries was the fact that Morton Baum, engineer of the recent three-day conference on the state of the theatre, really means to see that the issues raised will not become dead letters. For instance, he is working on the plan to attach a $1,000,000 rider to Democratic Senator Elbert D. Thomas' education bill, the funds to be allocated to and matched by States willing to subsidize their own theatres.

WHEN the late Julius Rosenwald was a young and moderately successful business man he set as his material goal an income of $15,000 a year, of which he would use $5,000 for personal expenses, lay aside $5,000 and give $5,000 to charity.
May I discuss in your columns the unnecessary and unfortunate conflicts in the finest radio programs vouchsafed us by the leading chains?
Following are excerpts from editorials of newspapers over the country on the North Atlantic security pact, as gathered by THE NEW YORK TIMES and The Associated Press:
WASHINGTON, March 19 -- The Senate Banking and Currency Committee asserted today that abandoning rent control at this time would give the country "a serious economic shock."

NAPPY is a healthy, happy little boy who already has won friends through earlier books about his getting a dog, planting a garden and finding a friend. This time Nappy is a "rootin', tootin', shootin' cowboy" with all the costume fixings.
ASPEN, Col., March 19 (AP) -- Mrs. Rhoda Wurtele Eaves of Montreal, Canada, and Jean Pazzi of the French National team placed first in today's downhill events in the North American ski championships.

A field goal with fifty-eight seconds to play gave the Abraham Lincoln High School basketball team a 41-40 victory over Stuyvesant and the PSAL championship before 7,000 highly excited onlookers at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon.

Following a series of price adjustments on a few products by several companies in recent weeks, competition in the domestic steel market is greater now than it has been at any time since the end of the war, but there is no immediate prospect of generally lower prices.

Laws in themselves cannot guarantee civil rights unless popular education first prepares the way for observance of the laws. This was the consensus of a junior high school panel and the audience at the weekly Youth Forum program sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES and broadcast yesterday over WQXR.

Methods by which the classroom teacher can improve her skills and adapt them to contemporary needs are presented in the recently published 1949 Yearbook of the Association for Supervision and Curriculum Development, which is affiliated with the National-Education Association.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- Secretary of State Acheson completed the negotiations on the North Atlantic treaty this week and he is now taking a brief rest somewhere in the vicinity of his prize compost pile at Sandy Spring, Md.

THE breadth and vitality of contemporary art are especially well illustrated in newly opened current exhibitions. The Federation of Modern Painters and Sculptors provides a lively attraction in the staid galleries of the National Arts Club.

For almost a decade Britons have been living by ration book. The little 5 by 3 1/2 inch red-covered clothing books, and their buff-colored clothing counterparts, have been as necessary for life in Britain as a passport is for traveling in Europe. The end of the war did not bring relaxing of controls.
TORONTO, March 19 (AP) -- Piling up a four-goal lead, the National Hockey League's pennant winning Detroit Red Wings coasted to a 5-2 triumph over the Toronto Maple Leafs tonight.

SUMMER-FLOWERING bulbs, while not nearly as popular or well known as the many spring-flowering kinds, have a distinct place in our gardens. For they give bright accents at times when color may be lacking.
ST. LOUIS, March 19 -- A new effort to block the operation of a Missouri Valley Authority by state legislation will be made soon, it was learned today.

LAKE SUCCESS, March 19 -- The North Atlantic Treaty may not be on the agenda of the coming General Assembly session, but United Nations observers were convinced today that the issue would touch off another clash between the Soviet and the Western powers.

THAT the 2 1/2-year-old child in this country gets "altogether too many spankings" is a statement Dr. Arnold Gesell made many years ago. Around that age, as Dr. Gesell conveyed then, and other specialists have said since, parental patience with the vagaries of behavior due to growth begins to wear very thin indeed.

ALTHOUGH routine weeding and cultivation fulfill the needs of many annuals and perennials, some will appear at their best only if they receive specific care as they develop. These further attentions result in straighter stems and over-all neatness, abundant bloom on bushier plants and large individual blossoms.

WHEN the New York City Opera Company announced its production of "Troubled Island," someone asked me whether I had any advice to give to young American composers who aspire to write opera. I said that I didn't feel that I should be handing out advice at this stage of the game -- after all, I hadn't yet had a success, I had only the promise of a production!

TELEVISION station WJZ-TV is planning to expand its schedule into the afternoon hours, beginning about April 1, with a two-hour package show entitled "Market Melodies." The telecasting schedule will be Tuesday through Friday from 2 to 4 P. M. and on Saturday from 10 A. M. to noon. The show would not be carried on Mondays.

ANNUALS provide the quickest, easiest and most dependable source of color for the garden. How to choose from the bewildering array displayed in seed catalogs and offered with tantalizing color illustrations is a problem for the novice and experienced alike.

GARDEN lighting -- illumination for effect -- is not to be confused with the necessary lighting of such structural features as steps, entrances or game areas. It refers, instead, to the illumination of trees and other plants, and as such it has a far different approach and meaning.

THE columnist who lives under the discipline of the daily deadline ordinarily has reason to be grateful for the gray oblivion of fading newspaper print. The exhumation of yesteryears' columns may reveal an unlovely spectacle -- an ephemeral assortment of superficial judgments and the wreckage and debris of omniscience.

INTO a classroom -- comfortably warm on a bitter night, although too severely furnished to be cozy -- filed seven men and five women. They were orderly about it, as if accustomed to follow directions. The faces varied from impulsive to deliberate and from almost handsome to dreadfully plain, yet all the faces possessed a quality in common.

A beefsteak dinner, featured by boxing bouts and other entertainment, will be given at the Madison Square Boys' Club, 301 East Twenty-ninth Street, on the night of April 4. Boys of the club will participate in the evening's program, which has been arranged instead of the annual theatre party benefit.

WHEN a writer of Miss Jameson's moral earnestness and dramatic gifts tackles the timely theme of political justice and human sacrifice, one can be sure that the result will at least be interesting. She has worked on the premise that in every individual's life there is "a moment of truth" (something like the existentialist's "engagement").

WASHINGTON, March 19 (AP) -- Farmers may top total crop production records this year. This possibility was seen today by officials of the Department of Agriculture as they gathered information on how much land farmers intend to plant to various food, feed and other crops.

PRINCETON, N. J., March 19 -- More than 300 leaders in physics, astronomy, mathematics and cosmology paid tribute here today to Prof. Albert Einstein, whom George Bernard Shaw once described as one of the three universe builders in man's recorded history.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg of Michigan, ranking Republican member of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, gave his full support today to the North Atlantic Treaty in a statement hailing it as "a powerful insurance policy against World War III."

PARIS, March 19 -- The biggest overhauling process in the Soviet Government since 1939, when Vyacheslav M. Molotov replaced Maxim Litvinov and Joseph V. Stalin named himself Prime Minister, has been taking place in Moscow.

ONE could hardly say that "The Girl on the Via Flaminia" was the best -- or even the second, third or fifth best -- of the new war novels by American writers. It is very good, but in a fashion that makes it difficult to compare with the others.

TOMORROW at noon Flower Show Week starts officially with the opening of the Thirty-third International Flower Show at Grand Central Palace. Many horticultural organizations will make this the occasion for special meetings.

MUCH of the color went out of tournament bridge when P. Hal Sims quit championship competition along about 1936, but his personality and his record were still there in the background, an inexhaustible source of anecdotes for the bridge-players' hot-stove league.

Wanted: A calm, deep water lake not too far from New York. Perhaps a fair-sized pond would do, if not too narrow and if at least three miles long. Fame and notoriety almost certainly would be assured.

ROME, March 19 -- Reports received here today from Albanians who have fled from their country to neighboring Greece said that a considerable amount of military preparation was taking place on the northeastern Albanian border facing Yugoslavia and along the Albanian littoral from Voiussa, a small town just west of Valona, to Butrinto which faces the Corfu Channel.

GLADIOLUS grow in almost any well-drained, good garden soil, preferably somewhat acid. They must, however, have full sun. Varieties come in a wide range of color, and corms should be bought from a reputable dealer.

For those of us who do not have television service, the current excitement over the new medium presents a peculiar and disturbing problem. Specifically, the question which I would like answered is this: Is the radio listener to be disenfranchised and forgotten by both the networks and the sponsors?

CHICAGO, March 19 -- Industrial development in the Chicago area, including the purchase of land and buildings, new construction and leasing of industrial property, declined to $16,175,000 in the first two months this year compared with $27,653,000 in the same period in 1948. However, of the thirty firms contracting for expenditures in February this year, six were new to the Chicago area and four of the six were newly organized companies.

The candidacy of Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. for the Democratic nomination for Representative in the Twentieth Congressional District to fill the vacancy caused by the death of Sol Bloom developed yesterday into a contest between those who believe that he should be named as a tribute to the memory of his father and those who believe that the nomination should go to a resident of the district.

SEATTLE, March 19 (AP) -- A nationwide check of over-the-road truck-drivers by American Federation of Labor teamsters is part of a campaign to raise the union's membership to between 2,500,000 and 3,000,000, a spokesman said today.

ASHEVILLE, N. C., March 19 -- Synthetic resins have been the "penicilin" of the lacquer and varnish industry and are responsible for recent major advances in the manufacture of lacquers and varnishes for furniture. This was reported here today by Dudley B. Blake, vice president in charge of sales of the Monroe Sander Corporation, Long Island City, manufacturer of industrial finishes.
SARASOTA, Fla., March 19 (AP) -- Bob Elliot's clouting sparked a pair of four-run rallies today as the Boston Braves downed Boston's Red Sox, 9 -- 4.
CONSERVATION of moisture within the plant is the most important factor in successful transplanting. Careful planting operations are followed with this purpose foremost in mind.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was rather quiet yesterday, and final prices were 2 to 8 points net lower.

MARGE and Gower Champion, the dancers, concede they are pleasantly stunned by their sudden rise to television success in the Admiral Broadway Revue (8 P. M. Fridays on Dumont and NBC). In the everyday roles of Mr. and Mrs. Champion they continue, meanwhile, to be capable of quietly assessing their experiences in the new medium.

In all this discussion of the merits of national polls ("The Case for the Public Opinion Polls," by George Gallup), everyone has been too polite to inquire into the performance and integrity of that essential member of the organization, the poll-taker.

The immigration and Naturalization Service processed almost 200,000 cases last year involving illegal entry of aliens into the country -- principally over the Mexican border and deported an additional 26,000 persons after special hearings, according to the service's records.

EMILY BROWN, the briefly "enchanted heart" of Mrs. Worthington's fourth novel, spends summers in Toulon with John Stickney, a famous painter who regularly leaves wife and family in New York for a spree abroad.

As the stage was set for the first face-to-face meeting between Mayor O'Dwyer and Clendenin J. Ryan in the wiretapping case this week, ten Democratic members of Congress from New York held a two-hour conference on the case with the Mayor at City Hall yesterday.

SAN DIEGO., Calif., March 19 -- Coming up with an improved brand of pitching and exploding a seven-run demonstration in the fifth, the final three riding home on a base-clearing double by Buddy Kerr, the Giants today flattened the White Sox, 11 to 4.

TEL AVIV, Israel, March 19 -- The French Government has decided to lift the embargo on the sale of arms to Syria and Lebanon, and a Syrian purchasing delegation is in Paris arranging for the shipment of weapons and ammunition, it was learned from a reliable source today.

EQUALLY happy in full sun or semi-shade, daylilies flourish in ordinary, well-drained soil, luxuriate when given an early spring application of well-rotted manure. A top-dressing of compost later in the season, and an abundance of water during dry spells will result in perfect bloom in August and September.

Sheila Minzer, 6-year-old pianist from New York, played to a sold-out house in Town Hall yesterday afternoon. Her program was composed entirely of works of Bach, including the Prelude and Fughetta in C major and one in C minor; fifteen Two Part Inventions; sections of the Sixth Violin Sonata and the Second English Suite.

LONDON, March 19 -- After a full decade of austerity, the controls and restrictions on ordinary necessities and amenities of life in Britain now are disappearing so rapidly that they may cease to be a major political issue by the time of the 1950 general election.

WASHINGTON, March 19 (UP) -- J. Edgar Hoover, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, charged today that the pages of the Yale Law Journal had been used to "distort and misrepresent the truth" about his organization.

When he reached his eightieth birthday a Swiss recently took stock of his life with the aid of an unusually detailed diary. He did not reach the conclusion that he was moderately successful, or rejoice in his brief triumphs, or bemoan his many failures, indiscretions and stupidities, or express any opinion about himself.

A TECHNICOLORED rainbow which arches over the home of the tearfully reunited Marches at the close of the Music Hall's new film is the ultimate manifestation of the brand of sentiment contained in the third (and most lavish) translation of "Little Women" to the screen.

The fact that increasing numbers of men and women want to continue their education through adult life was characterized last week by Paul A. McGhee, dean of New York University's Division of General Education, as a "sign of social health." The division constitutes the university's adult-education unit.

WE have to admit, in comparing one civilization with another, and in comparing the different stages of our own, that no one society and no one age of it realizes all the values of civilization. Not all of these values may be compatible with each other; what is at least as certain is that in realizing some we lose the appreciation of others.

That Arthur Miller's new play, "Death of a Salesman," should have been greeted with rapturous praise by both critics and public is not surprising at all. Considering the present standards of our theatre, anything above the level of the circus, the revue and the burlesque is considered a "masterpiece."
BRUSSELS, Belgium, March 19 -- In sharp contrast with most of Western Europe, Belgium provides a serious test of United States economic policy by the strength rather than the weakness of her economy.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 19 -- Just about the time the war was ending Larry MacPhail, then the president of the Yankees, conferred with Master Melvin Ott, then the manager of the Giants -- which should show you what ancient history all this is. The rambunctious Redhead had under contract four catchers of various degrees of ability and experience.

WITH fireworks and resplendent militia, Charleston, S. C., will re-enact on Wednesday, April 20, the opening phase of the battle of Fort Sumter, first engagement of the Civil War. The "battle" will be part of the festivities marking Charleston's five-day Azalea Festival, which also will include a parade, a street criers' contest, a lancing tournament, and the coronation of the Azalea Queen.

A SAUCE blended from a fine old cheese gives savor and substance to a luncheon or supper of macaroni with vegetables. Vary the ingredients as supplies dictate. Carrots, beans and peas are presented here, but almost any others might be selected, including vegetables remaining from another meal.

WHEN Father Carlisle is placed on the operating table just before he dies, Dr. Clifton discovers an iron chain around his waist. The mark of the flagellant is worn by the young priest in expiation of past sins.

The British Timber Control is placing orders for upper grade spruce with Eastern Canadian lumber mills at a rate far exceeding expectations, a local lumber distributor representing one of the largest lumber operations in Eastern Canada reported yesterday.

GARDENERS are intrigued by the novelty flowers and vegetables which appear in the catalogues each spring, but few of them know much about how they got there. Before the days of modern plant breeding, most varieties originated as the result of natural "breaks" or variants in the garden.

THE Broadway Limited took to the rails last week in a complete new dress, the first Pennsylvania sleeping car train to have all new cars since the war. The famous train which started in 1902 as the Pennsylvania Special and became an all-room train in 1938, now carries the following luxurious sleeping accommodations: two master rooms, four drawing rooms, eight compartments, thirty-nine double bedrooms, twelve duplex rooms and eighty-two roomettes.

It was strange indeed to find Sarah Wambaugh, in her letter on the Slovenes in Carinthia in THE TIMES of March 6, lending her authority to the old Habsburg-German arguments, pro-clerical speculation and questionable statistics that have been used against the Yugoslavs ever since they first sought to realize President Wilson's principle of the self-determination of peoples thirty years ago.

The purchase last week of brewing facilities here by one of the country's largest brewers -- long established only in the Midwest -- served to emphasize the fact that this area is increasing its lead as the beer producing center of the world. Official production figures for 1948 in both the greater metropolitan area and the state substantially exceed those of any other area or state.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, March 19 -- Scandinavian comment on the publication of the North Atlantic Treaty agrees on only one thing: It is epoch-making in that it officially seals the United States resolve to abandon its policy of aloofness from European affairs.
ON Feb. 13 the Book Review carried a notice that Cyril Clemens of Webster Groves, Mo., was soliciting letters of Mark Twain to be printed in "the official collection of Mark Twain letters."
I disagree somewhat with Mr. D. C. Gillette's comments on the tent drama as recently exposed in your columns.

IN his new novel Robert Graves has provided a witty and even playful but by no means frivolous footnote to that intense and exacting book, "The White Goddess." He has invented a New Cretan civilization, located some thousands of years in the future, that worships the Great Goddess under various names.

OTTAWA, March 19 -- During debate this week on a bill to extend the operation of the Foreign Exchange Control Act, an amendment was put forward by the Conservative opposition asking that the Canadian dollar be allowed to seek its true economic level within the limits imposed by the Bretton Woods agreement and suggesting that the International Monetary Fund be asked to modify its regulations to permit an orderly revaluation of currencies.

DETROIT, March 19 (AP) -- The year ahead can be just as good a year for the car industry as was 1948 -- "if we all will just work at it." That's the conviction of George T. Christopher, Packard Motor Car Company president and one of the auto industry's down-to-earth realists.

THE effectiveness of a garden pool is determined to a great extent by the planting in or around it. The sparkle and coolness of water is a refreshing feature in spring and summer, but it needs to be treated as an integral part of the over-all plan of the grounds.

EVERY spring new varieties of favorite perennials appear on the market. Some gardeners grow nothing but the old tried-and-true flowers; others collect just the novelties, and will consider nothing else. But old favorites and current introductions may be matched with complete harmony in spring planting this year.

The selection and placement of garden ornaments plays an important part in landscape design. Whether for practical use or decoration, they should be in keeping with the general composition and with the chosen location.

The eighteen-member United Nations Economic and Social Council has just wound up its eighth session after thirty-nine days of sometimes acrimonious discussion at Lake Success. This agency was generally spoken of as "ECOSOC" for short -- and at times the emphasis seemed to be on the pugnacious last syllable of this abbreviation.

MY latest discovery about chrysanthemums is that they like vermiculite! A thin mulch set around newly set plants gave such promising results in preventing disease and increasing vigor, that I intend to experiment further with its use.

THE arrival of the first blue-bird or robin each spring is greeted with as much enthusiasm as the initial burst of bloom from crocuses and daffodils. Yet any long-term program that aims at attracting birds to the garden will require considerable thought and patience.

MANY wild flowers will grow in the average garden without undue coddling. The possibilities are well worth investigating, especially since the vast amount of building in progress now means that many wild or wooded areas are being wiped out.

Behind the sensational charges and counter-charges involving wiretapping last week lay a fact of major importance: New York City will hold its quadrennial election for Mayor in less than eight months. The wiretapping fireworks were a preliminary to the political campaign that is now getting under way.

BUENOS AIRES, March 19 -- One of the current phenomena of the Argentine scene is increasing interest in financial weeklies that -- with most of the general press under Government control -- have managed to become increasingly outspoken regarding the nation's controversial economic situation.

Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York last week got his first major rebuff from the Republican-controlled Legislature since he took office six years ago. The rebuff came on the Governor's budget program. The actual concessions he was forced to make were not great; he retained the bulk of his program.

IF the lack of interest, as your critic so rightly put it, in Sean O'Casey's writings is hard for him and others to understand, what kind of befuddlement does he think besets Mr. O'Casey's representative in this country, who has had his interests at heart and his plays in his keeping and all to so little avail?

The Senate majority of unreconstructed Southerners and shortsighted Republicans having won their fight to block the President's civil rights program, the country will hope that they give their tired tonsils a rest now and get back to work on the legislation that was dammed up behind the Senate filibuster.

TEN - AND - A- HALF - YEAR-OLD Margitka sat in her fourth-grade classroom and drew a big apple on her slate because she was hungry. A minute later she was sent for by the pastor of the little Hungarian village in which she lived and told that it had been arranged for her to spend the summer with a foster family in Switzerland.
LONDON, March 19 (Reuters) -- Top teams held sway in English soccer today, with the leaders in all four groups either gaining ground or maintaining their positions.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., March 19 -- With the thermometer down in the twenties in the sun, snow smothering the shore and crews all but sewn in clothes like Eskimos, the sailors at the Larchmont Yacht Club went through seven races today in their small dinghies.

CLEVELAND, March 19 -- Recent reports that standard jet fighter planes of the United States Air Force are no match for the high-flying B-36 "intercontinental bomber" were accepted today as substantially true by some of the country's leading aeronautical experts. However, these men saw no reason for alarm over this phase of the development of the airplane.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 19 -- The Yugoslav Communist party's view of the North Atlantic Treaty is identical with that of the Communist Information Bureau. It opposes the treaty on the grounds that it is an instrument of aggression aimed at the Soviet Union and the "people's democracies" of eastern Europe.

NEW CITY, N. Y., March 18 -- This county seat of Rockland County claims the distinction of having a two-time prizefight champion as its postmaster. Joe Lynch, a product of New York's West Side, is New City's pride.

AS one New York City gardener wryly put it, "If we went in for sculpture or tennis, clay soil would be fine." Yet despite this and other problems peculiar to city gardening, spring in Manhattan finds some 5,000 urban dwellers girding themselves for their annual battle against the three S's: soil, soot and shade.

IN his perversely impressionistic book, "The American People," the Englishman Geoffrey Gorer estimated in passing the influence of the "school marm" on our culture. Edward Harris Heth's sixth novel, "If You Lived Here," attempts to speak on this subject in the more complete terms of fiction.

The voluntary hospitals of New York State do not face an immediate emergency but there is great uncertainty as to their financial future and should there be a depression they would be "in a precarious financial situation."

APPARENTLY moved by the same faith that moves mountains, Ingrid Bergman departed for Italy last week to make that heralded film with Roberto Rossellini, completely unperturbed by the fact that the director had no script ready.

CHICAGO, March 19 (AP) -- Grains made modest gains in slow dealings on the Board of Trade today. The market opened fractionally higher and held around opening levels for the rest of the session. May contracts had a little more strength than later months.

Negro colleges in the South have increased their farm and home demonstrations to promote better income and places to live, college agricultural and home economics teachers said yesterday. State and Federal agricultural agencies have cooperated to increase understanding of soil preservation and modern methods of production.

OAK RIDGE, Tenn., March 19 -- This city, which gave birth to the atom bomb, was thrown open to the public today in ceremonies that hailed the event as proof that democracy could balance the problems of secrecy and freedom in a world of tension.

LONDON, March 19 -- An Arab village at the head of the Gulf of Aqaba, a miserable sun-baked cluster of mud huts and palm trees, became the focus this week of the continuing conflict between Israel's ambitions and Britain's interests in the Middle East.

A sharp division of opinion among members of the American Civil Liberties Union was made clear yesterday in a discussion of government loyalty boards, the House Committee on Un-American Activities and a proposal to make known the financial contributors to private organizations.

PARIS, March 19 -- Broadcasting over a national network on the eve of the cantonal elections from the little town of Neuvic d'Ussel where he is a candidate for the departmental council, Premier Henri Queuille tonight denounced what he called the collusion of Communists and de Gaullists against the present Government.

GREENVILLE, Miss., is the small tree - embowered, bird - haunted, church - going, whisky - drinking, pleasure-loving metropolis of the Mississippi Delta. It is an adjunct to the great plantations that surround it; the provincial capital of a cotton-intoxicated region. There cotton-growing is more than a form of livelihood.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- Chaim Weizmann, president of Israel, appealed to "all members of the Jewish people" today to rally behind the new state that offers "a rightful place" for any Jew who wishes to enter.

ST. LOUIS, March 19 (UP) -- The five-day walkout of four operating brotherhoods against the Wabash Railroad is setting a pattern for settlement of grievances against other roads, strike leaders indicated today.

STE. MARGUERITE, Que., March 19 -- Miss Jacqueline Tracey twice dashed down treacherous Mount Baldy Speedway at breakneck speed to win individual honors and lead a Canadian team of women skiers to a handsome margin over an Eastern United States squad in today's thrilling downhill, first half of the international classic.

A crowd of close to record size for so early in the tournament saw Richard Gonzales, Jean Borotra, Earl Cochell and all the other favorites advance to the third round of the men's national indoor tennis championships yesterday.

Currently making the rounds of the Loew's circuit are the revivals of "Stagecoach" and "The Long Voyage Home," re-issued by Masterpiece Productions. This company certainly owes the public an apology for what it has done to the latter film.

WITH the closing tonight of the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo at the City Center, the season will be given over to the concert companies and recitalists until the Ballet Theatre arrives at the Metropolitan on Easter Sunday. Nothing at all in the Broadway area is listed for the current week, which means that the neighborhood houses will have to keep the torch alight for the nonce.
HOUSTON, Tex., March 19 (AP) -- Talk of reductions of prices for petroleum grows stronger here, but oil men still have hopes of holding the line.
STILL under the spell of the latest Metropolitan newcomer, I am impelled to voice my admiration for the Salome of the matinee performance of Saturday, March 12.

" MONEY isn't important until there isn't any," old Mrs. Twigley told her cat, Serena. But by the time Mrs. Twigley reached this conclusion money had become extremely important, for Mrs. T. had none and soon would have to sell her little house on Huckleberry Lane.

VIENNA, March 12 -- Readers of the Communist party organ Volksstimme here were startled yesterday to read that Secretary of State Dean Acheson had told a press conference in Washington that "America desires no cooperation with the Soviet Union within the framework of the United Nations."

THE motion picture business may have achieved the status of an industry, but it still is pretty much of a family affair, or a brother act, if you will. With few exceptions the top men who run the film business are blood relations, so it would seem that anyone wanting to make headway in the movie world shouldn't enter it alone, but preferably in association with his brother.

WHEREVER gardeners gather these days, the talk soon turns to power mowers and tractors. For while certain hand tools are still basic, power tools have lately become increasingly available and popular.

ALTHOUGH many people sincerely believe that they want to go to the theatre to laugh and forget their troubles, the record does not necessarily bear them out. By and large the serious plays are the most successful. For fifteen months the public has been fascinated by "A Streetcar Named Desire," which is a harrowing drama.

TIGRE Argentina -- Forty-five minutes by electric train from Buenos Aires sprawl "The Islands," or delta of the Parana River, where it flows into the estuary of La Plata. This is a water-wonderland combining some of the attractions of Venice with others of the Mississippi below New Orleans, and steeping both in an atmosphere that is Argentina's own.

ALL plants need fertilizing at one time or another, and the amateur gardener particularly is apt to have a lot of questions on the subject. What is more, some confusion exists as to just what is and what is not a fertilizer.
NEW ORLEANS, March 19 (AP) -- Rookwood, Joe W. Brown's crack bay gelding, ran like a greyhound to win the $15,000 added Louisiana Derby today by four lengths and shine as a Kentucky Derby hopeful.

PLANTING has been the business of civilized man from the beginning. And community planting is an expression of civilized man's aspiration to give a touch of nature's beauty to the mechanical framework in which civilization is carried on, now that life has become so complex that the individual cannot do the whole job.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- A long-range bomber of a type which the Navy says can handle atomic bombs took off from a carrier early this month, it was learned today. The plane was the heaviest ever launched in that fashion.

THE most delectable fruits are those the grower gathers from trees on his own home grounds. The satisfaction that comes with accomplishment is heightened by the flavor that only tree-ripened fruits possess.
WHITE PLAINS, March 19 -- The Royal Norwegian Government formally thanked two local organizations this evening for the care they gave to almost 3,000 Norwegian seamen during the war.

A new four-year course leading to the degree of Bachelor of Science in land planning will be introduced next fall in the College of Architecture at Cornell University. It will replace a five-year course in landscape architecture, which is being discontinued. The program, believed to be the first of its kind in the country, is designed primarily as a preparatory course for post-graduate specialization in landscape architecture or city and regional planning.

First-quarter earnings of the thirty-five member banks of the Federal Reserve System in this city to be indicated by the statements of condition scheduled for publication at the end of next week are likely to be generally unchanged from the levels of a year ago.

MARGARET LLOYD'S lively critical writings and perceptive interviews in The Christian Science Monitor have been an indispensable part of the American dance scene for a number of years. Her book joins "The Borzoi Book of Ballets," of several seasons ago, as a companion volume.

DENVER, March 19 (AP) -- Top-seeded Siena College of Loudonville, N. Y., will play St. Benedict's of Atchison, Kan., in the opening round of the National Catholic Intercollegiate Basketball Tourney tomorrow night.
Ingenuity is at work again in the utility industry. This time, an operating electric company is reviving a financing vehicle that had lain dormant for twenty years.

ROME, March 19 -- Publication of North Atlantic Treaty text and yesterday's vote in the Chamber of Deputies authorizing the Government to adhere to it have divided the Italian press on ideological lines into two camps. On one side are the extreme left-wing newspapers and on the other all the rest, with very few exceptions.

An area of Long Island City, cited in pre-war city planning recommendations as suitable for expansion of graphic arts enterprises, is beginning a new addition of large printing industry plants. The district lies roughly southwest of the Queensboro Plaza, and extends along the East River nearly to Newtown Creek.

In some years, only the coldframe can be started in March, but in springs like the current one, work can begin in the open garden now.

HALLANDALE, Fla., March 19 -- Coaltown, Calumet Farm's great 4-year-old, today equaled the world record for one mile and a quarter in winning the $20,000 Gulfstream Park Handicap by seven lengths.

ROME, March 19 -- Discussion of the Atlantic Pact, both inside and outside Parliament, has without doubt embittered the Italian political situation and deepened the animosities and hatreds that divide Italian from Italian.
VERO BEACH, Fla., March 19 -- Before these Dodgers finish playing with Connie Mack's Athletics they will probably set a record for length of exhibition games and nobody will be happy about it.

LATE last year, when most of the scheduled airlines of this country realized that only a miracle could pull them out of the red, a few of them decided that they had nothing to lose by experimenting with new types of service.

BELGRADE, March 19 -- The logic of the Cominform-Yugoslav struggle points to the possibility that dramatic events may be in preparation. But before discussing such possibilities, this correspondent believes it imperative to examine the so-called evidence of impending events which has gained wide currency in the world outside Yugoslavia.

NEW tools and implements -- pounds lighter than old types -- appear on the market each year to expedite garden chores. Rubber-tired wheel-barrows, so light that they can be lifted with one hand, may be trundled over the ground with the greatest of ease.

Financial markets slipped back into their narrow trading rut last week, little support being gained from the daily grist of news developments. Sentiment among industrial leaders continues to be cautious and stock prices gradually worked their way lower on balance.
GENEVA, March 19 -- Trade is one of the few kinds of human activity which still link the Communist and non-Communist worlds.

CHICAGO, March 19 (AP) -- Harrison Dillard matched his American indoor mark of 0:07.1 for the 60-yard high hurdles after Wisconsin's Don Gehrmann romped to a disappointing Bankers Mile victory in the Chicago relays tonight.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- Half of the two weeks' "memorial period" called by John L. Lewis has passed, but its repercussions continue. The drama of 400,000 coal miners quitting work for a fortnight to protest the appointment of a man whom Mr. Lewis did not wish to see head of the Federal Bureau of Mines has had a considerable effect in Congress and in the labor movement generally.
Railway Express Agency workers in Yonkers refused yesterday to handle freight trucked from New York by manufacturers trying to avoid the embargo placed on shipments.

The report to the Congress by the Commission on Organization of the Executive Branch of the Government, of which ex-President Herbert Hoover is chairman and Secretary of State Dean Acheson vice chairman, with particular reference to the reorganization of the Treasury Department, presents, in its recommendations, differences of opinion on the part of members of the commission.

Dr. Edward Lasker of New York was among the winners in the fourth round of the international chess masters tournament at Mar del Plata, according to a report from Argentina yesterday. His opponent was Cesar J. Corte of Buenos Aires, who adopted the Nimzowitsch defense against the Queen's Gambit played by the United States representative.
A new punishment, aimed at those who "slow down" play in golf championships, has been included in the latest revisions of the rules of the game as announced by the United States Golf Association.

WASHINGTON, March 19 (UP) -- Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican, of Ohio, said tonight that a government with "backbone" could use the Taft-Hartley law to stop the Teamsters Union from halting trucks to check the union membership of drivers.

MOST home-owners consider it too much trouble to keep a few hens to supply the family with fresh eggs. But today, with all the modern devices, maintaining a small flock is a simple matter that consumes little time.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 19 -- More by accident than design the Yankees undertook to spot the St. Louis Cardinals a 3-run edge in their fourth inter-league game before 3,340 at Al Lang Field today, and too late discovered they weren't quite up to the handicap.

THERE are three American cities, spaced at wide intervals across the country, in which I shall never be a lingering ghost: Los Angeles, Detroit and the one from which I write. Though I cannot share the affection with which several millions of my fellow-citizens regard one or the other, I seem to be more aware, each time I see them, of their significance for the understanding of twentieth-century American life.

FOR over 2,000 years pigeons have been used to carry messages, although the means by which they are able to return hundreds of miles to their homes remain one of nature's most challenging mysteries. Mr. Zim discusses this homing instinct as well as the better-understood facts about these birds.

ALBANY, March 19 -- A compromise between rival proposals for distributing the $40,000,000 in additional state aid to schools carried in Governor Dewey's budget, which was approved earlier this week, appeared probable tonight.

The open pair match that was the major event of the Eastern States regional contract bridge championship tournament started yesterday afternoon at the Park Sheraton Hotel. Julian Goldman, who presented the trophy, said this was the oldest contract pair event conducted in the East, and that in 1935, when 186 pairs entered, it set a record for any pair event in the history of bridge.

PHILADELPHIA, March 19 -- Sales reported by women's wear outlets in the city last week fell 15 per cent under this time last year. In the four weeks ending March 12 they were off 18 per cent. Pennslyvania Railroad carloadings last week totaled 109,531, lowest since the week ending Jan. 8, as against 128,210 a year ago, a decrease of 14.8 per cent.

Retailers featured full-length fitted coats and flared shorties in apparel promotions here last week, according to a survey made especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by the Retail News Bureau. Dark basic dresses, priced from $8.95, and flower-trimmed straw hats also were outstanding promotions, it was said.

We have been hearing a good deal about grand and petit juries, both Federal and state. Federal juries operate under the Judicial Act of 1789, enacted by the First Congress, here in New York, and county juries under the State Constitution, first adopted in 1777, and since amended from time to time.

WASHINGTON, March 19 (UP) -- A leading Administration Democrat predicted today that the House would add to the Administration's labor bill a provision to "cool off" national emergency strikes with court injunctions.

The need for teamwork among the various agencies working with children afflicted with heart disease was stressed in an Institute on the Cardiac Child in School and Community yesterday at the Henry Hudson Hotel.

LOS ANGELES -- The economic importance of the travel and vacation industry is clearly demonstrated by the fact that tourist business is now Southern California's second largest source of outside income, exceeded only by aircraft manufacturing.
WASHINGTON, March 19 -- The employment rolls of the Executive Departments of the Federal Government within the continental United States have been steadily going up for the past year.
