Young women of society, headed by Miss Dolly Lowell, are aiding in the sale of tickets for the premiere showing of the motion picture, "Portrait of Jennie," with Jennifer Jones, Joseph Cotten and Ethel Barrymore in the leading roles, on the night of March 29 at the Rivoli Theatre for the benefit of the Free Milk Fund for Babies, Inc.

In the record business expansion and civic development under way in Pittsburgh, more than two-thirds of the almost billion dollars worth of plants and facilities are represented by industrial and commercial construction. For two of the largest individual projects the Turner Construction Company of New York has been selected.

AN attractive flower border from May to October is possible but not easy to achieve. It is the result of careful planning, garden "know-how" and the use of foliage as well as flowers. Perennials are its backbone, while bulbs and annuals provide color when other bloom is scarce.

THE thug who fired a shotgun through Walter Reuther's kitchen window last April 20 performed one unintended service for the dynamic young leader of a million unionized automobile, aircraft and farm equipment workers. The weary months of convalescence from the assassin's bullet have given the owner of one of the most agile minds in America time to think.

ALTHOUGH all of Margery Allingham's seventeen books, from her earliest endeavor ("Blackerchief Dick" -- written when she was 16) to her new thriller ("More Work for the Undertaker"), have appeared in America as well as in England, Miss Allingham herself has now appeared here for the first time.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- President Truman said last night in a telegram to Secretary of State Dean Acheson that the proposed North Atlantic security alliance was consonant with the requirements of the United States Constitution and would strengthen the United Nations.

There are certain tools which every gardener will need, and should learn to use correctly. A spade or spading fork is used for turning over the soil when preparing a seed bed. An iron rake serves to smooth out the top soil and to cover seed.

The second in the spring series of free art lectures at the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street, will be held at 6 P. M. Tuesday in Room 213. Leon Dabo will speak on "Vision in Contemporary Painting."

Auxiliary Bishop Stephen J. Donahue of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York joined several priests, nuns and lay benefactors yesterday afternoon in donning aprons and waiting on table at a dinner for 200 aged men and women at the Home for Aged, 213 East Seventieth Street.

THE peninsular and hilly country of Korea, called "the Hermit Kingdom" until about seventy-five years ago, when the enterprising Japanese prevailed on the ruler to open up a couple of seaports, has been over a barrel throughout most of its melancholy history.

Copper has replaced steel as the major metal in scarce supply. Inventory reductions by consumer goods manufacturers have created some appearance of less business, but this does not reflect the condition of actual industrial demand. In addition, government stockpiling holds the key to copper supply.

A DRAMATIC experiment -- carrying the play into the minds and hearts of the audience instead of the traditional concept of trying temporarily to lift the audience to the make-believe of the stage -- is being undertaken at Yale University.

This movement, Communist-inspired, represented a reaction against the prevailing Fascist and Nazi dictatorships. It collapsed in 1939, when Russia threw her weight on the side of Germany and against the democratic nations.

GIVEN proper care, trees live long and useful lives, enhancing property values and bringing joy to homeowners. Keeping trees healthy or restoring them if they are weak and rundown is only sensible. A sound program means feeding, spraying, pruning and, in some cases, surgery.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- The furious events of this week in the Senate have left the shaken and battered forces of the Truman Administration facing yet another great dilemma on the filibuster-civil-rights question.

Coming up against peak figures developed in 1948 two weeks before Easter, sales of New York department stores were down about 22 per cent last week, the largest loss to be recorded since the beginning of the year. Unseasonable spring weather further tended to depress retail sales.
The proposal of J. J. Singh that a Southeast Asia League of America be formed in the United States should invite serious consideration.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 19 -- There was no material improvement in retail business activity in the Twelfth District during the past week. While building activity in the Far West for February enjoyed some increase over the previous month, volume was still considerably below February, 1948. In the 246 cities and counties surveyed for the month 23,748 building permits were issued. This represented a loss of 23.2 per cent from the same month last year.
KANSAS CITY, March 19 (AP) -- Oklahoma A. and M., twice national champion, qualified for the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball final by outclassing Oregon State, 55 to 30, tonight.

MONTREAL, March 19 (AP) -- The Montreal Canadiens routed the Chicago Black Hawks, 5 -- 1, tonight to take second place in the National Hockey League standings. The Canadiens are unbeaten in their last ten starts.

Not a great team, but certainly one that ranks among the slickest in the nation, the University of San Francisco, in a mild upset, took the measure of Loyola of Chicago in the final of the twelfth annual National Invitation college basketball tournament at Madison Square Garden last night.

THE ex-propaganda minister of International Surrealism, Andre Breton, says somewhere that three elements are necessary for a work of art to toe the party line. It must have explosive force, veiled eroticism and magic.

WASHINGTON, March 19 (AP) -- President Truman was guest of honor tonight at the annual dinner of the White House News Photographers Association.

THE rock gardener quickly establishes friendly relations with the more or less usual plants that turn his pet project into a sheet of color in May. Then he looks forward to trying some of the fascinating plants that grow on lofty mountain summits in this country and elsewhere in the world.

AUGUSTA, Ga., March 19 (AP) -- Miss Dot Kirby of Atlanta took the lead in the third round of the women's titleholders golf tournament today. Her 225 total for 54 holes put her two strokes ahead of Miss Peggy Kirk of Findlay, Ohio, with whom she was tied for first place yesterday.

PACO, an orphan Indian boy from the Andes, is as resourceful an individualist as we have come across in a long time. When his boss-man is injured in the streets of Lima and the authorities threaten to send Paco to an orphanage, the boy solves that problem by running as fast as he can.

THERE is a method called the "hate treatment" which doctors have sometimes used successfully in dealing with cases of hysterical paralysis. The doctors and the nurses walk into the ward and shout intimately wounding insults at the patient who, goaded beyond endurance, forgets his paralysis, leaps out of bed, attacks his persecutors and is thus cured.

MOSCOW, March 19 -- With the completion of the Supreme Soviet's annual budget session, the Moscow press is now centering attention on the proposed world congress of the supporters of peace which is projected to convene in Paris in April. This interest had been marked by the publication daily of several columns of resolutions approved by organizations, both Soviet and foreign, supporting the proposals for the Paris peace conference.
THE play that Sidney Kingsley brings to New York on Wednesday had its genesis in a phrase recurrent in the 1947 speeches of Gen. George C. Marshall -- "the police state."

ROSES in infinite variety are pictured and described in the catalogues. GLASGOW, Scotland, March 19 -- More than a dozen United States concerns are expanding in the European field and have set up factories in Scotland since the war, on sites developed by the Scottish government as "nurseries of fresh enterprise." American industry now holds a big stake in Scotland's economic recovery drive.

ONE of Arthur Crook's pet theories is that nearly all murderers are amateurs because the law sees to it that they never get a chance to become professionals. Crook's method is to give the murderer every opportunity to make mistakes and, if necessary, to needle him into making them.

SARASOTA, Fla., March 19 (AP) -- Baseball Commissioner Albert B. Chandler said today Attorney John Lord O'Brian of Washington had been assigned to represent him in legal matters involving player contracts. O'Brian, former head of the anti-trust division of the Department of Justice, is a member of the law firm of Covington, Burling, Rublee and Shorb.

ON Oct. 17, 1949, it will be just 100 years since Chopin died, and the pious observances of the centennial have begun all over the world. Some things you can predict for a centennial year as certainly as the succession of the seasons: a flock of all-Chopin programs, new editions of his music and new biographies.
A day-long search for a missing 8-month-old girl was ended last night when a civilian found her asleep in a hallway at 524 Brook Avenue, the Bronx, three blocks from the child's home.

German fine china factories in Eastern Bavaria are now in the final stages of complete post-war recovery which began six months ago and they have increased pre-war output considerably through extensive modernization, Jonathan Higgins, president of the Midhurst Importing Corporation, said in an interview last week.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 19 -- A new hitch in the Israeli-Lebanese armistice talks over Israeli conditions has caused a postponement of the signing. It had been hoped that an agreement would be signed tomorrow at Ras En Naqura, on the frontier, but it will now take until midweek at least and perhaps longer.

THE 1949 garden season which opens today presents the gardener with a challenge to plant and tend a finer garden than ever before. For this year brings a handsome array of new kinds of plants and new tools with which to grow them. Gardens should be not only better but easier to maintain.

It was just seventy-four days ago that President Harry S. Truman, facing the United States Congress in joint session, set the sights for the Eighty-first Congress. He said: "Every segment of our economy and every individual have a right to expect from our Government a fair deal."

LINCOLN, England, March 19 (AP) -- Fair Judgement, the 6-to-1 favorite, rushed out of the pack in the stretch today to bag the 100th Lincolnshire Mile Handicap. It was the first big stake of the British flat racing season.

The Boston Symphony concert which Dr. Koussevitzky conducted yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall advanced familiar yet suprising things -- familiar because of their familiarity, surprising because of the unexpected things that Dr. Koussevitzky did with certain of them, ending with a sweepingly dramatic performance of the finale of the Brahms C minor symphony.

It contains thirty-four papers dealing with delinquency from a psychoanalytic point of view and is less a book than a volume of a scientific journal containing heterogeneous contributions.

BEDS of tall bearded iris should be cleaned up now, and all of last year's withered foliage removed. Old leaves often harbor eggs of iris borer, and sometimes carry over fungus diseases such as leaf spot.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- Kenneth C. Royall, Secretary of the Army, defined the Army's mission today as safeguarding the national security "in harmony with the wishes of the people."

With four weeks remaining until Easter, manufacturers and retailers last week began the final push to revive apparel sales that have lagged badly since last fall. Every trick of manufacturing and sales ingenuity will be tried in a last-ditch effort to make the Easter parade a success.
WASHINGTON, March 19 -- Encouragement for guaranteed annual wage plans has been written into the proposed new Fair Labor Standards Act, which the House is expected to consider the week of March 28.

URUAPAN, Mexico -- Two and one-half hours away from this clean little Mexican town in the State of Michoacan is Paricutin, only active volcano on the North American continent and a major attraction for the visiting American tourist who wishes to see something out of the ordinary.

A demand that "dishonest and misleading" advertising of motion pictures be prohibited was unanimously endorsed yesterday afternoon by 210 delegates to the third annual Institute of the United Parents Association of America, Inc., as part of a program to make films in this country more suitable for children.

CHICAGO, March 19 -- A total of 420,418 persons enrolled in the non-profit Blue Cross hospital insurance plan in New York City in 1948, bringing the city's enrollments to 3,618,891. Some 3,686,879 joined throughout the country, bringing the nationwide total of enrollments to 32,997,161.

PARIS, March 19 -- The French Government has made the novel proposal to the international monetary fund that a new currency, linked to the dollar, be created in French Somaliland and its seaport, Jibuti. The currency nominally would be based on gold, but in reality would be based on the dollar value of gold and hence upon the dollar.

PITTSBURGH, March 19 (AP) -- The coal mine shut-down was a week old today and widespread speculation developed whether it would end as scheduled. John L. Lewis, head of the United Mine Workers, called for a two-week "memorial" and protest work stoppage. It should end a week from Monday.

HERE again is Kent Murdock, ace photographer of The Courier-Herald, sleuthing at his very best. A rather ill-assorted group of men and women are on the S.S. Kemnora when it docks at Boston. Kent meets the ship, unaware that his presence will aid international smugglers.

A VARIETY of green vegetables and herbs for salad may be grown as part of the main vegetable plot or tucked in a small, sunny bed of their own. However much space is given them, systematic planning will make it possible to have delicious greens throughout the year.

THE problem of planting in shade is one that many gardeners come up against Fortunately, there is an abundance of varieties that will thrive along a wooded path, or on the shady side of a wall, under a pergola, or in a border where overhanging branches shut out sun.

THE first modern book to be published in popular language on child photography based on principles of psychology has just appeared. It is "Child Photography the Modern Way" (Baltimore: The Camera Magazine. $4.95) and it describes in practical, how-to-do-it terms how Josef Schneider, once a child psychologist but now a professional photographer of babies, gets his subjects to react the way he wants them to.

Cannot something be done to alleviate one of the principal discomforts among those so generously provided us in our post-war prosperity? I refer to the broad casting of music over the loud speakers on luxury coaches.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- The move to establish a separate officer-training academy for the Air Force quietly gathered momentum this week as the newly established Service Academy Board worked on its recommendations for the new military institution.
WASHINGTON, March 19 -- The Voice of America announced tonight that it would begin broadcasting a daily program of information and commentary in Persian to Iran on Monday.

FOR the small suburban garden, suitable locations for a water feature are on or around the terrace and at the sides or the rear of the house. It is important to realize that the beauty of a garden depends as much on the correct placing of water features as on design. An impression of unity between garden and features should be maintained.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 19 -- The West Coast wondered this week about a new situation on the waterfront and what could be expected, as a result, in the way of improved labor relations and recapture of lost business.

LONDON, March 19 (AP) -- The movie technicians union demanded today that the Government take over idle studios to end the film industry's slump. Hundreds of technicians have been laid off in studio closings, brought about by high costs and declining profits.

The French Line announced yesterday that Capt. Joseph Cailloce, former master of the liner De Grasse, has taken over command of the Ile de France now nearing the end of reconversion work at St. Nazaire. The company also reported that Capt. Herve le Huede has been appointed to command the Liberte, formerly the German liner Europa. Capt.

STIMULATING the interest of its more mature audiences might prove a bit easier for the screen were it to alter the tone of the appeals it makes for their patronage. My reference, specifically, is to the low estate of the trailers used to advertise coming attractions.

ACCORDING to the Old Farmer's Almanac, "One swallow doesn't make the spring, nor does the first bluebird or the first robin." There is, however, a definite "advance" of spring from south to north, based on a regular pattern.

How the Controller of the Currency feels about banks investing in the revenue-backed obligations of local government has been put on the record once and for all in clear-cut language. Long the butt of technical rulings into which contradictory meanings had been read, the whole subject of the investment suitability of municipal obligations not backed by the taxing power is now covered fully in a statement by J. L. Robertson, deputy controller of the currency.

THE only difference between a hotbed and a coldframe is that the coldframe is heated only by the sun's rays, while the hotbed is heated by sun plus some artificial heat. One or the other is necessary for the gardener who wants an early start with vegetable and flower plants and to grow any special varieties.

MARGARET BARTON, who collaborated with Sir Osbert Sitwell on a delightful study of Regency Brighton, now retells, in an authoritative, absorbing volume, the story of David Garrick, the great English actor of the eighteenth century.

ITHACA, N. Y., March 19 -- Paced by its two indoor intercollegiate champions, James Fuchs, shot putter and sprinter, and George Wade, miler, Yale's track team defeated Cornell, 64 to 49, in Barton Hall tonight. Fuchs and Wade scored 10 points apiece.
SO many correspondents have written books about the Soviet Union that one of the problems for each newcomer must be to find a suitable title that has not been used before.

WILLIAM BARLOW left New York to find the gold that his father had once buried when pursued by pirates. The Revolutionary War caught up with him in Charlestown Harbor and he helped General Marion and General Moultrie defend the new fort on Sullivan's Island.

The argument put forward for the disqualification from teaching positions of Communists, that is, party members, is that Communists are not themselves free intellectuals because they are ironbound to the "party line."

TO obtain the most pleasure and use from any property, it should be carefully designed before any planting is done. This is particularly true of the small property where every inch counts, and where everything will be under close scrutiny.

TIN PAN ALLEY works every day at its job of creating popular songs. While it is always interested in a quick turnover, a constant parade of machine-made hits, the actual hope of every music publisher is to find an occasional song that will maintain its popularity through the years and eventually establish a kind of permanence justifying the industry's crowning adjective, "standard."

I read with much interest the discouraging set of statistics expounded by Lehman Engel in his article entitled "Letter to a Would-Be Duse." What he says for the most part is true. However, I would like to bring a brighter side of the dramatic picture to the attention of the public.

ORGANIZATION of the New York Good Roads Association, an unofficial body to promote greater interest in public highways and wider recognition of their economic importance, was announced last week by Charles H. Sells, former state superintendent of public works. Mr. Sells is executive director of the association, which is open to all New York State residents over 18, and has yearly dues of $1 a member.
Alarms and threats preceded and followed the publication of the North Atlantic Treaty last week as the approach of spring intensified the war of nerves in Europe.

PEONIES should be cultivated as ofte: as necessary to keep weeds down and the ground in good working condition at all times. When cultivating, however, care should be taken not to injure the roots or crowns. Whenever rain does not supply sufficient moisture, watering is accomplished by soaking the beds -- not sprinkling them.

Jokes circulating in Europe today include a few that are simply "a laugh for a laugh's sake," but most of them serve as ideological and political weapons. Many are merely new versions of old standbys. Here is a selection forwarded by Times correspondents.

WARSAW, March 19 (AP) -- The Polish Government told the Roman Catholic hierarchy tonight that it must stop all "inimical acts against the people's state" before there could be peace between the Church and state in Poland.

The withdrawal of Miss Sarah Gibson Blanding, president of Vassar College, as .a sponsor of the Cultural and Scientific Conference for World Peace became known yesterday as plans were being formed here for a "counter rally."

POSTMASTER General Jesse M. Donaldson made available last week a photograph of the 3-cent green stamp which will be issued on April 27 to commemorate the inauguration last Jan. 2 of Puerto Rico's first elected Governor, Luis Munoz Marin.

The regular season of the National Hockey League will come to an end tonight, when all six teams in the loop will see action. With the play-off positions virtually settled all around very little depends on the outcome of tonight's clashes. Very little, that is, from a team standpoint.
TEX McCRARY and Jinx Falkenburg, the professional couple about town, have joined the ranks of television attractions with a rather hectic half-hour known as "Preview" (8 P. M. Mondays on CBS-TV).

SOME of the gravest lapses of taste and worst instances of carelessness in publishing history have been committed in the cause of supplying the demand for popular-priced art books in America. The sins have been many: sloppy editing, haphazard arrangements, superficial and inaccurate texts, pictures distorted through "bleeding," disparate pages resulting from re-use of existing plates, and, above all, bilious off-register color.

One of the top powers in the sport since the middle of the last decade, New York University regained a place it has held eight times in the last twelve tourneys when it captured the three-weapon crown at the 52d annual Intercollegiate Fencing Association championships yesterday.

BERENICE ABBOTT, Bruce Downes and Charles Sheeler will comprise a panel to discuss "Photography to Us" at 4 P. M. today at the Riverdale neighborhood and Library Association, 5521 Mosholu Avenue. The symposium will follow an exhibition of about 150 photographic prints, in black-and-white and in color, by residents of the Riverdale community.

WASHINGTON, March 20 (UP) -- Senator Brien McMahon, Democrat, of Connecticut, said today he hoped to bring into the open this week a sharp split within the joint Congressional Atomic Energy Committee over how much secret information should be made public.

Heartened by settlement of the eleven-month-old dispute involving non-operating employes of the nation's railroads, the National Mediation Board last night called union and management representatives to meet in Washington Wednesday to seek adjustment of the controversy that has halted Railway Express Agency operations in New York and other Eastern centers.

LONDON, March 20 -- East London went through several hours of unprecedented mob excitement and disorders this evening when Sir Oswald E. Mosley's followers and angry Communists had their worst clash since the war ended. It took very heavy contingents of police on foot, in cars and on horseback to prevent what might have been serious rioting.
Sixty-six members of the Junior Blue Jackets of America patroled New York Harbor yesterday on the Coast Guard cutter Navesink. There was no seasickness.

Stopped cold in their history-making bid to win both the National Invitation and N. C. A. A. tournaments, the University of Kentucky's Wildcats will set out anew and try to annex just half of those honors when they help open the National Collegiate Athletic Association's Eastern Regional basketball play-offs at Madison Square Garden tonight.

BOSTON, March 20 (AP) -- Bostons Bruins clinched second place in the National Hockey League tonight by trouncing Toronto's Maple Leafs, 7 -- 2, while Detroit's first-place Red Wings were beating the Montreal Canadiens, 2 -- 1.

WASHINGTON, March 20 (UP) -- Government officials disclosed today that an increasing number of closed-shop and union-shop contracts were being "bootlegged" in violation of the Taft-Hartley Act and state labor laws.

The problem of juvenile delinquency in New York and around the country has come into sharp focus recently. Reported cases attributed to teen-age children reveal common behavior patterns and similar backgrounds which point to neglect from family and society. The commendable tendency of the courts dealing with the problem lately is to place new emphasis upon the sources of crime in the individual's surroundings.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, March 20 -- After having declined for two months, unemployment in Belgian industry increased again last week by nearly 1 per cent of the total labor force, according to unpublished official figures.
WILKES-BARRE, Pa., March 20 -- Wilkes - Barre's Barons poured in 127 points today to beat the Hartford Hurricanes and establish an all time professional basketball single game scoring record.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- Senator McGrath charged tonight that the American Medical Association was resorting to forms of coercion to force doctors to join its fight against the Administration's national health insurance plan.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- The National Federation of American Shipping, Inc., urged Congress today to give immediate consideration to its long-range merchant marine proposals despite a plea from another quarter that "controversial" items be set aside for the present.

One-room shacks or "wannigans," as they are called in Alaska, without running water or electric light, and with only kerosene stoves to supply heat, are the normal living quarters for many armed service personnel in Alaska.

ROME, March 20 -- More than 200 public meetings to explain the purpose and significance of Italy's adherence to the North Atlantic Pact were held throughout Italy yesterday and today by the Christian Democratic party.

ALBANY, March 20 -- Owen D. Young, retired industrialist who headed the commission that recommended establishment of a state university, urged in a letter made public today that all pending bills to revise the State University law be withdrawn or killed.

LONDON, March 20 -- The Moscow radio's first English language commentary on the Atlantic pact, monitored here today, said that the terms of the projected alliance "provide Anglo-American warmongers with an opportunity to utilize any pretext that suits them in order to unleash aggression."

The homemaker who has been thinking of throwing out that chair with the broken cane seat or a bed with damaged cane headboard might now decide to restore them to use, for today caning is achieving renewed popularity. Many designs, especially in the modern field, use new plastic materials and clever combinations of traditional caning.

WASHINGTON, March 20 (UP) -- Thirty-three young farmers from the Netherlands will arrive in the United States about April 7 to spend six months working on American farms, according to an announcement by the Economic Cooperation Administration.

MOSCOW, March 20 (UP) -- The army organ, Red Star, condemned a proposed Pacific pact as "intended to supplement the aggressive North Atlantic union." Pravda, official organ of the Communist party, reported that Spain was being prepared for a "significant role in the aggressive plans of the Anglo-American bloc."

Spring, followed by warm weather, is obviously the prediction that inspired the fashions to be shown this evening at Gimbels. The group of dresses and jacket ensembles selected for the fashion show are all priced under $15 and cover the three major size ranges.
TOKYO, March 20 (AP) -- An exiled prince of Indo-China today threatened more bloodshed for Asia unless the French granted his country independence.

MOSCOW, March 20 -- The text of the North Atlantic pact was published by the entire Soviet press today for the consideration of millions of Soviet readers who have been repeatedly warned by the Government and newspapers that this United States project represents a most serious threat to world peace.

The fundamental principles of American foreign policy which produced the North Atlantic Security Pact have been laid down anew, and in more concrete form than ever before, in the various pronouncements issued by the Government in connection with the publication of the Pact itself.
Robert Faegre has been appointed sales manager of the paper division of Minnesota and Ontario Paper Company, Minneapolis. He succeeds R. O. Warner, who has resigned.
DETROIT, March 20 (AP) -- The Detroit Red Wings battled their way to a 2-1 victory over the Montreal Canadiens in the final National Hockey League game of the season here tonight.

Sailcloth, with its clear colors and clean, sharp prints, plays the leading role in an exhibition called "Accent on Summer Living," opening today at the decorators' showroom of H. B. Lehman-Connor, Inc., 509 Madison Avenue.

Stamp collectors and Republicans alike lately have been denouncing the Administration. Too many commemorative issues, they say, too many dedicatory weeks. Since the present day promises to be peaceful, this column has no intention of jumping head first into that partisan matter.

LONDON, Monday, March 21 (AP) -- The Moscow radio said today that the Soviet Union and the Korean People's Democratic Republic had signed an agreement on economic and cultural cooperation providing for a "considerable increase" in trade between the two countries.

WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP) -- Fifty-five Senators said today they were inclined to favor the principle of the North Atlantic Treaty and only one -- Senator George W. Malone, Republican, of Nevada -- came out publicly against it.

WASHINGTON, March 20 (UP) -- Mayor George W. Welsh of Grand Rapids, Mich., said today that the nation's cities had been forced to turn to the Federal Government for help on housing and other problems because state governments had refused them aid.

Sales and earnings of the Combustion Engineering - Superheater, Inc., in 1948 were the highest on record, Frederic A. Schaff, chairman, and Joseph V. Santry, president, reported in the annual statement to stockholders, released today. The company is the result of a merger effected on Dec. 31, 1948, of the Combustion Engineering Company, Inc., and the Superheater Company.

Activity in the wholesale apparel market here last week was stimulated by what buyers described as "unusual values," according to reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices. Although coat and suit stocks were at a pre-Easter peak, retailers placed many fill-in orders.

LONDON, March 20 -- The City's chilly reception last week of the Government's economic survey found its only possible reflection in the stock markets. Industrial securities naturally bore the brunt of the attack, which at first sight appeared to be fully justified.
ST. LOUIS, Mo., March 20 (UP) -- Wabash Railroad officials said today that they would conform to "Government procedure" in attempting to settle the strike of 3,500 operating employes in six states.

A gay assemblage of plastic-coated chintzes is Schumacher's welcome contribution to outdoor fabric selections for summer. They look no tougher than the finest of glazed chintzes, although they are somewhat heavier to feel and could certainly be used to advantage indoors wherever glazed chintz would be appropriate.

Although Barrie Stavis has completely rewritten "The Sun and I," the new version is no improvement over the play the Federal Theatre put on in 1937. It is still the sort of drama that needs the cerebral agility of Bernard Shaw. Having concluded a highly creditable production of "Blood Wedding," the New Stages put on "The Sun and I" last evening in their Bleecker Street playhouse.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 20 (UP) -- The Government announced today a Cabinet shake-up in the republic of Bosnia-Herzegovina, one of the six states that make up Yugoslavia.

LONDON, March 20 -- Harry Pollitt, general secretary of the British Communist party, called on all British workers this afternoon to demonstrate their opposition to the North Atlantic Treaty. At the same time Emanuel Shinwell, Secretary of State for War, speaking in another part of England, promised that the British Government would carry out its obligations under the pact.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, March 20 -- The Commission of Inquiry into the causes of the racial riots in Durban last January, during which 142 were killed and more than 1,000 were wounded, has decided to close its public hearings tomorrow and draft its report.

There has been no recession in the magnesium fabricating and products business, and many new products now in production indicate increased volume for many industry members during the coming year, Charles I. Vogel and Ralph G. Gillespie, executives of Brooks Perkins, Inc., Detroit, disclosed here yesterday in announcing their company's new magnesium truck hopper and other new products.

Mae West, who is recovering from a triple fracture of the left ankle, won't be able to resume her role this week in "Diamond Lil," as had been expected by the management. Last night her physician reported that she was "progressing very nicely."

CLEARWATER, Fla., March 20 -- A decade or so ago the advertisements for a course in training the memory ran the oft repeated catchline, "of course, I remember. You're Mr. Addison Sims of Seattle." The lucky fellow who had taken the course and therefore never could forget a name or anything else, then went on to tell his surprised acquaintance where they had met and furnished full details as to his business and family ties.
SAN DIEGO, Calif., March 20 -- The Giants, aided by some lusty clouting on the part of Sid Gordon and Bobby Thomson, tripped the White Sox, 7 to 6, today.

ATLANTIC CITY, Mar. 20 (AP) -- Walter Elliott, 43-year-old miner who left the coal pits at Virden, Ill., to compete in the American Bowling Congress tournament, took seventh place in the singles today with a 692 score.

No matter how March winds blow, spring has come to at least one place in New York -- the International Flower Show, which opens at noon today at Grand Central Palace, Lexington Avenue between Forty-sixth and Forty-seventh Streets.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., March 20 -- The Rev. Dr. George Hugh Smyth, under whose leadership the Hitchcock Memorial Church here has grown from a congregation of nineteen members and nine children into one of 2,218 members and 464 children, will retire this spring.

The spring tide of art exhibitions brings more than twenty new attractions into local galleries and museums this week, including the Brooklyn Museum's third national print annual which opens to the public on Wednesday at the museum.

The skill with which Detective Margaret M. Leonard played the drab role of a cleaning woman was a major factor in trapping three men engaged in distributing narcotics on a nation-wide scale, her male partners said yesterday when they arraigned the prisoners before Chief Magistrate Edgar Bromberger in Felony Court.

The North Atlantic Treaty was characterized yesterday by Prof. Frederick L. Schuman of Williams College as a contradictory, self-defeating measure that might promote rather than prevent "a barbarous war with little prospect of victory."

IRVINGTON, N. Y., March 20 -- Consistent with the current belief that children suffering from physical illness have resultant emotional problems, Irvington House, which has been a pioneer in child heart care, is providing psychiatric as well as cardiac treatment for its 100 young rheumatic heart patients.
WESTWOOD, N. J., March 20 -- The 800 bicycle riders of Westwood, mostly children, were on warning today to proceed safely and sanely -- or else.
Two boys sledded down a snowy slope beside Cleopatra's Needle in Central Park yesterday at 5:49 P. M. as the sun slid northward across the celestial equator.
Thomas J. Curran, Secretary of State of New York, asserted yesterday that the United States was "acquiescing to the enslavement of millions of Europeans by Russia."
The last-place New York Rangers handled themselves like "logical contenders" as they skated to a 5-to-1 triumph over the Chicago Black Hawks at Madison Square Garden last night.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- President Truman will meet his buffeted legislative leaders from the Capitol tomorrow morning to take stock of the Administration's program before Congress. This will be the regular Monday morning conference but the first since the President's holiday at Key West.

A talented young violinist in the person of Albert Weintraub made his debut at Town Hall late yesterday afternoon. At the age of 21 his instincts proved to be musical to the point where he had trouble playing trivial music well.
WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP) -- Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican, of Ohio, said today that he might support an increase in taxes if there were any "substantial" Government deficit on July 1.

BERLIN, March 20 -- The United States and Britain differ seriously on the principles of the trizonal fusion agreement and completion of this integral part of the West German state now appears more remote than at any time since the signing of the London agreement last June.

Persecution of the Roman Catholic Church in Soviet-dominated countries is the result of Stalin's "fear of the Holy See as the only free moral authority left in the world," Msgr. Fulton J. Sheen of the faculty of Catholic University declared yesterday.

More than 800 executives are now working with the National Security Resources Board to solve the problems of preparedness for industrial mobilization, and this number is expected to reach 1,500 before the present studies have been finished. There is nothing alarming in this news.

Foreign exchange market was quiet during the past week with a good demand from commercials for spot sterling at $4.03 1/4, far forwards (sixty days and beyond) were in liberal supply which widened the discount more than 1 cent on spot; near-by contracts, however, held steady.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- A bill permitting draftees up to the age of 23 to choose the date of their induction will be introduced into the House tomorrow by Representative Frederic R. Coudert Jr., Republican, of New York.

A statement attacking the State Department for its criticism of the forthcoming Cultural and Scientific Conference for World Peace was issued yesterday by five Americans. The conference will open on Friday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

The Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., subject of one of the most controversial rate cases in the history of the Public Service Commission, had operating revenues of $370,832,235 last year, the largest in its sixty-five years of existence, according to the annual report that will be distributed this week to more than 155,000 stockholders.
WASHINGTON, March 20 (UP) -- The post-war seller's market has declined in nearly every line of commodities except automobiles and metals, the Department of Commerce reported today.

Kenneth D. Johnson, general counsel of the National Security Resources Board, has been named dean of Columbia University's New York School of Social Work, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, university president, announced yesterday. Succeeding Dr. Walter W. Pettit, who retired last September, Mr. Johnson will begin his association with the school on April 1, although not assuming the deanship until Oct. 1.
A young Brooklyn mother, trapped on the third floor of a burning building with her four small children, hurled them one at a time into a fire net and then leaped to safety herself yesterday morning.

WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP) -- More than 200,000,000,000 gallons of water are being pumped out of Pennsylvania's anthracite coal mines each year, but the mines are still being drowned out gradually, the Bureau of Mines said today.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., March 20 -- The all-breed event of the Providence County Kennel Club ended exactly the same tonight as the one at Manchester, N. H., the day before when the imported Scottish terrier, Mrs. John Winant's Ch. Walsing Winning Trick of Edgerstoune, took best in show and a boxer, the Claredda Kennels' Ch. Merry Monarch, placed at best American-bred.
WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP) -- The Justice Department has advised Congress that any court action to determine state rights to the water of the Colorado River should provide for complete adjudication.

Suspension of business by several well-known dress manufacturers in the medium and high price range has been motivated more by personal reasons than business conditions, it was pointed out last week. The poor spring season, however, has accelerated decisions to quit, manufacturers said, or to suspend operations until a greater degree of stability is achieved in the garment market.

Sinclair Refining Company will open a $250,000 campaign tomorrow in five Midwest cities to introduce what is claimed to be the world's first anti-rust gasoline. The company will use color pages and 1,200- and 1,000-line black and white ads in daily newspapers in Chicago, Detroit, Cleveland, Indianapolis and Milwaukee.
WASHINGTON, March 20 (UP) -- Oscar R. Ewing, Federal security administrator, today announced the allocation of $51,622 in Federal grants for cancer-control and teaching activities.

PARIS, March 9 -- In its efforts to organize a bloc to oppose the combined world influence of the Americas plus the Marshall Plan grouping of nations, Moscow must be fully aware that its economic gains from a Communist victory in China will not only be slight -- at least for several years -- but accompanied by a great increase in economic responsibilities that may prove a burden to the Soviet Union.

ALBANY, March 20 -- Republican leaders of the Legislature are considering an amendment to New York's stand-by rent control law that would permit the state to take over residential rent control through proclamation by the Governor.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 20 -- The Yugoslavs challenged their enemies of the Communist Information Bureau today to prove how their concept of economic cooperation differed from that of the Marshall Plan and the Truman Plan to develop backward countries in so far as the "exploitation" of small countries was concerned.

The Federation of Greek Communities of Greater New York, composed of eighteen Greek Orthodox Churches having a total membership of 80,000 persons, opened last night a week of activities to commemorate the 128th anniversary of Greek independence.
WARSAW, March 20 (AP) -- Alexander L. Zawadski, a member of the Politburo of the Communist United Workers' party, has become Poland's First Vice Premier.

FRANKFORT, Germany, March 20 -- Socialist and trade union elements in Germany have won an outstanding victory in their efforts to influence Allied Ruhr policies, it became known today with the disclosure of the final list of German steel trustees agreed upon by Gen. Lucius D. Clay, United States Military Governor, and Gen. Sir Brian Robertson, his British counterpart.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- John Foster Dulles, in a broadcast sponsored by the State Department, today voiced the hope and belief that "actions will make it clear that the North Atlantic pact is only defensive."

Reporting on operations last year of the Kendall Company, H. R. Lane, president of the forty-five-year-old manufacturer of surgical dressings and cotton textiles, informed shareholders in the annual statement to be released today that sales and earnings were the largest in its history.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., March 20 (AP) -- Senator J. Howard McGrath, Democratic National Chairman, said here tonight that President Truman "has no immediate intention" of stumping the nation for support of his legislative program.
Justice William O. Douglas of the United States Supreme Court charged last night that Soviet Russia was responsible for the present world discontent.

YONKERS, N. Y., March 20 -- A top union leader today predicted "rough going" for Yonkers if the city administration persisted in its decision to apply penalties of the Condon-Wadlin Act to 500 reinstated strikers in the Yonkers Public Works Department.

Representative John W. McCormack of Massachusetts, majority leader of the House, denied yesterday that recent actions by Congress had constituted a "deadly setback" for President Truman's Fair Deal legislative program and said that the time to appraise Congress was not in March but in June.
LAKE PLACID, N. Y., March 20 (AP) -- Al Broadhurst of Boston, North American indoor speed skating champion, won the senior men's division honors at the Lake Placid invitation races today.

The New York Rovers rang down the curtain on their 1948-49 home hockey season at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon on a happy note. A goal by Val DeLory in 12:44 of the third period enabled the Red Shirts to gain a 4-3 success over the rugged Soo Indians of Sault Ste. Marie, Mich., in an action-filled contest.

Bayard Rustin, 34-year-old Negro secretary of the Fellowship of Reconciliation, and Igal Roodenko, 32-year-old horticulturist and printer, left Pennsylvania Station yesterday afternoon for Hillsboro, N. C. where, they said, they will voluntarily surrender to serve thirty-day sentences for their defiance of the state's transportation segregation laws.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 20 -- Mervyn Leroy has been named by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer to direct "Key to the City" with Clark Gable and Loretta Young as his next assignment. Wayne Griffin, who brought the photoplay to the studio, will produce it next summer.

The largest gathering ever to attend the annual communion-consecration breakfast of the Grand Lodge of Masons of New York State -- 3,160 persons -- overtaxed the facilities of the main ballroom of the Astor Hotel yesterday morning to hear Dr. Abba Hillel Silver, rabbi of The Temple, Cleveland, and Lieut. Gov. Joe R. Hanley of New York join in condemning discrimination against minorities.

BERLIN, March 7 -- One of the most depressing aspects of German politics today is the failure of the political parties to attract any substantial support in the generation that has moved toward maturity during the war and the Allied occupation.

HAVANA, March 20 -- The Bellatrix, 58-foot Cuban schooner, owned by Manuel Rasco Jr. of the Miramar Yacht Club, crossed the finish line first tonight in Havana Harbor in the sixteenth annual St. Petersburg-to-Havana yacht race.

PITTSBURGH, March 20 -- The nation's steel industry last week again made a record with ingot output at 102 per cent of rated capacity, unchanged from the week before. The same rate or close to it is expected for this week. The coal impasse will have little effect on output unless it lasts more than the announced two weeks.
MOBILE, Ala., March 20 -- Alabama States' Righters have decided to hold their own dinner in opposition to the Jefferson-Jackson Day dinner organized by Truman Democrats for Birmingham, April 12.

The cargo-passenger vessel Schiedyk, latest addition to Holland-America Line's post-war fleet, is expected to arrive here this afternoon on her maiden voyage from Rotterdam. The freighter, with twelve passengers aboard, will dock at the company's pier, Fifth Street, Hoboken, N. J.

CHICAGO, March 20 -- Oats showed independent strength last week on the Board of Trade, as has been the case recently, with elevator interests and commission houses on the buying side. Not only is the acreage for this year expected to be decreased somewhat from that of 1948, but it is also figured that farmers will hold off selling their grain until more is known about the start of the new crop.

The fight must go on. If a handful of Southern Democrats and reactionary Republicans can team up to defeat the will of the overwhelming majority, then democracy has received the kind of blow which produces cynicism and communism.
COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo., March 20 -- Boston College's Eagles winged back to New England today with the National Collegiate A. A. hockey championship tucked in their stick bag.

BOTH in his life and writings Charles Walter Stansby Williams was one of the most remarkable literary figures of our time. Lacking an earned degree -- Oxford gave him an honorary M. A. -- he yet became one of Oxford's most learned teachers of literature. He was also one of the most popular. The British "Who's Who" for 1945, the year of his death, lists thirty-five titles by him: novels, plays, poems, essays, biographies.

SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, March 20 -- Irresolute college administrators are to blame for much of the excessive drinking and moral laxity revealed on scattered college campuses in recent years, according to Elles M. Derby of Ridgewood, N. J., president of Lambda Chi Alpha, one of the largest intercollegiate social fraternities.

Dr. Herbert Vere Evatt, President of the United Nations General Assembly, has turned over to Duell, Sloan Pearce the manuscript of a new book, which will be published on June 14. "The Task of the Nations" is an evaluation of the United Nations since its creation at the San Francisco Conference.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- A twenty-seven-year war over water, with Arizona and California as the chief antagonists, is erupting anew on the Washington front in an outburst of bills, charges and counter-charges.
PITTSBURGH, March 20 (AP) -- Unemployment resulting from the mine-work stoppage ordered by John L. Lewis passed the half-million mark today.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- Production of television receivers in February totaled 118,938 sets, compared with 121,238 produced in January, according to a report issued here today by the Radio Manufacturers Association. February television production was held back by a shortage of cathode ray tubes, it was said.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., March 20 -- Carrying on within a matter of minutes of official spring, thirty-two dinghies were out at the Larchmont Yacht Club today in what was a mild session on the water under all conditions except the cold.
Municipal bonds coming up for sale this week total $82,403,098, compared with $46,368,590 last week, and a weekly average for the year to date of $62,258,332, according to the Daily Bond Buyer.

ZURICH, Switzerland, March 20 -- The Belgian experiment in foreign exchange appears to have been a success far beyond expectations. Taking a daring action, the Belgium-Luxembourg Exchange Office announced on March 8 that thereafter Belgian franc bank notes would be repatriable in any quantity from any country by foreigners of any nationality and be available without any restriction for making any kind of payment to residents, permanent or temporary, in Belgium.

Not since the days of Thomas Mott Osborne's great moral triumph in his fight for enlightened prison reform at Sing Sing Prison. New York, has a case stirred such widespread public interest as Dr. Miriam Van Waters' magnificent victory last week for progressive prison advance at the Massachusetts Women's Reformatory.

CHICAGO, March 20 -- The Government's purchases of cash corn late last week were not reported officially, but trade estimates ranged from 300,000 to 1,500,000 bushels. Some interests said that all of the grain wanted was not secured, because the demand is for 14 per cent moisture grain, which is hard to meet.

One hundred persons gathered yesterday at 113th Street and Riverside Drive about the statue of Lajos Kossuth, the Hungarian statesman, and saw Selden Chapin, recently recalled United States Minister to Hungary, place a wreath.

CHICAGO, March 20 -- The nation's railroads and the sixteen non-operating unions reached a settlement today in their eleven-month dispute over wages and hours. Covered are employes who do not work on moving trains.

President Truman has returned from Florida a pound or two overweight but with enough work ahead of him to suggest that he may soon be back to fighting trim. During his absence the Administration lost the filibuster battle and with it, probably, the hope of enacting any significant part of the civil rights program promised in both major party platforms.

The eleven games that had been adjourned from the first four rounds of the international chess masters tournament at Mar del Plata were played off yesterday, according to a report received from Argentina.
ASPEN, Col., March 20 (AP) -- The North American ski championships were won today by two members of the daredevil French national team.

PARIS, March 20 -- For the first time in twenty years the ceiling of the authorized total of advances to the Bank of France is going to be lowered on March 31. It will drop from 200 billion to 175 billion francs.

The music of Robert Starer and Remi Gassmann was presented on Saturday night's Composers' Forum at McMillin Theatre, Columbia University. The quality of the music and performances made it the most attractive program of the series to date, despite the stark atmosphere of bare walls and naked floodlights.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- The United Jewish Appeal for $250,000,000 for the resettlement of homeless Jews got under way today with initial cash contributions totaling $26,851,967 from 126 communities in the country.

As a means of proteoting their occupancy of the stores in the East Harlem blockfront on the west side of Third Avenue, between East 123d- nd 124th Streets, a group of shop owners have combined under the corporate name of Third Avenue Retailers, Inc., and have purchased the nine three-story buildings in the block.

Down on Gramercy Park in a building crammed with mementoes and relics of the theatre and allied arts a group of distinguished actors, writers and artists paid tribute last night to a man who has never been on a stage, written a line or painted a picture.

Representative Vito Marcantonio, state chairman of the American Labor Party, denounced both Mayor O'Dwyer and Clendenin J. Ryan yesterday for their parts in the wiretapping case, the grand jury investigation of which will be resumed today.

STE. MARGUERITE, Que., March 20 -- A plucky Eastern United States team that appeared faced with defeat following yesterday's downhill race, today made a remarkable recovery in the slalom and alpine combined events to top a favored Canadian array as the annual international women's ski classic wound up under superb snow and weather conditions.
AMMAN, Transjordan, March 20 -- The Transjordanian Government has formally requested military assistance from Britain to defend its southern territory from reported incursions by Israeli troops.

The National Association for American Composers and conductors presented its fifth and final concert of the season last night at Times Hall. As at the preceding ones, admission was free and the program was devoted to music by American composers.

CHICAGO, March 20 -- The grain markets were unsettled on the Board of Trade last week. Liquidation was on early, but a resumption of fairly aggressive buying of cash wheat and corn by the Government brought about a strong rally, with wheat selling yesterday at the best price of the week and with the May inclined to gain ground on the new-crop months.
BERLIN, March 20 (AP) -- The text of the Western allied announcement outlawing the Soviet East mark in Western Berlin:

American Smelting Refining Company and consolidated subsidiaries had a net income of $38,926,816 during 1948, equal to $13.47 a share on 2,630,000 shares of common stock outstanding, according to the annual report to stockholders made public yesterday.

The proxy contest for control of the Merritt-Chapman Scott Corporation, a marine salvage, engineering and construction organization, continued over the week-end, with the independent stockholders' committee making a second solicitation of proxies for its slate of thirteen directors, and a group of employes of the company endorsing the present management.

NEW ORLEANS, March 20 -- City and port officials and representatives of International House and the International Trade Mart outlined today two recent moves in the tourist and educational fields designed to better hemisphere relations.

Looking back from here to there, the distance to the other side of the Atlantic is more impressive than the nearness. Europe is not so close to America as an overnight air flight suggests. The wonder of dining one night in New York and lunching next day in Paris actually accentuates the difference in the cuisine -- and all those larger differences that never broke on you so startlingly when the journey was longer.

WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP) -- Secretary of the Army Kenneth C. Royall announced today that four National Guard and four Reserve officers would go on active duty to help formulate future organization plans for those component branches of the armed forces.

WAITSFIELD, Vt., March 20 -- Ragnar Naess of the Amateur Ski Club of New York won the first Eastern veterans giant slalom championship at Mad River Glen today, negotiating the twenty-four-gate course in 1:18.6.

Two buildings with a total of forty apartments at 794 to 812 Middle Neck Road, southeast corner of Steamboat Road, Great Neck, L. I., were purchased by Levine Jacobs, operators, who were represented by Goodman Mabel, attorneys.

Immediate introduction in the State Legislature of a bill to make state rent control operative in any subdivision of the state that becomes decontrolled as a result of any such bill as the local option rent control measure passed by the House of Representatives was urged yesterday by the Liberal party.

Lillian Chookasian revealed a natural contralto voice of extraordinary magnificence in her recital at Times Hall yesterday afternoon. She was capable of producing tones of gorgeous color and richness all through her wide range, and her singing was sustained and powerful.

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., March 20 -- There were no extra inning antics by the Dodgers here this afternoon. In fact, their operations during the eight and one-half innings played were exceedingly futile.

The whole combat ground force, up to such elements as light tanks and 155-mm. guns, will soon be transportable by air. This opinion was expressed yesterday by officers of the First Army's headquarters on Governors Island in discussing an article by Maj. Gen. Henry B. Saylor in the current issue of the professional magazine, Army Ordnance.
TAMPA, Fla., March 20 -- Yankee pitchers had their first experience of the year with enemy home-run hitters today with painful consequences.

No originality is claimed for a party centered around the theme of "Please come for dessert ant coffee." It is not novel, merely apropos. Entertaining of this sort is inexpensive at a time when the budget-breaking effects of the March 15 deadline are still being felt.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., March 20 (AP) -- Cary Middlecoff kept a healthy distance ahead of the field as he turned the three-quarters pole in the Jacksonville open golf tournament today.

Plans are under way for the televising of "Arsenic and Old Lace," as the Ford Television Hour's presentation over CBS-TV on Monday, April 11, from 9 to 10 P. M. Boris Karloff and Josephine Hull, who handled leading roles in the Howard Lindsay-Russel Crouse production during its long Broadway run, are slated for their original roles in the forthcoming television production.

HAIFA, Israel, March 20 -- Israeli and Lebanese delegations initialed an armistice agreement this evening after a meeting at the frontier post at Ras en Naqura. They will meet again at 11 A. M. Wednesday in the border customs house to affix formal signatures to the documents.

Offering guidance without charge to young persons, veterans and the physically handicapped of all ages, the Vocational Advisory Service has always managed to exist on money given by foundations, a few philanthropic individuals, and, in recent years, the Greater New York Fund. Now, however, for the first time in its thirty-year history it is appealing to the community for financial support because of higher costs and the increased demand for its services.

Fear that the North Atlantic defense pact might lead to a new type of "Maginot Line" mentality was voiced yesterday by the Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell, pastor of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street.

As a result of well-advertised and well-received retail clearances, the outlook for the men's clothing industry was somewhat brighter on Jan. 31, 1949, it was announced over the week-end by Market Planning Service.

BERLIN, March 20 -- The West German mark was decreed today the sole legal currency in Western Berlin, and authorities of the Western powers declared "we are ready" for any Russian retaliatory measures.

Anna Ribner bought the five-story apartment house with twelve four-room suites on a lot 25 by 100 feet at 599 East 136th Street, the Bronx, from the Central Savings Bank. The property is assessed for $17,000 and was sold through Alexander Delle Cese, broker.

PARIS, Monday, March 21 -- Premier Henri Queuille's middle-of-the-road coalition of parties, with its combined strength, took an early lead today in the French cantonal elections, but the followers of Charles de Gaulle had won more seats than any other single segment.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 20 -- Israel and Lebanon agreed today on terms of an armistice, which will be signed on Wednesday. After repeated delays, the negotiations are now believed complete.
Six new films, including importations from Poland and England, will open in midtown theatres this week. The programs follow:
CHICAGO, March 20 -- Price changes in lard were nervous on the Board of Trade last week, with numerous small and rapid advances and declines, reflecting commission-house operations.

Iceland will receive an immediate report on the North Atlantic Treaty discussions and a decision will be made by the Government "in the next few days" as to whether it will become a party to the pact, Bjarni Benediktsson, Minister of Foreign Affairs of Iceland, said yesterday at La Guardia Airport, before leaving for home.

The United States Government should pursue a tougher policy toward those who seek to undermine American democratic institutions, the Rev. Dr. Lewis E. Christian, pastor of the Washington Square Methodist Church, 133 West Fourth Street, declared in his morning sermon yesterday.
AUGUSTA, Ga., March 20 (AP) -- A talented competitor from Findlay, -- Ohio Miss Peggy Kirk -- won the titleholders golf tournament today, her first major victory, with a record 299.

The Congress is now considering legislation to change the rule on overtime pay which the Supreme Court enunciated last June in the so-called longshoremen's overtime - on - overtime case. In that case the Supreme Court held that extra pay for night-time stevedoring did not excuse the employer from paying overtime for work over forty hours a week.
Dr. Walter N. Beekman, Brooklyn dentist and "dean" of Negro professional men in that community, yesterday attributed his progress to proficiency in several fields, including music and pharmacy.
Cotton prices here continued to move narrowly last week. On Saturday, active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were up 13 points to unchanged from the previous week.

NANKING, March 20 -- Nationalist B-24 bombers scored three hits yesterday on the runaway cruiser Chungking while she lay at anchor off Hulutao, a Communist-held port in South Manchuria, it was reported here tonight.
WASHINGTON, March 20 -- The votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls during the period March 12 to 18 are given in the appended tabulation:

Four armed robbers who invaded a house party on the Dutchess County estate of a greeting card manufacturer and had to shoot up the place to impress fourteen guests with their purpose were in the custody of the State Police yesterday.

ST. LOUIS, March 20 -- The St. Louis Symphony Orchestra closed its sixty-ninth season at the municipally-built and owned Kiel Auditorium here this afternoon, and it was evident, as it was at last night's concert, that the audience and the orchestra headed by Vladimir Golschmann hold each other in high mutual regard.

Because for centuries the church has been unduly optimistic, it continues to "soft pedal" and almost ignore the existence of sin, the Rev. Richard E. McEvoy declared yesterday in a sermon at St. Mark's Protestant Episcopal Church - in - the - Bouwerie, Second Avenue and Tenth Street.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- Senator Henry Cabot Lodge Jr., Republican, of Massachusetts, declared today that splinter parties would lose their present balance of power in Presidential elections if the electoral votes were divided in direct proportion to the popular vote in each state.
ALBANY, March 20 (AP) -- George L. Hinman of the Board of Regents declined comment today on Mr. Young's letter, but released the reply of his father. Harvey D. Hinman, which said in part:

In its first change of ownership in fifty-four years, the property at 349-51 West Twenty-eigth Street, consisting of two fiv-story apartment houses in the Chelsea section of Manhattan, was sold by the William Ottmann Estate to an investing client of Sidney Rubell and George Hallock Jr., brokers.

WASHINGTON, March 20 (UP) -- Senator Kenneth S. Wherry, Republican, of Nebraska, today called plans for a Missouri Valley Authority and similar river basin developments "another example of the 'creeping socialism' which confronts the people."
The Maritime Commission may take final action today on at least two applications for operating differential subsidies, spokesmen for the Government agency said yesterday.

A Pan American Airways Boeing Stratocruiser, huge double-decked airliner over which the Port of New York Authority and three of the airlines have been feuding since Jan. 25, landed for the first time in the New York area last night.

GARMISCH, Germany, March 20 (AP) -- A rough ice hockey match, marked by fist fights and arguments, was awarded to the American Amateur Hockey Association team on a forfeit today when the Swiss national team walked from the ice in the second period.

The finals of the open pair championship, the major event of the Eastern States regional contract bridge tournament, were won last night by B. M. Raymond of New York and A. Goldstein of Brooklyn. The match was played at the Park Sheraton Hotel.
Two Lutheran parishes in this city dedicated new church buildings yesterday with special services.
PITTSBURGH, March 20 -- Efforts were being made here tonight to prevent a strike of 1,184 trainmen which, if called, might cripple the steel industry in this area.

It is a pleasure to salute the Ninety-second Street Young Men's-Young Women's Hebrew Association on the occasion of its seventy-fifth anniversary. This agency has made a real contribution to the life of our community from its earliest days.

MOSCOW, March 21 -- Two Soviet architects, Boris Mikhalovitch Iofan and Karo S. Alabian, along with four colleagues, have been attacked sharply by Pravda for displaying what were termed the tendencies of decadent bourgeois cosmopolitanism.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- Floor consideration of the Administration's labor bill moved a step nearer in the Senate today as the Labor and Public Welfare Committee filed a seventy-nine page report outlining its reasons for supporting the measure.

A Government-assisted program to bring students from former enemy countries to the United States on one-year scholarships was announced yesterday by Donald J. Shank, vice president of the Institute of International Education.
The new 9,592 gross ton Holland-America Line freighter Schiedyk arrived here yesterday on her maiden run from Rotterdam to receive the welcoming salutes of dozens of harbor craft.

Two thousand families were persuaded to enroll their children in settlement houses last year through a house-to-house canvass of Brooklyn slum areas by Youth United, Supreme Court Justice George J. Beldock, president of the organization, reported yesterday.

ST. LOUIS, March 21 -- An optimistic statement that "we may get the trains running" was made late today by a union officer as representatives of four striking railway brotherhoods and the Wabash Railroad met at the suggestion of a Presidential fact-finding board.

You will render a public service in bringing to the attention of your readers the facts concerning four bills which are being rushed through the state Legislature without public hearings. To summarize the contents of these bills:

TEL AVIV, Israel, March 21 --If British troops take over Arab Legion positions along the Negeb front, as requested by Transjordan, Israel will consider the act a "very grave breach of the truce," according to a Government spokesman here.
WASHINGTON, March 21 -- House factions squared off tonight for consideration tomorrow of $90-a-month pensions, beginning at age 65, for veterans of both world wars.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- The Treasury announced tonight that tenders for $906,999,000 of ninety-one-day Treasury bills to be dated March 24 and to mature on June 23, which were offered on March 18, were accepted today.

LOS ANGELES, March 21 -- Dr. Robert A. Millikan, retired executive head of the California Institute of Technology, who will celebrate his eighty-first birthday anniversary tomorrow, received the Presidential Medal of Merit today from W. Stuart Symington, Secretary of the Air Force.

In a report from Washington by Lewis Wood, which appeared in THE NEW YORK TIMES of March 16, one sentence dealing with a Communist-sponsored peace conference which was to be held last year in Mexico, reads:

Harry Shub, violinist from Chattanooga, Tenn., who made his debut here eleven years ago, gave his fifth Town Hall recital last night. Mozart's F major Sonata (K. 377), Wilhelmj's arrangement of the D major Paganini Concerto and the Adagio and Fuga from Bach's G minor Sonata were his major selections.

Time pressure again figured in the international chess masters tournament, the fifth round of which was contested at Mar del Plata yesterday, according to a report from Argentina. Neglect of the clock caused Jacobo Bolbochan of Argentina to lose in eighteen moves to Hector Rossetto, former champion of Buenos Aires, who took first place with a score of 4 -- 1.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- A credit of $1,518,875, which will be available until Dec. 30, 1950, was granted today to the Nacional Financiera, S. A., a financial agency of the Mexican Government, by the Export-Import Bank.

Dr. Bryn Hovde, president of the New School for Social Research, withdrew last night as a candidate for the presidency of Queens College because, he said, he had been the "center of too much public controversy."

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- The Association of Interstate Commerce Commission Practitioners asked the Civil Service Commission today to hold a public hearing in connection with its recent order to administrative agencies of the Government to disqualify forty-two hearing examiners whose qualifications were checked by a group of six consultants, made up of lawyers and judges.

Of all types of possessions, the most warming undoubtedly are the souvenirs. Usually they are impractical and, in any cold - blooded economy, without any great worth. If offered as collateral at any loan agency, the shutters would snap in their faces, and during house-cleaning alien hands have a tendency to set them aside with the rubbish.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., March 21 (AP) -- Cary Middlecoff rolled down birdie road to the top $2,000 prize in the Jacksonville open golf tournament today.

BERLIN, March 21 -- The United States Military Government told the Soviet Military Administration in Germany today to come out in the open and talk over directly the huge bill submitted to the Americans for communications between Berlin and the United States zone.

Richard (Pancho) Gonzales, the National grass court tennis champion from Los Angeles, lost a set yesterday and had some disquieting moments in the third round before winning his match in the National indoor tournament.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., March 21 -- The demand for the clinic facilities of the mental hygiene division of the Westchester County Department of Health has doubled in the last twelve months, it was reported today by Dr. William A. Holla, Westchester County Health Commissioner.

Negroes need more trained leaders to develop a sense of social responsibility, the Office of Education of the Federal Security Agency reported yesterday in a study of national problems of Negro education.

The new 16,500 - ton Oslofjord, Norway's largest and most luxurious passenger liner, will be launched at Amsterdam, the Netherlands, on April 2, it was announced here yesterday by the Norwegian America Line. Crown Princess Martha of Norway is expected to name the vessel.

Consideration is being given to a questionable plan for turning over to Army management ships which have been carrying Displaced Persons to this country. The Army is perhaps the largest single operator anywhere. The Bureau of the Budget, backed by the Army and the International Refugee Organization, urged President Truman to transfer the trooper liners from the Maritime Commission so that they could move displaced persons more cheaply.

Officials representing sixteen small producers of television receivers and components yesterday unanimously agreed to establish a new trade association which will concentrate exclusively on television receiver manufacturing and distribution problems.

Kentucky and Illinois will clash tonight at Madison Square Garden for the right to meet the Oklahoma Aggies in the N. C. A. A. East-West final Saturday night at Seattle, Wash. This was determined last night at the Eighth Avenue Arena, where Adolph Rupp's Wildcats from Lexington overwhelmed Villanova, 85 -- 72, after the Illini had come from behind to register a 71-67 victory over Yale in the Eastern regional semi-final.

TWO books with a pronounced French accent have made their appearance along with the first days of spring. One, "Olivia,"* is the anonymous, autobiographical story of the emotional awakening of a teen-age English girl during her residence at a select school near Paris. The other is the third volume of "The Journals of Andre Gide," 80-year-old French author, critic, Nobel Prize winner.

Because of comparison to last year's twenty-nine-day February, newspaper advertising lineage for last month in fifty-two cities showed a statistical 2.7 per cent drop on the calendar month-to-month trend chart released yesterday by Media Records.
WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP) -- The text of President Truman's address to the United States Conference of Mayors today follows:
The military housing shortage in Alaska is the bottleneck that limits and restricts all our defense plans in the Territory.

DETROIT, March 21 -- Organized labor should ask for no wage increases in 1949 that would necessitate price increases, Dr. Edwin G. Nourse, chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, asserted today.

BERLIN, March 21 -- The Soviet Military Administration has taken no steps to counter the decree issued yesterday by the United States, Britain and France making the West mark the sole legal currency in the Western sectors of Berlin. The first official reaction was a remarkably mild criticism by Col. Alexei Yelisarov, Acting Russian Commandant in Berlin, in a statement issued tonight.

Ways to help the homemaker judge how a wallpaper pattern will look on the wall were outlined last evening by William Katzenbach of Katzenbach Warren. He was one of the speakers at the second lecture in a series sponsored by the Home Fashions League.

LAKE SUCCESS, March 21 -- The Catholic Near East Welfare Association asked Secretary General Trygve Lie today to place the problem of international control over the holy places in Jerusalem and Bethlehem before the interested agencies of the United Nations.

Demands for a $9, nine-hour day were made yesterday by the Taxi Drivers Organizing Committee on behalf of the city's cab drivers, who were called to two meetings next Tuesday to discuss "necessary action."

The United States is about to agree to a treaty under which an attack on any member of the North Atlantic community of nations will be considered as an attack on us. Thus we come to a turning point in the long road back from the isolationism into which we fell when the Senate rejected the League of Nations thirty years ago.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 21 -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer today announced the engagement of Joel McCrea for the leading male role, that of a circuit riding clergyman, in "Stars in My Crown," which William H. Wright will produce in May. Margaret Fitts has written the scenario from a novel by Joe David Brown which the studio bought early in 1948.

Both wool tops and wool futures were lower in yesterday's trading. Scattered hedging and liquidation were absorbed largely through dealer buying from Boston. Wool top contracts closed 1.2 to 2 cents a pound net lower on sales of 385,000 pounds. Grease wool futures were down 0.5 to 1.1 cents a pound on transactions of 90,000 pounds.

Old days of the New York bar were recalled last night as the New York County Lawyers Association turned out for "McManus Night," a tribute to Terence Joseph Patrick McManus, secretary of the association and for fifty-seven years a practicing attorney in New York.

ALBANY, March 21 -- The De Salvio-Quinn bill permitting New York City to cede to the Federal Government the site of former Castle Clinton in Battery Park for the erection of a national monument was passed in the Assembly tonight. It is scheduled to be passed in the Senate tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP) -- California was accused today of a desire to "gobble up much more than the lion's share" of Colorado River water.

HAVANA, March 21 -- Tiny Teal, 39-foot cutter owned by Palmer Langdon of the Larchmont Yacht Club, won the fleet and Class C honors on corrected time in the sixteenth annual St. Petersburg to Havana yacht race when she crossed the finish line here at 3:40.15 o'clock this morning.

HALLANDALE, Fla., March 21 (AP) -- A pair of noted "second horses" -- Happy C. and Brownian -- fought a thrilling stretch duel in today's featured sixth race at Gulfstream Park, the first named breaking the jinx by a nose.

MAMARONECK, N. Y., March 21 -- After seeing two controversial films on human growth and reproduction, a "jury" of 350 mothers voted overwhelming approval today of sex education for elementary and high school students.
