Applications by two steamship companies for operating differential subsidies on North Atlantic and South America routes received approval in part of the Maritime Commission yesterday, according to a spokesman for the commission here.

Current assets of 556 men's furnishings retailers throughout the United States decreased 11 per cent last year, according to analysis issued yesterday of financial statements of these concerns. The analysis was made by Thomas F. Turner of William Iselin Co., Inc., chairman of the standards committee of the Men's Furnishings Manufacturers Credit Group, which is affiliated with the New York Credit Men's Association.

A preview of spring from March to June was the scene presented by the thirty-third International Flower Show when the doors of Grand Central Palace opened at noon yesterday. Throughout this week, countless flowers will be on dispay, from African violets that are grown on window sills to complete gardens for suburban and country squires.

WASHINGTON, March 21 (UP) -- The Secretary of the Army, Kenneth C. Royall, and the Chief of Staff, Gen. Omar N. Bradley, today declared that it would be fine for Congress to authorize a seventy-group Air Force -- provided an 837,000-man Army also was voted.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- Miss Judith Coplon, 27 years old, the former Department of Justice employe, pleaded not guilty today to the second indictment charging her with having taken secret security information for the benefit of a foreign Government.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- The Arkansas Power and Light Company, Pine Bluff, Ark., filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering $8,300,000 of sinking-fund debentures, due in 1974, that are to be sold at competitive bidding.

VERO BEACH, Fla., March 21 -- A Special triple by Spider Jorgensen that cleared filled bases, plus a scoring fly by Duke Snider produced a ninth inning 6-5 victory for the Dodgers over their farmhands, the Montreal Royals, today.

The final events of the Eastern contract bridge championship tournament got under way at the Park Sheraton Hotel last night with twenty-five teams-of-four entered in the open contest for the Curt H. Reisinger trophy, and twenty-nine teams playing for the industrial team championship.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- President Truman, who returned only Saturday from a thirteen-day vacation in Key West, Fla., said today that the "increasing pressure of official duties" forced him to cancel a major speech of international importance scheduled to be given at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology's Mid-Century Convocation April 1.

The leadership of Tammany Hall has turned "thumbs down" on the candidacy of Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. to succeed the late Sol Bloom as Representative in Congress of the Twentieth District on Manhattan's West Side, it was indicated authoritatively yesterday.

The Cities Service Company did the greatest volume of business in its thirty-nine-year history last year. Net income of the $992,000,000 oil and gas system was $65,777,039, equal to $17.77 on each of the 3,700,000 common shares outstanding.

Larry Walz, who gave his debut piano recital in Times Hall last night, has talented fingers and careful adherence to the letter of the composers' indications to offer his listeners. Despite these assets, however, his program was not well chosen to display them on a first hearing.

ALBANY, March 21 -- Two of Governor Dewey's major legislative recommendations for the current year are facing possible defeat, and others may have to be modified drastically before they can win approval, it appeared tonight.

LONDON, March 21 -- As a result of yesterday's rioting in East London, the Home Office issued an order today prohibiting all public processions of political character in London for a period of three months. Home Secretary J. Chuter Ede announced this with obvious reluctance in the House of Commons, where the Government was bombarded with questions and criticisms.

Although sales declined almost $10,000,000 from the 1947 total, the Douglas Aircraft Company, Inc., turned the corner into profitable operations in the fiscal year, 1948, the annual report to stockholders, issued yesterday, revealed. Net income for the twelve months ended on Nov. 30, 1948 amounted to $5,829,206, equal to $9.71 a capital snare, contrasted with a net loss of $2,140,579 in 1947.
announced yesterday that it will receive bids on April 11 on $1,700,000 of electric revenue bonds dated April 1, 1949, due on April 1, from 1950 to 1969, and callable in 1957.
WASHINGTON, March 21 -- President Truman lashed out today at the real estate lobby, declaring that its backers would increase the cost of living.

GRASSELLI, N. J., March 21 -The creation of a completely new field of industrial chemicals, independent of foreign laboratory controls and based on exclusive American refinements of high pressure and high temperature acetylene reactions developed in their pilot plant here, was announced today by officials of General Aniline and Film Corporation.

CLEARWATER, Fla., March 21 -- Once upon a time the Phillie training camp was populated by ball players who looked longingly toward the front door and hoped that they'd be traded to a real ball club. Nowadays the Phillie training camp is populated by eager young ball players who would be terribly hurt and crushed if they were traded anywhere else.

Five of the contemporary designs that Laverne Originals has printed on heavy decorative fabrics or wallpaper are now being applied to crisp chintz. Since most of them are neat geometric or modern patterns they represent a distinct departure from the floral school of chintz design.

British delegates to the Cultural and Scientific Conference for World Peace, which opens here on Friday, informed the conference sponsors yesterday that the United States Embassy had revoked visas given them last week.

ROME, March 21 -- The Senate began discussion of the projected North Atlantic Treaty today in a comparatively peaceful atmosphere, with the Communists showing no intention of wishing to apply the delaying tactics that they had used in the Chamber.

A series of appointments in which Mayor O'Dwyer ignored Tammany Hall but took occasion to strengthen his position with the Brooklyn and Bronx Democratic organizations was announced yesterday at City Hall. Among the appointments were three additional Special Sessions judges at $15,000 a year.
WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., March 21 -- Macy's new branch here, described by the management as the largest department store in Westchester, drew 30,000 shoppers today when it opened for business.

Reflecting a reduction of $6,568,587 in dividend income on stocks of companies divested, net income of the North American Company last year was $18,360,030, equal to $2.14 a share, compared with $21,647,422, or $2.53 a share, in 1947, according to the annual report to be issued today.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- A State Department spokesman tonight confirmed that our Embassy at Paris had refused visas to three Frenchmen who wished to attend the Cultural and Scientific Conference for World Peace in New York.

PARIS, March 21 -- Complete returns from yesterday's local elections in one-half of France showed today that the Communists had suffered a slight setback while the de Gaullists had about held their ground.

Samuel D. Leidesdorf, certified public accountant, has been named chairman of the foundations committee of the United Negro College Fund, it was announced yesterday at the fund's offices, 38 East Fifty-seventh Street. His appointment is in connection with the sixth annual campaign that begins next month to raise funds in support of its thirty-one member colleges.

WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP) -- Representative Patterson, Republican, of Connecticut, said today he has asked a Congressional committee to study restrictions in the European aid law that virtually bar United States exports of machine tools to Marshall Plan nations.

The most valuable event on the Metropolitan Jockey Club's calendar, the $40,000 added Wood Memorial, has attracted forty-eight nominations, it was revealed yesterday. Among the 3-year-olds listed in the mile and a sixteenth run at Jamaica on Saturday, April 23, are thirty-one eligibles for the Kentucky Derby, twenty-two for the Preakness, and thirty-three that were considered good enough for nomination to the Belmont.

Only the most carefully screened Germans will be permitted in this country for the forthcoming German industry exhibition. Gen. Lucius D. Clay, United States Military Governor in Germany, announced yesterday.

Stock prices fell back into a narrow rut again yesterday, closing irregularly lower after an earlier show of strength. A better tone to the London market helped sentiment at the opening, but except for a few selected issues, changes were mostly fractional in either direction.

A number of furniture, fabric and wallpaper showrooms throughout the city are spruced up with new displays this week for the benefit of out-of-town delegates here for the American Institute of Decorators' annual convention. Yesterday four companies presented special showings.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 21 -- Officials of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology were caught unawares by President Truman's cancellation of his scheduled address at Boston Garden.

The New York County grand jury investigating a wiretapping plot against Mayor O'Dwyer and other city officials moved forward yesterday, setting the stage for the appearances of four principals in the case this afternoon.

TRENTON, N. J., March 21 -- A special joint meeting of the New Jersey Senate and Assembly will convene at 11 A. M. Thursday to receive Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll's proposals for a state-sponsored low-cost housing program.
The biggest proposed merger in airline history, the purchase by Pan American Airways of American Overseas Airlines, may be abandoned, it was learned here last night.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., March 21 (AP) -- The Louisville Nashville Railroad reported today that its freight business broke all records in 1948. The $179,600,760 total was $17,489,247 more than the year before, the railroad reported.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores were down 18 per cent last week compared with the corresponding week last year, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The decline for the four weeks ended last Saturday was 11 per cent.

URUMCHI, China, March 19 -- For almost two weeks Sino-Soviet talks here have been stalled while opposing factions in China's Central Government have struggled over the question of how much power to give the Russians in Sinkiang.
BRUSSELS, March 21 -- The current difficulties over widespread unemployment make Belgium, not for the first time, an important testing ground for the European Recovery Program.
May one reader express appreciation for your editorial "Those Communist Visitors" in your issue of March 18.

LAKE SUCCESS, March 21 -- The decision of the three Western powers to establish the West mark as the sole legal tender in their sectors of Berlin, thus in effect driving out the Soviet mark, is interpreted here as meaning that the Berlin dispute is now definitely beyond any hope of settlement by the United Nations.

The "shamefully high cost and unnecessary waste of time" now required for business to settle tax disputes with the Government may be substantially reduced if Congress will enact the Tax Settlement Board Bill (HR 2983), according to J. K. Lasser, chairman of the Federal tax committee of the New York State Society of Certified Public Accountants.

CHICAGO, March 21 -- Confusion over the so-called basing point and f. o. b. plant pricing methods may be allayed by Supreme Court decisions in cases now on their way to that body for judicial review, Paul F. Myers of Washington, D. C., anti-trust law specialist and counsel for the National Food Brokers Association, said today.

As a member of the Board of Regents for twelve years from 1934 to 1946 and then as chairman of the Temporary Commission which recommended establishment of a state university, Owen D. Young has special qualifications to advise in the dispute between the regents and the state university trustees.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 21 (AP) -- The Chinese Communists told the Indonesian Republicans today that they could beat the Dutch only by going Communist and establishing a united front with the Soviet Union.
LONDON, March 21 -- Transjordanian forces in Palestine were reported today to have been replacing the Iraqi army in the occupation of the disputed Tulkarm-Jenin-Nablus triangle north of Jerusalem.

The work stoppage here against the Railway Express Agency continued yesterday as union members awaited the outcome of a meeting of labor and management officials called for tomorrow in Washington by the National Mediation Board.

ITHACA, N. Y., March 21 -- Homemakers attending the Annual Farm and Home Week here, the second to be held at Cornell University since the war, are getting a taste of food with an international flavor. Many of the lectures and exhibits of this five-day "open house" for residents of the state, which opened today, are keyed to what is cooking in foreign kitchens.

EVANSTON, Ill., March 21 -- Religious liberty is an absolute right, derived from the fact that a man is a son of God, Bishop G. Bromley Oxnam, of New York, declared here tonight in a plea for religious freedom.

The upward movement of Brazilian dollar bonds yesterday carried three bonds of original issue in New York Stock Exchange trading to 70 or beyond, the first time that this price area has been reached by such obligations -- the 6 1/2s of 1926-57 and the Railway 7s of 1952 -- in several years.

On several occasions we have championed the cause of the smaller taxicab for New York City. All the conditions present in the city cry out for its adoption -- congestion of traffic, present high cost of automobiles, high operating costs, diminished earnings of drivers and owners, small average passenger load.

An underwriting syndicate headed by Paine, Webber, Jackson Curtis and Harriman Ripley Co., Inc., will offer to investors today $8,500,000 of long-term sinking-fund debentures and $1,891,432 of common stock of the Hollingsworth and Whitney Company, manufacturer of industrial papers.
WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP) -- The Senate Rules Committee today endorsed four investigations proposed by the Upper Chamber's Commerce Committee.

The national economy of Israel must be developed by a well- planned financial program that will enable that country to support a growing population and increase its domestic and foreign markets, speakers declared last night at a dinner-meeting of the Economic Commission of the Zionist Organization of America in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

ALBANY, March 21 -- Governor Dewey signed today the budget bill fixing the state income tax at 90 per cent of the normal rate. The new law applies to returns on 1948 income that must be filed by April 15.
Every weekday at 6 A. M. investigators of the State Department of Labor report for work near various factories in New York, where they lurk in shadowed doorways, behind fences or in parked cars.
ROME, March 21 -- Randolfo Pacciardi, Defense Minister, disclosed today that the Italian Communist party had lost 700,000 members in the last twelve months.

WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP) -- Russian exports to the United States dropped 75 per cent in January to the lowest point since the United States slapped a ban a year ago on shipments of industrial goods or "war potential" to the Soviet.

Seven students from Ohio State University who represent four countries embarked yesterday on a five-day tour of New York that will include trips to Lake Success and the Bronx Zoo and cover such varied points of interest as the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, Radio City, and Macy's basement.

CHICAGO, March 21 -- A warning that the country is again recklessly dipping into its natural resources for raw materials to a point where it may be inflicting "a crime against our future generations'' unless halted was voiced today by Sidney Danziger, of New York, president of the National Association of Waste Material Dealers.

LONDON, March 21 -- Britain's exports in February showed a drop from the record January figure, the Board of Trade reported today. The value of exports was 140,700,000, which represented a decline of 18,000,000 (about $72,000,000).

The Armco Steel Corporation had consolidated net income of $32,030,712, equal to $8 a common share, for 1948 on sales of $382,563,811, C. R. Hook, chairman, reported in the anual statement issued yesterday. Both earnings and sales set new records.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 21 -- Speculation over the condition of Phil Rizzuto's throwing arm was dispelled today when Manager Casey Stengel waxed enthusiastic over the satisfactory showing of the Scooter in the three exhibition games he has played with the Yankees.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 21 -- Net income, after taxes, of $1,403,884 for 1948 was reported today to stockholders of the American President Lines by George Killion, the president. He emphasized that this was achieved despite "the disastrous ninety-five-day tie-up" of west coast shipping last fall, which he described as "by far the largest single deterrent to your company's operation" during the year.
With their regular season just completed, officials of the Basketball Association of America yesterday announced play-off dates and held the annual player draft at the Hotel Commodore.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- The postal service would receive less rather than more money from publishers under contemplated rate changes that would increase postal charges for second class matter three times or more, publishers told a House Committee here today.

VIENNA, March 21 -- With the beginning of spring Czechoslovakia's economic planners are getting under way a geographical redistribution of industrial capacity involving construction of new plants in under-developed areas and dismantling of plants in what was formerly known as the Sudetenland.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- With the present law expiring March 31, Administration leaders in the Senate set up the machinery today to bring extension of rent control to a quick vote. As debate started Scott W. Lucas, the majority leader, declared that he wanted every Senator to have full time to discuss the bill and amendments that might be offered but that night sessions would start Wednesday if progress was not satisfactory.

The Ohio Oil Company last year had a consolidated net income of $49,333,158 after charges, taxes and reserves, equal to $7.52 each on the 6,563,377 capital shares outstanding, according to the company's sixty-first annual report released for publication today.

Mingling the casual air that American women love with unmistakably French chic, the first designed-and-made-in-America collection of fashions by Jacques Fath delighted the onlookers yesterday at Lord Taylor, with its swirling full skirts, pretty necklines both high and low, snug waist-length ices, airy capelet sleeves, condices, airy capelet sleeves, contrasting tone bodices and the flash of patent belts on almost every costume.

PARIS, March 12 -- It remains to be seen whether, as some observers suspect, Anastas I. Mikoyan, whose ministerial job in the Soviet Cabinet was terminated recently, received new duties supervising the Muscovite equivalent of the West's Organization for European Economic Cooperation.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- Farmers and farm workers should be put under Federal Social Security through the most simple and practical plan possible, the twenty-four-member Agrculture committee of the National Planning Association recommended today.

A $10,000 burglary, begun Saturday night, was finished in leisurely fashion Sunday evening after police had investigated and left the scene, a nine-story office building at 1674 Broadway, at Fifty-second Street, it was reported yesterday.
MOSCOW, March 21 -- Finland was warned today against aligning herself with the Western powers and was reminded that she became independent only after the Bolshevist revolution.

" Labor in America," by Foster Rhea Dulles, a one-volume history of the labor movement in the United States, will be issued on April 18 by Crowell. Mr. Dulles, Professor of American History at Ohio State University, is the author of "Twentieth Century America," "China and America" and "The Road to Teheran."

WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP) -- The Niagara Hudson Power Corporation, Syracuse, N. Y., should retire about $26,000,000 of gas and electric generating and transmission facilities by 1952, the Securities and Exchange Commission heard today.

Under favorable economic conditions, approximately $2,000,000,000 of private American funds can be invested abroad annually after 1952, according to a study of capital export potentialities by the National Association of Manufacturers.

SAN BERNARDINO, Calif., March 21 -- New York's own homegrown Sidney Gordon stole all the thunder from such home run titans as Ralph Kiner and Johnny Mize today as he exploded four successive hits, two of them circuit smashes over the left field wall.

Three men, arrested in connection with the first commercial rent gouge case in New York County, pleaded guilty in Special Sessions to all but one count of a twenty-five count criminal information alleging illegal rental fees. They were continued in bail by Justice Nathan D. Perlman for sentence March 30.

The struggle of the American people for federal legislation to guarantee and to safeguard the equal rights of all Americans has suffered a severe setback. We must face the fact that the recent fight against the filibuster has resulted in a change for the worse.

Margaret Webster's Shakespearean touring company, which has taken "Hamlet" and "Macbeth" to practically every state in the union and given thousands of college and high school students their first look at the Bard's works, will be seen on the strawhat circuit this summer, it was learned yesterday.

The first group of World War II veterans, most of them disabled, who have been studying the rudiments of custom tailoring at the Straubenmuller Textile High School, 351 West Eighteenth Street, will complete today the ten-month training course.
WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., March 21 -- The public debt in Westchester has been cut $7,000,000 in the last year, William B. Folger, County Budget Director, informed the Board of Supervisors this afternoon.
LONDON, March 21 -- Although the stock market here today started the week on a rather quiet note, prices generally were firm.

Prices moved lower, particularly on garments containing cotton or rayon, at the summer showing of the Metropolitan Juvenile Style Mart, now being held on the fifth and sixth floors of the New Yorker Hotel. Buyer attendance exceeded 350 for the opening on Sunday and was comparably good yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 21 -- Following are excerpts from the address of Bernard M. Baruch today before the United States Conference of Mayors:

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- Bernard M. Baruch, adviser to many Presidents, told the United States Conference of Mayors today that Harry S. Truman occupied "the most difficult post of any President, even George Washington and Abraham Lincoln."

HANOVER, N. H., March 21 (AP) -- A scuffle that followed objections to his wearing a college sweater led to the death of Raymond J. Cirrotta, 21 years old, a junior at Dartmouth, an attorney said today.

CHICAGO, March 21 (AP) -- A railroad president tonight described his industry as a giant so shackled that he was hard-pressed to battle his foes. The speaker was Laurence F. Whittemore of Boston, president of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad Company. He addressed the Western Railway Club.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- A new Cabinet-rank department to direct the welfare and educational programs of the Federal Government and a new and separate United Medical Administration were urged today by the Commission on Organization of the Executive Branch of the Government.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was quiet yesterday and prices declined 1 to 8 points.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., March 21 -- The Spring Antiques Show opened this afternoon at the Garden City Hotel with the Ballroom Colonnades and two salons filled with forty exhibitors' booths. Hours are 1 to 10 P. M. daily through Friday.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- President Truman told the Iranian people today that Americans desired a peaceful world free of the fears of war, free of oppression and free of want. His message, read in the Persian language, was sent in the first of a series of daily broadcasts to Iran by the Voice of America.

The last frontier melted away in the Nineties, but the frontier of science remains a vague intellectual region that recedes ever farther and ever widens as physicists, chemists and biologists make new discoveries. Even while we were in the national defense stage bills had been introduced that called for the creation of a government-supported foundation to carry on research on a scale that no single industry could match.

The article by C. L. Sulzberger in THE TIMES of March 1, "France Fears U. S. Lobbies May Undermine ERP Help," seems to me to provide fuel for the opponents of the European Recovery Program without adequately presenting both sides of the problem.

WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP) -The Department of Agriculture reported today that farmers expect to plant 84,809,000 acres of corn this year. This would be 1.6 per cent less than last year's acreage, which produced the largest corn crop of record.

BERLIN, March 8 -- He stood hugging the building, a trench coat belted tightly against the wind. He said: "I could tell you much more interesting things about the price of gold or diamonds or about rates of exchange, but I'm willing to talk of politics as well."

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- President Truman will ask Congress to allow him considerable freedom of action in allocating any military supplies that may be made available to the North Atlantic Treaty nations.

TOKYO, March 21 -- Throughout economic offices of the occupation forces the feeling is growing that the present austerity program is not going to work. There is danger, it is thought, that it will cut production and thus become a boomerang, bringing inflation rather than deflation.

The National Dairy Products Corporation in 1948 increased its sales for the tenth consecutive year, bringing the volume to $986,403,723, highest in the company's twenty-five-year history, according to the annual report of L. A. Van Bomel, president, to be distributed to shareholders today.
Trout fishing is as full of "trends" as an egg is of meat, and this season finds tackle and line manufacturers wondering what phobia will develop to make their work more interesting and hectic.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -Nearing completion of the bill authorizing $5,580,000,000 for a second year of the Marshall Plan, the House Foreign Affairs Committee voted broadened powers today for the Federal Government to underwrite private American investments in Europe.
A direct appeal to the public for support on liquor tax problems will be made here during the next two weeks with the unified support of the industry, it was learned yesterday.

Overseas airlines carried a total of 252,187 passengers in Atlantic operations last year, it was made known yesterday. The figure is almost 100,000 lower than that estimated by the airline companies at the year-end before final tabulation of statistics.

LAKE SUCCESS, March 21 -- Canada's proposal for a preliminary conference between Dutch and Indonesian Republican officials which might pave the way for full representation at the proposed round-table conference in The Hague, was subjected to another day of criticism and skepticism today in the United Nations Security Council.

NANKING, March 21 -- China's Ambassador to Moscow, Fu Ping-chang, was named Foreign Minister here today as Premier Ho Ying-chin completed the formation of his "peace-or-war" Cabinet. The full Cabinet list was promulgated by Acting President Li Tsung-jen who made a flying trip to Shanghai three days ago in an attempt to get holdout candidates to accept the portfolios.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- Non-farm employment fell 370,000 in the month preceding mid-February, but there are good prospects for 60,000,000 jobs again by summer, Ewan Clague, commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics, said today.

Two new films will open in midtown theatres today. At the Palace, the attraction is "Bad Boy," a drama about the rehabilitation of delinquent youths at the Boys' Ranch at Copperas Cove, Tex., featuring Audie Murphy, Jane Wyatt, Lloyd Nolan and James Gleason.

Theodore A. Hellman has been appointed as men's and boys' clothing and furnishings buyer at Frederick Atkins, Inc., store owned buying office. He formerly was with L. Bamberger Co. in the men's furnishings division and more recently in the boys' clothing and furnishings division.

United States Attorney John F. X. McGohey announced yesterday that he would produce witnesses and documents to prove the eleven Communist leaders now on trial held secret meetings to train professional revolutionists to overthrow the Government by force and violence.

The Milton Berle Show (Tuesday, 9 to 10 P. M., NBC-TV) will take a thirteen-week vacation after the telecast of June 14, and the Broadway Revue, with Sid Caesar, Imogene Coca an Mary McCarty (Friday, 8 to 9 P. M., NBC-TV and Dumont), will sign off after June 10.

Longshoremen are paid time-and-a-half pay for night and week-end work, regardless of whether they have worked any straight-pay hours. Last year a court ruling established this as regular pay rather than overtime, as it has always been called in the industry, thus creating "overtime on overtime."

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- The tradition of asylum in France is so deeply rooted in the hearts of Frenchmen that they never will prevent people who are deprived of homes and joy from finding happiness among them, Henri Bonnet. French Ambassador, said today.

"El Paso," a Western produced by William H. Pine and William C. Thomas for Paramount and starring John Payne and Gail Russell, will have its local premiere this morning at the Paramount. Lewis R. Foster directed the picture, which was filmed in Cine-color, from his own screen play and a story by J. Robert Bren and Gladys Atwater.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- Direct efforts to reunite the Northern and Southern Democrats of the Senate, for at least the period required to put through substantial parts of President Truman's legislative program, were begun today.
Commutation fare increases for northern New Jersey and points along the Jersey shore will become effective on Sunday. This was announced yesterday by the Pennsylvania Railroad.

Procter Gamble Company and Lever Brothers reduced prices yesterday of all grades of glycerine 15 cents a pound, making their products competitive with synthetic glycerine which remained unchange at around 24 cents a pound, f.o.b. Texas refineries, according to Shell Chemical Corporation.

Additional health facilities and medical services will be provided for 1,100 children of the West Side midtown area through the joint program of the Department of Health and the New York Kindergarten Association, recently begun at 542 West Forty-second Street, it was made known yesterday.

YONKERS, N. Y., March 22 -- Five hundred public works employes here empowered their union leaders today to call a new strike against the city if municipal officials carried out their decision to invoke the Condon-Wadlin Act.

An audience of 2,000 assembled at Carnegie Hall last night for the first recital appearance together in New York of Ferrucio Tagliavini, tenor, and his wife, Pia Tassinari, soprano. The event was programmed as "a joint Italian benefit concert."

ALBANY, March 22 -- Eviction from all limited-dividend housing of tenants whose income has increased during occupancy beyond the statutory limits for admittance is made possible under the terms of a bill that the Senate passed today after a bitter debate.

JERSEY CITY, N. J., March 22 -- Having completed an intensive seven-weeks study of dice-shooting in the more important bones-rolling centers of this country, Louis Ceresol and Albert Jauffret sailed today abroad the American Export liner Excambion, to introduce the bones at the Casino of Monte Carlo.

LONDON, March 22 (Reuters) -- The British Cabinet, which will consider next week ways to overcome the crisis in the film industry, may decided to double the capital of the Film Finance Corporation, which it founded to help producers raise money.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- A combination of Republicans and Southern Democrats in the Senate overrode Administration objections tonight in approving a formula allowing local government, below the state level, to remove rent controls.
Sixteen teams out of a starting field of twenty-eight qualified last night for the final round of the Eastern States contract bridge team-of-four championship tournament at the Park Sheraton Hotel.

LONDON, March 22 -- Contending that the Labor Government was removing economic controls even faster than its opponents had demanded, Harold Wilson, President of the Board of Trade, triumphantly announced in Parliament today the abolition of restrictions on the purchase and manufacture of more than fifty commodities and industrial materials.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 22 -- Israeli and Lebanese delegates will meet tomorrow at Ras en Naqura, a frontier post, to sign an armistice providing for Israel's evacuation of all Lebanese territory, an exchange of prisoners within forty-eight hours and a guarantee of the frontier by both sides.
WASHINGTON, March 22 (AP) -- Following is the text of Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg's address to the United States Conference of Mayors on the North Atlantic Treaty:
OTTAWA, March 22 -- Tax reductions amounting to $368,850,000 in a full year were announced by Finance Minister Douglas Abbott when he introduced the budget this evening.

Bernard F. Gimbel, president of the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau, was honored last night at the sixty-ninth annual dinner of the Hotel Association of New York City in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

PURCHASE, N. Y., March 22 -- As an aerial bulwark for the quick defense of New York from the sky in case of sudden war, the 137th Fighter Squadron of the New York Air National Guard is developing here a major base on part of the Westchester County Airport.

TAMPA, Fla., March 22 (AP) -- Baseball Commissioner Albert B. Chandler tonight was "deeply concerned but not afraid" of the court threat to the national game as he called upon baseball's friends to rally to its support.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- After voting twice off-the-record to kill the veterans' pension bill today, the House reconsidered when the roll was called. Tonight the measure, sponsored by Representative John E. Ranklin, Democrat, of Mississippi, was conceded by Administration leaders to be virtually certain of passage by the lower chamber.

Seven visitors from Moscow are due to arrive at La Guardia Field this afternoon. They are on their way here to attend the Cultural and Scientific Conference for World Peace which will meet in this city on Friday. They are coming to present the argument that world peace is readily obtainable through friendly and trustworthy cooperation, which, of course, is true.

PARIS, March 13 -- One of the most important aspects of the present "cold war" between the East and West is the contest for rare mineral materials useful in the processes of atomic fission or in the manufacture of particularly high-test steel required for jet and rocket engines.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 22 -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer has purchased "Matter of Fact," a screen story by Leonard Spiegelgass, as a prospective vehicle for Deborah Kerr, it was learned today. The deal was closed at a price of $60,000 by George Wilner, Spiegelgass' literary agent, who will fly to New York tomorrow.

DETROIT, March 22 (AP) -- After two grueling overtime periods, the Detroit Red Wings eked out a 2-1 victory over the Montreal Canadiens tonight on an unassisted goal by Max McNab at 4:52 of a third sudden-death session, in the opening game of the Stanley Cup hockey play-offs.

New issues of public utility and railroad securities totaling $50,400,000 were priced by underwriting syndicates yesterday for public marketing. Of the aggregate, three issues represented securities awarded yesterday to banking groups at public competitive bidding, as follows:
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was moderately active yesterday and final prices were unchanged to 10 points lower.

VERO BEACH, Fla., March 22 -- Morris Martin, big southpaw pitcher who had been kept out of action because of sinus trouble, was unveiled by the Dodgers today and responded by pitching four shut-out innings in an intrasquad contest.

The Metropolitan Golf Association yesterday announced another step in the general plan to establish a uniform handicapping system for golfers in this country, which the United States Golf Association recommended two years ago.

Parents are people who live with children and children are people, too, according to James L. Hymes Jr., Professor of Education at the State Teachers College, New Paltz, N. Y. Dr. Hymes' booklet "Being a Good Parent" has just been issued by the Bureau of Publications, Teachers College, Columbia University.
CHAPEL HILL, N. C., March 22 -- Gov. Kerr Scott tonight appointed Dr. Frank Porter Graham, president of the University of North Carolina, to the United States Senate.

A suit for $1,000,000 damages was started in Supreme Court yesterday against the Zenith Radio Corporation by two manufacturers of television sets and component parts. They charged Zenith with issuing false and fraudulent statements that the Federal Communications Commission was about to make changes in wavelengths that would make all other television sets obsolete, but that the Zenith sets were so constructed as to handle all possible changes.
The ideological war over the Cultural and Scientific Conference for World Peace, which starts three days of sessions in this city on Friday, had repercussions yesterday in both hemispheres.
Continuing the downward trend which has prevailed since Jan. 1, the price of No. 1 heavy melting scrap declined $1 a ton in Pittsburgh yesterday. The quotation is now $36 a ton, down $7 since Jan. 1.

LAKE SUCCESS, March 22 -- The Israeli delegation to the United Nations charged today that the recent arrival of British troops in the Aqaba area of Transjordan violated a Security Council resolution adopted last May 29. It contended that "the reinforcement of those forces last week was an aggravation of that original infringement," and that British forces should be withdrawn.
CLEARWATER, Fla., March 22 (AP) -- President Bob Carpenter of the Phillies today called for a rule that would require major league teams to bring their star players to all spring training camp games.

For the first time since the prewar period, wide usage of the so-called "deal" by food manufacturers in offering discounts and other inducements to grocers is being seen in various food markets, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 22 (AP) -- President Truman's nomination of Louis A. Johnson as the new Secretary of Defense was unanimously approved by the Senate Armed Services committee today. Mr. Johnson, a former assistant Secretary of War, was named to succeed James Forrestal, who resigned.

High fashion for the young of heart and small of figure characterized the Judy 'n Jill clothes presented during luncheon yesterday at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel. In junior sizes, the dresses escape the kiddish quality, bringing to everyone of small proportions gay cottons in soda fountain colors, for town and country.

A one-day exhibition of decorating materials and a luncheon at which citations were presented to winners in the American Institute of Decorators, design competition were the highlignts of yesterday's session of the institute's annual conference at the Pierre Hotel.

In an active market, cottonseed oil prices were weak and in new low ground for the season on the New York Produce Exchange yesterday. Selling was of a general nature and was due to some hedging pressure. Buying consisted of resting orders and short covering.

Merck Co., Inc., producers and distributors of medicinal chemicals and drugs, are proposing a two-for-one split-up of the common stock and authorization of 100,000 shares of new convertible preferred stock, George W. Merck, president, announced yesterday.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 22 -- The United Nations Commission on the Status of Women in its third session here today debated a Mexican proposal to present to the United Nations General Assembly a world convention guaranteeing the political rights of women.

Charles W. Ufford Jr., captain of the Deerfield team, captured three matches as the annual interscholastic invitation squash racquets tourney got under way yesterday at the Racquet and Tennis Club courts.

MOUNT VERNON, N. Y., March 22 -- Ground was broken here this afternoon for Mount Vernon's first large public housing project, which will comprise five apartment buildings for 496 families in an area recently occupied by substandard tenements.

When private interests can influence a legislative body over the concerted protest of conservation, sporting, wildlife and civic groups it would seem almost time that such groups put aside petty local differences and united to protect the future of the wildlife resources of the state.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., March 22 -- The Sonotone Corporation of this city and Elmsford, described by officers as the world's largest manufacturer of hearing aids, won a temporary injunction against alleged illegal interference with its sales outlets today in a decision by Supreme Court Justice J. Gordon Flannery.

With its earnings cramped by higher operating costs and with its claims for a $10,000,000 increase in rates denied by the Massachusetts Public Utilities Commission, the New England Telephone and Telegraph Company now proposes to appeal its rate case to the State Supreme Court.
A skunk named Blossom has received official permission from the Department of Health to continue her visit with friends in the city.

LONDON, March 22 -- The possibility that the deadlocked Austrian treaty talks might be drawing to a close arose today when it was learned that Soviet deputy Georgi N. Zarubin had been named a member of the Soviet delegation to the coming United Nations General Assembly session in New York.

The Rev. William Howard Melish, assistant rector of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Holy Trinity, Brooklyn, has inherited $10,000 and one-quarter of the residuary of an estate with a net value of $111,409, according to papers filed yesterday in the Surrogate's Court in Brooklyn.

ROME, March 22 -- Direct negotiations between the United States and Italy on the final disposition of the former Italian colonies in Africa will begin next week in Washington, Foreign Ministry circles said today. Italy's chief negotiator will be Foreign Minister

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- A great atomic reactor testing station costing eventually "hundreds of millions of dollars" will arise on the site of the inactive naval proving grounds at Arco, Idaho, under tentative plans announced today by the Atomic Energy Commission.

WASHINGTON, March 22 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board served notice on six feeder airline companies today to start operations by July 1. The board did not indicate what penalty would be set for failure to comply, but it is no secret in the industry that consideration is being given to revocation of their certificates.

Reassured by members of Congress and civic officials in Jersey City and Newark, N. J., that every effort would be made to permit them to remain in this country, sixty-four Polish seamen and women who deserted Polish ships here in the last year went through preliminary deportation proceedings yesterday at the Federal Immigration office, Newark.
INCHON, Korea, March 22 (AP) -- American aid executives in Communist-captured Tientsin were surprise passengers aboard the freighter Hanyang which arrived here today.

Queen Nazli of Egypt and her daughters, Princess Fathia and Princess Faikaia, were guests of honor at reception and supper party given last night by Mr. and Mrs. Clarence S. Rose 3d in the Cotillion Room of the Pierre. Earlier in the evening the party had attended the recital of Aurelio Di Dio, Egyptian violinist, at Town Hall.

When it comes to necklines, Fira Benenson is tops. She proved this yesterday in her custom-made collection presented in her showroom at 37 West Fifty-seventh Street, as she has done on previous occasions.

After two days of Marxist cliches and Communist slogans, Judge Harold R. Medina accused the defense in the trial of the eleven Communists yesterday of trying to mislead the jury into thinking the conspiracy charged against them was not actually a crime.

Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. told supporters yesterday that if the Tammany leadership denied him the Democratic nomination for Congress in the Twentieth District he would run independently for the post left vacant by the death of Sol Bloom.

CARACAS, Venezuela, March 22 (UP) -- New weekly sailings to New York will be started tomorrow by the Venezuelan Navigation Company, whose motorship Tachira will make the inaugural trip, the company announced today.

LONDON, March 22 -- Since the war Britain's money gifts abroad, including written off debts, have amounted to u400,000,000 ($1,600,000,000) -- ten times the value of money gifts to Britain in that period -- it was revealed in the House of Commons tonight by Douglas Jay of the Treasury.

Vigorous efforts will be made here to prove the feasibility of helicopter mail service in the New York area, it was learned yesterday. This will be done despite initial opposition by the Post Office Department in Washington on Monday at a pre-hearing conference with Ferdinand B. Moran, examiner for the Civil Aeronautics Board.

PARIS, March 22 -- Yugoslavia still considers herself not a neutral but part of the Eastern European bloc, and would not join the Marshall Plan, according to "responsible statesmen" in Belgrade who replied to a questionnaire published today in a leading Paris newspaper, the Monde.

Awards of merit were conferred last night on twelve outstanding Americans of the Jewish faith at ceremonies commemorating the seventy-fifth anniversary of the Ninety-second Street Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association, the nation's oldest and largest Jewish community center.

PRINCETON, N. J., March 22, -- A $300,000 endowed professorship in economics will be established at Princeton University as a memorial to Gordon S. Rentschler, Princeton alumnus and trustee, and chairman of the board of the National City Bank of New York.
WASHINGTON, March 22 (UP) -- There were fewer accidents per million tons of coal mined in 1948 than in any other year, the Labor Department reported today.

I see in a recent issue of THE TIMES a reference to Malmedy. What happened at Malmedy? Almost everybody has forgotten that name. German SS soldiers massacred Americans who had surrendered to them. Forty-three were sentenced to death, which General Clay reduced to eleven.

NEW DELHI, India, March 22 -- India's Prime Minister, Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru, plans to attend the Commonwealth Prime Ministers conference in London in the latter part of April. India's future relationship to the Commonwealth when this country becomes an independent republic is among the subjects likely to be discussed.

LONDON, March 22 -- Cancellation by the State Department of visas for four noted Britons who were going to the Congress for World Peace opening in New York Friday provided the chief sensation for afternoon newspapers in London today.

MOSCOW, March 22 -- Soviet press interest was today focused on Albania with the arrival in Moscow yesterday of a delegation headed by Premier Col. Gen. Enver Hoxha, one of the Soviet Union's stanchest friends.

Reminders that the opening of the New York racing season is only nine days away were received yesterday from (1) the National Broadcasting Company; (2) the Metropolitan Jockey Club, and (3) Hialeah Park.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- Congress was informed today that the current draft holiday would continue for the duration of the Selective Service Act, or through June 30, 1950, if voluntary enlistments continued at the present rate.

There is at least a moderately good chance that the present deepening unemployment and price declines will not turn into a full-scale depression, experts of the THE NEW YORK TIMES on labor and management told an audience of 500 teachers yesterday afternoon in Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street.
NANKING, March 22 (AP) -- Chinese Government peace delegates were being chosen today in the belief that talks with the Communists would begin soon.
WASHINGTON, March 22 -- Reconstruction of the White House, delayed by the recent Senate filibuster, is one step nearer to the excavation stage.
WASHINGTON, March 22 -- The Senate tonight confirmed Dr. James Boyd as director of the United States Bureau of Mines. The vote was 50 to 11.

The first move to split up the fleet of Government-owned, emergency-class passenger transports, recently scheduled to be turned over to the Army under a directive signed by President Truman, took place yesterday when the Army Transportation Corps announced it would operate but six of the vessels.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- The National Labor Relations Board ruled today that a council of labor unions violated the Taft-Hartley law by maintaining a list of "unfair employers to encourage employes to ignore the secondary boycott ban in the law.

The United States Conference of Mayors, meeting in Washington, has heard an unusually impressive list of speakers, including the President and some elder statesmen. The Mayors have been brought up to date on international and national issues. Finally and inevitably, however, the talk always gets around to the painful subject of money and taxes.
COPENHAGEN, Denmark, March 22 -- Foreign Minister Gustav Rasmussen moved a resolution in the lower house of the Danish Parliament today that Denmark should join the Atlantic Treaty.

WASHINGTON, March 22 (UP) -- The Senate Appropriations Committee refused today to restore Michael W. Straus, Reclamation Commissioner, to the Federal payroll and appointed a subcommittee to talk to President Truman about it.

The Children's Village has taken over the performances of two Broadway hits this year for its annual theatre benefit -- "Death of a Salesman," starring Lee J. Cobb, at the Morosco Theatre on the evening of April 1, and "Lend An Ear," starring William Eythe, at the Broadhurst Theatre on the evening of April 27.

ALBANY -- March 22 -- Passing the Senate without a dissenting vote, the Quinn-De Salvio bill to permit New York City to cede to the Federal Government the site of former Castle Clinton in Battery Park was sent to Governor Dewey today.

Beating off a double challenge from both left and right, the moderate coalition Government of Premier Queuille appears to have scored a modest but unmistakable victory in the latest French elections. The final results of the voting, held in only half of France to choose members of Departmental Councils (which approximate our state legislatures), will not be known till after the run-off ballot next Sunday.

FRANKFORT, Germany, March 9 -- Five young men, discussing their problems as representatives of German youth groups under various political and church auspices, agreed on one statement: German youth today would follow a new "strong man" if convinced that his path led to economic betterment and revived social standing among nations.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 22 -- A run famine between the Yankees and Tigers ended at A1 Lang Field today when the Bombers pushed over a tally in the eleventh inning for a 1-to-0 triumph.

After an interval of two years the Equity Library Theatre again will utilize the stage of a public library for one of its presentations. Next Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday evenings the ELT will put on Sidney Howard's "Ned McCobb's Daughter" at the Hamilton Grange Library, 505 West 145th Street.
LONDON, March 22 -- Despite war losses, the world's total gross tonnage of steam and motor ships has increased 17.2 per cent since 1939, Lloyd's Register reported today.
A small boy with a big distaste for foster care led subway employes a scary chase on the tracks at 3:30 P. M. yesterday.

"Stalin: A Political Biography," by Isaac Deutscher, expert on Russian and Eastern European affairs for The London Economist and The Observer, is planned for fall publication by the Oxford University Press.

Every decade or so the problem of congestion in the courts comes to a head as the panaceas adopted in the previous years wear off. The solution proposed by Judge Peck to ultilize judicial manpower to the highest and most efficient degree is interesting and will be of some effect but since it does not take effect until 1951 it is not a complete solution to the problem.

On his first day here as successor to W. Frank Watkins, retired, as Acting District Director of Immigration and Naturalization, Edward J. Shaughnessy announced yesterday that he had made several changes in the assignments of key personnel. He said he made "some promotions but no demotions."

CHICAGO, March 22 -- Although the grain markets dipped sharply at one time on the Board of Trade today in sympathy with soy beans and lard, there was no material pressure on wheat and corn except from professional traders, and short covering caused a good rally from the low with corn showing independent strength and gaining 3/4 to 1 1/2 cents a bushel.

Because their testimony had helped send to the electric chair the slayers of Benjamin (Chippy) Weiner, three self-confessed armed robbers received suspended sentences on five-to-ten-year prison terms in General Sessions yesterday.

HALLANDALE, Fla., March 22 (AP) -- C. W. Pershall's Fayette County drove to a length and a half victory in today's Maybelle purse at Gulfstream Park. Logan Batcheller guided the Balladier colt home in 1:43 3/5 for the mile and a sixteenth. Rampart and Childeric share the track mark of 1:43 1/5.

ALBANY, March 22 -- Changes in the State University Law to permit the Fashion Institute of Design and Technology in New York City to become a part of the State university system under the community college program were approved unanimously in the Senate today.
LONDON, March 22 (Reuters) -- Following Britain come Norway (5.3 per cent);France (3.5 per cent); and the Netherlands (3.1 per cent).

The silences of the Sailors' Snug Harbor and New York University since your articles on Washington Square were published a few weeks ago are ominous but not surprising. If negotiations have begun or been continued to obtain long leases on the north side of the Square, the secret has been well kept.

The Pittsburgh Consolidation Coal Company, in its fourth annual report issued yesterday for publication today, showed a consolidated net income for 1948 of $21,316,340 equal to $9.87 a share of common stock, in contrast to $13,833,006, or $6.52 a share earned in 1947. The results are exclusive of profit on disposal of properties of $1,362,041 in 1948 and $1,309,131 in 1947.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- The House Foreign Affairs Committee authorized tonight a continuation of the European Recovery Program through fiscal 1950 after cutting $200,000,000 from the $5,580,000,000 estimate submitted by the Administration.
The rules of the Senate prohibiting a majority of the Senators from limiting debate are inherently unconstitutional.
PARIS, March 22 -- A Communist maneuver to provoke a debate on the North Atlantic Treaty before its signature was rejected by the National Assembly today, with only the Communists voting for it.

The addition of more flowers yesterday to the ranks that already seemed to fill Grand Central Palace when the International Flower Show opened set a pace that will be maintained throughout the week. Each of the six days has its special classes, and fresh blossoms replace any that show signs of wilting.

William T. Whalen, who got lost as a police rookie in Brooklyn thirty-two years ago, was honored last night in the same borough by the Flatbush Chamber of Commerce for his recent "meritorious police work." In the presence of 1,000 persons Mr. Whalen, now chief of detectives, received a gold medal at the Chamber's annual dinner and dance in the St. George Hotel.

ALBANY, March 22 -- The Senate completed legislative action today on the Ten Eyck bill to require the licensing and fingerprinting of watchmen and guards employed on the piers of New York City. The bill, which now goes to the Governor, is designed to prevent employment of guards with criminal records.

THE greatness of George Bernard Shaw has often been obscured by his own blinding and enthusiastic appreciation of it. The eternal question is: Can he be that good? The answer, however furiously or reluctantly or idolatrously given, must always be: Yes. For he is secure among the contemporary immortals, along with Einstein, Casals, Toscanini and Thomas Mann.

LONDON, March 22 -- With public interest in the stock market here today at a low ebb, most prices were easier. The disposition was to await information on the removal of further controls, as announced by Harold Wilson, president of the Board of Trade.

Directors of Gimbel Bros., Inc., yesterday reduced the dividend on the common stock with the declaration of a quarterly of 25 cents, payable on April 25. Previously shareholders received 50 cents quarterly.

Rayon mills and converters will resist efforts of retailers for heavier discounts, a survey of the trade indicated yesterday. Recent price reductions on fabrics, they said, have more than offset any price advantage that might have been gained by re-institution of 8 per cent discounts that were in effect on piece goods sales prior to the war.

Promptly at 8 o'clock this evening the curtain is scheduled to rise at the premiere of "Detective Story" at the Hudson. To enumerate the salient facts: Sidney Kingsley is the author-director; Ralph Bellamy and Meg Mundy share stellar billing; Howard Lindsay and Russel Crouse are the sponsors.
ANN ARBOR, Mich., March 22 -- The University of Michigan granted to its students today sweeping critical powers over the caliber of its faculty.
The City Council approved yesterday a local law preventing garage and parking lot operators from charging rental fees or service charges in excess of 30 per cent above the rates on Oct. 31, 1946.

Exploding all over Madison Square Garden with a dynamic attack that never faltered, Adolph Rupp's Wildcats from Kentucky romped to a 76 -- 47 victory over Illinois in the N. C. A. A. Eastern regional final last night.

I spent most of last year in the United States, lecturing in forty-two out of forty-eight states. I found a tremendous sympathy with Britain, an extreme generosity and hospitality everywhere I went, and a sincere desire to do all they could for us.

BERLIN, March 22 -- Gen. Lucius D. Clay announced today that Ilse Koch could not be tried again by a United States Military Government commission for her activities at Buchenwald concentration camp without violation of the principles of double jeopardy.

A series of movies featuring the high spots in championship boxing bouts of the last ten years will be shown on NBC's Eastern and Midwestern television networks on Fridays, starting April 1, immediately after the live boxing bouts. The five-minute shows, which will show highlights in the careers of Joe Louis, Max Baer, Tony Zale and others, will be sponsored by the Chesebrough Manufacturing Company.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- President Truman stepped personally today into a concerted effort of the Government aimed at strengthening the airlines of the United States as a defense reserve regardless of the currently depressed financial condition of the industry.

WASHINGTON, March 22 (AP) -- Spokesmen for the warehousing industry objected today to a plan to let the Government build more storage bins for farm crops. Private warehouses are far from filled, they said.

Mayor O'Dwyer coupled his first appearance before the grand jury in the wiretapping case yesterday with the announcement that he had sponsored Albany legislation, which was introduced during the day, placing wiretapping equipment in the same category as burglary tools.

Phoenix, Ariz., sold yesterday bond issues totaling $7,350,000 to banking syndicates here at interest costs ranging from 2.63 per cent for $3,500,000 of water revenue bonds due from 1950 to 1978 to 2.81 per cent for $3,850,000 of general obligations due from 1957 to 1973.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., March 22 (AP) -- The American Woolen Company, the world's largest manufacturer of wool fabrics, today reported that orders have slumped to less than one-fifth of the volume a year ago.
ST. LOUIS, March 22 --The week-old strike of four operating brotherhoods on the Wabash Railroad ended today as the carrier and unions signed a back-to-work agreement.

Candy at the most reasonable prices possible is the motto of the new Pick-a-Package Confectionery, 1400 Second Avenue. The 25-year-old owner, Mrs. Shirley Alexander, offers an interesting assortment of chocolates for $1.09 a pound and hard candies for 39 to 59 cents. These tariffs, she is confident, are going to bring her many customers.

It took some disappointing news yesterday to break the stock market out of its rut. Prices on the New York Stock Exchange closed with a wide list of losses ranging from fractions to more than a point. Sales expanded to 840,000 shares, the largest in two weeks, comparing with 620,000 shares traded on Monday.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., March 22 (AP) -- Edward W. (Moose) Krause, head basketball coach, became athletic director of Notre Dame University today. He succeeds Frank Leahy, head football coach, who wants to devote more time to the eleven.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- Following is the vote by which the Senate tonight wrote into its rent-control bill an amendment giving cities and towns the power to remove controls if their state Governor approves:

Sol Maglie, Giant pitcher who was suspended in 1946 when he "jumped" to the Mexican League, will join the parade of ball players suing organized baseball for damages under the anti-trust laws, his attorney, John L. Flynn, announced yesterday.

Jean Borotra passed from the singles in the National Indoor Tennis championships yesterday but only after a two-hour fight that had the gallery marvelling at the endurance of the famous Basque from Biarritz.

A Polish young woman, who is alive because of a trick she played on Nazi officers, told yesterday how she has been searching in New York for more than a year for relatives who probably are living here.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- The House Rules Committee cleared today for House consideration a bill to require the use of American vessels for at least half of Government-financed shipments to any country.

EVANSTON, Ill., March 22 -- The conference of United States member churches of the World Council of Churches today committed the resources of the twenty-nine American denominations to study the relationship of Protestant and Orthodox Communions to modern society.

Two complicated provisions of the Displaced Persons Act, which have slowed the flow of European refugees into this country to a trickle, have been deferred to accelerate the successful movement of 205,000 displaced persons in the two-year limit imposed by the law, it became known yesterday.

ALBANY, March 22 -- New York City will get at least $17,600,000 of the $40,000,000 appropriation for additional state aid to education carried in the state budget and may get more, it appeared tonight.

Walter V. Davidson Jr. has been appointed assistant to the president of the W. B. Connor Engineering Corporation, manufacturers of activated carbon air purification equipment and ceiling air diffusers.

A revised amendment defining "market price" and outlining a new procedure for the payment by American exporters of commissions to foreign representatives abroad will shortly be announced by the Economic Cooperation Administration.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, March 22 -- After preliminary conversations with treasury officials, W. H. Parsons, director of operations of the International Monetary Fund, today saw Minister of Finance Nicholaas C. Havenga. Tomorrow he will attend a general conference with heads of governmental departments, bankers and financiers.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., March 22 (AP) -- Three bills designed to outlaw communism in Illinois were approved today by the Senate and sent to the House. However, the Senate refused to pass a fourth bill that would make it mandatory for organizations of twenty or more members that require a secret oath to file a roster of membership with the Secretary of State.
PARIS, March 22 (AP) -- A spokesman for the Ford Societe Anonyme, French subsidiary of the Ford Motor Company, denied today that the subsidiary had sent Marshall Plan goods to Poland.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- The White House announced today that the President and Mrs. Truman would give a small "black tie" dinner Thursday night in honor of former British Prime Minister and Mrs. Winston Churchill.

Many of the new place mats being introduced for spring are offered in either dark colors, muted shades or natural fibers so that they will harmonize with the hard-to-match shades of modern pottery dinnerware. The mats are easily washed or may be wiped clean with a damp cloth.

LAKE SUCCESS, March 22 -- Vassily A. Tarasenko of the Ukraine told the United Nations Atomic Energy Commission today that the United States was buying uranium ore from Canada at such low prices that they amounted to "robbery."

Means of cooperation between retailers and the Economic Cooperation Administration which would facilitate flow of consumer goods to stores in the United States were discussed yesterday at a meeting of ECA representatives and the committee advisory to the ECA of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

William A. Mitchell, a director, vice president and member of the executive committee of J. P. Morgan Co., Inc., New York, will resign and has accepted an invitation to become president of the Central Trust Company of Cincinnati, it was announced here yesterday. George Whitney, president of the Morgan organization, said Mr. Mitchell's decision had been accepted with "great regret."

When India and Pakistan agreed last December to a truce in Kashmir and to a plebiscite to determine to which Dominion the former Princely State would accede they asked that the Administrator to be appointed by the United Nations to oversee the balloting be "a personality of high international standing and commanding general confidence."

The city petitioned the Public Service Commission yesterday to rescind immediately the interim gas rate increase granted the Consolidated Edison Company and put into effect on Jan. 10. The higher rates were estimated to give $11,500,000 additional revenue to the company.

Bergdorf Goodman displayed yesterday a collection of French and custom order millinery for spring and summer. Side tipped or worn to the back of the head, most of the hats were small and close- fitting, brimless or finished with soft rolled edges.
BURBANK, Calif., March 22 -- A spanking breeze that blew down the San Fernando Valley with plenty of frost in it, had a most invigorating effect upon Leo Durocher's Giants today.

ALBANY, March 22 -- The Assembly voted 85 to 51 today to eliminate what were described as "weasel words" in a proposed law to end racial segregation in the National Guard and other state military units.
Pan American Airways will start today to fly its new Boeing Stratocruisers into New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, to familiarize flight crews with the big airport.

A wide variety of material for advertising and promotion campaigns on Father's Day, June 19, is being made available to department stores by the Father's Day Council, 50 East Forty-second Street, it was announced yesterday.

ORANGE, N. J., March 22 --Daniel A. Dugan of 17 Ridge Street, retired New Jersey DistNict Court judge here, who was long active i newspaper, political and civic circles, died this afternoon, He was 82 years olcL

Trailing a lead found through a penciled address on the back of a business card, narcotics squad detectives uncovered yesterday in a Queens furnished room a cache of 175 ounces of pure cocaine estimated to have an illegal street selling value of $3,195,000.

SEOUL, Korea, March 22 -- Police Chief Kim Tai Sun announced today the slayers of Mrs. Horace H. Underwood, an American, had been arrested and linked with the Communist South Korea Labor party. Mrs. Underwood, wife of the president emeritus of Chosen University, was shot to death in her home by two hooded men last Thursday.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg, Republican, of Michigan, told the United States Conference of Mayors today that the North Atlantic Treaty was "the most important step in American foreign policy since the promulgation of the Monroe Doctrine."
United States exports to Sweden have been replaced in large measure by those of the United Kingdom, Ingemar Hagglof, commercial counsellor of the Swedish Embassy in Washington, said here yesterday.

MOSCOW, March 22 -- Prof. B. Kedrov, prominent Soviet philosopher who two weeks ago was accused by Culture and Life of being guilty of "cosmopolitanism" in philosophy, today published a letter in the same publication recanting his errors and denouncing himself for serious guilt and a defective viewpoint.

With the Atlantic Pact a new region has come into being. A geographic expression and economic partnership has taken on overnight the shape of a political community. Already it is referred to as Atlantica. It is as if the lost continent of Atlantis had suddenly emerged from the sea that covered it and become solid ground again.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- A plan for the reorganization of the Memphis Street Railway Company, Memphis, Tenn., was approved today by the Securities and Exchange Commission. Upon consummation of the plan, common will be the company's only class of capital stock.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- The House passed and sent to the Senate today a bill to authorize a seventy-group Air Force despite President Truman's insistence on a "balanced" military establishment with forty-eight air groups. The vote was 395 to 3.

WARSAW, March 22 -- A growing "idolatrous cult" tied to capitalist science and production technique is threatening fulfillment of Poland's three-year plan, Hilary Minc, chairman of Poland's Economic Committee of the Council of Ministers, declared today.

Visiting buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday totaled 1,477, compared with 1,986 last week and 623 in the similar week of 1948, according to lists published in THE NEW YORK TIMES. There were 595 arrivals yesterday against 814 last Tuesday.

QUEBEC, March 22 (Canadian Press) -- Net profit of $7,986,717 for 1948 was reported today by Price Brothers Co., Ltd. The annual report noted that regular dividends on the 4 per cent cumulative redeemable preferred shares were paid and a dividend of $4 was paid on common shares, an increase of $1 above the previous year.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- Robert Moses, Parks Commissioner and construction co-ordinator of New York City, today took issue with Bernard M. Baruch on deferring public improvements until United States strategy in the international situation was settled.

As the only winner in the sixth round. Miguel Czerniak of Palestine moved into a tie for second place with Paul Michel of Germany at 4 -- 2 in the international chess masters tournament at Mar del Plata yesterday, according to a report from Argentina.

Edward J. Shaughnessy, special assistant to the Commissioner of Immigration and Naturalization, has been given the additional important post of district director in New York. He begins his administration by pledging cooperation and candor in handling news and information about the service.

BERLIN, March 22 -- Seven prime examples of the Soviet intelligentsia left here tonight in all the luxury the capitalist world could muster en route for what they have been told is the lair of Wall Street imperialists and instigators of new wars.

CHICAGO, March 22 -- Many elderly persons who hear with difficulty are suffering from "phonemic regression," and not from physical ear defects, Dr. Raymond Carhart, Professor of Audiology in the School of Speech at Northwestern University, disclosed today.

Negotiations between the Town Board of Brookhaven, L. I., and the Brookhaven National Laboratory of the United States Atomic Energy Commission are now under way to establish a fair payment in lieu of taxes for Government housing to be constructed in the town, it was announced yesterday.

HONG KONG, March 22 (AP) -- The Hong Kong Standard today quoted a British ship captain as having said that Communist-held Tientsin was paralyzed by a mass slowdown strike in protest against Communist rule.

Enough time for serious reflection having intervened, it now is clear that spring was a victim of its own advance press. It will be remembered that spring was scheduled for 5:49 last Sunday afternoon. That was the hour and minute set down by the astronomers, or whichever is the scientific classification for those contributors of agate type to the Farmers' Almanac.

HONG KONG, March 22 (AP) -- The Hong Kong Standard today quoted a British ship captain as having said that Communist-held Tientsin was paralyzed by a mass slowdown strike in protest against Communist rule.
WASHINGTON, March 22 -- The House Education and Labor Committee is expected to approve the Administration's labor relations bill in a few days, it was reported today.
BOSTON, March 29 (AP) -- Toronto's Maple Leafs blanked the Bruins, 3 -- 0, tonight in the first game of the National Hockey League's semi-final Stanley Cup series.

OTTAWA, March 22 (Canadian Press) -- The Canadian National Railways today budgeted for a 1949 deficit of $37,800,000, an increase of more than $4,000,000 over its 1948 deficit of $33,532,741. The deficit, indicated in the line's annual budget tabled in the House of Commons by Transport Minister Lionel Chevrier, would be the fourth in a row and the largest since pre-war years.

Enough time for serious reflection having intervened, it now is clear that spring was a victim of its own advance press. It will be remembered that spring was scheduled for 5:49 last Sunday afternoon. That was the hour and minute set down by the astronomers, or whichever is the scientific classification for those contributors of agate type to the Farmers' Almanac.

Fireman Dennis H. Greer of Hook and Ladder Company 22, while off duty, discovered early yesterday morning a fire in the apartment house, 51 Manhattan Avenue, in which he lives, and won an official commendation for carrying a severely burned woman tenant of an adjoining apartment to safety.
WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., March 23 -- Revenge for three straight setbacks by the Athletics came to the Dodgers on Wright Field today with a 5-3 triumph over Connie Mack's men.

LONDON, March 23 -- There was a roar of protest in the House of Commons today when John Platts-Mills, left wing Independent member, suggested that Gen. Hoyt S. Vandenberg, chief of the United States Air Force who recently visited England, came here "to make Britain a satellite" of the United States and to prepare the country "as part of an atom bomb base in the aggressive war."
COPENHAGEN, Denmark, March 23 -- The Danish Parliament began a two-day debate this afternoon on the Government's proposal to join the North Atlantic pact.

Wayne Coy, FCC chairman, yesterday dismissed as "a tempest in a teapot" the current discussion regarding the obsolescence of existing television receivers. In an address before the Advertising Club of Baltimore, according to The Associated Press, Mr. Coy said flatly that the twelve broadcasting channels presently assigned to television "will not be eliminated" and that "present television sets available on the market will get service from these channels continuously."
LEXINGTON, Ky., March 23 (AP) -- Superhorse Citation was ranked seven handicap pounds stronger than any horse that went to the races in 1948 under the Thoroughbred Club of America "yardstick" today.

E. A. Nichols, president of the Farnsworth Television and Radio Corporation, told the company's 18,000 stockholders yesterday that unless they approve the sale of the company to the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, "they face the probability of reduction in the value of their stock to a nominal amount, or even to nothing."

A riverfront estate of thirty-seven acres on the Nissequogue River Road, Smithtown, L. I., was sold by Mrs. Joseph L. Morrison to Hamden L. Forkner, Professor of Education at Teachers College, Columbia University, through Country Life Real Estate, brokers of Fort Salonga, L. I. Twenty-three acres are on the riverside and fourteen on the east side of the road.

LAKE SUCCESS, March 23 -- The Greek Government accused Yugoslavia today of allowing guerrilla bands to operate within her borders for the purpose of launching an attack upon the Greek-Yugoslav frontier.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -House Post Office Committee studies of second-class postal rates drew toward a close today with indications that the committee would recommend some increase in current charges, but only a small fraction of the estimated average 300 per cent requested by the Post Office Department.

Dmitri Shostakovich, famous composer, and six other Russian intellectuals who will represent the Soviet Union at the Cultural and Scientific Conference for World Peace arrived at La Guardia Airport yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- An application of the Potomac Electric Power Company requesting authorization to sell $37,000,000 of 3 1/4 per cent debentures, Series A, due in 1969, was denied today by the District of Columbia Public Utilities Commission.
WASHINGTON, March 23 (UP) -- The House Ways and Means Committee today apparently doomed President Truman's proposal for Federal aid to all needy persons.

Awarding contracts for 5,760,000 yards of woolen goods priced at over $19,000,000, the Quartermaster Purchasing Office yesterday ended the first phase of outfitting the Airforce in new blue uniforms. Manufacturers receiving serge, velour and tropical worsted awards had entered bids substantially below prices of comparable civilian fabrics.

LONDON, March 23 -- William Gallacher, Communist Member of Parliament, told the House of Commons tonight that the United States State Department used Scotland Yard in checking the records of four Britons to whom it has denied visas to attend the Cultural and Scientific Conference for World Peace in New York.

The Public Service Commission denied yesterday a request by the Westchester Electric Railroad Company for an interim increase of two cents -- from five to seven cents -- on its trolley operations between New Rochelle and New York.
