AINTREE, England, March 23 (AP) -- The hoodoo of Aintree's dangerous fences turned up again today to threaten the owner-rider of the favorite in Saturday's 103d running of the Grand National Steeplechase.

Dr. Harold J. Laski, a member of the Executive Committee of the British Labor party and a professor at the University of London, has been barred from making two lecture appearances on the campus of the University of California at Los Angeles.

The excellent editorial "The Filibuster" illustrates the impact upon our foreign policy of events in the Senate. The danger in this respect is even much greater. In the propaganda war against the American way of life, it will be asked. If democracy does not mean rule by the majority, what else does it mean?

New stemware designed by Russel Wright and to be introduced Monday at Altman's emphasizes that simple modern dinnerware and inexpensive accessories in plain colors may be combined into formal table settings. The new glassware will be shown in table settings that will augment the elaborate series now on view on the fourth floor.

ANKARA, Turkey, March 23 -- United States expenditures under the Truman Doctrine for the equip ping and training of Turkey's armed forces were described today by Maj. Gen. Horace L. McBride as "about the best investment the United States can make for the preservation of world peace."

Prof. Louis F. Budenz of Fordham University, former Communist official, testified at the Communist trial yesterday that the party had demanded his loyalty to Premier Joseph Stalin of Soviet Russia as the leader of Communist world revolution in all countries, including the United States.

The New England Telephone Telegraph Company borrowed $35,000,000 yesterday on twenty-five-year debentures at an interest cost of 2.99 per cent. The money will be used on June 1 to retire a like amount of 5 per cent bonds due in 1952.

Several upsets marked the first knockout round of the Curt H. Reisinger Trophy contest for teams-of-four in the Eastern States contract bridge tournament at the Park Sheraton Hotel last night, when the field was cut to eight teams.

TEL AVIV, Israel, March 23 -An armistice agreement between Israel and Lebanon was signed shortly before noon today at Ras en Naqura in a Lebanese Army post that was formerly a frontier customs house. The building, which is atop a white limestone promontory, will be returned to Israel under the armistice.

Joint military planning by the United States and Canada has become more important than ever before, Gen. Andrew G. L. McNaughton, Canada's rerpesentative on the United Nations Security Council, declared yesterday.
Your editorial "The Filibuster" of March 16 contains the seeds of its own refutation.

Television was viewed from all angles, literally and figuratively, yesterday at the closing session of the three-day conference of the American Institute of Decorators, at the Pierre Hotel. Pointers on the planning of television rooms and the placement of sets were provided by speakers at the afternoon meeting which also included a viewing of a television program devoted to interior decoration.

Richard (Pancho) Gonzales, national turf court tennis champion from Los Angeles, and Donald McNeill, former title-holder, advanced to the semi-finals of the national indoor tournament yesterday at the Seventh Regiment Armory. At the same time Miss Gertrude Moran of Santa Monica, Calif., and Miss Dorothy Head of Wilmington, Del., moved into the penultimate brackets in the women's singles.
Farrell Lines will accept payment for freight charges in either United States or South African currency for the three-month period beginning April 1, the steamship company announced yesterday.
CHICAGO, March 23 -- The North Atlantic pact was opposed and defended here tonight at a forum of the Chicago Council on Foreign Relations, in which three newspaper men took part.

This year, for the first time since the war, England's men's wear industry is showing evidence of regaining world leadership in styling, G. A. Gidley, general merchandise manager of Gimbel Brothers, Philadelphia, said yesterday aboard the Queen Elizabeth.

IF Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery keeps on telling his story of the war backward we'll all soon be worrying over the danger that Mussolini may capture Cairo. His first volume, "Normandy to the Baltic," appeared some time ago. His new book, "El Alamein to the River Sangro,"* covers the historic march of the magnificent British Eighth Army across the top of Africa, over to Sicily, and up the Italian boot on the road to Rome.

Counsel for the New York University Law Center will ask a further thirty-day adjournment in Municipal Court today of its eviction proceedings against eighty-five tenants in "artists' row" in Washington Square South.

The New York City Housing Authority announced yesterday that it would receive bids April 5 on $48,375,000 of serial bonds to finance permanently the construction of four non-cash-subsidy public housing projects.

In the heart of East Harlem's trouble-zone, a neighborhood where the mixed backgrounds of the population cause racial tensions to run high, Union Settlement stands as a beacon of social welfare, sympathy and human understanding. A pilot for many social experiments, the 54-year-old agency runs a full and well-rounded program, including a year-round day nursery and day care center and special programs for school-age boys and girls and teenagers.
WASHINGTON, March 23 (AP) -An expanded program to aid European recovery by unlocking the colonial resources of Marshall Plan countries was set in motion today.

BERLIN, March 23 -- Russian economic experts in the Soviet zone and their German associates expect that the present restrictions on trade between East and West Germany will be lifted by the middle of this year, according to a report on the economy of the Soviet zone recently prepared for one of the Western powers in Berlin.

CHICAGO, March 23 -- Corn was the market leader in the trading in grains on the Board of Trade today, showing a strong undertone and closing at the top with gains of 2/8 to 1 7/8 cents a bushel, May leading. Wheat gained 3/8 cent to 1 1/2 cents; oats, 1/4 to 3/8 cent, and rye, 3/8 to 1 cent.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., March 23 -- Chief of Police August Hlavaty of the Palisades Interstate Park Police began the department's spring refresher course this week with long hikes over rugged terrain. Details under lieutenants and sergeants are familiarizing themselves with the remotest sections in the seventy-five square miles of park lands by a hiking inspection of the 250 miles of park trails.
SARASOTA, Fla., March 23 (AP) -- The War between Tom Yawkey of the Boston Red Sox and Bob Carpenter, owner of the Philadelphia Phillies, is at an end.
The failure of the Senate to take affirmative action on legislation to remedy the "overtime on overtime" for stevedores is causing continued concern in that industry, it was learned yesterday.

The nation's gasoline stocks at the end of last week set a new record at 127,310,000 barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute. This was 1,122,000 barrels more than the 126,188,000 reported as of a week earlier.

The one-and-a-half-story building on a plot 50 by 100 feet at 226-28 Pine Street, Jersey City, N. J., was sold by the O'Mealia Advertising Company to Goodwill Industries of New Jersey for occupancy in an expansion move. D. E. C. Somers, Inc., was the broker.

Adolf C. Bleckner has purchased the one-story taxpayer on the westerly blockfront on Boston Post Road, between Allerton Avenue and Bronxwood Boulevard, the Bronx, from the estate of William T. Keogh. The property, which was held at $120,000, extends through to Matthews Avenue. Clarence G. Feltner was the broker.

NEWPORT NEWS, Va., March 23 -- In comparison with size, this community has absorbed as large a proportion of the rural Negro population as Harlem as well as a share of the same problems of housing, health, schooling and employment, community leaders said today.

The cartoon by Marcus in the Sunday issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES of Feb. 27, entitled: "The Speaker's Platform," gave me many moments of serious thought. The first quick glance seemed only to reveal a mad Russian (Stalin) at a rehearsal. Further perusal revealed his platform, which consisted of the coffins of the conquered countries of Europe.

Earl Browder, expelled former general secretary of the Communist party in America, accused the party's National Committee yesterday of planting a "slander" in an afternoon newspaper that he would be a Government witness in the trial of the eleven Communist leaders.

The Bowdoin College Glee Club, which has not sung here since 1941, gave a program last night at Town Hall that attracted an audience of more than 1,100. The eighty singers of the group were led by Frederic Tillotson, who has been professor of music at the college since 1936.

LONDON, March 23 -- Harold Wilson, president of the Board of Trade, disclosed today that the Government - sponsored National Film Finance Company was granting some loans to movie producers conditional upon the producers deferring part or all of their fees until costs of movies have been recovered.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 23 -- Otto Preminger, Twentieth Century-Fox producer-director, and Philip Dunne, scenarist, have returned from a three-week trip to China, and Dunne has begun work on a photoplay titled "Transit Hong Kong," which Preminger will produce and direct.

MOSCOW, March 23 -- The North Atlantic treaty was described today as a "pact of war," "a new cordon sanitaire against the Soviet Union," and a revived Holy Alliance in the most corrosive attack yet appearing in Moscow. It was published by Literary Gazette, organ of the union of Soviet writers.

The four health centers maintained by the Children's Health Service of the New York Diet Kitchen Association will benefit by proceeds from the performance of "Detective Story" on April 21 at the Hudson Theatre. Frequent committee meetings are being held in the interests of the project.

" Outpost in Morocco," a melodrama starring George Raft, which opens at the Capitol, is this morning's lone film newcomer. Robert Florey directed and Samuel Bischoff and Joseph N. Ermolieff produced from a screen play by Charles Grayson and Paul de Sainte-Colombe and a story by Mr. Ermolieff.

WARSAW, March 23 -- The Polish Government explained today that it had asked the recall of the United States Embassy's press attache because it could no longer tolerate the "brutality of American-news bulletins."

LOS ANGELES, March 23 -- California sunshine, acting up these many weeks, took another perverse turn today when an itinerant shower strayed in the path of the Giants and Pirates and washed out the second game of their exhibition series scheduled for San Bernardino.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- Russian charges that Iran was being converted into an American military base were denounced as "false and demonstrably untrue" by Secretary of State Dean Acheson at a news conference today.

J. H. Kindelberger, chairman of North American Aviation, Inc., informed stockholders at the annual meeting in Los Angeles yesterday that net income for the six months ending on March 31, 1949, will be about $2,780,000, equal to 81 cents a capital share. In the like period a year ago the net was $753,438, or 22 cents a share.

ALBANY, March 23 -- Bills extending for three years New York City's authority to levy a sales tax and other special imposts were approved by both the Senate and Assembly today without discussion. They go to Governor Dewey for approval.

There seems to be some talk going around to the effect that the distinguished foreigners who have received, and accepted, invitations to participate in the Cultural and Scientific Conference for World Peace, although granted visas to enter the United States, will not be permitted to travel freely in this country for the purpose of addressing various audiences.

WASHINGTON, Mar. 23 -- President Truman said tonight that James Forrestal, retiring Secretary of Defense, had made a record of which to be proud. He delivered the tribute at a farewell dinner given to Mr. Forrestal by the Secretaries of the Army, the Navy, and the Air Force.

Although Sidney Kingsley's style is dated, his drama is powerful and straightforward. The style is realistic. The drama is "Detective Story," put on at the Hudson last evening. As in the case of "Dead End," Mr. Kingsley has accumulated a vast number of details about life in New York and given them the form of a vivid drama with a disturbing idea.

Bridgeport, Conn., sold $1,500,000 of trunk sewer and disposal plant bonds due on April 1 from 1950 to 1964 to National City Bank at a bid of 100.04 for 1.40s, an interest cost of 1.395 per cent. The bonds were reoffered at prices to yield 0.65 per cent to 1.50 per cent.

PARIS, March 23 -- Although the North Atlantic defense pact is not yet a binding document, its strongest European supporters already are legally bound to defend each other against aggression under the Brussels Treaty, which created the Western Union.

" Sailfish," a new sporting craft designed and built by Alcort, Inc., Waterbury, Conn; Hoggson Brothers, Inc., designers and builders of bank buildings; Spencer Muns, Hempstead, L. I., mail-order advertisers of watches; all to Gotham Advertising Company, Inc.

The weather man sprayed the air with spring fever yesterday afternoon, just in time for the millinery show of Easter bonnets presented at B. Altman's. A large collection of hats by top designers was offered. French copies took their place on the runway along with American creations, some of which were by West Coast designers.

WASHINGTON, March 23 (AP) -- Exports to South America declined to $174,200,000 in January from $204,800,000 in December, the Census Bureau reported today. Imports from South America fell to $144,300,000 from $162,500,000.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- James Forrestal, Secretary of Defense, has ordered, effective immediately, that all information about new weapons, munitions and other defense equipment "of any kind" be cleared only through his office.

BALTIMORE, March 23 -- The New York Knickerbockers will have their backs to the wall tonight at Madison Square Garden when they oppose the Baltimore Bullets in the second game of their Basketball Association of America play-off series.
LONDON, March 23 -- Government leaders assured a somewhat jittery House of Commons today that the Communists would be contained in Germany and Greece.
Permit me a word of praise for your editorial of March 16 on the strategy of Negro Americans working for what they are entitled to in the way of civil rights.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -Forty-two countries today unanimously adopted the international wheat agreement, described as a "trading instrument" to make possible "planned production and organized marketing of wheat throughout the world."

ALBANY, March 23 -- Senator Samuel L. Greensberg of Brooklyn and Assemblyman James G. Lyons of Monticello, minority members of the Temporary Commission on Agriculture, declared today that the $200,000 spent by the commission to investigate milk prices in New York City might better have been used to supply milk to under-privileged children.

PHILADELPHIA, March 23 (AP) -- Mrs. Kasenkina said here, "The Soviet woman, despite her sturdiness and resistance to hunger, cold and suffering, cannot thrive on the misery that is her lot." She detailed these "appalling conditions under which the women of the Soviet Union are forced to live":
RALEIGH, N. C., March 23 (UP) -- A high-speed Diesel engine is purring along contentedly on a diet of pulverized coal mixed nearly half-and-half with its fuel oil.

LONDON, March 23 -- The concern of British workers over the rising cost of living was reflected today in discussions of the General Council of the Trades Union Congress, which decided to ask the Government to consider reducing prices and making cuts in sales taxes.

NEW DELHI, India, March 23 -- Prime Minister Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru said in a speech here last night that "imperialist domination," typified by the Indonesian situation, and racial discrimination, as seen in South Africa, were symptoms that "may well lead to conflict on a big scale."

ALBANY, March 23 -- The Senate passed a bill today under which New York City firemen could settle their differences with the O'Dwyer administration over permanent salary schedules by means of a referendum.

MELBOURNE, Australia, March 23 (Reuters) -- The British crew of the 7,128-ton Canadian collier Haligonian Duke are virtual outcasts on the Melbourne waterfront because of a dockers' ban on the ship, imposed on Feb. 24 after the Australian Seamen's Union declared her "black."

The precocity of the crocus this season in Central Park has raised a few eyebrows among members of the Park Department's horticulture division who have not witnessed a spring busting out all over as early as this one in thirty-odd years.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- The Arkansas Power and Light Company, Pine Bluff, Ark., asked the Securities and Exchange Commission today for authorization to issue and sell to its parent, the Electric Power and Light Corporation, New York, an additional 320,000 shares of $12.50 par-value common stock for $4,000,000.
BUCHAREST, Rumania, March 23 -- The (Communist) Government clamped on new ration restrictions today bearing heavily on the moneyed classes.
WASHINGTON, March 23 (AP) -- The Senate today unanimously confirmed the nomination of Louis A. Johnson to be Secretary of National Defense. He succeeds James Forrestal.

Dr. Albert Einstein will head a distinguished list of sponsors for the "Salute to the President of Israel," which will be held April 23 at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel with President Truman and Dr. Chaim Weizmann as the guests of honor, it was announced yesterday by Abraham Feinberg, chairman of the dinner committee. The date of the dinner was incorrectly listed in THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday as April 26.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- President Truman told more than 1,000 delegates to the President's conference on industrial safety today that their goal should be to reduce the 2,000,000 job accidents that occur yearly by half by the end of three years.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- The Truman Administration's Senate forces were challenged today by Senator Kenneth S. Wherry of Nebraska, the Republican floor leader, to proceed almost immediately to a head-on struggle with the Southerners on the civil rights issue.
LONDON, March 23 -- Gold shares were best in the stock market here today. With Cape and London business broadening, prices finished higher throughout the list after an active day's trading.

LAKE SUCCESS, March 23 -- The United Nations Security Council today requested its Indonesian Commission to bring representatives of the Netherlands Government and the Indonesian Republic together to find ways of enforcing its previous decision for a cease-fire, a return of the Republican regime to Jogjakarta and the release of Indonesian Republican leaders by Dutch forces.

Stocks snapped out of their lethargy yesterday as prices on the New York Stock Exchange scored one of the best advances of the year. Gains were sprinkled liberally throughout the list, ranging from fractions to 2 points in the second heaviest trading session of the month.

How to make children like foods that are good for them was discussed yesterday at a panel session of dietitians and housekeepers for child-caring agencies at the American Red Cross center. Although the meeting was concerned mainly with institutional feeding, many of the ideas brought forth may be applied by mothers at home.

CHICAGO, March 23 (AP) -- Promoter Joe Louis win stage the Ezzard Charles-Jersey Joe Walcott showdown for his vacated world's heavyweight title in Chicago -- right where he won it from Jim Braddock in 1937.
WASHINGTON, March 23 -- The bill for pensions for veterans of both World Wars ran into trouble in the House today.

Following their theme that smart fashions need not be expensive, Milgrim brought forth yesterday on their fourth floor an array of attractive spring and summer styles, all, with the exception of a few gabardine suits, priced below $50.

The New York City Opera Company will open its spring season with Verdi's "Aida," tonight at 8:15, at the City Center. Heading the cast will be Camilla Williams in the title role, Margery Mayer as Amneris, Rudolf Petrak as Radames and Lawrence Winters as Amonasro.

Without the aid of the European Recovery Program, England "would have been faced with a revolutionary situation" that would have brought about "a dictatorship of either the right or the left," a Labor Government official declared here yesterday.

The Cultural and Scientific Conference for World Peace will be called to order at 7 P. M. tomorrow in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel for the avowed purpose of drafting a resolution to further international cooperation and attain world peace.

Directors of the Pennsylvania Railroad at their meeting held yesterday in Philadelphia declared a dividend out of 1948 earnings of 75 cents a share on the capital stock, payable on May 2. This will be the 226th dividend to be paid by the company in its unbroken record of returns to stockholders in each of its 102 years of existence.

Prices on first quality goods from its finished dress goods department will be guaranteed through June 30, it wa announced yesterday by Dan River Mills. The guarantee will also apply to first quality stormwear fabrics, but is not applicable to Dan River suitings, work clothes, shirtings or gray goods.

HALLANDALE, Fla., March 23 (AP) -- There were two racing rarities at Gulfstream Park today -- a Calumet Farm horse won at 10 to 1 and a judges' error in the placing of a second horse was corrected after official prices had appeared on the infield board for the fourth race.

BUENOS AIRES, March 23 -Deadlocked on the question of the convertibility of sterling, British and Argentine negotiators seeking a successor to the Andes Pact are known to be considering a large-scale oil-for-meat deal as a major element of an over-all accord.

Joseph J. O'Connell Jr., chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board, said last night that the air transport industry should settle into a profitable pattern this year. He warned, however, that the economy and efficiency of even the largest lines would be watched closely.
Belief that the Truman program will be enacted "in whole or part" by the Eighty-first Congress was expressed yesterday by James A. Farley at the Advertising Club, 23 Park Avenue.
WASHINGTON, March 23 (AP) -- Senators were urged today to give the Civil Aeronautics Board power to approve or disapprove stock issues and creation of debt by commercial air carriers.

LONDON, March 23 (AP) -- Impresario Harold Fielding said today he is feuding with the British Broadcasting Corporation over pay for its broadcasts of the Philadelphia Orchestra programs. The orchestra will reach Liverpool May 21 for twenty-eight British concerts.

VIENNA, March 23 -- To counter the resistance of the Hungarian peasantry to the collectivization of agriculture on the Soviet system, the Hungarian Government has proclaimed new regulations "for the protection of farm cooperatives."

MANILA, March 15 -- Confronted with demands of private enterprise for a policy declaration on government in business, President Elpidio Quirino has announced that the Philippine Government is prepared to lease, sell or place under management all its profitable corporations and production projects with the exception of cement-making and rice-marketing, which are regarded as prime necessities.

In line with a recommendation of the Public Service Commission, the Third Avenue Transit Corporation yesterday filed a plan of merger and consolidation of its operating companies in Manhattan, the Bronx and Westchester County.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- The United States Conference of Mayors adjourned a three-day meeting here today after the municipal leaders endorsed several points in President Truman's legislative program, including extended and "strengthened" Federal rent controls.
The United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers yesterday asked the Congress of Industrial Organizations of which it is the third largest affiliate, to call a national wage conference.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- The National Labor Relations Board held today that a local of the American Federation of Labor Carpenters' Union violated the secondary boycott ban of the Taft-Hartley Law by picketing a Montgomery, Ala., department store, at which a building contractor was employing nonunion carpenters.

BOMBAY, India, March 23 -- Cargo probably will be carried free after Thursday between Bombay, Marmagoa, Karachi, and the United Kingdom and continental ports as the rate war over this sea route continues with undiminished vigor.
Theatrical figures and British business men were among 1,958 passengers who arrived here yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Elizabeth.
VIENNA, March 23 -- Oscar Karlweis last night brought to the Vienna stage a big, white rabbit familiar to New Yorkers.

The voluntary steel allocation program has been cut back 150,000 tons for June, compared with February. The released steel will be available to other industrial users in the open market, Secretary of Commerce Charles Sawyer said at a press conference at the University Club last night.

Rare models of frigates of the War of 1812 carved by American war prisoners out of beef bones salvaged from their meals have just been put on display in a window of the Seaman's Bank for Savings, 20 East Forty-fifth Street.

A late entry in the dwindling theatrical season is a new play called "Gayden" by the husband and wife writing team of Robert and Mignon McLaughlin. Acquired by Gant Gaither several weeks ago, the play will be placed in rehearsal on Monday.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was quiet yesterday and final prices were 2 to 10 points net higher.
The case of the Board of Regents versus the Board of Trustees involves three principal issues:

The following list of sponsors of the Cultural and Scientific Conference for World Peace, said to be correct as of yesterday, was given out by the National Council of the Arts, Sciences and Professions, sponsor of the conference:

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 23 -- Yankee rookies occupied the center of the stage today in the second skirmish against Washington, but the Bombers had to call on their pros before squeezing through with a 5-to-4 decision.

A strong hint that the police have been tapping the wires of some of the persons involved in the current investigation of alleged illegal wiretapping was given late yesterday afternoon in General Sessions Court.

Rearming of Japan by the United States should be considered only as a "last bitter choice," it was agreed last night by four speakers on the weekly radio forum, "What's On Your Mind?", sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES and broadcast over WQXR.
ALBANY, March 23 -- The State Temporary Commission on Rents proposed in a report today that New York City stores renting for more than $7,500 a year be exempted from the Business Rent Control Law.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- Appointment of Dr. Frank P. Graham to the Senate aroused demands in that chamber today for a Congressional investigation of the North Carolina educator's clearance for access to atomic energy secrets.

WASHINGTON, March 23 (AP) -- An emergency board reported a settlement today in the dispute between Northwest Airlines and employes represented by the International Association of Machinists, with a pay rise for the workers.
ATLANTA, March 23 -- Georgia today took away the license of a Negro real estate dealer who sold homes in a white neighborhood to Negroes.

Federal Judge Edward A. Conger reserved decision yesterday on an application by Danny Gardella, Giant outfielder who was suspended in 1946 when he jumped to the Mexican League, for a temporary injunction barring organized baseball from interfering with his playing.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federad Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended March 16:

TOKYO, March 23 -- Labor union officials must cease to get their union salaries from company payrolls, according to an order from headquarters to the Japanese Government today. Between 100,000 and 150,000 union officials at present draw their pay only from the companies.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- The Maritime Commission and representatives of maritime labor today approved proposed legislation extending the time limit on the use of construction reserve funds set aside for vessel replacements.
WASHINGTON, March 23 -- By a party-line vote of 8 to 5, the House Labor subcommittee today approved without any change the Administration's labor relations bill.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee of the National Board of Review, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 a group of motion pictures to be shown, tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.

" The World of Emma Lazarus," a biography of the essayist, philanthropist and poetess whose lines are inscribed on the Statue of Liberty, has been scheduled for publication by Schocken Books on April 28, just two months short of the 100th anniversary of her birth.

FRANKFORT, Germany, March 23 -- The Economic Cooperation Administration is studying the possibility of a gigantic public works program to provide jobs for Western Germany's 10,000,000 restive refugees.

The designation of William W. Waymack as chairman of the National Citizens Council on Civil Rights comes at an especially fitting time. Following the filibuster defeat suffered in the Senate by advocates of federal legislation to protect civil rights, his acceptance of this unpaid post insures that the fight will be pressed under the leadership of an experienced public servant.

MOSCOW, March 23 -- The leading international commentary New Times tonight sharply recalled to the Finnish people their bitter experience of two wars and warned them that the Fagerholm Government had embarked on a perilous course of treaty violation.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 23--The Arab Higher Committee of Palestine will boycott the United Nations Conciliation Commission's hearings tomorrow because of the rejection of its status as a governmental organization, a well-informed Arab source asserted tonight.
BERLIN, March 23 -- The production goals set for Western Germany under the Marshall Plan are endangered by the lack of long-term investment capital.

Winning in the seventh round of the international chess masters tournament yesterday, Hector Rossetto of Argentina and Miguel Czerniak of Palestine remained at the top among eighteen competitors, according to a report received from Mar del Plata.

Winston Churchill returned to the United States yesterday for his first visit since January, 1946. Though he is in his seventy-fifth year -- he will have a birthday anniversary in November -- he was literally in the pink of condition.

A fifty-six game schedule has been prepared by the Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference for the 1949 season, Jack Coffey, conference president, announced last night. The season will begin Saturday, April 2, when Fordham will play the United States Merchant Marine Academy at Kings Point, L. I.

Successful attainment of its European recovery objectives by the Economic Cooperation Administration will, temporarily at least, mean a decrease in American exports to Europe and a substantial cut in our shipments to Latin America, speakers said yesterday at the annual convention of the Export Managers Club of New York at the Statler Hotel.

As a regular reader of Mr. Krock's fine column, I was especially interested in his recent observations to the effect that "a treaty obligation to resort to arms under the North Atlantic Community Agreement could supersede the power of Congress "to declare war."

PATERSON, N. J., March 23 -- David Dubinsky, president of the International Ladies' Garment Workers Union, speaking at dedicatory ceremonies in connection with the formal opening of the new Barbizon Corporation plant in this city, today declared that unions are a constructive force in industry, and that a harmonious relationship with a union is not a hindrance to prosperity but encourages staple and efficient industry.

Zinc became the second nonferrous metal to recede from high post-war levels, when it dropped yesterday 1 1/2 cents from 17 1/2 cents to a new official price of 16 cents a pound, for prime Western grades, New York refiners reported.

The State Liquor Authority revoked yesterday the liquor license of a restaurant at 505 West Twenty-third Street on the ground that the licensee had operated it as a "front" for Waxey Gordon, beer baron and racketeer in prohibition days. His real name is Irving Wexler.

ALBANY, March 23 -- The Assembly administered a sharp rebuff today to the Board of Regents, voting down the Condon-Barrett bill that would have halted transfer of existing state teachers' colleges and educational institutions to the Trustees of the State University on April 1. The vote was 49 in favor of the bill and 94 opposed.

Harry Cykman, who played at Carnegie Hall last night, is in his twenties, but he has been in the business of playing the violin long enough to know his own powers. His program last night was put together cunningly to suit his artistic affinities, and the result was that he gave a good account of himself.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- On the eve of the Senate debate on the $5,580,000,000 Marshal Plan authorization bill, Senator Robert A. Taft, of Ohio, Republican leader, said today that he was for cutting the amount by up to $1,000,000,000 on the ground that the Administration's request was "obviously padded."

GLEN COVE, L. I., March 23 -- Historic Station No. 10 of the New York Yacht Club, which has been the Hempstead Harbor shelter for the club fleet for fifty years, will be purchased by the city of Glen Cove as soon as details of the sale can be arranged between the municipality and the officers of the club.

From its vast store of spring merchandise, the Tailored Woman culled thirty-eight pieces representing what in its style expert's opinion is its best for presentation to the large luncheon audience assembled in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday.

As fourteen leading intellectuals of Russia, Poland and Czechoslovakia arrived here yesterday for the Cultural and Scientific Conference for World Peace, anti-Communists said they would throw the biggest picket ring in the city's history around the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, where the three-day conference will be held, starting tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, March 23 -- Following is the Senate roll-call on its rent control extension bill:
WASHINGTON, March 23 -- The Senate passed tonight by a vote of 68 to 10 an extension of rent controls to June 30, 1950, that envisages ending of all Federal regulation at that time.

The Queens Advisory Planning Board recommended to the City Planning Commission yesterday the establishment of a headquarters and factory building of the Bulova Watch Company at Queens and Yellowstone Boulevards, Forest Hills, Queens.

After early declines, coffee futures rallied somewhat yesterday to close the day irregular on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. Trade hedge selling early in the session was absorbed on a downward scale. Scattered trade short covering toward the close rallied contract '@).'

Intolerance is a "sign of the immaturity that occurs with age," Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll of New Jersey declared here yesterday. He spoke at a meeting at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel at which he received a Thomas Jefferson prize for the Advancement of Democracy from the Council against Intolerance in America for his part in the adoption of the New State Constitution in New Jersey forbidding racial or religious segregation in the militia.

NANKING, March 23 -- The Chinese Communist radio said tonight that peace talks with Acting President Li Tsung-jen's Nanking Government would be held "very soon." This was the first public acknowledgment from the Communists that they were preparing for such negotiations since the Communist leader, Mao Tze-tung, received an unofficial Shanghai peace mission almost a month ago.

The New York State Assembly lived up to the best state tradition in eliminating segregation from the New York National Guard without any ifs, ands or buts. There was little excuse for making elimination of segregation in the New York Guard dependent on adoption of a similar program in the United States Army, Navy and Air Force.

ALBANY, March 23 -- Declaring that lobbyists have been interfering with legislative processes, Benjamin F. Feinberg, Senate majority leader, announced today that they would not be allowed on the floor of the Senate or the Assembly for the balance of the session.
ROME, March 23 -- Pope Pius today urged that Catholics avoid reading anti-Catholic propaganda, which, he said, was based on slander and lies.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 23 -- Harold E. Stassen, President of the University of Pennsylvania, accepted today an invitation to address the mid-century convocation of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology on April 1 at Boston Garden.
A familiar figure came to town yesterday with an age-old but ever-wonderful story. He spoke of clowns with whitened scalp and reddened noses, of blaring music, spangled costumes, feats pyramidal.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., March 23 -- The famed New Jersey mosquito of fact and joke is fighting a losing battle in many sections of the state, the New Jersey Mosquito Extermination Association was told today at its thirty-sixth annual meeting.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- The National Mediation Board tried today to help negotiate an agreement between the Railway Express Agency and the American Federation of Labor's Railway and Steamship Clerks but George M. Garrison, president of the union, said he barred further negotiations until the company withdraws a $5,000,000 damage suit charging a slowdown in New York City.

Unusual flowers and old favorites catch the attention of gardeners as the International Flower Show starts its fourth day at Grand Central Palace. Many a variety name is written down, and many an idea noted from gardens for duplication at home.

Another new store in its retail expansion program was opened by Bond Stores, Inc., yesterday morning in Brooklyn. The new establishment, a four-story structure at Fulton Street and Gallitan Place, becomes the eleventh store under Bond Stores management in the metropolitan area.

Official confirmation on the opening of the trout season in New York has now arrived and the general season will open on the second Saturday, April 9, with a special lake trout and rainbow trout season opening on April 1 in seven upstate lakes and their tributaries.

Beginning next fall, two five-year scholarships at Columbia University will be granted annually to sons of New York electrical workers by the Joint Industry Board of the Electrical Industry, A. Lincoln Bush, the chairman, announced yesterday. Fathers of applicants must be members of the board's pension system.

Two representatives of St. Paul's School, A. C. Ewing and David Watts, gained the semi-final round of the interscholastic invitation squash racquets tourney at the Racquet and Tennis Club tourney yesterday along with Charles W. Ufford Jr., of Deerfield and Bart Lachelier of Phillips Exeter.

Alfred Rodgers, not to be confused with Richard Rodgers, the composer, was merely saying it with music -- writing bebop melody, that is, in a book in front of 1205 Brook Avenue, the Bronx, last Oct. 16, when so rudely interrupted by his arrest, his attorney indicated in Bronx Special Sessions Court yesterday.

DUESSELDORF, March 10 -- Any casual passerby can recognize at a glance that shopwindows of the Rhineland are filled once more -- with gleaming fresh, postwar designs and wares. But it requires more effort to discover that something strikingly parallel has been happening in the mentalities of the younger generation in this region.

Supported by a growing number of patrons, Sam Atkins, lower East Side tavern owner, defiantly faced 4,000 rival bar and grill proprietors yesterday in his fight to sell beer for a nickel a glass instead of a dime.
HOT SPRINGS, Va., March 23 -- Continuous all-out advertising was urged on business management here today as essential to success in the returning rule of "tough" competition.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, March 23 -- Expansion of the Benelux Economic Union to include Western Germany and France is under discussion, it was learned from an unimpeachable source here today.

DETROIT, March 23 -- Left and right-wing forces in the huge Local 600, United Automobile Workers, CIO, were locked tonight in a battle of ballots that both sides agreed would make or break the whole strategy of the UAW's drive for a fourth-round pay increase in 1949.

A two-hour meeting between representatives of the Masters, Mates and Pilots, AFL, and Atlantic and Gulf Coast steamship operators was held yesterday afternoon, but no progress was reported in the wage review. A spokesman for the employers' group, the Committee for the Companies and Agents, Atlantic and Gulf Coasts, said another meeting is scheduled for Monday afternoon.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 23 -- Important American engineering concerns have been surveying Yugoslavia's industrial expansion program with a view to examining the possibility of accepting contracts for capital construction and heavy industrial equipment.

BALDWIN, L. I., March 23--One man was killed and ten other persons, including a Brooklyn rabbi, were injured at 3:45 P. M. today when an automobile containing members of a funeral party was involved in a head-on collision with another car on the Southern State Parkway near the Grand Avenue overpass here.

The Westinghouse Electric Corporation will cut back production of a number of appliances from 12 to 30 per cent beginning April 1, J. H. Ashbaugh, vice president in charge of the electric appliance division, disclosed yesterday. He attributed the cutbacks to heavy inventories and added that the curtailment of output will be "gradual."

The Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, Inc., reported yesterday for 1948 a consolidated net income of $132,800,055 after charges, taxes and reserves, equal to $4.18 each on the 32,332,015 capital shares outstanding. This compares with $97,708,927, or $3.13 a share, in 1947.

Northwest Airlines, Inc., operator of transcontinental and trans-Pacific air routes, is negotiating for loans totaling $21,000,000 to buy new equipment, it was reported yesterday. The airline is understood to have asked the Reconstruction Finance Corporation for $11,000,000 and for the balance from a group of banks.

The first proclamation of American policy to help free peoples to maintain their independence was made two years ago when President Truman announced a program of aid for Greece. This was the precedent for the Atlantic Pact. The Truman Doctrine is the nucleus from which the Marshall Plan and the new defense system have developed with inexorable logic.

TOKYO, March 23 -- Allied pressure on financial issues is now forcing the conservative government of Premier Shigeru Yoshida to repudiate some of its most important campaign promises by means of which it was able to sweep Leftist and middle-of-the-road parties out of office last January.

TOKYO, March 23 -- Allied pressure on financial issues is now forcing the conservative government of Premier Shigeru Yoshida to repudiate some of its most important campaign promises by means of which it was able to sweep Leftist and middle-of-the-road parties out of office last January.

Cardinal Spellman paid tribute yesterday to members of the Committee of the Laity, comprising 1,000 Catholic business and professional men, for their assistance in the current campaign for $2,500,000 sought by Catholic Charities of the New York Archdiocese in its thirtieth annual appeal.

Continuing Wednesday's rally, prices on the New York Stock Exchange moved slightly higher yesterday, but trading was less buoyant. Advances ranged from fractions to a point, with railroad and selected airline and aircraft issues strongest.
Earl Cochell of San Francisco, sixth in the national ranking, was eliminated from the national indoor tennis championship yesterday at the Seventh Regiment Armory.

Admission price reductions, ranging from 10 cents to 35 cents, have been quietly introduced in recent weeks by six first-run Broadway movie houses to help bolster sagging early morning and matinee attendance, a survey yesterday disclosed. Slighter lowering of night price scales also has gone into effect.

The first unit of the Maritime Commission's passenger-ship construction program will be started Tuesday when the Bethlehem Steel Company's Quincy, Mass., shipyard puts down the keel for the first of two express liners for the American Export Lines.

In a general order to all commands in all boroughs, Police Commissioner William J. O'Brien yesterday directed all members of the police department to "extend every consideration and courtesy to representatives, delegates and secretariats of foreign countries to the United Nations."

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 24 (AP) -- With speedy Richie Ashburn scoring the winning run from second on an infield hit, the Philadelphia Phils defeated the St. Louis Cardinals, 5 -- 4, today in an exhibition contest that went 11 innings.

The $300,000 goal of the New York Public Library to augment its yearly income was realized yesterday, four months after the institution began its first public fund-raising campaign, it was announced by Morris Hadley, president of the board of trustees, at the initial meeting of the newly-organized women's council of the library.
BATON ROUGE, La., March 24 (AP) -- A weakened portion of levee gave way today, and the Mississippi River flooded several square miles of sugar cane country.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- The Marine Corps announced today that Gen. Alexander A. Vandegrift, Marine commander in the Pacific campaign and corps commandant from 1944 through 1947, will retire from the active list on April 1 after forty years of service.

A twenty-month search of the city for the kinfolk of a 28-year-old Polish refugee, who lived no more than a city block from the relatives she sought, ended yesterday when they were reunited in the offices of the United Service for New Americans, 350 Broadway.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- President Truman's program to broaden and liberalize the contributory Social Security insurance system eventually would require annual outlays of $13,000,000,000 to $20,000,000,000 in old-age, survivors' and disability benefits, Congress was informed today.
PHILADELPHIA, March 24 (UP) -- The former Metropolitan Opera House was obtained today for a Philadelphia "world peace" rally on April 4 featuring Dmitri Shostakovich, the Russian composer.

According to a dispatch to this newspaper from Brussels, discussions are under way looking toward expansion of the Benelux Economic Union to include France and Western Germany. This is encouraging news. The Benelux Union project, started as early as 1944 and involving Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg, was the first realistic European attempt to deal with the problems of a changed world.
French Hospital began last week an experiment to break down the barriers of glass and antiseptic care that have kept more love than germs from passing between babies and parents.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 24 -- The recent visit of two representatives of H. A. Brassert and Company of New York leading steel consultants of the United States, and a new development in the current Anglo-Yugoslav negotiations for a long-term trade agreement may contribute heavily toward strengthening the Yugoslav position against the Communist Information Bureau.

VERO BEACH, Fla., March 24 -- Gil Hodges, who is the best first baseman in camp until somebody proves the contrary, caught nine innings in an intra-squad Dodger game today, but, according to Manager Burt Shotton, no significance is to be attached to this move.
"The Communist has no place in the schools of America," Dr. Harry N. Wright, president of City College, 139th Street and Convent Avenue, asserted yesterday.

Soviet spokesmen in the United Nations stand self-convicted of obstructionism and should be treated as convicts, Senator Ralph E. Flanders, Republican, of Vermont, declared in an address here last night.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- The thanks of Greece for aid by the United States will be expressed here next week by an "unofficial delegation" bringing a collection of gifts to President and Mrs. Truman, it was learned here to day.

WHITE OAK, Md., March 24 -- The world's most powerful X-ray generator, capable of taking pictures through sixteen inches of steel, was put on display and formally dedicated today at the Naval Ordnance Laboratory here. The photographs it takes reveal the internal structure of the metal and show up hidden defects or weaknesses.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- President Truman signed with "gratification" today a joint Congressional resolution authorizing the United States to contribute $16,000,000 toward the relief of 700,000 refugees of the recent fighting in Palestine.

Authorized and therefore legal wiretapping in New York City is limited to not more than about 350 cases a year, an inquiry showed yesterday. Court orders permitting listening in on telephone conversations are being held to a month in duration at present, so that it appears that probably not more than thirty legal "taps" can be carried on at any one time.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- President Truman expressed today unstinting praise of Dr. Frank P. Graham, president of the University of North Carolina, hailing him as a great American who would make a good Senator.
The recent murder of Mrs. Underwood in Korea points up the high price which American educators and missionaries may pay in line of self-imposed duty.
RANGOON, Burma, March 24 -- The North Burma army has recaptured its headquarters city of Meiktila [1 on map] from Karen rebels, the Government said today.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 24 -- The United Nations Conciliation Commission heard representatives of the Arab refugees here today and was impressed by statements that the majority of the refugees wished to return to their former homes and to live in peace with their neighbors, a commission spokesman said tonight.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- A proposal to consolidate reorganization proceedings of the $370,000,000 Philadelphia Company, Pittsburgh, with pending corporate simplification action involving the Standard Gas and Electric Company, Philadelphia's parent, was described today as "premature and wholly unfounded" by counsel for Standard Gas.

Police plans were changed yesterday to permit unrestricted demonstrating on all four sides of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, where the Cultural and Scientific Conference for World Peace will open tonight with a dinner in honor of its foreign delegates.

Debate on the second installment of ERP opened in the Senate yesterday with sure indications that Congress will continue the foreign aid program but with some doubt as to whether the full amount asked for the next fifteen months -- $5,580,000,000 -- will be authorized and appropriated.

LONDON, March 24 -- Ernest Bevin went aboard the liner Queen Mary at Southampton tonight for his happiest political trip as Foreign Secretary. He is going to Washington to sign the North Atlantic pact on behalf of Britain.

The State Department charged yesterday that the Soviet Government feared a free interchange of "ideas and persons" with the United States because it knew the Russian people would learn of the failure of communism to provide them with American standards of living and freedom.

Although few anglers think of North Carolina as a trout fishing state, there are some excellent mountain streams in the western counties, and last week one of the lakes in that area produced a 14-pound 1-ounce rainbow, which is a real whopper for Eastern waters.

About 1,300 persons, including members of both major political parties, many public officials and civic leaders, attended a testimonial dinner to John R. Crews, Commissioner of Elections and Brooklyn Republican leader, given last night by the Boys' Club of the Navy Yard District in the St. George Hotel.

By the beginning of 1950, the steel industry "will find itself again in what might be termed its 'normal' condition of being overbuilt," Ernest T. Weir, chairman of the Corporation, declared in the annual report to stockholders, issued yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- The replacement of Marshal Bulganin by Marshal Vasilevsky as Soviet Minister of the Armed Forces was regarded here as a continuation of the Cabinet shake-ups in Russia that have been marked by the relieving of policy officials by technicians.

The two-story store and apartment building at 2126 Flatbush Avenue, near Quentin Road, Brooklyn, has been purchased for investment by Mrs. Goldie Horowitz from Louis Beer Sons. The property is on a lot 20 by 100 feet. Title was insured by the Home Title Guaranty Company.
The small-craft fleet of New York Harbor made the office-building canyons of the Battery echo yesterday with staccat blasts in welcome to a new member.

Dr. Raymond S. Hall, assistant director of the Seamen's Church Institute since 1947, was formally inducted yesterday as director of the organization by the Right Rev. Charles K. Gilbert, Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York.

LAKE SUCCESS, March 24 -- Secretary General Trygve Lie today postponed the ceremonial laying of the cornerstone of the permanent United Nations headquarters in Manhattan after learning from news agency reports that President Truman would not be able to officiate.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed quiet, 5 to 8 points net higher, yesterday.

Word from London that holders of bonds of the German Potash Syndicate are slated to receive some return on their investment -- the first since 1940 -- caused something of a stir in financial circles here yesterday despite the fact that there is no market interest whatever in these securities.

Summer children's camps throughout the nation, estimated to purchase approximately $200,000,000 worth of foods, equipment and general supplies annually, are off as much as 10 per cent in advance enrollment compared with last year, Edward Healy, president of the American Camping Association, disclosed yesterday at its meeting and exhibit of suppliers in the Statler Hotel.

LONDON, March 24 -- Marshal Nikolai A. Bulganin has been relieved of his post as Minister of the Soviet Armed Forces, the Moscow radio announced tonight. He has been succeeded by Marshal Alexander M. Vasilevsky, who directed the Soviet troops that invaded Manchuria in 1945.

Two new films will open in Broadway theatres this morning. At the Strand, the attraction is "A Kiss In The Dark," a romantic comedy produced by Warner Brothers, starring Jane Wyman and David Niven. Delmer Daves directed and Harry Kurnitz wrote the script and produced from a story by Everett and Devery Freeman.

The refusal by the Soviet Union to agree to "effective international control" of atomic energy has delayed important peacetime developments in that field, Wilbur E. Kelley, manager of New York Operations of the United States Atomic Energy Commission, declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- Working against a March 31 deadline, a Congressional conference committee of twelve members took up today the difficult assignment of reconciling the Senate and the House bills providing for extension of rent controls.

The extent to which the Philippine Government has engaged in enterprises which under our system would be left to private capital illustrates the dilemma that faces all Governments with semi-developed industrial economies. There is not the risk capital there to start new enterprises.

DETROIT, March 24 (AP) -- Rookie Gerry Plamondon scored his third goal of the game after 2:59 of overtime, enabling the Montreal Canadiens to gain a 4-3 victory over the National Hockey League's champion Detroit Red Wings before 13,718 fans at Olympia tonight.

The proposed International Trade Organization charter establishes principles in the field of customs procedure that are unprecedented in international agreements, Marc Catudal, adviser of the division of commercial policy of the State Department, said here yesterday.
MOSCOW, March 24 -- Soviet newspapers described today an elaborate aerial wolf hunt in northern Finland and suggested the project was a cover-up for a more important activity.

ALBANY, March 24 -- The cost of abating stream and harbor pollution in the state was estimated at $300,000,000 today in the report of a special legislative committee headed by Assemblyman Harold C. Ostertag, Wyoming County Republican.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., March 24 (AP) -- Robert C. Tait, Pittsburgh banker, today was named president of the Stromberg-Carlson Company. He succeeds Dr. Ray H. Manson, president since 1945, who becomes chairman of the board.

Spring is here. In the countryside, in the suburbs too, the leaves are unfurling, the birds are building their nests, the turtles are on the logs in the pond while the frogs sound off below, the skunk cabbages are shooting up out of the soft black mud, and in the woods there are wild flowers, white and violet, appearing all unbeknownst to anybody at all.

The sponsors of the Cultural and Scientific Conference for World Peace, to be held at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel this week-end, yesterday termed "ridiculous" recent charges that they were operating "on an extraordinarily opulent budget."

PARIS, March 24 -- French Foreign Minister Robert Schuman and Italian Foreign Minister Count Carlo Sforza, in a ceremony here tomorrow, will sign a protocol providing the first steps for a customs union and a series of other agreements between the two countries.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- John L. Lewis told his resting coal miners today to get ready for work on Monday and implied that the two-week suspension was a light drill in preparation for a more rugged show of discipline a few months hence.
AINTREE, England, March 24 (AP) -- The probable field for Saturday's Grand National was reduced today to 43.

MOSCOW, March 24 -- Pravda today hailed what it termed the collapse of the United Nations Economic and Social Council's hearings on "forced labor," which it charged were a gross anti-Soviet slander designed to draw the workers' attention away from the desperate plight under which they live in the capitalist United States.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, March 24 (AP) -- The Lower House of the Danish Parliament approved today the nation's entry into the pact by a 5-to-1 margin. The action was referred to the Upper House, where similar approval is regarded as certain.

LONDON, March 24 -- Experiments pointing to the conclusion that cancer is caused by a virus and not, according to the view held in many fields of research, by chemical agents, may lead to the "biggest advance in cancer research for many years," The British Medical Journal said tonight.

VIENNA, March 24 -- How the Hungarian Government, which frequently has complained of "espionage" by United States officials in Hungary, searched their rooms and shadowed their every movement up to the time of their expulsion was related today by Lieut. Col. Peter J. Kopcsak and Lieut. Col. John P. Merrill, assistant military attaches in Budapest.
Four teams won their way to the semi-final round of the Eastern States contract bridge team-of-four tournament for the Curt H. Reisinger Trophy in the matches at the Park Sheraton Hotel last night.

Robert F. Wagner Jr., chairman of the City Planning Commission, is a candidate for the Democratic nomination for the United States Senate seat now held by his father, who has been in ill health for several years. He expressed this aspiration publicly at a meeting of the Williston Park Democratic Club in American Legion Hall of that Nassau County community Tuesday evening.

ATHENS, March 24 -- Speaking over the Athens radio today, United States Ambassador Henry F. Grady, in his capacity as President Truman's personal envoy during Greece's "Work and Victory Week," praised the Greek spirit in the current struggle.
LONDON, March 24 -- Britain's weak and groggy Liberal party opened a three-day annual conference at Hastings today in preparation for a last-ditch stand at next year's general election.

Pope Pius XII, in his first speech prepared specially for television use in the United States, will present a message of thanks on Sunday to those who have contributed to the Bishops Fund for Victims of War. Although the Pope has been shown in televised newsreels in the past, the televising of the four-minute film on which his talk is recorded will mark his first appearance in a program planned specifically for the medium.

Mohawk Carpet Mills, Inc., yesterday announced an average overall price reduction of 2 per cent on its rugs and carpets, effective today. The action marks the first price reduction by a major carpet mill since the end of the war.
DENVER, March 24 (AP) -- A hard-running team from St. Francis of Brooklyn beat highly touted St. Thomas, 59 -- 41, tonight to move into the semi-finals of the national Catholic basketball tournament.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 24 -- Hal Wallis, independent producer at Paramount, announced today that his schedule for the next eighteen to twenty-four months will include seven pictures in addition to two which he is now filming, a third which he is editing and a fourth which is ready for release.

An agreement of affiliation between the New York Hospital and the Hospital for Special Surgery was announced jointly yesterday by William H. Jackson, president of the Society of the New York Hospital, and Samuel S. Duryee, president of the New York Society for the Relief of the Ruptured and Crippled.
WASHINGTON, March 24 -- Winston Churchill came to Washington today to dine with President Truman at Blair House tonight.

Brought up to date, "Shuffle Along," the Negro musical of yesteryear, is to be revived on Broadway for the second time, it became known yesterday. Irving Gaumont said he would sponsor the show in the early summer, with John Murray Anderson in charge of the direction.

DETROIT, March 24 -- Three strikes in the automobile industry made 33,300 workers idle today in eight plants. As was the case on Monday, Tuesday and yesterday, Chrysler was the hardest hit, with 24,700 workers affected in various locals of the United Automobile Workers, CIO.

TEL AVIV, Israel, March 24 -- The Israeli Foreign Ministry is making a determined bid to convince the Soviet bloc countries that recent restrictions on the departure of Jews to Israel are incompatible with their strong support for the new state in the United Nations.

Insurance companies no longer consider air travel on scheduled airlines in this country a significant underwriting factor in the issuance of life insurance, the Institute of Life Insurance reported yesterday.
ALBANY, March 24 (AP) -- Here is a summary of the technical changes proposed in the state-aid formula under which an extra $40,000,000 would be allocated to school districts:
If present trends continue, the country is likely to see a revival of something supposed to have been laid to rest two decades ago, and that is legislative log-rolling in relation to the tariff.

NANKING, March 24 -- With the new popular peace hopes tinctured by continuing doubt as to whether the Nanking Government and the Communists can come to terms, spokesmen for both sides stressed the need today for economic reconstruction.

Compulsory national health insurance, now pending in Congress, was both bitterly attacked and strongly defended during a forum dinner last night at the New School for Social Research, 66 West Twelfth Street.

LAKE SUCCESS, March 24 -- Alberto Tarchiani, Italian Ambassador to the United States, expressed the hope today that Italy's African colonies would be restored to Italy under a United Nations trusteeship. The General Assembly is to decide on the disposition of the former Italian colonies at its spring session.

NEW DELHI, India, March 24 -- The customs union between India and the five French Indian colonies adopted as a wartime expedient has been abrogated by India to take effect April 1. At the same time, a permit system replaces the former unresticted travel between India and the French possessions.

Most of the machine and hand-printed wallpapers displayed yesterday by the A. H. Jacobs Company, 509 Madison Avenue, are subtle and restrained in design and coloring. Planned to provide livable backgrounds for a variety of rooms, the papers have medium-scaled motifs arranged to form pleasant diamond-shaped patterns when several widths are hung on the wall.

Dmitri Z. Manuilsky, former head of the Communist International, supervised the American Communists in their post-war revolutionary turn against the United States Government, accord ing to evidence yesterday at the Communist trial. Mr. Manuilsky is Foreign Minister of the Ukraine, a part of the Soviet Union.
WASHINGTON, March 24 -- By a single vote, 208 to 207, the House sent the much-mauled World War Veterans Pension bill back to its Veterans Affairs Committee today "for further study."
WASHINGTON, March 24 -- Following is the House vote today to shelve the veterans' pension bill:

The committee acting for the 5 1/4-per-cent secured serial bonds of the Missouri Pacific Railroad reported yesterday that it had filed a petition with the Interstate Commerce Commission seeking a reduction of $1,590,100 in the claim of the Missouri Pacific against its subsidiary, the New Orleans, Texas Mexico Railway.
LAKELAND, Fla., March 24 -- It was established beyond doubt today that the Detroit Tigers are the citrus circuit nemesis of Casey Stengel's Yankees.

The National Association of Manufacturers has invited the Soviet delegates who are here for a left-wing conference to have a look, at its expense, at the American production machine. It will arrange for them, if they are interested, a tour of some of our biggest factories, so that they may have "an opportunity to see American men and women at work and prospering under our system of free, individual enterprise."

Brooklyn, accustomed to getting its sports excitement at Ebbets Field, was struck by new violence last night when the Roller Derby began an eighteen-night stand at the old Fourteenth Regiment Armory. About 4,000 persons saw the rough-and-tumble competition with first-night honors going to Brooklyn over the Bronx, 16 -- 12.

The undersigned organizations join heartily in the request contained in your editorial of Feb. 28 that the State Commission Against Discrimination issue more complete reports, thus making possible an understanding and assessment of the work of that agency.

Price reductions on galvanized steel products, scrap steel and scrap aluminum were reported yesterday. Those affecting galvanized steel reflected the preceding day's reduction in the price of zinc, but the lower quotations for scrap steel and aluminum represented adjustments in a market of declining demand.

Dividends of 30 cents each on the common and Class A stock, both payable on April 29, were voted by the Arkansas Natural Gas Corporation. Previous payments were 20 cents each in November and an initial of a like amount in April last year.

Blue Moon hosiery prices have been reduced 10 to 15 per cent at the wholesale level, effective March 28, it was announced yesterday by Largman Gray Company, Philadelphia, hosiery manufacturers. New retail prices, effective April 9, will range from $1.15 a pair for 45 gauge to $2.25 for 54 gauge clocked.

ORLANDO, Fla., March 24 -- For year after year there was one memorable truism in baseball, a play on words which proclaimed, "Washington -- First in war, first in peace and last in the American League." Those were the days when Walter Johnson used to pitch his heart out without ever raising the Senators from their lethargic spot at the bottom of the standings.

ATHENS, March 24 (UP) -- Premier Themistocles Sophoulis appealed today for United States or other Western troops to help close Greece's northern frontier against her Communist-governed neighbors. The Greek Government would be "most grateful" for such military aid, Mr. Sophoulis said.

A ski season that started with great expectations, then turned out to be one of the worst in Eastern annals, will come to an inglorious finish this week-end as far as most of the enthusiasts in this part of the country are concerned. Diehard skiers and those who follow the "high-line" of northern-exposed mountain trails will delight in "sun-tan" skiing, as bright sunshine combined with "sugar" snows provide sport the next few weeks.

CHICAGO, March 24 -- Grains rallied strongly in the late trading on the Board of Trade today after fluctuating in a nervous manner. Closing irregular with wheat 3/4 cent a bushel lower to 7/8 cent higher than yesterday; corn, 1/8 cent lower to 5/8 cent higher; oats, 1/8 cent lower to 3/8 cent higher; rye, unchanged to 3/8 cent lower, and soy beans, unchanged, to 3/4 cent lower.
LONDON, March 24 -- Buying of Brazilian rails and utilities and a sharp decline in German potash bonds gave some life to the stock market here today.

An anthology about the West dealing with the histories of ten of its leading cities will be issued Monday by Norton. It is entitled "Rocky Mountain Cities." Edited by Ray B. West, the book contains chapters on Reno, Salt Lake City, Cheyenne, Coeur d'Alene, Butte, Denver, Albuquerque, Sante Fe, Tucson and El Paso. Carey McWilliams has written an introduction.

DUESSELDORF, March 24 -- Disappointment over the forthcoming German border revisions agreed on by six-power experts was expressed today by officials of the British Military Government. The Britons took the position that the frontier rectifications, mainly in favor of Belgium and the Netherlands, would embarrass and inhibit them in their activities in Germany.

WASHINGTON, March 24 (AP) -- February retail sales, after adjustment for seasonal differences, were unchanged from January the Department of Commerce reported today. They were practically the same as in February last year.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- The House Committee on Un-American Activities reported today that spies for Russia had "penetrated right to the very heart of our atomic work" and "made away with some of our atomic secrets."

LONDON, March 24 -- The Soviet Union scored a minor tactical victory today in the four-power negotiations here on an Austrian peace treaty. After six weeks of virtual deadlock over the Yugoslav claims against Austria, the three Western powers agreed to a Soviet suggestion to sidetrack these claims and pass on to other unagreed articles in the treaty draft.

MADRID, March 24 -- Government circles here are said to be greatly disturbed over a pastoral letter by Pedro Cardinal Segura y Saenz, Archbishop of Seville, charging the Spanish Press Directorate with having censored his ecclesiastical statements.

Chicago Sanitary District borrowed yesterday $15,000,000 on callable serial bonds due from 1952 to 1969 at an interest cost of 2.4811 per cent. The bonds were sold at competitive bidding to a banking syndicate headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., and Harriman Ripley Co., Inc., at a bid of 100.209 for 2 1/2s.
Dr. Harold J. Laski, a member of the Executive Committee of the British Labor party, was invited yesterday to speak on April 26 at a Harvard Law School forum.

Three large group shows opening this week are centered on different themes and give the public a view of the broad field of contemporary American art that stretches between the widely separated goal posts of abstraction and academic realism.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- The consumers' price index dropped 1.1 per cent between Jan. 15 and Feb. 15, the fifth consecutive decrease and the largest monthly decrease recorded since the Bureau of Labor Statistics began calculating the index on a monthly basis in late 1940.

CHICAGO, March 24 -- The Borg-Warner Corporation announced today record sales and net earnings in 1948 and disclosed plans to manufacture two new types of automatic transmissions for automobiles. The transmissions, developed by Borg-Warner, will be offered to motor car manufacturers "with prospect of adoption toward the end of the year," said C. S. Davis, president.

The Marine Marlin, the second of six emergency-class passenger transports to be turned over to the Army Transportation Corps for operation to European ports as displaced-persons carriers under the terms of a Presidential directive, arrived here yesterday with 464 passengers from Antwerp, Southampton and Cobh.

There's a possibility that Coaltown will go after the richest stake of the Jamaica race meeting that will open a week from today. Calumet Farm has nominated him -- together with Faultless, Fervent and Free America -- for the $50,000 added Gallant Fox Handicap on Saturday, April 30.
Robert F. Wagner Jr., chairman of the City Planning Commission, told Mayor O'Dwyer yesterday that the city needed $1,317,000,000 more to carry out its five-year public works program.

ALBANY, March 24 -- The Senate and Assembly relaxed from their legislative duties today to help Governor Dewey celebrate his forty-seventh birthday. After a resolution had been approved commemorating the occasion, delegations were appointed in both houses to visit the executive chambers and sing birthday greetings.

The New York City Opera Company opened its spring season with a performance of Verdi's "Aida" last night at the City Center. This work, which was added to the organization's repertoire last fall, received a carefully detailed presentation at this latest hearing and aroused an enthusiastic response from the large audience in attendance.

LAKE SUCCESS, March 24 -- The United Nations Trusteeship Council today rejected a Soviet proposal asking the British administrators of Tanganyika to return to the native inhabitants of the area all lands "alienated" from them and now held by Europeans and other non-indigenous owners.

Dr. Selman A. Waksman, head of the Department of Microbiology at Rutgers University and a student of his, Hubert A. Lechevalier, have discovered a new antibiotic, or germ-fighter, which may prove to be a conqueror of tuberculosis if it survives the tests on experimental animals to which it is now being subjected.

Mrs. Morris de Peyster will give a book tea on April 4 in her home at 1060 Fifth Avenue to mark the opening that day of the twenty-eighth annual New York Book Week of the American Merchant Marine Library Association.

WASHINGTON, March 24 (AP) -- Senator Pat McCarran, Democrat, of Nevada, said today the State Department had decided to "let China go" without any effort to put props under the failing Nationalist Government.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., March 24 -- A report made here today on the current outlook for business and advertising revealed a surprising optimism in the light of recent recession fears. The forecast, containing confidential replies by 128 member companies, highlighted the second day of the Association of National Advertisers' spring meeting at the Homestead Hotel.
WASHINGTON, March 24 (AP) -- Manufacturers and distributors of cosmetics today held a second meeting with Federal Trade Commission officials to establish trade practice rules for the industry.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- The disputed ship transfer project under which all the so-called emergency liners in the displaced persons trade would be turned over to the Army appeared to have collapsed today under the weight of protests from members of Congress, maritime labor unions and the private shipping industry.

Rayon staple output by domestic producers will dwindle to 50 per cent of capacity next month, according to Matthew H. O'Brien, secretary of the Rayon Yarn Producers Group. Filament yarn output, he estimated, will decline to 81 per cent of capacity in April.

Robert Villemain, French middleweight, and Jake La Motta, Bronx veteran, will headline the boxing program tonight at Madison Square Garden, where they will trade punches for twelve rounds, or less. Some 12,000 fight fans are expected to witness the Frenchman's second American appearance.

LONDON, March 24 -- British show business is resisting a parliamentary move to "impose" a new kind of freedom upon it. The theatre world is alarmed by a private bill, to be debated in the House of Commons tomorrow, which would abolish censorship of stage plays.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 24 (AP) -- Sir Laurence Olivier won the Academy Award tonight for the best male acting performance of 1948 for his playing of the title role in "Hamlet," the J. Arthur Rank British production.
Sharp increases in sales and earnings for the twelve months ended on Jan. 31 were reported by Montgomery Ward Co. in its seventy-seventh annual report released yesterday.

Justice Alfred V. Norton in Supreme Court, Brooklyn, reserved decision yesterday on a motion of the nine "deposed" vestrymen of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Holy Trinity, Brooklyn, for a temporary injunction to restrain the Rev. Dr. John Howard Melish, rector of the church, and his supporters from:

LAKE SUCCESS, March 24 -- Romulo Betancourt, former president of Venezuela, said today that he planned to ask the United Nations to take action regarding 2,000 persons who he said were held prisoners by the military junta that seized power in Venezuela last November.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- Sales of securities by underwriting firms slipped $500,000,000 in 1948, compared with 1947, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today. Its survey showed the underwriters handled 265 stock and bond issues totaling $3,000,000,000 last year, against 311 offerings amounting to $3,500,000,000 the year before.

MINEOLA, L. I., March 24 -- Counsel for Raymond M. Fernandez and Mrs. Martha Beck interposed pleas of not guilty by reason of insanity in behalf of his clients at their arraignment in County Court here today on indictments charging them with first degree murder in the death of Mrs. Janet J. Fay of Albany.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- Amid charges of "railroading" by foes of the Administration's labor relations bill, the House Education and Labor Committee today approved the measure without change and sent it to the House.

Running about two weeks behind schedule because of hot controversies now largely disposed of, the New York Legislature hopes to adjourn by the middle of next week. Important legislation remains on the docket, some of it virtually untouched, part of it advanced in one house but not the other, some of it moving toward final action, but in defective form.

Sam Atkins, lower East Side tavern owner, didn't know whether he was coming or going yesterday as he settled his labor union difficulties and served beer at a nickel a glass to an avalanche of customers, four deep at the bar.
The Great Bear Spring Company, to the Gotham Advertising Company. Arthur F. Connolly is account executive.
