Supported chiefly by military orders, the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation and the Consolidated Vultee Corporation bettered in 1948 their operating records of the preceding year, while the United Aircraft Corporation continued its profitable operations, their annual reports disclosed yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 24 -- For the first time since the start of World War II, a freighter of the Italian Line tied up today at San Francisco. Capt. Giovanni Polonio, who was on the run between Italy and the West Coast for several years before the war, was welcomed by officials of the General Steamship Corporation, the line's local agent, on the arrival of his ship, the Tritone.
PARIS, March 24 -- Two secret visits to Paris by high United States officials to discuss Germany have taken place in the last few days.

Evidence that the lungs may act as a check-valve capable of regulating the transfer of blood from the right to the left ventricle of the heart, promising to lead to new understanding of the cause and nature of some forms of heart disease and to improved methods of treatment, was presented yesterday before a gathering of more than 700 alumni of the Cornell University Medical College.

Three days tardy for an arraignment on a grand larceny charge, 42-year-old William Lackie, a plumber, turned up at the Queens County Courthouse, Long Island City, at 7:30 A. M. yesterday with two cents in his pocket. He told a tale of having walked and hitchhiked 130 miles from Athens, N. Y., since 1 P. M. on Tuesday.
New York's multi-million-dollar brewing industry -- and millions of beer drinkers -- face the threat of a strike, the second in five months, sometime after April 1, it became known yesterday.

Public response to the heart-warming invitation of the International Flower Show, which this week transforms Grand Central Palace into a magic place of beauty and of fragrance, has been unusually warm and enthusiastic this year. The reasons are not far to seek.
The Board of Estimate voted yesterday to increase the rents of Woodside Houses by 30 per cent over the $12.50 a room a month originally announced for the 1,357-family project.

CHAPEL HILL, N. C., March 24 -- Bill Heusner, Northwestern's Olympian, sent the twenty-sixth annual National Collegiate Athletic Association swimming championships off to a blazing start tonight with a successful defense of his 1,500-meter free-style title in near-record time.

HALLANDALE, Fla., March 24 (AP) -- Bobby Permane, 25, of Camden, N. J., today suffered a broken leg and possible shoulder fracture when he fell from his mount during the fourth race at Gulfstream Park.

Orchids from London and Belgium, and leis from Hawaii fulfilled the title of the International Flower Show at Grand Central Palace yesterday. Camellias grown on Long Island, roses, carnations, lilies and gardenias also were added to the displays on the third floor.

The Americans for Intellectual Freedom announced yesterday that more than 200 prominent persons have joined them in denouncing the Cultural and Scientific Conference for World Peace as a "Communist front operation" and have pledged their support of the counter-rally to be held tomorrow at Freedom House.

Leo Propper, formerly president of Propper - McCallum Hosiery Company, Inc., has joined the Largman Gray Company of Philadelphia, manufacturer of Blue Moon hosiery, in an executive sales capacity, effective April 1. His New York office will be at 347 Fifth Avenue.

Senator Kenneth S. Wherry of Nebraska said last night that decisions made by Congress in the next two weeks would be the most important, short of war, it has made in its history, but predicted that the Republican-Southern Democratic coalition would defeat "basic issues of New Dealism."

Many of the new trends already reported from Paris were collected and presented by Macy's at a luncheon yesterday at the Plaza Hotel. So keen was the public to see what the "dernier cri" was that not only was the Terrace Room packed, but there was an overflow showing in the Persian Room.

A 10-year-old girl in a pink ruffled dress whose great-great grandfather studied with Franz Liszt made her debut yesterday as a pianist at the twelfth spring festival of the New York City Federation of Women's Clubs at the Astor Hotel.

WASHINGTON, March 24 (UP) -- James Forrestal, retiring Secretary of Defense, told Congress today that his successor, Louis A. Johnson, should have more direct authority over the armed forces in order to make unification work.

ALBANY, March 24 -- The Senate today passed, 45 to 9, a bill urged by Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein to regulate so-called "non-profit" cemeteries operated by membership corporations The nine negative votes were cast by Republicans.

Still alive and breathing, the New York Knickerbockers last night at Madison Square Garden avenged Wednesday night's one-point defeat at Baltimore with a ten-point victory over the title-defending Bullets. With a convincing 84-74 triumph on their home court, Joe Lapchick's lads evened the Series C Eastern Division playoffs in the Basketball Association of America.
WASHINGTON, March 24 -- During the week ended March 23, member bank reserve balances decreased $576,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

The first legal suit of its kind in the New York State will be brought against the Board of Education next week if the education officials refuse to eliminate from the public schools Charles Dickens novel "Oliver Twist" and Shakespeare's play "The Merchant of Venice," it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- Loading of revenue freight for the week ended on March 19 totaled 607,767 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 101,559 cars, or 14.3 per cent, fewer than for the preceding week, 91,826 cars, or 13.1 per cent, fewer than for the corresponding week last year, and 236,274 cars, or 28.0 per cent, fewer than for the corresponding week two years ago.

LONDON, March 24 -- Addressing a meeting held here tonight to honor six Soviet women visitors, Dr. Hewlett John, Dean of Canterbury, called for wide support for a peace congress to be held here in June.

Sales and earnings of the Crane Company and its subsidiaries in 1948 were the largest in its ninety-three-year history, the annual report disclosed yesterday. It was noted, however, that earnings for January of this year declined substantially from that month a year ago, because of inability to offset increases in wages and salaries and to pass more than a small part of increases on to the consumer.

ALBANY, March 24 -- A tentative agreement was reached today at a Republican Senate conference on apportionment of the $40,000,000 in additional state aid for schools carried in the budget. Final agreement was deferred until individual members could ascertain how the compromise would affect their districts.

A group of fifty-five ranch-style houses is planned for two improved tracts in Huntington, L. I., known as Richard Hill and Margaret Hill, which have been sold by the Maric Holding Corporation. The property, comprising fifty-five acres, is at Huntington Bay Road and Cove Road.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- Application of the electrolysis principle in the preservation of ship bottoms may settle the long-standing dispute between the Maritime Commission and the private ship repair industry over the question of who will do the ship preservation job.
Sailors Snug Harbor soon will sublet to New York University almost the entire square block of property north of Washington Square and east of Fifth Avenue, it became known yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 24 -- Formation of the Transit Van Corporation to furnish "both the equipment and the system needed to facilitate shipment and interchangeability of cargo between all forms of transportation" was announced here today.

ELIZABETH, N. J., March 24 -- A Superior Court jury decided here tonight in favor of two elderly sisters who had said they would be literally cut off from the outside world if denied access to a 900-foot dirt road through the property of two neighboring families.
ALBANY, March 24 -- New York State motorists will have only one license plate in 1950 as a result of action taken in both houses of the Legislature today.
FRANKFORT, Germany, March 24 -- German and Western Allied efforts to form a Western German state have reached a crisis.

Erich Eliskases of Austria, last year's victor in the annual chess masters tournament at Mar del Plata, triumphed in the eighth round of the current competition at the South American resort yesterday, according to a report from Argentina.

Industrial executives were urged yesterday to lower their breakeven points as an anti-recession step, and reductions of as much as 30 per cent were envisaged. George T. Trundle, president, Trundle Engineering Company, Cleveland, told more than seventy-five members of the National Fibre Can and Tube Association, at the annual convention at the Astor Hotel, that by this step, plus lower prices and increased inducements "to get customers back," manufacturers could effectively fight recession trends.

ALBANY, March 24 -- In an effort to rescue the Dewey Administration's state-wide building-code bill from probable defeat, its legislative sponsors revised its provisions today to permit municipalities to suspend its operation, in whole or in part in their territories.

Declining for the fourth consecutive week, business loans by banks in this area dropped $73,000,000 last week, to $5,461,000,000 -- the lowest level since Sept. 8 last year -- the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. According to the data, covering the reporting New York City member banks during the week ended on Wednesday, reductions occurred in nearly every individual instance.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- President Truman finished wiping his April travel slate clean today, erasing his April 10 date to lay the cornerstone of the United Nations headquarters, and the April 23 date for a dinner honoring Dr. Chaim Weizmann, both in New York.

BURBANK, Calif., March 24 -- A rookie lefthander named Irving Medlinger and Red Embree, the lean righthander cast off by the Yankees the past winter, combined youth and experience on the mound today to silence the Giant bats, while Zach Taylor's Browns bagged the second game of the exhibition series, 2 to 0.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- The bill authorizing $5,580,000,000 for European recovery in the next fifteen months appeared well on its way through the Senate late today after bipartisan foreign policy spokesmen spiked arguments for cutting the amount as much as $1,000,000,000.
SAIGON, Indo-China, March 24 (UP) -- French Far Eastern Headquarters charged today that Chinese Communists were fighting with Viet-Minh guerrillas against French troops in Indo China.

On the recommendation of the Director of the Budget, Thomas J. Patterson, the Board of Estimate authorized yesterday a $72,713,000 bond issue to be used by the Board of Water Supply as an additional appropriation to defray the cost of various states of construction work on the Delaware water system project.

BOSTON, March 24 (AP) -- Toronto's fourth-place Maple Leafs went two victories up in their four-out-of-seven Stanley Cup hockey semi-finals tonight by again upsetting the second-place Boston Bruins, this time by 3 -- 2, at the Boston Garden.

PARIS, March 24 -- The newspaper Populaire, organ of the Socialist party, which has five Ministers in the Cabinet, severely criticized the Government's handling of the North Atlantic treaty negotiations in a first-page editorial today.

Charles W. Ufford Jr. of Deerfield captured the final of the interscholastic invitation squash racquets tourney at the Racquet and Tennis Club yesterday when he turned back Bart Lachelier of Phillips Exeter by 15 -- 10, 10 -- 15, 15 -- 10, 15 -- 6.

VIENNA, March 24 -- Dr. Karl Gruber, Austria's Foreign Minister, declared today that the conclusion of a state treaty for Austria and the withdrawal of occupation troops would have no strategic significance for either the East or the West.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., March 24 -- Vacation-minded motorists eying the Taconic State Parkway to the north learned today that the twenty-one-mile extension of the parkway in the area east of Poughkeepsie would not be ready for use until late next fall or early winter.

Paul Flaum, in the sixth grade at Public School 106, Parkchester, the Bronx, became a gaucho yesterday -- at least for an hour. Through the Platoon Program of the Museum of Natural History he and hundreds of other public school children imagined they were participating in fiestas and other features of Latin American life as they took part in a four-hour course at the institution.

America will not be an effective stronghold to rally the rest of the world if it fails at home in applying the principles of individual and group freedom it upholds, W. W. Waymack, recently retired member of the United States Atomic Energy Commission, declared last night.

Today's events: Philharmonic-Symphony, Leopold Stokowski, conductor, John Corigliano, violin, Carnegie Hall, 2:30 o'clock; Jascha Heifetz, violin, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; "Aida," City Opera Company, City Center, 8:15; Henriette Michelson, piano, Town Hall, 8:30; Celtic Choral Society, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30; Juilliard Orchestra, conducted by Eleazar De Carvalho, Juilliard School, 8:30.

Steadiness prevailed in early trading of coffee futures on scattered buying by outside interests on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday. Prices eased later in the day on small liquidation. Final prices for contract "D" were 25 to 3 points lower with the spot month the weakest feature.

In the hope that a four-cornered contest for Representative in the Twentieth Congressional District to fill the vacancy caused by the death of Sol Bloom might give a Republican candidate a chance of election, leaders of that party are watching the situation caused by the candidacy of Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. for the Democratic nomination and have begun to discuss possible nominees.

The Springtide Cotillion for debutantes of this season and young women who will be presented to society next winter will be held Monday night in the Crystal Room of the Ritz-Carlton. The fete is under the direction of Miss Bonnie May Murray.

An exhibition of French furniture, rugs, fabrics and accessories that may be seen only by invitation has been set up in the offices of the French magazine, Arts et Industrie, in the Maison Francaise, 610 Fifth Avenue.

KARACHI, Pakistan, March 24 (Reuters) -- The Pakistan Government tonight denied that Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru, Prime Minister of India, was the "Pandit Sahib" mentioned a sinvolved in a recent plot to assassinate the Premier of Pakistan's Northwest Frontier Province, Abdul Qaiyum Khan.

A new product known as "Airex" moth-killer will be backed by "the largest and most concentrated advertising and merchandising campaign ever put behind a mothicide," it was announced yesterday by its manufacturer, the general chemical division, Allied Chemical and Dye Corporation.

Winston Churchill, who exhibited a bland disregard for police security arrangements yesterday when he returned to the city from Washington, was the guest of Henry Luce, publisher of Time, Life and Fortune, at a private dinner for 220 distinguished guests at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel last night.

CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa, March 25 -- The convention of the United Farm Equipment and Metal Workers, CIO, today unanimously rejected what it called "the dictatorial ultimatum" of the CIO executive board directing the union to affiliate with the United Automobile Workers, CIO.
BALTIMORE, March 25 (AP) -- Historic Lexington Market was burned out by a quick fire just before dawn today and Henry H. Hoenes, the superintendent, estimated the loss at about $5,000,000.

The General Steel Products Corporation, of which Thomas Kearns is president, has purchased the former Lane Lifeboat and Davit Corporaton's property at the foot of Fortieth Road and the Flushing River in Flushing, Queens, from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

DUESSELDORF, March 25 -- In one of the shortest sessions on record in Bonn, Western Allied liaison officers advised a committee of seven from the Parliamentary Council this afternoon that the German counter-proposals to the Western military governors' memorandum on the Western German constitution were inacceptable.

Before this week's long battle in the House of Representatives over the Rankin pension bill is forgotten -- and it will not be forgotten long, for Mr. Rankin announced yesterday that he is coming right back with a modified version of his original bill -- we should like to file for future reference the statistics of the vote by which this matter was at least temporarily disposed of.
BOSTON, March 25 -- Trustees of the Peter Bent Brigham Hospital completed negotiations today for the installation of thirty-two "minimal" private room units designed especially for the institution.

Three of the newly-opened one-man shows provide striking diversity in the week's art events. Rolph Scarlett is showing a group of his latest non-objective paintings at the Jacques Seligmann Gallery. Their titles, "Dancing Yellows," "Dynamic Towards Left," etc., give a good idea of their subject matter which has no human or symbolic associations in its spirited working out of line and color relationships.

Indefatigable exhibitors continued to bring new entries to the International Flower Show at Grand Central Palace yesterday. Flower arrangements are the only changes today, but the entire show may be seen from 10:30 A. M. until 9 P. M.

Laurence Olivier and his film "Hamlet," already well weighted with honors, can claim another laurel. Inspired, no doubt, by yesterday's news of those Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences awards, the press agents of Universal - International, distributors of "Hamlet," came up with some statistics to prove that no other "Hamlet" has had as many performances here as the one to be seen on the screen of the Park Avenue.
Of nine games scheduled for the ninth round of the international masters' chess tournament at Mar del Plata yesterday only two were decided, according to a report received from Argentina.
WASHINGTON, March 25 -- The 128th anniversary of Greek independence was memorialized today by President Truman, who extolled the will of the Greek people to work and fight for freedom.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- Lieut. Gen. W. Bedell Smith, Ambassador to Russia during the three critical post-war years, resigned today and is expected soon to assume command of the First Army, with headquarters at Governors Island, New York.

It is a dubious comfort for the woman who has been condemned as a common scold to have the reassurance that she will not receive a dousing in the pond via the ducking stool. It is the designation that rankles, not the punishment.

NEWARK, N. J., March 25 (AP) -- A second cultural and scientific conference for world peace, similar to the one being held at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, is scheduled for Newark next Tuesday with almost the same participants.

Tornadoes and high winds ripped through parts of Texas, Mississippi and Louisiana Thursday night and yesterday, killing at lease seven persons and injuring fifty-four others, the Associated Press reported.

The unexpectedly sharp decline of $15,000,000 in United States purchases in Brazil during January may adversely affect the rate at which payment backlogs due American exporters are cleared up, if the downward trend in United States buying continues this year, Jose Garrido-Torres, director of the Brazilian Government Trade Bureau, warned here yesterday.

New juvenile furnishings now available indicate that designers are beginning to think of children -- and their parents, too -- as people, instead of delicate beings to be surrounded by pastel pinks and blues, which they will soon out-grow.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- Opponents of the North Atlantic treaty kept asking in the Senate today whether the United States would be pledged under the treaty to use armed force against an aggressor in the North Atlantic area.

A coalition of liberal Democrats and progressive Republicans in Congress to offset the combination of Southern Democrats and conservative Republicans was urged last night by Representative Jacob K. Javits. Mr. Javits, a Republican elected with Liberal party support, spoke at a Liberal party forum at 601 Eighth Avenue.

ALBANY, March 25 -- Bertram D. Tallamy, State Superintendent of Public Works, reported to Governor Dewey and the Legislature today that his department let 156 contracts during 1948 for construction and reconstruction of 566 miles of highway.

AINTREE, England, March 25 (AP) -- Some 300,000 persons are expected to watch the 103d Grand National Steeplechase tomorrow over this four-and-one-half-mile "jumper's nightmare" course. Perfect racing weather is forecast.

SEATTLE, March 25 (AP) -- The country's top basketball coaches, numbering 116, met today to consider possible rule changes, but kept a collective optic on the University of Washington Pavilion, where Kentucky and Oklahoma A. and M. were working out for their National Collegiate Athletic Association East-West championship game tomorrow night.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- Senate Democratic leaders abandoned their plan to push through the $5,580,000,000 Marshall Plan authorization bill tonight after three members held the floor for nearly seven hours but expressed confidence the measure would be passed Monday or Tuesday without crippling amendments.
JEFFERSON CITY, Mo., March 25 -- For the first time, the Missouri Basin Inter-Agency Committee struck back publicly today at critics of its plan for development of the vast Missouri River Valley.
WASHINGTON, March 25 (UP) -- Controller General Lindsay C. Warren said today the Government may be losing many thousands of dollars because of an unwise provision in more than 200 housing contracts.

The Venezuelan Department of Commerce has received a recommendation from the Board of National Economy in that country to increase the tariff on rayon goods 150 per cent, according to New York textile exporters.

On the eve of an anti-Communist conference sponsored by Americans for Intellectual Freedom today at Freedom House, 20 West Fortieth Street, Secretary of Labor Maurice J. Tobin applauded yesterday the group's courage "in exposing and opposing anti-democratic doctrines."

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- Bold reorganization in three major fields of governmental activity -- overseas administration, Federal-state aid relationships, and scientific research -- was recommended today in a three-decker report submitted to Congress by the Commission on Organization of the Executive Branch of the Government, headed by former President Herbert Hoover.

Retail sales declined during the week in comparison with the last week of Lent last year. Department store sales were estimated to be about 19 per cent below the corresponding week last year. Sales last week were 18 per cent below a year ago.

Lillian Bass Titlebaum sold the two-story building and extension at 255 Schenectady Avenue, southeast corner of Lincoln Place, Brooklyn, to the 255 Schenectady Avenue Corporation for cash above a purchase money mortgage of $20,000. M. C. O'Brien, Inc., was the broker.
STAMFORD, Conn., March 25 -- Miss Flora Mai Holly, founder of the book and author luncheons, was honored today by prominent personalities of the literary world.

A new reduction of 1 cent a quart in the retail price of milk was heralded yesterday when the Federal-State agency regulating the marketing of milk for this area announced the April farm price for the fluid.

With many of the nation's leading athletes scheduled to see action, the National A. A. U. women's indoor track and field championships will be staged at the 102d Engineers Armory tonight. Defending its team crown will be the contingent from Tuskegee (Ala.) Institute.

For the first time since 1940 some home furnishings stores are preparing to reduce budgets and buying commitments 10 to 15 per cent, it was learned yesterday. The reductions are being made, according to trade sources, because volume is lagging behind last year.

PARIS, March 25 -- The European council for the Marshall Plan adopted today the program of action for the year 1949-50 that had been proposed to it by the Steering Committee of Cabinet Ministers March 8.

PARIS, March 25 (Reuters) -- Saint Nazaire dockers ignored a request from the Canadian Seamen's Union to boycott the Canadian coal-carrying ship Vancouver County because it was manned by a "blackleg crew," Marcel Trouve, local agent for the Acadia Overseas Freighter Limited of Halifax, Nova Scotia, told reporters today.

Relief cargoes weighing more than 54,000 pounds and valued at $37,000 were contributed by various groups and organizations throughout the United States, are on the high seas destined for the Netherlands aboard three Holland-America Line vessels, it was reported here yesterday by United Service to Holland, Inc., 70 Pine Street, shippers of the goods.

Emil K. Ellis, an attorney, protested yesterday the proposed state legislation to curb unauthorized wiretapping on the ground that the Quinn-Steingut bill provided no penalties for indiscriminate wiretapping by public law enforcement agencies.

DES MOINES, March 25 (PA) -- A North Carolina tobacco village of 367 population was announced today as the sweepstakes winner in a nationwide community beautification contest. The Macclesfield, (N. C.) Women's Club, which has thirty-five members, will receive $1,000 as a sweepstakes award and an additional $1,000 as winner in the 10,000 and under population class in the 1947-1948 More Beautiful America contest, sponsored by Better Homes and Gardens magazine.

The opening ceremonies of the Generals Assembly session of the United Nations, at Flushing Meadows on Tuesday, April 5, will be covered by all television stations in a pool telecast from 11 A. M. to 1:30 P. M.
A new Foreign Service Bill is now in preparation at Washington. May I be permitted to speak of a crying omission in the present law which demands correction.

TORONTO, March 25 (Canadian Press) -- John A. Marsh, general manager of the Canadian Exporters Association, said in an address tonight to the Canadian Credit Men's Association that one-half the world, led by Sir Stafford Cripps, has moved back the clock of progress by barter trading or state trading.

LAKE SUCCESS, March 25 (AP) -- The United Nations announced today the nominations of twenty-nine diplomats and journalists for membership on the United Nations Subcommission on Freedom of Information and of the Press.

LONDON, March 25 -- The world's largest-selling daily newspaper, The Daily Mirror, was fined 10,000 ($40,000) today, and Silvester Bolam, its editor, was sent to prison for three months, on charges of gross contempt of court for having published on March 4 sensational details of a murder case awaiting trial.

Profit-taking put an end yesterday to the two-day rally on the New York Stock Exchange, as stock prices sagged fractions to a point or more in slow trading. It was one of the dullest sessions of the month, with sales totaling only 630,000 shares, compared with 920,000 on Thursday.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., March 25 -- The Association of National Advertisers wound up its annual spring meeting here today with pep talks that urged immediate stepping up of ingenuity, risk-taking and hard work to match the faster pace of old fashioned competition.
VERO BEACH, Fla., March 25 -- Don Newcombe, the star Negro righthander, was put on display again today and wound up as the losing pitcher in a 3-0 victory for the Dodgers over the Montreal Royals.

WARSAW, March 25 -- While the Polish Government introduced a new variation into its campaign against the Roman Catholic Church, Archbishop Stefan Wyszynski, Primate of Poland, held a conference today in Cracow with five leading Bishops to deliberate on the course of action that the church should take.

The death of eight Bowery derelicts in twenty-four hours, apparently from wood alcohol poisoning, touched off a wide police investigation yesterday. It was the largest number of fatalities from denatured alcohol in the area since prohibition days.
WASHINGTON, March 25 (AP) -- Jewels, stocks and other personal property of the late Mrs. Eleanor Patterson, publisher of The Washington Times-Herald, were valued today at $2,221,711.47.

MOUNT VERNON, Ohio, March 25 (AP) -- The Cooper-Bessemer Corporation, which sets aside a part of profits annually to buy annuities for employes, has amended the plan to give workers a voice in its administration.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 25 -- Allie Reynolds is ready! The big right-hander proved it today by going seven innings against Eddie Sawyer's Phillies, the longest pitching chore of the training campaign for a Yankee flipper.

With cotton traders waiting on Congress to appropriate funds for the Economic Cooperation Administration before making new commitments, business on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday was rather restricted, and final prices were 3 points lower to 4 points higher than on Thursday.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 25 -- A long and bitter attack, on the United States by Soviet delegate Elizavieta A. Popova was strongly opposed here today by other delegates of the United Nations Commission on the Status of Women. These delegates included Judge Dorothy Kenyon of the United States, who pleaded that the commission be permitted to get on with its work.

New York's Knickerbockers and Baltimore's Bullets, having split the first two games in their Eastern Division Series B in the Basketball Association of America play-offs, will tangle in the rubber contest tonight at Madison Square Garden.
ROME, March 25 -- Foreign Minister Count Carlo Sforza left this morning by train for Paris en route to Washington to sign the treaty. He will proceed from Paris by air for New York Sunday afternoon.

A landlord accused of converting an Upper Manhattan apartment house, originally built for sixty-nine families, into individual dwelling quarters for 1,200 persons, was fined a total of $350 yesterday and received a suspended thirty-day sentence.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 25 -- Poland Banks, novelist and independent producer, today filed suit against RKO Radio Pictures in the California Superior Court for $670,000 damages for alleged breach of contract in connection with the projected filming of Banks' story "Carriage Entrance," for RKO release.

Placard-bearing men and women denounced Soviet Russia and communism outside the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday and last night in a protest against the opening session there of the Cultural and Scientific Conference of World Peace.
The Public Service Commission refused yesterday to rescind the order by which on Jan. 10 it raised the Consolidated Edison Company's gas rates $11,000,000 a year.
CHICAGO, March 25 (AP) -- Federal charges that ninety firms and individuals conspired to fix the price of Amerian cheese were dismissed today.
Fluorescent lighting tubes are coated on the inside with an extremely poisonous material that may be liberated if the glass tubes are shattered, several medical authorities warned yesterday.

ATHENS, March 25 -- For the first time the armed forces of another nation took active part today in the traditional celebration of Greece's Independence Day -- the anniversary of the 1821 proclamation of freedom from the Ottoman Empire -- when 500 marines and bluejackets from the United States Navy's Sixth Task Fleet marched at the head of a column of Greek soldiers, sailors and airmen.

Although installment credit terms have been extended somewhat beyond plans made by most department and furniture stores when Regulation W was revised earlier this month, few are offering the maximum twenty-one months allowed under the law, credit men disclosed here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- Spokesmen for the pubishers of 6,000 small daily and weekly newspapers protested today to a House group that the proposed new postal regulations would make every local postmaster the judge of what constitutes advertising or reading matter in their publications.

Vivian Connell's highly regarded script, "The Nineteenth Hole of Europe," will be presented at the Lenox Hill Playhouse, 331 East Seventieth Street, for matinee and evening performances today and tomorrow. It will be the fourth production of the Invitational Series of the Experimental Theatre, under the auspices of the American National Theatre and Academy.

More eloquent testimony in behalf of the fine safety record of the airlines would be hard to find than the judgment of the life insurance companies. The Institute of Life Insurance reports that travel on the scheduled carriers in the United States is no longer a significant underwriting factor.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 25 -- The united trade unions of Yugoslavia have dispatched a letter to the World Federation of Trade Unions protesting the Prague radio's "defamatory" campaign against the Yugoslav unions and demanding that the world federation intervene to prevent the Czechoslovaks from wrecking "international labor solidarity."
The Cultural and Scientific Conference for World Peace, target of bitter controversy, got under way here last night against a mixed background of dinner oratory and pickets chanting in the rain.

TEL AVIV, Israel, March 25 -- It becomes more apparent each day from outside reports that while Israel might have won a military battle, she stands a chance of losing a political war, observers here believe. Political pressure is being slowly but surely applied against Jews throughout the Arab world and also in Eastern European countries that have prevented them from emigrating.

GREENSBORO, N. C., March 25 (AP) -- Frank Stranahan, the Toledo amateur star, who grabs off a major golf tournament or two each year, took the first-round lead in the $10,000 Greensboro open today with a five-under par 34, 32 -- 66.

Michael De Capite has received the $1,000 prize of the Friends of American Writers for his novel, "The Bennett Place." Mr. De Capite, author of two previous novels, is in India on an assignment with the United Nations Commission for India and Pakistan.

QUEBEC, March 25 (Canadian Press) -- Premier Maurice Duplessis of Quebec announced today at a press conference that "important new discoveries of high-grade iron ore have been made in Northeastern Quebec." These deposits, he said, are "miles and miles" from the area in Ungava where iron-ore development is in progress.

The vicious circle of difficulties that has handicapped the proper development of our Alaskan defenses since the war may be broken this summer if present plans and programs are pressed vigorously and receive full support from Washington.

PHILADELPHIA, March 25 -- Foreign missions should concentrate their work in rural areas rather than in the cities as at present, church leaders were told today at the Agricultural Missions Conference sponsored by more than twenty Protestant denominations.

LONDON, March 25 -- A Foreign Office spokesman said today that if press reports of a speech made in Switzerland by Dr. Konrad Adenauer, President of the Parliamentary Assembly in Bonn, were accurate, "it is something to be deprecated and portends ill for the future of German democracy."

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- Average primary market prices declined 0.2 per cent in the week ended March 22, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The index stood at 158.2 per cent of the 1926 average, 0.2 per cent lower than four weeks ago and 2.6 per cent less than the comparable week in 1948.

Just glancing at the problem in a casual manner, it would seem that a simple listing covering the opening dates of the varied and assorted trout seasons in New York would require a minimum of effort and planning, but those who have tried to puzzle out the complicated statement of the State Conservation Department realize that simplicity has been lost in the shuffle.

Jake La Motta was the most surprised person in Madison Square Garden last night when he heard himself declared the winner of his twelve-round feature bout with Robert Villemain of France. Everybody else was surprised, too, but none so much as the Bronx warrior who, on the receiving end of Villemain's punches almost all through the battle, presented the picture of a badly beaten warrior when it was all over.

Net income of the Southern Railway Company in 1948 amounted to $19,248,065, equal to $12.51 a common share, compared with $11,892,761, or $6.85 a share, in 1947, Ernest E. Norris, president, reported in the annual statement issued yesterday. Fixed charges, he said were covered 2.51 times last year, compared with 1.93 times the year before.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- Production workers in manufacturing plants earned an average of $54.25 a week in February, according to preliminary estimates made available today by the Bureau of Labor Statistics. These earnings are virtually unchanged from the levels reached last fall.

Within several hours the police solved a grotesque murder mystery yesterday but the solution came as an anticlimax. The man to whom all signs pointed unmistakably as the slayer lay beyond arrest in a mortuary chapel.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., March 25 -- Three hundred and fifty men and women students from colleges and universities throughout New York State arrived here on the Vassar campus today to participate in the three-day spring conference of the Student Christian Movement of New York State.

LOS ANGELES, March 25 -- As the Giants tonight moved into the closing days of this phase of their spring training by engaging the Pirates under the lights at Hollywood ball park, it became patent that Manager Leo Durocher is beginning to give serious thought to one of the really big problems.

LONDON, March 25 -- The House of Commons, by 76 votes to 37, gave a second reading today to a private member's bill to abolish censorship of stage plays. According to Parliamentary procedure, the bill now goes to committee for revision and then comes back to the House for its third and final reading.
So many Yorkville shopkeepers have gone into gray marketing Deutsche marks that the commission dropped yesterday in most of the district's outlets from half to a quarter of a point.

The Women's Swimming Association first team of Jean Piser, Betty Mullen, Barbara Daggett and Marie Corridon retained the senior metropolitan 400-yard free-style relay championship in a meet at the W. S. A. pool in London Terrace last night.

In pleading before a Senate committee for a broadening of the powers of his office, as embodied in the bill introduced by Senator Tydings, Defense Secretary Forrestal was not asking for these powers for himself but for his successor, Louis A. Johnson, who will take over the office on April 1.
GENEVA, March 25 (AP) -- Czechoslovakia has filed a formal charge that the United States' export licensing system constitutes a violation of the Geneva tariff agreement of 1947.

New York will play host next week to more than four thousand of the nation's leading physicians, who will be attending the thirtieth annual session of the American College of Physicians. During the five-day session these specialists in internal medicine will hear papers on recent advances in medical and clinical science, attend panel discussions and teaching sessions, and visit some twenty clinics held in local hospitals.
Boston, Mass., announced yesterday that it would receive bids Tuesday on $5,000,000 of temporary loan notes dated April 1 and due Nov. 3.

The Corcoran Gallery of Art in Washington, D. C., will open this evening with a preview reception its twenty-first biennial exhibition of contemporary American oil painting. It is somewhat smaller than its predecessors, with 187 paintings as against 313 in the 1947 exhibition.

The problems, needs and interests of adolescents are being subordinated to "textbook teaching," Prof. Harold Alberty of Ohio State University charged last night to 450 principals, administrators and teachers in Judson Memorial Auditorium, 55 Washington Square South.

The tone of the Cultural and Scientific Conference for World Peace was set yesterday morning, at a mass press interview of foreign delegates, with warnings that new "military blocs" and scientific weapons were bringing the world toward the brink of war.

A net profit of $17,907,659 was reported yesterday in the 1948 annual statement of the Ingersoll-Rand Company, equal to $8.84 a common share. In 1947 the net profit was $16,287,709, or $8.03 a common share.
The belt that spans the whittled waist takes many shapes and forms in the "Look" of 1949, according to reports from shops about town.

Earnings of Loew's, Inc., for the sixteen weeks beginning Nov. 26, last, are estimated at around 60 cents a share, compared with 49 cents a share for the sixteen weeks ended on March 11, 1948, J. Robert Rubin, vice president, informed shareholders at the annual meeting yesterday.

A method for measuring dimensions of chemical substances one hundred-millionth of a centimeter thick with a precision within one billionth of a centimeter was described yesterday at a meeting of the physics and chemistry section of the New York Academy of Sciences at the American Museum of Natural History.

The Lester Foundation has sold the Pyro Plastic Building at 526-32 North Avenue East, Westfield, N. J., to the North West Realty Corporation, a holding company for the Lawrence Manufacturing Company, maker of trophies, plaques and advertising novelties.
Federal Judge Harold R. Medina asked for a glossary to explain international Communist language at the trial of the eleven Communists yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- The plan for a prestige ship, a super-liner capable of winning speed laurels on the Atlantic, may be completed within a week under a formula worked out in the Maritime Commission, it became known today.

WASHINGTON, March 25 (AP) -- Representative Wright Patman, Democrat, of Texas, proposed today an investigation to determine whether corporations have held back illegally about $15,000,000,000 that should have been paid to stockholders in the last three years.

The Government impounded yesterday 133 "Roll-A-Ray Heat Massage Machines" at the warehouse of Ludwig Baumann, 45 Pearson Street, Long Island City, Queens, on the ground that printed instructions accompanying the device were "false and misleading" and in violation of the Federal Food, Drug and Cosmetic Act.

Today's events: Rudolf Serkin, piano, Carnegie Hall, 3 P. M.; Music for Children, Brooklyn Museum Symphony Orchestra, conducted by David Le Vita, at the museum, 2; Philharmonic-Symphony, Leopold Stokowski, conductor, Carnegie Hall, 8:45; College of St. Elizabeth Glee Club Town Hall, 8:30.

PITTSBURGH, March 25 -- The American Bar Associations nonpartisan plan for election of judges drew high praise here today from James M. Douglas, Chief Justice of the Missouri Supreme Court. Justice Douglas spoke at the Middle Atlantic Region Conference on Legal Education.

ALBANY, March 25 -- Employment opportunities for members of minority racial and religious groups were further widened during the last year as a result of the efforts of the State Commission Against Discrimination, according to the commission's annual report filed today with Governor Dewey and the Legislature.

LAKE SUCCESS, March 25 -- The United Nations is stepping up its program of inquiry into a global project of economic and technical help to the backward countries of the world. Secretary General Trygve Lie announced today at his weekly press conference.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- The National Labor Relations Board opened the door today to a possible victory by the Progressive Mine Workers of America, rival of the United Mine Workers of America, in an election for bargaining representatives.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- President Truman asked Congress today to establish a commission to supervise the reconstruction of the White House to insure that its historic and architectural features are preserved.

The pledge of cooperation yesterday between Regents and Trustees to press forward with development of the State University will be welcomed and applauded by all in the state who are interested in education. The Regents recognize that "a practical working relationship between the two boards must be established."

ALBANY, March 24 -- State Adjutant General Ames T. Brown said today a revised ruling of the United States Controller General has made eligible for non-disability retirement pay hundreds of former members of the New York National Guard and Naval Militia. They involve veterans who have completed at least twenty years of satisfactory service and are 60 or older.

Lieut. Gen. Walter Bedell Smith has succeeded at last in persuading the President to accept his resignation as Ambassador to Soviet Russia. The resignation was based on General Smith's desire to return to the United States, and to active duty with the Army, after seven years abroad on various assignments, of which three were spent on this difficult job in Moscow.

VIENNA, March 25 -- A Communist effort to stir a movement among the so-called Volksdeutsche from Rumania now in Austria to return to Rumania was disclosed yesterday by Dr. Fritz Buresch, who said that his work was supported by the Rumanian Legation here.
DENVER, March 25 (AP) -- The St. Francis Terriers from Brooklyn reached the final of the National Catholic Basketball Tournament tonight with a 69-40 victory over St. Benedict's of Atchison, Kan.

The excellent editorial in THE TIMES of March 18 entitled "Building Service Wages" leaves out of account one important factor in the development of the present situation that should be called to public attention.

ST. NICKOLAS, Belgium, March 21 -- The factory of Max Meert here in the heart of Flanders, whose artisans founded the modern textile industry six centuries ago, is working at only half capacity. Fifty miles away, on the other side of Brussels, Paul Jacobs' smaller, less modern establishment has more work than there are workers to perform.

Financing transactions scheduled for next week will bring an issue of new industrial bonds to the public market, the second such appearance in recent weeks. The issue will consist of $12,000,000 of first mortgage collateral trust obligations of the Colorado Fuel and Iron Company to be marketed on Tuesday or Wednesday by Allen Co.

CHAPEL HILL, N. C., March 25 -- A titanic 200-yard breast-stroke duel in which Purdue's Keith Carter dethroned the mighty Joe Verdeur of La Salle, and meet records by Bill Smith of Ohio State in the 220-yard freestyle and Yale's 400-yard relay quartet marked the first full session of the twenty-sixth National Collegiate Athletic Association swimming championships tonight.

WASHINGTON, March 25 (AP) -- A bill to "prohibit the use of Panamanian and Honduran vessels or other vessels being operated under 'runaway' flags for transportation of Economic Cooperation Administration commodities" was introduced today by Senator Warren G. Magnuson, Democrat, of Washington.

Spokesmen for the forthcoming Cultural and Scientific Conference for World Peace claim that its objects include the re-establishment of cultural relations between the United States and the U.S.S.R. In this respect it is relevant to recall such items as the following:

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- Fleet Admiral William D. Leahy, the only man ever to serve as Chief of Staff to the President, stepped out of that unique position with ceremony today, and President Truman said he would not name a successor.

ALBANY, March 25 -- With unanimous approval, the Assembly sent to the Governor today the Desmond parking bill designed to ease the parking problem of cities. The bill would authorize the use of the condemnation power of cities to acquire sites for the private development of public parking garages and parking lots.

Lieut. Gen. W. Bedell Smith, retiring United States Ambassador to the Soviet Union, will make his first speech since his return from Moscow at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel on April 9 as part of an observance of Army Week, it was announced yesterday.

Announcement of an increase in specified truck tolls on the Bronx Whitestone and Triborough Bridge aroused emphatic protests yesterday from the New York State Motor Truck Association and the Bronx Chamber of Commerce. Both organizations termed the ruling unwarranted and adopted without due consideration of rights of truck operators.
The national outdoor tennis champion and the national indoor titleholder will meet for the indoor crown today at the Seventh Regiment Armory on Park Avenue.

NEW DELHI, India, March 25 -- India will raise her voice again in international councils on behalf of the Republic of Indonesia as a result of the United Nations Security Council's revised formula in the case as proposed by Canada, a spokesman for the Indian External Affairs Ministry indicated today.

President Eisenhower's announcement that Kenneth D. Johnson has been named Dean of the New York School of Social Work -- a graduate school of Columbia University -- is welcome news. Professionally trained social workers are being challenged as never before to apply their skills in new areas of human relations and community organization.
WASHINGTON, March 25 (UP) -- President Truman's Fair Employment Board today set up machinery to prevent job discrimination against Negroes, Jews and other minority groups in the Federal Government.

LONDON, March 25 -- The Lancashire textile industry made plans today to maintain exports to Canada following the Canadian decision to end after July 1 special tariff concessions on British cotton and rayon piece goods.

Domestic sugar futures on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange continued strong yesterday. New high prices were established in the July and September delivery months. Firmness in the raw market aided futures prices. At the close, the market was 2 to 5 points higher.

There is no shock of surprise in the City Planning Commission's announcement that $2,096,000,000 will be needed in the next five years for New York City's capital improvements and that only $500,000,000 is available in the way of funds under present debt limitations.

WEST POINT, N. Y., March 25 -- The National Collegiate Athletic Association's fifth annual fencing championships, an enlarged version of the Eastern intercollegiate tourney which was held at City College last week, started its two-day stand at the United States Military Academy today.

ROME, March 25 -- Communist Leader Palmiro Togliatti today accused Defense Minister Randolfo Pacciardi of having issued figures on the strength of the Italian Communist party based on inaccurate intelligence reports. He said the number of Communists who had renewed their party cards on Feb. 28 was 1,896,634.

LONDON, March 25 -- Britain will extend her list of exports banned to Iron Curtain countries and an announcement to this effect is expected early next week. Both at the Foreign Office and at the Board of Trade it was said that this country was fully aware of the desirability of preventing goods of potential military value from reaching the Soviet Union or its satellites.
A tentative plan for music on Staten Island ferries developed yesterday into the makings of a libretto with Gilbert and Sullivan touches. As of last night the project was all words and no music.

Verdi's "La Traviata" was the second offering of the New York City Opera Company's spring season, last night at the City Center. It has been several months since the company last played it, a fact which probably accounts for the awkward pauses on stage, the singers' searching glances at the conductor, a few false entrances and the breathless tempo of act I.

The twenty-fourth Eastern States contract bridge tournament at the Park Sheraton Hotel entered its closing stages last night, with players competing in the one-session individual championship -- the last event on the ten-day program.

WASHINGTON, March 25. (AP) -- Mildred E. (Axis Sally) Gillars was sentenced today to serve ten to thirty years in prison for broadcasting Nazi propaganda during World War II. She also was fined $10,000.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- James Forrestal, Secretary of Defense, ordered today further consolidation of the armed forces' medical services in a move expected to result in both better treatment of certain diseases and in the use of critically-short medical personnel.
TOKYO, March 13 -- The Conservative Government of Premier Shigeru Yoshida has about decided to permit the official reopening of Tokyo's black market restaurants.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- Tracerlab, Inc., Boston, a company operating in "the field of nuclear physics and tracer chemistry," filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering 104,000 shares of $1 par value common stock that are to be offered publicly.

DETROIT, March 25 -- Detroit's erratic production week, snagged by lay-offs, slowdowns and strikes, was further complicated by an announcement by the Burroughs Adding Machine Company that, effective April 1, it would furlough indefinitely 1,500 employes.
CLEVELAND, March 25 (AP) -- Ships of the Great Lakes fleet shoved off today for the upper Lakes and their first cargoes of iron ore of the season.

Municipal Court Justice Benjamin Shalleck was reported yesterday to be the first choice of the dominant group in Tammany for the Democratic nomination for Representative in the Twentieth Congressional District to fill the vacancy caused by the death of Sol Bloom.

ALBANY, March 25 -- The Assembly approved unanimously today a bill to tighten the licensing requirements of unincorporated maternity hospitals with a view of curbing "black market" transactions in babies.

FRANKFORT, Germany, March 25 -- Two patterns of political opportunism are beginning to emerge in Western Germany among politicians and industrialists, according to Western Allied officials here and in Bonn.
The Sanitation Department is preparing a program for a thorough five-borough spring cleaning job, with the dates tentatively set for May 2 to 14, it was learned yesterday.

LONDON, March 25 -- Business in the stock markets here today dwindled to a low level before small week-end interest centering on British Government bonds, gold-mining shares and Brazilian railway issues.

WASHINGTON, March 24 (AP) -- Two examiners for the Interstate Commerce Commission recommended today that the Gulf, Mobile Ohio Railroad Company be permitted to absorb the Kansas City, St. Louis Chicago Railroad.

If the head chef of a fine New York restaurant invaded your kitchen, what sort of dinner would he plan, what kind of dishes would he create? Probably there are as many answers as there are chefs. Like other artists, their efforts are highly individual; what one would do, another would not.

The marine industry can solve its own safety problems without any further Government regulation, control and administration, according to Capt. Edward C. Holden Jr., USNR, an official of the United States P. and I. Agency, Inc.
ALBANY, March 25 -- Two important educational controversies that raised key issues at the session of the Legislature appeared to have been settled tonight.

The Port of New York hummed with activity yesterday as almost 5,000 passengers arrived or sailed on twelve liners and an additional 2,135 persons boarded the Cunarder Queen Elizabeth, which was scheduled to sail early today.
WASHINGTON, March 25 -- The railroads of the country today, for a second time, raised their request before the Interstate Commerce Commission for increased railway mail pay.
LAURENS, N. Y., March 25 (AP) -- Laurens Central School was closed today because of widespread illness among its students.
SANTIAGO, Chile, March 25 (UP) -- United States and Chilean steel interests signed a far-reaching deal today assuring the development of the Chilean steel industry.
ALBANY, March 25 -- Governor Dewey signed today the Wise-Morgan bill making the State Workmen's Compensation Insurance Fund subject to a 2 per cent tax on premiums.
Mayor O'Dwyer intervened yesterday in the gathering dispute between taxi drivers and taxi owners, calling both sides to City Hall conferences on Monday.

WASHINGTON, March 25 (AP) -- Industrial production, sliding off with employment, prices and living costs, declined in February for the third consecutive month and probably will go lower again in March.

LONDON, March 25 (AP) -- A British baroness, Julia Lady Lyveden, who gave up a fortune and a brilliant social career in her widowed youth to become a nun, has died in a convent in York. The cause and date of her death were not disclosed.

Since hostesses have found that home television sets are a medium of entertainment in more ways than one, new accessories have been designed to help make easier the chairside serving of refreshments. Many of the new gadgets are made of non-breakable plastics, on the ground perhaps that someone in the crowd is apt to follow the motions of a prizefight too intently.

LAKE SUCCESS, March 25 -- The application of Israel for membership in the United Nations, approved by the Security Council on March 4, will be expedited for final action by the General Assembly during its meeting at Flushing Meadow beginning April 5, it was announced here today by Secretary General Trygve Lie.

The Afghanistan Embassy distributed copies here yesterday of a communique issued by the Afghan Ministry of Foreign Affairs in Kabul, Afghanistan, regarding alleged bombardment by the Pakistan Air Force of the independent territory of the Pashtuns (Pathans), lying northwest of Pakistan.

ALBANY, March 25 -- Expansion this year of the state's program for the treatment of cerebral palsy was urged today in a report submitted to Governor Dewey and the Legislature by the Joint Committee to Study the Problem of Cerebral Palsy.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- A modified veterans' pension bill designed to replace the one shelved by a 208-to-207 vote of the House yesterday was introduced today by Representative John E. Rankin, Democrat, of Mississippi, sponsor of the original measure and chairman of the Committee on Veterans Affairs.

HALLANDALE, Fla., March 25 (AP) -- Jockey William McKinley Cook shoved the horses themselves out of the spotlight at Gulfstream Park today -- by the simple process of shoving more of them first past the wire than any rival rider at the meeting.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- Senate and House managers agreed tonight to recommend to Congress that continued rent controls be put on a "home rule" basis, with the Governors of the states being the arbiters.

Positive action by individual communities is the only way to safeguard the health of 40,000,000 Americans now living in areas without adequate public health service, Basil O'Connor, president of the American National Red Cross and the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis, said yesterday at the twenty-ninth annual meeting of the National Health Council.
COPENHAGEN, Denmark, March 25 -- Denmark formally accepted today an invitation to adhere to the North Atlantic treaty. Parliament gave final authorization for the step.

Clergymen and laymen of Greater New York will hear the Rev. Dr. Erwin L. Shaver, director of week-day religious education of the International Council of Religious Education, on "Legal Aspects of Released Time Classes," at 1:15 P. M. Thursday at the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Holy Nativity, 204th Street and Bainbridge Avenue, the Bronx.
LONDON, March 25 (UP) -- Margaret Truman may make a concert tour of Britain next year, Harold Fielding, British impresario, said today.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- Winston Churchill and Gen. George C. Marshall, two great figures of World War II, spent an hour in closed conference at the British Embassy today. In view of the troubled world situation, the meeting aroused curiosity and speculation, but what the former British Prime Minister and the former Chief of Staff of the United States Army discussed was not disclosed.

Before the main feature of the Cultural and Scientific Conference for World Peace went on last night at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel an unscheduled prelude was acted out in one of the hotel rooms between the toastmaster and an educator who wished to be included among the speakers at the dinner.

CHICAGO, March 25 -- Grain markets closed at the top of the Board of Trade here today on general buying. An advance of 1 1/2 cents a bushel in Government bids for cash wheat in the Southwest compared with early yesterday and of 1 to 1 1/2 cents in bids for corn furnished the background for the buying, which lifted the markets quickly.

OCEAN GROVE, N. J., March 25 -- As this sea shore community, founded in 1869 as a seasonal camp meeting site, looks to the celebration of its eightieth anniversary this summer, it still adheres strongly to its ancient blue laws that make it unique in towns in the nation.

Henriette Michelson gave her farewell recital last night at Town Hall. The pianist, whose career as a teacher at the Institute of Musical Art and later at the Juilliard School of Music covered a period of more than forty years, plans to make Israel her home, and her appearance yesterday evening was her last here before her departure next month for Jerusalem, where she will continue her musical activities.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 25 -- The United Nations Conciliation Commission disclosed that it had asked the Arab states to submit memoranda by next week containing their suggestions for handling the refugee problem.
The North Atlantic Security Pact will make the United Nations organization not less, but more necessary, Norman J. O. Makin, Australian Ambassador to the United States, declared here last night.

The one-story taxpayer building containing five stores at 178 West 171st Street, the Bronx, has been purchased by Abraham Wishengrad from the Acva Realty Corporation, of which Fred Hardy is president. Sale was for cash above mortgages of $13,467.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 25 -- The reaction here today to last night's Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences awards was one of surprise coupled with a self-conscious awareness of fair play done, because the lion's share of the "Oscars" went to the British.

New orders booked by furniture manufacturers during February were down 22 per cent, compared with the previous month and 23 per cent compared with the like month last year, according to the monthly report issued yesterday by Seidman Seidman, accountants for many leading factories.
FRANKFORT, Germany, March 25 (AP) -- Gen. Lucius D. Clay commuted to life imprisonment today the death sentence of a second German defendant in the Malmedy massacre trials.

The Revercomb Displaced Persons Act was branded yesterday as "unworkable and unashamedly discriminatory" by Representative Emanuel Celler, New York Democrat, speaking at the nineteenth annual conference of the National Council on Naturalization and Citizenship at the Astor Hotel.

NANKING, March 25 -- Peiping became, in effect, the capital of Communist China today as Communist leader Mao Tze-tung, his secretariat, and the party's Central Committee shifted their headquarters from Shihkiachwang to the ancient cultural capital. It was a new milestone in the career of 55-year-old Mr. Mao, who was once an obscure assistant librarian at Peking University.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- A 6 per cent payroll tax would be required to put the present social security insurance system on a self-sufficient basis and finance improvements sought by President Truman, the House Ways and Means Committee was told today.

HERE is another good horse story by the author of "The Horse Called Pete." It is not so poignant as that first book, nor so succinctly written, but 7-to-11-year-old girls will share Nancy's experiences with pleasure and ready understanding.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- It is now up to the stockholders. As fine a team of efficiency experts as money could buy, all serving without pay, is about to complete the case for putting the biggest business on earth on a business basis.

PLENACOLOR, a fast new color film from which enlarged prints are made on Ansco Color paper, is announced by Ansco. The new material is available in 120 and 620 size film for use in simple box cameras and in adjustable cameras at 1/50th of a second at f/1l in bright sunlight.

The conspiracy trial of eleven Communist leaders is being held in Courtroom No. 1, the largest in the Federal Court House in New York City. It is a high-ceilinged room, walled in walnut and black marble. On the bench is Judge Harold R. Medina, 61.

A funeral service was held yesterday at 2 P. M. for Jose Del Pino, Spanish language tutor who committed suicide early Thursday morning after strangling Mrs. Helen Reinberg in her apartment at 277 Park Avenue.

SUN VALLEY, Idaho, March 26 (AP) -- Henri Oreiller, blond captain of the touring French National ski team, ran the Olympic course on Baldy Mountain in 2:54 today to win the downhill in the Harriman Cup races.

ROME, March 26 -- The police today arrested a young man named Antonio Grillo who had written to Communist Deputy Luigi Longo yesterday volunteering to assassinate Premier Alcide de Gasperi as a means of keeping Italy out of the North Atlantic treaty. The youth said he had merely sought to attract the attention of the Communist party in order to induce it to relieve his poverty.

WHEN I landed last August I knew no more about the United States than any other well-meaning and ignorant Englishman. After only two or three days I had formed certain very clear views and impressions, and since I made a note of them at the time I can recall that momentary lucidity.

A member of the class of wonder drugs previously derived only from living molds has been produced artificially on a practical scale for the first time in history, it was announced yesterday by Parke, Davis Co. of Detroit.

ATLANTA, March 26 -- Sales tax proposals were under discussion in three Southeastern states this week as means were sought to pay for expanded education, health, welfare and other Governmental services.
When Fleet Admiral William D. Leahy stepped out of his post as Chief of Staff to the President on Friday, President Truman told reporters that the Admiral's place would not for the present be filled.

PARIS, March 26 -- The French and Italian Foreign Ministers, Robert Schuman and Count Carlo Sforza, today signed a treaty that prepares the way for a customs union between the two countries within one year's time and calls for an economic union in six years.

TOURNAMENT play between two teams of four is strategically identical with rubber bridge in most respects. You press hard for games, bidding the game even when you have slightly less than an even chance to make it. You don't risk your contract for overtricks, and you avoid doubtful overcalls that might get doubled.

THESE are Victorian sisters of whom Miss Meredith, author of "The Rich Woman," tells us. They are the daughters of a country clergyman of the nineteenth century, and their lives are presented in retrospect. We meet Janet, the hardier of the two, when she is 80-odd and has just buried the frailer Cassie.

It was a great satisfaction to read "Blueprint for the Backward Areas" by Willard R. Espy. Mr. Espy emphasizes the vital concept of helping people to help themselves, and the importance of adjusting such assistance to simple but basic needs.

IN the words of the preface of his new book, Professor Northrop's aim is to give "attention to the methods suggested by the contemporary social sciences and the philosophy of culture for the removal of obstacles" to world order.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- For perhaps the first time, President Truman's friends and foes found themselves this week in substantial agreement on the important proposition that the best place to be President of the United States is in Washington.

Prevention of tax avoidance has sometimes caused our Federal tax authorities and the courts not only to reject what would otherwise be accepted as good accounting practice, but also to deliberately choose inconsistent rules.
Premium lists have just been issued for an unobtrusive dog show that attracts a tremendous entry. It is the tenth annual event of the Kennel Club of Northern New Jersey at Teaneck on April 10.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. -- Since the winter just ended was one of the warmest on record, the Chambers of Commerce and the resort hotel operators of Florida's west coast cannot promise much of a change in the climate for the April-May spring season. Daytime temperatures will range for the next two months between 70 and 85 degrees, while nights should be crisply comfortable in the high fifties and sixties.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -President Truman denounced the Eightieth Congress from one end of the country to the other in his campaign last year as "the second worst Congress" in history, and he took particular pains to blast it for its subservience to lobbies.

More than 2,500 invitations have been issued by the New York City Mission Society for a ceremony next Thursday evening honoring Mrs. Alberta T. Kline, director of its Harlem unit, it was announced yesterday. Planned to celebrate the twenty-five year service record of Mrs. Kline in society activities, the celebration will be held at the Mother A. M. E. African Methodist Episcopal Zion Church, 140 West 137th Street.

ZOLA ROSS writes with keen enthusiasm of the roaring days of Nevada's Virginia City when the Comstock Lode was a world wonder. The throb of the mine machinery blends with the rumble of town life, with its boom-town cast of characters from the new millionaires to the flashy hussies of D Street. Beautiful Rene Courtelot is the usual heroine for this melange of history and romance.

CINCINNATI, March 26 -- Institutions such as the Hebrew Union College are failing to receive adequate financial support because many American Jewish leaders insist that the task of foreign relief be completed first, Dr. Joseph L. Fink, Rabbi of Temple Beth Zion of Buffalo, said here today at Founder's Day exercises at the Hebrew Union College.

WITH the opening of the coaxial network cable last January, one of the Midwestern shows to come eastward was "Kukla, Fran and Ollie" (7 P. M. Monday through Friday over NBC video). Though its local arrival was greeted with more enthusiasm than was accorded any of the other Chicago attractions, its welcome none the less was on the conservative side.

PEEKSKILL, N. Y., March 26 -Seventy-five years as a member of the First Methodist Church will be observed soon by Charles A. Clark, 87-year-old retired postal employe who every Sunday is in his regular pew in the same edifice where he took the Christian vows three quarters of a century ago.

Dense fog yesterday disrupted transportation schedules here and warm, humid weather that the Weather Bureau predicted would last for the week-end, sent the mercury up to 64 degrees at 4:30 P. M., 13 degrees above normal.

BELGRADE, March 26 -- Borba and Politika, the most important newspapers in this country, today published a series of disclosures and accusations that removed all doubt as to the serious and perhaps even potentially dangerous situation that exists between Yugoslavia on the one hand and Bulgaria and Albania, spearheads of the Communist Information Bureau, on the other.

One patrolman was killed and two were wounded shortly before last midnight in a running pistol battle with two bandits fleeing after a hold-up in a Queens liquor store. The shooting took place on Broadway near Forty-seventh Street, Astoria.

BERLIN, March 26 -- After eight months of blockade, the division of Berlin is almost complete. This is now two cities rather than one, and more like two cities straddling an international border than neighboring communities of one country.

Two hundred and ten teachers and college students will go abroad this summer to study the implications of the Atlantic Pact and observe political and economic conditions in Western Europe, it became known yesterday.

SINCE my review of Graham Greene in the Feb. 13 issue, it has been brought to my attention that readers have raised the question of the distinction Greene makes between his "novels" and his "entertainments." The novels are serious treatments of Christian moral and theological themes.

IF we remember rightly, the death knell of the "B" picture has been sounded more than once during the last half-dozen years. Still drawing upon memory, we seem to recall that Warner Brothers and Twentieth Century-Fox, at least, formally renounced this type of program film during the war years when pictures enjoyed exceptionally long runs at theatres and, as a consequence, production schedules were scaled down.

NOT since the invention of the turnstile has there been such violent spinning and twirling in sports as there is these days. The revolving, however, is not that of cash customers. It is the new whirling-dervish routine which television has made fashionable among sports promoters.

On May 15, 1929, the worst medical disaster in the nation's history occurred when nitrate X-ray film in the cellar of the Cleveland (Ohio) Clinic ignited by spontaneous combustion. The film was in storage vaults in a small brick-lined room near the clinic's furnace.

Attacks on American foreign policy, warnings that the nation was in the grip of a war hysteria and pleas for a better understanding with the Soviet Union highlighted yesterday morning's "keynote session" of the Cultural and Scientific Conference for World Peace in Carnegie Hall.

MR. BUCHANAN has condensed, in one thin volume, history of political parties in the United States. A good deal more than half of the pages are devoted to pictures, cartoons, campaign posters and drawings, to furnish "a pictorial history of the American two-party system."

AS the "handicapped" GI in that fine post-war film "The Best Years of Our Lives," Ex-Sgt. Harold Russell is not casting himself in a hero's mold. The autobiography of the erstwhile paratrooper, who lost his hands when a faulty explosive went off accidentally, is rather an appeal for understanding of the plight of amputees and of the work of those who gave him helping hands.

GREENSBORO, N. C., March 26 (AP) -- Frank Stranahan, Toledo amateur, shot a 2-under-par 69 today to cling to his one-stroke lead with 135 for thirty-six holes of the $10,000 Greenboro open golf tournament.

Norway, dependent on sea commerce for a large share of her economy, has rebuilt her war-depleted merchant marine to within 200,000 gross registered tons of pre-war strength according to a survey of the country's fleet made public yesterday.

The turmoil caused by the Cultural and Scientific Conference for World Peace is all to the good. It brings out into the open alike the excellences and deficiencies of those who approve the conference and would cooperate with it and those who regard it as a propaganda device for red totalitarianism.

Leading intellectuals, liberals and members of the artistic world gathered yesterday under the auspices of Americans for Intellectual Freedom at Freedom House, 20 West Fortieth Street, in an afternoon of speechmaking aimed as a counter-blow to the "Communist-controlled" Cultural and Scientific Conference for World Peace at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Ready for the opening of New York's 196-day racing season next Friday are (1) precisely 225,000,000 daily double tickets, tucked away in three newly purchased safes, and (2) nearly all of the 1,005 horses now stabled at the Jamaica, Belmont Park and Aqueduct tracks.

I WRITE in reply to George Durst's letter which appeared on your page on March 20. Mr. Durst, it seems, wishes to extend the present intolerable practice of having radios blaring away wherever you go. Specifically, he thinks it would be nice to install radios on the Staten Island ferryboats -- hitherto quiet, peaceful, means of transportation, embellished by some truly impressive scenery, which needs no music to set it off.

WHILE producers and distributors were still dolefully eyeing doldrums, movie theatres in the United States earned more than $200,000,000 after taxes in 1948, it was revealed last week by Al Lichtman, newly appointed vice president of Twentieth Century-Fox.

An end to the suspense of some legislative matters created a more hopeful attitude in financial circles last week. The softness which has permeated the economy, in the form of price cuts, unemployment and slow-downs, continued to spread as the stock market alternated widely in interpreting them.

Emphasizing that "both sides would lose in an atomic war," a panel of six high school students urged yesterday that concessions be made within the United Nations on American and Russian proposals for the control of atomic energy.

WINTER PARK, Fla., March 26 (AP) -- The Boston University varsity crew retained its "flag and bag" trophy by defeating Rollins College's varsity eight by a two and one-half length margin today at Lake Maitland.

CHICAGO, March 26 -- Investigation of "any and all subversive activity" at the University of Chicago and Roosevelt College here by the Illinois Legislature's Seditious Activities Commission were lively topics of debate among Central Westerners this week.
LONDON, March 26 -- Only a year ago they made jokes in the Fleet Street bars about a horse picker named Cayton.

" LETTERS to the Editor" in Russian newspapers often include significant trivia, indications of current conditions in the Soviet Union. Almost without exception such letters are critical, aimed at publicizing errors and incompetence on the part of local officials and institutions.

When public hearings are opened shortly before the House Ways and Means Committee in Washington on amendments proposed to extend coverage of the Social Security Act, members of the National Council of Salesman's Organizations will be on hand to endeavor to undo the harm they say was done to many salesmen by passage of the Gearhart amendment over President Truman's veto in the Eightieth Congress.

Evidence indicating that the post-war shortage of steel and luminum in the United States will be ended soon was accumuating last week. Definite breaks in the markets for some products of the two metal industries in recent months have now been followed by some shut-downs of productive facilities.

HAS a tuna sandwich ever made your children question you about that "chicken of the sea"? If so, here are all the answers in a rousing sea tale about a modern tuna clipper off Lower California and Mexico.

MOSCOW, March 26 -- The chief editors of a new Soviet encyclopedia that has been ordered by the Council of Ministers promised in Pravda today that they would produce the "best encyclopedia in the world" and would strictly "reflect the party line -- all the facts will be precise and correct."

Sociologists in their eagerness to establish clubs, playgrounds and other means to channel the interest of delinquent children have ignored the basic reason for the organization and existence of boy gangs.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 26 -The West Coast took a new interest in peacetime uses of atomic energy this week with the announcement that a 400,000-acre site in southeastern Idaho, just to the north of the Snake River, had been selected by the Atomic Energy Commission for its vast nuclear power reactor plant.
