CHRISTOPHER BICK has tried hard to re-create in modern terms and in much detail the tiny village of Domremy, the friends and neighbors of the d'Arc family, the childhood games and chores as well as the later victories and hardships of the Maid.

There was an independent nation in Europe. It loved democracy, which you taught it. Because it never betrayed democracy, it was oppressed by Hitler during all the years of the war. Your victory saved the life of this small nation. At all places where it was allowed it welcomed you Americans as liberators with grateful affection.

In a recent issue THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine published an article by Professor Sidney Hook of New York University in which he argued that known Communist party members should not be allowed, to teach in American colleges because, as adherents to the party "line," they are not free to seek the truth.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., March 26 -- Members of the Association of National Advertisers representing a cross section of American industry said here today that the advertising business is being well alerted to the task it faces in the uneasy shift to a full buyers market.
PRAGUE, March 26 -- The British Vice Consul, Capt. Philip C. Wildash, was accused in a communique today of having taken part in a terrorist organization preparing against the Czechoslovak Government.

PHILADELPHIA, March 26 -Pennsylvania Railroad carloadings last week totaled 92,557 as against 114,410 a year ago, decrease of 19.1 per cent, and for 1949 to date Pennsylvania Railroad loadings totaled 1,201,708 to compare with 1,347,552 last year, decrease of 10.8 per cent.

WHILE serving as intelligence officer in the Eighth Australian Division, Leslie Greener was taken prisoner and removed to a Japanese prison camp. At this time Mr. Greener was not a young man. But evidently his stamina was above average, or he had learned the habit of courage thoroughly, for he was able to find some measure of release even in Japanese custody.

VERO BEACH, Fla., March 26 -- Morris Martin and Jack Banta combined to pitch the Dodgers to their second shut-out of the Grapefruit League season today when the Brooks beat the Washington Senators, 4 -- 0, before 1,100 fans.

NO one should know better than Clarence Derwent that the theatrical season of 1949 is on the wane. The lights, of the legitimate theatre in the nation's capital have blinked out thanks to Mr. Derwent and his arbitrary dictatorial tactics as head of the Actors Equity Association.

ST. LOUIS, March 26 -- The most comprehensive plan yet devised by the Department of Agriculture for the control of land and water resources in the Missouri River Valley reaches to the heart of the biggest problems in the area.

WASHINGTON. HOW can we get able men for the Government of the United States? President Truman has spotlighted this increasingly serious problem by asking for pay rises for many high-ranking officials in the Executive branch. The appropriate Congressional committees have approved his recommendation and included additional top officials.

POSTMASTER GENERAL JESSE M. DONALDSON last week released a lengthy statement in which he held that the Postoffice Department "should be entrusted to provide really important commemoratives without legislation." Citing Congressional measures that had been introduced up to March 3 for forty stamps during 1949, he said that if all these bills were enacted, the printing of so many stamps "would be impossible of accomplishment in a three-year period."

Among the theatre parties taking place this spring are the three which the Lenox Hill Neighborhood Association has arranged for as a special benefit to aid the organization in meeting a financial emergency. The performances selected are of "The Biggest Thief in Town," at the Mansfield Theatre on Thursday and April 18 and of "Detective Story," at the Hudson Theatre on April 25.
WASHINGTON, March 26 (AP) -- The text of the communique released by the six Western Governments today on adjustments of the Western German frontier:

PLANS for the reduction of highway accidents and for solving traffic and parking congestion problems will be presented at the nineteenth annual safety convention and exhibition sponsored by the Greater New York Safety Council, opening Tuesday and continuing through Friday at the Statler Hotel.

ACCORDING to Hollywood, the major activity of the male Arab -- who, of course, is the double of Rudolph Valentino -- is the kidnapping of doe-eyed females. Object: matrimony. This conception of Hollywood explains why Arabs prefer movies made in Egypt.

TRUMBULL Conn., March 26 -Two Yale students, driving to Scarsdale, N. Y., were killed and a third escaped with minor injuries when their auto overturned and burst into flames about 1:30 A. M. today on a westbound lane on the Merritt Parkway here.

The year-end decline in industrial activity has definitely lost momentum, for production is now generally at levels that are being maintained and in some instances improved. This summarized reports for March made to the Business Survey Committee of the National Association of Purchasing Agents, whose chairman is Robert C. Swanton, director of purchases of the Winchester Repeating Arms Corporation Division of Olin Industries, Inc., New Haven.

Daily treatment with fine mists of penicillin or streptomycin apparently gives most sinusitis patients no more relief than do other treatments, according to Drs. Eduardo R. Pons Jr., Walter M. Glass and Bettina Garthwaite of the Departments of Medicine and Otolaryngology of the College of Physicians and Surgeons, Columbia University, and the Presbyterian Hospital.

The protest against the Cultural and Scientific Conference for World Peace continued yesterday when 250 shouting, booing, and jeering pickets marched before Carnegie Hall, where a session was under way, between 11 A. M. and 1:15 P. M.

MORE ghosts are rustling around American public affairs these days, both in politics and in the high-pressure private campaigns for various causes, than have ever congregated since the first Walpurgis Night. The unholy assemblage is literary, of course, rather than ectoplasmic.

Representatives of the "Atlantic community" are converging on Washington for the formal signing of the Atlantic Pact, the first step in a system intended to provide politico-military security for Western Europe.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- In the present debates on the European Recovery Program the nation is promised another test of the axiom that nothing succeeds like success. For when measured against the original claims of its sponsors, there is no doubt that the program has succeeded.

DARIEN, Conn., March 26 -Ronnie Mutch of Darien won the horsemanship championship in the indoor spring fixture of the Ox Ridge Hunt Club today with a total of 29 points. The 13-year-old rider also took the Maclay Trophy event and qualified for competition in the 1949 National Horse Show.

BERLIN, March 26 -- A six-nation commission of the Western powers has agreed upon thirty-one "minor rectifications" of Germany's Western frontiers involving a total area of approximately 135 square kilometers [52 square miles] and about 13,500 inhabitants, an official announcement said tonight.

Your report on the forthcoming film "Alice in Wonderland" mentions the fact that Lewis Carroll did not agree with Sir John Tenniel's rendering of Carroll's animal characters. This sent me searching for a book that came into my hands some years ago.
ROME, March 26 (AP) -- Dry weather has struck a staggering blow to Italy's post-war industrial recovery.

FOR THIS WEEK: Prune trees and grape vines as soon as possible. Avoid leaving stubs where decay may start, by cutting close to the main stem. . . . Fertilize or rake top dressing into the lawn whenever weather per mits. . . . Plant edible peas and sweet peas this month. . . . Rake up litter and leaves from the flower borders, under hedges and the lawn. . . .

IF ever a dual-purpose plant existed, the dwarf fruit tree comes closest to being just that. Its low, compact form is covered with blossoms in the spring, and it yields a family-sized crop of delicious fruit during late summer and fall.

KOHLERIA can be grown as a house plant for its handsome foliage and showy tubular flowers. Although seldom found in window gardens, it proves as satisfactory as African violets and gloxinias, and thrives with similar care.

Richard (Pancho) Gonzales of Los Angeles, national tennis champion on grass and clay, extended his domain to wood yesterday in winning the indoor crown on the board courts of the Seventh Regiment Armory.
More than 5,000 early red and white double-flowering tulips will go on display in the Channel gardens at Rockefeller Center Thursday for two weeks, it was announced yesterday.

Lehman Engel, in "Letter to a Would-Be Duse," mention the many valiant souls who have created their own theatre. Right here in New York is an example -- the illustrious Theatre Guild that was the outcome of the Washington Square Players.

WASHINGTON, March 26 (AP) -Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican, of Ohio, suggested today that Congress limit European recovery funds to $4,280,000,000 and let President Truman decide whether to use that amount during twelve or fifteen months.

Syracuse University this year will begin graduate courses leading to the Master's degree in library science. Under the new program, liberal-arts students or undergraduates in education courses may begin professional study in their junior year by combining the library work with their regular undergraduate courses.

IT is axiomatic that music is one of the fundamental theatre arts. Everybody understands that without it you could have no operettas, musical comedies, revues or any of the other variations of the music-with-girls genre. There is less realization, however, of the part that music can and does play in the form described as legitimate drama.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 26 -- The club he used to pilot brought grief to Casey Stengel at Al Lang Field today. In his first meeting with the Boston Braves since his National League managerial days, the Yankee skipper didn't get all the pitching he expected, and his Bombers went down to defeat, 5 to 3, before 2,902 customers.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -James Forrestal, Secretary of Defense, reported today that the consolidation of many of the functions and operations of the separate armed forces had resulted in savings of at least $56,517,421 since the beginning of unification.
PHILADELPHIA, March 26 -- Hubert E. Madden, 52 years old, president of the Atlantic Ford Motor Coach Sales Company, was killed early today on a midtown sidewalk.

THE illusion that we shall some day have a chance to start over with a clean slate is the last one we ever give up. At the very least we speculate on the other lives we might have had. What thread not followed might have led to something better than this imprisoned present hour?

AS demonstrated up front (page 3), a volume called "Sixteen Self Sketches" is finally published. It contains, to be pedantic, not sixteen but seventeen chapters in autobiography by Bernard Shaw. It was promised for October, 1948, but manufacturing problems delayed the British edition.

INCREASING attention is being focused by the high command of show business on the activities of the nation's little theatres. At the three-day conference on the state of the stage held here this month, speakers emphasized the importance of stimulating the work of zealous and talented actors and stage craftsmen whose efforts are spurred largely by faith in themselves and the future.
NOTHING is much more important these days than the adequate flow of factual information and objective interpretation to the American people, for on their shoulders rest the gravest of decisions.

TORONTO, March 26 (AP) -- Veteran left winger Woody Dumart fired the winning goal after 16 minutes 14 seconds of overtime tonight as the Boston Bruins fought to a 5 -- 4 victory over Toronto before 14,112 fans at Maple Leaf Gardens in a Stanley Cup semifinal game.
WASHINGTON, March 26 (AP) -- The Government is getting ready for a probable nation-wide referendum among farmers within the next 120 days on the question of putting wheat under production controls.

DALLAS, March 26 -- Pre-Easter promotions increased interest in women's apparel, but there was little change in men's clothing sales last week. In other phases of Southwestern business, oil men continued to hold hopes that oil prices will not be cut, despite strong rumors of crude oil price reductions.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 26 -- Dr. James Rhyne Killian Jr., who will be inducted next Saturday as the tenth president of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, believes that engineers, scientists and other technically trained men in this atomic age should have a solid grasp of the humanities.

Lake George was quick to come to the front with a beckoning finger of welcome to Guy Lombardo following last week's recital that the band-leading speedboat pilot was looking for a lake near New York on which he hopes this spring to set a new world one-mile record.

In three sales this week the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street, will auction autograph letters, books and manuscripts, modern paintings, drawings, prints and African sculptures, eighteenth-century English furniture and art objects.

IT is one of the tokens of our culture that the only films which have yet really shown some deep and mature comprehension of the great human tragedy of our times -- meaning, of course, the vast despoilment of mankind in the wrack of World War II -- have been a few made in Europe.

THE refreshing characteristic of this book is its accent on reasonableness. It was written in a period when the Taft-Hartley Law was firmly in effect and the only changes that seemed likely were those aimed at putting additional restraints on organized labor.

ENGLISHMEN have always been amused by their returning exile: the pukka sahib, retired from Indian service, was a favorite British pre-war cartoon. But now there are enough homegrown exiles adrift in England to induce fellow-feeling for Colonel Blimp.

Death took an enforced holiday for about 14 minutes in Brooklyn yesterday and as a result 3-year-old Jane Martin was reported resting comfortably last night in Kingston Avenue Hospital for Communicable Diseases.

Arthur Cook, Olympic small-bore champion, led the Maryland University rifle team to a close victory over Army, 1,404 to 1,399, in the twenty-nine-team field of City College's third annual R. O. T. C. Trophy match yesterday at the CCNY range.

AT a recent forum on modern art at Columbia University, under the sponsorship of the Department of Painting and Sculpture, a zealous questioner from the floor implicitly denounced the modern artist for not directly promoting the democratic ideal.

BLACKIE was, of course, a blackbird, and the daily problems, perils and excitements which filled his life one spring and summer were observed by the author and are related in story form for young readers. With his wife Rusty, Blackie built a nest in a pomegranate tree in a California orchard.

A DEXTROUS fantasy, this novel with the Kubla Khan title is freighted with allegory. It begins with a trick courtroom scene, presided over by an ex-judge who relinquishes his bench to the witnesses. The ease concerns a monkey in the Central Park Zoo who spat in the eye of a beautiful young woman -- not without cause.

CHICAGO, March 26 (AP) -- Promoter Joe Louis, with a fine sentimental touch, today announced the Ezzard Charles-Jersey Joe Walcott bout for his vacated world heavyweight crown would be held here on June 22 in Comiskey Park.

WASHINGTON, March 26 (UP) -- Senator John L. McClellan, Democrat, of Arkansas, said today the Democratic National Committee apparently "is trying to play politics" with the Hoover commission on Government reorganization. He is one of the Congressional members of the commission.

The appointment of fourteen new surveyors who will handle business for the American Bureau of Shipping in Great Britain and Ireland was announced yesterday by the bureau, a technical classification society. At the same time, the bureau also assigned one surveyor each to the Yokohama, Japan, and Trieste offices.

T. S. ELIOT has become an institution. His adopted nation has bestowed Upon him the Order of Merit; last year he received the Nobel Prize for literature, when he was also presented with a collection of tributes on his sixtieth birthday; F. O. Matthiessen's "Achievement of T. S. Eliot" has been reissued.

The Western Big Three occupying powers of Germany last week made an important move, in an undramatic manner, in the struggle over the Russian-blockaded city of Berlin. They issued a largely technical communique which said in part: "As from today the East mark shall cease to be legal tender in the Western sectors of Berlin."

SAN FRANCISCO, March 26 -Talk of a possible West Coast strike on June 15 by the Marine Engineers Beneficial Association, CIO, brought today from J. B. Bryan, president of the Pacific American Shipowners Association, a prediction that a wage dispute with the engineers would be settled amicably.

Seven qualified clergymen and four skilled workers with children have been provided for in the 1949 budget of the Migrant Committee of the New Jersey Council of Churches to meet the religious needs of the families of 18,000 migrant laborers expected to harvest next summer on fruit and vegetable farms in that state, it was learned here yesterday.
The first question put to Spanish Foreign Minister Alberto Martin Artajo was: "What is the economic situation of Spain today?"

LONDON, March 26 -- A powerful Cambridge varsity crew snatched victory today from Oxford in the most thrilling finish to the annual rowing classic seen here since the deadheat of seventy- two years ago.

VIENNA, March 26 -- The new Communist paramilitary organization known as Kampfgruppe (literally, battle group) is expected to be on hand for the Communist "peace demonstrations" scheduled tomorrow in front of Vienna's city hall.
MOSCOW, March 26 (AP) -- A Tass dispatch today blamed anti-Communist "hysteria" for the recent death at Hanover, N. H., of Raymond Cirrotta, Dartmouth College junior.
NEWARK, N. J., March 26 -Princeton University's polo team wound up its season tonight by routing the Ramapo Cubs, 16 -- 8, at Essex Troop Armory.
WASHINGTON, March 27 -Definite progress toward forming a new world labor federation of free trade unions was reported here today.

CHICAGO, March 26 -- Recent sharp increases in savings accounts in Chicago banks may be levelling off, statements of conditions just issued by Chicago state banks indicated. The total as of March 22 was $572,192,000, an increase of $4,985,000 since the Dec. 31 statement.

WASHINGTON, March 26 (AP) -A survey of the "home rule" out look shows that several states are working on their own rent laws. A few already have their own statutes. It is expected that one of them. New York, will renew its stand-by measure for another year.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- Developments this week on the labor front added up to a rapidly forming conviction in some quarters that the Congressional fight over labor legislation will not only be unprecedentedly bitter but that the outcome may even be a source of complete disappointment to all concerned -- labor, industry, Congress and the Administration.

The Hoover Commission's reports affecting banking, although unlikely to be implemented soon, constitute a serious potential threat to the business at this time, according to informed observers. The reports, they assert, may now be used to support legislation already pending in Congress, which the industry considers far more dangerous to the banking system.

President Truman's "bold new program for making the benefits of our scientific advances and industrial progress available for the improvement and growth of underdeveloped areas" comes into the news again with the announcement that Dr. Isaiah Bowman had been named to head ECA's new "colonial development division."

The Eastern States indoor speed skating championship will be held this afternoon at the Brooklyn Ice Palace, with attractive Miss Mary Lynch of Newburgh the choice to capture the senior women's title.

More than 500 delegates from motion-picture councils throughout the country are scheduled to attend the Fortieth Anniversary Conference of the National Board of Review of Motion Pictures beginning Wednesday at the Hotel McAlpin, it was announced yesterday by Quincy Howe, president.

Forty-one American college students have begun their own experiment in international understanding and cooperation. Their laboratory is the campus of New York University, and their objective is to put world problems into personal terms.

Arithmetic will be easily taught and thoroughly understood only when it is linked to social, deductive and experimental science, Dr. Nathan Lazar, instructor in the teaching of mathematics at Columbia University's Teachers College, declared yesterday.

A 16-year-old Bayside High School girl, Miss Mae Faggs, sprinted over the board floor at the Third Engineers Group Armory last night to win the 220-yard women's National A.A.U. indoor championship. In doing so she beat one of the famed women athletes of this country.

TOKYO, March 26 -- Taking firm action against strikes for political purposes in Japan, R. T. Amis, chief of Allied Headquarters labor relations, yesterday summoned the leaders of fourteen affiliated unions of the Communist-dominated National Congress of Industrial Organizations and told them that the occupation would not tolerate their attempt to prevent projected revisions in the labor union law by striking.

HALLANDALE, Fla., March 26 (AP) -- Christopher T. Chenery's Mangohick, in his first race since September, romped to a length and a quarter victory today in Gulf-stream Park's $5,000 Suwanee River Purse. Mon's Boy was second and High Shine third, three-quarters of a length farther behind, in the six-furlong feature for 4-year-olds and upward.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- The National Guard Association of the United States asked today that Lieut. Gen Elwood Quesada, special assistant to the Air Force Chief of Staff, be relieved of his assignment on the grounds of his being "eminently unfit" to do his job.

LONDON, March 26 -- In a strong note to Czechoslovakia, which was published today, the British Government protested against the arrest of Captain Wildash in Prague on the basis of "vague and obscure" charges he had "plotted" against the Czechoslovak state.

FOR Walter Hendl's money, the ideal conductor would have Fritz Reiner's right hand and Leopold Stokowski's left. How he came to this conclusion -- and how it came to be quoted here -- is a story of an "ordinary" American boy who began to study music in high school, and, at 31 has been appointed musical director of the Dallas Symphony.

BUENOS AIRES, March 26 -- Two escaped quislings among Norway's top war criminals have just arrived here by small motorboat and joined the colony that includes at least six other wanted men who came in similar craft last July.

SPRINGFIELD. Ill., March 26 -- The Governors of states that were carved from the old Northwest Territory had been invited by Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson to participate in observing the 250th anniversary of Cahokia, the first permanent white settlement in the Mississippi Valley.

MONTREAL, March 26 (AP) -The third-place Montreal Canadiens fought off a third-period drive by the Detroit Red Wings tonight to take a 3-2 decisicn and move in front of the National Hockey League champions, 2--1, in their Stanley Cup semi*final series.

FOR pure entertainment there is no fender joke in town than "Life With Mother." During an uneventful week on Broadway, I took occasion to revisit it recently in the company of the illustrious Moscow Art Theatre actress.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange held steady yesterday within a narrow range and closed two to four points net higher.

FRANKFORT, Germany, March 26 -- Failure of the three Western powers to draft a common policy on Germany might spell the end of the present program for the creation of a Western German government, an informed official source said today.

IN one way and another I have used in my writings pretty well everything that has happened to me in the course of my life. Sometimes an experience of my own has provided me with an idea and all I have had to do is to invent the incidents to illustrate it.

In the wildest basketball game ever played at Madison Square Garden the New York knickerbockers last night defeated the Baltimore Bullets, 103 -- 99, in overtime. The victory sent Joe Lapchick's lads into the play-off semi-finals of the Basketball Association of America.

THE metaphysical novel, or theological thriller, when successful, can be as interesting and as exciting as even the better Boy-Meets-Girl products that clutter the libraries. Unfortunately very few of them are successful. This one is.

WILLINGNESS to take a chance on an idea is paying off for both the New Haven Railroad and Broadway. Several weeks ago the carrier, in association with Jo Heidt, press representative of the Theatre Guild, developed the inspiration of running a train from New Haven, with stops along the way, that would arrive here in time for dinner and the theatre.

Navy blue coats, suits and dresses and low-price nylon blouses were featured in retail promotions here last week, according to a survey made especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by the Retail News Bureau, Inc. Leather handbags, pearl jewelry and fabric gloves featured in accessory promotions.

THE current trend among amateur photographers toward smaller print sizes to counteract the rising cost of photographic paper had a trial demonstration last week in a prize contest for prints from 2 1/2x3 1/2 to 5x7 inches.

Dr. Sidney Hook, chairman of the Philosophy department at New York University, gave his version yesterday of his Friday night encounter with Dr. Harlow Shapley, in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. In an account of the incident THE NEW YORK TIMES reported that Dr. Hook was "incoherent."
The National Labor Relations Board announced yesterday the outcome of one of the biggest representation elections it has ever held, involving 14,500 agents of the Prudential Life Insurance Company.

Increasing attention is now being given in foreign trade circles to Point 4 of President Truman's inauguration address in which he called for a "bold new program for making the benefits of our scientific advances and industrial progress available for the improvement and growth of under-developed areas."

When the thirty-third International Flower Show closed its doors at Grand Central Palace at 9 o'clock last evening, there was little doubt in the minds of exhibitors that this flower exposition had been not only beautiful but also popular.

THE plays of Sean O'Casey are certainly not what Lady Gregory and William Butler Yeats had in mind when they founded the Abbey Theatre or when they hypnotized John Millington Synge into giving them the folk comedy which they could dream of but could not create.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 26 -- Dr. Fairfield Osborn, president of the New York Zoological Society and the Conservation Foundation, asserted tonight that for more than a century the United States had not "lived within our renewable natural resources income."

On the face of precipitous Mount Behistun in Iran is the 2,500-year-old sculptured monument of Darius the Great, which has been likened to the famous Rosetta Stone of Egypt because it provides the key to the languages spoken in ancient Babylonia and Elam.

Jimmy Montgomery, the 14-year-old son of a Hot Springs, Ark., barber, will arrive in New York today to receive officially his title as "Boy of the Year" from the Boys' Clubs of America and take part in the annual observance of National Boys' Club Week which opens tomorrow.

The Cultural and Scientific Conference for World Peace was criticized for befuddling and deferring earnest efforts for the prevention of war by Rabbi William F. Rosenblum in a sermon in Temple Israel, 210 West Ninety-first Street, yesterday.

THIS is a very moving book whose appeal transcends personal association. For Morris Cohen in his sixty-seven years carved out a career of pervasive influence and achieved a serene spirit, although he was handicapped by extreme poverty in early youth and the lifelong ill health which resulted from it.

THE St. Louis Symphony Orchestra is one of the most venerable in the land. Since it will be 70 next season and since it has managed to get along with the same conductor, Vladimir Golschmann, for the past eighteen years, you would think that it had nothing to worry about.

This morning we find ourselves in the midst of repercussions stirred up by the current meeting in this city of the Cultural and Scientific Conference for World Peace. This is one of those occasions in which the side shows are at least as important as the circus. The circus consists of a gathering of some hundreds of persons avowedly interested in science, the arts and a better understanding among the nations.

While this is not the season for discussions on firearms, and on shooting safety, an incident which took place this week makes it quite clear that the proper precautionary measures are important both in and out of season.

Eddie Eagan, chairman of the New York State Athletic Commission, will conduct a closed meeting of his board tomorrow. The head of the governing body of boxing in the Empire State will hold the session to inquire into the circumstances that caused Referee Harry Ebbets and Judge Harold Barnes to cast their votes for Jake La Motta in his fight with Robert L Villemain of France at Madison i Square Garden on Friday night.

BOSTON, March 26. -- Last week's decline in retail trade in Boston was the sharpest in many years. Merchants say the reason for the poor showing is that a year ago this was the heavy shopping second week before Easter, whereas this year it is the fourth pre-Easter week.

Federal legislation pointing toward the annual issuance of more than a billion dollars of local authority bonds to finance low-rent public housing is reviving an old controversy of investment banking practice.

THIS is a novel of the long years in the late sixteenth century when the Netherlands were gallantly struggling to throw off the yoke of Philip of Spain. The valiant resistance of William of Nassau, the nobles, burghers and peasants to foreign oppression is here recounted with scrupulous attention to historical detail.

HIGH up on the Acropolis of Athens, the ruins of the Parthenon and the Erectheum dominate the Greek sky. They were part of the gigantic architectural program undertaken in the fifth century B. C. after the destruction of the Persian Wars and were the greatest of the many temples and altars on the commanding bluff which had once been a citadel.

LAKE SUCCESS, March 26 -Rightly or wrongly, a considerable number of delegates and United Nations employes saw a sign of the times in President Truman's announcement Thursday that he could not spare the few hours he would have needed to come from Washington April 10 to lay the cornerstone on the new United Nations headquarters in Manhattan.

THE forty-seven keys on Honey's typewriter opened the way to events of both immediate and future importance in her teen-aged career. For Honoria Cathcart planned to become an author. When her high school stenography course enabled her to work as part-time secretary to a famous novelist, Honey determined to learn the art of writing at first hand.

TEHERAN, Iran, March 26 -- A high military source said today that a detachment of fifty Soviet troops had killed one Iranian soldier and had wounded and captured two others in a disputed frontier region in northeast Iran.
I WISH to protest in the strongest possible terms the insult to the general public offered by the review, in the March 6 issue of THE TIMES, of Mr. T. S. Eliot's most recent volume.

CHICAGO, March 26 (AP) -Grains, soy beans and lard turned downward on the Board of Trade today. The market opened weak and showed no ability to rally, extending its early losses. While dealings were not heavy, persistent selling pressure was present in all pits.

MALCOLM BARNES' excellent translation of Charles Gos' book on fatal mountain-climbing accidents in the Alps is strangely fascinating and should be welcomed not only by mountaineers but by all lovers of adventure. The style is graphic.

TO American readers Mr. Empson is probably best known as an adventurous and lively critic through his "Seven Types of Ambiguity" and "English Pastoral Poetry." Readers of the earlier volume, especially, recognize him as a sensitive analyst of the effects of multiple meaning in English verse.

It was heartening to note the recent letter from Clarence Derwent about the absurd lack of living theatre in the nation's capital. The lassitude of producing organizations about the potential audience they are missing in Washington is hard to understand.

IN mellow mood, his gray head bared to the warming sun, Lewis Stone strolled about the motion picture plant where he has worked a quarter of a century, reminisced on life and his job. Both had been good. He had just come from a festooned sound stage where he had eaten a hearty luncheon with 70-odd other actors and heard his employer say some kind things about his long service.

WEST POINT, N. Y., March 26 -- After two long days of competition, Army and Rutgers shared the three-weapon championship as the fifth annual fencing tournament of the National Collegiate Athletic Association ended at the United States Military Academy today.

ALBANY, March 26 -- The net supplemental appropriation bill, totaling $639,919.15 and bringing the grand total of the record state budget for the next fiscal year to $937,702,971.44, was introduced in the Legislature today by Senator Arthur H. Wicks and Assemblyman D. Mallory Stephens, the Republican fiscal committee chairman.
NANKING, March 26 -- The Communist Central Committee announced officially today that it had voted to start peace talks with the Nanking Government in Peiping on Friday, April 1.

THE fear of using insecticides in gardens harboring pets appears to be widespread these days. Yet, in my experience, pets and poisons are quite compatible if reasonable caution is exercised in the application of the chemical.

Rudolf Serkin was heard in his only New York recital of the season yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall. The eminent pianist was definitely out of the vein during most of his program, but retrieved himself near its close with a performance of five Etudes of Debussy, which represented him at his fine best.

CHAPEL HILL, N. C., March 26 -- Joe Verdeur of La Salle evened his score with Keith Carter of Purdue -- and set an American record in the bargain -- as the twenty- sixth National Collegiate Athletic Association swimming championships came to a smashing close tonight in North Carolina's Bowman Gray Memorial Pool.

Two or more burglars proved between Friday night and early yesterday morning that it is sometimes more convenient to break down walls than to open doors. This procedure is almost dictated when the walls are of plasterboard and door tampering might set off burglar alarms.

OUT of the blue, often at the most awkward of moments, children ask, "Where do babies come from?" And for many adults answers to such questions add up to "sex education." This isn't all there is to it.

" Boy Meets Girl, Moscow Version," by the Russian woman, Irma Volk, was a most depressing love story, particularly when read on an early spring evening. An American who dared submit a similarly styled article would be, at best, a would-be hack.
CHICAGO, March 26 (AP) -- Common sense in the department store can save owners thousands of operating dollars a year, a new University of Illinois study reveals.

RIO DE JANEIRO, March 26 -- The Brazilian press considers the Cultural and Scientific Conference for World Peace now being held in New York, not as a move to create peace but to create Bolshevist propaganda against the Atlantic Pact.

PARIS, March 26 -- Out of the election run-off to be held Sunday in the cantons of France, which usually decide questions of local roads and schools, French politicians have made a referendum on the present national coalition Government, the grouping of parties that is known as the "Third Force."

The Government of Israel is now concerning itself with the status of Jews in Arab lands. Particularly it is concerned with the status of Jews in Egypt, in Iraq and in Syria. Apparently it considers that such matters offer no great difficulty of arrangement in Transjordan and in Lebanon. It is said that Jews are in danger in certain parts of North Africa and in Yemen.
PHILADELPHIA, March 26 (AP) -- Senator William Langer, Republican of North Dakota, declared tonight that Administration leaders "imposed deliberate mass starvation policies on 50,000,000 Germans."

AN important retrospective exhibition of Augustus John's portraits and water-colors in American collections, at Scott Fowles, affords an unusual opportunity to sum up the contribution of England's most celebrated contemporary painter.
AINTREE, England, March 26 -- An unsung 9-year-old gelding named Russian Hero jumped like a stag today to capture the 103d Grand National Steeplechase in a runaway finish.

LAWN areas are first, both in time and importance, on the spring gardening schedule. The appearance of the lawn this summer depends largely on the work done now in repairing present damage and forestalling later trouble.

JOSEPH O'CONNOR has been Professor of Classics and Modern Language at St. Brendan's College in Killarney and has also written short stories, chiefly in Gaelic, on the art and folklore of his native land. It is his vast and detailed knowledge of his own people, along with the affection he holds for them, that gives "The Norwayman" freshness and rugged honesty.

CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa, March 26 -- A national work holiday for outright repeal of the Taft-Hartley Act was urged here today by the United Farm Equipment and Metal Workers, CIO. The union's national convention unanimously adopted a resolution including this proposal after a speech in support of it by Lee Pressman, the union's attorney and former general counsel of the CIO.

Al Parsells came into his own last night at Squadron A Armory. Stymied in four seasons of indoor polo, Parsells made every shot pay off as he led his Ramapo Polo Club to a 9-8 success over the New York Athletic Club in the final of the Eastern portion of the National 12-goal tournament.
ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., March 26 (AP) -- Lawrence Fox of Indianapolis scored 696 tonight for sixth place in the singles competition of the American Bowling Congress tournament.

THE role that records can and should play in giving the public a broad perspective of the work of even well-known composers of our own century is emphasized by two new albums, one devoted to Bela Bartok and the other to Manuel de Falla.

With department store sales here last week recording the fifth consecutive weekly decline, hopes held earlier by some merchants that March and April sales combined would exceed those of corresponding months last year have practically disappeared.

THE miraculously precise workings of the human body, with its remarkable capacity to adjust to a wide range of activity, have fascinated thinkers since the dawn of civilization. And the impact of disease on those mechanisms has led men to search for means of a cure.

NEW DELHI, India, March 26 -Senior officers of India's armed forces will visit the United States and Britain in April for an exploratory study of training methods, equipment, and ordnance production techniques that might be developed in India in the future.
Following are summaries of the panel discussions held yesterday as part of the Cultural and Scientific Conference for World Peace at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel:

STE. MARGUERITE, P. Q. -With deep snows covering from three to five feet of base, the popular skilands of the Laurentian Mountains should provide at least a month more of good spring skiing. A large influx of snow-starved Americans is expected to enjoy the facilities in the area stretching from Shawbridge, forty miles north of Montreal, to lofty Mount Tremblant.

THIS is the third book of short stories from the workshop of that veteran poet-novelist. Christopher La Farge. Ranging from The New Yorker at its sleekest to The Woman's Home Companion, from prize winners to manuscripts that failed to find a magazine outlet, from stories-for-fun to stories that grapple grimly with the cosmos, the collection is well-labeled.

MINNEAPOLIS, March 26. -The somewhat slowed pace of business activity in the Ninth Federal Reserve District was reflected in employment figures released this week by the Minnesota Employment - Security Division. It showed employment in retail trade had dropped 2 per cent in January and February, while employment in manufacturing continued the trend that began in November by dropping another 1 per cent.

WHEN Miss Abbott brought Lanny, the six-toed kitten, from the Humane Society shelter to her own home he got into all kinds of trouble. He destroyed a potted plant, he tore paper napkins, he broke his mistress' knitting wool.

Dr. Selman A. Waksman, head of the Department of Microbiology at Rutgers University, New Brunswick, N. J., and one of his students, Hubert A. Lechevalier, announced in Science last week that they had discovered a new antibiotic which, so far as the evidence goes, may have a brilliant future in the treatment of tuberculosis.

ALBANY, March 26 -- More than 40,000 additional income tax returns have been received from residents of the state since last Monday, when Governor Dewey signed the bill setting the rates, Spencer E. Bates, President of the State Tax Commission, said today.

As a civilian physician who served in the Army during the last war, I have continued my interest in the progress and the activities of medical departments of the Armed Forces. There is no question in my mind regarding the serious nature of the shortages in professional personnel which are confronting the medical services of the Armed Forces.

David Aboff, formerly president and general manager of the Gale Textile Corporation, has been appointed stylist and technical adviser of the Airedale Worsted Mills, Inc., with headquarters in the New York sales office at 350 Fifth Avenue.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 26 -Losses in retail business activity throughout the Twelfth district were more severe during the past week than the previous few weeks. Bank loans and investments as of March 16 totaled $10,916,000,000. This represented a decline of $188,000,000 from March 17, 1948.

A new slogan was coined yesterday by Advertising Women of New York: "Five Thousand Women to Save Five Thousand Lives." And the idea behind it is to get 5,000 volunteers to staff 500 booths in Manhattan during the New York City Cancer Committee's drive starting April 4 to raise $1,250,000 toward the American Cancer Society's goal of $14,500,000.
LAFAYETTE, Ind., March 26 (AP)-----Garion Campbell of Michigan Normal tied the American indoor record for 60-yard low hurdles tonight, beating a fast field in the Purdue Relays.

LOS ANGELES, March 26 (AP) -The Swoose, lone survivor of the original United States Far Eastern Air Force, left here today on the first leg of her last flight that eventually will take her to the Smithsonian Institution's National Air Museum in Washington.

SEATTLE, March 26 (AP) -- The basketball coaches of America argued for an hour this morning over swapping a three-letter word for one of four letters in the official rules book. They finally voted, 25 to 24, in favor of changing "may" to "must."

A new-type recruitment campaign that will not capitalize on "see-the-world" slogans, but on selling the United States Navy as an occupation, has been started by the service, it was disclosed yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 26 (AP) -The Senate has approved the following nominations for postmasterships in New York:

MISS RACHEL MURDOCK first met murder some ten years ago, when she simply acted as Watson to a likable young police lieutenant. But the gingery old lady soon branched out as a detective on her own, and carried her sharp wits and her cat Samantha through one set of murders after another.
The May Day parade, in recent years almost entirely Communist-sponsored and wholly Communist-directed, will be held this year on April 30, it was decided yesterday at a meeting in Manhattan Center.

The Public Service Commission, in a four-to-one decision yesterday, sanctioned a further increase of $770,000 in interim gas rates of the Long Island Lighting Company on condition that the system cut annual electricity rates $1,200,000.

One is inclined to say that those of the rising generation who did not hear the first two acts of Verdi's "Aida" as performed by Arturo Toscanini with the NBC orchestra and chorus and soloists yesterday afternoon in Radio City just have not heard "Aida."

FROM its farm and market reporters, stationed allover the country, the United States Department of Agriculture receives "flashes" on food supplies which along with other material, are translated into monthly bulletins. These list the most plentiful products in groceries; usually they are reasonable in cost, too.
TRIESTE, March 26 -- The world still awaits any concrete factual reaction by the Soviet Union to the creation of a defensive coalition by the Western democratic nations.

LOS ANGELES, March 26 -Basking in the sunshine as they disported themselves in the presence of 5,664 onlookers in picturesque Wrigley Field, the Giants today put in their most profitable afternoon of the spring training campaign to date.

AN interesting experiment in "local airline" operation that eventually may prove extremely significant to air transport in this country has been going on for almost two years in Texas. Despite its potential value to the air transport pattern of the nation, this test-tube operation has received scant public attention.

DUESSELDORF, March 26 -- The office of Karl Arnold, Minister-President of North Rhine-Westphalia, issued today one of the most vigorous denunciations of the Western powers yet made by a Western German official. Commenting on the border revisions the statement said in part:
ST. JOSEPH, Mo., March 26 (AP) -- The Nashville (Tenn.) Goldblumes will wear the women's National A. A. U. basketball crown for at least another year.

Sir James Frazer in his great work "The Golden Bough" has something to say about "the magic spring" -- which should not be confused with the spring magic just now in the air. The magic spring was the revival of the earth which was regularly brought about at this time by magic for more generations than anyone can know for sure.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., March 26 (AP) -- Four southern and southwestern states felt tornadic winds today and tonight.

FIVE years ago Mr. Wiltse published his "John C. Calhoun, Nationalist, 1782-1828," which was received with general favor. The present volume, the second of a projected trilogy, covers a stirring decade of history and can be read by itself.

THERE was no mistaking the large and amiable lady in the dark blue suit. She was Molly Goldberg, a familiar figure for the past twenty years because of radio, the stage and now television. Her handshake was warm, friendly and vigorous, but she had hardly uttered a word before she excused herself.

THIS is the second recent attempt to put into fiction the story of St. Joseph, Florida's first boom town, a bubble that burst with plague and hurricane a century ago. (Rubylea Hall's "The Great Tide" was the first.) Mr. Key gives us the tale of Maury St. John, quondam doctor, slave trader, lecher, gambler, sailing master and what not.

AMERICA is the oldest country in the world, Gertrude Stein once remarked, because it was the first to enter the twentieth century. The rest of the world has been following and protesting much too much. Crushed or at least crippled in the twentieth century, France is nostalgic for the seventeenth and England for the nineteenth.

The Truman Administration maps its day-to-day tactics vis-a-vis the Eighty-first Congress on Monday mornings. At the White House the President has a session with leaders from Capitol Hill -- Vice President Alben W. Barkley, Senate Majority Leader Scott W. Lucas, Speaker Sam Rayburn, House Floor Leader John McCormack.
NEW ORLEANS, March 26 (AP) -- Grand Entry, Fantasy Farm's black colt, won the $10,000 added Louisiana Handicap as the Fair Grounds rang down the season's curtain today.

PARIS, March 26 -- The European council for the Marshall Plan completed today the translation of the "program of action" framed by the Ministers' Steering Committee into more specific recommendations and even set up a timetable for reports on progress from member countries.

Business conditions here last week continued to show a recession from the 1948 peaks. Retail trade, suffering from comparison with the early Easter figures of last year, went behind an estimated 19 per cent. From this point on, however, retail sales comparisons will be more favorable as trade moves into heavy shopping in the three weeks remaining before Easter.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- The National Labor Relations Board found today that an employer violated the Taft-Hartley Act by circulating an "anti-union" newspaper and by causing the police to maintain surveillance over union organizers and the union activities of its employes.

HOWARD HUGHES, controlling owner of RKO, and Stanley Kramer, head of Screen Plays, Inc., have squared off for what may prove to be a good Hollywood fight, if neither party backs down. Late last year RKO made a picture called "The Set-Up" from a narrative poem by Joseph Moncure March, and Screen Plays made a picture called "Champion" from a story by Ring Lardner.
OTTAWA, March 26 -- At midnight Thursday Newfoundland will become the tenth province in the Canadian Confederation after an eighty-two-year fight to remain independent.

Various United States Government agencies have advanced large sums of money in the last eight years to aid Mexican economy and representatives of that Latin-American country again are in Washington seeking loans that are understood to aggregate more than $400,000,000.

LAKE SUCCESS -- The United Nations received the go-ahead signal last week to continue its efforts to reduce passport restrictions, liberalize frontier and customs formalities and generally assist the free movement of tourist traffic.

TOKYO, March 26 -- The steering committee of the Diet has now drafted the much-discussed resolution for the establishment of an un-Japanese activities committee, paralleling the un-American activities group of the United States Congress.

Congressional action on rents last week assured about 15,000,000 tenants that they would have controls in some form after the expiration of the present rent law this Thursday. The working-out of the details of the new rent-control measure is in the hands of a Senate-House conference that has been meeting for the last two days to iron out differences between the two chambers' bills.

ALTHOUGH subtitled "an historical novel of Texas in the Seventies," "Smoke Up the Valley" is actually a rootin'-tootin' romance of blazing six-shooters and gore sufficient to satisfy the most avid seeker of slaughter in the chaparral.

NEWPORT NEWS, Va., March 26 -- Industrial and educational leaders say that race relations in this section of the state are excellent "when we take into account the rural background of the majority of our workers." Most of the employment here is supplied by a private shipbuilding company.

BESIDES six or eight annual exhibitions, nation-wide in scope, in which artists hope to be represented, the Corcoran Biennial of contemporary American oil painting has held its pre-eminence through the years. Three medals and $5,000 in prizes, together with supplementary purchases, make representation in this event in the nation's capital highly desirable.

Praise for Lehman Engel's splendid article----"Letter to a Would-Be Duse." There is one item I feel important that is omitted. When an actor does have a good year (a year in which he has a hit show) he must: naturally, pay an income tax on that year's earnings.

Samuel Caruba, 16 years old, of 875 Elsmere Place, the Bronx, died yesterday morning in Fordham Hospital after he had shot himself in the head Friday night at his home with an automatic pistol he bought last January from another youth.
Students in many American high schools and colleges are receiving inferior instruction in modern languages, according to Dr. Stephen A. Freeman, director of Middlebury College Language Schools.

WAYNE COY, chairman of the Federal Communications, last week clarified the muddled situation in the television industry concerning assignment of new television channels and the effect of such action on sets now on the market.

TRADITIONALLY, summer has been the season of escape from school. But the earnest young musicians, particularly those wanting to compose or conduct, seem to be reversing the trend. They are flocking to summer schools, but in a sense they are getting vacations too.

Applications for apartments in Woodside Houses, Queens, the first project to open in Mayor O'Dwyer's program of public housing without cash subsidy, will be distributed tomorrow at 9 A. M. at the offices of the New York City Housing Authority in the five boroughs, it was announced yesterday by Thomas F. Farrell, chairman.

PARIS, March 26 -- French political parties have, with the exception of a few districts, joined in a barricade against the Communists for tomorrow's run-off elections for the Departmental Councils in France.
LINCOLN DOWNS, R. I., March 26 (AP) -- A record crowd of 27,000 broke the track betting mark today as Lincoln Downs. New England's newest track, opened the Eastern thoroughbred racing season.

The Committee for Progressive Zionism, composed of prominent Zionists opposed to various policies of the Zionist Organization of America, announced yesterday that it had called a nominating convention at the Commodore Hotel on April 17 to select a slate of officers to be presented to the Zionist convention on May 28.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -President Truman in a radio address tonight during the interdenominational program. "One Great Hour," declared that the Parable of the Last Judgment made clear "our duty toward those millions of people in other countries who have suffered and still suffer the miseries of war, destruction and tyranny."

IN the year 1924 I was working as a junior clerk in the Foreign Office in London. I was attached to the Near Eastern Department, and my specialty was supposed to be Greek politics, parties and feelings. During the previous autumn I had spent several weeks in Greece, collecting material and impressions for my book on the last year of Byron's life.

Brother Adrian Lewis bent over his work table yesterday as the light from a goose-neck lamp glinted on his steel-rimmed spectacles. Delicately manipulating a thick hatpin, he etched minute lacework in a large Norway maple leaf.

ANOTHER shake or two was given to prices in important markets last week coincident with the news that the cost of living had taken its biggest tumble in almost nine years. The metals list was studded with reductions, including the first break in zinc. Chemicals were weak in a number of products.

" OLIVIA," the author tells us, is an autobiography; the story of her first love. No romance in the ordinary sense, "Olivia" chronicles a 16-year-old English girl's awakening to life and tragedy through an unfortunate attachment to her French schoolmistress.

" THE characters and events in this novel are fictitious. Any resemblance to actual persons or events is incidental." In this novel, strangely enough, the characters are fictitious. They quote Ruskin in the rear echelons with the casualness with which a Mailer character rolls off a curse in combat.

HARTFORD, Conn., March 26 -Gov. Chester Bowles, whose inauguration in January was delayed four hours by Republican demands for a recount, is finding the patience he displayed then good training for the General Assembly deadlock he now faces.

IF the key to eventual improvement in the artistic quality of films is, as many believe, the education of movie audiences, then the United States can look with profit to France for some helpful hints in this direction. For this country introduced and brought to a high degree of development what is probably the most efficient instrument for cultivating the tastes of the movie-going public: the cine club.

International Publishers, Communist publishing house specializing in works and documents on the Soviet Union, has issued a new translation of the sensational book on the Soviet war economy by N. A. Voznesenky, member of the Soviet Politburo.

Two current problems discussion groups that meet regularly in the branches of the New York Public Library will explore the subjects "Should Communists teach in our colleges?" and "Freedom of speech -- for all or for the few?" The first topic will be discussed on Tuesday at 190 Amsterdam Avenue, and the second on Thursday at 224 East 125th Street, both at 8 P. M. The meetings are open to the public.

BALLET THEATRE duly got itself restored to action in Washington a week ago yesterday after nearly a year of inactivity, and with about half the company new, will return to the Metropolitan Opera House on Easter Sunday for three weeks.

WHEN a university professor wins a $10,000 prize for a popular book on his own subject, it is the academic equivalent of a professional author selling the Hollywood rights to a novel for twenty times $10,000. The winner is Dr. Clyde Kluckhohn, whose "Mirror for Man," chosen for the prize from 250 manuscripts in the Whittlesey House-Science Illustrated contest for books on science for the layman, has just gone quickly into its second printing.

MOSCOW, March 26 -- In a series of exposes carried out in the past few weeks, the Soviet press has uncovered the existence of what are described here as "homeless cosmopolitans." These exposes undoubtedly are among the most important in the post-war drive to uncover ideological digressions and strengthen the general basis of Soviet philosophy.

The coming of spring and warmer weather brought dress sales to a satisfactory level in the wholesale apparel market here last week, but coat and suit sales continued to compare unfavorably with last year's pre-Easter figures, according to a report made especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., Inc., resident buying office.

ALL that heady exhilaration which inlanders know when they first come to the seacoast is captured in this salty tale. To Betsy and Dave Dustin, Colorado-reared, the Maine island promised all kinds of excitement -- and abundantly fulfilled its promise.

FROM London to Teheran and back again is a long journey in space and time. The airplane telescopes geography and shortens distance. It rubs out frontiers and makes the earth look like the neat topographical map it certainly isn't; at the same time it sharpens the perspective on the present.

With a defeat of Arturito Pomar of Spain in the tenth round, yesterday, Hector Rossetto of Buenos Aires strengthened his hold upon first place in the international chess masters tournament at Mar del Plata, according to a report received from Argentina.

IT is a delight each spring to watch the coiled-up "fiddleheads" unfold as the fresh new ferns come out. For somehow they seem to typify the development that every plant is undergoing at this season of the year.

LONDON, March 26 (Reuters) -- Portsmouth, first division leader in the English League which was favored to take the Football Association Cup this year, was stopped today by Leicester City, a second division team faced with threat of relegation. The score was 3 -- 1.

The ideological conflict between East and West, with its possibilities of war or peace, came under sharp, searching scrutiny yesterday at the second day's sessions of the Cultural and Scientific Conference for World Peace.
Mayor O'Dwyer is scheduled to welcome the thirtieth annual meeting of the American College of Physicians convening tomorrow morning in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

WEST POINT, N. Y., March 26 -- The Cross of the Legion of Honor and the Croix de Guerre with palm were conferred upon the colors of the United States Military Academy today by Lieut. Gen. Georges Marie Joseph Revers, Chief of Staff of the French Army.

Industry has entered the second phase of its top-level personnel reorganization program which began early in January with ousting of "deadwood" executives unable to cope with the return of pre-war competitive conditions, W. Gail Camp disclosed in an interview last week.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 26 -The United Nations Conciliation Commission was said to have begun today a concrete effort with the Syrian delegation to get consideration for a plan for the voluntary resettlement of Arab refugees outside Israel.

Deep in Paraguay are three villages whose 600 residents are living a communal life based upon the Sermon on the Mount. Two members of the communities, Herman C. H. Arnold and Alan J. Stevenson, are on a visit to the United States to explain their way of life to interested groups.

I have what you have not. I am what you are not. I have taken what you have failed to take and I have seized what you could never get. Therefore, you suffer and I am happy; you are despised and I am praised; you die and I live: you are nothing and I am something, and I am all the more something because you are nothing.

SALT LAKE CITY, March 26 -Westerners who have been wondering whether the election of a Republican Governor in Utah would mean a tightening up of state spending received an affirmative answer this week when Gov. J. Bracken Lee trimmed $3,843,800 from the $52,000,000 appropriations bill which was passed by the Democratic-controlled state Legislature.

BURBANK, Calif., March 26 -- The St. Louis Browns have decided not to evict the St. Louis Cardinals from Sportsman's Park pending a court decision on their suit to break the lease. Previously the Browns had said they would file eviction notice April 1.
WASHINGTON, March 26 -- The recent upward trend of unemployment is being checked, if not actually reversed, according to the latest unofficial estimates of Government experts.

BEGINNING readers will flock to "Mrs. Polly's Party." They will be the delighted guests of this friendly old lady who lived alone with her pet cat in a snug little house "at the foot of the mountains," and gave parties for her neighbors' children.

NATIVE opera gets a shot in the arm with the spring season of the New York City Opera Company, which opened last Thursday night. Next Thursday the company gives the first performance of "The Troubled Island" -- that is to say Haiti -- the libretto by Langston Hughes, the music by William Grant Still.
Down at 299 Broadway they've got your number. What's more, if you decide to change it, they'll know what it is before you or anyone else knows it.

Henry Noble Hall, veteran writer and lecturer, died yesterday at 5:10 P. M. in Memorial Hospital, where for several years he had been a voluntary "guinea pig" in the study of cancer. He was 77 years old.

About 7:45 last Friday evening men and women of more than a score of countries sat down to a banquet in the grand ballroom of New York's Waldorf-Astoria. They were delegates to a three-day meeting called the "Cultural and Scientific Conference for World Peace."

MADAME DE STAEL'S indictment of travel as "the saddest of pleasures" is often echoed by the nineteenth-century "rediscoverers" of southern South America, on whose writings Mr. Jones, an Associate Professor of History at the University of Minnesota, has based his book.

A group of five Swedish furniture manufacturers with nine factories and eleven retail stores in Sweden announced plans yesterday to export modern furniture to the United States independently of the Swedish Furniture Manufacturers Export Association.

As an American who has lived in beautiful Buenos Aires for nearly a year and a half, I take exception to parts of "A Survey of the Argentine Mind," by Milton Bracker. Americans have a habit of going into a foreign country with a chip on their shoulders, telling the people they meet how much more wonderful the United States is.

Seeking to retain some vestige of the long - range production schedules that prevailed when fabrics were in short supply, a growing number of textile mills are guaranteeing prices for future delivery. The move, textile men said last week, may exert a stabilizing effect upon the market.

THE ostensibly natural deaths of minister and wife leave the Reverend Martin Buell literally holding the baby. But the problems of this unplanned parenthood recede into unimportance as he realizes that a singularly callous murderer is loose in his small Montana parish.

FROM the first snowdrop to the last May-flowering scilla, bulbs play a leading part in bringing color and interest to the winter and spring garden. A little planning will disclose many spots where different kinds can be planted.

THE first question a returning tourist heard in New York was the same one that was constantly tossed in his direction at every training camp in Florida: What about Joe? No baseball man bothered to add the last name. The DiMaggio part of it was superfluous. With eager solicitude they merely asked after Joe and all of them were obviously disturbed by the answer they received: "Not so good."

SAN FRANCISCO, March 26 -- Stimulated partly by Washington talk of a national prepaid health program, doctors of eight Western states expect to have ready by summer a plan under which millions of persons may join physician-sponsored medical care services on an individual or family basis.

APRIL 20 marks the 117th anniversary of the creation of the first area in the United States to be set aside by act of Congress "as a health and recreation center for the people of the nation for all time." The area known today as Hot Springs National Park, in Arkansas, has since become one of the best-known pleasure and health resorts in the country.

THIS novel by a 36-year-old Jamaican newspaper man attempts to be, in its author's own words, "a tale that will offer as true an impression as fiction can of the way by which Jamaica and its people came to be today." As such, it is disappointing.

SEATTLE, March 26 -- The University of Illinois came from behind to squeeze past Oregon State College tonight, 57 -- 53, and earn third place in the National Collegiate Athletic Association's basketball play-offs. Kentucky battled with Oklahoma A. and M. in the final.

MIAMI BEACH -- Vacationers who must watch their budgets will find the southeast Florida resorts tailored to suit their purses during the spring season which opens April 1. And they won't find much missing from what is offered during the winter months in the way of attractions, entertainment and climate.

Public power proponents last week won their greatest victory since the creation of the Tennessee Valley Authority sixteen years ago. On Wednesday the City Council of Tacoma, Wash., adopted an order for condemnation and acquisition of about $15,000,000 of the property and business of the thirty-seven-year-old Puget Sound Power and Light Company.

" Yoicks! or, The Fox Outfoxed," by Osbert Lancaster, made no reference to one fascinating aspect of English foxhunting, namely, the reports of hunts in the press. The Times, London, for instance, would devote at least one of its broad columns, in solid gray agate, to the previous day's doings of the Pytchley, the Belvoir (Beaver to you ), the Quorn, Mr. Fernie's or another celebrated pack.

Even if military science becomes as mechanized as the American kitchen, the security outposts of any country will be only as strong as the morale of the men who man them, just as the quality of the cake still depends on the cook. The Army, Navy and Air Force men who hold one of this country's important outposts, that of Alaska, could be pardoned if their morale were low.
WASHINGTON, March 26 (UP) -- The new and cheaper Rankin veterans' pension bill appeared tonight to be slated for passage by the House.

WASHINGTON, March 26--House and Senate conferees agreed today on a fifteen-month extension of rent control with a "home rule" clause. This settled one of the last two major conflicts remaining between the bills passed by the respective chambers.

PARIS, March 26 (Reuters) -Mme. Eugenie Cotton, French scientific research worker, and Paul Eluard, poet, protested here today against the refusal of United States authorities to grant visas to them to attend the Cultural and Scientific Conference for World Peace in New York.

To most of us the man who dies of a disease dies a natural death. That is not the way Dr. R. Roessle of the University of Berlin's Pathological Institute looks at it. Death that follows cancer, a stroke or any sickness he considers unnatural.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- Representative Christian A. Herter, Republican, of Massachusetts, member of the House Rules Committee, has demanded a sweeping investigation of United States occupation policies and administration in Germany and Japan.

PHILADELPHIA, March 27 -- A six-point program for schools to follow in developing attitudes for world peace was proposed here today by Dr. William F. Russell, president of Teachers College, Columbia University.
Kentucky's Wildcats and their All-America center, Alex Groza, set or shared seven records in their three-game drive to a second straight N. C. A. A. basketball title.

There are reliable reports from Albany that the Legislature is preparing to rush through, before adjournment, a bill (Int. 3059) which could do considerable damage under the laudable purpose of assuring "the elimination of subversive persons from the public school system."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 27 -- Indicating labor support of the threat, voiced last week by Senator William F. Knowland, Republican, of California, to use renewal of ECA legislation as a basis for investigating British restrictions on the marketing of American motion pictures, the Hollywood AFL Film Council tonight made public a telegram to be sent to Senator Knowland charging that British "discrimination" has cost the jobs of "thousands of American workmelt."
Hospitals in New York will have a shortage of internes starting July 1, it was announced yesterday in the March Bulletin of the Hospital Council of Greater New York.

New York public school teachers must not be "neutral" in presenting American ideals and loyalties to their students, declares a special bulletin being issued today by the Board of Education to all members of the city school system.

WASHINGTON, March 27 (UP) -- The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation reported today that the assets and deposits of its 13,612 insured banks have quadrupled since the corporation was created in 1935.
WASHINGTON, March 27 (UP) -- Defense Secretary James Forrestal today approved consolidation and standardization of Air Force and Naval aviation medical training in one aeromedical center.

Hector Rossetto held first place, with Carlos Guimard second after twenty-one adjourned games from seven of the rounds in the international chess tournament at Mar del Plata had been played off yesterday, according to a report from Argentina.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, March 27 (Reuters) -- The present slump in the world's rubber industry is a hard blow for Ceylon, whose economy is largely dependent on her rubber exports. If the situation worsens, or if no assistance is forthcoming from the Government, rubber plantations on the island may have to close down, putting about 100,000 workers out of their jobs.

The United States Air Force expects to train more aviation cadets as officer pilots this year than in any previous peacetime twelvemonth. The training program has been improved, in order not only to fit pilots more adequately to fly the new, faster jet airplanes, but to indoctrinate the candidates for positions of responsibility in many fields while serving in the Air Force.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -Representative Frederic R. Coudert Jr., Republican, of New York, proposed today that Congress be empowered to determine the extent of representation in the Senate for any new state admitted to the Union.

NEW DELHI, India, March 27 -- An uncomfortable time of decision is at hand for India. To be or not to be in the British Commonwealth is the question, and the conference of Commonwealth Prime Ministers, scheduled to begin in London on April 23, has been called to settle this and no other matter, according to informed sources here.
Many tickets have been purchased for the premiere showing of the motion picture, "Portrait of Jennie," tomorrow night at the Rivoli Theatre for the benefit of the Free Milk Fund for Babies, Inc.

TEL AVIV, Israel, March 27 -- The Israeli Government decided tonight to transfer five of its Ministries to Jerusalem, thereby serving notice on all concerned that the Israeli-controlled area of Jerusalem was considered part of the new state.

A pleasure it was to meet with the exceptional talent and the original attitude toward the music he interpreted of William Masselos, the young man who gave a recital yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall. Mr. Masselos' ideas of program making are his own, as well as his interpretive concepts.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- Stanley Marcus, of the nationally known Dallas, Tex., specialty shop, Nieman-Marcus, received the Chevalier award of the Order of the Legion of Honor at a dinner given for him this evening by Henri Bonnet, French Ambassador.

Leading steamship operators have been asked by the city to work out a plan under which the industry itself would take control of the waterfront public loading system and crush the loading racket, shipping men reported yesterday.

Fine pima cottons in bright colors, and slim, dark basic dresses have brought spring into Gimbels' specialty corner over the week-end. The clothes will be presented officially to the public this evening.

WASHINGTON, March 27 (AP) -Newton B. Drury, Director of the National Park Service, declared today in his annual report that the year had brought increasing pressure to break down park service policies and standards.

ALBANY, March 27 -- If approved by the Legislature, as appears probable, the proposed new formula for state aid to education will increase payments to most school districts in the metropolitan area by 25 to 35 per cent.

On Sunday afternoon, Dec. 16, 1870, Dr. Isaac Mayer Wise, founder of American Reform Judaism, preached the dedicatory sermon at the laying of the cornerstone of the Central Synagogue, Lexington and Fifty-fifth Street.

Thirty-two feature films of more than 300 previewed by film critics representing women's organizations with a combined membership exceeding 20,000,000, were rated as having exceptional merit, the Motion Picture Association of America announced yesterday.

Mushrooms, which three weeks ago were 59 cents a pound, today are 49 cents. The present price, comparatively reasonable, indicates that now is the time to offer this food in a variety of ways that will add interest to everyday and special occasion menus.

In a speech that rivaled the bitterest diatribes of Soviet Foreign Minister Andrei Y. Vishinsky, Dmitri Shostakovich, famous Russian composer, demanded yesterday that "progressive" artists throughout the world lead the fight against "the new aspirants for world domination, now engaged in resurrecting the theory and practice of fascism."
LOS ANGELES, March 27 -- Giant power went all out today to overcome the usual mound short-comings of the Polo Grounders and in the end might triumphed.

Nearly forty new art exhibitions, many of them of outstanding importance, are to open in local museums and galleries this week. On Wednesday the Museum of Modern Art will open its big retrospective exhibition of the work of Georges Braque; on Saturday the Whitney Museum will open its annual exhibition of contemporary American sculpture, water-colors and graphic work.

LONDON, March 27 -- The first reactions in London to the signing of the wheat pact show no particular exuberance for this new deal. Commenting on the agreement, The Financial Times says it is possible that the main importing countries would never have agreed to the terms as they stood if the wheat agreement could have been divorced from outside influences.

Jimmy (Stuffy) Montgomery, 14, of Hot Springs, Ark., a lad who never thought much about becoming a railroad engineer, realized the dream of countless other youngsters yesterday when he "took over" the controls of the New York Central's Knickerbocker from Harmon into Grand Central Terminal.

The gathering in Washington of Foreign Ministers to sign the Atlantic Pact will be a made-to-order occasion for a thoroughgoing and dispassionate review of Western policy on Germany. Such a discussion, based on the experience of four years of occupation and the present mutilation of Europe, unforeseen when this policy was made, is long overdue.

Almost 9,000 persons went to the City Center for the three operas of the first week-end of the New York City Opera Company's spring season. They were rewarded by well-rounded performances that had dramatic conviction and plenty of spirit.

The sixteenth annual sale of Easter Seals to help raise funds for the nation's more than 28,000,000 handicapped is under way. The drive is sponsored by the National Society for Crippled Children and Adults and a goal of $7,000,000 has been set.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, March 27 -- By international agreement, the whaling season in the Antarctic ended last midnight. There is confirmation that the total catch was relatively large, although not record breaking.

"The Quiet One," the. film drama now in the seventh week of its premiere engagement here at the Little Carnegie Theatre, has been voted the winner of the first annual award, for "creative achievement in documentary films," by the City College Film Institute.

SEATTLE, March 27 (AP) -- Back to the blue grass state goes the national collegiate basketball championship -- won by a great University of Kentucky team that broke the heart of the fighting Oklahoma Aggies last night, 46-36.

Aluminum, Ltd. and consolidated subsidiaries, leaders in the aluminum industry outside the United States, attained new peacetime records in 1948 with sales of $208,645,068 and net earnings of $27,329,642, equal to $7.34 a share on the 3,722,050 shares outstanding, the report for the year, issued today, discloses.

CHICAGO, March 27 -- Liquidation developed in the lard market on the Board of Trade last week, prices declining to within striking distance of the low level of Feb. 10, when loose lard was quoted at 10 1/2 cents a pound. At one time last week it was offered at 10 7/8 cents.

CAIRO, Egypt, March 14 -- Egypt's suffragettes, who are in the process of organizing an active woman's rights party, have stirred up something.
