The excitement created here, where the veil is still seen frequently but were the modern woman is also in evidence, has shown how strong Oriental tradition remains, despite skyscrapers, glittering modern cars and the other outward signs of the changing East.

Delegates from the Soviet Union and its satellites to the "cultural conference" are unable to voice their own opinions under penalty of forfeiting their lives, it was asserted yesterday in a resolution adopted by the newly organized Russian League for People's Freedom.
PITTSBURGH, Monday, March 28 (AP) -- Coal was dug by members of the United Mine Workers east of the Mississippi today for the first time in two weeks.

Declaring that the national administration had abandoned the concept of a One World peace advocated by Wendell L. Willkie and Franklin D. Roosevelt, Henry A. Wallace called yesterday upon his hearers to urge the members of the United States Senate to reject the North Atlantic Pact.

With sales of soap to consumers rapidly reaching the saturation point and synthetic detergents coming into wider use, soap manufacturers face the "keenest competition in years," according to a report on the soap market called Market Trends for Packaged Soaps, Synthetic Detergents and Laundry Bar Soaps, issued over the week-end by the Bureau of Advertising of the American Newspaper Publishers Association.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 27 -- Borba, official newspaper of the Yugolsav Communist party, continued today its allegations of attempts by the Communist Information Bureau to infiltrate Yugoslavia's frontiers with an announcement that the Yugoslav security police had arrested many spies who had penetrated Yugoslav territory from Albania with the intent to commit acts of espionage, sabotage and terrorism.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., March 27 (AP) -- Tornadic winds which swept through six Southern states over the week-end left at least twenty-eight persons dead, scores injured and hundreds homeless. There was untold property damage.

Frances Chesno, violinist, assisted at the piano by Otto Herz, gave a sonata recital yesterday afternoon at Times Hall. The works performed comprised Mozart's Sonata in B flat major (K. 454); Brahms' Sonata in A major; Beethoven's Sonata in G major, Op. 30, No. 3, and the Sonata in D minor by Schumann.
Fifteen thousand men, women and children, in picturesque garb of ancient and modern Greece, paraded up Fifth Avenue yesterday afternoon in celebration of the 128th anniversary of Greek independence.

A concert version of Strauss' rarely performed opera "Elektra" and Mahler's Eighth Symphony, scored for outsize orchestra and a chorus of 1,000 voices, will be features of the Philharmonic-Symphony's next season, it was announced yesterday.
SAULT STE. MARIE, Mich., March 27 -- The New York Rovers defeated the Sault Ste. Marie Indians, 7 -- 6, today and captured a semi-final berth in the Amateur Hockey Association play-offs.

Although Consolidated Natural Gas Company had record high sales and revenues last year, the increased income was not sufficient to offset higher costs, F. H. Lerch Jr., president, reported to stockholders yesterday. Net income for the year was $12,265,714, equal to $3.75 a share of capital stock, compared with $14,769,652, or $4.51 a share in the previous year.

Col. William A. Roberts, Washington, D. C. attorney, who is soliciting proxies in opposition to the management of the Pittsburgh Steel Company, is seeking election to its board of directors, it was announced over the week-end.

While Soviet spokesmen at a leftwing rally in New York proclaimed their devotion to liberty, democracy and peace and accused the West of "fascism, warmongering and planned aggression," the Soviet Government by its deeds provided a commentary on their meeting that spoke far louder than their words.

CHICAGO, March 27 (AP) -- Ch. Charles River Color Sergeant, a 7-year-old Irish setter owned by Mrs. Frank Cory of Arlington Heights, Ill., tonight won best-of-show honors at the International Kennel Club show.
Three legal cases now pending, any one of which can have revolutionary effect on the liquor industry here, were being watched closely at the week's end.
BOWIE, Md., March 27 (AP) -- Maryland's earliest and shortest spring horse racing season starts tomorrow at Bowie's track in the "southern pines."
LARCHMONT, N. Y., March 27 -- Thirty-six dinghies swept through seven races today in the regatta at the Larchmont Yacht Club.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 27 -- Strikes and demonstrations have taken place in the Syrian port city of Latakia against the Government's decision to enter armistice negotiations with the Israelis and against its participation in conversations regarding peace in Palestine.

The domestic cotton market continued to be dull last week with price changes insignificant. At the close on Saturday active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were 1 point lower to 16 higher than the week before. In the preceding week prices were unchanged to 13 points net higher.

ALBANY, March 9-7--Spring examinations for admission to the[ state teachers' colleges preparing .general elementary teachers s. nd teachers of certain special subjects will be held April 2, the State Education Department announced today .

Dr. Arthur Upham Pope, in a letter printed in THE TIMES of Feb. 26, 1949, made certain remarks about an unnamed claimant against the Iranian Government. Dr. Pope accused this claimant of using methods that "savor of pressure," "in the hope of harassing and embarrassing the Persian Government until out of sheer annoyance it will purchase peace by agreeing to unjust demands."

Most people watch the expiration of March and the coming of sweet April with satisfaction, but there are those who regard the lengthening of days and the sun's increasing warmth with little enthusiasm.

Warmer weather spurred activity in the wholesale apparel market here last week, according to reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices. Buyers were mainly interested in Easter merchandise and print, cotton and formal dresses.
Three and a half million workers now enjoy the protection of union-sponsored health, welfare or retirement plans, with their employers paying all or most of the bill.
Ralph W. Sterling has been appointed director of sales and assistant to the president of Palm, Fechteler Co., decalcomania designer and manufacturer,

ALBANY, March 27 -- The Dewey Administration may seek to make the pending disability benefit bill a Republican party measure in an effort to corral enough votes to insure its approval by the legislature over solid Democratic opposition, it appeared tonight.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- The most urgent legislative meeting tomorrow on Capitol Hill will be a morning session of the Joint Conference Committee that is trying to reach agreement on the bill to extend rent control.

Spring weather that verged on summer attracted hundreds of thousands to metropolitan beaches yesterday and kept traffic on main arteries around the city fairly heavy. City parks had sizable crowds, and playgrounds were thronged with baseball and handball players.

Eighteen thousand persons made their way through a noisy, militant picket line into Madison Square Garden last night to attend the final session of the three-day Cultural and Scientific Conference for World Peace.

Bobby Jahn of the home club and Miss Mary Lynch of the Newburgh Skating Club captured the major titles at the Eastern States indoor speed skating championships at the Brooklyn Ice Palace last night. The competition was held under the auspices of the Middle Atlantic Skating Association.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- Rexford Guy Tugwell, an original New Deal "brain-truster" and chairman of the Platform Committee at the Henry A. Wallace Progressive party convention in Philadelphia last July, admitted today that Communists were prominent in the Progressive convention and campaign and said that he should have left the party last August.

The bitter old saying of the disappointed private flyer -- "If you've time to spare, go by air" -- was reversed emphatically here yesterday by two young musicians, Mona Paulee, mezzosoprano, and her pilot-accompanist-husband, Dean Holt, veteran of the Air Transport Command, told how they had never missed a concert in two years' travel in their Beech Bonanza, but had been able to fill in for other musicians delayed on concert engagements for other reasons.

LAKE SUCCESS, March 27 -- Although the spring session of the United Nations General Assembly will open on April 5, the United States. Britain and France have not yet agreed upon a complete program for the disposition of the former Italian colonies in Africa, it was revealed today.

It will be the East's top amateur boxers against the best of the West tonight when the twenty-second annual Golden Gloves intercity bouts are staged at Madison Square Garden. Sixteen battles are scheduled on a program figured to produce the keenest kind of action.

Three friends of Dominick San Antonio, held for killing a patrolman and wounding two others after fleeing late Saturday from the holdup of an Astoria, Queens, liquor store, were rounded up yesterday by the police and charged with violation of the Sullivan Law.

GREENSBORO, N. C., March 27 (AP) -- Defending champion Lloyd Mangrum of Chicago birdied the final hole to tie Sammy Snead of White Sulphur Springs, W. Va., for first place at 276 today in the $10,000 Greensboro open golf tournament.
Yesterday was Red Cross Day in Chinatown. Women and children carrying collection cans toured the entire area, using the Chinese phrase "kun jor" as their motto. It means "give."

CHICAGO, March 27 -- More than 2,000 persons today witnessed the dedication of a new $18,000 "dream" home for Roberta Lee Mason, 14-year-old heroine who saved the lives of her four younger brothers and sisters when fire destroyed their former home three miles southeast of Des Plaines Ill., Feb. 17.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, March 27 -- The opinion that Turkey should follow a policy of armed neutrality appears to be gaining support in the press and among political circles in the country since it was voiced recently in the official organ Ulus.

Claudio Arrau's piano recital last night at Carnegie Hall was one of the outstanding events of the current music season. In a lengthy and formidable program, the artist, who was in top form, provided his large audience with a series of performances of the first rank, maintaining the highest level of attainment in all of his offerings.

A syndicate represented by Edward Sulzberger, broker, has purchased two five-story apartment houses, with a total of thirty suites, at 511-15 West 138th Street, in the vicinity of City College, in a deal negotiated by Pearce Mayer, brokers. The property is assessed for $66,000 and was sold for cash over a mortgage, due in November, 1957. The plot is 75 by 100 feet.

George Fielding Eliot's new book, "If Russia Strikes -- ," will be published by Bobbs-Merrill on April 18. The book deals with what might happen in case of war in the immediate future, analyzing the weapons and methods available today and the effectiveness of American air-atomic power.

Limited coeducational instruction through joint classes is being considered for students of Columbia University's Barnard and Columbia Colleges, as well as the School of General Studies, according to the annual report of Dr. Harry J. Carman, dean of Columbia College, made public yesterday.
BERLIN, March 27 -- A Soviet army captain writing in the army's official German - language newspaper said today that the Soviet Union would invade western Europe in the event of a war.

In a documentary broadcast commemorating Army Day, NBC's 'Living -- 1949" series will encircle the globe to give on-the-spot reports of the nation's soldiers at home and abroad. Entitled "The Ramparts We Watch," the documentary will be presented over the NBC network next Sunday at 12:05 P. M. and will be rebroadcast locally over WNBC on Saturday, April 9, at 2:05 P. M.

The Broadway stage is beckoning Menasha Skulnik, who is recognized as a top ranking Yiddish comic. Mr. Skulnik said yesterday he is planning to take a leave of a year or two from the Yiddish theatre to make his Broadway debut next season.

DENVER, March 27 (AP) -- Regis of Denver, St. Francis of Brooklyn and Loyola of Baltimore dominated the all-tournament team selected by sports reporters covering the National Catholic Invitational Basketball competition which ended last night.

HAMPTON, Va., March 27 -- Private colleges for Negroes in the South are being hard pressed to maintain standards in salaries, equipment and housing with Government-financed institutions, school authorities said here today. State colleges have attracted many department heads and specialists with offers of better salaries and perquisites, they said.
Seven films, including arrivals from England and Italy, will open in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:

The Joint Distribution Committee, major American agency aiding distressed Jews abroad, announced yesterday in its annual report that it spent $70,600,700 last year on relief, resettlement and reconstruction in behalf of nearly 700,000 Jews in other countries.

Three attractive wood-frame houses, which would provide the answer to a home-starved veteran's prayers, are nearing completion at what is probably the most unusual building project in the city. But the irony of it is this: once completed, the buildings will have to be torn down.

The greatest task of the church in the next twenty-five years is the responsibility of converting the threat of destruction by the atom bomb into a promise of a united world, Dr. Donald Hatch Andrews, Professor of Chemistry at Johns Hopkins University in Baltimore, declared here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- The American Red Cross, now setting up a $250,000 program for relief to Indians made destitute by blizzards in four states, today urged the country to succor the Navajos and Hopis in Arizona and New Mexico.

The accidental discharge of an automatic pistol with which two boys were playing resulted yesterday in the fatal shooting of one of them, Joseph Roberts Jr., 12 years old, of 105 Hawthorne Street, Brooklyn.

Cardinal Spellman celebrated pontifical mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday, marking the opening of the thirtieth annual New York Catholic Charities Fund appeal in the 376 parishes of the archdiocese.

Mayor O'Dwyer's executive budget for the fiscal year beginning July 1 will be the largest in the city's history but will be balanced without resort to any new special taxes, it was learned last night. It will be the Mayor's third successive budget to pass the $1,000,000,000 mark.
SAN FRANCISCO, Calif., March 27 (AP) -- Cleveland's Indians, given superlative pitching that allowed only one earned run in eighteen innings, won two contests from Pacific Coast League clubs today.
Commercial selling of spot sterling last Friday depressed the rate to $4.03 1/16, lowest in a month, and was easily the most surprising incident of the week in the foreign exchanges.

ACCORDING to Albert Payson Terhune the dog is a noble animal. The noted author would as soon kick his favorite collie as say a disparaging word about any of his canine friends. But they can be pretty dumb, too. Ten times a night at the St. Petersburg Kennel Club, the oldest operating dog track in the country, eight greyhounds pursue a mechanical rabbit around the quarter-mile course.

BERNARD SHAW, who lists his recreation in "Who's Who" as "being past 90," is the author of nearly fifty plays. Less generally realized is the fact that he is also the author of nearly thirty other books, which range from such heavy barrages of Shaviana as "The Intelligent Woman's Guide to Socialism and Capitalism" to long-forgotten pamphlets on Fabianism.

Two thousand pickets, as noisy and militant as those usually assembled in behalf of a left-wing cause, marched outside of Madison Square Garden last night to register their opposition to the Cultural and Scientific Conference for World Peace.

A week-long police hunt for the slayer of Benjamin Klein, a tombstone setter, at 245 East Houston Street, ended last night. Assistant Chief Inspector Conrad Rothengast, in charge of detectives, said one of two suspects picked up earlier in the day had confessed, accusing the other of being his accomplice.

ZURICH, Switzerland, March 27 -- Consistently rising quotations in Zurich all last week for the bank notes of most leading European countries convinced experts in Switzerland that, in consequence of the operation of the Marshall Plan a strong general upward monetary trend has set in.

The "tax on beauty" -- as manufacturers have designated the 20 per cent levy on cosmetics, jewelry, handbags and furs -- will be in for a rough time in Congress this session if the current plans of trade groups have their hoped-or results.

Net profits after all charges, but before dividend payments, of all member banks in the Second Federal Reserve District averaged 7.0 per cent of total capital accounts in 1948, Allan Sproul, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, said in a report to be issued today. The figure compares with 8.1 per cent in 1947.

The Cultural and Scientific Conference for World Peace, which ended a three-day session at Madiso Square Garden last night, was described yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Norman Vincent Peale as a "propaganda effort" and "not an honest intellectual adventure."

WASHINGTON, March 27 (UP) -- Senator Milton R. Young, Republican, of North Dakota, accused the Department of Agriculture today of adding "needless millions" to the cost of its price support program by refusing to pay higher prices for rye.

VERO BEACH, Fla., March 27 -- The two no-hit kids, Dick Fowler of the Athletics and Rex Barney of the Dodgers, hooked up in a nine-inning duel here this afternoon and came up to the final frame with each having allowed the same number of hits, three, and score tied at 1 -- 1.

A permanent "action committee" was created yesterday by the Cultural and Scientific Conference for World Peace to carry out decisions reached at the three-day international meeting that had been denounced by the State Department and that was heavily picketed by opponents of Soviet Russia.
In the recent anti-filibuster fight there were three factions in the Senate: the Dixiecrats, the Democrats and the Republicans.

By the end of the present year, with good luck, the Jewish Displaced Persons camps in Europe may be practically empty. This is the hopeful prospect held out in the annual report of the Joint Distribution Committee, made public this morning. Earlier estimates of rapid progress are thus confirmed.

MOSCOW, March 27 -- The Lapland wolf hunt that has received considerable attention in the Soviet press was presented today in much more serious terms by the Soviet Army's organ, Red Star, which charged the expedition had been designed with the collaboration of Norwegian and Finnish military authorities, as well as United States and British military intelligence representatives.

LONDON, March 27 -- Another important step toward formation of a Council of Europe will be taken tomorrow when the Ambassadors of ten nations of Western Europe open a conference at the Foreign Office. This will be the first meeting in which powers outside the Brussels pact will formally discuss Europe's next stage on the thorny path toward unity.

PARIS, Monday, March 28 -- The French Communists sustained a crushing defeat yesterday in the cantonal elections, while the Cabinet's coalition parties held the lead they took March 20 on the first balloting.
WASHINGTON, March 27 (UP) -Secretary of Agriculture Charles F. Brannan may be asked soon to set up minimum quality standards for new canned frozen orange juice, officials said today.
The Brooklyn Hispanos defeated the Kearny Celtics, 4 to 3, in an American Soccer League contest at Hawthorne Field, yesterday.

PITTSBURGH, March 27 -- The nation's steel industry operated last week at 102 per cent of rated capacity, unchanged from the week before. Operations since the first of the year have established a record which is expected to stand for some time.

EDMONTON, Alberta, March 27 -- A message from inside the Arctic Circle tonight told of the rescue of seven United States airmen from the barren waste of Ellesmere Island, some 850 miles northeast of the magnetic pole.

There isn't much real wilderness left in the United States. Some of what there is lies in the Quetico-Superior area, which straddles the boundaries of Minnesota and Ontario, about two million acres of roadless land set in the heart of about 15,000 square miles of forest and park.

LONDON, March 27 -- The shadow of the Government's Economic Survey has lifted from the stock markets in the last week, but only to be replaced by that of the impending budget, due now in little more than a week. The effect has been to keep the markets extremely idle and rather heavy.

A record volume of business handled last year by Time, Inc., produced the largest gross and net income in twenty-five years, Roy E. Larsen, president and Maurice T. Moore, chairman, informed shareholders in the annual report being distributed today.

WASHINGTON, March 27 (AP) -Military preparedness and economic security require intensified research and exploration to assist the domestic mineral industries in becoming stronger, the Bureau of Mines said today.

ROME, March 27 -- By 188 votes to 112, with eight abstentions, the Senate confirmed tonight its confidence in Premier Alcide de Gasperi's Government and authorized it to negotiate Italy's adherence to the North Atlantic treaty. Communist Senators expressed their feelings at the end of the sitting by singing "The Internationale" and "The Red Flag."

The fifteen new designs in table accessories that Steuben Glass, 718 Fifth Avenue, is introducing today should see frequent use in the home, for they are either simple in form, small in scale or both. Several of the pieces have ornamental touches either toward the base or toward the tops, such as in decanter stoppers, where delicate spiral twists or bubbles within the crystal point up the simplicity of the shapes.

WASHINGTON, March 27 (UP) -- President Truman today did as he had asked all other Americans to do -- attended church in connection with an inter-denominational fund-raising offering for overseas relief.

It is a good thing to find something on New York's calendar every once in a while that serves to remind us of the constant vigil we should all keep to avoid accidents. Such an event is the forthcoming annual Safety Convention and Exposition to be held at the Hotel Statler for the four days beginning Tuesday.

ST. LOUIS, March 27 -- The threat of floods in the Missouri River Valley as the result of record snowfalls and blizzards early this year has been sharply reduced within the last four weeks, according to Maj. Gen. Lewis A. Pick, chief of the Corps of Army Engineers.
DETROIT, March 27 -- The dream of a post-war $1,000 "standard-size" automobile is causing great interest in Detroit as a result of the return of a competitive market.

CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa, March 27 -- Grant W. Oakes today was re-elected, by acclamation, as international president of the United Farm Equipment Workers, CIO. He has headed the UFEW since its organization in 1938.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- A major obstacle to constructive maritime legislation is the inability of the shipping industry to agree on what it needs, according to Representative Schuyler Otis Bland, veteran Democratic member of Congress from Virginia, who is chairman of the House Committee on Merchant Marine and Fisheries.
WASHINGTON, March 27 -- The votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls during the period March 19 to 25 are given in the appended tabulation:

NOTRE DAME, Ind., March 27 -- Irene Dunne, motion-picture actress, was announced today as the 1949 recipient of the Laetare Medal, awarded annually since 1883 by the University of Notre Dame to the outstanding member of the Roman Catholic laity in the United States.

Brewery workers voted yesterday by acclamation to request their international officers for authority to take a strike vote that would empower local leaders of the union to call a city-wide beer strike sometime after Friday.
After long negotiations the often reported merger of Lloyd's Register of Shipping and the British Corporation Register of Shipping has been concluded, it was announced yesterday.

Unless the Government "goes into the hovels of the poor," cleans the slums and sees that every one gets an equal opportunity, "we are sowing a seed of communism that will some day destroy us," Mayor O'Dwyer declared yesterday.

New York motorists will pay about 33 per cent over pre-war prices for the annual spring renovating of their cars this year, according to estimates yesterday by the Automobile Club of New York. The over-all expenditure for this type of work is expected to exceed $6,400,000.

Robert Schrade, a young pianist who is gifted with fingers of unusual strength and accuracy, made his Town Hall debut late yesterday afternoon. A sizable audience gathered for the recital, and applauded fervently.
Henry Payne (Hank) Iba, Oklahoma A. M. master strategist, yesterday was named "coach of the year" in the third annual balloting of the Metropolitan Basketball Writers Association.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- The National Labor Relations Board further defined its own jurisdiction today by refusing to take a building industry case involving a $33,000-a-year business. Four board members took three different views of the matter.
SUN VALLEY, Idaho, March 27 (AP) -- Two great French skiers won the Harriman Cup ski races today. They both won the downhill races yesterday and swept the slalom today.
WASHINGTON, March 27 (AP) -J. A. Krug, Secretary of the Interior, said today that communism "had fallen completely flat" in American overseas possessions.

The former Canadian Navy frigate Hollowell is scheduled to leave the Todd Shipyards Corporation's Brooklyn yard today after a three-week stay, during which ten new Todd-manufactured oil burners have been installed and miscellaneous repairs made to prepare the 1,400-ton vessel for a transatlantic voyage.

LONDON, March 27 -- Praise for United States idealism as exemplified by economic aid came today from one of Britain's most fervent socialists, Attorney General Sir Hartley Shawcross. Speaking at Swansea, Wales, he said:

Your editorial "The Courts Bill at Albany," in the March 14 issue of THE TIMES, urges prompt passage of the Williamson-Brook bill "so that a start may be made to reorganize an outmoded court structure along modern lines to meet more adequately the people's needs."

NASSAU, Bahamas, March 27 -- The first race in the International Star Class open series today for the Johnnie Walker Cup was won by Lockwood Pirie of Chicago with Twin Star. He led from the start and finished about a minute and a half in front. Twenty started.

TAMPA, Fla., March 27 (AP) -- The Cincinnati Reds returned to the victory column here today, walloping the National League champion Boston Braves, 13 to 4, in an old-fashioned slugfest feattured by two five-run innings for the Cicinnatians.

ALBANY, March 27 (ZI--A 53 per cent increase in welfare costs in New York State nce 1945 was reported today by the Special Legislative Committee on Social Welfare. The committee gave no figures on the comparat/ve welfare costs but attributedthe rise in part to inflation.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 27 -- By remote control Eddie Dyer learned here today that his Cardinals had shut out the Yankees, 1 -- 0, for their tenth victory in the citrus circuit.

MOSCOW, March 27 -- From the farthest corners of the Soviet Union members of the Komsomols -- Soviet organization of youths between the ages of 15 and 26 -- are assembling in Moscow for the first All-Union Congress in thirteen years which opens Tuesday.

Four alleged safe-crackers whose distaste for burglar alarms led them to dig through two wood and concrete floors to get at the safe of a Brooklyn jewelry store were arrested early yesterday by a squad of policemen who had kept an all-night watch on the burrowing operation. A fifth man who the police said was a lookout for the four and who apparently got bored with his job, was picked up later.

A proposal that the partially completed $250,000 Park Avenue lighting project be replaced by a new system in which sidewalk lights would be substituted for the present grass strip standards has been forwarded to Mayor O'Dwyer by the Municipal Art Society, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- National security and the country's standard of living depend on an all-out program of resource development, especially in the fields of synthetic fuels and water power, Julius A. Krug, Secretary of the Interior, declared today.

Two new films will arrive in midtown theatres today. At the Rivoli, the attraction is "Portrait of Jennie," a romantic fantasy produced by David O. Selznick, with Jennifer Jones, who plays the title role; Joseph Cotten and Ethel Barrymore featured.
WASHINGTON, March 28 -- Here is a comparison of the major provisions of the present rent law with the main sections of the compromise rent bill approved today by a Senate-House conference committee:

WASHINGTON, March 28 (AP) -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson has decided to give a free hand generally to the experienced United States delegation at the forthcoming session of the United Nations General Assembly.

With $1,000,000 received in the last two weeks, the 1949 Red Cross campaign in this city has raised since March 1 more than $2,500,000 of its goal of $4,635,000, Brig. Gen. E. F. Jeffe, chairman of the fund, reported yesterday.

ATHENS, March 28 -- A defeat of a Communist-led army on a scale almost equal to that sustained earlier in the year at Florina and Kerdyllia was reported in today's General Staff communique. This was based upon advices from the battle area in the Tzoumerka Mountains, which form part of the southern Pindus range.

Westinghouse Electric Corporation yesterday announced immediate suggested list price reductions ranging from 20 to 50 per cent on nine radio models. J. F. Walsh, sales manager of the home radio division, who made the announcement, placed the maximum cut at $130 on two AM-FM radio-phonograph console combinations.
WASHINGTON,, March 28 -- Leading communications experts called on American business today to make "company and personal sacrifices" to help the country prepare for a national emergency.

Those planning a fishing trip to New England for the landlock, squaretail or togue seasons will not want to leave without a copy of Gene Letourneau's "Secrets of Streamer Fly Fishing," which is just off the press.

MOSCOW, March 28 -- Pravda's millions of readers learned today that the Cultural and Scientific Conference for World Peace met in New York under conditions of unprecedented interest despite efforts by American reactionary circles to stir up hysteria against progressive peoples' leaders participating in the assembly.

LONDON, March 28 -- A Government spokesman declined in the house of Commons today to give an assurance that Britain's meat ration, which is now lower than ever before, could be maintained even at the present level for the next four months.

HAMPTON, Va., March 28 -Hampton Institute, which was founded in 1868 by Samuel Chapman Armstrong, Civil War general, reported today marked interest in its division of trades and industries. About 500 students, mainly men, are enrolled in the division, twenty-eight in printing.

Directors of Ferd. Mulhens, Inc., have elected Oscar C. Olin as president and Harold E. Horowitz as chairman of the board, it was announced yesterday by the company, makers of "4711" toilet preparations.
WASHINGTON, March 28 -- Democratic leaders of the House began today to plan for a long Eastern holiday for that chamber, but the word was passed that the Senate would stay on the job.

In your issue of March 10 appeared a letter by the former Rumanian Minister Edmond Ciuntu, in which he endeavors to present an explanation and analysis of the difference between the number of Jewish inhabitants of prewar Rumania -- 750,000 -- and the surviving 400,000.
Alarming health conditions throughout up-state New York were brought to light yesterday by the American Academy of Pediatrics in a critical report based on a thirteen-month investigation.
PHILADELPHIA, March 28 -- A sharp attack on the United States Chamber of Commerce and other "tax-fighting groups" was made here today by leading American educators.
WASHINGTON, March 28 -- Count Carlo Sforza, Italian Foreign Minister, arrived at Washington tonight. He said he would be glad to sign the North Atlantic pact "becaues it means peace."

A strike of 1,500 warehousemen and maintenance workers yesterday tied up sixteen of the port's warehouses in Brooklyn, Staten Island and New Jersey, halting the distribution of an estimated $100,000,000 worth of goods.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- Pan American Airways today challenged the right of James M. Landis, former chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board, to request board records of which he allegedly knows only because of his former position for use as a private attorney in a case before the board.
Governor Dewey was described yesterday as the "founding father" of legalized wiretapping in New York.

WASHINGTON, March 28 (UP) -- The United States has slammed the door on Russia's demand for the release of Valentin Gubitchev, Soviet employe of the United Nations accused as a spy, a State Department spokesman said today.

It is frequently asserted that mere force can never conquer an ideology. but it can be stated with greater confidence that the mere possession of adequate military strength may well prevent the use of force by such a country as Russia in order to drive her ideology of communism into other nations.

WASHINGTON, March 28 (AP) -The Supreme Court decided today that activities of the Women's Sportswear Manufacturers Association of Boston violate the Sherman Anti-Trust Act. Justice Jackson delivered the unanimous decision.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- The seven German women who started a tour of the United States in New York on Feb. 19 under the auspices of the National League of Women Voters arrived here today. Their ten-day stay in the city is nicely timed for the blooming of the cherry trees along the Potomac.
WASHINGTON, March 28 (AP) -- The first shipments of surplus arms that Iran is buying from the United States are now being delivered to Persian Gulf ports, diplomatic officials said today.
An experiment in learning "how the other faith worships" has just been completed by a group of six students at Teachers College, Columbia University, it became known yesterday.

ALBANY, March 28 -- Governor Dewey announced tonight that he would refuse to approve removal of Federal rent controls from any part of the state "except upon the clearest proof that controls are neither necessary nor desirable."

BOSTON. March 28 (AP) -- Sales of the Bigelow-Sanford Carpet Company for the first quarter of the year are expected to be 6 per cent less than last year's $20,702,854, James D. Wise, president, reported today.

A device that makes machines shout warnings to careless workers, speaks to smokers in fire zones and may be used to call out to jaywalkers or motorists had its first showing yesterday at the Statler Hotel.

A year ago next Sunday President Truman signed the E.R.P. authorization bill, describing it as "America's answer to the challenge facing the free world." Now a new authorization for a second installment of aid to Europe is about to pass the Senate and will come up in the House tomorrow.

Judge Harold M. Kennedy in Federal Court, Brooklyn, denied yesterday the petitions of four organizations to intervene in the bankruptcy proceedings involving the Long Island Rail Road. At the same time the court admitted, as general parties in the action, three banking institutions and the Pennsylvania Railroad as creditors and trustees.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- Fred M. Howser. Attorney General of California, filed suit here today in the Federal District Court against Drew Pearson, columnist and radio commentator, asking $300,000 damages for broadcasting "untrue, false and defamatory" statements.

The Theatre Guild has decided to sponsor next season William McCleery's latest play, "Good Housekeeping," in which Helen Hayes will play the starring role and in which her daughter. Mary MacArthur, also will have a part. The decision ended once and for all various conjectures concerning the organization's willingness to undertake the project.
Four men were arrested yesterday in Brooklyn on wiretapping charges after telephone evidence was offered in a divorce case. One of the four was the plaintiff-husband.

LAKE SUCCESS, March 28 -- Romulo Betancourt, former President of Venezuela, today communicated to United Nations delegations a letter of protest accusing the present Venezuelan regime of violating human rights, destroying freedom of the press and employing the "Hitlerian system of holding hostages."

NEW DELHI, India, March 28 -- United Nations observers who went to western Kashmir to investigate the rebel "Azad" (Free) Kashmir administration of that disputed territory found a normally functioning Government there with only few Pakistani advisers, one of the observers reported on his return here yesterday.
The Alleghany Corporation reported yesterday for 1948 a net income, exclusive of security transactions, of $3,925,952 after charges and taxes. This compared with $1,835,599 in 1947.

Milton Berle will appear over NBC television for fourteen hours on Saturday, April 9, in an effort to raise money for the Damon Runyon Memorial Cancer Fund. He will first come before the NBC cameras at noon, and will work his way into every show being aired over the Eastern and Midwestern networks during the course of the day.

WASHINGTON, March 28 (AP) -- A. L. Cole, general business manager of Reader's Digest, Pleasantville, N. Y., told the House Post Office Committee today that proposed increases in second class postal rates would "far exceed profits" of his magazine.

CHICAGO, March 28 (UP) -- Federal Judge Alter J. Labuy today signed a consent judgment by which eighteen screw companies agreed to end manufacturing and marketing agreements which the Government charged were in violation of anti-trust laws.

Donald Harrington, 34-year-old associate minister of the Community Church, was named last night to succeed John Haynes Holmes, pastor since 1907. Mr. Harrington was elected by a rising vote of the congregation at a special meeting in the church building at 40 East Thirty-fifth Street.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., March 28 -- Ten town Supervisors in Westchester, representing a population of 54,652 out of the county's 600,000, are controlling the forty-four-man Board of Supervisors in a continuing fiscal discrimination against villages, Supervisor Gordon Miller of Pelham Township charged today at a board meeting.

NANKING, March 28 -- Already plagued by mounting economic difficulties and internal political fissures, the Nationalist Government is now being kept off balance militarily by continuing Communist forays against its bridgeheads on the upper (northern) bank of the Yangtze River and by intensified unrest in South China.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- Registration statements covering $10,000,000 of bonds, 200,000 shares of preferred and 882,991 shares of common stock were filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission by four companies.

Wool futures recovered moderately yesterday on buying by Boston dealers and short covering by commission houses. Offerings were limited. Wool top contracts closed at net advances of 1.2 to 2 cents a pound on sales of 225,000 pounds. Grease wool futures were up 1.5 to 2 cents a pound, with transactions amounting to 72,000 pounds.

In 1938 permanent personal registration of voters in New York State was made permissive by constitutional amendment, but the Legislature has never made it effective. About a month ago, in renewing our support of this reform in voting machinery, we asked whether it would not be possible to bring out some compromise providing for a test run to see how the system worked.

The remains of Paranthropus Crassidens, a man who was eaten by a tiger 1,000,000 years ago in a small and damp limestone cave in the side of a hill near what is now known as Pretoria in the Union of South Africa, were brought to the Northern Hemisphere yesterday afternoon for the first time by Dr. Robert Broom, a noted 32-year-old Scottish zoologist.

David E. Lilienthal, chairman of the United States Atomic Energy Commission, and Dr. S. A. Waksman, Professor of Microbiology at Rutgers University and discoverer of life-saving antibiotics, including streptomycin and neomycin, were among the eleven winners of Page One Awards named yesterday by a jury of fourteen members of the Newspaper Guild of New York.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- America might as well "throw away its high hopes for enduring prosperity and peace if we and other countries, working together, can't create economic stability," William L. Batt, vice chairman of the Advisory Committee on Foreign Aid of the State Department, said today.

The Cultural and Scientific Conference for World Peace has now finished its meetings in our city. As far as we can observe world peace is about where it was before these meetings started. On the other hand, the fears with which some of our citizens seem to have been afflicted have not been realized.

BELLEAIRE, Fla., March 28 -- Speakers at the Institute on Industrial Relations today warned industry's management and personnel men that the first defense of the free enterprise system must be made within their own plants, with their own workers.

Kathleen Ferrier, the attractive young British contralto, was in a difficult position last night. Not only did she have to give her first New York recital on top of orchestral successes and a big build up, but in making her bow at Town Hall she had to face an audience so large that it overflowed onto the stage.

A consolidated net income of $16,127,753 was shown in 1948 by the Greyhound Corporation. compared with $17,243,563 the year before, according to the annual report issued yesterday for publication today.

The United Mine Workers welfare and retirement fund, most ambitious of all union welfare projects, is paying out $2,000,000 a week in benefits to soft-coal miners and their families. The companion fund for hard-coal miners is distributing another $200,000 a week in pensions, death and disability payments and medical fees.
SEATTLE, March 28 (AP) -- Basketball's rule makers hit at defensive tactics of a losing team today by tightening the penalty on fouling in the game's last two minutes.
The Kaiser-Frazer Corporation has completed a major shake-up of top executives and will reduce the prices on its automobiles by $196 to $300 in an effort to stimulate sales, it was learned yesterday.

Dinnerware and tablecloths offered in brown, deep wine and eggplant indicate that color inhibitions in table settings have now been completely set aside, Helen Sprackling, stylist and author, declared last night. She spoke on "Designs for Dining" at the third lecture meeting of the Home Fashions League, following Hensleigh Wedgwood, President of Josiah Wedgwood Sons, Inc., who gave a history of the pottery industry.

Your distinguished newspaper has published stories regarding an appeal made to tile Greek Government on behalf of Emmanuel Glezos, sentenced to death by the Greek Military Courts, by several European and American personalities and organizations. Mr. Glezos, a Greek citizen, was described as a democratic citizen and a journalist.

The city's entry into a somewhat higher-priced housing field brought an eager response yesterday from more than 30,500 persons. The New York City Housing Authority distributed that many applications for Woodside Houses, in Queens, where 1,357 apartments will rent for an average of $16.39 a room a month, with gas and electricity included.

Your edition of March 14 contained a letter by Benjamin Gassman setting forth the Liberal party stand in opposition to the Williamson-Reoux bill on permanent personal registration which is now under consideration in the Legislature.

FRANKFORT, Germany, March 28 -- For the first time since the Berlin blockade the United States Military Government has granted permission to a Russian correspondent to visit the American zone. Last July a group of Russian correspondents received a permit, but only to pass through to the French zone.

JERSEY CITY, N. J., March 28 -- Members of the United States Maritime Commission will inspect the Hoboken piers and waterfront properties on April 22. Then the commissioners will hold a public hearing in Hoboken to hear the views of local residents on whether to return the piers, in federal hands since the first World War, to the city of Hoboken.

RHODES, March 28 -- Dr. Ralph J. Bunche, Acting United Nations Mediator for Palestine, expects to begin the final drafting of an Israeli - Transjordanian armistice agreement tomorrow, it was announced here today. Dr. Bunche hopes for signatures by the end of the week but said tonight that he did not wish to make any definite forecast.

CLEVELAND, March 28 -- The year-old National Association of Foreign Student Advisors was urged today to pursue a three-point program aimed at world understanding through education and to present American facilities for higher learning on a broader basis.

Frank J. Tubridy, former end on the City College football team and line coach for the past two years, has been named to replace Dr. Harold J. Parker as head coach, it was announced yesterday. Parker, coaching on special assignment from the C. C. N. Y. Hygiene Department since 1947, had asked to be relieved of the post.

With the return of sharp competition to the food business, functions of the food broker are becoming increasingly important, Paul S. Willis, president of the Grocery Manufacturers of America, predicted here yesterday upon his return from the National Food Brokers Association annual convention in Chicago.
Painting portraits for "hanging" in Times Square resembles in only one respect the work of the easel artist in the traditional north exposure garret -- most of the time it's cold as all outdoors.
Major proposals for "providing the most traffic relief in the shortest time" were advanced yesterday by the Automobile Club of New York in a letter to the city's new Traffic Commission.

Employing a rugged two-handed attack. Chico Varona. Cuban welterweight, stopped Roy Carter of the Bronx in 0:41 of the second in the main event scheduled for eight rounds at the St. Nicholas Arena last light. After Varona had dropped his rival for a count of nine Referee Eddie Joseph halted the bout.

Most, if not all, of the foreign delegates to the Cultural and Scientific Conference for World Peace, which ended three days of sessions here Sunday night, will depart within a few days on a cross-country tour.

PARIS, March 28 -- The rebuilding of the French railroad network was praised today by David K. Bruce, chief of the French mission of the Economic Cooperation Administration. In ceremonies at Cherbourg marking the arrival of 1,000 American freight cars, Mr. Bruce pointed out the importance of direct Marshall Plan aid as well as of the use of counterpart funds in the reconstruction of the French rail system.

In addition to the long-term objective of improving industrial productivity, Great Britain and Western Europe must achieve short-term aims of reducing the dollar gaps in national income accounts and increase exports to the United States and Canada.

BOSTON, March 28 -- The President of the Puget Sound Power and Light Company protested today what he termed "a wild stampede to chop up, by piecemeal condemnation, Puget's interconnected power pool system."

The Juilliard String Quartet gave the second of its concerts at which it has presented all six of Bela Bartok's quartets last night in Times Hall. The fame of the first concert when this remarkable organization gave three of the Hungarian master's works in the chamber music form a month ago had spread, to judge from last night's audience.

TEL AVIV, Israel, March 28 -- An Israeli Government committee of experts on Arab affairs has been working for more than a month to formulate plans for the resettlement of displaced Arabs in Israel and neighboring countries.

CAMDEN, N. J., March 28 -- The keel of the $12,000,000 steamship President Jackson, first American-flag passenger liner to be started since the war, was laid down today at the New York Shipbuilding Corporattion's yard on the Delaware River.
Sir Francis Evans, British Consul General, presented British Empire decorations to nine Americans, two French citizens, a Greek and a Briton in a ceremony yesterday at his home, 1 Beekman Place.

LONDON, March 28 -- Representatives of ten Western European nations found themselves in substantial agreement today when they began studying a draft of the constitution for the proposed Council of Europe. This was announced in a communique after they had held two secret meetings at the Foreign Office.

GREENSBORO, N. C., March 28 (AP) -- Sam Snead proved a superior mudder today to defeat Lloyd Mangrum by two strokes in their playoff for the top prize of $2,000 in the Greensboro open golf tournament.
ISTANBUL, Turkey, March 28 (AP) -- Turkish newspapers rejected today the proposition that Turkey could remain neutral in a new world war.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 28 -- Bryan Foy has settled his contract with Eagle-Lion and will join Warner Brothers as a producer after he completes two films, "Trapped" and "Port of New York," which are now in preparation at E-L. His contract with E-L as a profit-sharing autonomous producer still has two and a half years to run. His agreement with Warners is for three years on a straight salary.

Women with an appreciation for fine tweeds will be pleased to note their return to prominence this spring. Temporarily curtailed during the war, they have leaped to a first place in fashion this season and promise to be even more important for fall.

BOISE, Idaho, March 28 -- A warning that the West, America's "problem child", was being developed on the basis of "fragmentary information" was voiced today by Dr. J. R. Mahoney director of business research at the University of Utah at the annual meeting of the Western States Council here.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- With the present law expiring at midlight Thursday, a serious fight brewed tonight over a compromise bill, drafted by a Senate-House conference, offering landlords a "fair net operating income" in extending rent control for fifteen months.

BALTIMORE, March 28 -- Preparations are being made by the 5,000,000 members of the International Transport Workers Federation to clamp an international boycott on all ships sailing under the flags of Panama and Honduras, it was announced today by Harry Lundeberg, president of the Seafarers International Union, AFL.

BOWIE, Md., March 28 -- C. C. Tanner's Nearway, who hadn't won a stake since his days as a topflight 2-year-old in 1947, earned two decisions to take the top award in the Rowe Memorial Handicap as the Maryland racing season opened today at the Southern Maryland Agricultural Association's horse park.

TRENTON, N. J. March 28 -- A broad program of low-cost, low-rent housing, financed largely through self-liquidating loans to builders, was presented today by Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll to a joint session of the New Jersey Legislature.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was quiet yesterday, and final prices were 4 to 7 points net lower than on Saturday.

Washington suburban sanitary district, in Maryland, receive bids on $2,000,000 of water and sewer bonds on April 13. The issue will be dated April 1, 1949, and will mature on each April 1 from 1950 to 1989, with interest not to exceed 4 per cent.

CLEARWATER, Fla., March 28 -- Badgered by high winds and an epidemic of extra-base clubbing, the Yankees succumbed to the Phillies (the Fighting Phillies they are calling them this year) before a gathering of 1.953 this afternoon. The count was 7 to 3.

Attempts to lift the stock market out of the doldrums met with little success yesterday and prices on the New York Stock Exchange closed mixed after making moderate gains. Activity around midday, when prices were at their best, expanded sales to 700,000 shares, from the 630,000 total on Friday.

TRIESTE, March 28 -- The first political elections in the history of the Free Territory of Trieste -- and the first balloting in this region for a quarter century -- will be held in the Anglo-American zone in June.

A wide revision of the curriculum -- the first in twenty-five years -- was approved yesterday by the faculty of Barnard College, Columbia University. The new program, to go into effect next September for incoming students, will put greater emphasis upon the acquisition "of a broad foundation in the humanities and sciences."

News comes again today from Robert F. Moyer, head of Altman's food department, whose trip West in search of delicacies bore some of the savory results reported here twelve days ago. More of the products he selected on his travels have now arrived at the store, where they go on sale for the first time this week.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- The House Foreign Affairs Committee approved today a $54,000,000 bill to save the China aid program from expiration on April 3, but to give President Truman unlimited discretion in disbursing future money.
BOSTON, March 28 (AP) -- Five thousand men and women stormed Filene's basement today for a firstsince-the-war sale of men's suits, topcoats and overcoats at one price -- $11.

VIENNA, March 28 -- French Higi Commissioner Gen. Emile Bethouart disclosed in an interview in the Innsbruck newspaper Tiroler Tageszeitung yesterday that the United States Army was establishing several supply depots in the French zone.

CHICAGO, March 28 -- Aimed at the solution of problems "hindering" the development of voluntary health plans, a meeting of representatives of participants in medical care plans and a committee of the American Medical Association is scheduled for April 29 in Chicago.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- The American shipping industry is in a deplorable and disappearing condition, President Truman was told today by a delegation headed by Senator Warren G. Magnuson, Democrat, of Washington.
VIENNA, March 28 -- Week-end reports from Hungary are that new general elections are expected within the next few months under an amended election law that will insure a rubber-stamp Parliament.
TRENTON, March 28 -- The State Assembly passed unanimously tonight four measures requiring a loyalty oath of anyone appointed or elected to a public position in New Jersey.

With warmer weather accelerating consumer purchases of spring clothing, a turning point has been reached in New York's wholesale markets, it was pointed out yesterday. A definite increase in reorders was noted according to resident buyers, and retailers are filling in on inventories thinned out by reactivated buying.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 28 -- The United Nations Conciliation Commission has asked delegates of the Arab states if they would be willing to continue their conversations at some neutral place with the delegates of the Israeli Government also present.

The Government's twelve-year-old anti-trust suit against the Aluminum Company of America entered what the litigants hoped was its final phase yesterday. Federal Judge John C. Knox opened hearings to determine whether the concern should be compelled to divest itself of some holdings.

Senate and House conferees have reached agreement on a compromise formula under which rent control, in force since January, 1942, would be continued for another fifteen months. Congress must act on the measure before midnight Thursday, when the legislation, as extended by the Eightieth Congress a year ago, is due to expire.

A call for further wage increases to increase labor's purchasing power and avert a possible depression was issued yesterday by John Green, president of the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, CIO.

That head in itself is no attraction to the fair sex, but a leaflet coming from the New York Stock Exchange firm of Gude, Winmill Co. to its lady customers is something else again. The booklet outlines a ten-week course for women only in "Managing Personal Funds" to be given at the Guaranty Trust Company's main office.

LONDON, March 28 -- In an attempt to prevent "The Snake Pit," American film dealing with inmates of a mental hospital, from being shown in Great Britain. 140 nurses and other members of the staffs of several mental hospitals sent a letter of protest to the British Board of Film Censors.

The twelfth annual appeal of the Greater New York Fund, which this year has set $8,000,000 as its goal from the business community, will get under way on April 25 and run through June 10, it was announced yesterday by the campaign chairman, John D. Rockefeller 3d.

Mayor O'Dwyer promised yesterday to enlist the services of 2,000 extra policemen to guard against violence in a threatened city-wide taxi strike that a union spokesman said would probably take place some time before midnight Friday.
ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., March 28 (AP) -- Bernard Rusche, 32-year-old law student at the University of Cincinnati, took the singles lead today in the American Bowling Congress tournament.

The Standard Oil Company of California reported yesterday for 1948 a consolidated net income of $161,491,932 after charges, taxes and reserves, equal to $12.42 each on the 13,003.953 capital shares outstanding. The 1947 net income was $107,268,575, or $8.25 a share.

In a record turnout that jammed 1,700 members into the Academy of Medicine Building, the New York County Medical Society voted overwhelmingly last night to pay the $25 assessment levied by the American Medical Association on all its members for a fight against compulsory health insurance.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- A trial examiner for the National Labor Relations Board today found two Congress of Industrial Organizations maritime unions guilty of an illegal secondary boycott by picketing six Gulf port shipyards last autumn.

Mayor O'Dwyer authorized yesterday another anti-Tammany gesture, giving use to the belief that he was prepared to shed all appearance of connection with the Manhattan political organization between now and the Mayoralty campaign.

TOKYO, March 28 -- Effective April 1 the Japanese textile industry will operate under only two indicated exchange rates, 330 yen to the dollar for all imports and most exports, and 420 to the dollar for a limited list of exports. The move, which will put certain manufacturers under severe pressures, was explained as further preparation for establishment of a single official rate, expected some time later in the year.

LONDON, March 28 -- Although budget day (April 6) falls in the middle of the next stock exchange account starting on Wednesday, hopes for taxation relief made themselves felt in the stock market here today. Buyers selected tobaccos on the chance of a cut in duty and breweries on talk of reduction in beer duty in view of falling production.

CINCINNATI, March 28 (AP) -- The major leagues today revised their much-discussed rule to permit so-called bonus players to be sent to the minors for one year after they are signed by a major league club.

Vice Admiral Earle W. Mills, U. S. N. (retired), at a directors' meeting of the Foster Wheeler Corporation was elected executive vice president and a director and David McCulloch, formerly executive vice president, as named vice chairman of the board, it was announced by Harry S. Brown, president and chairman.

The media of communication gave "really fantastic coverage" in presenting ideas for racial and religious amity during this year's Brotherhood Week, Nelson A. Rockefeller, general chairman of the observance in the last week of February, reported yesterday.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 28 -Henry Ford 2d, president of the Ford Motor Company, said today that be expected automobile prices to drop slightly this year.

CAIRO, March 28 (AP) -- Princess Fawzia, former Empress of Iran, was married today to Ismail Shirine Bey, Egyption diplomat. In keeping with ancient custom, it was assumed the Princess did not attend the ceremony in Kouba Palace.

The hospitals can contribute effectively as health centers to a broad program of preventive medicine, providing a "total of services required to maintain and foster health." Dr. Stanhope Bayne-Jones, president of the joint administrative board of the New York Hospital - Cornell Medical Center, told a gathering of 2,000 physicians yesterday.

NEWARK, N. J., March 28 -Several thousand veterans from five North Jersey counties are scheduled to meet tomorrow night to picket the Mosque Theatre here during a "Cultural Rally for Peace" sponsored by the New Jersey Council for Arts. Sciences and Professions.

Two contract bridge teams met last night in the final round of play for the Eastern States team-of-four championship and the Curt H. Reisinger Trophy, bringing to a close the tournament that has been in progress, off and on, at the Park Sheraton Hotel since March 6.

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 28 -Back from their nine-day tour of Southern California, Manager Leo Durocher and his Giants were greeted today by their latest mound acquisition, Hank Behrman, who according to most reliable reports, represents an investment of $50,000.

The Girard Trust Company of Philadelphia is inviting until April 18 tenders of Quaker City Cold Storage Company, Inc., first mortgage bonds due on May 1, 1973, up to an amount of $15,000 in the sinking fund.

WASHINGTON, March 28 (UP) -- The delegates are Mr. Austin; John Foster Dulles, Republican foreign policy adviser; Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt; Dr. Philip C. Jessup, recently named United States Ambassador-at-Large, and Benjamin V. Cohen, former State Department counselor.

The Munitions Board of the National Military Establishment is exploring the possibility of stockpiling in this country quantities of German scrap metal of grades used by American steel mills and foundries, it was learned yesterday.
Settlement of the long controversy over New York International Airport at Idlewild, Queens, between the airlines and the Port of New York Authority was reported to be in sight last night.
The Boeing Airplane Company, in its annual report issued to stockholders today, showed net earnings for 1948 of $1,715,908, in contrast to the $448,499 loss sustained the year before.

LOS ANGELES, March 28 -- Three local members of the Communist party were sentenced to a year's imprisonment by Federal District Judge Peirson Hall today for criminal contempt in repeatedly refusing to tell a Federal grand jury about the party's organization.

The leaders of the Police, Fire and Sanitation Department bands, whose brass tunes have won the plaudits of royalty and government heads, are precisians in the observance of international musical protocol.

Another milestone on the path toward European unity is approaching for the diplomatic representatives of ten nations who have met in London to put the finishing touches on a draft constitution for what is already being hailed as the beginning of the first European Government.
LONDON, March 28 -- Inadequate and expensive housing and the rising cost of living were shown today to be the chief preoccupations of the rank and file of the Labor party, which now rules Britain.

A plea for more adequate psychiatric facilities for the neglected and dependent children of New York was made yesterday by Miss Julia Goldman, director of the Jewish Child Care Association's child guidance department. She called the existing resources "very limited."

Stephen J. Carney, Commissioner of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity, vigorously defended yesterday the city's plan for the illumination of Park Avenue from Forty-sixth to Ninety-sixth Streets. The Municipal Art Society had sent a letter to Mayor O'Dwyer suggesting the use of sidewalk lights instead of the center strip illumination project now under way.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower left today for Key West, Fla., the President's own retreat, to recuperate from an illness which has confined him for the last week. His physician, Maj. Gen. Howard Snyder, who accompanied him, explained the illness as an inflammation of the stomach.

VERO BEACH, Fla., March 28 -- For the first time since players began rolling off the assembly line at this extraordinary camp the Dodgers played a ball game today against their farmhands, the St. Paul Saints, and while the Brooks won it, 9 -- 4, it was pretty much of a costly victory.

Dr. Miklos Nyarady, former Hungarian Finance Minister who took advantage of an official mission to Austria and Germany last November to escape from his Communist-dominated homeland, was among 657 passengers who arrived here yesterday on the French liner De Grasse.

The New York Knickerbockers will resume their quest of more aurels -- and dollars -- in the Basketball Association of America playoffs tonight. Having disposed of the Baltimore Bullets by taking the odd game in the set last Saturday night at Madison Square Garden. Joe Lapchick's lads will be at Washington, engaging the Capitols in the Eastern Division semi-finals, designated as Series B.

Once more the New York Community Trust, 120 Broadway, New York 5, has given us an excellent annual accounting of its stewardship over the millions of dollars it has handled and is handling for the benefit of many worthy philanthropies. The resources of this organization are now shown to have grown to $18,201,629, with appropriations in 1948 reaching $649,910, the highest in the organization's history.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores last week dropped 15 per cent below the corresponding period last year, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The decline for the four weeks ended last Saturday was 14 per cent.

PARIS, March 28 -- Strengthened by the clear Government majority in the cantonal elections held yesterday and on March 20. Premier Henri Queuille prepared today to resist the pressure of Charles de Gaulle and other non-Left-Wingers for a reorganization of the Cabinet.
Heirlooms that have occupied places for generations in the homes of New York families are on public display today in the Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue and 103d Street.

Bamboo, already familiar in window blinds and furniture, now is being woven into draperies that may be hung like fabric panels. Unlike window blinds, the bamboo for draperies is woven vertically and may be hung from standard curtain tracks.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- Louis A. Johnson assumed the office of Secretary of Defense today with an expression of confidence that, should a war of aggression break out, "we can stop it." "With God's help and guidance," he asserted, "we are determined that American youth will not again have to take part in the tragedy of a war.

Members of the Blue Hill Troupe, one of the country's outstanding companies of amateur performers of Gilbert and Sullivan operettas, will give a dinner on Friday at the Astor to celebrate the twenty-fifth anniversary of the founding of the organization.

Argentina's inability to use sterling and other non-convertible currencies arising from her trade with Europe to cover her large deficit with the United States has been the basic factor in her recent financial difficulties, says a bulletin to be published today by the Institute of International Finance of New York University.
Lieut. Gen. Walter Bedell Smith, former Ambassador to Moscow, will take command of the First Army at Governors Island this afternoon.

Beginning next month, Rotoette, Troy, N. Y., manufacturer of rotary tillage power equipment for gardening, will devote its entire 1949 advertising budget to newspaper space, it was announced yesterday by C. W. Kelsey, president of the company.

LONDON, March 28 -- The Soviet Union tried unsuccessfully today to persuade the Big Three Western powers to write into the Austrian peace treaty a provision tantamount to authorizing the forced repatriation of refugees and displaced persons from Austria.

Revenues of the Brooklyn Union Gas Company were $38,153,385 in 1948, the highest in the fifty-three-year-history of the utility, according to the annual report to be distributed to stockholders today. The total was $6,790,141 above the $31,363.244 shown for 1947.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -Two Czech delegates to the cultural conference in New York hailed the "moral" results of the meeting today and said they would go home to report that a "powerful progressive force for peace" exists in the United States.

Rallying to take the last two bouts on the card, the New York team fought to an 8-8 tie with Chicago in the twenty-second intercity Golden Gloves amateur boxing tournament at Madison Square Garden last night.

ALBANY, March 28 -- The Assembly Rules Committee reported favorably tonight a bill appropriating $50,000 for a study of the feasibility of setting up a state system of off-track betting on race horses. The bill will be taken up for passage in the Assembly tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, March 28 (AP) -- A new battle over the issue of Government power projects was shaped today as the House Appropriations Committee endorsed a big transmission program in the Interior Department's $577,324,408 money bill for the year starting July 1.

Devious are the ways of women in raising funds for their Alma Mater. Mount Holyoke College alumnae do it by selling gadgets. They gave their trade secrets away yesterday at a fund-raising spring rally in the Community Church Center, 40 East Thirty-fifth Street, showing how they reached 79 per cent in a year toward their pledge of $1,000,000.
John F. X. McGohey was sworn in yesterday by Federal Judge John C. Knox for his second four-year term as United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York.
WASHINGTON, March 28 (UP) -- The Supreme Court today nullified an Alabama law requiring Negroes to pass a so-called "white supremacy" intelligence test in order to vote.

NASSAU, Bahamas, March 28 -- Patrick O'Gorman of the Western Long Island Sound fleet sailed Wahini home first today in the opening race of the Star Class spring championship series, covering the ten-mile course in 2 hours 39 minutes 50 seconds.

CHICAGO, March 28 -- Grains made a strong finish after a weak start on the Board of Trade today, short covering being the main influence in the late trading. Wheat showed the most strength and finished with gains of 7/8 cent to 1 5/8 cents a bushel, December leading.

Duane Jones, president of the Duane Jones Advertising Agency, has been named chairman of the promotion committee of the New York City Cancer Committee's 1949 fund drive, it was announced yesterday by John Reed Kilpatrick, chairman of the executive committee of the campaign.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- Answering its own rhetorical question, "Are Depressions Necessary?" the Democratic National Committee arranged tonight a forum representing Democrats in Congress, farmers and rail labor to contend that enactment of President Truman's fair deal program offered the best chance to stabilize the economy.
ALBANY, March 28 -- The Senate acted tonight to bring the charges of finance companies for the financing of automobiles under state regulation for the first time.

It is a rare thing in the city's musical life for one recitalist to substitute for another on less than three hours' notice. It happened last night when Charlotte Martin agreed at about 6 P. M., to play Enrique Arias' piano recital in Carnegie Hall.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- The Distinguished Service Medal, highest honor that may be conferred upon a civilian, was presented today to James Forrestal, retiring Secretary of Defense, at a surprise White House ceremony.

Harry Ebbets and Harold Barnes, the two officials who voted for Jake ka Motta in the latter's 12-round fight with Robert Villemain of France at Madison Square Garden last Friday night, were temporarily relieved of consideration for assignment to future fights, it was announced yesterday by Eddie Eagan, chairman of the New York State Athletic Commission.

Tonight's events: Philadelphia Orchestra, Eugene Ormandy, conductor: Helen Traubel, soprano, Carnegie Hall, 8:30 o'clock; "An Evening at the Opera," presented by the Opera Workshop, Lexington Ave. Y.M.-Y.W.H.A.. 8:40; Amri Galli-Campi, soprano, and Frank Premezzi, 13-year-old pianist, benefit for Italian War Orphans. Hotel Pierre, 8:30; Mata and Hari, dancers, Brooklyn Academy, 8:30.
Commissioner of Investigation John M. Murtagh announced yesterday that he had started to "review" all the city permits under which the three major milk companies in this area operate.
LONDON, March 28 -- Responsible diplomats said today Britain and France had agreed to most of a United States plan to save a list of West German industries from dismantling.

Varied divertissements are being planned for the circus bazaar in behalf of charitable enterprises furthered by St. Bartholomew's Protestant Episcopal Church, to be held on April 28 and 29 in the auditorium of the community house of the church at 109 East Fiftieth Street.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- Gerhart Eisler, whom the House Committee on Un-American Activities, calls the "No. 1 Communist in the United States," asked the Supreme Court today to invalidate the law that set up the committee.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- The margin requirement for deals in stocks was cut from 75 to 50 per cent today by the Federal Reserve Board, effective Wednesday. An investor or speculator will have to put up only 50 per cent of the price of securities in cash.
In Weather Bureau records, yesterday will go down as unusually warm for March. That is because the high for the day was 71 degrees. But the high was reached at exactly five minutes after midnight.

WASHINGTON, March 28 (AP) -- A Federal grand jury today indicted Herbert John Burgman, former employe of the United States Embassy in Berlin, on treason charges. He is accused of broadcasting Nazi radio propaganda during the war.
SAN FRANCISCO, March 28 -Dr. Arthur B. Lamb of Harvard University will receive the 1949 Priestley Medal, highest honor in American chemistry, the American Chemical Society was informed here tonight.
ROME, March 29 -- The central committee of the Italian Communist party has decided to intensify its fight against the North Atlantic treaty by organizing a nationwide "peace front."

TOKYO, March 29 -- Over bitter Communist opposition, the Diet's lower house today voted to establish its much-discussed "Special Examination Committee" to investigate actions hampering the economic rehabilitation of Japan.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed somewhat irregular yesterday, 4 points higher to 10 points net lower.
ALBANY, March 29 -- The Assembly approved without discussion tonight the Hults-Becker bill to set up a commission to study off-track horse-race betting.

Sterling Drug, Inc., in its annual report for 1948, to be released today, records the sixteenth consecutive annual sales increase, notes that sales of medicinal preparations for the first time exceeded $100,000.000. and shows that earnings were the second highest in the company's history.

An electric table broiler that doubles as a frying pan and a skillet from which fats are drained through a valve in the side are among several kitchen gadgets new in the housewares departments of city stores.

VIENNA, March 29 -- Julius Deutsch of the Austrian Socialist party, former general in the Austrian Army, proposed in the Arbeiter Zeitung today that token forces should be substituted for the present occupation armies in Austria if the treaty talks in London broke down.

ALBANY, March 29 -- After six years as Republican majority leader and President pro-tempore of the Senate Benjamin F. Feinberg is slated to resign tomorrow to accept the chairmanship of the Public Service Commission. He has been in the Senate sixteen years.

The announcement from Washington late on Monday of a reduction in margin requirements from 75 per cent to 50 per cent gave the stock market yesterday its biggest lift since early in January. Trading was the heaviest since last November and final prices of the key issues were up 1 to 4 points and near their best for the day.

" Fear No Evil," an Italian-made biography based on Monte Cassino Abbey and its founder, St. Benedict, will open today at the Fifth Avenue Playhouse, Fosco Giachetti appears as St. Benedict, with Nino Pavese, Alfredo Varelli, Lilianne Laine and Manoel Roero in supporting roles.
CINCINNATI March 29 (AP) -- The current crop of major league baseball's high-priced rookies, better known as bonus players, will not get a year of minor league seasoning after all.
Four of the major railroads in this area started yesterday to recall most of 35,000 workers still on leave who were among those furloughed during the recent mine closings.

BOSTON, Mass., borrowed yesterday $5,000,000 on temporary loan notes due on Nov. 3. The issue was sold at public bidding to Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., at 1 per cent interest, plus a premium of $126. The notes were reoffered at a price to yield 0.95 per cent.

The first break in copper prices since its rise to a post-war peak was announced yesterday by American Smelting and Refining Company. It was only 1/4 cent a pound and applied only to custom smelter product. In the industry custom smelters produce about 25 per cent of total copper refined.

In your issue of March 20 it is reported that at a meeting of the American Civil Liberties Union held the day before, Prof. Thomas I. Emerson of Yale advised "total abolition and extinction" for the House Un-American Activities Committee.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- The Senate Armed Services Committee indicated rather clearly today that it would qualify proposals to centralize authority in the National Military Establishment. The proposals are in an amending bill laid before the committee by the Administration.

LONDON, March 29 -- The United States Government has established here a joint committee of American experts to supervise the distribution of such arms as Congress may vote for Europe in connection with the Atlantic pact. Formal announcement of the committee is expected shortly in Washington.

OKLAHOMA CITY, March 29 -- A serious concern with the problem of balancing land costs and density of population in public housing projects was expressed today by planning experts at the National Citizens Conference on Community Planning.

FRANKFORT, Germany, March 29 -- Some Western Allied officials here foresee a probable resumption of negotiations with the Russians on the issues in Germany but only after the Western bargaining position has been strengthened further by the signing of the North Atlantic Pact and the establishment of a Western German government.
