LOS ANGELES, March 29 -- The world's first commercial installation of the "Fido" off-burning system for freeing flying fields of fog was put in operation today at the Los Angeles Municipal Airport. "Fido" is an abbreviatian of "fog, intensive, dispersal of."

TORONTO, March 29 (AP) -- The source of the earth's magnetism, the thing that makes a compass point north, may have been tracked down in studies by Dr. E. C. Bullard, head of the University of Toronto's Department of Physics.

A proposal to conduct "Town Meetings of the Air" in at least fourteen world capitals was approved last night by George V. Allen, Assistant Secretary of State in charge of public affairs, who is director of the Voice of America programs.

Retailers who have been buying women's apparel on the basis of price to the exclusion of all other factors are hastening the approach of a serious business recession, it was charged last night by Joseph L. Dubow, executive director of the Merchants Ladies Garment Association.

SAYVILLE, L. I., March 29 -- The contract under which the Lockheed Aircraft Service at nearby MacArthur Airport reconditions the planes used by the Military Air Transport Service for the Berlin airlift has been extended through June 30, it was announced here today.

RIO DE JANEIRO, March 29 -- Brazil today put in effect her new regulations on foreign - exchange transactions. The entire foreign-exchange structure underwent severe modifications, a step that foreign bank executives considered wholesome.

After four days of sightseeing in New York, Borje E. Johnson, 34 years old. and Ake G. Carlson, 26, global Swedish hitch-hikers, continued yesterday to rate the Negro tribal dances they had seen in the Belgian Congo as their "most interesting experience."

GARDEN CITY, L. I., March 29 -- Thirteen hundred women jammed into Cathedral House today to learn from ideas presented at the Sixth Annual Woman's Forum of Nassau County what they could do in their own Long Island communities to erase racial and religious prejudice.

The Museum of Modern Art, having held a preview last evening, will open to the public today (until June 12) a retrospective exhibition of the work of Georges Braque. First shown at the Cleveland Museum, the exhibition includes eighty-five paintings and collages together with a group of drawings, prints and illustrations and pieces of sculpture.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, March 29 -- For two hours in the House of Assembly this afternoon Eric H. Louw, Minister of Economic Affairs and leader of the South African delegation to United Nations, complained of the world press, with particular reference to the reports of the racial riots in Durban last January.

WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP) -- Net sales of 1,283 United States corporations reached a record peak of $112,900,000,000 in 1948, according to a report by the Securities and Exchange Commission. This is an increase of nearly 15 per cent over sales for 1947.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- President Truman promised a delegation of West Coast members of the House, who called on him to aid the shipbuilding industry in their area, to have his assistant, Dr. John R. Steelman, confer with them on the situation.

The Communist leaders on trial here have refused financial help from Anna Louise Strong, American writer ousted by the Soviet Union on spy charges, William L. Patterson, national executive secretary of the Civil Rights Congress, announced yesterday.

ALBANY, March 29 -- Disability benefit insurance and two other key Dewey Administration bills were saved tonight from defeat on the eve of final adjournment of the Legislature when dissident Republicans were whipped into line through application of party discipline.

Tomorrow the United States Commission of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization will open its second national conference in Cleveland. The meeting will bring together over the week-end representatives of practically every cultural activity in this country.

The State Department and the Attorney General's office halted yesterday the proposed cross-country tour of eighteen members of the Soviet and satellite nations' delegations to the Cultural and Scientific Conference for World Peace.

URUMCHI, Sinkiang, China, March 28 -- The three pro-Soviet northwest districts of Sinkiang, which rebelled against China in 1945, are now looking toward a coalition with the Provincial Government at the same time that a deal with the Soviet Union is being negotiated.

BALTIMORE, March 29 -- The international boycott of ships flying under the flag of Panama and Honduras will begin by May 1, according to J. H. Oldenbroek, general secretary of the International Transport Workers Federation.

A single-engine propeller-driven F-51, a fighter plane developed and used during World War II, crossed the country from Burbank, Calif., to La Guardia Airport yesterday in 5 hours and 5 seconds. Although the official record set in 1947 was bettered by more than an hour, the new record may not be considered official because of incomplete recording of the 2,477-mile flight.
PRAGUE, March 29 -- The Government announced today that two United States soldiers had been tried secretly as spies and sentenced to long terms in prison at hard labor.

The Zarief quadruplets, now residents of the Manhattan Beach section of Brooklyn, celebrated their fifth birthday yesterday with forty classmates in the kindergarten of Public School 225 at Ocean View Avenue and Brighton-Thirteenth Street.
PHILADELPHIA, March 29 -- The United States faces the worst school building crisis in its history, a noted educator warned here today.

LAKE SUCCESS, March 29 -- Charles E. Bohlen, Counselor of the State Department, came out to United Nations headquarters today to give assurance that the North Atlantic pact was not meant as a substitute for the world organization.
WASHINGTON, March 29--Louis A. Johnson, Secretary of Defense for twenty-four hours, moved with startling abruptness today in his initial efforts to gain greater unification of the armed services.
A half-hour television program making extensive use of pantomime and the dance, entitled "Through the Crystal Ball," will have its premiere at 9 P. M. Monday, April 18, over CBS video.

An improved coordination between the work of the child health centers and that of the nursery schools should result from the joint program of the Department of Health and the New York Kindergarten Association, launched recently at 542 West Forty-second Street.

American Communist leaders began plotting in 1945 to start civil war if this country becomes involved in war with Soviet Russia, according to yesterday's evidence at the Communist trial. They made similar plans during the Stalin-Hitler pact, it was testified, for use in case we joined the British against the Nazis.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- The famous "herd" of narra carabaos was back today in its old habitat -- the spacious lobby of the White House executive offices -- and Presidential callers had better beware. The legs of many well-known persons have been made black-and-blue by the beasts.

BRADENTON, Fla., March 29 (AP) -- Big John Sain, 20-game winner for the past three seasons, went the full nine-inning distance for the first time this spring today as his Boston Braves subdued the Cincinnati Reds, 8 -- 3.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, March 29 (AP) -- Top-seeded Don McNeill of Orange, N. J., opened his bid in the Bermuda Tennis championships today by defeating H. Brown-low Eve of Bermuda in a second-round match, 6 -- 3, 7 -- 5.

The privilege of worshipping in a church pew, earmarked 150 years ago for "the Governor and other respectable characters," has been offered to Governor Dewey by the Rev. Richard E. McEvoy, rector of the Protestant Episcopal Church of St. Mark's in the-Bouwerie, Tenth Street and Second Avenue.

Members of the Soviet delegation to the recent Cultural and Scientific Conference for World Peace have declined an invitation by the National Association of manufacturers to tour American industrial plants, the NAM was informed yesterday.

Five thousand taxi drivers voted unanimously yesterday to go on strike beginning early Friday morning. Their leaders predicted that not a cab would move until the owners agreed to negotiate with them.

By steamer, plane and train ranking representatives of nations of the Atlantic community are speeding toward Washington to give formal expression to the determination of the Western World to defend itself against new aggression and at the same time make top-level attempt to solve some of the stubborn problems left over by the war.
WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP) -- Dr. Edwin G. Nourse, chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, has submitted his resignation, informed officials said tonight.

CHICAGO, March 29 -- Grain markets fluctuated in a nervous manner on the Board of Trade today and closed irregular with wheat 7/8 to 2 cents lower, July leading. Corn was unchanged to 1/2 cent lower; oats, 1/8 to 3/8 cent lower; rye, 1 3/4 to 2 cents higher, and soybeans, 1/4 to 3/4 cent lower.

Gross revenues of the Hilton Hotels Corporation last year increased to $43,171,720, highest on record, from $42,543,078 in 1947, C. N. Hilton, president, informed shareholders in the annual report to be released today.

Rabbi Pincus J. Lerner has purchased the two-story two-faxnily building at 702 Avenue L, Brook]lyn, from Saul Goodman and will Iconvert it into a synagogue. Tng,, :property, on a plot 28 by 9C. 'eet,-fg. was acquired for cash above ,ur-.. I chase money mortgage ot S i00..' ]isberg-Lenz Ine was the b

LONDON, March 29 - A spokesman of the British Government declared in the House of Lords tonight that resettlement and rehabilitation of Arab refugees from Palestine could be successfully accomplished only by large-scale development projects in the Arab countries.

Samuel M. Coplon, father of Miss Judith Coplon who is under indictment here and in Washington on espionage conspiracy charges, died early yesterday morning at his home 178 Ocean Parkway, Brooklyn. He would have been 70 years old today.

No "deluge" of failures among men's furnishings retailers is anticipated by manufacturers because merchants have been forewarned and have had ample time to build up their working capital, according to the concensus yesterday at the spring conference of the Men's Furnishings Manufacturers Credit Group at the Gramercy Park Hotel.

MOSCOW, March 29 -- The cause of world peace is seen here as materially aided by great success reported for the New York Cultural and Scientific Conference for World Peace, and the Soviet press is looking forward to the Paris congress April 20 to broaden the people's revolt against what it regards as such belligerent excursions as the North Atlantic treaty.

WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP) -- Foreign Minister Count Carlo Sforza of Italy appealed personally today to Secretary of State Acheson to back Italy's plan for regaining control of her war-lost African colonies.

American Airlines, Inc., operated profitably in the final three quarters of last year but was unable to offset the deficit of $4,285,000 incurred in the first quarter, the annual statement disclosed yesterday. The net loss for 1948 was reported at $2,894,000, compared with an adjusted loss of $3,401,000 in 1947.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- The American theory that wives buy most of their husbands clothes gets a setback in a scientific survey of men's preferences in nine textile products, issued today by the Department of Agriculture.
LEXINGTON, Ky., March 29 (AP) --The filly that was foaled unexpectedly at Keeneland last week learned the name of her daddy today.

NANKING, March 29 -- Gen. Chang Chih-chung, chairman of the Nationalist peace delegation, flew to Fenghwa today to see retired President Chiang Kai-shek. The delegation here added the final touches to its preparations for negotiations with the Communists in Peiping.

FORTY years ago "the most influential banker in the world and the mightiest personal force in American business life" was J. Pierpont Morgan. What manner of man he was, what he actually did to loom so large on the American horizon, is not generally known, because Morgan has become a symbol of entrenched greed.

Between 60 and 70 per cent of income from La Guardia Field, New York International Airport and Newark Airport is expected to come from non-flight revenues, Robert S. Curtiss, director of the Department of Concessions and Revenues, The Port of New York Authority, told members of the Sales Executives Club yesterday at their monthly luncheon in the Roosevelt Hotel.

After initial steadiness, coffee futures turned easy yesterday in late trading on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. Trade and scattered new selling was absorbed on a scale downward by professional interests. Final prices for contract "S" were 12 to 26 points lower.
PUTNEY, Vt., March 29 -- Twenty-four teachers have gone on strike at the Putney School, the unique private preparatory school founded here in 1935.
LONDON, March 29 (AP) -- Marcel Cerdan, world middleweight champion, knocked out Britain's Dick Turpin in the seventh round of a scheduled ten - round, non - title fight at Empress Hall tonight.
Wearing a blue business suit, Lieut. Gen. Walter Bedell Smith, former Ambassador to the Soviet Union, assumed command of the First Army at Governors Island yesterday without ceremony of any kind.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 29 -- The announcement the Yankee camp eagerly had been awaiting was made today. Joe Di Maggio will start his first game of the year in center field tomorrow.

A salutary settling of the nation's economy and the definite end of the runaway price spiral were predicted by John G. Forrest, financial editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, and Felix Belair, Jr., a member of its Washington Bureau, in addresses at Times Hall yesterday.

A warning that restricted diets may be prescribed as the result of mistaken diagnosis and lead to a state of "dietary invalidism" was sounded yesterday at the annual meeting of the American College of Physicians, at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, by Dr. Henry J. John of Lakeside and St. Luke's Hospitals in Cleveland.

TOKYO, March 29 -- Japan must have a balanced budget, a workable exchange rate, better taxes and provide guarantees that foreign investments will be protected in future before any large amounts of money can come here, according to a memorandum from the American Chamber of Commerce in Japan, sent to General MacArthur today.
Eddie Eagan, chairman of the State Athletic Commission, said yesterday he would hold a hearing Friday on the disputed Nick Barone-Joe Taylor fight last week at Syracuse.

Criticism of newspaper marketing and readership research at last week's New York American Marketing Association chapter meeting was termed "healthy" yesterday but lacking in consideration of the short duration of the projects most severely attacked.
ROCHESTER, N. Y., March 29 (AP) -- Striking new knowledge for mankind was promised today at the dedication of the giant new cosmic ray cyclotron -- an atom-smasher -- of the University of Rochester.

Tammany Leader Hugo E. Rogers in an embattled mood told yesterday what he thought of his critics. In his suite on the twentieth floor of the Municipal Building, which he occupies as Borough President of Manhattan, Mr. Rogers vigorously defended his activities in both positions, and also issued a moderate declaration of independence of Mayor O'Dwyer.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- The Cambridge Electric Light Company, Cambridge, Mass., filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering $2,750.000 of twenty-five year notes, Series A, due 1974, that are to be sold at competitive bidding.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- The Senate and House voted final approval today to a fifteen-month extension of rent controls. The bill also gives the states and localities the option of ending regulation sooner and offers landlords a "fair net operating income."

Two new vacuum cleaners in the 1949 Westinghouse line will have disposable paper bags that eliminate the dusty chore of emptying required by the conventional type of cloth bag, the company announced yesterday. The "Toss-Away" bags will be provided with a tank-type cleaner and with the Deluxe Upright model, both to be at Gimbels and other stores in about two weeks.

NASSAU, Bahamas, March 29 (AP) -- John Hazen White of Central Long Island Sound and Greenwich, Conn., won the second Star Class Johnnie Walker Cup race today in the closest finish since the spring championships started Sunday.

HANOI, Indo-China, March 29 (AP) -- A band of Chinese Communists seized part of the Indo-Chinese border town of Moncay Sunday and attacked the garrison in the citadel there, the French announced today.
Andrew Logue, indicted for malicious mischief, not only won his freedom in Richmond County Court yesterday, but gained also important help toward a better life.

The high level of current inventory of tax-exempt bonds on dealers' shelves continues to be of major interest in the financial world. Although the market is on the quiet side, its basic firmness in the face of swelling inventory is reflected by the aggressive bidding going on for new issues.
An assistant manager of a National City Bank branch disappeared yesterday and the police reported that $690,000 in cash and bonds was missing from the bank.

Out-of-town buyers registered in] the market for the week ended [yesterday numbered 1,337, against] 1,477 last week and 648 in the corresponding week a year ago, according to listings apppearing inI THE NEW YORK TIMES. There I were 633 arrivals yesterday, corn-! )areal with 595 last Tuesday.
BOISE, Idaho, March 29 -- Business interests of the Far West, on an eleven-state basis, have entered the fight against establishment of a Columbia Valley Authority.
Two young war veterans, both amputees, paid the "first installment on their life-saving obligation" yesterday when they gave blood to the Red Cross.

CLEVELAND, March 29 -- The Board of Foreign Scholarships, acting under the Fulbright Foreign Study Exchange plan, authorized today the establishment of 305 scholarships and grants for American students to study and teach in France.

The Federal legislation proposed under the Economic Stability Act of 1949, or Spence bill, "is based on a misconception of the nature and requirements of a free-enterprise system," the Guaranty Trust Company of New York asserts in its Monthly Survey, published today.

Indicating that they anticipate another large entry, possibly in excess of the record 1,411 of last year, the United States Golf Association has allocated thirty sectors, one more than in 1948, for those who will try to qualify for the United States Open golf championship.

Sixty representatives of industry, labor, the Army, Navy and Coast Guard gathered yesterday at the Twenty-One Club, 21 West Fifty-second Street, for a presentation ceremony to spur the New York City Cancer Committee 1949 fund - raising drive starting on April 4.

Tammany Hall, which has become a little shy at the mention of any connection between it and Frank Costello, one-time slot machine king, withdrew its candidate for head of the United States Assay Office in New York after Senators in Washington received letters picturing the candidate, Dr. Charles L. Singer, as Costello's dentist.

BELLEAIR, Fla., March 29 -- Thomas G. Spates, vice president of General Foods Corporation and personnel adviser to the Atomic Energy Commission, told a business group here today that the power of freedom was the decisive advantage of the United States in competition with the Soviet Union.

TORONTO, March 29 (AP) -- Rookie Sid Smith scored two goals and assisted in another tonight to lead the Toronto Maple Leafs to a 3-1 triumph over the Boston Bruins in the fourth game of their semi-final round Stanley Cup play-off series.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, March 29 (AP) -- The Dutch Government accepted today an invitation from the United Nations Commission for Indonesia to discuss a settlement of Indonesian problems directly with Republican leaders in Batavia, Java.

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 29 -- The Giants got their last glimpse of the Browns this spring today and if they never see Zack Taylor's cast again it probably will be too soon enough for them. For the St. Louisans, paced by Paul Lehner, battered New York pitching for 18 assorted wallops to win, 22 to 9.

LONDON, March 29 (AP) -- J. Arthur Rank, Britain's top movie producer, announced today plans to consolidate all his film-making activities into one new company. He hopes to cut producing costs by 250,000 ($1,000,000) a year.

LONDON, March 29 -- Marshal Vassily D. Sokolovsky, Soviet Commander in Chief in Germany and inflexible instrument of the "cold war" waged with the Western powers over Berlin, was promoted to First Deputy Minister of the Armed Forces of the Soviet Union in a new official reshuffle announced tonight by the Moscow radio.
WASHINGTON, March 29 -- Fifty-five Government hearing examiners who were found unqualified for their jobs will be given opportunities for rehearing and appeals before the Civil Service Commission.

Reflecting the designer's own individuality, the custom millinery collection of Omie Monce stressed high crowns, silhouettes tilted extremely to the side of the head and berets fashioned of pleatings with scarf ends that looped about the throat, in a showing yesterday at 36 Central Park South.

Leaders of the American Federation of Labor, the Congress of Industrial Organizations, and the British Trade Union Congress will meet in Washington April 7 to discuss the formation of an international labor organization of non-Communist nations, it became known yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP) -- The House voted $564,530,270 today for flood control and navigation projects during the fiscal year starting July 1.

Six distributing companies in Brooklyn signed agreements yesterday sending 300 of the 1,500 striking port warehousemen back to their jobs amid indications that the remainder of the dispute would be settled soon.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- The Lesinski labor bill reached the second stage of the House legislative process -- a Rules Committee hearing -- today as Republican members of the Labor Committee issued a minority report charging a "betrayal of the public interest."

OSLO, Norway, March 29 -- After an eight-hour debate marked by Communist disturbances in the public gallery the Norwegian Parliament approved tonight Norway's joining the North Atlantic defense alliance by 130 votes to 13. Those voting against the pact were Communists and two Labor party members. There were seven abstentions.

RHODES, March 29 (AP) -- Israeli and Transjordanian delegates accepted armistice terms today and returned to their capitals for final approval of the draft. They are expected to return on Thursday. If the pact is approved, it may be signed the following day.

" The Pilgrimage of Western Man," by Stringfellow Barr, a story of civilization in the western /world over the last four centuries Iwill be published by Harcourt Brace on April 25. Mr. Barr, who I. is president of the Foundation for World Government, discusses the events that have led to the present world crisis and analyzes the problems of today.

QUINCY, Mass., March 29 -- In a simple ceremony amid the clatter of riveters and the normal noises of a busy shipyard, the keel of the American Export liner Independence was put down this morning at the Bethlehem Steel Company's yard here.

A Government attorney disclosed in Federal court yesterday that a person "in very high authority" had blocked the sale of the aluminum reduction plant in Massena, N. Y., to the Aluminum Company of America.

MONTREAL, March 29 (AP) -- Gordie Howe scored twice tonight to spark the Detroit Red Wings to a 3-1 triumph over the Montreal Canadiens in their best four-out-of-seven semi-final round Stanley Cup play-off series before 11,225 fans.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 29 -- A deal for Laraine Day to play the feminine lead in RKO's long-delayed "I Married a Communist," has reached final stages of negotiation, it was learned today from a studio source. The picture has been repeatedly postponed since last fall, and Paul Lukas, who was signed for one of the leading roles, already has been paid $50,000 for his now-expired commitment to appear in the film.

BERLIN, March 29 -- The timing of the Western powers' announcement that fifty-two square miles of territory on Germany's Western borders would soon become part of other countries could hardly have been worse, in the opinion of United States, British and French officials, as well as leading Germans.

Another 10,000 New Yorkers yesterday joined the 30,500 who on Monday had obtained applications for Woodside Houses. Fifty-first Street and Northern Boulevard, Queens. The first of the New York City Housing Authority project's 1,357 apartments are to be ready late in May.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 29 -- The prospect that the 21-year-old annual awards of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences will be abandoned because of opposition from "New York home offices" of the major film companies was disclosed today by Jean Hersholt, retiring president of the academy.

A commission composed of men of the stature of Viscount Mount-batten of England should be sent by the principal North Atlantic Pact signatories to Russia to convince the Russians that this security pact is defensive and not aggressive in its nature, Prof. Harold J. Laski declared last night.

LINCOLN, R. I., March 29 (AP) -- The Lansing Stable's Patty Knot led E. A. Simpson's Solater by half a length and then withstood a claim of foul by the latter's rider to win the Cranston Purse today at Lincoln Downs.

Mayor O'Dwyer has been asked to use his "influence" to delay consummation of a real estate deal between Sailors Snug Harbor and New York University, pending a full investigation "to protect the public interest."

Park Commissioner Robert Moses scored a legal victory yesterday in his battle to have New York's 140-year-old Castle Clinton razed, when the Appellate Division set aside an injunction that forbade the demolition unless approved by the New York City Art Commission.

Maria-Theresa, one of the six adopted daughters of Isadora Duncan as well as one of her most distinguished disciples, last night presented a solo program of "Poems of the Dance" at the Carnegie Recital Hall in commemoration of the centenary of the death of Chopin.
WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP) -- The Government's Export-Import Bank, which makes loans abroad, reported today "net earnings" of $23,700,000 in the last half of 1948.

The Jamaica track, where metropolitan flat racing will get under way Friday for another year, was the scene of constant activity yesterday. The jockey colony was beginning to assemble and horses were being vanned and shipped in steadily during the day.

The recently increased personnel of the Police Department's waterfront squads foreshadows the day when the waterfront "will be just as nice as any other place in the city," Police Commissioner William P. O'Brien declared here yesterday.

With Eugene Ormandy taken ill, Alexander Hilsberg, associate conductor, took over last night's Carnegie Hall concert of the Philadelphia Orchestra and directed an all-Wagner program with dramatic power and incandescent fervor. It was Wagner, thanks to the discipline and opulence of this orchestra, at its best.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- Attempts to explain the status of the national economy were bogged down today in a morass of semantics. Official Washington appeared to be as confused as the average taxpayer about the country's financial position.

A rugged former taxicab driver who drew away the brace encasing his fractured neck and walked out of a hospital, was under arrest yesterday as the alleged leader of a gang of hijackers who stole fourteen trucks containing $164,000 in merchandise.
LONDON, March 29 -- Although this was the last day of the account, the stock markets made a reasonably good showing here today due to some bare closing in quiet conditions.

THE second-guess is an integral part of sport. Practically everyone who saw the Villemain-La Motta fight at the Garden last Friday -- and most of those who didn't -- thought that the Frenchman won from here to the Eiffel Tower and back again. Two important dissenters were Harry Ebbets, the referee, and Harold Barnes, one of the judges.

After a couple of days on the 100-yard range, trying out two new varmint rifles, we arrived at two conclusions: one, that it was just as well we were trying for groups and not score; two, that we should spend more time on the range.

ALBANY, March 29 -- The Senate approved tonight a bill suspending for another year the statutory ban on the use of oleomargarine in any hospital or other institution supported in whole or in part by public funds. It now goes to the Assembly.

DETROIT, March 29 -- In an election expected to influence strongly contract wage negotiations in the automobile industry this year, Thomas Thompson has led his right-wing slate to victory in Local 600 of the United Automobile mobile Workers, CIO. The local comprises workers at the giant Rouge plant of the Ford Motor Company.

An understanding by Americans of Britain's need to pursue a vigorous selling policy in dollar markets in its efforts to make itself self-supporting was urged last night by Sir Greville Maginness, president of the British Employers Confederation. He spoke at a dinner of the Anglo-American Council on Productivity at the Plaza Hotel.

BATAVIA, Java, March 29 (AP) -- A Dutch informant said today that Dr. Soekiman, leader of the powerful All-Moslem Masjumi party (Right Wing Republicans), had been permitted to return to the Indonesian Republican capital, Jogjakarta.

MAYS LANDING, N. J., March 28 -- The residents of this community went to church today to pray for divine assistance to save their jobs in the town's main industry, a textile mill now gradually closing down.

LONDON, March 29 -- The Commonwealth Prime Ministers will meet in London on April 21 Prime Minister Clement Attlee announced in the House of Commons today. It can now be stated with assurance that this meeting will concern itself primarily and perhaps exclusively with the vital problem of India's future relationship to the Commonwealth.

Federal authorities here announced yesterday that Betty Gannett, assistant organizational secretary of the national Communist party, had been released from Ellis Island on $1,000 bail after her arrest Monday evening for a deportation hearing.

ALBANY, March 29 -- The Feinberg bill to eliminate from public school employment persons affiliated with organizations listed as subversive by the State Board of Regents was passed in the Senate today by a vote of 41 to 14 and sent to the Assembly.

PARIS, March 29--Charles de Gaulle praised the North Atlantic pact today as "an important manifestation of intentions," but he said that its practical effects could be judged only when it became known what would follow in the way of arms and a strategic plan.

How industrial plants may reduce operating costs without sacrificing their safety standards was discussed yesterday at one of nine sessions on the opening day of the Greater New York Safety Council's nineteenth annual convention.

Extensions for standard card tables, as well as folding tables that may be expanded to serve more than four people at cards -- or at dinner -- are increasing in variety of both style and size, judging by the selections available in local stores.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., March 29 -- Only the soundest possible judgment in making consumer-credit loans will keep losses low in this period of threatened economic stress, the National Consumer Installment Credit Conference, sponsored by the American Bankers Association, heard today.

Over-all retail orders for cast-iron summer furniture are equal to last year and volume is already heavier in some cases, D. Richards Bradley, treasurer of the National Association of Summer Furniture Manufacturers, reported yesterday. He said that individual store purchasing is small but steady.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- First blood in the semi-final playoffs of the Basketball Association of America was drawn tonight by the Washington Capitols, who downed the New York Knickerbockers, 77 -- 71, before 4,000 persons.

Four prisoners made a break for freedom last night at the city penitentiary on Rikers Island and remained in hiding for several hours after an intensive man-hunt had been started and police throughout the city had been alerted.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- The Army issued two directives today that tighten enlistment and reenlistment rules, especially as they relate to men with dependents. The shortage of family-unit housing was cited by the Army as one important factor in revising the regulations.

LOS ANGELES, March 29 -- Russia's drive for world domination has been "stopped cold" in Western Europe and economic recovery in that area by 1952 will "more than probably" force the Kremlin into a "live and let live" policy, Paul G. Hoffman, Economic Cooperation Administrator, asserted today.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 29 -- The Yugoslav Government issued today a sweeping denial of every rumor circulated abroad in recent weeks alleging internal disorders and revolts in Yugoslavia, attempts to assassinate Marshal Tito, troop mobilization, army purges and secret political negotiations with representatives of the Western powers.

Two new issues of public utility and railroad securities totaling $16,060,000 will be placed on the market today. The new flotations were purchased by banking groups at public competitive bidding. The offerings are as follows:

HOUSTON, Tex., March 29 -- The Dodgers were grounded again today. Their chartered DC 4, which took off about 3:30 P. M. from New Orleans after an uneventful flight from Vero Beach, was forced to pass over Beaumont, their destination, and land at this city seventy-eight miles west.
For the first time in its sixty-three ears, the city's branch of the American Association of University Women has a home of its own.
WASHINGTON, March 29 -- The State Department announced the signing in Helsinki today of an air transport agreement on standard lines between the United States and Finland.

Unlike the oyster, pearls are in season the year round, although for summer they will have as rivals in the costume jewelry field white chalk beads. This is the general trend seen throughout collections that are going into the stores.

It is good news that a nonpartisan organization of some seven hundred well-known people in all parts of the country has been formed, under the leadership of President Robert Johnson of Temple University, to work for "far-reaching and enduring reforms in the Federal Government" on the basis of the reports of the Hoover Commission.

The twenty-first annual Wightman Cup tennis matches between women's teams of the United States and Great Britain will be played at the Merion Cricket Club, Haverford, Pa., Sept. 9 and 10, the United States Lawn Tennis Association announced yesterday.
Balmy spring sunshine has brought the pitchmen of lower Broadway out of their winter hibernation with a great variety of low-priced wares for sale to the noonday throngs of lower Manhattan.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 29 -- The fight for women's suffrage has begun in earnest in the Arabic world of the veil and the harem as a result of the women's meetings here.

CHICAGO, March 29 -- The Mid-West Shippers Advisory Board predicted today that in the second quarter of this year 1.7 per cent fewer freight cars would be loaded in the Midwest area, which centers on Chicago, than were loaded in the second quarter of 1948.

NEW CITY, N. Y., March 29 -- Rockland County Supervisors adopted a resolution unanimously today asking the Federal Government not to convert the atom bomb plant at Oak Ridge, Tenn., from coal fuel to natural gas because local home owners and factories would suffer from a gas shortage.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- The House Veterans Committee began hearings on a watered-down pension bill today in the face of strong indications that the Truman Administration would oppose it on the same grounds that it fought the original bill introduced by Representative John E. Rankin, Democrat, of Mississippi.

The Chesapeak Ohio Railway Company last year had record operating revenues of $334,555,157, compared with $312,953,036 in 1947, according to the road's seventy-first annual report released for publication today.

A low bid of $3,046,000 was submitted yesterday for the general construction of the Charles W. Berry Houses in the Dongan Hills section of Staten Island, it was announced by the New York City Housing Authority.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- A formidable campaign to cut by 10 per cent the Administration's $5,580,000,000 bill to carry forward the European Recovery Program was opened late today by two Senate leaders, one a Republican and the other a Southern Democrat.

William P. Buckner and Stephen S. Tolk, two professional gamblers who last summer promoted a Park Avenue gambling party under the guise of charity, were sent to the penitentiary for one year each yesterday in Special Sesions. A third defendent, Charles (Chic) Farmer, night club press agent, received a six-month jail term for persuading guests to gamble.

BOWIE, Md., March 29 (AP) -- Proving quite disturbing to form players in the crowd of approximately 9,000. J. Rittiner's 4-to-1 shot Arnie won the Anchorage Purse today as the Rarco Stable's odds-on favorite Bull could not finish better than third in the six-horse field.

PHILADELPHIA, March 29 -- Formation of a "nonpartisan and nonsectarian" citizens committee to press for Congressional action on economic and efficiency reforms through reorganization of the Executive Branch of the Federal Government was announced here today.

LONDON, March 29 -- Britain's doctors, who now are being paid at an annual average rate equivalent to nearly $10,000 for their work in the Labor Government's universal free medical service, demanded more money today to meet higher living costs.

The Condon-Mailler Disability Insurance Bill is in no sense an adequate answer to the real need of workers for social insurance against loss of income due to temporary disability, and would saddle the state with an administratively complex and financially unsound system.

The production of thousands of apartments, a drive by landlords to obtain rent rises that will give them "fair net operating income" and continued operation as usual by the City Rent Commission were forecast here yesterday, as Congress passed the Federal rent control bill.
Port warehousemen on strike in Brooklyn, Staten Island and New Jersey voted overwhelmingly yesterday to return to work this morning for a thirteen-cent hourly increase retroactive to Dec. 1.

SARASOTA, Fla., March 30 (AP) -- With two out in the twelfth inning, Vern Stephens powered a 400-foot home run over the left field wall today, providing Boston's Red Sox with a 1-0 triumph over the Detroit Tigers.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 30 -- Warner Brothers announced today that the studio will put eight pictures before the cameras in the next five weeks, ending the period of inactivity which has seen the start since November of only one film at the studio, the current Jane Wyman vehicle.

CHICAGO, March 30 -- Grain markets made a strong close on the Board of Trade today after being slightly lower early. An advance in parity price on grain as of March 15 compared with Feb. 15, except on wheat, was a market influence.

ALBANY, March 30 -- Senator Benjamin F. Feinberg, of Plattsburg, Republican leader of the Upper House of the Legislature since 1944, was appointed chairman of the Public Service Commission today. He will be sworn in tomorrow.
A dispute over the manning of three new Pan American Stratocruisers without radio operators threatened yesterday to tie up, possibly tomorrow, the line's world-wide air network.

WASHINGTON, March 30. (UP) -- Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican, of Ohio, said tonight that the North Atlantic pact might increase the chance of another world war, and called on the Senate and public for a "complete discussion" of the issues before binding the nation to abide by it.

Aided by the rearmament program and a good market for farm machinery, the Sperry Corporation raised its shipments and profits sharply in 1948, Thomas A. Morgan, president and chairman, declares in the annual report, issued for publication today.

ALBANY, Thursday, March 31--With the Republican leadership back in control after quelling several incipient rank-and-file revolts, the 172d session of the State Legislature adjourned sine die this morning after passing a number of major bills.

WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP) -- Two Pittsburgh subsidiaries of the Columbia Gas System, Inc., asked the Federal Power Commission today to authorize construction, retirement and sale of natural gas facilities in New York and New Jersey.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended March 23:

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 30 -- Joe DiMaggio made his first start of the year in centerfield today at Al Lang Field, but figured only inconspicuously in a 7-to-6 victory over the Reds in eleven innings that pulled the Yankees out of a four-game losing streak.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill. March 30 -- An ex-Communist was hired today by the Illinois Legislature's Seditious Activities Commission to help it hunt for Communists in Chicago colleges.

The case made by advertising and publishing groups against high increases in mailing rates was credited yesterday with probable killing of the "more fantastic" rate boost proposals. These, a group spokesman said, were provision of a sliding scale of second-class rates based on the ratio of publications' reading matter to advertising content, and empowering the postoffice to class reading matter mentioning products, prices or companies as advertising.

Electric rate reductions totaling $1,200,000 a year will go into effect tomorrow for customers of the Long Island Lighting Company in most of Nassau and Suffolk Counties and parts of Queens. The reduction was ordered by the Public Service Commission yesterday following the filing with the commission last Thursday of revised tariffs as recommended recently by a majority of the commissioners.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 30 -- The establishment of a military dictatorship in Damascus today by the Syrian Army under Commander in Chief Husni Zayim is understood here to be a victory for extreme nationalism. The seizure of power also is considered a triumph for the groups favoring some sort of unity with Iraq, to be followed, perhaps, by a broader unification of Arab territories.

SHANKS VILLAGE, N. Y., March 30 -- Private business establishments operating under Government lease in the veterans' housing project here as well as a cooperative market catering to 1,150 member families received notice today that their leases would be canceled effective June 30. No reason was given for the order.

Presidents of five major motion-picture companies meeting here yesterday confirmed the report from Hollywood on Tuesday by Jean Hersholt, retiring president of the Motion Picture Academy of Arts and Sciences, that the industry no longer would support the Academy's annual film awards.
A stand opposing ratification by Congress of the Havana Charter for an International Trade Organization on six principal grounds was taken yesterday by the National Association of Manufacturers.

BERLIN, March 30 -- A great guessing game on the Soviet Union's intentions in Germany got going again today on the heels of Marshal Vassily D. Sokolovsky's reassignment to be Deputy Minister of the Soviet armed forces but no one in any position of authority pretended to know what it meant.

ALBANY, March 30 -- The Wachtel-Butler Bill appropriating $30,000 for three experimental classes for the instruction of children suffering from cerebral palsy was sent to the Governor today after unanimous approval by the Senate.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- A Congressional drive for a bigger military budget got briskly under way today with a request by the chairman of the House Armed Services Committee for $1,599,600,000 more than President Truman's proposed figure of $14,765,000,000.

Dr. Jaime Torres Bodet, Director General of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, maintained yesterday that the holding of the Cultural and Scientific Conference for World Peace -- and any international meeting -- was in keeping with the traditions of the United Nations.
Your recent article, "Recruiting the New Teacher," caught the eye particularly of those of us who, each year, have to fill in the ranks of faculties.
What to wear and how to wear it were told in detail to 3,000 women in Loeser's spring fashion show yesterday afternoon in the Garden City Hotel for customers from the Garden City branch store.

LOS ANGELES, March 30 (AP) -- A. Atwater Kent, retired radio manufacturer who died March 4 at the age of 75, left $1,335,000 to charities and educational institutions and $2,000,000 to his widow, Mabel Lucas Kent, from whom he had been separated for eight years.

Education on the Declaration of Human Rights should be approached state by state instead of on a national basis, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, chairman of the United Nations Commission on Human Rights, declared yesterday.

Department and specialty stores throughout the nation took lower profits during 1948 rather than jeopardize sales volume, according to a report issued yesterday by the Controllers Congress of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

Regal Electronics Corporation yesterday introduced the first ten-inch tube television receiver built to retail for less than $200 at a press preview of its new line in the New Yorker Hotel. The set, a table model, will list for $199.50 and is $20 lower than the nearest competitive model, according to B. H. Rice, general sales manager.
After a twenty-four-hour manhunt by air, sea and land, four convicts who had escaped from Rikers Island Penitentiary were still at large last night.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- John W. Snyder, Secretary of the Treasury, said today the Treasury was nearly half way through sending out refunds for overpayment of 1948 income taxes and hoped to finish the job by June 1.

Participants in the WQXR "What's on Your Mind?" forum on the subject, "Do We Need a National Divorce Law?" agreed last night that marital clinics, established throughout the country, would help eliminate many of the problems of marriage and divorce.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today refused to rule that bus fare increases made effective between New York and points in Bergen County, N. J., and Rockland County, N. Y., in April, 1947, were unlawful.

BOSTON, March 30 (AP) -- The Toronto Maple Leafs, defenders, gained the Stanley Cup's final round by out-skating the Boston Bruins for a 3-2 victory and a four-games-to-one margin in the National Hockey League's B Series play-offs tonight before a capacity crowd of 13,909 at the Boston Garden.

A 60-year-old man who is accused of abetting the suicide of a life-long friend by giving him a pistol, was arraigned yesterday in Felony Court on a charge that court attaches said had not been used since 1906.

A new career-planning and placement procedure for college graduates was announced yesterday at a meeting of the Columbia University student chapter of the American Institute of Industrial Engineers. The program has been developed by the Society for the Advancement of Management for 4,500 students in seventy - five chapters in the country.

Some retailers are preparing to drastically restrict or eliminate entirely promotions of full ninety-three piece dinnerware sets, buyers reported yesterday. A spokesman for a large buying group said his stores will concentrate on twelve-piece "starter" sets to retail as low as $23.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., March 30 (AP) -- The groundwork was laid today for a Federal Supreme Court test of Birmingham's regulation requiring separation of Negroes and whites. It came at the opening of Senator Glen Taylor's appeal from a police court conviction here last May 5.
LINCOLN, R. T., March 30 (AP) -- G. Y. Booker's Lawless Miss, a heavily played second choice, today won the featured Westerly Purse before a crowd of 7,995 at Lincoln Downs.

As a result of the spring weather, every day that passes promises better opening day fishing on the Catskill and southern New York streams. Reports from a number of these waters indicate that conditions right now are better than they have been in some years.

WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP) -- A steel company official today asked Congress to block for two years any Federal Trade Commission action to ban the basing point pricing system. But a CIO spokesman said the lawmakers should not intervene in that manner.

Ordered by the State Department to quit this country within a "reasonable time," several members of the Soviet and satellite nations delegations to the recent Cultural and Scientific Conference for World Peace succeeded yesterday in booking passage for their home countries.

ALBANY, March 30 -- following is the result of today's roll-call vote in the Assembly on passage of the Feinberg bill directing the Board of Regents to purge school systems of teachers who are members of subversive organizations:

WASHINGTON, March 30 -Pressure by the Communist-dominated World Federation of Trade Unions on some affiliates of the Congress of Industrial Organizations to continue relations with the WFTU are regarded here as a threat to CIO policy that will be met by disciplinary action against any affiliate yielding to the pressure.

In the healthy American tradition of expressing approval and disapproval of our public officials, the undersigned wish to register their protest against the general attitude and particular votes of Dorothy Kenyon, appointed by President Truman to represent us in the United Nations, where she is a member of the Commission on the Status of Women.

Rival factions within the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, CIO, were warned yesterday by Allan S. Heywood, organizational director of CIO, to halt internal dissension and organize a united program in the interests of the labor movement.

WASHINGTON, March 30 (UP) -- Representative Emanuel Celler, Democrat, of New York, demanded today that the Federal Power Commission cancel a private sale of $60,000,000 in utility bonds to insurance companies and order them sold by public competitive bidding.

PHILADELPHIA, March 30 -- An estimated increase of 9,000,000 school children during the next ten years, bringing the total number in elementary and high schools to 34,000,000, threatens American education with a "grave crisis," school leaders warned here today.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- Winston Churchill, Britain's war leader, today emphatically denied a statement made on the floor of the Senate that he had fought against the United States in the Spanish-American War.
LONDON, March 30 -- A reasonably good start of the new account was made in the stock market here today with the gold-share market claiming most interest.

Another round in the fight between banks and savings and loan associations, was begun yesterday. The American Bankers Association filed a protest brief with the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, in Washington charging that the board, in proposed new regulations for the associations, is attempting to mislead the public through permitting those institutions to describe their shares as "savings accounts" and to term themselves "Federal Savings Associations."

DAMASCUS, March 30 (AP) -- Brigadier Zayim said the coup was to deliver Syria from "despotism" and would not interfere with previous foreign engagements. His statement was taken to mean that Syria would go ahead with negotiations for an armistice with Israel.

A few days after the year's first warm week-end is the obvious time to sit straight and clear up a few of the misconceptions about spring. That season is the creature of the poet and the lyricist. The word, spring, happens to rhyme with wing, which suggests the soaring flight of either birds or its rhyme, words; with sing, suggesting a happy carol; and with zing, meaning zip.
With the alternative of a twenty-month jail sentence confronting them, three self-admitted rent gougers were told yesterday in Special Sessions they had until April 18 to raise fines of $5,000 each.
Andrei A. Gromyko came back to town yesterday with a new job, a new suit and the same old determined "no comment" on just about everything diplomatic.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- The quarterly report of the Council of Economic Advisers, which will be put in President Truman's hands in a week or ten days, is expected to reflect the easing of the economic situation and consequently a diminishing need for the standby price controls requested by the President.

The military coup d'etat in Syria will have little effect on the current peace trend in the Middle East, it was asserted by Lieut. Col. Mati Dagan, a member of the general staff of the Israeli Army, upon his arrival at La Guardia Field yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- An immediate and broad expansion of the world-wide information program being conducted by the State Department, including the activities of the Voice of America, was urged today by the United States Advisory Commission on Information in its first semi-annual report to Congress.

A wide division appeared yesterday among the New York locals of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, AFL, over the issue of support or non-support of a nation-wide check starting tomorrow on the union status of truck drivers.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- A determined Republican drive to cut deeply into the second installment of $5,580,000,000 in the four-year Marshall Plan was opened today by Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio and was gathering momentum when the Senate adjourned to resume debate tomorrow.

PANAMA, March 30 (AP) -- Delegates to the national merchant marine conference are drafting a declaration that they say will refute charges of substandard wages and working conditions on ships flying the Panama flag.

The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange gained strength yesterday and final prices were 6 to 26 points net higher than on Tuesday, with the distant months relatively stronger than near months.

TEL AVIV, Israel, March 30 -- Premier David Ben-Gurion informed the Knesset (assembly) tonight that the Government had instructed the Israeli delegation at Lake Success to request a United Nations inquiry as to whether the Arab states, particularly Syria and Iraq, were complying with the General Assembly resolution outlawing genocide.

Conflicting opinions concerning the cost, efficiency and "socialistic aspect" of the proposed national health program were presented yesterday by a Government official and a representative of the American Medical Association before members of the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies.

A development which ought to end the last Communist pretense that the struggle in Greece is a Greek civil war, and should establish its character clearly as an international conflict under the direction of Soviet Russia's Cominform, is announced by the Greek rebel radio station.

Paul Hindemith, one of Germany's outstanding composers, who left his native land after Nazi attacks had been made on his music, returned to the United States yesterday on the Queen Elizabeth from his first visit to Germany since the Nazis were overthrown.

LAKE SUCCESS, March 30 -- In a statement made public here today, Dr. Luis Gomez Ruiz, Venezuelan Foreign Minister, denied charges that his Government was holding 2,000 political prisoners arrested when the new Venezuelan Government had come into power last November.
WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP) -- An improvement in the supply of metals was emphasized by two Department of Commerce actions today:

With a city election coming on Nov. 8, representative of business industry and labor will express approval of Mayor O'Dwyer's administration at a testimonial luncheon for him today at the Commodore Hotel.

The nation's gasoline stocks last week reached a new high record of 128,087,000 barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute. This was an increase of 777,000 barrels over the 127,310,000 at the end of the preceding week.

Representative Lesinski, chairman of the Labor Committee, has asked the House of Representatives for a "closed rule" on his Administration bill to repeal the Taft-Hartley Act and to substitute therefor the old Wagner Act with a few comparatively trifling amendments.

Jed Harris' production, "The Traitor," will be unfolded on Broadway tonight at 8:15 o'clock at the Forty-eighth Street Theatre. The author, Herman Wouk, a newcomer to these parts, has written several novels, the latest of these being "The City Boy."

UNION CITY, N. J., March 30 -- An 80-year-old recluse who died as a charity patient at North Hudson Hosiptal in Weehawken, N. J., on March 12 left an estate that the police of this city believe will amount to nearly $500,000.

Two American painters who have studied abroad take a look at the world and present differing reports on their canvases. At the Babcock Gallery is the work of Holmead, Pennsylvania-born but better known in Europe, where his masters were Vlaminck and the Belgian expressionist Permeke.

DURING the war years money was merely some green stuff with incendiary characteristics. It burned holes in pockets. The wisest thing to do therefore was to get rid of it. The favorite unloading spots were the hoss pavilions where large chunks were fed into the hungry maw of the Iron Men in bountiful profusion.

The New York Legislature's 172d session, which began on Jan. 5 and adjourned early today, turned in, on the whole, a creditable record of accomplishment. Some good things got lost, some bad things got through; the defects can be cured in part but not in entirety by the Governor's veto.

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 30 -- The Giants, who already have given ample evidence that they are very apt to be the year's most unpredictable ball club, gave more of the same today as they turned about to give Billy Meyer's Pirates, currently the hottest cast in the grapefruit belt, a round going over.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- The House received today the first of several bills that Representative John S. Wood, chairman of the Committee on Un-American Activities, is drafting as the basis for an item-by-item legislative program to curb Communist activities.
HAMILTON, Bermuda, March 30 (AP) -- The three top-seeded players -- Don McNeill, Earl Cochell and Bill Vogt -- moved into the semi-finals today in the Bermuda tennis championships.

Nat Holman was honored by the United States-Israel Sports Committee at a dinner at Toots Shor's last night. The veteran City College basketball coach is scheduled to take off tomorrow for Israel, whose Government has invited him to help in the development and promotion of the court pastime in the new state.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., March 30 -- A wealthy recluse directed in her will, filed for probate here today, that her body be cremated and her ashes scattered on the grave of her dog, Chief, in the Hartsdale Canine Cemetery. Most of her estate was left to charity.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- The Truman Administration plans to ask Congress soon to approve a multi-billion-dollar omnibus health program, of which compulsory health insurance would be only one of six major features.

To enjoy "The Biggest Thief in Town," which opened at the Mansfield last evening, you have to do Dalton Trumbo one favor. You have to agree that an undertaker's parlor is a comic place and that body-snatching is hilarious. To judge by the laughter in the theatre last evening, many people have no difficulty in agreeing with Mr. Trumbo's ghoulish point of view.

MEMPHIS, March 30 -- Mankind's new armament of scientific tools should be used to explore the mysteries of the plant kingdom to provide an "ever-renewing source" of abundance, Wheeler McMillen, president of the National Farm Chemurgic Council, declared today.
WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Truman's statement today on signing of the rent control bill:

How a racket endangering California motorists was broken up and the resultant supply of footwear for destitute people in China increased, was described yesterday at the annual safety convention sponsored by the Greater New York Safety Council at the Statler Hotel.

NANKING, March 22 -- A "millet economy" and a commodity backed currency, first tried out in the backward hinterlands, have been applied by the Communists in their new experiment with big city rule in North China. The Reds are relying on the poor man's cereal and other "daily necessities" to back their people's bank note, cushion inevitable currency depreciation and help pay wages.

After making four promotions among officers, Fire Commissioner Frank J. Quayle promised yesterday that he would fill fourteen vacancies in the higher ranks before July 1, provided the necessary funds were made available by Budget Director Thomas J. Patterson.

Sales of the Philco Corporation last year reached a new high record of $275,424,340, exceeding the 1947 volume of $226,507,592 by $48,916,000, or 21 per cent, with virtually every major division sharing in the growth, the fifty-seventh annual report to shareholders disclosed yesterday.

Government buying and stronger Southern crude markets aided the advance of cottonseed oil futures on the New York Produce Exchange yesterday. Except for a brief sell-off with action in the Western markets the futures market showed considerable strength.

Complete financing for Eagle-Lion's requirements for the next twelve months has been arranged, it was announced yesterday by Arthur B. Krim, president, before leaving for Hollywood. Actual shooting at the studios will begin in two or three weeks, with the first pictures to go before the cameras being two Bryan Foy productions, "Port of New York" and "Trapped."

Briefs submitted to Federal Judge Simon H. Rifkind yesterday by the Government and by an attorney acting as a friend of the court agreed that Valentin A. Gubitchev, Soviet engineer under arrest on an espionage charge, could not legally claim diplomatic immunity.

The increasingly bitter competition between the country's two leading manufacturers of phonograph records, Columbia Records and the Radio Corporation of America, neared the "show-down" phase yesterday as Columbia announced a price cut of approximately 20 per cent on its standard ten and twelve-inch records, effective April 1.

ALBANY, March 30 -- This year's session of the State Legislature, which neared its end tonight with clocks stopped in both Senate and Assembly, has been punctuated by a series of clashes between members of the Republican majorities in the two houses and Governor Dewey.

JAIPUR, India, March 30 -- The "children of the sun and moon," famous Rajput princes who claim descent from those celestial bodies and have maintained some degree of independence against the changing tides of Indian history for 1,000 years, went into eclipse today.

New York State achieved a record low in automobile accident deaths in 1948, excluding the war years, Commissioner Clifford J. Fletcher of the Bureau of Motor Vehicles announced yesterday. He spoke at the annual safety conference sponsored by the Greater New York Safety Council at the Statler Hotel.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 30 -- The impending visit of Winston Churchill overshadowed today's final preparations for the three-day, mid-century scientific convocation that will begin tomorrow at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
Postoffice officials here are conducting a large-scale drive to uncover the "big operators" behind a new wave of Mexican Sweepstakes tickets flooding the city, it became known yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -Secretary of State Dean Acheson said today that he was beginning a series of informal conversations with other Foreign Ministers on many questions relating to the integration of the Western nations.

FRANKFORT, Germany, March 30 -- United States Air Force Headquarters in Europe announced today the arrival of Maj. Gen. Clayton Bissell, who has held some of the highest positions in the Army and Air Force, to face charges that might lead to a courtmartial.
Television's growth as a mass advertising and entertainment medium was pictured yesterday as a force for expanding the national economy, and as a possible depression preventive.

The filing this year of state income tax returns, the deadline for which is April 15, is lagging "far behind previous years" in the metropolitan area, the State Department of Taxation and Finance reported yesterday. Offices here have received only 12,000 returns so far this year, as compared with 20,000 twelve months ago.

All the major radio and television networks and most independent stations will air the proceedings connected with the signing of the North Atlantic Pact in Washington on Monday afternoon. Originating in the Interdepartmental Auditorium in the Labor Department Building, the ceremony represents a culmination of months of conferences and negotiations between the United States, Canada and ten Europe an countries.

FRANKFORT, Germany, March 30 -- The United States and British Military Governments have "invited" the German bizonal administration to draft anti-trust legislation that would place in the hands of the Germans some of the authority and responsibility for the decartelization program.

Retail sales of perfumes, cosmetics and other toilet preparations, excluding toilet soaps, totaled $687,600,000 during 1948, it was announced yesterday by the Toliet Goods Association, Inc. This compares with $682,100,000 in 1947, an increase of about 0.8 per cent.

Carlos Guimard of Argentina and Rodrigo Flores of Chile were the winners yesterday in the twelfth round of the international chess masters tournament at Mar del Plata, according to a report received from Argentina.

BOISE, Idaho, March 30 -- The Chamber of Commerce of the United States set out today to "offset pro-Columbia Valley Authority propaganda coming from Washington" and to show the country that there was "at least a division of opinion" in the Pacific Northwest as to whether a valley authority should be created to direct the destiny of the Columbia River basin.
Richard H. Crowe, assistant manager of the National City Bank branch at 195 Broadway who disappeared last Sunday, appeared yesterday to have taken with him a record amount of...

DAMASCUS, Syria, March 30 -- The army executed a bloodless coup just before dawn today. All towns and strategic points in Syria were reported quiet and in control of the army tonight. Communications were cut, except for official use, in the interest of security, but there has been no sign of any countermove, and Brig. Husni Zayim, leader of the army, is in full control.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- The House Rules Committee, considering a request for a procedural rule on the Lesinski labor bill, continued today with a hearing that was sometimes disorderly and seldom dealt with the rule.

Mrs. Durand Taylor of South Orange, N. J., state chairman of the International Relations Committee of the New Jersey Congress of Parents and Teachers, will sail for Europe next Tuesday aboard the liner America, it was announced yesterday. Working through various national ministries of education, she will make a survey of schools and communities that have been aided by Americans.

DAMASCUS, Syria, March 30 -- Israel has dropped her demand for mention of the British forces at Aqaba in the Israeli-Transjordanian armistice agreement. The text of the agreement is virtually settled, it was reported on good authority in Rhodes today.
ALBANY, March 30 -- The Nurse Practice Act, passed by the Legislature in 1938, will go into effect Friday. The act requires the licensing of all persons who nurse for hire.

Broadtail, mink, fox and ermine were the luxurious mediums selected by Ritter Brothers to show off to full advantage the artistry of their spring designs in a showing yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. Characteristic of the handsome wraps were the soft, natural shoulders that dominated, whether the style be cape or jacket.

Three hours of picketing came to a highly satisfactory anti-climax yesterday for Mrs. Thomas Colligan and her 22-month-old son, Thomas Jr. Alternately carrying and leading the child, Mrs. Colligan carried a sign outside the New York City Housing Authority offices at 2 Frankfort Street, only to learn at the end that had she gone inside she would have found that the apartment she sought was ready for her.

Taking advantage of the early seasonable weather, millinery stores and departments are pushing hat sales to equal or surpass last year's peak figures, according to millinery buyers. Some of the larger stores will exceed their February to May, 1948, volume by at least 5 per cent, they said, as the result of concerted promotional efforts.

Coincident with the announcement of completion of the merger of Foremost Dairies, Inc. of Jacksonville, Fla., and Maxson Foods System, Inc., under the name of the former, Paul E. Reinhold, president of the merged company, reported yesterday that earnings before taxes of the dairy unit of the business were about $250,000 larger in the first twelve weeks of this year than last year.
WASHINGTON, March 30 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today registration statements for debentures and stock filed with it.

The concert for children from elementary schools presented by the New York Youth Concert Association, Inc., yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall, was given before a sold-out house. An audience composed of 2,970 students from public and private schools of New Jersey, Connecticut, Long Island and Westchester County heard the program, performed by an orchestra of sixty pieces, under Wheeler Beckett.

Richard S. Reynolds Jr., president of the Reynolds Metals Company, testified in Federal Court yesterday in the Government's anti-trust proceeding against the Aluminum Company of America that his company was forced to close an aluminum-reduction plant in Longview, Wash., in May, 1947, when the market dropped.

The university medical clinic, keystone of medical education and training, is in a critical situation because of lack of sufficient funds, Dr. Walter W. Palmer of New York, president of the American College of Physicians, warned at the annual convocation of the college last night at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

PARIS, March 30 -- Foreign Minister Robert Schuman left tonight by plane for Washington to sign the North Atlantic Pact, to seek clarification of its military implications and to discuss German questions with Secretary of State Dean Acheson and Foreign Secretary Ernest Bevin.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, March 30 (AP) -- Howard Fast, left-wing American novelist, cabled the Rumanian Intellectuals Congress today that he had had "difficulties" in obtaining a United States passport for travel to Europe.

ST. LOUIS, March 30 -- R. M. Evans of Washington, a member of the Federal Reserve Board, made a strong defense today of regulation W, under which the board of governors of the Federal Reserve system prescribes terms and conditions for granting installment credit.

ALBANY, March 30 -- New York City will get a total of $23,600,000 in the city's next fiscal year out of the $40,000,000 in new state aid for schools. It originally had been expected that the city's share would be $17,600,000.

TOKYO, March 30 -- The first details of how the United States aid to Japan is going to be incorporated in the Japanese budget were made public today by the Economic Stabilization Board. Apparently, 175,000,000,000 yen will be divided among debt amortization, railway and telephone construction, and aid for industrial recovery.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson declared today that the United States Government "views with grave concern" the conviction in Czechoslovakia of two American soldiers and their sentence to ten and twelve years at hard labor on charge of espionage.
Though the electronic range that cuts cooking time from hours to minutes will not be possible for home kitchens for several years, one of its chief drawbacks is being overcome.

Defense Secretary Johnson's first day in the Pentagon was encouraging. He not only talked about unification of the armed services; he did something about it by ordering a concentration of cooperating interdepartment agencies around his own office. He promised to do even more unifying, either by consent or by decree.

To cope with an enrollment crisis caused by the post-war rise in birth rate, the Board of Education is planning to construct prefabricated elementary school buildings and other emergency structures to last from ten to twenty years.

THE EDITORS LUNCH CLUB put us over a barrel yesterday. Under the chairmanship of Henry James Jr. these arbiters of book publishing in America asked a probing lot of questions. We faced the cheerful Torquemadas of the written word with answers prepared on the eve of trial. We cannot speak for Lewis Gannett, Max Gissen or Robert Minton, but here are some of the questions, with our replies:
Operators of major taxi fleets announced yesterday their intention to keep thousands of cabs rolling after the start of the strike set for early tomorrow morning.

NANKING, March 30 -- Gen. Ku Chu-tung, Nationalist Chief of Staff, told the Legislative Yuan today that the Chinese Communist Army had carried its military preparations to a point where it would be ready to attack the Yangtze River line within the next sixty days if Kuomintang-Communist peace negotiations at Peiping failed.
WASHINGTON, March 30 --Claiming a "crushing defeat" of the real estate lobby, President Truman signed today the bill extending Federal rent controls for fifteen months.

Trading in stocks yesterday under the new margin requirements brought new gains in prices in an active session on the New York Stock Exchange. The advance, however, was not as sharp as on Tuesday. Prices eased from the opening levels, rallied in late trading, to end on an irregularly higher note.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- Paul T. Culbertson flew back to Madrid today to resume his post as Charge d'Affaires amid indications that the State Department would not change its policy of banning loans to Spain on the ground that the Franco regime was a bad political and financial risk.

ATHENS, March 30 -- About 600 purported representatives of communities in Greek, Yugoslav and Bulgarian Macedonia met this week in a small village in the Vitsi mountain area of northwestern Greece near the Albanian border, according to a rebel radio broadcast heard today in Salonika. The broadcast was believed to have been from Bulgarian soil.

Robert W. Kenny, a former Attorney General of the State of California and holder of 1,600 shares of capital stock of the Farnsworth Television and Radio Corporation, brought an action in Supreme Court here yesterday to enjoin the officers and directors of the corporation from holding any meeting of the stockholders for the purpose of considering or voting on a proposed sale of the company's assets to the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation.

LINDEN, N. J., March 30 -- A brown mongrel of Eskimo strain that has haunted the Esso Standard Oil Company's refinery docks here since last summer waiting for its master, believed to be a Norwegian ship's officer, was the subject today of a chain of messages sent to oil ports throughout the world in an effort to reunite the dog and its master.

A new chapter in the history of our armed forces opened in Washington this week as James Forrestal, retiring Secretary of Defense, turned over the most difficult office next to the Presidency to his successor, Louis Johnson.

LONDON, March 30 -- Representatives of the United States, Britain and France reached an agreement today after many months of hard bargaining on the issue of the dismantlement of German plants for reparations and on the list of prohibited German industries.

TEL AVIV, Israel, March 30 -- News of Syria's coup came as a surprise and shock to the Israeli Government. There are many schools of thought on the possible consequences, but the primary reaction is that the revolution will seriously delay armistice talks.
As one who more often than not agrees with your editorial position, I am driven by your treatment of the subject of veterans' pension legislation to write my first letter to an editor.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- Some of the country's top experts in ship construction began conferences here today on the cost of war features to be built into a 48,000-ton liner to be the largest passenger vessel ever constructed in the United States.

REYKJAVIK, Iceland, March 30 (UP) -- A Communist mob, defying club-swinging police, hurled stones into the chambers of Parliament today while it was voting, 37 to 13, to join the North Atlantic treaty and end Iceland's traditional isolationism.
WARSAW, March 30 -- Conclusion of a new trade agreement calling for the exchange of $152,000,000 worth of products with the Soviet zone of Germany was announced by the Polish Government today.

The Israeli Consulate reported yesterday that in the last three months 1,802 visas had been granted to Americans to visit Israel and that applications for visas were being received at the rate of thirty a day.

GREENBROOK TOWNSHIP, N. J., March 30 -- A bride-to-be and three of her bridesmaids were fatally injured last night and two others were badly hurt when their automobile, the brakes of which had apparently failed, crashed into the side of a truck trailer near here.

They have no recognizable faces any more. We used to know countries called Czechoslovakia, Hungary, Poland, Rumania. They had characteristic features, distinguishable from one another. Now they all wear the same mask, display the same manners, employ the same methods.

Unofficial but circumstantial reports from Washington early this week had it that Dr. Edwin G. Nourse, chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, was resigning his post. It now appears, however, that if the former Brookings Institution economist ever contemplated such action he has been persuaded to reconsider and remain in the Government.

The Equity Library Theatre yesterday launched its campaign to obtain $25,000 to continue operations next season by appealing to the members of Broadway shows. Of the sum required, the Actors Equity Association, sponsor of ELT, already has contributed $7,500.
WASHINGTON, March 30 -- National Air Lines, Inc., and Pan American Airways today completed a deal presaging direct air service between New York City and Latin America.

BONN, Germany, March 30 -- At the obvious dictation of its invalid chief, Dr. Kurt Schumacher, the Social Democratic faction in the Parliamentary Council here, risked the collapse of the entire project for a Western German state this afternoon.
MOSCOW, March 30 -- The flower of Soviet youth assembled in the Great Hall of the Kremlin last night for the first All-Union Komsomol [Communist Youth] Congress in thirteen years.
