A bright circus poster with a laughing clown caught the eye of 9-year-old Rose Gelbard two weeks ago -- exactly one week after she, her brother, Jackie, 4, and parents, Mr. and Mrs. Willi Gelbard, arrived in this country.

MEXICO, D. F., March 29 -- A Senate committee in Washington toward the end of April will have a hearing on the development of those Western hemispheric areas which could contribute greatly to a stable democratic world. Among these the backward regions of Mexico are in some ways the most important to the United States, and one of their chief handicaps is lack of transportation.

LONDON, March 30 -- The House of Commons conceded reluctantly tonight that Britain could not make enough first features to fill 45 per cent of the showing time in British theatres. To save the theatres from following studios into a slump, Commons agreed to reduce from 45 to 40 per cent the quota for first-feature British pictures that must be shown here.

Thirteen local housing authorities will receive bids on April 17 on issues of temporary-loan notes totaling $22,356,000 for financing Federal-aided projects, it was announced yesterday. Major borrowings included in the total are $1,120,000 by Boston; $1,350,000 by Camden, N. J.; $2,111,000 by Houston, Tex., and $13,789,000 by Los Angeles.

Failure once more to reach an agreement in a contractual wage review between East and Gulf Coast ship operators and the Masters, Mates and Pilots, AFL, threw the entire dispute into arbitration yesterday.

It is seldom that the pattern of trading in the stock market in two successive sessions is as similar as it was yesterday and Wednesday in forenoon dealings. After an active and higher opening, with many large blocks of stocks, the tape fell behind up to three minutes in reporting transactions in the early part of the first hour on both occasions.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., March 30 (AP) -- Superintendent of Banks Elliott V. Bell told New York State savings bankers tonight to be prudent in the use of newly enacted investment powers. Mr. Bell referred to a bill just passed by the Legislature permitting savings banks to invest up to the total of their surplus funds in securities not on the state's list of legal investments.

Hazards arising from the growing industrial use of radioactive materials are being controlled effectively by the Government and by industry, the annual convention of the Greater New York Safety Council was told yesterday.
Twenty-one action-filled bouts highlighted the second round of the Metropolitan A. A. U. boxing tournament at the New York Athletic Club last night.

Federal Judge Harold R. Medina rebuked Eugene Dennis and other defendants at the Communist trial yesterday for "sneering and snickering" while the judge was trying to explain the issues in the case to the jury.

The legend of Tristram and Iseult has been retold in many modern poems and, of course, in Wagner's opera. Once again it is the subject of a modern writer, Rut. Collier Sharpe, in "Tristram of Lyonesse: The Story of an Immortal Love."

BOWIE, Md., March 30 (AP) -- Blue Lancer, a lightly campaigned but highly proficient son of Blue Swords, charged through the stretch with a bid which was not to be denied and emerged victorious by two and one-half lengths in the first running of the six-furlong Farrell Handicap today.
BEAUMONT, Tex., March 30 -- The weather yesterday made it very difficult for the Dodgers to get into this Texas city and today made it almost as tough for them to get out.

A series of new upholstered pieces designed by Paul McCobb features the spring decorating show opening today at Modernage, 16 East Thirty-fourth Street. They are used in several arrangements with Martin Feinman's Multiplex Modern mahogany pieces that appear in a new finish, a silvery, washed effect called "platina."

To clear the air before the coming city election, the City Fusion party last night asked both Governor Dewey and Mayor O'Dwyer to explain certain recent political developments. Clendenin J. Ryan was challenged to prove his charges against the Mayor or "keep still."

A funeral service for Samuel M. Coplon, father of Miss Judith Coplon, who is under indictment on espionage conspiracy charges, was held yesterday at 12:45 P. M. in Gutterman's Prospect Park Memorial Chapel, 2239 Church Avenue, near Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn.

Following the lead given it by Ilya Ehrenburg in Pravda last September, the American Communist party has embarked upon an anti-Zionist line, the Morning Freiheit, Communist Yiddish newspaper, revealed Tuesday. The change in the American party's line also follows an intensive campaign against "Jewish bourgeois nationalism" and against leading Jewish cultural figures in the Soviet Union itself.

Of 135 taxicab drivers interviewed yesterday on the city's streets by a team of seven reporters of THE NEW YORK TIMES only five had attended Tuesday's meetings at which those present had voted unanimously for a strike beginning tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP) -- John W. Snyder, Secretary of the Treasury, said today that economic adjustments of recent months had been "healthy and helpful" and the outlook was for "continued prosperity."

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 30 -- Borba, official newspaper of the Yugoslav Communist party, took the line today that the Communist Information Bureau was in effect strengthening the policy of the United States and other sponsors of the North Atlantic treaty through its incessant attacks on Yugoslavia.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee of the National Board of Review, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14, a group of motion pictures to be shown, tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified. The programs follow:

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- Democratic and Republican members of the House Public Works Committee, at a hearing today on a bill to set up a commission on renovation of the Executive Mansion, asked why House authorization was by-passed for Senate appropriation on the $5,400,000 reconstruction of the White House.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 30 -- Marshal Tito's Government accused the Communist regime in neighboring Bulgaria tonight of instigating "repeated brutal attacks" on Yugoslav militiamen along the frontier.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- The House Veterans Committee received today a rough estimate that it might cost $6,752,000,000 over the next fifty years to provide $72-per-month pensions to World War I veterans with low incomes at the age of 65.

It is a case of win or out for the New York Knickerbockers tonight. To stay in the running for the Basketball Association of America play-off title, Coach Joe Lapchick's squad must defeat the Washington Capitols at Madison Square Garden.

CLEVELAND, March 30 -- George V. Allen, Assistant Secretary of State for Public Affairs, deplored "mental isolationism" today as he praised American steps, through the international exchange of students and teachers, to obtain a lasting peace making for human betterment.
ALBANY, March 30 -- The court reorganization proposals advanced by Presiding Justice David W. Peck of Appellate Division were killed tonight in the Assembly.
LONDON, March 30 -- British predictions that defeat in Palestine would cause political up-heavals in Arab states were fulfilled today in Syria, where the army seized control of the Government.

A group of fifteen women, comprising the All-English Ladies' Lacrosse Association touring team of 1949, arrived here yesterday aboard the liner Queen Mary. They will coach players and teachers of the game in this country.

DAMASCUS, March 30 (UP) -President Shukri al-Kuwatly, Premier Khalid el-Azem and other leaders were arrested in the coup, which was bloodless and without incident except for a lone attempt by Communists at Aleppo to oppose it.

Five hundred pickets, most of them protesting Britain's handling of the Palestine issue, demonstrated yesterday outside the Cunard White Star pier as the British Foreign Secretary, Ernest Bevin, arrived aboard the Queen Mary. Several pickets threw vegetables at Mr. Bevin's car as he drove off.

Ten thousand persons attended the thirtieth anniversary rally of the Uniformed Fireman's Association of Greater New York in Madison Square Garden last night. A speaking program was followed by entertainment and dancing.

First-quarter sales of durable goods are down about 10 per cent, compared with last year, distributors and manufacturers in the New York area revealed here yesterday during a canvass of the field. These companies market lines of small tools, light machine tools, power plant accessories, shop equipment and mechanical rubber goods, among other "durable" items.

In celebration of its fortieth anniversary, the Schola Cantorum, under Hugh Ross, presented Bach's "St. Matthew" Passion last night at Carnegie Hall. The chorus had sung the work previously with various orchestras, but had not performed it before at its own concerts.

If the boys and girls won't go to the museums, then take the museums to them. That is what the Board of Education and New York's leading cultural institutions are doing in an unusual program to show a series of priceless art collections in the public high schools.

NEWARK, N. J., March 30 -- Thomas J. Dolan, former executive director of the Harrison Housing Authority, pleaded guilty in Federal Court today to three counts of a four-count indictment charging him and three colleagues on the authority with conspiracy to defraud the Government in operation of a housing project.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Okla., March 30 -- There is no reason to make huge investments in the country's highway system and watch its value decrease through reduction in traffic capacity resulting from poor planning, a Federal highway planner declared today.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., March 30 -- "Elbow grease" applied by students in place of money has resulted at the Rutgers University College of Engineering in one of the best-equipped school metal processing laboratories in the East, it was announced today.

The Hosiery Wholesalers National Association, Inc., will extend its activities in all fields affecting its members, it was announced last night by Leo Guzik, counsel and executive director. He spoke at the annual meeting and election of officers of the association in the New Yorker Hotel, where he said the need for cooperative action was becoming increasingly imperative in the industry.

LONDON, March 30 -- A statement that the 509th Long Range Bomber Group of the United States Air Force, which is to be stationed in Britain next month, is especially trained in atomic bomb technique was loudly cheered by Conservatives in the House of Commons today.
CANTON, Okla., March 30 (AP) -- Tornadoes hit five times in northwest Oklahoma before dawn today, killed three persons, injured a score and did property damage estimated at about a million dollars.
Employers in the men's and women's clothing industry are almost as proud of the welfare funds set up under their union agreements as are union officials.
It will be twenty-five years today since Einar Christian Nielsen joined the staff of the Hospital for Special Surgery as a physical therapist.

ATHENS, March 31 -- Speaking on the Voice of America radio program tonight, John Nuveen Jr., chief of the Economic Cooperation Administration mission to Greece, outlined "some of the accomplishments" that have been recorded since President Truman pledged United States aid to the Greek people two years ago.
WASHINGTON, March 31 -- During the week ended March 30, member bank reserve balances decreased $341,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., March 31 (AP) -- The Governor of Maryland changed his mind today and tossed a decisive monkey wrench into the plan to abandon the famous Pimlico race track.

LONDON, March 31 -- Tempers drawn taut by seven weeks of prolonged and acrimonious negotiation of an Austrian peace treaty flared here today as Soviet Deputy Georgi N. Zarubin bitterly denounced the Western powers for allegedly blocking the repatriation of Soviet citizens from the Western zones of Austria.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- Senator Charles W. Tobey, Republican, of New Hampshire, said today he "felt certain" that this session of Congress would do something to plug the loopholes in the internal revenue code that annually cost the Government "in the neighborhood of $1,000,000,000 in taxes."
LAKELAND, Fla., March 31 (AP) -- The Tigers shelled three pitchers for seventeen hits today for a 16-to-5 victory over the Red Sox.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -Gold production throughout the world has been rising generally since the end of the war, but in 1947 remained far below the pre-war peak years, the International Monetary Fund showed in a report made public here today.

When Winston Churchill spoke in Fulton, Mo., on March 5, 1946, he urged a virtual military alliance between the United States and Britain and charged Russia with seeking indefinite expansion of her powers and Communist doctrines.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., March 31 -- Two hundred students from fifty mid-Atlantic colleges participating in the model United Nations General Assembly being held on the Rutgers College Campus "achieved" in four hours today what their adult namesake has not been able to accomplish in four years -- the general breakdown of political and national blocs.

ROME, March 31 -- The left-wing Socialist parliamentary group, composed of forty-one Senators and fifty-one Deputies, decided this morning to carry on a last-ditch fight against the North Atlantic treaty. As part of their campaign they intend to demand a new general election in order that the Italian people may manifest at the polls whether they wish Italy to form a part of the Western defense system.
URBANA, Ill., March 31 (AP) -- Development of a new bread softener, which a research official said could replace six times its own weight in fats and oils used for baking, has been reported here.

Grayson-Robinson Stores, Inc., national chain of popular price stores, set new records in sales and earnings in 1948. The figures in both categories were up for the tenth successive year, Hyman P. Kuchai, president, informed shareholders in the annual statement mailed to stockholders yesterday.
CLEVELAND, March 31 (AP) -- Two rail brotherhoods set up machinery today to put the locomotive engineer and his fireman into the same union. They said it would end "jurisdictional strife."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 31 -- The first deal between a motion-picture studio and one of the ten men indicted late in 1947 for contempt of Congress because of a refusal to answer a question on Communist affiliations has been concluded by Twentieth Century-Fox, it was learned today from the studio.

The estimated number of persons over 65 years of age in the United States will reach 18,000,000 by 1975, or virtually double the 1940 figure, Dr. Clyde V. Kiser, demographer of the Milbank Memorial Fund, said yesterday.
TRENTON, March 31 -- The New Jersey Legislature completed action tonight on veterans' bonus legislation.

The surfcasters who make an annual trip to the North Carolina beaches for channel bass can prepare for an early departure this year, for a wire was received from Bill Sharpe yesterday reporting the first rod and reel catch of the season at Oregon Inlet.

The new National Guard bill to end racial segregation in state military units contains a possible "joker" that would nullify the purposes for which it was designed, informed sources here said yesterday.

WHEN young Calder Willingham wrote "End as a Man" there was considerable moaning and gnashing of teeth in a famous Southern military college. Most readers, while murmuring to themselves something about so much smoke and a little fire, could not believe that any American institution could be such a sink of barbaric iniquity.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., March 31 -- Many persons, successful by society's standards, are suffering inwardly because they are driven by unconscious neurotic forces and these individuals constitute a challenge to science that has never been fully appreciated.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- Department store sales in the week ended March 26 were 16 per cent below sales in the corresponding week last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. Part of the decline was attributed to the fact that Easter this year is not until April 17, whereas last year it fell on March 28.

BOSTON, March 31 -- Great scientific discoveries are in prospect, the opening session of the convocation at Massachusetts Institute of Technology was told today by Dr. John Ely Burchard, Dean of the Humanities and general chairman of the meeting.
The made-to-order clothes of Farquharson Wheelock, 23 West Fifty-seventh Street, were presented yesterday in the Persian Room of the Plaza Hotel.

Three new films will arrive in first-run theatres today. At the Roxy, the attraction is "The Fan,' Twentieth Century-Fox's adaptation of Oscar Wilde's "Lady Windermere's Fan," with Jeanne Crain, Madeleine Carroll, George Sanders and Richard Greene featured.

Paired in the thirteenth round of the international chess masters tournament at Mar del Plata yesterday, Hector Rossetto and Carlos Guimard, both of Buenos Aires, played cautiously to a draw in twenty-one moves, according to a report received from Argentina.

By the margin of the longest shot ever made at Madison Square Garden the New York Knickerbockers last night defeated the Washington Capitols, 86 -- 84, in a thrill-jammed overtime conflict that squared their Basketball Association of America semi-final play-off series.
Mayor O'Dwyer failed yesterday in a last-minute attempt to prevent the city-wide taxi strike set for 4:30 o'clock this morning.

With interior features of a station wagon and the exterior appearance of a four-door sedan, a new 1949 "utility" automobile designated the "Traveler" was put on display yesterday by the KaiserFrazer Corporation at the KaiserFrazer Sales Corporation, 1710 Broadway.
WASHINGTON, March 31 -- A State Department spokesman confirmed tonight that the United States had received a note from the Soviet Government protesting against t he North Atlantic Pact.

Ike Williams, world lightweight champion and the welterweight contender, Kid Gavilan, who are all even as far as honors go in their past two bouts, meet again tonight in the ten-round attraction at Madison Square Garden.

Consolidated net income of the Aluminum Company of America for 1948 amounted to $39,941,367, equal to $7.66 a common share, compared with $30,025,588, or $5.63 a share, in 1947, according to the annual report to stockholders, issued yesterday.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., March 31 -- The Dodgers won another ball game in Texas today, beating Gus Mancuso's Missions, 8 -- 1, before 8,245 cash customers at the new Mission Stadium, with Oakland Joe Hatten turning in the third route job.

Net earnings of the American Viscose Corporation last year rose to $29,107,000 from $19,540,000 in 1947, according to the annual report of Dr. Frank H. Reichel, board chairman, mailed to stockholders today.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -Attorney General Tom Clark said today that the Justice Department had withdrawn its request to Congress for legal authority to tap wires and utilize the information obtained as evidence in prosecutions involving espionage and internal security.

TEL AVIV, Israel, March 31 -- The Israeli Government will not negotiate an armistice with Syria until the stability of the new regime is established, a Foreign Office spokesman declared here tonight. The armistice foundations already laid with the deposed Government of Khalid el-Azem must be reconsidered in the light of the latest events, it was held.

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 31 -- Despite the fact that the Giants have just signed a contract committing themselves to train here for another five years, the weather, which has been acting up ever since the athletes returned from their California jaunt last Monday, took an even more perverse turn today.

NASSAU, Bahamas, March 31 -- The second race in the Star Class spring championship series, held this afternoon over a windward and leeward course in an eight-to-ten-mile wind, was won by Durward Knowles' Nassau yacht, Gem. Her time was 4 hours 23 minutes 55 seconds.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson started today the most arduous series of diplomatic conferences, receptions, luncheons and dinners held in this capital since the Washington Conference of 1921-22.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson today expressed to the Dutch Foreign Minister, Dr. Dirk U. Stikker, the hopes of the United States Government that a compromise could be reached soon over Indonesia.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 31 -- The annual awards of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences will be presented next year despite the withdrawal of financial support by motion-picture producing companies, the Academy declared tonight in a formal statement.

Plans to raise $3,500,000 next fall and winter for the construction of a 200-bed general, voluntary, nonsectarian hospital in Queens by the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York were announced yesterday in the annual report of Ralph E. Samuel, president.

VIENNA, March 31 -- Yesterday's decision of the Austrian Cabinet to demand at the London treaty conference that Austria be relieved of the obligation to pay for the upkeep of displaced perons living here has created a potentially embarrassing situation for the Western occupation powers.

" Mrs. Gibbons' Boys," one of the few shows destined for Broadway before the rapidly waning season ends, already has arranged for a home. It will be the Music Box, where the Will Glickman-Joseph Stein comedy will settle down May 4.

An abbreviated course in twentieth-century French painting can be taken at the Perls Galleries, where a well-selected group includes more or less important examples by the important artists of the School of Paris.

There are a good many cliches of Broadway and Hollywood in the score of William Grant Still's opera, "The Trouble Island," after the libretto of Langston Hughes, given its premiere last night in the City Center of Music and Drama. One approaches the subject somewhat from this direction.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today approved transfer of the operating rights of the Hudson River Day Line to the Hudson River Boat Company, Inc., which will continue operations from the New York Harbor area as far north as Poughkeepsie, under the Day Line designation and trademark.

If Western Germany is once more to become a "valued paying customer" for American goods, the United States must be prepared to accept German products, George J. Santry, United States Military Government Coordinator for the forthcoming German Industrial Exhibition in New York, said yesterday.

Four convicts who escaped from the Rikers Island penitentiary Tuesday evening spent thirty-six hours in a rat-infested, dripping-wet hideout before they were re-taken into custody yesterday morning. They were so weakened by their experience that two of men were too feeble to come out of their refuge and surrender.

PANAMA, March 31 -- Foreign Minister Ignacio Molino and United States Ambassador Monnett B. Davi today signed at the Foreign Office a bilateral aviation agreement, which President Domingo Diaz has recommended for approval by a special session of the National Assembly, opening here this afternoon.
BOSTON, March 31 -- Following are some highlights of Winston Churchill's speech tonight :

James C. Buckley, director of airport development for the Port of New York Authority and one of the framers of that agency's present commercial airport plan for metropolitan New York, will leave his post "within the next few days" because of illness, it was learned yesterday.

Bates Fabrics, Inc., has advanced the price of combed broadcloth to the manufacturing trade by approximately 5 per cent, it was announced yesterday. The advance covers all plain colors except white and was instituted primarily to maintain a proper ratio between prices to manufacturers and the over-the-counter trade.

Some quality bedroom furniture manufacturers are offering special suites in advance of the July home furnishings markets in an effort to stimulate lagging volume, retailers reported yesterday. This is the first time since before the war that special offerings have been made between the January and July shows, they said.

The case of James Kutcher, legless veteran who was dismissed from his government job for membership in the Socialist Workers Party, will be taken to the United States Supreme Court if the Loyalty Review Board and inferior courts fail to reinstate him, his attorneys said yesterday.

ALBANY, March 31 -- Under an arrangement with the Board of Regents approved today, trustees of the State University will have substantially the same control over the colleges and institutes under their jurisdiction as the boards of private colleges.
ALBANY, March 31 -- The principal measures acted on during the 1949 session of the legislature, which adjourned before 1 o'clock this morning, were:
Barbara Custance is a pianist of strongly attractive musical personality, which she exhibited at Town Hall last night, in her second recital since her debut six years ago.

Ways of making the American home a safer place for living were discussed yesterday at two sessions of New York's annual Safety Convention after the home had been described as "the great neglected area in the field of accident prevention."

LONDON, March 31 -- The British Government announced today a long list of products of potential military value that are to be added to those for which export licenses are required. This in effect means Britain is extending her security ban on goods going behind the Iron Curtain.
MOSCOW, March 31 -- Mihail A. Suslov has been replaced as chief of the Propaganda and Agitation Section of the Communist party Central Committee.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., March 31 (AP) -- Laurence F. Whittemore, president of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad, said here last night that his company does not fear an investigation by Congress proposed on Tuesday by Representative C. C. McGrath, Democrat, of New York.

Charging that "graft and corruption" were prevalent in various city departments, Councilman Edward Rager, Manhattan Republican, criticized Governor Dewey, Mayor O'Dwyer and members of the Democratic and Republican parties yesterday.
ALBANY, March 31 -- Governor Dewey vetoed today without comment the Hults-Becker bill appropriating $50,000 for a legislative study of the feasibility of legalizing off-track betting on horse racing.
WASHINGTON, March 31 -- The railroads of the country asked today an increase of 35 per cent in the rates they receive for the transportation of mail.

PHILADELPHIA, March 31 -- Local 2, representing 2,700 workers at the Sun Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company in Chester, has voted to disaffiliate with the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, CIO.

The questions of the day -- in the horsy set -- are "What's good?" "What do you know?" and "What do you hear?" For today, at old Jamaica, 13.6 miles from the center of old Manhattan, the New York racing season opens its 196-day run, with eight races every afternoon and the daily double thrown in for good measure.
Mayor O'Dwyer's broadcast over WNYC on the taxi situation follows:
WASHINGTON, March 31 -- President Truman insisted today that Congress approve the full $5,580,000,000 he requested for European recovery in the next fifteen months of the Marshall Plan.

WASHINGTON, March 31 (UP) -- The United States Maritime Commission today arranged to charter three converted troop ships to United States Lines to handle an expected heavy volume of student tourist traffic to Europe this year.

MEXICO, D. F., March 30 -- A previous article under the above heading in this space recounted something of the issue between the Mexican Government and certain large American oil companies, an outcome of the act of 1938 by which the properties of these companies were expropriated.

TUCKAHOE, N. Y., March 31 -- Miss Maureen Elizabeth Murphy, who said she had heard of the exploits of Gerard Graham Dennis, the "gentleman raffles," and thought that jewel burglaries at suburban estates should be an "easy racket," was booked today by the Eastchester police on three burglary charges -- one involving a house Dennis was accused of ransacking.

Great Gull Island, seventeen-acre former Army fortress six miles off Orient Point, L. I., was awarded to the American Museum of Natural History yesterday and will become a wild life sanctuary and a center for nature studies.

Congressional adoption of the 10 per cent reduction in Marshall Plan appropriations, recommended by Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican, of Ohio, would be a serious blow to European recovery, William C. Foster, Ambassador-at-Large to the Economic Cooperation Administration countries, said yesterday.

TOKYO, March, 27 -- The high cost of weddings and the Allied drive to enforce greater austerity on Japanese recipients of United States' bounty are closing down Tokyo's elaborate "marriage halls," which did a thriving business before the war and in the early days of the post-surrender inflation.
WASHINGTON, March 31 -- Cancer control has now gone far enough along its way to merit a hopeful slogan, officials of the American Cancer Society said today in starting the 1949 fund drive.

The newly organized Brooklyn Antiques Forum held its first meeting last night at the Brooklyn Women's Club, 114 Pierrepont Street, with two speakers presenting ideas on decorative backgrounds for period furnishings.

Leopold Stokowski began the final week of his activities this season as guest conductor of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra's regular subscription concerts last night at Carnegie Hall. His program contained the Purcell-Wood Suite, which had not been presented previously by the society; Mozart's Symphony in G minor (K. 550) and three excerpts from Wagner's "Goetterdaemmerung."

CHICAGO, March 31 -- The Swoose -- last Flying Fortress bomber of pre-World War II vintage still flying -- chugged into Douglas Airfield this afternoon to take its place in the Chicago branch of the Smithsonian Institution's National Air Museum.
WASHINGTON, March 31 -- J. Monroe Johnson, director of the Office of Defense Transportation, suggested today that the Government finance the construction of 550,000 railroad freight cars.

DAMASCUS, Syria, March 31 -- All Syria today is under a military dictatorship. Students paraded in the streets, cheering the leader, Gen. Husni Zayim. The army completed during the night the work of taking over the country begun by a bloodless coup d'etat before dawn yesterday, and life in Damascus returned to normal today except for patrols in evidence all over the city and a drastic censorship on communications.

A recent full-page McGraw-Hill advertisement in THE TIMES declares war on the President's proposal to encourage increased steel capacity. "Socialism" Mr. McGraw calls it, saying that the recent election "gave no mandate for socialism."

David E. Lilienthal, chairman of the United States Atomic Energy Commission, appealed last night for "balanced understanding" of the bright and the somber sides of atomic discoveries. He addressed the annual dinner of the American College of Physicians at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
London, Friday, April 1 (AP) -- The text of the Soviet memorandum on the Atlantic pact as reported by Tass and distributed here by the Soviet Monitor, follows:

SAN FRANCISCO, March 31 -Deadly carbon monoxide gas can be neutralized in the air with a new silver permanganate powder, it was reported today at the national meeting of the American Chemical Society.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- Plans of American industry for new plants and equipment, a significant index of economic trends, call for expenditures of $18,310,000,000 this year, a decline of $920,000,000, or nearly 5 per cent, from the 1948 level, the Securities and Exchange Commission disclosed today.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 31 -- Faced with harsh competitive conditions, the cotton textile industry is placing more emphasis on research, that is the development of new products and new markets, M. Earl Heard, research head of the West Point Mills of Georgia, told the the American Cotton Manufacturers Association at its annual meeting here today.

The several reports prepared for the Board of Education by a special committee reveal not only the extent of the classroom space emergency the city faces as a result of the recent high birth rate, but also a readiness within the board to apply intelligence and common sense in meeting the emergency.

Those new goings-on at Ann Arbor (said our man with the unlikely name of Balboa Prawn as he seated himself and fingered a Phi Beta Kappa key resting on his well-filled waistcoat) permitting University of Michigan students to grade members of the faculty on teaching performance pose some interesting questions.

City officials and representatives of twenty-nine civic, welfare and religious organizations throughout the city were urged yesterday to support the expansion program of the Goodwill Industries of New York, Inc., for the benefit of several hundred physically handicapped persons who need rehabilitating.
BOSTON, March 31 -- Boston took Winston Churchill to its heart today, but wished it could have seen more of him.

Plans were completed yesterday for the construction of a twenty-one-story store and office building on the site of the seventy-seven-year-old Gothic edifice of the Collegiate Reformed Church of St. Nicholas at the northwest corner of Fifth Avenue and Forty-eighth Street. This apparently ends the long controversy concerning disposition of the property.
ALBANY, March 31 -- Nursing practices in public and voluntary hospitals in New York City may have to be revised radically as a result of the Nurse Practice Act, which goes into effect tomorrow.

BOSTON, March 31 -- In a ringing speech that drew frequent loud outbursts of applause, Winston Churchill declared bluntly tonight that only the atomic bomb in the hands of the United States had prevented Communists from over-running all of Europe and bombing London.

Richard Miles of New York, who has won the title four consecutive years, started the defense of his United States Table Tennis Association men's open singles championship last night by defeating Virgil Smith of Akron, Ohio, 21 -- 6, 21 -- 6, 21 -- 14, in a second-round match.
PARIS, March 31 -- Over Government opposition the National Assembly voted today a motion urging the Government to take gasoline off rationing by July 1.

A syndicate represented by E. L. Gothelf, attorney, has purchased for investment from Mary Ziegelbaum the ten-story and penthouse apartment building for sixty-seven families at 1349-53 Lexington Avenue, southeast corner of Ninetieth Street, it was announced yesterby the Rhinelander Estate, the day.

The entire sixth and seventh floors in the thirty-six-story office building under construction at 100 Park Avenue, the old Murray Hill Hotel site, have been leased by the American Airlines, Inc., it was announced yesterday. The company also took an option on the fifth floor.
Individual taxicab owners and operators of small fleets scurried about yesterday trying to buy strike and riot insurance coverage, but found the market closed to them.

All industries or groups which have found their business hampered by varying local requirements and by regulations that make it necessary to supply out-of-date or nonstandard materials were urged yesterday by the American Standards Association to study a new analysis it has just issued.
The welfare fund won five and a half years ago by the American Federation of Musicians, AFL, is going under new management.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- The House Public Works Committee, assured today by the Budget Bureau there had been no intention to by-pass it in the $5,400,000 reconstruction of the White House, voted approval of the bill to set up a six-man Commission on Renovation of the Executive Mansion.

City-wide relief from traffic congestion through operation of the downtown Union Motor Truck Terminal was forecast yesterday at the annual safety convention sponsored by the Greater New York Safety Council at the Hotel Statler.

They were called the "children of the sun and moon," but actually they were children of the sword. They had obtained their land in the heart of India by warlike prowess and had held it by the same. When the British made India an empire the sword still gleamed, but in another service. This week they held what was perhaps their last durbar at Jaipur.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- President Truman announced today that he would favor an official loan for the increased production and marketing of Mexico's petroleum, if various Government departments and agencies that are now studying such a proposition recommended it.

DUESSELDORF, March 31 -Dr. Konrad Adenauer has volunteered to attempt a solution of the critical situation confronting the Bonn Assembly. He will try to evolve a formula for a financial administration in the Western German state that will meet both the Western Allied and the Social Democratic views.

The fiftieth book written by James Branch Cabell, "The Devil's Own Dear Son," will be issued on April 14 by Farrar, Straus. It will mark the author's seventieth birthday. The story, described as a "romantic satire," is set in St. Augustine, Fla., and Hell, "with a side glance at Heaven."

Maintaining their downward trend for the fifth consecutive week, business loans by banks in this area declined $23,000,000 last week to $5,438,000,000, the lowest level since Sept. 8, last year. According to the data issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, a variety of small repayments accounted for reduction in borrowings from the reporting New York City member banks in the week ended on Wednesday.

Liquor price cuts as high as a dollar per fifth at the retail level, effective immediately in Pennsylvania and during the next few days in nine other monopoly states, were announced yesterday by two leading distillers.
The Police Department was placed yesterday on its "gravest" emergency footing to control any violence that might arise from the taxicab strike and "to insure the safety of the public."

Herman Wouk has written a second-rate melodrama about a first-rate subject. In "The Traitor," which was acted at the Forty-eighth Street last evening, he catches a brilliant scientist in the process of giving secret information about atomic energy to a Russian spy.

The Commerce and Industry Division of the New York University-Bellevue Medical Center Fund started yesterday toward a goal of $1,500,000 by June 30. The money will be part of $6,027,000 needed within the next few months to cover immediate building costs of the center, which will rise between Thirtieth and Thirty-fourth Streets along the East River.

NANKING, March 25 -- After almost ten weeks of Red rule in Tientsin and a slightly shorter period in Peiping, the popular reaction to the Communists is now said to be compounded of continuing enthusiasm among students, a reserved "show-me" attitude on the part of most Chinese and the first traces of disenchantment among foreign business men and some workers.

Reversing the trend of the last two sessions, the stock market lost ground yesterday in calmer trading. Losses ranged to an extreme of around 2 points in the key issues, although most declines were a point or less. Turnover dropped to 980,000 shares, or about half the 1,850,000 shares traded on Wednesday.

Because of the universal esteem in which Rabbi Stephen Wise is held, it is startling to read in your columns his suggestion that action be gained on the problem of civil rights by calling the Senate into special session during the summer and wearing down the Southern members by "attrition."

CHICAGO, March 31 (AP) -- Maynard G. (Scotty) Fessenden of Chicago, president of the Western Golf Association, today was voted the man who made 1948's outstanding contribution to golf in the second annual poll of the Golf Writers Association of America.
WASHINGTON, March 31 -- The National Labor Relations Board, voting 3 to 2, set aside today a collective bargaining election because of pre-election threats made by a union organizer to an employe.

WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP) -- The Power Commission authorized today the Texas Gas Transmission Corporation of Shreveport, La., and the Texas Eastern Transmission Corporation of Owensboro, Ky., to build additional pipelines from Texas and Louisiana to Ohio at an estimated cost of more than $97,500,000.

UNION CITY, N. J., March 31 -- The Internal Revenue Bureau will conduct a "routine" investigation into the sources of the $500,000 estate of the late Joseph Bowling, 73-year-old retired revenue agent who died of malnutrition March 12 as a charity patient in the North Hudson Hospital, Weehawken.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 31 -- Yugoslavs and the Communist Information Bureau have begun a series of new maneuvers against each other presaging intensification of the struggle for power.

MUNICH, Germany, March 31 -- The political climate in Bavaria is more depressing than anywhere else in Western Germany for in the words one senior United States official used in assessing his work, "What does it all matter, if we got out tomorrow, the Nationalists and Nazis would return in full strength."

NANKING, March 31 -- Preliminary efforts of Acting President Li Tsung-jen to get the Communists to lift their "bamboo curtain" in Peiping have failed. The Communists, it was learned today, have rejected a request by the Nanking Government to permit Chinese and foreign newsmen to cover the projected peace talks there.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- The American Labor party will seek a New York State Supreme Court order on Monday requiring Governor Dewey to set a date for a special election in the Twentieth Congressional District to fill the vacancy in the House created by the death of Sol Bloom.

For the coming fiscal year, the Advisory Commission on Information points out in its report to Congress, this country has budgeted for its three most important efforts to save the peace and the democratic way of life $15,000,000,000 for rearmament, $5,580,000,000 for economic help to other democracies of the free world and $36,000,000 for the distribution of information on what we are doing and the way we live.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- The Mississippi River Fuel Corporation, St. Louis, filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering 327,610 shares of $10 par value common capital stock that are to be offered to the company's common stockholders of record of April 12.

The voting trust agreement involved in divorcement of theatre ownership by Paramount Pictures, Inc., and outlined in the reorganization plan to be voted on at a special meeting of stockholders on April 12, is designed as a temporary measure, Barney Balaban, president, explained in a letter mailed yesterday to stockholders.

Mrs. Daniel M. McKeon and Mrs. Robert L. Hoguet Jr., are cochairmen of the arrangements committee for the annual children's party, in aid of the scholarship fund of the Girls Service League, to be held tomorrow afternoon in the Little Theatre of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest.
BOSTON, March 31 -- President Truman sent his regrets today to Massachusetts Institute of Technology for his inability to attend the opening session of the Institute's convocation.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- Labor partisans in and out of Congress railed against the House Rules Committee and voiced a suspicion today that a coalition of its members intended to bottle up the Lesinski labor bill as long as it could.
Radio officer licenses have been issued in the Third Coast Guard District to 165 operators who, effective today, require the papers to sign on merchant ships.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- Present and former state unemployment officials and business men leveled a heavy barrage of criticism today at proposals for the complete federalization of the Federal-State unemployment compensation system.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- Echoing President Truman's praise of the new rent control law, Tighe E. Woods, Federal Housing Expediter, asserted today that its provision for a "fair net operating income" for landlords "does not mean a general rent increase for all tenants."

Although its earnings for the first quarter of this year were 95 cents a share, the New Jersey Bell Telephone Company declared the usual quarterly dividend of $1.25 a share. The balance of 30 cents of the dividend declaration amounts to about $500,000 and must come from surplus, which is smaller than in 1927 at which time the organization started state-wide operations.

The attitude of those opposing the Cultural and Scientific Conference is so maddening in its stupidity that the sentiments of your editorial on the subject need, I feel, to be stated with more emphasis.

The lowest point of the year in tire sales has definitely passed and The B. F. Goodrich Company sees no reason why it should change earlier 1949 total sales estimates which envisaged 85,000,000 tires for the country as a whole. James J. Newman, vice president in charge of sales for Goodrich, disclosed here yesterday that the normal seasonal increase in tire orders has started.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on March 26, 1949, totaled 596,329 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 11,438 cars, or 1.9 per cent fewer than for the preceding week; 67,334
WASHINGTON, March 31 -- President Truman asserted today that a budget deficit this year would be far more dangerous for the country than his proposed $4,000,000,000 tax increase plan.
DETROIT, March 31 -- At the insistence of the union's international executive board, Walter P. Reuther, president of the United Automobile Workers, CIO, now uses a $12,000 armored automobile.

The steamship industry has offered its cooperation to Commissioner of Investigation John M. Muratgh on waterfront problems, but has demurred on the commissioner's proposal that the industry take over control of public loaders.
The big round brass doorbell of the famed "Cafe Lafayette" at Ninth Street and University Place, shone like the setting sun as the half-century-old hotel last night closed its doors to the public.

Poor school equipment and family prejudices against industrial training were among the causes given yesterday by the National Urban League for a lag in job preparation by Negro youths. The league also asked for a change in school curriculums to prepare youths for industrial plant requirements.

The Charles W. Hoyt Company, Inc., will celebrate its fortieth anniversary today at the agency's headquarters, 551 Fifth Avenue. Founded in New Haven, Conn., by Charles W. Hoyt, father of Winthrop and Everett W. Hoyt, now board chairman and president, respectively, the agency will mark the occasion with its original "staff," Miss Agnes Smith, still active in its affairs.

Harlem paid tribute last night to Mrs. Alberta T. Kline, who for twenty-five years has directed the Harlem unit of the New York City Mission Society. The testimonial was held at the Mother African Methodist Episcopal Zion Church, 140 West 137th Street.

Youth indeed was served yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel when 150 business and industry representatives gathered to honor the Boys Clubs of America in general and the "Boy of the Year" in particular.

CLEVELAND, March 31 -- Deploring the "discouraging, disagreeable, frustrating" role played by Russia, Dean Rusk, Assistant Secretary of State, asserted today that the United Nations would prevail in establishing peace despite the "terror and international intimidation" of Eastern Europe.

CHICAGO, March 31 -- Grains reacted after showing early strength on the Board of Trade today to close irregular as the result of profit-taking and pressure from professional traders. Wheat was up around 3/4 cent at the extreme, but weakened later to close 1/8 cent off to 1/2 cent higher, on the day, new-crop months showing the strength.
WASHINGTON, March 31 -- President Truman disclosed today that he expected to be at home throughout May as well as April to any members of Congress who wished to see him on affairs of the nation.

Five hundred leaders in Jewish activities here gathered last night at a dinner in honor of Mrs. David M. Levy, philanthropist and executive chairman of the women's division of the United Jewish Appeal of Greater New York.

Local 807 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters will undertake today a check on the union status of 150,000 truck drivers in the New York area as part of its national officers' campaign to double the teamsters' present membership of 1,000,000.

The causes of the military revolt in Syria remain obscure. This is probably because there are so many of them, for Syria is the center of a ferment that stirs the Middle East from Aleppo to Teheran. General Husni Zayim, leader and engineer of the bloodless coup d'etat, has declared that the overthrow of the Government is purely an internal affair and has nothing to do with foreign policy.

LONDON, March 31 -- The British Government is giving serious consideration to extending financial aid for the resettlement of Palestine Arab refugees in Transjordan and for an economic development of that country, the Foreign Office reported today.
Following is the text of Winston Churchill's address last night at the Mid-Century Convocation of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in Boston, as recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

There is a need for films for children only, Madeleine Carroll, actress and producer, asserted yesterday at the final meeting of the National Board of Review of Motion Pictures, held at City College's School of Business.

The Hudson Manhattan Railroad, operating between New York and Jersey City, Hoboken and Newark, announced yesterday that it planned to drop about 2,000 trains from its weekly schedules beginning April 24, because of a sharp reduction in commuter travel and an increase in expenses.

A showing of fashions by Jane Derby, orchids by Thomas Young, Inc., jewelry by Black Starr Gorham and Fredrica furs was presented yesterday at the Plaza Hotel by the Nearly New Shop, which is operated for the benefit of day nurseries and related children's services.
HAVANA, March 31 -- In an interview tonight, Antonio Prio Socarras, Minister of the Treasury, defended payment by Cuba of claims made by United States individuals or companies.

Richard H. Crowe, the missing assistant of the National City Bank branch at 195 Broadway, has been busy for the last five days paying off creditors with what seems to be stolen money, while at the same time ducking a nation-wide police net.

BUENOS AIRES, March 31 -Argentina today formally notified Britain of the expiration of the Andes agreement and announced that pending a new accord involving higher meat prices, shipments of frozen beef to Britain would be limited to 10,000 tons monthly, beginning tomorrow.

LONDON, March 31 -- In the financial year that closed tonight Britons paid more than ever before in taxation, to give the country a record revenue surplus of u831,000,000 (about $3,324,000,000). This is about u42,000,000 more than was budgeted for by Sir Stafford Cripps, Chancellor of the Exchequer, who will present his new budget Wednesday.

Local 807 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters will undertake today a check on the union status of 150,000 truck drivers in the New York area as part of its national officers' campaign to double the teamsters' present membership of 1,000,000.

The causes of the military revolt in Syria remain obscure. This is probably because there are so many of them, for Syria is the center of a ferment that stirs the Middle East from Aleppo to Teheran. General Husni Zayim, leader and engineer of the bloodless coup d'etat, has declared that the overthrow of the Government is purely an internal affair and has nothing to do with foreign policy.

LONDON, March 31 -- The British Government is giving serious consideration to extending financial aid for the resettlement of Palestine Arab refugees in Transjordan and for an economic development of that country, the Foreign Office reported today.
Following is the text of Winston Churchill's address last night at the Mid-Century Convocation of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in Boston, as recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

There is a need for films for children only, Madeleine Carroll, actress and producer, asserted yesterday at the final meeting of the National Board of Review of Motion Pictures, held at City College's School of Business.

The Hudson Manhattan Railroad, operating between New York and Jersey City, Hoboken and Newark, announced yesterday that it planned to drop about 2,000 trains from its weekly schedules beginning April 24, because of a sharp reduction in commuter travel and an increase in expenses.

At a moment when representatives of twelve nations are gathering in Washington to sign the North Atlantic Security Pact -- which may be said to have been inspired by his own speech at Fulton three years ago -- Winston Churchill again lifts his voice to warn the democratic world of the perils which make the Pact necessary and to counsel a course of action which he considers most likely to avert a Third World War.

BERLIN, March 31 (UP) -- Soviet troops made two lightning raids into the United States sector yesterday and seized four Germans suspected of having smuggled goods into the western sector, United States officials said today.
LAKE SUCCESS, March 31 -- Australia and India today threw the Indonesian controversy before the United Nations General Assembly.

FRANKFORT, Germany, March 31 -- The three Western military governors have informally threatened the leaders of the Bonn Parliamentary Assembly with disconuance of this project for the creation of a Western German state and the adoption of an alternative method.

With gross revenues up $22,274,000, Transcontinental Western Air, Inc., reduced its net loss in 1948 to $478,987 from a deficit of $8,079,761 in 1947, Warren Lee Pierson, chairman, reported yesterday. Last year's total revenues were at a new high of $101,114,141.

LONDON, March 31 -- Britain and Egypt concluded today a financial and commercial agreement under which Britain, while reducing the number of dollars available to Egypt, will increase exports -- particularly of heavy capital goods -- to make up Egypt's loss.

Commission house and local professional absorption aided cottonseed oil futures in their climb to new high ground on the New York Produce Exchange yesterday. Prices met with considerable profit-taking and realizing and reacted to early unsteadiness in lard.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., March 31 (AP) -- Joe Verdeur, young Navy veteran of Philadelphia, bettered the championship 300-yard individual medley record today as the National AAU indoor men's swimming meet got under way.
MOSCOW, Friday, April 1 -- The Soviet Union charged today that the North Atlantic treaty was actually "aggressive" and directed against it.

In what the majority of those present regarded as the first definite move for the renomination and re-election of Mayor O'Dwyer, business, commercial, financial and labor leaders of New York joined yesterday in praising his Administration at a luncheon in the Grand Ball Room of the Commodore Hotel. Seventeen hundred persons were present.
The four-man Yugoslav delegation to the recent Cultural and Scientific Conference for World Peace will leave this country on April 8 on a Pan American World Airways plane, it was learned yesterday.

Prof. Louis F. Budenz of Fordham University, former Communist official, went under cross-examination for the first time at the Communist trial yesterday and stood firm against a two-hour attack on his credibility. Defense counsel failed in attempts to shake his five-day testimony as a Government witness, but will continue today.

Jose Limon and his admirable company of assisting artists under the direction of Doris Humphrey last night gave us an evening of genuine magnificence at the Ziegfeld Theatre. We need to be reminded occasionally that the dance, besides being an amusing medium for coquetry and personal display, can also be an art of nobility and elevation of spirit; but it is not often that we are reminded so eloquently.

Seven thousand CIO brewery workers in the metropolitan area were called out on strike at 2:05 A. M. today, it was announced by Paul O'Dwyer, counsel for the International Union of Brewery, Soft Drink, Cereal, Distillery and Grain Workers of America.

Disclosure that local post office officials are conducting a drive to turn up the big distributors behind the new Mexican Sweepstakes ticket-selling in this area, plus the revelation that last December's winners have not been paid off, has already resulted in blocking the sale of at least $175,000 in tickets and the disposal of $450,000 worth may be prevented.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- Admiral De Witt C. Ramsey, Commander-in-Chief of the Pacific Fleet, who will retire on May 1, today was elected president of the Aircraft Industries Association, effective July 1.

LONDON, March 31 -- South African gold-mining shares claimed most of the attention in a generally firm stock market here today. With brokers reporting big public interest in addition to professional buying, prices again were higher throughout. Small profit-taking was easily absorbed.
A man lifted a shotgun carefully to his shoulder yesterday and fired at nothing.

FRANKFORT, Germany, March 31 -- A censored version of the record of the secret spy trial of a Czechoslovak national conducted in Munich last month was released by the United States Army today. It disclosed testimony that in addition to having had Czechoslovak intelligence connections, the convicted defendant had been a Moscow-trained agent for the Russian secret service.

MOSCOW, March 31 -- What could be described as the repressive nature of the United States regime and its concern lest the American people learn the truth concerning the world situation was brought out vividly today in a series of reports on repercussions of the Cultural and Scientific Conference for World Peace held in New York.

BRADENTON, Fla., March 31 -- The burning desire to avenge earlier humiliation at the hands of the Boston Braves erupted today in a Yankee bombardment which saw the Bombers paste two of Billy Southworth's strong-arm hurlers as they blasted the National League champions into defeat.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- President Truman acknowledged with a smile today that there was a White House "lobby" booming Joseph A. Fox, Washington Star correspondent, for appointment as Commissioner of the District of Columbia.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- Negotiations between this country and Saudi Arabia on the new status of the giant Army-built Dhahran air base on the Persian Gulf are virtually completed, and the State Department plans disclosure of the final terms within forty-eight hours.

LONDON, April 1 -- Before the opening of the stock markets here today brokers had some fears that two days of rising prices, coupled with Winston Churchill's forthright speech last night in Boston and advances in prices, of some steels would be a cue for week-end profit-taking.

A sudden strike by 250 radio officers of the Pan American World Airways that had forced postponement yesterday of all transatlantic flights here and in Europe was settled early this morning, a union spokesman announced. The strike had been called over replacement of radio telegraph facilities with pilot-operated radiophones.

The Theatre Owners of America has become a sustaining member of the Society of Motion Picture Engineers, it was jointly announced yesterday. The television committees of both organizations, together with their executives, will meet next Friday to explore "fields of mutual interest in theatre engineering, including theatre television.''

The first positive clue to the whereabouts of Richard H. Crowe, assistant manager of the National City Bank branch at 195 Broadway, who is missing with what remains of $884,660 he took from the bank, was uncovered yesterday in Jacksonville, Fla.

WASHINGTON, April 1 (AP) -- If the United States is "to avoid losing" any future war, General Hoyt S. Vandenberg testified today, the Air Force must be able to complete "three basic tasks" in a hurry.

BOSTON, April 1 -- Winston Churchill was cited tonight as "the Twentieth Century symbol of resistance to oppression," in receiving his newest title as honorary lecturer of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

Vat dyes, usually associated with washable machine-printed fabrics, are used in most of the screen prints in the new Cohama display at Altman's. Since vat dyes are color fast, those of cotton may be safely washed.

BRADENTON, Fla., April 1 (AP) -- The left-handed Glenn Elliott became the second Braves hurler to go the distance today when he turned back the Cardinals by a 5-3 count in the last home game of the Grapefruit League season here.

LONDON, April 1 -- Soviet Ambassador Georgi N. Zarubin waited until the middle of this morning to go to the Foreign Office to deliver the Russian note protesting against the Atlantic pact. As the Moscow radio broadcast the text to the world last night and it was even published in this morning's newspapers British Government officials felt no compunction in labeling the note as propaganda and not serious diplomacy.

The Soviet note of protest against the North Atlantic Pact is presumably written solely for the record. The views it expresses are so contrary to the known facts in the case, as those facts have been stated repeatedly by the sponsors of the Pact, that the Soviet Government certainly does not expect its protest to result in the scrapping of this new agreement almost on the very eve of the day set for signing it.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 1 (AP) -- The Louisville Times said today Churchill Downs likely would be sold soon to a foundation for operation as a non-profit horse racing plant.

NEWARK, N. J., April 1 -- The Lackawanna Railroad today announced an increased commuter fare schedule effective May 1, which would increase current rates an average of 18 per cent for rides of medium length. For distance under six miles, the fares would be slightly decreased.

LAKE SUCCESS, April 1 -Russia's charge that the North Atlantic treaty "breaks" the United Nations Charter, created some concern here today, with the majority of the top secretariat staff generally agreeing that the pact adheres strictly to the letter of the Charter but violated its spirit.

Most of the world's peoples are comparing critically United States pronouncements on democracy with actual practices toward racial and religious minorities here, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, chairman of the United Nations Human Rights Commission, warned yesterday.

Students in Eastern colleges in increasing numbers have been planning careers as Christian ministers since World War II. This is particularly true of veterans studying to become clergymen, directors of religious education or church organists under the GI Bill of Rights.

Having received assurance that improvements have been made in the lighting of the court in Washington's National Guard Armory, the New York Knickerbockers will play as scheduled against the Washington Capitols tonight in the third and deciding game of the Basketball Association of America's eastern play-offs.

A sturdy unemployed stevedore caught in a smoky fire jumped yesterday forty-five feet from his third floor apartment at 41 North Portland Avenue, Brooklyn, landed unharmed in a back yard and then caught his two infant children dropped by his wife, whose fall he also helped to break. Only the wife was injured.
A door left open by an 11-year-old boy on his way to school paved the way at 9:10 A. M. yesterday for the hold-up of the youngster's family and the theft of $12,400 in rings and $240 in cash.

In Boston Winston Churchill referred to his Fulton speech of three years ago but he did not mention the "Iron Curtain," the phrase he originated at that time. One reason may be that the curtain is not quite so opaque as it was. This is not to say that the outside world knows any more than it ever did about what goes on inside the Kremlin.
The cotton futures market closed 3 points net lower to 6 points higher, following a quiet session on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- Following is the vote by which the Senate defeated tonight a proposal by Senators Robert A. Taft, Republican, Ohio, and Richard B. Russell, Democrat, of Georgia, to cut the authorization for the European Recovery Program by 10 per cent:

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- The tactical plan of Republicans and Southern Democrats to pass a strong labor bill in the House was made clear today as the Rules Committee completed hearings on a procedural rule for the bill.

Miguel Czerniak of Palestine entrenched himself in third place in the international chess masters tournament at Mar del Plata yesterday by winning the black side of a French defense from Franz Benkoe of Hungary, according to a report from Argentina.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 1 -- Samuel Goldwyn has borrowed Susan Hayward from Walter Wanger to play opposite Dana Andrews in "My Foolish Heart," which will be Goldwyn's next film the producer announced today. Miss Hayward will play the role originally scheduled for Teresa Wright, who parted company with the Goldwyn company after a dispute last December.

Night vs. Day A man who works night hours, as for instance one who helps to put out a morning newspaper, often finds himself ruminating on the pluses and minuses of his turned-about life, if for no other reason than it differs from the 9-to-5 routine.
The wisdom of Solomon and the polish of a trained diplomat were recommended yesterday as the essential factors required by a traffic policeman in a busy metropolis.

LONDON, April 1 -- Israeli representatives, it was indicated here today, are prepared to drive a hard bargain when they enter trade and financial negotiations with the British Government during the next few weeks.

Bernard H. Spiro of The Long Island Star-Journal has been awarded the first prize gold medal or the best student essay on "What I Got Out of the Advertising and Selling Course of the Advertising Club of New York," it was announced yesterday.

Berlin is the calmest city in Europe, with peace on sound principles the sole aim of its people, Dr. Ernst Reuter, Lord Mayor of Berlin, declared here yesterday at an official reception in the Council Chamber of City Hall.
Tradition, and towering walls of stone, eight feet thick and thirty tall, are all that remain of historic Fort Lafayette, a rampart that has stood watch in the harbor Narrows since 1812.

OTTAWA, April 1 -- In St. John's, capital of Newfoundland, and in Ottawa, capital of Canada, ceremonies linked by radio, celebrated today the entry of Newfoundland in to the Canadian confederation as the tenth province.
Operations last year of the Food Machinery and Chemical Corporation resulted in a net income of $5,283,377, compared with $6,164,526 earned in 1947, the annual report disclosed yesterday.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 1 -- A purge of high-ranking Communist party officials in Bulgaria was reported today.

The European Recovery Program, starting its second-year course through Congress successfully passed through the first part of a perfectly understandable bog of economy-mindedness when the Senate turned down two amendments which would have cut the Administration's proposed expenditure for ERP.

Film producers and distributors are carrying too big a share of the financial risk and are entitled to a greater percentage of theatre earnings, executives of Twentieth Century-Fox told local movie house owners and managers in outlining yesterday the company's intentions to seek higher film rentals from theatres.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., April 1 (AP) -- Two rising young swimmers today battled their way to their first national Amateur Athletic Union indoor championships. Keith Carter of Purdue and Bob Gibe of the Detroit Athletic Club defeated the Olympic and defending champions.

Although purchases of men's and boys' workshirts are showing a seasonal increase, buying is not sufficient to bring production up to full scale proportions, it was pointed out yesterday. Work shirt manufacturers are still working two, three and four days a week, according to reports received here, and are limiting their output to actual orders only.
Thousands of Brooklyn subway riders bound for Manhattan were delayed by a power failure during the rush hour yesterday morning on both the IRT and the BMT divisions.

TEL AVIV, Israel, April 1 -Four Israeli soldiers riding in a military car between Faluja and Hebron were ambushed early today and all killed, it was officially stated here tonight. This area is one of the delicate spots in Israel and the affair has increased border tension to a high degree.

With almost every stream from the New Hampshire border to the Dennys River free of ice, the Maine trout and salmon season opened yesterday, and while many streams were high and discolored, the impatient members of the brotherhood turned out in good numbers.

WASHINGTON, April 1 (AP) -- The Justice Department said today it has "no serious objection" to legislation which would bar the Federal Trade Commision temporarily from ruling out the basing-point pricing system in certain cases.
The report of the Pacific Western Oil Corporation yesterday showed its net income for 1948 increased to $7,305,434 or $5.32 a share from $3,811,936 or $2.77 a share earned the year before.

WASHINGTON, April 1 (AP) -- Members of a House Appropriations subcommittee reported privately today they had agreed to restore the veterans' hospital construction program to the size it was before President Truman trimmed it.

WASHINGTON, April 1 (UP) -Herbert John Burgman, 52 years old, former State Department employe in Berlin, pleaded innocent today to charges that he betrayed his country by broadcasting over the wartime Nazi radio.

Federal Judge Edward A. Conger declined yesterday to direct organized baseball to reinstate Max Lanier and Fred Martin, Cardinal pitchers who were suspended for five years when they jumped to the Mexican League in 1946.

Christened a "Country Antiques Fair," the annual spring New York Antiques Fair will open Monday at 1 P. M. for a six-day run at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Thirty - fourth Street.
LONDON, April 1 (Reuters) -- Moves by Malaya, Ceylon and other producer countries to raise the price of rubber may follow the Rubber Study Group's conference which ended in London today.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- Average primary market prices declined 0.1 per cent in the week ended on March 29, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The index stood at 158.1 per cent of the 1926 average, 0.4 per cent lower than four weeks ago and 1.7 per cent less than the comparable week in 1948.

NASSAU, Bahamas, April 1 -Patrick O'Gorman sailed Wahini of the Western Long Island Sound fleet of Larchmont to victory in the Johnny Walker Trophy series for Star Class yachts by finishing first in the final race today and amassing a total of 60 points.

Retail sales increased during the week due to increased buying for the Easter season. Department store sales were estimated as about 4 per cent above the corresponding week last year. Sales last week were 15 per cent below last year.
It was a moot question yesterday whether the few taxicab drivers who braved the first day of the strike or their occasional passengers were the more nervous.

Stocks continued to drift uncertainly yesterday as prices on the New York Stock Exchange, except for a flurry in gold shares, were confined generally to minor changes. Trading was at a slow pace with transfers of 850,000 shares, the smallest since Monday. Sales on Thursday amounted to 980,000 shares.
WASHINGTON, April 1 -- The number of unemployed dropped by 54,000 and the number of employed increased by 479,000 during March.

New York City's budget is on the heroic scale, like everything else about the city. Larger than the budget of any state, larger than the annual outlay of many a foreign country, it increases again this year to $1,179,026,930. Yet, to our way of thinking and considering the times, the increase of $17,266,422 over the present year is a modest one.

Federal Judge Simon H. Rifkind ordered a delay yesterday in the trial on espionage charges of Miss Judith Coplon, Department of Justice employe, and Valentin A. Gubitchev, Russian engineer suspended by the United Nations organization.

Despite the critical drubbing administered several days ago to Dalton Trumbo's "The Biggest Thief in Town," Lee Sabinson, its producer, still retains faith in the author's ability to work out a script deserving of respect The producer has commissioned the playwright to provide him with another opus for next season.
The text of Mayor O'Dwyer's budget message submitted to the Board of Estimate and the City Council follows:
LONDON, April 1 -- Navies of four of the Western European Union powers will hold combined war exercises from June 30 until July 8, the Admiralty announced today.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- The Westchester Lighting Company of Mount Vernon, N. Y., filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering $12,000,000 of general mortgage bonds, series due May 1, 1979, to be offered at competitive bidding.

Kid Gavilan had little trouble with Ike Williams, lightweight champion of the world, in their ten-round bout at Madison Square Garden last night. Seeking a chance at the welterweight crown, the Cuban flailed away almost without cease at his lighter foe and gained the unanimous vote of the officials.

BRADFORD, Pa., April 1 (AP) -- Pennsylvania grade crude oil has gone down another 20 cents a barrel. The cut brought to about $1.45, or $1.50 a barrel, the total reduction since last Dec. 11, when the Joseph Seep purchasing agency announced its first cut. At that time Bradford (Pa.) and Alleghany (N. Y.) district oil was selling for $5 a barrel. The new price is $3.55.
WASHINGTON, April 1 -- The United States Government informally rejected today the Soviet Union's protest against the North Atlantic pact.

If there is anything superior to coffee in the morning or ice cream on a warm day, it is perhaps the first asparagus of spring. The green succulent spears epitomize the pleasantest season; they are, in fact, available only during spring. June peas in January may be among the miracles of modern marketing.
ALBANY, April 1 -- The state's 1948-49 fiscal year ended yesterday with a surplus of $2,275,203, Controller Frank C. Moore reported to Governor Dewey today.

MOSCOW, April 1 -- Yesterday's Soviet memorandum to the seven sponsoring powers of the North Atlantic treaty was regarded here today as raising a number of issues, including the question of whether grounds now had been laid for denunciation of the Russian pacts with France and Britain.

Early settlement of the eleven-year-old reorganization of the Pittsburgh Railways Company through an amended plan of re-organization that "involves substantial concessions on the part of the Philadelphia Company," parent concern, was indicated yesterday by Edward O. Boshell, chairman and president of the Standard Gas and Electric Company, of which the Philadelphia Company is a subsidiary.

The heads of the two biggest unions in the mass production industries are studying mortality tables and hospitalization charts these days. Their concern is not with their own health or life expectancy, but with the demands for welfare and retirement programs they intend to submit in collective bargaining negotiations this June.
HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, April 1 (Canadian Press) -- A rough battle for control of sea-going labor shaped up today in the wake of a strike called by the Canadian Seamen's Union on the East Coast.

The New York State Commission Against Discrimination appealed yesterday to primary and nursery school teachers to indoctrinate their pupils against race and class prejudices. The appeal was made at a meeting at commission headquarters of delegates to the joint convention of the New York State Association for Childhood Education and the New York State Association for Nursery Education.

Fourteen breweries in the metropolitan area shut down operations yesterday as 7,000 members of the brewery workers union went on strike over safety, security and other issues. The fourteen included the six largest.

BELLEAIR, Fla., April 1 -- Thomas G. Spates, vice president of General Foods Corporation, again rapped the knuckles of industrial "big brass" today with the challenge that he believed they had only "the rest of 1949 to save the United States" from socialism or communism.

ALBANY, April 1 -- The Feinberg Bill directing the Board of Regents to purge the public school system of teachers and other employes who are Communists or "fellow-travelers" was signed today by Governor Dewey, without comment.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores, reflecting the later Easter, showed a decline of 10 per cent in March, compared with the corresponding month last year, according to the survey made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

ALBANY, April 1 (AP) -- The New York State Catholic Welfare Council, representing the Catholic Bishops of New York State, today condemned the showing of two sex education films -- one of them to school children.

LONDON, April 1 -- Representatives of the United States, Britain and France made a last and apparently fruitless effort today to reach agreement on disputed points of an occupation statute for Germany. Their meeting was secret as usual but there were no indications that the deadlock had been broken.

LONG BRANCH, N. J., April 1 -- George Wiley, a local race-track figure, was sought today by police in connection with ownership of a supposedly empty "club" building raided here yesterday by detectives from the Monmouth County Prosecutor's staff. Prosecutor J. Victor Carton said the raid uncovered "the largest book-making wire room I have ever seen."

The virtual elimination of the taxicab from city streets enabled traffic to flow through the normally congested business sectors yesterday at a speed 30 per cent greater than before the strike, police traffic experts estimated.

William Helis' Rippey, back from a California campaign that didn't produce a great deal more than shipping expenses, won horse-of-the-day honors -- and $21,050 -as New York's racing season opened at chilly, showery, daily-doubly Jamaica yesterday. He beat a dozen others in the fortieth Paumonok Handicap, a sprint which grossed $30,100.

The New York State Commission Against Discrimination announced yesterday that it would survey facts in the current dispute between Local 968 of the International Longshoremen's Association and the AFL union's leadership.
A new declaration of war against the city's rat population of 15,000,000 was voted yesterday by the Board of Estimate.
