A further increase in cancer caused by irritating agents associated with many industrial occupations was predicted yesterday by Dr. W. C. Hueper of the United States Public Health Service's National Cancer Institute at Bethesda, Md.

The cause of higher education and greater skills in the electrical field should be well served by the two annual five-year scholarships at Columbia University set up by the Joint Industry Board of the Electrical Industry. The grants, to begin next fall, will be made to sons of New York electrical workers, applicants whose fathers are members of the board's pension system.

CHICAGO, April 1 -- Sears, Roebuck Co. ended its fiscal year on Jan. 31 in the strongest position in its history after achieving record levels of sales and profits in 1948 and completing a three-year expansion program on which it spent $200,000,000, General Robert E. Wood, chairman, said today.
Sailing dates and other details covering the movement of students and teachers to Europe this summer were made public yesterday by the Council on Student Travel, 156 Fifth Avenue.

FRANKFORT, Germany, April 1 -- N. H. Collison, deputy special representative of the Economic Cooperation Administration in Germany, gave six reasons today why foreign investors "would not rush in" to invest in Western Germany when the present prohibitions were lifted.

The five-story apartment house at 1833-1855 Bryant Avenue, the Bronx, accommodating sixty-three families, has been sold by the Gerard Realty Company to Frank Slater. The property, assessed at 172,000, was acquired for cash above mortgages of $120,090. Pearce Mayer were the brokers.

LONDON, April 1 -- A sharp exchange of notes between Guatemala and Britain over British plans for Honduras was published here today. Guatemala, which refers to British Honduras as "the Guatemalan territory of Belize," objects to Britain's plan to settle immigrants in Honduras and include that colony in a possible future federation of British territories in the Caribbean area.

The Lincoln Savings Bank of Brooklyn has sold the six-family apartment house at 96 Pulaski Street, Brooklyn, to Brenna Z. Greenberg. Bassuk Brothers were the brokers. Title insurance was furnished by City Title Insurance Company.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., April 1 -- Gerard Graham Dennis, alleged international jewel thief, made an unsuccessful attempt at freedom here at 8:05 o'clock tonight but was caught two blocks away in a parking lot. Pursuing police fired six shots at the fleeing prisoner as pedestrians backed against walls to avoid being hit.

PARIS, April 1 -- United States shipping companies exporting goods to France will have two more weeks before having to arrange for all freight to be prepaid in dollars in accordance with the decree that was to have been effective today.

WARSAW, April 1 -- The Polish Government has informed foreign relief organizations that they will no longer receive subsidies for their operations in this country after the end of this month. As a result it is expected that at least sixteen foreign relief agencies will close down their operations and withdraw their foreign staffs.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 1--Gen. Husni Zayim, Syrian Army chief who seized power on Wednesday, is unable to form a political Cabinet and is continuing to run the country with a "technicians'" Cabinet formed of the Directors General of the Government departments, according to latest reports here tonight.
WASHINGTON, April 1 -- Three unions of telegraph operators affiliated with the American Federation of Labor called today on the Senate for an investigation of the Federal Communications Commission.

BERLIN, April 1 -- In an effort to prevent the flight of scientists intellectuals, technicians and educators to the West and to enlist their support, authorities of the Soviet occupation zone announced today an involved program of special privileges for the "intelligentsia.''

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today required railroads taking part in coastwise, intercoastal, export, and import traffic at the Edgewater Docks Station of the New York, Susquehanna Western at Edgewater, N. J., to equalize rates with those applying from interior points to piers served by the Hoboken Manufacturers' Railroad Company at Hoboken, N. J.
BOSTON, April 1 -- Harold E. Stassen, president of the University of Pennsylvania, called tonight for a billion-dollar-a-year "MacArthur plan" in Asia to fight communism.

"Sketch for a Self-Portrait," by Bernard Berenson, the American art historian, has been set for April 21 publication by Pantheon Books. It is an assessment of the author's personality and a psychological study of his self. As an art critic, Mr. Berenson is the author of several books, among them "Italian Painters of the Renaissance'' and "The Venetian Painters of the Renaissance."

The dream that came true when Miss Ada Fishburn arrived in America on the Queen Elizabeth a month ago will start fading into a happy memory today as the 24-year-old factory worker sails for home to England on the Queen Mary.

MUNICH, Germany, April 1 -The Bavarian party, which stands for Bavarian separatism, is reactionary and contains a large percentage of monarchists, is the fastest-growing political organization in Germany today.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson began today a short series of tripartite discussions on the future of Western Germany with British Foreign Secretary Ernest Bevin and French Foreign Minister Robert Schuman.

The new Belgian tax treaty, which is expected to be ratified this year, is favorable to elimination of double taxation on business enterprises, but less so with respect to dividends, according to analysis of the treaty made for the Belgian Chamber of Commerce and issued here yesterday.

CLEVELAND, April 1 -- Dr. Jaime Torres Bodet, Director General of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, asked the American film industry and comic strip artists tonight to throw their talents whole-heartedly into the international campaign to improve the "stunted minds" that "breed war."
SYDNEY, Australia, April 1 (AP) -- Some wool buyers are predicting a drop in Australian wool prices at the Brisbane sales, which open Monday.
WASHINGTON, April 1 -- A Senate committee moved today to set up stronger Congressional veto powers over President Truman's right to make administrative reorganizations in the executive branch.

ALBANY, April 1 -- New York City fared very well through the 172d Legislature that ended its session early yesterday, according to a summary issued today by Harold L. Herzstein, the city's legislative representative.
Private placements of bond issues totaling $91,000,000 in behalf of distillery, public utility and pipeline enterprises were announced yesterday. The borrowings were as follows:
The Army Ordnance emonstra-I tion on Army Day, next Wednes-I day, at the Aberdeen (Md.) Prov-I ing Grounds, will be televised byI the NBC network from 4 until 5:30 P.M.

Mayor O'Dwyer submitted yesterday to the Board of Estimate and the City Council an executive budget of $1,179,026,930 for the fiscal year beginning July 1. It was the largest in the city's history and the Mayor's third successive budget to pass the $1,000,000,000 mark.

A secret language used by Communist leaders enables them to advocate violent revolution among the initiated, according to yesterday's evidence at the Communist trial, without showing their hand to the general public.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- Asserting that the Government invited "waste and favoritism" and "even corruption" when it made direct loans to individuals or private enterprises, the Commission on Organization of the Executive Branch of the Government recommended today that Congress review the power of Federal lending agencies.

Public utility financing will hold the center of interest in next week's roster of new issues of securities, with offerings of stock exceeding flotations of bonds. Bids will be taken on Tuesday on 1,000,000 common shares of the Ohio Public Service Company, 361,840 shares representing new financing, and the rest for the account of the Cities Service Company.
The Five-wind Ensemble, with Frederick Marantz, pianist, and Nina Quartin, soprano, were the performers on last night's Debut and Encore Concert at Town Hall, and they made it an enlightening event.

The statement of condition of the Irving Trust Company for March 31, issued yesterday, showed deposits of $1,037,114,002, compared with $1,113,181,691 on Dec. 31, 1948, and $995,260,551 on March 31, 1948. Total assets for the three periods were: $1,166,717,061; $1,243,828,631 and $1,130,105,157, respectively.

Delegates representing the metal worker and railroad employe sections of the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, CIO, suffered a defeat yesterday when the union's fourteenth annual convention elected a "shipyard" slate of twelve general executive board members.
MORRISTOWN, N. J., April 1 -Thousands of persons from this county attended today ceremonies opening the Bamberger store here.

WASHINGTON, April 1 (AP) -- A spokesman for specialized periodicals that are sent free of cost to readers today requested postal rate "parity" with paid-subscription publications. The request met immediate opposition from representatives of the paid circulation press, which gets the lower second-class postal rates.

New York University extended its hold on Washington Square yesterday by leasing most of the square block between Washington Square North and Eighth Street from Fifth Avenue to University Place from Sailors' Snug Harbor for 203 years.

NANKING, April 1 -- As six Government delegates left by plane today for Peiping to talk peace with the Chinese Communists, Nationalist soldiers beat up 100 demonstrating students here and Red troops fanned out from the Peiping-Hankow railway to take up positions closer to the Yangtze in still another river sector.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- Senator Henry Cabot Lodge Jr., Republican, of Massachusetts, today protested the refusal of a midtown hotel to accept as guests two Negro high school students from Nantucket, Mass., who had planned to visit the capital.

ROME, April 1 -- The Left-Wing Socialists made it plain today that they had no intention of joining the Communist-promoted "peace front" designed to spearhead Communist opposition to the North Atlantic treaty. They have undertaken to fight the treaty but to do so as an independent party.

The North Atlantic pact brings to a dangerous climax, unnecessarily, the clash between two great segments of the world's peoples; each imbued with an exalted opinion of its own military prowess, each stubbornly convinced its own way of life is superior, each suspecting the other of mortal enmity.

Defense counsel for Mrs. Alice R. P. Satterthwaite, accused of violating the Social Welfare Law by placing babies for adoption, sought to file an affidavit yesterday in General Sessions granting permission to inspect grand jury minutes in the case.

As the second and final event in the Gabrilowitsch Memorial Series of this season, the National Orchestral Association presented Haydn's "The Creation" last night at Carnegie Hall in collaboration with the Dessoff Choirs, Paul Boepple, conductor.

CHICAGO, April 1 (AP) -- Federal Judge Walter J. La Buy today gave trustees of the Majestic Radio and Television Corporation permission to sue its former president. Attorneys said they might sue for $500,000.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- The House passed today a bill to abolish all Federal taxes on oleomargarine. These have been levied for sixty-three years. The House eliminated a clause restricting interstate shipments. The final roll-call vote was 287 to 89.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- Count Carlo Sforza, Italian Foreign Minister, expressed hope today for an agreement of the Foreign Ministers of the Atlantic powers who are here on the question of the former Italian colonies in Africa before he left this capital.

Statement showing executive budget recommendations for the various city departments, all funds, for 1949-50 submitted by Mayor O'Dwyer to the Board of Estimate and the City Council, with comparisons between the budget for 1948-49 as modified to March 15, 1949, and the executive budget for 1949-50.

BOSTON, April 1 (AP) -- The Waltham Watch Company, the nation's largest watch works, which was shut down on Dec. 31 pending a financial reorganization, will reopen on April 13. This news for 2,300 employes was announced today by the company's court-appointed trustees after a hearing in Federal court on the reorganization plan.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 1 (AP) -- The Maryland Racing Commission chairman quit in a huff today because two tracks received ten extra days each.
NEW KENSINGTON, Pa., April 1 (UP) -- The United Mine Workers today opened its drive for a shorter work day, increased welfare benefits, and higher wages for 400,000 soft coal diggers.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- Ernest Bevin, British Foreign Secretary, depicted today the Atlantic pact as a powerful weapon of defense against would-be "totalitarian" aggressors because it created "a common pool" of the free world's manpower, military and economic assistance.

PARIS, April 1 -- In a recorded Voice of America broadcast tonight on the French radio on the eve of the anniversary of the passage by Congress of the Economic Cooperation Act, Ambassador W. Averell Harriman, chief European representative of the Economic Cooperation Administration, declared that European countries are making progress toward paying their own way in trade with the United States.
April is the beginning of the garden flower season. City dwellers are returning from country weekends with arms full, while suburbanites renew the luxury of cutting flowers for their homes.

VIENNA, April 1 -- Celebrating the first anniversary of the European Recovery Program, Lieut. Gen. Geoffrey Keyes, United States Commander in Austria, tomorrow will praise the Austrians for making "good use" of the help given by the United States.
New York's multi-million dollar taxi industry was seriously hobbled yesterday by a strike of cab drivers, but promises and predictions of violence failed to materialize.

Pig lead prices were reduced one cent a pound yesterday, setting a market price of 16 cents for a new low for the fourth time in the past month, since the post-war peak of 21 1/2 cents was established last November. In another line, aluminum casting alloy ingots, reductions of 1 cent a pound in each of three major grades, brought lowest prices of these products since Jan. 26.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., April 1 -- Casey Stengel had his little joke on Joe McCarthy this afternoon at Al Lang Field. The Yankee skipper sent George Stirnweiss off on a theft of second base and in the tenth inning this bit of larceny paid dividends when Stirnweiss scampered over the plate with the run that gave the Yanks another triumph over the Boston Red Sox. The score was 4 to 3.

PHOENIX, Ariz., April 1 -- Freddie Fitzsimmons officially came back to the Giants today and even though the weather prevented him from doing anything more taxing than taking his gear out to the ball park, it was patent the one-time knuckle-balling mound ace now engaged as coach was tickled pink to be with the Polo Grounders once again.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., April 1 -- A note of high optimism for the success of the United Nations in solving present world problems prevailed on the Rutgers College campus as the collegiate version on United Nations General Assembly came to a close today.

New clinical evidence that continued exposure to relatively minor infections can lead to disabling and crippling ailments was presented yesterday before the thirtieth annual meeting of the American College of Physicians at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
CHICAGO, April 1 (AP) -- A child-guidance specialist today said that society "feels guilty" over its treatment of the emotionally-disturbed child.

Broadcasters have been selling "too much poor listening over bad AM reception" whereas "FM the 'life saver' -- the radio industry's only means of giving every person good reception" has virtually gone begging, Edgar Kobak, president of the Mutual Broadcasting System, charged here yesterday.

JIMMY DURANTE used to sing a resonant and wildly dramatic ballad in praise of wood. In the course of the song -- which was violently illustrated, you remember, with many more or less portable wooden wares -- Mr. Durante paid practically all man's debts and respects to the products of Mr. Kilmer's trees. We'd quote the lyrics if we had them -- and permission to enter the copyright brambles.

PARIS, April 1 -- Moscow's memorandum denouncing the pact has accentuated the belief in official and wider circles here that the new treaty has frightened Soviet leaders and that they may take some impulsive action in retaliation.

A nation-wide letter campaign ridiculing the teaching profession and urging women to stay away from the classroom has been quietly conducted in this country during the last month, it became known yesterday.

The Whitney Museum will open to the public today its annual exhibition of contemporary American sculpture, water-colors and drawings to be current until May 8. Included in the showing are seventy-eight pieces of sculpture; as many water-colors, gouaches and pastels; and some forty drawings.

For the second performance in his series at the Ziegfeld Theatre, Jose Limon last night elected to present a program very much lighter in substance than that of his opening night. Not until the final number, when the "Lament for Ignacio Sanchez Mejias" was repeated from the earlier performance, did he take us into any deep emotion or solemnity of mood. But it was a delightful program, for all that.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- The National Labor Relations Board told the Civil Service Commission today that it badly needed the services of the experienced trial examiners who were found by commission consultants to be unqualified for their work.

A bill placing a minimum on the age of all rum exported from Puerto Rico is virtually certain of becoming a law within the next few weeks, it was learned here yesterday. The bill is now before the Puerto Rican Legislature, now in session, and is practically supported unanimously by all factions of the Government, according to reports.

A letter by Dr. E. Sukenik in THE NEW YORK TIMES of March 19 comments on a news story published in THE TIMES on March 4 based on my article, "A Commentary on the Book of Habakkuk, Important Discovery or Hoax?" that appeared in the January number of The Jewish Quarterly Review.

Coffee futures were active and lower as trade and commission-house selling depressed prices of contract "D" 15 to 25 points on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday. Support was on a scale-down, with some short covering in evidence to absorb the selling. Contract "S" followed this trend with final prices 5 to 31 points lower.
PHILADELPHIA, April 1 (AP) -Seven British industrialists and trade union executives today inspected two Philadelphia industries in a nation-wide tour of manufacturing plants.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson in a letter to the National Conference of Christians and Jews today denounced the religious persecution in Eastern Europe as "a Godless inquisition."
Mrs. Henrietta Brackley Tuthill of the Fencers Club won the individual senior foil competition for the Mildred Fish Medals on the strips of the Fencers Club last night. Nine contestants took part.
The jokers of the world emerged from their shells yesterday for their one big day of the year -- April Fool's Day. Today, most everyone is glad that the nonsense is over for another twelve months.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 1 -- Accomplishments and prospects as they appear at the mid-point of the twentieth century were scrutinized today by thirty eminent scientists, philosophers, educators, statesmen and industrialists of ten countries, who took part in six panels at the Mid-Century Convocation of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

ATLANTIC CITY, April -Harrison L. Todd of Camden, president of the New Jersey Association of Real Estate Boards, today urged the state's home builders to devise ways to finance mortgage loans on homes for war veterans.
WASHINGTON, April 1 (AP) -Following is the text of the speech made today by British Foreign Secretary Bevin at a National Press Club luncheon:

CHICAGO, April 1 -- Grain markets averaged lower on the Board of Trade today, but rallied from the inside prices and closed irregular, with wheat 1/2 to 7/8 cent a bushel lower; corn, 1/2 cent lower to 1/8 cent higher; oats, 3/8 to 1/2 cent lower; rye, 3/4 cent lower, and soybeans, 3/4 cent higher. Lard was 5 to 7 cents per 100 pounds higher.

HOUSTON, Tex., April 1 -- Fear that Peewee Reese had developed a hernia was dissipated early today when the Dodgers' shortstop and captain visited a local physician instead of waiting until reaching Fort Worth, as originally intended.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- Senator Glen H. Taylor, Democrat, of Idaho, today said that he was "pleased with the verdict" of a Birmingham (Ala.) jury which yesterday found him guilty of disorderly conduct. The case was a result of his efforts to address a mixed audience in Birmingham last May 1 when he was running as candidate for Vice President on the Henry Wallace ticket.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- The Senate rejected tonight successive attempts to cut deeply into the $5,580,000,000 sought by the Truman Administration for the European Recovery Program in the next fifteen months.

LONDON, April 1 -- The French Deputy to the Austrian treaty negotiations unexpectedly offered today to strike from the treaty draft three French - sponsored articles that would have barred Austria's production of certain types of military equipment, engaging in military research or stockpiling materials of potential military value.

A campaign by Local 807 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, AFL, to check the union credentials of truck drivers entering and leaving the city as well as of local drivers began yesterday. The campaign is part of a nation-wide drive by the union to double its membership of 1,000,000.

PALISADES, N. J., April 1 -- Columbia University was notified today that its Lamont Geological Laboratories here were located illegally in a residential zone and that any laboratory operations there would be liable to a fine of $50 a day.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- Heads of the women's divisions of the two major political parties -- Mrs. India Edwards, director for the Democrats, and Mrs. Robert W. MaCauley, Republican vice chairman -- were in the receiving line at today's reception to open the National Women's Party convention to press for the Equal Rights Amendment. The measure has been variously before Congress since 1923.

An editorial under the heading "Shipping Policy," appearing in THE NEW YORK TIMES issue of March 22, has come to my attention. This editorial carries several misstatements that have characterized other press statements recently appearing on this subject and conveys a generally incorrect picture of this matter to the public.

WASHINGTON, April 1 (AP) -- Representative of the motion-picture industry asked President Truman today to help them solve what they called a serious unemployment situation in the trade. They sought the President's aid particularly in getting the State Department to assist the industry in overcoming "artificial restrictions" on the making of American films abroad.
ATHENS, April 1 -- Constantin Rentis, Minister of Public Order, issued notice today that members of the Greek Communist party would be treated as traitors and so prosecuted when arrested.
JERSEY CITY, April 1 (AP) -- The Burlington Bridge Commission has lost its fight to ease a court restraint barring payment today of interest on its outstanding bonds.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- Lorenzo S. Winslow, architect for the White House, was preparing his defenses against a threatening siege of souvenir hunters today as early action on its reconstruction was pledged after a score of members of Congress inspected the mansion.

Mementos of the "straw hat" circuit presented to the New York Public Library by Leighton Rollins, theatrical producer, will be on view at Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street through May. Entitled "Summer Theatre," the exhibition outlines the activities of summer stock during the last twenty years.

PERHAPS the most desirable feature of automatic watering in the greenhouse is the big saving in time and effort it makes possible. Equally important, however, is the fact that this method of sub-irrigation does a more thorough and accurate job than surface watering.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- President Truman's plan to broaden and liberalize the Federal social-security system appeared to be in some jeopardy today from what was described in one quarter as too much solicitude.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- If the New York Knickerbockers go to Minneapolis for the Basketball Association of America final play-off they will be there merely as spectators. For, tonight, in the National Guard Armory, Joe Lapchick's men were eliminated from the running as the Washington Capitols finished strongly and earned an 84-76 victory in the rubber game of the Eastern Division finals.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., April 2 -- Advocates of "white supremacy" at Southern polls received a severe setback this week when the United States Supreme Court affirmed the ruling of a lower court in Mobile, Ala., that Alabama's Boswell Amendment was unconstitutional.

THIS story of Bill Gordon, an 18-year-old guide in northern Maine, is full of good living, sane thinking and presents a reassuring outlook on life. Bill's adventures build up naturally from the day he gets his guide's license to the climax of a manhunt and forest fire.
MOSCOW, April 2 -- The Government newspaper Izvestia has exhaustively analyzed the grounds for the official Soviet charges that the North Atlantic pact violates the charter of the United Nations.

Wellesley College will hold its fourth Institute for Foreign Students from June 30 through Sept. 10. The institute, planned to meet individual needs, offers courses in pronunciation, oral communication and written English. It is intended for foreign students who will enter North American colleges in the fall.

THERE is a quiet charm about D.E. Stevenson's books which her admirers find not only entertaining but soothing. Like Angela Thirkell, she creates a small world of tempests and ripples in a teacup. The result is quite as engaging if less literary.

KINGS POINT, L.I., April 2 -- Fordham's baseball squad, paced by the stellar hurling of its veteran right hander, Jim Arbucho, got off to a flying start in its 1949 debut today when it defeated the Merchant Marine Academy, 7 -- 3. The contest marked the opening of the Metropolitan Intercollegiate Conference schedule.
WARSAW, April 2 -- The Roman Catholic episcopate of Poland has addressed a note of protest to the Government charging it with the use of pressure tactics, it was learned in Catholic circles today.

FRANKFORT, April 2 -- The political tide in Germany, which seemed last autumn to be running so strongly in favor of the Western Allies, now is ebbing. The process of establishing a West German State, one of the basic goals of the tri-power policy in Europe, has been so beset by differences and difficulties that the Parliamentary Council convoked at Bonn eight months ago to write a Constitution has been unable to complete its task.

AS one of the few full-fledged women directors in television, Frances Buss has a success story which runs counter to the glamorous norm. Most of her life -- she is only 31 -- has been riddled with luck, a good deal of it bad.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson assured the United States delegation to the United Nations today that the purpose of the North Atlantic treaty was to strengthen the United Nations.

As a sponsor of the Cultural and Scientific Conference for World Peace it is my impression that no adequate hearing has been given those of us who refused to withdraw even though we are critical of both the Soviet Union and the Communist party.
WASHINGTON, April 2 -- Behind the scenes, the battle over minimum wage law revision is taking on the character of a knockdown and dragout fight.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- The perennial issue of statehood for Hawaii and Alaska hovers on the legislative horizon and may provide, before it is settled, another opportunity for President Truman to separate his Congressional sheep from the goats.

LAKELAND, Fla., April 2 -- Casey Stengel was busy on some mysterious errand with General Manager George Weiss, so Frankie Crosetti led the Yankees into this town today for the finale with the Detroit Tigers and had the satisfaction of seeing the Bombers shutout Red Robert Rolfe's squad before a gathering of 1,456. The score was 3 to 0.
WASHINGTON, April 2 (U.P.) -- Republicans and Southern Democrats of the House publicly claimed victory today in their battle to block the Administration's drive for Taft-Hartley Act repeal.

A FEW weeks ago, shortly after had been appointed chief of the Swedish Royal Opera, Joel Berglund let drop a remark concerning a possible closer collaboration between opera in Sweden and in the United States. Like a pebble dropped in a well, the splash has now come back, slightly amplified.

THE property department, always an essential element of the theatre, is becoming equally important in television production. During the years of radio, the responsibility for creating an illusion of reality rested with the sound effects department.

RAY BOLGER is a very remarkable man. Indeed, if some uninhibited enthusiast were to name him the greatest dancer in the world, this department, which could not stick its neck out by making such a nomination or even assenting to anything of the kind, would sit by with a warm glow of satisfaction and say absolutely nothing.

OBVIOUSLY writing a satire, not only of French life but of Victorian novels as well, Mr. Gabriel Chevallier, author of "Scandals of Clochemerle" and several other books, begins his latest with this first sentence:

INEVITABLY, the writers given to the shock approach in novels must concentrate on extremes of character and behavior. This is the equivalent of maintaining constant fortissimo of highest and lowest notes in a symphony orchestra.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- The United States and Britain, in vigorous notes today to Bulgaria, Hungary and Rumania, charged the Russian satellites with repeated, continuing and "notorious" violations of their peace treaty guarantees of respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms and demanded that they abide by their pledges.

PHOENIX, Ariz., April 2 -- The Giants were having a deal of trouble with the American League's tail-end White Sox today when a couple of Leo Durocher's eager-eyed youngsters weighed in with a pair of spectacular moves that made possible a nerve-tingling tenth-inning victory for the Polo Grounders. The score was 5 to 4.

AT first glance "City of the Bees" appears to be the work of a naturalist who was once a bee and has written the inside story of life in a hive. The bees' most secret thoughts, most intimate feelings, most personal motivations -- their whispered hopes and unspoken desires, their reflections on life and conception of the world -- all is revealed.

When Newfoundland attached herself, on Friday, to the Dominion of Canada she took a further step in a long series of political changes. All of those changes have been made within the framework of the British Commonwealth and Empire and for almost a century they have been made both with the consent and at the behest of the Newfoundlanders themselves.

LONDON, April 2 -- A European Union by consent and not by conquest has been a utopian dream since Dante whote his "Monarchia" at the beginning of the fourteenth century. Today it promises to become a reality which is a startling and even a thrilling thought.

Miss Stacey Frey has been appointed assistant to the president of Snow Crop Marketers, Inc. She joined the company in 1947 and was formerly with the Birds Eye-Snider division of the General Foods Corporation.

Many members of society actively interested in the maintenance of the New York Infirmary have subscribed to the spring supper dance to be given Wednesday at the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria after a gala invitation preview of a Degas loan exhibition at the Wildenstein Gallery.
Cabs rolled in greater numbers on the streets of New York yesterday as arrests growing out of the taxi strike mounted to forty-two, of which nineteen took place during the day.

British business and advertising groups are hopeful that announcement of the British Government's budget next Wednesday will provide for some lifting of purchasing taxes, Hugh Appleton, a top London advertising executive, said on his arrival here on Friday.

CENTERVILLE citizens are so beaten down by greedy mine owners and corrupt police that in the face of violent outrage all they say is "This is Centerville." Nevertheless, the miners do strike. Detective Michael Shayne arrives with a $5,000 retaining fee and a letter from a mine owner in his pocket, too late to save his client from murder.

AT Atlantic City's Convention Hall the world's biggest sports contest is being fought out amid a crash of falling timber and a spell of good intramural fellowship. It is the annual tournament of the American Bowling Congress, a sort of revival meeting which brings 30,000 keglers rolling in from the nation's home-town alleys.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- Making good a threat he made Tuesday to eliminate useless boards, Louis Johnson, new Secretary of Defense, abolished nine of them today and ordered a sweeping review to determine the fate of hundreds more.

OMAHA, April 2 -- A wide variety of weather, practically all of it nasty, held command in the Middle West this week, slowing down farm work, making many roads impassable and providing the region with its top conversation piece.

THIS is the story of a Welsh family who, in the Eighteen Hundreds, give up their farm in the hills of Wales and came to America because of the troubles brought upon them by Megan, a daughter of the house. To atone for a wrong she has done, Megan must bring up her sister's fatherless child as her own -- this payment, according to Welsh tradition, being the "spear penny."

INSTEAD of serving up the usual thinly disguised segment of autobiography, Mr. Nemerov has undertaken for his first novel the much more difficult task of presenting a satiric view of certain phases of contemporary civilization.

CHICAGO, April 2 -- The outlook for the enactment of fair employment practice legislation in many Northern states is "more favorable" this year than ever before, according to the American Council on Race Relations. Prof. Louis Wirth of the University of Chicago is president of the council.

Charging discrimination against young workers in industry, including Negro veterans of World War II, members of the Young Progressives of New York urged support yesterday of legislation pending in the House of Representatives to extend to July 25, 1951, the allowances granted by the GI Bill.
THANKS to modern medical care and good health protection, many more children's lives are saved today than were saved a generation ago; many more children's maintain tip-top health while growing up.
WASHINGTON, April 2 -- Consumers for five months have enjoyed the first sustained decline in the price index since the war, but there is reason to believe the slide is about over for a while.

THE night before "South Pacific" began its sensational stand in New Haven it was generally agreed by the high brass that about fifteen minutes would have to be cut from the running time. Emlyn Williams, author of "Night Must Fall" and "The Corn Is Green," was present and the Messrs.

THE totem poles of the Haida Indians loomed too close to the Monroe's Alaskan homestead for complete comfort. True to British colonial tradition, Pa Monroe, head of that Scottish pioneer family of the Eighteen Eighties (first met in "Watch for a Tall White Sail"), didn't consider his heathen neighbors fit companions for his children.

HALLANDALE, Fla., April 2 (AP) -- F.A. Blaser's Count-a-Bit, a Kentucky Derby eligible, today won Gulfstream Park's $5,000 Fountain of Youth Handicap by two lengths before 12,093 fans. The Treplow Stable's Fugitive was second, two lengths in front of the Savoy Stable's Top Admiral -- another Derby candidate.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- Vice Admiral Arthur W. Radford was appointed by President Truman today to be Commander of the Pacific Fleet and High Commissioner of the Trust Territory of the Pacific (formerly Japanese-mandated) Islands.
Hopes for a spring upturn in employment were set back yesterday with release of figures showing a new rise in state unemployment benefit payments last week.

Arturo Toscanini's performance of the second half of Verdi's "Aida" yesterday afternoon in Radio City was the expected culmination of his achievement with the first part of the opera in the same place with the same forces the week previous.
CONTRARY to general belief, a rock garden may be well planned, of good design and proportion, and yet be small enough to fit even the moderately sized suburban plot.

CHAPEL HILL, N. C., April 2 (AP) -- They rewrote the record books of the Carolina Relays today as six new marks were established by a speedy, talented band of athletes from eight Southern and two Eastern institutions.

PALM BEACH, Fla., April 2 -- Development of a constructive forward-looking foreign trade policy by all divisions of the cotton textile industry in cooperation with the cotton growers was urged by Dr C.T. Murchison, president of the Cotton-Textile Institute, in a talk before the closing session of the American Cotton Manufacturers Association convention here today.
DETROIT, April 2 (AP) -- More price cuts will be made by the auto industry over the next few weeks. This is the belief of many industry chroniclers and not a few top industry executives.

Reversing the downward trend of the last five weeks, retail trade here last week showed an increase over the same period last year. The rise for department stores was put at 4 per cent. Pre-Easter volume is now rising, but current comparison is with the post-Easter period of last year.
Junior high school students representing a cross-section of youth in the metropolitan area agreed yesterday that their communities were "perfect except for a few things."

LONDON, April 2 -- The Economic Cooperation Administration in Britain announced here today that approval has been given for three projects to make United States technical information and experience available to British agriculture, industry and colonial development.

LAKE SUCCESS, April 2 -- Disagreements between the Western powers and the Soviet bloc have now reached unprecedented intensity, and there is not much chance that the spring session of the United Nations' General Assembly, which opens on Tuesday, will do much to reduce it.

After ten years in this country, in which she has been the guiding spirit in many concerts of early music, Edith Weiss Mann, harpsichordist, finally got around to giving her first New York recital. She made her solo bow yesterday afternoon at Town Hall.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- The European Recovery Program "must always operate under emergency pressure" if it is to attain its objectives, Paul G. Hoffman, Economic Cooperation Administrator, warned today.

MONTREAL, April 2 (AP) -- The Montreal Canadiens, sparked by rookie Gerry Plamondon, who scored twice, beat the Detroit Red Wings, 3 -- 1, tonight to tie their semi-final round Stanley Hockey Cup play-off series at three games each.

The children who dislike school do so because they fail to recognize the importance of education in the attainment of their life goals. This is the finding of Prof. Arthur T. Jersild and Miss Ruth J. Tasch, whose study on "Children's Interests" will be released next week by the Horace Mann-Lincoln Institute of School Experimentation through Teachers College of Columbia University.

STUDENTS at the University of Minnesota, convinced that the best way to promote international understanding is through a first-hand knowledge of the people of other lands, have devised a system to surmount their chief hurdle--lack of funds for travel abroad.

THIS is the story of the meeting of the man and the hour. Such meetings are infrequent -- romantics to the contrary. Yet when, in May, 1940, Winston Churchill assumed the leadership of a Britain half-armed but wholehearted, the man and the hour were one. As long as free men draw strength from the heroic past they will remember the story of Britain's stand -- alone -- for the freedom of the Western world.

PHOENIX, Ariz., April 2 -- Although trade rumors have been zooming about the Giants these many weeks, the current dizzy season seemed to have reached its peak today when reports of so many deals filled the air it looked for a time as though the Polo Grounders would have nothing left but the Section Five Club with which to open the season.

BOWIE, Md., April 2 (AP) -- Claude C. Tanner's Nearway became a double stakes winner during this young meeting and kept his unbeaten record for the year intact when he annexed the mile and seventy-yard thirty-fourth running of the Bowle Handicap today.

Needle-trades officials recommended yesterday a policy of making friends with workers alongside as the best way to break down race prejudice in an industry. They condemned left-wing pressure groups as preying on Negroes and Puerto Ricans, who they said could advance in the industry along the same path of making friends and introducing their families to the trade.

In the University of California's College of Pharmacy Pierre Carlo, Jean Dufrenoy, V. L. Pickering, Robertson Pratt and Peter P. T. Sah have been speeding up the growth of plants by means of chemicals, and with such striking results that their studies may be of agricultural importance.

While awaiting a cure for the stock market's chronic price heaviness and shrunken turnover, Wall Street is going in for "another language" -- the language of mutual-investment-fund promotion. No longer content to sell mutual-fund shares to investors on a casual basis, many major firms doing a general underwriting, sales and brokerage business are setting up special departments to sell the investment company shares.
FROM the weather point of view we had an exceptionally mild February and had to wait till March for a touch of something brisker. That goes for the theatre, too.
A campaign to raise $50,000 to "wipe off the books" the new Feinberg law banning Communists and "fellow travelers" from public school jobs was started yesterday by the CIO Teachers Union.

RANGOON, Burma, April 2 (Reuters) -- Six members of Burmese Prime Minister Thakin Nu's Cabinet resigned today, as insurgent forces of the Left-Wing "White Band" People's Volunteer Organization were reported in control of the entire area on the northern banks of the river Irrawaddy opposite Rangoon.

At least 5,000 taxicabs will be on the street by tomorrow morning, small fleet and independent owners predicted yesterday. They were backed by many cab drivers, who rather shamefacedly conceded that "we have our nerve back."
DETROIT, April 2 -- Automotive circles were awaiting with intense interest tonight a price reduction announcement expected to be made by the Ford Motor Company on a country wide basis tomorrow.

Widespread medical speculation in the last few weeks has centered about the possibility that DDT, when improperly used to kill insects on food-producing farms, may be carried over into the nation's perishable food markets in quantities sufficient to cause mild poisoning to human consumers.
IN company with several others I attended a recent performance of "Life With Mother" at the Empire Theatre. The house was approximately one-third empty.

NANKING, April 2 -- Mao Tze-tung, chairman of the Chinese Communist party, tonight relaxed his earlier insistence on the punishment of Kuomintang "war criminals" as Nationalist and Communist negotiators in Peiping entered the first stage of the peace talks aimed at ending the civil war.
WASHINGTON, April 2 (UP) -- Former Attorney General Francis Biddle and a group of associates tonight called for establishment of a $15,000,000,000 National Resources Corporation.

Moscow today is the showplace of the Soviet Union and it is probably the most unrepresentative city in Stalin's domain. One might as well try to generalize about the United States on the basis of a short visit to midtown Manhattan as to reach general conclusions about the 200,000,000 Soviet people from observation of Moscow alone.

Regardless of the cause of death, the Federal Government imposes a tax upon the estates of deceased persons, subject only to the statutory amount of exemption One important exception to the operation of this tax has been recognized by the Congress.
CLEVELAND, April 2 -- A new word, "Unescan," has been fashioned at the meetings of the United States Commission for the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization.
The importance of propagating the principles of religion and morality as a means of promoting world peace was stressed by rabbis in sermons here yesterday. They also spoke about Israel.

Earl Bailly can neither feed nor dress himself, but he can turn out a painting in a week. And though he works by holding a brush with his teeth, his colorful canvases seem to rival many created by hand.

HIGHLY personalized eyewitness reporting seems to have had its day in many sections of the American press. The telephone and teletype and rewrite man have taken much of the personal touch out of modern journalism.

AFTER lon years of subversive activity, I-tollywood's sympathizers in the Soviet film industry have finally !been exposed. Reports from Iosi cow indicate that these "harmful" i and "anti-patriotic" characters are )being dealt with in suitable manher to prevent their doing further damage.

Weekday religious education on released time for public school students will become one of the major current topics for group and community discussions in New York and other states this month, it was learned yesterday.

Organizers of the city-wide taxicab strike suffered a legal setback in Supreme Court yesterday when Local 35, United Construction Workers, was temporarily barred from picketing the garage of a major fleet owner with signs carrying the word "strike."

"THE PSYCHOANALYTIC READER" is the first volume of a projected series of anthologies containing translations of representative articles taken from various professional periodicals that are inaccessible to the general reader.

FOR a few weeks at least plus signs will return to retail sales figures. The reason for this is that Easter business will be compared with the post-holiday trade of last year because the holiday comes three weeks later.
WASHINGTON, April 2 (AP) -- The Army wants a song it can call its own and conducted a worldwide contest to find it. Today it picked out five to try on the public.

AS a former film critic, now interested in television, I would like to say in regard to a story published last Sunday that Mr. Raibourn, like most of the Hollywood authorities on television, is competely at sea.

BEFORE the war John Horne Burns was a teacher at a well known private school in New England -- and after his stint in the ETO returned to the classroom while he was finishing that fine first novel, "The Gallery." Later he abandoned his teaching career to devote his full time to writing.

SOMEBODY seemed to have an interesting scheme to snuff out old ladies retired to a luxurious home in Westchester County ($20,000 down for admission). Soon after Miss Abbie Stanhope, 70, moved in, she received a mysterious note saying "It's the newcomers who die."
WOR has just completed a study which, the station says, shows the types of radio programs that are holding up best against television "competition."

IN the process of finding out the name and function of a magical balloon the Easter rabbit blows it up to record size and is carried away into the sky. His flight through space is punctuated by the explosion of the balloon and terminates in the local pond. Fortunately for the entertainment value of this story the Easter rabbit is accompanied by his appealing friends the kitten, the pig, the duck and the dog.

THE first British precision-made 35mm miniature camera is now being manufactured and will be available in this country late this year, according to the inventor, David Waddington, an outstanding English photographer. He said here last week that the camera will sell for about half the price of the best German miniatures.

ALBANY, April 2 -- The young lawyers' section of the State Bar Association concluded its eleventh annual meeting today with the election of Philetus M. Chamberlain of Rochester as chairman to succeed Charles J. Robin Jr. of Albany.

Olympia, the colt that Fred W. Hooper is counting on to give him a second Kentucky Derby victory on May 7, made a Coaltownish run at Jamaica yesterday to gain what amounted to a no-contest decision in the $21,200 Experimental Handicap No. 1. He led from gate to wire and the closest of his five pursuers was eight lengths astern at the end of the six furlongs.

The special committee appointed by the National Foreign Trade Council to formulate recommendations in connection with President Truman's "bold new program" for assistance to under-developed areas of the world will have its initial meeting here this week, it was learned yesterday.

In the most active session on the New York Cotton Exchange for a Saturday in months, the cotton futures market closed irregular yesterday, to points lower to 34 points higher than on Friday. The strength was most pronounced in new crop months.

DAMASCUS, Syria, April 2 -- Gen. Husni Zayim, army chief, dissolved Parliament last night, and the new "administrative" Cabinet of technicians formed by him following his seizure of power by a coup met today for the first time.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- Attorney General Tom Clark said at a dinner of the National Women's Party tonight that this country should follow the example of the United Nations by giving more rights to women.

THIS is the avalanche season high in the mountains of Utah. Now masses of snow and ice, tilted precariously on ridges packed with a winter's accumulation of dry-powder snowfall, begin their rumblings and shakings underfoot.

RICHMOND, Va., April 2 -- Springtime arrived in the Upper South this week with a wave of hot weather that caused gardens to burst into bloom. But weather had plenty of competition for public interest.

Mike Jacobs returned to New York yesterday after a long period of convalescence in Florida and declared himself ready, able and willing to get back into the pugilistic picture, of which he was so long the dominant figure.

A NEW "music-play" by Ernst Bacon, a fantasy entitled "The Drumlin Legend," will be the featured work of Columbia University's fifth annual Festival of Contemporary American Music. The work, commissioned for the occasion, follows the style of Mr. Bacon's earlier music-play,...

Dr. John B. Graham and his wife, Dr. Ruth M. Graham, both on the staff of the University of Oregon's Medical School, have made some studies which convince them that it may be possible to increase human resistance to X-rays and even to the deadly rays of an exploded atomic bomb.

RICHMOND, Va., April 2 (AP) -- Samuel R. Fry's Valdina Scamp went to the front at the final jump today to win by nearly four lengths the Deep Run Hunt Cup and set a new record for the Strawberry Hill course. Ten thousand spectators watched the six-race program.
ALBUQUERQUE, N. M., April 2 -- Congress came in for some sharp criticism in the Southwest this week in regard to its maneuverings on both rent control and veterans' pensions.

Although available crude oil production is in excess of demand, motorists this spring and summer may expect to pay the present "scarcity" prices for gasoline. Some weakening in the present controls over crude oil production would be about the only way to bring about lower prices.

Three transatlantic and six transpacific flights postponed by Pan American World Airways became of a strike of 250 radio operators were dispatched yesterday as soon as passengers and crews could be rounded up after normal schedules were resumed on settlement of the dispute.

TAKE no large bets on it, but at the rate it is moving up the best-seller ladder to the right J.P. Marquand's "Point of No Return" looks like the strongest contender thus far for "The Big Fisherman's" crown. Mr. Marquand's "B.F.'s Daughter" (1946) moved up faster yet -- it was No. 6 at the outset and No. 1 the following week. But "B.F.'s Daughter" had no "B.F." to contend with.

THE controversy over the future of the "Oscars" handed out annually since 1928 by the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences reached its climax in New York last week when the major film distributors announced the discontinuance of their annual subsidy for the presentation of the academy awards.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, April 2 -- In an attempted coup led by Col. Edgar Cardona, Minister of Security, against the regime of Junta President Jose Figueres, Army units today seized two chief strongpoints of the city, the Artillery Barracks and Bellavista Barracks.

VIENNA, April 2 -- The new oil well opened by the Russians in Matzen is almost certainly the center of an important new oil field that greatly changes the Austrian oil production picture and will make exploration rights the key problem in the four-power negotiations on Austrian oil properties just begun in London, oil experts here said today.

JAPAN'S non-fiction best-seller list is a battle royal of ideas. Among other ideas, the list reflects the claims of Buddhism, Christianity, communism and sentimentality, with the last perhaps leading.

TEL AVIV, Israel, April 2 -- Elaborate plans have been drawn to make Jerusalem the cultural and educational center of Israel and to double the city's population within five years. The first step will be to erect a congress hall with 1,800 seats where the World Zionist Congress will meet in the future.

Ending of a strike of twenty-four faculty members of the Putney School, a "progressive" private co-educational boarding institution at Putney, Vt., was announced yesterday at the CIO Teachers Union annual education conference in the Commodore Hotel.

THIS impressive, three-volume history of the beginnings of Italian national music is the result of forty years of research and study by an outstanding musicologist. It is an illuminating contribution not only to musical scholarship but also to our knowledge of life and art in sixteenth-century Italy.

SHOULD Jean, pregnant by a divorced husband and saddled with a blind father, marry Bradford Masters, weak, handsome, plausible, singing, guitar-playing hero? Will Bradford Masters, weak, handsome, etc., pull himself together to shoulder the responsibilities of marriage?

LAKE SUCCESS, March 31 -- Following is a list of problems to be discussed by the United Nations General Assembly session opening at Flushing Meadows on April 5:

BERLIN, April 2 -- Germany will be prohibited from producing synthetic rubber, oil and gasoline under the three-power reparations accord reached in London earlier this week, authoritative sources said today.
I am amazed that the world-respected Times would lend its columns to such ridiculous propaganda as Sam Boal's article on New York cabbies.

JUST at the time that the tough genre in fiction needs revitalizing John Macdonald turns up. There is nothing startlingly new about Mr. Macdonald's plot (though there is great technical dexterity in his interweaving of three levels of criminal endeavor); kidnapping, contraband, decadence and brutality are familiar elements of the hard-boiled school.

In the offices of a big New York business concern on lower Broadway, there is a large room where 160 employes do tabulating procedures that are essential to its operation. Each day, however, an average of eight of the computing machines are idle, their operators having failed to report to work because of illness.

CHICAGO, April 2 -- While city dwellers throughout the Central West studied the new Federal rent-contol law this week with some misgivings, the farmers of this area were reported to be facing another spring "seedtime" with optimism.

Cardinal Spellman will deliver a special message this evening at the conclusion of the Ave Maria Hour over radio station WMCA, which will have as a Passion Sunday feature a drama based on the life of Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty, it was announced yesterday.

With the Atlantic pact due to be signed in Washington tomorrow, the Soviets are speeding up their attacks on it. It is the Russian case that the treaty is a warlike measure aimed at Moscow; it is the case of the Atlantic powers that it is a measure of joint protection against aggression committed against any of its parties.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 1 -- Macedonia, the political conglomerate that has known no full independence as a unit since pre-Christian days and is at present divided among Yugoslavia. Bulgaria and Greece, is emerging as a key strategical issue of the "cold war" in the Balkans.

SPRING continues to produce busy schedules. The chief event of the week is the New York debut of the Ballet Repertory Company, headed by Thalia Mara and Arthur Mahoney, at the Ziegfeld on Friday and Saturday.

An Ambassador from Korea is in the United States to urge upon this country the necessity for providing more adequate defense forces for the Republic of Korea. Before he left Seoul the Ambassador, Chough Pyung Ok, stated that he would appeal for the equipment of an armed force of about 100,000 men in addition to militia and police, and it is such a program, presumably, that he has laid before our Government.

PARIS, April 2 -- Joseph Paul-Boncour, ex-Premier and formerly French delegate to the League of Nations, in an address tonight to the Socialist party at Montlucon said that Western Europe must be prepared to fight in the event of a war between the Soviet Union and the United States.

THE artist is accused these days of not knowing what he is doing or taunted with failing to make clear whatever meaning he may have. He himself believes he is more eloquent in paint than polemics, in stone than in semantics.

FORT WORTH, Texas, April 2 -- The Dodgers continued to flatten their minor league opposition when they outscored their Texas League farm hands, the Fort Worth Cats, by 9 -- 3 at La Grave Stadium today.

AMSTERDAM, April 2 -- The largest passenger liner ever built in the Netherlands for foreign account was launched here today by Crown Princess Martha of Norway who named the sleek 16,500-ton vessel Oslofjord. When completed later this year she will become the flagship of the Norwegian American Line and next season will enter service between Oslo, Bergen and New York.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 2 -Dr. James R. Killian Jr. was inaugurated as the tenth president of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology here this morning in the presence of a gathering of 4,500 alumni, faculty members and guests, including 235 official delegates from universities and learned societies of the United States and other countries, dressed in colorful academic robes.

A "career woman" in spite of herself, whose primary interest -- children -- accounts for her leading position in law, business and social welfare work, has now become the first of her sex to become a trustee of a downtown bank. The woman, mother of four children, fortyish and an attractice brunette, is Mrs. Helen L. Buttenwieser.

IT is given to few Scotsmen to know so much about any foreign country as Professor Brogan knows about at least three. I say "Scotsman" with due emphasis. Professor Brogan's American publishers recklessly describe him on the jacket as a "brilliant Englishman," but the flattery of the adjective will hardly make up for the insult of the noun.
Winston Churchill extended a branch of the olive to Soviet Russia yesterday, but he conceded that it was a futile gesture; that the reach of Western hands falls short of the Kremlin.

AFTER studying the routines of law enforcement in Gotham for about two years. Sidney Kingsley has completed a wonderfully accurate drama, "Detective Story," which is now filling the stage of the Hudson with cops and robbers.

The article in Sunday's TIMES (March 27) by Bernard Friend on the cine clubs of France and their alleged "contribution toward raising the artistic level of films," is interesting * * * as an example, by contrast, of widespread ignorance as to what is happening right here in the United States.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 2 -- A jumble of speed laws in Westchester County, with limits ranging from twenty to fifty miles an hour on similar parts of the same highways, is spurring police chiefs and town officials this spring to renew demands for remedial state action.

OTTAWA, April 2 -- In two debates and a ceremony held outside the building, the Canadian Parliament this past week set a new and high record in diverse achievement, in the opinion of those who attended these events.

CLEVELAND, April 2 -- The Federal Council of the Churches of Christ in America today received $100,000 from the Rockefeller Foundation for a three-year study of the application of Christian principles to economic life.

With the arrival of the Coast Guard cutter Evergreen at Argentia, Newfoundland, Thursday, the Coast Guard opened its annual surface vessel hunt for icebergs that menace North Atlantic shipping in the spring and summer.

In New York's five boroughs about 32,000 hackmen are licensed to drive 11,510 taxis. Daily they haul about a million fares, discuss with them the weather -- "Is it hot (or cold) enough for you, Mac?" -- sports, the traffic problem and international affairs, sometimes help cops "follow that car" and occasionally aid in the emergency delivery of a baby.

VINCENT STARRETT is a critic, columnist, writer of detective fiction, connoisseur of Sherlock Holmes and a poet. His previous collection of verse, "Autolycus in Limbo," appeared in 1943. The present collection, "Brillig," shows him to be, in Samuel Johnson's language, a "clubable man."

The horse family has most of its evolutionary life span behind it and will die out soon, meaning within 10,000,000 or 20,000,000 years -- a mere tick of the biological clock. The evolutionary life span of man is not predictable because his fossil history is fragmentary.

The adrenals, two small glands above the kidneys, and the pituitary, a gland at the base of the brain, may hold the key to a medical treatment for the mental disease schizophrenia. Such is the opinion of Dr. Gregory Pincus; director of Laboratories of the Worcester Foundation for Experimental Biology; Dr. Hudson Hoagland, executive director of the Foundation: Dr. Harry Freeman, an endocrinologist associated with the group, and Fred Elmadijan, a physiologist of Worcester, Mass.

The 500-acre Teterboro Airport in Bergen County, N.J., became the property of the Port of New York Authority yesterday when Frederick L. Wehran transferred ownership to the bi-state agency. The purchase contract for the freight air terminal was signed last August.

In all New York finals, Dick Miles, the defending champion, retained his United States open table tennis singles title by overcoming Martin Reisman in straight sets and Mrs. Leah Thall Neuberger beat Mrs. Reba Kirson Monness in a gruelling five-set match for the women's crown at the St. Nicholas Arena as the tournament came to a close early this morning.

Several hundred surplus propeller-driven aircraft win be part of the first year's consignment of arms and equipment to be transferred to western European nations after the signing of the Atlantic pact.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, April 2 -- Nurullah Sumer, state minister in charge of coordination of Turkey's economy, said today that participation of United States capital "in various enterprises in the economic field will be welcomed."

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 2 -- Premier Marshal Tito has appealed for national unity as an essential guarantee of victory over Yugoslavia's enemies, in a speech on the Adriatic island of Brioni, where he has been vacationing. The speech, delivered Thursday, was made public here today.

The Amerada Petroleum Corporation last year made new high records in crude oil production, oil reserves, drilling expenditures and earnings, according to the annual report issued yesterday by A. Jacobsen, president.

WHEN reading the article in yesterday's book review by Mr. Maverick entitled "Books and Congressmen," I noticed his reference to Jove springing full-born on the floor of Congress. It has always been my impression that the Roman mythology represents Minerva as springing full-born from the head of Jove.

Dr. Edward Lasker of New York lost to Hector Rossetto of Buenos Aires in the fifteenth round of the international chess masters tournament at Mar del Plata, giving the South American a much-needed point to retain the lead, according to a report from Argentina.

THE disclosure last week by Jean Hersholt, retiring president of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, that the major film companies had decided to stop financing the famed Academy awards was the piling of Ossa on Pelion so far as this year's awards were concerned.

As the Ambassador from Yugoslavia has replied to my letter in THE TIMES of March 6 about the Slovene-speaking Carinthians in southern Austria may I have the courtesy of your columns once more to answer him.

IT was with nearly unmixed pleasure that I read in your March 20 issue about a book entitled "The Coming Age of Wood." Equally pleasurable was the review by E.B. Garside. Together, book and reviewer that is, made for a happy section of a page in your Book Review.

CANAL ZONE'S Bureau of Posts has made available photographs of preliminary sketches of vignettes for four stamps which will be issued on June 1 "in commemoration of the discovery of gold in California 100 years ago and the many people from the eastern part of the United States who transited the Isthmus of Panama on their way to the West Coast."

There are not enough doctors to give adequate medical care to the 36,000,000 children of the nation, especially those living in rural areas, and many family doctors have not received enough training in the care of children.

PHILADELPHIA, April 2 -- Leading school officials of the United States, anxious to see Congress enact a Federal-aid-to-education bill, mapped this week a vigorous campaign of action in behalf of this twenty-five-year-old effort. The educators, who came here to attend a regional conference of the American Association of School Administrators, hoped 1949 would bring this controversial issue to a successful conclusion.
ATLANTA, April 2 -- People in the Southeast this week were largely concerned about where current trends are taking the American economy.

THERE are histories of science enough. Most of them are mere chronicles, valuable chiefly as reference books to fix dates and to learn what a given worthy may have discovered in his time. We want not only a chronicle but an interpretation of science.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., April 2 -- Jimmy McLane, 18-year-old prep school senior, upset Olympic champion Bill Smith of Ohio State to win the 440-yard free-style swim in record time today. His victory clinched the National Amateur Athletic Union men's indoor championship for the Near Haven (Conn.) Swim Club.

WASHINGTON -- The steady increase in the number of motorists on the highways, especially during the peak summer vacation months, is causing Federal highway officials to be concerned about the nation's highway program.

A salesman who recently stopped in a store to buy cigars for a client stroked a cat lying on a counter and was bitten on both hands. He received injections against rabies from the Health Department but he worried so much about the possibility of contracting the disease that he became an insomniac and was unable to return to his job.

Carbon monoxide poisoning, a constant menace in garages, mines and tunnels, can be prevented by a new chemical powder developed by Dr. Morris Katz and Sophie Halpern of the Defence Research Board, Department of National Defense, Ottawa, Canada. The active agent of the powder is silver permanganate.

Bullish margin speculators had a "day" in the market during the latter part of last week, but otherwise the 50 per cent margin requirement caused hardly a ripple in Wall Street or any place else in the economic scene.

This is the season when one can listen only so long to any recital of the world's shortcomings. Then we have to get outdoors and see the world itself. There we know that though a thousand things may be wrong, a million things are right.

Turnover in the selling field is on the increase, according to the record of job openings, placements, and the active list of registrants in the Sales Placement Office of the State Department of Labor at 44 East Twenty-third Street.

THE tourist who is traveling at Eastertime, whether he is heading east, west, south or north, will have ample opportunity to attend Easter services on April 17, for special observances are being planned in nearly every part of the nation.

THE Brooklyn Botanic Garden will celebrate its tenth annual Forsythia Day on Tuesday. The program, to be held in the auditorium at 3 P.M., will include demonstrations of forsythia arrangements by Mrs. William Stickles, as well as speeches by Park Commissioner Robert Moses, George S. Avery Jr., director of the Brooklyn Botanic,Garden, and others.

Joseph Barry's vivid and knowledgeable article "To Understand France, Study Her Clowns," plunges me into a welter of nostalgia. I wept into my beer over the photos of my old friends, Francesco and Alberto Fratellini.

PITTSBURGH, April 2 -- An angry crowd of 5,000 persons assailed about 250 men and women as they left Carnegie Music Hall here tonight at the close of a meeting called by the Communist party of Western Pennsylvania to protest the current conspiracy trial of eleven Communist leaders in New York City.

ROME, April 2 -- The Pope today celebrated the fiftieth anniversary of ordination to the priesthood by spending most of the day in prayer and meditation. He canceled all his audiences except the one he granted this afternoon in the Belvedere Courtyard to 50,000 Roman school children who brought him gifts and good wishes.

Like 12-year-old boys anywhere, Joey and his friend, Pete the Squeak, are in and out of trouble a good deal of the time.

IT is always sad to see a promising theme imperfectly utilized. Ernst Lothar's latest novel deals with the problems confronting an Austrian, a new citizen of this country, returning to the city of his birth after eight years of exile.
For the first time in its forty-seven year history, the Barnard College Greek Games resulted in a tie between the freshman and sophomore classes yesterday. Each side scored a total of 50 points.

And when the society celebrates its annual conservation day next Thursday at the American Museum of Natural History this will be the conference theme.

THE four Hill children, in the summer of 1908, were very happy when their father rented a farm for the summer. They found, or acquired, a whole menagerie of animals -- kittens, baby mice, a horse, pigs, chickens and a dog.

Fans that belonged to famous ladies in the days when the talents of leading artists and artisans were lavished upon them will be displayed at the New York Antiques Fair when it opens tomorrow at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory, Park Avenue at Thirty-fourth Street.

Delegates to a conference of eastern and seaboard branches of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People were told yesterday that the advocates of Federal civil rights legislation had been "jolted" but not stopped by the Senate filibuster of Southern Democrats and Northern Republicans.

STAR magnolia, now in flower, might well be called a four-season plant. It is the first magnolia to bloom, displaying fully opened blossoms now, while buds are only starting to break on saucer magnolia and other flowering trees.

The General Cable Corporation tomorrow will announce price reductions for building-wire products of 5 to 10 per cent, raising its total recent price cuts to a range of 17 to 25 per cent under post-war peaks. This illustrates the growing opinion among industrialists that "the time for token price reductions has passed."

SALT LAKE CITY, April 2 -- Western officials this week carefully studied provisions of the nation's new rent-control law, with tenants hopeful that state and community officials could retain the rental status quo in the face of demands for increases which building owners say are badly needed.

An effort to drive Communists out of office in the Barbers and Beauty Culturists Union of America, CIO, will highlight its third national convention, which is to open tomorrow, an announcement from union headquarters said yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, April 2 -- Pennsylvania Railroad carloadings last week totaled 87,177, as against 103,200 last year, a decrease of 15.5 per cent, and for this year to date totaled 1,288,885, to compare with 1,450,752 in the like 1948 period, a decrease of 11.2 per cent.

THESE are four lines from Oscar Hammerstein 2d's lyrics in "South Pacific." In the next few days Bali Ha'i will start calling you by way of Richard Rodgers' tune. Perhaps it has already started over your radio or television set or through your window from a passing whistler.

A DESIGN cover and smooth paper stock, with halftone reproductions, feature the new and revised spring issue of "Photo Notes," publication of the Photo League, 23 East Tenth Street. In its new format, which was designed by Warren Nardin with the dignity and taste befitting its mature standards, the 7x8 1/2-inch quarterly takes its place as an important and unique factor in contemporary photographic literature. Single copies are 35 cents, subscriptions $1.25 a year.

LONDON, April 2 -- Diplomats in London have been impressed by the calmness and firmness with which Iran has reacted to the recent pressure from her gigantic northern neighbor, the Soviet Union. One of them said yesterday, "Teheran doesn't frighten easily any more."

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- Louis Johnson took office as Secretary of Defense only last Monday, but on Tuesday he already had the Pentagon Building in a first-degree case of jitters. What Mr. Johnson threatened, with serious mien and a stern voice, was efficiency and unity.

In the next five years New York's public schools will need 10,500 new qualified teachers, but at the present rate of recruitment, attrition and matriculation in the four municipal colleges there will be a shortage of 2,400 by 1954.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- The National Labor Relations Board. making its second decision under the "jurisdictional disputes" provision of the Taft-Hartley Law, ruled today that the CIO Longshoremen's Union did not have jurisdiction over barge-loading employes of an Alaska lumber company.
WASHINGTON, April 2 -- Stephen J. Spingarn, until recently assistant general counsel of the Treasury Department, joined President Truman's White House staff about six weeks ago, it was learned today.

The arrival of the pleasant season used to ring down the curtain on an unusual winter series at the turn of the century -- that of manhole explosions. According to an editorial in THE TIMES of Dec. 23, 1900, the "customary diversion of our citizens" like a "continuous performance of vaudeville" usually began about the first of December and lasted until spring.

PHILADELPHIA, April 2 (AP) -- Tenants cannot use the Federal courts to sue landlords for rent refunds or treble damages unless the claim amounts to at least $3,000, the United States Third Circuit Court of Appeals ruled today.
WASHINGTON, April 2 (AP) -- The President's Council of Economic Advisers thinks the average American's level of living should rise about 27 per cent by 1958.

Winston Churchill has been visiting this country at intervals for a long time. He came first, so far as the records show, late in 1895, on his way to act as a correspondent in Cuba. No cheering crowds greeted him and there were no Communists to picket his meetings or his hotel.

Bacteriophage (or phage for short) was discovered in the early part of the century. An apparently healthy germ colony growing in a nutritive broth would suddenly die off and other cultures raised on a plate of solid jelly would appear moth-eaten and ragged. In 1915 it was demonstrated that this bacterial destruction was brought about by a chemical agent too small to be seen under a microscope.

Lowering of margin requirements by the Federal Reserve Board last week had a temporary stimulating effect on the stock market. Cross-currents of opinion from Washington on business conditions, however, still create uncertainty as cracks in the nation's economic structure continue to show.

With Ralph Beard, Alex Groza, Wallace Jones and Cliff Barker of Kentucky's great team contributing forty of their side's points, the East beat the West, 65 -- 64, in the fourth annual college all-star basketball game at Madison Square Garden last night.
A man and his wife were killed yesterday afternoon when a car she was driving along the Harlem River Speedway crashed through a retaining wall and into the Harlem River.

THOSE who are accustomed to think that twentieth-century European painting stops at the Rhine will profit by two new exhibitions: that of Oscar Kokoschka at the Galerie St. Etienne and that of an abstract group, headed by Kandinsky and Mondrian, at The Pinacotheca, which give an excellent idea of the two opposite extremes of feeling that northern European artists from 1910 on have been concerned to express.

ALBANY, April 2 -- The Socialist party, seeking a minimum of 50,000 votes for its 1950 gubernatorial candidate, opened a two-day annual state convention today, with Coleman Cheney, Professor of Economics at Skidmore College and state chairman of the party, as keynote speaker.

After man has left the countryside to shut himself up in vast piles of stone, after he has lost what Sir Thomas Browne called pudor rusticus, after he has come to depend on a complicated system of human exchange for his survival, he becomes forgetful of the over-riding mystery of creation.

NASSAU, Bahamas, April 2 -- The Spring championship of the International Star Class Racing Association was captured today by Patrick O'Gorman of the Larchmont Yacht Club of New York in the Wahini. O'Gorman thus completed a sweep of the two series here, having annexed the Johnny Walker Trophy yesterday.

IF James T. Farrell was not the outstanding American novelist of the Thirties, he was, at the very least, an outstanding example of what an American novelist in the Depression Period should be. PARIS, April 2 -- France's prospects at the beginning of the second year of the Marshall Plan are better than they have been for a decade, David Bruce, chief of the ECA mission to France, said today.
