MANILA, April 2 -- Persistently repeated reports of the presence of one or more alien submarines, presumably Russian, operating off the eastern Luzon coast and landing guns, ammunition and supplies for the dissident Filipino Hukbalahaps, are beginning to be taken seriously here.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., April 2 -- All records for the number of sailing dinghies in one regatta went overboard today in the first session of the national championships at the Larchmont Yacht Club.

THE Ile de France, luxury liner of the French Line, will return to the transatlantic run July 27, when she makes her post-war maiden voyage from Le Havre to New York. For months, French artists and workshops have been busy preparing appointments for the ship which are even more luxurious than those that made her one of the finest of her kind when she made her first crossing on June 22, 1927.

Trader Bedford, the black gelding belonging to the Trader Horn Stables of Arthur M. Nardin, New York City, took the open jumper championship of the season's third and final Brooklyn Cavalry horse show at Squadron C Armory, Brooklyn, last night.

OSLO (By Wireless) OUT of the dark, wet cold of the North Sea the storm-tossed little ship sailed into the sheltered water of Stavanger. Lights twinkled from the foreshore; the sheer, bleak hills were silhouetted behind them. As the ship, with engines almost muted, maneuvered her way in alongside, a solitary policeman patrolled the broad planks of the wooden quay which, with its overhead lighting, might have been a stage set for an Ibsen tragedy.

THE creator of a successful detective character is apt to entertain a lively and understanding sympathy for the Baron Frankenstein. Readers seize upon the one character and revel in him, to the neglect of the author's other work.

WASHINGTON, April 2 (AP) -- The national committee of the Young Democratic Clubs of America met today to elect a president to succeed Roy G. Baker of Sherman, Tex., who was resigning. The surprised winner: Roy G. Baker.

Relaxation of margin requirements by the Federal Reserve Board last week does not necessarily indicate that a reduction of bank reserve requirements may be anticipated in the near future, according to informed observers. The action on margins, coupled with that on consumer credit less than a month ago, it was pointed out, is not one which would logically precede a cut in bank reserves under present conditions.

THESE early poems and stories by Kahlil Gibran appear in a smooth translation by Anthony R. Ferris, with an eloquent foreword by Martin L. Wolf and some tall superlatives by the publisher. Gibran, whose book "The Prophet" has become a guest room classic, was born in the shadow of Mount Lebanon.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- The Senate will probably give its consent to the ratification of the North Atlantic treaty in much the same way as a grumpy father consents to the marriage of his beautiful daughter to the wily foreigner.

CHICAGO, April 2 (AP) -- Grains got off to a slow start but finished with a strong tone on the Board of Trade today. Heavy short-covering came into the market in the last thirty minutes. The advance of cotton in New York also had some influence in creating a buying atmosphere here.

DALLAS, April 2 -- Department store sales in major cities last week slumped in comparison to last year's figures, but volume actually was only slightly less than the preceding week. Business otherwise maintained a level course with few changes.
PANAMA -- Plane travel has superseded the 290-mile trip from the seacoast to Quito over the Guayaquil and Quito Railroad, and Ecuador's quaint capital is now easily accessible to travelers.

THE Boeing Stratocruiser, the newest, biggest and most luxurious commercial airliner in the world, went into regular service last week on Pan American Airways' San Francisco to Hawaii run. Pan American, other airlines that have ordered the big plane, and air travelers everywhere will follow the initial operations of the Stratocruiser with keen interest.

William Howard Melish, assistant minister of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Holy Trinity, Brooklyn, declared in his sermon yesterday morning that, whatever the outcome of the current controversy at the church, he and his father, the Rev. Dr. John Howard Melish, had sought "to follow in the footsteps of our Master."

Three thousand persons gathered at Pennsylvania Station yesterday afternoon for ceremonies that marked the departure of the United Jewish Appeal's "Caravan of Hope," a special train on a three-week tour to enlist widespread support of its $250,000,000 campaign in behalf of Jewish needs throughout the world.

LONDON, April 3 -- Within a few days Britain will know its tax rate for the new fiscal year, which has just opened. DETROIT, April 3 (AP) -- The Detroit Red Wings and the Montreal Canadiens will meet here Tuesday night in the seventh game of the National Hockey League's Stanley Cup semi-final for the richest jackpot the sport ever has known for a single game.

The exhibit, aptly called "Span of Flight," is much more than a showing of the products of this experienced supplier of planes, power plants, propellers and other accessories to the progress of aviation.

Margarita Zambrana, who made her debut as Santuzza in "Cavalleria Rusticana" with the New York City Opera Company Saturday night at the City Center, proved one of the most important finds of the organization to date. The 22-year-old Cuban dramatic soprano disclosed a voice of unusually beautiful quality, possessed pronounced histrionic ability, and, in addition to these assets, boasted a prepossessing stage presence.

AMSTERDAM, April 3 -- The prices of Netherlands bank notes have appreciated considerably in recent weeks in Switzerland and Belgium. In Switzerland 100 guilders is now worth 100 francs against 80 at the beginning of February and the official rate of 162.50 -- a discount of the guilder against the Swiss franc of 38.5 per cent, against 60 per cent a year ago.
CHICAGO, April 3 (AP) -- State sales-tax collections topped $1,500,000,000 last year -- nearly three times the pre-war level.

RIVERHEAD, L. I., April 3 -- Prospects of a profitable return to potato growers in Suffolk County as they begin planting the 1949 crop appears bright, thanks to the Department of Agriculture acreage-control program.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., April 3 -- The Yankees and the St. Louis Cardinals reached the parting of the ways on the citrus circuit today in circumstances that were highly satisfactory to the estimable Charles Dillon (Casey) Stengel.

Establishment of the merchant seamen wage levels that prevailed on American-flag vessels in October, 1945, as the minimum to be paid by steamship companies holding Government operating-differential subsidies, has been recommended to the Maritime Commission by G. O. Basham, chief trial examiner for the agency.

If Washington Irving could have emulated Rip Van Winkle, his most famous fictional character, and returned yesterday to familiar haunts after long absence, he would have found at least one recognizable spot in this city.

MOUNT ROSE, Nev., April 3 (AP) -- A 19-year-old Dartmouth University student and an 18-year-old waitress from Sun Valley, Idaho, today won the first annual men's and women's National Ski Association giant slalom championships.

It has been nearly ten years since the lights of London and other British cities shone at their brightest. War switched them off in September, 1939. Austerity kept them dimmed when the war was over. On Saturday night they blazed again. Horns tooted merrily on Piccadilly Circus, and the crowds turned out as though for a parade.

LUDOWICI, Ga., April 3 (UP) -- Judge Mel Price of the Atlantic Circuit Court, ruled today that a Negro could not be tried for murder at the current term because members of that race had been deliberately excluded from the jury lists.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- Dr. Agnes E. Wells of Saginaw, Mich., who was dean of women at the University of Indiana from 1919 to 1938, was elected chairman today of the National Woman's party, which has campaigned for twenty-six years for the Equal-Rights Amendment.

Net income of the United Corporation for the first quarter of 1949, according to the report to be released today, was $1,062,445, compared with $1,332,619 earned in the similar three months of last year.

PHOENIX, Ariz., April 3 -- The Giants wound up their stay in Phoenix on a triumphant note today as Sid Gordon, with the Polo Grounders trailing by a run in the last half of the tenth, unfurled a prodigious drive into the teeth of a desert gale.
LOS ANGELES, April 3 (AP) -- The United States polo team surged from behind today and posted a 10-to-9 victory over the Venado Tuerto four from Argentina.

CHICAGO, April 3 -- Grain markets held within comparatively narrow limits on the Board of Trade last week, with prices both higher and lower than the finish of the previous week. Aggregate trade, however, was not large and a high percentage of it was professional.

Defense Secretary Louis Johnson has made a good start on a difficult and complex problem. His order on Saturday abolishing nine boards that had outlived their usefulness and calling for a prompt examination and review of the various boards and committees in the defense establishment is a good augury.

Frederick Specht has no trouble living in two centuries simultaneously. Unlike most persons in their nineties, he is neither frozen in the past nor awed by the future. He says "ishkabibble" as gaily as though it were the latest idiom and wears flashy ties with the dignity reserved for Ascots.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- Senator J. Howard McGrath of Rhode Island, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, called upon his Republican colleagues in the Senate today to help make rent controls "unnecessary" by cooperating to enact housing legislation.

BALDWIN, L. I., April 3 -- More than 100 Navy officers and enlisted men have traded the roar of the seas for the roar of the presses and the allure of the tropics for a travel poster version at the unique printing plant of the Navy Recruiting Bureau here.

A prediction that the international unity generated by the Marshall Plan would force Russia to abandon its plans to "communize Western Europe" was made last night by Paul G. Hoffman, head of the Economic Cooperation Administration.

The infant state of Burma is having hard going. Its Government is facing not one civil war but two, and at times three, civil and military insurrections simultaneously. The treasury is bankrupt. The major export, rice, has not been restored because of commotion in the Irrawaddy Delta.
The Communist party and other interested groups have spent $103,802 thus far in the defense of the eleven party leaders on trial in Federal Court here.

The first turboprop engine to be publicly displayed in the United States was installed in the grand ballroom of the Commodore Hotel yesterday as the feature of a three-day "Span of Flight" exhibition to be opened tomorrow morning by the Curtiss-Wright Corporation.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., April 3 -- Sharon Cate, 17-year-old Port Washington High School student and daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert C. Cate, Port Washington, was found dead shortly after midnight this morning in the kitchen of the family home, 20 Longview Road, with all jets of the gas range turned on.
For two and a half hours yesterday afternoon the Queens Army Day parade moved past the official reviewing stand in front of the Jamaica Vocational High School, 162-02 Hillside Avenue.

The creation of the American Federal Reserve System was a direct sequel to the panic of 1907. The primary purpose behind the legislation was the prevention of such financial crises in the future through the effective mobilization of the nation's bank reserves.

The three-day-old brewery strike was widened yesterday to take in American Federation of Labor craft unions and for the first time in the history of the brewing industry here the threat was made to leave the giant vats untended.

A tract of land providing sites for fifty-two bungalows in the $9,000-$10,000 price class has been purchased by Harry Friedman, builder, on Hazel Road, in Clifton, N.J. Financing for the project has been arranged by Bankers Ltd., under the 20-year FHA-insured mortgage plan.

LONDON, April 3 -- After a trial of nine months, Britain's universal free medical service, whose operations are being studied by those interested in a similar service in the United States, has definitely come to stay.

PITTSBURGH, April 3 -- The national steel ingot rate last week was off 2 points to 100 per cent of rated capacity. This drop was the largest change in eleven weeks. It was caused in part by the taking off of some equipment that had been operating on conversion steel.

In James Reston's dispatch in THE TIMES of March 26 it is shown that the question of who initiates armed action under the Constitution was debated in the earliest years of the Republic, and was a critical point in dispute between Hamilton and Jefferson. But, I think, it might fairly have been stated that in no particular has the Hamiltonian doctrine of broad construction of the Constitution been more completely vindicated.

DAMASCUS, Syria, April 3 (AP) -- Brig. Gen. Husni Zayim, Military Governor of Syria since Wednesdey's bloodless coup, said tonight he would stamp out any "destructive Communistic propaganda and similar theories."

Declaring that the Displaced Persons Act "is difficult to administer and has bogged down," Edward Corsi, State Industrial Commissioner, urged yesterday that "we remove the restrictions that make the law difficult for displaced persons to come into the United States."

BERLIN, April 3 -- The trade unions were described today in a report released by the Manpower Division of the United States Military Government as the "only reliable factor" in the German economy working for the country's "democratic reconstruction."

A week of truly historic significance has dawned upon the world. Today, in ceremonies in Washington befitting the importance of the event, the ranking statesmen of twelve nations will affix their signatures and seals to the North Atlantic Security Pact, which makes the Atlantic community of 332,000,000 people a reality and pledges all its members to stand together in defense of their ways of life and of Western civilization.

The demise of the all-but-forgotten art of pandybatting was the plaint yesterday of Henry W. Howell, who also had a sad word to say about the fading of Latin and Greek from the curriculums of modern schools. Pandybatting was an old form of school discipline in which the palm of a pupil's hand was struck with a switch or cane.

LAKE SUCCESS, April 3 -- The belief is growing in United Nations circles here that Soviet attacks on the North Atlantic pact will compel United States representatives to give a fuller explanation of the reasons why Washington considers the new treaty compatible with the United Nations Charter.
WASHINGTON, April 3 -- The American Federation of Labor called upon its millions of members today to help needy European families through shipments of CARE packages.

ALLAIRE, N. J., April 3 -- State fire marshals praised fifty Boy Scouts and their leaders today for their courage and efficiency in beating down a forest fire that threatened their camp on the old Arthur Brisbane estate here late yesterday.

Maj. Gen. Canrobert Pereira de Castro, Minister of War for Brazil, Maj. Gen. Alvaro de Castro, Chief of Staff of the Brazilian Army, and a party of Brazilian Army officers attended solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday.

World Catholicism is facing a campaign by the "agents of anti-Christ" to destroy church unity by causing dissension among the hierarchy and splitting it from the lay membership, the Most Rev. Richard J. Cushing, Archbishop of Boston, told members of the Police Department's Holy Name Society yesterday.

SHANGHAI, April 3 -- The Chinese Communist party and its anti-Government friends declared tonight that the North Atlantic pact was aimed at provoking a new world war -- and that in such a war they would fight beside "China's ally, the Soviet Union."

Today is the birthday of a new community of nations. With the signing of the North Atlantic Pact a union of the free comes into being. The twelve subscribers of the treaty by no means include all the democracies, nor do all represent the same form and degree of democracy.

CHICAGO, April 3 -- Members of Chicago Typographical Union 16 voted almost 14-to-1 today to reject the contract proposal of the Chicago Newspaper Publishers Association to end the sixteen-month-old strike of composing room employes of Chicago's five daily newspapers.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 3 -- Fidelity Pictures, headed by Howard Welsch and Hugh Peters, has acquired screen rights to A. P. Herbert's 1920 novel, "House by the River," and will produce a film adaptation under the title "Floodtide" for Republic release.
Fear of fire and yellow fever that descended upon New York periodically 150 years ago was responsible for the founding of what is now the Bank of the Manhattan Company.

CLINTON, N. J., April 3 -- The wind-up of the amateur all-age, fourth stake on the Jockey Hollow Field Trial Club's five-event program, brought the laurels today to Shore's Frank Doone, handled by his owner, Sandy Shore of Lynchburg, Va.

A dwelling in the Gracie Square section changed hands for the first time in thirty-two years when 429 East Eighty-fourth Street was sold by the Anjack Operating Corporation, Jacob Green, president, to Dorothy Glock of White Plains, N. Y. The buyer intends to alter and occupy the house, according to J. W. Gerrish, the broker in the sale.

At least 6,000,000 Americans alive today but marked for death from cancer can be saved through early detection and prompt treatment of the disease, Charles F. Kettering, scientist and automotive industrialist, said last night at the opening rally of the American Cancer Society's 1949 fundraising campaign for $14,500,000.

DETROIT, April 3 (AP) -- The United Automobile Workers, CIO, announced today that a strike had been authorized to start Wednesday at the Midland Steel Products Company unless grievances were settled by that time. Midland supplies frames for the Chrysler Corporation and a walk-out would seriously affect Chrysler's operations.

The population of the seventeen counties surrounding New York increased 14 per cent between 1940 and 1947, while that of the city increased only 4.6 per cent, according to a bulletin made public yesterday by the Regional Plan Association.

Terming results of the first annual Carpet Fashion Opening "successful beyond our expectations," Merrill A. Watson, president of the Carpet Institute, Inc., reported over the week-end that 2,447 stores participating in the March 1-10 campaign had supported the campaign with 2,689,556 lines of newspaper advertising costing $1,394,778.

TEL AVIV, April 3 -- French labor leader Leon Jouhaux, visiting Israel as a guest of the General Federation of Jewish Labor, was pelted with potatoes and oranges by Communist hecklers tonight when he made a public address in the Tel Aviv Museum.

Joseph Pizzi, now a pleasant youth of 15, gave his third accordion recital at Town Hall last night, showing again that he is an extraordinarily gifted musician and that the accordion is a finer instrument than most people think.

The two-story residence for two families at 87-76 126th Street, Richmond Hill, Queens, has been sold by Hugo Casper to John M. Reich, who will occupy one of the floors, according to Home Title Guaranty Company, which insured title.
WASHINGTON, April 3 -- Senate debate on the $5,580,000,000 authorization for the European Recovery Program in the next fifteen months goes into its third calendar week tomorrow.
AKRON, Ohio, April 3 (AP) -- One of the worst traffic jams in the city's history occurred today when dedication ceremonies were held for the million-dollar Akron Baptist Temple.

The Paris Theatre at 4 West Fifty-eighth Street, in cooperation with the Schools Motion Picture Committee of the National Board of Review, will present a special film program for children under 10 on four consecutive Saturday mornings, beginning this week at 11 A. M.
BUDAPEST, Hungary, April 3 AP) -- The Hungarian Workers party (Communist) has adopted a new five-year economic plan that calls for an improved army "to defend the peace."

RHODES, April 3 -- A general armistice agreement between Israel and Transjordan was signed here tonight by their delegations after thirty-three days of negotiation. Thus all of Israel's immediate neighbors except Syria have signed armistice documents as a major step toward a permanent peace settlement in Palestine.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., April 3 (AP) -- Sheriff John Lynch of Dade County, Georgia, said today that seven Chattanooga Negroes were taken from him by a group of hooded Ku Klux Klansmen last night near Hooker, Ga.

With cartons of cigarettes tucked under their arms and 155 pounds of excess hand luggage, the seven-man Russian delegation to the recent Cultural and Scientific Conference for World Peace took a grim departure from this country last night.

Dr. Daniel Bukantz, former City College star who was a member of the United States team in the recent Olympics, captured top honors in the annual metropolitan electrical epee championship held at the Fencers Club yesterday. In the runner-up post was James Strauch of Salle Montague, another ex-C. C. N. Y. luminary.

Tapia Caballero, Chilean pianist, who two years ago was appointed cultural attache of the Chilean Embassy in Mexico City, made his first appearance here yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall. Senor Caballero showed himself at once a musician and an executant of a high order.

The 7,114-ton liner Borinquen of the Atlantic Gulf and West Indies Steamship Lines will arrive in New York today on her last trip for her present owners, it was announced yesterday. She is scheduled to be turned over to the A. H. Bull Steamship Company, which acquired her recently along with two other Agwilines vessels and that line's Dominican and Puerto Rican holdings.

The twenty Coast Guard cutters on ocean station patrol in the last year in the Pacific and Atlantic have contributed to the safety of thousands of overwater airplane flights, according to a Coast Guard report made public last week by John W. Snyder, Secretary of the Treasury.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 3 -- A missing link of the plant world -- the most primitive corn known to botanists -- has been discovered in a New Mexico cave by two young Harvard scientists.
DETROIT, April 3 -- Following are the comparative retail prices, f.o.b. Detroit, announced today by the Ford Motor Company on most of its passenger cars and trucks.

THE golden islands of the South Seas may not be the isles of the blest, but they are not a bad earthly substitute. That is the impression conveyed by Robert Gibbings in his "Over the Reefs and Far Away,"* a charming book of travels by a remarkable man. Mr. Gibbings is an Irishman, stocky and superbly bearded, a naturalist, an artist, an authority on typography and a writer.

Profits of the Mid-Continent Petroleum Corporation have increased in each of the last ten years, with 1948 being the best in its history, Jacob France, president, declared in the annual report issued today.

NEW DELHI, India, April 3 -- The current "radio war" between Afghanistan and Pakistan, according to reports reaching here, has brought new unrest to the traditionally unmanageable autonomous tribal territory on Pakistan's northwest frontier, an area inhabited by 5,000,000 Moslem tribesmen mostly of Afghan stock.

Prices of cotton in the domestic market fluctuated irregularly last week in a relatively narrow trading range. At the close of trading on Saturday, active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net gains of 7 to 50 points, compared with a decline of 1 point to an advance of 16 points in the previous week.

SHANNON, Eire, Monday, April 4 (AP) -- The world's largest commercial airliner landed here today in the teeth of a 65-mile-an-hour wind. It was the first transatlantic flight for the huge Boeing stratocruiser.

FORT WORTH, Tex., April 3 -- Burt Shotton's Dodgers were strictly uninhibited today, producing hits, runs, errors and good and bad pitching with equal abandon as they trounced their Fort Worth farm hands again.
SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, April 3 -- Government forces crushed a revolt early today and captured several ringleaders who had planned to overthrow the military regime.
LONDON, April 3 -- In London and elsewhere in Europe today high Government officials expressed their nations' thanks for United States aid on the first anniversary of the European Recovery Program.

Back to resume his duties as President of the United Nations General Assembly, Dr. Herbert V. Evatt of Australia declared yesterday that the North Atlantic pact, while helpful, was no substitute for the United Nations. The world organization, the Australian diplomat said, still is "the primary organ which will help in achieving peace for the world."

The progress of theatre television, motion pictures for television and high-speed photography will be featured in technical reports, forums and symposiums to be presented at the sixty-fifth semi-annual convention of the Society of Motion Picture Engineers to be held today through Friday at the Statler Hotel, it was announced by the society yesterday.

NANKING, April 3 (UP) -- Travelers from North China reported today that more than 3,000 university students suspected of anti-Communist thinking have been massed in a huge concentration camp near Peiping.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- The North Atlantic treaty, ending the military isolation of the United States as the United Nations and the European Recovery Program ended its political and economic isolation, will be signed at the State Department auditorium on Constitution Avenue here tomorrow afternoon.
Last Christmas tens of thousands of plant specimens were put to bed under a warm blanket of evergreen branches in the Thompson Memorial Rock Garden at the New York Botanical Garden in Bronx Park.

TEL AVIV, Israel, April 3 -- Israel's signing of the armistice tonight with Transjordan removes one of the greatest obstacles to peace and gives hope for a stabilized future, according to political experts here. The new line in the central area between Tel Aviv and Haifa puts a blunt edge on the threatening spearhead that had constituted the most volatile area in Palestine.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., April 3 -- Five members of the Philadelphia Phillies discovered today they had been robbed of a total of $891 by a sneak thief who invaded their rooms while they slept last night in the Bankhead Hotel.
DETROIT, April 3 -- The Ford Motor Company became today the fourth major automobile manufacturer to cut prices when it announced reductions of $12 to $120 effective Monday.
Black markets in rental housing will be more readily curbed under the new Federal rent control law, John J. Pendergast, local regional housing expediter, predicted yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- The National Planning Association set forth today eight points, cutting across the whole national economy, that it said must be considered in the formulation of a sound farm program.

At any day now, one of the rituals of the spring is about to begin. This is the semi-annual washing of windows, and it is tiresome. For several months past, torn sheets and frayed shirts have been piled in a dejected heap on the closet floor, and the grocery boy all too recently brought strange soaps in his basket.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission has certified that the required number of security holders of the Rutland Railroad Company had assented to the plan of reorganization approved by the ICC and the Federal District Court for Vermont.

Plans to celebrate the 100th anniversary of the birth of Jacob A. Riis, reporter, lecturer and pioneer in the movement to improve living conditions in New York slums, were announced yesterday by the Citizens Housing and Planning Council and the Jacob A. Riis Neighborhood Settlement.
ALBANY, April 3 -- Appointments of new directors to the Rockland, Harlem Valley and Rochester State Hospitals were announced today by Dr. Frederick MacCurdy, State Commissioner of Mental Hygiene.

Holding that the depressed stock market is due to many and complex causes, a study just released by the New York Society of Security Analysts sets forth seven general suggestions for promoting a remedy for the current "investor indifference."

A sharp increase in demand for spring apparel here last week helped to narrow the wide gap between this year's pre-Easter sales and last year's figures, according to reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices. It was pointed out that the later Easter this year allows a longer spring selling period, which will help bring combined March and April sales nearer to last year's level.

It is apparent from the Red Cross interim report on its 1949 fund drive during March that generous response to its appeal is still needed from those of its friends who have not yet sent in their contributions. The organization reports that during March New Yorkers gave 54 per cent of the city's $4,635,000 quota, this sum coming from 55 per cent of last year's givers.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- Government labor experts said today they believed they had found an almost perfect solution in the dispute over the Taft-Hartley's law closed-shop prohibition and union-shop restrictions.
BUENOS AIRES, April 3 -- Argentina will continue to ask high prices for exportable food surpluses. President Peron indicated today when he addressed the farmers in a nation-wide radio hook-up.
ORLANDO, Fla., April 3 (AP) -- Baseball paid tribute today to two of its greatest veterans whose ages total 165 years.

While Italian exports are scheduled to rise sharply by 1952 when Marshall Plan aid is scheduled to end, increasing imports into that country are likewise vital to aid scheduled expansion of plant capacity and rehabilitation of agriculture, according to Leo J. Wollemberg, associate editor of "Economic News from Italy."

MOSCOW, April 3 -- The Moscow City Council revealed today a vast plan for expanding and rehabilitating the city's housing and utilities in which 2,875,000,000 rubles will be expended for capital investment this year.

With forty openings in local museums and galleries this week the art season continues in full swing. Among the important events is a Degas exhibition at Wildenstein, for the benefit of the New York Infirmary, opening on Wednesday evening with a gala preview, admission $6; open to the public from Thursday, admission 60 cents.

FRANKFORT, Germany, April 3 -- Parades and formations of United States troops bigger than any since the end of the war will be held throughout Europe Wednesday in observance of Army Day. In some instances fighter planes will make their appearance over reviewing grounds.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 3 -- A fight over the issue of autonomous rights of international unions of the Congress of Industrial Organizations was foreseen today as the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union prepared to open its eighth biennial convention here tomorrow.

The Pierpont Morgan Library, 29 East Thirty-sixth Street, will open tomorrow an exhibition of material acquired since 1924, when it became a public institution. Entitled "The First Quarter Century of the Pierpont Morgan Library," the show will be in tribute to Miss Belle de Costa Greene, the library's director from its beginning until her retirement on Dec. 1.
Six boys from the same Yonkers neighborhood were believed yesterday to have drowned in Long Island Sound off Mamaroneck when their fourteen-foot rowboat powered by an outboard motor overturned.

Two riding academy horses were killed but three riders escaped serious injury when two horses collided head-on at 1:55 P. M. yesterday on the bridle path on Pelham Bridge Road, 500 feet west of the Pelham Split Rock Golf Clubhouse, the Bronx, the police of the Barkley Avenue precinct reported.

Mayor O'Dwyer's proposed budget for 1949-50 charges against the revenues of the municipal transit lines the annual $191,566 burden of carrying forty-four administrative jobs in the Board of Transportation that are now listed in the city's expense budget, it was learned yesterday.
PARIS, April 3 -- For the second time this year the dollar is being sold under 400 francs on the black market; the pound sterling below 1,200 francs and the Swiss franc, under 100.

MONTREAL, April 3 (AP) -- The International Civil Aviation Organization submitted to fifty-one member states today a set of uniform rules designed to ease the problems of crossing international boundaries by air.

Recent reductions in price of Belgian linen damasks and piece goods have brought quotations down about 40 per cent from the peak reached in 1947. This was reported over the week-end by two Belgian linen manufacturers, now on sales visits to the United States, who were interviewed in the offices of the Belgian Chamber of Commerce, 50 Rockefeller Plaza.
BADEN, Germany, March 25 -- Huge stretches of freshly cut timber, frequently along the roadside, scar the beauty of the famed Black Forest of Germany.
Your editorial of March 23, "Longshoremen and Overtime," is a welcome endorsement of the proposed legislation to solve the problem of overtime on overtime.

THAT "gigantic numbers game" -- the quotes are the personal property of the most august turf fathers -- was resumed at Jamaica the other day when the restoration of the Daily Double marked the formal opening of the racing season. No one got hurt and no racketeer tried to muscle in on this particular numbers game.

Because the health of adults depends in no small degree upon the medical attention they receive in childhood, it is particularly important that the children of the nation receive good medical care, Dr. John P. Hubbard, one of the country's leading pediatricians, declared yesterday.

Protestantism must achieve unity in this century or it will cease to exist, Henry R. Luce, editor in chief of Time, Life and Fortune magazines, declared yesterday at a luncheon that closed a two-day "conference on the ministry" in the church house of the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church at Seventy-third Street.

Public school buildings in the United States, on both the elementary and high school levels, are in "deplorable" condition today, with a vast number in need of immediate repair or replacement. Millions of children now attend classes in buildings that are obsolete, potential firetraps or totally inadequate to meet the needs of a modern educational program.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 3 -- Moshe Piyade, leading Yugoslav Communist theoretician, who has been guiding the Communist party in the struggle against the Communist Information Bureau, said today at a mass meeting in Belgrade that "no (Cominform) resolution can have any effect against a people's state."

A meeting this week of the board of directors of the United States Lines will probably result in the company's agreeing to build the projected 48,000-gross ton superliner, which would be the fastest merchant vessel afloat, it was indicated yesterday.

PARIS, April 3 -- The police were called on to guard the Town Hall in the Parisian suburb of Issy-les-Moulineaux today while the election of municipal officials, broken up this morning by a Communist riot, was completed. No Communists attended and no member of their group got in office.
Bishop G. H. M. Chang of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Fukien in Southeastern China yesterday issued an appeal for more evangelistic, educational and medical missionaries to that area.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- Republican leaders appear to have abandoned any plans for an interim national convention this year to draft a new statement of party principles for the 1950 Congressional election campaign.

" Prowling Russia's Forbidden Zone," by Werner Knop, will be published by Knopf on April 21. It is an eye-witness account of what the Russians are doing with Soviet Germany and how the Germans feel about it. The author, on assignment for The Saturday Evening Post, was smuggled over the Soviet German border and visited various sectors in disguise.

The sardines that are packed in France are considered by many connoisseurs to be the finest in the world. Beginning to compete with them is a similar product canned in French Morocco and offered here for just half the price of those from the mother country.
Abraham Kavy, head of the Kingsand Realty Corporation of Brooklyn, received a summons for violation of the Sabbath Law yesterday in the aftermath of a publicity stunt that backfired.

Mary Kennedy, young soprano from Paterson, N. J., who made her local debut three years ago, gave her second New York recital late yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. Her program, which was mostly in English, included such old favorites as "Denny Boy" and "The Last Rose of Summer."

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- The National Federation of Small Business, in a telegram to Attorney General Tom Clark today, bitterly assailed the statement made to the Senate judiciary subcommittee on Friday by Peter Campbell Brown, acting assistant to the Attorney General, to the effect that the Justice Department has "no serious objection" to legislation which would bar the Federal Trade Commission temporarily from ruling out the basing-point pricing system in certain cases.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., April 3 -- After the second and third regatta sessions, the final ones in the annual national dinghy championships held this time at the Larchmont Yacht Club, an almost entirely new group of champions over those of last year came ashore today.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- The United States and France, it was learned today, have made considerable progress toward reaching the basis for an agreement about how to run the proposed United States-British-French trizone in Germany.

NANKING, March 26 -- Striking at old provincial localism by uniting areas on the basis of geographical features and economic ties, the Chinese Communists have merged their old "border governments" into new regional groupings in the wake of territorial conquest by the Red Army.

Donald Harrington, associate minister of the Community Church, took to task yesterday the hierarchy of the Roman Catholic Church and charged it was following "a communistic pattern of pressure that might become a real threat to American democracy should its power be allowed to grow."

TOKYO, April 3 -- Rules permitting the return of foreign patent rights canceled or sequestered during the war were issued today. They also allow allied nationals to choose between accepting royalty payments accumulated here or extending the royalty agreement for a period equivalent to the time that was lost.

WASHINGTON, April 3 (AP) -- A Senate subcommittee said today that Attorney General Tom C. Clark and the Interior Department Loyalty Board had given "a clean bill on loyalty" to two reclamation officials, Michael W. Straus and Richard Boke.

A possibility that the three-day-old taxi strike might be brought to a swift, peaceful conclusion developed late last night with the disclosure that Mayor O'Dwyer had held an unscheduled, private conference with the national leaders of the striking union.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 3 -- The largest civic construction program in Europe, if not in the world, is now well under way in Belgrade, where a new city bridging the gap between the ancient Serbian capital and the once Austro-Hungarian-dominated town of Zemun is being built on the site of a former Nazi concentration camp.

BOSTON, April 3 (AP) -- Although lacking seven of last year's titleholders, the Amateur Athletic Union boasts that its national boxing championships, which open tomorrow at the Boston Garden, will reach a new high for both quality and quantity.
VIENNA, April 3 -- Chancellor Leopold Figl asserted today that Austria was faced with an "invasion of refugees from the East."

Today in every section of our city, the call once more goes out for each of us to give all he can in time, in energy and in money to fight cancer. This is the fourth annual campaign of the American Cancer Society and its New York City Cancer Committee.

Those mysterious radar "angels" -- weird spots or "blips" of light on the radar scopes, which have baffled electronics experts for years -- have been tracked down at last, the Bell Telephone Laboratories announced yesterday. The cause -- "bugs, and other high-flying insects."

A tabulation of 1948 corporate earnings figures just released by the National City Bank in its monthly letter shows that 3,262 corporations in all lines of business had a combined net income after taxes of about $11,700,000,000 last year, compared with $9,500,000,000 in 1947, an increase of 22 per cent.

ATHENS, April 3 -- Leros Island, one of the Dodecanese Archipelago off Asia Minor, has received its first batch of young rebel fighters since it was selected a few weeks ago as a "repatriation" center.

Although it couldn't be verified yesterday, there's a chance of "Magnolia Alley" arriving April 18 at the Mansfield. Lester Cutler, producer of the new George Batson play now trying out in Boston with Jessie Royce Landis and Jackie Cooper in the leading roles, admitted he was negotiating for a local house.

CHICAGO, April 3 -- Corn has been showing independent strength of late on the Board of Trade, reflecting continued small receipts from the country and refusal of farmers to sell freely even on the upturn that carried the May future to a new high since March 10.

J. Paul Sticht has been appointed director of personnel administration of Campbell Soup Company, Camden, N. J. Mr. Sticht was former international director of industrial relations of Trans World Airline.

Your editorial "Recruiting the New Teacher," which appeared in the March 3, 1949, edition of your valuable paper has recently come to my attention. I want to congratulate you upon the constructive approach to the teacher recruiting problem which you have suggested.
WASHINGTON, April 3 -- The votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls during the period, March 26 to April 1, are given in the appended tabulation:

LAKE SUCCESS, April 3 -- Following is the text of the Transjordanian-Israeli armistice agreement signed today at Rhodes and received by the Secretary General of the United Nations from Dr. Ralph J. Bunche, Acting Mediator for Palestine:

Winning his adjourned games from the twelfth and fourteenth rounds of the international chess masters tournament at Mar del Plata, Hector Rossetto of Buenos Aires yesterday established himself firmly in first place with a score of 12 1/2 -- 2 1/2, according to a report from Argentina.

RHODES, April 3 (AP) -- The armistice agreement provides for a reduction of forces on both sides of an armistice line to a depth of six miles, except in the Aqaba area, at the northern tip of the Red Sea. There, a high authoriy said, Israel will be allowed considerably more forces than the Arab Legion because of the presence of British forces at the Red Sea port.

CHICAGO, April 3 -- A better undertone in the vegetable oil markets combined with a fair export business and a relatively small run of hogs to market resulted in higher prices for lard futures on the Board of Trade last week. Aggregate trade was fair, with shorts taking the buying side on the dips.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., April 3 -- The annual dinner of the Metropolitan Basketball Writers' Association, signifying the official end of the court season, was held at the Bear Mountain Inn tonight with nearly 200 coaches, players, officials and newspaper men present.

New additions and improvements in sectional storage pieces that may be assembled into large wall areas or room dividers now make it possible to plan more versatile arrangements as well as budget-priced groupings.
CHICAGO, April 4 (AP) -- President Truman has called on Americans to "emphasize the spiritual values in family life."

LONDON, April 4 (AP) -- Tommy Yarosz, light heavyweight contender from Monaca, Pa., and Tony Janiro, hard-hitting Youngstown, Ohio, welterweight, scored impressive victories before a sell-out crowd of 10,600 in Harringay Arena tonight.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 4 -- Albania, which remains loyal to the principle of the Communist Information Bureau that Soviet nationalism is the sole nationalism permissible to a "freedom-loving People's Democracy," was more or less put into business as a Communist state by Yugoslav funds and technical direction.

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- Congress responded today in a mood of gravity and of hope, and in a spirit promising that a long inquiry of its own was yet to come, to the signing of the North Atlantic treaty.

The workings of an engine that will extend the range of the Navy's P2V patrol bomber to 14,000 miles were disclosed yesterday by the Curtiss-Wright Corporation. Known as the Turbo-Cyclone 18, the engine, an advanced version of the power plants of the B-29 and Constellation, is being produced in quantity for the type of bombing plane that now holds the world distance record.
ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., April 4 -- Jimmy De Brucque of Fairmont, W. Va., today came within a drink of water of a perfect game at the American Bowling Congress tournament.

WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP) -- The armed forces of Canada and the United States are exchanging officers to work on the mutual defense problems of the two nations, the National Miliatry Establishment said today.

The six-story seventy - two family apartment house at 1459 Wythe Place, northwest corner of 172d Street, the Bronx, has been sold by the Bar-Jim Realty Corporation, of which Mendel Racolin is president, to the Dalcin Realty Corporation, of which Leo M. Picker is vice president.

CHICAGO, April 4 -- Government support of the flaxseed and linseed oil markets has made the Commodity Credit Corporation owner of about 23,000,000 bushels of flaxseed and at least 180,000,000 pounds of linseed oil at a cost to taxpayers of an estimated $186,000,000. By the end of June the Government will own virtually all these commodities not in the hands of consumers.

The arrest last Saturday of a longshoreman on a charge of helping two stowaways to debark from the Italian liner Vulcania at Pier 84, North River, was announced yesterday by Edward J. Shaughnessy, acting district director of the Immigration and Naturalization Service.

WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP) -- Launching one of its biggest peacetime spending weeks in history, the House Appropriations Committee today approved a $701,122,079 money bill for the Agriculture Department.
MOSCOW, April 4 -- In Moscow the signing of the North Atlantic treaty was greeted with predictions that the signatory nations soon would be enthralled as military vassals of the United States.

The Marxist Society and the Progressive Students of Columbia, both of which are student groups at Columbia University, and the Karl Marx Society at Brooklyn College have been subjected to disciplinary action at their respective institutions, it was announced yesterday.

A television wage increase for union musicians has been agreed upon under a new one-year contract signed with the networks, James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians, AFL, announced yesterday. Under the new arrangement, musicians on local telecasts will receive 80 per cent of the comparable rate for standard radio broadcasts instead of the previous 66 and 2/3 per cent.

A Moscow-dominated American Politburo ran the Communist party of the United States by totalitarian control over the party's nominal ruling bodies, according to yesterday's evidence at the Communist trial.

An American edition of Vera Panova's "The Train," which won the Stalin Prize in 1946, will be issued by Knopf next Monday. The novel, described as non-political, deals with a group of individuals on a Russian hospital train in World War II.

The money market was easier yesterday and Federal funds dropped to 3/8 per cent compared with 3/4 to 7/8 per cent on Friday and 1 per cent on Wednesday. Member banks, after reporting excess reserves of $30,000,000 on Wednesday night, suffered a decline in this surplus to $15,000,000 on Thursday.

Governor Dewey plans to call shortly a special election in the Twentieth Congressional District to pick a successor to the late Sol Bloom, it was reported authoritatively yesterday. The election will probably be held around May 15.
GENEVA, April 4 -- Death rates have dropped sharply since World War II in nearly all countries for which figures are available, the United Nations World Health Organization reported today.

Hopes that a new international, anti-Communist congress of labor unions might be formed were expressed yesterday by Matthew Woll, vice president of the American Federation of Labor, in welcoming ten visiting French and Italian union leaders.

Buying was cautious yesterday at the Shoe Manufacturers' Fall Opening at the New Yorker Hotel. Prices on most lines held to previous levels, but reductions of 15 cents or more per pair were noted on men's work shoes.

A large and lifelike potrait of the late Wendell Willkie is the center of attraction in the exhibition of portraits by Russell A. Thompson at the Grand Central (Vanderbilt Avenue) Galleries. The portrait was not commissioned but was executed by the artist from several photographic studies in the possession of Mrs. Willkie, who acquired the portrait on its completion.

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- Harvey Stemmer and David Krakower, two New York men, convicted of offering bribes to stars of the New York Giants professional football team in the winter of 1946, today were assured a Supreme Court review of their case.
TOKYO, April 4 -- Premier Shigeru Yoshida today called on the Japanese people "to endure any hardship" to free the nation as rapidly as possible from the necessity of continued United States support.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., April 4 -- Study of the plasticity of metals -- the way their molecules react when subjected to stresses and strains -- may result in savings in building construction, a British scientist said here today.
A sharp criticism of buildings and facilities used for criminal cases in Queens was made yesterday by the county grand jury in a presentment handed to Judge Peter T. Farrell.

ATHENS, April 4 -- A communique issued by the Greek General Staff tonight said that "important" engagements involving heavy casualties on both sides were being fought in the southwest section of the mountainous Grammos area. Last summer the National Army's main effort was expended to clear well-dug-in positions of their rebel defenders.

Mayor O'Dwyer paid a brief visit yesterday to the Women's League for Israel's spring luncheon meeting at the Astor Hotel. The league is opening its fund-raising drive for $500,000. Arriving at 1 P. M. with Controller Lazarus Joseph, the Mayor spoke immediately to the 1,500 members.

Little hope rernaind last night that the Yonker youthz whose fishing boat overturned Saturday in Long Island Sound off Rye would be found alive. An all-day Toast Guard and police search ]yelded only the rowboat s anchor, found in fourteen feet of water near the Mamaroneck-Rye boun-! davy.

The signing of the North Atlantic Security Pact is the answer of the Atlantic Community to the Soviet bloc, formed by force of Russian arms and Communist fifth columns, and still expanding. The Western bloc, consisting of free and independent nations, is the product of a civilization which, with all its shortcomings and failures, has worked steadily for peace with honor, for liberty and human dignity culminating in a democratic way of life.
Mayor O'Dwyer's cut of $20,100,000 from the budget request of the Board of Education may seriously imperil the city's school system, it was charged yesterday.

DAMASCUS, Syria, April 4 -- Chief of State Husni Zayim has assumed personal responsibility for implementing the Government's powers to abolish the license of any newspaper or other periodical considered inimical to the national interest or security or menacing to Syria's foreign relations.

Today, on the occasion of the fiftieth anniversary of his entrance into the medical profession, one of America's great pediatricians, Dr. Sidney V. Haas, is being honored for his pioneer work in the field of pediatrics.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 4 (AP) -- There's enough mortgage money in the country -- it just isn't on tap in the right places.

The Rev. Dr. John Howard Melish, 74-year-old rector of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Holy Trinity, Brooklyn, said yesterday that he would not "recognize" as legally binding an official order terminating his forty-five-year pastorate, handed down earlier in the day by Bishop James Pernette De Wolfe of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Long Island.
Federal Judge William Bondy refused yesterday to give Alger Hiss permission to inspect the minutes of the special Federal grand jury that indicted him last Dec. 15 for perjury.
CHICAGO, April 4 (AP) -- A Federal judge today blocked the Nu-Enamel Company's proposed $600,000 sale of an oil subsidiary to two Houston, Tex., men.

No human being in our society is free from the ever-lurking threat of cancer. No one can predict where it will strike. But all of us have an opportunity to contribute to the limit of our means to the never-ending, forward-looking and effective campaign to combat it.
BOSTON, April 4 -- The American Gem Society unveiled today the pilot model of a "practical" micro-camera for "fingerprinting" gem stones.

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- The National Association of Manufacturers demanded today that Congress make an "immediate and thorough investigation of the Federal Trade Commission based on the findings of the Hoover Commission Task Force."

WASHINGTON, April 4--Leonard E. Johnston, manager of the Atomic Power Laboratory in Schenectady, N. Y., today was named manager of the Atomic Energy Commission's new Nuclear Reactor Station to be built near Arco, Idaho.

Bees not only have a color sense but they are sensitive to ultraviolet, normally invisible to human beings, Dr. Karl von Frisch, Austrian scientist, declared last night. He told 600 persons at a lecture in the Museum of Natural History that it was the color red, vivid to man's eye, that left the bees cold.

LAKE SUCCESS, April 4 -- During the spring session of the United Nations General Assembly, which opens at Flushing Meadow tomorrow afternoon, there will be a real shortage of color personalities and top-drawer statesmen and virtually none of the spectacular fanfare that Paris gave to the last meeting.

The Congressional bill setting a moratorium on further anti-trust cases based solely on legality of basing point price systems will be passed this session, it was declared yesterday by its author, Senator Francis J. Myers, Democrat, of Pennsylvania.

Furniture designs that are light in appearance and adaptable to different roles are being introduced this week at Pascoe-New York, 10 West Fifty-fifth Street. New upholstered furniture, a few storage units and variations on the firm's basic L-shaped chair are already on display.

Deposits of the National City Bank of New York in the first quarter of this year declined to $4,444,516,006 on March 31 from $4,643,112,364 at the close of last year, according to the bank's statement of condition to be published today. Deposits at the end of March, 1948, were $4,507,009,250.

America has more than fulfilled its promise as a land of opportunity to Zoya Mikulovsky, 26-year-old Polish-born emigre and victim of Nazi aggression. Miss Mikulovsky, a senior at Barnard College, has won the George Welwood Murray Fellowship, one of Barnard's highest academic honors, for graduate study in the humanities.

HOWARD NEMEROV, a poet and a teacher of English at Bennington College, has written a novel which his publishers call "impolite," "satanic" and "shocking." Their restraint is commendable, for "The Melodramatists"* is certain to remind its readers of a great many stronger adjectives, among them demented, erudite, savage, dull and clever.
The number of taxicabs on New York's streets more than doubled yesterday, the fourth day of the strike called by the Taxi Workers Organizing Committee of 'John L. Lewis' United Mine Workers.

Almost daily THE NEW YORK TIMES carries stories of the armistice terms Israel is signing with Arab countries with the implication that a settlement of the Palestine problem is at hand. Having just returned from three months in the Near East, I can assure your readers that peace has not returned to that unhappy area, and will not return until Israel redeems her promises of compensation, which are twofold:

Wage increases for the city's 46,000 transit workers will be sought in the near future, Councilman Michael J. Quill, international president of the Transport Workers Union, CIO, announced yesterday at a City Council meeting.

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- Senator Scott W. Lucas of Illinois, the majority leader, warned members today that an extended or special session of Congress would be ordered in event President Truman's legislative program was not disposed of by July 31.
Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt was the recipient last evening of an "award in human relations" presented by the Bureau of Intercultural Education, at a dinner at the Pierre Hotel attended by 350 persons.

In what was said to be the largest price cut on floor coverings since the war, Alexander Smith Sons Carpet Company announced to retailers yesterday that temporary reductions as high as 20 per cent will be made, effective immediately, on "certain lines and patterns in popular-price grades."

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- In the first direct vote of the Eighty-first Congress on a civil rights issue, the House today wrote an amendment barring discrimination or segregation on the basis of race, color or creed into a bill establishing a Women's Reserve in the Coast Guard.

One of the most inspiring of all international efforts--the U. N.'s International Children's Emergency Fund--will receive an award tonight. The Foreign Press Association will honor at its annual dinner the Fund's executive director, Maurice Pate, for "outstanding contribution in the United States to international good-will."

With 400 persons waiting outside, the Country Antiques Show opened its doors yesterday afternoon at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street, where 150 dealers' booths colorfully simulated an oldtime country show.

ALBANY, April 4 -- Veterans and their families now constitute 60 per cent of the population of the state, Leo V. Lanning, director of the Division of Veterans Affairs, stated today in his annual report. The number of veterans residing within the state increased by 35,000 during 1948, he said.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., April 4 -- Railroads must be relieved of the obligation to furnish local service for which they are no longer "the most efficient medium," Laurence F. Whittemore, president of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad, said here tonight, declaring "public apathy" is bankrupting the nation's transportation system.

Tonight's events: Stell Anderson, piano, Carnegie Hall, 8:30 o'clock; Olga Lepkova, mezzosoprano, Town Hall, 8:30; Lewis Moore, piano, Times Hall, 8:30; Joan Derbyshire, soprano, Mannes School, 8:30; Alice M. Ditson Chamber Concert, student composers, McMillin Theatre, Columbia University, 8:30.

The city's radio station WNYC is seeking a permanent authorization from the Federal Communications Commission to broadcast daily until 10 P.M., Seymour N. Siegel, director of the station, announced yesterday.

DETROIT, Tuesday, April 5 -- Returns early today showed the political force created within the Democratic party by Gov. G. Mennen Williams and the Political Action Committee of the Congress of Industrial Organizations trailing in its bid for control of the State Administrative Board.
Gen. Mark W. Clark declared yesterday that he knew nothing of reports that he might be transferred from his command of the United States Sixth Army in San Francisco to a post in Berlin or Moscow.

A small segment of the New York brewing industry went back to work yesterday after the companies involved agreed to place two drivers on trucks, institute a thirty-five-hour week and grant any other conditions that strikers evenually win from the big breweries.
PARIS, April 4 -- Charles de Gaulle advised France today to "reserve her judgment" of the North Atlantic pact until she learned what the United States intended to do to give it military reality.

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- President Truman extended today the impact of the North Atlantic pact by declaring it "a shield aganist aggression" everywhere in the world that, had it existed in 1914 and 1939, would have prevented both World Wars.

WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP) -- Following are the texts of the addresses made at the signing of the Atlantic treaty. President Truman spoke last; the speeches of the Foreign Ministers are presented in the order of their delivery.

A committee of mothers presented to Deputy Mayor John J. Bennett yesterday at City Hall a petition protesting what they termed plans to reduce in size a small park bordering the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive at Forty-ninth Street.

NANKING, April 4 -- The Ministry of Defense acknowledged today that elements of Gen. Lin Piao's Fortieth Army had captured Sinyang, important South Honan rail center, 100 miles above Hankow. According to the Peiping radio, the Communists "annihilated" a Nationalist regiment in taking the walled city, but there was no indication that the Government troops had put up a strong resistance.

There were no uniforms, except those of the United States Marine Band, when the North Atlantic Pact was signed yesterday in the Departmental Auditorium in Washington. No medals glittered. There was no outward glitter at any point in the program. This drama was majestic only in what it signified.

SHANKS VILLAGE, N. Y., April 4 -- Letters were mailed from here today to the home Representatives and Senators of the 1,200 student veteran families here in protest against the Federal Housing Authority order canceling on June 30 the leases of local commercial facilities.
WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP) -- The Supreme Court rejected today a merchant seaman's $50,000 claim for lifetime maintenance and medical care because he was totally disabled in a wartime accident.

A letter of Dec. 18, 1860, from Abraham Lincoln to Henry J. Raymond, founder and editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, in which the President-elect sarcastically repudiated opinions imputed to him, was sold at auction yesterday for $1,700.

One hundred invited guests attended last night a reception and exhibition in honor of Miss Belle da Costa Greene, director of the Pierpont Morgan Library for twenty-five years until her retirement last November. The event was held in the library, 29 East Thirty-sixth Street.

Obviously the only thing for the soft drink manufacturer to do under current operating conditions is to increase prices, Walter S. Mack Jr., president of Pepsi-Cola Company, declared yesterday at the opening of the three-day annual convention of the New York State Bottlers of Carbonated Beverages, Inc., in the New Yorker Hotel.
CHICAGO, April 4 (AP) -- Twenty-four eye doctors were dismissed today as defendants in the Federal Government's anti-trust suit against six large eye-glass manufacturers.

Although in general I agree with the expressions of opinion in your valuable editorial columns, I must take serious issue with you on your leading editorial in THE TIMES of March 31, in which you give the present New York legislative session credit for a commendable record of accomplishment.

NOVI SAD, Yugoslavia, April 4 (UP) -- Five Yugoslavs accused of having spied for Hungary and of having distributed anti-Tito propaganda pleaded guilty today in the first trial of alleged agents of the Communist Information Bureau held in Yugoslavia.
WASHINGTON, April 4 -- The Government counted up a budget surplus of $1,048,000,000 at the close of the three-quarter mark of the current fiscal year March 31, the Treasury reported today.

The stock market fluctuated irregularly over a narrow range yesterday. Selected issues including some of the oil shares showed moderate strength and advanced a point or more. Largely because of the activity in the lower-price issues, sales expanded to 920,000 shares, compared with 850,000 last Friday.

Characterizing the North Atlantic pact as "the best present insurance for the maintenance of peace" and "the most promising assurance of survival" in the event of war, a group of more than 100 prominent persons yesterday urged the United States Senate to ratify the newly signed covenant.

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- The North Atlantic pact is regarded by highly qualified observers here as representing the complete repudiation by the Truman Administration of any last remnants of isolationism in its foreign policy, no matter how many people in this country may have desired to adhere to the United States' traditional policy against European alliances.

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- The Appalachian Electric Power Company, Roanoke, Va., asked the Securities and Exchange Commission today for authorization to establish an $18,000,000 line of credit with four banks.

GENEVA, April 4 -- The Governments of the West must soon decide how to handle the continuing flow of refugees from the Communist areas of the world, a United States spokesman told the International Refugee Organization today.

With gross revenues last year at a level 27.2 per cent above the previous peak, Eastern Air Lines realized a net profit of $2,346,871, equal to 98 cents a capital share, in 1948, Capt. E. V. Rickenbacker, president and general manager, reported yesterday. The company's profit in 1947 was $1,259,196, or 53 cents a share.
WASHINGTON, April 4 -- The Southern Coal Producers' Association today began preparing for what a member said would be the "toughest wage negotiations since 1933."
WASHINGTON, April 4 --President Truman declared tonight that the North Atlantic treaty countries had passed a milestone in history today.

CHICAGO, April 4 -- If there is any single outstanding issue confronting colleges today, it is the lack of great and inspiring teachers, Dr. Ordway Tead, chairman of the Board of Higher Education of New York City, asserted today at the opening of the National Conference on Higher Education, sponsored by the Department of Higher Education of the National Education Association.
RANGOON, Burma, April 4 (Reuters) -- Troops today mopped up scattered pockets of insurgents in Mandalay, recaptured from the Karens and Communists last night.
WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP) -- A bill to prohibit general price-fixing, permitted under a 1937 amendment to the Sherman Anti-Trust Act, was introduced by Rep. O'Toole, Democrat of New York.

MEXICO, D. F., April 3 -- When the President in his message on the State of the Union proposed that the United States Government in association with private finance make a systematic effort to produce a stable economy in "underdeveloped areas" of the earth, the vision of a prosperous Mexico at once entered many minds.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 4 (UP) -- The Belgrade radio said tonight that the purge of Bulgarian Communists had been intensified and that a total of 300, including Deputy Premier Kostov, had been arrested.

The current strike of taxicab drivers may well be considered a test of the supineness of the general public and public officials. In so far as the owner-drivers are concerned, it is unquestionably their own choice as to whether or not they work. Most of them want to work, but are being intimidated by union "goons."

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- American aid to Europe in the coming year will lean increasingly in the direction of industrial machinery and equipment for long-range development, the Economic Cooperation Administration said today.

From Buenos Aires comes word that the two great Argentine newspapers, the Nacion and the Prensa, are now forced to operate on a week-to-week basis as a result of the "nationalization" of newsprint. Within the last few days officials of the Ministry of Industry and Commerce have visited the plants of both publications and taken control of some 13,000 tons of paper.
Flounder fishing, like other forms of piscatorial art, requires that the practitioner be at the right place, at the right time, with the right bait, and that fish are present.

The annual report of the New York City Omnibus Corporation, Which is being mailed to stockholders today, show that gross revenues of the company and its subsidiaries increased to $16,760,349 last year but the company sustained a net loss of $1,517,901. This is the first year in its history that the company showed a loss and omitted all dividends.

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- Arthur Bliss Lane, former United States Ambassador to Poland, said tonight that he had requested his lecture agent to cancel his engagement to speak at the Community Church in New York next Sunday.

DETROIT, April 4 -- A uniform industrial hygiene code, designed to standardize specifications and requirements throughout the forty-eight states, was proposed today by the American Conference of Governmental Hygienists at its annual convention.

TEHERAN, Iran, April 4 -- A military informant said today that a Russian regiment, supported by tanks and armored cars, had made a new foray into Azerbaijan Province and attacked an Iranian Army post.

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- Individuals saved $4,900,000,000 in liquid form during 1948, $3,400,000,000 less than in 1947 and approximately the same amount as in 1940, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today.

Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. accepted yesterday the chairmanship of a committee that is to build a children's village on the outskirts of Jerusalem. The project will cost $1,000,000, and the twenty homes planned will provide care for about 1,000 war orphans and displaced children now in Europe.

PARIS, April 4 -- The presiding judge of a Paris court ruled today that Victor A. Kravchenko had been libeled by the Communist weekly Lettres Francaises when it published a series of articles to the effect that the former Soviet official had never written "I Chose Freedom" and that the book was principally composed of lies.

Claudette Sorel is a pianist of great potentialities. Giving her third recital at Town Hall last night -- her first was in 1943 at the age of 11 -- she played with a spirit and precision beyond her years.

NEWPORT, R. I., April 4 -- THE day of the palatial villa, for which this social summer colony has been noted for half a century, is, definitely on the wane. Leaders in the Social Register are still numerous here, but, largely because of such matters as the servant problem, high taxes and the desire for comfort rather than ostentation, they show an increasing preference for less pretentious dwellings than were formerly the vogue.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 4 -- Harry Bridges, president of the CIO International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, has no intention of changing his policies to conform with those of the national CIO, he said here today.
TROY, N. Y., April 4 (AP) -- A 19-year-old freshman was held on two charges today in the fatal shooting of a classmate at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute.
DALLAS, Tex., April 4 -- The Negro fans of this Texas city had a great day this afternoon when Jackie Robinson and Roy Campanella put on a show for them they'll never forget.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores increased 7 per cent last week over the corresponding period last year, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The decline for the four weeks ended last Saturday was 10 per cent.
WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP) -- Jesse M. Donaldson, Postmaster General, defended the postal service today against accusations of being unbusiness-like.

LONDON, Tuesday, April 5 -- Russia has protested to the United States, Britain and France that recent changes in the frontiers of Western Germany break agreements with the Soviet Union, Tass said today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 4 -- Columbia has concluded a deal with Lionel Houser, scenarist, by which Houser will produce "The Tougher They Come," his own photoplay, with William Holden in the leading role. The scenario, which Houser wrote independently, deals with a wartime merchant marine captain who sticks to his profession after the war.
LEXINGTON, Ky., April 4 (AP) -- A small-scale Times Square tribute was paid Kentucky's National Collegiate basketball kingpins today.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 4 (AP)--Twelve persons were arrested today at the American Zinc Oxide Company plant, accused of violating a court ban against picketing.

LONDON, April 4 -- A Pan American World Airways seventy-one-ton stratocruiser touched down gently in almost a gale at London Airport this afternoon, to complete her maiden trans-Atlantic flight from Idlewild.

CHICAGO, April 4 -- Grain markets showed an easy undertone on the Board of Trade today, although May wheat and soy beans developed fair strength at one time. However, the close was under the best prices with wheat off 1/8 to 3/8 cent, corn 3/8 to 3/4 cent; oats, 1/8 to 1/2 cent.

Peter Godfrey has been assigned to direct "Barricade" at Warner Brothers. Robert Douglas has joined the cast of the picture, which will be produced by Saul Elkins and will feature Dane Clark, Virginia Mayo and Raymond Massey. . . . Warners' forthcoming Danny Kaye vehicle has been re-titled "Always Leave Them Laughing."

Good quality camembert cheese is again coming to this country from Normandy, where it originated at the end of the eighteenth century. Two shipments have arrived this year. Two more are scheduled. They are the first since before the war except for one last summer, the quality of which was generally considered unsatisfactory.

Lauritz Melchior, who as a Wagnerian Siegfried has slain more Metropolitan Opera dragons than any dragon gamekeeper could count, returned to the city yesterday to report on his tussles with the unmusical monsters of Africa. As a big-game hunter, it was deduced, the operatic tenor is no less sure-fire than when wielding his sword on Fortieth Street.

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- The Supreme Court in a 5-to-4 opinion, ruled unconstitutional today a section of the New York State farm and marketing law used to keep an out-of-state milk company from opening a new receiving plant at Greenwich, N. Y.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., April 4 -- Bob Porterfield stood pre-eminent tonight among the Yankee pitchers who have gone the route. For today the young Virginian who was hustled up from Newark last August in the Bombers' frustrated bid for the American League pennant, blanked the Cincinnati Reds, 2 to 0, with a one-hit performance that topped anything any Yankee hurler has accomplished since the training campaign got under way on March 1.

LAKE SUCCESS, April 4 -- The United Nations General Assembly will reconvene at Flushing Meadow at 3 P. M. tomorrow to dispose of items left over from its Paris session and renew the debate between the Soviet bloc and the Western powers.
TEL AVIV, Israel, April 4 (AP) -- The Israeli Government came under fire from both left and right tonight for its armistice with Transjordan but won a vote of confidence in Parliament.

In 1948, the New York City Cancer Committee put to work fighting cancer $1,018,098 contributed by you. Forty per cent ($452,390) went to the American Cancer Society for its national program of basic research and education, which included research grants totaling $950,984 for Columbia University, Cornell University, Memorial Hospital, Montefiore Hospital, New York University, St. Vincent's Hospital and other New York institutions.

The survey released last week by the Department of Agriculture on men's preferences in clothing has been the subject of misinterpretation by the wool manufacturing industry, it was charged yesterday by the National Federation of Textiles.
DURHAM, N. C., April 4 (AP) -- Duke and Yale baseball teams battled to an 8-8 deadlock today in a game halted by darkness after eight innings.
Bergen County, N. J., announced yesterday that it would receive bids April 13 on $3,980,000 of improvement bonds dated April 1, 1949, and due from 1949 to 1970.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., April 4 -- The Rev. Brother Harold A. Filehne, head of the Department of Religion at Iona College here, has been named assistant general of the Christian Brothers Congregation, it was announced today by the Rev. Brother Arthur A. Loftus, president of the college.

BOSTON, April 4 (AP) -- Eugene Linscott, 17-years-old competitor from Grand Rapids, Mich., stamped himself as the National A. A. U. boxing tournament's outstanding performer to date by defeating two capable welterweights tonight at the Boston Garden.

If you put an ear to the ground these days, that steady rumble is not the ground swell for '52, it's the pound of bats on the plate from the Grapefruit League. To the straining ear of the true fan, the first faint tattoo was audible over a month ago. He has built up steam ever since. With season's opening near at hand, he's close to the bursting point.
WASHINGTON, April 4 -- Without a dissenting voice the Supreme Court today upheld state power to prevent union picketing of an ice plant to stop the sale of ice to non-union peddlers.

With Easter less than two weeks off, Gimbels took those women into consideration who wear the so-called half sizes, namely 14 1/2 to 22 1/2, and offered them a selection of costumes at a showing held in the store yesterday afternoon. What is more, costumes were moderately priced, ranging from $7.95 to $35.
A spectacular four-alarm fire yesterday morning in a seven-story tenement at 142 West 131st Street injured ten firemen and made 125 persons homeless.

Professor Berdan, who is dead at 75, had the greatest gift of great teachers, enthusiasm which increased as he divided it with others. As a freshman at Yale in 1892 he came under the influence of a young man who was serving his first year as a full-time instructor in the English Department.

Irving Honigsberg has purchased the fourteen-family apartment house at 9 Montague Terrace, Brooklyn, from the estate of Robert Reid, which has owned the property since 1919. Chauncey Real Estate Company was the broker.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 4 -- The United Nations Conciliation Commission announced here tonight that it was reporting to Secretary General Trygve Lie its plans to "continue and expand" exchanges of views with all Governments concerned in the Palestine question at some neutral place "in the near future." The time and place have not been settled.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, April 4 -- The inaugural assembly of the Permanent Council for the Coordination of International Congresses of Medical Sciences was held here today.

The United States Maritime Commission plans to set aside a high quality fleet of 258 vessels in perfect repair and "ready to go" on twenty-four hours' notice in case of national emergency, it became known yesterday.

CHICAGO, April 4 -- Both the schools and families of the country are declared to be shirking responsibility by failing, in large part, to help the youth of America to choose jobs that are meaningful and satisfactory.
