Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday closed irregular, with old-crop months 9 to 22 points higher, and new-crop months 4 to 6 points net lower than on Saturday.
TRENTON, April 4 -- A bipartisan maneuver in the Assembly brought passage tonight of a bill to make milk price control mandatory in New Jersey.
National advertisers' investment in newspaper space climbed to a new all-time high of $389,261,000 last year, it was announced yesterday by the Bureau of Advertising, A. N. P. A.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, April 4 (AP) -- Earl Cochell of San Francisco, winner of the Bermuda championship last week, opened his bid in the Coral Beach tennis tournament today with an easy victory over Charles Ward of Bermuda. Cochell, not removing his sweater, won, 6 -- 0, 6 -- 0.

There may be those who question the wisdom of Britain's use of valuable airlift space to carry cigars to besieged Berlin, but if there are it is safe to assume that cigars smokers are not among them. Foreign Secretary Bevin disclosed not long away that Britain had flown in to Berlin about five million cigars in thirty days.

WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP) -- By a one-vote margin, the Senate Expenditures Committee refused today to exempt the Corps of Army Engineers from a bill to give President Truman broad powers to reorganize the Government.
The lay-off of 1,500 driver-salesmen by six major baking companies on Feb. 28 was termed a "lockout" and therefore an unfair labor practice yesterday by the National Labor Relations Board.

Museums are not store houses but reservoirs of ideas for furniture and fabric designers today, Lili Blumenau, keeper of textiles of the Cooper Union Museum, and Michele Murphy, curator of industrial arts of the Brooklyn Museum, emphasized in talks last night.
Vern Mitchell of Detroit won a split decision over Caesar Brion, Argentine heavyweight, in the main bout of eight rounds at the St. Nicholas Arena last night. Mitchell weighed 188 3/4, Brion 193 1/4.

The Tide Water Associated Oil Company reported yesterday for 1948 a consolidated net income of $39,387,374 after charges, taxes and reserves, equal after preferred dividend requirements to $6.04 each on the 6,408,132 common shares outstanding. For 1947 the company reported a net income of $30,175,955, or $4.57 a common share.
BOWIE, Md., April 4 (AP) -- Apprentice Jockey Benjamin Civitello rode six winners in eight races at the Bowie race track today. He scored with four of his mounts here last Tuesday.

RHINEBECK, N. Y., April 4 -- A weatherbeaten wooden garage, an abandoned rooming house, a Catholic chapel and a Methodist parsonage serve as the public schools for the elementary and high school students in this historic upstate community.

A new issue of $10,000,000 of 4 per cent fifteen-year debentures of the General Telephone Corporation will be offered to investors today by an underwriting syndicate headed by Paine, Webber, Jackson Curtis, Stone Webster Securities Corporation and Mitchum, Tully Co. The debentures are priced at 102.25.
WASHINGTON, April 4--The North Atlantic treaty was signed today by twelve nations that have been divided by history and geography for more than 150 years.

The New York Life Insurance Company announced yesterday that it would start tomorrow to build a nineteen-story and penthouse apartment building on the site of the old Third Avenue carbarn, the block from Sixty-fifth to Sixty-sixth Streets and Third to Second Avenues.

The New York City Cancer Committee opened its part of the 1949 American Cancer Society fund drive yesterday with its 504 collection booths staffed by volunteers. In terminals and stores, restaurants and post offices, the women shook coin boxes, reminding passers by to "Guard those who you love -- Give to conquer cancer."

ALBANY, April 4 -- The State University came into physical existence today as the Board of University Trustees formally took over from the Board of Regents administrative control of thirty-two teacher colleges and other state institutes with enrollment exceeding 30,000 students.

Wool futures again were in supply yesterday. Wool top contracts dropped 1.5 to 3 cents a pound on transactions of 300,000 pounds. Grease wool futures declined 1.7 to 2.1 cents a pound, with the exception of the July contract, which was unchanged. Sales were 168,000 pounds.

DALLAS, Tex., April 4 -- A gratefully humble Dorothy Parker and her colleague, Ross Evans, radio and stage writer, received a warm reception from a premiere audience that saw their new play, "The Coast of Illyria," tonight at Dallas Theatre '49, under Margo Jones' direction.

LONDON, April 4 -- Gold shares took a loss in the stock market here today when speculators took profits on a large scale. In early dealings prices were marked down on less favorable Cape advices but during the afternoon selling pressure became heavy and shares finished at lowest of the day with declines of 1-16 to 5-32.

MINNEAPOLIS, April 4 (AP) -- Although George Mikan tallied 42 points, the Minneapolis Lakers made hard work of scoring an 88-84 victory over Washington in the first game of the championship play-offs for the Basketball Association of America title tonight.

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- C. H. Buford of the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific Railroad was named today chairman of a "task force" to study problems of railroad transport for the National Security Resources Board.

CLINTON, N. J., April 4 -- The big, valuable J. Overton Paine Trophy, in competition since 1937, was retired today when Dr. H. E. Longsdorf's 5-year-old liver and white pointer dog Henderson Tom won the imperial open all-age stake, closing feature of the five-day spring meeting of the Jockey Hollow Field Trial Club.

Mike Jacobs, Twentieth Century Sporting Club promoter, and Brig. Gen. John Reed Kilpatrick, president of the Madison Square Garden Corporation, had a "routine business" meeting yesterday dealing with boxing matches at the Eighth Avenue arena.

Several decades in the life of Charles Dickens will be chronicled in "The Ivy Green," the new play by Mervyn Nelson, which makes its local debut tonight at 8 o'clock in the Lyceum Theatre. Hall Shelton, who was last represented on the New York stage by "Louisiana Purchase," is the sponsor.

Desmond FitzGerald, chairman of the Committee of Five Million, spent fifteen minutes yesterday afternoon with the grand jury that is investigating tapping of the telephone wires of Mayor O'Dwyer and other city officials.

PHILADELPHIA, April 4 -- Federal Judge George A. Welsh today authorized the withholding of $10,646 of the wages due twenty-five members of the crew of the cargo ship Flying Arrow that docked here last night.
DETROIT, April 4 -- The Nash-Kelvinator Corporation announced tonight price cuts ranging from $20 to $120 on its "600 Airflyte" and "Ambassador Airflyte" motor cars, effective at midnight.

PHILADELPHIA, April 4 -- The relationship of the armed forces "will be closely adjusted to combat trim in the very near future," Louis Johnson, Secretary of Defense, declared today at the commissioning of the U. S. S. Roanoke.

EL PASO, Tex., April 4 -- Resuming hostilities with the Indians, the Giants waded into the world champions right up to their elbows today and wound up by flattening Lou Boudreau's Tribe by a score of 15 to 10. That reduced the Clevelanders' lead to a three-to-two margin for the five games of the series played to date.

Civic organizations and railroads serving the Port of Baltimore have followed the lead of Philadelphia and have filed a petition with the Interstate Commerce Commission protesting the lowering of railroad rates on Great Lakes grain moving to New York for export, it was reported yesterday.

TRENTON, N. J., April 4 -- The Kimberley School, small, fashionable girls' preparatory school in Montclair, received tax exemption today in a ruling of the State Supreme Court, which held the school was not operated for profit.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- The House Armed Services Committee charged today that "persons within the National Military Establishment" were endangering the country's security "through their efforts to sell the public their own particular views regarding air power."

SPRINGFIELD, Mo., April 5 (AP) -- Mickey Owen, former major league baseball catcher, testified in Federal Court today that he left Mexico in 1946 "because of the way I was treated in being released and humiliated on the ball field."
WASHINGTON, April 5 (AP) -- Baseball's famous "reserve clause" -- once more under fire in the courts -- may be legalized by Congress.
Issues of public utility common and preferred stocks valued at $18,075,000 were bought by investment banking syndicates yesterday at public competitive bidding. The awards were as follows:

More than a hundred prominent physicians and laymen paid tribute yesterday to Dr. Sidney V. Haas, internationally known pediatrician, at a luncheon at the New York Academy of Medicine, in recognition of his pioneering contributions to the field of pediatrics.

North of the great institutions on Morningside Heights lies a valley, called Manhattanville. Here 60,000 people live in thirty-six average city blocks. It is an interracial community: one-third Negro, one-third Puerto Rican, and the remaining third comprised of twenty-two nationalities.

LOS ANGELES, April 5 (AP)--A new streamlined operations plan for the Rexall Drug Company was announced today by Justin W. Dart, president. The plan provides for expansion of its franchised dealer division and formation of three virtually independent retail chains.

The jewel collection of the late Evalyn Walsh McLean, including the famed Hope Diamond, passed yesterday from the executors of the Washington social leader's estate to the New York gem dealer, Harry Winston.
LONDON, April 5 -- As a result of a few letters written by one man to the British newspapers, 600 contributions were received today by a Jewish organization for the aid of Palestine Arab refugees.

Peary's attainment of the North Pole in 1909 is celebrated today by appropriate ceremonies in Washington arranged by the American Polar Society, a permanent group interested in the history and exploration of the Arctic and Antarctic regions. That final dash for the Pole is still regarded by many who remember the headlines of the day as a superlative athletic feat, but success came for other reasons.
WASHINGTON, April 5 -- The Air Force announced plans today for another transfer of funds to step up the purchase of its biggest and fastest bombers.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- Administration efforts to expedite Senate action on European recovery legislation were abandoned late tonight after an "all night" session had been averted by an admission of defeat in a move to limit debate by agreement.

The pound sterling market yesterday lost most of the tension that had developed on Monday following a report that the British were planning a devaluation move -- a report now flatly denied by official spokesmen of the British Embassy in Washington. In the day's trading the spot rate was maintained at $4.02 3/4, unchanged.
Columbia and Fordham will send their most experienced hurlers to the mound when the two local nines meet at Baker Field at 3:30 P. M. today in the fifty-eighth game of a rivalry dating back to 1884.
WASHINGTON, April 5 (AP) -- The Board of Immigration Appeals took under advisement today the plea of John Santo, former CIO-Transport Workers Union official, to postpone his deportation proceedings.

The greatly increased number of cabs on the street, especially in daytime hours, the union's own actions and statements, and its changed attitude toward an election to determine its strength among drivers all pointed yesterday to a weakening of the force of the taxicab strike.
CHICAGO, April 5 -- Government funds are being spent at a rate 1,100 times faster than a century ago, the Family Economics Bureau of the Northwestern National Life Insurance Company said today.

The talkative nature of barbers is an old story. It appears in literature, the drama and on vaudeville stages and in that large body of folklore signed by Anon. In it, barbers are philosophers, teachers, political economists and sometimes they even are humorists.

ROSH PINA, Palestine, April 5 (UP) -- Armistice negotiations between Syria and Israel opened here today but immediately ran into trouble when the Israeli delegates refused to deal with representatives of Syria's new military regime.

BOWIE, Md., April 5 (AP) -- Ben Civitello, the clever apprentice from Newark, Del., who rode six straight winners on yesterday's program, remained in the limelight today when he scored with three mounts. The string included Lady Alice, who also completed a consecutive double for the Rarco Stable in the sixth race.

DUESSELDORF, April 5 -- The three Western Allied Foreign Ministers advised the Parliamentary Council in Bonn today to give careful and serious consideration to the military governors' proposals for the form of the proposed Western German state.
The number of workers drawing unemployment benefits in this state declined by 5,413 last week, according to figures made public yesterday by Edward Corsi, State Industrial Commissioner.

OKLAHOMA CITY, April 5--Branch Rickey flew here today to watch his Dodgers trounce the Oklahoma City Indians, 7--5, held a brief press conference in his field box, then took to the air again for Fort Worth to see his Texas League farm hands play Buffalo tonight.
WASHINGTON, Wednesday, April 6 (AP) -- Washington was left without morning newspapers today by a dispute between the papers and the local of the AFL Printing Pressmen's Union.

WASHINGTON, April 5 (AP) -- The National Boxing Association today classed Joe Walcott, Ezzard Charles and Lee Savold as logical contenders, in that order, for the heavyweight title vacated by Champion Joe Louis.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- Charles Sawyer, Secretary of Commerce, said today that there was approximately 7,000,000 metric tons of iron and steel scrap available in Japan, "a substantial portion of which could readily be shipped to the United States."

TOKYO, April 5 -- Reaction in Japan to the new budget has been sullen and Premier Shigeru Yoshida has been made the scapegoat for the resentment against the occupation policy which has forced further austerity upon the people.
RANGOON, Burma, April 5 (AP) -- Sources close to the Government said rebel Karen forces in suburban Insein offered unconditional surrender today.

Clarence Derwent, president of Actors Equity, has been drafted by the union's nominating committee to run for re-election, it was announced yesterday. Mr. Derwent, who is about to conclude a term of three years, had told friends that the duties of Equity's president should be undertaken by someone else.

The large vacant plot at the northeast corner of Eastchester Road and Givan Avenue, including the blockfront extending to Mickle Avenue, in the Bronx, has been acquired for cash by the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York from the Chase National Bank, as trustee, for the erection of a new church edifice.

Warren H. Leland, examiner for the National Labor Relations Board, rejected yesterday an offer by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company to prove that the United Office and Professional Workers, CIO, had not complied with the non-Communist sections of the National Labor Relations Act.
With tempered optimism, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, United States delegate, expressed the hope yesterday that this session of the General Assembly might witness "even an unusual amount of agreement."

The Admiral Corporation yesterday introduced a new line of television -- FM-AM radio and automatic phonograph console and credenza combinations which it claimed is priced $50 to $200 below the nearest comparable competitive units.
Eddie Cantor now is virtually set to appear in television over the NBC network in October. His show, which will be of the musical-comedy type, probably will not be seen more than twice a month.
LONDON, April 5 -- Deep anxiety about Britain's dwindling meat ration found emotional outlet tonight in one of the angriest scenes in the House of Commons for many years.
A wooden church clock that had tolled every half hour for 111 years without ever having missed a stroke ran down yesterday.

CHICAGO, April 5 -- Grain markets reversed their early action late in the session on the Board of Trade today with wheat closing at the top with net gains of 3/4 to 1 3/8 cents a bushel, May leading. Corn was unchanged to 1/2 cent up; oats, 1/2 cent up to 1/8 cent down; rye 1 3/8 to 1 1/2 cents off and soy beans, 1/4 to 1/2 cent off.

WASHINGTON, April 5 (AP) -- The House approved a $701,122,079 appropriation for the Agriculture Department today to help farmers produce, find markets, fight pests, make a profit and conserve their soil.

The audience that witnessed the performance of "Where's Charley?" in the St. James Theatre last night was increased by 636 as a result of collaboration between Broadway and the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad.
By your past support of the American Cancer Society and its New York City Cancer Committee you have helped build a broad research program against a threat to mankind.

ATHENS, April 5 -- Guerrilla forces, steadily reinforced during the day, pressed home a series of attacks mainly between the Albanian border and the Sarantoporos River today. The guerrillas announced the formation of a full new "Free Greek" Cabinet.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- The 1,500,000 television receivers sold to date represent only 3 per cent of saturation of the national market, John W. Craig, vice president of Avco Manufacturing Corporation and general manager of its Crosley division, said here today.
BELFAST, Ireland, April 5 (AP) -- Rinty Monaghan successfully defended his world flyweight boxing championship tonight by decisively defeating Maurice Sandeyron of France in a fifteen-round fight.

The discordant animal roar in Madison Square Garden's basement has given way to a harmonious choral. The riggings in the Garden arena are secure and the props in order. Fresh, red, white and blue banners festoon the hall. For tonight the Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey Circus will unfold its seventy-ninth annual edition.

GENEVA, April 5 -- The Council of the International Refugee Organization approved today the allocation of $9,000,000 for reimbursement of voluntary agencies engaged in resettlement of refugees in Israel.

JERSEY CITY, April 5 (AP) -- Increases in sales of Old Gold cigarettes the first two months of this year were substantially ahead of those for the industry as a whole, the P. Lorillard Company reported today to its stockholders at their annual meeting.
WASHINGTON, April 5 (AP) -- Congress was asked today to finance a long-range program aimed at putting United States airlines on their feet financially by enabling them to fly in all kinds of weather.

John Russell Scott, whose death yesterday was reported in the British cables, was the son of one of England's greatest editors and a distinguished newspaper publisher in his own right. His father was Charles Prestwich Scott, the celebrated "C. P." who raised a local organ, important commercially to northwest England but negligible in national politics, into a great newspaper with an international standing.
MIDLAND Mich., April 5 -- Dow Chemical Company executive personnel was shifted today as a result of the plane-crash death last Thursday of Dr. Willard H. Dow.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 5 -- Japan is the key to economic recovery and development in the Far East, Edward P. Reubens, Professor of Economics at Cornell University, declared here today at a joint meeting of the American Oriental Society and the Far Eastern Association.

The Young People's Concerts Committee of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony has resorted to the radio to try to locate three of the finalists in its young composers' contest. Yesterday WQXR broadcast an appeal for information on the youngsters who submitted Rondo for Kitten on the Strings, Fughetta and Three Preludes, Op. 2.

ATLANTA, April 5 (AP) -- Georgia voters rejected emphatically today a proposed $46,000,000 in new taxes to improve schools, roads, health and other state services. Slushing through mud and rain to vote, a surprising number of citizens, who would have paid the new tax bill, rolled up a three-to-one margin against it.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- Pensions of $72 a month for low-income veterans of World War I at the age of sixty-five would cost the Government $17,000,000,000 over the next fifty years, according to new estimates given to Congress today.

Operations last year of the Pittston Company and its subsidiaries resulted in a net income of $5,214,553 after all deductions, equal to, $8.56 a share on 608,957 common shares outstanding, according to the nineteenth annual report issued yesterday.

ROME, April 5 -- The whole Italian press dedicated many columns today to the signing of the treaty. Even extreme Left Wing papers gave the ceremony in Washington considerable display, though under headlines designed to lessen its importance.

LONDON, April 5 -- Profits constitute an increasing proportion of Britain's national income, Sir Stafford Cripps recorded tonight in a White Paper on the eve of his budget. The White Paper analyzing the national income and expenditure and an economic survey for 1949 will provide the background against which Sir Stafford will introduce his budget.

MONTREAL, April 5 (Canadian Press) -- Net railway earnings lower than those of any year since 1905 were announced tonight by the Canadian Pacific Railway Company for 1948 "despite gross earnings which reached a new high."

Several persons connected with the city fusion movement, including former Under-Secretary of State A. A. Berle Jr., state chairman of the Liberal party, appeared briefly yesterday before a New York County grand jury investigating wiretapping.
LONDON, April 5 -- Although suffering from inactivity, which was attributed to uncertainty about the Government's coming budget, most sections of the stock market here today were cheerful.

The Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company leased with the option of two renewals a building to be built and owned by Bonanno Construction Company on Grand Avenue in Ridgefield, N. J., just off U. S. Highway No. 1, according to Cushman Wakefield, broker in the deal.

JERSEY CITY, N. J., April 5 -- The Democratic organization of former Mayor Frank Hague won first place on the local ballot today for the thirty-sixth straight year, and six astounded opponents said it just couldn't be so.
DUESSELDORF, April 5 -- Parades of jack booted Nationalists, singing "Deutschland Ueber Alles" are the most spectacular manifestation of the revival of authoritarianism in northern Germany.

Modern hand-woven rugs in which virtually every length of colored yarn has been selected individually to form the design for a particular setting, are featured in the exhibit opening today in the gallery of America House, 485 Madison Avenue.

Reports from Catherine Creek, which opened for rainbow trout fishing on Friday, indicate that there are plenty of big rainbows still swimming around and plenty of anglers still trying to get them into creels.

Dr. Karl von Frisch, an Austrian authority on bees, whose credited achievements include an understanding of their language, said last night in a lecture that the insects possessed senses of taste and smell as keen in some respects as those of human beings.

NANKING, April 5 -- The Communists called on Acting President Li Tsung-jen's Nanking Government tonight to break with Chiang Kai-shek and "American imperialism" or make possible an unopposed crossing of the Yangtze by the Communist Army into South China.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- Dr. Jaime Tortes Bodet of Mexico, Director-General of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, conferred with President Truman today and said afterward he was highly encouraged over the President's "keen interest" in the organization and its work.

Forty-second Street, one of the busiest thoroughfares in the world, will undergo complete repaving this summer, Borough President Hugo E. Rogers of Manhattan announced yesterday. The operation will include removal of the street's trolley tracks almost from river to river.

MENDOZA, Argentina, April 5 -- One of the ten members representing the United States delegation at the first National Congress of Philosophy at the University of Cuyo here declared yesterday that he planned to reopen the question of academic freedom in Argentina in a report to the American Philosophical Association, of which he is a member.

LUBBOCK, Tex., April 5 -- The Giants toppled the Indians in grand manner today, 8 to 4, to gain their second successive victory over the world champions. That squared the series at three games apiece, not to mention extending the New York streak to five triumphs in a row.
WASHINGTON, April 5 (AP) -- Atty. Gen. Tom Clark has assured Congress that if war came now the nation would be "in pretty good shape" so far as subversives were concerned.
WASHINGTON, April 5 -- The Department of Justice has recommended to Congress four changes in Federal anti-trust laws.

Fur manufacturers in planning volume lines for next fall are seeking to avoid style mistakes which reacted adversely upon demand during the last season, it was reported here yesterday. For the first time in years, it was stated, new lines are being prepared to meet more fully requirements of women 5 feet 5 inches tall or under, who are credited with constituting a heavy percentage of prospective purchasers.

MOSCOW, April 5 -- Pravda delivered a slashing attack on American geneticists today on the ground that they had developed theories of overpopulation for United States imperialists to justify expansion. Prof. Herman J. Muller was singled out for particular criticism.

Ralph B. Austrian, television consultant of 1270 Avenue of the Americas, predicted yesterday that network radio would decline rapidly in the next five years and be superseded by coast-to-coast network television.

KINGS POINT, L. I., April 5 -- A six-run assault in the eighth inning enabled the United States Merchant Marine Academy baseball team to turn back Manhattan College, 8 -- 7, in their Metropolitan Collegiate Conference game today. The victory was the first in two circuit starts for the Mariners while the Jaspers were making their tournament debut.

The wartime aid given to the British people by the New York chapter of the American Red Cross received official recognition yesterday when Sir Francis Evans, British Consul General, presented a certificate of appreciation to the chapter from his Government.
The Rev. William J. Kelley, chairman of the State Labor Relations Board for the last five years, announced his resignation yesterday in protest against a recent action of the state Legislature.
Two members of the Vathke family in Brooklyn's Bay Ridge section are alive today, thanks to Peewee, a pet cat.

While four other Kentucky Derby eligibles were being readied for yesterday's High Quest, the secondary feature at Jamaica, Joseph M. Roebling's Blue Peter was in his stall at near-by Belmont Park, recuperating from an impaction of the caecum.

Twenty Danish workers who have been in this country since Feb. 11 studying modernized methods for increasing production in their own country arrived here yesterday and will depart for home Friday. The tour was made under the auspices of the Economic Cooperation Administration.

The largest wine-selling drive ever undertaken on a national scale was officially opened yesterday at a "Spring Wine Luncheon" in the Statler Hotel. The promotion will continue on through the month and has the full support of all segments of the industry, according to James L. McNamara, New York representative of the Wine Advisory Board, the organization sponsoring the move.

Standard market, or media data forms, or both, are now being used by sixty - four newspapers, and cover some sixty-four cities, it was announced yesterday by the Bureau of Advertising, ANPA. The standard forms, devised and recommended by the 4-A's newspaper committee, the Newspaper Advertising Executives Association's research committee and the bureau, are designed to standardize local market and media information in a uniform format for use by national advertisers and agencies.

Coffee futures rallied sharply in active trading on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday. Trade demand and short covering advanced prices in contract "S" 15 to 23 points above Monday's levels. Contract "D" was also in demand, with final prices 30 to 42 points higher.

It is appropriate, on Army Day, to think about the traditions of the United States Army and our conceptions of them. But at once a curious paradox arises. Most of those traditions and conceptions exist largely in our subconscious minds. What the Army is, and ought to be, is something that we take almost entirely for granted.

The Communist party maintained secret funds to carry on certain aspects of its Moscow-dominated program for violent revolution in this country, according to yesterday's testimony at the Communist trial.

WASHINGTON, April 5 (AP) -- Extra millions of dollars to combat subversive activities in the United States and to build up the Voice of America abroad were recommended today by the House Appropriations Committee.

To ex-GI's who waited hours in line for what was often only two meals a day, and who slept on five-decker canvas bunks separated two feet from each other, a visit to the Army transport Henry Gibbins will come as something of a revelation.
The chief organizer of the city's five-day-old taxicab strike announced his resignation last night as the strike gave increasing signs of collapse.

Increasing unemployment among older workers may create an era of the "fearful fifties" that will force many of the middle-aged onto public relief rolls and into mental hospitals, it was warned yesterday. Speakers at a panel meeting of the Welfare Council discussed the problem before 130 representatives of affiliated organizations.

Charles E. Gilbert has sold his four-story residence at 4 Sutton Square, in the Sutton Place area, to a "well-known New Yorker" for occupancy, according to Douglas L. Elliman Co., brokers. Mr. Gilbert bought the house a short time ago from Stanton Griffis, who in turn had acquired it from Mrs. Elizabeth N. Graham (Elizabeth Arden).

Mayor O'Dwyer told a group of Stuyvesant Town tenants yesterday that his administration had done everything in its power to end discrimination in all housing developments. This has been done, he explained, as a matter of policy.

OTTAWA, April 5 (Canadian Press) -- Labor Minister Humphrey Mitchell disclosed in the House of Commons today that the powerful anti-Communist International Longshoremen's Association, AFL, put pressure on Canadian shipowners to ditch the Canadian Seamen's Union which last week called a general strike of East Coast shipping.

The atmosphere was subdued at Flushing Meadow yesterday when the United Nations General Assembly opened its spring session. An under-capacity crowd of public visitors and delegation guests paid scant notice to a dozen-odd Foreign Ministers and focused most attention on two financial wizards -- Bernard M. Baruch and Thomas J. Watson.
GENEVA, April 5 -- Britain will negotiate a new tariff agreement with Norway, Sweden and Denmark as a group.

The case of Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty, the conviction of the Bulgarian Protestant clergymen and Israel's application for United Nations membership were still not on the official agenda of the General Assembly last night as it ended its first meeting at Flushing Meadow.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- President Truman has requested Frank Pace Jr., Director of the Budget, to scrutinize with extreme care from the cost point of view all estimates of the arms assistance program that will implement the North Atlantic pact by providing military equipment for signatory powers.

WASHINGTON, April 5--The Wood bill, choice of a North-South coalition to succeed the Taft-Hartley Act, would extend the non-Communist affidavit provision to employer representatives and also to influential union figures who are not necessarily "officers," as the term is commonly used.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 5--Acting United Nations Mediator Dr. Ralph J. Bunche arrived here from Rhodes this afternoon and ...
The paper industry was chided yesterday for allowing pessimistic "jitters" to depress its business when it has opportunity for as prosperous a year as last.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 5 -- Warner Brothers has named Eleanor Parker to play opposite Humphrey Bogart in "Chain Lightning," the studio's photoplay about jet aviation which Stuart Heisler will direct starting April 18. The scenario is based on a screen story written under the pseudonym of J. Redmond Pryor, the author's actual identity never having been disclosed.

Several members of Congress and investigators now or formerly with the House Committee on Un-American Activities have been "invited by the special Federal grand jury investigating subversive activities to testify before it, John Gilland Brunini, the jury's foreman, disclosed yesterday.

Ellsworth B. Buck, former Representative in Congress and one-time president of the Board of Education here, was shot twice and seriously wounded late yesterday afternoon as he left his office in St. George, S. I. The Richmond County District Attorney, a witness, described the shooting as a "spite job" by a former merchant marine engineer.
PRINCETON, N. J., April 5 -- Exploding with eleven runs in the ninth inning, Fordham University's baseball team trounced Princeton by 12 -- 3 today on University Field.

AN interesting contrast capable of inspiring a number of melanoholy reflections may be found in the points of view of novelists who have written about American Indians. There was a time when "another Red Skin bit the dust" was so popular a phrase that it was part of the national folklore and when the pioneer saying "The only good Indian is a dead Indian" was taken for granted by writers and readers alike.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 5 (AP) -- The Cambridge School Committee has barred Dr. Harold J. Laski, British Labor official, from speaking in a public school hall.

Without a single dissenting vote the Assembly and Senate passed the Olliffe bill to provide the same pension rights and salary protection for teachers in our city colleges as now given to all other teachers in schools and colleges. In justice to our staff of hard-working college teachers, we believe that the bill should be signed by Governor Dewey.

David L. Cole of Paterson, N. J., has been chosen to arbitrate the contractual wage review between the Committee for the Companies and Agents. Atlantic and Gulf Coasts (licensed personnel), which represents about forty steamship operators, and the Masters, Mates and Pilots, AFL, it was made known yesterday.

PARIS, April 5 -- A French request for an assurance of the release this year of nearly $900,000,000 of the counterpart fund under the Marshall Plan will soon be submitted to Paul G. Hoffman, Economic Cooperation Administrator.

The progress of the civil rights struggle presents many encouraging and some discouraging results, two speakers reported yesterday at the teachers' course on evaluating the news, sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES and the Board of Education. Delbert Clark was moderator of the session, which was held at Times Hall.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- The National Advisory Committee for Aeronautics said today that it was stepping up its research efforts on supersonic flight because improved models of present military planes "will encounter flight conditions for which basic design information is still lacking."

Gangs of teen-age girls, described as more vicious than their male counterparts, are operating in various sections of Brooklyn as auxiliaries to the groups of marauding boys, it was disclosed yesterday.

The Sinclair Oil Corporation last year had a record consolidated net income of $81,048,602 after charges, taxes and reserves, according to the 1948 annual report for publication today. The net was equal to $6.76 each on the 11,974,003 capital shares outstanding.

CHICAGO, April 5 -- A survey of accounts receivable of Chicago manufacturers and wholesalers at the end of February indicated an increase in past due accounts, fewer buyers paying bills when due and an increase in the average age of accounts, compared with the same month last year.
A campaign is under way in New York State, directed by the Education Department in Albany, to construct school buildings that are simple and inexpensive in design, it became known yesterday.
Gen. Omar N. Bradley, Army Chief of Staff, asserted last night that the North Atlantic pact may become as important to American security in a military sense as possession of the atomic bomb.

" Bride of Vengeance," an historical drama produced by Paramount dealing with the Borgias and starring Paulette Goddard, John Lund and Macdonald Carey, will have its local premiere at the Paramount this morning. Mitchell Leisen directed and Richard Maibaum produced the offering from a screen play by Cyril Hume and Michael Hogan and a story by Mr. Hogan.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 5 -- Yugoslav reports of the purge in the Bulgarian Communist party indicate that a substantial segment of the Bulgarian Communist hierarchy has been involved in the struggle, the outlines of which are not yet clear.

Loans of the Chase National Bank outstanding in the first quarter of this year rose to $1,524,426,115 on March 31, according to the bank's statement of condition on that date, published today. The total compares with $1,482,834,294 on Dec. 31, 1948, and $1,405,956,869 on the March date a year ago.

ALBANY, April 5--Governor Dewey approved today an extension of the law giving cities power to tax the gross income of utility corporations. The tax is used by virtually every city in the state. New York City gets $2,000,000 to $3,000,000 a year from this source.

Mayor O'Dwyer continued yesterday to act shy on the subject of his candidacy for re-election, a candidacy taken for granted by virtually all of the political leaders in the city, as well as the Mayor's close associates.

Netherlands authorities have withdrawn from their letters of credit used in the purchase of Marshall Plan cargoes a clause objected to be the Economic Cooperation Administration, it was reported here yesterday. American shipping companies have protested the clause, which they charged circumvented the requirement that ECA shipments must be shared with American vessels.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, discussed unemployment with President Truman today and urged him to send a special message to Congress on the "development of a full-employment economy."

The committee on taxation of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York criticized Governor Dewey and members of the State Legislature yesterday "for their failure to deal realistically with the state's financial problems during the recent legislative session."

DETROIT, April 5 -- Michigan voters have rejected decisively a bid by Gov. G. Mennen Williams, Democrat, and the Political Action Committee of the Congress of Industrial Organizations for a mandate over state government.

Yesterday, in the presence of ten of the twelve Ministers who signed the Atlantic Pact the day before, the United Nations met in general assembly to proceed with the business left unfinished in Paris last autumn. This is supposed to be a carry-over session, but several new and controversial subjects have been put on the agenda. The Soviet delegate is expected to make a leading issue of the Western defense treaty.

With a draw in eighteen moves against Paul Michel of Germany in the sixteenth and semi-final round, Hector Rossetto of Buenos Aires attained a score of 13 -- 3 in the international chess masters tournament at Mar del Plata yesterday, thereby leading the field of eighteen by a full point, according to a report received from Argentina.

PARIS, Wednesday, April 6 -- Gen. Omar N. Bradley's statement in New York last night that the strategy under the North Atlantic pact must aim at defending Western Europe, not merely at liberating it again, was regarded by observers here today as likely to bring greater reassurance to the French and other Continentals than any utterance yet made by a United States leader.

URUMCHI, China, April 1 -- Talks have opened here between China and the Soviet Union on the renewal of the agreement negotiated in 1939 for operation of a "joint airline" spanning this borderland province of Sinkiang in northwest China.

A trend "to the right rather than the left" in the nation's economy was foreseen yesterday by Emil Schram, president of the New York Stock Exchange, in an informal analysis of financial conditions based upon the current Administration program.

Holding his youngest child on his lap, Rabbi Lipe Goldman laughed happily yesterday as he sat in the shelter of the United Service for New Americans -- the Hotel Marseilles, Broadway and 103d Street. "This is our rebirth," he said," and our new life and new hopes and new beginnings."

The $2,000,000 mark in sales of apartments in Queensview, a non-profit cooperative dwelling community to be built in Queens, was reached yesterday, according to an announcement by Louis H. Pink. The president of the Associated Hospital Service is president also of Queensview Housing Enterprise, Inc., which will build the development when all 728 apartments have been sold at a total of about $8,142,800.

Units of the Organized Reserve Corps in metropolitan New York and New Jersey will centralize their expanded training programs at Fort Totten, in Little Neck, Queens, early this summer. First Army Headquarters announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 5 -- Western Europe will need only 10,000,000 tons or coal from the United States in the coming fiscal year, the United Nations European Cooperation Administration estimated today.
WASHINGTON, April 5 -- The Office of Defense Transportation today took steps toward the final elimination of its wartime control over freight cars.
LONDON, April 5 (UP) -- The United States, Britain and France appeared certain today to reject Moscow's protest against their decision to strip Germany of fifty-two square miles of territory.

TAMPA, Fla., April 5 -- Nine days after he fled from New York allegedly with $884,660 in cash and bonds belonging to the National City Bank, Richard H. Crowe, one of its trusted em ployes, was arrested last night and arraigned here today.
Former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman and Mrs. Lehman were mong 931 passengers who sailed yesterday for Cobh, Havre and Southampton on the United States liner America.

Visiting buyers registered in the New York market for the week ended yesterday totaled 1,279, compared with 1,337 last week and 1,546 in the similar week of last year, according to lists appearing in THE NEW YORK TIMES. There were 616 arrivals yesterday, against 633 last Tuesday.

Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, and William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, urged yesterday that organized labor support the American Cancer Society's fund campaign this month, the New York City Cancer Committee announced.

Dr. Herbert V. Evatt, Australian Minister for External Affairs and President of the United Nations General Assembly, opened its spring session at Flushing Meadow yesterday with a spirited defense of the organization and a demand that all regional agreements "be subordinated to and must be in accordance with those set forth in the Charter of the United Nations."

Landlords seeking to evict tenants must comply not only with the Federal Government's new regulations but with the stricter ones administered here by the City Rent Commission, it was made plain yesterday. The local laws narrow the grounds on which evictions can be effected, while the Federal rules lengthen the process in certain cases.

LONDON, April 5 -- United States Ambassador Lewis W. Douglas received a severe injury to his left eye yesterday while casting for salmon on the Test River near Southampton. Eye specialists, who flew to operate on the Ambassador, said today it would be another forty-eight hours before they could determine whether his vision might be permanently impaired.

The two six-story buildings at 83-15 and 83-19 116th Street, Kew Gardens, Queens, accommodating 116 families, have been sold by Harry and Samuel J. Lefrak and William B. Lambert to a syndicate represented by Monroe Blumenau of L. Blumenau's Sons, brokers.
One need not be a Southerner to appreciate hot bread at any meal. Steaming biscuits or muffins add both fragrance and flavor to a menu, whether served above or below the Mason-Dixon Line.

There will be twelve conductors during the New York Philharmonic-Symphony's summer season at the Lewisohn Stadium, and one of the features will be a concert version of the Kurt Weill opera, "Street Scene," based on Elmer Rice's play.

One of five identical exhibitions, "The Fifty Books of the Year," arranged by the American Institute of Graphic Art, opened last night in the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street. Simultaneous openings of the institute's twenty-seventh annual showing of its selection of good book design were held in oBston, Washington, Chicago and San Francisco.

BOSTON, April 5 (AP) -- Five hard-fisted Californians gave the Pacific A. A. U. Association top honors as the sixty-first National boxing championship tournament was reduced to its semi-final stage tonight at the Boston Garden.
PHILADELPHIA, April 5 -- The Philadelphia Orchestra's only tuba player would like to keep on tooting his big horn in Philadelphia.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- The National Distillers Products Corporation, New York, field today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering $40,000,000 of twenty-five year sinking fund debentures due on April 1, 1974, that are to be offered to the public.

Michael Todd isn't happy unless he is at grips with something off the beaten track. The more novel it seems the more enthusiastic he becomes. From trustworthy sources it was learned yesterday that he had acquired "My Darlin' Aida," the inspiration of which was Verdi's opera, "Aida."

LONDON, April 5 -- The three Western deputies seeking to negotiate an Austrian peace treaty failed after repeated attempts here today to elicit from Soviet deputy Georgi N. Zarubin an estimate of Austria's oil production for 1947, although the Soviet Union is claiming 60 per cent of that production.

Plans for a world-wide boycott of merchant vessels under Panamanian registry, scheduled to start next month, were discussed here yesterday by officials of the American Federation of Labor Maritime Trades Department and the International Transport Workers Federation at a meeting in the offices of Joseph P. Ryan, president of the International Longshoremen's Association.

Following is the text of the opening address before the United Nations General Assembly at Flushing Meadow yesterday by the Australian Minister for External Affairs, Dr. Herbert V. Evatt, Assembly President:

DETROIT, April 5 (AP) -- The Red Wings, champions of the National Hockey League, whipped the Canadiens, 3 -- 1, tonight to move into the Stanley Cup final play-off series against the Toronto Maple Leafs.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- Senator Frank P. Graham, Democrat, of North Carolina, urged today that the United States not be committed to unilateral sanctions against the Netherlands Government because of its defiance of the United Nations in dealing with the Republic of Indonesia.

Summer rugs of fiber or similar materials in novel weaves, which have generally been used in summer cottages or for a refreshing change while wool rugs take a rest, now include more types suitable for year-round use. Gimbels focused attention yesterday on such rugs for city or country homes, summer or all-year use by displaying a variety of new patterns as well as reliable stand-bys such as textured linen rugs and rush squares.

Women interested actively in the work of the Children's Aid Society's Homemaker Service are sponsoring an exhibition of "Period Rooms in Miniature" to be held from April 12 to 30 at the Grand Central Art Galleries for the benefit of the organization.

ROME, April 5 -- The stimulating effects of the Marshall Plan upon the Italian economy and the efficient way in which the Government has managed the Italian part of the aid were brought to light today. It was learned that the revenue from all sources in the next fiscal year is expected to cover seven-eighths of the total expenditures.

NORWALK, Conn., April 5 -- The Norwalk Catholic Action Committee today asked Gov. Chester Bowles to withdraw his name from a list of sponsors for the dinner forum to be held by The Nation Thursday night at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel in New York.
Walter M. Taylor has been appointed sales manager of the Autocar Company, Ardmore, Pa. He joined the company in 1936 as district sales manager at Philadelphia.

I heard it first on the radio -- sandwiched in between relatively unimportant matters like the Atlantic pact and the taxi strike. Dr. John M. Berdan of Yale had died. I was shocked. Then I went out and got the morning papers, and read about it -- there was the black heading atop the long column -- the headings and columns that record the passing of the great and near-great.
Stockholders of the Merritt-Chapman Scott Corporation reconvened yesterday but after a forty-five-minute wait the meeting was adjourned at 2:45 P. M. until April 25.

I heard it first on the radio -- sandwiched in between relatively unimportant matters like the Atlantic pact and the taxi strike. Dr. John M. Berdan of Yale had died. I was shocked. Then I went out and got the morning papers, and read about it -- there was the black heading atop the long column -- the headings and columns that record the passing of the great and near-great.

TEHERAN, Iran, April 5 (UP) -- A Foreign Office spokesman said today that there had been three clashes between Russian and Iranian troops in three months along the frontier and that Iranian protests against the incidents had been fruitless.

Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange became fairly active yesterday, despite the rather narrow fluctuations, and final prices were unchanged to 4 points higher, except for the July, 1950, contract, which closed nominally 4 points lower.

Share prices on the New York Stock Exchange moved along at a fairly active pace yesterday, closing irregularly higher. It was a repeat performance on Monday's market, the turnover aggregating 900,000 shares, against 920,000 shares the day before.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, April 5 (AP) -- Earl Cochell of San Francisco, top-seeded player, led the favorites into the quarter-finals of the Coral Beach tennis tournament today with a 6-0, 6-0 victory over Dick Freisenbruch of Bermuda.

TRENTON, N. J., April 5 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll signed today civil rights legislation designed to encourage racial and religious tolerance in employment, education, recreation and public accommodations.

NEW HAVEN, April 5 (AP) -- Larry Robbins, former executive vice president and director of the Eversharp Company of Chicago, today became president and chairman of the board of the 130-year- old New Haven Clock Company. He succeeds James A. Heitzmann, who had held the presidency since last June, resigning last week.

SAYVILLE, L. I., April 5 -- A new flight instrument that simplifies the tasks of the airplane pilot and that eventually may reduce the 400-foot ceiling now required for landings to 100 feet received its first public demonstration here today.

Herbert A. Payne and Raymond E. Minner have been elected vice-presidents and secretaries of the Home Indemnity Company, it was announced yesterday. Kenneth E. Black and Clarence Ramsett were made secretaries.
The address by Gen. Omar N. Bradley, Chief of Staff, before the Jewish War Veterans at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel last night follows:
The New York City Housing Authority borrowed $48,375,000 yesterday on city-guaranteed serial bonds maturing over fifty years at an interest cost of 2.90108 per cent.

A comprehensive loan exhibition of paintings, pastels and drawings by Degas has been arranged at the Wildenstein Galleries for the benefit of the New York Infirmary. A gala preview will be held this evening and the exhibition will open to the public tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- The North Atlantic treaty, which must be ratified by the Senate to give life and force to the free world's new defensive alliance, was put today far down on the list of coming Senatorial business.

Two summer dark tones -- navy and toast -- were singled out to provide the theme for the showing of Henry Rosenfeld fashions yesterday at Russeks. Used in combination or single, they appeared first in smooth broadcloths, crisp butcher linens, cool shantungs and sheers and smart town denims.

FRANKFORT, Germany, April 5 -- The State Supreme Court of Wuerttemberg-Baden upheld today the constitutionality of the tax on newspapers and periodicals to which the publishers had strongly objected as a blow to the freedom of the press.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 5 -- The eighth biennial convention of the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, CIO, went into executive session today with ranking officers of the national Congress of Industrial Organizations in attendance.

CHICAGO, April 5 -- Asthma, hay fever, eczema and other alergic conditions may have their origin in unexpressed childhood hostility to parents, the annual convention of the American Orthopsychiatric Association was told today.

PHOENIX, Ariz., April 5 -- Representatives of 125,000 Indians of eighteen Southwestern tribes met today in the first regional conference of its kind to discuss such mutual problems as health, education and welfare, and how the Federal and State Governments could assist in them.
LONDON, April 5 (AP) -- Tommy Yarosz leaves for New York tomorrow on the Queen Elizabeth without getting any action on his challenge to Freddie Mills, world light-heavyweight boxing champion.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., April 5 -- Frank Shea had his official "unveiling" today in a scrub game at Huggins Field without ill effect.

Examinations of new fabrics offered by wool manufacturers reveals that many are actually duplications of existing cloths but priced from 15 to 30 cents cheaper, it was pointed out yesterday. The hidden reductions, however, wool textile men said, have not stimulated buying for the fall season, and few manufacturers of fashion apparel have bought more than 30 per cent of the season's requirements.

Both the East and the West Coast were represented in the cotton fashions exhibited yesterday noon by Zachery Bogart's Cotton Shop in the Oval Room of the Ritz-Carlton. Louella Ballerino of Los Angeles brought a fresh young note to the showing.

We have experienced no abatement, through the years, of our enthusiasm for the circus. We still feel something of the same excitement, the same awe at dangers risked, the same wonder at the daily miracle performed to keep on schedule for the one-day stands on the road. It is the seventy-ninth annual edition of Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey that opens tonight at Madison Square Garden.

Dr. Herbert V. Evatt, President of the United Nations General Assembly, told an international gathering last night that "nothing else can be a substitute" for the United Nations in bringing about peace and justice in the world.
WASHINGTON, April 5 -- The 1950 census is expected to show a United States population of 150,000,000 persons -- an increase of about 19,000,000 from the 1940 census of 131,669,275.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- Europe has lost its influence in Asia and will no longer be safe until it develops Africa for the latter's food and resources, Count Carlo Sforza, Italian Foreign Minister, said today.
EFFINGHAM, Ill., April 5 -- A midnight fire swiftly turned St. Anthony's Hospital into a deathtrap for an estimated sixty-six persons early today.

The eleven-story and penthouse apartment building at 264 Lexington Avenue, near Thirty - fifth Street, was purchased by Henry Payson, operator, in a deal reported yesterday by Harold M. Silverman and Berley Co., brokers. Assessed for $220,000, the property is 49 by 100 feet and contains thirty-five apartments.
WASHINGTON, April 5 -- A determined effort to unite northern and southern bituminous coal operators in "a united front" to face John L. Lewis and the United Mine Workers is now under way.
WARSAW, April 5 (AP) -- Archbishop Stefan Wyszynski, Roman Catholic Primate of Poland, was disclosed today to have condemned the pro-Government press for "insulting and abusing" Pope Pius XII.

GRAFENWOEHR, Germany, April 6 -- At the biggest demonstration of United States troops in Europe since the end of the war. Gen. Lucius D. Clay explained to members of his command today that the North Atlantic pact meant a commitment to fight against an aggressor.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- A Federal court today denied the right of the Civil Aeronautics Board to assign a route to an aviation company that had made no application for it. This was the first case of its kind.

PHOENIX, Ariz., April 6 -- An overhauling of the vast structure of laws affecting Indians -- now reputedly numbering 4,300 -- and gradual withdrawal of the Government from administration of Indian affairs were urged today at the Southwestern Indian Conference.

LAKE SUCCESS, April 6 -- John Foster Dulles, United States representative, opened the debate on the disposition of the former Italian colonies today by proposing that the General Assembly assign United Nations trusteeships over Cyrenaica to Britain and over Italian Somaliland to Italy.

Knitted outerwear manufacturers will not accept the burden of increased inventories to accommodate timid retail buying policies, Sidney S. Korzenik, executive director and counsel of the National Knitted Outerwear Association, warned yesterday.

On April 1 you published in these columns a letter from Walter Reuther, president of the United Automobile Workers, CIO, commenting on an editorial advertisement over my name which appeared in your newspaper on March 16.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, April 6 (AP) -- Strong-stroking Fred Kovaleski of Detroit fashioned the major upset today as the men's singles division of the Coral Beach tennis tournament moved into the semi-finals. He expelled Bill Vogt of Philadelphia, the third-seeded contender, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 2.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- Restrictions imposed by the Senate Expenditures Committee on Presidential reorganization powers signaled today an important oncoming test for the Commission on Organization of the Executive Branch of the Government.

WASHINGTON, April 6 (AP) -- Striking American Federation of Labor pressmen voted tonight to return to their jobs, ending a 25-hour walkout that had halted publication of Washington's four daily newspapers.

The penthouse at 35 West Fifty-third Street has been leased by the Salnor Realty Company to Educational Methods, Inc., which will operate as the Eddie Duchin Piano Studios, according to Douglas L. Elliman Co., broker in the deal.

SEOUL, Korea, April 6 -- Miss Louise Yim, Korean Minister of Commerce and Industry, denied today charges of a national inspection committee that she had misappropriated public funds to finance her election to the National Assembly.

The second annual Grocery Inventory Research Clinic will be staged at the Edgewater Beach Hotel in Chicago May 4 by the Bureau of Advertising, A. N. P. A., with the cooperation of fourteen newspapers conducting monthly grocery inventory research, it was announced yesterday.

Friends of the Urban League for social work among Negroes met at Gracie Mansion yesterday to spur a fund-raising campaign for $500,000 here for the support of the national office and various local branches. Mrs. Paul O'Dwyer, the Mayor's sister-in-law, was hostess and shared the chairmanship of the sponsoring committee with Mrs. Samuel Chapman.

LONDON, April 6 -- To a glum House of Commons and a disappointed nation, Sir Stafford Cripps forcefully presented today the unpalatable fact that, so long as Britain's expenditures for defense and social services continued at their present rate, there could be no substantial tax reductions.

Bigelow-Sanford Carpet Company yesterday reduced prices 10 to 20 per cent on certain items on its woven carpet line. The special low prices will apply for a limited time only, according to G. C. Denebring, vice president for sales. He said that the reductions were made to meet competition.

In his budget speech yesterday Sir Stafford Cripps, Chancellor of the British Exchequer, told a packed House of Commons: "There is no doubt whatever that Britain needs continued American aid." We think that many Americans, reading Sir Stafford's review of 1948 and his courageous financial program for 1949, will find themselves replying: "There is no doubt whatever that Britain has merited such aid."

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- The Senate refused overwhelmingly today to encourage its Appropriations Committee to cut heavily the $5,580,000,000 sought by the Administration for the European Recovery Program in the next fifteen months.

After early advances ranging up to 20 points, coffee futures turned weak in late dealings on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday. Early support was given by producer interests and trade covering. Commission house selling in an empty market lowered prices sharply toward the close. Final prices in contract "D" were 40 to 53 points lower.

Charley Fusari, Irvington, N. J., welterweight, scored an easy victory over Al Guido, Bronx veteran, in the feature bout of ten rounds at the Manhattan Center last night. Boxing craftily at long range, the Jersey boxer received the unanimous vote of Referee Barney Felix and Judges Charley Shortell and Tom Guilfoyle.

Probably the most progressive post-war development in retailing will be seen next Monday at the F. R. Lazarus Co., a department store in Columbus, Ohio, where a new "bulk service building" will be officially put in operation.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended March 30, the Federal Reserve Board reported today:

To clear up the question of "What Is Modern, Anyway?" that has confused consumers and designers alike, Harold M. Schwartz, furniture and fabric designer, was interviewed yesterday by Mary Roche, home editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, at a luncheon meeting of the Home Fashions League at the Hotel Roosevelt.

Richard H. Crowe, the National City Bank assistant manager who disappeared ten days ago with $884,660 of the bank's cash and bonds, came back to New York last evening to face the music. He was accompanied by three Federal Bureau of Investigation agents and a deputy United States Marshal and there were more to meet him at the airport.

TULSA, Okla., April 6 -- While Brooklyn's Joe Hatten was shutting out Tulsa of the Texas League, 10 to 0, today for his second nine-inning job, President Branch Rickey of the Dodgers continued his search for first-base insurance by returning one player to one farm club and calling up another player from another farm club.
The Johns-Manville Corporation, in a proxy statement mailed yesterday to 12,000 stockholders, submitted a proposed employe stock purchase plan to be voted upon at the annual meeting on May 13.

More than 150 civic, business and social welfare leaders attended a dinner at the Hotel Astor last night for Benjamin Lazrus, who was chairman of the 1948-49 fund-raising campaign of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York, the most successful drive in its thirty-two-year history.
GENEVA, April 6 -- The International Refugee Organization decided today to warn all displaced persons and refugees in its care that the organization soon would begin to end its activities.

President Truman, Governor Dewey and Mayor O'Dwyer urged yesterday that Federal, state, county and municipal employes in this city give generously to the 1949 campaign of the Greater New York Fund. The drive, with a goal of $8,000,000, starts April 25.

With two-thirds of the city's taxicabs back on the streets, the Taxi Workers Organizing Committee of John L. Lewis' United Mine Workers officially ended last night its efforts to keep 4,981 owner-driven cabs idle.

Although we have supported federal aid to education, and endorse the greater state aid to localities which Governor Dewey signed into law yesterday, it is clear that neither of these can be permitted to take the place of local responsibility.

BOSTON, April 6 (UP)--The largest individual stockholder of Montgomery Ward Co., is openly opposing the re-election of Sewell L. Avery as chief executive of that mail-order and chain-story concern. The stockholder is the Massachusetts Investors Trust, one of the largest "Boston type" investment trusts, with resources of over $200,000,000, it owns 104,000 common shares of Montgomery Ward -- valued currently at more than $5,000,000.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- Democrats and Republicans traded victory claims today on the basis of Tuesday's local and state elections in Missouri, Wisconsin and Michigan. The Democrats reported gains in St. Louis and in Wisconsin, while the Republicans held their own in Michigan.

Cornelius N. Bliss was one of our finest citizens. A native of New York, he took pride in its great institutions of music and the arts, and shouldered heavy responsibilities in the direction and financing of them. His services to the Metropolitan Opera were acknowledged, upon his retirement as chairman of the board in 1946, with a tribute to his "devoted loyalty and effective leadership."

Suzanne Bloch's annual concerts of early music are specialized events, but they have been building in popularity year by year and her program for the current season, which was given last night at Times Hall, not only drew an audience of 500 that filled the auditorium to capacity, but almost fifty persons had to be turned away.
The scientist who pierced the secrets of the language of the bees told here last night how he had done it.
OTTAWA, April 6 (AP) -- A surprise American witness in the Sam Carr trial testified today that he had agreed in 1940 to spy in Japan for Russia.

The future of Italy's former colonies in North Africa was discussed by four newspaper correspondents last night over WQXR in the weekly forum "What's on Your Mind?" conducted for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Delbert Clark.

The 3,000-mile flight for life of a 52-year-old infantile paralysis victim was completed successfully yesterday afternoon when his specially equipped plane landed at La Guardia Airport after heavy fog had caused a four-hour detour to a South Jersey airport.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- The foreign secretaries of the United States, Britain and France met twice today and were reported to have made substantial progress toward the following compromise on the control of Western Germany:

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 6 -- At the end of March Yugoslav doctor living in Bulgaria was tried by a Sofia court on charges of espionage. He was named Cedomir Ilitch. Dr. Ilitch was convicted and sentenced to twelve years in prison.
James J. Sutherland has been appointed general manager of the electronics division of Sylvania Electric Products, Inc. He formerly was controller of the electronics division at Boston.

NEW DELHI, April 6 -- Foreign private investment capital win be welcomed in India, subject only to the restrictions and regulations hat apply equally to Indian capital, Prime Minister Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru told Parliament today.

The Hope Diamond of sinister legend arrived in New York yesterday, together with the rest of the regal collection of jewels that belonged to the late Evalyn Walsh McLean, a few hours after the announcement of its sale to Harry Winston, gem dealer.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., April 6 -- The Athletics upset whatever celebration plans the Yankees had for their farewell game at Al Lang Field today as towering Dick Fowler snapped a six-game New York winning streak with a four-hit itching effort for a 6-to-1 triumph.

Methods of eliminating health hazards created by burned-out fluorescent lamps were agreed upon yesterday by eighteen representatives of industry, education and government groups at a conference called by the Department of Health and Sanitation.

BOSTON, April 6 (AP) -- Hammer-fisted Maurice Harper, 18-year-old Oakland school boy, gained top individual honors as his California team-mates clinched the team prize in the finale of the sixty-first National A. A. U. boxing championships tonight at the Boston Garden.

Rose Schneiderman, for 31 years president of the New York Women's Trade Union League, will retire from that post at the end of this month, the league announced yesterday. In an uncontested election Gerel Rubien, educational director of Local 62, International Ladies Garment Workers Union, will be named to head the organization.

The joint executive board of the United Brewery Workers, CIO, announced last night "a sharp reversal of strategy" to enable tavern keepers in the metropolitan area to obtain beer during the current strike against fourteen major New York breweries.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- Appraising the economic implications of the North Atlantic treaty, Dr. Edwin G. Nourse declared yesterday that the costs of the accompanying program for arming Western Europe should be squeezed out of the national military budget.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- Frieda S. Miller, Director of the Women's Bureau of the Department of Labor, today announced a project under the international exchange of persons program, through which five representatives of women's groups in Mexico and South America will study seven women's organizations in this country.
Lashing out at "bogus Americans who do not know the fundamentals of the Constitution," Eddie Cantor called yesterday for a concerted church, school and family campaign to wipe out intolerance.

DETROIT, April 6 -- Great hope for the rehabilitation of chronic alcoholics through the use of antabuse as a medical aid was held out today by Dr. R. G. Bell, a Canadian specialist in the treatment of alcoholism, on the basis of the first ,reported clinical trial of the drug in its new application in North America.

The Jewish Agricultural Society, Inc., whose main purpose is to encourage and advance farming by Jews in the United States, made public its annual report yesterday, showing that it had lent $11,000,000 to Jewish farmers in forty states since its founding in 1900.
WASHINGTON, April 6 (AP) -- President Truman today received the America's Democracy Legacy Medallion for his program "to secure full civil rights for all his countrymen."

ALBANY, April 6 -- The Feinberg-Milmoe bill revising the basis for apportioning state aid to education and increasing the amount to be distributed by $40,000,000 became law today with Governor Dewey's approval.

A thirty-year flight from Russian imprisonment ended here yesterday for Dr. Alexander Mitinsky, a 73-year-old Czarist metallurgist, who arrived among 826 displaced persons on the Army transport Gen. W. M. Black.

Difficulty in deciding the trend of the market was again evident in the movement of stock prices on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. At the closing bell, however, quotations were irregularly lower in quiet trading. The utility group developed the most activity, while selected industrial stocks slipped listlessly to the minus side.

A peaceful revolution is taking place in the nursing profession. The trend toward legally distinct branches within the profession, each having its own clearly defined skills, was described yesterday by leaders in the field.

Forty years ago yesterday, when he was a wiry fellow of 43 years, Matthew A. Henson watched Comdr. Robert E. Peary stake out his claim to the North Pole. Then, at his chief's direction, Peary's Negro companion led their four Eskimo helpers in "three rousing cheers."

Production of a 111-inch wheelbase car, the shortest in the 1949 Plymouth line, was announced yesterday by the Plymouth division of the Chryesler Corporation. The vehicle, a three-passenger coupe, is constructed to afford additional maneuverability in traffic and meet the requirements of restricted parking.

Court proceedings over the right of Glidden, Morris Co., securities dealers, to inspect the stock record books of the New York Water Service Corporation, were averted yesterday when the utility's management capitulated to the firm's request. Glidden, Morris represent more than 2,000 shares of the company's outstanding stock.

Pleas for armed preparedness to insure the peace the world is seeking were made throughout metropolitan New York and New Jersey yesterday as thousands of citizens gave recognition to the nation's soldiers on the twenty-second observance of Army Day.

Eight special excise taxes yielded the city $2,194,222 more in the nine months ended March 31 than in the corresponding period of the preceding fiscal year, Controller Lazarus Joseph disclosed yesterday.

Mrs. Theodore Weicker will give a tea tomorrow in her home at 1115 Fifth Avenue as the first in a series of fetes planned in advance of the Bachelor and Benedict Tea Dance which will take place April 29 in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria. Mrs. Weicker's guests will include members of various committees for the tea dance, arranged to augment the Student Ticket Endowment Fund of the Philharmonic-Symphony Society of New York.

A woman student at Brooklyn College and a young man companion were fined $50 each and sentenced to six months in jail yesterday by Magistrate Abner C. Surpless in Flatbush Court, Brooklyn, after their conviction for blocking traffic while distributing Communist leaflets.

In a move believed to be unprecedented in the annals of the Protestant Episcopal Church, the controversy between the vestry of Holy Trinity Church in Brooklyn and the Rev. Dr. John Howard Melish, rector, will be brought to civil trial on April 18 in Brooklyn Supreme Court.

" Crusade in Europe," the twenty-six-part film series on the life of General Eisenhower, has been bought by Time, Inc., publishers of Life, Time, and Fortune, and will be aired over the ABC television network beginning either May 5 or May 19.

LAKE SUCCESS, April 6 -- Over Soviet objections, a United Nations committee voted today to begin immediate and detailed examination of three documents on press freedoms that have been proposed as world-wide conventions to assist news-gathering and protect freedom of information.

CHICAGO, April 6 -- Kenneth C. Royall, Secretary of the Army, told an Army Day luncheon today that war was not imminent, but that if an Eurasian army swept over western Europe, the Mediterranean and the Middle East, the resulting war would last ten to twenty years -- "perhaps more."

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- Recalcitrant left wing unions affiliated with the Congress of Industrial Organizations will soon have the choice of upholding CIO policy or taking the road which may lead to formation of a Cominform-directed labor union federation in the United States.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., April 6 (AP) -- Andy Varipapa, Hempstead, L. I., trick-shot specialist, earned some of the American Bowling Congress tournament's $300,000 in prize money today, but his cut will be small.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- The Idaho Power Company, Boise, filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering 10,000 shares of 4 per cent preferred stock. $100 par value, and 200,000 shares of common stock, $20 par value.
BERLIN, April 6 -- The Communist-dominated People's Council issued a new appeal tonight to the Bonn Parliamentary Council for a conference to create a united Germany.

FRANKFORT, Germany, April 6 -- One of the few points of unanimity among United States, British and German officials in the Western zones is that the 10,000,000 to 13,000,000 German refugees who have entered the zones since 1945 constitute Western Germany's most complex and dangerous political and economic problem.

LONDON, April 6 -- Although jobbers were adhering strictly to a go-slow policy in the stock market here today, there was a general air of cheerfulness and budget "favorites" (shares likely to benefit by tax reductions), which have been in demand during the last few days, held at their best levels.

CHICAGO, April 6 -- Heavy short covering developed in the grain markets on the Board of Trade today. Wheat led the advance and was up 3 cents at one time. Profit-taking developed on the advance and the best prices were not maintained, wheat closing 1 1/2 to 2 5/8 cents higher, new crop months showing the most strength.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- This city, with the rest of the nation, celebrated Army Day in the traditional way today, with parades, speeches and cheers for the boys in olive drab. But the sun was hardly down before it became the most memorable Army Day of all, because it was suddenly proclaimed the last.

The largest shipping subsidy in American maritime history is involved in the proposed construction of a superliner "prestige" ship for the Merchant Marine, according to figures made public last night by the Maritime Commission.

A Boston advertising man who has spent the last nine years in the Communist party and auxiliary groups as an undercover "contact" of the Federal Bureau of Investigation took the stand at the Communist trial yesterday as a surprise witness.

NANKING, April 6 -- Acting President Li Tsung-jen's Government here was backed up against the wall today by a new Communist demand for the "surrender" of the Nanking regime and a privately delivered ultimatum that was reliably reported to have given General Li less than a week to agree to the formation of a joint committee for the integration of Government troops into the "People's Liberation Army."
WASHINGTON, April 6 (UP) -- The House Appropriations Committee voted $43,000,000 today in emergency funds to keep the Berlin airlift running at full capacity through June 30.

LAKE SUCCESS, April 6 -- The United Nations Political Committee supported today a motion by United States delegate Warren R. Austin to return to the Interim Committee (Little Assembly) without recommendation a draft resolution empowering the President of the General Assembly to appoint a conciliator in cases of minor disputes.
WASHINGTON, April 6 (UP) -- The Navy announced today that, under its budget for the fiscal year 1950, it would keep a 409-ship fleet in the Atlantic and 285 vessels in the Pacific.
GENEVA, April 6 -- The groundwork is being laid for a complete revamping of the Marshall Plan soon after Congress completes action on next year's appropriation.

The return to normality in the steel industry is continuing apace. One of the latest evidences of the adjustment is the reduction in the price of standard steel rails just posted by two leading producers. Another is a drop in the tariff for galvanized steel products of subsidiaries of the United States Steel Corporation.
