Asa S. Bushnell, Commissioner of the Eastern College Athletic Conference, was surprised yesterday to learn that the National Collegiate Athletic Association was waggling an official finger at some of his ivy-clad institutions.

MINNEAPOLIS, April 6 0P) -- The Minneapolis Lakers beat the Washington Capitols tonight, 76 to 62, and increased their lead to two games in the Basketball Association of America championship play-off. George Mikan scored only 10 points for the victors.

WASHINGTON, April 6 (AP) -- Senator Matthew M. Neely of West Virginia said today he planned to propose meetings between newspaper publishers and the Post Office Department to work out an agreement on second-class mail rates.

PARIS, April 6 -- Army Day speeches by Secretary of the Army Kenneth C. Royall and former Under-Secretary William H. Draper Jr., in the United States today like the speech in New York by Gen. Omar N. Bradley yesterday, appeared to French observers to indicate a closer United States approach than ever before to the guarantees for Europe that the French suggested more than a year ago.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- Attorney General Tom Clark urged Congress today to pass the Administration's anti-spying bill and defended as indispensable a "catch-all" provision to permit effective prosecution.

The nation's gasoline stocks last week declined 318,000 barrels to 127,769,000 at the week-end, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Light fuel oil supplies were down 165,000 barrels to 48,556,000 and stocks of heavy fuel oil were reduced 82,000 to 58,710,000.

Fifty striking taxicab drivers, who had read that the $14,000,000 treasury of the United Mine Workers was behind them, got a cold reception yesterday when they appeared at the union's regional headquarters, 250 West Fifty-seventh Street, to request financial assistance.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., April 6 -- Members of the American Association of Advertising Agencies, gathered at the Greenbrier Hotel here for the organization's thirty-first annual meeting, today elected Clarence B. Goshorn, president of Benton Bowles, Inc., their new board of directors' chairman.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- The Office of Education, in the first survey of university degrees made on a nation-wide basis, reported today that 318,749 college and university degrees were conferred in the year ended June 30, 1948. The survey embraced all categories of academic degrees.

Although defeated for the first time in the seventeenth and final round yesterday, Hector Rossetto of Buenos Aires finished in first place in the international chess masters tournament concluded at Mar del Plata, according to a report received from Argentina.
RANGOON, Burma, April 6 (UP) -- The Karen tribesmen ended their revolt against the Government today and announced they would support the regime of Premier Thakin Nu.

PARIS, April 6 -- Paul Reynaud, former Premier, in a speech delivered tonight at a dinner of French Independents, urged a revision of policy in the direction of economic liberalism. Without this change, he warned Premier Henri Queuille, the country might face a political deadlock.

Directors of the Republic Pictures Corporation resumed the payment of dividends on the $1 cumulative convertible preferred stock with the declaration yesterday of 25 cents a share for payment on July 1. The last payment was a similar amount on July 1, 1948.

Avoiding the fanciful and holding to their dependable, quality styling, Dein-Bacher of the Waldorf presented their spring and summer furs yesterday. Mink in luxurious stoles and airy capes and cape jackets was featured in a showing at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

In your editorial of March 16 you advocated a careful modification of Allied plans for the dismantling of German industries as stimulus to a self-sustaining Germany that can share in European recovery.

Maple sap, still being tapped in New England and up-state groves, is rated as especially fine this year. New Yorkers are getting a chance to find this out for themselves almost as soon as those in the producing areas.

SOMERS, N. Y., April 6 -- This country hamlet, birthplace of the American circus and one-time center of Westchester social and business life, is a pilgrimage point this month for persons commemorating the 134th anniversary of traveling animal shows.

Equipment modernization plans expected to save thousands of dollars annually were announced yesterday by the Hudson Manhattan Railroad Company with the introduction of its first new six-car train with multiple car-door control.

SPRINGFIELD, Mo., April 6 (AP) -- Mickey Owen, former Brooklyn Dodger catcher, said today that he had only one fight with another player while playing baseball in Mexico. Owen is the defendant in a $127,500 breach-of-contract suit brought by Jorge Pasquel, Mexico City baseball promoter.

A study of the Arab lands of the Middle East, their religions and economic problems, by Kermit Roosevelt, will be published by Harper on April 27 under the title "Arabs, Oil and History." The subjects discussed range from table manners for a camel-and-rice banquet in a sheik's tent to data on espionage and American enterprise in the desert.

As an admirer of Mr. Churchill and as an Englishman who has spent almost a year in this wonderful country, may I be permitted to give brief expression to some thoughts and feelings that are prompted by his visit and recent speech.

The full schedule of programs for the main phase of the Berkshire Festival to be held by the Boston Symphony Orchestra, under Serge Koussevitzky, next summer at Tanglewood in Lenox, Mass., was announced yesterday.

The mammoth task of philanthropy needs efficient coordination to prevent costly waste and duplication. It calls for precise, long-range planning to make certain that its funds will bring the greatest possible benefit to the community and to those who are in need.

ALLENTOWN, Pa., April 6 -- Three persons were killed and two critically injured late last night or early this morning when their chartered plane crashed in the desolate Blue Mountains about twenty miles northwest of Allentown. All were residents of Reading, Pa.

Mark it down on the calendar that Saturday, April 9, the ninety-ninth day of 1949, will be rainy, windy and cold. In "The Old Farmer's Almanac" Saturday, April 9, is sandwiched between two weather forecasts; one reads Storms again, the other Cool but nice.

LOS ANGELES, April 6 -- A Federal grand jury returned two indictments today against nine persons and a corporation, charging them with attempting to ship airplanes, airplane parts and other equipment to Jewish forces in Palestine in violation of the arms embargo.

Two new films will open in midtown theatres this morning. At the Radio City Music Hall, the attraction is "A Connecticut Yankee in King Arthur's Court," Paramount's new version of the Mark Twain novel, with Bing Crosby in the starring role.

The possession of a hen pheasant has been known to cause considerable trouble and even some expense, but the bright-plumaged cock pheasant that alighted in the courtyard of the Phipps Garden Apartments in Sunnyside, Queens, yesterday created a situation that will be debated for some time to come.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., April 6 -- The California State Senate voted 22 to 14 today in favor of a resolution asking Congress to call a constitutional convention to permit United States participation in a world federal government.

HOUSTON, Tex., April 6 -- Kenneth G. MacKenzie of the Texas Company in New York City was one of three veteran petroleum technologists to whom certificates of appreciation were awarded tonight by the American Petroleum Institute at a dinner of the group's refining division here.

MOSCOW, April 6 -- The Government newspaper Izvestia warned today that "dark forces of Finnish reaction" were attempting to violate the Soviet-Finnish mutual assistance treaty, but expressed confidence in the efforts of "democratic Finnish forces" to insist on strict observation of the pact.

A four-point program for improving Economic Cooperation Administration procedure in connection with export orders was suggested yesterday by speakers at the meeting of the Foreign Credit Interchange Bureau at the Statler Hotel.

Although double those of the late Nineteen Twenties in actual dollars, capital expenditures by business of $19,200,000,000 during 1948 and $16,200,000,000 in 1947, are only 7 per cent higher when allowance is made for increase in population and price changes, the Northern Trust Company, Chicago, reports in its monthly bulletin.
Strong protests were voiced yesterday by trade groups here on the restrictions announced by Cuba on textile imports, effective April 15.

Reporting on operations last year of Technicolor, Inc., Dr. Herbert T. Kalmus, president and general manager, informed shareholders in the annual statement mailed yesterday, that sales, earnings and employment were the largest on record.

New issues of common and preferred stocks of public utility concerns valued at more than $6,900,000 will be placed on the market today by banking syndicates. Two new issues were bought by the underwriting groups at negotiated sales, and the third, a preferred stock issue, at sealed-bid-and-deadline competition.

Jockey Douglas Dodson donned mud silks and pulled on rubberized pants before going out to ride the Spring Hill Farm's Nell K. in the $17,525 Prioress Stakes at the rain-soaked Jamaica track yesterday. He might just as well have worn sunny-day gear, for Nell K. brought him back with the riding costume unspotted.
WASHINGTON, April 6 (AP) -- This country's foreign trade dropped again in February, as it did in January, the Census Bureau reported today.
WASHINGTON, April 6 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today made public a petition of the Eastern railroads for authority to increase less - than - carload class rates.

Reconstruction work, which had been decided upon even before yesterday's storm damage, will make it necessary for Steeplechase Pier at Coney Island to be closed to the public next summer, Park Commissioner Robert Moses said yesterday.
ATHENS, April 6 (AP) -- The Greek Government fought a civil service strike today as a menace to the war effort and began to apply terms of the martial law that prevails throughout the country.

THE best ball player in the spring training camp of the Cincinnati Reds this year in the opinion of every expert in Florida was William Harold Terry, a first baseman. He could field better than anyone else on the premises and he also could hit better. Unfortunately, though, he happens to be 50 years old and even the Redlegs, as desperate as they are for talent, hardly could consider him for a regular post.

CHICAGO, April 6 -- Eighty to ninety per cent of all accidents do not happen "by accident," but are determined by people's unconscious conflicts and may often be partial suicide attempts, Dr. J. Cotter Hirschberg, a national authority on accident-proneness, asserted at the closing session today of the American Orthopsychiatric Association's convention.
The nation celebrated Army Day yesterday with speeches and fanfare that justly reflected the admiration the nation feels for its oldest armed service.

BONN, Germany, April 6 -- The first implications of a break in the hitherto rigid attitude of the Social Democratic party toward Western Allied specifications on the form of the proposed Western German government developed this afternoon.

Plans for a new school building to serve Union Free School District No. 1, in Smithtown, L. I., were announced yesterday in connection with the purchase by the Board of Education of a twelve-acre tract of land on Lawrence Avenue, south of Main Street, in the Village of Branch, from Evelyn W. Miller.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- Official Washington today received Bulgarian confirmation of a deep split in the ruling Bulgarian Communist party that already has put the No. 2 Communist on the shelf, if not in jail, and has resulted in an order for "speedy and severe measures" against others displaying "nationalist and anti-Soviet tendencies."

HOUSTON, Tex., April 6 -- The Giants really are rolling and while there is doubt what this portends for the championship campaign ahead there is no doubt it is beginning to get into the hair of the current world champions.
Last night a circus came to fill Madison Square Garden with spangled splendor, from its tanbark arena to its steel-beamed ceiling.

Charles Van Newkirk, the unemployed marine engineer who shot former Representative Ellsworth B. Buck because of a personal grudge on Tuesday evening in Staten Island, was arraigned yesterday morning in Felony Court at Stapleton, S. I.

EFFINGHAM, Ill., April 6 -- This small Illinois community today counted seventy-three persons dead in the fire that destroyed St. Anthony's Hospital. Meanwhile, townspeople started a drive to build a new hospital.

Nettie Rosenstein's spring and summer fashions, presented yesterday noon in the Cotillion Room of the Hotel Pierre, offered that designer's conception of how well-dressed American women should look from morning until night. These were clothes of refinement and beauty.

LONDON, April 6 -- The sterling area incurred a net gold and dollar deficit during the first quarter of 1949 of 82,000,000 (about $328,000,000), the Treasury reported tonight. But mostly because of Marshall Plan aid, Britain's holdings of gold and dollars rose during the quarter 14,000,000, to 471,000,000.

LAKE SUCCESS, April 6 -- The United States asked the United Nations General Assembly today to consider the trials of Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty and Bulgarian Protestant clergymen as violations of the peace treaties with Hungary and Bulgaria.

Business was assured again yesterday that it has nothing to fear from Government as long as it serves the public interest. This assertion, made by Representative Jacob K. Javits, Republican-Liberal of New York, was coupled, however, with a warning that Government and business must cooperate to avoid a depression, or face a triumph of communism.

The rocket engine for the X-2, the experimental Bell airplane that is expected to exceed the records of the X-1 which Capt. Charles Yeager last year flew "many hundreds of miles faster than the speed of sound," will be built by the Curtiss-Wright Corporation at its Caldwell, N. J., plant.

WASHINGTON, April 6 (AP) -- A "secret" meeting of National League club owners and Baseball Commissioner Albert B. Chandler scheduled for tomorrow at the Mayflower Hotel was canceled temporarily today, hotel officials said.

The Lawyers Trust Company reported as of March 31, total deposits of $71,907,152 and total assets of $78,426,876, compared, respectively, with $77,738,783 and $84,301,543 on Dec. 31, 1948. Cash on hand and due from banks amounted to $22,301,241 against $25,548,139: holdings of United States Government securities to $39,564,935 against $42,109,914 and loans and discounts to $13,055,550 against $13,136,806.
PATERSON, N. J., April 6 (AP) -- A blind man who said he was 107 years old pleaded from a wheelchair today for the home in which he says he has lived for seventy-five years.
BOWIE, Md., April 6 (AP) -- Make Swing came back home to Maryland to suffer the first defeat of her young racing career today in the Bowie Kindergarten Stakes, which Eastern Flyway won handily.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 6 -- By contrast to yesterday when the course was closed because of rain, the fifty-eight selected stars, who will participate tomorrow in the first round of the Masters tourney, one of the top-flight golf events of the year, completed their final preparations in the sunshine over the windswept Augusta National Golf Club layout.
These are the green years of medical discovery, a fact that lends hope to the fight to con quer cancer. The problem of cancer is profound and complex.

Well-known members of society are serving on the patroness committee for the annual musicale in behalf of Knickerbocker Hospital which will be held tonight in the ballroom of the Colony Club under the auspices of the women's auxiliary of the hospital.

Pleas of not guilty were entered yesterday by counsel for twenty-one unlicensed members of the crew of the merchant vessel Flying Arrow as the Coast Guard resumed hearings of misconduct charges against the group. The crew members were alleged to have refused to proceed to sea at Manila and again at Singapore.
WASHINGTON, April 6 -- An employer's recognition of a union is not as positive as formal certification of the union, the National Labor Relations Board said today.
Theodore Olin Thackrey, editor and publisher of The New York Post Home News, resigned yesterday at the request of the directors of the New York Post Corporation, owner of the afternoon tabloid.
SYRACUSE, N. Y., April 6 (AP) -- Floyd B. Schwartzwalder, head football coach at Muhlenberg College since 1946, today was named gridiron mentor at Syracuse University.
Brooklyn acquired yesterday its first nutrition clinic to curb nutritional abnormalities in children.

ROME, April 6 -- The Soviet Government will close all its consulates in Italy on April 15, the Foreign Ministry announced today. The Hungarian Government will close its consulate in Milan on the same date.

Five Americans, two Frenchmen and an Englishman were decorated at Governors Island yesterday in ceremonies held in the Officers Club. The awards were made by Maj. Gen. Roscoe B. Woodruff, deputy First Army Commanding General, in the presence of his superior, Lieut. Gen. Walter Bedell Smith.

MOSCOW, April 6 -- The attention of the readers of Pravda was recalled today to the declaration of confidence made by Premier Stalin little more than five months ago that the peoples of the world would not allow themselves to be led into a third world war.

Fada Radio and Electric Company yesterday introduced an improved frequency modulation sound system as a feature of several television receivers in its 1949 television and radio line. The line was shown for the first time at a dealer meeting in the Park Sheraton Hotel.

WARSAW, April 6 -- The United Polish Workers (Communist) party has abandoned the "cell system" as a basic unit in its organization in favor of a system that will concentrate control and direction of the party apparatus in a smaller number of officials.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- Implications of "threats" and "pressure tactics" on the part of the American Legion in the interest of pensions for World War veterans caused a sharp flare-up before the House Veterans Affairs Committee today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 6 -In a deal comparable to that recently concluded by the American Tobacco Company, the General Mills Corporation has contracted to pay $10,000 a piece for fifty-two half-hour television films to be produced by Apex Pictures, a company headed by Jack Chertok, it was learned today from Apex.

Rated as one of the major events of the Broadway theatre season, "South Pacific," the new musical co-starring Mary Martin and Ezio Pinza, makes its local bow this evening at 8 o'clock at the Majestic Theatre.
Trading on the New York Cotton Exchange in cotton futures was moderately active yesterday, and final prices were 1 point higher to 6 points lower.

An unauthorized meeting of one hundred Brooklyn College students to protest the suspension on the campus of the Karl Marx Society was dampened yesterday. No sooner had the meeting got under way in Boylan Hall than a crew of maintenance men equipped with water buckets and mops started an unscheduled cleaning of the corridor that drove the students from the building.

SALT LAKE CITY, April 6 (AP) -- Further increases in railroad freight rates would retard development of the West's infant phosphate fertilizer industry, an Interstate Commerce Commission hearing was told today.

HOUSTON, Tex. -- Although the contrasts between Texas and Mexico, in all their visible aspects, are registered with stunning sharpness to airplane passengers as they cross the Rio Grande and afterward when they move about among the Mexican people, the impact of these differences strikes the homeward traveler even more powerfully when he returns to Houston.

A thirteen-year-old indiscretion by George Bernard Shaw, entitled "The Millionairess," was presented last night by the Dramatic Workshop of the New School at the President Theatre. Previous productions of the play in this country were by summer stock groups.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- President Truman declared tonight that he would not hesitate to use the atomic bomb again if it were necessary for the welfare of the United States and the democracies of the world. But, he said, he thought the Atlantic treaty would make such action unnecessary.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- Senate Republican chiefs made a plan today to broaden and heighten their long counter-attack upon the Truman Administration, a counter-attack seriously delaying much of the President's program.

Net income of the Texas Gas Transmission Corporation last year was $1,451,073, or 66 cents a share, compared with $1,124,207, or 51 cents, in 1947, according to the annual report being distributed today to stockholders by J. H. Hillman Jr., chairman, and W. T. Stevenson, executive vice president.

ST. LOUIS, April 6 (UP) -- Olympia, Fred Hooper's speedy 3-year-old who romped to impressive victories in the Flamingo, San Felipe Stakes and Experimental Free Handicap No. 1, today replaced Blue Peter as winter book favorite to win the Kentucky Derby.

Further diminution of urban population through expansion of highway systems will be shown by the 1950 population census, according to a forecast by Charles M. Upham, engineer-director, American Road Builders Association. The trend of decentralization is described by him as a movement that will grow year after year "if people have good safe arteries for traffic and personal transportation."

Passenger revenues of the municipal transit lines for the first eight months since the fares were increased on July 1, 1948, totaled $138,172,684, the Board of Transportation reported yesterday. Operation of the lines during the eight-month period produced revenue of $111,536,911 from subway and elevated lines and $26,635,773 from bus and street car lines.
WASHINGTON, April 6 -- White House architects and repair experts today were awaiting Congressional action, expected shortly, to begin the $5,400,000 renovation job requested by President Truman.

ATHENS, April 6 -- The rebel attack in the Western Grammos mountain area, evidently from bases in Albania, appeared today to have lost momentum and official quarters here expressed the opinion that the National Army would be able to deal a counter-blow within a few days.

Dr. Eugene Percy Roberts has practiced medicine in New York since 1894 when he was graduated from the old New York Homeopathic and Flower Hospital, now the New York Medical College Flower and Fifth Avenue Hospitals. In his eighty-first year he is still in practice and believes he is the oldest Negro doctor in the metropolitan area.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 6 -- Philip Murray, in a message read at the convention of the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union here today, challenged "unwarranted rumors and unfounded reports spread against the CIO and its policies."

The Schools Motion Picture Committee of the National Board of Review, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14, a group of motion pictures to be shown, tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- The Joint Chiefs of Staff of the three armed services will resume conferences on defense policy tomorrow with Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower at Key West. It was said today that Louis Johnson, Secretary of Defense, would join his top military officers at a later date, perhaps this week-end.

Pay increases for eighty-three employes, including three Tammany district leaders who hold top positions in the office, were among scores of "budget modifications" recently granted in the office of Borough President Hugo Rogers of Manhattan, it was learned yesterday.
Considerable damage, mostly of minor nature, was caused throughout the metropolitan area yesterday by uncommonly strong April winds.

Pan American Airway's Boeing Stratocruiser, the Clipper America, will take off from the New York International Airport at Idelwild late this afternoon with Governor Dewey and Mayor O'Dwyer at the top of the list of those who have accepted invitations for a flight around the New York area in the world's largest and fastest airplane.

Expressing confidence of success in nominating a fusion ticket for the city election, Charles H. Tuttle, chairman of the Inter-County Republican Committee for Return of Good Government to New York City, announced last night the formation of six subcommittees.

Whenever the Government begins to play openly with the idea of introducing a "two-price" system in any area of the economy it is time for the public to be on its guard. For "two-price" systems are in most cases merely a political device for making producers happy by guaranteeing them high prices while at the same time retaining the good-will of consumers by promising them the benefits of low prices.
Down in Greenwich Village, two exhibitions opening this week show abstraction and naturalism side by side.

The Board of Estimate sent back to the City Council yesterday for reconsideration the bill passed by that body on March 22 in an effort to place ceilings on rents and service fees charged by the 1,200 garages and 2,000 parking lots operating in the city.

Joseph William Cash, the wrong man who received the right discharge from the Navy in one of the strangest cases of mistaken identity, will appear in Brooklyn Federal Court today on a writ of habeas corpus for a determination of whether he is being held illegally in a Navy brig.

"Dedee," a French-made drama, starring Simone Signoret in the title role and Marcel Pagliero, which arrives at the Ambassador, is this morning's lone film newcomer. Yves Allegret directed from a story by Ashelbe. Bernard Blier, Dalio and Jane Marken are among the principals.

A pedestrian was seriously injured at 9:20 o'clock last night when a taxicab climbed a curb at Forty-third Street and the Avenue of the Americas after a collision with another cab and pinned him against a store front. It took a police emergency squad twenty minutes to free him.

MACON, Ga., April 7 -- Jackie Robinson and the Dodgers played here tonight before an overflow crowd of 6,532 white and Negro fans in a ball park that seats only 4,000 and the Brooks won their eighth straight game from minor league opposition, beating the Macon Peaches, 11 -- 2.
The Bank of the Manhattan Company has ben appointed paying agent in New York for a $5,571,000 debenture issue, maturing on May 15, 1955 to 1964, of the city of Edmonton, Alberta, Canada.

Today's events: Philharmonic-Symphony, Bruno Walter, conductor, Carnegie Hall, 2:30 o'clock; Gertrude Rennert, piano, Town Hall, 8:30; "Carmen," City Opera Company, City Center, 8:15; Chamber Music Concert, Juilliard School, 8:30; Queens Symphonic Society, Howard Shanet, conductor, Forest Hills High School, 8:30; Lois McKenzie, contralto, Judson Auditorium, 55 Washington Square South, 8:30; American People's Chorus, Elmer Bernstein, conductor, Yugoslav-American Hall, 405 West Forty-first Street, 8:30.

Now that furniture made of wrought iron and rattan is making its seasonal appearance in local stores, homemakers who have been planning to use such pieces indoors may begin to judge them for their dual roles. More and more furniture formerly associated only with summer settings is being designed for indoors the year round.

WASHINGTON, April 7 (AP) -- The State Department said tonight that it would release tomorrow information on "the urgent need" of some of the Atlantic pact countries for military assistance from the United States.

Discussing the military and strategic significance of the North Atlantic Security Pact, Gen. A G. L. McNaughton, Canadian delegate to the United Nations, hailed the pact yesterday as the answer to the North American defense problem presented by the Iron Curtain countries.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- The United Mine Workers welfare and retirement fund will make pensions of $100 a month available to miners at 60 years of age instead of 62 as heretofore, it was announced today.
About every generation the Big Show comes up with a performance of such reckless dare-deviltry that the circus family acclaims it as the "polyclinic act."

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 7 -- The congress of the People's Front of Yugoslavia, which is scheduled to convene Saturday in Belgrade, will be the scene of important political acts in relation to her struggle against the Communist Information Bureau.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- The National Labor Relations Board upheld unanimously today a trial examiner's finding that when 114 out of 115 employes quit individually within thirty-six hours their action constituted a strike under the Taft-Hartley Law.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, April 7 -- Earl O. Shreve, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States and a vice president of the General Electric Company, told the National Institute on Community Health today that he had heard no assertion that President Truman's proposed health insurance program would improve the quality of medical care.

CHICAGO, April 7 -- Grain prices swung wildly on the Board of Trade early, heavy short covering early and some increase in outside buying bringing about higher prices, but liberal profit-taking developed later, and the close was irregular with wheat 7/8 cent a bushel lower to 3/8 cent higher than yesterday.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., April 7 (AP) -- The Florida Supreme Court has voided a state fair trades law under which a manufacturer was allowed to set a minimum price for his product. The 1939 law was ruled unconstitutional by a 6-1 vote of the court.

Three officers of an apartment rental bureau, who were accused of "preying" on thousands of home seekers and allegedly mulcting them for $76,000 on unfulfilled promises to solve their housing problems were arraigned yesterday in Special Sessions.

Certificates of appointment were presented yesterday to members and former members of the Business Executives Advisory Committee of the city's Department of Commerce, at a luncheon in the New York Athletic Club.
Physical and health education may provide the best means for easing racial and religious tensions among school children, 200 education officials were told yesterday.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., April 7 -- The first-base situation on the Yankees entered a new and surprising phase today as Casey Stengel led his thirty-one-man squad out of town on the journey that will lead through Texas, Indiana and Ohio, on the way to the Stadium and the opening of the season, April 19.
NORWALK, Conn., April 7 (AP) -- A meeting of holders of bonds in the Norwalk Tire and Rubber Company, scheduled for Monday in the company's New York offices, has been canceled.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 7 -- Israeli authorities have promised to withdraw "immediately" from the position seized Tuesday in Syrian territory, Dr. Ralph J. Bunche, Acting United Nations Mediator on Palestine, said today before leaving Beirut for Rhodes on the first stage of his journey to New York.

The fourteen-story and penthouse apartment building at 912 Fifth Avenue, adjoining the northeast corner of Seventy-second Street, has been sold by the 912 Fifth Avenue Corporation to Frederick Brown, the latter reported yesterday.

LONDON, April 7 -- George Bernard Shaw had strong words for state and church censors "who never read plays" today, and proposed that their jobs be transferred to theatre managers and watch committees.

Justice William O. Douglas of the Supreme Court declared last night that "lasting peace" could be achieved only if the democracies regained the "initiative" from the Soviet Union in directing the forces of world unrest.

NEWARK, N. J., April 7 -- A proposed reduction in schedules of the Hudson Manhattan Railroad was postponed today until at least May 3, pending further hearings before the State Board of Public Utility Commissioners.

Richard H. Crowe "came clean" with the Federal Bureau of Investigation yesterday, and by nightfall the $690,000 in bonds that he stole, along with cash, from the vaults of the National City Bank on March 27 had been recovered.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- The Anglo-American Council on Productivity ended its second series of meetings today with the expressed conviction that a valuable two-way exchange of information and experience had been accomplished.

Predicting the continued vogue of short coiffures, Guillaume of Paris, who arrived this week from France, introduced three of his new brief hair styles yesterday at the Salon Lentheric, 673 Fifth Avenue. The first, the "Petal" design, showed the hair parted on the side, swirled smoothly across the back and brushed into clusters of short feathery curls at either side.

The Brooklyn Museum is making a move designed for a better understanding of the early arts and crafts of South America in the exhibition of antique furniture, silver, ironwork and religious painting to be opened with a private view for members today at 3 P. M.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- The way was cleared today for construction of a 48,000-ton superliner -- largest ever built in American shipyards -- through final agreement on costs reached between the Maritime Commission and the United States Lines. The vessel has been in the planning stage for three years.
DAMASCUS, Syria, April 7 -- The resignation of President Shukri El Kuwatly and Premier Khaled al-Azem was announced by Chief of State Husni Zayim at a press conference here today.

PARIS, April 7 -- French standards of living have undeniably improved after a year of the Marshall Plan, David Bruce, chief of the Economic Cooperation Administration mission to France, today told members of the Workers Force union in the Ministry of Economic Affairs.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on April 2 totaled 725,623 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 129,294 cars, or 21.7 per cent more than for the preceding week, 64,992 cars, or 9.8 per cent more than for the corresponding week of last year, and 10,464 cars, or 1.5 per cent more than during the corresponding week of 1947.

LONDON, April 7 -- A major trade union spokesman in the House of Commons, Mark Hewitson, warned the British Labor Government tonight that, unless it granted wage increases to workers whose living costs are slated to rise under the new. national budget, "there will be industrial disputes such as there have never been in this country since the end of the first World War."

DAMASCUS, Syria, April 7 -- Gen. Husni Zayim, Chief of State, announced today that he had been informed that Israeli authorities had decided to withdraw entirely the force of about 250 men that had penetrated a short distance into the No Man's Land on the Syrian frontier near the village of Kuna Iaba two days ago.

FORT WORTH, Tex., April 7 -- The Giants weathered quite a number of things today in a noble effort to hold their grip on the Indians. They shook off a homer, double and single by Manager Lou Boudreau. They belted Bob Feller for six runs inside of five innings.

No one will be surprised this morning to read that Richard Rodgers, Oscar Hammerstein 2d and Joshua Logan have written a magnificent musical drama. Even before they set pencil to paper and chose "South Pacific" for the title, alert theatre-goers very sensibly started to buy tickets for it.

Reporting on operations of Libby, McNeill Libby, food canners, for the fiscal year ended on Feb. 26, last, Daniel T. Creeden, president, informed shareholders yesterday that sales were the heaviest in its eighty-one-year history.
ATLANTA, April 7 (AP) -- Almost 200 Georgia teachers quit their classes today and urged thousands of others to join in a state-wide protest walkout.
WASHINGTON, April 7 (AP) -- President Truman's reappointment of Gov. Ernest Gruening of Alaska for a third term was approved today by the Senate Interior Committee.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- President Truman today nominated Stephen T. Early, press secretary to the late President Roosevelt and now vice president of the Pullman Company, to fill the new post of Under-Secretary of Defense.

Six youthful members of the Young Sportsmen, who told police that they organized their gang to halt juvenile group warfare in the East Bronx, appeared in Bronx County Court yesterday and received jail sentences or were placed on three years' probation.

Ohio State's Howard Rahm gained the leadership of the straight-rail division of the national intercollegiate billiard championship tournament by scoring two victories in the opening matches yesterday. After turning back Robert Whitman, Utah, 100 -- 57, he defeated Bob Eck of Cornell, 100 -- 91.
Mrs. Henry S. Pascal, member of the board of trustees of the Public Education Association, spoke last night against released time projects in week-day religious education.

ALBANY, April 7 -- The State Tax Commission announced today that taxpayers would have four additional days, until April 19, to file their 1948 state personal income and unincorporated business tax returns. This is the first blanket extension of time for filing in the history of the state income tax.

It was the United States Army itself that gracefully paved the way for the statement by Defense Secretary Johnson that the Army Day that we have observed this week would be the last of its kind. When the Army chose its slogan for the celebrations that have been going on this week it fixed on this: "The United States Army -- Part of the Team -- for Security!"

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- The Senate Expenditures Committee asserted today that it had put sharp restrictions on Presidential reorganization powers in order to shut off the demands for the exemption or special treatment of one agency or another of Government.

The Lehman Corporation as of March 31, the third quarter of its fiscal year, reported a net asset value of $47.24 a share, according to Robert Lehman, president, in a stockholders' pamphlet report released today. This compared with $46.57 on Dec. 31, and $50.22 a share on June 30 of last year.
Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora warned last night that if the national economy collapsed, the United States would be unable to help other countries combat communism.

WASHINGTON, April 7 (UP) -- A bill granting $10,000-a-year pay rises to Cabinet members and increasing the salaries of 114 other Federal executives was approved today by the House Post Office and Civil Service Committee.
The reverse of the usual incidents involving striking taxi drivers and non-strikers occurred yesterday in the Bronx when a picket was knocked down by a taxicab leaving a garage for the day's tour.

This is the season for the Open House, for the spring is the period in which it appears under various aliases and to serve various ends. The corporate Open House is the annual meeting of stockholders held in Flemington, N. J.
Undoubtedly you are familiar with the procession of shortcut "cures" to which desperate humanity has turned time and time again, and the tragedy of false hope that has ended them.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 7 -- Two new production projects, a baseball film and an African wild animal movie, were announced today by Republic Pictures. Herbert Kline, documentary producer, will make "The Cleveland Story," in which George Brent and the Cleveland baseball Indians will appear, while George Breakston and Yorke Coplen will do the animal film, which will be photographed in Central Africa, utilizing Republic's impounded sterling credits.
PARIS, April 7 (AP) -- Prince Aly Khan obtained a civil divorce today. Lawyers said it would be at least six weeks before he and Rita Hayworth, film actress, may marry.

Excavation work for the city's new Gansevoort market and meat center at Gansevoort and Washington Streets has been slowed by the presence of a subsurface old Dutch timber fort, Markets Commissioner Anthony Masciarelli said yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, April 7 -- The ad hoc Political and Security Committee of the United Nations General Assembly, after an afternoon of acid debate, today approved a proposal by the Little Assembly that the General Assembly consider the creation of a panel of conciliation and inquiry.

Lamb prices have gone beyond the levels of last week, when they hit the high point for the year. In fact, lamb chops are selling for more than they ever have, even during the period of skyrocketing meat costs following the end of price control.

DURING the Nineteen Twenties Gene Fowler was at one time the managing editor of The New York American and at another press agent for Tex Rickard. He loved both jobs and the New York of which they were a part, the New York of frenzied newspaper deadlines, sport, show business, crime and wonderfully raffish and wonderfully vital people.
THE NEW YORK TIMES of Feb. 27 carried an interview with the Norwegian Minister of Trade, Erik Brofoss.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, April 7 (AP) -- Unseeded Miss Barbara Scofield of San Francisco upset second-ranked Miss Nancy Chaffee of Ventura, Calif., today to gain the final round of the Coral Beach tennis tournament. The scores were 6 -- 1, 6 -- 0.
LAKE SUCCESS, April 7 -- The Soviet Union began an attack in the United Nations today against the North Atlantic security pact.

ALBANY, April 7 -- The Public Service Commission today ordered the Surface Transportation Corporation, which provides bus tranportation for all of the Bronx and part of Manhattan, to overhaul its operating schedules so as to cut down overcrowding, particularly in rush hours.

Business loans by banks in this area dropped $116,000,000 last week for the largest weekly decline since the end of the war. The reduction, according to the figures of the reporting New York City member banks, issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, brought the total of such loans outstanding at the close of the week ended on Wednesday to $5,322,000,000, the lowest point since last Aug. 4.
WASHINGTON, April 7 (AP) -- Housing Expediter Tighe E. Woods today ordered rent controls removed from 17,985 dwellings in six scattered states.

Top quality brands of imported spirits and wines are making substantial sales gains throughout the country at the expense of lesser known imports, I. M. Bomba, vice president of Schieffelin Co., declared yesterday at the company's annual convention of the import division in the Statler Hotel.

SALZBURG, Austria, April 7 -- A West German army could be raised to fight under United States high command against Soviet Russia, according to testimony of nine unnamed German generals to be quoted tomorrow in the Salzburg monthly Berichte Und Informationen.

Several days ago this newspaper carried an account of one of the longest and most hazardous rescue flights yet attempted by the Coast Guard. To pick up Private Kenneth W. Collier Jr., an 18-year-old soldier from Urbana, Ohio, whose appendix had burst and who was in urgent need of immediate hospitalization, the Coast Guard sent a flying boat from its base in San Francisco to the Army transport Gen. A. W. Creely.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- Vice Admiral Alan G. Kirk, American Ambassador to Belgium, was reported today to be under serious consideration for appointment as Ambassador to the Soviet Union. However, President Truman said at his news conference that he had not decided on a choice for the post.

Many residents of the Pierrepont Hotel at 55 Pierrepont Street in the Brooklyn Heights section of Brooklyn were roused from slumber early yesterday morning by a fire in a room on the fifteenth floor. The fire was discovered at 5:15 A. M. by Thomas Shoemaker, the occupant of the room, who was just then returning to it after visiting friends on the same floor of the seventeen-story structure.

LONDON, April 7 -- Portugal's Premier, Dr. Antonio de Oliveira Salazar, appealed today for the inclusion of Spain in the North Atlantic pact to make the alliance a more effective defense measure against an aggressor.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- President Truman said today in a message to Prime Minister Attlee of Great Britain that the countries taking part in the European Recovery Program had completed a year of great accomplishment and that the United States was proud of its part in it.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- Action of the House Judiciary Committee in approving the Gossett-Lodge bill gave hope today that Congress would get its first real opportunity to consider and vote on a new method of electing Presidents.

TOKYO, March 31 -- Japan is about to begin a check-up on her "ghost" population, probably numbering more than 1,000,000. The group exists, apparently, for the purpose of drawing government rations but can not be found in the flesh.

LONDON, April 7 -- The Labor party was holding a formidable lead in the early returns in the London County Council elections here this morning. Soon after midnight, returns from six of twenty-six boroughs showed that Labor had won fifteen Council seats against the Conservatives' three.
Daylight saving time will go into effect at 2 A. M. Sunday, April 24, but the number of communities using it will be somewhat smaller than last year, The Associated Press reported yesterday.

Development of international finance will prove to be the foundation of world government and cooperation, Benjamin Strong, president of the United States Trust Company of New York, told the ninth annual forum on Current Economic and Social Trends at Town Hall yesterday.
PHILADELPHIA, April 7 (AP) -- A jury of six women and six men awarded $6,000 damages today to a Philadelphia woman and her husband as a result of a derailment of a Reading Company train.

While it is necessary to conserve currency in foreign countries, some assurance should be given to American producers that eventual payment of frozen funds will be made, it was declared last night by Ellis Arnell, former Governor of Georgia.

The Right Rev. William T. Manning, retired Protestant Episcopal Bishop of New York, was decorated yesterday as Grand Commander of the Order of the Phoenix, one of Greece's highest awards, for services to his "church, country and all of humanity."
Governor Dewey ordered yesterday that a special election for Representative in the Twentieth Congressional District be held on May 17 to fill the vacancy caused by the death of Sol Bloom.

LONDON, April 7 -- Samuel Reber, United States deputy, proposed today that the Austrian treaty conference be adjourned for two weeks over the Easter holiday to give the deputies a chance to "rest and reflect" and to consult their Governments.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- Plentiful food for consumers and assured incomes for farmers were announced as the aim of the new long-range farm program, presented by Secretary of Agriculture Charles F. Brannan today at a joint meeting of House and Senate Agriculture Committees.

COLUMBIA, S. C., April 7 (UP) -- Manager Billy Southworth tonight denied a Boston columnist's report that the Braves are split with dissension, but admitted that the club held a meeting today to straighten out its listless play.
It's cherry blossom time in Central Park. The Department of Parks issued this bulletin yesterday, along with the news that the pink-blossomed trees are two weeks ahead of last year's flowering.

For two weeks Federal agents of the Alcohol Tax Unit had under surveillance a barn at 114 Healey Avenue, Inwood, L. I. They watched as men carried into the structure an assortment of material, including brass piping, several hundred five-gallon cans, 100-pound bags of sugar, a quantity of mash and huge vats.

Edward J. Shaughnessy, district director of the Immigration and Naturalization Service, took over the important New York area on March 15 with the declaration that there was nothing secretive about the department that guards the country's gates -- that it was no Gestapo, no NKVD.
COLORADO SPRINGS, Col., April 7 (AP) -- Miss Yvonne Sherman of New York took the lead today in the United States women's figure skating championships.

LONDON, April 7 -- Price setbacks in cinema, brewery and chain store shares provided the city's first reaction to the announcement by Chancellor of the Exchequer, Sir Stafford Cripps, of a continued austerity budget. In the stock market here today the floor of the Exchange was crowded with members well before the official opening.

Operating under official approval, the United States Military Government German Exposition opens at 10 o'clock tomorrow morning with more than 500 manufacturers from Western Germany showing a wide variety of wares in the Museum of Science and Industry, 30 Rockefeller Plaza.

In your issue of March 30 Eveline M. Burns, president of the Consumer's League of New York for Fair Labor Standards, expresses her views with respect to the Mailler-Condon bill providing non-occupational disability benefits for New York State workers.

Because of the increasing age level of the population, with its concomitant increase in chronic disease and disability, the general hospital of the future must play a more important role both in the prevention of disease and the rehabilitation of patients, Dr. Howard A. Rusk declared last night.

CHICAGO, April 7 -- Officials of several investment companies holding blocks of stock in Montgomery Ward Co. said today they would vote for the re-election as a director of Sewell L. Avery, chairman and chief executive of the merchandising company.

Mohawk Carpet Mills, Inc., yesterday withdrew twenty patterns in four axminster carpet grades from its running lines. Francis I. Monahan, vice president for sales, said that the discontinued merchandise in the hands of the mill and its distributors will be sold at discounts from 10 to 12 1/2 per cent in line with established policy on dropped patterns.
Nardis of Dallas, Inc., women's sportswear manufacturer, to J. B. Taylor, Inc., Dallas Newspapers, consumer magazines and radio.

CANAAN, Conn., April 7 -- Ezra Winter, 63-year-old mural painter whose best known work is the huge "Fountain of Youth" that decorates the foyer of the Radio City Music Hall in New York, killed himself this afternoon in a woods near his studio.
LAKE SUCCESS, April 7 -- Poland accused the press and radio in the Western countries today of abetting the "cold war" with the Soviet bloc by deliberately distorting news and by "war-mongering."

Selling by producer interests and overnight liquidation reduced sharply the price of coffee futures on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday. New low records were established for the life of the current contracts with the exception of the spot months.

The Beethoven Festival of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, under Bruno Waiter's direction, continued last night at Carnegie Hall with a program which opened with excerpts from the Bonn master's "Die Geschoepfe des Prometheus," and also contained his Fifth and Sixth Symphonies.

Lower prices on lead products were posted yesterday by leading producers, reflecting the 1-cent drop in pig lead prices Wednesday. National Lead Company reduced prices of lead sheets and pipe 1 cent to 20 cents a pound, and lead traps and bends formerly sold at list plus 55 per cent were repriced at list plus 53 per cent.

It does appear that the American lyric theatre has acquired a double bill of two short operas of native origin which have a genuine entertainment value. They are the little operas, the one a comedy, the other a melodrama of Gian-Carlo Menotti given last night in the City Center of Music and Drama.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- President Truman made it clear today that he did not intend that the cost of helping arm the North Atlantic defensive alliance should be paid out of his proposed $41,900,000,000 national budget for the 1950 fiscal year.

Making good their recent pledge to combat the present Israeli regime and Zionism, United States Communists are now accusing Israel's Government of having become a tool of the United States and having betrayed Jewish interests, according to recent issues of the Morning Freiheit, Communist Yiddish newspaper.

The controversy over the proposed sale of the Farnsworth Television and Radio Corporation to the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation moved yesterday toward a climax as Senator Homer E. Capehart, Republican, of Indiana, and Robert W. Kenny, former Attorney General of California, voiced opposing recommendations.

PARIS, April 7 -- In his statement last night that the atomic bomb would again be used if necessary, president Truman went about as far as He could to assure Europe of quick United States action under the North Atlantic pact in case of aggression, in the opinion of authorized circles here.

HALIFAX, N. S., April 7 (Canadian Press) -- Canadian Seamen's Union officials said today that thirty-one ships were tied up in the deep-sea shipping strike called a week ago because East Coast operators had signed a bargaining agreement with a rival union.

THE presentation here of the Saga of Smiley Johnson apparently stirred up considerable activity among the letter-writers. The most authoritative of these came from Warren Eckel of Kew Gardens, a comrade-in-arms, who contributed a few extra flourishes to the touching story of the Green Bay Packer guard whose death on Iwo Jima shocked the entire Marine Corps.

ALBANY, April 7 -- New rules governing the supply of gas to new customers for heating homes, factories, offices and stores were announced today by the Public Service Commission. For some areas, mostly upstate, they ease existing restrictions. In others, present restrictions are continued.

MEXICO CITY, April 7 -- An Interior Ministry official said today the Mexican Government had authorized the sale of the Dec. 25 Mexican sweepstake tickets after a bond of 1,000,000 pesos was posted by International Sweepstakes, SA (Incorporated) to guarantee the payment of all prizes.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- The Foreign Secretaries of the United States, Britain and France reached an agreement in principle today on the control regulations and basic law for the three zones of Western Germany.

PARIS, April 7 -- The probable resignation or ousting of Generalissimo Francisco Franco by the end of the year was predicted here today by Trifon Gomez, secretary general of the exiled Spanish Socialist Labor movement. He said that the present economic condition of Spain was "catastrophic."

BOWIE, Md., April 7 (AP) -- The Bedford Stable's Dry and I. G. Schorsch's Bad Light won the feature races today. In the fifth event Dry turned a mile and seventy yards in 1:44 4/5, while Bad Light required one second longer for the same route in the sixth.

LONDON, April 7 -- Figures released here today by the Office of the Economic Cooperation Administration showed that during February $273,100,000 was authorized for the purchase of commodities and services for participants in the European Recovery Program.
John D. Rockefeller 3d announced last night that labor this year would share in the leadership and participate more actively in the affairs of the Greater New York Fund.
WASHINGTON, April 7 -- The Administration's soldiers and its economists are now involved in a basic controversy over the proposed military arms program for Western Europe.

PHILADELPHIA, April 7 -- The musical library of Francis Hopkinson, poet, signer of the Declaration of Independence and early American composer, has been presented to the library of the University of Pennsylvania, it was announced today.
GUATEMALA, April 7 (UP) -- The Government said today that it had rushed Army and Air Force units to the Mexican border area to suppress "subversive" groups.
EFFINGHAM, Ill., April 7 (AP) -- Officials of fire-ravaged St. Anthony's Hospital tonight set the toll at seventy-four as diggers in the ruins neared the end of their search.

The Board of Estimate now begins its hearings on the Mayor's proposed executive budget of $1,179,026,930. Of this budget, which represents an increase of $17,266,422 over the current year, Mayor O'Dwyer said in his message: "Each and every request submitted was carefully studied. Every item of questionable utility was eliminated. Only those deemed most essential remain.

PHOENIX, Ariz., April 7 -- The problem of education was appraised today as the root of all other problems confronting Indians of the Southwest, whose representatives concluded their first regional conference here with the resolve to press a new campaign for Indian betterment.

"Inside New York," WMCA's series which analyzes the weaknesses in the city's services, concludes its programs for the season on April 15 with a dramatization entitled "A Package for You." The program, which will be heard from 9:30 to 10 P. M., will summarize the findings of the season's programs in the fields of health, schools, crime, hospitals and psychiatric care.
LANCHOW, China, April 7 -- Two Moslem generals, whose armies control northwest China, say that there is no hope of peace and that they will fight on against the Communists.

HOUSTON, Tex. -- Texas is booming with the production of land crops, steel, chemicals and the direct mineral yields of the earth, and public spending for necessities and luxuries is sustained despite a high-price level. But, though the "old" fortunes here were made in building, cotton and ranching, the national tax structure now allows only one way for a citizen to become a "new" millionaire.

Arbitration of the issues of a wage review between Atlantic and Gulf Coast steamship operators and the Masters, Mates and Pilots, AFL, will begin Monday in the offices of the American Arbitration Association, 9 Rockefeller Plaza. David L. Cole of Paterson, N. J., will preside as chairman of a committee that includes himself and two men from each faction.

CHICAGO, April 7 -- Senator Scott W. Lucas, Democrat, of Illinois, asserted tonight that Republican leadership in the Senate "must assume the responsibility for striking the dagger into the heart of civil rigts."

ROME, April 7 -- The announcement in Lake Success only three days after the Atlantic treaty had been signed that Italian hopes had suffered a serious setback as a result of an Anglo-American agreement on the final disposal of pre-Fascist Italian colonies has made a most painful impression in Italy.

AMMAN, Transjordan, April 7 (UP) -- King Abdullah of Transjordan predicted today that the current political situation in the Middle East might force the creation of a greater Syria, combining such states as Transjordan, Syria and Iraq.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, April 7 -- Turkey can be counted upon to participate actively on the side of the Western Allies in any future war with the Soviet Union, according to Abidin Daver, the country's leading military analyst. His declaration, the most bluent yet made on the subject of an authoritative public figure here, appeared in the form of a front-page commentary published in Cumhuriyet, Turkey's largest newspaper.
WASHINGTON, April 7 -- James Forrestal, former Secretary of Defense, is under treatment for nervous and physical exhaustion, it was disclosed today.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 7 -- The eighth biennial convention of the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union today sought "direct answers" from Philip Murray, national president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, to four questions.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- Treaties specifically protecting new American investments abroad, to supplement government guarantees of these investments, were urged today in a study of Point Four of the President's development program, made public by Representative Christian A. Herter, Republican, of Massachusetts.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- Department store sales in the week ended April 2 were 8 per cent above sales in the corresponding week of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The following lists percentage changes from like periods of 1948:

WASHINGTON, April 7 (AP) -- The House voted funds today to strengthen the "Voice of America," intensify the anti-subversive drive of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, and pay America's share of the cost of running the United Nations.

NANKING, April 7 -- Acting President Li Tsung-jen waited today for the return of Premier Gen. Ho Ying-chin from Canton before submitting a formal reply to the Communist ultimatum demanding that he agree to the incorporation of Nationalist troops into the Communist "people's liberation army" by Saturday.
PHILADELPHIA, April 7 (AP) -- A Federal court ruled today that a New Jersey stevedore is entitled to 50 per cent in a mechanical device for loading grain on ships.

Family counseling, now offered only by private agencies, should be a government responsibility, "available as a right to all who have need of it," according to Miss Frances Taussig, executive director of the Jewish Family Service, and one of the country's leading social workers.

It seems unfortunate that the great part of the discussions of the North Atlantic Treaty center on its anti-aggression features, beginning with Article 3. While at this stage of the so-called cold war these provisions may appear to have special importance, it is the opinion of the writer that greater hopes for lasting peace are to be found in the words of Article 2.

Purchase of 1,580,000 television receivers this year is almost certain but as many as 2,170,000 sets may be sold by the industry if it improves selling techniques, Frank Mansfield sales research director, Sylvania Electric Products, Inc., declared yesterday.
The Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York was chided gently yesterday by Charles F. Kettering, the inventor, for being "agin" too many things.

Morton Krouse, a portly pianist with a yearning for the subway brand of chewing gum and chocolate, retrieved yesterday in Small Claims Court the 46 cents he lost a penny at a time since last September in underground platform vending machines that failed to deliver the goods.
New Jersey brewers declined yesterday to send their trucks into New York on the ground that to do so would expose their drivers to injury at the hands of striking brewery workers here.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 7 -- As a result of efforts of the Communist Information Bureau to apply a stranglehold upon Yugoslavia and to reduce commerce with this country to a point where internal economy suffers, Belgrade has turned Westward to build up its foreign trade.

Plans of a group of commercial banks here for the establishment of a high-speed, automatic tele-printer network, linking their offices with those of more than one hundred banks in thirty-seven cities throughout the nation, have been virtually completed, it was learned yesterday.
ECCLESHALL, Eng., April 7 (AP) -- A Magistrates' court decided today to close a school whose boys and girls discussed sex and entered each other's bedrooms at night.

TEL AVIV, Israel, April 7 -- For the first time since the Arabs started their exodus from Israel in panic, their own leaders appealed to them today to stay where they were. An urgent appeal, which originated from the Ramallah radio controlled by King Abdullah of Transjordan, pleaded with the Arabs in the "triangle area" not to abandon their homes, as hundreds of thousands of others had done.

LAKE SUCCESS, April 7 -- A move to put the treason trial of Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty, Roman Catholic Primate of Hungary, on the agenda of the United Nations General Assembly was approved today by the General, or steering, Committee.

Action by the Board of Estimate yesterday in approving a temporary construction easement incidental to the erection of the Hunt's Point Sewage Treatment Works at Ryawa Avenue and Whittier Street, the Bronx, advanced one phase of the city's program for reducing the pollution of the waters around New York.
BERLIN, April 7 (UP) -- Lord Mayor Ernst Reuter of Western Berlin said today that the United States Government had assured him that "we will not be delivered" to communism.

CHICAGO, April 7 -- President Truman said today in a message to the convention of Americans for Democratic Action that he was not worried over "petty and temporary victories by obstructionists" fighting the program on which he was elected last year.

SPRINGFIELD, Mo., April 7 (AP) -- A Federal court jury tonight awarded $51,428.56 in damages to Mickey Owen, former Dodger catcher, in his counter suit against Jorge Pasquel, former Mexican Baseball League president. Pasquel's claims were turned down.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- The Veterans of Foreign Wars of the United States joined the American Legion today in urging Congress to include some 18,000,000 veterans of World War II in any pension plan designed to benefit the veterans of World War I.

MOSCOW, April 7 -- As more consumers' goods become available in the Moscow market there has been an increasing spread of advertising in the newspapers and magazines, on billboards, occasionally on the radio and even by direct mail.

Msgr. John O'Grady, secretary of the National Conference of Catholic Charities, warned last night against too much government control in the social welfare feld. He told a Brooklyn audience of 100 workers that there should be a greater amount of volunteer personal service among the needy.

LAKE SUCCESS, April 7 -- Jean Chauvel, French representative in the United Nations General Assembly's Political Committee, said today that Part of Eritrea should be ceded to Ethiopia "as a reparation for the past and a guarantee for the future," but he proposed that the remainder of Eritrea, together with Italian Somaliland and all of Libya, should be returned to Italy under a United Nations trusteeship.
WASHINGTON, April 7 -- During the week ended April 6, member bank reserve balances increased $292,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

The Atlantic pact sets bounds to the physical area that the signatories mean to defend against aggression, but it also gives the West the opportunity of taking the initiative in cultural, social and economic areas, Lester B. Pearson, Canadian Secretary of State for External Affairs, declared last night.

Gabriel Banat, violinist, born in Rumania twenty-two years ago, made his American debut in recital at Town Hall last night. The performance featured the Sonata No. 3 in A minor by Georges Enesco with the composer, who has been appearing as accompanist in his own works hereabouts of late, assisting at the piano.

The Chancery Office of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York announced yesterday preliminary plans to hold on Sunday, May 1, at the Polo Grounds, a special service of prayer and protest against religious persecution behind the iron curtain of Soviet Russia and its satellites.

Rose Schneiderman, who will retire at the end of this month after thirty-one years as president of the New York Women's Trade Union League, is proud of her part in two historic strikes. In 1909-10 she threw her energies into the cause of the women waistmakers, raising funds, making speeches, helping defend arrested strikers.
EAST LANSING, Mich., April 7 (AP) -- The end of the reign of the University of Wisconsin as team champion of the NCAA boxing tournament was almost assured tonight.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- A head-on collision between the European Recovery Program and Administration plans for rearming Western democracies under the North Atlantic alliance seriously jeopardized today prospects of the full $5,580,000,000 for a second Marshall Plan installment.

The week-old taxicab strike dwindled yesterday to little more than the grinding of one overworked mimeograph machine, on which the Taxi Workers Organizing Committee of John L. Lewis' United Mine Workers turned out denunciations of the police and called for Mayor O'Dwyer's defeat in any future political contest.

BUENOS AIRES, April 7 -- Beginning May 1, the Peron regime expects to go on the air daily with short-wave broadcasts. The undertaking is similar in concept and intention to the Voice of America. Argentina's "Voice" will concentrate on the United States and Brazil. Russia will be by-passed.
CHICAGO, April 7 (AP) -- A conference on displaced persons today recommended simplification of administrative procedures to get a DP into this country.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were moderately active yesterday and final prices were 1 point lower to 30 points higher, with the strength most pronounced in the distant months.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- First direct steps toward starting the Truman civil rights program through the Eighty-first Congress were taken today. Hearings on proposed legislation designed to outlaw the poll tax as a requirement for voting in Federal elections were scheduled to begin on Tuesday before a House subcommittee on administration.
Textile exporters here requested the State Department yesterday to urge the Cuban Government to postpone the effective date of the new restrictions on imports of American textiles for sixty days.

LAKE SUCCESS, April 7 -- The renewed fighting in the Grammos Mountain region of Greece has produced in the past few days a new series of charges and countercharges in the United Nations by Greece and her northern neighbors.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- Raymond M. Foley, Federal Housing and Home Finance Administrator, declared today that adoption of the Administration's 1,050,000-unit low-rent housing program would set up "a most effective bulwark against the inroads of socialism or communism."

The crowded schedule of sealed-bid-and-deadline financing transactions scheduled for Monday and Tuesday of next week is being felt in underwriting circles days ahead of the bidding. Three major utility bond issues are coming up -- $10,000,000 of Ohio Public Service Company bonds on Monday, and $50,000,000 of Commonwealth Edison debentures and $25,000,000 of Bell Telephone of Pennsylvania debentures on Tuesday.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 7 -- A strong wind bothered most of the fifty-eight players in the opening round of the thirteenth annual Masters tournament over the Augusta National Golf Club course today. But it failed to affect the efforts of Lloyd Mangrum of Niles, Ill., at the moment the leading money-winner of the campaign.

Trading on the New York Stock Exchange slowed yesterday and prices closed irregularly lower. Selected industrial issues paced the decline as transfers, smallest in more than a week, totaled only 840,000 shares, compared with 930,000 shares on Wednesday.

DETROIT, April 7 -- A countrywide increase in perils for motorists on the highways was revealed today through a car age summary by the Automobile Manufacturers Association. The results showed that almost 13,000,000 passenger cars and 2,400,000 trucks, or more than a third of the motor vehicles now in service, were more than ten years old.

The next twenty-four hours will give the weather man his final opportunity to ruin the week-end for the thousands of trout fishermen who are planning to embark on their traditional opening day trip to the trout streams in New York.
GENEVA, April 7 -- Russia has asked the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe to consider the problem of unemployment in Western Europe at its fourth session in Maj.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., April 7 -- Counsel for the State of Rhode Island charged today that the United Electric Railways Company, which is seeking an increase in fares has "utterly failed to prove it is entitled to relief."
ATHENS, April 7 (AP) -- The General Staff indicated today that the Greek Army had pulled the teeth of the guerrilla offensive in the Grammos Mountains.

Communist plans for "colonizing" the General Electric jet airplane-engine plant at Lynn, Mass., and other key industrial plants, were described at yesterday's session of the Communist trial. Herbert A. Philbrick, an advertising man who spent nine years in the Boston Communist movement as a "contact" for the Federal Bureau of Investigation, linked the "colonizing" with a post-war program for concentration of party "activists" in war industries.

The French Provincial influence in furniture and decorative fabrics comes to the fore in new furnishings introduced by Macy's yesterday in model rooms on the store's ninth floor as well as in small settings on the seventh floor.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today ratified the appointment by Judge Harold M. Kennedy of the Federal District Court of two trustees for the Long Island Rail Road Company, but denied ratification of a third trustee.

ALBANY, April 7 -- Edwin F. Jaeckle, former Republican state chairman, was appointed today by Governor Dewey as a member of the Law Revision Commission. He will serve out the unexpired term of Glen R. Bedenkapp, another former Republican state chairman, who was named recently as a member of the Public Service Commission.

New York's "flying cops" are a sturdy crew. Based in a hangar on the windswept flats of Floyd Bennett Field in Brooklyn, the Police Department's Aviation Bureau operates on a round-the-clock schedule, in fair weather or foul, patroling the skyways and performing heroic life-saving missions.

In the special legislative committee report on the cost of abating stream and harbor pollution in New York, the state has an excellent blueprint for undertaking a task that is long past due. Here in New York City we will not be unduly surprised at the committee's finding that sewage treatment works costing $180,000,000 are needed in our five boroughs.
WASHINGTON, April 7 (AP) -- Cornelius Vanderbilt Whitney of New York won Senate confirmation today as Under-Secretary of Commerce.

ATHENS, April 7 -- Alexander Dalietos, Greek representative to the United Nations Special Committee on the Balkans, charged before an opening meeting of the committee here today that Albania was overtly assisting the Greek guerrillas in the current military operations in the Grammos Mountain area.
Mose Rauzin's 7-year-old Buzfuz was much too rough a customer for Greentree Stable's Capot to handle in the latter's 1949 debut at Jamaica yesterday.

Harold Sumner, 34 years old, of 1067 Colgate Avenue, the Bronx, was fined $250 yesterday in the Court of Special Sessions, Long Island City, Queens, after pleading guilty to one count of an information charging him with rent gouging.

CHICAGO, April 7 -- The Department of Higher Education of the National Education Association called on the Federal Government today to aid the states in financing public elementary and secondary education, to establish a state-controlled national scholarship program, and to set aside $1,000,000 to study the best methods of administering these projects.

One of the most intensive aerial searches in recent months was under way at dawn today for a derelict schooner believed to have two small children locked in her cabin, the Coast Guard here announced early this morning.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., April 7 -- Beginnings of "muscle flexing" by a no longer passive buyer promises a severe test of advertising as a sustaining force of free enterprise economy, members of the American Association of Advertising Agencies were told here today at the first general session of a three-day annual meeting in the Greenbrier Hotel.

ALBANY, April 7 -- Governor Dewey approved today without comment a bill introduced by Assemblywoman Maude Ten Eyck of Manhattan designed to combat thefts and racketeering on New York City's waterfront.

While waiting for Albert Camus to send them his new play, "La Corde" ("The Halter"), Robert Whitehead and Oliver Rea have obtained the dramatic rights to Ludwig Lewisohn's novel, "The Case of Mr. Crump." The producers are planning to have it dramatized in time for a production during the 1950-51 season.

TRENTON, N. J., April 7 -- The traditional academic trilogy, the three R's, gave way today to the three B's -- baseball, barbering and bricklaying -- for 750 students at Trenton Catholic Boys High School.

MOSCOW, April 7 -- In an important review of the twenty-third volume of the collected works of Lenin, Izvestia, the Government newspaper, today quoted extensively from his essay on just and unjust wars.

A program of ten rowing regattas has been arranged for members of the Eastern College Athletic Conference this spring, Commissioner Asa S. Bushell announced yesterday. The schedule will get under way April 23 with the Compton Cup and Blackwell Cup races.

The Rev. Dr. Adam Clayton Powell Sr., pastor-emeritus of the Abyssinian Baptist Church, 132 West 138th Street, announced yesterday plans for a child guidance center that will be opened this fall at 24-26 Morningside Avenue under a trained personnel to combat child delinquency in the West Harlem-Manhattanville area.

Coroview Realty, Inc., has purchased the taxpayer property at 102-43 to 102-55 Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills, from Martin Fisher and Bernard Stoljenberg. The property occupies a plot 103 by 101 feet and is assessed at $140,000. Sale was subject to a mortgage of $103,400.

New York University opened the defense of its Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference title by defeating City College, 5 -- 3, at Ohio Field yesterday. The Violet runs, none of which was earned, all were scored in the third inning, when Coach Bill McCarthy's charges combined four of their six hits with a walk and two Lavender errors.

JERSEY CITY, N. J., April 7 -- The case of the "magic ballot box," an open drum that every four years since 1917, with one exception, has produced top place on the ballot for the Democratic slate of candidates for the city commission, will be presented to the Hudson County grand jury tomorrow by Superior Court Judge William Brennan.

The five-story apartment building at 1775 Bryant Avenue, the Bronx, accommodating twenty-six families, has been sold by Anna Altman to Max Friedman. The property, on plot 50 by 100 feet, is assessed at $65,000. It was sold for cash above a mortgage of $39,000.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- The American Federation of Labor today proposed specific steps be taken shortly to form a new global labor federation to replace the Communist-dominated World Federation of Trade Unions.

Thirteen local public housing authorities borrowed $22,356,000 on issues of temporary loan notes under the Federal Housing Administration program at interest rates ranging from 0.95 per cent to 0.98 per cent. The notes, dated May 31, 1949, will mature variously on Nov. 10, 1949, and on Feb. 10, 1950.

CHICAGO, April 8 -- Grain markets showed a heavy undertone on the Board of Trade today. At no time were the prices of wheat, corn or oats more than a small fraction above the finish of the previous day, and the close was about the day's bottom.
FRANKFORT, Germany, April 8 (AP) -- Only six of the forty-three Germans sentenced to death in 1946 for the Malmedy massacre actually will go to the gallows.
CHICAGO, April 8 (AP) -- Secretary of Treasury John W. Snyder predicted today America may be entering "one of the greatest periods of business development in our history."

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, April 8 (U.P.) -- Great Britain, France, Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg agreed tonight on a sweeping plan for the defense of Western Europe and on means of carrying it out.
