Frans Vroons, young Dutch tenor from the Amsterdam Opera, made his debut with the New York Opera Company as Don Jose in "Carmen," last night at the City Center. Marko Rothmueller sang Escamillo for the first time at this performance.

Wearing their full-dress uniforms here for the first time since World War II, the 2,200 cadets of the United States Military Academy at West Point will feature New York's last Army Day parade this afternoon.

The regional office of the Bureau of Labor Statistics, of which Robert R. Behlow is director, made its files available yesterday so that the data alleged by the Soviet press to describe the economic situation in the United States could be checked.

"How Secure These Rights?" by Ruth G. Weintraub, a report on anti-Semitism and discrimination against other minority groups, will be published on April 21 by Doubleday. The report is based on material assembled by B'nai B'rith.

TOKYO, April 8 -- Premier Shigeru Yoshida today sharply warned the heads of Government departments to stop delaying the slash in public payrolls that the administration was planning as part of its economy program under the Allied nine-point plan for Japanese economic rehabilitation.
Heavy demands for Easter finery are pushing retail store sales here ahead of last year for the season, a check of larger department and specialty stores disclosed yesterday.
FORT DIX, N. J., April 8 -- A military court handed down today a directed verdict of not guilty, for lack of sufficient evidence, on two counts in the court martial of Lieut. Col. Paul Graves.

Sharing gains from labor-saving suggestions and equipment installations can remove much of the friction between management and labor, and bulwark the private enterprise system, J. W. Nickerson, consultant, of Bigelow, Kent, Willard Co., New York and Boston management engineers and accountants, told more than seventy-five members of the Northern New Jersey Chapter of the Society for Advancement of Management at their monthly meeting at the Essex Hotel, Newark, last night.
Functional summer fashions for young people was the idea behind the show held yesterday at Bonwit Teller.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- The Census Bureau estimated today that the number of persons employed full time -- thirty-five hours or more a week -- increased by 313,000 in March over February, but the total was 1,596,000 below March, 1948.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- Sharp Dohme, Inc., Philadelphia, has filed a registration statement covering 208,373 shares of no par value common stock that is to be offered to the public, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today.

Seventeen million calls are now received yearly by the New York Telephone Company's weather forecast service, whose tenth anniversary was marked yesterday in the company's "weather bureau" at 435 West Fiftieth Street. Six million calls were averaged annually in the early years of the service's operation.

The long-threatened beer drought was on yesterday in a dozen Manhattan taverns as a result of the strike by 6,200 employes of thirteen major breweries. Mark Scanlan, executive secretary of the United Restaurant Liquor Dealers of Manhattan, Inc., an association of 1,200 bars, said he had received that bad news from members yesterday.

One of the largest bedroom furniture manufacturers in the country is offering discontinued suites to stores at a 20 per cent discount, retailers reported yesterday. They said this was the first "closeout" by a primary source involving more than a 5 per cent discount since before the war.

Patience didn't pay off for three young thugs yesterday. They waited for sixty minutes in a Brooklyn transportation company office for a $1,500 payroll that never came -- and departed with $5 taken from the cashier, leaving behind four tied-up employes.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- The question of postal rates for second-class mail matter, which includes newspapers and periodicals, will be threshed out in a conference of Senators and the representatives of publishers and the Post Office Department, under tentative plans approved here today.

Details of a proposed garden-apartment development to provide accommodations for 500 families in White Plains, N. Y., were revealed yesterday by Sam Minskoff Sons, builders, with the announcement of their purchase of thirty-one acres of land at Bryant and Mamaroneck Avenues from the Society of the New York Hospital.

General commendation of Mayor O'Dwyer's executive budget of $1,179,020,930 for 1949-50 was expressed yesterday by representatives of business and civic organizations at the first of three public hearings before the Board of Estimate.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 8 -- Delegates to the biennial convention of the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, in more than four hours of free-swinging debate, today denounced and defended national representatives of the Congress of Industrial Organizations for recommending withdrawal of the CIO from the World Federation of Trade Unions.

Today will be Milton Berle Day on NBC television. In the interest of the Damon Runyon Memorial Cancer Fund, the comedian will come before the television cameras beginning at 12 noon and will continue for about sixteen hours until 4 A. M. Sunday.

CHICAGO, April 8 -- The Americans for Democratic Action opened its second annual convention today with a call on Americans to "mobilize immediately" to save the "Fair Deal" program from the attacks of "the reactionary coalition" of "the Republican Old Guard and their Confederate allies" in Congress.

Alice (of Wonderland fame) would be bewildered to distraction were she to tour the city's confectioneries today. For, instead of a single mysterious White Rabbit nervously glancing at his watch as he scurried along, she would see thousands of bunnies -- light, dark, small, large, standing, sitting, jumping, running.

LONDON, April 8 -- Winston Churchill's Conservatives have scored a surprising success in London's municipal elections. They won a majority of the popular vote cast yesterday and tied with the Labor party, which has controlled the London County Council for fifteen years, in the number of seats on the new Council.
The diverse character of modern American painting could hardly be better illustrated than in five current New York exhibitions.

Today's events: Philharmonic-Symphony Young People's Concert, Leopold Stokowski, conductor, Ben Gaskins, piccolo, Carnegie Hall, 11 A. M.; Upsala College Choir, Town Hall, 3; Rossini's "Stabat Mater," New York Chamber Chorale, Thomas G. M'Carthy, conductor, Carnegie Recital Hall, 5:45.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, April 8 (AP) -- Top-seeded Earl Cochell of San Francisco and the veteran Sidney Wood of New York reached the final of the Coral Beach tennis tournament today. They will meet tomorrow for the men's singles title.

The country's oldest "pulp" magazine publishing house, which for three generations has tickled the fancy of the adventure-minded with the derrings-do of such disparate characters as Buffalo Bill and The Shadow, has abandoned the field.
WASHINGTON, April 8 -- Eight of the twelve signatories of the North Atlantic treaty made a formal and urgent appeal to the United States today for financial and military assistance.

LAKE SUCCESS, April 8 -- Israel's application for United Nations membership was sent to the General Assembly today with a recommendation that a decision be taken without the usual preliminary debate in committee.

SALZBURG, Austria, April 8 -- After playing down its conflict with the Catholic Church for the period following the trial and conviction of Joseph Cardinal Mindzenty, the Hungarian Government has renewed its pressure on the Hungarian Bench of Bishops -- this time to compel them to endorse the forthcoming Communist inspired Paris peace congress.
The Children's Zoo of the Bronx Zoo will open officially at 10:30 this morning for its ninth season with some animal or bird officiating at the ceremony.
BUENOS AIRES, April 8 (AP) -- The Argentine Government has imposed tighter controls on dollars collected in the United States for the accounts of Argentine exporters.

Eddie Eagan, chairman of the New York State Athletic Commission, yesterday was drawn into the promotional wrangle involving the services of Ray Robinson, holder of the world welterweight championship.

PARIS, April 8 -- As a counterdemonstration to the Communist-supported World Peace Congress to be held in Paris April 20, a group of French Leftist leaders sent out invitations today to an international meeting against the danger of wars arising from dictatorships and totalitarian methods.

LAKE SUCCESS, April 8 -- Led by the United States and Britain, a United Nations committee flatly rejected today a move, backed by the entire Soviet bloc, to deny newspaper and radio reporters working for a foreign news agency in their native countries basic rights traditionally associated with freedom of the press.

WASHINGTON, April 8 (AP) -- Following are the texts of a statement by Secretary of State Dean Acheson on the need for United States military assistance to eight Western European countries, of the requests by the Brussels Treaty powers (Britain, France, Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg) for military aid and of the reply from the United States.

Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. issued a statement yesterday formally announcing his candidacy for election as Representative in the Twentieth Congressional District at the special election on May 17. He said he would run as a supporter of the New Deal of his father and the Fair Deal of President Truman.

Warning that the passage of recent legislation in various states was designed to curb the political and social rights of teachers, Dr. Harold Taylor, president of Sarah Lawrence College, declared last night that teachers were the basic force for the preservation of democracy and could be trusted to carry out their duties.

Retail sales increased during the week due to demands for Easter apparel. Department store sales were estimated as about 5 per cent above the corresponding week last year. Sales last week were 8 per cent above last year.

When the sun goes down tonight it will mark the close of another opening day for thousands of tired, happy and unhappy, successful and unsuccessful, trout fishermen who, depending upon their enthusiasm and equipment, have spent several hours standing in cold water ranging in depth from their ankles to the chest -- all in the name of sport.

Those arch-feudists of the tank, the Illinois A. C. and the New York A. C., advanced to the final of the National A. A. U. hardball water polo championship by winning their semi-final tests in the Winged Foot pool last night. They will play off for the crown tonight.
WASHINGTON, April 8 (AP) -- Demands for the conservation and development of the country's natural resources marked the thirty-ninth convention of the National Rivers and Harbors Congress today.

BRONXVILLE, N. Y., April 8 -- Prize winners were announced tonight at a preview given in the Gramatan Hotel of forty-five pictures and eight pieces of sculpture, representing the pick of works of art executed in the past year and previously exhibited in fourteen member clubs of the Westchester County Federation of Women's Clubs.

SAN MARINO, Calif., April 8 -- A 3-year-old girl fell down a 120-foot dry well pipe fourteen inches in diameter tonight, and rescuers and heavy-duty digging equipment worked feverishly to reach her. Giant floodlights illuminated the vacant lot where the well was located, and police struggled to keep back crowds of onlookers. A steady stream of fresh air was pumped into the well.

WARSAW, April 8 -- The Catholic Church served notice today on the Polish Government that the regime would have to deal with the Vatican if it wished to obtain any changes in the church structure in the territories recovered from Germany by Poland.

At the annual meeting of the Athey Products Corporation, held yesterday in Chicago, W. L. Kubik, formerly vice president, was named to the new position of executive vice president. Roy Iverson, vice president of Brailsford Co. of Chicago, and Paul R. Doelz, president of Kelman Co. of Minneapolis, were elected directors to fill vacancies on the board.

Prevented by physical disabilities or illnesses from traveling to regular classes, 504 boys and girls received their first lesson by radio yesterday when the Board of Education started its High School of the Air for Homebound Children.

Ann Schuyler Hamlen, 17-year-old Schenectady, N. Y., high school student who hopes to be "a good salesman for America," received yesterday a prize of a trip to Switzerland for having won top honors in a nationwide essay contest.

WINSTON CHURCHILL cheerfully told a Boston gathering the other day that he was happy they asked him to lunch -- since he understood Boston tea parties were not always so amiable. A faint touch of the same jovial prudence seems to animate D. W. Brogan's "American Themes,"* a new book of friendly yet penetrating observations on the United States by a Scotsman who has spent a lot of time on this side of the water.
LAKE SUCCESS, April 8 -- The Soviet Union today cast its thirtieth veto in the United Nations Security Council to keep the Republic of Korea out of the world organization.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- The United States, Britain and France announced today full agreement on all questions for the establishment and control of a western German federal republic, uniting their three occupation zones politically and economically.

Building of five new veterans' hospitals, military construction and improvements of harbors and waterways by the Corps of Engineers, Department of the Army, will involve a total of $55,000,000 in the New York District for the 1949 fiscal year, it was disclosed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- President Truman declared tonight that the Democrats must win the 1950 congressional election after he heard Democratic party leaders pledge a war chest of $1,000,000 to attain that objective.
WASHINGTON, April 8 -- Following is the text of French Foreign Minister Robert Schuman's press conference statement:

It is bad news for automobilists that the extra strain put upon already weakened highway surfaces in New York, New Jersey and other areas by overloaded trucks will call for millions of dollars' worth of repairs to vital parts of the nation's road system. The American Automobile Association has felt it necessary to urge rigid restrictive methods to protect thousands of miles of roads already badly damaged by winter conditions.

Manhattan and Bronx bus riders will travel in somewhat better style within the next few weeks, as the result of orders announced yesterday by the Public Service Commission. The commission approved applications of three privately operated lines for permission to finance the purchase of 185 new buses.

Ocean Brief, the 5-year-old mare that is doing her racetracking this season as a representative of the King Ranch, carried the hopes -- and the cash -- of a plurality in the crowd of 21,802 in yesterday's top race at showery Jamaica. It was a safe journey.

LONDON, April 8 -- Second thoughts on the Government's budget did nothing today to brighten things in the stock markets here. In fact declines, instead of being concentrated on "budget disappointments" spread to almost all other groups.

DETROIT, April 8 (AP) -- Joe Klukay's goal after 17 minutes 31 seconds of overtime carried the defending champion Toronto Maple Leafs to a 3-to-2 victory over the Detroit Red Wings at Olympia tonight in the opener of their four-out-of-seven-game Stanley Cup hockey finals.

Ernest Bevin, the British Foreign Secretary, sailed for home yesterday on the Cunard liner Mauretania "optimistic" about international affairs and the hope for peace implied in the North Atlantic treaty.
Sean MacBride, Eire's Minister for External Affairs, reiterated here yesterday earlier statements that his country could not join the North Atlantic Pact until Britain relinquished Northern Ireland.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was quiet yesterday, and closing prices were irregular, 5 points higher to 9 points net lower than on Thursday.

LOS ANGELES, April 8 (UP) -- There will be no more "new looks" in clothes for American women until American men get a new look in their wallets, A. W. Zelomek, head of a New York statistical service, said today. He predicted that fashions this year would have a "down-to-earth" look, which he said was all 1949 husbands could afford.

Thirty-three young Dutch farmers coming here on a six-months visit to study American farming were among 101 passengers who arrived yesterday aboard the Holland-America Line vessel Edam. They were greeted at the line's pier at Fifth Street, Hoboken, N. J., by representatives of the Economic Cooperation Administration, the Department of Agriculture and the Netherlands Government.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- A registration statement was filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission by Joseph W. Frazer and Henry J. Kaiser, voting trustees under a voting trust agreement dated Feb. 10, 1947, and amended Dec. 28, 1948, between the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation and the Graham-Paige Motors Corporation and others.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- The Senate passed and sent to the House today a $5,580,000,000 authorization for European recovery spending in the next fifteen months. In the 70-to-7 vote, twenty-six Republicans joined with forty-four Democrats to sustain the Truman Administration's estimate.

PHILADELPHIA, April 8 -- The proposed International Trade Organization, which would function as a special agency within the framework of the United Nations, was praised and denounced today during a debate at the annual meeting of the American Academy of Political and Social Science.

ALBANY, April 8 -- Governor Dewey vetoed without comment today a bill to permit Surrogate Francis D. McGarey of Brooklyn to designate a Supreme Court justice to assist him in the disposition of pending cases.

MEXICO CITY, April 8 -- Why the United States delegation will refuse to sign the radio agreement drafted by the International High Frequency Conference at tomorrow's closing session was explained tonight at a stormy meeting of representatives from sixty-nine countries who have labored for months on the allocation among themselves of broadcasting channels.

Negotiations between the Belgian Line and the Department of Marine and Aviation for an extended lease on Piers 14 and 15, North River, are very close to a successful conclusion, it was learned yesterday. The deal would give the steamship company a West Side terminal on a permanent basis for the first time in its history.

Prof. Dirk J. Struik of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology was named at the Communist trial yesterday as a teacher in a secret Communist school for professional revolutionists in Cambridge, Mass.

Two Brooklyn youths, who were arrested last night, were said by the police to have confessed that between March 25 and the day before yesterday they had committed ten armed hold-ups and that in the last twenty-four hours they had added six more to their record.

ANNECY, France, April 8 -- The United States agreed today to discuss its restrictions on exports to Czechoslovakia as a possible violation of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, to which both countries adhere.

Thalia Mara and Arthur Mahoney presented their little Ballet Repertory Company at the Ziegfeld Theatre last night in its New York debut. The project had its beginnings at the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival two summers ago, when Miss Mara and Mr. Mahoney decided that the only way to organize a ballet company without subsidy was to start with the best young material available and work from the ground up.

Your China reporter, Henry Lieberman, quotes an officially endorsed Communist press editorial as ascribing to Dr. Sun Yat-sen, the founding father of China's modern statehood, the injunction "that Russia and the new-born Chinese Republic should march forward hand in hand" and as using this alleged injunction to line up behind their party comrades in Europe in a warning of support of Russia against America.
DOTHAN, Ala., April 8 (AP) -- Southern Democrats offered today to deal with any political party that holds out a guarantee of states' rights.
RANGOON, Burma, April 8 (AP) -- Burma's civil war flared up with new fury tonight on the approaches to Rangoon after Karen rebels in Insein had not surrendered as scheduled.

Hope that Italy would be permitted to share in the development, under United Nations trusteeship, of her former North African colonies was expressed last night by Governor Dewey at a testimonial dinner to Count Carlos Sforza, Italian Foreign Minister.

ANNANDALE - ON - HUDSON N. Y., April 8 -- A five point program which would enable the United States to promote political freedom and economic security throughout the world and offset a depression at home was outlined tonight by Representative Jacob K. Javits of New York, a member of the House Committee on Foreign Affairs.

EAST LANSING, Mich., April 8 (AP) -- A pair of 1948 N. C. A. A. boxing champions won another chance at top honors tonight with victories in this year's semi-final bouts. Michigan State's Chuck Davey, undefeated in college boxing, and Don Dickinson of Wisconsin came through tonight's tests safely and will meet tomorrow for the 145-pound title.

LONDON, April 8 -- The announcement that the United States Government would ask Congress for authority to rearm Western Europe had been confidently expected here for some months. Nevertheless it has evoked deep gratitude and praise on the part of official and diplomatic circles.

Governor Dewey and thirty-nine newspaper and magazine publishers, bankers and industrialists made a forty-two-minute flight over the New York area yesterday as the first passengers to fly here in Pan American Airways' new Boeing Stratocruiser.

All factors considered, dress business has been "fantastically" good this season, it was asserted yesterday by Jack Davis, of Jay Day Dress Company. Manufacturers who have stuck to their principal function of selling wherever and whenever they can, he said, will find that in the first three months of the year, they have produced as many, if not more, dresses than in the corresponding period last year.
O'Brien Machinery Company, Philadelphia, to Gray Rogers, also Philadelphia. Newspapers, national magazines and trade papers.

Two new pictures will have local premieres today. "Champion," a prize fight melodrama based on the Ring Lardner story, will be presented at the Globe. Kirk Douglas stars in the picture, produced independently by Stanley Kramer's Screen Plays, Inc.
WASHINGTON, April 8 (AP) -- The Department of Commerce today took quota limits off the export of several nonferrous metals, minerals and manufactured goods.

The November grand jury, which has been investigating fraudulent divorce actions, indicted a 39-year-old Harlem lawyer yesterday on charges of subornation of perjury, false impersonation and third degree forgery.

Tax liens for $2,077,592 were filed by the Government in the State and Federal Courts yesterday against Serge Rubinstein, the international financier now serving a jail sentence for draft dodging; his wife, Laurette, and three Rubinstein corporations.
The city of Cleveland, Ohio, announced yesterday that it would receive bids April 28 on bond issues totaling $7,900,000. Dated May 1, 1949, the bonds will come due Sept. 1, 1950 to 1974.

Coffee futures were higher in moderate trading activity on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday. Local trade demand, week-end covering and scattered new buying advanced prices in contract "S" 35 to 24 points. Selling was scattered on a scale up.

WASHINGTON, April 8 (AP) -- Removal of all Federal controls on installment buying was proposed today by Representative Wright Patman, Democrat, of Texas, chairman of the House Small Business Committee.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 8 -- Marriner S. Eccles, member and former chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, told the Commonwealth Club here today that the best chance of avoiding a third World War was to compel a prompt settlement with Russia.

Swedish labor leaders, here studying American production methods as guests of the Economic Cooperation Administration, reported yesterday that they had reassured American labor and Governmental officials as to declining Communist power in their homeland.

BERLIN, April 8 -- The speedy establishment of a Western German state as a result of the tri-power agreement on Germany in Washington was predicted tonight by Gen. Lucius D. Clay, United States Military Governor in Germany.
WASHINGTON, April 8 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today blocked a proposed equalization of export grain rates for North Atlantic ports pending an investigation.

Active industrial ordering of some chemicals, certain steel products and power plant equipment lines has appeared, where prices are considered right, it was learned yesterday. With some companies a sudden wave of buying reversed a trend of stagnation which existed earlier in the week.

The Hospital Department's program recently started to enable a patient to receive full clinical care at home after preliminary treatment at a hospital, has passed the experimental stage in five municipal institutions and will be extended to eight others next month, it was learned yesterday.

Railroad equipment-trust financing will be missing next week from the roll of new security offerings for the first time in many weeks. Bond houses will be occupied mostly with the bidding on Tuesday on $50,000,000 of fifty-year debentures of the Commonwealth Company and on $25,000,000 of twenty-five-year debentures of the Bell Telephone Company of Pennsylvania.

At last the Governments of the United States, Great Britain and France have reached a working agreement on the administration of Western Germany. Only those who have watched the waverings and diversions of the three-track mind of the occupying powers, and its effect on the German population, can fully appreciate what a milestone this is in Western policy.

NANKING, April 8 -- The Chinese Communists were reported tonight to have modified their original pre-negotiation ultimatum on reorganization of Nationalist troops following receipt of a humble telegram addressed to Red Leader Mao Tze-tung by Acting President Li Tsung-jen.

LONDON, April 8 -- The United States, British and French deputies discussing the Austrian peace treaty announced here today that their governments would make no claims to German assets in the Western zones as war reparations.
ROME, April 8 -- Minister of the Treasury Giuseppe Pella drew a prudently optimistic picture of the Italian financial and economic situation in a four-hour budget speech in the Senate today.

The series of articles published in this newspaper recently on the operation of union welfare funds raises some interesting questions about the future of collective bargaining in this field. It is clear that many of the fears felt when these funds first appeared have not been justified.

The Atlantic pact countries are "the forces driving the world to war," in the opinion of Pawel Hoffman, one of three Polish delegates to the recent Cultural and Scientific Conference for World Peace, who sailed for home yesterday on the Gydnia America liner Batory at "the invitation" of the State Department to leave the country within "a reasonable time."

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 8 -- The position of labor unions in Yugoslavia is remarkably similar to their status in the Soviet Union and there has been no deviation from these Marxist conceptions as a result of Belgrade's argument with the Communist Information Bureau, according to a veteran Yugoslav labor figure.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 8 -- A streak of good putting enabled Herman Keiser, 35-year-old St. Andrews, Ill., professional, to score a 68 in the second round of the Masters tourney over the Augusta National Golf Club course and share the lead tonight at the halfway mark with a total of 143.
WASHINGTON, April 8 (UP) -- The United States Court of Appeals today reversed the contempt-of-Congress conviction of two officials of the Joint Anti-Fascist Refugee Committee.

OBERLIN, Ohio, April 8 -- President William E. Stevenson of Oberlin College today announced the appointment of David R. Robertson of the University of Wichita, to be director of the Oberlin Conservatory of Music. He will assume his duties Sept. 1, upon retirement of Dr. Frank H. Shaw, who has been director for the last twenty-five years.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 8 -- Prof. Dirk J. Struik of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology termed "absolute nonsense" today the charges that he had preached a doctrine of the violent overthrow of the United States Government.

The fact-finding phase of the Civil Aeronautics Board's hearing into an airline accident at Gander, Nfld., in which none of the passengers was injured and few if any knew they had narrowly averted serious trouble, ended here yesterday afternoon.
WASHINGTON, April 8 (AP) -- Following is the text of the three-power communique issued by the Foreign Ministers of the United States, France and Britain concerning the agreement on German matters:

HALIFAX, April 8 (Canadian Press) -- A waterfront battle flared today when railway police broke picket ranks of the striking Canadian Seamen's Union and put 200 seamen of a rival union aboard three ships.

Under the leadership of railroad shares, stock prices recovered early fractional losses yesterday and closed moderately firmer in slightly larger volume. Sales in the final hour accounted for more than one-fourth of the day's business, as total transfers aggregated 850,000 shares, compared with 840,000 shares on Thursday.

Prompt action followed a complaint received yesterday morning by the office of District Attorney Frank S. Hogan that the National Room Service, Inc., an apartment rent bureau, was "still doing business."

Gen. Lucius D. Clay, United States Military Govemnor in Germany, and W. John Logan, director-general of the Joint Export Import Agency in western Germany, joined yesterday in backing the United States Military Government German Exhibition, which opens at 10 o'clock this morning in the Museum of Science and industry, 30 Rockefeller Plaza.

In the various documents pertaining to the plan for United States military assistance to eight European nations one idea and one set of phrases recur repeatedly. That idea is mutuality and community of effort in self-defense. The Brussels Treaty Powers in their request of April 5 stated that those Powers were considering a "common defense program."

The commemorative devotions of Palm Sunday, recalling the triumphal entry of Jesus into Jerusalem, will take place in the city's churches tomorrow. Palms will be blessed and distributed at all Roman Catholic and some Protestant Episcopal churches after the traditional ceremony. There will be processions and special music.

Two armed men took $20,740 in furs, jewelry and money yesterday from the Brooklyn home of William Friedman, owner of the Wear-Ever Baby Carriage Company and president of Beth-El Hospital, after tying up Mrs. Friedman and a maid.
WASHINGTON, April 8 -- Business inventories registered a seasonal increase of $450,000,000 in February, the Department of Commerce reported today.

Ways of making woolens unpalatable to moths or of killing moths, the eggs and larvae, are taking new forms. Among these are push-button fog-dispensing sprays that can treat a three-piece suit in a couple of minutes or a dress in even less time.

Paddy Young, Greenwich Village warrior, stopped Nick Mistovich of Youngstown, Ohio, in the eighth round of the scheduled ten-round main bout at the St. Nicholas Arena last night. The end came in 2:41 of the session when Referee Eddie Joseph stepped in to prevent further punishment for Mistovich.
John L. Lewis' Taxi Workers Organizing Committee called off its strike at 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon with the walkout in its eighth day.

New York's subways have gone into the business of selling soft drinks, candy, gum, peanuts and crackers on such a scale as to earn for the city indicated annual revenues of $1,404,252 on the basis of present facilities alone, a survey disclosed yesterday.
ATLANTA, Ga., April 8 -- The Dodgers continued their mastery over minor league opposition tonight by outscoring the Atlanta Crackers, 6 -- 3, under the lights of a jammed Ponce de Leon Field.

Your account in a recent issue of the well-deserved elevation of Dr. William F. Russell to the presidency of Teachers College contains statements tending to give a wrong impression regarding the history of the college before the year 1897 when I resigned as president and James E. Russell became not the "first dean" but the second, I having been appointed dean in 1889.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., April 8 -- Renewal of basic function and principle was urged on advertising here today as the prime "must" for its job of helping business overcome the hazards of recession and severe competition.
COLORADO SPRINGS, Col., April 8 (AP) -- Margaret Anne Graham of Tulsa, Okla., glided her way into an early lead in the junior ladies' national ice skating championships today.

You have lived up to a high tradition of fairness in publishing recently the late Admiral Keyes' version of King Leopold's capitulation in May, 1940, contradicting Winston Churchill's memoirs on this point.

A substantial upswing in March made a good-sized cut in the margin of decline in building and engineering awards in the first three months of 1949, the F. W. Dodge Corporation reported here yesterday. The report covers the thirty-seven states east of the Rocky Mountains.

The Playwrights Company and Leland Hayward, sponsors of "Anne of the Thousand Days," have scheduled a seven-week summer vacation for the Maxwell Anderson play co-starring Rex Harrison and Joyce Redman. The holiday will get under way on June 25 and end on Aug. 15, when the engagement is expected to be resumed.

Queens detectives pressed a search last night for a manila envelope containing $50,000, which disappeared mysteriously from the offices of the KLM Royal Dutch Airlines at New York International Airport at Idlewild.

Hugh K. McGovern, operator, has purchased the six-story apartment building at 1895 University Avenue, the Bronx, containing fifty-eight suites, from the Alextar Realty Corporation. The property is assessed at $205,000 and was acquired for cash above mortgages of $174,640.

PARIS, April 8 -- The agreement on Germany reached in Washington after four years of almost constant disagreement between the United States and Britain on one hand and France on the other, is considered here to be the result of a changed situation in Europe and of altered views in Paris and Washington.
The "missing" schooner yacht Keewatin was discovered, safe and with all hands aboard, in a little harbor in the British West Indies yesterday afternoon.

Former President Herbert Hoover received the John O'Hara Cosgrave Gold Medal last night from the Dutch Treat Club at the Plaza Hotel for the outstanding contribution to the American way of life during the last year.

BOSTON, April 8 (AP) -- Boston Braves' front office officials, with the exception of absent Lou Perini, the president, tonight joined forces in denying that their players were feuding with Manager Billy Southworth.
Two weeks to the day after he stole $883,660 in cash and bonds from the National City Bank Richard H. Crowe was indicted here yesterday for violations of three Federal laws.

SHREVEPORT, La., April 8 -- After days and days of heavy shelling, a select group of representatives of the pitching craft decided to take matters into their own hands today as the Giants and Indians moved into this bustling Louisiana metropolis.

Capt. Albert S. Luker of Asbury Park, N. J., master of the Isbrandtsen Company freighter Flying Arrow, testified yesterday at a Coast Guard hearing that twenty-three members of his vessel's crew had refused to return to the ship at Manila for a sailing scheduled for midnight, Jan. 6, as a protest against two other crew members.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- The National Coal Association raised a question today whether John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers, was trying to price coal out of the fuel market by such moves as a lowering of the miners' pension eligibility age from 62 to 60.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 8 -- Arthur Freed is preparing a musical film at Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer under the title "An American in Paris," which will utilize the music of George Gershwin, it was learned today.
DETROIT, April 8 (AP) -- An amendment to the articles of incorporation of the Detroit Cleveland Navigation Company will be voted on at the company's annual stockholder's meeting here on April 19.
HONOLULU, April 8 -- Mauna Loa, on the Island of Hawaii, is erupting again for the second time this year, Hilo reported today.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- The House passed its ninth appropriation bill of the present session today against a background of charges from the Republican side that, at this point, Democrat-controlled money grants to regular Federal departments stood $1,241,384,242 in excess of funds allowed by the GOP last year.

Small-stemmed spring flowers the country over are nodding as in greeting to a welcome season. This animation comes from the bee. It is she (the worker being female) who, with her 13,000 eyes, has seen the blossom usually long before being discovered by a pair of human eyes.

All but six occupants of apartments in four five-story tenement houses from 426 to 432 West Fifty-second Street -- to be razed to make way for a nurses' home for St. Clare's Hospital -- had been moved out late yesterday and were awaiting transportation to temporary shelter in the East River Housing Project, 102d Street and Roosevelt Drive.

Past Time, a 6-year-old grey gelding belonging to Mr. and Mrs. John C. Kehoe Jr. of Center Moreland, Pa., made the most progress toward the conformation hunter championship at the beginning of the point competition at the Squadron A horse show yesterday.

PARIS, April 8 -- Paul G. Hoffman, head of the Economic Cooperation Administration, has agreed to release to the French Government 25,000,000,000 francs from the counterpart fund of the Marshall Plan for productive investments, it was announced today.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- A railroad emergency board today indicated in a report to President Truman that railroad strikes were increasing despite machinery for adjusting such disputes under the Railway Labor Act.

MOSCOW, April 8 -- The Soviet press today reported a deepening unemployment crisis in the United States with at least 5,000,000 workers now jobless and layoffs rapidly increasing in all branches of industry, despite huge Government expenditures on Marshall Plan aid and military armaments.

The nomination of Stephen T. Early for the post of Under-Secretary of Defense came as a surprise to those who had thought of the position only in its technical and administrative aspects. His choice, however, suggests inevitably that the President and the Defense Secretary are vitally concerned with the relationship between the defense establishment and the public.

The issue of the Italian colonies has come up before the United Nations because the Powers immediately concerned could not agree on what to do with these vast stretches of sandy but strategic African territory. The question has been hanging fire since the first meeting of the Foreign Ministers in 1945.

The American motion-picture industry yesterday opened a new phase of its attack against the "unfair and discriminatory" quota regulations now in force in England. Samplings of British opinion criticizing the harmful effects of the 45 per cent quota are presented in a ten-page printed booklet which the Motion Picture Association of American now is mailing to Congressmen, government officials, the press, radio and others.
CLEVELAND, April 8 (AP) -- The Hupp Corporation announced today it sustained a loss of $380,228 after all charges for the year 1948.

Tom Hines of Wisconsin moved into a tie with Howard Rahm of Ohio State for straight-rail honors as the second day of the national intercollegiate invitation billiard tournament ended at Columbia University yesterday.

Supreme Court Justice Meier Steinbrink has been scheduled to preside over the civil trial of the issues in dispute between the vestry of Holy Trinity Church in Brooklyn and the Rev. Dr. John Howard Melish, rector.

A game of marbles, played by four young boys on a dirt pedestrian walk adjacent to a railroad cut on Park Avenue in the Bronx, ended in tragedy yesterday when a bakery truck struck a municipal vehicle, caromed off the roadway and smashed into the players.

LONDON, April 8 (UP) -- The J. Arthur Rank movie organization gave dismissal notices to an estimated 2,000 workers in its Denham and Pinewood studios tonight after forty-seven electrical workers went on strike. Production on three films, "Chiltern Hundreds," "Cockpit" and "Pete Pub," was stopped and work on "Madeleine," due to start Monday, was canceled.

DAMASCUS, Syria, April 8 -- Syrian-Israeli negotiations for armistice appeared today to have run into trouble. Brig. Gen. William E. Riley of the United States Marine Corps and Henri Vigier, representatives of Dr. Ralph J. Bunche, Acting United Nations Negotiator on Palestine, went to the Syrian frontier with members of the Syrian delegation.

A majority of the City College student body, the largest of the four municipal colleges, voted yesterday, 2,797 to 1,885 to strike Monday in a demand for the suspension and trial of two members of the faculty whom they charge with discrimination.

MOBILE, Ala., April 8 -- Uncertainty continued to plague Casey Stengel today. The Yankee skipper made this admission as he passed through this town with his 31-man squad on the way to Beaumont, Texas, and the inaugural of the road version of the Yankee exhibition campaign tomorrow against the minor league Beaumont Exporters.

FRANKFORT, Germany, April 8 -- Officials of the United States Military Government in Bavaria have undertaken a toy-collecting drive for about 25,000 children in rufugee camps. They are children of Sudeten Germans from Czechoslovakia or illegal border crossers from the Soviet zone.

Gov. Thomas E. Dewey and State Controller Frank C. Moore were guests of the directors and officers of the Bank of the Manhattan Company at a luncheon yesterday marking the 150th anniversary of the founding of the bank in 1799. The luncheon, held at the bank's offices, 40 Wall Street, was followed by a tour of the bank and an inspection of a special historical exhibit set up on the main banking floor.

ATLANTIC CITY, April 8 -- Service employes of nine major beachfront hotels went out on strike today in what they termed "a 100 per cent walkout." Union officials asserted that 1,800 persons had quit their jobs.

Savings and loan associations in this state in January and February registered an increase of $29,045,728 in total savings held, according to a survey released yesterday by Zebulon V. Woodard, executive vice president of the New York State Savings and Loan League.

Brooklyn College authorities suspended yesterday for the rest of the term two students who addressed an unauthorized meeting called on the campus Thursday afternoon, to protest the suspension of the Karl Marx Society.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- President Truman called upon civilian and military leaders today to develop community welfare and guidance programs for the 1,600,000 young men and women now in uniform and the millions more who will be returning to civilian life in the next ten years.

The "reforestation program" along the Fifth Avenue frontage of Rockefeller Center was completed early yesterday morning as nurserymen planted the last of eight American elm trees near the northwest corner of Forty-ninth Street.

OTTAWA, April 8 (UP) -- Sam Carr, 43-year-old organizer for the Canadian Communist party, was sentenced to six years in prison today after his conviction on charges that he obtained a forged passport for a Soviet spy.

Federal specialists and students in American Indian problems discussed at a conference yesterday self-government measures for Reservation Indians that have been advanced by the Office of Indian Affairs of the Department of the Interior.

THERE were moments this past winter when harassed city police officials must have wondered whether they were running a police department or a training school for theatrical talent. The source of their confusion was, of course, "Detective Story," Sidney Kingsley's drama of life in a busy police station.

ON June 21, 1826, the aged statesman at Monticello made the next to the last entry in his register of letters received, a register begun nearly half a century earlier and, since 1790, kept up to date with thoroughgoing completeness. The entry which thus brought to a close an inventory of what has been called the greatest treasure house of information ever left by a single man read:
HELSINKI, Finland, April 5 -It is high time, apparently, that somebody appointed a learned commission to prepare a report on "Finland and her troubles." The learned commission would have a tough job.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- Two powerful labor leaders; Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, and Harvey W. Brown, head of the Independent International Association of Machinists, took steps today that indicated their belief the promised repeal of the Taft-Hartley Act was in jeopardy.

Sectarian religion in the public schools is a threat to America's democratic traditions, Dr. Jerome Nathanson, director of the Ethical Culture Society's John L. Elliot Institute, declared yesterday at the annual spring conference of the Teachers Guild, AFL.

IN his review on March 27 of the Northrop "Ideological Differences and World Order," Max Radin says "the word 'ideology' means . . . coherent system of ideas about society and the world . . . a relatively new word . . . not yet admitted to the Oxford English Dictionary."

Columbia University and John Marshall struggled through three hours and thirty-three minutes in their eleven-inning baseball game yesterday at Baker Field, with the Lions finally taking the decision, 5 -- 4. Both teams were bothered by the wind and cold, and if no scoring had occurred in the eleventh the game was to have been called.

The United States today is enjoying the medical leadership of the world mainly because of the "unconquerable spirit of free enterprise" of its people, Charles P. Cooper, president of Presbyterian Hospital of the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center, declares in his annual report, which was made public yesterday.
ANYONE who reads the standard literature of bridge learns about certain delicate and wholly praiseworthy plays, then sits around the rest of his life waiting for a chance to use them.

The year holds one moment, which may last for a week, when tree and bush and vine are on the breathless verge of leafing out. It is then that you stand on a hillside and look across the wooded valley and see the scarlet and orange of maple blossoms like a touch of pastel crayon across the treetops.

Seventy-nine men were arrested yesterday afternoon in two police raids on alleged betting establishments on the upper West Side. Seven of the prisoners, charged with bookmaking and acting in concert, were held in bail of $500 each for arraignment tomorrow in Gamblers Court.

ATLANTA, Ga., April 9 -- Declaring that he had received a better reception in Atlanta than anywhere he had been, Jackie Robinson today denied he had said he "soon would be back in the good old U. S. A."

WASHINGTON, Conn., April 9 -- Capt. John Warner Moore, who was fleet chaplain on Admiral Chester W. Nimitz' staff in the last World War, has been appointed to the faculty of The Gunnery, a college preparatory school here for boys, it was announced today by Ogden Miller, headmaster.
LONDON, April 9 -- If ever a country looked ripe for communism and Soviet domination, Iran is it.

FOR THIS WEEK: As the peas sown last month start to grow, fill in the trench in which they were planted or hill up the soil. . . . Weed the asparagus bed and feed with a balanced commercial fertilizer. . . . Look over vines and make certain that their supports or staples are firm. Pull wistaria clear of house gutters and shingles and, if necessary, cut off slender tip growth. . . .

THIS little footnote to recent interesting and rather distinguished reviews of new books by T. S. Eliot and by some of his commentators has nothing to do with critical issues. Nor is it partisan with respect to the faults or the virtues of Mr. Eliot's poetry.

ALBANY, April 9 -- At the request of Mayor O'Dwyer, Governor Dewey approved today the Desmond-Steingut bill empowering cities to assemble sites for public garages or parking places through use of their condemnation powers.

THIS mystery novel opens on what appears to be the "perfect" murder. Chad Severn is a thoroughgoing cad with a fatal fascination for wealthy women. After three years of marriage to Emily Trimbal, he can wait no longer fox her father to die a natural death (leaving them his millions); he decides to smother the old man in his sickbed.

AS is now its annual custom, "The Greatest Story Ever Told" will observe the Easter season with two special dramatizations this Sunday and next (6:30 P. M. on the ABC network and WJZ). The Biblical drama for today.

Grey geldings owned by Mr. and Mrs. John C. Kehoe Jr. of Center Moreland, Pa., led for both the conformation and working hunter championships going into the final day of the Squadron A horse show by placing in the ribbons yesterday afternoon and evening at the Madison Avenue Armory.
BUENOS AIRES, April 9 -- Britain is suggesting absolute parity for any new trade agreement signed with Argentina, it was confirmed today.

IF Richard Halliburton had written this account of two years spent island hopping in the South Seas, the reader would wind up fatigued by the effort of it all. But as told by Robert Gibbings, it is an enchanting and peaceful Odyssey from Fiji to Tahiti.

DALLAS, April 9 -- Department store sales in the Eleventh Federal Reserve District during the past week were the best of any week this year, but still fell slightly below sales for the same period of 1948. Other business factors were brighter.

An afternoon of play by a group of small boys in a Queens lot ended in tragedy yesterday afternoon, when one of the youngsters was burned to death inside an upturned packing crate. A second child, also inside the crate, was burned so severely that he is not expected to survive.

A FEW weeks ago Dr. Norbert Wiener, Professor of Mathematics at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, picked up THE NEW YORK TIMES Book Review, adjusted it to the right distance from his horn-rimmed glasses, and read the following:

TOM PAINE, slandered by Teddy Roosevelt as a "dirty little atheist," is nowadays receiving his deserved historical vindication. What Howard Fast and W. E. Woodward did in the adult biography field Miss Hawthorne does, and brilliantly, in this book for high school ages.

LIKE Mr. Dortort's first novel, "Burial of the Fruit," his present effort is poignant and muddled by turns, and badly overwritten all the distance. Like its predecessor, it is concerned largely with the blight of poverty, and uses the Brownsville section of Brooklyn as the drab background for much of its disjointed drama.

THE newest wonder boy in this community is 35-year-old Stanley Kramer who, with three pictures completed, one of them as yet unreleased, is apparently proving that an independent movie producer with ideas can make the grade in Hollywood.

EAST LANSING, Mich., April 9 -- Winning finalists in the two lightestweight classes tonight gave Louisiana State University the team title in the twelfth annual National Collegiate A. A. boxing tournament.

THIS is less an encyclopedia than an important first step toward one, for the dance is a subject too broad to be compassed by a book of these dimensions. Even so, Mr. Chujoy has perhaps not used the space at his disposal to the best advantage.

MORALISTS sometimes complain that the devil has all the good tunes, and economic conservatives have lamented that the radicals have been writing all, or nearly all, the good books in the field of social thought. Whom could the conservatives pit against John Maynard Keynes, William Beveridge, Alvin H. Hansen or Harold J. Laski?

TO THE EDITOR: I was much interested in the article on the Parthenon and the Elgin Marbles. In it Harold Nicolson very movingly traced the history of the removal of these superb statues to London and strongly advocated that they be now returned to the land of their origin.

MINNEAPOLIS, April 9 -- For the third successive month, department store sales in March lagged behind those of the corresponding month last year in the Ninth Federal Reserve District, the Minneapolis bank reported today. The bank's figures, however, showed an increasing tempo in dol tar volume of sales as Easter approached.

In the words of the British Foreign Secretary, Ernest Bevin, the Three-Power agreement announced in Washington on Friday is an attempt by Britain, France and the United States to help the Germans "create a new, democratic Germany, with whom those of us in Europe and the rest of the world can live in confidence and peace."

The Canadian Pacific Line, preparatory to returning to the Pacific travel trade as an air carrier rather than in its pre-war role of surface operator, will conduct survey flights in the next two weeks over transpacific air routes, it became known here yesterday.

Rear Admiral Charles Lees Brand, USN, has been appointed resident representative for new construction for the American President Lines, at the Camden yards of the New York Shipbuilding Corporation. He will assume his new duties on May 1 following his retirement from the Navy as Assistant Chief of the Bureau of Ships in charge of shipbuilding and design, and General Inspector of Ships.

ONE remembers how, even with the war on and all the enormous physical destruction, there were moments when the beauty that has always been Italy's would flash out and astonish even the dog-tired soldier marching on some sunken and dusty road between mountains pitted with old pillboxes and green lovely fields full of hidden and menacing bakelite mines.

LOS ANGELES, April 9 -- The North Pacific Coast-Europe service of the Holland-America Line approached its pre-war level this week with the arrival here of the 10,820-ton passenger-freight motorship Dalerdyk. The vessel is a gleaming, streamlined reconstruction of the Damsterdyk, which headed the service before the war.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- Tides raised by the moon in the earth's liquid core are slowing the planet's revolution and increasing the length of the day. This thesis is advanced in a report prepared for the official organ of the British Association for the Advancement of Science by Dr. W. M. Elsasser of the University of Pennsylvania.

PHILADELPHIA, April 9 -- Pennsylvania Railroad carloadings last week totaled 108,093 as against 99,749 a year ago, an increase of 8.4 per cent, and for year to date Pennsylvania Railroad loadings totaled 1,396,978 to compare with 1,550,501 last year, a decrease of 9.9 per cent.

LONDON, April 9 (UP) -- Film workers, rejecting management's contention that the crisis in the British movie industry was an "act of God," demanded tonight that the Government nationalize at least part of the business.

Following an increased consumer demand for Easter apparel, activity in the wholesale apparel market here last centered on fill-in orders for most ready-to-wear lines, according to a report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., Inc., resident buying office.

AMONG the showplaces of Cornell University is the Bailey Hortorium, a collection of 200,000 plants given to Cornell by a man who retired thirty-six years ago as dean of its college of agriculture. At 91, Liberty Hyde Bailey is still adding to the prize gatherings of blackberry plants and palm trees.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- Woodlawn, the 127-acre estate at Alexandria, Va., that George Washington gave as a wedding gift to his adopted daughter, Nellie Custis, will open its gates tomorrow to the public as a new national shrine.

AS short-story writer and author of at least a dozen novels, Kay Boyle has in the past twenty years established a unique kind of reputation. In the Nineteen Thirties when the novel with a social message was in vogue, Miss Boyle, leading the detached life of a depatriate, was writing intense little stories of poetic delicacy and irony.

THIS is a woman's story of special interest to those who believe that life begins at 40 -- or later. Madge Fairlie, the "slender reed," does not really begin to "live" until she is almost 60. Her story, however, starts twenty-five years earlier when she is mistress of the type of town house now nearly extinct save in Mary Petty drawings.
I write to protest Professor Hook's vicious and sophistic attack upon academic freedom.

The Mayfair Assemblies, which have been held for eight years under the direction of Miss Clementine Miller, will be continued during the winter season with two dances, on Dec. 17 and Feb. 11, in the St. Regis Roof. One hundred debutantes of the coming season will receive invitations from the committee of patronesses.

TO the familiar reasons usually advanced in explanation of the lack of teachers -- low salaries, slow advancement, a "restricted" life -- I should like to add another. That is: teaching isn't teaching any more.

LOUISIANA, Mo., April 9 -- On the anniversary of V-E Day, Sunday, May 8, 1949, a train will roll some eighty-five miles from St. Louis to this Mississippi River community. But it won't be an ordinary train.

The Women's Metropolitan Golf Association, in commemoration of its fiftieth anniversary, has a tournament schedule that will keep the golfers of the district on their toes from the first week in May until the middle of October.

The Philharmonic - Symphony gave the last of the season's Young People's Carnegie Hall Concerts yesterday morning, and took the occasion to present many prizes, scrolls, certificates, medals and ribbons. Leopold Stokowski was master of ceremonies, as well as conductor.

ONE day last winter the prediction was made by Bill Veeck, a character whose enthusiasms are unbridled, that Steve Gromek, the reformed soft-ball player, would be a 20-game winner for the Cleveland Indians this season. When the heap big chief of the Tribe makes a statement his listeners never know whether he's just doing some headline hunting or whether he really means it.

IF the season as a whole produces anything more distinguished than the recent series of performances by Jose Limon and his gifted associates, we shall be lucky indeed. In these days, when the healthy trend of the dance toward the theatre sometimes looks more like a mad scramble toward "show business," it is reassuring to find a group of artists working incorruptibly as artists, with dignity and substance and without regard to timepleasing.

WHETHER a mystery story should try to be something more, a story of character, too, is a matter for debate. On the side of a judicious mixing of mystery and personal problems, in palatable if not equal proportions, "The Seventh Step" is an ordinary example, with familiar ingredients.

LONDON, April 9 -- Tens of thousands of Scotsmen flushed with their soccer team's humbling of England's mightiest by three goals to one here today took possession of London tonight and they livened up the old town in a way unknown since before the war.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- President Truman assured Dr. Robert L. Johnson of Philadelphia, president of Temple University, in a letter given out today, that he would send to Congress a number of plans submitted by the Commission for the Organization of the Executive Branch of the Government, headed by Herbert C. Hoover, as soon as he had legislative authority to do so.
TELEVISION, a prime factor in many changes in American social customs, also is creating a boom in the business of wig making.

China Muddle In China last week events seemed to be moving swiftly toward a change in the Nationalist-Communist civil war. In Peiping, delegations of both sides sat down to begin formal negotiations for peace. In Nanking leaders of the Nationalist Government gathered to debate their reply to Communist demands for virtual unconditional surrender.
JEFFERSON VALLEY, N. Y., Apirl 9 -- Next winter's fur coats are beginning to develop this month at prospering and expanding mink ranches of the North Atlantic states.

Prospects for reaching a mutually satisfactory settlement in forthcoming contract negotiations between Atlantic and Gulf Coast shipowners and three maritime unions affiliated with the Congress of Industrial Organizations remain good as preliminary steps are scheduled for this week. Present contracts expire on June 15.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- European countries that are getting Marshall Plan assistance expect 375,000 Americans to travel on the Continent this year, the Economic Cooperation Administration said today. This would be double the number last year.

THE adventure of discovery and faith was shared not only by the pioneer collectors of modern art but also by the great art dealers who had the courage to introduce and support the advanced artists of their time when these were unknown and ostensibly "bad risks."
DAMASCUS, Syria, April 9 (Reuters) -- Gen. Husni Zayim, Syrian army chief who took over the Government last week, today warned Israel "to beware of the Syrian Army."

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 9 -- A 30-year-old North Carolinian, Johnny Palmer of Badin, today moved into undisputed leadership at the end of fifty-four holes in the Masters tournament over the Augusta National Golf Club course with a score of 214.

SEOUL, Korea, April 9 -- President Syngman Rhee left Seoul by air this morning for Cheju Island, fifty miles off the south coast, where he will conduct a personal inspection of the mopping-up operations against Communist-led guerrillas.

THE Atlantic's earliest rush travel season opened April 1, with major shipping lines reporting that all classes of space were booked virtually to capacity on eastbound voyages for the next four months. Some lines reported "closed books" extending well into August and September.
Professor Hook's article merely shifts the witch hunt for Communists from legislatures to faculties, which are subject to pressures just as insistent and narrow as the former.

Dr. Ordway Tead, chairman of the Board of Higher Education, asserted yesterday that the city's proposed cut of $408,000 from the board's $1,258,000 budget request for its state-subsidized teacher training program in 1949-50 was a "serious encroachment upon the legal authority of the Board of Trustees of the State University."
THE Thundery One is back in the United States. He was preceded to this country by Mr. Quick Rich. The Cherry is not now expected here. There is a certain mystery at the moment about The Hammer.

THE trouble with Asia, according to Owen Lattimore, is that the whole continent is out of control. Nothing that the United States or its allies can do, he contends, will ever put the West back in control of the lands and peoples from Suez to the western Pacific.
TO THE EDITOR: This is a fan letter to Mrs. Taylor -- the graying, slender Yankee schoolmarm of whom Harry Gilroy wrote in his article titled "Americanization of Hans Schmidt."

Flags Up In 1934 John L. Lewis' catch-all District 50 of the United Mine Workers tried to organize New York cab drivers through strikes. The strikes collapsed as cab drivers went back to work. Last week a second strike attempt by District 50 ended about the same way.

NEW DELHI, India, April 9 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru, inaugurating the Indian National Commission for Cooperation with the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization today, declared that international bodies "must take note of the new importance of Asia in the world setup."

In the parlance of gangdom, there's a "hot lab" up Boston way trafficking in the Atom Bomb. But rest your fears. It has the backing of top scientists, such as Dr. Karl T. Compton, chairman of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and chairman of the Research and Development Board of the National Military Establishment, and a bagful of peaceful plans for helping industry.

PRINCETON, N. J., April 9 -- Blasting a pair of hurlers for twelve hits, Princeton University's baseball team defeated Williams, 10 -- 0, on University Field today for its fourth victory of the season.

CHICAGO, April 9 (AP) -- Wheat showed a firming tendency toward the close of trading on the Board of Trade today, erasing earlier small losses. Buying in part represented short covering and followed trade reports that the Kansas City office of the Commodity Credit Corporation would entertain offers of cash wheat for delivery through April 20.

HERALDRY is still a flourishing business in Britain. At the musty old College of Arms near the flowing Thames new excitement reigns since the birth of Prince Charles. The venerable Kings, Heralds and Pursuivants of Arms have turned temporarily aside from the weekly flow of 500-odd requests for heraldic information to consider a new and more fascinating problem.
WASHINGTON, April 9 (AP) -- New Yorkers asked the Senate Appropriations Committee today to provide money to start a $2,420,000 construction project to improve Jones Inlet.

Contrary to the belief of some educators, the junior college movement will benefit, rather than hurt, the four-year colleges in the country, according to Dr. C. L. Littel, president of Bergen Junior College, Teaneck, N. J.

THERE is a healthy movement afoot to salvage great poetry from dust-attracting print and return it to its original realm of living words. Of course the idea isn't new as the Oxford Festival of Spoken Poetry in England and recordings by actors and poets show.

DETROIT, April 9 -- All of the factors necessary for piling up one of the greatest production and selling periods in automotive history during the next three or four months are present in Detroit today.

ALBANY, April 9 -- On advice of the New York County Lawyers Association. Governor Dewey vetoed today a bill that would have required judges to impose a sentence of life imprisonment if a jury recommended mercy in a felony murder case resulting in conviction.
Retail trade had its pre-Easter spurt last week. Department store sales were estimated as about 5 per cent above the corresponding week last year, which however was in the post-Easter period.

SURPRISING as it may be to some, the sovereign Government of the United States enters into formal bargaining contracts with its employes in the Tennessee Valley Authority, the Bonneville Power Administration, Inland Waterways Corporation and the Alaska Railway.

ONE of the most worth-while enterprises conducted by the Government is the Archive of American Folk Song, which reposes at the Library of Congress in the nation's capital. Scholars in the field are well aware of its existence, but the public as a whole is not.

FORMER New York City Magistrate Julius Isaacs has put out a gentle biography, a pleasant, humane bit of writing. Because it is singularly local in theme and in treatment, it may not find many readers outside Gotham-on-Hudson.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 9 -Ira Godin hurled Harvard to a seventeen-inning 6-5 victory over the Navy baseball team today.
SPRING is an especially good season for planting or moving evergreens. This is one group of plants that should be handled without fail before April has ended.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 9 -- The effort of President Philip Murray of the CIO to bring West Coast left-wing unions into line with national CIO policy was a lively subject along the Coast this week.
Thousands of letters opposing issuance of a permit for the Communist-directed May Day parade have been received by the Police Department, it was learned yesterday.

NBC tripped over its own ballyhoo last Sunday evening. For weeks the network has been lauding the comedy team of Dean Martin and Jerry Lewis, even to the point of issuing a publicity handout in Latin. For the opening show at least the build-up was fatal.

A SAINT of the Roman Catholic Church and one of the fathers of primitive, non-Marxist communism, a humanist who wrote one of the most enduring and influential books in world literature, and one of the greatest Lord Chancellors of England, Thomas More has puzzled later generations by contradictions in his character and work.

Dr. Meiklejohn writes with persuasion and in the liberal tradition in his defense of the right of Communists (with a capital "C," a very important distinction) to teach in our colleges and universities. His personal prestige and his espousal of the currently unpopular side of a great controversy establish beyond doubt the sincerity and the depth of his thoughts.

WASHINGTON, April 9 (AP) -- The Washington Capitols snapped out of their slump tonight and thoroughly trounced the Minneapolis Lakers, 83 -- 71, to hold a slim chance to win the Basketball Association of America championship play-offs.

BELGRADE, April 9 -- The Soviet Government made public its official denunciation of the North Atlantic pact on March 31, so that the actual signature of that historic document has produced little concrete reaction to date.

NEW HAVEN, Conn. -- Every day of fine weather is bringing nearer the possibility of a speedy, unhampered motor trip from New York to Boston, one of the most heavily traveled routes in the whole country.

RANGOON, Burma, April 9 (Reuters) -- Peace talks between the Burmese Government and Karen rebels in Insein broke down because the Karens insisted upon a country-wide truce to enable military and political leaders from all battle zones to meet and discuss terms, an official announcement said here tonight.

Students striking tomorrow to demand suspension and trial of two members of the faculty at City College whom students charge with discrimination will resist attempts by non-student groups to reject "politics" into the protest, it was announced yesterday by a member of the strike committee.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- Although the public has heard little about Point Four -- President Truman's "bold new program" to improve the world's underdeveloped areas -- there has been a good deal of activity here to implement it.

The People's Guild of Brooklyn, which for twenty years without fanfare has encouraged housewives to devote some of their time to reading and discussing books ranging from the world's classics to the latest best sellers, will go out of existence next month "because it has fulfilled its purpose."

LONDON, April 9 -- Leaders of the British Labor party who have just passed their worst week -- politically speaking -- since they came to power in July, 1945, were reported today to be planning a strenuous campaign to regain the ground lost to the Conservative party in the recent local elections throughout England and Wales.

Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. made public yesterday a letter from Henry Morgenthau Jr. endorsing him for Representative in the Twentieth Congressional District at the special election to be held on May 17. The former Secretary of the Treasury wrote:

Especially designed insulated clothing and intricate instruments have been developed by University of Washington scientists for Arctic research and tested successfully at temperatures ranging to 40 degrees below zero. All this is part of a preliminary investigation of the effects of Arctic temperatures on the minds and bodies of service men.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., April 9 -- Passage by the United States House of Representatives last week of a bill to repeal the 63-year-old Federal tax on oleomargarine kindled the hopes of cotton men in the Deep South that the Eighty-first Congress might finally write that bill into law.

Financial markets last week reverted to the cautious role that they have played recently. Stocks fluctuated within a narrow range as price cuts increased and Congressional action on domestic political issues continued to lag. The trend of stock values, in general, repeated that of the previous week.

WASHINGTON, April 9 (AP) -- The world's sugar production for the 1948-49 season is now estimated at a record 37,689,000 tons, according to the United States Department of Agriculture. This is 11 per cent higher than the last season's total and 9 per cent higher than the pre-war (1935-39) average.

Passover, the oldest festival of liberty in human history, will be celebrated by Jewish congregations from sundown Wednesday to sundown the following Wednesday, April 20, by Reform Jews and to sundown Thursday, April 21, by Orthodox and Conservative Jews.

In connection with the item about the lady who has been answering phone calls for the "Kiss Me, Kate" boxoffice, you might be interested in a similar and even more exasperating predicament in which I have been for a matter of years.

A new type of artificial kidney has been developed in Philadelphia at the Jewish Hospital by Drs. Julian A. Sterling, Laurence B. Weiss, Arthur Schneeberg and Joseph C. Doane, and engineers William and Robert Bernard. The experimental work was financed by Dr. Doane.

City College's baseball team put two big innings together yesterday to gain its first Metropolitan Collegiate Conference victory in two starts by turning back St. John's College, 7 to 5, at Dexter Park, Woodhaven.

The "cultural delegates" have departed from our shores but a committee of intellectuals is about to take up the same task as theirs in Paris. This emphasis on culture and intellect in the world struggle is a little confusing to those who try to follow trends and happenings.

UNLIKE many novels about the problems of Negroes in country, "Without Magnolias" is a good story. In addition to an effective sympathy, Bucklin Moon has a good eye, a sharp ear and an unobtrusively smooth narrative style that carries his book along.

The appearance of domestic surpluses of some manufactured products now points up the importance of the whole foreign economic aid program of this country, William L. Batt, president of S.K.F. Industries, Inc., Philadelphia, and president of the International Committee on Scientific Management, emphasized last week during an interview at the Engineer's Club.

LAKE SUCCESS, April 9 -- Andrei A. Gromyko, Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister, today accused Britain, the United States and France of establishing powerful military bases in the former Italian colonies and revived a Soviet proposal, made in Paris last September, that they be placed under a collective United Nations trusteeship.

Tom Hines of Wisconsin captured the straight-rail crown at the national intercollegiate invitation billiard tournament yesterday by turning back Howard Rahm, Ohio State, 100 -- 73. The contestants had been deadlocked with four victories apiece in the round-robin competition before Hines, 1947 champion, took the final.

Spokesmen for groups of Indians yesterday asked for a greater part in shaping the destiny of the race at the closing session of the conference on Indian affairs which was called by the Association on American Indian Affairs, Inc., and the American Indian Fund. The conference was held at the American Museum of Natural History, Seventy-ninth Street and Central Park West.

The "Urgent Message from Henry Wallace" carried as a full-page advertisement in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Wednesday, April 6, and the address of Gen. Omar N. Bradley before the Jewish War Veterans, appearing in the same issue, furnish an illuminating study in contrasts.
