DARIEN, Conn., April 9 (AP) -- Coast Guard, police and other searchers feared tonight that two of four men, who were fishing in Long Island Sound off here, drowned when their boat was swamped by waves in a strong wind today.

THIS brisk nine-finger sonata on mayhem opens with the arrival of lawyer-sleuth Devijian in Miami to probe the murder of a black-marketing Senator. Number One Suspect, the Senator's scholarly young Negro chauffeur, is already in Dade County's skyscraper jail; and, since Devijian represents the Negro Anti-Discrimination Committee, he finds he must move warily among local politicos, playboys, bookies, bouncers and super-tanned sirens.
CHICAGO, April 9 -- Charles M. Odorizzi resigned today as vice president of Montgomery Ward Co. The 40-year-old executive has been in charge of the mail order division for eight years.

The $50,000 in $100 bills for which a feverish search had been conducted since it was reported "missing" from the freight office of the KLM Royal Dutch Airlines at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, at 2 P. M. Friday, was found early yesterday in a hole in the ground.
LONDON. April 9 (Reuters)It was an inspired Scottisi team that today drubbed England, 3--1, before 99,500 in Wembley Stadium to capture soccer's triple crown.

EARLY this month the ground is carpeted with the gray-green leaves of Erythronium americanum. Otherwise known as troutlily, dogtooth violet and divers nicknames, they are excellent for shady places in the flower or shrub border, and in the rock garden.

NOW that "We Were Strangers" ("Rough Sketch") is ready for release, Horizon Pictures, the John Huston-Sam Spiegel company, is in motion again on a second project. This, Spiegel let it be known last week, is "The Third Secret," an adaptation of Dostoievsky's "The Eternal Husband," and, he added, "James Mason likes t very much and it's only a matter of financial arrangements now."

In 1910 the women's garment district in New York was centered in the narrow streets of the East Side. The majority of the factories were in dirty, wooden walk-ups, with splintered and sagging floors. A wood-burning stove in the middle of the room provided the only heat in the winter, and the constantly burning gas jets made the already humid atmosphere intolerable in the summer.

The approach of the Passover holidays, commemorating the deliverance of the ancient Hebrews from bondage in Egypt, brings hope for progress in human liberty and brotherhood, Rabbi David de Sola Pool said yesterday in a sermon in the Spanish and Portuguese Synagogue, Seventieth Street and Central Park West.
WASHINGTON, April 9 -- Prospects now are strong for a deficit in the fiscal year 1949-50 unless taxes are increased. And an increase in taxes does not appear very likely at the present time.

WHEN animals turn the tables on human beings the result is always highly satisfactory to children -- perhaps because it appeals to their innate sense of justice. This story, told in the rhythms (but not the dia lect) of a Southern folk tale, makes good use of the theme.

The bright prospects of the North Atlantic pact, which promise the ultimate stabilization of Europe, were clouded last week by the increasing difficulties of our occupation policies in Germany and Japan.

Several card parties will be held during the coming weeks to raise funds for the work of various philanthropies. One will be the bridge and bazaar in behalf of the Artists and Teachers Benevolent Society on May 3 at the Pierre. Proceeds will be donated to the needs of the organization, which was founded in 1915 by Mary A. Fisher to provide care and shelter for needy artists and teachers.
WASHINGTON, April 9 -- The National Women's party, for twenty-six years crusader for an Equal Rights Amendment, appeared to have high hopes for success as it held its convention here this week.

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- Scathing criticism of United States aid policies and officials in Greece is contained in an unpublished report in the hands of the Joint Congressional Committee on Foreign Economic Cooperation.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., April 9 -- Confidence in a continuing high advertising volume was expressed here yesterday by leading executives as the American Association of Advertising Agencies ended its three-day meeting at Greenbrier Hotel.

MANY of the forty-four State Legislatures meeting in 1949 are considering or will consider bills to provide modern medical care for alcoholics. This is a hopeful trend away from the established morality approach to problem drinking. If it continues, many thousands of alcoholics can be rehabilitated by medical science and the prob lem of alcoholism brought under control.
"FOR the first time since the war" is a phrase that has almost petered out. But we are happy to revive it again in connection with a bunch of items we have been saving up in a special folder.

BERLIN, April 9 -- The Western Allied military governors sent to the Parliamentary Council in Bonn today the Occupation Statute expressing the wish of the United States, British and French Governments that the German people should enjoy self government to a maximum possible degree.

NOTHING in the history of modern medicine has been more dramatic than the rise of psychiatry and psychoanalysis as potent influences in studying and alleviating man's emotional and physical disorders. And yet too frequently the methods which these sciences use are considered more as forms of a modern black magic than the applications of an orderly and reasonable science.

Military assistance from the United States to peace-loving nations constitutes the best international insurance against the threat of aggression, Lieut. Gen. Walter Bedell Smith, new commander of the First Army, declared last night.

Six high school students listed yesterday the vital issues in the news as these: The North Atlantic pact, the three-power agreement on Germany, the East-West conflict, the appeal of eight powers to the United States for financial and military assistance, the European Recovery Program and the trial of the eleven Communist leaders here.
WASHINGTON, April 9 -- An apparent direct association between cosmic rays and the progress of tuberculosis has just been shown by a Dutch investigator, Dr. S. G. Ong of the University of Leyden.
The United States Military Government German Exposition opened yesterday at the Museum of Science and Industry in Rockefeller Center, with exhibits inside and pickets outside.

BEING confident that there will be no hitches to endanger the 1949-50 season, the Metropolitan Opera Association last week sent out notices to its 7,000 subscribers inviting them to renew their subscriptions. The circular carried the news that prices will remain unchanged, that ehe new season will open Nov. 21 and that it will again run for sixteen weeks.

IN this first novel, Robert K. Marshall spins an appealing, ballad-like tale of his native North Carolina mountains. It is the story of the Little Squire, last of the Boydens, a strange, haunted family set apart from their mountain neighbors by a degree of prosperity and the violence that has marked their history.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., April 9 -- Rutgers opened its home baseball season today by defeating Fordham, 9 -- 6, before 600 fans.

MIDDLEBURG, Va., April 9 (AP) -- Cormac, a dark-brown, 6-year-old gelding owned and ridden by 17-year-old Eugene Weymouth of Greenville, Del., today won the four-mile Louie Leith Cup Memorial Steeplechase.

A NEW type of slide-mounting device, the Bindomat, will soon be made available by E. Leitz, Inc., 304 Hudson Street. The unit provides a convenient method of mounting, lining up and binding 35mm and 2 1/4-inch-square transparencies.

A Washington critic of Equity's position regarding racial discrimination at the National Theatre here states that racial intolerance in the nation's capital carries the weight of 150 years with it. If the traditionalists continue to pile up the years, they will have the local mores originating in the Dark Ages, which period is no doubt the proper setting for racial hate.

Dr. Halvard M. Lange, Norwegian Foreign Minister, declared yesterday that he was opposed to the inclusion of Spain in the North Atlantic pact, contending that her participation "would weaken the basis of the pact."

THE TIMES has rendered a great service by presenting Dr. Meiklejohn's article. Sidney Hook's statements were convincing and authoritative. They did not ring true. As a college student seeking the truth, and a student of American history and thought, I sensed a paradox in Mr. Hook's arguments.

Recent passage of a disability compensation bill by the closing session of the New York Legislature opens a vast market potential for insurance men. Casualty writers estimate that the measure affects 170,000 to 25,000 employers.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- The United States faces a new era in the history of public school education, Dr. Earl J. McGrath, recently appointed United States Commissioner of Education, said here today. The future, he predicted, will bring a tremendous expansion on all levels, from nursery school through the university.

LAWRENCE, Mass., April 9 -- A telegram stating that "elements of a full-scale depression" exist in Lawrence was sent to President Truman today by Representative Thomas J. Lane, Democrat, of Massachusetts.

PAMELA KELLINO, the name under which Mrs. James Mason is known to a wide public, was brought up in a kind of domestic zoo. Her mother, it seems, found herself literally, unable to pass a pet-shop window. Dogs, cats, rabbits, goldfish, canaries, lovebirds, ducks, even horses and goats, created a profusion of animal sights, sounds and smells in and around her home.

Savings in costs, sufficient to enable manufacturers to meet lower price demands during a recession period, can be derived from installing adequate waste, scrap, salvage and reworked production controls in the majority of America's leading industrial plants which do not use modern quality control methods.
VIENNA, April 9 -- The Austrian Government thanked the United States, British and French Governments today for their renunciation of all claims to German external property in Western Austria.

TITUS POMPONIUS ATTICUS, Cicero's well-known friend and correspondent, was one of the wealthiest and most cultivated men of his time, a unique figure in an age which for unrest, turmoil and violence can be compared only to our own.

LED by a trio of Southerners, two of whom are among the most courtly of Hollywood's citizens, while the third is widely regarded as a refreshing study in American youth, a Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer location unit of forty-eight members is currently engaged in a duel of manners and social interplay with the residents of this old town of the Magnolia State.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- President Truman created an emergency board by executive order today to investigate the dispute that has kept thousands of Railway Express Agency employes in New York idle since March 9. Though the dispute is countrywide, the stoppage has been confined to the New York City area, where it began after the agency asserted that the employes were engaging in slowdown tactics.

ALBANY, April 9 -- The State Tax Commission today urged all residents of New York who must file returns for personal income tax or the unincorporated business tax to mail the returns as soon as possible. About 3,500,000 returns are expected.

ATLANTA, Ga., April 9 -- School teachers of twenty-one southeast Georgia counties agreed today they would not sign contracts for another year unless the state made some provision to improve facilities and raise their salaries. They asked that the Legislature reconvene to deal with the school situation if Gov. Herman Talmadge continued to refuse to issue a call.
BUENOS AIRES, April 9 -The Argentine Football Association today suspended more than 200 players for two years for failure to reach contract agreements.

HERE is an invaluable book for any one planning to live in a hot climate -- or any climate likely to be warm for a great portion of the year. Beginning with such preparations as immunizations and the selection of clothes, Dr. Calverley, who is an experienced physician in the field of tropical medicine, places special emphasis on the problems of rearing a family in a hot climate.

THE fact that both Russia and America have greatly widened their orbits of control and influence has been recognized by everyone. The importance of * * * the rise in Asia of new forms of power not subject to the old forms of imperial control has been seriously underestimated.

CHICAGO, April 9 -- Radio parts manufacturing firms here have been active and "in good shape" as far as orders are concerned. There has been some curtailment of employment in recent weeks. While accurate figures have not been available, estimates indicate an over-all reduction of about 25 per cent.

FOR a number of years mothers coming to a well-child clinic have been told by a nurse or pediatrician, "There's a clinic upstairs which is interested in helping mothers train their children in good habits." The mothers were free to use or ignore this service, as they pleased.

WE have just returned from England, a land where the curtain rises at 7 P. M., but where it rises in more than fifty theatres in the West End of London and keeps rising in countless others in every town and hamlet in every province of that country.

Two Brooklyn high school boys accused of embarking on a short-lived but whirlwind stick-up career on March 25 were held on charges of assault and robbery and violation of the Sullivan law in Brooklyn Week-End Court yesterday.

CHUCK LACEY, completing his third year in major league baseball, was being acclaimed one of the great catchers of all time. Without warning, his active playing career was abruptly ended by an accident. Given an opportunity to manage the team and to play or pinch-hit occasionally, he seemed to be on the threshold of renown in a new capacity.

Ever since Trilby and La Boheme, the popular conception of an artist has been one of long hair, flowing tie, and "artistic" temperament.

Asserting that a sixth of the population could not afford to pay for the medical care it needed, J. Donald Kingsley, acting Federal Security Administrator, contended yesterday that the nation's health was being endangered by the dollar barrier between the patient and physician.

The idea of celebrating the founding of the United Nations on April 25 each year, mentioned in your columns on April 7, offers great possibilities if the day could be made a legal holiday.

ALL the familiar elements of the Southern problem novel are present in Mrs. Sumner's new book. Her heroine, young Bentley Carr, who has married into the poor but aristocratic Churston family, has to cope with long-hidden miscegenation, varying degrees of intolerance, a Northern reformer, a future for her child, a dead love and a new one.

BOWIE, Md., April 9 (AP) -- George M. Jacobson's Big Dial found little opposition in the $10,000 added Southern Maryland Handicap, closing feature today. Following the late withdrawal of Claude Tanner's Nearway, Big Dial romped to victory at 7 to 10 before 17,897 racegoers.

AGNES DE MILLE has assembled an impressive list of performers, including herself, for a pair of benefit performances on Saturday and Sunday at the Lexington Avenue "Y." Next Sunday evening the Ballet Theatre will open its three-week season at the Metropolitan Opera House, celebrating its local return after nearly a year.

NEW light is being thrown on what ails the movie industry by a contingent of top Twentieth Century-Fox executives as they awing around the country telling theatre owners that the producer-distributors are not getting a fair shake of the dollars coming through the box office.

Ellsworth B. Buck, former United States Representative and one-time president of the Board of Education here, who was shot and seriously wounded last Tuesday, was discharged yesterday from the Staten Island Hospital at New Brighton.

A step toward forecasting in situations where formerly lack of information made the probability of error high was described yesterday by Dr. E. J. Gumbel of New York and Dr. H. von Schilling of the Naval Research Laboratory, New London, Conn., in a paper presented before the Institute of Mathematical Statistics meeting at Columbia University.

Faced with a rush of re-orders that could not be filled in time for Easter, New York garment manufacturers last week pointed out that stronger buying policies by retailers earlier in the season would have made it possible for stores to top their best previous records.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 9 -- Facing a show-down between left and right-wing forces, delegates attending a bistate district convention of the United Electrical Workers, CIO, closed ranks long enough today to show unanimity on a nonpolitical issue but not until the rightists had obtained a clear majority in two minor tests with their adversaries.
OTTAWA, April 9 -- Parliament adjourned last night for an Easter recess that will be employed by all parties in examining general election prospects.

Fears of a possible imminent industry price war are plaguing carpet manufacturers, several mill representatives declared last week. The feeling that a price war may occur results from avowedly temporary substantial price concessions on a limited number of patterns by two leading mills during the week and the first real postwar return by others to traditional pre-war dropping of patterns to be liquidated at good discounts.
MOSCOW, April 9 -- A new play depicting the rout of agents of United States imperialism has scored a smash hit on Moscow's theatrical boards, this time at the famous Vakhtanga Theatre.

HONOLULU -- A major building and expansion program covering Hawaii's hotels and other tourist accommodations was proposed at the all-carrier conference here last week, which was attended by representatives of American air and steamship lines, travel agencies, hotels and advertising companies.
SOFIA, Bulgaria, April 9 (UP) -- A communique branded as "pure fiction" today recent Yugoslav allegations that large numbers of Communists had been arrested in Bulgaria.

A drastic revision of the American system of education, to place greater emphasis on vocational and technical training, was proposed yesterday by Dr. William J. Wallin, Chancellor of the Board of Regents.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- The United States, France and Britain cast a host of historical precedents overboard this week in a demonstration of Western solidarity unparalleled in peacetime. They chartered in general a new course for the North Atlantic community as a whole and in particular a new approach to the problem of Germany.

Subsidies for Farmers The Truman Administration last week put before the Eighty-first Congress a new farm program -- a program of vast economic and political implications. It took a new approach to the role of the farmer in the national economy. It took a new approach to the relationship among farmers, consumers and the Government -- an approach that seemed to be influenced by the "welfare state" principles of President Truman's "fair deal."

Nineteenth century landscapes, portraits and genre paintings will be auctioned on Wednesday at 8 P. M. in the first of two sales to be held this week at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street. The pictures are from various owners, among them Mrs. Louis V. Aronson of New York and Arthur J. B. Tait of Clearwater, Fla.
Highlighted by the world famous marching precision of 2,200 cadets from the United States Military Academy at West Point, New York's last Army Day parade swung down Fifth Avenue...

It is in a way unfortunate that the European Recovery Program, the North Atlantic Pact and proposals for military aid to Western Europe have all come up at once. The Senate's discussion of the ECA authorizations was inevitably affected by these related subjects.

TO THE EDITOR: Some weeks ago I read with great enjoyment Helen Colton's article on "Lassie" ("Top Dog in Hollywood"). Today I saw a showing of "The Hills of Home" and, contrary to my usual behavior at a Lassie picture, did not shed one tear.

Theodore Jacobsen, 9 years old, of 225 Fifty-sixth Street, Brooklyn, a Marine cadet in the Bluejacket Guard group, which meets in Public School 194, Sixtieth Street and Sixth Avenue, Brooklyn, marched with his unit in the Army Day parade yesterday but lost his friends at the disbanding point at Sixty-second Street and First Avenue.
The best laid schemes o' mice and men -- and now zoo officials -- gang aft agley.

SIMPLE and unpretentious, Miss Panova's tale centers about a Russian hospital train that was set up in the early days of the war and assigned to the lines in the rear of the fighting armies. Its personnel -- the Commissar, the doctors, nurses, machinists, cooks -- gradually form a closely-knit collective.

Considerable increase in the volume of summer buying and a substantially improved fall season in the apparel, accessories and associated lines was the consensus of forecasts among salesmen polled here last week, some of whom had recently returned from road trips.
Despite increasing evidence that normal conditions are returning swiftly for the domestic steel industry, its leaders are not worried -- yet -- that a major recession is imminent.

America's medical care of its 36,000,000 children is among the best in the world. Yet according to the two-volume report of the American Academy of Pediatrics which has just been published by the Commonwealth Fund, medical care for children in this country varies greatly from community to community.
Cancer can be cured, if you act in time! Medical records show that chances of being cured are almost fifty-fifty if danger signals are recognized and a doctor's care sought in time.
TEL AVIV, April 9 -- There is no love lost between Israel and Britain for many reasons, but both seem to be reaching a point where they realize that they need each other.

"The greatest service we can do the common man today is to abolish him and make all men uncommon," Sir Norman Angell, economist and author, declared yesterday at the opening session of the first annual Dean's Day of Columbia University's School of Engineering.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, April 9 (AP) -- Earl Cochell of San Francisco was extended to four sets today before he defeated the veteran Sidney B. Wood of New York in the singles final of the Coral Beach tennis tournament. The scores were 6 -- 2, 4 -- 6, 10 -- 8, 6 -- 1.

THOUGH Easter is not a heavy-travel holiday like the Fourth of July and Labor Day, airlines, railroads and buses will augment their services for the coming week-end beginning Wednesday. Easter will find many New Yorkers taking advantage of the four-day holiday to make short trips out of town, while out-of-towners will converge on Manhattan to view the Easter Parade on Fifth Avenue, the flower displays and to attend the sunrise service in Central Park.

IN appearance, "Makers of Opera" is a very attractive book; its binding handsome, its typography clear and well spaced, its illustrations arresting, its pages thick and glossy. This favorable impression is further intensified by the author's introduction:

Army's A team, with 1,408 points, outscored nineteen others yesterday at the City College range in the New York sectional shoot of the National Rifle Association championships. Army's B squad was second with 1,389, while N. Y. U. placed third with 1,381.
EUROPE'S opinions about Americans have grown more complex since Samuel Johnson in 1775 remarked: "They are a race of convicts and ought to be thankful for anything we allow them short of hanging."

The race for the saver's dollar has developed into a heated contest among savings institutions, according to present indications. Banks, traditional leaders in the field, have been losing ground in recent years, and it now appears that they have become concerned over their position.

MOST New Yorkers have never been inside a truly modern house. Any who wanted to would have had to obtain an introduction to the man who owns one, make an appointment to see it and travel for at least an hour from Times Square.
RICHMOND, April 9 -- Spring planting, state politics and public school problems held main interest here this week.
Good pitching and tight fielding carried the New York University baseball team to an 8-3 victory over Villanova at Ohio Field yesterday.
TOKYO, April 9 -- Many members of the Japanese Diet were in an angry mood this week over the "austerity" budget of the Government of Premier Shigeru Yoshida.

Statements of condition of the fifteen largest banks in this city for March 31 showed an almost general decline in deposits and resources in the first quarter of 1949. With few exceptions, the banks had smaller loans and discounts and holdings of Government securities than at the end of 1948.

WASHINGTON, April 9 (AP) -- The National Intercollegiate Rifle championship was won today by Woodward G. Eicke, George Washington University sophomore, with an all-time record score of 290 out of a possible 300 points.
The taxi strike was over yesterday every place except in the Bronx. There fifty drivers for the Willow Cab Company, 728 East 141st Street, continued the walkout.

AZALEAS splash their brilliant colors across the landscape for two full months in spring, and fortunate indeed is the gardener who grows them. Yet many who have visited Southern gardens and seen the vivid azalea displays are under the impression that they can only be grown in mild climates.

THE Camera Club, which in its day nurtured Edward Steichen and expelled Alfred Stieglitz, has just passed its sixty-fifth anniversary. The oldest amateur photography group in New York and the only one in the country to operate its own quarters continuously since March 30, 1884, the club has been the scene of some of the most important events in photographic history.

The lights are on in Wall Street these nights, and brokerage firms are advertising in trade union papers. If interpretations are correct, these are significant developments that augur well for the securities business.

With the "green light" now given United States exports of many equipment items to Yugoslavia, total two-way American trade with that country this year is expected to approximate $24,000,000, or about double the 1948 figure.

ONE of the most engaging qualities about the children in Noel Streatfeild's stories is that they have their normal quota of human frailty. It is a debatable point if Jane, the central figure of this latest of the "Shoes" series, hasn't rather more than her share -- but who wouldn't sympathize with a plain middle child, whose older sister and younger brother are extremely talented?

THE April meeting of the Long Island Horticultural Society will be held in the Horticultural Building of the Long Island Agricultural and Technical Institute, Farmingdale, Tuesday at 8 P. M. "Planting Fields" will be the subject of the lecture by William C. Carter, superintendent of the W. R. Coe estate at Oyster Bay.

THIS is a single-volume history of American magazines, with occasional comment on their "influence." Written by the editor of "100 Years Ago: American Writing of 1848," it contains a spate of interesting material, intelligently arranged.

The New York City Cancer Committee awarded prizes yesterday in its seventh annual high school poster and exhibit contest. The awards were made in ceremonies at the American Museum of Natural History. Art students from Abraham Lincoln High School, Brooklyn, won the first six prizes in the poster competition.

BEAUMONT, Tex., April 9 -- The Yankees ran into their first taste of minor league opposition and a considerable bit of difficulty today at Stuart Stadium. They tangled with the Class AA Beaumont Exporters and romped off with the decision 4 to 1. But it took a lot of doing.

NANKING, April 9 -- Although the Communist army continued to drive Nationalist troops from a number of Yangtze River bridgehead positions and pressed down to within forty miles of Hankow, Government peace hopes were stimulated here today by the arrival of a mildly worded telegram sent to Acting President Li Tsung-jen by Mao Tze-tung, the Communist leader.

ON April 11, 1945, four years ago tomorrow, Harry S. Truman, Vice President of the United States, was presiding over the Senate. When the session was over he came down from the rostrum to talk with two correspondents he knew well. What he said, in effect, was this: that he did not like the Vice Presidential post, that he had not asked for it and that he wished he could be out of it.

To mark the twenty-fifth anniversary of its founding, the Blue Hill Troupe, one of the country's outstanding companies of amateur performers of Gilbert and Sullivan operettas, will present performances of "Patience" at the Hunter College Playhouse on the nights of April 20, 21 and 22, and on the afternoon of April 23. The matinee is planned especially for children.

CHICAGO, April 9 -- Senator Paul H. Douglas, Democrat, of Illinois, today gave advance notice of a proposal he will submit in the Senate for a United Nations-wide non-aggression pact, supplementing the North Atlantic pact, which would circumvent the Security Council veto.

SIGNING of the North Atlantic Treaty and passage by the Senate of the full appropriation for the European Recovery Program tended to shift some business attention last week to foreign affairs, but the main emphasis was still upon the domestic situation. On balance, industry probably eased a little further, while retail trade staged a comeback in the peak Easter shopping week.

WITH the opening last Thursday night of "South Pacific," Richard Rodgers and Oscar Hammerstein 2d once again have a smash hit on Broadway. And once again Broadway, supposed to know all the answers, is asking, "How do those guys do it, anyway?"

GENE FOWLER, reporter, sports and managing editor, motion - picture writer and author, having done distinguished lives of P. T. Barnum and John Barrymore, now tunes his typewriter to the doings of his friend James J. Walker, once Mayor of New York. The subtitle is apt, because Jimmy was distinctly a product of his period -- the idol of the Era of Wonderful Nonsense.
CHATTANOOGA, April 9 -- The Ku Klux Klan and its imitators have been stalking through various sections of the Southland with renewed frequency in recent months.

The strike of many public school teachers in Georgia that followed a state-wide voters' referendum rejection of added taxes for education calls attention anew to the great inequalities that exist, over the nation, in the money spent by the states for education.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- The House Appropriations Committee approved today a national defense budget for fiscal 1950 totaling $15,909,116,800. This sum is larger by $631,252,100 than the amount asked by President Truman in January.

Among the card parties being given this spring for the benefit of charitable organizations will be the party sponsored by the Chi Kappa Club on the afternoon of April 22 in the Wedgwood Room of the Waldorf-Astoria to further the work of the Stony Wold Sanatorium.

WEST POINT, N. Y., April 9 -An effective six-hit pitching performance by Jack McCarthy, backed up with a ten-hit offensive and the flawless fielding of his team-mates, gave Army a 10-0 victory over Swarthmore College as the cadets opened their season at Doubleday Field today.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 9 -- Officers of the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, CIO, were accused today by R. J. Thomas, assistant director of organization for the Congress of Industrial Organizations, of engaging in "a deliberately planned attack on the CIO."

The main purpose of the bill "for the reorganization of government agencies" now pending before the United States Senate is to delegate to the President plenary powers to reorganize any of the agencies of the Federal Government. The President's reorganization plans will be submitted to a review by Congress, but are to go into effect from their own legal momentum unless there are adverse votes in both House and Senate within sixty days.

THE proposal of Pan American Airways and Pan American Grace (Panagra) to interchange equipment with National Airlines is the second move in recent months by Pan American to consolidate its position as the world's largest international air carrier.
You have done a service in launching the Hook-Meiklejohn controversy. I want in.

IN his public roles, Joseph Quincy Adams, who died in 1946, was singularly fortunate. A productive Elizabethan scholar, he turned out books, articles, reviews, essays and annotated works for more than four decades; and the many references to his writings in this volume are evidence of the respect and confidence with which his labors are held.
LONDON, April 9 -- Satisfaction was expressed in British diplomatic circles here today with the decision of the International Court of Justice on the Corfu Channel mining case.

OCCUPATIONAL therapy is fast coming into its own in the hospital picture and every day more girls turn their attention to that profession as a life work. Mary Wolfe Thompson, whose vocational stories have already won a 'teen-aged audience, opens her latest story with Trudy Westcott's first morning at her first job at Hillhaven Hospital.
WASHINGTON, April 9 (AP) -The Air Force hoped in February that it might end the Berlin airlift this summer, but it now plans to keep flying supplies into the blockaded city indefinitely.

LAKE SUCCESS, April 9 -- Delegates to the spring session of the General Assembly are taking stock of the position of the United Nations in the light of the North Atlantic treaty; and it is generally agreed that United States policy will be paramount in determining the future role of the world organization.

FROM France comes a writer never before translated for American readers, Louise de Vilmorin, with a novel which in spirit is like a breath of spring air after the recent output of Sartre. "Erica's Return" is a simple love story of a young Flemish girl, and it belongs to that genre of haunting fantasy of which Alain-Fournier's "The Wanderer" is a classic.

IN late spring, when most of the planting has been done, it is fun to walk down the rows and watch the tiny seedlings rapidly develop into husky young plants. But the possibility of spring frosts is a constant threat and one the gardener must be prepared to combat quickly and on short notice.

Observers at Flushing Meadow express some surprise that Mr. Gromyko, head of the Russian delegation, has not yet let loose against the Atlantic Pact. It is true that it has not yet been placed on the agenda of the United Nations Assembly, but, in the past, a little matter like that has not deterred the Soviets when they wished to expose their point of view.

A WELL-PLANNED maintenance program for the garden is just as important for success as the proper selection of seeds and plants. No matter how much study is given to planning and planting, if the garden is neglected during the year the results are bound to prove disappointing.

Bulwarked by three Olympians and a couple of talented new recruits, the Illinois Athletic Club retained the National A. A. U. indoor hard-ball water polo championship by defeating the New York Athletic Club, 5 to 2, in the Winged Foot pool last night. It was the sixth title triumph in a row for the Chicago outfit, dominant in this rugged aquatic pastime for two decades.
PHILADELPHIA, April 9 -- A noted Protestant churchman asserted today that religion and the United Nations were better instruments for peace than the North Atlantic pact.

ATLANTA, April 9 -- The Dodgers, who have been lording it over their minor league cousins for nine straight games through Texas, Oklahoma and this state, were put in their places today. The Atlanta Crackers slapped them down rudely by a 9-1 score.

FRANKFORT, Germany -- While the hotel keepers of this country are concentrating their efforts on preparations for 1950, they are not overlooking the probability, already confirmed by advance reservations, that a large number of American tourists will visit western Germany this spring and summer.

AMMAN, Transjordan, April 9 (UP) -- Glubb Pasha, almost-legendary British chief of the Arab Legion, said today that Israel won control of Palestine through a "virtual European invasion" that brought a "new, vicious imperialism to the Middle East."

Louis Bloetjes, 40 years old, a former counselor to veterans at Columbia University and assistant to the dean of the School of Business, was found dead of gas poisoning yesterday at 9 A. M. in his apartment at 12 East Eighty-eighth Street.

RECENT anthologies have generally shown an increase in quality of content as well as usefulness of purpose. A notable example of this is "The Fellowship of the Saints," a compendium of Christian religious writings from the time of Clement of Rome in the first century to our own day, selected and arranged by Dr. Thomas S. Kepler of the Oberlin Graduate School of Theology.

THE sweeper in the skies of Miss Wright's biography is Maria Mitchell, a prodigy who became America's first woman astronomer, a distinguished member of the original Vassar faculty and a feminist leader. Maria was born in 1818 into a family of Nantucket Quakers, at which time the island was still a quietist stronghold and of course a great whaling port.

THE calmness of Hollywood's ideological temper these days, as contrasted with the frenzy of a year ago, was evidenced last week by the fact that Twentieth Century-Fox's purchase of screen rights to Albert Maltz' forthcoming novel, "The Journey of Simon McKeever," passed almost without notice.

KATHERINE SCOTT'S parents were dead, her guardian was going to America, and she rebelled at boarding school. There was no place to send her but to her mother's father or brother in southern Ireland, whom she had never seen.

THE HAGUE, April 9 -- The International Court of Justice awarded judgment to Britain today in her claim for damages from Albania for the mining of two British destroyers in Corfu Channel on Oct. 22, 1946.

FRANZ KAFKA's diaries are closer to what are called notebooks, closer to what D. H. Lawrence called his "Pansies," his unrhymed verses, than they are to a writer's journal of daily events. For Kafka, his diaries were among the means he used of learning how to write, of making sure that his writing, as long as he lived, would not wholly cease.

THE reduction of history to hokum, which, at times, seems the purposeful aim off some of our movie-makers in their striving to "entertain," is something to which this reviewer is bitterly but hopelessly resigned. So long as we have motion pictures, we're going to have much false history, we suppose.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass, April 9 -- Dean Wilbur J. Bender of Harvard College today defended the college against what he termed "the three most common criticisms" -- that Harvard is interested only in mental giants as students, that Harvard discriminates against athletics, and that Harvard is a nest of Communists.

TO THE EDITOR: In re "The Argentine Mind," by Milton Braeker, I would like to point out that throughout history the test of a nation's cultural advance and of its civilization has been, usually, the standard of living of that nation's people.

TWO of the important younger surrealist painters now exhibiting recent work -- the Frenchman Victor Brauner at the Hugo Gallery and Jimmy Ernst at the Laurel -- prove that, though surrealism as a movement has failed to make good its early claims to detonate the realms of reason and reality, it is still capable of inspiring paintings that can be classified and criticized as works of art.

ATHENS, April 9 -- Militant communism controls no part of Greece, but no part of Greece, especially the mountainous region extending along the 500-mile hostile northern border, can be reckoned safe from possible guerrilla incursion.
On Pact and Germany This is Ernest Bevin's view of the past few days: "It has been a great week in the history of the world." These were the week's events:

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 9 -- Marshal Tito in effect crystallized his break with orthodox communism today. He reminded applauding delegates of the People's Front congress that Marxism and Leninism endorsed "equality of rights and sovereignty for small nations."

In line with the need for better customer service and less costly handling of merchandise, F. R. Lazarus Company's department store in Columbus, Ohio, is making an official opening tomorrow of its "bulk merchandise building," a streamlined warehouse which guarantees twenty-four hour delivery to the customer of any merchandise sold in the store.
CHICAGO, April 9 (AP) -- Today's report of the markets in the Union Stockyards by the United States Department of Agriculture follows:

ON my arrival in New York the other day from Central America on my way back to Europe. I was shocked to learn of the letters which appeared in THE TIMES on March 6 about myself. The inquisitorial tone of both letters accusing me of crimes I did not commit gave me much distress.

CHICAGO, April 9 -- The signing of the North Atlantic pact easily captured the top attention of Central Westerners this week. A sense of gravity over the nation's commitment and of concern as to the possible consequences was evident.

In Easter promotions of women's apparel by retail stores here last week emphasis was given to millinery, toppers, print and redingote dresses, calf handbags and nylon blouses, according to a survey made especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by the Retail News Bureau, Inc.

BERLIN, April 9 -- A new crisis within the leadership of the Polish Communist party has developed over the relations between Moscow and Warsaw, it was reported here today by persons who recently returned from the Polish capital.
CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa., April 9 (AP) -- Iowa Teachers won the team championship in the National A.A.U. wrestling tournament tonight as two defending champions lost their crowns.

ATLANTIC CITY, April 9 -- The warm sunshine proved to be more powerful than the striking Hotel and Restaurant Employes Union, and the Palm Sunday week-end found Atlantic City playing host to thousands of holiday visitors.

JACK BENNY, who has made a decent living on radio for seventeen years as the amiable tightwad, doesn't give the impression of being a bit disturbed about television. He already is convinced that he will succeed in the new medium as in the old, but is in the process of working out the changes in his radio format which he thinks will be required.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., April 9 -- A cold wind and the lack of "bites" gave opening-day trout fishermen in Westchester County a healthy time outdoors and very little else. While several hundred fishermen were out early to welcome the opportunity to hook the sporty trout in streams, brooks and akes of Westchester, they met with little success, in general.

A flash fire and explosion wrecked an automobile service station at 134 Throop Avenue, Brooklyn, at 1:11 P. M. yesterday. Five persons, including two firemen, were injured slightly, five cars in or near the place were damaged, a telephone cable burned through, cutting off service over a two-block area, and two three-story tenements, one on either side of the station, were scorched by the flames.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., April 9 (AP) -- Notre Dame dominated the Southern Relays today, scoring five firsts and four seconds in the fifteen-event track meet. No team points were awarded.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 9 -- There was marked recovery in retail business activity in most areas of the Twelfth District last week. Although sales reports from larger stores disclosed an over-all loss in the entire district from the same week of last year, declines were not nearly as severe as they have been during the last several weeks.
GUY S. HENSLEY of Washington, D. C., should be taught how to do a little research before accusing the president of Actors Equity Association of using arbitrary, dictatorial tactics.

BOSTON, April 9 -- Interest mounted this week in a recent proposal of the six New England Governors to spend $2,000,000 in the next ten years on a cooperative, continuing survey of the region's economy. The project would be undertaken by a New England Development Authority, which would be empowered to seek Federal funds for financing various projects outlined in the six-state compact.
A HOST at Annual Farm and Home Week, recently held at Cornell University, was the New York State College of Home Economics, which had open house for residents of the state.

INTENSIVE studies undertaken to correct the faults of high-way-accident repeaters, now recognized as the most perplexing of all problem drivers, are being conducted by the Center for Safety Education of New York University and the New York State Bureau of Motor Vehicles.

WHILE television is kicking its heels, and leaping with lusty young life, the film studios are one by one putting up the shades, and facing what should be the busiest season of the year with dark floors and thousands of technicians out of employment.

WASHINGTON, April -- Joseph W. Kaufman, former chief prosecutor in the trial of Krupp munitions officials, tried at Nuremberg, cabled Gen. Lucius D. Clay, United States Military Governor, today protesting his recent action in amending the decree confiscating the property of Alfred Krupp von Bohlen und Halbach, German munitions and industrial magnate.
The cotton futures market was moderately active during yesterday's short session on the New York Cotton Exchange and final prices were 4 points higher to 3 points lower than on Friday.

FARMINGDALE, L. I., April 9 -- Effective pitching by Walt Jasinski and Don Ronan enabled the Kings Point Merchant Marine Academy nine to sweep both ends of a double-header against the Long Island Aggies, 6 -- 1, 8 -- 3, today.

In the belief that "traditional law school admission policies have placed undue emphasis upon quantitative requirements," the Law School of Baylor University will admit next September a selected group of students with only two years of pre-legal schooling, instead of the customary three.

On March 6 you published a letter of Pablo Casals protesting against Gaspar Cassado using his name for publicity. Your readers, and especially the innumerable friends and admirers of Pablo Casals, will be interested to hear that I visited this great musician and world citizen last fall in his voluntary exile in Prades, Southern France, near the Spanish-Catalonian border.

TOKYO, April 9 -- A direct labor attack was promised today on the policies ordered by the Occupation. The Federation of Labor Unions for the Tokyo Shibaura Engineering Works -- the largest electric machinery and appliance maker in the country -- has issued a manifesto announcing that it would launch a general strike to protest the split-up of the company's properties ordered to prevent undue concentration of economic power.

PARISIANS pride themselves on having a special defense against their troubles. It is called wit. And this spring, if the tourist wants to experience it at its local best, let him turn to any guide to the city's amusements.
Beer rationing -- a phrase calculated to cause shudders along Third Avenue -- will go into effect in hundreds of New York taverns tomorrow, it was predicted yesterday.

PATERSON, N. J., April 9 -- Hunter College's three-year reign as intercollegiate women's fencing champion came to an end today when a strong New York University squad, in command from the very start, went on to capture the 21st edition of the title event at Paterson State Teachers College. In second place was Brooklyn Colloge, with Hunter third.
THIS fairy tale from Cornwall may well turn out to be a classic. Unique in its blend of fantasy and fundamentals, it is written in a singularly cadent style, and enhanced by enchanting illustrations.

PARIS, April 9 -- The Paris press, like French officials in Germany, took it for granted today that the first French High Commissioner for Germany under yesterday's Washington agreement would be Andre Francois-Poncet, who for several months has been the Principal French political representative in Germany.

Appealing for city controls upon public loaders at the piers, Howard E. Galvin, executive vice president of the Brooklyn Chamber of Commerce, declared yesterday that present practices were causing shippers to utilize the facilities of other ports.

WHILE height and color are essential links to the balance of the border, habit of growth is perhaps the most important consideration for plantings along a path or walk. This applies particularly to grass walks in the garden, and is profitably extended to any flower bed that meets the lawn.

NEARLY a quarter of a century has flashed by since Lee Tracy acted the excitable hoofer in "Broadway," and twenty-one years have dropped into oblivion since he played the dynamic Hildy Johnson in "The Front Page."

A HEARING of the new Chamber Orchestra of Philadelphia in a program consisting mainly of seventeenth and eighteenth century music seldom played, and a reading of the literature of the New School of Music in Philadelphia, to which that orchestra belongs, point to a curious and unfortunate situation in American music today, which needs widespread remedial action and the special attention of our music educators.

OMAHA, April 9 -- Developments in the Iowa Legislature have confirmed the belief among labor union officials that they face strong opposition in their campaign against anti-closed-shop laws in that state and in Nebraska, North Dakota and South Dakota.

IN 1835 Alexis de Tocqueville pointed out an enduring paradox of American religious life: Stricter control over manners and morals was maintained by our system of free churches than by the established churches of the Old World.

THE Amsterdam Concertge-bouw Orchestra, whose management has been getting increasingly embroiled in tangles with the authorities since it decided to accept official subsidies, is now undergoing a full-dress investigation by a commission of the Municipal Council.

Although eventually the United States may have to develop a synthetic liquid fuels industry to supplement its natural petroleum resources, the oil industry believes that there is no necessity for the immediate construction of synthetic oil plants on a large scale as proposed recently by Julius A. Krug, Secretary of the Interior.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- The opposition to much of President Truman's legislative program by many in Congress appears to have sharpened a bit this week, though it is too early to write off that program.
WASHINGTON, April 9 -- Its leaders driving for passage by Monday night, the House held an extraordinary all-day Saturday session today to speed renewal of spending authority for European recovery.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 9 -- Marshal Tito told the third People's Front congress, which convened today, that "no intimidation from the West or East can divert us from our principles as determined followers of Marxism-Leninism or from our road to socialism."

MOSCOW, April 9 -- Soviet physical and atomic science again today carried off top honors in annual Stalin Prize awards, with emoluments of 15,250,000 rubles, distributed to Soviet scientists, research specialists, technicians, designers and inventors.

The tenty-seventh annual selection of well-designed books made by the an display at the New York Public Library as well as in Boston. Washington Chcago and San Francisco. The exhibits will run through April 26. Pages from six of the Fifty Books are shown here.

NEW ORLEANS, April 9 -- Clint Hartung, weathering a rough second inning, today became the second Giant pitcher to do a fulltime job on the mound as Leo Durocher's Polo Grounders up-ended the Pirates, 8 to 5. The victory, viewed by 7,678 fans, squared the spring series between the clubs at two victories apiece.

SAN MARINO, Calif., April 9 -- The most intensive and desperate rescue effort since the Floyd Collins tragedy in Kentucky in 1925 was being pressed late tonight to save Kathy Fiscus, 3 1/2 years old, who has been trapped ninety feet down the narrow shaft of an abandoned well for nearly thirty-two hours.

The free weekly art lecture at the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street, will offer on Tuesday at 6 P. M. "The Art of Wood Carving." Peter Lipman-Wulf, sculptor, will be the speaker.

THE carefully selected exhibition of oils, pastels and drawings by Degas, at the Wildenstein Galleries, is so important in itself that it seems at first glance unnecessary to attach double significance to it. But such significance is there, in connection with the current Braque retrospective at the Museum of Modern Art.

MYSTERY novelists have been accused, with some justice, of neglecting the dignity of death in their preoccupation with establishing whodunit. It's also true, however, that they've largely neglected the awful indignity of petty family viciousness that can arise post mortem.

"PEACE OF SOUL" is the twenty-third volume by the eloquent and popular, and perceptibly hurried, Catholic orator and professor. While refusing to write off his contemporaries as irresponsible neurotics, Monsignor Sheen does proclaim "the modern soul" to be radically introverted and stubbornly conditioned to approach reality from the deep well of its own unquiet self-consciousness.
COLOMBO, Ceylon, April 10 (Reuters) -- The Government of Ceylon will spend $16,500,000 on improvements to Colombo harbor, reputed to be the third largest artificial harbor in the world.

The American Gas and Electric Company's operations last year resulted in a net income of $19,348,009, equal to $4.32 a share, compared with $18,727,781, or $4.17 a share, in 1947, according to its annual report for 1948, which is being distributed to stockholders today.

IN slightly less than four weeks another Kentucky Derby will be staged before 100,000 or so screaming, semi-hysterical fans at sprawling Churchill Downs. But this will be more than just another Derby. It will be an ultra-special occasion because this will be the seventy-fifth Run for the Roses, the diamond jubilee celebration of the most glamorous race that the American turf has known.

Lit Brothers, Philadelphia department store, "had the largest volume of business, the greatest number of transactions, and the biggest profits in its history," during the fiscal year ending on last Jan. 31, according to Harold W. Brightman, president. Mr. Brightman made the statement in issuing the company's annual report published today.

Reversing "fifty years of a do-nothing policy from the standpoint of collective activity," the men's wear industry will spend between $500,000 and $1,000,000 on the promotion of men's fashions this year, Bert Bacharach, director of the Men's Fashion Guild of America, told more than 800 leaders of the men's wear industry who attended the dinner of the Associated Men's Wear Retailers of New York at the Statler Hotel last night.

Edward R. Stettinius Jr., former Secretary of State, has signed a contract with Doubleday for a book giving the inside story of the Yalta Conference. Scheduled for publication in September, the book will be titled "Roosevelt and the Russians."

Paul Blanshard, author, lawyer and former Commissioner of Accounts of this city, called last night for "a truly democratic resistance movement to Catholic power" in order to preserve traditional American freedoms in scientific and cultural affairs.

WASHINGTON, April 10 (UP) -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican, of Wisconsin, told his fellow Congressmen today that they would stand convicted as "greedy, grasping politicians" if they passed a tougher rent control bill for the District of Columbia than they did for the rest of the nation.

MOSCOW, April 10 -- The long list of Stalin Prizes awarded to Soviet authors, composers, artists and architects is notable for the encouragement to a group of previously inconspicuous musicians. These include many composers from various constituent republics, among them Georgia, Estonia Azerbaijan and Daghistan.

LONDON, April 10 -- As still more Labor party losses are recorded from last week's local Government elections, Morgan Phillips, Labor party secretary, called on his followers today to review their organization and to give a better account of themselves in the next round of the fight with the Conservatives.

All those conversations that have been carried on between Katharine Hepburn on the one hand and the Theatre Guild on the other culminated in the signing of the stage and film star to portray Rosalind next season in "As You Like It" under the Guild's banner, it was announced yesterday.
BERLIN, April 10 (AP) -- Following is the text of the Occupation Statute drawn up by the three Western powers for control of Western Germany:

Some cancers can be cured today. Many more cold be cured if they reached medical care earlier. Better diagnostic techniques are being found. A recent development has raised the percentage of correct diagnosis of lung cancer, now operable, from 36 per cent to 95 per cent.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- The next step in the history of the North Atlantic pact will come tomorrow or Tuesday when President Truman will send the treaty to the Senate for its approval. It is agreed that its consideration both in committee and on the Senate floor will be long and exhaustive. The Administration's proposal to supply arms to the European signers, which will follow the treaty submission, will get similar scrutiny.

WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP) -- The Army has disclosed that it has about 96,000 men in the United States zone of Germany, but has planned to reduce the total during the next year to about 92,000. A force of about 5,000 men in Trieste, the state at the northern end of the Adriatic, facing Yugoslavia, will remain unchanged.

LAKE SUCCESS, April 10 -- A Latin American bloc headed by Brazil is endeavoring to find a sure formula through which the resolutions of the 1946 General Assembly of the United Nations on the Franco regime in Spain will be either amended or declared void, it was learned today.

Plans for converting the apartment house at 90-10 150th Street, in Jamaica, Queens, into a nurses' home have been announced by Mary Immaculate Hospital which bought the property through the Harold I. Cross Company, broker, and insured title with the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.
Cardinal Spellman officiated at the solemn blessing by palms that preceded the solemn mass of Palm Sunday in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 10 -- The first challenge in eight years to Harry Bridges' leadership of the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, CIO, came early today in nominations that closed the union's stormy weeklong convention.

The warm weather fashions now filling the shops give a striking illustration of the two extremes fashion designers have taken in the field of cotton. Sturdy work fabrics like jean and burlap are transformed into modish town costumes, as are filmy voiles and transparent organdies.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 10 -- One of its paradoxical aspects of this period of history is that as a result of her political quarrel with other nations of the same Communist ideology, Yugoslavia has been forced to look toward the capitalist West for the commerce necessary to the survival of her program of a planned economy.

CHICAGO, April 10 -- The second annual convention of Americans for Democratic Action adopted today foreign and domestic policy statements generally consonant with those of the Truman Administration and unanimously elected Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, Democrat, of Minnesota, national chairman.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., April 10 -- In a puffy nor'wester that ranged from five to seventeen knots and made smart although wobbly going at times, the sailing dinghies at the Larchmont Yacht Club had ten races today through water alternately ripple-streaked and glassy, according to where the slippery breeze hit it.

The Young Women's Christian Association here plans the construction of three buildings, renovation of seven others and two camps, and provision of additional residence facilities in its first large-scale building activity since 1913.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- Three-hundred signers of an open letter urged today that Congress reject the North Atlantic pact, and called upon President Truman to begin direct negotiations with Russia to "settle outstanding differences."

A proposed local law to compel motorists to remove ignition keys from unattended parked automobiles will be discussed tomorrow at a meeting of the General Welfare Committee of the City Council. It is sponsored by the Youth Counsel Bureau of the District Attorney's office as a way of reducing teen-age delinquency.

FRANKFORT, Germany, April 10 -- The text of the Occupation Statute was delivered here this morning to Dr. Konrad Adenauer, president of the Parliamentary Council, by Hans Simons, United States liaison official.

Orville Fredricksburg (Curly) Stewart was in the midst of another of his diversified chores as general utility worker with Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey Circus when a veteran trouper observed that yesterday marked Curly's fifty-fifth consecutive year as a circus man.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- Even before the first formal request for military assistance, leaders of several Western European countries recommended to Kenneth C. Royall, Secretary of the Army, that the number of American troops on the European continent be increased.

Another busy week in the art world gets off to a start with a show of modern French and American primitive paintings at the Sidney Janis Gallery and with one-man shows of paintings by Robert Gwathmey at the ACA and by Paul Sample at the Associated American Gallery.
WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP) -- Rent Administrator Tighe Woods said today "when a governor approves a decontrol action taken by a State Legislature or a local governing body, the action is final."

With a strong consumer demand for Easter apparel reversing the downward trend noted in retail sales within the last few months, retailers had to fill in rapidly diminishing inventories here last week, according to a report on the New York wholesale garment markets prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

Some of your admiring readers may think that the Appellate Division, by reversing Justice Null's decision, has ended the life of the fort. They are wrong. The fort has as many lives as a cat. My father heard Jenny Lind sing there in the Fifties and I expect my youngest great-grandson will hear one of her successors warble from the same nest or perch.

PARIS, April 10 -- The wholesale price index for industrial products dropped from 2159 in February to 2129 in March on the basis of 1938 as 100. This represents a fall of 1.4 per cent. It is the first time in twenty-four months that the index has not risen.

NUREMBERG, Germany, April 10 -- A crowd of 2,500 excited Ukrainian displaced persons, protesting Russian Government policies, attempted today to march on the former Russian mission building in Munich but was dispersed by heavily-armed United States military police who hurled several dozen tear-gas bombs into their midst.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- President Truman, in a message to the National Economic Action Conference which opened here tonight, called for closer cooperation of farm, labor and cooperative organizations which "have a common stake in the economic progress of the nation."

SYDNEY, Australia, Monday, April 11 (AP) -- The independent Sydney Morning Herald today editorially criticized Immigration Minister Arthur A. Calwell for his severe application of the white Australia policy.

BERLIN, April 10 -- Negotiations to organize a privately owned press communications company have started between representatives of the reconstructed press of Western Germany and the German Economic Commission for the bizonal area.

TOKYO, April 10 -- Japanese were speculating with the greatest interest today on a possible sequel here to the agreement among the three major Western powers to abolish the military rule in Germany after the establishment of a new western German State and substitute civilian control.

A new air-conditioned theatre is under construction at Lakewood Park, Pa., for the Kenley Players, who will open their summer season on June 14, it was announced here yesterday. John Kenley is operator of the theatre.

It is evident from Mr. Gromyko's first speech that he did not come to this session of the U. N. Assembly with instructions to spare his verbal ammunition. The fireworks started on the tattered issue of the Italian colonies. In four years of sterile argument the Soviet Union has changed its position often enough to demonstrate that its purpose is not to settle this question but to leave it unsettled.

Fifty thousand persons passed through the Greenhouse of Prospect Park yesterday to view a great cross made of flowers, which will be on display until a week after Easter. According to a guard, this is the fiftieth year that the Park Department has built the huge cross.

ALBANY, April 10 -- The State Tax Commission announced today that, with the new filing deadline only nine days away, approximately 85 per cent of the estimated 4,000,000 persons who must file state income tax returns for 1948 have yet to do so.
Fellowships amounting to $395,000 were announced yesterday by the John Simon Guggenheim Memorial Foundation in its twenty-fifth annual series of fellowship awards to scholars and artists.

It is perhaps invidious for those in American who have never known the exhaustions and horrors of war at first hand to point the finger of scorn at European music, which is apparently utterly in too weak and fatigued a psychological state to be able to get out of its past.
The Grand Union Company will open its newest supermarket on Wednesday at 49-09 Thirty-first Avenue, Woodside, Queens, it was announced over the week-end by L. P. Shield, president.

LAKE SUCCESS, April 10 -- The United Nations will be asked tomorrow by the World Jewish Congress to take steps to guarantee the rights of 28,000 to 30,000 Jewish inhabitants living in Tripolitania and Cyrenaica, in the former Italian colony of Libya.

In a press interview on April 1 the Italian Minister for Foreign Affairs advocated an Italian trusteeship over former colonies in Africa on the pretense that such a regime would assure participation in their operation by Europeans who knew and understood them and their people, while it would give a recognized position to the natives.

The first act of the three-man emergency board designated by President Truman in the Railway Express Agency wage-hour dispute will be to call for an end of the month-old tie-up of express operations in this city, it became known last night.
PARIS, April 10 -- Inaugurating the midseason, Jacques Fath features a flyaway overskirt in a collection of enchanting linen gowns, dramatically simple, as lovely as summer itself.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 10 -- Dr. Charles Seymour announced today that he would retire as president of Yale University on July 1, 1950, because of his conviction that "fresh leadership of the most vigorous sort" would best serve the university's interest. He will be 65 years old next Jan. 1.

A little girl was dead. That was the news -- just one little girl. Three days ago only a few people knew the name of this little girl. Yesterday there was no one in this country and few in other civilized countries who had not heard of 3-year-old Kathy Fiscus of San Marino, Calif. Millions upon millions followed this heartbreaking story as they did no other news of the day.

The New York Central System last year expended nearly $106,000,000 in carrying forward its post-war program of modernization and improvement, the railroad announced in its 1948 report, for publication today. Of this amount slightly more than $90,000,000 was for the Central and leased lines and the remainder for controlled and affiliated companies.

David Soyer, serious young 'cellist, who has given two previous New York recitals and who was heard with the Bach Aria Group for its first season, was the artist late yesterday afternoon in the Carnegie Hall "Twilight Series."
BERLIN, April 10 -- The Occupation Statute handed to the Parliamentary Council at Bonn by the Western powers this morning already is being sharply attacked in influential German political circles.

Tomorrow night's total eclipse of the moon will be televised, weather permitting, by WPIX in cooperation with the Hayden Planetarium. A specially mounted camera of The Daily News television station will focus on the eclipse through a telescope on the thirty-sixth-floor roof of the News Building at 220 East Forty-second Street.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 10 -- Although in possession of a numerical majority, a right wing group failed today in an attempt to put District 7 of the United Electrical Workers, Congress of Industrial Organizations, on record as supporting a movement to remove the present left wing international leadership of the union.

SAN MARINO, Calif., April 10 -- The anxious and compassionate vigil which millions throughout the nation, personally and through thoughts and prayers, had kept for two nights and days for 3-year-old Kathy Fiscus came to a sorrowful end tonight.

VIENNA, April 10 -- How to organize labor and management in nationalized industry to obtain steadily increasing output from more or less constant resources is the recurring concern of Czechoslovakia's leaders in the fourth month of their all-embracing five-year plan.

Prices of cotton in the domestic market continued in a relatively narrow trading range last week. The trend was toward firmer ground. At the close of trading on Saturday active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange showed for the week net gains of 1 to 28 points compared with net advance of 7 to 50 points in the previous week.

BOSTON, April, 10 -- Local 25 of the American Federation of Labor Teamsters' Union, the 9,000 members of which do a large share of New England's trucking, voted today to authorize a strike starting at midnight Monday, unless a last-minute conference produced a settlement.

HAWTHORNE, N. Y., April 10 -- A plea that child care agencies pledge mutual cooperation in meeting the problems of placement and care of emotionally disturbed and dependent children of New York was made today by Ralph E. Samuel, president of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York.

With 18,100 paid admissions counted up to 4 P. M. yesterday, the United States Military Government German Exhibition at 30 Rockefeller Plaza will begin a five-day session for wholesale and retail buyers at 10 A. M. today.
WASHINGTON, April 10 (UP) -- American Federation of Labor printing pressmen and stereotypers on the capital's four daily newspapers voted today to strike at 8 A. M. tomorrow.

Ralph Sheldon, young pianist from Minneapolis, gave his third New York recital late yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. He was heard in a program consisting of the Bach - Busoni "Chaconne": Schumann's "Kreisleriana," and the Nocturne in C sharp minor, Op. 27. No. 1, Fantasy in F minor and Polonaise in A flat. Op. 53, of Chopin.

Pullman, Inc., reported yesterday for 1948 a net income of $8,152,082 after charges, taxes and reserves, equal to $3.18 each on the 2,561,731 shares outstanding at the year-end. This compared with $6,329,569, or $2.38 on the 2,658,431 shares outstanding in 1947. In the year the company purchased and retired 96,700 of its shares.

LONDON, April 9 -- Although sharp movements in the stock markets last week followed introduction of the new budget they were due either to disappointment that hopes of speculators were not realized or that some unexpected although small relief in taxation had been granted.
ATHENS, April 10 (Reuters) -- Evangelos Manganas, former leader of the right-wing "X" organization, is once again under arrest, according to a Ministry of Public Order announcement today.

Iron and steel making has become the foremost industry in which the responsibilities of chief engineers have broadened far beyond former tasks, Arthur Lazarus, vice president of the engineering concern of Day Zimmerman, Inc., Chicago, disclosed here over the week-end.

DETROIT, April 10 (AP) -- Young Sid Smith, up from the Maple Leafs' Pittsburgh farm club, plunked in all three goals tonight as Toronto defeated the Detroit Red Wings, 3 to 1, for a two-game lead in their Stanley Cup hockey series. The best of-seven cup finals move to Toronto Wednesday for the third game

Industhy must plan for voluntary decentralization of its key production units, it was declared over the week-end by Paul V. Galvin, president of Motorola, Inc., Chicago, who announced the opening of a new research laboratory in Phoenix, Ariz.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- A group of Republican members of Congress headed by Senator Owen Brewster, Republican, of Maine, have signed a petition calling on President Truman to seek firm United Nations action against the Netherlands in the Indonesian dispute, it was disclosed today.

News that Kathy Fiscus was found dead in a California well pipe set off a remarkable demonstration of nation-wide public interest and sympathy late last night. Thousands who had followed the story closely for three days made no secret of their sadness when they telephoned newspaper and radio switchboards for confirmation of the child's death.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 10 -- Lazar Kolesevski, Premier of the Macedonian People's Republic in Yugoslavia, accused the Communist Information Bureau today of having broken the unity of the Greek Communist rebellion.
GREENVILLE, Tex., April 10 -- Viewed from any angle, the Yankees got a chilly reception here today.

The executive budget proposed for the Board of Education, while providing for new school construction, does not permit improvement of school services, Dr. Alice V. Keliher, chairman of the Citizens Committee on Children of New York City, Inc., 136 East Fifty-seventh Street, charged yesterday.

LONDON, April 10 (UP) -- The Moscow radio today broadcast a long criticism of United States soldiers in Europe, charging that the German people who saw "the abomination of Hitler's racism can now see American racism in all its hideousness."

Your editorial on "Rent Control" in THE TIMES evidences a common misconception of the housing and rent problems of our nation. Your seeming approval of the principles of the "local decontrol" and "fair return" provisions of the proposed 1949 law, and your satisfaction over the fact that the Congress has not followed President Truman's request for a strong rent control act, both indicate a misunderstanding of the true nature of this problem.

IN 1910, when Robert J. Casey was only 20 years old, he went to visit his uncle in Rapid City, S. D. Although Mr. Casey was a South Dakotan himself, for he was born in Bereford, this was his first venture into the Black Hills. Even at that early age his relish in human eccentricity, which has made him one of the best reporters and story-tellers of his time, must have been strong.

NEW ORLEANS, April 10 -- The Giants for the second time in three days became involved this afternoon in another air tight mound duel and this time they demonstrated they can, on occasion, win these things.

The men of the Coast Guard, although specialists in emergencies, do their level best to head them off. A case in point: Saturday the service's meteorologists issued small craft warnings; Saturday three young men, heedless of the warnings, pointed their 24-foot open boat through Rockaway Inlet and were not picked up until yesterday morning by a passing New-foundland-Canadian freighter.
PARIS, April 10 -- Three more days remain before the French Parliament takes its Easter recess of nearly a month before resuming its sessions on May 10.

The Matson Lines is strengthening its offices the Eastern part of the country in a drive to recapture trade lost during the long West Coast maritime strike last year, it was made known over the weekend.

Secretary of Agriculture Brannan produced a blueprint for a new "farm program" last week that could have emanated only from an Administration politically desperate for a plan that would be popular at any cost.

Some of the questions posed in letters from readers concern culinary problems that undoubtedly arise in more than a few kitchens. We've selected some of those that are of general interest and present them today along with the answers as a sort of "readers' forum:"

Spring came back to the city yesterday, Palm Sunday, after a week of wind and chill that had many New Yorkers -- badly spoiled by the mild winter -- wondering just what season it was anyway. The temperature in the city, 49 degrees at 11 A. M., rose steadily with the help of a bright sun until it reached 61 at 4:20 P. M.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- Senator J. Howard McGrath of Rhode Island, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, advocated today adoption of the Administration's proposed farm program because, he contended, it would aid city dwellers as much as farmers.
WASHINGTON, April 10 -- The votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls during the period April 2 to 8 are given in the appended tabulation:

MARION, S. D., April 10 -- The St. Mary's Catholic Church was wrecked by an explosion today while it was partly filled with Palm Sunday worshipers. Six elderly persons were killed and at least fifty persons were injured when the roof and brick walls came tumbling down upon them as they knelt in their pews.

GLENS FALLS, N. Y., April 10 -- James A. Farley, former Postmaster General, said here today that the United States should have an Ambassador to Madrid and otherwise renew diplomatic relations with Spain for security reasons.

PITTSBURGH, April 10 -- The national steel ingot operating rate last week was off 1 point to 99 per cent of rated capacity. Indications are that it may drop slightly this week. Trade reports support the view that the long upward trend in output has been checked and that any significant changes now will be on the downside.

DETROIT, April 10 -- The general council of Ford Local 600 of the United Automobile Workers, CIO, approved today strike action against the Ford Motor Company's Rouge plant in Dearborn. A mass meeting of the local's 60,000 members was set for 10 A. M. Saturday to take a strike vote.

An anti-Communist successor to the defunct Greater New York CIO Council will be formally organized here April 25, with Michael J. Quill, president of the Transport Workers Union, as the most likely choice to head it.

The new Cuban regulations governing imports of rayon textiles are not intended to restrict trade but "to secure better administration of duties and eliminate misclassification irregularities which have been taking place," A. C. Werner, president of Burlington Mills International Corporation, said in an interview for publication today.
Elimination of the Taft-Hartley Law's ban on the closed shop was recommended yesterday by the committee on labor and social security legislation of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York.
COLORADO SPRINGS, Col., April 10 (AP) -- The six-year reign of Miss Gretchen Merrill as queen of the nation's amateur figure skaters is ended.
