An investor has purchased from John Louis Galgano and Mrs. Jean Samish the five-story apartment house on a lot 25 by 100 feet at 233 East Sixty-seventh Street, adjoining the northwest corner of Second Avenue, in a deal negotiated by Douglas L. Elliman Co. and Robert J. Glenn, brokers.
MEXICO CITY, April 10 (AP) -- The Soviet Union today joined the United States in refusing to sign the proposed international agreement dividing short wave radio frequencies.

SAN MARINO, Calif., April 10 -- More than two days of waiting to see if a child were dead or alive nearly a hundred feet below the surface of the earth in an abandoned well tonight had touched the emotions of Southern California and the nation as a whole.

Clendenin J. Ryan, president of the Government Affairs Club, 31 East Sixty-ninth street, announced yesterday that he would publish a weekly newspaper, to be known as The Public Guardian, to carry on with greater effectiveness his fight against "the sinister forces that are eating at the heart of American life."
NANKING, April 10 -- Three powerful Communist armies hammered hard at the Government's thin bridgeheads north of the Yangtze River today with the avowed aim of invading South China.
The national council of the National Maritime Union, CIO, at the semi-annual meeting here last week made an effort to legislate Communist party members from the organization's rolls.

CHICAGO, April 10 -- Corn developed a heavy undertone and prices ranged lower last week on the Board of Trade after an early upturn to a new high since early March. The decline was caused largely by a belief that there would be a large movement of cash corn to market.

Sam Young has been appointed assistant to the vice president and sales manager, Edward D. Lane of Lamont Corliss Co. Mr. Young joined the wholesale distributing company in 1939 and was until recently Southern division manager.

N. Y. Newspaper Linage Up 5% Advertising in New York newspapers during the first three months of this year totaled 36,615,805 lines, or a gain of 4.89 per cent compared with the corresponding period of last year, according to a compilation of Media Records figures.

Agencies of the United Palestine Appeal expended $165,000,000 in 1948 for immigration, rehabilitation and resettlement in Israel, Magistrate Morris Rothenberg, act-national chairman, announced yesterday.

Pound sterling was shaken sharply last week, the spot rate getting down to $4.02 3/4, while the discounts on forwards widened to more than 3 cents on 90's and about 8 cents on six-month contracts. In each instance these are new lows since February, 1948.

LONDON, April 10 -- Despite the approach of total peace in Palestine, political unrest in the Arab countries continues to delay the resumption of normal operations by British, United States and other foreign oil interests in the Middle East and the spectacular program of expansion that they have been planning.

LONDON, April 10 -- Prime Minister Attlee charged today that the responsibility for dividing the world "rests squarely on the shoulders of the rulers of the Kremlin." The world, he added, could be reunited only if the Communists gave up their "ideological imperialism."

The Tammany executive committee will meet at 4 P. M. today to set the time and place for a meeting of the members of the Democratic County Committee of the Twentieth Congressional District to nominate a candidate for Congress to fill the vacancy caused by the death of Sol Bloom at a special election on May 17.

With the deadline for a strike of 25,000 janitors, elevator operators and other service employes in Manhattan apartments only nine days off, the State Mediation Board will begin today informal efforts to head off a work stoppage.

PARIS, April 10 -- The two closest aides of Bao Dai, former Emperor of Annam -- Prince Buu Loc, who negotiated the recent agreement between Bao Dai and the French Government, and Nguyen Dac Khe -- will leave Paris by plane tomorrow for Indo-China to prepare for the return of Bao Dai to that country.

LOS ANGELES, April 10 (AP) -- Argentina's championship polo team won two victories today from a picked United States quartet in their international series -- one on the playing field, the other in a committee room before the match started.

BUENOS AIRES, April 10 -- President Juan Peron delivered the closing address last night at the first Argentine Congress of Philosophy in the provincial capital of Mendoza. Delegates from nineteen countries, including ten from the United States, attended.

GREAT NECK, L. I., April 10 -- Registered voters of Union Free School District will ballot at a special election tomorrow night on three propositions that would authorize the Board of Education to buy two new school sites and erect two prefabricated community schools for occupancy in September.

Representatives of the city's three public library systems announced yesterday that they would consolidate their forces in an appeal for higher pay for library employes and expanded services. A plea will be made when the Board of Estimate resumes its public hearings this morning on Mayor O'Dwyer's executive budget of $1,179,026,930 for 1949-50.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 10 -- Samuel Jackson Snead of White Sulphur Springs, W. Va., often called luckless because of his inability to sink short putts when titles were at stake, today forgot all about such misfortunes and won the thirteenth Masters golf tournament with a concluding-round 67 for a seventy-two hole total of 282.
Self-centered living was described yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Robert J. McCracken, pastor of the Riverside Church, Riverside Drive and 122d Street, as the "root of practically all our miseries."

Scoring the deciding goal in the last two minutes of play, the Brookhattan-Galicias gained a 3-2 victory over the New York Americans in the second round of the annual Lewis Cup competition sponsored by the American Soccer League before a crowd of 2,500 fans at Sterling Oval yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 10 -- Ann Blyth will play the leading role in "Abandoned," a photoplay which Irwin Gielgud is writing at Universal-International for production by Jerry Bresler, the studio has announced. The photoplay deals with the baby adoption racket and is scheduled for production in May.
CHICAGO, April 10 -- Grain markets were unsettled on the Board of Trade last week, wheat averaging higher and corn lower, owing in part to closing of spreads between the two grains.

The first major easterly extension of the Long Island State parkway system since World War II will be opened without ceremony at 11 A. M. today. At that hour the five-mile strip on Northern State Parkway from Union Avenue at Westbury to the Plainview Road near Woodbury, both in Nassau County, will be ready to handle passenger car traffic the Long Island State Parkway Commission announced yesterday.

Regional alliances such as the proposed North Atlantic pact were denounced yesterday by the Rev. Dr. John Howard Melish, rector of the Holy Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church, Brooklyn, as harbingers of "race suicide and national disaster."

BOSTON, April 10 -- Archbishop Richard J. Cushing said today that proposed Federal legislation for increased child welfare "would be an important and dangerous step toward the 'slave state' we deplore so much abroad and fear so much at home."

Famous combat planes have a way of getting war-weary early, perhaps because a quick way to fame is to fly in war's first missions when the going is rugged. The Swoose, a Flying Fortress built in October, 1941, had more durable wing feathers. She flew out to the Philippines a month before Pearl Harbor, and was on hand to give -- and take -- the first cracks at the Japanese.

Indicating preparations for harder-selling times, most advertising agencies are stepping up per-man production and tightening personnel requirements generally, it was learned last week in a round-up of comment from key trade sources.

ATLANTA, Ga., April 10 -- All attendance records were shattered here today, and the Dodgers were a bit broken up as well when Cliff Dapper's Crackers scored their second straight triumph, 8 -- 4, before a crowd of 25,221 cash customers, 13,885 of them Negroes.

April is the month when suburbanites to whose domiciles lawns are attached are wont to eye the scraggly bunches of green spears valiantly pressing upward at spring's beck and to resolve to launch an operation known as Doing Something About the Grass.
Striking brewery workers offered yesterday to come to the rescue of thirsty New Yorkers by providing "safety escorts" for trucks loaded with New Jersey beer.

Each year's announcement of the Guggenheim awards sends one's mind into the future. What will be the fruits of these grants? The fields are as broad as only a free democratic culture allows: political science, economics, biography, physics (including the nuclear variety), medicine, chemistry, biology, botany, anthropology, sociology, history, American and other literatures, the history and practice of the fine arts, music, mathematics, folk lore, creative writing.

Despite increased costs more patients were cared for by New York Hospital last year than ever before and the deficit was less than for 1947, it was disclosed in the annual report made public yesterday.

TEANECK, N. J., April 10 -- After a long day of judging, during which more than a thousand dogs were benched, an entry that had never gone best in show before was put at the head of the long list in the tenth annual fixture of the Kennel Club of Northern New Jersey today.

In some respects the substance of the judgment that was handed down by the International Court of Justice on Saturday in the claim of Great Britain against Albania for damage to British ships by mines in Albanian waters is less important than the simple fact that a judgment was handed down.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., April 10 -- Francis R. MacLeay, chairman of the New Rochelle Municipal Housing Authority, announced today that his group planned to reject the lowest of three house-wrecking bids tomorrow to forestall a union threat to close down two low-cost housing projects totaling $5,480,000.

Results of long-term experiments on the relative roles of heredity and environment in the evolution of plants and animals, contradicting the theories of the Soviet plant-breeder, Prof. T. D. Lysenko, which have been pronounced as the official party line for Soviet geneticists and biologists, were announced yesterday at Columbia University.
Six new films, including importations from England, Italy and Greece, are slated to open in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:
New items being introduced for spring cleaning will help make that chore easier and the results longer lasting.

ALBANY, April 10 -- Governor Dewey signed today a bill giving the State Industrial Commissioner administrative supervision over all boards and divisions of the State Labor Department, including such so-called autonomous agencies as the State Labor Relations Board and the Workmen's Compensation Board.

The annual report of the National Gas and Electric Corporation, issued for publication today by Willis C. Fitkin, president, shows that its operating subsidiaries sold more gas and oil in 1948 than in any previous year, with the result that operating revenues reached a new high of $4,914,058, as com-

The stable of Mr. and Mrs. John C. Kehoe Jr. of Center Moreland, Pa., ended its dominance of the hunter competition in the Sixth Squadron A horse show yesterday by taking the championships in both conformation and working divisions and doing it with a verve that left no question.

Kyron Foundation, Inc., a Delaware charitable corporation, all the stock of which is held by Survey Associates, Inc., 112 East Nineteenth Street, has purchased the business and assets of the Continental Pharmaceutical Corporation, distributors of the dietary supplement, Kyron, it was announced yesterday.

James M. Landis, attorney for a group of American Overseas Airlines employes opposing the company's merger with Pan American Airways, last night expressed gratification over word from Washington that public counsel of the Civil Aeronautics Board had endorsed formally his motion for documents and correspondence in support of his charges of "monopolistic activities" on the part of Pan American.

NUREMBERG, Germany, April 10 -- The last of the Nuremberg trials will enter its final phase tomorrow with the reading of the judgment on twenty-one German diplomats and other high-ranking officials of the Nazi Reich -- the so-called ministries or "Wilhelmstrasse Platz."

Joanette Juniors, Inc., dress manufacturers with offices at 1400 Broadway and a factory at 586 Broadway, filed a $1,000,000 damage suit in Federal Court yesterday against the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, AFL.

Herbert A. Philbrick testified at the Communist trial yesterday that he was ordered by Communist officials to keep his party membership secret and swear he was not a member if anyone asked him. He depicted the Communists as operating like a conspiratorial group and not as a legitimate political party.

Your dollars contributed to the American Cancer Society through its New York City Cancer Com mittee makes possible substantial grants for cancer fact-finding projects in such institutions as Memorial Hospital, Montefiore Hospital and the Columbia University, Cor nell University and New York University medical colleges.
WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP) -- Howard University's Chi Delta Mu fraternity has broken a thirty-three-year precedent by admitting to membership a white student, 21-year-old Paul Guth of New York City.

Sales of leading mail order and' chain store companies declined 9.8 per cent in March, compared with the corresponding month in 1948, according to a compilation covering forty-two companies made by THE NEW YORK TIMES. In February a decrease of 2 per cent was shown.
The United States Customs Service, following the lead of the armed services in the recent war has adopted the use of visual aids in the training of future inspectors, it became known yesterday.

The first year of Marshall Plant aid has laid the basis for continued improvement in Italy, and makes the country a strong prospect to conduct her economic life without extraordinary outside aid after 1952, in the opinion of David M. Freudenthal, special assistant to the chief of the Economic Cooperation Administration mission in Rome.

Under the auspices of the United Nations General Assembly an attempt is being made to write a Convention on the Gathering and International Transmission of News which will broaden the field of public information. Much effort has been spent on this project, and much progress has been made.

BUENOS AIRES, April 11 -- Juan Peron, President of a country where the economy is largely under Government control, sang the praises tonight of private enterprise in a broadcast to the United States. He also said the purpose of the new daily shortwave program was "to report honestly the results of our hard battle for a better country and for a humanity closer to its essential duties."

A vacant parcel of land, 200 by 500 feet, at the southeast corner of Beach Channel Drive and Beach Ninetieth Street, Hammels, Queens, has been purchased by the Beach Ninetieth Street Housing Project, Inc., from Charles I. Stoloff and others for improvement with forty-eight housing units.

CHICAGO, April 11 -- Television will be the dominant broadcasting medium of the future, Wayne C. Coy, Federal Communications Commission chairman, predicted today at a luncheon meeting of more than 2,000 delegates attending the annual convention of the National Association of Broadcasters.
TOKYO, April 11 (AP) -- Lieut. Gen. Kuzma Derevyanko, head of the Soviet mission to Tokyo, today asked Gen. MacArthur to cancel an order purging Jichizo Matsumoto from politics.

Plans for participation in a county-wide fight against Tammany Hall in the primary elections this September were discussed last night at an organization meeting of the Fair Deal Democratic Club of the First Assembly District. Committees were appointed to complete the organization of the club and to establish a headquarters in the district within two weeks.
WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP) -A out of $508,750,060 in the amount President Truman asked to run the Veterans Administration next year was recommended today by the House Appropriations Committee.

LITTLE enough is known in this country about the ferocious struggle on the Russian-German front in the second World War. While the fighting was going on American correspondents saw only a tiny fraction of it and that fraction under official auspices. Since the war Russian commanders have not been writing their memoirs and Russian infantrymen have not been writing novels; or, if they have, they have not been published in this country.

Picket lines were maintained yesterday in front of the terminals and offices of the Railway Express Agency, nullifying efforts of the company to recall 4,000 of 6,500 clerks idle since the second week of March.
MIAMI BEACH, Fla., April 11 (AP) -- Favorites breezed through opening-round matches in the first annual Good Neighbor tennis tournament here today.

NUREMBERG, Germany, April 11 -- Baron Ernst von Weizsaecker, former State Secretary in the German Foreign Office, and four other defendants in the ministries case, which is the last of the Nuremberg war trials, were found guilty by the American court today of having committed crimes against the peace -- that is, initiating, planning and waging an aggressive war.

Robert P. Boylan, chairman of the board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange since May, 1947, was renominated for a third one-year term at a meeting of the Exchange's nominating committee yesterday. The annual elections will be held at the Exchange on May 9.

SAN MARINO, Calif., April 11 -- A preliminary autopsy indicated today that 3-year-old Kathy Fiscus died peacefully from lack of oxygen, soon after her plunge ninety-five feet down an abandoned well shaft here on Friday.

JAIPUR, India, April 2 -- It is said that the fantasy that the world expects of India died this week when fifteen Princely States of Rajputana, some of them a thousand years old, were merged under a prosaic Indian Union Government in a glittering ceremony here that was probably the last of the durbars (princely courts).

LONDON, April 11 -- Satisfaction in the stock market here today with the results of the County Council elections was offset by news of the London dock strike and most sections did little more than mark time. Another factor was absence of buyers which brokers think will last until after the Easter holiday.

Brooklyn civic pride has been placated somewhat and all is quiet once again. But for a few hours last Thursday certain of the borough's citizens with City Hall (Manhattan) connections kicked up quite a fuss over what were considered to be disparaging remarks spoken by Drew Pearson in a foreword to the motion picture, "City Across the River," it was learned yesterday.
Many of the town's taverns were drying up yesterday as balmy weather intensified a beer drought occasioned by the eleven-day-old brewery strike.

SEOUL, Korea, April 11 -- Declaring that "no self-respecting nation will submissively and subserviently accept the arbitrary and dictatorial power of totalitarian rule in Moscow," President Syngman Rhee today castigated the Soviet Union's veto of the Korean Republic's bid for United Nations membership.

SEOUL, Korea, April 11 -- President Syngman Rhee on Saturday told 2,500 captured anti-Government guerrillas on Cheju Island to "forget the past," and he said that their "task is to become loyal citizens of the Republic."

Curtailed advance purchasing of boys' tailored clothing fr spring has been climaxed by a last-minute 'scramble by buyers for desirable I merchandise for pre-lflaster selling, reports in the trade here yesterday indicated.

MONTREAL, April 11 -- Freda Linton, 33-year-old mystery woman of the Soviet spy ring case, surrendered to police today. Canadian authorities had sought her since she dropped out of sight three years ago.
WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP) -]The Senate passed todsy a bill l authortsing the Afro- Foree to set {up a 3,000-mile testing range for I guided missiles at a top cost of 1 $75,000,000.

Mayor O'Dwyer was urged yesterday by the Citizens Union to improve the special terms of the city's Magistrates' Courts. A report by the group recommended that the Mayor name a citizens' committee to look into court conditions, particularly those relating to the problems of human maladjustment.
WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP) -- The Washington Capitols staved off a desperate last-half rally tonight to defeat the Lakers, 74 -- 65, in the Basketball Association of America championship playoffs.
WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture today forecast this year's winter wheat crop at 1,019,686,000 bushels, which would be the second largest on record.

Favorites were going along swimmingly at the Jamaica race track yesterday until the biggest favorite of them all came up. Then came the crushed to those of the 26,909 fans -- and they were in the great majority -- who made the King Ranch's Better Self the standout choice to take the Alcedo, the mile-and-a-sixteenth test that occupied the feature spot on the program.

Preparatory to the launching of the college rowing season on Saturday, some of the leading coaches of the East gathered with former oarsmen and the press yesterday for the first of the weekly crew luncheons at the New York A. C.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- Bipartisan supporters of the European Recovery Program demonstrated on eight successive House tallies today that they had more than enough votes to prevent a reduction in the Marshall Plan authorization and to pass the measure tomorrow substantially as reported by the Foreign Affairs Committee.

BOSTON, April 11 (AP) -Thel Massachusetts House today approved a $269,412,498 budget for the fiscal year beginning July 1. It is the biggest in the common-, wealth's history, $49,548,066 moreI than that for last year. i
HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., April 11 (AP) -- Four Kentucky Derby eligibles had to take a back seat today in a photo finish of the Chesapeake Trial, which Henry Hecht's The Pinscher won by a nose.
Two American Federation of Labor seamen's unions protested yesterday support that they said had been given to the CSU by the Marine Cooks and Stewards (CIO).
When Winston Churchill's familiar accents came over the air April 1 many of us listened with a thrill to the magnificent English which had heartened the Allied world during the war.
Mrs. Mabel Boll Cella, who wanted to be Queen of the Air when the world knew her as the Queen of Diamonds, died Sunday of a stroke in Manhattan State Hospital for the mentally ill on Wards Island.

Ten weeks have gone by since Local 32-B of the Building Service Employes International Union, AFL, gave public warning that it considered a strike inevitable when its contract with Manhattan apartment house owners ran out April 20. A number of things have happened since that time to reduce the "inevitability" of a strike, but there is no lessening in the expectation of landlords and union representatives that it will occur.
HALIFAX, April 11 (Canadian Press) -- What may be ultimate showdowns for control of the Canadian merchant marine loomed today in at least four world ports.
BALTIMORE, April 11 (AP) -- International League Orioles humbled Boston's National League champion Braves, 3 -- 2, today before a slim 1,500 crowd at Babe Ruth Stadium.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 11 -- The idea of a Balkan federation, which has been one of the most persistent political dreams of the Twentieth Century, is today as far from realization as at any time before World War II.
LAKE SUCCESS, April 11 -- The United Nations Commission on Human Rights elected eight new members and re-elected four old ones today to its subcommission on Freedom of Information and of the Press.

LAKE SUCCESS, April 11 -- Count Carlo Sforza, the Italian Foreign Minister, today urged the Political Committee of the United Nations General Assembly to recommend "a fair compromise" on the former Italian colonies that would return Italian Somaliland, Eritrea and Tripolitania to Italy under a United Nations trusteeship.

Fists flew as police battled student pickets in an attempt to clear the entrance to the main building of City College at Convent Avenue between 138th and 139th Streets at 8:45 A. M. yesterday. Violence that police said assumed near-riot proportions ushered in the first general strike of students of a municipal institution of higher learning in this city.

MOSCOW, April 11 -- The Soviet public was told by Pravda today that United States ruling circles have unleashed a "debauch of reaction" against all democratic American elements and particularly against what was called the leading bulwark of progressive policy, the American Communist party.

British competition using Boeing Stratocruisers on the North Atlantic seemed assured here yesterday with the confirmation by the New York headquarters of British Overseas Airways Corporation of the purchase of four of the double-decked giants for sterling from the Scandinavian Airlines System.
VIENNA, April 11 -- Several Austrian Cabinet Ministers admitted in speeches over the week-end that the finances of the Austrian State were "in a difficult situation."
Plans of the city to build a new bridge from Queens to Welfare Island are facing the active opposition of owners of tugboats plying New York Harbor, it became known yesterday.
If anything can be uncanny in a sunlit Central Park glade, it was uncanny yesterday how swiftly the arrival of a stock of fish was followed by the arrival of small boys equipped for bent-pin fishing.

PHILADELPHIA, April 11 -- The first problem of the mental hospitals of the country is to get the Legislatures of the various states to appropriate enough money to pay for competent personnel, Dr. William C. Menninger, president of the American Psychiatric Association, declared tonight.

DETROIT, April 11 -- The continuation of attacks on the steel industry after it had succeeded in overcoming a post-war shortage was interpreted today by Walter S. Tower, president of the American Iron and Steel Institute, as a precursor of attempts to nationalize many American industries.

With Government expenditures mounting steadily at a time when the American economy has entered a period of "disinflation," a new cleavage is developing in Congress and within the Administration itself between those, broadly speaking, who consider objectives more important than costs and those who consider costs more important than objectives.
If your child asks for cod liver oil with his breakfast, don't send for a psychiatrist. He may have been convinced in school that he ought to develop healthy teeth.

Conditions for the Newport to Annapolis race, which will be the longest ocean contest on the Atlantic this year, were completed yesterday by the New York Yacht Club, which will hold the event in cooperation with the Naval Academy Yacht Squadron and the Annapolis Yacht Club.

Leonard Eisner, New York pianist, who made his debut three seasons ago, gave his third Town Hall recital last night. His program included Beethoven's G major Rondo, Schubert's A minor Sonata, Op. 164; Liszt's "Funerailles" and Schumann's Novellette.

CHICAGO, April ll--A program of instruction for retailers by radio stations and a network of university classes on the use of radio in retailing was urged here today by Howard P. Abrahams, manager of the sales promotion division and visual merchandising group of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- Increased power production and lower rates were urged today by C. Girard Davidson, Assistant Secretary of the Interior. "Electric power in adequate quantities and at reasonable rates is one of the main requisites for maintaining true prosperity," he said.
WASHINGTON, April 11 -- The House Rules Committee sent the Administration's labor bill to the House today under an "open" rule permitting amendments from the floor.
A reading of the North Atlantic pact appears to yield no assurances to the signatories of that pact as to the policies which may be pursued in face of the eventuality discussed below.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- The legislation calling for the repeal of the tax on oleomargarine became the vehicle today for a move to cut excise taxes back to 1942 levels, with an estimated saving to the public of $600,000,000 a year.

With output in March exceeding that of any month on record, the greatest production of raw steel in history was poured out of the steel-making furnaces of the nation in the first quarter of 1949, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
Without public fanfare, the Consolidated Edison Company since Jan. 1, 1947, has recognized alcoholism as a basis for retirement through disability.
WASHINGTON, April 11 -- On the eve of his fourth anniversary in office, President Truman viewed the future tonight in a mood of quiet optimism that peace would be assured in two years.
BERLIN, April 11 -- The three Western powers have agreed upon the form and scope of the police agencies to be allowed the German federal republic, it was learned today from an authoritative source.

Henry Wallace, leader of the Progressive party, charged last night that the Atlantic pact is "a pact of war" from which may come the "trigger-happy shots" to put this country at war with half the world. He addressed two American Labor party rallies in the Bronx and Queens protesting the pact and urging the election of ALP candidates in by-elections.

Fashion cults imported from Europe that have hindered the development of true contemporary design in the United States were attacked last night by T. H. Robsjohn-Gibbings, designer. He urged designers and decorators to study instead the works of modern pioneers like Frank Lloyd Wright, architect, who have by-passed the whims of fashion.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- Former President Herbert Hoover declared today that great savings, running perhaps to $1,500,000,000 a year, could be made in the National Military Establishment by radical change of budgeting and accounting methods and other simpler reforms.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., April 11 -- The University of Alabama today denied students of Talladega College, a Negro institution at Talladega, Ala., the right to attend sessions of the spring art festival at the former institution to which Negro students had been invited to send an exhibit.

LAKE SUCCESS, April 11 -- Dr. Ivan Kerno, Assistant Secretary General in charge of the United Nations' Legal Department, said that today's International Court opinions "mark an important strengthening of the legal status of the United Nations under international law."
For the first time, blind persons can obtain accident insurance policies, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Robert D. Irwin, sightless director of the American Foundation for the Blind.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- President Truman said today that he was firmly convinced of the need for a speedy peace between Israel and her Arab neighbors, and he pladged this country's assistance to attain that objective.

LAKE SUCCESS, April 11 -- An $8,000,000 check for the relief of refugees in Palestine was presented here today to Secretary General Trygve Lie of the United Nations by Warren R. Austin of the United States.

LONDON, April 11 -- An unprecedented effort to sell British goods in North America -- the "most difficult market in the world" -- was announced in the House of Commons today by Harold Wilson, president of the Board of Trade.

Mays Department Store of Brooklyn will have a $1,250,000 branch store with parking facilities for 600 automobiles in the shopping center being developed at the Glen Oaks housing project in Bellerose, Queens. Details of the expansion program were revealed yesterday by Joe Weinstein, president of Mays, who said the branch store is expected to be ready for occupancy next April.

ST. LOUIS, April 11 (AP) -- The nation's present zinc production capacity is adequate to supply all domestic needs and allow some for a Government stockpile, Howard I. Young, president of the American Zinc, Lead and Smelting Company, said today.

The State Insurance Department is vigorously pressing criminal actions against unlicensed accident and health insurance companies and their solicitors, who have defrauded gullible persons of $10,000,000 in the last year, it became known yesterday.
PARIS, April 11 -- The French Communist party today opened an intensified campaign to win over the Socialists for a "fight to keep the peace."
WASHINGTON, April 11 -- Five Republican Senators put public pressure on the Democrats today for action to liberalize the Displaced Persons Act as urged by President Truman.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- The South Carolina Electric Gas Company of Columbia, S. C., filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering an unspecified number of additional shares of its $4.50 par value common stock.
BERLIN, April 11 -- The Soviet Military Administration and its German Communist allies tonight launched a new drive for the establishment of an East German state.

Rural Free Delivery People who live in town and who dig their mail from apartment house mail boxes, have it handed to them by hotel clerks or find it laid out neatly for them on office desks o' mornings are viewed with pity, now that spring is everywhere, by their truly rural friends.

Add to the list of films opening this week "The Life of Riley," a Universal - International comedy written, produced and directed by Irving Brecher and starring William Bendix in the title role, which will arrive at the Criterion on Saturday.
WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP) -- An examiner for the Interstate Commerce Commission today accused a small Midwestern railroad of deliberately attempting to lose business, in order to scrap its line.

LAKE SUCCESS, April 11 -- A proposal for creation of an 800-man United Nations guard was referred to a special eleven-nation committee for study today after debate before the General Assembly ad hoc Political and Security Committee had raised another East-West row.

It is gratifying to the conservationists throughout the state to learn that their claim that both the law and the administrative handling of proposals for reservoirs in the Forest Preserve need correcting has at last been recognized by the Legislature in the appointment of a committee as suggested by the Governor to review and correct the exisiting laws.
ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., April 11 -- The strike of nearly 2,000 union service employes against ten major beachfront hotels ended its fourth day tonight without any prospects of an early settlement.

Five more families were moved out of the four tenement houses at 426-432 West Fifty-second Street -- to be razed to make way for an addition to St. Clare's Hospital -- yesterday, leaving only two more families on the site.

Five women shopping experts, hailing from such places as Pilotmound, Boone County, Iowa, and Dowagiac, Mich., got the "works" of a New York reception yesterday and left their hosts mildly bewildered at their poise and assurance.

Mayor O'Dwyer said yesterday that the Board of Education and the Board of Higher Education should be elected rather than appointed so that the members could be required to give an account of their stewardship to the people on election day.

Taking advantage of the need of workers for protection against a loss of wages because of sickness, the Dewey Administration has just put over a bill written by the insurance companies for the benefit of the insurance companies.

Carrying the fight to his foe after the third round, Frankie Abrams, veteran Detroit boxer, won the unanimous decision over Jean Walzack, French welterweight champion, in the feature clash of ten rounds at the St. Nicholas Arena last night.

The wiretap inquiry, which had been occupying a grand jury's attention since March 14, entered its fifth week yesterday when "several minor witnesses" were called. A spokesman for the District Attorney' office would not identify them further, but he said the panel had adjourned after hearing them.

Canada Dry Ginger Ale, Inc., has leased the entire fourteenth floor, containing 23,000 square feet, in the thirty-six story office building under construction on the former site of the Murray Hill Hotel at 100 Park Avenue, Cushman Wakefield, Inc., renting agents, reported yesterday.

Sidney Robinson, formerly ' a! part owner of the Copacabana! night club, received a suspendedI sentence from Federal Judge AI-I fred C. Coxe yesterday when he1 pleaded guilty to an indictmenti charging he filed a false oath in! a 1942 bankruptcy proceeding. Hei was put ort probation for thirtyI days.
BOSTON, April 11 (UP) -- A bright object which looked like a ball of fire with a tail flashed through the skies over the northeast tonight and Harvard Observatory said it "absolutely" was a meteor.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- The Senate Democratic majority counted noses today and concluded that it could defeat a Republican-sponsored amendment to ban racial discrimination in the general housing program. Senator John W. Bricker, Republican, of Ohio, has announced that he would force a voting test on the amendment.

Price reductions of 25 to 50 cents a ton to spur consumer buying during the summer, were made effective yesterday by a number of leading anthracite producers selling to wholesalers. Some producers predicted that these reductions might amount to as much as 75 cents or $1 per ton when passed on to consumers at the retail level.
WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP) -- Publication of this city's four daily newspapers was halted today by a strike of about 200 American Federation of Labor mechanical workers.
The Budd Company last year had the highest sales and earnings in its history, according to the annual report issued for publication today.

ALBANY, April 11 -- In an attempt to prevent unscrupulous persons from exploiting grief, so-called non-profit cemetery corporations were made subject to state regulation today with Governor Dewey's signature of the Feinberg Bill.

A five-run rally in the eighth inning enabled Wagner College to overcome C. C. N. Y., 8 to 4, at Wagner Field, Grymes Hill, Staten Island, yesterday. The victory was the first of the season for the Seahawks against three losses.

LONDON, April 7 -- The principal aim of the British Color Council's Interior Decoration Design Center, opened in London last February, is to stimulate and encourage a good standard of design and color in all branches of interior decoration.
MINNEAPOLIS, April 11 (AP) -- Athletic scholarships will be given at the University of Minnesota next fall for the first time in the institution's history.

ALBANY, April 11 -- Governor Dewey signed today Senator Seymour Halpern's bill requiring the Motor Vehicle Bureau to re-examine every licensed automobile driver who becomes involved in three accidents within a period of eighteen months.

WILMINGTON, Del., April 11 (AP) -- Stockholders of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. approved today a four-for-one stock split of the $20 par common stock. The ratification at the annual meeting was by a vote of 9,747,663 shares to 10,531.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- The leadership of American aviation, both military and civilian, faces a serious threat from more advanced research facilities developed in foreign countries, high official spokesmen told Congress today.

Two men were killed yesterday when they jumped or fell in front of subway trains. The accidents caused delays at Sutter Avenue, Brooklyn, in the morning rush hiur, and at South Ferry later in the day.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- Herbert Hoover said today that the Senate Expenditures Committee imposed a "double veto" on Presidential reorganization powers that was completely out of line with the importance of the authority.

PHILADELPHIA, April 11 -- Federal Judge George A. Welsh revoked late today his order of April 4 permitting the Isbrandtsen Steamship Company of New York to withhold $10,647 of the wages due twenty-three former members of the crew of the cargo ship Flying Arrow.

TEXARKANA, Tex., April 11 -- Before a record crowd of 8,500 enthusiasts who swarmed all over the playing field in this focal point of four states today, Leo Durocher's polo grounders took a shellacking from the Cleveland Indians.

The wool futures market yesterday was generally steady on buying by dealers. A limited amount of hedge selling was absorbed readily. Wool top contracts finished at 0.5 to 1.5 cents net higher on sales of 150,000 pounds. Grease wool futures were unchanged to 1 cent net lower on transactions of 108,000 pounds.
WASHINGTON, April 11 -- The Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers lost its appeal today to place an additional engineer on diesel locomotives.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 11 -- Twentieth Century-Fox has purchased the screen rights to Gerald Kersch's 1946 novel, "Night and the City," from Charles K. Feldman's agency for $175,000, it was learned today. As a part of the deal Fox also required a screen adaptation of the story by Jo Eisinger, prepared under the supervision of Feldman, who bought the novel three years ago for a reported $55,000.

ANNECY, France, April 11 -- President Truman will soon send the charter of the International Trade Organization to Congress for approval, the United States advised the delegates of thirty-five countries at the opening here today of the largest tariff conference ever held.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange stiffened yesterday and closed at, or near, the best levels of the day, 5 to 25 points net higher than on Saturday.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- Spokesmen for non - Communist French and Italian trade unions will advise the Department of State in the next day or two that extension of Marshall Plan aid to Franco Spain would endanger the Atlantic pact.

Plans to revitalize New York's recreation facilities for service men and women will get under way at 10 A. M. Thursday when members of the reorganized United Service Organizations, Inc., meet in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel to plan a program, it was learned yesterday.
Chester, Pa., Municipal Authority announced yesterday that it would receive bids on May 5 on $5,740,000 of water revenue bonds dated Dec. 1, 1948, and due Dec. 1, 1949 to 1988.
Members of the canning industry are looking ahead to increased purchasing by the armed forces during the coming fiscal year beginning July 1, it was learned here yesterday.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 11 -- Those who have been searching for a new golfing star to take the place left vacant by the convalescing Ben Hogan, found instead, in the winner of the Masters Tournament, a veteran, Sam Snead.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 11 -- Premier Marshal Tito ended the third congress of the People's Front today by telling 1,600 cheering delegates that his first loyalties and responsibilities were to the Yugoslav people, a Socialist Yugoslavia "and to nobody else."

" Light snow in the mountains" was the refrain hummed through chattering teeth by the hardy souls who drove to the Catskill streams for the opening week-end, and although the Beaverkill and Willowemoc were low and clear the snow flurries on opening day dashed many hopes.

Edward J O'Shaughnessy, District Commissioner of Immigration and Naturalization, announced yesterday that Hirsch Teper, London tailor, who figured in the recent Belcher-Gibson bribery investigation in the House of Commons, had been excluded from this country.

CHICAGO, April 11 -- Arthur C. Romer resigned today as vice president in charge of inventory management of Montgomery Ward Co. At the same time, Sewell L. Avery, chairman, announced the appointment of a new manager for the mail order division to succeed Charles M. Odorizzi, vice president, who quit last week.

Queen Elizabeth and the Elizabethan period are subjects of books by two famou British authors, Edith Sitwell and A. L. Rowse, which will be published by Macmillan. Miss Sitwell, whose book on the early years of Elizabeth, "Fanfare for Elizabeth," was published in 1946, is completing a full biography.

PARIS, April 11 -- The Cabinet discussed tonight the question of loosening credit somewhat to check an incipient slump resulting from the fall of farm prices and the consequent tightening of money. It was understood the Government favored no general expansion of credit but was disposed to facilitate loans where there had been no speculative accumulation of stocks.

BAD GODESBERG, Germany, April 11 -- The Social Democratic party, which has in effect seceded from the Parliamentary Council at Bonn so far as work on the current draft of a constitution for Western Germany is concerned, proposed today to substitute for that draft a document described as an "administration statute."

Communists are trying to capture the women's vote in Italy, Mrs. Marc A. Law of North Brook, Ill., declared yesterday at the League of Women Voters, 461 Fourth Avenue. A former vice president of the national league, which established the Carrie Chapman Catt Memorial Fund, Mrs. Law had just returned from a five-months' trip in which she studied the conditions of Italian women.

Two large retail buying groups, serving fifty-three stores, are considering marketing their own private brand television receivers soon, it was learned yesterday. Both organizations are seeking to introduce ten-inch direct view tube table units at list prices under the market.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, April 11 -- The International Court of Justice, in an advisory opinion delivered today, declared the United Nations could sue Governments for injury caused to the organization or any of its agents in the execution of his duty.

ALBANY, April 11 -- The Court of Appeals consented today to withdrawal of an action by the Freethinkers of America challenging the constitutionality of the practice of releasing pupils from public school to attend outside religious classes.

Prof. John M. Marsalka, who recently invited Dmitri Shostakovich, Soviet composer, to speak at Yale University, only to have his plans canceled by university authorities, has been dropped from the teaching staff, as of June 30, next, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- Class 1 steam railroads of the United States expect to make $1,341,939,422 in capital expenditures in 1949, according to a report issued today by the Bureau of Transport Economics and Statistics of the Interstate Commerce Commission.
OTTAWA, April 11 (By Canadian Press) -- Twin developments indicating a still further improvement in Canada's trading position with the United States were announced today.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- The annual rate of personal income declined $2,500,000,000 in February, the Office of Business Economics of the Commerce Department announced today. The February total was $217,000,000,000 compared with $219,500,000,000 in January.

BALTIMORE, April 11 -- Although there is a change from a seller's to a buyer's market, sales reports from grocery manufacturers and distributors show that business continues good and prospects for the future bright, it was said here today by Paul S. Willis, president of the Grocery Manufacturers of America, Inc.

Thirteen investment banking syndicates competed yesterday for the purchase of two new issues of public utility bonds totaling $12,000,000. Subject to clearance by the Securities and Exchange Commission, the new issues of securities are to be reoffered to investors later in the week. Awards were as follows:

The usual restricting influence of the forthcoming Easter holiday was exerted in the stock market yesterday, which dragged through the dullest session in two weeks. Activity in the rail shares, the favorites last week, quieted, with the result that sales dropped to 720,000 shares.

A strike threatened for today at Bloomingdale's, which, according to officials of the Bloomingdale Department Store Union, Local 3, independent, would have affected 2,000 workers, was put off last night as a result of intervention by Joseph E. O'Grady, director of the city's Division of Labor Relations.

" The Kraft Music Hall," a permanent feature on radio since 1933, goes off the air with its 9 to 9:30 P.M. broadcast over NBC on May 26. The action taken by Kraft Music Hall to cancel its long run musical show removes from NBC's Thursday night line-up one of the oldest shows in radio history.
Of all the "economic theories" extant, it is probably safe to say that none has provided a greater paradise for politicians over the years than the so-called doctrine of underconsumption.

JERSEY CITY, N. J., April 11 Issuance of a subpoena for a court-directed check on his financial dealings since 1941 was termed today by former Mayor Frank Hague an attempt to smear his reputation and to embarrass his nephew and successor, Mayor Frank Hague Eggers, and other members of the City Commission, all of whom seek re-election on May 10.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores were unchanged last week in comparison with the corresponding week last year, accordir)g to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The decline for the four weeks ended last Saturday was 7 per cent.

NANKING, April 11 -- The formal Nationalist-Communist peace talks in Peiping, which were originally scheduled to start April 1, have been delayed by informal sparring between the Nanking delegates and Communist leaders on three basic issues raised by the Communists, it was learned today.

Tammany Hall turned down yesterday the candidacy of Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. for Representative from the Twentieth Congressional District on Manhattan's West Side, and nominated Municipal Court Justice Benjamin Shalleck instead.

" Market conditions" yesterday resulted in the indefinite postponement of a secondary offering of 225,000 shares of common stock of the Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railroad. The first news that the offering would be made after the close of the market came around 1:30 P. M. Within a few minutes the price dropped almost 2 points.

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's intention to remain "for years to come" president of Columbia University was affirmed last night by the university's provost, Prof. Albert C. Jacobs. The university official said that reports of General Eisenhower's taking a permanent Government position were as baseless as those that had him accepting the Presidential nomination of one of the major political parties.

TEL AVIV, Israel, April 11 -- Sodom, Biblical spot on the southern end of the Dead Sea, lowest body of water on earth, is preparing once again to serve the world with its chemicals. It was from there that the world's most ample supply of potash -- used for explosives in wartime and fertilizer in peacetime -- was exported.

Since last September, when she undertook the role of Blanche DuBois in the so-called national company of "A Streetcar Named Desire," Uta Hagen has been winning acclaim in the country's major cities. Her compelling portrayal has sparked the imagination of out-of-town drama appraisers, who have likened it to the fires struck by the late Jeanne Eagels in "Rain" and to the late Laurette Taylor's acting triumph in "The Glass Menagerie."

ALBANY, April 11 -- A charge that racial discrimination in Stuyvesant Town "is supported, participated in, effectuated and made possible by state action" was made today during Court of Appeals argument in two actions seeking to require renting of apartments in the housing project to Negroes.

PARIS, April 11 -- The French Communist party formally pronounced today a judgment on the Washington agreements for Germany that seemed diametrically opposed to the party line as exemplified by the Soviet-controlled press in the Eastern zone of Germany.

GREENVILLE, S. C., April 11 -- Ralph Branca, slated for his third route pitching job of the exhibition tour today against the local Sally League farm club, will have to split an assignment with Oakland Joe Hatten tomorrow in Charlotte.

MARYKNOLL, N. Y., April 11 -- The Most Rev. Patrick J. Byrne, a member of the Catholic Foreign Missions Society of America and a former Maryknoll superior in Japan, has been appointed Apostolic Delegate to Korea and named Titular Bishop of Gazera, according to information received here today from the Vatican.

A forty-two-year-old Rumanian rabbi, his wife and their twelve children arrived here yesterday aboard the Swedish American liner I Gripsholrn. He is Rabbi User Jonas Weinberger, who said he had fled !when the Germans occupied Rumania.

TRENTON, April 11 -- A sharp criticism of Trenton police authorities for failing to close bookmaking establishments here that finally were raided by the state was issued today by the Mercer County grand jury.

LAKE SUCCESS, April 11 -- Wearily but patiently, Dr. Charles Malik of Lebanon closed an all-day session of the General Assembly's Social, Humanitarian and Cultural Committee tonight by offering a few suggestions to the United Nations members.

The Jewish Child Care Association, one of the largest affiliates of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York, dedicated yesterday its new residence for boys under its care. The home, to be known as Fellowship House for Boys, is at 216 East Twentieth Street.

Once more there is delay in regulating the fees charged by parking lots and garages. The effort of the City Council last month to put a ceiling price on 1,200 indoor and 2,000 outdoor parking facilities has been defeated, at least temporarily, by the return to it by the Board of Estimate of a bill which the Corporation Counsel holds would not be sustained in the courts.

The Association of the Bar of the City of New York has set a fine example for Congress in its consideration of changes in the Taft-Hartley Law. The association turned over the task of formulating labor law recommendations to a committee made up of twenty-two attorneys, including a number who devote most of their professional careers to representing unions or large corporations on labor matters.

An attempt to arbitrate the issues of a wage review between the Atlantic and Gulf Coast steamship operators and the Masters, Mates and Pilots, AFL, started yesterday at a meeting m the offices of the American Arbitration Association, 9 Rockefeller Plaza. David L. Cole of Paterson, N. J., presided as chairman of a committee that includes himself and two men from each faction.

Dr. Charles Seymour will have served Yale for nearly forty years when he retires at the age of 65 in 1950. He became president in 1937, and has directed the university's affairs through difficult times. A depression, then a world war, then the problems of peace-time readjustment made their varied impact felt on the university.

LONDON, April 11 -- About one-third of the shipping on the Thames was affected today by a strike of more than 7,500 dockers. Fifty-four ships, many carrying food supplies for Britons, were idle at their berths. In five more, cargoes were loaded or discharged by skeleton crews.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- The choice of this country is not between the proposed new Administration farm program and no program, but rather between a new costly program that will aid consumers and the present costly program which does not, Charles F. Brannan, Secretary of Agriculture, told the House Agriculture Committee today.

ANTOFAGASTA, Chile, April 11 -- A major clash over the seating of the Peruvian and Venezuelan delegates is threatened at the fourth regional conference of the International Labor Organization, which will open in Montevideo, Uruguay, on the 25th.

The Taxi Workers Organizing Committee filed fifty complaints of unfair labor practices yesterday with the State Labor Relations Board, alleging widespread firings and the existence of a black list against drivers who participated in last week's strike.

Parachutes are of no use -- in fact, they might prove an added danger -- for passengers on airline planes, according to an analysis of recent accidents by O. E. Kirchner, director of engineering for American Airlines. He spoke yesterday at the air transport session of the Society of Automotive Engineers in the Hotel New Yorker.

Consolidated net income of the Swift International Company, Ltd. in 1948 was 7,015,858 Argentine pesos, equivalent to $1,446,670 in United States currency, the annual report, issued yesterday, disclosed.

CHICAGO, April 12 -- Education through radio, "which penetrates all barriers," will be a powerful force in "tearing down the iron curtain," Attorney General Tom C. Clark told the convention of the National Association of Broadcasters today.
James Forrestal's physician at the Naval Medical Center at Bethesda describes the former Secretary of Defense, who is a patient there, as suffering from "operational fatigue."

Norma France, mezzo-soprano who appeared here with Alfredo Salmaggis "Chicago" Opera Company at the Hippodrome sixteen years ago, last night made her recital debut at Town Hall. The critical stir she made at the earlier appearance was still largely valid last night, for she has a large voice of almost contralto depth, rich in color and, for the most part, tellingly phrased.

TUSCALOOSA, Ala., April 12 -- Dr. Francis Taylor, director of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York, has canceled speaking engagements at the University of Alabama here and also at Alabama College at Montgomery and Alabama Polytechnic Institute at Auburn.

SALONIKA, Greece, April 12 -- Two Communists with a long record of service to their party were tried in absentia this afternoon in a Salonika court house for the murder of George Polk, United States journalist, employed by the Columbia Broadcasting System.

NEWARK, N. J., April 12 -- An annual increase of $8,305,000 in the operating revenues of the New Jersey Bell Telephone Company was granted today by the Board of Public Utility Commissioners of New Jersey. The board rejected a request for an increase of $16,152,000 that the company said was necessary to enable it to earn a fair return on its investment.

MOSCOW, April 12 (AP) -- A Pravda commentator charged today that a projected search for Noah's Ark by British, United States and Dutch archaeologists was a "biblical masquerade" covering a spy expedition.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- Charles F. Brannan, Secretary of Agriculture, today told the House Agriculture Committee that the proposed new unit limit for Government price supports to big commercial farmers would not apply to crops already under acreage limitations and marketing quotas.
HYDE PARK, N. Y., April 13 -- Simple but impressive ceremonies today at the grave of Franklin D Roosevelt marked the anniversary of his death April 12, 1945, at Warm Springs, Ga.

Anyone who is accustomed to stuffing things out of sight into bureau drawers would have to get out of that habit if he were to move into the "House in the Museum Garden," the exhibition home just completed at the Museum of Modern Art.
WASHINGTON, April 12 (UP) -- Following is the text of President Truman's message to the Senate asking ratification of the North Atlantic Treaty:

Miss Vivien Kellems, Westport, Conn., manufacturer, who for more than a year has refused to deduct taxes from the pay of her employes, accused Secretary of the Treasury John W. Snyder of "timidity" yesterday for his refusal to seek her indictment.

Stanley Hiller Jr., 23-year-old inventor, who raised $2,500,000 in California to develop his revolutionary new "Hillercopter," landed at the foot of Wall Street yesterday morning, ending the first transcontinental flight for such an aircraft.

CHICAGO, April 12 -- Prices of grain closed irregular on the Chicago Board of Trade today. Wheat showed pronounced strength to end at about the top, with gains of 1 to 1 1/2 cents a bushel, May leading, despite a bearish construction placed on a Government report issued late yesterday forecasting the second largest winter wheat crop on record.

Consumers buying eggs for the Easter and Passover holidays will pay a higher price this year because the Government is supporting egg prices high above the parity level, the Butter and Egg Merchants Association charged yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- A Government economist urged today that the steel industry's plan to step up its capacity be increased "at least four or five times." Simultaneously, leaders of the cooperative movement in this country announced that they were considering a proposal to enter the steel business.

Vincent Riggio, president of the American Tobacco Company, was presented with the "Applause Award" for "outstanding contributions to the profession of selling" at the luncheon yesterday of the Sales Executives Club at the Roosevelt Hotel.
Stockholders of the American Broadcasting Company, Inc., at yesterday's annual meeting elected Alger B. Chapman as a director, increasing the board membership from eight to nine.

LONDON, April 12 -- Technical "facilities" necessary to the United States Air Force for atomic bombardment have been prepared in this country by agreement between the United States and British Governments, it is learned here.

Stock prices responded favorably to good news yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, after opening lower under the leadership of the tobacco group. Several large blocks of low-price issues contributed to the expansion of sales to 850,000 shares, compared with 720,000 shares on Monday.
For the benefit of home planners who must begin to think now of next winter's heating problems, the Eureka Williams Corporation introduced yesterday a new line of oil heating equipment.

Former President Herbert Hoover will make a series of five broadcasts over CBS next week on the work of the Commission on the Organization of the Executive Branch of the Government, which he heads. Mr. Hoover will appear on the network from Monday through Friday, 6:15 to 6:30 P. M., as the guest of Lyman Bryson, CBS counselor on public affairs, in informal discussions on "You and the Hoover Commission."

The split in the Democratic ranks in the Twentieth Congressional District caused by the independent candidacy of Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. and the organization candidacy of Municipal Court Justice Benjamin Shalleck caused the Republicans to perk up yesterday and start a search for a strong candidate who might win for them in an otherwise hopelessly Democratic territory.

Out-of-town buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday numbered 909, against 1,279 last week and 1,599 in the corresponding week a year ago according to listings appearing in THE NEW YORK TIMES. There were 324 arrivals yesterday compared with 616 last Tuesday.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 12 (AP) -- The Naval Postgraduate School announced today that Dr. Roy S. Glasgow of St. Louis had been named its new academic dean.

BONN, Germany, April 12 -- Members of the Christian Democratic Union delegation in the Parliamentary Council here today called their opposite numbers in the Social Democratic ranks smartly to order and demanded that the concluding session at Bonn be held not later than April 21.

THERE is a strange breed of men known as clockers. They time the morning workouts of every horse to put foot on the race track. The jockeys wear no distinguishing colors and their mounts wear no numbers. Yet these sharp-eyed operatives never make a mistake in identifying the horses, a baffling trick to the uninitiate.

Four new issues of bonds, debentures and preferred stock totaling $120,000,000 will be placed on the market today by underwriting syndicates. Two of the offerings represent new flotations of public utility securities which were bought at public competitive sale by underwriting syndicates.

PRINCETON, N. J., April 12 -- In a contest which saw the lead change hands three times, Princeton and Pennsylvania battled over eight innings to a 6-6 deadlock today before play was halted because of darkness.

HAVE you yet discovered Joyce Cary, that astonishingly brilliant Irish-born English novelist whose belated presentation to the American reading public is causing such rejoicing? If you haven't you have missed one of the most technically accomplished novelists now alive, a virtuoso of prose narration and a master of characterization.
Passages from Robert E. Sherwood's "Roosevelt and Hopkins" were cited last night by Senator Wayne Morse to show how this generation had missed an opportunity to obtain world peace.

State officials, who had been hopeful that the unemployment rolls would start turning downward with the arrival of April, reported yesterday that the number of workers seeking unemployment insurance and veterans' readjustment benefits had gone up 2,447 last week.

Two ex-convicts were arrested in Brooklyn yesterday charged with having committed "dozens" of house burglaries in Brooklyn and Queens in the last six months. The woman friend of one of them also was taken into custody as an accomplice.
The United Nations has been the "victim" of misleading advertising by well-meaning but inexperienced friends, John Foster Dulles asserted yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- The financial position of domestic airlines should be "materially improved" by the end of 1949, Joseph J. O'Connell Jr., chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board, told Congress today.

The Glenn L. Martin Company had a consolidated net profit of $402,643 in the first quarter of 1949, contrasted with a net loss of $480,362 in the same period of last year, Glenn L Martin, president of the aircraft manufacturing company, reported yesterday at the annual meeting of stockholders in Baltimore.

Arguments are brewing among Connecticut communities about the birthplace of Phineas T. Barnum. The fuss may have something to do with the planned June arrival in that state of a circus with which Mr. Barnum was once connected.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- Kenneth C. Royall, Secretary of the Army, said today that savings of a billion dollars a year could be made in the military budget if the Secretary of Defense received the authority to say yes or no.

NUREMBERG, Germany, April 2 -- Two out of twenty-one defendants in a trial of former Nazi Government officials were set free tonight, cleared of charges against them, but the United States War Crimes Tribunal convicted twelve more high Nazi officials for their role in the extermination of 6,000,000 Jews.

VIENNA, April 12 -- Chancellor Leopold Figl told his Cabinet today that he has been informed by high commissioners of three Western occupation powers that Austria must continue to defray local schilling expenses of maintaining camps in this country for displaced persons.

Carmelo Bova, 15-year-old Italian war amputee, happily stretched his artificial arms and hands before reporters here yesterday to demonstrate the "miracle" of American cineplastic surgery. The boy's arms had been blown off when he was nine years old.

Equipped with the new Frost-N-Rite kit, even a novice can do a master job of cake decorating. Delicate rosebuds and gardenias of frosting may remain the province of the professional, but with this set simple designs and inscriptions may be easily -- and legibly -- fashioned.

NANKING, April 12 -- An angry Legislative Yuan passed a resolution today calling for the punishment of Gen. Tang En-po, commander of the Nanking-Shanghai area, and the abolition of the secret police, following the arrest Sunday of two legislators without the Government's knowledge.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- The United States and Canada through an exchange of notes established today the Joint Industrial Mobilization Committee to exchange information and coordinate views of the two Governments in connection with planning for industrial mobilization in the event of an emergency.

Although point-of-purchase advertising is of prime importance in today's selling, millions of dollars spent for this purpose are "going down the drain," W. P. Lillard, sales promotion manager for General Foods Corporation, declared yesterday. He addressed more than 800 advertising men at the annual symposium on display advertising sponsored by the Point-of-Purchase Advertising Institute, Inc., in the Biltmore Hotel.

CHARLOTTE, N. C., April 12 -- Frustration assailed the Dodgers on all fronts today. Their exhibition with the Senators was rained out -- the second straight day for that sort of thing -- and the arrival of the two Rickeys was only 50 per cent achieved.

ALBANY, April 12 -- Describing wire tapping for private purposes as "a nasty business," Governor Dewey signed today the Steingut-Quinn bill making the possession of wire-tapping equipment a crime comparable to possession of burglar tools.

Ironic indeed will be the result if a United Nations' effort to free the news channels of arbitrary censorship winds up in clamping censorship down more tightly than ever. Yet this is the present and obvious danger now facing the work of the U. N.'s subcommission on Freedom of Information and of the Press.
HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., April 12 (AP) -- Carrying the silks of Samuel Greenfield of Baltimore, High Trend surprised the talent in winning today's six-furlong feature contested by six sprinters.

A close fight is developing over the question of whether Israel's application for membership in the United Nations should be presented directly to the General Assembly or should go first to an Assembly committee, it was learned last night.

The Coast Guard hearing into misconduct charges against twenty-three members of the crew of the Isbrandtsen Company freighter Flying Arrow was adjourned early yesterday afternoon after brief testimony from Jean A. Brown, second assistant engineer.

The view that the wisdom of legislation is to be tested by political processes, not by litigation, is being restored in the courts, Associate Justice William O. Douglas of the United States Supreme Court declared last night.
Over the protests of the Netherlands, the United Nations General Assembly voted today to open full debate on the three-year-old war in Indonesia.

Our visitor was an urbane gentleman of medium stature. His dress was conservative and a bit formal, and he had a twinkle in his eye. Invited to have a chair, he sat down, and held out to us not a silver cigarette case but a tortoise-shell snuff box.
Excerpts from yesterday's debate at the United Nations General Assembly concerning the recent trials of Catholic and Protestant church leaders in Hungary and Bulgaria follow:
WASHINGTON, April 12 -- Louis Johnson, Secretary of Defense, said today that he and the Joint Chiefs of Staff had agreed that "war is a little further off today than it was a little while ago."

FORT MONMOUTH, N. J., April 12 -- The Army Signal Corps has designed and constructed a "silent chamber" that produces absolute silence, simulating the sound conditions found in the center of a desert, it was announced today.
Dr. Louis I. Dublin, Metropolitan Life Insurance Company statistician, gave this progress report on the battle to conquer cancer: "Altogether, the outlook for the future is hopeful.

LEXINGTON, Va., April 12 -- Education in the United States is facing a growing threat of Government "thought-control," Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of Princeton University, warned here today at the 200th anniversary celebration of the founding of Washington and Lee University.

TORONTO, April 12 (AP) -- Before National Hockey League fans start shouting "Break up the Maple Leafs" they had better figure a little deeper if they actually want to halt the Stanley Cup monopoly which seems to be shaping up for the Toronto team.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- A man in the back row stood up and told the Senate today that he had been trying his level best to work for the general welfare and hoped that the historians would say he had not failed. It had not dawned on the people in the gallery until Senator Scott W. Lucas, the Majority Leader, announced it, that President Truman was in their midst.

Erwin D. Canham, a member of the United States delegation to the United Nations General Assembly, said yesterday that in his opinion the United States would not sign a proposed convention on freedom of the press if several objectionable changes were incorporated.

A debate on whether the Hungarian trial of Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty and the Bulgarian prosecution of fifteen Protestant leaders violated the human rights and fundamental freedoms clauses of the United Nations Charter and peace treaties was authorized by the General Assembly yesterday by a 30-to-7 vote, with twenty naitons abstaining.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 12 -- Twentieth Century-Fox will not film "The Journey of Simon McKeever," the forthcoming novel by Albert Maltz which the studio bought twelve days ago for a reported $35,000, the Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation announced today in a formal statement which included no explanation of the decision to abandon the property and the investment.

New York City Housing Authority announced yesterday that it would receive bids April 22 on $31,611,000 of temporary loan notes to help finance three state-aided projects. Of the total, $11,580,000 will come due Dec. 15, 1949, and $20,031,000 May 10, 1950.
LONDON, April 12 -- The spread of the London dock strike and the approaching Easter holidays created a generally poor tone in the stock market here today.
Although slightly fuzzed by some high-riding clouds a total eclipse of the moon provided a gradually changing astronomical spectacle for New Yorkers last night.
Negotiations between representatives of thirteen major breweries and the United Brewery Workers, CIO, continued deadlocked yesterday despite a counter-offer by management.
Communist party members are taught that treason against the United States would be justified in a war with Soviet Russia, according to yesterday's testimony at the Communist trial.

It is no longer a secret that whatever may be wrong with the theatre, there is no fault to be found with the talent that is available. This fact was demonstrated convincingly yesterday afternoon at the Forty-sixth Street Theatre, where the Stage Managers Club presented "Talent '49," the second in a series of annual productions by the organization to enable lesser-known performers to display their abilities before producers, agents and other theatre representatives.

PARIS, April 12 -- Organizers of the Communist-supported Congress of Partisans of Peace that opens here next week today protested to the French Government its action limiting visas to be granted delegates from Eastern European states.
WASHINGTON, April 12 -- The United States has rejected a suggestion by the British that the Greek Army and Air Force be increased in a new effort to end the Greek war this year.

HALIFAX, N. S., April 12 (Canadian Press) -- There was more violence on the Pacific Coast today, while there was comparative calm elsewhere on the Canadian shipping scene, troubled by a jurisdictional dispute between the Canadian Seamen's Union and the Seafarers International Union (AFL).

TEL AVIV, April 12 -- As a Passover gesture, the State of Israel has decided to admit Sidney Stanley, principal witness in the tribunal that investigated allegations of corruption in British public life.

A little less demonstrative and somewhat more sparing in the use of invective, student pickets at City College continued to march yesterday on the second day of their strike. They were closely watched by shifting police details.

DALLAS, Tex., April 12 -- As its final production for the season, Theatre '49 is presenting a play about Charles and Mary Lamb by Dorothy Parker and Ross Evans. "The Coast of Illyria" they call it, in memory of the mythical shore where Shakespeare once shipwrecked a brother and sister.

The Small Business Committee of the House of Representatives will undertake a study of the impact of big retail activities on the small manufacturer, it was announced last night by Congressman Wright Patman, Democrat, of Texas, co-author of the Robinson-Patman Act, and chairman of the committee.

Two sections of a fourteen-foot, bored-out pine log, through which New York's original water system operated, have just been unearthed in a good state of preservation from the ground in front of 80 Maiden Lane.

The North Atlantic treaty should be supplemented by another equally constructive measure -- that is, action designed to make it abundantly clear that Washington's intentions are not aggressive, to give the Kremlin an opportunity to demonstrate that its intentions, too, are not aggressive, and to render aggression actually more difficult and hazardous.

MADISON, Wis., April 12 (UP) -- The Wisconsin Supreme Court upheld today the acquittal of William T. Evjue, editor of The Madison Capital Times, on charges of violating a state law banning publication of a rape victim's name.

ALBANY, April 12 -- A first step toward providing more state financial aid for public libraries, many of which are now in dire straits, was taken today at an hour-long conference between Governor Dewey and representatives of library officials and technicians.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 12 -- The perils faced by public planners were outlined here today by Robert Moses, coordinator of construction for New York City. He coupled his description of his "dangerous trade" with an attack on some writers in the field who he said used big words but overlooked practical considerations.
One of the most important Gothic statues in the western hemisphere will go on view today at The Cloisters, branch of the Metropolitan Museum of Art in Fort Tryon Park.

WASHINGTON, April 12 (AP) -- Senator Walter F. George, Democrat, of Georgia, said today he would oppose any effort to cut Federal excise taxes by tacking amendments onto the bill to repeal taxes and restrictions on oleomargarine.
ALBANY, April 12 (AP) -- Governor Dewey granted a sixth stay of execution today to three men convicted of first-degree murder in the shooting of Anthony Hintz, boss stevedore, in New York City.

Arnold Toynbee, British historian, said yesterday that the North Atlantic Pact, with European Recovery Program aid, would enable the Western European countries to pull through their crisis and that he saw no immediate danger of a shooting war.

Under a flawless ride by Ted Atkinson, Daniel Hess' Blue Lancer, a classy 3-year-old colt that never has finished worse than second, captured yesterday's Jamaica feature, the six-furlong Boniface, in the excellent clocking of 1:11 4-5. Backed down to 3-to-4 by most in the crowd of 24,363, Blue Lancer made every move a winning one.
Dr. Chaim Weizmann will arrive at the New York International Airport at Idlewild, Queens, from Paris today on his first visit to this country since his election as first President of Israel.

A hearing was opened in Federal Court yesterday on a motion by the Securities and Exchange Commission for an order approving a plan calling for dissolution of the Electric Power and Light Corporation under a section of the Public Utility Holding Company Act of 1935.

The first of six passenger vessels, acquired by Turkey from the United States Maritime Commission, completed her sea trials yesterday, after reconversion at the Hoboken yard of the Todd Shipyards Corporation.
