WASHINGTON, April 12 -- A delegation representing forty-three prominent Massachusetts businessmen and civic leaders advocated at a conference with Dean Acheson, Secretary of State, today a foreign policy having the objective of a functioning world organization capable of maintaining security.

Dr. Theodore Brameld's apologia in THE TIMES of April 3 of his sponsorship of the Cultural and Scientific Conference for World Peace misstates the facts about the criticism American liberals have directed against this conference.
SAN MARINO, Calif., April 12 (AP) -- A funeral service will be held tomorrow for Kathy Fiscus, whose tragic death in the depths of an abandoned well shocked the world.

The Passover festival, time-honored feast of liberation observed by Jews the world over, begins at sundown today. The festive season ends next Wednesday for Reform Jews and one day later for Orthodox and Conservative Jews.

FORT WORTH, Tex., April 12 -- While Joe DiMaggio was soaring to his clinical rendezvous today, Bob Porterfield was hurling an eight-inning no-hitter for the Yankees against Fort Worth, a Dodger farm club, before 2,247 onlookers today.

PARIS, April 12 -- David K. Bruce, now chief of the Economic Cooperation Administration's mission to France, is to be named United States Ambassador to France, it was learned tonight. Jefferson Caffery, whom he will replace, is to be assigned elsewhere. Mr. Bruce is now in Washington.
Luxene, Inc., makers of dental materials and equipment, to the Schuyler Hopper Company.

Harrison Dillard, the brilliant sprinter-hurdler from Cleveland who won the Olympic 100-meter dash, and Reggie Pearman, New York University's crack middle-distance runner, left from La Guardia Field for British Guiana aboard a Pan American World Airways plane yesterday. Accompanying the athletes was Joe Jancey, New York Pioneer Club coach.

Mayor O'Dwyer was told yesterday that motorists of this city would remain unprotected against unscrupulous garage owners through the rejection of Councilman Joseph T. Sharkey's garage and parking lot rent control bill.

NEW DELHI, India, April 12 -- Burmese Premier Thakin Nu has asked India for arms to put down the Karen rebellion and for help in obtaining funds from the British Commonwealth to finance this spring's rice exports, it was reliably learned tonight after a conference of the Burmese Premier with Indian Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru and other high Indian officials.

We believe that the House Subcommittee on Immigration should report out the Celler displaced persons bill -- H. R. 1344 -- in its entirety. There is no time for lip service to this cause. The time for action is now. It seems incredible that this bill, and its companion in the Senate, the McGrath-Neely bill, continue to be tossed around, debated, studied as though the subject were brand new.

BERLIN, April 12 -- The United States, British and French Foreign Ministers in their recent sessions in Washington agreed that their document on the fusion of the three Western zones of Germany would apply to Berlin "so far as practicable," it was learned today.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 12 -- A decision to make Western orientation the foundation of the new Syrian regime's foreign policy is believed here to be indicated in recent developments.

The problem of integrating persons past the age of 65 into a civilization advanced by recent discoveries in science and medicine was discussed yesterday by Dr. Howard A. Rusk, an associate editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, and William L. Laurence, the newspaper's science reporter.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- A recent Supreme Court decision will completely thwart the intent of Congress to grant to the Federal Government supreme authority in the field of labor relations affecting interstate commerce, according to a brief filed by the Government in the Supreme Court today.

The uncertainty regarding possible devaluation of the pound sterling that has been a dominant factor in the foreign exchange market for ten days was demonstrated again yesterday and sent rates for spot and forward contracts down to fresh low points.
Directors of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) declared yesterday a cash dividend of $1.50 a share in addition to a stock dividend of four shares for each 200 shares held, payable on June 10.

ALLAIRE, N. J., April 16 -- Here among the rural remnants of a once thriving early nineteenth century industrial community stand unmarked monuments to a wealthy champion of labor's cause, who pioneered his beliefs more than a hundred years ago.
ATHENS, April 12 (UP) -- The in-and-out Cabinet of Premier Themistocles Sophoulis resigned abruptly tonight, but King Paul promptly asked Mr. Sophoulis to form a new Government.

WASHINGTON, April 12 (AP) -- Representative Dean P. Taylor and Senator Irving M. Ives, New York Republicans, proposed today that Congress invite the International Olympic Committee to hold the 1956 Winter Games in Lake Placid, N. Y. The 1952 Olympics have been awarded to Finland.

John D. Rockefeller 3d, city-wide chairman of the Greater New York Fund's twelfth annual campaign, made public yesterday an endorsement of the drive by Governor Dewey. The fund will seek $8,000,000 from business organizations and employe groups from April 25 to June 10.

A program for the rehabilitation of the 1,900-mile Siamese railway system, which may eventually involve an expenditure of $45,000,000, was outlined here yesterday by a four-man trade mission from Siam. It is expected that a substantial amount of this sum will be spent on American-made equipment.

Both the United States and Australia are seeking to develop regional cooperation for the common defense of southeast Asia and the Pacific within the framework of the United Nations, Dr. Herbert V. Evatt, Deputy Prime Minister of Australia and president of the United Nations General Assembly, declared last night.
LONDON, April 12 -- The strike of London dockers took on grave proportions today as the numbers involved have doubled since the walkout began yesterday over the dismissal of thirty-three men.

American industry was told yesterday it must take the initiative in promoting greater consumer use of its products and that large markets now exist into which new products can be introduced. These conclusions were advanced at the production conference of the American Management Association at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, by A. D. H. Kaplan of the Brookings Institution, Washington, D. C.

Four men were arraigned yesterday in Kings County Court on an indictment charging them with illegal wiretapping to obtain evidence in a divorce action. On their pleas of not guilty, Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz released them in $1,000 bail each for trial, a date for which was not set.
Between morning and mid-afternoon yesterday Mrs. Jean Foster, a Flatbush housewife, went through an emotional experience that combined sheer delight, blank despair and overwhelming relief.

More than 700 persons admitted to the City Hall Board of Estimate chamber in relays heard spokesmen for city employe labor groups present demands to the Board of Estimate yesterday for general salary increases ranging up to $850 annually for all civil service workers.
WASHINGTON, April 12 (UP) -- Sixteen young Dutch farmers registered for the draft before leaving for six months' work on farms in fourteen Eastern and Midwestern states.

The one-story business building at 295 Taafe Place, Brooklyn, has been purchased by the Lomey Manufacturing Corporation, through its newly formed 295 Taafe Place Realty Corporation, from Standard-Yne Service, Inc. The pin manufacturing concern will move its facilities from 31 West Thirty-first Street, Manhattan, to the Brooklyn building.
WASHINGTON, April 12 (AP) -- The Government acted today toward providing an extra $595,890,000 in GI benefits for the next three months, partly because of increased joblessness among veterans.

WASHINGTON, April 12 (AP) -- Secretary of Agriculture Brannan today predicted that the Government, already alarmed at its largest holdings of corn in history, will be buying pork within sixty days to hold prices up.

If Mr. Truman wished to dramatize how far this country has moved in the international field during his Presidency he could not have done so more effectively than by sending the Atlantic Pact to the Senate for ratification on the fourth anniversary of his accession to power.

CHICAGO, April 12 -- The last vice president, save one, resigned today from Montgomery Ward Co. The action left the company with one officer of vice president rank, compared with nine a year ago, no president and a chairman and chief executive, Sewell L. Avery, the uncompromising figure who has been the storm center of all the company's management disputes.

In a message that brushes aside specious reasoning and wishful thinking and faces the realities of the situation, President Truman yesterday submitted the North Atlantic Treaty to the Senate with the request for "advice and consent" to its ratification as an essential step toward a just and enduring peace.

LONDON, April 12 -- Another but milder five-year dose of socialism for Britain was prescribed today by the leadership of the Labor party, which has governed the country since 1945 and now is starting to campaign for re-election in 1950.

PEORIA, Ill., April 12 (AP) -- Caterpillar Tractor Company reported today that it proposed to declare a 100 per cent stock dividend on its common shares. A second proposal would authorize 350,000 shares of cumulative preferred stock.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., April 12 -- With the arrival tonight of several bus loads of strikebreakers from New York, hotel owners in this resort city moved to halt a five-day walkout of service employes and bartenders that has crippled operations in ten major ocean-front hostleries.
WASHINGTON, April 12 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture today gave farmers until Aug. 1 to reclaim 1948 cotton stored under Government price-supporting loans.
ST. LOUIS, April 12 (AP) -- Zinc production has increased 55 per cent per man-hour in the last ten years, General Manager W. C. Page of the U. S. Smelting, Refining and Mining Company said today.
Grenville Mellen, a member of the United States Maritime Commission, has been named vice chairman of the Government shipping agency, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- The United Light and Railways Company, Chicago, asked the Securities and Exchange Commission today for authorization to borrow $19,500,000 from four banks. The company expects to use the proceeds to redeem outstanding prior preferred stock, which consists of 37,993 shares of 7 per cent first series, 52,329 shares of 6.36 per cent series of 1925 and 99,516 shares of 6 per cent series of 1928.

ANNECY, France, April 12 -- The United States and other major trading countries began work here today on a means of preventing the tariff concessions negotiated multilaterally from being vitiated by unilateral changes in currency values.
JACKSON, Miss., April 12 -- The tour of the world champion Indians and Giants struck a snag today when adverse weather washed out the eleventh game of their exhibition series.

Snapping a 1-all tie by getting three runs in the fifth inning, New York University gained undisputed possession of the lead in the Metropolitan Collegiate Conference yesterday by halting Manhattan's baseball team, 4 to 1, at Ohio Field.
WASHINGTON, April 12 (AP) -- The text of Secretary of State Acheson's report to President Truman on the North Atlantic treaty follows:

LONDON, April 12 (AP) -- A British archaeologist said today he really would be looking for Noah's Ark on a trip to the Soviet border. He scoffed at a charge by Pravda in Moscow that he was bent on spying.

Mme. Flora had distinguished guests for her party in the third act of Verdi's "La Traviata" last night at the Metropolitan Opera House. They included eleven well-known former stars of the Metropolitan who came back as "supers" to aid in the drive to raise $250,000 for next season.

PHILADELPHIA, April 12 -- A charge that the mental hospitals of the country are deteriorating in that they are failing to give their patients what modern medicine has to offer was made today by Dr. George S. Stevenson, president-elect of the American Psychiatric Association.
The battle of ideologies that raged around last month's "cultural" conference at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel will be transplanted to Paris at the end of this month, it became clear yesterday.
The American Joint Distribution Committee yesterday wrote "mission accomplished" on one of its most intensive relief campaigns: "Operation SOS," the Supplies for Overseas Survivors Collection.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 12 -- Yugoslavia today is in the unusual position of being on amiable terms with none of her neighbors.

FORT WORTH, Tex., April 12 -- The Yankees will launch their quest of the 1949 American League pennant one week from today without the aid of Joe DiMaggio. Wallopin' Joie is in for another siege at Johns Hopkins Hospital, Baltimore.

LAWRENCE, Mass., April 12 -- A Communist "push" to promote unrest in this textile city of many jobless became evident today as party workers appeared at the local employment security office to press pamphlets into the hands of benefit claimants.

HALLANDALE, Fla., April 12 (AP) -- Treplow Stable's Fugitive, 7-to-10 favorite, won the featured Giralda Purse at Gulfstream Park today, leading all the way and covering the mile and a sixteenth in 1:44 3-5 over a fast track. Whirltown was second and Appease Not third in the field of eight 3-year-olds.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 12 -- The sister trade papers, Variety and Daily Variety, filed suit today in the Federal District Court here against the Screen Writers Guild asking an injunction restraining the guild from enforcing its rule against trade - paper advertising by guild members.

Mrs. Greta Appel had her heart set for years on going into the restaurant business. For twenty years she had worked in restaurants as a counter girl. She had definite ideas on what she would do if she owned her own eating place.

Brooklyn College opened its baseball campaign yesterday by defeating John Marshall of Jersey City, 9 -- 5. The visitors, who lost to Columbia in extra innings last Saturday, fielded virtually the same team that swamped the Kingsmen, 19 -- 0, last year.
ALBANY, April 12 -- Governor Dewey signed today a bill aimed at the eventual elimination of segregation of white and Negro troops in the New York National Guard and Naval Militia.
Intervention by Joseph E. O'Grady, the city's labor trouble shooter, averted yesterday a strike set for this morning at Bloomingdale's department store.

WASHINGTON, April 12 (U.P.) -- Capital Airlines, which received $4,905,082 for flying mail last year, reported today that it realized a net profit of $123,997 on its 1948 operations. This compared with a net loss of $1,581,091 in 1947 when its airmail pay amounted to $4,126,513.

A grand jury inquiry into the wiretapping plot against city officials resulted yesterday in the indictment of John G. Broady, attorney and private investigator for Clendenin J. Ryan, an O'Dwyer administration foe, and two other men on charges of illegal wiretapping.

Consolidated net income of the Niagara Hudson Power Corporation for the first quarter of this year was $4,567,000, compared with $3,889,000 a year ago. Earle J. Machold, president, disclosed at the annual meeting of stockholders in Syracuse yesterday.
Those who pushed business problems aside on Monday and Tuesday had better luck and more solitude on the near-by trout waters, but the watershed lakes continued to be very poor producers.

The approval of the reorganization of Paramount Pictures, Inc. by an overwhelming vote of stockholders at a special meeting yesterday, will set in motion the divorcement of the company's motion picture business from the theatre and distribution operation.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 12 (AP) -- John M. Marsalka, denied re-appointment by Yale as assistant professor of history and Russian studies, said today he was awaiting action by the American Association of University Professors before deciding what next to do.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were irregular yesterday and final prices were 15 points higher to 1 point lower.

Two sons of taxicab drivers won four-year college scholarships yesterday in the second annual Terminal System scholarship competition. The awards were made at the system's garages at Forty-fifth Street and Eleventh Avenue by Daniel G. Arnstein, president of the company.

Operation by the Long Island Rail Road of its Fishermen's Special train to Canoe Place on Peconic Bay and Montauk will be resumed Saturday, May 14, and continue every Saturday and Sunday through Oct. 31, it was announced yesterday.
MIAMI BEACH, Fla., April 12 (AP) -- Seeded players had little trouble advancing to the third round in the first annual good neighbor tennis tournament today.

Coffee futures trading was active with prices recovering toward the close on the the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday. Trade and commission-house selling was absorbed on a scale down by trade hedge covering and some support from producer interests.
TOKYO, April 12 -- The Japanese Government today cracked down on official publications of the Communist party, slashing by two-thirds their allotment of strictly rationed newsprint.

"The Germans Strike Again," a Greek-made drama, will have its local premiere today at the Golden Theatre on West Forty-fifth Street. Basil Logothetidi and Costas Tsaganeas are starred in the offering, directed by Alecos Sakellariou from his play of the same name. Dialogue is Greek and there are English titles. The Finos Film production is being released here by Helbranco Distributing Corporation.

The Russian Embassy took steps yesterday to obtain the release of Valentin A. Gubitchev, the Soviet engineer who has been held in the Federal House of Detention in $100,000 bail since his arrest last month on an espionage charge, but nothing came of it.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- President Truman asked the Senate today to ratify the North Atlantic treaty and thus signal the free world's determination to stand united to maintain peace with justice. Ratification would be notice, as well, he said, that this free world would act against any who might break that peace.

By a preponderance of votes, "Death of a Salesman," "The Madwoman of Chaillot" and "South Pacific" were selected yesterday by the New York Drama Critics Circle as the outstanding Broadway shows of the 1948-49 season.

The National City Bank of New York and the Manufacturers Trust Company are now experimenting in the use of "personalized" checks, imprinted with the name of special checking account holders without extra charge, it was learned yesterday.

Consumer pressure for high quality at lower prices, together with the threat of recession, makes it imperative that national brand manufacturers meet these challenges with a new, aggressive advertising and selling campaign in cooperation with retailers, it was declared yesterday by Charles B. Dulcan Sr., vice president and general manager of the Hecht Company of Washington, D. C.

ALBANY, April 12 -- Mayor O'Dwyer in a memorandum made public here today requested Governor Dewey to veto the state building code bill that was approved by the Legislature in its closing hours under heavy pressure from the Governor.
WASHINGTON, April 12 -- The House approved overwhelmingly today an authorization of $5,380,000,000 for the European Recovery Program in the next fifteen months.
WASHINGTON, April 12 -- The Senate became locked today in bitter controversy which, it was conceded widely, might spell the future of the Tennessee Valley Authority in voting tests due tomorrow.

A singer who hires Carnegie Hall for a debut recital tempts fate. But Lee Fairfax, young Virginia baritone, who took that chance last night, astonished thos unfamiliar with the quality of his voice by showing himself equal to such surroundings.

The Consolidated Grocers Corporation in the thirty-six weeks ended on March 5 increased its net profit to $2,037,718 from $1,919,545 for the corresponding period last year, as a result of the inclusion of operations of the wholly owned subsidiary, Rosenberg Brothers Co., Inc., the report said yesterday.

"The American Cancer Society, by its campaign of popular education and its patronage of scientific research in the surgical treatment of cancer, is rendering magnificent service to humanity," writes Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, president of Columbia University.

ALBANY, April 13 -- Governor Dewey has informed Republican leaders that he will follow a "hands-off" policy in the selection of a new state chairman. This was disclosed today after Miss Jane Todd, as acting chairman, had summoned the Republican State Committee to meet here April 21 to pick a new presiding officer.
HEMPSTEAD, L. I., April 13 -- Six unearned runs helped St. John's to defeat Hofstra by 8 -- 7 in a Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference game today.

Sixty-four per cent of sixty-seven typical men's stores throughout the country have indicated that they will cover from 50 to 60 per cent of their requirements of men's fall clothing when the lines are opened in the next few days, according to a sample survey by the National Association of Retail Clothiers and Furnishers, issued yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, April 13 -- The proposal of Jan Drohojowski, delegate to the General Assembly's Social Committee, for government right to suppress certain news material was defeated here today, but the Polish delegate received at least a pledge of some remuneration.

NEWARK, N. J., April 13 -- Each of the fourteen tables in the annual table-setting contest at Bamberger's today had a colored cloth rather than a white one. The tables and their floral centerpieces were arranged on an "Easter Sunday buffet" theme by local branches of the Garden Club of New Jersey.

Alfred B. Cohen, fur buyer of Kirby, Block Co., resident buyers, will receive the 1949 annual award of the Fur Garment Traveling Salesmen's Association, Inc., for outstanding services toward the betterment of the fur industry, it was announced yesterday.

TRIESTE, April 13 -- The local population of the Free Territory has clung to three main opinions as to the future of Trieste during the last three years while the big powers have continually shifted their viewpoints according to the changing requirements of continental strategy.

Jose Basora, veteran warrior from Puerto Rico, stopped Vern Lester of San Francisco in the main bout scheduled for ten rounds at the Manhattan Center last night. The end came in 2:47 of the sixth when Referee Frank Fullam interfered to spare Lester punishment.

Greece has not fallen, but the national army is pretty literally hanging on by its bootstraps to the steep mountain crags commanded by its enemies. It is significant that the recent raids in the Grammos area, which was freed last year at a terrible cost of blood and effort, were made in greater strength than any attacks since the beginning of hostilities.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Strong endorsement of a separate United States Academy for the Air Force, similar to those for the Army at West Point and the Navy at Annapolis, came today from the Service Academy Board of the National Military Establishment.

Pointing out that Federal grants to states and cities for the 1950 fiscal year were budgeted at nearly $2,500,000,000, Thomas S. Holden, chairman of the Federal grants-in-aid subcommittee of the National Association of Manufacturers, declared yesterday that a "great illusion" accounted for the readiness of the governmental subdivisions to accept the grants.

Daniel E. Fox, a Brooklyn letter carrier, is unhappy about his future. On June 30, after more than fifty-four years with the Post Office Department, Mr. Fox is scheduled to retire, because on June 24 he will have reached his seventieth birthday and the mandatory retirement age.

TORONTO, April 13 (AP) -- The Toronto Maple Leafs moved within a game of becoming the first team in modern professional hockey to win the Stanley Cup three successive times tonight as they downed Detroit Red Wings 3 -- 1. It was their third straight victory without defeat in the best-of-seven final National Hockey League series.

HALLANDALE, Fla., April 13 (AP) -- Plymouth Stable's Gold Eagle, with L. Loveridge in the irons, came between horses entering the stretch and went on to win the Gulfstream Park feature by two and a half lengths today.

CHICAGO, April 13 -- The last remaining vice president of Montgomery Ward Co. resigned today. He is Willard H. Sahloff, the company's merchandise manager, who was picked for the job last June by Sewell L. Avery, its chairman.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- The United States, Britain and France sought in separate agreements today to maximize Western Germany's contribution toward European recovery and encourage its efforts, within security limits, toward economic self-sufficiency.

Dr. Chaim Weizmann, first President of the State of Israel, arrived yesterday at the New York International Airport at Idlewild, Queens, with the somber warning that his embryo nation still faced the danger of military attack. This is Dr. Weizman's first visit to this country since his election.

PRAGUE, April 13 (AP) -- No information was available at the Embassy on a story that a Miss Mary Selody, an American girl in charge of an orphanage in Moravia, also had been threatened with expulsion for "creating public disorder." Her home town was not known here.
There was hope along thirsty Third Avenue yesterday. Beer -- barrels, gallons and bottles of it -- is about to come to New York from New Jersey.

BEIRUT, Lebanon; April 13 -- The plight of the free press in the Arab Orient was described today in the most literate city of the Middle East as desperate following Gen. Husni Zayim's abrupt decree suppressing permanently eleven out of nineteen Damascus newspapers.

LONDON, April 13 -- A draft constitution for the Council of Europe has been completed by diplomatic representatives of the ten countries involved, the Foreign Office said today. The diplomats have been meeting here regularly for the last two weeks.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- People who are still arguing over the chief reason why the President was elected last November may, after noting his actions on the fourth anniversary of his accession, be more willing to settle on this one -- that he responds normally to normal impulses.

CHICAGO, April 13 -- Except for May wheat, grain prices ranged lower on the Board of Trade here today, with the finish on a strong rally from the early low as the result of short covering. May wheat was up 1 cent a bushel at one time, selling at a new high level since early last March and closed 7/8 cent higher, with the distant deliveries 1/2 to 1 1/8 cents lower.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- A bill calling for drastic revision of the Displaced Persons act to eliminate provisions criticized as discriminatory and unworkable, was approved today by a House Judiciary subcommittee.

Coffee futures were higher in moderately active trading on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday. Demand from local trade and producer interest advanced prices for contract "S" 35 to 13 points above the previous levels.

Testimony before the Senate Committee on Armed Services in support of the Tydings bill to tighten up the unification of the defense services is becoming increasingly impressive. The very fact that some of the expert witnesses differ in regard to desirable amendments lends even more weight to their unanimity in favor of the bill itself.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- The Civil Aeronautics Board today formally asked Congress to grant it regulatory control over contract air carriers, comparable to that which it exercises over the regular airlines. The request was made by Chairman Joseph J. O'Connell Jr. in testimony before a subcommittee of the Senate Committee on Interstate and Foreign Commerce.

Governor Dewey's acceptance of the principle that public library problems are a matter of state concern and his cooperation in the making of a recess study of how those problems can be met are an encouraging development. They are a logical consequence of his statement in late February when he said: "I would like very much to see us help the libraries.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- The national leadership of the Republican party is expected to reach a number of basic decisions for the conduct of the 1950 Congressional campaign in an important three-day series of meetings beginning here April 23.

Jews throughout the world commemorated yesterday with prayer and thanksgiving the beginning of another Passover -- the traditional festival of liberty that had its inception 3,500 years ago when the ancient Israelites escaped Egyption slavery and set out for their Promised Land.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., April 13 -- John McAllister, 52 years old, who has been in jail almost continuously since he was 16, won a dismissal here today of the last remaining charge against him and became a free man. The dismissal was in line with a February victory in Bronx County.

PHILADELPHIA, April 13 -- About nine-tenths of the mental hospitals in the country are using some form of shock therapy. One-fourth of the remaining institutions, chiefly private mental hospitals, are not using shock because they do not believe in it, preferring psychotherapy.

NORWALK, Conn., April 13 -- Elliot E. Simpson, New York financier, said today that a special meeting of the stockholders of the Norwalk Tire and Rubber Company had been called for May 3 to remove incumbent officers of the company.

PHILADELPHIA, April 13 -- Judge George A. Welsh of the United States District Court refused today to permit the Isbrandtsen Steamship Company of New York to deposit again with the court $10,647 withheld from the wages due twenty-three crewmen of the Flying Arrow when they were fired here ten days ago.

LONDON, April 13 -- Labor members of newly elected London County Council took control of that body today by what their Conservative opponents called "an un-English trick." The cry of "Fascists!" was shouted across the council chamber at the Laborites.

A substantial demand for rugs and carpets is still available if merchandise is priced right, Dr. Jules Backman, New York University Professor of Economics, declared yesterday. He spoke at the spring meeting of the Carpet Institute, Inc., in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Reactions of a handful of issues to sepcific news developments featured an otherwise indecisive stock market yesterday. Price changes generally were in small fractions, but a few issues moved a point or more. The close was irregularly lower.

ALBANY, April 13 -- With the assertion that it is the finest measure of its kind yet adopted by any unit of government, Governor Dewey signed today the Mailler sickness disability compensation bill, which the Legislature passed under strong Administration pressure.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Arthur Hays Sulzberger, publisher of THE NEW YORK TIMES, will receive the Army Certificate of Appreciation tomorrow in a ceremony to be held in the office of Kenneth C. Royall, Secretary of the Army, it was announced today.
LONDON, April 13 (UP) -- Following are excerpts from the text of Britain's formal rejection of Soviet charges regarding the Atlantic pact:

Following are excerpts from addresses given yesterday by Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union and Warren R. Austin of the United States. The section in Mr. Gromyko's speech dealing with the North Atlantic treaty is given in full. He spoke in Russian and the translation is unofficial.

While Supreme Court Justice Bernard Botein was hearing two petitions here yesterday for enjoinment of a special stockholders meeting of the Farnsworth Television and Radio Corporation scheduled for today to effect a merger with the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, C. H. Wiggin, secretary of Farnsworth, announced in Chicago that a resolution would be introduced calling for an adjournment until next Tuesday.

Pan - American Day, which will be observed today, was marked last night by 400 members and guests of the Pan American Society of the United States and its twenty associated organizations at a dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. The dinner honored the Latin-American consular corps in this city.

ST. PAUL, Minn., April 13 (AP) -- Injured wrist and all, George Mikan pushed in 29 points tonight to spark the Minneapolis Lakers to a 77-56 victory over the Washington Capitols for the championship of the Basketball Association of America.

More than 300 Displaced Persons who last year were scattered in twenty countries awaiting an opportunity to come here, attended their first Passover Seder in the United States last night at the Marseilles Hotel as guests of the United Service for New Americans, Inc., at its headquarters.
Arthur S. Meyer, chairman of the State Mediation Board, acted yesterday to avert a threatened strike by 20,000 building service workers in 2,000 Manhattan apartment buildings.

BUENOS AIRES, April 13 -- The one Argentine export for which there is still a big demand and upon which a large part of this country's economy rests may not be available for the foreign market after April 21, according to today's outlook.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- The long-expected demand for a Columbia Valley Administration to develop the great water system of the Northwest for power, irrigation and flood control was presented to Congress by President Truman today.

LONDON, April 13 -- The Labor party's nationalization program was the sole topic of conversation in the stock market here today. Jobbers marked prices lower at opening -- with wider margins between buying and selling levels -- but investors soon showed they had decided to stand firm. Jobbers reported later that there was "no selling and no signs of it."
Branch Rickey said yesterday that baseball's reserve clause is opposed by persons of "avowed Communist tendencies" and he drew immediate fire from men challenging the game in the courts.

BALTIMORE, April 13 (AP) -- Four leather-bound parchment scrolls, described by Dr. F. W. Albright, archaeologist of Johns Hopkins University, as "the greatest manuscript discovery of modern times," soon will be offered for sale to the highest bidder.

Aided by Dom Montalbano's grand-slam home run in the third inning, Manhattan College trounced St. Francis, 8 -- 0, at the Parade Grounds diamond in Prospect Park, Brooklyn, yesterday. The game, halted after seven innings on account of rain, was the first victory in four starts for the Jaspers and marked the Terriers' second loss in two games.

Exiled leaders of Communist-dominated countries will pledge themselves to work together in unity to liberate their peoples from Communist oppression at a rally Thursday night, May 5, in Carnegie Hall, it was announced yesterday.

JERSEY CITY, N. J., April 13 -- Stockholders of the Hudson Manhattan Railroad Company elected today four new members to the ten-man board of directors in the shortest and most peaceful annual meeting held here in the last four years.

THE map exists for Quentin Reynolds to cover it. A cheerful and pacific man by nature, he takes all turmoil as his province. And since things everywhere have a way of getting violently unstuck these days, from Patagonia to Peiping, he finds the material for his delayed-news odysseys all over the planet.

United States postal inspectors broke into a vacant store at 314 Stanton Street a little before 8 o'clock last night and recovered $50,000 worth of silks, furs and other apparel that had been stolen from the mails in the last few months.

ANNECY, France, April 13 -- Denmark, Norway and Sweden advised the participants in the Annecy trade conference today of their intention to establish a common Scandinavian tariff that might eventually lead to a customs union.

Now that the Senate and House have approved companion measures calling for the extension of the Marshall Plan through the fiscal year 1950, it is to be hoped that this action will be followed by a speedy restoration of the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act to its status before 1948.

BUFFALO, N. Y., April 13 (AP) -- The Bell Aircraft Corporation announced today an operating loss of $1,036,901 for 1948. The net loss was $347,122 after consideration of a gain of $689,779 on the sale of a plant at Burlington, Vt. The company had a net loss of $1,183,995 in 1947.

Jess Larson, War Assets Administrator, disclosed in Federal Court yesterday that the Henry J. Kaiser interests had bid $33,000,000 last April 4 for the purchase of four Government-owned aluminum plants. He said that the offer was under consideration by his agency.

Two university economists and a union executive agreed last night that the country had not been going through a depression. They spoke in a broadcast over station WQXR on "What's on Your Mind?" With more cooperation among the Federal Government, management and labor, a decline in the country's economy could be averted, they hold.

In a heavy rain storm last night, Richard H. Crowe, former assistant manager of the National City Bank branch at 195 Broadway, who disappeared with $883,660 of the bank's funds and bonds, led agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation to his grandmother's grave in a Staten Island cemetery where $49,122 was unearthed by seven men who dug by the aid of flashlights.

DUESSELDORF, April 13 -- The British Military Government today abolished the district League of Deutsche Rechtspartei [German Right party] in the Gifhorn area of Lower Saxony and confiscated its funds and records.

Wagner's "Parsifal" received the first of its two post-season presentations last night at the Metropolitan Opera House. The title role was sung by Set Svanholm, and Osie Hawkins was the Amfortas at this performance. Otherwise, the cast was identical with that of the previous hearing of the opera last month curing the regular series.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., April 13 -- One of the ten struck resort hotels here, the Chelsea, reached an agreement with its employes today, but little or no progress appeared to have been made at the others that were struck as a group last Friday.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- As a means of furthering national security, Charles Sawyer, Secretary of Commerce, urged Congress today to approve a bill to promote the conservation of the tin ore reserves of the Western Hemisphere and increase their availability to the United States through diversification of tin-recovery facilties.

Seeking to buy a new loom for every one that it now owns, the Springs Cotton Mills of Lancaster, S. C., has placed an order for 14,000 looms with the Draper Corporation of Hopedale, Mass., it was announced yesterday. The new looms will be used for both replacement and expansion, it was said, and will be delivered to the seven manufacturing units of Springs Cotton Mills over a period of eleven years.

Since most types of woven fiber matting come from tropical lands where keeping cool is a highly developed art, even a few yards of these fibrous materials can, by suggestion, cool off the August atmosphere of a New York apartment.

Representative Richard M. Nixon, Republican, of California, co-author of the anti-Communist bill that was rejected by the Senate last year, predicted here yesterday that legislation aimed against communism would be passed at the present session of Congress.

CHICAGO, April 13 -- The National Association of Broadcasters today asked that the Federal Communications Commission make it a policy not to license any Federally owned or operated radio station to operate commercially in competition with privately owned stations.
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- The Veterans Administration announced today that, in some hardship cases, it would waive claims against veterans in default on loans under the "GI Bill of Rights."

Morningside Heights is an "unusually self-sufficient and cosmopolitan community," in which "forvard-looking planning for improved conditions" would be welcomed by the residents, Morningside Heights, Inc., decided after a survey made public yesterday.

THERE could not possibly be any more distressing news than the announcement that Joe DiMaggio had been forced to return to the hospital for a re-examination of the most famous heel since Achilles. More alarming still were the hints that the Yankee Clipper may have come to the end of a quite remarkable career. That would be a blow of staggering impact.

Dr. Bela Fabian, a member of the Executive Committee of the Hungarian Government - in - Exile, has completed a biography of Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty that Scribners will publish in the summer. The author, who was for seventeen years a member of the Hungarian Parliament and leader of the Independent Democratic party, worked with the Cardinal to prevent racial persecutions under the Nazi regime.
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- The House approved and sent to the Senate today a record peacetime outlay of $15,909,116,800 for defense for the fiscal year starting next July 1. The vote was 271 to 1.

BALTIMORE, April 13 -- Ignoring the weather which washed out a Dodger exhibition game for the third straight day, President Branch Rickey of the Brooklyn club arrived this morning by plane and was closeted with Red Smith, the Cubs' trading agent, a good part of the day.

LONDON, April 13 -- Leaders of the Trades Union Congress spent an hour and a quarter today with Sir Stafford Cripps, Chancellor of the Exchequer, discussing his "iron" budget and the reception they expect it to receive from organized labor.

PARIS, April 13 -- Foreign Minister Robert Schuman and Herve Alphand, chief of the economic section of the Foreign Office, defended Washington agreements on Germany today against charges that France had made too great a concessions.

Former President Herbert Hoover issued a statement yesterday replying to the challenge of Army Secretary Kenneth C. Royall to a part of the criticisms in the "task force" report on the preliminary military budget for 1950.

Fortune Gallo's San Carlo Opera Company will open its annual twelve-day season at the Center Theatre, Rockefeller Center, on Wednesday night, May 4. Sixteen performances, including four matinees, are scheduled. The repertoire will consist of eleven operas, five of which will have second presentations on the three final days of the engagement.

For two and a half hours yesterday Walter P. Marshall, president of the $207,000,000 Western Union Telegraph Company since last December, replied to a series of attacks from several voluble stockholders. It was the ninety-third annual meeting for shareholders, but Mr. Marshall's first.

Congressional hearings on proposed amendments to the Unification Act and consideration of service appropriation bills followed yesterday a series of considerably publicized changes or "reforms" made by Louis Johnson, who has been Secretary of Defense for the past two and a half weeks.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson assured German political leaders through statements made at his weekly news conference today that under the Allied occupation statute the proposed new Western German state could operate widely and effectively in the field reserved for final approval by the occupying powers.

Ralph T. Walker, new president of the American Institute of Architects, defended the building industry yesterday with a denial of the charge that it was backward and unprogressive, but urged teamwork by all elements in the construction field particularly to help bring housing costs down.

The nation's crude oil output last week averaged 4,916,050 barrels daily, the lowest level in about three years. This was a decline of 156,350 barrels daily from the output of 5,072,400 in the previous week. The drop of 154,750 barrels in the output of Texas accounted for virtually all the decline.
The Soviet Union charged yesterday that the North Atlantic Security Treaty was a weapon of aggression forged by the Western powers to aid intensive plans for war against Russia.

Post-war Communist teaching and advocacy of violent destruction of American democracy are based on instructions from Premier Joseph Stalin of Soviet Russia issued just before the Hitler-Stalin pact, according to yesterday's testimony at the Communist trial.
WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP) -- The Senate today approved President Truman's appointment of Stephen T. Early as Under-Secretary of Defense, a new job.

An egg-rolling contest -- one form of sport that's more often talked about than indulged in -- will be held on Saturday afternoon on the Great Lawn in Central Park, Eightieth to Eighty-fourth Street. The children's museum of the Metropolitan Museum of Art has an Easter egg tree.
Mayor O'Dwyer singled out the Greater New York Fund yesterday as a money-raising effort that deserves special support from city employes.
WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP) -- Following is the text of the State Department's announcement on revision of the German reparations program:
Interrupting training maneuvers on the Atlantic for a gala Easter week-end in New York, a flotilla of thirty American warships will sail into New York Harbor tomorrow morning.

WASHINGTON, April 13 (UP) -- The National Labor Relations Board today reaffirmed that even under the old Wagner Act a union could not force a member to lose his job under a closed shop contract because he was active for a rival organization.

PRAGUE, April 13 -- The United States Embassy today announced the arrest in Prague of Miss Vlasta Adele Vraz, an American citizen who is chief of the American Relief for Czechoslovakia, which distributes food and clothing to children.

The possibility of restoring the Palace Theatre, now showing double film features, to its former status as an ace vaudeville house was conceded yesterday by Sol A. Schwartz, general manager of the RKO circuit. Exactly when the change would be made could not be ascertained from Mr. Schwartz.

The annual Easter Chess Festival, sponsored by the Southern Counties Chess Union under the auspices of the British Chess Federation, started off auspiciously yesterday at the Milton Day Training College in Southsea. The competition drew close to a hundred entries in the various events on the program, according to a report from London.

Pathos and irony characterized some of the testimony that irate gas consumers of the Consolidated Edison Company gave at hearings before the Public Service Commission yesterday on the $11,440,000 annual gas rate increase that went into effect on Jan. 10.

For the first time since the collapse of its unsuccessful citywide taxi strike, the Taxi Workers Organizing Committee, affiliated with John L. Lewis' catch-all District 50, applied yesterday to the State Labor Relations Board for certification as bargaining agent for a group of drivers.

Coincident with the report of earnings for the first quarter, the Mathieson Chemical Corporation announced yesterday that it had concluded arrangements as of April 1 for a twenty-year unsecured loan of $20,000,000 with the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company.

HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., April 13 (AP) -- After late scratches had reduced the field to four starters, William G. Helis' Mr. Ace, the 7-10 favorite, won the thirty-sixth running of the $10,000 added Harford Handicap by six lengths today.

The first of two performances of Beethoven's Ninth Symphony that Serge Koussevitzky and the Boston Symphony will give this week in New York took place last night in Carnegie Hall, and a thrilling occasion it proved to be. These will be the last two New York performances of Koussevitzky's twenty-five-year engagement as conductor of the orchestra which he has served so greatly and so well.

Despite inroads by synthetic fibers, the popularity of worsteds and quality woolens is undiminished in the men's and women's wear fields, according to speakers at the annual meeting of the National Association of Wool Manufacturers in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., April 13 -- A seven-fold increase in sales during the next three years now appears likely for spray type insecticides, cosmetics, drugs, paints and deodorants. From wartime "bug bombs" a $17,000,000 peacetime business has already been developed and this total is expected to reach a $150,000,000 national market.

CHICAGO, April 13 -- The First National Bank of Chicago has topped the Continental-Illinois National Bank and Trust Company in total deposits, the first time in twenty years that the First has outranked the Continental in this department of banking.

Last in the backstretch and sixth as the field of eleven turned for the wire, Peter A. Markey's 4-year-old Piet cut between horses high in the straightaway and went on to a handsomely earned two-length decision in the $17,775 Jamaica Handicap at the home base of the Metropolitan Jockey Club yesterday.

PARIS, April 13 -- To keep neutral Switzerland associated with its executive committee, now composed of the Atlantic pact countries, except for Greece, the European Marshall Plan Council created today the new post of rapporteur for that committee. The committee is the active directing body, under the authority of the Council, of the gradually coordinating recovery efforts of the nineteen Marshall Plan nations and areas.

TULSA, Okla., April 13 -- The city of Tulsa turned itself upside down today in celebration of the world premiere of a motion picture titled "Tulsa," and no one can be blamed in assuming the city was named after the film, instead of vice versa.
Last year 420,143 persons enrolled in the Associated Hospital Service of New York's Blue Cross Plan to bring the total membership to 3,626,321, Louis H. Pink, the president, reported yesterday.

BERLIN, April 13 -- Initial German reaction to the three-power agreement on prohibited and limited industries and the retention totally or in part of 159 industrial plants previously listed for removal as reparations, varies from indignation to grudging gratification.

Once Edward A. Alderman, for a quarter-century president of the University of Virginia, called Thomas Jefferson "a glorious, intelligent radical." He was also "a glorious, inspired amateur" whose versatility still fascinates his biographers on the 206th anniversary of his birth, celebrated yesterday.

In the news again as a potential Broadway prospect is "The Trial," ithe Andre Gide and Jean-Louis Barrault dramatization of the Franz Kafka novel, which for many months has intrigued Joseph Schildkraut as a possible vehicle. If the project takes form, Robert Whitehead and Oliver Rea will be the sponsors.

NANKING, April 13 -- Formal peace negotiations between the Communists and delegates of the Nanking regime opened today in Peiping after an "informal" exchange of views lasting twelve days, the Communist radio said tonight.

Entering second weeks today are "A Connecticut Yankee in King Arthur's Court," at the Radio City Music Hall, and "City Across the River," at the Capitol. . . . "Joan of Arc" begins its twenty-third week today at the Victoria. . . . "The Wandering Jew" starts a sixth week today at the Little Cine Met.
WASHINGTON, April 13 (UP) -- Backers and critics of the House-approved bill to erase Federal taxes on oleomargarine today got in their final words before the Senate Finance Committee.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- In the twelve weeks since Inauguration Day President Truman has replaced most of the top foreign policy officials of his Administration and is now recruiting a new crew of diplomats for the principal United States posts overseas.

Frederick Brown extended his realty activity yesterday to the Chelsea section where he bought the nineteen-story apartment house at the southwest corner of Seventh Avenue and Fifteenth Street from the Eciton Corporation in a transaction negotiated by the Cruikshank Company and the Sonnenblick-Goldman Corporation, brokers.

SEATTLE, Wash., April 13 -- An earthquake more destructive than any previously recorded in the Pacific Northwest shook an area of 150,000 square miles today, causing four deaths, injuries to about fifty persons, and property damage put at many millions of dollars.
WASHINGTON, April 13 (UP) -- American Federation of Labor pressmen and stereotypers today ended their three-day strike which closed the capital's four daily newspapers.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows the following principal charges for the week ended April 6, the Federal Reserve Board reported today:...
CHICAGO, April 13 (AP) -- The American League today conferred with Commissioner Albert B. Chandler on player suits against organized baseball, but results of the discussion were kept secret.

Looking ahead to the Easter menus, we've come to the not too startling conclusion that everything should be as delicious and decorative as possible, but with a minimum of time and trouble in the kitchen. The feminine head of the household usually finds herself putting forth her greatest culinary efforts on a holiday.

I read with interest the editorial appearing in your issue of March 26 referring to the much-needed chapel in the United States Coast Guard Academy at New London. As one very much interested in the welfare of the Coast Guard, I very much appreciate the interest you have shown.
BALTIMORE, April 13 (AP) -- Joe DiMaggio probably will be discharged from Johns Hopkins Hospital tomorrow, but the Yankee centerfielder will continue treatments for his sore heel as an out patient.

LONDON, April 13 -- The British Government has rejected the contention of the Soviet Union that Britain's participation in the North Atlantic treaty runs counter to Article 7 of the Anglo-Soviet treaty of 1942, it was disclosed here today by the Foreign Office.

NEW DELHI, India, April 13 -- Representatives of eleven Asian and Near Eastern nations meeting under the chairmanship of Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru today indicated that these powers would continue to demand implementation of the United Nations Security Council's resolution of Jan. 28 for settlement of the Indonesian problem.

The New York County Executive Committee of the Liberal party formally nominated Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. for Representative in the Twentieth Congressional District at a special meeting at the party headquarters in the Claridge Hotel yesterday afternoon.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- The new official Truman medal, memorializing the President's inauguration on Jan. 20, was issued today and for the first time in history such a medal shows the White House with the balcony that Mr. Truman wanted built.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- For the second time in two weeks the National Labor Relations Board today found an organizer for the International Ladies Garments Workers Union guilty of violating the Taft-Hartley Act by threatening employes.

The peace of Easter and Passover vacation descended last night on the City College campus after three days of a demonstrative student strike against alleged anti-Semitism by a professor and discrimination against Negroes by another faculty member.

LAKE SUCCESS, April 13 -- The United Nations is about to make another effort to ease tense relations between Greece and her northern neighbors, Albania, Yugoslavia and Bulgaria, arising from the Communist-led guerrilla uprising in Greece and frontier rectification issues.

LONDON, April 13 -- The situation in the three-day-old dock strike here was reported easing slightly today after 1,500 members of the Transport and General Workers Union, one of the three principal dock unions, voted to return to work.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- A Labor Department canvass of members of Congress indicates that the Truman Administration's labor relations bill will be approved "without substantial change," Secretary Maurice J. Tobin said today.

Three calls for statements of condition of banks were issued yesterday by various authorities. In Washington, the Comptroller of the Currency announced that all national banks would be required to provide such statements as of April 11, and the Federal Reserve Board made a similar request as of the same date to state banks which are members of the Federal Reserve System.

Eighteen local housing authorities will offer for sale on April 28 issues of temporary-loan notes totaling $25,927,000 to finance projects under the Federal Housing Administration program, it was announced yesterday. The notes will be dated May 24, 1949, and will mature Sept. 2 and Dec. 20, 1949, and May 26, 1950.

LONDON, April 13 -- A first-night audience gave a warm welcome tonight to "Royal Highness," the dramatization of the true story of Princess Louise of Belgium, who was unjustly shut away as a lunatic for five years by her husband.

The state building code bill that was approved by the Legislature and is now before Governor Dewey would create "a uniform performance code" throughout the state that should effect a reduction in building costs of as much as 10 per cent in New York City, State Housing Commissioner Herman T. Stichman said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Early and assured approval of the national low-rent housing bill, authorizing construction of 810,000 Federally subsidized units in the next six years, was forecast tonight as the Senate cleared the decks for debate tomorrow.

TUCSON, Ariz., April 13 -- J. F. (Pop) McKale, who has worn a baseball uniform every summer since 1903, plans to retire as coach of the University of Arizona nine. He said today that he would turn the reins over to assistant Frank Sancet next season.

The General Assembly decided yesterday morning to refer Israel's application for membership in the United Nations to its Political Committee, thus destroying any possibility that Israel could be admitted until the closing weeks of the spring session.
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- A new peace offensive, directed to the Russian people, was demanded today by Senator Ralph E. Flanders before Senate action toward ratifying the North Atlantic treaty.

Even the five lawyers in the Securities Bureau of the State Attorney General's office, who usually consider their job of blocking fabulous fraudulent business deals as routine, were startled yesterday at a multi-million dollar "plan" for the construction of two monumental television "cities."

SALONIKA, Greece, April 13 -- Gregory Stachtopoulos, Greek newspaper man, took the witness stand in his own defense today and testified that George Polk, correspondent for the Columbia Broadcasting System, was killed by a shot in the head in a rowboat on Salonika Bay last May 8.

FRANKFORT, Germany, April 13 -- A United States court in Nuremberg finished reading tonight an 800-page judgment of crimes committed by members of the former German Foreign Office, bringing the record of convictions in the last of the Nuremberg trials to nineteen out of twenty-one defendants.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was active yesterday and final prices were irregular, 16 points higher on May contracts and 8 higher to 5 lower on other months.

In THE TIMES for April 3, Louis Stark outlines some of the issues in what he terms the "knock-down, drag-out fight" in Congress over revision of the Minimum Wage Law. Mr. Stark mentions the opposition to the widened coverage and the increased wage coming from certain groups of employers.

A thirty-five-passenger bus, converted into a home on wheels for a California family of seven, was the unusual vehicle left here yesterday when the group embarked for Europe yesterday on the United States Lines passenger vessel Washington.

Oversimplification may have left the United States with a jet fighter which, instead of being "all things to all men, is nothing to anybody," J. Carlton Ward Jr., chairman of the board of Fairchild Engine and Airplane Corporation, told the Wings Club yesterday.

Two policemen, one perched forty feet above the ground on a clothesline pole and the other standing on two ashcans, engaged in a pistol battle yesterday with two Harlem stick-up men, fatally wounding one while the other escaped.

LEXINGTON, Va., April 13 -- Dr. George F. Zook, chairman of President Truman's Advisory Commission on Higher Education, told top officials of forty-six leading southern colleges and universities here today that institutions practicing racial segregation among students were violating Federal law.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Senate and House conferees agreed tonight on an appropriations authorization totaling $5,430,000,000 to press the European Recovery Program through its second year. The conferees at the same time decided to recommend a contingent liability of $150,000,000 to provide certain guarantees to American investors in private enterprise in participating countries.

A strong bid for the potentially high volume market in children s toiletries will be aided next week with one of Macy's largest single-product promotions, it was learned yesterday. The manufacturer, Columbia Products, Inc., has been licensed by the Borden Company to use its "Elsie" trade family in packaging, display and over-all promotion tie-ins.
A wire received from New Brunswick yesterday states that the Miramichi is clear in some of the best fishing areas, with good catches of spring salmon being taken by the early anglers.

LAKE SUCCESS, April 13 -- The Social Committee of the United Nations General Assembly today rejected a proposal to insert in a proposed convention on news gathering a section that would, in effect, allow governments to suppress material that they deemed false, distorted or likely to provoke war.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- The Maritime Commission announced today the design for a totally new type of cargo vessel planned for mass production in event of war. It is a successor to The Liberty ships of the second World War. Bids for construction of a prototype of this class will be asked within two or three weeks, the commission said.

Helen V. McBride has sold the two-story four-family residence on a plot 25 by 90 feet at 60-30 67th Avenue, in Ridgewood, Queens, to George Buesing, who insured title with the City Title Insurance Company. The property was sold subject to a mortgage of $4,500.

The New York Central System petitioned the Public Service Commission yesterday for higher commutation fares. It proposed a new type of monthly ticket, good Mondays through Fridays, that would increase commuting costs 31 per cent for riders able to use it. An increase of 46 per cent was asked for the unrestricted monthly ticket.
Cyrus S. Ching, director of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service, looked back yesterday over thirty years in the field of Labor relations and found that great progress had been made.

HARTFORD, Conn., April 13 (AP) -- Ted Williams delighted an overflow crowd of 8,444 fans today by belting three home runs for the Boston Red Sox as the American League pennant contenders played a 10-10 tie with the Boston Braves.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 13 -- Twentieth Century-Fox today announced the engagement of Jose Ferret to play opposite Gene Tierney in the screen adaptation of Guy Endore's novel, "Methinks the Lady." Otto Preminger, who will produce and direct the film, closed the deal in New York with Ferrer, whose salary reportedly will be $75,000.

LONG BRANCH, N. J., April 13 -- Raymond P. Kline, one of the last of the "hello boys" of the New Jersey Bell Telephone Company in the Monmouth County area, retired to day after forty-eight years of service.

HOUSTON, Tex., April 13 (AP) -- Catcher Joe Garagiola drew a walk with the bases loaded in the last of the thirteenth inning today to give the St. Louis Cardinals a 3-to-2 decision over the Chicago Cubs.

PARIS, April 13 -- The French Government today gave its approval to Washington's formal proposal to appoint David K. Bruce United States Ambassador to France. The United States Embassy here was so notified after today's Cabinet meeting and it was assumed that President Truman soon would send Mr. Bruce's name to the Senate for confirmation.

Plane-launched guided missiles can intercept a bombing raid on New York or any other American city, which is "within the realm of possibility this very hour," Gen. Joseph T. McNarney, chief of the Air Materiel Command, said here last night.

Following publication of the Occupation Statute granting the Germans limited self-government under Allied control, the Western Powers now announce agreement on a substantial increase in German industrial production. This increase is to be achieved, first, by curtailment of the much-disputed program for dismantling German industrial plants, and, second, by the resumption of production -- under varying restrictions -- in a series of previously prohibited industries.

The one-story taxpayer on a plot about 40 by 55 feet at 2672-74 Gerrittsen Avenue, Brooklyn, occupied by Thomas Roulston, Inc., as a food market, has been sold to the Winson Realty Corporation by John Bottjer, in a transaction negotiated by Louis Lefkowitz and Carl Davis.
Eugene B. Lucas has been named national sales manager of Walco, Inc., East Orange, makers of Walco phonograph needles and Walco tele-vue lenses and other television accessories.

TERRE HAUTE, Ind., April 13 -- Big Johnny Lindell may be elected to carry the centerfield load for the Yankees during the absence of the ailing Joe DiMaggio. This was indicated by Manager Casey Stengel today when the Bombers pounded out a 10-to-4 victory over the Terre Haute Phillies of the Three-I League, a Philadelphia Phillies farm link.

GENEVA, April 13 -- W. Averell Harriman, Ambassador in Europe of the Economic Cooperation Administration, will head the United States delegation to the fourth session of United Nations Economic Commission for Europe, meeting here on May 9.

Fewer and fewer veterans are getting home loans under the GI Bill of Rights, despite a record building program, William V. Brown, loan guarantee officer of the New York regional office of the Veterans Administration, told the fifth annual Long Island mortgage conference, sponsored by the Long Island Real Estate Board, at the Garden City Hotel in Garden City, L. I., yesterday.

Correct handling of layoffs and employment cutbacks are now in the forefront of tests facing management because of disinflation, management and union spokesmen agreed yesterday during the second day of the production conference of the American Management Association in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

TEL AVIV, Israel, April 13 -- Probably never before in Jewish history did the tales of the Hagadah, relating the exodus from Egypt, assume such significance as tonight when they were being read to thousands of Jews who are gathered here from all parts of the Diaspora.

Three days of public hearings before the Board of Estimate on Mayor O'Dwyer's proposed executive budget of $1,179,026,930 produced, as usual, a few constructive ideas and a long procession of witnesses, with most of them favoring larger expenditures. The general impression left is that the budget to be adopted sometime before April 27 will not differ greatly from the original.
David Kapp, vice president in charge of recording, has been elected a director of Decca Records, Inc. He has been with the company since 1935.

PHILADELPHIA, April 13 -- Fires broke out aboard the Pennsylvania Sun, a 17,878-ton oil tanker, and the American Attorney, a 7,607-ton freighter, after they collided head-on today in fog-engulfed Delaware Bay, fifty-five miles south of here.

A television documentary on the Marshall Plan, its purpose to describe the plan's aims as well as the behind-the-scenes forces in Europe which made it necessary, is being readied by ABC-TV for a showing in June.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 13 -- Jim Arbucho pitched and batted Fordham to a 3-2 victory over Yale today as the Elis and Rams renewed a baseball rivalry which has been in existence for fifty-seven years.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., April 13 -- Responding to the urge of going on another of their grand offensives, the Giants tore off ten runs in the second inning today and from there went on to trounce Lou Boudreau's Indians by a score of 16 to 6.

CHICAGO, April 14 -- Frogs exposed to killing doses of radiation are being kept alive indefinitely "on borrowed time" by subjecting them to near freezing temperatures at the Argonne National Laboratory, it was disclosed here today.

Acting on a tip from an undisclosed source, the police of the East 126th Street Station yesterday arrested Paul Curavella, 39 years old, of 411 East 116th Street, as the assailant of an East Harlem tavern owner who had been selling beer at a nickel a glass.
WASHINGTON, April 14 -- An additional program to support milk prices through Government purchase of non-fat dry milk solids was announced today by the Department of Agriculture.

MOSCOW, April 14 -- The newspaper of Soviet youth, Komsomolskaya Pravda, today republished the reply given by the late Maxim Gorky to a United States journalist's question, "Does your country hate America and what does your country think of the civilization of America?"

FREEHOLD, N. J., April 14 -Monmouth County Judge John C. Giordano reserved decision today on a motion by counsel for Frank Hague, Democratic state leader and former Mayor of Jersey City, to set aside a subpoena demanding that the extent of Mr. Hague's wealth be made public.

Two small girls and one little boy, all from distant lands, saw their first American circus yesterday. Their voices were lost in the din set up by thousands of American youngsters in Madison Square Garden. But their joy was not a whit less than that of the young natives.

Although a few of the week-end trout fishermen will be sidetracked by the openings in New Jersey, Connecticut and Pennsylvania, those planning a trip to the Catskill streams have excellent prospects of finding good fishing.
WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP) -President Truman said today he wants Congress to continue the Government's power to control time-payment buying.

WILMINGTON, Del., April 14 -- Stockholders of the Avco Manufacturing Company in their annual meeting here today elected Dr. Robert L. Johnson, president of Temple University, Philadelphia, as a member of the board of directors.

PARIS, April 14 -- The notable rise in value of the French franc in terms of foreign currencies, which experts call a de facto stabilization, is regarded as bringing closer the day when the Government can peg the franc at a single exchange rate instead of the awkward double rate maintained since last October.

With trading holding to the general low level in force all week, share prices in the pre-holiday market yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange moved within a narrow range and closed irregularly lower. A comparatively few issues fluctuated as much as a point.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 14 -Gen. Husni Zayim, Syrian Chief of State, announced in Damascus today that a "constitutional" cabinet would be formed in preparation for a return to democratic government. Fadi el-Attasi, member of the People's party, who was asked to assemble a government, began negotiations late this afternoon.
WASHINGTON, April 14 -- A bill formally to "repeal" the Taft-Hartley Act but to retain its major provisions was introduced today by Representative John S. Wood, Democrat, of Georgia.
ALBANY, April 14 -- The Court of Appeals, in a four-to-two decision, held today that there had been no "systematic and intentional exclusion of Negroes" from the Nassau County grand jury.
A number of developments of considerable potential importance to the future of our defense structure have occured since Louis Johnson took office as Secretary about two-and-a-half weeks ago.

Under some circumstances things of vast importance can be done with a minimum of fanfare. Typical is the creation this week through an exchange of notes with the Government of Canada of the Joint Industrial Mobilization Committee. This carries a step further the process of real integration that was initiated in 1940 with the creation of the Permanent Joint Board on Defense.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- An issue of fundamental importance has arisen between the United States and the Brussels Treaty powers over the distribution of any United States military equipment that may be made available to defend the North Atlantic area.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 14 -- In Yugoslav opinion, two problems remain to be settled before the principal obstacles to normal relations between Yugoslavia and Italy are leveled. They involve Italian claims for compensation of Italian property in the Province of Istria ceded to Yugoslavia after the war, and certain border rectifications. Of the two questions compensations is the more difficult to settle.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- Passage by the Senate of a deficiency appropriation bill of $595,890,000, urgently sought for veterans' aid, prompted tonight a blistering Republican attack on President Truman's fiscal policies.

LAKE SUCCESS. April 14 -The Social Committee of the United Nations General Assembly voted 34 to 4 today to approve provisions in a proposed international convention on news-gathering that would facilitate the "freest possible movement of correspondents."

It is evident that we shall have no lack of great performances of the Beethoven Ninth Symphony this week in New York City. The demonstration when Bruno Walter finished his performance of the work at the Philharmonic-Symphony concert of last night in Carnegie Hall testified to this.

The Carrier Corporation has signed contracts for the installation of Carrier Conduit Weather-master Systems in the forty-story Secretariat Building of the United Nations and the twenty-five-story Mutual Life Insurance Building at 1730-48 Broadway, Cloud Wampler, president, announced yesterday.

President Truman was urged to take immediate action by naming a special committee to survey the problems of dollar shortages and nonconvertible currencies, "which are crippling United States foreign trade," in a resolution adopted last night at a meeting of the Independent Merchant Exporters Association at the Diplomat Hotel.

Jess Larson, War Assets Administrator, testified in Federal Court yesterday that he had put through a deal to sell the Government-owned aluminum reduction plant at Massena, N. Y., to the Aluminum Company of America despite strong opposition from Attorney General Tom Clark.
WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP) -The Administration is seeking a wider market for World Bank bonds.

JERSEY CITY, N. J., Apr 14 -Superior Court Judge William J. Brennan Jr. denied today a motion by Attorney John B. Graf, counsel for the "Freedom Ticket" group of candidates in the municipal commission elections on May 10, to set aside the original drawing for places on the ballot and order a new drawing held.

Net income of the New Jersey Power and Light Company for 1948 was $667,000 compared with $1,135,000 for 1947, according to the annual report, released yesterday. This showed a decline of 41 per cent. A severe sleet storm at the beginning of the year and the expenses incurred as a result were held responsible for the drop.

Antique dealers just back from their annual trips abroad in search of European furniture, silver and porcelain bring discouraging reports to American collectors on the difficulties still existing in finding rare pieces or even the less expensive popular types.

PHILADELPHIA, April 14 (AP) -- The oil tanker Pennsylvania Sun and the freighter American Attorney exchanged warning signals early yesterday morning just before they collided head-on in Delaware Bay, a Coast Guard hearing was told today.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 24 -- RKO today announced the acquisition of two stories, "A White Rose for Julie," by Leo Rosten, and "Terror," by Hugh King.
Mr. and Mrs. Joseph E. Davies are expected to arrive today from their home in Palm Beach, and will be at the Pierre.
WASHINGTON, April 14 -- The Army Certificate of Appreciation was presented today to Arthur Hays Sulzberger, publisher of THE NEW YORK TIMES, for his "outstanding patriotic service" in 1941 and 1942.

BOSTON, April 14 (AP) -- Johnny Pesky's homer with one on in the fifth inning clinched victory for the Boston Red Sox over the Braves in their fifth pre-season exhibition clash today before 6,851 fans at Braves Field. The score was 6 to 2.

FRANKFORT, Germany, April 14 -- A delegation from the parliamentary council in Bonn met with the three Western Military Governors here today to discuss the Occupation Statute and the problems of drafting a Western German constitution.

DUESSELDORF, April 14 -- Incredulity and gratification with which German officials and industrialists of the Ruhr area greeted the list of enterprises exempted from dismantling by the Western agreement was short-lived. By this afternoon it had shifted to gloom over the omission of a group of plants termed the largest and most effective in the field of steel production.

The appointment of Robert Ogden Purves, former manager and vice president of the North Atlantic Area of the American Red Cross, as national director of field organizations of the American Cancer Society was announced yesterday by Mefford R. Runyon, executive vice president. The appointment will be effective May 2.

James Neary, 13 years old, of 2328 Homer Avenue, the Bronx, yesterday interrupted a perfect fishing day to save a man's life. Strolling toward a near-by creek at 11 A. M. the boy passed a station wagon parked in Randall Avenue near Zerega Avenue, the Bronx, in which a man was slumped over the wheel.

Government encroachment on the American way of life is threatening free enterprise and individual activity, Asa S. Knowles, vice president of Cornell University, declared yesterday at the fifty-second annual convention of the Eastern Business Teachers Association meeting at the Hotel New Yorker.

VIRGINIA BEACH, Va., April 14 (AP) -- E. J. (Dutch) Harrison of Lititle Rock, Ark., today fired what he termed one of the finest rounds of his career to set a new competitive course record over the 6,065-yard layout of the Cavalier Yacht and Country Club.
A new heat record for this year was set at 4:25 P. M. yesterday when the temperature was officially recorded as 77.2 degrees.

Prominent competitors in the international tournament being held in connection with the Easter Chess Festival of the Southern Counties Chess Union at Southsea, England, were again successful in the second round yesterday, according to a report from London.

LAST June a curious short story was published in The New Yorker which caused more excitement and produced more admiring, bewildered and indignant letters than any other work of fiction which the magazine had ever published. It was called "The Lottery" and was written by Shirley Jackson, a young woman who had contributed a number of other stories to The New Yorker and to many other magazines.

ALBANY, April 14 -- The Court of Appeals dismissed today an appeal brought by six New York City vocational high school teachers for an order directing the city Board of Education to equalize the hours of service required of teachers in the vocational schools with those required of academic high school teachers.

BUFFALO, N. Y., April 14 -The Playboy Motor Car Corporation, which had reached the pilot model stage in its plans to market a small automobile, filed late today a petition for reorganization under the Federal Bankruptcy Act in United States District Court here.
