It doesn't matter to Carol Stone, who just closed in "They Knew What They Wanted," whether she goes into a musical or a drama. She is versatile in either field. Yesterday it became known that she is willing to take over the leading feminine part from Joan Roberts in the musical hit, "High Button Shoes."

Student strike leaders at City College rejected yesterday the suggestion of the General Faculty that all students return to their classes on Tuesday morning and "use the normal means of communication with Administration and Faculty" in an effort to gain the ends they have been seeking through picketing.
The boys at The Lambs call Jimmy Lane "the luckiest guy on Broadway," and Jimmy Lane himself modestly admits that there may be some truth in it.

DOBBS FERRY, N. Y., April 14 -- Three young men who wore red handkerchiefs as masks, carried pistols and were described in a nine-state police alarm as "very tough," staged a bold $850 afterdinner hold-up tonight at the home here of Francis G. Goldenberg, a retired investment broker.

ALBANY, April 14 -- The Court of Appeals ruled today that Jane Froman, the singing star, could recover no more than $8,291.67, the maximum amount collectible under the Warsaw Convention, for injuries sustained in the crash of the airplane Yankee Clipper Feb. 22, 1943, near Lisbon, Portugal.

Worthington Miner, producer of "Studio One" and "The Goldbergs" for CBS television, is on the verge of branching into the field of children's programs. Starting on Sunday, April 24, Mr. Miner, in association with Norman and Irving Pincus, will produce a fantasy for children, "Mr. I. Magination."
NANKING, Friday, April 15 (UP) -- The Nanking Government has reached a "preliminary understanding" with the Communists on settlement of the civil war, a high official said today.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- As debate on the national low rent housing bill opened in the Senate, the Democratic leadership denounced today a conspiracy to defeat the program by seeking to add an anti-segregation amendment.

Repayments to banks in this area by utilities, food, tobacco, sales finance and oil companies, reduced the total of business borrowings $29,000,000 during the week ended on last Wednesday. According to the data on reporting member banks issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, the reduction was the seventh in as many weeks and brought the total outstanding to $5,293,000,000, the lowest level since Aug. 4, 1948.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -Southpaw or rightpaw, it really won't affect the ball game, but President Truman was being coy today about which it will be when he tosses the horsehide for the opening game between the Senators and the Athletics here on Monday.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange turned strong and active yesterday and final prices were 6 to 19 points net higher.
The Pennsylvania Railroad filed petitions yesterday for a 20 per cent increase in the commutation rates on its New York Division from Trenton, N. J., northward, effective May 15.

Hector McNeil, British Minister of State, strongly implied before the United Nations General Assembly yesterday that the Soviet Union must contemplate acts of aggression or it would not protest the North Atlantic pact.
The police and postal authorities made further inroads yesterday into "one of the biggest rackets in town" when they seized three more men on charges stemming from the theft of parcel post packages.
Thousands of children, adults and veterans will receive Easter gifts through the activities of civic organizations, it was announced yesterday.
A young river of beer flowed into New York from New Jersey yesterday, thoroughly moistening all the city's dry spots, of which there were reported to be plenty.
HICKORY, N. C., April 14 -- The Giants turned on another grand offensive today but this time their efforts drew a backfire that almost blasted them into the next stop.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- The State Department added its denial today to that of the Norwegian Government of reports in Finnish Communist newspapers republished by Pravda in Moscow that a United States transport delegation consisting of military specialists had been in Norway since mid-March studying the territory and ports with the idea of setting up naval and air bases.

BALTIMORE, April 14 (AP) -- Joe DiMaggio's heel bothers him and so do reporters trying to find out how he's coming along, the New York Yankee slugger said angrily today upon leaving Johns Hopkins Hospital.

In observance of Good Friday, major security and commodity exchanges throughout the United States and Canada will be closed today. Banking institutions in most states will be open as usual as will the various livestock markets. The New York Stock and Curb Exchanges and the Chicago Board of Trade will resume operations tomorrow.

The one family residence occupying a plot 103 by 125 at 1338 Parsons Boulevard in Malba Heights, Whitestone, Queens, owned by Kenneth D. McMillan, has been sold to a client of Held, Rawick Schnurr. A purchase money mortgage of $12,000 was executed as part of the transaction, in which title insurance was supplied by the City Title Insurance Company.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., April 14 -- Two big innings enabled Hofstra to down Manhattan, 9 to 6, in a Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference game today. It was the first league triumph for the Flying Dutchmen.
WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP) -The Navy disclosed today that it had flown bombers from an aircraft carrier in the Atlantic to Moffett Field, Calif., spanning the continent.

Devotions of Maundy Thursday were conducted yesterday for Christians throughout the world except in Eastern Orthodox churches, and those of Good Friday will be solemnized today. Eastern Orthodox communions will have these services on corresponding days next week and celebrate Palm Sunday day after tomorrow, their Easter coming on April 24.
CANTON, China, April 14 (UP) -- Kwangtung Province military authorities defied the Nanking Government today and prevented the Central Bank of China from removing a large shipment of silver by plane.

An old Canadian bush flier who now, as an Air Vice Marshal of the Royal Canadian Air Force heads training for air war in the Arctic, said here yesterday that conditions were so difficult that all an enemy could do over that region would be to send "nuisance raids" against the main industrial complex of the North American continent.

A party of New York City officials and newspapermen descended 340 feet underground in Westchester yesterday and inspected a part of a thirteen-mile pumped-out trunk section of the Delaware Aqueduct, "feeder" for part of New York's water supply.

Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation and its voting-controlled subsidiaries had consolidated net earnings of $12,509,265 in the fifty-two weeks ended on Dec. 25, Spyros P. Skouras, president, reported in the annual statement mailed to stockholders yesterday.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., April 14 -- Three men were arrested here early this morning after attacks on striking hotel employes. Later in the day, during a court hearing in which the hotel operators sought a restraint order on picketing, hotel owners and the union agreed to prevent any future outbreaks of violence.

Asserting that capitalism falls short of providing the perfect economic system because it has failed to solve the problem of recurrent depressions, Senator Joseph C. O'Mahoney of Wyoming yesterday called for a national economic convention of representatives of business, labor, agriculture, and consumers to arrive at a formula for aiding stabilization.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- Western Germany is permitted to build dry cargo ships and tankers up to 7,200 gross tons each and with speeds not exceeding twelve knots under the tripartite limited industries agreement signed yesterday by the military governors of the Western occupation zones.
CHICAGO, April 14 (AP) -- An American Medical Association committee today urged steps to make it easier for qualified foreign physicians to practice in the United States.

With messages of congratulation and greeting from President Truman, Pope Pius XII and other dignitaries, America, national Catholic weekly journal of opinion published by the Jesuit Fathers in this city, marks its fortieth anniversary in tomorrow's issue.

The Rosedale community in Queens will have two rival Memorial Day parades unless a row among war veteran organizations is settled peacefully. The first step was taken yesterday toward bringing the issue to the attention of the national commanders of the groups involved.

ROME, April 14 -- Two of the most troublesome obstacles to a trade treaty between Italy and Yugoslavia have been overcome by two agreements just concluded between the two countries. The first was signed in Belgrade yesterday and concerns Italian fishing rights in the Adriatic.
LONDON, April 14 -- Although business could not be described as large in the stock market here today most sections were cheerful and there was a fairly widespread improvement in prices.

There wasn't much to choose among the six starters as they neared the eighth pole in yesterday's main event at Jamaica. And there still wasn't much to choose among three of them -- the three on the outside -- a sixteenth of a mile farther along the trail.
LONDON, April 14 -- The strike of London dockers, which since Monday has virtually tied up the country's busiest port, was called off today.

LANSING, Mich., April 14 -- Michigan officialdom and thousands of citizens paid tribute today to Chase Salmon Osborn as his body lay in state for eight hours in the Capitol, where he had served as Governor in 1911-12.

Men's suit manufacturers would like to see much lower prices as a means of increasing volume, but until and unless costs recede more, prices for fall on maintained qualities cannot be expected to drop more than an average of 3 per cent, Jerome I. Udell, president of Max Udell Sons Co., Inc., manufacturers of Gramercy Park Clothes, said yesterday in the company's "open letter" to customers.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on April 9, 1949, totaled 757,784 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 32,161 cars, or 4.4 per cent, more than for the preceding week, 74,850 cars, or 11.0 per cent, more than for the corresponding week last year, and fifty-five cars, or .01 per cent, fewer than for the corresponding week two years ago.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- A Senate Judiciary subcommittee postponed action today until May 16 at the earliest on a proposed constitutional amendment to change the method of electing the President and Vice-President.

Mrs. Oksana Kasenkina, the former Russian school teacher who found sanctuary in Roosevelt Hospital after her leap from a window of the Soviet consulate last August, presented yesterday to Mayor O'Dwyer the first ticket for a concert to be given by the Doctors' Orchestral Society at Hunter College auditorium next Thursday.

WARSAW, April 14 -- Class warfare in the agricultural sector of Poland's economy will begin in earnest this year, according to plans formulated by Polish agricultural leaders. Poland's Peasant Self-Help Association, which until now has permitted some cooperation with wealthy peasants, has just redrafted its charter along new principles.

BOSTON, April 14 -- Three lay members of the Boston College faculty and a lay teacher at its affiliated Jesuit high school have been dismissed for insisting on teaching "ideas leading to bigotry and intolerance," the Very Rev. William L. Keleher, S. J., president of the college, asserted today.

PHILADELPHIA, April 14 -- Taking a stand on one of psychiatry's most controversial issues, the value of brain operations in mental illness, Dr. Edward A. Strecker, noted psychiatrist, reported today that in examining thousands of patients he had found only eighteen for whom he recommended psycho-surgery.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- The Department of Agriculture announced today that "Nutrient X" in milk, discovered by two Government scientists in 1932, is undoubtedly Vitamin B12, recently isolated in crystalline form from liver extracts and first marketed only six weeks ago.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- The outlook for the projected giant "super-carrier" United States, the keel of which is scheduled to be laid next week at Newport News, Va., was left unsettled by President Truman today.

Hugo Heimann worries about Germany as much today as he did when he helped found the Weimar Republic. Each day he reads every word he can find in many newspapers and he turns on the radio to hear what they say about the country in which he lived for eighty years.

While members of the congregation Shaare Telfiloh were commemorating in their homes the new Passover season Wednesday night, burglars broke into their synagogue at 1679 West First Street in the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn and escaped with $400 in cash taken from a 500-pound safe.

With Charlie Gersten going the distance on the mound, City College's baseball team collected twelve hits off four Fordham hurlers to beat the Rams at the Rose Hill field yesterday, 9 to 2, in a Metropolitan Conference game.

General Electric Company today began a series of meetings with distributors in fifty-two marketing areas to introduce new models in its traffic appliance line. A company official revealed that the new models are toasters, waffle irons and vacuum cleaners but declined to supply any retail prices.
TRENTON, N. J., April 14 (AP) -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll today signed into law a bill authorizing construction of New Jersey's first state toll road.

PITTSBURGH, April 13 (AP) -The Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation declared today that its plants here will have to curtail operations unless Pennsylvania agrees with neighboring states on permissible truck - load weight limits.
WASHINGTON, April 14 -- During the week ended April 13, member bank reserve balances increased $16,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

Fifty-six races were carded for the International Class sloops when their owners held their spring meeting last night in the New York Yacht Club. Again starting the season and closing it, as they have since they were built, they will have a tune-up contest on May 8, carry on through all the Yacht Racing Association regattas, as well as Larchmont and Manhasset Race Weeks, and wind up on Oct. 12.

ALBANY, April 14 -- Brig. Gen. Ames T. Brown, State Adjutant General, said today he had been notified by Maj. Gen. Kenneth F. Cramer, chief of the Army's National Guard Bureau, that the New York National Guard led the nation with a strength of 28,296 on March 31.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- Acting on President Truman's request yesterday for a Columbia Valley Administration, two House Democrats introduced today a bill that would set up the CVA as a Government corporation of three directors and would consolidate the already extensive water projects of the Northwest.

FRANKFORT, Germany, April 14 -- One by one, nineteen former high officials associated with the Nazi Foreign Office were sentenced in Nuremberg today to prison terms varying from four to twenty-five years by a United States tribunal sitting in the last of the Nuremberg war crimes trials.

WASHINGTON, April 14 (UP) -The Civil Aeronautics Administration announced today a billion-dollar national plan under which 4,977 airports would be built or improved to meet current and expected demands for air service.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- Studies by the Civil Aeronautics Administration, made public here today, indicate that installation of navigation aids that would assure regular year-round schedules by the airlines would yield net annual profits to the lines of approximately $30,000,000.
BERLIN, April 14 -- United States Military Government officials admitted today that an attempt to effect land reform in the United States zone had failed.
WASHINGTON, April 14 (UP) -Tighe E. Woods, the rent director, tonight formally gave tenants the right to challenge rent increases ordered by area rent offices.
WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP) -- A Senator's proposal to give $1,500,000,000 to Nationalist China in military and economic aid was opposed today by Secretary of State Dean Acheson.

The last writings of the late physicist, Max Planck, will be issued on Sept. 15 by the Philosophical Library, entitled "Scientific Autobiography." Dr. Planck was the author of several books on science and the originator of the quantum theory which provided one of the basic propositions underlying the splitting of the atom. He received the Nobel Prize in physics in 1919.

A shiver ran through the mountains from Vancouver, B. C., to Portland, Ore., on Wednesday. Farmers and business men in an area that covers 150,000 square miles felt it. In Seattle and Portland office buildings, hotels and homes were evacuated. It was the most destructive earthquake ever recorded in the Pacific Northwest.
Federal income taxpayers who are due for substantial refunds from the Government will have to wait longer for their money than first official announcements indicated, it was found yesterday.

Your editorial of April 5, "East and West," is an excellent contrast between the democratic way of life in the nations of the West in contrast with the way of life in the "Soviet bloc." It is undoubtedly true that our civilization has brought a large measure of liberty and human dignity to the people.

Twenty-two Protestant ministers and theologians issued a statement yesterday declaring that the Atlantic pact means "continuance of the cold war in a divided world" and the likelihood of eventual disaster. The churchmen appealed for greater use by the United States of the United Nations and the exploring of "the possibilities of negotiating peace with the Soviet."

CINCINNATI, April 14 -- The Yankees went down to the ninth inning at Crosley Field today before they could penetrate the left-handed pitching of Ken Raffensberger of the Reds in the closing installment of their spring exhibition tour.

NEWARK, N. J., April 14 -- The central downtown section of this city was without electric power for sixteen minutes today, beginning at 4:19 P. M., after a short-circuit in a sub-station of the Public Service Electric and Gas Company.

The United Nations General Assembly sent a new appeal to the Big Five last night to give up a share of their veto power in the Security Council. By a vote of 43 to 6 the Assembly approved a resolution handed in by the United States, Britain, France and China asking for moderation in the use of the veto and advance consultation among the Big Five before major Council decisions.

FARMINGDALE, L. I., April 14 -- A conference to explore the possibilities of setting up in public schools standard training courses for ground employes of commercial airlines was held at the Long Island Agricultural and Technical Institute here today.

LEXINGTON, Ky., April 14 (AP) -- De Luxe kept Calumet Farm's name in The Kentucky Derby picture today, but Free America, another Calumet racer, was nosed out by Miss Neal in the $10,000 added Phoenix Handicap at Keeneland's opening.
An Ohio grade-school teacher, in New York on an Easter holiday, was seized yesterday after holding up a midtown liquor store to augment his dwindling vacation funds
WASHINGTON, April 14 -- Surgeon General Leonard A. Scheele today announced establishment of the National Institute of Mental Health of the Public Health Service.
Following are excerpts from addresses in the debate yesterday on the North Atlantic treaty in the United Nations General Assembly, given in the order of delivery:

Churches in Germany are reflecting significant growth in membership, influence and interdenominational friendship, Bishop J. W. Ernest Sommer of the Methodist area of Frankfort, reported yesterday in an interview at the Methodist Building, 150 Fifth Avenue.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 14 -The Waterfront Employers' Association appealed today to Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, to assure fulfillment of a contract signed by the W. E. A. and the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, CIO, following last fall's ninety-five-day maritime strike.

Expressing opposition to what he termed the "indefensible and excessive" retirement income plan awarded to J. Carlton Ward Jr., chairman, by directors of the Fairchild Engine and Airplane Corporation, Sherman M. Fairchild, the corporation's founder and a large stockholder, yesterday asked other stockholders for their reaction.

Mayor O'Dwyer described briefly last night how he had sought to modernize the city government. He spoke at the annual meeting of the Citizens Union at the Willkie Memorial Building, 20 West Fortieth Street, before 150 persons.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson, in a Pan American Day address today before the Council of the Organization of American States, expressed the conviction "that the cohesive forces at work for unity and cooperation will prevail in time over the divisive forces working for disruption and disaster."
Following is the text of the veto resolution introduced by the United States, China, Britain and France and approved last night by the United Nations General Assembly.

International Minerals and Metals Corporation and some other custom smelters accepted orders for copper yesterday at 21 1/2 cents, a drop of 1 3/4 cents a pound from prices prevailing since the 1/4-cent cut on March 29. Primary producers made no price announcements.

New York's firemen are accustomed to springing into action when the firebell rings and dashing away to quench the fire. But when the firemen themselves need help, when equipment breaks down en route to a fire, distress calls go to the low, block-long building in Long Island City that houses the departmental repair shops.

The purchase by Roy Foster, ppresident of the A. De Pinna Company, Fifth Avenue outfitters, of the seven-story store and loft building at 9 East Forty-eighth Street, near Fifth Avenue, was announced yesterday. The property is assessed for $160,000 and was bought from the Rubin Brothers Holding Company in a deal negotiated by Brown, Harris, Stevens, Inc., broker.

Rose fever time will be here pretty soon, and after that hay fever, and even now in California, where the climate is more splendid, there is acacia fever, with smarting eyes and running nose. These fevers are the result of allergies, the scientists say, although there is more to an allergy than carrying an extra handkerchief.

SEATTLE, Wash., April 14 -Cities in the Pacific Northwest were returning rapidly to normal business pursuits today following yesterday's earthquake that resulted in eight deaths and caused damage that Gov. Arthur B. Langlie of Washington said might reach $25,000,000.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- The Senate and House put the finishing touches today on a $5,430,000,000 authorization for European recovery in the next fifteen months and sent the measure to the White House for President Truman's signature.

Assistant Chief Inspector John T. Schmitt in command of the uniformed forces in Manhattan West and Inspector James L. Clancy, one of his divisional commanders, applied yesterday for immediate retirement. The men chose to forego thirty-day vacations in their apparent haste to leave the Police Department.

In a move to cut shipping costs, speed deliveries, and give wholesalers larger benefits through quantity orders, General Foods Corporation will build a central warehouse for all of their products in Jersey City this year to service the northeastern area, it was learned here yesterday.

The Atlantic Pact cannot call a hundred divisions into being overnight. That point will be scored and underscored as soon as it is ratified, as undoubtedly it will be, and the debate on its implementation begins. The degree to which the Pact will have "teeth" is properly a matter for discussion in the Senate, since this country will be the chief although by no means the only contributor to whatever armed forces are set up.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- The sharp dispute over allegations of Army waste and inefficiency broke out anew today with a firm restatement of the charges by the Eberstadt committee of the Commission on Organization of the Executive Branch of the Government.

Leg of lamb is about 79 cents a pound today, while the average price for ham is about 65 cents. Chain stores are offering this cut of smoked pork for a few pennies less, one setting the price at 59 cents. A difference of 14 to 20 cents indicates which of these traditional Easter meats will be the choice in most homes this weekend.

Criticizing the president of the Board of Education and the Superintendent of Schools, James Marshall, Manhattan member of the board, has come to the defense of Mayor O'Dwyer in a controversy over whether $17,600,000 in additional state aid should be spent for school buildings or for operational expenses.
HONOLULU, April 14 (UP) -- One man was killed and thirteen injured seriously today in a gun explosion aboard the destroyer Hollister during maneuvers forty-seven miles southwest of Pearl Harbor.

Here and throughout the world the Jewish people sat down last night for the second Passover Seder in celebration, not only of the exodus from Egypt and the deliverance from bondage, but also in praise of the new nation of Israel.

Benjamin Feldman, 41-year-old Brooklyn druggist and former rabbi must stand trial for the third time on a charge of having poisoned his 24-year-old wife, Mrs. Harriet Feldman, in 1943, the State Court of Appeals ruled in Albany yesterday.

The past year has been a busy one for the Seamen's Church Institute of New York at 25 South Street, New York 4, we learn from the annual report of the institute released by its director, the Rev. Dr. Raymond S. Hall. The year 1948, as seafaring men saw it, was one of steadily decreasing jobs in the shipping industry.

CHICAGO, April 14 -- Montgomery Ward Co. today installed eight new vice presidents as new demands were made on Sewell L. Avery, chairman, by stockholders for an explanation of events that led to recent wholesale changes in top executives.

Gerhart Eisler, German Communist out on bail pending appeal on his convictions for contempt of Congress and making false statements on an exit-permit application, appealed unsuccessfully yesterday to the United Nations to intervene so he may return to Germany.

Harvey S. Firestone Jr., chairman of the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company, was elected yesterday president of the United Service Organizations, Inc., at the first meeting of the new board of directors for the recently reactivated agency.

DHAHRAN, Saudi Arabia, April 14 -- The world slump in oil demand has called a halt to the rapid expansion of output by the Arabian-American Oil Company fields here. A decision has been taken to "level off" at the present rate of 500,000 barrels of crude oil daily until or unless a rising demand called for an increase in the future.

Beginning next week, Admiral Corporation will open a concentrated newspaper advertising campaign for its line of seven electric refrigerators with a 1,700-line insertion in some 110 markets, it was announced yesterday. Eighteen national and key local dealer newspaper ads in 1,000, 1,200, 1,500 and 1,700 line sizes will run on a schedule of three insertions weekly every other week until July 1.

Valentin A. Gubitchev, the Soviet engineer under indictment on an espionage charge, insisted again yesterday in Federal court that he had diplomatic immunity and could not be tried here. But Judge Alfred C. Coxe overruled his objections and set May 2 as the trial date.

HARTFORD, Conn., April 14 -- Both houses of the Connecticut General Assembly passed bills today lifting license fees on oleomargarine and permitting its use in state institutions, but the unanimity ended there. The Senate bill removed all color restrictions on oleo now sold only in uncolored form, while the House bill retained the present ban on colored oleo.

ALBANY, April 14 -- Even though, by its terms, it cannot become operative, Governor Dewey approved today a bill by Assemblyman D. Mallory Stephens extending New York's stand-by residential rent control law until July 1, 1950.

ALBANY, April 14 (AP) -- The Public Service Commission today ordered the New York Water Service Corporation and three subsidiaries to stop charging customers on so-called private streets for installation of mains and services.

George Havelka, the 24-year-old Czech who led twenty-two of his countrymen to freedom after the Communist coup in Czechoslovakia, arrived at La Guardia Airport yesterday aboard a Pan American Airways plane from London, accompanied by his wife and 3-year-old doughter Eliska.

Olin Dows has bracketed the Hudson River Valley and its most famous twentieth-century inhabitant in his wash drawings for his new book, "Franklin Roosevelt at Hyde Park," now on view at the Macbeth Gallery. A native of that region, Dows knows the landscape inside and out and captures its romantic quality with delicate and affectionate accuracy.

New York State's oldest school for girls, the Gardner School, founded in 1858, received an award yesterday "for humanitarian endeavor" conferred by one of Italy's oldest industrial families, the Necchi family of Pavia.

Appointment by the Economic Cooperation Administration of Industry Advisory Committees was urged yesterday in a resolution adopted yesterday by the board of directors of the Overseas Automotive Club. If such ECA advisory committees are set up, it was announced by M. R. Sacra of the Black Decker Manufacturing Company, president, at the luncheon of the club at the Shelton Hotel, an automotive committee will be promptly named.
WASHINGTON, April 14 -- President Truman left unconfirmed and undenied today the frequent reports that Kenneth C. Royall, Secretary of the Army, soon would resign.

An antique watch, smaller than a dime, decorated with a delicate floral design, another so intricately enameled that it is protected by an outer case with designs worked in raised silver, along with a watch made for Czar Nicholas II of Russia and another created for Pope Pius IX, will go on display today on the second floor of Cartier's, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-second Street.

DETROIT, April 15 -- The Hudson Motor Car Company, which will observe its fortieth anniversary on Monday, today joined the list of automobile manufacturers who have reduced prices. Hudson announced price reductions ranging from $15 to $100, effective at midnight.

Three new films will open in first-run theatres this morning. At the Roxy, the attraction is "Mr. Belvedere Goes to College," a Twentieth Century-Fox comedy starring Clifton Webb in the title role and Shirley Temple. Elliott Nugent directed and Samuel G. Engel produced from a script by Richard Sale, Mary Loos and Mary McCall Jr., Tom Drake, Alan Young and Jessie Royce Landis are among the principals.
The Monsanto Chemical Company had net earnings of $4,461,608 in the quarter ended on March 31, after deductions for taxes and all charges, Edgar M. Queeny, chairman of the board, reported yesterday.

BERLIN, April 14 -- The German Economic Commission of the Soviet zone moved toward restoration of trade relations with the Western sectors of Berlin today when it announced permission had been granted to enterprises of the Soviet zone and the Soviet sector of the city to establish commercial ties with concerns in the Western sectors of Berlin.
The Monsanto Chemical Company had net earnings of $4,461,608 in the quarter ended on March 31, after deductions for taxes and all charges, Edgar M. Queeny, chairman of the board, reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 14 -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, with two other Republicans, introduced today a national health bill calling for Federal aid to states instead of compulsory insurance.

The new French Line freighter Wyoming, first of four fast cargo ships designed for the company's Pacific Coast-France service, arrived here yesterday on her maiden run. She was built at the de La Loire shipyards, St. Nazaire, France.

On the education page of your edition of April 10 you carried the story of a summer course at the University of San Marcos of Lima, Peru, which will be co-sponsored by Louisiana State University and the International House of New Orleans. Presumably, North American students will be encouraged to study Latin-American subjects at San Marcos.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 14 -- Premier Georgi Dimitrov of Bulgaria was reported tonight to be in the Soviet Union on a "leave" granted by the Bulgarian Communist party and the Council of Ministers.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- The Playboy Motor Corporation, Buffalo, asked the Securities and Exchange Commission today for permission to withdraw a registration statement covering 1,000,000 shares each of the company's Class A and B common stock.

Viola Morris, soprano, and Victoria, Anderson, contralto, known as the English Duo, gave a concert at Town Hall last night. Their program consisted of music from the sixteenth to early eighteenth centuries, sung solo, in duet and with flute solo and duet, as well as with the discreet regular piano accompaniments by George Reeves.

BERLIN, April 14 -- The German Economic Commission of the Soviet zone moved toward restoration of trade relations with the Western sectors of Berlin today when it announced permission had been granted to enterprises of the Soviet zone and the Soviet sector of the city to establish commercial ties with concerns in the Western sectors of Berlin.

Charging the administration of Governor Dewey with having squandered the state's $700,000,000 surplus, Paul E. Fitzpatrick, Democratic State Chairman, declared yesterday that the Governor and his aides must take sole responsibility for a 50 per cent increase in state income taxes.

CHICAGO, April 14 -- Heavy short-covering developed in May wheat on the Board of Trade here today and disclosed a lack of aggressive selling, the close being at the top with a gain of 3 5/8 cents a bushel and at the highest level at which that future had sold since late last January.
HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., April 14 (AP) -- Scoring the initial victory of the meeting for Warren Wright's Calume Farm, Whirl Blast brought a mild surprise in the featured Pan American Purse today.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- The House went off on a ten-day Easter recess today with its Democratic members assigned by leaders to tell constituents back home that the Truman "Fair Deal" program was making strong headway despite "obstructionism and legislative slowdowns" by the Republicans.

Albert H. Bogutz, head of the Newton Elkin Shoe Company, was elected president yesterday of The Guild of Better Shoe Manufacturers. Mr. Bogutz is a director of the National Shoe Manufacturers Association and received a fashion design award from the Philadelphia Art Museum in October, 1947.
The fur will fly in Rome ten days hence when the International Olympic Committee starts paring down the program for the 1952 games at Helsinki, The Associated Press reports.
Worcester Housing Authority, Mass., announced yesterday that it would accept bids until April 21 on an issue of $1,250,000 of temporary loan notes dated April 28, 1939 and due on July 18, 1950.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- Department store sales in the week ended April 9 were 7 per cent above sales in the orresponding week of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The following lists percentage changes from like periods of 1948:
WASHINGTON, April 14 -- By a vote of 3 to 2, the National Labor Relations Board today further outlined the area in the building trades where its jurisdiction operates.

Mr. Truman's plan for a Columbia Valley Administration, embodied in his message of Wednesday and represented in legislation introduced in Congress yesterday, is not as controversial as it looks. Mr. Truman, as he says, is not suggesting an expansion of federal powers or an "encroachment on the rights of states, communities or individuals.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, April 9 -- Strict control over the personnel and content of all daily newspapers, weeklies and monthly and other publications in the Netherlands is sought in a bill now before the States General. It is designed to rid journalism of undesirable elements and what is deemed to be unjust, dishonorable or irresponsible writing.

The Fair Deal Democrats, an organization of young men and women who are opposed to the renomination of Borough President Hugo E. Rogers, leader of Tammany, endorsed yesterday the candidacy of Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. for Representative in the Twentieth Congressional District as "part and parcel" of their fight against the present leadership of Tammany.

Elimination of "price-at-time-of-shipment" terms by steel producers, and some improvements in steel mill inventory practices, were urged yesterday by the steel committee of the National Association of Purchasing Agents, according to the report of Fred G. Syburg, manager of purchases, Chain Belt Company, Milwaukee, Wis.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- The Potomac Electric Power Company, Washington, D. C., filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering $10,000,000 of first mortgage bonds, due on May 1, 1984, and 592,250 shares of $10 par value common stock.

I have just had the opportunity to see a letter which appeared in your esteemed paper on March 31 and which referred to my work in Lebanon as United States delegate to the third session (just concluded) of the United Nations Commission on the Status of Women.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- Prolongation of the deadlock over the chairmanship of the National Security Resources Board was indicated today when President Truman reiterated that he would not withdraw the nomination of his friend, Mon C. Wallgren.

WASHINGTON, April 14 (UP) -Acting in behalf of a coalition of Republicans and Southern Democrats. Representative Wingate H. Lucas, Democrat, of Texas, today introduced a bill to set up a flexible minimum wage geared to the cost of living.
WASHINGTON, April 14 -- That part of the nation's capital occupied by Griffith Stadium became Dodgertown tonight.

Charles B. Jackson, 26-year-old son of Harold P. Jackson of 10 Crestmont Road, Montclair, N. J., chairman of the National Committee for Traffic Safety, was fatally injured on Thursday in an automobile collision near Washington, Ind., according to word received here yesterday.

Retail sales increased during the week, according to estimates made here yesterday. Department store sales were believed to be about 5 per cent above the corresponding week last year. Sales last week were 1 per cent above last year.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 15 -- A red-bearded youth, puffing on a cigar, dropped 243 feet from the Golden Gate Bridge in a parachute today.

JAIPUR, India, April 2 -- With all of more than 500 formerly autonomous principalities now incorporated into the Indian Union, and their Princes reduced from rulers to pensioners, the Indian National Congress, the governing party, is turning its attention to the abolition of the jagirdars, anachronistic vassal lords who still thrive by tens of thousands throughout India.

LINCOLN, Neb., April 15 (AP) --] Haven H. (Ike) Hanscom, assistant freshman coach at the University of Nebraska in 1948, has been named freshfan mentor, head] coach Bill Glassford said today.] [Hanscom form?ly coached at Scottsbluff, Neb: high school.

Far-sighted Italian industrialists, looking to the United States for the latest technological improvements, have gone a step further and are applying in their undertakings both modern production techniques and advanced social-welfare projects.

It seems to me that your editorial writer was in error when he told us in your April 12 issue that the theory that underconsumption was responsible for important economic ills is fallacious. The facts are against him.

MOSCOW, April 15 -- A proposal was advanced today by Moscow geographers for the formal designation of the Antarctic regions whose discovery is generally credited to Russian explorer Fabian von Bellingshausen as "the Russian sector of the Antarctic mainland."

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- House - approved appropriations have reached a level $4,200,000,000 above outlays voted last year, Representative John Taber of New York, ranking Republican Appropriations Committeeman, asserted today as a Republican drive for fund slashes got under way in the Senate.

MORGANTOWN, W, Va., April 15 (U.P.) -- A young farm hand admitted tonight that he was a member of a gang that financed a winter vacation in Florida for themselves and their wives by looting banks and stores.

The pre-Broadway plans of "The Fundamental George," the forthcoming production by Theatre Incorporated and Elliott Nugent, have undergone a bit of a change, it was learned yesterday. Scheduled originally to be introduced on the West Coast before a New York presentation in the fall, the play now will test its wings this summer on the Eastern rustic circuit.

PHILADELPHIA, April 15 (AP) -- The Athletics pushed over a run in the ninth after two were out on successive hits by Taft Wright, Hank Majeski and Sam Chapman to give them a 4-to-3 victory over the Phillies in the first game of the city series today.
A possibility of a break in the five-week tie-up of the Railway Express Agency developed yesterday with the announcement that striking union members would vote today on a back-to-work proposal.

Although CRALOG, the Council of Relief Agencies Licensed for Operation in Germany, 122 East Twenty-second Street, has aided more than 20,000,000 persons in Germany in its three years of relief work there, 13,000,000 refugees there still suffer from hunger and lack of clothing, Arthur S. Joice, executive secretary, said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 15 -- Starting with a plea for compulsory health insurance. President Truman may yet go over Congress' head and take his fight for "fair deal" legislation directly to the people.
LONDON, April 15 -- Another American musical comedy took its place on the London stage last night, apparently to remain for a long, long time.
TORONTO, April 15 (AP) -- The Detroit Red Wings plan to shuffle their line-up tomorrow night in a last, desperate attempt to check the Toronto Maple Leafs' bid for their third successive Stanley Cup.
Four new one-man exhibitions of paintings again demonstrate the well-proved point that modern art speaks no single language.
BALTIMORE, April 15 (AP) -- Joe Di Maggio said today he didn't know when he might be able to get back in a New York Yankee uniform, but "I'm very optimistic."
Howard (Jake) Cann, veteran basketball coach of New York University, said yesterday he was "interested" in the coaching job open at Harvard University, the Unites Press reported.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 15 -- Final negotiations between the Nasser Brothers and the owners of the United Artists Distributing Corporation looking toward a transfer of the company to the Nassers, were in progress today and the prospect of a consummation looks "pretty good," James Nasser, the senior brother of the film-producing-exhibiting family, said late this afternoon.

Easter and warm sunshine put a shuffle into the New York gait yesterday and daubed Times Square with tinges of Main Street. Until gusty showers hit the city in late afternoon a leisurely stroller could have passed most people without jostling.

WASHINGTON, April 15 (UP) -- Lieut.-Gen. Walter Bedell Smith, former United States Ambassador to Moscow, indicated tonight that he believed the odds favored eventual war with Russia unless the Communists changed their tune.

A bill to repeal the Taft-Hartley Law, as such, and to replace it with a modified version, has been introduced in the House by John S. Wood, Democrat, of Georgia. Many of its provisions are those on which Senator Taft and his liberal Republican colleague, Senator Ives of New York, have reached agreement.

Kent Cooper, executive director of The Associated Press, said yesterday that the AP had served 1708 newspapers and 940 radio stations in this country during 1948 with a degree of teamwork "rarely if ever matched."

AKRON, Ohio, April 15 -- Three state highway departments will test a new development in road building in this country within forty-five days, officially under-taking for the first time the laying of road stretches incorporating powdered natural rubber with asphalt.

Windows are wide open again along Sullivan Street and banshee wails float once more over tenement roofs these nights and filter into crowded streets from areaways. Responsible for these hair-raising harmonies are the Italian bagpipes of Rocco Costello.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., April 15 -- While a bright sun greeted Good Friday observers and many guests arriving here today, thel hote strike remained deadlocked and indications were that Atlantic City would experience a major strike over the Easter week-end for the first time.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., April 15 -- Employes at two Allis-Chalmers plants in Springfield, voting today in a National Labor Relations Board election, chose the United Auto Workers, CIO, as the union to represent them as bargaining agent with the company.

Operations of the Caterpillar Tractor Company in the quarter ended on March 31 resulted in a net profit of $4,796,621 after taxes and all charges, according to the report issued yesterday by L. B. Neumiller, president.

For the first time since the war industrial purchasing agents have revived competitive bidding on a wide range of industrial hardware and durable goods requirements. Wholesalers and distributors, anxious to reduce inventories, are offering price concessions.

ROME, April 15 -- In an encyclical published today Pope Pius XII indirectly appealed to the leaders of Catholic nations that are members of the United Nations to ask the Israeli Government for guarantees on the centuries-old rights of the Catholic religion in Palestine.

Starting at 6 A. M. tomorrow, Easter worshipers will be able to follow by radio and television the traditional sunrise services in New York and in other sections of the country. Radio stations will bring in broadcasts from several foreign countries as well.
CHICAGO, April 15 -- "Very promising" gains in the treatment of tuberculosis were reported today at the opening session of the meeting of the American College of Allergists.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., April 15 -- Many people throughout the country are awaiting Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson's action on a bill that would levy $1 fines on persons who permitted their cats to run at large.

A concert by the Columbia Grand Opera Quartet, with Genevieve Rowe, Helen Olheim, William Hain and Arthur Kent as artists, will be given on the evening of May 2 in the ballroom of the Women's National Republican Club at 3 West Fifty-first Street.

Many department stores expect substantial increases in home furnishings dollar volume beginning next week and are counting on beating 1948 sales figures in several minor items, a buying office executive declared yesterday. His organization serves thirty-two department stores all over the country.

CHICAGO, April 15 (AP) -- "The open market for scrap metals has, temporarily at least, ceased to exist," an advertisement signed by the Scrap Iron and Metal Industry of Greater Chicago in Chicago newspapers said today.
A college rowing season of heavy activity through the Poughkeepsie regatta on June 25 gets under way today in the East at Annapolis and Philadelphia.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- An increasing tendency to inject politics into the issue of reciprocal trade agreements, threatening a slowdown in Senate consideration of the question, was stressed today by Senator Walter F. George, Democrat, of Georgia.
WASHINGTON, April 15 (AP) -- A motorists' organization asked the oil industry today to explain higher gasoline prices.

SHANGHAI, April 15 -- Nationalist China's currency appears to have slipped over the precipice and is plunging faster than at any time in the history of the present gold yuan or its predecessor, the Chinese National Currency.

The first trickle of comfort for beer drinkers came early today with the announcement by the CIO Brewery Joint Board that a back-to-work agreement has been signed with the Edelbrew Brewery, Inc., of 1 Bushwick Place, Brooklyn.

NEW DELHI, India, April 15 -- One of India's most important provinces, East Punjab, and Vindhya Pradesh, the union of thirty-five Princely States in central India, have been plunged into political chaos, necessitating action by the Central Government today to maintain orderly administration.

PITTSBURGH, April 5 -- Business in the Pittsburgh district last week increased to its highest level since mid-February with production, shipments and trade all showing increases, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh.

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company, in a preliminary statement for the quarter ended on March 31, estimated yesterday the net income at $53,280,000, equal to $2.26 a share on an average of about 23,541,000 shares outstanding. In the initial three months of last year the net income was $48,281,789, or $2.23 a share, on 21,683,000 shares then outstanding.

Skillful stick-handling and a strong defense enabled the Syracuse lacrosse team to score a 17-6 victory yesterday over City College. A crowd of 500 dwindled as the score mounted on at first a sunlighted, then windswept and finally rain-lashed green at Van Cortlandt Park.

Three maritime unions, affiliated with the Congress of Industrial Organizations and representing more than 50,000 seagoing workers, have served notice of intention to modify existing agreements with the Committee for the Companies and Agents, Atlantic and Gulf Coasts and negotiations are expected to start on Wednesday.

Please print this letter concerning your editorial "The City College Strike" to show the reading public that you now have your facts straight, and that they were wrong and slanted in a smearing direction on April 13.
Continuous throngs of worshipers crowded the city's Christian churches and cathedrals yesterday at the traditional devotions of Good Friday.

Newspaper-test campaigns will begin shortly in ten cities in the vicinity of New York on a new hair preparation, Beer-Bob Hair Set, manufactured by Beer-Bob, Inc., it was announced yesterday. L. H. Hartman Company, Inc., has been appointed to handle the account.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- David E. Finley, director of the National Gallery of Art, has announced that an exhibition of early Italian engravings will open at the gallery on Sunday. The show will close on June 19.
BOLOGNA, Italy, April 15 -- An analysis of developments within the Soviet Union and its satellite states appears to indicate a gradual shift in Moscow's policy toward the new State of Israel.

The news at the City Center last night was the first appearance of Ralph Herbert in the title role of Mozart's "The Marriage of Figaro." It was as pleasing an appearance as one could ask, but it was only one attractive aspect of a highly attractive performance.

HIGHLAND PARK, Ill., April 15 -- Judge Frank H. Myers of Washington, D. C., chairman of the National Interfraternity Conference, today appealed to the convention of the National Association of Deans and Advisers of Men to cooperate with him in remedying what he termed the weaknesses of fraternities.

PATERSON, N. J., April 15 -- Paterson's Board of Public Works today barricaded a part of East Twenty-sixth Street that fronts the entrance to a New Jersey State motor vehicle inspection station and designated it a "play street" despite a warning received from Arthur W. Magee, Motor Vehicle Director, that the action was illegal.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- The Army asked Congress today to allow Maj. Gen. Harry H. Vaughan, Military aide to the President, and eighty-six other present and former Army officers to accept gifts and decorations from foreign governments.

Joe Miceli, East Side welterweight, outpointed Buddy Holderfield of Little Rock, Ark., in the star bout of ten rounds at the St. Nicholas Arena last night. Referee Ruby Goldstein and judges Arthur Aidala and Arthur Susskind cast their votes for Miceli, who scaled 143 pounds to his rival's 143 3/4.

WASHINGTON, April 15 (AP) -- Senator Styles Bridges, Republican, of New Hampshire, today demanded a Congressional investigation of the State Department to find out exactly this country's policy toward China.

The age-old problem of the wrinkled summer dress and the crumpled wardrobe that emerge from the suitcase after a brief trip is fast vanishing in this world of scientific miracles. Due to the vast research and development achieved by chemistry, fabrics -- cottons in particular -- are now being treated successfully, it is claimed, for crease resistance.

PARIS, April 15 -- The names of 104 American sponsors of the Congress of Partisans of Peace, which opens here next Wednesday, were announced today by the organizers meeting, who are largely Communists. [Reuters said the announcement was made by Louis Aragon, a poet and member of the Communist party.]

Three new films will open today at local houses. "The Life of Riley," based on the radio comedy program, will be shown at the Criterion. William Bendix is the man of the title and the supporting cast features James Gleason, Rosemary DeCamp, Bill Goodwin, Beulah Bondi and Meg Randall.

BERLIN, April 15 -- A compromise solution of the present stalemate over the draft constitution for a Western German federal republic is expected as a result of strong feeling within the Social Democratic party against the party executives' opposition to the final draft of that document.

CHICAGO, April 15 -- The Tucker Corporation lacked assembly lines and other facilities for commercial production of automobiles when it went into reorganization on March 3, trustees of the company said today in their first report to Federal Judge Michael L. Igoe.
WASHINGTON, April 15 (AP) -- Representative Olin E. Teague, Democrat, of Texas, today called Congress the "worst offender" in disclosing secret military information.
PARIS, April 15 -- Paris lights went up tonight as France began the observance of the Easter holiday in pre-war style.

LONDON, April 15 -- Good Friday turned out to be the hottest and brightest day of the year in London, and Britons made the most of it. In some places the temperature was the highest for the holy day in fifty years. It reached 74 at Kew Gardens and 76 at Southport.

HACKETTSTOWN, N. J., April 15 -- A bright sun, sparkling water, plenty of hungry trout and an enthusiastic legion of anglers turned out this morning to open the New Jersey trout season -- and on several of the central and northern streams many had limit catches well before noon.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 15 -- Longshoremen of the San Francisco Bay area last year experienced the safest work year in history and those for the West Coast as a whole had their safest period in twenty years, the Waterfront Employers Association announced today.

BARKHAMSTED, Conn., April 15 (AP) -- An airplane crashed and exploded in woods here about 4:30 P. M. today, blasting out a crater twenty-five feet deep and thirty-five feet in diameter. The pilot was killed.

Alumnae of Manhattanville College of the Sacred Heart, the Academy of the Sacred Heart, Maplehurst, in Greenwich, Conn., and the Academies of the Sacred Heart in Noroton, Conn., and at 1 East Ninety-first Street will give a tea dance on May 2 at the pre-opening of the roof of the St. Regis.

WARSAW, April 15 -- Aspiring to carry at least 55 per cent of its foreign trade in Polish bottoms, the Government plans to possess a fleet of 600,000 tons by the end of 1955, shipping authorities said today.
DETROIT, April 15 -- Two wildcat strikes made almost 17,000 men idle today at plants of the Ford Motor Company and the Chrysler Corporation.

JERUSALEM, April 15 -- A long, narrow stream of pious pilgrims trod today the winding cobbled streets of the Old City along the Via Dolorosa to Calvary, where the Prince of Peace was crucified almost 2,000 years ago. This city, still barricaded from modern Jerusalem, opened its gates for a few minutes to allow a few specially selected Christians to enter, but closed them again because the war clouds have not yet cleared.

To accommodate those shopping at the last minute for Easter, Abraham Straus is offering a fine, country-cured ham, prepared according to a century-old formula. Like all old-fashioned hams this one has to be cooked, but its savory goodness makes it well worth that effort.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission was asked today by a committee representing holders of Class A common stock of the Arkansas Natural Gas Corporation, Shreveport, La., a subsidiary of the Cities Service Company, to take action in a dispute involving stockholdings and equity in Arkansas Natural Gas.

Four civic organizations advocating an increase in the Board of Education's operating budget took to task yesterday James Marshall, Manhattan board member, for supporting Mayor O'Dwyer's contention that $17,600,000 in additional state aid should be used for school construction.

I was much interested in the recent letter from your correspondent Will Close, relative to the demoniac skill with which taxi drivers bounce loose manhole covers in the City of New York. I could tell Mr. Close, in the expressive vernacular of our times, that he has not heard anything.
ROME, April 15 (AP) -- Following is an unofficial translation of the Latin text of Pope Pius XII's second encyclical letter on Palestine, which was released today:

March food sales, as reported by many leading food manufacturers, were the greatest in the history of the industry. Credit for this increased volume is given to public acceptance of lower prices, according to the Grocery Manufacturers of America, Inc., association representing the industry.

Impractical, exaggerated car styling, failure to curb countrywide garage and parking problems and increasing hazards created by drunken drivers were emphasized yesterday by the American Automobile Association.

FULLERTON, Calif., April 15 (AP) -- The new flight-endurance champions, Dick Riedel and Bill Barris of this city were more than three-quarters through their goal of 1,000 hours as their little plane droned between Fullerton and Santa Ana tonight.
Charles H. Silver, vice president of the American Woolen Company, has been appointed chairman of the Citizens Committee for the Loyalty Day Parade on April 30, it was announced yesterday.

On the stipulation of millinery industry representatives that an effort will be made to increase density of packages, the Railway Express Agency has agreed to delay filing of increased rate schedules on hats for six months, it was learned yesterday from Sam Finkelstein, executive director of the Millinery Stabilization Commission.

After three rounds of the international masters tournament at the congress of the Southern Counties Chess Union at Southsea, England, yesterday, the three continental experts were in a triple tie for the lead, according to a report from London.
The major league preview in the Bronx yesterday was a howling success -- strictly from a Flatbush standpoint.
STAMFORD, Conn., April 15 -- The traditional New England dual government of town and city in Stamford ended today with the inauguration of officers of a new consolidated government.
Three teen-aged "pirates" surrendered ignominiously yesterday to the United States Army after a brief oral exchange in the Upper Bay off Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, April 15 (UP) -- Federal and Wyoming state and county officials failed today to agree on the future of the Jackson Hole National Monument, and decided that a special legislation measure must be drafted.

Election of Malcolm Monroe and D. D. Richardson as vice presidents of the Monroe Calculating Machine Company of Orange, N. J., were announced yesterday. George A. Staniar was elevated to treasurer and Fred R. Sullivan, to controller.

WASHINGTON, April 15 (AP) -- Federal, state and local governments employed 6,083,000 persons in January, the Census Bureau reported today. The aggregate public payroll for the month was $1,340,400,000.

DHAHRAN, Saudi Arabia, April 15 -- Natural gas burned as waste in the oilfields here is sufficient to produce 800,000 tons annually of high-grade fertilizer at the world's lowest price, virtually wiping out the present world shortage, experts say.

RICHMOND, Va., April 15 -- The Indians and Giants brought their transcontinental exhibition tour to the Atlantic seaboard today but this in no way brought about any alteration in their methods of operation.

Today's events: Philharmonic-Symphony Young People's Concert, Leon Barzin, conductor; Eugenia Hyman, piano; Saul Goodman, percussion, Town Hall, 11 o'clock; "Lucia Di Lammermoor," Metropolitan Opera, 2; Teressa Testa, violin, Brooklyn Museum, 2; Ragtime Concert, Tony Parenti and his Ragpickers, Carl Fischer Hall, 5:30.

PASADENA, Calif., April 15 -- Trying to keep abreast of Percy MacKaye's soaring imagination, the Pasadena Playhouse put on the first of four new plays about the Hamlet legend last evening. Set thirty years before the time of Shakespeare's "Hamlet," it is entitled "The Ghost of Elsinore" and it chronicles the affairs of King Hamlet, Queen Gertrude, Polonius, Claudius and Yorick up to the day of Prince Hamlet's birth.
MIAMI, BEACH, Fla., April 15 (AP) -- Gardnar Mulloy, Miami, today eliminated the last Latin American entry in the men's singles division of the first annual good neighbor tennis tournament.
Thirty ships of the United States Navy, including the gigantic aircraft carrier Franklin D. Roosevelt, slipped into New York yesterday, without ceremony and with little attention from the public.

BERKELEY, Calif., April 15 -- Discovery of the two largest active earthquake faults ever found was reported here today to a sectional meeting of the Geological Society of America by Dr. Hugo Benioff of the California Institute of Technology. The faults' existence had been known but their vast dimensions had not been fully realized.

RAWALPINDI, West Punjab, Pakistan, April 15 (Reuters) -- The United Nations Commission for India and Pakistan today presented both dominions with its proposals for a truce agreement in the state of Jammu and Kashmir.
Easter travel reached its peak late yesterday afternoon, with train, bus and airline terminals reporting the volume generally about the same as Good Friday a year ago.

Easter sunrise services all over the country tomorrow are expected to attract the largest aggregate attendance on record. Throngs of worshipers will assemble in hundreds of communities from coast to coast. One of the earliest established such gatherings will be on the Boston Common.

ARMONK, N. Y., April 15 -- Connecticut dogs dominated the open derby and open puppy stakes that launched the annual pointer and setter trials of the Southern New York Field Trial Club on a three-day run over the Paterno estate today.

LONDON, April 15 (Reuters) -- Portsmouth maintained its three-point margin at the head of the English Football League today, coming from behind to down Birmingham, 3 -- 1, but Newcastle United continued to threaten the leader.

A Navy veteran of three years' service on submarines, his petite wife and five other couples are among this year's class of sixty-four men and women from 18 to 30 years of age who will end in June nine months of religious and social work study at the Salvation Army Officers Training College in the Bronx.

The shortage of physicians and dentists in the Armed Forces continues to be critical. There will be a deficit of 1,600 physicians and 1,160 dentists by the end of July. Unless repaired, this deficit will be increased by 2,000 physicians and 1,400 dentists by December.
TEHERAN, April 15 (AP) -- Tension between the Soviet Union and Iran, never long absent since the end of World War II, has increased in the last three months.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, April 15 (AP) -- Informed sources in Sofia today scoffed at reports from abroad that Premier Dimitrov had retired either as Premier or as secretary general of the Bulgarian Communist party.

The letter of Secretary Acheson to Senator Connally, written on March 15 and now made public, was a precise listing of objections to a specific Senate bill that would have provided $1,500,000,000 of economic and military aid to China. As such it was persuasive and telling at certain points, as, for example, the objection to entailing the revenue of major Chinese ports to repay United States aid.

The Federal Bureau of Investigation announced yesterday the recovery of $6,620 more of the $883,660 Richard H. Crowe took with him on March 25 when he bowed out as assistant manager of the National City Bank branch at 195 Broadway.

The arrival of the new French Line freighter Wyoming on Thursday marked the first step in a program involving the building of at least thirty-three cargo and passenger ships by 1951, according to Guy de Berc, managing director of the company in the United States, Canada and Mexico.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- Average primary market prices declined 0.3 per cent in the week ended on April 12, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The index was 157.6 per cent of the 1926 average, 0.5 per cent lower than four weeks ago and 3.1 per cent less than the comparable week in 1948. All major groups of commodities showed a decline over the week.
Because of a passport mix-up, a Minnesota dairy farmer began the first leg of a long-planned visit to Sweden yesterday with a tugboat journey down the Hudson to Bedloes Island.

The failure of business schools to prepare students for actual jobs was criticized yesterday at the fifty-second annual convention of the Eastern Business Teachers Association meeting at the New Yorker Hotel.

Flowers are traditional with the Easter season. Their appearance in homes is almost as widespread as in places of worship, and thousands of people who never think of wearing flowers on other days of the year take a corsage for granted on Easter Sunday.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, April 15 -- Dr. T. Keith Glennan, president of the Case Institute of Technology, tonight told the third annual conference of the American Foundation for High Blood Pressure that it was time for industry to put more of its resources into improving and protecting its human assets.

Henry A. Wallace, Progressive party leader, accused the State Department yesterday of evasiveness on the applications for visas by three European legislators invited by him to discuss world problems in a nationwide tour starting April 27.

Ted Atkinson, who hadn't been able to make up his mind whether he wanted to ride Greentree's Capot or Greentree's Wine List in the Kentucky Derby, apparently had it made up for him yesterday at Jamaica. For Wine List, 3 to 10 in the betting on the strength of his three-for-three record, was a dog-tired second in his first try at middle-distance running.

CHICAGO, April 15 -- Unchanged prices on men's clothing lines for fall were revealed here today by several leading manufacturers. Values will be greater, but there has been no reduction in costs to justify lower clothing levels, they reported.

SAN JUAN, P. R., April 15 -- The Puerto Rican Senate, ending its annual session early this morning, passed unanimously and without discussion a resolution supplementing the Monroe Doctrine with the "Munoz Doctrine" warning Latin-American nations to keep their hands off Puerto Rico's relations with the United States. The House is expected to take similar action tomorrow.

PHILADELPHIA, April 15 -- There is no evidence that mental illness, either in acute form as psychosis or in the anxiety stage called neurosis, has increased during the past decades, it was asserted today by Dr. Daniel Blain, Medical Director of the American Psychiatric Association.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 15 (AP) -- Tony Lavelli, Yale all-America, decided today to pass up numerous professional basketball offers in favor of a music career.

Always at this season the eyes of a large part of the world are turned toward Jerusalem. The Holy City is the scene of the Easter story, and millions who have never been there visit in imagination these days the place of Golgotha, the Mount of Olives, the Way of Sorrows, the tomb from which the stone was rolled away to signify the triumph of life over death.

New devices for detecting the presence of synthetic drugs in the human body soon will enable New York to strengthen its leadership in the field of forensic medicine, Dr. Thomas A. Gonzales, Chief Medical Examiner of the city, said yesterday.

City College student strike leaders will take their case for open trials for two members of the faculty to State Commissioner of Education Francis Spaulding and the Board of Higher Education on Monday, it was learned yesterday. They charge the two with racial and religious discrimination.

VIENNA, April 15 -- The Hungarian Communist party has been assigned 60 per cent of the legislative candidacies in the common list that is to be presented to the Hungarian people in general elections fixed for May 15, according to advices today from Budapest.
VIRGINIA BEACH, Va., April 15 (AP) -- Frank Stranahan taught nineteen of golf's big-time players a lesson on the links today.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., April 15 (AP) -- The new curlator process for making newsprint may prove a saving to publishers, but manufacturers say there is no chance of the savings reaching the $5.50 a ton mark, as reported erroneously in Associated Press stories March 13 and 14.
LONDON, April 15 (AP) -- In pastoral setting or crowded city, Christians of Europe flocked to the churches of their faith today to commemorate Christ's death upon the cross.

SALONIKA, Greece, April 15 (UP) -- Pro-Government Greeks demonstrated in mass in Salonika today, forcing cancellation of the afternoon session of the trial of Gregory Stachtopoulos and his mother, Mrs. Anna Stachtopoulos, accused in the slaying of George Polk, American correspondent.

PRAGUE, April 15 -- The United States Embassy announced today it had delivered a note to the Czechoslovak Foreign Office voicing objection to the "arbitrary" methods used by Czech authorities in the arrest and detention of Miss Vlasta Vraz, Prague representative of American Relief for Czechoslovakia.

MOSCOW, April 15 -- A journalistic glimpse of the new Moscow, suggesting how its skyline will have been transformed by the erection of eight new high buildings ranging from sixteen stories to thirty-two, was given to the Soviet public today.

We carry in another column on this page a letter from Alfred Baker Lewis taking exception to an editorial of April 12 which dealt with certain historic perversions of the so-called Doctrine of Underconsumption. Our editorial was directed specifically at the argument that government-guaranteed high prices for the farmer would also "help the city people" by providing a market for their products and services.

FORT WORTH, Tex., April 15 (AP) -- Convair's giant XC-99 transport, largest plane in the world, took off from Carswell air base at 4:50 P. M. today with a 100,000-pound weight load -- the heaviest ever lifted by a plane.

Owen Wagner, 28-year-old grade school teacher captured Thursday as he sought to kill himself after allegedly holding up a wine store, was remanded to the City Prison yesterday. He was held in $5,000 bail for a hearing Monday on assault, robbery and Sullivan Law charges when arraigned before Magistrate Morris Rothenberg in Felony Court.

NANKING, April 15 -- Marshal Yen Hsi-shan, warlord ruler of besieged Taiyuan in Shansi province, was reported today to have failed to persuade Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek to place the national treasury at the disposal of Acting President Li Tsung-jen's Government here.
This is the new Army, as pictured yesterday by leaders of its Special Services Division, who should know:

The new nation of Israel should be a powerful influence for the spread of freedom and humanitarianism in the Near East and elsewhere in the world, rabbis said yesterday in sermons on the second day of Passover.

Net sales of Franklin Simon Co., Inc., in the fiscal year ended on Jan. 31, last, increased to $19,806,688 from the previous year's volume of $18,222,410 as a result of new stores, but profits declined, J. Howard Denny, president, reported in the annual statement released for publication today.

Warnings that too-heavy solutions of DDT were likely not only to kill insect pests but also birds, fish, frogs, crabs and other desirable wildlife were uttered yesterday by John H. Baker, president of the National Audubon Society.
BOSTON, April 15 (AP) -- President Ford Frick of the National League today was requested to place Ray Sanders, injured Boston Braves first baseman, on the inactive list, effective on Monday.

New York University's baseball team extended its winning streak to four games yesterday by defeating Syracuse, 5 -- 3, at Ohio Field, the Bronx, in a contest halted by darkness and rain after five innings. The defeat marked the opening of the season for the Orange.

An appraisal of the national debt by the Committee on Public Debt Policy, of which W. Randolph Burgess of the Nations City Bank of New York is chairman, will be published by Harcourt, Brace on Thursday. "Our National Debt: Its History and Its Meaning Today" also presents the committee's program for controlling it with safety.

LONDON, April 15 -- Foreign Secretary Bevin returned to Britain today with the declaration that "the understanding between the United States, Canada and Europe generally is better now than ever it has been." Mr. Bevin, who left here last month to participate in the signing of the Atlantic pact in Washington, arrived at Southampton on the Mauretania.
Bronx police began a wide-scale hunt yesterday for a sex killer after an 8-year-old West Farms school boy was found strangled to death with a small belt.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- The National Labor Relations Board today agreed to hear oral arguments on the legality of the union shop contract between the United Mine Workers of America and the bituminous coal industry.

BERLIN, April 15 -- The State Department and the British Foreign Office received reports in the last month that the Soviet Union was contemplating the restoration of at least part of Lower Silesia to Germany in a major gamble to win Germany for communism.
The House action last week on the largest peacetime military appropriation bill in history was a sad reflection on the processes of democracy as practiced by too many of our Congressmen.

Everybody pays preliminary lip service to the desirability of a uniform building code. When any such code appears on the near-by horizon, however, the unanimity vanishes in a cloud of yes buts. We regret to note that Mayor O'Dwyer, whose ardent support of more and better housing we have frequently commended, has arrayed himself against the state building code bill.

HEMINGWAY, Yeats, E. B. White, Eudora Welty, Thurber, Shakespeare, A. J. Liebling, Blake, Gertrude Stein, Marvell, Donne, Virginia Woolf, Saki, Aldous Huxley, T. S. Eliot, Lord David Cecil, Keats, James Joyce, Irwin Shaw, E. M. Forster, Katherine Anne Porter, William Faulkner and Scott Fitzgerald are gathered together in the enormously hospitable pages of "The Critical Reader"* to make one of the best anthologies that have come this way in a long time.

MANILA, April 4 -- An over-all view of Philippine economic rehabilitation since the war shows the nation to be growing back into its pre-independence patterns and habits of trade, finance and economics. The republic, in its third year of independence, has made progress toward stability. Its trade balance is on the road to equalization, and the Administration says it has a balanced budget. Yet it faces the problem of economic survival after 1951.

CLEVELAND, April 15 (AP) -- In a $725,000 damage suit, Northwest Airlines, Inc., contends that the Glenn L. Martin Company sold Northwest five defective planes, including one in which thirty-six persons were killed.

PRAGUE, April 15 --Evzen Loebl, Czechoslovakia's Deputy Minister of Foreign Trade, departed by air for Washington today at the head of a six-man delegation whose announced purpose is to settle compensation claims of Americans for property nationalized since 1945.
Jersey City is embroiled in the hottest political campaign in twenty years.

LAKE SUCCESS, April 15 -- With the Soviet bloc's first bitter protests in the United Nations against the North Atlantic treaty now out of the way, the General Assembly will resume its committee work here on Monday. No United Nations meetings were held today and tomorrow also will be a holiday.

A partial liquidating distribution was authorized yesterday to North American Company stockholders of 100 per cent of the common stock of the Kansas Power and Light Company, it was announced by Herbert C. Freeman, president of North American.

WASHINGTON, April 15 (AP) -- A sharp reduction in the operating losses of the Government-owned Inland Waterways Corporation, which provides freight service on the Mississippi and Missouri Rivers, was announced by Charles Sawyer, Secretary of Commerce, today.

The green season firmly established, the first refugees from brick houses are flooding into our local oasis, Central Park. Benches are painted, rowboats launched and grass planted as the 600-odd denizens of the menagerie preen themselves for their first large-scale public appearance since the mercury terminated their run last year.
A major medical mystery, unsolved for twenty-seven years, was reopened yesterday during a daylong symposium conducted by the New York Academy of Sciences.

Paul Reynaud, former French Premier, said yesterday that the United States could "create a state of mind favorable to the reconstruction of Europe" by increasing its armed forces "west of the Iron Curtain."

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- The Soviet Union is threatening to invoke a clause of the 1921 Soviet-Iranian treaty that would give Soviet forces the right under certain circumstances to enter Iran's soil, it was learned tonight.

Although it is heartening to vocational counselors to learn that a distinguished body like the American Orthopsychiatric Association devoted part of its recent conference in Chicago to a discussion of "The Determinants of Occupational Choice," we must disagree with some of the statements made by Dr. Eli Ginzberg, as reported in THE NEW YORK TIMES recently.

To combat the dust that comes along with the fresh air when bedroom windows in the ctiy are wide open during warm summer days, there are new bedspreads available that are fresh in appearance and easy to keep that way. Many of them -- those of chenille or seersucker or both -- need no ironing.

Aubrey S. Eban, Israeli representative to the United Nations, charged last night that the very Arab states that had questioned Israel's peace-loving disposition were themselves "guilty of the only recorded instance of a violent war waged against a resolution of the General Assembly."

WASHINGTON, April 15 (AP) -- A new White House of steel, bronze and marble that "would last as long as the Pyramids" was proposed today by Representative Clarence Cannon, Democrat, of Missouri, chairman of the House Appropriations Committee.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, April 15 (AP) -- The Foreign Office said tonight Belgium was postponing taking over some German border territory recently granted to her provisionally by the Western Occupation powers.
