BOSTON, April 15 (AP) -- Financial reorganization of the Waltham Watch Company, which would bring it a loan of $6,000,000 from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation and other benefits, was approved today by the Federal Court. The company's 6,500 creditors and stockholders were allowed until May 9 to file objection or assent.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- The fifty-eighth Continental Congress of the Daughters of the American Revolution will open formally here Monday. Attendance of more than 5,000 members is expected. Mrs. Roscoe C. O'Byrne, president general of the organization, will call the Congress to order.

The inner workings of the Communist party of the United States at the grass-roots level are a mystery to most Americans. Last week some of the mystery was dispelled by the public testimony of Herbert A. Philbrick, a 33-year-old native Bostonian who spent nine years in various Communist organizations as an undercover operator for the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

TRENTON, N. J., April 16 -- The New Jersey primary election Tuesday should be a tame affair. Only a one-sided contest for the Republican nomination for Governor is attracting any state-wide attention. The polls will be open for voters in the 3,707 election districts from 7 A. M. to 8 P. M., but a light vote in both major parties is expected.

IN spite of their temperamental behavior, potted gardenias are grown successfully by home gardeners. To persuade a young plant, loaded with plump buds, to fulfill its promise of beauty and fragrance, adequate humidity and controlled temperatures must be provided.

Card parties combined with fashion shows and teas continue as a popular means of raising funds for various charitable organizations. The annual card party and tea for the benefit of the Social Service Department of St. Bartholomew's Protestant Episcopal Church will be held on April 28 in the Community House of the church, 109 East Fiftieth Street.

The Brazilian Government honored Edward Johnson, general manager of the Metropolitan Opera, yesterday afternoon by making him an officer of the National Order of the Southern Cross. The award was made at the home of J. B. de Berenguer Cesar, Consul General of Brazil, 471 Park Avenue

The City College baseball team yesterday withstood a strong rally to earn a 7-6 decision over Hofstra at Van Cortland Park in the Bronx. It was the third victory in four Metropolitan Baseball Conference games for the Beavers, who gained undisputed possession of second place.

TO the pitifully small volume of serious writing we possess on the art of the motion picture, this second selection of Eisenstein's essays and speeches comes as a welcome addition. Dated between 1928 and 1944, charged with the insistent and graceless energy of the dialectic approach, they are not easily digestible.

A direct clash of medical opinion on the effectiveness of vitamin E in the treatment of a number of difficult medical ailments occurred late yesterday afternoon at the final session of an international conference on the vitamin sponsored by the New York Academy of Sciences.

RUTH COLLIER SHARPE'S elaborate retelling of the Tristram story will disappoint or please, depending on the reader's familiarity with this medieval legend and on the predilection which he may have for a particular version. Many writers, from Malory to E. A. Robinson, have retold the story of the prince who was to have brought back Ysolt of Ireland to become the bride of King Mark of Cornwall and who fell in love with her himself.
Two detectives went out shopping for Easter hats on Broadway yesterday, but after a pistol battle, came back with two men suspected of robbery instead.
SALMON BEACH, Wash., April 16 (AP) -- An earthquake-loosened cliff gave this little colony a breathtaking brush with disaster today.

A YEAR which produces novels by Elizabeth Bowen, Graham Greene, Ivy Compton-Burnett and Henry Green looks, as thinks go now, like a bumper year for the English novel. Add one or two respectable names like Aldous Huxley, Evelyn Waugh and H. E. Bates and the list looks even better; those of us who have been saying that the English novel is dying on its feet will have to think again.

Concern over the possibility of a poor grain crop in Europe this year was expressed by W. Averell Harriman, Marshall Plan Ambassador to Europe, on his arrival from Paris yesterday at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens.

After seven weeks of intensive rehearsing, during which most of the athletes have worked themselves as close to mid-season condition as ever they are likely to attain, another major league baseball campaign will start tomorrow with two cities drawing the honor of beating the gun by a matter of twenty-four hours.

FOR THIS WEEK: Cut dead flowers from bulbs in the garden but leave the green foliage to assure bloom next year. . . . Feed seedling pansies sown last summer with liquid or dried manure. . . . Water seedlings and all kinds of plants thoroughly when they are transplanted. Better yet, choose a cloudy or showery day for this chore. . . .

HOLLYWOOD showed signs last week of coming out of the worst film production depression of the last decade. The long awaited revival of activity at Warner Brothers, where three new pictures went before the cameras, brought the number of feature films in production up to thirty-two, a figure not far short of normal.

MASSILLON, Ohio, April 16 -- The leader of the famed "Coxey's Army" march on Washington in 1894 celebrated his ninety-fifth birthday anniversary today, still convinced his theory of "money at cost" would solve the economic problems of the world.

WRITTEN with broad sympathy, "The Trembling Years" is a frequently moving study of a 17-year-old girl stricken by infantile paralysis, and the physical and psychological adjustment she is forced to make. Kathy Storm, a bright, active girl suddenly deprived of the casual self-reliance of a healthy body, is both resentful and terrified and vents her frustration on those around her.

B-12, the latest vitamin discovered in the B-complex, is the subject of research conducted by Dr. Stefan Ansbacher and Harley L. Hill of the Research Laboratory of Vi-D.-Co., Marion, Ind., and Elizabeth B. Ramsey of the Laboratory of Industrial Hygiene, New York City. B-12, clinically known as APA (anti-pernicious anemia factor), has been used with success in treating human anemias.

In tribute to high-ranking Israeli diplomats, more than 5,000 persons gathered last night at three ballrooms of the Astor and Commodore Hotels at the seventeenth annual Histadrut third Seder, sponsored by the National Committee for Labor Israel.

CHICAGO, April 16 -- A new drug for use in the treatment of allergy, which does not cause marked drowsiness or other toxic effects found in other presently available drugs, was described today by Dr. Stanislaus Jaros of Tuckahoe, N. Y., before the anuual meeting of the American College of Allergists.

The readjustment of industrial production budgets moved into first place in management activities last week as more than 800 executives convened at the annual production conference of the American Management Association at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
I have just concluded arrangements for entertaining myself and family at several hit attractions during Easter Week, on a close schedule, admitting of little variation.

In operation only two months, since the present term opened on Feb. 14, the new Speech for Business course in the Sales Training Unit at the City College Midtown Business Center, 430 West Fiftieth Street, has already achieved some notable results in the correction

THE American dilemma has been described as our inability to live up to the high moral precepts we have enunciated in such political documents as the Bill of Rights, the Constitution, and even the Four Freedoms -- a dilemma documented in "American Dilemma," the monumental work of Gunnar Myrdal.

Last Friday Drs. A. R. Judd and Alfred E. Henderson of the Pennsylvania State Department of Health Sanatorium, Hamburg, Pa., told the American College of Allergy, assembled at Chicago, that with neohetramine, an anti-allergic, they had relieved cases of tuberculous pneumonia and other forms of tuberculosis in which there is coughing and spitting.

With the poise and finesse of Bobby Jones in his prime, 7-year-old Maurice Lehon of 627 East Eleventh Street grasped the shiny soup spoon as he outlined his strategy in moving the pink wooden egg twenty yards on the Great Lawn in Central Park yesterday.

Al Parsells' Ramapo Polo Club and the Squadron A trio rode into the final of the Squadron A spring championship series last night by turning in thrilling victories in the next to last week of competition at the uptown armory.

PLANNED as a basic reference book for school libraries, the Oxford Junior Encyclopaedia attempts to achieve the form of a genuine encyclopedia and the style and vocabulary of a work suitable for young people. The set will consist of twelve volumes, each dealing with a range of related subjects and linked to all other volumes by means of cross-references.
WASHINGTON, April 16 -- St. John's University of Brooklyn spotted Georgetown two runs, then went on to an easy 9-3 victory over the Hoyas today.

DORIS HUMPHREY has received a Guggenheim Fellowship for the purpose of writing a book on choreography "with special reference to sources and methods for the composition of modern dances." This is an important award by which the entire field stands to profit, for Miss Humphrey is an outstanding authority in the little mastered field of dance composition, and a book by her can scarcely fail to establish itself as a source book from the start.
ATLANTA, April 16 (AP) -- The Southern Regional Council listed today fifty crimes of intimidation last year in pointing to a "pattern of violence" in the South.

CLEVELAND, April 16 (AP) -- The General Synod of the Evangelical and Reformed Church will meet here Wednesday to take final action on merger of the denomination with the Congregational Christian Churches.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -Four brewery institutes and their members in Washington, Oregon, California and Idaho have denied Federal Trade Commission charges of conspiracy to fix prices in beer and malt liquor sales. The commission said today that answers to its complaint

OTTAWA, April 16 -- Canada's favorable balance of trade slumped heavily in February with imports up and exports down. Imports from the United States increased by about $12,000,000 for a total of $148,800,000 and a deficit in the trade account of $40,600,000 for the month.

TOKYO, April 16 -- Today this is a country of the unhappy bureaucrat. The Japanese office-holder has most reason for uncertainty and dissatisfaction because the new budget makes virtually certain that the ranks of the Government employes will be thinned by almost 600,000 before the summer.

Negro leaders in the South who have begun a campaign to equalize public school facilities will follow a course of demanding "equal although separate" buildings and equipment, a petition by a citizens' group to the Atlanta Board of Education disclosed yesterday.

RICHMOND, Va., April 16 -- The eyes of people of the Upper South were fastened this week on politics, spring plowing and the baseball season. But a feeling was growing that was best summed up by a familiar question: "Where do we go from here?"

ALTHOUGH executives of the networks involved were unwilling to discuss the matter last week, the ring for the summer bout between NBC and CBS for Sunday night radio listeners quietly was being cleared for action. Specifically, both networks were thinking in terms of plans for that all-important 7 P. M. period, traditionally the crucial hour for gathering Sabbath Day listeners.

WHAT can happen when television allows visual considerations to take precedence over news values is vividly illustrated by the NBC "News Caravan," presented at 7:45 P. M. Monday through Friday. The result is more akin to a newsreel show than to a program which enables the viewer to keep abreast of the day's news.

PECONIC, L. I., April 16 -- The Eastern Suffolk Cooperative, Long Island's largest farm employers organization, has voted to hire 200 to 250 Poles from displaced persons camps in Europe to help with potato and vegetable harvests in this area.
CHICAGO, April 16 (UP) -- The American League may get two "breaks of the game" this coming season which could mean as great a year as the league enjoyed in 1948.

More than seventy-five detectives joined Bronx police yesterday in criss-crossing the West Farms section for the sex slayer of 8-year-old Jackie Goldsmith, who was found strangled at noon Friday in an abandoned tunnel at East 177th Street and West Farms Road.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 16 -The Coast this week turned its attention to seismology, as an earthquake, the most severe on record in the Pacific Northwest, shook Oregon, Washington, and British Columbia.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, April 16 -- As Arthur Creech Jones, British Colonial Secretary, ends his exploratory tour of Central Africa, reports from Southern and Northern Rhodesia and Nyasaland agree it has probably brought realization of "Capricorn Africa" one step nearer.

NEW DELHI, April 16 -- Admiral Chester W. Nimitz's immediate appearance as administrator of the plebiscite to determine whether the princely state of Jammu and Kashmir -- about the size of Minnesota -- should join India or Pakistan struck a snag last night.

The sale of a $1,000.000 block of Chrysler stock for cash featured trading in yesterday's market in the New York Stock Exchange. Amounting to 19.882 shares at 50 1/4, it was the largest single cash transaction on the floor of the Exchange in three years.

Yesterday was the final day of the Metropolitan Opera's post-season week. The matinee performance was Donizetti's "Lucia Di Lammermoor," heard for the ninth time this season and the second time this week. It was the company's second - most performed opera, receiving one less hearing than 'La Boheme."

IF New York seems pleasantly relaxed and languid again, it is doubtless because "South Pacific" has opened successfully and has settled down to the quiet luxury of a long run. There is nothing more for any New Yorker to worry about now.

LOS ANGELES, April 16 -Precautions to prevent a repetition of the Kathy Fiscus tragedy occupied California this week. Governmental agencies, private organizations and individuals hurriedly launched surveys to locate other abandoned water wells, as well as equally hazardous open oil wells, oil waste pits and miscellaneous unguarded excavations.

ORANGE, N. J., April 16 -- James J. Savage, who was a contender for the world's heavyweight boxing championship around the turn of the century, died here today of a heart attack at his home, 226 Snyder Street. He was 66 years old.

ANNECY, France, April 16 -- For the second time since World War II the major trading nations of the world led by the United States and Great Britain -- with the Soviet Union conspicuously absent -- gathered this week to tackle one of the most durable problems of Western civilization.

FRANKFORT, Germany, April 10 -- Talk of a new Rapallo is heard everywhere these days in Military Government and German circles. This is a reference to the Treaty of Rapallo of April, 1922, when Germany made a surprise agreement with Russia.
OMAHA, April 16 -- Farm country Congressmen returning home for their Easter recess will learn whether their rural constituents regard the Brannan farm subsidy plan as:

The thanks of all thinking Americans should go to you for publishing Raymond Fosdick's magnificent warning, "We Must Not Be Afraid of Change." This is the kind of statement we have been needing, the protest against current fears of a native who knows in his bones and his brain just what is that magic compound of concept and experience on which our life in this land is based.

PLAINLY, the most helpful service which this writer can perform, on this particular Sunday, is to act as a capsule counselor -- or just an old-fashioned family physician -- to those who would movie-go this week. And, in view of the week's distinction, we presume the number will be large.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- The Women's National Press Club announced today that its "Woman of the Year" award would go to Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt for her work in 1948 as chairman of the United Nations Human Rights Commission. President Harry S. Truman will present this award at the club's annual dinner and stunt party on May 14. Five other women were named who will also receive awards in as many different fields.

Thirty-three seasons of trouping under the Big Top have given Felix Adler no blase or cynical reaction to circus life. Enthusiasm still runs at fever pitch for this 51-year-old dean of clowns of Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey Circus.

PHILADELPHIA, April 16 -- Successful experiments in the detection of brain tumors with a combination of cancer-retarding dyes and radioactive isotopes of iodine were announced tonight by the Cancer Commission of the University of Pennsylvania.

WHEN I received the first volume of Bela Bartok's published letters (Hungarian Arts Council, Budapest, 1948, edited by Dr. Janos Demeny) chance would have it that almost the first page that caught my eye -- on excitedly thumbing through the volume -- was this excerpt from a letter to his mother dated Dec. 30, 1930: "The success in London was, it is true, rather big, but just a little belated -- by some twenty-four years."

WHEN Joseph Bolivar DeLee died, in April, 1942, at the age of 72, recognized by many as the world's leading obstetrician and teacher of obstetrics, he left a number of tangible monuments. His authoritative textbook, "Principles and Practices in Obstetrics," had become the "bible" for students and practitioners all over the world.

KILLINGWORTH, Conn., April 16 -- The Connecticut trout fishermen were just a day late for the right weather to open their season, but despite the rain during the early hours and the wind that made casting difficult, there were some excellent catches on the smaller streams.
BOSTON, April 16 (AP) -- Six Ronan Catholic churches in the Boston area were picketed yesterday in protest against the discharge of three Boston College instructors who accused the college of heresy.
My Request, the reddish 4-year-old colt owned by Ben F. Whitaker of Dallas, did a handsome job in the $23,950 Excelsior Handicap at chilly Jamaica yesterday.

In the last shopping days before Easter retailers here last week intensified promotions of women's suits, flower trimmed straw hats, nylon blouses, gloves and calf handbags, according to a survey made especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by the Retail News Bureau, Inc.

Reflecting the changeover to harder selling, the use of premium promotions is entering a period of new record highs, it was declared here last week by Howard W. Dunk, head of the New York Premium Club. The dollar value of premium merchandise this year

ONE of the most persistent matters to plague producers and buyers of recorded music is that swishing sound called surface noise. Two developments have helped to reduce it: the use of vinyl plastics, of which disks can be made smoother than with shellac, and the more recently popularized use of reduced turning speeds. Both still have room for improvement.
YOUR critic's report on "The Traitor" gave me such a jolt of displeasure that I am doing something I have never done before. I am writing a letter of protest to an editor.
THE many varieties of narcissus now in bloom suggest new ideas for next season's garden. In making notes on possible additions for fall planting, the Irish daffodils well deserve consideration.

Many of the jobs which interest young people -- such as airplane pilot, newspaper reporter, radio announcer and agent for the Federal Bureau of Investigations -- will be relatively hard to find during the next several years. But the vocational outlook will be brighter in many other occupations, including physician, teacher, librarian, stenographer and automobile mechanic.
SALT LAKE CITY, Utah, April 16 -Congressional proposals calling for admission charges to the region's national forests held the Western spotlight this week.

READING, said Lord Bacon, maketh a full man. It is an observation quite applicable to Reinhold Niebuhr of the Union Theological Seminary. His latest volume, derived from lectures, is filled to overflowing with the surge of ideas sweeping over this most prolific of all periods of cultural transition.

A new two-and-one-half-ton, six-wheel military truck has been built by the Studebaker Corporation in response to a request by the Federal Government. The corporation announced yesterday that the vehicle was built at company expense for demonstration to the Army ordnance department. It is described as combining ruggedness and power with serviceability and ease of maintenance.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 16 -Undefeated New York University, behind the effective pitching of Tom Casey, gained its fifth baseball victory at Yale Field today 9 -- 3.

The hard-worked typewriter has become a vital mechanical cog in the machinery of New York's far-flung government. Their importance is recognized at city store-house B53, New Dock and Water Streets, Brooklyn, in the shadow of the Brooklyn Bridge.
WASHINGTON, April 16 (AP) -- The Bureau of Agricultural Economics predicted today further declines in industrial production, prices and consumer incomes. But it said no serious recession was in view.

SAN JUAN, April 16 (By Religious News Service) -- Samuel Cardinal Stritch, Archbishop of Chicago, is scheduled to arrive here tomorrow for a three-day visit during which he will dedicate new buildings at the St. Ildefonso Seminary in Aibonito, between San Juan and Ponce.

ATHENS, April 16 -- Aristides Poulanzas, a graphologist on the staff of the Athens Police School, testified in court here today that Mrs. Anna Stachtopoulos wrote the address on the envelope containing the identification cards of George Polk, American correspondent, which was received by the Salonika police by mail six days before the body of Mr. Polk was found in Salonika Bay last May 16.
ALBANY, Calif., April 16 (AP) -- Charging ahead in the stretch, Dinner Gong, the favorite, won the $15,000 added Golden Gate Mile at Golden Gate Fields today by one length in 1:36.

WASHINGTON, April 16 (UP) -- A surplus of pork and milk may cause President Truman to ask Congress for hurry-up authority to make direct subsidy payments to farmers, Secretary of Agriculture Charles F. Brannan said today.

ATLANTA, Ga., April 16 -Georgia's school-fund crisis was in the spotlight this week as the state's political leaders were criticized for their refusal to shoulder the responsibility for raising the funds needed to improve educational facilities and to increase teachers' pay.

More than twice as many public housing units were started in New York in the first quarter of 1949 as were initiated by private builders in the same period according to figures compiled by the regional office of the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics.

A self-conducted tour of the Lesser Antilles, down at the "waistline" of the Western Hemisphere, offers plenty of interesting possibilities to the traveler who is looking for out-of-the-ordinary adventure.

New pyrethrum-like chemicals that kill insects have been made synthetically for the first time in the laboratories of the Bureau of Entomology and Plant Quarantine. This remarkable development is the culmination of intensive studies carried on during the past fifteen years by bureau chemist F. B. La Forge and his associates.

CHICAGO, April 16 (AP) -- May wheat failed to hold a gain of around 2 cents a bushel on the Board of Trade today. Late in the session selling in this contract increased, following reports that a fair amount of cash wheat was moving out of the Northwest into the Minneapolis market.

CHICAGO, April 16 (AP) -- Rookie Gus Zernial's three-run homer and air-tight pitching by Howie Judson and Allen Gettel paced the Chicago White Sox to a 3-1 victory over the Chicago Cubs today. A chilly turnout of 7,131 saw the Comiskey Park game.

MAKE it coral this Saturday for the thirty-fifth anniversary of Carnegie Tech's Drama Department. For Shakespeare's 385th birthday also marks the premiere that lighted in Pittsburgh the nation's first college branch of theatre arts.
Arthur Miller, author of the hit play, "Death of a Salesman," received the 1949 award of the New York Drama Critics Circle at the close of yesterday's matinee performance at the Morosco Theatre.

Financial markets were practically at a standstill last week as a result of the approaching Easter holidays. On the New York Stock Exchange, where trading was suspended on Good Friday, prices moved narrowly and irregularly in slower trading.

GERTRUDE CRAMPTON'S Pottlebys are direct descendants of Lucretia Hale's Peterkin family. Like the Peterkins, the Pottlebys are a numerous but devoted family, continually involved in foolish enterprises (whose folly it tickles young readers to perceive).

The Administration is endeavoring to meet the deficit in the budget of the Post Office Department by once again raising the rates of postage on everything except first-class mail, i. e., letters and sealed matter.

DETROIT, April 16 -- Comparative studies at the University of Chicago of the blood serum of cancer patients and normal and other noncancerous individuals have revealed significant differences that constitute "what is for all practical purposes a simple, cheap and reasonably sure blood test for cancer," it was reported here tonight at the annual meeting of the American Association for Cancer Research.

MR. PORTERFIELD'S letter on the origin of the word "ideology" is interesting. And it is true that as now generally used it is fairly equivalent to the German "Weltanschauung" -- a way of looking at human affairs that follows a particular pattern preferred by a particular group of the human race.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- The Congress of the United States tends to pass laws very much as the late President Franklin D. Roosevelt used to mix martini cocktails -- all scientific at the beginning and slap-dash at the end.

Just as sound is a vibration of the air, so an earthquake is a vibration of the earth's crust. Such a crustal vibration occurred in the Pacific Northwest last week. It was felt over an area of 150,000 square miles.

IT is quite likely the history books will prove that 1948 really was one of the decisive years of modern times, one of those years in which the allegiance of millions of Europeans began to move irrevocably in a slow flooding almost imperceptible at the time.

The brief visit of the Syracuse baseball team to the metropolitan district ended with a 6-5 victory over Fordham yesterday at the losers' field in the Bronx as the upstaters scored two runs in the ninth. Beaten by New York University in their opening game on Friday, the wearers of the Orange were off to a three-run spurt in the initial inning and added one in the fourth.

ON Thursday the League of New York Theatres will hear that its proposed compromise plan for the promotion of the theatre on a national scale is unacceptable to the press agents' union and that, as of the moment, the whole idea seems irretrievably snagged.

Placing an order for $15,000,000 worth of new looms to be delivered over a period of eleven years, the Springs Cotton Mills last week indicated its intention of maintaining full production in the face of general curtailment in the cotton textile industry.

ARMONK, N. Y., April 16 -- A pointer and a setter belonging to Edward de Neyer of Longmeadow, Mass., placed one-two in the open all-age stake at the twenty-second annual trials of the Southern New York Field Trial Club this bitter day on the Paterno estate.

DALLAS, April 16 -- Department store sales in the Eleventh Federal Reserve District fell below sales for the corresponding week of last year despite merchants' earlier predictions that Easter sales volume likely would push the week's sales above 1948.

MERRICK, L. I., April 16 -- Balked by family objections in his desire to marry a 21-year-old Merrick girl, a young aircraft worker killed the girl's father with a shotgun blast here at 2:30 o'clock this morning. He then held off twenty police from a barricaded second-story bathroom for one hour before he surrendered.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- Iran is expected to revive her resolution of 1946 before the United Nations Security Council for the world organization to take action if the Soviet Union goes to unwarranted lengths in its present threat to enter Iranian territory

PHILADELPHIA, April 16 -Pennsylvania opened its 1949 rowing season today by making a clean sweep in the triangular regatta with Rutgers and Washington and Lee over a wind-swept course on the Schuylkill River.
PRINCETON, N. J., April 16 -- In its first Eastern Intercollegiate League game of the campaign, the Princeton baseball team today was toppled by Navy, 6 -- 5.

PROPER care of grape vines is a fairly simple matter. A small sprayer does an adequate job of pest control, pruning is not difficult and the crop is easy to harvest. Probably the two most important chores are severe pruning, which should be done in late winter, and control of black rot.

The Young People's Concerts Committee of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony presented the last of its concerts of the season yesterday morning at Town Hall. Leon Barzin, who conducted, described it as "a little concert for little people," for it was one of the two events in the elementary series designed for children between 6 and 9.

WASHINGTON, April 16 (AP) -- Senator Styles Bridges, Republican, of New Hampshire, proposed today that Marshall Plan aides be summoned from Europe to tell Congress how it could save money on foreign aid.

BOSTON, April 16 (AP) -- Homers by Tom O'Brien and Junior Stephens, the former's with a mate aboard, helped the Red Sox defeat the Braves, 5 -- 2, before a chilled crowd of 17,246 at Fenway Park today.

Mayor O'Dwyer will welcome Vice President Alben W. Barkley to the city at the dinner of the Democratic State Committee at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel Thursday evening, at which he will be the principal speaker.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- Hugh D. Scott Jr., Republican national chairman, accused President Truman and his Congressional lieutenants today of trying to conceal "the total bankruptcy of Democrat leadership'' by accusing Republicans of impeding "Fair Deal" legislation.

This city has 700,000 men and women who have not gone beyond the sixth grade of elementary school and who are handicapped by a lack of adult education facilities, Dr. Harry J. Carman, president of the New York Adult Education Council, declared yesterday.

The board of trustees of the National Physicians Committee, lobbying organization officially endorsed by the American Medical Association, has voted to cease all activities as of April 1 and liquidate the affairs of the committee during this year, according to an announcement received here yesterday.

THIS volume is chiefly concerned with eight lakes -- Donner, Cold, Honey, Pyramid: Mono, Webber, Meadow and Tahoe. Although none of these is in the High Sierra, and one of them is not even within sight of the range, all receive their water from melting Sierra snow. The authors, who have long been associated with the area, admit that a more accurate title would have been, "Lakes of the Northern Sierra and Western Great Basin."
YOUR reviewer Francis Steegmuller concludes his review of "The Journals of Andre Gide" in the April 3 issue with several questions which I cannot resist answering.
LIBERTY, Mo., April 16 (AP) -- The Missouri River was shortened by 4.7 miles today.

DOVER, Del., April 16 (AP) -- A twice-married woman and her 16-year-old son were charged with first-degree murder today in the slaying of an elderly Virginian whom the woman met through a "lonely hearts" club.

LAKE SUCCESS, April 16 -- Although United Nations delegates are agreed that the former Italian colonies in Africa are for the present economic liabilities, their importance in terms of prestige and military strategy has confronted the General Assembly with one of its most perplexing problems.

IN the era of open range and jumped claims dear to professional admirers of the Old West, editorialists as outspoken as the authors of this searching volume might have ended useful careers upon tarred rails or snow-sprinkled foothills.
Six results were recorded in the fourth round of the international masters tournament at Southsea, England, yesterday, according to a report from London.

A few weeks ago, by a vote of 208-207, the House of Representatives defeated a proposal that the Federal Government pay pensions of $90 a month to all veterans of World War I or II upon reaching the age of 65, and of $120 a month to any veteran of World War I or II who, on account of age, physical or mental disability or blindness, required the aid and attendance of another person.

The bizarre wiretapping plot against city officials took another mysterious turn yesterday with the arrest of a fourth investigator on a charge of conspiring with others to tap a telephone line illegally.

Utility executives are thinking seriously about "grass roots" financing not unlike the local stock-selling drives of the Twenties. Two factors are largely responsible for this. First, the Government's double tax on dividends; second, restrictive state regulations governing the types of securities that institutions may purchase.

Not everyone can visit England's famous Lake District now that April's there, but a visit to New York City's own Lake District is not much trouble. Instead of going over to a Hudson River pier and boarding the Queen Mary, the traveler goes to Grand Central and takes the Golden's Bridge train to Katonah, forty miles north.

Uneconomic industrialization projects in Latin-American countries, developed during wartime prosperity and a sellers' market, will have to stand the test of a return to more normal conditions and a buyers' market in order to survive, F. J. Emmerich, executive vice president of Block International, said here yesterday.

BEFORE the war you could mail books anywhere in the country for 1 1/2 cents a pound. This rate represented a principle at least as old as Postmaster General Ben Franklin -- that government should encourage the distribution of newspapers, magazines and other "information of a public character."

Manufacturing companies will hire fewer college graduates to fill responsible engineering and potential executive vacancies this June than they did in 1948, personnel executives in charge of college recruitment for two large corporations disclosed last week.

EIGHT months have brought about a big change in the life of Joan Eunson, who will have fifteen candles on her birthday cake come July 18. Last Labor Day she was giving some thought to comparing vacation experiences with classmates at the Birch-Wathen School in West Ninety-third Street.
The Railway Express Agency will resume full, normal operations in the metropolitan area at midnight tonight after a five-week tie-up, it was announced yesterday.

VIRGINIA BEACH, Va., April 16 -- A putting star who admitted his game had not been up to par of late, and one of golf's greatest players put on a brilliant exhibition here today to lead Captain Bob Hamilton's four-man team to victory in the feature attraction of the $10,000 Cavalier Specialists tournament.

Warships in the Hudson produced a picnic atmosphere along the waterfront yesterday. Thousands of persons, including many children, stood in line to visit the Navy's carriers, escort carriers and destroyers moored at piers from Beach Street to West Fiftieth Street.
WASHINGTON, April 16 (UP) -- John L. Lewis' United Mine Workers today refused to confirm or deny a report that it had entered the banking business.

HARTFORD, Conn., April 16 (AP) -Cooley Co., a local stock brokerage house, sixty years old, has a recipe for making friends and influencing people -- customers -- and reports success. It concluded that the best way to bring in customers was to go after them and explain stocks to them.

" FAVORITE book lists" at least stir stimulating debate. With Francis Steegmuller's list of seven favorite mystery novelists and twelve books (April 3 issue) I vigorously dissent. I agree only on: "Dashiell Hammett, "The Maltese Falcon" (my 2d, "The Dain Curse") and Eric Ambler, "A Coffin for Demetrios."

One of the first major television centers in the country will rise on the old Twenty-second Regiment Armory site comprising the entire block bounded by Broadway and Columbus Avenue, Sixty-seventh and Sixty-eighth Streets, it became known last night.

Yesterday's athletic champions are today's scholars -- at least at Columbia's Teachers College. Seven former athletic stars, including Paul Governali, former All-American left half-back for Columbia, explained last week why they are doing graduate work leading to the Doctor of Education degree.
LONDON, April 16 -- Just as it was making preliminary plans to seek another five years in office, the British Labor party received a shock at the polls last week.

HALLANDALE, Fla., April 16 (AP) -- G. C. Hunt's Blue Holly, a 13-to-1 shot, breezed to a two-length victory in Gulfstream Park's $5,000 Hallandale Purse today. Top-weighted Mangohick, owned by Christopher T. Chenery, was second, six lengths in front of M. Shagrin's Speedy Lee.
WASHINGTON, April 16 -- Below the surface of events, Congress is graphing for political advantage over the largely immobilized bulk of President Truman's legislative program.
Victorious in all of his eight bouts in the final round, Dr. Tibor Nyilas of Salle Santelli retained the metropolitan open saber championship yesterday at the Fencers Club.

BECAUSE of the state's eccentric geography and meteorology and its interesting proportion of don't-give-a-cuss inhabitants, there is scarcely such a thing as a bad book about Maine. Writers about Maine do pretty well for themselves and help to keep many a publisher out of liquidation and in Madison Avenue offices and Fairfield County (Conn.) homes. But they should form a mutual protective association against the Gould boys -- R. E. and Nephew John.

PARENTS who are thinking of starting a cooperative nursery group should go to see several good nursery schools, read up on the education of young children, and then, working with a qualified teacher interested in the cooperative idea, make plans to fit their own community.

The lines of controversy on the question of a Federal health program became clear last week. The issue arises from one of the cardinal proposals in President Truman's "fair deal" -- and it is likely to bring about a bitter battle in the Eighty-first Congress.

LONDON, April 16 (Reuters) -- Portsmouth, unbeaten at home this season, increased its lead to four points in the English soccer league today with a 5-0 decision over the Wolverhampton Wanderers as second-place Newcastle United tied with Bolton, 1 -- 1.

A springtime fete that has drawn a large advance subscription is the Bal des Oiseaux, to be given on May 12 in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria for the benefit of the Hospitalized Veterans Music Service, a subsidiary of the Musicians Emergency Fund.

DARIEN, Conn., April 16 -- James M. Baker, member of a prominent family here, was in serious condition today at the Norwalk Hospital, where he was admitted late last night with three bullet wounds received on the grounds of a neighbor's home.

JERUSALEM, April 16 -- As today is the Jewish Sabbath, no one was available for comment on the recommendation of Pope Pius XII that Jerusalem be internationalized and its Holy Places safeguarded. Unofficial reaction indicates, however, that internationalization is entirely out of the question as far as Israel is concerned, and that if other powers insist, it would mean resumption of the war in Palestine.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., April 16 (AP) -- Buddy Behrens of Rollins College today upset, top seeded Billy Talbert of New York to move into the semi-finals of the Good Neighbor tennis tournament, then lost to Gardner Larned, also from Rollins.

THE Cine-Kodak Reliant Camera, taking 8mm roll film, is announced by Kodak as its first completely new post-war movie camera. The camera features sprocketless film loading; prefocused 13mm f/2.7 Kodak Cine Ektanon lens and the Cine-Kodak universal exposure guide. The price is $89. An accessory 38mm f/2.8 telephoto lens for triple magnification is $42.75. Zipper case is $6.75; combination case, $23.50.

MIDDLEBURG, Va., April 16 (AP) -- Irish Oyster won the William Skinner Memorial Steeplechase by five lengths today from the Rokeby Stables' favored Genancoke. Lechei Hombre was third, eight lengths farther back.

WHEN ferocious African Congo elephants invade the Clifton coffee plantation, trampling and uprooting the bushes which have taken years to grow, young Bob Clifton secures a temporary appointment as government elephant hunter to save his parents' plantation from destruction.
WASHINGTON, April 16 (UP) -- A row boiled up between two Senate committees today over the Administration's plan to help rearm Western Europe under the Atlantic defense pact.

THE wide sweep of China's civil war and social revolution, two related phases of a gigantic historical event, embraces 450,000,000 people directly, promises to transform the map of East Asia and increases the threat of a new world conflict. And yet an Indian journalist, when he arrived for the first time in Nanking shortly after Gandhi's assassination in New Delhi, asked: "Where is the upsurge ? Where is the emotion?"

BERLIN, April 16 -- Progressive and controlled relaxation of current restrictions against German participation in civil aviation has been recommended to the State department by the United States Military Government.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 16 -- Recent broadcasts of Radio Moscow to Yugoslavia indicate Marshal Tito's regime rates a high priority in the Soviet Government's list of targets.

The Maritime Commission faces the prospect of drastically reduced operations in the next fiscal year unless budget cuts made by the House Appropriations Committee and subsequently approved by the entire House in the Independent Offices Bill are restored either by the Senate Appropriations Committee or in conference between both Houses on the bill.
The proposed "prestige" super-liner for the American merchant marine will pose an insurance problem of a magnitude never before faced in this country, under-writers said yesterday.

WASHINGTON -- The passport division of the State Department has asked Congress for funds to reopen three of its pre-war regional offices in order to meet the record demands in the foreign-travel field. Request has been made to re-establish centers in Boston, Chicago and New Orleans.

THIS volume is a timely, though over-technical, reminder of our persistent neglect of the crucial problems of industrial mobilization. The authors -- David Novick, Melvin L. Anshen and William C. Truppner -- are all scarred veterans of the wartime Battle of Washington.

AT its best, this authoritative symposium of essays by twenty-one distinguished social scientists makes fresh and provocative thrusts beyond the current intellectual frontiers. Beginning with discussions of cultural variation in Islamic, Chinese, Indian, Russian, Latin-American, Negro and North American family types, the book is chiefly interesting for its analysis of the contemporary American family.

THE interruption of normal art traffic with Europe during the war years has been followed by an unparalleled sequence of exhibitions of work by modern artists and their immediate predecessors, with further events projected. So that this decade has offered us an opportunity for second thoughts on many things.

ARISTOCRACIES, Aldous Huxley once remarked, can always be counted on to produce a certain number of strong-minded eccentrics; indeed, for the aristocrat eccentricity, like hunting and love-making, has been one of the traditional sports.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- Once again the House has voted to lift the taxes on oleomargarine that the Federal Government has levied for sixty-three years. And once again the fate of the repealer rests with the Senate, with the outlook no brighter than ever.

The derivation of ornamental design from sources in nature will be the subject of the next free art lecture at the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street. Mrs. Lilo Nelson will be the speaker on Tuesday at 6 P. M., the regular day and hour for the weekly lectures presented by the library in its art education project.

CHICAGO, April 16 -- Chicagoans found that their 1948 property taxes were 25 per cent above those for 1947 when their tax bills came in the mail this week, and dismay over the fact led to threats of a property owners' tax strike unless rent ceilings were modified or removed.

ON Tuesday the Theatre Guild will celebrate its thirtieth birthday. It is an important milestone for the Guild, an important one for the theatre it tries to serve. Its achievements over the three decades since it began operations as an outgrowth of the struggling Washington Square Players have been on an heroic scale.

BALLET Theatre opens at the Metropolitan Opera House tonight for a season of three weeks, with Nora Kaye, Nana Gollner, Janet Reed, Muriel Bentley, Diana Adams, Igor Youskevitch, John Kriza, Hugh Laing, Norma Vance, Ruth Ann Koesun, Mary Burr and a number of other old familiars, along with such newcomers to the roster as Maria Tallchief, Bambi Linn, Jocelyn Vollmar and Paul Godkin.

FOUR years ago when the siren wailed in the spacious bunker in Benrato, a suburb of Duesseldorf, terrified humanity poured through its doors by the hundreds to seek shelter from falling bombs. Today the same siren imposes quiet before camera rolls in one of the world's strangest film studios.

If they never bore a bushel of fruit, the peach trees and the plum trees of this land would be well worth cherishing simply for the beauty of their blossoms. They are among the earliest of all our fruit trees to bloom, often putting forth flowers while the leaves are still shrugging their way out of bud.

The Dodgers celebrated their return to Ebbets Field by beating the Yankees for the second time in a row yesterday. However, there was little in the 7-6 triumph that fostered pennant dreams among the 12,439 members of the Flat-bush faithful who shivered through the ragged contest.

At this time of the year the office of a president of a baseball league in many respects is similar to the headquarters of one of our major political parties on election night. Reports continually are arriving and you sift through these to find a trend.

Several social work organizations and Negro colleges in the South are at resent campaigning for vocational opportunities for Negro youths. The National Urban League has placed job placement and vocational training foremost in its work and various trade unions with Negro memberships have also been active in widening the field of job opportunity.

Local fans, 8,812 of them, who took their first look at the Giants yesterday at the Polo Grounds liked what they saw as Leo Durocher's team displayed late foot and handed the world champion Indians a 10-9 setback that earlier did not appear likely.

BECAUSE of their rapid rate of growth, annual vines quickly transform an ordinary or unsightly spot into one of real charm. They may even be planted to cover a blank wall or a terrace for a season, while perennial vines, such as wistaria or climbing roses, are just getting started.

New York's political spotlight turned last week on Tammany Hall when that organization rejected a bid by Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. to be the Democratic candidate for Congress to succeed the late Sol Bloom. Young Mr. Roosevelt thereupon charged that Tammany was run by a non-representative clique, and he announced his independent candidacy.

News of recovery in the Philippines, as reported in this newspaper yesterday, is heart-warming. Coconut products and hardwood are at the pre-war level. Rice, sugar and hemp are two-thirds of the way back. Mining, after a slower start, is on the increase. The budget is balanced.

BERLIN April 16 -- In "The Prince" Nicolo Machiavelli conjectured that the state of affairs in Italy was so desiderate that salvation could be expected only from the intervention of a powerful despot.

LOS ANGELES, April 16 -- California's new old-age pension, providing $75 a month at 63, aside from its dent in the state exchequer, already is causing community concern in regard to care of elderly "immigrants" from other states.
In illustrating the interesting article of F. Emerson Andrews on "New Challenges for Our Foundations," THE TIMES fell into a rather common error.

ROME, Sunday, April 17 -- Premier Alcide de Gasperi early this morning announced the long-awaited land reform, which has the purpose of splitting up the largest estates and making land available to Italy's land-hungry peasants. It is thought that the measure will contribute powerfully to checking Communist propaganda that has been describing the Government as an exponent of capitalist interests and as inimical to the humbler sections of the population.

The first installment of the valuable art collection formed by the late Joseph Brummer. internationally renowned antiquarian and art dealer, will be auctioned this week in four sessions at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street.
ST. LOUIS, April 16 (AP) -- The Browns opened their St. Louis city-series exhibition stand with a bang today, swamping the Cardinals, 12 to 1.

DETROIT, April 16 (AP) -- A strike threat at the Ford Motor Company's big River Rouge plant was reinforced today by a union decision to poll 65,000 production workers next week on a walkout.
MOSCOW, April 16 -- The largest and most consistent advertisers in the Soviet Union are the state food trusts and the State Insurance Company, known as Gosstrakh.

ROME, April 16 -- It is now a full year since Marshal Tito, formerly Generalissimo Stalin's favorite in Eastern Europe, was accused of heretical interpretations of the Marxist-Leninist doctrine. By masterly security measures the Cominform was able to keep this a family quarrel until it took the desperate step of publicly condemning the Yugoslav regime last June.

HARTFORD, Conn., April 16 -- A Connecticut state income tax proposed by Gov. Chester Bowles will be the subject of a public hearing on Wednesday in the Hall of the House of Representatives of the General Assembly.

Two Government agencies, American occupation authorities in Germany and the domestic steel and scrap industries are impinged on a multi-horned dilemma over suggested stockpiling here of some 2,000,000 tons of foreign scrap metal for use in any future emeregncy.

NEWARK, N. J., April 16 -- Several hundred tons of war surplus merchandise stored under an un-walled shed of the Garden Surplus Sales Corporation, at Port Newark, were ruined in a spectacular fire this morning.

Now that the call of spring is summoning drivers in greater number than ever to the open road, there is reason for special care to prevent accidents. The condition of the automobile fleet, which is larger than it ever was before, makes this imperative. The number of older vehicles in use is far above the pre-war total.

THERE are many people who may have contemplated the treasures of the Morgan Library without ever meeting personally its erstwhile director, Belle da Costa Greene. But no one there could have been unaware of her taste, her intelligence, her dynamism.

BERLIN, April 16 -- United States and British fliers won a signal victory for the West in the "cold war" today when, on the 294th day of the blockade of Berlin, they flew 12,940.9 short tons of supplies into the city on 1,398 flights in the twenty-four-hour period that ended this noon.

" Who pays the piper calls the tune." This may work if you're hiring a publicist, or even an economist, but don't try it on a municipal bond attorney. He may be paid by the local government body, but his responsibility is first to a public that hardly knows that he exists.
LONDON, April 16 (UP) -- Russia has failed to meet her goal for crude oil production and has run into "serious difficulties" in exploiting new fields, it was disclosed today.

Brava, Ljuba Welitsch! And brava, Geraldine Farrar -- for her letter of March 20. I am not entirely sure, as Miss Farrar is, that a full-bodied voice necessarily needs a full-limbed support, but in essence she is perfectly right.

ADD Susie to the gallery of especially amusing felines. Susie was very smart -- just like your cat and mine. She could jump through young Johnny's arm, play with a ball and climb a ladder. But Susie wasn't entirely happy. She fancied herself as a circus performer, so one day Johnny took her to the big top.

The spring sunshine must have looked brighter to the inhabitants of the battered city of Berlin yesterday as they heard the American and British airlift planes coming to the three airfields of the Western districts at the rate of one a minute. It has been a bad winter for Berlin.

TOO many writers of humorous mystery novels seem to feel that there's no reason why the plot should hang together if the writing's funny enough. Edmund Crispin, like Carter Dickson, knows better. After a few chaotic early attempts, he's learned by now how to juggle Wodehousian farce, social satire and a strictly constructed detective plot, keeping all three balls glinting through the air so adroitly that they form one delightful pattern.

Two forums to discuss issues involved in the student strike at City College have been scheduled, Prof. Joseph E. Barmack, chairman of the student-faculty committee on student activities, sponsors of the meetings, announced yesterday.

PUBLISHED on the author's seventieth birthday, "The Devil's Own Dear Son" is Mr. Cabell's fiftieth book. These impressive figures may call forth still another round of somber "revaluations," or summaries of a historically astonishing career. There is really no such need. The magic green stone will surely be recovered from Matanzas Bay, and Mr. Cabell will surely write many more books.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, April 16 -- Constant emotional upsets such as worry, fretting and anger are clearly evident in high blood pressure patients, but the role of such tensions in the ailment is not completely known.

DARIUS MILHAUD'S third big opera, "Bolivar," which he wrote in this country after the fall of France, will be premiered next month by the Paris Opera. The work, dealing with the South American liberator, is described as "an epic historical fresco."

WILMINGTON, Del., April 16 -- The du Pont de Nemours Co. has achieved remarkable success in combating alcoholism with the Alcoholics Anonymous program, Dr. George H. Gehrmann, medical director of the company, said today.

ALL a Southerner has to do to talk like a Yankee is to put a "u" sound before every "r" in his conversation. That gives a reasonably fair -- and unbearable -- impersonation. It's a little harder for a Yankee to talk like a Southerner; but then, there's more zeal available and such battered props as "you-all" and "Ah sweah" add spice to the lonely hilarity.

ANNANDALE - ON - HUDSON, N. Y., April 16 -- The twenty-three students who man the Bard College volunteer fire department take unusual pride in never having fought a major fire. So far they have arrived early enough to put out the blaze while it was still small.

ARTURO TOSCANINI was dissatisfied with the way a rehearsal was going some days ago. Signaling the members of his NBC Symphony Orchestra to stop playing, the maestro, whose boiling point is low in musical matters, glared at the musicians. Then he flung at them the most scathing indictment he could think of at the moment, "You play like a bunch of old men!"

HOLLY SPRINGS, Miss. -- The old South will take precedence over the new in this northern Mississippi town during its eighth annual Pilgrimage, April 24-27. Fourteen antebellum homes will be open, affording visitors a view of life as it was in 1849, complete with colorful costumes and the traditional courtesy of the period.
TEL AVIV -- The eleven-month-old Republic of Israel is turning its attention now to welcoming 1,000 tourists here for the concurrent observance in the Holy Land of Easter and Passover.

THIS is the "high season" in the Midsouth. With the regular visitors who spent the winter in the Midsouth resorts and continue to linger, plus the motorists who are heading north (with stop-overs) from Palm Beach and Miami Beach, the hotels and inns around Aiken, Tryon, Pinehurst and Southern Pines report heavy crowds.

THIS town is still talking about the letter you published on March 20 -- the one from Margaret Murray. Everyone agreed with what she said about democracy, but on the whole people were more interested in what she said about Brooklin.

LONDON, April 16 (Reuters) -- Thousands of London dockers, who resumed work today after a five-day strike, are to work throughout tomorrow, Sunday, in an all-out effort to turn round the ninety-four ships held up by the strike.

PATERSON, N. J., April 16 -- The Board of Public Works here agreed late today to open a "play street" leading to a state motor vehicle inspection station, but only after hundreds of inspection-bent motorists had been turned away by wooden barriers.

How the marketing of large blocks of common stock has undergone drastic change in Wall Street since the old days is shown by three current equity offerings aggregating more than $90,000,000 in subscription value.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 16 -- A proposal for settlement of a suit of more than $40,000,000 brought last October against the Matson Navigation Company is to be laid before stockholders at a special meeting on April 25.

AS near as any statistician ever has been able to figure out, there have been 58,386 regularly scheduled major league baseball games since the turn of the century. Toss in a few hundred world series and all-star engagements for good measure and it adds up to -- well, it adds up to an awful lot of baseball.

HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., April 16 -- Capot, the fleet-footed 3-year-old colt who is the second choice in the Kentucky Derby future books, should be capable of making quite a showing in the blue grass classic if in condition.
FAIRY roses, otherwise known as Miniatures, have tiny flowers and buds no larger than kernels of corn. With a minimum of care, they will bloom the year round, and without benefit of a greenhouse.

MONKTON, Md., April 16 -Pine Pep, ridden by Michael J. Smithwick, rallied from last place in a field of fourteen to win the thirty-eighth My Lady's Manor Steeplechase today. As Maryland opened its point-to-point season, Smithwick also rode Done Sleeping to victory in the John Streett Memorial timber race which followed.

TWO plausible reasons explain the vogue of "primitive" or "naive" painting in the twentieth century. Either advanced taste takes refuge in simplicity as a last form of sophistication, or else popular taste, dismayed at the overintellectualism of modern art, turns with relief to the direct expression of direct feeling.

RENO, Nev., April 16 (UP) -- Senator Pat McCarran, Democrat, of Nevada, today accused Secretary of State Dean Acheson of giving the Senate "misleading" and "false" information on American aid to China.

According to the Gospel of St. John, which differs only in detail from the other gospels. Mary Magdalene came to the sepulcher "early, when it was yet dark," and saw that the stone that had closed the entrance had been rolled away and that the tomb was empty. Then, as John continues, she wept and One whom she had at first taken to be a gardener said to her.

HONOLULU, T. H., April 16 (AP) -- A tank - landing ship tank aboard which were the bodies of 120 American war dead arrived here today. Thus ended the last general search for the men who fell in the South Pacific war.

TORONTO, April 16 -- The Toronto Maple Leafs won the Stanley Cup, professional hockey's highest award, for the third straight year tonight, beating the Detroit Red Wings, 3 to 1, to sweep the best-of-seven series in four straight games.

Elections will take place throughout the Soviet Union on July 1 to fill leading posts in the All-Union Voluntary Society for Assistance to the Army, Col. Gen. V. Kuznetsov, organizational chairman, disclosed in a report on the civilian military training agency's work that has just arrived here.

There are fifty-nine flagpoles in the court at the entrance to the U. N. General Assembly's auditorium at Flushing Meadow. Flags fly from only fifty-eight of them. The fifty-ninth will fly the blue and white standard of Israel when that nation is admitted to the U. N. Last week an obstacle to Israel's admission arose and cast some doubt that final action will be taken at the current session.

" CROOKED HOUSE" is not top-hole Agatha Christie, but good going in its own way. Taverner is the Scotland Yard man on the case, but the keenest sleuthing is done by Charles Hayward, fiance of the granddaughter of the murdered man.

WALKIE-TALKIE radio will be made available to the general public for the first time on June 1, with the full activation of the Citizens Radio Service by the Federal Communications Commission. After the service is opened, a person wanting to converse with another within a limited area will be permitted to do so on his own miniature sending and receiving set. He need not have technical knowledge of radio.

Compiled with the aid of official ECA figures and estimates, a six-color chart detailing the manner in which American industrial concerns can benefit by Marshall Plan sales to participating countries has been prepared by the Westinghouse Electric International Company.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- The appointment of Dr. Martha Eliot, Associate Chief of the Children's Bureau, as Assistant Director General of the United Nations World Health Organization was announced today both in Washington and Geneva.
WEST POINT, N. Y., April 16 -- Rutgers University defeated Army, 7 to 6, at Doubleday Field today in a baseball game that was marred by low temperatures and high winds.

THE way business is going consumer-wise was made clear in the Easter trade season just concluded. The buying public wants values even during a period when fashion is supposed to take attention off the price tag.

UPON "local color" fiction in this country, especially upon that which deals with hill people of the South, there has for generations rested a peculiar curse: it has persistently yielded to the easy formula that among hills and hillbillies is to be found a solace and a strength no longer available in cities.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 16 -The American and French Universities in Beirut, Dr. Henry Meleney, head of the Department of Public Health at New York University, and the Commonwealth and Rockefeller Foundations are working here on plans for a public health institute to train officers for a full-scale war on disease in the Middle East.

FOR distinctiveness and charm, a garden is as dependent on architectural features as it is on beds and borders of colorful flowers. In fact, it is difficult to focus attention on any one spot for a whole season, using plants alone.
" Certainly any disease that has become a national disaster warrants the support of all our people in an endeavor to bring it under control," writes Secretary of State Dean Acheson.

Three more "Clan" ships in various stages of completion will enter the service of Cayzer, Irvine Co., managers of the Clan Line Steamers, Ltd., in the next few months, according to the Barber Steamship Lines, New York agents for the British line.
JERUSALEM, April 16 -- Christian worshipers will cross into the old city tomorrow to attend Easter mass in the Church of the Holy Sepulchre, traditionally Christ's burial place.

ONE of the unique cultural phenomena of our time is the existence of a large and influential group of Communist "fellow-travelers." In many ways their activities constitute a more serious threat to democratic life than those of Communist party members. By applying one standard of judgment to the Soviet Union and an entirely different one to every other nation, including their own, they have revived and strengthened the old suspicion against all dissenters.

IT is a delight to see flowers blooming outdoors again, but it is sometimes even more rewarding to bring a few indoors where they can be enjoyed at close range. The delicacy of the first spring blooms is most appealing.

BUENOS AIRES, April 16 -- President Peron will hear within the next few days from his Ambassador to Washington a basis for greatly increased sales to the United States that might clear the way for a thorough overhauling of the trade agreement of October, 1941.
WASHINGTON, April 16 -- The stage is being set for a full-scale Congressional investigation of the major insurance companies and their investment practices.
SINCE you mentioned our "all-out" campaign to raise $35,000 or suspend operations in your story on the St. Louis Orchestra, I thought you might be interested in the outcome of the effort.

LONDON, April 12 -- American visitors, who in the past often wondered why the British housewife never bothered about house-hold labor-saving gadgets, would be surprised if they could see the rapid transformation that is taking place now.

ANYONE who cares to understand what the United States must do in order to avoid depression at home and war abroad may benefit from reading this brief, simplified but highly concentrated analysis. It is directed primarily to those who voted for President Truman.
LONDON, April 16 -- Statesmen of seven of Britain's Dominions meeting here next Thursday will be confronted with problems of far-reaching importance to the Commonwealth and the world.

The thirteenth annual Three Choir Festival to be sponsored by Temple Emanu-El will be held at the temple on May 6 and 7. The programs will be devoted to "Songs of the Americas, Colonial and New," and the event is being planned as a tribute to the American composer.

ALL the world loves a lover -- and a bride. She who is about to become one chooses spring for the wedding; it is still the favorite season for getting married. She wears a white dress and her mother's veil, demands the Wagner and Mendelssohn nuptial music, carries flowers or a prayer book, and, in short, follows a pattern prescribed by tradition.

PHILIP VAN DOREN STERN'S new novel is composed of one-third Donald Henderson Clarke, one-third Kathleen Winsor and one-third sheer hokum, all thoroughly mixed. It is laid mostly in the California mountains behind Sacramento, but in terms of literary distance it is much nearer Hollywood.

NANKING, April 16 -- Despite the veil of secrecy cloaking the Peiping peace talks, indications mounted this week that the Chinese Communists were striving to use the negotiations to absorb the Nanking regime, to put their troops in position to cross the Yangtze River peacefully and to bring about the "final elimination" of the old ruling Kuomintang of Chiang Kai-shek.

PRAGUE, April 16 -- The Czechoslovak police at 1 P. M. today released Miss Vlasta Vraz, Prague head of the American Relief for Czechoslovakia, from Pankrac prison seven days to the hour after they had taken her from her office.

LONDON, April 16 -- Despite the opposition of Minister of Defense A. V. Alexander, the annual conference of the Cooperative party in Weston-Super-Mare adopted a resolution today condemning military conscription and calling for its repeal when the threat of war has ceased. The Cooperative party is one of the constituent organizations of the Labor party.

Colgate University's preceptorial laboratories, under the direction of Dr. Strang Lawson, are attempting to uncover the reasons why some students do not understand some professors. At present, the university has found, some professors might just as well be lecturing to their classes in Mongolian slang for all the good that it does.
THE short story remains the most vigorous branch of American literature because it is in pretty direct contact with its audience, which is a large one.

Discriminatory barriers have been broken in most of the organized sports, but the American Bowling Congress remains a restrictive club with the "spirit of good fellowship" applying only to whites. Included in the figure "20,000,000 bowlers" are Negroes, who are denied a chance to compete across the color line and note should be made of the boycott of A. B. C. alleys.

THE Easter display at the New York Botanical Garden Greenhouses in Bronx Park will feature the seasonal colors of lavender and gold. Among the many flowers included in the exhibit will be daisy chrysanthemums, purple snapdragons and phlox, stocks, pinks, azaleas, hydrangeas and calceolarias.

THE average passenger flying to Bermuda today in a Douglas DC-4 or a Lockheed Constellation probably never thinks of the fact that it was only nineteen years ago this month that a flight from New York to Bermuda warranted page one coverage in New York's newspapers.

Your editorial on April 9, Mrs. McCormick's column on April 11 and other material you have published seem to me, following travel and discussion in recent weeks in this country, to reflect the feeling many Americans have of wanting some better proposal for the former Italian colonies than that now being made by our Government.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 16 -- Gen. Husni Zayim formed tonight a Cabinet for Syria with himself as Premier and Minister of Interior and of Defense. One of the first acts is expected to be the signing of a treaty with Iraq, for which Iraqi Premier Nuri as Said arrived in Damascus during the day.

OMAHA, Neb., April 16 -- Midwestern farmers are "listening in" attentively on Congressional debate on whether the Government should enter the telephone business, at least indirectly. The proposal is contained in a bill that has been approved by the House Agriculture Committee.

THE doors of the temple of Janus in Rome, open during war, were closed on the morning of the first Easter. There was no great war between 31 B. C. and about the end of the second century A. D. More than a century and a half after the Crucifixion Tertullian could write: "Each day the world becomes more beautiful, more wealthy, more splendid."

DUBLIN, April 16 (UP) -- At one minute after midnight tomorrow guns will roar in Dublin as they did in the Easter Monday Rebellion thirty-three years ago, but this time they will peacefully proclaim the birth of the independent Republic of Eire.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 16 -- A strong wind from the north of increasing intensity whipped up the waters of the Severn and made it necessary to call off the Navy-Columbia rowing regatta this evening.

REALLY, New Yorkers don't know what life is all about. (Neither, for that matter, I suspect, do Bostonians or Philadelphians, or even Chicagoans). I believe I am fairly entitled to a word on the subject, since I was born within a stone's throw (well, a long stone's throw) of the street in which I write.

DEFINE the boundary of the area to be photographed, then try to understand it, was the advice given by Berenice Abbott, internationally famous photographer and author, in a talk at the Riverdale Library last week on the subject, "Photographing Your Community." Miss Abbott is the author of "Changing New York" and of a book of photographic impressions of Greenwich Village to be published this fall.

Although many aggressive supermarkets and chain grocery stores here are showing substantial gains over last year's sales at this point, profits are smaller due to higher costs which have become "fixed," it was reported here last week.

THERE are two possible limitations to this set of Little Golden Books. Books three inches by two inches are difficult for grown-up and child to share while reading and thin paper backs will not stand much loving handling. Outweighing these minor faults are the successful art, stories and packaging that make up this set.

CHICAGO, April 16 -- The plight of public school systems and the need for new legislation to avert a repetition of the Effingham (Ill.) hospital fire, in which seventy-five men, women and children perished, engaged the attention of Central Westerners this week.

The substitute farm aid program proposed by the Truman Administration is taken generally as a public admission that the present plan, like the others that have preceded it, is proving a costly failure.
WASHINGTON, April 16 -- The National Labor Relations Board today held a chief of police and two police officers guilty of unfair labor practices under the Taft-Hartley Act.

DETROIT, April 16 (AP) -- The automobile industry's biggest postwar sales season probably will end early in July. The industry expects to make and sell more cars in the next three months than in any previous like period of its history.

The Russian leaders, "but not the people," are the chief threat to world peace, in the opinion of junior high school students who participated yesterday in the weekly Youth Forum sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES and broadcast over WQXR.

PLANNING a shrub border for the city garden is far different from doing the same thing in the suburbs or country. Limitations are imposed in the city of which less hampered gardeners never dream. The urban backyard calls for careful selection of each plant and its exact placement in the plan.

" I DON'T think of myself as a translator," said Justin O'Brien, who recently completed what the critics consider a superlative translation of the three-volume, 1;145-page "Journals of Andre Gide." Prior to his efficient labors on the crystalline prose of M. Gide, Mr. O'Brien had, as a matter of fact, done but one job of translation -- the poems of Valery Larbaud -- and that as an enamored amateur.

TOKYO, April 16 -- The Japanese press and public are becoming deeply alarmed over the constantly mounting wave of postwar juvenile crime and the present session of the Diet is to be asked to frame preventive measures.

THE Anti-Saloon League waged its "moral crusade" for the Eighteenth Amendment with a fury unsurpassed in our nation's history. Bishop James Cannon Jr. of the Methodist Church, who died in 1944, was its tireless, driving leader.

The Brewers Board of Trade suffered yesterday the second defection from its ranks when Metropolis Brewery, Inc., 501 First Avenue, signed an individual contract with the striking United Brewery Workers. CIO.

The wind-up of Easter trade here was marked by small gains over last year. Department store sales, it was estimated, were about 5 per cent above the same calendar week of 1948, which however was in the post-Easter period.

Fifth Avenue shop windows were in full bloom yesterday. Floral life was the general Easter theme in stores between Thirty-fourth and Fifty-ninth Streets, and every few steps women previewing their Easter finery stopped off to comment and enjoy the displays.

SPOKESMEN for French, Italian and British automobile manufacturers report that a great number of Europe-bound tourists are planning to buy foreign cars from dealers in the United States this year, accepting delivery after they land overseas.

HAPPINESS is never my aim. Like Einstein, I am not happy and do not want to be happy; I have neither time nor taste for such comas, attainable at the price of a pipeful of opium or a glass of whisky, though I have experienced a very superior quality of it two or three times in dreams.

Most special elections generate little interest among the voters. Usually fewer than one-quarter of the eligible voters bother to turn out and cast their ballots. The machine candidate of the party with the biggest registration in the district is generally a sure winner.

PRAGUE, April 16 -- Premiers Antonin Zapotocky of Czechoslovakia and Istvan Dobi of Hungary signed today a treaty of friendship and mutual military aid in Budapest that completed the network of twenty-one such treaties among the six "people's democracies" and Russia.

BOSTON, April 16 -- Communism suddenly became a major topic of conversation this week in New England as the result of developments at the New York trial of eleven top party members and of an outburst of activity by fellow-travelers in the textile city of Lawrence, Mass.

A middle-aged man in well-cut clothes walked wearily into the Nassau County police headquarters at Mineola, L. I., early yesterday morning, plumped two heavy suitcases on the floor and told a surprised desk sergeant that he had been a fugitive for thirteen years and was surrendering on an embezzlement charge.

Norman Thomas declared yesterday that the Socialist candidates for city office, headed by Joseph G. Glass, nominee for Mayor, would have an opportunity during the coming campaign to tell the people of New York what was going on in the O'Dwyer Administration.

RUNNING contrary to the general summer trend, the Buick Motor Division of the General Motors Corporation will make its debut in "big time" television programming in the last week in June and will continue its show through July and August and into the fall. The sixty-minute variety show will feature Olsen and Johnson of "Helizapoppin'" fame.

DETROIT -- The steady improvement of cars through evolutionary rather than revolutionary methods is the prevailing trend in the automobile industry, Harlow H. Curtice, executive vice president of General Motors Corporation, declared here last week.

LOS ANGELES, April 16 (AP) -Michigan State and Southern California's Trojans battled each other to a standstill and a 61-61 tie today in an intersectional track and field struggle that more than came up to expectations.

CHICAGO, April 16 -- The Easter meat trade, especially for hams, was disappointing to packers, and largely responsible for the recent severe decline in the market for hogs to the lowest price levels since the Office of Price Administration had control in October, 1946.

THE political ferment of Southeast Asia cannot obscure the continuing importance of the area's ancient religious-cultural folkways. Burma today is torn by conflict between the dominant Burmese (believers in Hinayana Buddhism) and the partly Christianized Karen separatists.

CHICAGO, April 16 -- The number of building permits issued in March for housing units to be constructed here and in the suburban area reached a new high for the month since 1940, while total permits for all types of construction set a record for the month in the same years except 1946.

Drs. John G. Trump and J. Eugene Nelson are two M. I. T. Frankensteins who have created not a monster but a wooden man to note the effects of high-voltage X-rays produced by the Van de Graaff and other atom-splitting machines. "Mr. Cruikshank" is the wooden man's name.

A QUARTER century after the first appearance of Gide's "Dostoevsky," the volume stands remarkably well the trial of a second reading. The readers of today, as Arnold Bennett said of those of yesterday, "will receive light, some of it dazzling, on both Dostoevsky and Gide."
WASHINGTON, April 16 (AP) -The Puerto Rican Senate's censure of the Inter-American Commission on Dependent Territories was described by a member of the commission today as premature and uncalled for.
