A general rededication to the principle of the brotherhood of man as a means of promoting world peace was urged upon religious leaders by rabbis in sermons here yesterday, during the confluence of the Jewish Passover and the Christian Easter.

The steady decline in employment along the waterfront in 1948 placed an additional burden on the Seamen's Church Institute, largest shore home in the world for seamen, according to the organization's 114th annual report.

* * * The Raymond B. Fosdick article -- "We Must Not Be Afraid of Change" -- hits the nail right on the head. We are living in a world of change; our country thrived on change; our democracy prospered on change; and, yet, today, thought that recommends change is met with name-calling and abuse.

CHICAGO, April 16 (AP) -- Marten Mendez, 33-year-old aircraft worker from San Diego, Calif., and 24-year-old Miss Ethel Marshall of Buffalo, N. Y., tonight were crowned men's and women's national badminton champions.

NEW ORLEANS, April 17 (AP) -- Kentucky, Villanova, Bradley and Tulane have accepted bids to play in the annual Sugar Bowl basketball tournament here Dec. 29-30. Basketball chairman Sam Corenswet disclosed the selections today.
A sunny, but brisk day that may cloak new Easter finery with topcoats and furs will greet worshipers and fashion paraders today as the Christian world unites to commemorate the Resurrection.

THE United States of America is unique among the great nations in that it has never been rent by religious war, but it seldom occurs to an American that this is peculiar. The peculiarity, as he sees it, is exhibited by those nations that spill blood over matters of faith and doctrine.

An increase in the demand for budget-price toppers and full-length coats was noted in the wholesale apparel market here last week, according to a report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company, Inc., resident buying office. A large number of reorders called for summer suits with emphasis on navy.

WHERE tiger-skin rugs once growled at one another across his green and red offices, philodendrons now reach toward the wide-draped windows. A real elephant's-foot humidor, loaded to the crusty ankle with six-bit cigars, has given way to a yard-long cigarette tray and an oaken bucket filled with Havanas and pipe tobacco.

WASHINGTON, April 16 (UP) -- The Veterans Adminstration issued "a peacetime fact sheet" today outlining the benefits for which the veteran who was never under fire could apply. It boils down to consideration for service-connected disabilities or death, and provision for survivors, but it does not include the war veterans' right to take education and training under the G. I. Bill of Rights.

POTTERSVILLE, N. J., April 16 -- At the annual spring field trial meeting of the New Jersey Spaniel Field Trial Club on the MacQueen Game Farm today the work of the dogs was so excellent it was called phenomenal by the judges, even though the wind howled so much that guns were handicapped and the dogs nearly blown off the courses.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- A country-wide campaign designed to obtain increased local support for the nation's public schools is now being conducted by the United States Chamber of Commerce. Thus far 1,300 committees on education have been created in towns and cities throughout the country.

PHILADELPHIA, Pa., April 16 (AP) -- A seventh-inning home run by Eddie Waitkus with one man on base broke a 2-2 tie and gave the Phillies a 4-2 victory over the Athletics today. The National League victory evened the city series at one-all.

Although no retailers here admitted yesterday to being overly pleased with Easter trade results, few were greatly disappointed. Estimates of the period as compared with the pre-Easter period last year place sales about even or slightly higher this year.

THIS is less a South African novel than a novel about South Africa. It should thus be distinguished from such books as "Cry, the Beloved Country" and "King of the Bastards," where story, setting and psychology are naturally integrated to produce something distinctively and authentically South African.

Three hundred and ninety Protestant children are awaiting foster care in the city, Henry G. Hotchkiss, acting president of the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies, 122 East Twenty-second Street, announced yesterday.

TOKYO, April 10 -- The United States taxpayer is getting a break. He is receiving a substantial return on his investment in the Japan Air Material Area, twenty-five miles from Tokyo. The area's factories and storehouses supply the 1,200-plane Far East Air Forces, ranging from the South Pacific to the Bering Straits.
TOKYO, March 23 -- We imitative Japanese are feeling the impact of the West today, perhaps to a greater extent than at any time since Perry's opening of these islands almost 100 years ago.
The campaign for the election of a Representative in the Twentieth Congressional District on May 17 to fill the vacancy caused by the death of Sol Bloom will enter its intensive phase this week.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 17 -- The historic bell of the Mission San Antonio de Padua in Monterey County, California, began late today a flight across America and the Atlantic to enhance Western world unity for May Day.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- With all the painstaking care of generals mapping a military campaign, coal operators are drafting the strategy they will attempt to carry out in their annual set-to with John L. Lewis this spring.

Although World War II added to some reservoirs of scientific knowledge, it seriously depleted others. One example of such depletion, according to Dr. John H. Hett of the New York University College of Engineering, was in the field of fundamental scientific data on the jet propulsion engine.
James P. Smith has been appointed manager of over-the-counter piece goods sales of Southeastern Cottons, Inc. He was formerly advertising manager of the Burlington Mills Corporation (N. Y.).

LAKE SUCCESS, April 17 -- In its first official act of deference to the concept of a Supreme Being the United Nations will set up a special chamber for prayer and meditation in its headquarters now under construction in midtown Manhattan, it was learned here today.

New York steel warehouses are reaping benefits, instead of losses, out of the business recession. Second-quarter profits appear to be holding up well toward high levels of the first quarter, and the only threat they fear is a possible coal shut-down in midsummer, spokesmen disclosed here last week.

JERUSALEM, April 17 -- Just as dawn was breaking this morning over the Mount of Olives, church bells started ringing from various monasteries and churches throughout the Jerusalem hills. It was as if the words, "He has risen," had suddenly reached all ears.
Bronx police pressed their search yesterday for the strangler of 8-year-old Jackie Goldsmith as the murdered boy was buried in Degul Yehuda Cemetery in Deans, N. J.

After nearly a year's absence, during most of which time it was in a state of suspended animation, the Ballet Theatre returned last night to the Metropolitan Opera House with most of its old stars in their accustomed places and a number of new persons in the ranks.

The annual George Foster Peabody Radio Awards "for outstanding meritorious public service" will be announced on Thursday at a luncheon to be given by the Radio Executives Club of New York at the Hotel Roosevelt.

LONDON, April 17 -- A week crowded with incidents, any one of which might have affected market sentiment considerably, has had remarkably little effect on security prices. This probably is because of the conflicting nature of the events and because in any event public interest in the markets would have been reduced by the nearness of the Easter holiday.

ARMONK, N. Y., April 17 -- Local members of the Southern New York Field Trial Club saw their entries capture two of the three places in the twenty-second running of the association's amateur all-age stake held on the windswept Paterno estate today.

We are disturbed to note that a United Press error of April 7 concerning the American Farm Bureau Federation is included in THE TIMES of April 10. We refer you to Section E, Column 2, Paragraph 2, starting "American farming families. * * *"

An analysis of anti-Semitism in 1948 in this country, made public yesterday by the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith, indicated that it was a year of "great gains, violent reactions and, in certain areas, increased discrimination," but should go down "on the credit side of the ledger."

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 17 -- Yale University has established a Division of the Social Sciences and a Social Science Planning Center, Dr. Charles Seymour, president of the university, announced today. They will be directed by Prof. Arnold Wolfers.

The Committee for Progressive Zionism, opposed to various policies and the present administration of the Zionist Organization of America, named yesterday a committee of fifteen to "explore" the possibilities of achieving peace and unity in the American Zionist movement.

The arrival of the Cunard White Star liner Caronia today will mark the end of the winter cruise season, which participating steamship companies called highly successful despite the small number of vessels that could be spared from their regular transatlantic routes.

Last Saturday's concert at Carnegie Hall was the last New York concert for Serge Koussevitsky before his retirement as head of the Boston Symphony Orchestra. In twenty-five years he has raised that organization to a virtuoso group of the first rank and made the "Boston tone" the envy and hope of many a younger orchestral group.
BOSTON, April 17 (AP) -- Thanks to a forced-in run in the eighth inning, the Red Sox today downed the Braves by 4 -- 3 before a chilled crowd of 8,171 at Fenway Park.

CHICAGO, April 17 -- Although unemployment in the Seventh Federal Reserve District has almost tripled in the last five months, the "basic economic conditions leading to a major recession this years" do not now appear to be present, the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago said today in its April issue of "Business Conditions."
FRANKLIN, N. J., April 17 (AP) -- High school athletes make better scholars than do non-athletes, according to a ten-year survey made at Franklin High School.

Easter Monday in 1916 fell a week later than it did this year. On April 24, 1916, Padraic Pearse, standing on the steps of the Dublin Post Office, proclaimed "The Provisional Government of the Irish Republic," or, as the last three words are rendered in Gaelic, "Poblacht na h-Eireann."

LONDON, April 17 -- Hundreds of London's Irish gathered this afternoon in Trafalgar Square where the base of Nelson's Column was the platform for a fervid meeting of protest against the partition of Ireland.

WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP) -- Early arrivals to the Fifty-eighth Continental Congress of the Daughters of the American Revolution paused today in their round of Easter festivities to pay tribute to 2,711 D. A. R. members who died during the last year.
PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., April 17 -- The respective recorders of the Penguin and Class B one-design dinghy classes today announced the final standings in the spring and season series on Manhasset Bay.
ST. LOUIS, April 17 (AP) -- The Cardinals exploded for four home runs today to down the Browns, 7 to 4, in the final contest of a two-game St. Louis city series. The Browns won yesterday, 12 -- 1.

CHICAGO, April 17 -- The lard market was somewhat unsettled on the Board of Trade last week, breaking early with vegetable oils and then rallying after it was reported England was in the market for a substantial quantity. However, loose lard was marked down sharply and at one time was quoted at 9 7/8 cents a pound, lowest since November, 1941, but part of the loss was recovered later.

NEW BEDFORD, Mass., April 17 -- Mrs. Wilma Ybarbo, freed in Germany last Friday after serving 107 days for the fatal shooting of her husband, United States Army Sgt. John Ybarbo of Goliad, Tex., came home today to her 6-year-old son, Jimmy.

A canvass of the members of Congress, declared our wishful-thinking Secretary of Labor, Maurice J. Tobin, a day or two ago, indicates that the Truman Administration's labor bill will be approved "without substantial change."

NANKING, April 17 -- The Communists announced officially tonight that peace negotiations with the Nanking Government would terminate in Peiping Wednesday. This gave Acting President Li Tsung-jen only three more days to make up his mind on the Communists' demand that their army be allowed to cross the Yangtze River and establish bridge-heads at ten places on the south bank.
Before an overflow congregation of more than 5,000 Cardinal Spellman celebrated the pontifical mass of Easter Sunday in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday.

The present conflict between East and West is considered a conflict between democracy and totalitarianism. Yet a treaty deeply affecting all our lives has been composed in secret and has been signed a little more than two weeks after announcement of its text to the American people. It is difficult to see how this procedure can be considered democratic.

A new piece of furniture -- a sideboard seven feet long -- has been put on display in the showroom of Schmieg Kotzian, Inc., 521 has graceful proportions, gentle eighteenth-century curves, elaborate interior fittings and many other pleasant features.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- The Truman Administration's national health insurance program would make health care "practically a Government monopoly," three prominent Roman Catholic welfare groups asserted today in advancing an alternative plan.

An average decline of 50 cents in clerical salaries from the February level is an indication that more "white collar" workers are looking for jobs that are becoming scarce, according to the bi-monthly Current Index of Clerical Salary Rates for April issued over the week-end by the Commerce and Industry Association of New York, Inc.

The management of the New York Central Railroad Company has nominated Winthrop W. Aldrich and Albert B. Dick Jr. for directors, the vote to be taken at the annual meeting in Albany on May 25. The information was contained in the proxy statement for the meeting issued over the weekend.
WASHINGTON, April 17 -- Selden Chapin, United States Minister to Hungary, said today that Communist leaders do not seek to abolish the church in iron curtain countries, but to absorb it.
TEHERAN, Iran, April 17 (AP) -- The Foreign Office said today that the Iranian Government "has not so far taken any official steps" toward cancelling the 1921 treaty with Russia.

The timeless story of the resurrected Christ, Who rose from the dead so that others might have everlasting life, was told yesterday in nearly a score of Easter sunrise services throughout the metropolitan area.
LOS ANGELES, April 17 (AP) -- The United States squared its international polo series with Argentina today, as Cecil Smith and George Oliver paced the Yanks to a 14-to-12 victory.

Spring strides slowly along the river valleys, across the plains and over the hills. Behind her comes the green tide. These first hesitant days the beginning color is faint and thin. Winter-faded grasses have been wind and storm woven into a thick, drab plaid. They have formed a protecting covering to shelter billions of herb roots against thawing and heaving during Nature's rest period.

Nearly 7,000 persons attended the Cathedral of St. John the Divine yesterday for the 11 A. M. service of holy communion. They began to arrive early, some almost an hour in advance, and by 10:45 A. M. seats throughout the entire length of the great nave were filled.
ELIZABETH, N. J., April 17 -- The sale of twelve dwellings, including several in the Elmora residential section here, have been reported by realty brokers in the Elizabeth area.

ALLAMUCHY, N. J., April 17 -- Angelique de Bretagne, an eagerly hunting and stylish moving little Brittany spaniel from Cincinnati, took the top honor here today in a tightly contested open all-age stake, feature event of the American Brittany club's North Jersey regional spring trials.

HIGHTSTOWN, N. J., April 17 -- Two penguins are hiking through this area and State Police have been asked to find them. The penguins are among eight that made a break from a couple of crates on a truck about 2 A. M. today.

CHICAGO, April 17 -- Despite generally declining employment throughout the United States, it remains at a high level in most of the independent retail stores of the nation, the National Association of Retail Grocers reported today.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- The National Labor Relations Board ruled unanimously today that there is no strike when one man quits work, even if he is ordered off the job by a labor union official. The ruling was the first of its kind under the Taft-Hartley Act.
BERLIN, April 17 -- The American radio station in Berlin will shortly be silenced for lack of funds, official sources said today.
PITTSBURGH, April 17 (AP) -- The Tigers won a 4-2 exhibition victory over the Pirates before 11,434 shivering fans today.

MOSCOW, April 17. -- Several hundred Moscow boys and girls and a sprinkling of courageous adults had the time of their lives today watching an old favorite in a new setting -- "Uncle Tom's Cabin," revived under the auspices of Moscow's Central Theatre of of Transport.

DUBLIN, Monday, April 18 -- Dublin heralded the birth of the Irish Republic at one minute past midnight with a fanfare of trumpets and a salute of twenty-one guns from O'Connell Bridge in the presence of jubilant thousands lining the streets.

A program for speeding up collectivization of Rumanian agriculture along Russian lines was presented recently in a report by Gheorghe Gheorghiu-Dej, general secretary of the Rumanian Workers (Communist) party, to the Central Committee of the party.

BERLIN, April 17 -- German officials of the Soviet zone's Economic Administration have approached Western German economic officials in Frankfort with proposals that trade between Eastern and Western Germany be resumed as soon as possible, it was learned authoritatively today.

The New York Chamber Orchestra, under Dean Dixon, gave a concert last night at Town Hall. Featured on the program were three novelties by contemporary composers. It was their first New York hearing. These comprised "Offrande a une ombre" by Henri Barraud, "Suite for String Orchestra" by Michal Spisak, and "A Bill of Rights" by Dorothy H. Herbert.

Heading this week's art events is the Metropolitan Museum's Classical Exhibition, which opens to the public on Thursday. With paintings, sculpture, prints and decorative arts from the age of Pericles to the time of Picasso, it demonstrates how classicism has affected subsequent art.

The Anaconda Copper Mining Company in 1948 had a net income of $53,408,966, equal to $6.16 a share, an increase of $9,837,058, or 22.58 per cent over the $43,571,907, or $5.02 a share earned the year before, according to the annual report to be released today.
Ebbets Field seldom was a scene of triumph for Casey Stengel -- even when that legendary bird flew out from his cap years ago -- and yesterday was no exception.

CHICAGO, April 17 -- Prices of corn held within comparatively narrow limits last week on the Board of Trade here but managed to average slightly higher, largely in sympathy with wheat. There was no material pressure and buying was not aggressive, with a considerable part of the business being of a professional character.

Representatives of brokerage firms in ten leading cities will meet here on Wednesday with members of the Association of Customers' Brokers and the Stock Brokers' Associates of Chicago to form a national association of brokers and representatives, it was learned yesterday.
NEWARK, N. J., April 17 -- It's wonderful what the West Side youngsters see by looking into a hole in the ground that has been getting bigger for the last three weeks.
BOGOTA, Colombia, April 17 (UP) -- Soldiers clashed with some 200 armed civilians in a bloody battle a few miles northeast of the capital, the Government announced tonight.

The Easter matinee at the New York City Center was Bizet's "Carmen," with Robert Rounseville appearing as Don Jose for the first time. Although his was only one of several fine performances, he was alone in drawing fusilades of cheers after every aria and at his curtain calls.

DETROIT, April 17 -- The first experimental evidence that cancer cells must be supplied in their diet a growth-essential factor that normal cells can manufacture within themselves, and a new chemical that inhibits the growth of cancer in animals by depriving the cancer cells of this vital growth substance, were discussed here today at the annual meeting of the American Association for Cancer Research.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, April 17 -- The commission of inquiry into the racial riots in Durban last January warned in a report issued here tonight that, "unless the position is carefully watched and all exhibitions of public violence are firmly repressed, the natives [Zulus] may make another attack on the Indians to square their account.''

PRAGUE, April 17 -- Czechoslovakia has advanced from the equilibrium of foreign trade achieved in 1948 to a favorable trade balance in the first quarter of this year, Evzen Loebl, Deputy Minister of Foreign Trade, asserted in an article in the Czech press over the week-end.

Gloves, which have long been spice to a wardrobe, now take on fashion importance because of the new short and pushed-up sleeves on coats and suits. Hence a great variety of lengths as well as colors and fabrics are available in summer gloves.
New York staged its greatest Easter celebration yesterday -- a glittering spectacle that combined, in curious fashion, an uneven mixture of piety and levity.

Four teen-age stockroom employes of the Frederick Loeser department store on Fulton Street in downtown Brooklyn were charged yesterday with having systematically stolen store merchandise valued at somewhere between $10,000 and $80,000 in fifteen months.
PARIS, April 17 -- France's merchant marine is nearing pre-war tonnage levels but with more freighters and tankers and fewer passenger liners than before the war.
COOPERSTOWN, N. Y., April 17 (AP) -- The Cardiff Giant, an 80-year-old hoax once accepted by thousands as a "petrified human," was back in the limelight today as the center of a $100,000 lawsuit.

Amid the continuous ringing of bells, signifying the presence of ice-cream, popcorn, hot-dog, jelly-apple and soda-pop vendors, 36,786 persons lined the waterfront yesterday waiting their turns to board eight warships docked along the Hudson River.

CHICAGO, April 17 -- May wheat developed independent strength on the Board of Trade last week. At the top it showed over 7 cents a bushel above the finish of the previous week and went to a new high since mid-January, with short covering based on the maintenance of strong premiums for the cash article being the dominating influence.
ALBANY, April 17 (AP) -- The state forwarded today a total of $100,794,692 in state aid for schools to county treasurers and the treasurer of New York City.

Pound sterling was hit hard again last week, the spot rate slipping to $4.02 3/4, the support point, previously touched about ten days ago for a new low, while the discount on forwards widened to approximately 8 cents on 90-day contracts, and to 12 cents on six months', new minimums since February, 1948.

Four men who were picketing the Paramount Theatre in Times Square at 9 o'clock last night were arrested on a charge of disorderly conduct. They said they were members of Local 306 of the Motion Picture Operators Union, AFL.

The conservative buying policies shown by many retailers earlier in the season in regard to spring merchandise resulted in an exceptionally large number of reorders received by the wholesale apparel market here last week, according to reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

The State Department's action last week in establishing the jurisdiction of the nation's courts in cases of dispossession or confiscation of property by the Germans has cleared the way for Arnold Bernstein's $5,000,000 suit against the Holland-America Line for recovery of the Red Star Line, it was learned yesterday.

A powerful team of experts, bent on regaining the championship of the Metropolitan Chess League for the Manhattan Chess Club, yesterday defeated last year's winners, the Log Cabin Chess Club of West Orange, N. J., by the score of 6 -- 2 at the rooms of the Manhattan club.

The Kearny Celtics and Philadelphia Nationals scored third-round victories yesterday to tie for first place in the annual Lewis Cup competition sponsored by the American Soccer League. A playoff for the trophy is scheduled.

Despite the low temperature, the bright sun brought out a full measure of Easter finery yesterday in one of the largest throngs in years for the fashion parade in Fifth and Park Avenues. It was a big day for furs, with mink jackets and cape stoles the favorites, though a few women braved the cold in spring coats and suits without furs.

Steven Kyle, owner of Ameri-craft, decorators, bought the one-family brownstone front dwelling at 350 East Sixty-ninth Street from John and Margretta Cort for cash over a mortgage of $15,000 in a deal negotiated by Jean M. Smythe, broker.

Sheldon Jones did his sharpest -- by far -- pitching of the spring and Willard Marshall his heaviest and most effective clubbing and the Giants easily routed the world champion Indians, 8 -- 3, at the Polo Grounds yesterday.
PULLMAN, Wash., April 17 -- A young veteran rated as an expert marksman by the Army killed three police officers and a taxi operator today before he was killed in a two-hour gun fight with a posse.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., April 17 -- Supreme Court Justice Lee Parsons Davis, veteran courtroom protagonist, big-game hunter, fishing authority, camera expert, musical-saw virtuoso and storyteller par excellence, has a new hobby that involves needles and looms.

The city's waterfront crime investigation is progressing satisfactorily, but Commissioner of Investigation John M. Murtagh, who is heading the inquiry, still believes solution of the problem rests on early elimination of the pier-loader racket.

Prices of cotton in the domestic market last week moved into firmer ground. At the end of the week active futures prices on the New York Cotton Exchange showed advances of 20 to 64 points over the previous week. Strength in the near-by positions led the advance.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- Maple T. Harl, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, announced today that the deposits of all insured commercial and mutual savings banks totaled $153,000,000,000 at the end of 1948, $1,000,000,000 less than at the beginning of the year.

Parishioners of Holy Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church in Brooklyn who are thought to be in favor of its vestry's efforts to oust the Rev. Dr. John Howard Melish, rector of the church for forty-five years, are being importuned by letter to participate in tonight's annual parish elections, it was learned yesterday.

The omission of prayer at the signing of the North Atlantic pact was denounced yesterday by the Rev. 'Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell, pastor of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Fifty-fifth Street.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 17 -- The Arab countries have begun an intensive fence-mending campaign in an effort to re-establish their position as a bloc now that the fighting against Israel has ended.
WASHINGTON, April 17 -- President Truman and his family worshiped at two Easter services this morning.

VIRGINIA BEACH, Va., April 17 (AP) -- Amateur Frank Stranahan and Professional Bobby Locke today toured the Cavalier Country Club layout together through the last two rounds of the $10,000 Cavalier Specialists golf tournament and finished in a tie for the fifty-four-hole medal play honors.

PARIS, April 17 -- The outstanding event of the last week was the rise of the franc in terms of foreign currencies on the Paris black market. This produced speculation regarding a new change in the exchange rate. Informed observers here summarize the situation thus:

Your columns of April 4 carried a story by Harrison Salisbury on the report of the Moscow City Council. He quotes the report that "this year's plan provides for the addition of 378,000 square meters of living space, which is 49 per cent above last year's total."

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- This country's schools were defended against charges that the "three R's" are neglected for social studies, and that social studies are experimental and time-wasting, in an annual report issued today by the National Education Association.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 17 -- The screen adaptation of "Famous," a short story by the late Stephen Vincent Benet, has been announced by Paramount as a Bing Crosby vehicle to follow "Mr. Music" on the actor's schedule. Charles Brackett will produce the film in the fall, and John Van Druten has been engaged to write the scenario.
PHILADELPHIA, April 17 (AP) -- The Athletics captured the city series with a 5-2 victory over the Phillies today after each team had won a previous contest.

ROME, April 17 -- Thousands of Catholic pilgrims and tourists milled with Italian throngs in Rome's 400 churches today to attend Easter mass. At noon they converged on St. Peter's Square, hoping to receive the Pope's blessing.

URUMCHI, China, March 30 -- The hard-righting Moslem horsemen who dominate most of Sinkiang will never peaceably allow communism to penetrate that gigantic province, according to the Kazakh chieftain, Osman Bator.
AMSTERDAM, April 17 -- Dutch rubber quarters here give it as their view that the recent conference of the Rubber Study Group in London was "a complete washout."
DUBLIN, Monday, April 18 -- The Declaration of Independence making Eire the Republic of Ireland is a 486-word, poorly printed document originally scribbled on a scrap of paper thirty-three years ago.

DUBLIN, Monday, April 18 (UP) -- The Irish Free State, with the status of a Dominion, came into being Jan. 15, 1922. But not until the repeal of the External Relations Act last December, 1948, did Ireland cut her last tie with Britain.

The old lady was in a worn black coat, but she had a new hat with a wreath of red roses around the crown and two corsages of red roses pinned to her shoulder. She was wedged in between two pretty granddaughters, in gray suits just out of the bandboxes, on the steps of St. Patrick's Cathedral as the biggest Easter Parade in history jammed the Avenue.
WASHINGTON, April 17 -- The votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut during the period March 9-15 are given in the appended tabulation:

Before the war, a man holding a girl's hand usually found it small and delicate. When they danced he hardly felt it if she stepped on his foot. But today if the same girl landed on his shoe he might find himself with a crushed toe. If she squeezed his hand hard, she might break his finger.

A NEW baseball season will formally open in Washington today and Harry S. Truman, from Missouri, is scheduled to toss out the first ball. Although he doesn't rank with the ace pitchers, the President has proved that he knows how to win the big ones. He fanned the side with the bases full last November just as Tom Dewey was warming up in the bullpen and getting ready to take over this inaugural day chore.
LA JOLLA, Calif., April 17 (AP) -- Defending champions Ted Schroeder and Bob Falkenburg won the Pacific coast men's doubles tennis crown again today, but it was tough going.

The Port of New York Authority charged yesterday that airlines suing over leases at New York International Airport at Idlewild, Queens, were trying to get rights and privileges not provided in the leases. Calling the terms of the leases "unconscionable," the authority demanded their renegotiation.
DAMASCUS, Syria, April 17 -- Iraq announced today recognition of the new Syrian regime headed by Gen. Husni Zayim, Chief of State.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., April I7 -- Fall to spring sailing dingy racing ended the 1948-49 season today at the Larchmont Yacht Club after the most successful campaign on record. The mild winter and a new injection of enthusiasm made it such.

SHIELDS, Ky., April 17 (AP) -- Ambrose Metcalfe, 29, police chief of Harlan County, was shot to death on the street here today. A few hours later state police said that they had arrested Arthur Jackson and Ford Sizemore on murder warrants issued by County Judge W. J. R. Howard.
The Municipal Art Society charged yesterday that city officials had issued conflicting and misleading statements regarding new plans for improved lighting of Park Avenue.

When the Chinese Communist radio announced that the representatives of the Chinese Government had just seventy-two hours to accept Mao Tze-tung's surrender terms it tore away the last shred of pretense that what was happening in Peiping was a "peace conference." If the Government wants "peace" it can capitulate. It won't get it otherwise.

BOSTON, April 17 (AP) -- Billy Southworth's Boston Braves will get right down to the business of defending their National League pennant tomorrow with their ace hurler, Johnny Sain, slated to oppose Ken Heintzelman and the Philadelphia Phillies at Braves Field.

The addition of 6,441 cases to the city's public assistance rolls in March -- the largest single monthly increase in eleven years -- was reported yesterday by Welfare Commissioner Raymond M. Hilliard.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., April 17 (AP) -- The Rhode Island Reds won the American Hockey League championship tonight by defeating the Hershey Bears, 4 to 2, in the seventh and deciding game of their Calder Cup series. The auditorium crowd of 7,556 was the largest ever to attend a hockey game in this city.

CHICAGO, April 17 -- A plea for the study of the early beginnings of allergy in young children to prevent their becoming chronic asthmatics or hay fever or eczema sufferers in later life was made today by Dr. Bret Ratner. Dr. Ratner, who is Professor of Clinical Pediatrics at New York Medical College, spoke at the annual meeting of the American College of Allergists here.

The National Industrial Advertisers Association's twenty-seventh annual conference, to be held June 12-15 at the Statler Hotel in Buffalo, will be attended by approximately 1,000 of its 3,400 members, it was announced over the weekend by Blaine G. Wiley, executive secretary.

An audience of more than 2,800 persons, in which the women out-numbered the men by eight to one, filled Carnegie Hall last night for Nelson Eddy's first New York recital in five years. One of the listeners was Margaret Truman, daughter of the President.

LAKE SUCCESS, April 17 -- Brig. Gen. Carlos P. Romulo, head of the Philippine delegation to the United Nations General Assembly, called on the United States today to follow up the North Atlantic treaty with measures to improve the economic development of the nations of the Pacific and Asia.

The American Cancer Society has started to distribute information on the new blood test for cancer, described on Saturday at the annual meeting of the American Association for Cancer Research in Detroit, it was announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP) -- Harry Truman, a fellow who knows what it's like to be a decided underdog, will open the 1949 baseball season tomorrow and then root for the underdog Senators.

Evidently the vogue for feeding bananas to infants and children is responsible for developing a taste for the food. As a nation we show a decided predilection for the yellow fruit from the tropics. And if anyone doubts the truth of that statement, he should recall wartime and the lengths to which consumers went to snare a bunch or two of bananas from one of the rare shipments that used to come in.

There are many theories about what is the worst thing that can happen to a man. Essayists have hazarded unprovable guesses ranging from money to marriage, stressing the dangers lying in an oversupply or complete lack of either one or both.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- The 1949 campaign of the American Red Cross for $60,000,000 has been oversubscribed. The passing of the goal is on a national basis, and some communities, including New York and Los Angeles, have not yet made their quotas.

LONDON, April 17 -- On the eve of Eire's complete withdrawal from the British Commonwealth, the Ministers of the seven remaining Dominions are making their way to London for a conference at which a formula will be sought for keeping India and the other Dominions that may become republics within the British family of nations.

CHICAGO, April 17 -- Prices of Diesel-electric locomotives are being reduced about 5 per cent, effective immediately, by the Electro-Motive Division of the General Motors Corporation, C. R. Osborn, general manager, announced today. He said this is the first general price reduction in the industry since 1939.
MIAMI BEACH, Fla., April 17 (AP) -- Earl Cochell of San Francisco today defeated Gardner Larned of Rollins College, Fla., in straight sets to win the first annual Good Neighbor tennis championships.

"Magnolia Alley," opening tonight at the Mansfield, introduces the following trio to Broadway: Lester Cutler, a film producer, who is sponsoring the George Batson comedy; Jackie Cooper, screen actor, who hasn't been seen on the local stage, and Carl Shain, who makes his bow as a Main Stem director.

One quarter of all money raised in the current Cancer Fund drive for $1,250,000 will be allocated by the New York Cancer Committee and the American Cancer Society to provide fellowships, grants - in - aid and funds for institutional research so that scientists may continue their mass attack on cancer without interruption.

About 86 per cent of the retailers selling worsted and gabardine non-patch pocket suits from $45 to $60 prefer single-breasted suits to two-button, with the two-button model favored principally in metropolitan areas. This and other findings are contained in a survey of 312 leading retailers by Gramercy Park Clothes, Max Udell Sons Co., Inc.
BALTIMORE, April 17 (AP) -- The Doc says Joe DiMaggio is "doing very well" -- well enough to leave Baltimore, where he has been undergoing treatments for his sore heel.
HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., April 17 (AP) -- Horse racing's equivalent of the World Series starts less than three weeks from today and it looks like a struggle to the last wire.

Airlines report increases in all kinds of air traffic out of New York for the first quarter of 1949 large enough to indicate that the year will be profitable for both domestic and international carriers. The first quarter's operations, owing to bad weather, usually constitute a heavy debit item in the annual tabulations.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 17 -- A satisfactory snowpack in the Sierra and big public and private construction projects for power and irrigation purposes made northern and central Californians optimistic today over water and power supplies for 1949.

A housekeeper who broke her arm helping her employer change an automobile tire, a maid who fractured her knee when she fell off a chair attempting to wind a wall clock, a laundress who toppled out of a second-floor window while hanging out her wash, are among 781 domestic employes in New York State who collected disability claims amounting to more than a half million dollars in 1948, the State Workmen's Compensation Board revealed yesterday.

HOUSTON, Tex., April 17 (AP) -- The River Oaks Country Club tennis tournament, with its greatest field of amateur stars in history, opens tomorrow with forty men's singles matches. Only two of the nine seeded players will see action the first day.

A development of potentially far-reaching consequences has been initiated by an announcement by President Rhee of Korea that discussions are under way with the United States for the withdrawal of the last American troops from that country "in the course of several months."

Henry A. Wallace renewed last night his attack on the North Atlantic pact and said it was clear that it might not be long before United States troops were sent to Western Europe to man the weapons to be provided by the pact.

LAKE SUCCESS, April 18 -Over vigorous Soviet objections, the Social Committee of the United Nations General Assembly approved tonight the first part of an article on censorship for incorporation into an international convention on news-gathering.

As one to whom the Easter Parade has been an Institution through two generations, the Old New Yorker has a word to say about Sunday's record turnout. To him, it was very different from what Easter Parades used to be -- and different from any other parade.

In the Kentucky mountains, about fifteen miles from the little village of Manchester, there in a branch called Little Sextons creek and at the head of the creek is a lonesome hollow. There Henry Hornsby was born in 1910 and there he stayed until 1928 without ever seeing a railroad train or a typewriter or ever riding in an automobile.
WASHINGTON, April 18 -- The Supreme Court ruled, 5 to 4, today that a one-sided "quickie" divorce such as some of those obtained in Reno could be declared illegal.

Competitors in the international masters tournament at the Easter Chess Festival in Southsea England, resumed play yesterday after a week-end interval and there was a significant break among the three leaders, according to reports from London.
A psychosomatic clinic for persons suffering from gastric ulcers, hypertension, asthma and allergies has been opened at Lebanon Hospital, the oldest general hospital in the Bronx.

Homemakers care far more about demonstrating good taste in their homes than retailers and manufacturers ever would dream possible, John Gerald, design and merchandise consultant, told an audience of home furnishings students last evening.

" Mr. Belvedere Goes to College," the comedy which opened at the Roxy on Friday, set a new Easter week-end record for the house by grossing $80,317 for the three-day period ending Sunday night. This mark tops by $30,000 the figure set over a similar period by "Sitting Pretty," it was announced by the management yesterday.

ALL three local teams will open the new baseball season in town today. The Giants will visit the Dodgers at Ebbets Field and the Yankees will be hosts to Washington at the Stadium. Here's an oddity, though. All three teams will have different managers than they did on inaugural day a year ago and that's something that never before happened in our village.

A noticeable characteristic of contemporary music is its attempt to avoid cliches. The varying degrees in which they succeeded distinguished the compositions of Louise Talma and Allen Sapp on last night's Composers Forum at the McMillin Theatre, Columbia University.

WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP) -- A. B. Harper, Fort Smith, Ark., today submitted a high bid of $5,257,000 to the War Assets Administration for the purchase of a 100-mile natural gas pipeline in Louisiana.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- President Truman, in a message sent tonight to the opening session of the continental congress of the Daughters of the American Revolution, said that grave issues face our country at home and abroad.

After ten months of discussion initiated in July, 1948, the wine industry has adopted a voluntary statement of principles outlining ethical, traditional and constructive wine advertising practices, the Wine Conference of America, 717 Market Street, San Francisco, announced yesterday. The conference represents nineteen national and regional vintners' associations.

A strike against the New York, Ontario Western Railroad was called yesterday by four operating brotherhoods, shutting down several freight links between the Pennsylvania coal fields and New England and one of the principal passenger lines between this area and the Catskill Mountains.

FRANKFORT, Germany, April 18 -- Seventy thousand troops, virtually all the United States has in Germany, went into action today against a mythical "aggressor" in the largest war games ever engaged in by the United States Army in Europe.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- President Truman knocked off from affairs of state for a while today to enjoy baseball, and to receive a trophy for having been the best guesser last year when the ball season opened. He guessed that New York would win the first game.

SEOUL, Korea, April 18 -- United States representatives here and Korean Government officials have begun discussions in preparation for withdrawal of American troops from Korea within the next several months, President Syngman Rhee announced at a special press conference this morning.

DUBLIN, April 18 -- 0n this day of rejoicing, religious services and military parades that marked the inauguration of the Republic of Ireland, Premier John A. Costello said this afternoon that the ending of partition would b simple "if we could get round a conference table with good-will."
The 1949 world series will be an all-Boston affair in the opinion of the nation's major league baseball writers.
WASHINGTON, April 18 -- Refusal of the Civil Aeronautics Board to revise air line mail pay rates retroactively was sustained today by the Supreme Court in a 6-to-2 decision.

Jess Larson, War Assets Administrator, disclosed in Federal Court yesterday that he had agreed to postpone final action on the sale of the Government-owned aluminum reduction plant at Massena, N. Y., to the Aluminum Company of America until the court ruled on the anti-trust proceeding against the company.

ALBANY, April 18 -- Anticipating a last-minute rush to pay the state income tax by tomorrow night's deadline, the State Tax Commission announced today that district offices in New York City and elsewhere would remain open until 9 P. M. to receive returns.

The recent action of the ECA in establishing a division for the development of colonial areas, and the designation of Dr. Isaiah Bowman to head it, strongly implements the program announced by President Truman in his inaugural message. By itself it is a praiseworthy development. But considered along with our national policy toward our own colonies it is certainly an anomaly.
A move was started yesterday to have the daily double declared illegal at New York tracks.

Meeting in the church proper, 317 parishioners of the 490 said by Dr. Melish to be eligible to vote, rejected last night four vestrymen who have been opposed to Dr. Melish and elected in their stead five members of the congregation who will support the rector in the removal dispute.

A noteworthy loan exhibition of paintings and drawings by the highly individual post-impressionist artist, Georges Seurat, has been assembled by the Knoedler Galleries for the benefit of the Home for the Destitute Blind. A preview reception will be held at the galleries this afternoon from 4 to 7 o'clock at which the admission charge will be $6.

Price reductions ranging up to 6 per cent marked the opening of several fall lines of men's clothing here and in other markets yesterday, although many lines showed practically no change from previous quotations.

After record tractor sales in the first quarter, orders now indicate an even higher peak during the second quarter because buyers in five major national markets are still ordering heavily, W. K. Cox, advertising manager, the Caterpillar Tractor Company, disclosed yesterday at the Commodore Hotel.

Combined net asset value of the United States Foreign Securities Corporation and the Unite States International Securities Corporation as of last March 31 amounted to $68,664,736, the quarterly report disclosed yesterday.

Israel is not and will never be a warlike nation, Moshe Sharett, Foreign Minister of the new state, said yesterday afternoon at a meeting of 300 Zionists and civic leaders in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, where he received a completed engineers' report for creation of a Jordan Valley Authority involving plans for irrigation and hydro-electric development in Palestine.

Whether it be a simple or formal wedding, in town or country, Gimbels was ready with a host of attractive suggestions for the important day as well as for the trousseau in a bridal showing last night at the store.

BOSTON, April 18 -- The Most Rev. Richard J. Cushing, Archbishop of Boston, moved tonight to put an end to the public controversy caused by the action of Boston College in dismissing four lay instructors who had accused the institution of heresy in its teachings of Roman Catholic doctrine.

With the heavy construction industry now "willing and even anxious" to enter into firm advance contracts, four major projects in the city to cost $190,000,000 are progressing ahead of schedule, it was reported yesterday.

Yale opens its rowing season Saturday against Pennsylvania and Columbia on the Schuylkill and the occasion will be notable for the fact that the Elis, through the body of the race, will abandon their high stroke of the past two seasons for the low-beat characteristic of most college crews.

RANGOON, Burma, Tuesday, April 19 (AP) -- The Government announced today the surrender of Karen rebels in the army center of Maymo, forty miles north of Mandalay, and said that its forces had completed reoccupation of the city.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 17 -- Hamid Frangie, Lebanese Foreign Minister, went to Damascus today to confer with Gen. Husni Zayim, Syrian Premier, continuing the series of visits and counter-visits among Arab leaders that is accompanying their efforts to patch up the unity of the Arab states.

Although the weather has been discouraging in some areas, the all around fishing reports are better than fair and many of those who have persisted despite rain and wind have been rewarded by fairly good catches, both in fresh and salt water.

The controversy between the vestry of Holy Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church in Brooklyn and the Rev. Dr. John Howard Melish, rector, was brought to civil trial yesterday before Justice Meier Steinbrink in Brooklyn Supreme Court.

On the heels of the Berlin Airlift's amazing achievement of last Friday and Saturday comes news that the American radio station in Berlin will soon be silenced because there are no funds to pay for it. Just as we have a splendid story to tell the people of metropolitan Berlin, including those in the Russian sector, we are about to lose one of the most effective means of telling it.
VIRGINIA BEACH, Va., April 18 (AP) -- Bobby Locke of Johannesburg, South Africa, kept a promise today.

VIENNA, April 18 -- The Hungarian Government, adhering to the slogan that "every kulak is guilty of something," is liquidating the rich peasants more quickly than was done in its time in Soviet Russia. This slogan was coined by an editorial writer in the Peasant party organ Szabad Szo, which supported it with the statement:

Plans for the opening this summer of Camp Poyntelle for underprivileged children of all races and creeds at Pontelle, Pa., high in the Pocono Mountains, were announced yesterday by the Infants Welfare League Camp, Inc., of 381 West End Avenue, sponsors of the project.

The attempt to indoctrinate American Jews with the idea that Israel is their homeland is artificial, presumptuous and dangerously misleading, Rabbi Irving F. Reichert of San Francisco, vice president of the American Council for Judaism, declared here last night at the annual meeting of the New York chapter of the organization.

Running away from the opposition with the greatest of ease, Up Beat scored in the Bay Ridge Classified Handicap at the Jamaica Race Track yesterday. The victory of the 4-year-old son of Pharamond II was popular with the 21,467 fans, who backed him into heavy favoritism over four others in the six-furlong dash.

TOKYO, April 18 -- The Japanese Government has completed plans for the mass discharge of super- numerary Government employes demanded by the Allies as an economy measure. According to a draft program 750,000 bureaucrats will be separated from the payrolls -- a big bite out of Japan's 1,700,000 Government workers.
A "modern Paul Revere" rode down Broadway and Fifth Avenue on the back of a handsome brown horse yesterday afternoon as an appeal to New Yorkers in behalf of peace and world federation.

While a cold rain splashed on the sidewalk outside, cottons glowed yesterday on the third floor of Lord Taylor with all the friendly warmth of midsummer fashions. The thirty-three dresses being shown to customers and representatives of the press were all by Sara Ripault.

CHICAGO, April 18 -- Wilbur H. Norton, former president of Montgomery Ward Co., challenged today the assertion of the company's chairman, Sewell L. Avery, that last year's series of executive resignations resulted from a "conspiracy.'' Mr. Norton's statement was upheld by other former officials.

WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP) -- The South Carolina Public Service Authority failed today to get a United States Court review of its unsuccessful efforts to buy the capital stock of the South Carolina Power Company.
Manchester, Conn., announced yesterday that it will receive bids April 26 on an issue of $1,689,000 of school bonds dated May 1, 1949 and due on each May 1 from 1950 to 1969.

NEWARK, N. J., April 18 -- New Jersey's polls will be open tomorrow from 7 A. M. to 8 P. M., bringing to a close a primary campaign notable for its apathy. Unofficial estimates are that no more than 500,000 persons will vote.

PINEHURST, N. C., April 18 (AP) -- Defending Champion Harue Ward of Tarboro put together nines of 35 and 34 for a three-under-par 69 today to win the medal in the forty-ninth annual North and South amateur golf tournament.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores declined 3 per cent last week compared with the corresponding period last year, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The drop for the four weeks ended last Saturday also was 3 per cent.
Nylon fabrics were featured in a fashion show at McCreery's yesterday afternoon. The costumes were styled from McCall patterns and included beachwear, town clothes, evening and wedding gowns.
HONOLULU, April 18 (AP) -- Howard N. Ripperger, 54 years old, of 33-40 157th Street, Flushing, Queens, was brutally beaten and killed last night in a hotel room.

The F. W. Woolworth Company will occupy 10,000 square feet of space in the Glen Oaks shopping center in Bellerose, Queens, for the newest of retail outlets, George M. Gross of the Gross-Morton Company, builder - owner, announced yesterday.
Federal Judge Samuel H. Kaufman severely castigated yesterday the attorney for a small group of bondholders which is trying to force the Third Avenue Transit Corporation into bankruptcy.

Reflecting largely the purchase of additional equipment, the long-term debt of the Great Northern Railway last year was increased $12,791,294, going to $248,352,115 on Dec. 31, 1948, according to the road's annual report. However, F. J. Gavin, the president, said the road's fixed charges of about $7,500,000 last year were $175,000 less than in 1947 and the lowest in fifty years.

ATLANTA, April 18 (AP) -- What was described later as "premature'' speculation about the next general manager of New York's Metropolitan Opera was touched off today by Edward Johnson, the present general manager.

Seton Hall will play host to thirty-two colleges, ninety-eight high schools and five prep schools at its third annual relay carnival at Newark City Stadium on Friday and Saturday, but considerations of hospitality won't keep the Pirates from trying to steal their own show.

PHILADELPHIA, April 18 -Max Robb, vice president and general merchandise manager of Lit Brothers, was elected today executive vice president to succeed Walter T. Grosscup, retiring on May 1 at the age of 65.

A Negro witness at the Communist trial testified yesterday to plans made by the Communist International at Moscow to set up a separate Negro nation in the South as part of a proposed violent revolution and Communist dictatorship in the United States.

Forty persons were injured, one of them seriously, in two bus accidents due to skidding on the wet streets caused by rain here yesterday. In one of the accidents a car collided with a bus and in the other a bus struck an elevated pillar.

A tea and exhibition of West African handicrafts and sculpture sponsored by the Afro Arts Bazaar was held yesterday afternoon at the Theresa Hotel, Seventh Avenue and 125th Street. The bazaar is a gift shop opened recently at 9 West 125th Street by Mrs. Estelle M. Osborne and Miss Ella Moten as an outlet for handicrafts of Negro peoples and a cultural center for Negro arts.

Opponents of the proposed merger of the Congregational Christian Churches, and the Evangelical and Reformed denomination have filed suit in Kings County Supreme Court to test the validity of the union, it became known yesterday.
LAKE SUCCESS, April 18 -- Poland asked the United Nations today to intervene in the case of two trade unionists condemned to death by the Greek Government.

SALONIKA, Greece, April 18 -- Gregory Stachtopoulos, on trial for his life before a Salonika court for the part that he is alleged to have played in the killing of George Polk, told in almost leisurely fashion today the story of his own political Odyssey.
Gaetano Annalora, 123 1/2 pounds, Italian featherweight, defeated Teddy Swain, 127, of Toronto, in the feature eight-round bout before 1,615 persons at the St. Nicholas Arena last night.

BOSTON, April 18 -- An agreement freezing the wages of laborers on heavy construction and highway projects on a state-wide basis until August, 1950, was filed today with John J. DelMonte, the Commissioner of Labor and Industries.

DAMASCUS, Syria, April 18 -- De facto recognition of the new Syrian regime by Turkey was indicated tonight in an official announcement that the Turkish Minister had called on Foreign Minister Adel Arslan following the formation of a new Syrian Government over the week-end.

When the failure rate and the age of the bankrupt concern are considered, the number of business failures during 1948 and the early part of this year is not significant, it was stated yesterday by A. D. Whiteside, president of Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 18 -- Sessue Hayakawa, Japanese film star of Hollywood's silent era, has been engaged by Twentieth Century-Fox to play Colonel Suga in "Three Came Home," the Nunnally Johnson production of Agnes Newton Keith's book about her experiences in a Japanese internment camp.

TOKYO, April 18 -- Public reaction to the recently concluded Socialist party convention is, on the whole, unfavorable. Although some little progress had been made toward creating a program for the future, the newspapers generally appear to feel the party distinguished itself more for fist fights than political leadership.
WASHINGTON April 18 (AP) -- The text of President Truman's statement on a report of a special commission on labor-management relations in the atomic energy industry follows:
PARIS, April 18 -- High French officials said today the Soviet Union was "seeking contacts" with the Western powers for discussion of Berlin and Germany.

Groucho Marx is the latest of the big names in radio who may be making the switch to CBS in the fall. There is nothing definite to report at the moment except that Elgin, sponsor of the Marx show, is anxious to keep the comedy quiz program adjacent to Bing Crosby.

Twenty-six United States warships steamed out of New York Harbor yesterday morning after a week-end visit in the course of which nearly 60,000 persons were guests aboard eight units tied up along the Hudson River. Chief interest centered about two aircraft carriers, the Franklin D. Roosevelt J and the Leyte, which, with three destroyers and three escort carriers, were open to the public on Saturday and Easter Day.
WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP) -- The Federal Court of Appeals upheld today the conviction of Gearhart Eisler, German-born Communist, on passport fraud charges.

WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP) -- The House Committee on Un-American Activities said today that Communists had engineered the Paris "peace" conference to stir atomic and other scientists to disobey their Governments.

Before the Senate adjourned yesterday it was in the second day of its discussion of the Ellender Housing Bill, introduced by the Louisiana Senator with the support of ten other Democrats and eleven Republicans. Housing bills are always complicated. Their objectives are not.

LAKE SUCCESS, April 18 -Cuba proposed today the creation of a special fifteen-member United Nations committee to conduct on-the-spot investigations whether human rights and fundamental freedoms had been violated in a series of prosecutions of religious leaders by the Communist Governments of Hungary, Bulgaria and Yugoslavia.

The training orchestra of the National Orchestral Association gave its final concert of the season last night. Following the custom, its director, Leon Barzin, instituted last year, the closing program afforded a "re-hearing" to musicians who distinguished themselves during the season.

Webb Knapp, Inc., and the American Securities Corporation have joined with the 1407 Broadway Realty Corporation, of which S. M. Hirsch is president, in forming a new company to complete the forty-two story office and showroom building at 1407 Broadway, it was announced yesterday.

Some markets abroad for securities and commodities remained closed yesterday in observance of Easter Monday. The London Stock Exchange was closed as well as the Toronto and Montreal Stock Exchanges. Both the London and Singapore markets for rubber also observed the holiday.
A deftly-worded invitation to end the student strike at City College was extended and turned down last night at a meeting of the Board of Higher Education.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- In his recent Cardozo lecture before the New York City Bar Association Associate Justice Douglas of the Supreme Court, among other important statements, expressed his judicial philosophy as follows:

LAKE SUCCESS, April 18 -- Pakistan and India today gave their general endorsement to a Soviet proposal that the General Assembly establish a collective United Nations trusteeship over the former Italian colonies in Africa instead of handing them over to individual countries for administration.

Bedding manufacturers are offering better quality in some mattresses at unchanged prices and these offerings are expected to increase substantially, retailers reported yesterday. They said that improved ticking is supplied on a limited number of both innerspring and box mattresses.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- An attempt to attach to the ratification of the North Atlantic treaty a highly controversial proposal for a fundamental alteration of the United Nations is being prepared by a "considerable" group of Senators.
WASHINGTON, April 18 -- The Far Eastern Commission has extended for another nine months the period during which countries may examine Japanese industries for technical and scientific information.

A fire that started in a defective kerosene stove a little before 2:30 P. M. yesterday, caused the deaths of a widowed mother and two of her children and critically injured another of her children. It burned out one side of a four-story brick tenement building at 593 Quincy Street, Brooklyn.

Ira Haupt Co., members of the New York Stock Exchange, announced that Dr. Thatcher C. Jones, Gregory I. Harrington and Stephen Kovacs have joined the institutional department. Walter E. Sullivan has joined the municipal bond department and Richard M. Seidlitz, the mutual funds department.
BOSTON, April 18 (AP) -- A field of 180 marathon runners of all sizes and nationalities are ready for tomorrow's fifty-third Boston A. A. 26 miles, 385 yards classic.

Your editorial "The Libraries Win An Ally," in the issue of March 4, and your editorial "State Aid to Libraries," which appeared on April 14, are recent examples of THE TIMES' long and effective crusade for the public libraries of New York State.
The United States should consider increasing its armed forces in Western Germany until the Atlantic pact becomes fully effective, Paul Reynaud, former Premier of France, said her yesterday.

Following the lead of some men's wear manufacturers who have cut prices for fall, Joselli Suits, Inc., will open its women's fall line with reductions ranging up to $4 on its medium-priced suits, it was learned yesterday.

NEWPORT NEWS, Va., April 18 -- With a minimum of ceremony but a good deal of secrecy, the keel for the mighty and controversial super-aircraft carrier United States was formally set in place today with no final assurance that a vessel would ever come of it.
Dr. Ralph J. Bunche, acting United Nations mediator for Palestine, arrived here yesterday from his post abroad to give to the Security Council a final account of his difficult mission.
WASHINGTON, April 18 -- The State Department confirmed today reports from the Korean capital that talks looking to a date for withdrawing all American troops from that country were in progress.

Tammany Hall moved yesterday to concentrate its strength behind Municipal Court Justice Benjamin Shalleck, its nominee for Congress in the Twentieth District, where the organization's strength is due to be tested by the independent candidacy of Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. in a special election May 17.

Five minutes after he had finished rehearsing for a radio appearance, Henry M. Roe, 101 years old, a messenger for President Lincoln in the Civil War, died yesterday of a heart attack in the Columbia Broadcasting System Building, 485 Madison Avenue.

Former President Herbert Hoover urged a reduction in the number of Federal employes and streamlining of governmental functions last night in the first of five radio programs over the Columbia Broadcasting System.
A score of families moved yesterday into clean, comparatively spacious new homes in the first building ready at Lillian Wald Houses, a New York City Housing Authority low-rent project.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- Critics of the Administration backed national housing program asked for and got today an explanation of the reason for proposing Federal grants, running up to $500 each, for improving the homes and structures on submarginal farms.

The former J. R. Maxwell estate in the Red Spring Colony section of Glen Cove, L. I., has been purchased by Homes Harbor, Inc., for improvement with ranch-style houses on half-acre plots to be sold in the $30,000-$40,000 price range. The property comprises twenty-two acres with a frontage of 800 feet on Long Island Sound.
SHANGHAI, April 18 -- Fears are rising in this city that an artificial rice famine will result from the current accelerating inflation.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- Just as if it wasn't his idea in the first place, the Washington Senators opened the American League baseball season today by demonstrating to President Truman that perseverance is an extremely handy quality, especially when you're behind in the last half of the ninth inning.

A French textile engineer was the narrator yesterday at the premiere of an extraordinary motion picture -- a documentary that depicts the daily routine in a Nazi camp where he was a prisoner for five years.

A Gilbert and Sullivan company born on a yacht will give its twenty-fifth anniversary performance this week by the grace of baby sitters and a church that allowed its basement to be converted temporarily into a set-building studio.

Ten delegates from nine Western Europe countries arrived yesterday on the Queen Mary for the three-day conference of the central committee of the International Metalworkers Federation, which starts tomorrow in Washington.

Else Fink, who has sung in opera and concert in many countries abroad, made her New York debut at the Town Hall last night. Her soprano voice, her program and her singing had many things in their favor. It was an interesting debut, but it left one with the feeling that Miss Fink could and should do better.

ALBANY, April 18 -- Three bills designed to improve state programs for assistance and rehabilitation of physically handicapped children, particularly victims of cerebral palsy, were approved today by Governor Dewey.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- An emergency fact - finding board opened hearings today on the dispute involving express clerks which resulted in a five-week shutdown of the operations of the Railway Express Agency in New York. The clerks returned to work today.

Columbia University has established for the first time in its 195 years an automatic retirement plan, effective in 1950, which sets 65 years as the retiring age for administrative personnel and 68 for academic officers, Albert C. Jacobs, university provost, announced yesterday.

A new approach to the problems facing the mental hospitals of the nation marked the Mental Hospital Institute held in Philadelphia. The men on the psychiatric firing line -- the hospital superintendents -- met under the auspices of the American Psychiatric Association to find out what they might do to comfort better the 650,000 patients in their care.
The cotton market was moderately active yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange and final prices were 3 to 15 points net lower.

Last midnight Colonial Airlines established a record in safe air transportation. It had operated for nineteen years without death or injury to any passenger or any crew member. The small airline had flown a total of 250,545,622 passenger-miles over its system of 3,182 miles, including its daily flights between Bermuda and New York.

Nearly two decades ago Adolf Berle Jr. and Gardiner Means published "The Modern Corporation and Private Property." The work was an elaborate study of the structure and operations of American stock companies, and to the student of corporation finance it provided a mine of new and interesting material.

ST. LOUIS, April 18 (AP) -- The Browns filed suit today to evict the Cardinals from Sportsman's Park, but attorneys predicted legal delays would assure the National League club of a home throughout the 1949 baseball season.

For a long time yesterday it looked as if the five little kittens that were born last week to Blackie, the St. Barnabas House cat, were going to cost somebody an average of $160 apiece. This was because Blackie's feline instinct for privacy had led her to give birth to the kittens in a hanging ceiling.

NANKING, April 18 -- Fuller information on the "final' twenty-four-point Communist peace draft, submitted to the Nanking Government under a deadline expiring forty-eight hours from tonight, disclosed today that the Communists had confronted Acting President Li Tsung-jen with what amounted to an instrument of unconditional surrender.

Prices on the New York Stock Exchange continued yesterday to fluctuate narrowly. Closing quotations showed gains and losses pretty well divided. A few selected industrial issues broke out of the rut and showed gains, of more than a point.

MOSCOW, April 18 (UP) -- The Soviet organ Pravda today devoted three columns to a speech by Chinese Communist Jen Pi-shih who called for complete destruction of remnants of the Nationalist Government's "reactionary armed forces and ruling bureaucracy."

A 36-year-old ex-convict who had been picked up by the police Saturday night for questioning in the Bronx strangling of 8-year-old Jackie Goldsmith made a break for freedom and was shot in the left thigh and recaptured at 8 o'clock yesterday morning.

CHICAGO, April 18 -- May wheat, which had been showing independent strength of late, reversed its action on the Chicago Board of Trade today and showed a heavy undertone, closing about at the bottom because of scattered selling which disclosed a lack of aggressive support.

ALBANY, April 18 -- Governor Dewey announced at a news conference this afternoon that he had arranged to make a six-week vacation trip to Europe. He will leave on May 5, immediately after the thirty-day bill period ends.

If, as Jessie Royce Landis, the star of "Magnolia Alley," kept insisting last night, there's nothing like a mint julep to make a hot day hotter, it is also true that there's nothing like a weak comedy to make a warm theatre warmer. Perhaps, indeed, the place for George Batson's new play, is the cooler climate of the summer theatres, where it was tried out last season.

Irregularity prevailed in the commodity markets yesterday. Wool-top futures closed 0.5 cent higher to 0.5 cent lower on sales of 235,000 pounds, while grease-wool contracts finished with losses of 0.5 to 1.5 cents on transactions of 210,000 pounds.

The New York repertory theatre company, formed several months ago by Sam Wanamaker, Jos Ferrer and Richard Aldrich, announced yesterday that it had consolidated its plans and financial resources with those of Theatre Incorporated. Henceforth, the repertory project will function under the auspices of TI.
HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., April 18 (AP) -- Murray Hill Farm's Boo Boo Shoo displayed superior mud-running ability in winning the $4,500 Bush River Purse today.

WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP) -- Highly accurate weather predictions for twelve months in advance are possible, Dr. Charles G. Abbot, research associate at the Smithsonian Institution, reported today. He bases the system on periodic fluctuations in the heat radiation of the sun.
LONDON, April 18 (Reuters) -- A surprise defeat at Birmingham today deprived Portsmouth of an Easter hat-trick but did not reduce its four-point lead over Newcastle in English soccer.

CHICAGO, April 18 -- Added information about the Goethe bicentennial convocation and music festival, to be held June 27-July 16 at Aspen, Col., was made public today by Dr. Robert M. Hutchins, chancellor of the University of Chicago and chairman of the Goethe Bicentennial Foundation.

LAKE SUCCESS, April 18 -- A proposal that the United Nations convoke an international economic conference to draft a program for halting a world-wide trend toward recession was made to a subcommission of the Economic and Social Council today by R. F. Harrod, British economist.

" Abe Lincoln of Pigeon Creek," a new novel by William E. Wilson, is scheduled for fall publication by Whittlesey House. The book is based on the life of Lincoln during the years he spent as a boy in southern Indiana. Mr. Wilson is the author of "The Wabash" and "Crescent City."

ATHENS, April 18 (AP) -- A General Staff spokesman said today that Greek commandos, operating near the Albanian border, had driven Communist-led guerrillas from a strongly fortified area in hand-to-hand fighting.

The nation-wide 1949 campaign of the American Red Cross has been successful, with the quota of $60,000,000 already oversubscribed by more than $2,000,000 and some reports not yet complete. Americans may take deep satisfaction in this evidence of accepted responsibility in many fields of service.
Your contribution to the current Cancer Fund campaign for $1,250,000 will enable the New York City Cancer Committee of the American Cancer Society to continue its program of public education.

COPENHAGEN, April 18 (Reuters) -- Dave Freeman, United States Thomas Cup player and holder of the all-England badminton title, today won the Danish international championship when he beat Malaya's Ooi Teik Hock, 15 -- 11, 14 -- 18, 17 -- 15.

REIDSVILLE, N. C., April 18 (UP) -- Mrs. Joe Goodman Sr., who reported her son kidnapped and ransomed for $30,000 in Beverly Hills, Calif., admitted here today that the story was a hoax to conceal her racetrack losses from her husband, officers reported.

Commissioner of Investigation John M. Murtagh, who is heading the inquiry into the waterfront crime problem, directed yesterday that steamship operators "without further delay assert authority and control" over piers leased from the city, to end pier loader racketeering.

With one of this city's entries hoping for the best though braced for a time to receive the worst, while the other two view their immediate prospects with singular confidence, the 1949 major league baseball campaign will open in the metropolitan area on two fronts today -- the Yankee Stadium and Ebbets Field.

Tonight's events: Philadelphia Orchestra, Eugene Ormandy, conductor, Claude Raines, narrator, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Chamber Art Society Orchestra, Robert Craft, conductor. Town Hall, 8:30; Kay Fredericks, soprano, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30; Alice M. Ditson, Chamber Music Concert, McMillin Theatre, Columbia University, 8:30; Notre Dame University Glee Club, Daniel H. Pedtke, director, Cathedral High School, 8:30.

SCRANTON, Pa., April 18 -- The pilot model for the production-control plan John L. Lewis is seeking to apply in the country's soft-coal mines is already functioning by voluntary agreement in the anthracite mines of Northeastern Pennsylvania.
WASHINGTON, April 18 -- A Senate Commerce subcommittee asked the Reconstruction Finance Corporation today to supply it with all possible data on the financial conditions of the nation's airlines.
RENO, Nev., April 18 (UP) -- Nevada's libera divorce laws require that defendants who do not appear in person in divorce hearings must be served personally with a summons if at all possible.
One of this country's most famous documents -- the Gettysburg Address -- will be on public exhibition today at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street.
You have made serious errors in your reply to my letter of April 16, giving an incorrect date, and your research as to what happened on that date was inaccurate.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- The Civil Aeronautics Board today canceled privileges for the "large irregular air carriers" as of May 20. After that date each of about sixty such companies, operating some 200 aircraft, will be licensed to fly only on the basis of individual conditions, which are to be strictly examined.

Despite sporadic picketing, paid attendance at the Military Government German Industry Exhibit in Rockefeller Center has averaged 8,000 a day since the opening on April 9, exhibit officials said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -American justice in the trials of seventy-three Nazi storm troopers accused of slaughtering eighty American prisoners of war near Malmedy, Belgium, during the Battle of the Bulge went under investigation itself today before a Senate Armed Services subcommittee.

Purchase of ten additional fire engines will be made possible through savings from changed specifications in requisitions for thirty-five of the vehicles, Fire Commissioner Frank J. Quayle said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP) -- The Commercial Telegraphers Union, AFL, today asked Congress to reject a request by the Western Union Company for certain exemptions fro proposed revisions of the minimum wage law.

BOSTON, April 18 (AP) -- Ken Heintzelman, starting his tenth major league season at the ripe age of 33, ruined Boston's first National League pennant raising in thirty-four years by hurling the Phillies to a 4-0 shutout over the Braves today, on a cold and windswept field.

The backlog of export drafts on Latin America sent out for collection but not yet paid increased $10,000,000 in March to $138,000,000, according to reports prepared by twelve New York banks. The data, compiled monthly and issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, is based on the collection experience of the banks in trade between United States exporters and Latin-American importers.
