BUENOS AIRES, April 18 -- After an all-night convention, the Radical party, which makes up the Opposition to President Juan D. Peron, decided by a vote of 80 to 16 that its national and provincial legislators could take the oath to the new Constitution.

It would be strange indeed if the world headquarters of man's noblest earthly aspirations, with its great tower reaching to the sky and its six city blocks of surrounding area, were too small to have a room where a man could bow his head to confess his need for divine help.
All things considered, Joseph Schulhof, his wife Charlotte, and their son Peter are on good terms with fate.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- President Truman's special commission on labor relations disputes in atomic energy plants recommended today appointment of a three-member panel to adjust such controversies in the background of a "broad code of conduct" outlined by the commission.

A labeling program for bread like that now used for cattle feeds is urged by Dr. Clive M. McCay, Professor of Nutrition at Cornell University. On every bag of feed is printed the exact proportion of ingredients used to prepare the mixture, plus the amount of nutrients in terms of protein and calcium.

PARIS, April 18 -- As delegates to the forthcoming peace congress continued to arrive in Paris from many European countries, it was realiably reported here tonight that two of the group of five Italian delegates had been prevented from crossing the French frontier at Modane earlier today.

ANNECY, France, April 18 -- Britain believes that her exports to the dollar area can be expanded without subsidies on the basis of present prices and quality. Harold Wilson, President of the Board of Trade, said here today.

WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP) -The Supreme Court today ordered a lower court to decide who should share $2,765,205 placed in escrow by a gas-well company while it fought a rate-cutting order. The question is whether the money should go to local distributing concerns, ultimate consumers or both.

BERLIN, April 18 -- As a result of the long-standing feud between the United States Military Governor in Germany, Gen. Lucius D. Clay, and the Economic Cooperation Administration, the Military Government has decided not to ask ECA for the release of any more counterpart funds for investment here, it was learned today.

Drs. George S. Counts and Sidney Hook, in your issue of April 13, criticize my letter of April 3 in which I defended my sponsorship of the Cultural and Scientific Conference for World Peace. I should appreciate the privilege of a further comment because of the underlying questions involved.

Five women received scholarships last night, permitting further study of advertising, at graduation ceremonies of the Twentieth Annual Survey of Advertising Course in the Aastor Hotel. The twenty-four-week course, conducted by the Advertising Women of New York, Inc., was attended by 396 students.

A move to increase the $6,000 annual pension of former Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander to $7,666 was rejected yesterday at a monthly meeting of the board of trustees of the Police Pension Fund, held at Police Headquarters.
Record operations were attained in all phases of business last year, the Humble Oil Refining Co., an affiliate of Standard Oil Company (New Jersey), declared yesterday in its annual report for 1948.

Eight qualifying places have been allotted the New York Metropolitan district for the National P. G. A. championship which will get under way on the links of the Hermitage Country Club, Richmond, Va, May 25, it was announced yesterday at the annual meeting of the Metropolitan P. G. A. at the Hotel New Yorker.

CHICAGO, April 19 (AP) -- Rip Sewell, always a Chicago nemesis, won a pitching duel of 40-year-olds today as the Pirates nicked Emil (Dutch) Leonard for an unearned ninth-inning tally and a 1-0 victory over the Cubs.
In the manner of the monarch to whose memory the day was dedicated, Tommy Henrich yesterday gave the Yankees a victory over the Senators as the American League season got under way at the Stadium.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- A Senate Armed Forces subcommittee investigating American military justice in the prosecution of seventy-three Nazi SS men for the slaughter near Malmedy, Belgium, of eighty United States prisoners of war in the 1944 Battle of the Bulge booked key men of the trials today for interrogation.

SCHENECTADY, N. Y., April 19 -- Charles E. Wilson, president of the General Electric Company, declared here today that G. E. now had "substantially completed" a $500,000,000 investment in plant and equipment and was prepared to compete "hard and aggressively" for the home and industry market.

CHICAGO, April 19 -- In an election here tonight, employes of the McCormick Works of the International Harvester Company retained the United Farm Equipment and Metal Workers Union, an affiliate of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, as their bargaining agent with the company.

TOKYO, Wednesday, April 20 -- Gen. Douglas MacArthur today released a controversial report on Japan's chemical industry by Frederick Pope, former president of the Chemical Construction Company of New York.

Deciding against partial or progressive "token" price cuts in favor of a single and substantial maximum cut, Dan River Mills announced yesterday a reduction on cotton colored yarn dress goods of 5 1/2 to 12 1/2 cents a yard. The old range of prices from 47 1/2 to 75 cents a yard has been revised to 38 1/2 to 62 1/2 cents, according to W. J. Fullerton, merchandise manager of the dress goods division.

SPARROWS POINT, Md., April 19 -- A super tanker, the Burgan, larger even than the World War I battleships Maryland and Colorado, was launched at noon today at the Sparrows Point yard of the Bethlehem Steel Company.

With no official fanfare one of the most spectacular hits New York has ever offered its sidewalk superintendents opened yesterday at the United Nations East River site, where onlookers watched raptly as a forty-ton crane wrenched upright the first steel beam for the skyscraper headquarters.

WASHINGTON, April 19 (UP) -- Twenty-three Republican Senators asked President Truman today to take steps through the United Nations to enforce United Nations decisions in the dispute between the Netherlands and Indonesia.

ROME, April 19 -- Premier Alcide de Gasperi revealed today that Italy was proposing a new solution for the problem of establishing administrative regimes for her former colonies and that this was now being considered by diplomats gathered in the United States for the United Nations Assembly meeting.

The Rev. Gordon B. Wadhams, who resigned on March 15 as rector of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Resurrection at 115 East Seventy-fourth Street, has been received into the Roman Catholic Church, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- The quarterly report of the Soviet Union's State Planning Commission has not yet appeared this month in the Soviet press, a circumstance that stirred new conjectures here today concerning difficulties with the five-year plan.

Commenting on tomorrow's prospective meeting in Washington of the Anglo-American Film Council, Arthur H. Lockwood, president of the Theatre Owners of America, yesterday declared that his organization not be expected to "look with enthusiasm upon the efforts of the British to obtain more playing time for their films in American theatres."
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange became more active yesterday and final prices were 4 to 15 points higher.

A six-point program for the National Association of Steel Exporters will be presented by Mauray I. Cohen, president of the National Association of Steel Exporters at the annual meeting of the association tomorrow evening at the Essex House, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- spokesman for the maritime committee of the Congress of Industrial Organizations warned today that shipping strikes would tie up the East and West Coasts on June 15 unless preferential hiring in the industry is clearly legalized by that time.

ALBANY, April 19 -- On Mayor O'Dwyer's request, Governor Dewey signed today a series of bills increasing the pay of district attorneys in New York, Bronx, Kings and Queens Counties from $20,000 to $28,000 a year and giving the Board of Estimate power to fix the pay of assistant district attorneys.

Following the deadline sale yesterday of $16,677,000 of the Rochester Gas and Electric Corporation's bonds, word quickly spread throughout underwriting circles that the indicated reoffering on a 2.97 per cent basis has brought a substantial indication of interest from a major insurance company which has kept aloof from the high grade public bond market for nearly two years.

DONORA, Pa., April 19 (AP) -- About ninety residents reported today that they had developed new wheezes and coughs as the Federal Government tested industrial fumes in Pennsylvania's "smog-death" city. The United States Public Health Service is trying to find what was in the air last October when a smoke-fog blanket settled down on Donora and twenty-two persons died of suffocation.

If anything was demonstrated more clearly than anything else at the Chamber Art Society's concert devoted mainly to music by Stravinsky and directed by Robert Craft last night in Town Hall, it is that Stravinsky is not at his best as a composer unless he has a stage spectacle to illustrate his music.

MOSCOW, April 19 -- A comprehensive three-year plan for a 50 per cent increase in Soviet meat, fat, butter, milk, eggs and livestock production was placed before the nation today in a joint decree of the Council of Ministers and the Central Committee of the Communist party.
Players of favorites had difficulty getting out from behind their own goal line at Jamaica yesterday.

A group of writers who were chosen in a nation-wide ballot of mystery authors for outstanding work last year in six fields of detective story telling received "Edgars" last night at the third annual Edgar Allan Poe Awards dinners held here and in Hollywood.

Prices on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday again went to slightly lower levels in quiet trading. Changes, however, were too small to mark a definite trend, but final quotations showed more declines than advances. Fluctuations of more than a point occurred in only a comparatively few issues.

Israel's leaders, led by President Chaim Weizmann, are aiding the United States to "enslave" their country and conspiring to have it join a Mediterranean pact against the Soviet Union in alliance with Franco Spain and other countries, it is charged by the Morning Freiheit, New York, Communist Yiddish daily, in its anti-Zionist campaign.

Earnings of the Phelps Dodge Corporation for the first quarter of 1949 were $12,800,000 before deduction of mine depletion, or about $2.52 a share, Louis S. Cates, board chairman, reported to stockholders at the annual meeting held yesterday.

Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll of New Jersey won a clear-cut victory yesterday in his campaign for renomination by the Republican party. Returns at midnight gave him a margin of more than 2-to-1 over Robert L. Adams, director of the Somerset County Board of Freeholders.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee expects to receive from Secretary of State Dean Acheson at a closed session Thursday a report on the developing program of military aid to Europe with which the Administration intends to fortify the North Atlantic treaty.

EAST HAMPTON, L. I., April 19 -- A 24-year-old unemployed milk-truck driver with a weakness for women's high-heel pumps was being held tonight in Riverhead jail after the police had recovered seventy-nine pairs of the shoes in his Amagansett home -- all sizes 5 1/2 or 6.

The "touch system" is the best way to find the news in fabrics for fall, according to Miss Jeanne Pierre, chairman of the fabrics division of the Fashion Group, Inc. At a luncheon yesterday at the Hotel Biltmore she explained that new finishes that gave surface interest were evident throughout the textile markets in wool, rayon, cotton and nylon.

Eleven persons who will visit Israel and neighboring areas on a "study tour" under the sponsorship of the American Christian Palestine Committee were urged yesterday to bring back the truths that would dispel "misinformation and untruths about Israel."
New York still has $1,000,000 to go to reach its Red Cross fund-raising goal of $4,635,000, Brig. Gen. E. F. Jeffe, chairman of the city's drive, declared yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, April 19 -- Members of the Social Committee of the United Nations General Assembly finally approved today a much-debated article on press censorship for inclusion in a proposed convention on news gathering.

LITTLE FERRY, N. J., April 19 -- Bonanza days in the used-car market are over. That's what they say at this self-styled "Used Car Capital of the World" that stretches for more than a mile along Route 6.
The Women's Action Committee for Lasting Peace may be dissolved next week, it was learned yesterday.

If anything were needed to document the value of the research conducted by the National Advisory Committee for Aeronautics, it could be found in the thirty-fourth annual report of this agency which plays so vital a role in our military security and our commercial progress.

SALEM, Mass., April 19--The participation today of Ben Gold, president of the International Fur land Leather Brokers' Union, CIO, in an all-day session with tannery representatives failed to break a four-mnth deadlock over contract negotiations.

DETROIT, April 13 (AP) -- Johnny Groth, the Tigers' rookie outfielder from Buffalo, blasted two home runs today as Hal Newhouser tamed the White Sox, 5 to 1, with three hits. The crowd of 53,435 set an opening-day record for Detroit.

John G. Broady, named last week as the instigator of a wiretapping conspiracy against Manhattan Borough President Hugo Rogers, was indicted again yesterday with four of his employes on charges of participating in a wiretap swindle that netted $8,071 from stockholders in a Brooklyn automobile sales concern.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- An economic report by the Tool Owners Union, Inc., said today that a net loss in employment of at least 2,455,000 persons could be expected if Congress approved the $4,000,000,000 tax increase recommended by President Truman.

FAIRVIEW, N. J., April 19 -- Simon Douglas, 107 - year - old blind Negro, a former slave, lost his suit for clear title to the one-room shack at 154 Broad Avenue here that he has called "home" for seventy-five years, but he will not be evicted.

Confronted by a set of adverse reviews. Lester Cutler lost no time yesterday in deciding to withdraw his production of "Magnolia Alley" on Saturday night after a week's run at the Mansfield. Panning a show is a critic's prerogative, he said.
PATCHOGUE, L. I., April 19 -- Duke, who doesn't know that he's a mongrel, regards himself as a 100 per cent police dog, and every member of the village police department agrees with him.

FRANKFORT, Germany, April 19 -- Western Germany and Yugoslavia have agreed to exchange more than $34,000,000 worth of goods -- machine tools for the Yugoslavs and food for the Germans -- this year, occupation officials disclosed today.

The Teachers Union, CIO, charged yesterday that the city's vocational high schools were being used as educational "dumping grounds" and that there was a "half-century lag" between school practices and conditions in industry. Spokesmen for the Board of Education emphatically denied the charge.

A scroll was presented yesterday to Mrs. Lytle Hull, president of the Musicians Emergency Fund, by the Veterans Administration in recognition of the work done by the fund's Hospitalized Veterans Music Service. The presentation was made by Lieut. Col. Edwin A. Leibman at a luncheon in the St. Regis Hotel.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 19 -- Evelyn Keyes' suspension by Columbia for refusing a feminine lead in "You Made Me Love You" has been terminated and the actress will instead play opposite Dick Powell in "Mrs. Mike," Sam Bischoff and Edward Gross, producers of the film, announced today.
SHANGHAI, April 19 -- Inside a newly erected wooden fence built around this city, 5,500,000 Chinese and 15,000 Americans, British and Europeans await the approach of the Communists.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- A Presidential Emergency Board told the Railway Express Agency and the AFL Railway Clerks today that the hearing in their dispute would be limited to ten days -- five for each side to present its case.

A mother dog with her five puppies, and three cats and a parrot were rescued at 6 P. M. last evening from a smoke-filled delicatessen store at 1369 Boston Road, the Bronx, by a 12-year-old girl with a basket.

Winning again in the sixth round, Nicholas Rossolimo, chess champion of France, took undisputed possession of the lead yesterday in the international masters chess tournament at Southsea, according to a report from London.

The Players, a club for actors, writers and artists founded in 1888 by Edwin Booth, is taking official cognizance of television this year. On Sunday, May 1, the club's annual observance of Shakespeare's birthday will be its own version of the Bard's tragedy, "Macbeth."

LONDON, April 19 -- With a thin attendance in the stock market here today, the last day of account produced few startling movements. What business there was, however, advanced some prices. Some British Government bonds made gains up to one-eighth, while industrials generally were a few pence up at the close.

A four-run rally in the eighth inning yesterday enabled Brooklyn College to come from behind and defeat City College for the first time in five years, 6 -- 4, at the Flatbush field. It was Brooklyn's first start in the Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference, while the Beavers' league record now stands at three victories and two defeats.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that the Cincinnati Gas and Electric Company had filed a registration statement covering 249,334 shares of $8.50 par value common stock to be offered to Cincinnati Gas stockholders.
A consolidated net income of $24,529,419 was earned in the quarter ended on March 31 by the Union Carbide and Carbon Corporation and its subsidiaries, according to the report issued yesterday.

Coffee futures were active and higher on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday. Local trade and commission houses were early buyers, with profit-taking supplying the contracts. Prices eased late in the day on new selling and slightly lower Brazilian cables.

Two large safe deposit boxes owned by Serge Rubinstein, international financier now serving a jail sentence for draft evasion, turned up $350,000 in United States Treasury certificates and 10,000 shares of aircraft company stock when they were opened yesterday afternoon by government officials and the financier's attorneys.

BOSTON, April 19 -- The Rev. Leonard Feeney, ordered silenced by Archbishop Richard J. Cushing as a result of the Boston College heresy dispute, asserted today that the prelate's action was "invalid."

LAKE SUCCESS, April 19 -- Divisions over the allocation of the former Italian colonies in Africa were accentuated by today's debate in the Political and Security Committee of the United Nations General Assembly, and representatives of the Latin-American and Arab-Asiatic blocs will confer tomorrow in an effort to reach a compromise settlement.

LAKE SUCCESS, April 19 -- Bolivian leader asserted before the United Nation Ad Hoc Political and Security Committee today that the persecution of religious leaders in Hungary and Bulgaria divided the world between the "divine" and "satanic" blocs.
" There is hardly a person who has not had the sorrowing experience of a loss of a relative or friend through the ravages of cancer," writes Secretary of the Treasury John W. Snyder.

Purchasing agents can reduce inventories as much as 10 per cent without hampering production schedules because materials are now in better supply. A. M. Kennedy Jr., purchasing agent, meter division, Westinghouse Electric Corporation, Newark, N. J., declared yesterday.

A decision in the controversy between nine former vestrymen of Holy Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church of Brooklyn Heights and their rector, the Rev. Dr. John Howard Melish, will be rendered at 10 A. M. today in Brooklyn Supreme Court by Justice Meier Steinbrink.

Robert W. Dowling, president of the City Investing Company, will speak on "Public Relations in Real Estate" at the meeting this noon of the Realty Luncheon Club of New York in the Metropolitan Room of the Brass Rail Restaurant, Fifth Avenue and Forty-third Street.
Loss of teeth from decay may be ended by impregnation to prevent caries, the Midtown Dental Society heard last night at its annual scientific meeting at the Statler Hotel.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 19 -- The process of establishing collective farming in Yugoslavia has been accelerated in recent months with appreciable results. According to the latest official reports, 41 per cent of the land in the Voyvodina, the richest plain in Yugoslavia, today belongs to state-owned farms and farm cooperatives of the collective model.
LEXINGTON, Ky., April 19 (AP) -- Johns Joy won his Kentucky Derby spurs against older horses at Keeneland today but bowed to a 35-to-1 shot, Plumper, who closed fast.

TEL AVIV, April 19 -- The chief rabbi of Israel, Dr. Isaac Halevy Herzog, and Mrs. Herzog are flying to the United States next Monday at the invitation of Henry Morgenthau Jr., national chairman of the United Jewish Appeal campaign, it was announced today.

DETROIT, April 19 (AP) -- Stockholders of the Chrysler Corporation today voted to increase the number of common shares of the corporation and to increase their par value. An amendment to the certificate of incorporation was authorized to change the number of shares from 15,000,000 to 20,000,000 and to re-state their par value at $25 instead of $2.50.

PINE-HURST, N. C., April 19 (AP) -- Taking their cue from the defending champion, Harvie Ward, favorites mowed down lesser opponents with machine-like precision today as match play began in the North-South amateur golf tournament.

The student strike at City College went into its fourth day yesterday after a five-day holiday lapse, but the back of the class boycott aimed at forcing the trial and ouster of two faculty members for alleged discrimination appeared to be broken.

A number of waterfowl hunters have, from time to time, expressed considerable interest in the "methods" employed by the United States Fish and Wildlife Service in drawing up waterfowl regulations, so this question along with others of similar nature will be answered in regional meetings to be conducted by the service.

Supreme Court Justice Bernard Botein yesterday dismissed two suits brought by stockholders to prevent the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation from acquiring the assets of the Farnsworth Television and Radio Corporation.

At the time of the Stalin-Hitler pact Communist officials ordered party members working in a Cumberland, Md., textile plant to draw maps of the plant for the party, according to yesterday's testimony at the Communist trial.

Governor Dewey said last night that the North Atlantic pact, together with United States treaties with South American countries, represented an "unshatterable bulwark against tyranny" that was valuable to peoples of the Middle East and Far East as well as the West.

NANKING, April 19 -- Top-level Government leaders met here today under the chairmanship of Acting President Gen. Li Tsungjen and voted to notify the Chinese Communists they would be unable to sign the twenty-four-point peace draft submitted to Nanking by the Communists in the form of a surrender ultimatum expiring at midnight tomorrow.
I have before me an editorial of which the caption is " U. S. War Party," and which begins, "Is the United States in the grip of a War Party? Apparently so."

In the debate at Lake Success over freedom of news and information matters have taken a favorable turn. A few days ago there seemed to be considerable sentiment in favor of sanctioning government censorship of the news on such broad and almost all-inclusive grounds as "national prestige" and "national dignity."

Variety as well as economy often is possible if meat is purchased in one large piece, then divided at home into smaller cuts for different meals. And this way of cooking the subdivisions from scratch eliminates leftovers.

ALBANY, April 19 -- Governor Dewey placed responsibility for any further delay in starting the St. Lawrence River hydro-electric development squarely on the Federal Government today in approving a bill broadening the powers of the State Power Authority.

ALBANY, April 19 -- On the ground that it was unconstitutional, Governor Dewey today vetoed a bill making it unlawful to print, distribute or sell books, magazines or pamphlets devoted principally to accounts or pictures of bloodshed, lust or heinous acts.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- A short-story writing contest for Army personnel and those who have belonged to organized reserve components more than ninety days was announced today by Maj. Gen. Russel B. Reynolds, Chief of Special Services for the Department of the Army.

Some leading Irish-American organizations are opposed to the suggestion by President Mean T. O'Kelly of the new Republic of Ireland that English be dropped in favor of Gaelic, a sampling showed yesterday.

BOSTON, April 19 -- Karl Gosta Leandersson, Sweden's 30-year-old champion, scored a runaway triumph in the fifty-third annual Boston Athletic Association marathon run today, as an estimated 500,000 spectators lined the route of what is described as America's greatest free sports spectacle.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- The fifty-eighth continental congress of the Daughters of the American Revolution today adopted a rigid rule limiting addresses to three minutes, and speakers to no more than one hearing a day on any one subject.

Rehabilitation of the Indonesian economy has made remarkable progress, but the area still faces a critical shortage of dollars, Joseph W. Vander Laan, attache at the United States Consulate at Batavia, said in an interview here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 19 (AP) -- Poland bid openly today for more trade with the Western nations. Polish Ambassador Jozef Winiewicz, during an hour-long talk with Assistant Secretary of State Willard L. Thorp, asked the United States to "clarify" its trade policies. The envoy told reporters later that Mr. Thorp promised to take the matter under consideration.
The Rev. Dr. Stephen S. Wise, world-famous senior rabbi of the Free Synagogue here, died at 4 P. M. yesterday in Lenox Hill Hospital.

EAST HAMPTON, L. I., April 19 -- Preliminary planting to landscape the grounds of a seventeenth-century farm using only trees, shrubs and flowers available there at that time has been started here. When completed, the historic Mulford Farm, which faces the East Hampton Village Green, will look as nearly as it did almost three hundred years ago as twentieth century ingenuity can make it.

Eugene, Ore., sold yesterday $2,000,000 of water and electric utility bonds due May 1, 1950 to 1959 to Blyth Company, Inc., and associates at a bid of 103.352 for 5s, 1 1/4s and 1 1/2s, an interest cost of 1.39822 per cent. The bonds were reoffered at prices to yield from 0.70 per cent to 1.55 per cent.

A $1,000 reward, offered through the "personal" column of THE YORK NEW TIMES today, brought to light the strange robbery in March of $10,000 worth of unused United States coins, the hobby collection of a local business man.

Recently one of your Cambridge, Mass., readers wrote, not indeed to defend the doctrines of our late visiting Communists, but to defend their freedom to talk here. Now a Yale graduate writes to deplore Yale's refusal to open its doors to a concert and talk by Dimitri Shostakovich.

LAKE SUCCESS, April 19 -- Dr. Herbert V. Evatt, president of the United Nations General Assembly, communicated directly with the Government of Greece today concerning the fate of two Greeks condemned to execution.

Not far from where he kicked the field goal that gave Princeton a 16-14 football victory over Columbia last fall, Frank Reichel turned in an impressive performance in a pitcher's role as the Tigers defeated the Lions, 6 to 2, at Baker Field yesterday.
RALEIGH, N. C., April 19 (UP) -- Gen. George C. Marshall said tonight he believed the Atlantic pact "will bring much more quickly the air of freedom."
PRAGUE, April 19 -- The cornerstone of a monument in Pilsen commemorating liberation of the city by the United States Army was boarded up a week ago.

It is generally recognized -- and deplored, in masculine circles -- that what-nots, pianos and other articles of virtu must submit to a spring dusting-off. Perhaps too little appreciated, however, is the extent to which two small household words, with but four letters between them, also are dusted, polished and worked over -- and overworked -- now that warmer days are here.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- President Truman approved legislation today authorizing $5,430,000,000 for the European Recovery Program over the next fifteen months, and the Economic Cooperation Administration drafted a request for the $1,000,000,000 made available to it under the law from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

The fundamentals of the national economy this year are "promising" and there is no logical reason "why a progressive disappearance of the artificial wartime stimulants to demand should cause alarm," according to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- Cordell Hull, the former Secretary of State, has returned to his home in the Wardman Park Hotel after two and one-half years at the Bethesda Naval Hospi tal, and following what is described as an "excellent recovery."
URUMCHI, China, March 29 -- In the heart of central Asia, in a great hinterland bounded by India, Tibet and Russia, the United States Information Service is at work.
BOSTON, April 19 -- The largest group of displaced persons to land in Boston -- 884 -- debarked at Commonwealth Pier today from the Army Transport W. G. Haan.

LONDON, April 19 -- Discussions on the future makeup of the British Commonwealth will begin informally here tomorrow. Prime Minister Clement R. Atlee will start a series of individual meetings with the dominions' statesmen who have arrived for the Commonwealth Prime Ministers' conference, the second within seven months.
ST. LOUIS, April 19 (AP) -- Those upstart Browns walloped the world champion Indians, 5 -- 1, today behind the pitching of baby-faced Ned Garver.

PHILADELPHIA, April 19 -- The Rev. Dr. Robert I. Gannon, former president of Fordham University, told more than 7,000 Roman Catholic educators here today that the introduction of the ideal of mass production into our schools had resulted in a rapid extension downward of American education.

PARIS, April 19 -- Frederic Joliot-Curie, French High Commissioner for Atomic Energy, tomorrow will preside at the opening of the World Congress of Partisans of peace, which under the sponsorship of the French Communist party is moving toward a protest against the North Atlantic pact.
DETROIT, April 19 -- Workers at the Lincoln plant of the Ford Motor Company voted today 484 to 15 to strike. The vote was taken by Local 900, United Automobile Workers, CIO.

A full-scale promotion drive on Old Sunny Brook blended whisky, featuring newspaper ads in 478 cities, will be started the last week of April, it was announced yesterday by National Distillers Products Corporation. Magazines, outdoor posters, car cards and display materials will be closely coordinated in a promotion built around the Old Sunny Brook cowboy trade character.

An extensive international investigation of all factors causing extremely high damage losses to American export shipments will be undertaken as part of the recently started program to improve export packaging, it was learned yesterday.

DETROIT, April 19 -- Isolation in pure form of a hormone that plays a key role in the fertility of both male and female, animal and human, was reported here today at the annual meeting of the Federation of American Societies for Experimental Biology.

The Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company of Chicago reported as of April 11 total deposits of $1,919,952,947 and total assets of $2,118,893,603, compared, respectively, with $2,159,926,637 and $2,356,427,996 on Dec. 31, 1948. Cash on hand and due from banks amounted to $583,354,764, against $674,458,774; holdings of United States Government securities, to $1,076,869,865, against $1,132,234,194, and loans and discounts to $358,103,789, against $458,734,636.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- President Truman sent the 1949 International Wheat Agreement to the Senate today with a plea for "early consideration" so it might ratify the pact in time to put it in effect by July 1, the start of the new crop year.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 19 -- With the resumption of stevedoring activity on the Panamanian freighter Don Anselmo, which had been picketed for ten days by the independent marine firemen's union, the West Coast maritime industry today predicted a peaceful year on the waterfront, despite storm signals from two quarters.

Bert Andrews, author of "Washington Witch Hunt" and winner of a 1947 Pulitzer Prize for Journalism, has signed a contract with Appleton-Century-Crofts for a book on the Alger Hiss-Whitaker Chambers case and the impending Hiss trial.

Waterfront barkeeps who still wonder why business no longer booms when British liners dock here should check on Ninth Avenue food stores. For British rationing has made the English seaman the most temperate seafarer in town. His money now follows the supermarket instead of the grog shop trail and when he staggers it is under the weight of a food package.

Integrating the Long Island Rail Road into the city rapid transit system and varying the fares on the whole publicly owned network according to distance traveled were recommended yesterday to Governor Dewey by Goodhue Livingston Jr., member of the City Planning Commission.

Dollar volume of Electrolux Corporation will reach a record high this year, a company official predicted yesterday. The company is one of the largest vacuum cleaner manufacturers in the country selling directly to consumers through door-to-door salesmen.

Benjamin Feldman, Brooklyn pharmacist, whose two previous first-degree murder convictions were reversed by the Court of Appeals, will be tried for a third time, Kings County District Attorney Miles F. McDonald announced yesterday.

Hugo Wiebke, owner of a pork store at 479 Willis Avenue, the Bronx, is one butcher who takes advantage of science to save his bacon. Twice in six months burglars attempting to rob his store have been frustrated by the electric eye he uses to guard against invaders.

ALBANY, April 19 -- Republican county leaders who are seeking a new state chairman to replace Glen R. Bedenkapp, who resigned, were reported today to have narrowed the field to two possibilities. They are: Representatives William L. Pfeiffer of Buffalo and W. Sterling Cole of Bath.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- Senator Paul H. Douglas, Democrat, of Illinois, told the Senate today that the country's slums were "a moral cancer, a health hazard and an economic loss" against which the national housing bill, now under debate, would make "appreciable inroads."

The State Congress of Industrial Organizations, representing more than 1,000,000 union members, announced yesterday that beginning next week it would "invade" Congressional districts outside of New York to organize political action groups in support of President Truman's fair deal program.

KINGSTON, N. Y., April 19 -- Lieut. John J. Lawson of the Wurtsboro Barracks of the State Police checked off a busy twenty-four hours tonight, with a party of boys lost on Slide Mountain in the Catskills accounted for and a New Paltz State Teachers College professor safely home after a cold night lost in the Shawangunk Mountains.

BERLIN, April 19 -- The Soviet Military Administration has again told the German Economic Commission in the Soviet zone of occupation that all interzonal barriers to rail, water and highway traffic will be lifted by the middle of the year, it was learned today from a highly reliable Allied source.

In a ceremony of dignified simplicity, yet as eloquently expressive as some of the historic home runs that thundered off his unexcelled bat, a monument was unveiled to the memory of Babe Ruth yesterday in "The House That Ruth Built."

CHICAGO, April 19 -- Grain markets turned strong on the Board of Trade today after a steady to slightly lower opening. May wheat led the advance, being up 3 1/8 cents at one time to a new high since mid-January, and closing trades were up 5/8 to 2 7/8 cents, May going 30 cents over the July at one time, the widest difference so far this season.

The Kathryn Turney Long Fund, which was established five years ago to foster opera in America, has made a grant to finance two six-week opera courses this year in the Metropolitan Opera Studio Building. It is hoped that the courses will break ground for a permanent Opera Academy at the Metropolitan.
GENEVA, April 19 -- Sixty-two nations, including Russia and the United States, have accepted invitations to a diplomatic conference of the International Red Cross opening here Thursday.

TOKYO, April 19 -- Japan today celebrated her most successful food year since the end of the war. Presiding at public ceremonies in Tokyo, Agriculture Minister Kotaro Mori announced that Japanese farmers had overfulfilled their quota of rice deliveries from the 1948 harvest that was distributed by the Government at controlled prices as the official ration for city dwellers.

Four new issues of public utility bonds and preferred stock totaling more than $50,000,000 in par value were prepared for marketing yesterday by underwriting syndicates. Offerings to be made today to investors are as follows:

The Philadelphia Orchestra ended its New York season with a concert at Carnegie Hall last night that introduced a new Lincoln in the person of Claude Rains and gave a good deal of pleasure to its well-wishers and subscribers. Eugene Ormandy, recovered from his illness, was back to round off the season.

LEXINGTON, Mass., April 19 -- A bas-relief monument commemorating the handful of Minute Men who faced the British on Lexington Green was unveiled today, on the 174th anniversary of the opening of the Revolutionary War.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- Savings and loan associations increased their combined assets approximately 12 per cent in 1948 to $13,100,000,000, the Home Loan Bank Board announced today. This continued the steady rate of growth of these assets in the last six years.

The sixth annual fund-raising campaign for the thirty-one member colleges of the United Negro College Fund, Inc., got under way yesterday at a meeting of 400 friends of the fund in the Rainbow Room at Rockefeller Center. The drive, which is for $1,400,000 for current expenses of the colleges, is sponsored by John D. Rockefeller Jr., who was present to give his endorsement.

The situation in Germany lends credibility to persistent rumors that the Soviet Union is ready to lift the Berlin blockade in exchange for fresh discussions of the German problem. The record air lift the other day underscored with a flourish that the Western sectors of the city can stand the blockade more easily than the Eastern sectors can endure the counter-blockade.

Reports from Nanking are that the Government of Acting President Li has rejected the latest Communist ultimatum as amounting to a demand for its virtually unconditional surrender, and that China is again on the verge of civil war.

The question of the resignation of Robert F. Wagner, senior United States Senator from New York, has been reopened in the last week, it was learned yesterday. Senator Wagner has been in ill health for a number of years and his condition has not permitted his attendance at any sessions of either the Eightieth or the Eighty-first Congress.

The bolt of Robert B. Blaikie's Seventh Assembly District Democratic Club to support the independent Congressional candidacy of Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. was counteracted to some extent yesterday. Mr. Blaikie's Assemblyman and State Senator both announced they would support Municipal Court Justice Benjamin Shalleck, the Tammany candidate.

TEL AVIV, April 19 -- Just after dawn today in the desert wastes below Sodom known as the "Wilderness of Zin," Bedouin tribes ambushed an Israeli civilian truck, leaving six dead and five wounded. This area, the most rugged terrain in the Negeb, is between the Dead Sea and the Gulf of Aqaba.
WASHINGTON, April 19 -- The Government has joined in efforts to promote overseas sales of lumber -- once so scarce that the shortage threatened to slow the post - war United States building program.

Three new films will open in first-run theatres this morning. At the Paramount the attraction is "The Undercover Man," a Columbia melodrama starring Glenn Ford and Nina Foch. Joseph H. Lewis directed the Robert Rossen production, which was written for the screen by Sidney Boehm.

LONDON, April 19 -- Representatives of Soviet satellite countries in Berlin were reliably reported today to have been putting out hints to the Western powers recently that it would not be too difficult to arrange with the Soviet Union for lifting of the Berlin blockade.

There has been much misinformation and misunderstanding concerning the New York Disability Benefits Law. The letter of Louis Hollander in the April 12 issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES confounds that confusion.

MOSCOW, April 19 -- It's spring and a new edition of the Moscow circus has come to town, complete with dancing poodles, trained horses, acrobats, high-wire artists, a strong man and a fresh line of jokes and satire directed against the United States, Winston Churchill, the Marshall Plan and the Atlantic pact.

Fordham's team romped to a 9-1 victory over Manhattan in a Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference game on Fordham Field yesterday. This was the Rams' second triumph against one defeat in league competition.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- A savings bond is a certificate for Americans indicating a share in their Government, President Truman said tonight as he urged further investment in bonds to help maintain a "sound and secure nation."

The New York Police Department and the New Jersey State Police joined yesterday with the officials of the University Hospital, 300 East Twentieth Street, to save the life of a three-month-old girl who needed a respirator.

Price reductions on its line of diesel-electric locomotives were announced yesterday by the American Locomotive Company. Duncan W. Fraser, chairman, told shareholders at the annual meeting that the company can operate at a profit despite the cuts which range from $4,000 to more than $8,000 a unit.

They opened the baseball season in Brooklyn yesterday and so far as the vast majority in a record inaugural gathering of 34,530 were concerned they could toss the remaining games of the 1949 National League schedule right out of a window and start the world series at Ebbets Field tomorrow.
Several makes of foreign cars were shown yesterday at a preview of the showroom of Fergus Motors, Inc., 290 Park Avenue. The public opening will take place tomorrow.

CHICAGO, April 19 -- Another former official of Montgomery Ward Co. today assailed chairman Sewell L. Avery's charge of conspiracy among departed officers, and another major institutional stockholder said it would not send in proxies for Ward's annual stockholders' meeting on Friday.

It was established yesterday through legal channels that Joseph William Cash of Brooklyn, who considered himself a civilian, is still in the Navy, a fact that he contested in an action in Federal court, Brooklyn. Judge Leo F. Rayfiel ruled that the discharge issued him on March 28 was a "mistake" brought about by an unusual coincidence in names.
WASHINGTON, April 19 -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio predicted today that Congress would pass no comprehensive health bill this session.

WASHINGTON, April 19 (AP) -- Maritime Commission representatives will meet Friday in Hoboken, N. J., with city officials to discuss terms of lease or sale of the Hoboken shipping terminal to the city.

WASHINGTON, April 19 (UP) -- Spokesmen for shipping companies urged today continued exemption of seamen from coverage of the wage-hour law. They said inclusion of their employes would lead to "outrageous pay increases for hours not worked."

HOUSTON, Tex., April 19 (AP) -- Richard Gonzales, national champion, and second-seeded Ted Schroeder had little difficulty in winning their first matches today in the River Oaks invitational tennis tournament.

Few human problems in the United States today are more meaningful than those of middle-age, yet very little is thought about them and even less is written, Zelda Popkin, novelist, said yesterday. She spoke at a luncheon meeting of the Town Hall Club at Town Hall.

CINCINNATI, April 19 (AP) -- Two errors by Nippy Jones and Tommy Glaviano let three unearned Cincinnati runs across the plate today in a 3-1 victory over the Cardinals. There was a top-coated, overflow crowd of 32,118 on hand for the National League opener in 54-degree temperature.
BUENOS AIRES, April 19 -- At least four persons were killed and thirty-one wounded in the provincial capital of Salta yesterday in the worst labor disturbance since President Juan Peron was sworn in.

INDIANAPOLIS, April 19 (AP) -- A British-built Austin apparently set a new American speed record today for open stock cars in spite of bad luck at the finish of its seven-day run at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway.
" YOU belong to an ancient art," said Don Tiburcio. "It is an art that speaks to the hearts of men who understand violence. It is a thing for glory, and to stir the multitude."

TOKYO, April 19 -- Complete figures on the cost of the recent war to Japan have been prepared. They show Japan lost non-military assets with a present value of 4,000,200,000,000 yen or $15,700,000,000. This is entirely separate from military appropriations during the war, which aggregated about $15,300,000,000.

HALIFAX, N. S., April 19 (Canadian Press) -- The first ship to leave Montreal manned by members of the Seafarers International Union, AFL, sailed today on the twentieth day of the deep-sea strike called by the leftist-led Canadian Seamen's Union.
ST. LOUIS, April 19 -- The rowdiest inauguration in the city's history's marked the swearing-in today of Joseph M. Darst as the thirty-seventh Mayor of St. Louis.

PITTSBURGH, April 19 (UP) -- A Pittsburgh mother, whose thirteenth child was born hale and hearty, was today described as an amazing exception to the theory that a difference in parents' RH blood factors endangers childbirth.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- Twenty-one more boards and committees in the National Military Establishment fell today in the on-slaught by Louis Johnson, Secretary of Defense, on duplication. He said that the units, many of which had been inactive for several years or never in operation, were "useless."

LAKE SUCCESS, April 19 -- Bulwarks against global depression, flimsy at best, are crumbling momentarily in the face of a widening recession because economic agencies like the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development and the International Monetary Fund are hidebound by safety-first policies and are openly defied by Governments bent on economic nationalism, a United Nations committee of experts declared today.

PHILADELPHIA, April 19 (AP) -- Lou Brissie, the Athletics' sophomore left-handed pitcher with the war-shattered leg, started the American League season today just as he had last year -- beating the Red Sox, by 3 -- 2, at Shibe Park. Eddie Joost hammered a homer into the left-field stand in the seventh for the deciding run.
The Prime Ministers of the British Commonwealth, meeting in London today, will tackle a tough technical problem. They have come together to discuss, primarily, the future status of India.

Stephen Wise was an intense, eloquent and even belligerent crusader for what he believed in. A descendant of rabbis, he was brought to this country as an infant, was schooled in New York City and became a prominent figure in the city's life. He had great gifts as a speaker, but he had also a talent for organization.

Out-of-town buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday numbered 1,138, against 909 last week and 1,481 in the corresponding week a year ago, according to listings appearing in THE NEW YORK TIMES. There were 709 arrivals yesterday compared with 324 last Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- Walter S. Franklin, executive vice president of the Pennsylvania Railroad, testified today before two Interstate Commerce Commission examiners here in support of a proposal of the Pennsylvania and the Wabash Railroad to purchase the stock of the Detroit, Toledo Ironton Railroad, and a proposal of the Pennsylvania to buy the stock of the Springfield Suburban Railroad Company.
PITTSBURGH, April 19 -- The steel industry, eager to avoid any charge that it is attempting to cut a pattern for coal, is likely to take a back seat in contract negotiations with John L. Lewis year.
WASHINGTON, April 19 (AP) -- A Government check every month for everyone over 65 years of age was proposed today by Alabama's Gov. James E. Folsom.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- The National Legislative Council of the American Federation of Labor today condemned the new labor relations bill offered by Representative John S. Wood, Democrat, of Georgia, as worse than the Taft-Hartley Act "in several important respects."

Formal plans of labor-management cooperation, now more prevalent than a decade ago, have reduced the friction between management and unions and improved employe attitude, the American Management Association disclosed yesterday.

Smaller retail stores (those reporting annual sales ranging from $25,000 to $2,000,000) have little to fear from chains, larger stores, or any other type of competition, members of the executive board of the smaller stores division of the National Retail Dry Goods Association agreed yesterday at an open meeting in the Statler Hotel.

IN view of the fact that this was opening day, the rigid rule against fraternization was followed more in the breach than the observance at Ebbets Field yesterday. Those friendly enemies, the Dodgers and the Giants, roamed around the Flatbush pastures before the game, shaking hands, slapping backs and giving each other the how's-the-wife-and-kiddies treatment.

A year ago tonight Mayor O'Dwyer took what will probably be regarded, in retrospect, as the most important action of his administration. He announced the end of the five-cent transit fare which had become hallowed in political history. There is a human tendency to overlook the beneficial results of that change in policy, which became effective July 1, 1948.

CHICAGO, April 19 -- The ban against presentation in Chicago of Jean-Paul Sartre's play "The Respectful Prostitute" was lifted today by Police Commissioner John C. Prendergast. The play will open at the Harris Theatre on May 15.

The injunction sought by Danny Gardella to compel organized baseball to reinstate him or, in the alternative, to restrain it from interfering with his playing was denied yesterday by Federal Judge Edward A. Conger.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- Responsible officials in Washington are now confident that John J. McCloy, president of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, will be appointed United States High Commissioner for Germany.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- The nation's airlines today faced a complete survey of their financial structure by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, under an official request made by the Senate Committee on Interstate and Foreign Commerce. The study would be completed by June 30.

The Rev. James F. Brown, 28 years old, who described himself as a Baptist minister, was booked on homicide charges at noon yesterday at the Liberty Avenue Police Station, Brooklyn, after he had allegedly confessed beating his wife, Anna, 29, to death thirteen hours before.

OAKLAND, Calif., April 19 -- The Norwegian motorship Brandanger, "fast freeze freighter" of the Interocean Line, was loading fresh fruits for European ports today after arriving here yesterday on its maiden voyage. The Brandanger has 60,000 cubic feet of refrigeration space and a frozen food locker of 10,000 cubic feet.

BOSTON, April 19 (AP) -- After 17 scoreless innings -- nine of them in the National League opener yesterday -- the Braves sprang to life today and twice defeated the Phillies, 4 -- 3 and 11 -- 2, before a Patriots' Day crowd of 30,337.
SHANGHAI, Thursday, April 21 -- After a series of running battles yesterday between Yangtze shore batteries and two British naval

BOSTON, April 20 -- Dr. Arthur H. Compton, chancellor of Washington University, called tonight for the organization of athletics "as an integral part of the educational pattern." He further urged the financing of the program from general university funds as a means of relieving the "compromising status" of coaches.

Within a few hours after the rejection of their ultimatum demanding the unconditional surrender of the Chinese National Government, the Communists unleashed what looks like an all-out offensive against Nanking and the whole Yangtze River line.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- President Truman appointed Vice Admiral Alan G. Kirk today as Ambassador to Russia to succeed Lieut. Gen. Walter Bedell Smith, who was relieved of the post recently and is now in command of the First Army in New York.

Successful management of the burdensome national debt requires a "stiff dose of sound American common sense", according to the Committee on Public Debt Policy headed by W. Randolph Burgess, chairman of the executive committee of the National City Bank of New York.

The revolt against Robert B. Blaikie, Tammany leader of the Seventh Assembly District, who is supporting Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. for Representative from the Twentieth Congressional District at the special election on May 17, broadened yesterday.

The action of Bishop James Pernette De Wolfe of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Long Island in ordering the Rev. Dr. John Howard Melish to relinquish his forty-five-year rectorship at Holy Trinity Church on Brooklyn Heights was upheld yesterday in Brooklyn Supreme Court by Justice Meier Steinbrink.

John F. Kenny, who was listed as a fugitive on Tuesday when he was one of five men indicated on charges of shaking down of stockholders in a Brooklyn automobile agency, surrendered yesterday at the District Attorney's office.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 20 -- Attorneys for the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, CIO, and the Waterfront Employers Association struck a snag today at the opening of a hearing by the National Labor Relations Board on the legality of the West Coast longshore contract embodying a provision for continued operation of a hiring hall.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- Resolutions opposing the International Trade Organization and the International Labor Organization were held in abeyance by the fifty-eighth Continental Congress of the Daughters of the American Revolution today in one of the stiffest floor fights in recent years.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- Registration statements covering $4,000,000 of debentures, 125,000 shares of capital and 42,448 shares of common stock have been filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission by two companies.

PARIS, April 20 -- From the outset of its opening meeting today in the Salle Pleyel the World Congress of the Partisans of Peace became a drive against "American capitalist imperialism" and for peace with the Soviet Union at any price.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- Louis Johnson, Secretary of Defense, ordered into effect today a policy of racial equality for the National Military Establishment that substantially enlarged employment opportunities for Negroes in the armed services.

FOR more than a quarter of a century Garry Schumacher was a baseball writer, one of the very best. Few of the press box tenants were as shrewd as he in analyzing players, plays or any other aspect of the game and his opinions were treated with wholesome respect by his fellow-members of the typewriter-pounding fraternity, the highest compliment those rugged individualists could pay him.

SHUSHAN, N. Y., April 20 -- Unlike the Beaverkill, Neversink and Willowemoc, the Battenkill does not attract a great volume of anglers from the city, for it is somewhat off the beaten track. But for the fly fisherman who wants a little solitude with his brown trout fishing it has a real appeal.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- Broadening an earlier decision that ruled that a strike for the hiring hall was a violation of the Taft-Hartley Act, the National Labor Relations Board today held that even a strike threat for that purpose was illegal.

LONDON, April 20 -- Delegates of twenty-one nations, assembled here today for the opening session of the conference of the European Movement, heard Winston Churchill, a president of honor of the movement, warn them that Europeans must "sink or swim together" or become "paupers or slaves."

Federal Judge Samuel H. Kaufman threatened yesterday to dismiss the petition for reorganization of the Third Avenue Transit Corporation on the ground that it was not filed in good faith if he did not receive "a very complete explanation" of transactions in the company's bonds by two of the petitioners and their relatives.

MINNEAPOLIS, April 20 (AP) -- Dr. Willem J. Luyten, chairman of the Astronomy Department at the University of Minnesota, today announced the discovery of a pair of stars believed to be nearer to the earth than any other star except one, Alpha Centauri.

The re - establishment of scientific relations with leaders of medical science in German universities was characterized as an important outgrowth of the medical missions sponsored by the Unitarian Service Committee, Inc., of this city, Dr. Howard C. Taylor, Professor of Obstetrics and Gynecology at the College of Physicians and Surgeons, Columbia University, declared yesterday.

Arturo Toscanini and the NBC Symphony Orchestra, assisted by Rose Bampton and Set Svanholm, gave a program of Beethoven and Wagner for the benefit of the City College Centennial Fund last night in Carnegie Hall. The statement in itself is merely one of fact.

A contributor to your "Letters to The Times" on April 1, Reavis O'Neal Jr. writes: "Walter White and his group believe these goals [civil rights] should be attained by ramming a law down the throat of the South."

TOKYO, April 20 -- In an unprecedented action, Japan's professional baseball league today suspended Manager Osamu Mihara of the Tokyo Giants for the remainder of the season for "unsportsmanlike conduct?"
WASHINGTON, April 20 -- The Russians have rejected a United States scientist's attempt to check up on the force of gravity in the Russian-occupied zone of Germany, the scientist disclosed today.

The prospects of a deal for the purchase of United Artists by the Nasser Brothers has diminished considerably, according to advices from the Coast. Unofficial reports from those closest to the negotiations indicated that the arrrangements had struck an obstacle involving a shortage of capital on the part of the Nassers and the refusal of the owners of UA, Charles Chaplin and Mary Pickford, to accept any terms short of cash.

The nation's gasoline stocks declined 1,600,000 barrels to 125,922,000 week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Light fuel oil supplies, however, were up 249,000 barrels to 49,169,000 and stocks of the heavy grade rose 1,278,000 to 59,788,000.
LAKE SUCCESS, April 20 -- The merger of two future United Nations treaties on news gathering and the correction of false reports were approved today by the social Committee of the General Assembly.

Retail store sales will break even this year with those during 1948 if proper promotional methods are used, Charles G. Nichols, president of G. M. McKelvey Co., Youngstown, Ohio department store, declared yesterday. Mr. Nichols, who is chairman of the board of directors of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, addressed the annual meeting in the Statler Hotel.

Fear of mugging, purse snatching and terrorism by youthful gangs is keeping residents in the vicinity of Central Park out of the park after dark despite an increased detail of detectives and plaincothesmen, it was learned yesterday.

Underwriting syndicates offered yesterday three new issues of public utility and railroad securities having a par value of $24,727,000. All follow upon awards at competitive sales. The marketings are as follows:

Home handymen who have been curious about the practicability of Klaus Grabe's make-it-yourself furniture now have an opportunity to examine the finished product. Yesterday at 126 East Fifty-sixth Street the designer opened an exhibition of the thirteen living and dining room pieces that are available in pre-cut form as well as in paper patterns.
NANKING, April 20 -- Two British naval vessels, the destroyer Consort and the sloop Amethyst, were attacked by Communist artillery today on the Yangtze River.

Emphasis on a new growth in newspapers' basic contributions in public service news reporting and in economic welfare through the power of advertising highlighted the opening of the National Newspaper Promotion Association's annual convention yesterday at the Roosevelt Hotel.

MINNEAPOLIS, April 20 -- Sister Elizabeth Kenny bowed out today as an administrative figure in the Sister Elizabeth Kenny Foundation and the foundation charted a new course designed to bring closer cooperation with other medical groups.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- A second substitute plan for the liquidation and dissolution of the International Hydro-Electric System, Boston, was fried today with the Securities and Exchange Commission by the system's trustee, Bartholomew A. Brickley.

VIENNA, April 20 -- The Austrian Government today protested to French occupation authorities against the alleged beating and handcuffing of a Socialist member of the Austrian Parliament traveling on the Arlberg express through the French zone of Austria.

PINEHURST, N. C., April 20 (AP) -- Surviving a nineteen-hole second-round scare, defending champion Harvie Ward of Tarboro, N. C., came back with a more comfortable third-round victory in the afternoon to lead the way to the quarter-finals of the forty-ninth North and South amateur golf tournament today.

The Louis O. Coxe and R. H. Chapman play, temporarily titled "Billy Budd," based on Herman Melville's sea novel of the same name, has caught the collective attention of Lassor H. Grosberg, Richard W. Krakeur and Norris Houghton as a potential Broadway prospect for next season.

LONDON, April 20 -- Unofficial but strong indications were given today on the eve of the meeting of British Commonwealth Prime Ministers in London that several of the statesmen already saw their way clear to an arrangement whereby India could be kept in the Commonwealth while becoming a republic.

Orlando Zulueta of Cuba defeated Jimmy Warren of Brooklyn in the star bout of ten rounds at the Manhattan Center last night. All three officials, referee Ray Miller and Judges Sam Rosenblatt and Tony Rossi cast their votes for the Cuban.

To represent the United States in Moscow is an assignment to test the patience, skill and wisdom of the ablest Ambassador. Just now, when this country is more than ever the target of abuse and ridicule in Soviet press, theatre, even the circus, it is an uncomfortable post for an American.
ST. LOUIS, April 20 (AP) -- Bob Feller, the Indians' high-salaried pitcher, has a pulled muscle in his right shoulder, but only time will tell how serious the injury is.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- The Civil Aeronautics Board granted millions of dollars in retroactive mail pay today to two transatlantic airlines and gave strong notice that it, and not the companies, would hereafter be the judge of increased services to be subsidized with Government funds.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 20 -- Lower prices and ways of reducing costs brought more than 2,500 industrial executives here today to view the exhibits of thirty-six office equipment companies at the biennial business show of the New Haven Chapter of the National Association of Cost Accountants held in the Goffe Street Armory.

The Board of Education and the National Conference of Christians and Jews will establish next September eight special centers to promote better relations among the city's religious and racial groups, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson supported the position of the American motion-picture industry at his news conference today in its efforts to have the British Government reconsider its recent order for all British theaters to set aside 45 per cent of their time for showing British-made films, instead of the previous quota of 40 per cent.

Many reservations have been made for the spring ball in aid of the New York State Association for Crippled Children to be held tomorrow night in the ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton. The event marks the climax of the organization's annual Easter seal campaign.

Traditional and historic methods of merchandising men's wear must give way to bolder approach if the industry is to make its cooperative promotion campaign a success, it was asserted yesterday by William H. Howard, vice president in charge of sales promotion, R. H. Macy Co.

Nicholas Rossolimo, champion of France, continued his winning career yesterday in the seventh round of the international tournament at the Easter Chess Festival in Southsea, England. He heads the standing with a score of 6 1/2 points out of seven, according to a report received from London.

CHICAGO, April 20 -- Grain markets turned reactionary after an early bulge which carried wheat and corn to a new high on the current movement and into new ground for several months. Heavy profit-taking developed on the bulge and the markets reacted quickly with wheat closing l 1/8 cents lower to 3/4 cent higher, the former on May.

Four hundred pieces of Orrefors glass have been brought from Sweden for the exhibition that opened yesterday at Georg Jensen. They include everything from small ashtrays, candle holders and simple table glassware to large trophies and exquisite bowls and vases that must be classed primarily as works of art.

ALBANY, April 20 -- The Court of Appeals, in a 2-to-3 decision, ruled today that an arbitrator had exceeded his powers in ordering reinstatement with back pay last year of about sixty-two Western Union employes who were suspended for four months for refusing to handle "struck traffic."

The largest corporate financing on record was authorized yesterday by stockholders of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company. At the sixty-fourth annual meeting they approved issuance of $395,000,000 of debentures. The ten-year 3 1/8 per cent securities, to be dated June 20, will be offered to shareholders of record of May 6, one for each six shares of stock held, at $100.
WASHINGTON, April 20 -- Employment in nonagricultural establishments declined in March for the third successive month, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.
ALBANY, April 20 -- Governor Dewey signed today a bill setting up a board to prevent further pollution of the state's streams, lakes and marine waters and to take steps to abate existing pollution.
For the second Wednesday in succession, it was "pay to the order of Peter A. Markey" at the conclusion of yesterday's stakes race at Jamaica.

Sales of Gimbel Brothers, Inc., increased for the tenth consecutive year to the highest volume in the history of the company, Bernard F. Gimbel, president, reported in the annual statement issued for publication today. The volume for the fiscal year ended on Jan. 31, last, was 2 per cent above the $6,043,699 sales transacted in the preceding fiscal year.

ROCHESTER, Minn., April 20 -- Preliminary tests during the last seven months at the Mayo Clinic with a hormone from the skin of the adrenal glands has opened up an entirely new approach to the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis, the most painful form of arthritis, that cripples millions, it was revealed here tonight.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended April 13:

PITTSBURGH, April 20 (AP) -- Westinghouse Electric Corporation stockholders met in a production aisle amid the bang and clatter of workmen's hammers and drills today and heard a comparatively optimistic prediction of business for 1949.

Ole Olsen and Chick Johnson have been signed at last for a television show by NBC. Sponsored by Buick, the two jokesters of "Hellzapoppin" fame will appear from 8 to 9 P. M. on Tuesdays after the Milton Berle show goes off the air for the summer.

At the end of the War of 1812 this country's national debt stood at $129 million, or about 13 per cent of the national income. The Civil War left us, in 1865, with a debt of $2,675 million, or slightly more than 50 per cent of our income. Between that time and the outbreak of the First World War the nation's capacity to produce increased enormously.

Consolidated net income of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation amounted to $6,818,691 in 1948, compared with $222,068 in the preceding year, according to the annual report released today.

The proposal for governmental control of power development in the Columbia River Valley appeals to the imagination largely because of the magnitude of the play and the implied element of perfection assumedly attainable through a governmental agency.

HARTFORD, Conn., April 20 -- Gov. Chester Bowles' proposal for a state income tax to supplant the sales tax was attacked today by spokesmen for large and small businesses at a public hearing in the State Capitol.

CLEVELAND, April 20 -- Debate on the agreement to establish the new United Church of Christ that is expected to be the seventh largest Protestant denomination in the United States opened here today at a special meeting of the General Synod of the Evangelical and Reformed Church.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- The proposed special appropriation toward rearming the European nations (and Iceland) which signed the North Atlantic Pact became officially a part of the debate on approving the treaty itself when the State Department on April 8 released the requests of these nations for military aid and its pledge to assist them.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 20 -- Ronald Reagan has notified Warner Brothers that he will not accept a loan-out assignment to Columbia for the Santana production, "Baby Is Here," formerly titled "You Made Me Love You," with Barbara Hale.

The maiden voyage of the 18,000-gross ton liner La Guardia in the American Export Lines' service between New York and Italy, scheduled for May 27, is already booked to capacity, George C. Gaede, passenger traffic manager of the company, said yesterday.

Members of the Fashion Originators Guild will begin showing fall lines on June 6, it was announced yesterday by Leonard W. Gendler, executive secretary. A two-week market period has been set for this year's showings compared to a four-week period last year when the lines opened May 17.

SHANGHAI, China, Thursday, April 21 (UP) -- The damaged British destroyer Consort, which sailed from Nanking yesterday to the rescue of the grounded British sloop Amethyst, docked here today. Nine of her crew were killed and three wounded in a three-hour running battle with Communist shore batteries that earlier had attacked the Amethyst.

BERLIN, April 20 -- Millions of dollars worth of property that belonged to Hitler's Reich or district governments of the Reich was disposed of today by the United States Military Government's enactment of a law clarifying title to these properties in the American zone.

PHILADELPHIA, April 20 -- With enrollment in Catholic high schools expected to increase another 20 per cent within the next decade, the recruiting of both lay and religious teachers has become imperative, the National Catholic Educational Association was told here today.

The immediate economic outlook is far better than in any other comparable post-war period in the nation's history, Leon Keyserling, vice chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, declared last night.
CHICAGO, April 20 (AP) -- Bob Rush, 23-year-old sophomore, hurled the Cubs to a 4-0 triumph over the Pirates today before 11,218.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- Confronted by a split among fellow Republicans on his proposal to bar segregation in public housing, Senator John W. Bricker of Ohio asserted today that he would press the amendment to give the Senate opportunity to show that party platforms meant something.

PITTSBURGH, April 20 -- A threat that Poland and other Soviet satellite countries would quit the International Labor Organization, a United Nations affiliate, was voiced here today at the opening of an ILO conference on world coal problems.

Under a warm sun, 5,000 of Bellevue's sick -- young and old -- sat yesterday morning in the makeshift stands on the parade grounds facing the East River on Twenty-ninth Street, some propped up on pillows, others in wheel chairs, babies held in nurses' arms.

A short, thick-set man with years of off-shore weather etched deeply in his face climbed nimbly up the side of the country's largest passenger liner at 12:30 P. M. yesterday to start an expert landing operation for which the Port of New York is known the world over.

Memorial Hospital for Cancer and Allied Diseases is considered by many authorities as the "finest university for cancer studies in the world." Its clinics, wards, and laboratories, its libraries and statistical records, its special classes for training physicians, medical students and nurses all have added immense knowledge and prepared hundreds of skilled technicians for the eventual conquest of cancer.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- It was learned authoritatively today that Russians had been putting out feelers concerning the possible lifting of the Berlin blockade and dealing with over - all German problems, but these feelers have been on such a plane that their true worth and value cannot yet be assessed.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., April 20 (AP) -- Alabama went beyond the South's regional education plan today and drew up its own program to give equal training to white and Negro college students.

Coffee futures trading was active on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday. After registering early advances of about 50 to 60 points on trade buying and short covering, the market reacted rather sharply on profit-taking and scattered new selling.

A 2 1/2-year-old girl was instantly killed in her carriage and a boy the same age was fatally injured yesterday when a light truck skidded crazily across a Bronx intersection. Four other persons were injured in the accident, which occurred at 2 P. M. at the broad intersection of the Edward L. Grant Highway, 170th Street and Jesup Avenue.

DETROIT, April 20 -- A windfall in which the United States Government is the only loser has brought travel bargains to United States citizens living in border cities since Canada abolishd its 15 per cent travel tax on March 23, four weeks ago today.

RANGOON, Burma, April 20 (AP) -- Official sources said today that Burmese planes had killed 100 of a force of 800 rebel Karen tribesmen attacking the railway town of Nyaunglebin, ninety miles north of Rangoon.
LAKE SUCCESS, April 20 -- The United Nations Conciliation Commission for Palestine reported today that the Israeli Government had repeated its refusal to accept internationalization of Jerusalem.
Providence, R. I., announced yesterday that it will receive bids on May 19 on bond issues totaling $3,229,000. Dated June 1, 1949, the bonds will come due on each June 1 from 1951 to 1974.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were moderately active yesterday and final prices were unchanged to 10 points net lower.

MUSE, Pa., April 20 -- Enthusiasm for the "share the work" program proposed by John L. Lewis runs high among miners whose mines have little work and low among those who are working fulltime. This was the major conclusion reached in a survey of sentiment among members of the United Mine Workers in this section of western Pennsylvania.

Museum representatives from New York and out-of-town, collectors and dealers turned out in force yesterday to attend the opening of the four-day auction sale of the distinguished art collection of the late Joseph Brummer. The session brought $47,905.

AMERICAN literature is being represented in the Moscow circus this week as a masked two-gun man in evening clothes, according to the story that got through Soviet censorship yesterday, and how it is being represented in the Paris peace circus of traveling and fellow-traveling intellectuals we shall doubtless know before the week is over.

Prices on the New York Stock Exchange moved irregularly lower yesterday in the heaviest trading this month. Losses generally were in fractions, with a relatively few issues fluctuating more than a point.

The case against Israel presented by Mary Garvin in her letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES of April 5 is logical only if one disregards Arab responsibility for the war in Palestine. In defiance of the United Nations they launched a war of aggression agains, the State of Israel in the hope that the Jews would be defeated and the entire land of Palestine made into an Arab land.

Charles H. Kaman announced at the Wings Club yesterday that the twin-rotor helicopter, which he designed and has been building at Bradley Field, Windsor Locks, Conn, has received its official Approved Type Certificate from the Civil Aeronautics Administration.
Maltreated by the Dodgers for the second straight day, the Giants must be wondering whether there is such a thing as the law of averages.
HOUSTON, Tex., April 20 (AP) -- Rain washed out men's singles play in the River Oaks tennis tournament today but four California women stars managed to turn in victories before the downpour began.
BERLIN, April 20 -- German Communist leaders today continued to indicate that the blockade of Berlin and the Western blockade of Eastern Germany would soon be lifted.

ALBANY, April 20 -- A bill revising the state insurance law to permit the sale of "package policies" by a single insurer covering various types of risks was approved today by Governor Dewey. Similar laws are in force in thirty-seven other states.

R. V. C. Bodley, lecturer and author of "Wind in the Sahara" and "The Quest," has signed a contract with Houghton Mifflin for a book titled "In Search of Serenity." The book, partly autobiographical, tells how he found serenity while wandering through North Africa and Asia.

New York University's undefeated baseball team shut out Hofstra, 5 -- 0, yesterday in a Metropolitan Conference game at Ohio Field. This was the Violets' sixth straight victory and their third league triumph.
