The contribution of Greek and Roman art to western civilization forms the theme of an exhibition opening today at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. It brings together objects dating from the age of Pericles to the time of Picasso, and thus attempts to document visually through sculpture, paintings, prints and decorative arts the impact of the arts of antiquity on 2,500 years of western civilization.
WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP) -- The Government reported today it that the war-inspired boom in farm lands prices apparently had passed its peak.

DETROIT, April 20 -- Certain blood cells have been found to be resistant to atomic radiation, it was reported today by Comdr. John L. Tullis, who served as a Navy pathologist at the Bikini bomb tests.

The American Car and Foundry Company's "caterpillar" train, low-slung and rail-hugging, made its first public demonstration run yesterday over the rails of the Delaware, Lackawanna Western Railroad between Hoboken and Port Morris, N. J.

New Federal rent regulations governing most residential space throughout the country offer possibilities for increased return for many owners, and are likely to lead to higher rents for many of the 1,650,000 tenant families in this city, according to Robert W. Dowling, president of the City Investing Company.
The International League today opens its sixty-sixth consecutive season with all eight teams scheduled to play.

Dr. Lorenzo Mendoze-Fleury, alternate representative to the United Nations from Venezuela, has purchased for his use the five-story dwelling at 39 Beekman Place from William Schwarz in a transaction reported yesterday by Albert B. Ashforth, Inc., the broker.
LAKE SUCCESS, April 20 -- China followed Pakistan and India in proposing that the General Assembly establish a collective United Nations trusteeship over the former Italian colonies in Africa.

PRAGUE, April 20 -- Amid impassioned denunciations of "aggressive plans" of Western "imperialists," 168 delegates to the Paris "peace conference" who had been denied French visas and some 200 others from Communist Eastern Europe and Asia began a five-day junior peace congress in the Prague Parliament today.

LAKE SUCCESS, April 20 -- Well-informed sources revealed today that the United States delegation would support the repeal of a ban on the admission of the Franco regime in Spain to United Nations specialized agencies if such a proposal was presented to the General Assembly.

SALONIKA, Greece, April 20 -- Nicholas Vasilikos, of counsel for the defense of Gregory Stachtopoulos, asserted tonight in his wind-up in the hearings on the killing of George Polk, American correspondent, that several persons who had testified as witnesses in court here, were themselves deeply implicated in the case.

DETROIT, April 20 (AP) -- Rookie Outfielder Johnny Groth continued his terrific hitting today with a grand-slam homer, a double and a single to drive in all five runs as the Tigers beat the White Sox, 5 -- 2. It was Groth's third homer in the first two games of the American League campaign and ran his runs-batted-in total to seven.
The Yangtze River, the scene for many centuries of some of man's worst inhumanity to man, echoed again yesterday to the sound of shellfire as the civil war in China was resumed.

Pending amendments to Federal Reserve Board margin requirements were announced yesterday. They are technical and will be chiefly effective, it was noted here, in permitting customers of stock brokerage houses to withdraw parts of the proceeds of the sales of securities from accounts that are not fully margined.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 20 -- Col. Gen. Svetozar Vukmanovitch - Tempo, famous war - time Partisan leader, told the miners congress at Belgrade yesterday that many Communists in all countries of the world secretly supported the Yugoslav demand for equality with all the Communist states but lacked the courage to declare themselves openly against the Communist Information Bureau.

Plans were completed yesterday by fifty representatives of 35,000,000 Protestant and Eastern Orthodox communicants in the United States for what was announced as "the greatest evangelistic campaign ever undertaken by them" in this country.

Not a Senator reached third as Vic Raschi fashioned a three-hit 3-0-shut-out for the Yankees before 12,551 fans at the Stadium yesterday. Before any rash claims are made, following two straight New York victories, however, it is pertinent to note that both triumphs were recorded at the expense of a team that shapes up as the weakest in the American League, if not in either major circuit.

A grand-slam homer by Tony Camera and the six-hit pitching of Tom McKeon were highlights of Fordham's 10-4 victory over Brooklyn College on Fordham Field in the Bronx yesterday. It was the Rams' second victory on successive days and their third against one defeat in Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference competition.

Although he has never seen an oil well, Detective William Fox, the only Doctor of Philosophy in the New York Police Department, has undertaken a special Federal Government assignment to develop a technique to extract petroleum from rock formations.

Reflecting substantially larger sales, the net income of the Douglas Aircraft Company, Inc., in the quarter ended with last February rose to $2,001,529, after all charges from the $23,862 earned in the same three months of the previous year.

ALBANY, April 20 -- The Court of Appeals unanimously reinstated today the temporary $21,500,000-a-year reduction in electric rates of the Consolidated Edison Company ordered by the Public Service Commission as of Jan. 10.

Formation of a national association of customers' brokers was announced last night following a meeting of representatives from brokerage firms in several leading cities at a dinner in the Columbia University Club at 4 West Forty-third Street.

BOSTON, April 20 (AP) -- Boston's Braves made it three victories in four games today, edging the Phillies, 6 -- 5, before 6,095 fans, who saw the losers' Willie. (Puddin' Head) Jones equal a modern major league baseball record by hitting four doubles in a single contest.

For the past week or so hatters have been earnestly engaged in their annual effort to persuade the male animal to toss his weather-beaten chapeau on the shelf and to purchase a new, lightweight spring model.

LOS ANGELES, April 20 (AP) -- American polo star George Oliver today joined Argentine Roberto Cavanagh on the injury list but both hope to ride Sunday in the third and deciding game of the Argentina-United States international series.

ALBANY, April 20 -- New York's death rate for January from all causes was the lowest on record but the suicide rate for the month was the highest in six years, the State Health Department reported today. The number of murders and automobile accidents was also up sharply.
ST. LOUIS, April. 20 (AP) -- The Indians knocked out three pitchers and downed the downs, 7 -- 3, today, with Bob Lemon hurling the distance before 2,919 fans at Sportman's Park.

Two Brooklyn fires, one a five-alarm blaze and the other a two-alarm fire preceded by an explosion, caused heavy damage to industrial plants and tied up trolley and bus traffic yesterday. Although near-by buildings were shaken and families driven to the street no injuries were reported.

HANOVER, Germany, April 20 -- Firmly back again in the saddle as chairman after thirteen months incapacity, Dr. Kurt Schumacher rode down all opposition today within his Social Democratic party and reasserted his domination over its policy at Bonn.

A holographic will written in French by Sultan Ahmed Kadjar, deposed Shah of Persia (now Iran), in which he set up a trust fund for the benefit of his mother, Queen Malekeh-Djahan, who died at Saint Cloud, France, on Nov. 14, 1947, presents problems of law and distribution.

ALBUQUERQUE, N. M., April 20 (AP) -- Representative Robert Lewis Coffey Jr., 30 years old, of Johnstown, Pa., decorated wartime fighter pilot, was killed instantly at 4:40 P. M. today when his jet fighter crashed here. His P-80 Shooting Star crashed on the take-off after a refueling stop at Kirtland Air Force base.

The Army and the Navy paid tribute yesterday to the "morale-building work" of the American Women's Voluntary Services in war and peace at the opening of the organization's Manhattan motor transport unit fund-raising drive for $50,000.

The New York Opera Company gave its second performance of Offenbach's "The Tales of Hoffmann" last night at the City Center. Six artists were assigned important roles which had been in other hands at the initial presentation of the engrossing production, Franz Vroons appearing as Hoffmann, Brenda Lewis as Giulietta, Frances Yeend as Antonia, Frances Bible as Nicklause, James Pease as Crespel and Ralph Herbert as Lindorf, Coppelius and Miracle.

Nine major brass mills announced price reductions yesterday, trade sources announced, reflecting quotations in line with 21 1/2-cent prices for copper and 13-cent prices for zinc. These included, among others, Reverse Copper and Brass, Inc.; the Bridgeport Brass Company and the Chase Brass and Copper Company.
CHARLESTON, S. C., April 20 --Mayor William O'Dwyer of New York City today joined thousands of South Carolinians and other visitors in helping Charleston celebrate its annual Azalea Festival.

Major changes in customs procedure, including elimination of the use of foreign value as a basis for duty purposes, are now in an "advanced stage" of consideration, Secretary of the Treasury John W. Snyder revealed here yesterday. This change has long been sought by importers.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- Although there has been a demand for further relaxation of installment credit controls, the Federal Reserve Board emphasized today that in many instances terms actually applied by retailers and lenders are more stringent than government regulations require.

LAKE SUCCESS, April 20 -- Hopeful of reaching a vote by late tomorrow or Friday, the United Nations Ad Hoc Political Committee continued today the East-West controversy over the recent trials of Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty in Hungary and fifteen Protestant leaders in Bulgaria.

LONDON, April 20 -- Opening of the new account found the stock market here today in a cheerful mood. A "bullish" background was provided by the reported possibility of the lifting of the Berlin blockade and by prospects of reinvestment of the money distributed in payment for gas stock.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- The Senate Republican Policy Committee adopted today an attitude of searching skepticism toward President Truman's forthcoming request for new appropriations to help arm the European members of the North Atlantic defensive alliance.

Federal Television Corporation yesterday introduced its 1949 television receiver line featuring what it claims is an exclusive new simplified tuning system at a press and dealer preview in its offices and showrooms, 137 Duane Street. The tuning system, built into all twenty models in the line, makes television tuning as simple as radio, according to A. S. Stahl, president.

Canon Thomas A. Sparks, pastor of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, said yesterday that the Rev. Gordon B. Wadhams had notified Bishop Charles K. Gilbert on March 31 of his intention to accept Catholicism.

Plans for the formation of a continuing anti-Communist world federation for intellectual freedom were unfolded here yesterday by Dr. Sidney Hook, of the New York University Philosophy Department, and James T. Farrell, author of twenty-two books.

BUENOS AIRES, April 20 -- It was learned today that the Argentine decision to continue to subsidize meat packers to enable them to meet their increased payroll was taken as a temporary measure. The Government hopes the subsidy no longer will be necessary once Britain comes to terms in the current trade pact negotiations.

The Rev. Fabian Flynn, who has served as delegate to Germany, Austria and Hungary for War Relief Services-National Catholic Welfare Conference for the last three years and who returned here seven months ago to report on relief conditions overseas to the Catholic Bishops of the United States, left yesterday on the Queen Mary to direct the work of the agency in Austria.

Several gas customers of the Consolidated Edison Company voiced vigorous protests before Ernest A. Bamman, Public Service Commission examiner, on the interim gas rate increase of more than $11,440,000 a year that went into effect on Jan. 10. The hearing was in the commission's office at 233 Broadway.

NANKING, April 20 -- Ministry of Defense sources said today that the Communists had breached the Yangtze River line and made landings on the south bank of the river near Wuhu, fifty miles southwest of Nanking. The report was accompanied by a sudden withdrawal of most of the United States Marine platoon guarding the United States Embassy property here.
The five-day-old student strike at City College, largest of the four municipal colleges, was "suspended" at 11:45 A. M. yesterday.

The chief feature of last night's program by the Ballet Theatre at the Metropolitan Opera House was Eugene Loring's "Billy the Kid," a work which is likely to be the chief feature of any program, for it is one of the most distinguished ballets lets of our time.

WEST POINT, N. Y., April 20 -- Home runs by Jim Stuff and Jim Irons in the fifth inning featured Army's 10-8 victory over Williams College at Doubleday Field today. Both circuit clouts cleared the left-field fence, a distance of 350 feet.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- A Senate Armed Services subcommittee inquiry into the war crimes trials of Nazis convicted of the Malmedy Massacre of eighty-three American war prisoners, turned today into an attack by a visiting Senator on the whole practice of Army justice.

ALBANY, April 20 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey approved today a bill that makes it impossible to hold any harness racing meeting this year at the old Empire City track in Yonkers. The measure, introduced about a week before the close of the Legislature, had been approved by both houses on the final day.

The awful waste of human values that attends the continued existence of city slums is, of course, the most moving argument for their eradication. A personal inspection tour of such areas in our large cities should be required study for Congressmen about to vote on a housing bill.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- The Senate was told by the chairman of its Commerce Regulating Committee today that the Federal Communications Commission was playing into the hands of radio and television controls dangerous to free speech.

LAKE SUCCESS, April 20 -- Creation of a special United Nations agency to administer the funds and technical assistance that may be granted to underdeveloped countries under President Truman's "bold new program" was proposed today by a United Nations committee of economic experts.

LONDON, April 20 -- Ambassadors of the ten Western European countries who have drafted here the Statute for the Council of Europe will recommend to their foreign ministers that Greece and Turkey be invited to join the Council, it was reliably stated here today.

A six-month survey just completed by the Department of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity shows that from October through December, 1948, New York's consumption of water was about the same as that of the comparable period in 1947.

Newspaper advertising in fifty-two cities during March totaled 202,070,185 lines, a gain of 6.6 per cent over the like period of 1948, a compilation by Media Records showed yesterday. Categories recording gains were automotive, up 51.7 per cent; general, 21.1 per cent; retail, 4.7 per cent, and financial, 0.5 per cent.

The tumultuous story of air transport between the United States and Colombia entered a new phase last night when a DC-4 of Aerovias Nacionales de Colombia (Avianca) landed at the Pan American Airways terminal at La Guardia Airport with an official Colombian delegation opening regular twice-weekly flights.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- The Department of Commerce opened today a four-day conference designed to inform Negro youths of opportunities in small business. The youths were told that every American, regardless of race, creed or color, "should be able to enter into business and achieve whatever success his initiative, his energy and his talents and ambition bring him."

PHILADELPHIA, April 20 (AP) -- Sam Chapman and Elmer Valo combined today to give the Athletics their second straight 3-2 victory over the Red Sox -- the deciding tally crossing the plate in the tenth inning.
Three notes from a shopping pad lead off today's food news. First off:

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., April 20 -- The thirteen-day strike involving nine of the largest beachfront hotels here ended today with the apparent "capitulation" of members of the Hotel and Restaurant Employes Union, Local 508, AFL.

Former President Herbert Hoover advocated last night that salaries for top-level Government jobs be made high enough to enable the Government to compete with private enterprise for the highest type executives.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- The law requiring Congress to make advance estimates of Government expenditures and receipts was invoked today in the campaign for reductions in spending to avoid a tax increase.

A plot of vacant land containing about 57,000 square feet bounded by Twenty-sixth and Twenty-eighth Avenues, 123d and 124th Street, Flushing, Queens, has been sold, according to John D. Connaughton, agent. Samuel Pollack represented the buyer and John A. Murray acted for the seller. Title was insured by Inter-County Title and Mortgage Company.

The body of the Rev. Dr. Stephen S. Wise lay on view yesterday beneath the altar of the Free Synagogue, which he founded in 1907. Dr. Wise died on Tuesday of a chronic stomach ailment at Lenox Hill Hospital at the age of 75.
Earnings of the American Woolen Company in the first quarter of this year were $3,000,000 below those of the corresponding three months of 1948, according to the unaudited statement issued yesterday.

The elimination of thousands of tons of dead weight in skyscraper construction through the use of a light-weight aggregate in plaster was stressed at a luncheon meeting of the Great Lakes Carbon Corporation yesterday at the Hotel Belm/ont Plaza.

The Gulf Oil Corporation reported yesterday for 1948 a record consolidated net income of $153,539,299 after charges, taxes and reserves. The net, equal to $13.53 each on the 11,345,250 capital shares outstanding, compared with $95,540,059, or $10.53 each on the 9,076,200 shares outstanding in 1947. Net sales increased to $1,068,876,539 from $797,211,423 in 1947.

The Banner manufacturing Corporation has leased the one-story building at 107-109 Liberty Avenue, corner of Christopher Avenue, Brooklyn, from Harriett Hertz and will use it for the manufacture of automobile seatcovers. The building contains 13,000 square feet of space.

It is encouraging that the program of aid so badly needed by the Navajo and Hopi Indians is regarded by the Department of the Interior as a continuing task. These dwellers in the great Southwest have had small attention from the Great White Father in Washington.

When the Gramercy Park Association's flower show opens at the National Arts Club next Tuesday a tiny exhibit of daisies, jonquils and iris will spread from ordinary little test-tubes encased in ordinary plaster forms. But with that ordinary array will go the hearts of four little girls and two little boys in the ward of the Bellevue Hospital Chest Clinic in Building F G.

It is curious to consider that old war horse, "Princess Aurora," as a novelty, but it amounted to that last night when the Ballet Theatre presented George Balanchine's new arrangement of it for the first time at the Metropolitan Opera House.
WASHINGTON, April 21 -- The Senate vote against writing an anti-segregation clause into the Federal Housing Bill was as follows:

Your editorial of April 13 regarding the Mayor's budget strikes several interesting aspects of city administration. To me it emphasizes particularly the need for a thorough understanding of the position of the chief executive for efficient administration in order to bring about the so-called "balanced diet of services" so that "other less influential services will not be starved."

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- Senator William F. Knowland, Republican, of California, charged in a speech in the Senate today that Secretary of State Dean Acheson had "pulled the rug out from under" the Chinese Nationalist Government and demanded an investigation by a joint Congressional committee of United States foreign policy in the Far East.

John D. Rockefeller 3d, campaign chairman of the twelfth annual drive of the Greater New York Fund, predicted yesterday that the campaign, opening officially Monday, would achieve its goal of $8,000,000. The goal is $2,750,000 more than the amount raised in 1948.

A proposal that the United States stockpile some 2,000,000 tons of foreign scrap metal for use in any possible future emergency was sidetracked -- at least temporarily -- by the Munition Board's scrap subcommittee at a meeting in Philadelphia yesterday.

CHICAGO, April 21 (AP) -- Bob Scheffing smashed a homer with Andy Pafko aboard in the eighth inning to give the Chicago Cubs a 4-3 triumph over the Pittsburgh Pirates before a ladies' day crowd of 15,869 today.

Dr. Hans M. Magnus, physician and surgeon, has purchased the building at 114-128 228th Street, corner of 115th Avenue, in St. Albans, Queens, from the Regent Development Corporation and will occupy it as his home and office. Title was insured by the Home Title Guaranty Company.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- If the Marshall Plan countries will unceasingly bind their efforts and ambitions together, there will be no third world war, Paul G. Hoffman, chief of the Economic Cooperation Administration, assured more than 300 members of the American Society of Newspaper Editors today.
HOUSTON, Tex., April 21 (AP) -Two seeded players were eliminated today as eight nationally known stars moved into the quarter-finals of the fifteenth River Oaks tennis tournament.
WASHINGTON, April 21 -- The Truman Administration put before Congress today a $1,130,000,000 program for military assistance to the North Atlantic treaty countries.

A soldier absent without leave for the last ten months, his 19-year-old common-law wife and an ex-convict were accused by Federal and city authorities yesterday of having stolen from mailboxes scores of Government checks for income tax refunds and other payments.

Willard Hall, Inc., sold the six-story apartment house for forty-seven families on a plot 100 by 102 feet at 405-07 East Seventy-second Street to an investing client of Samuel S. Rubenstein, attorney, in a deal reported yesterday by Douglas L. Elliman Co., the broker.

The American Farm Bureau Federation, with a membership of 1,325,000 farm families, is the largest organization of its kind in the nation. What its leaders have to say on any proposed legislation is always interesting and important; what they have to say on controversial issues affecting agriculture is doubly so.

The voluntary hospitals of New York, constituting a "colossal" business operation, are being run in many cases without adequate centralized management, Dr. Eli Ginzberg, director of the New York State Hospital Study, declared yesterday.

A theatrical producing partnership of some significance, which would merge the talents of Norman Bel Geddes and Eddie Dowling, is being discussed by both of them, according to reliable sources. When the venture would start rolling and with what offering could not be learned.
Keen Johnson, former Governor of Kentucky, and vice president and director of public relations of the Reynolds Metals Company, has been elected a director of the company, it was announced yesterday.

Pooling of resources by Belgian export manufacturers is vital to selling more goods in the United States, Maurice Heyne, commercial counselor to the Belgian Embassy in Washington, said here yesterday. He urged a thoroughgoing market research and promotional program to overcome "deficiencies" of current Belgian selling methods in this country.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- The Daughters of the American Revolution today ended a heated three-day debate by adopting resolutions against United States participation in the International Trade Organization and against the "Freedom to Organize" convention of the International Labor Organization.

Revisions in extra charges and deductions for certain products are being prepared by the individual steel-producing subsidiaries of the United States Steel Corporation, Benjamin F. Fairless, president, announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 21 -- During the week ended April 20, member bank reserve balances increased $71,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

A new principle for a steam iron that eliminates all possibility of explosions was the feature last night of the Fourth Annual Safety Award Dinner sponsored by Lewis Conger and held in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

A one-year contract with no increase in wages has been signed by bricklayer unions, representing 7,000 workers in the metropolitan area, and the Building Contractors and Mason Builders Association, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP) -- The Christian Science Church asked Congress today to amend pending Social Security legislation "so that Christian Scientists will be completely exempted if they so elect."

The 1949 program of Local 100, Transport Workers Union, CIO, constituting the demands to be made for improved wages and working conditions of about 48,000 employes of municipal and private transit lines, will be submitted to the union membership for approval at mass meetings next Monday and Tuesday, it was made known last night.

LAKE SUCCESS, April 21 -- The Netherland Government has announced its willingness to allow the Republic of Indonesia to return to its one-time capital at Jogjakarta, provided guarantees are given that guerrilla warfare will end and Republican leaders agree to a roundtable talk at The Hague.

Highly competitive bidding for works of art of the type and quality rarely seen at auctions, marked yesterday the second session of the Joseph Brummer sale at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street.

The United States Treasury yesterday issued a 12 per cent call on its War Loan accounts with the Class B banks. The call, based on balances as of the close of business on April 20, is payable in two instalments, half on April 26, and the balance on the following day.

SHANGHAI, April 21 -- In a voice subdued by his two-day ordeal, a chief boatswain's mate from the British sloop Amethyst told last night how he had led fifty-nine survivors through an inferno of machine-gun fire, wriggling from island to island like alligators and finally reaching safety.

The silverware industry is cutting back production sightly this year for the first time since the end of the war because of some falling off in retail orders, Evarts C. Stevens, president, International Silver Company, revealed in an interview yesterday.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., April 21 (AP) -- The National Amateur Athletic Union women's indoor swimming meet jumped the starting gun today with elimination heats in one of the twelve events on the three-day program scheduled to begin tomorrow.

PINEHURST, N. C., April 21 (AP) -- For the second straight year, Harvie Ward, Frank Stranahan and Arnold Palmer reached the semi-finals of the North and South amateur golf tournament. Joining them in the round of four with a victory today was Pinehurst's Dick Chapman, 1940 National amateur champion, but never a winner here.

In a proclamation issued yesterday at City Hall Mayor O'Dwyer designated Sunday, May 15, as I Am an American Day. He announced that the traditional city-sponsored celebration would be held on the Central Park Mall.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- Vice President Barkley would be called to service on the National Security Council, the country's top advisory group for the integration of domestic, foreign and military policy, under an agreement reached tentatively today by the Senate Armed Services Committee.
Navy officials would seek an overhauling of naval reserve laws and regulations affecting merchant marine reservists under a plan now being considered in Washington, they reported yesterday.

Frederick Brown, operator, has bought the four-story apartment house at 1928-34 Palmer Avenue, corner of Palmer and Wendt Avenues, in Larchmont, N. Y., from the 1928 Palmer Avenue Corporation. S. Cutler was the broker in the sale of the building, which contains twenty-eight apartments and four stores.

ROCHESTER, Minn., April 21 -The hormone from the adrenal gland, known as Compound E, dramatically demonstrated last night by staff members of the Mayo clinic as the agent that promises to play the same role in controlling rheumatoid arthritis that insulin plays in diabetes and liver extract in pernicious anemia, also is being used "with encouraging results" in the treatment of rheumatic fever.
WASHINGTON, April 21 -- Southern coal operators took unprecedented action today to open negotiations for a new contract with the United Mine Workers of America.
